text:
"Fie upon these cakes, so disappointing!
Their \"buttercreams\" be made with shortening, naught butter in sight.
He who hath tasted true buttercream doth know
'Tis not as stable on the shelf, nor white as snow,
And tasteth of real butter, not this fake concoction.
The chocolate cake, too, hath some strange flavor within.
Fake rum, perchance? Alas, I fear men buy
These cakes through ignorance, not knowing any better.
Buttercream, a term used loosely, it seemeth,
Outside of Europe, where 'tis truly made with butter.
Carl, too, doth cling to outdated designs,
Stuck in his ways, with naught but simple cakes in mind.
No rolled fondant ribbons, nor pulled sugar flowers,
Nor bright colors, shall thou find upon his wares.
If simple cakes be thy desire, and thou art not dismayed
By fake buttercream, then Carl's may be thy haven.

Deb R., from Carl's, didst leave a comment, thanks,
With pictures, too. 'Tis clear which cakes Carl didst adorn,
The simple piping design, love birds, all his own hand.
The others, more creative, interesting, were not his.
Oh, and how much shortening doth thy bakery consume,
To make this \"buttercream\", a veritable boon!"

"A sorry tale of woe, I do declare,
Our dinner cruise did turn out quite awry.
For $70 per head, we did expect,
At least some soda, but alas, we were bereft.

Two dollars per pop, we had to pay,
And refills, they did not come our way.
The bathrooms broke, oh what a sight,
We had to switch boats, no compensation in sight.

Two hours we sat, and waited patiently,
For the buffet, that did not impress.
Red potatoes, pork, and soggy greens,
And prime rib, that was far from prime, I ween.

Thirty minutes we waited, for a server to appear,
But when he came, his service was quite queer.
He did not know our table, oh dear,
And once he found out, he disappeared, oh so clear.

An experience to remember, indeed,
But not the kind that we would like to rehearse.
Alas, poor service, it doth seem,
Did mar our night, and made it quite a dream."

"I ventured forth alone on seafood night,
And found that M and Studio B had changed their plight.
Fewer tables now, and those that sat, did so with nary a care,
For long periods of time, they gathered dust and hair.
The line, oh how it stretched and twisted,
A serpentine queue, that ne'er seemed to cease.
Three items only, did they add to the fare,
Oysters, crab legs, and shrimp, but not the king's share.
All else, their regular buffet, did remain,
But for these few, the price did rise again.
My kin refused to wait, and thus didst I,
For over an hour, didst I stand, ere a table didst come nigh.
I fear, I shall not return, till changes do occur."

"Hark, good sir! Forsooth, we've had our luncheon three days a sennight from yonder Vons deli, these seven months past. And lo, there be an employee, ever in foul humour and discourteous, that doth mar our meal. I, in mine anger, didst call and speak with the assistant manager, but alas, naught didst change. Yester-morn, my comrade didst venture forth to fetch our repast, and behold! The manager himself didst tend the counter. My associate didst recount our woeful tale, and the manager didst proffer one feeble excuse upon another, in defence of the serving-wench's poor service and surly demeanour. And mark this well, my friend! This very day, when mine associate didst return, he was informed that, henceforth, we must pay for the bacon! Fie upon it! 'Tis a paltry sum, indeed, yet a grievous affront, and a sorry jest, that we, who hath not been charged for bacon these seven months past, should now be penalized for speaking out against such shabby treatment! As a manager myself, in a like trade of servicing guests, I say 'tis a disgrace, a mockery, and a bitter pill to swallow!"

"Hark! A word of caution, traveler, take heed,
For in the halls of Caesar's Palace, a dire deed
Doth lie within the buffet, a feast most woeful,
Where selection doth lack, and quality doth suffer.

Avoid the spread, dear friend, for 'tis a sight most grim,
Where dishes doth resemble leftovers of a slim
And though the eating area doth appear quite fair,
'Tis but a ruse, a trick to draw thee there.

The price, oh how it doth offend, a sum most steep,
For what doth amount to naught but scraps to keep.
And so, dear friend, take heed of this warning true,
And shun the buffet, lest thou suffer too."

"This place doth suck, I do declare,
The victuals be low-end, soggy, and dear.
The service, a jest, a farce, a sham,
For two hours, thou'lt wait, and still no ham.
They know not change, nor do they care,
For cash, they'll keep, and none shall share.
Their servers, poor souls, with naught to gain,
And tips, a rarity, like rain in Spain.
This place, a symbol of Charlotte's woe,
A haven for yuppies, lost in their glow."

"Hark! The ownership doth seem to have changed hands,
And with it, the quality of customer service doth wane.
A pox upon the new proprietors, say I,
For they do demand cash only, in lieu of credit,
And claim the machine doth still lie broken, by and by.
What sorcery is this? A month, and still naught but cash?
I shall not darken their doorstep, nor partake of their fare,
For 'tis a fool's errand, to be sure.
How dare they question my financial acumen,
Or seek to know the ways in which I choose to spend?
I'll have none of it, good sirs, I'll have none of it,
For 'tis a madhouse, and a den of witlessness, to boot.
So heed my words, fair friends, and shun this place,
Lest ye be treated like a simpleton, and suffer their disgrace."

"Hark, what woe doth befall me! A pizza personal, bought at two of the clock, doth now betray my belly's trust. My wife, a taco didst consume, and now, at seven, I do vomit forth the pizza, poisoned by food. Alas, poor stomach, how thou art wronged! Away, ye culinary fiends, and tempt me not with thy false promises of satisfaction!"

"O, wouldst thou learn the name of this club be changed?
'Tis DXS, forsooth, a place of much douchery.
Alack, a club most lacking in originality,
Wherein the sole delight was yonder pool,
Unused by any, save those who didst dare
To venture forth and risk the wrath of staff.
The music, middling, didst not stir the soul,
Nor didst the line, which stretched and wound about,
Awaiting entry, for an hour or more.
The staff, with rudeness didst they greet,
And prices, high, didst make the purse feel light.
Alas, the club, o'erfilled with people, was it not,
A place of wonder, nay, a den of woe."

"Thus far, methinks, this place doth leave much to be desired. Four persons have I spoken to, and all, save one, didst display a manner most brusque and uncivil. Alas, not a single soul couldst assist me in my quest to become a new patient. Methinks they do not require my custom! Verily, 'tis vexing that my queries, via phone, didst remain unanswered. Fie upon this wretched day!"

"Hark, what news is this? A birthday signup, a gift most fair,
A $30 card, a sumptuous treat, beyond compare.
We ventured forth, mid-week, to dine and make merry,
At one of my dear places, a haven most cheerful.

Alas, the service was poor, the server new and slow,
Our meal did take two hours and a half, I do declare.
I spied the manager, upon my trip to the loo,
And told him of our plight, but naught did he do.

The fried rice, a dish most wondrous, didst fail,
The cook, new and unskilled, didst err, I do avow.
He gave the bowl to the wrong guest, then took it back,
And gave it to another, with a birthday to crack.
My girl, she did receive her rice, with burned bits galore,
A sorry sight, a meal most poor, I do implore.

Alack, the upgrade, a few dollars didst cost,
A price to pay, for such a sorry feast, I do aver.
Yet still, we dined, and laughed, and made good cheer,
For birthdays are, a time to cast away fear."

"Hark, what woe is this? A craving for meat jun doth plague me,
And so, I ventured forth to find some sustenance.
But lo, the address I found was old and out of date,
And he who answered my call was not sympathetic in the least.

I paid fourteen pieces of silver for a meager feast,
A single slice of kalbi, nigh transparent, I did receive,
A piece of BBQ chicken, and one slice of meat jun,
But alas, no Koch-jun sauce did they provide, nor chopsticks to eat.

Oh, how I wish I could give this place a negative star,
For the experience was naught but shame and waste.
My time, my gas, my money, all were spent in vain,
And so, I leave with a heavy heart and a bitter taste."

"Alack, what chaos doth this store present!
Expired wares and wilted greens, a sorry sight.
Yet still, fair Rajbhog doth beckon thee,
Despite the distance, worth the extra mile."

"A single star doth shine with grace. The golden-haired manager, alas, doth show no civility. In truth, I deem her the head manager, a fact most vexing. Never shall I step foot in this ULTA again, for she didst mistreat a worker in plain sight of all. Her conduct was most unbecoming, and I didst feel great dismay at her comportment. Yet, one kindness may I speak of: Nadia, the clinique representative, didst show great courtesy."

"Methinks 'tis two years since first I stepped within these hallowed halls, where healers ply their trade with varying degrees of skill. Some few, methinks, are fair and skilled, yet others - alack! - do leave much to be desired. Their minions, too, are oft-times lacking in their duties, cancelling appointments without a care, losing documents most crucial, and demanding payment ere denying treatment, vexing me sore.

"Take, for instance, my recent quest to begin allergy shots. In April, I didst request this service, hoping 'twould start forthwith. Alas! Not so, for naught but silence didst greet mine ears until May, when I, inquisitive, didst ask why no charge had been laid upon mine account. Then, in May, they didst order mine serum, promising to begin in June. But lo! In late June, I didst call, and they, in confusion, didst declare they knew not whether mine serum had been prepared. And thus, they didst confirm mine appointment, which, alas! They didst lose, leaving me to wander, dismayed.

"And now, dear friends, mark well this tale, for 'tis a cautionary tale of woe. For in the brief span of three months, the hours set aside for allergy shots have been changed - without a word of warning - thrice!

"When at last I finish mine allergy shots, I shall flee this place, ne'er to return again."

"Alack, what woeful fare didst greet mine eyes!
Gluten-free, they claimed, but naught but wretched lies.
A smoothie, thick with vanilla's sickly sweet,
And stevia's bitter tang, didst assault mine taste.
Eggs, rubbery and cold, a travesty, indeed,
Junk food, masquerading as healthy feed.
Bread, made from rice and tapioca's starch,
Didst turn mine stomach, with its uncouth march.
If thou dost seek such gluten-free, processed foul,
Pray, venture forth, and sample it, thou fool!"

"Alas, my heart doth heavy bear the weight of woe,
To pen these words, a tale of woe and sorrow.
A place of feeding, where my hopes didst lie,
Didst fail me, leaving naught but dismay.

Their hours, they didst proclaim, till ten o'clock,
Yet, alack, they shut the door, ere nine had struck.
And thus, my visits, oft as night didst fall,
Were met with naught but empty tables, all.

The food, it was not bad, I must confess,
But service, oh, how it didst disappoint!
For they, the keepers of the eatery, didst not,
Understand the meaning of their own hours, it seemed.

A busy man, with work and study, I,
Could not, alas, arrive before the night.
So, coming late, with hunger pangs, I didst find,
The doors, shut tight, and naught but darkness within.

New Seoul, a place of better worth, I say,
For though it may not look so fine,
The food and service, do make up for't,
And they, their hours, do truly keep, I find.

Sol's on the Square, a place of sorrow, now,
For though it looks well, the food and service, how,
Do fail, and leave a man, in woe and despair,
As I, alas, have found, to my great sorrow, there."

"Hark, fair maiden, let me tell thee now,
I have not dined at Coco's in full ten year,
In youth, with grandparents, I didst partake,
But now, my love, didst crave their sweet pie.

A fortnight past, my dear, didst dine with friend,
And swore she'd return, such was her desire,
To taste their culinary delight once more,
And thus, I joined her, eager to partake.

Alas, the hostess, slow to seat us, was,
Though empty chairs didst surround, in abundance,
Five minutes passed, and still we waited,
Patient, I was, for feast most excellent.

But lo, the wait didst stretch to thirty-five,
And still, our sandwich, didst not arrive,
The waitress, vague excuses didst proffer,
And thus, I paid, and left, in disgust, alive.

Nevermore, shall I set foot in this place,
Poor service, and poor customer grace,
Shall not be tolerated, by my hand,
Forsooth, farewell, Coco's, thou art banned!"

"Fie upon their services, for naught but woe
They bring, with false claims and poor show.
Alack, I paid for irrigation, yet nary a drop
Did flow, when heat did swelter and plants did plop.
I called, and lo, no answer came the day before,
So out of town I went, with temp'rature at fourscore.
Good fortune, then, that I didst make the call,
For waterless, my plants had stood, and withered wouldst all.
A pox upon their house, say I, for ill they do,
And A&P on Ironwood, my business shall pursue."

"Aye, I concur with ratings low and comments dire,
Some woeful transformation hath beset the menu,
And thus, my visits to Pete's shall cease,
Forsooth, the fare at 4121 N. 44th St.,
In Phoenix, I did frequent with zeal,
But now, alas, I bid thee adieu,
Pete's Fish and Chips, thou art but a memory,
A relic of the past, naught but a name,
And I do ponder, why such change came."

"This place, alas, doth leave much to be desired.

1. They did deceive us with their breakfast tale,
A falsehood that did cause our hopes to fail.
2. The dishes they did offer, few in number,
A paltry selection, and not worth the plunder.
3. And thus, with little choice, we paid the price,
Eighteen dollars, a sum not worth the sacrifice.

Methinks 'tis wiser to dine at MGM Grand's feast,
Or Rio's spread, where though the cost be greater,
The value received doth make the difference clear.

Avoid this place, my friends, and heed my warning,
For here, the food doth lack, and service, too, is scorning."

"Hark, what news is this? In New York, a city of renown,
ESPN doth serve the worst of victuals, I do declare.
Their boneless buffalo wings, a dish most foul and vile,
Doth make mine stomach churn with naught but bile.
And Anchor Steam, the best of brews they have,
Doth fail to quench mine thirst, or soothe mine soul.
Alas, dear friends, avoid this place, I pray,
For 'tis a den of culinary woe, and naught but dismay.
Disney, thou hast struck out, in this venture most dire,
Better luck next time, ere thou dost conspire."

"Hark! A traveler I, with tales to tell,
Of ports and planes, of delays and hell.
In cabs, in lines, in walkways slow,
The journey's pace doth seem to go.
But fear not, friends, for in this plight,
I'll don my headphones, rock through the night.
Ahead of time, arrive we must,
To dance with tunes, and thus we'll trust."

"Methinks 'twas but a singular ill fate,
That didst befall mine own self on that day,
A meal most vexing, with naught but dismay.

My pork, alack, was tepid, devoid of zest,
And in its stead, a soupy taste didst possess.
The rest, alas, didst suffer from the cold,
A chill that didst seep into mine very soul.

In sooth, 'twas like the victuals of a hall,
Where students do congregate, and that is all.
Yet, still, I wouldst not dismiss them straight,
For who knows? Mayhap they shall redeem their fate."

"Fie upon this wretched place, where service doth falter!
A group of friends didst come, on a Friday night, to dine,
But oh, how poorly didst they serve us, with nary a care!
Orders muddled, dishes wrong, a sorry state of affairs.
And when our feast didst finally arrive, they bid us leave,
Forsooth, our time limit had been reached, they didst perceive.
Pray tell, how couldst we stay within the bounds of time,
When every order was awry, a jest most foul and grim?
In this fair town, where sushi doth abound,
This pitiful excuse for a restaurant, doth flourish still?
Fie upon it, say I, a pox upon the house,
For incompetence doth reign supreme, in this woeful place!"

"Hark! A mess I've made, good sirs, I pray thee tell,
Of chicken bits, both Cajun and mild, I didst order well,
Eight pieces, boneless, didst I request,
But lo, what came to me, was not what I had sought,
Four Cajun, four mild, so dry they were,
My ire doth rise, my heart doth sore,
Alack, what woe is this, that I must bear?
My meal, a disappointment, full of despair."

"Alas, my first time, and what a woeful sight!
My legs, unkempt, with scars that marred their might.
The one who tended, friendly, yet, alack,
The job, ill-done, left me in disarray.
I pray thee, look upon these pictures, dear,
And see the state of my poor, tweezed skin, so fair."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, this place doth not deserve a single star, nay, not even half a one! Forsooth, the prices they do charge, ten dollars for a burger, eight dollars for a shake, doth border on the realm of lunacy! And, alack, I didst use a Groupon, and yet, it still didst cost my wife and me, twenty dollars and more, by the stars! In this fair town, there be better places, where one may find a burger most divine, but, alas, this place, it doth not rank among them, I do declare.

Firstly, I do detest spending such sums, when service doth not meet mine expectations, and secondly, our food didst sit in a window, for five minutes, whilst a man didst take three orders, and lo, he didst tarry, most vexingly! And, at this location, the service didst suck, most mightily, I do avow. Place Station, doth indeed, doth suck, and, mark my words, 'tis a non-union establishment, and, alack, 'twill show, in the quality of their fare, and service, I do predict.

And, as for Johnny Rockers, more like Johnny Crockers, I do say, for the prices they do charge, doth not match the quality they do provide, nay, not by the hairs of my chinny chin chin! I didst wonder, why, oh why, doth people think this place, doth be so grand? But, lo, the Yelp reviews, didst tell a different tale, of overpricing, and poor service, most woefully, I do declare!"

"Canst thou give naught stars? Verily, I wouldst. For Jill and Cindy, her receptionist, be most unprofessional. Unresponsive, they be. Rude messages they send. The appointed hour, Cindy doth give thee wrong, and Jill doth chide thee with harsh words. She doth rage like a tempest. Alas, despite many visits, the hair removal doth not work. Avoid this place, fair maiden."
"Verily, the site did resemble a waste land, with prices far too steep. And those who tended the grounds, their demeanor didst strike fear within my heart."

"Fie upon this wretched place, my dearest spouse and I didst find it most vexing. The dcor, aye, 'twas fair and cozy, but alack, the caterwauling from yon lounge didst mar the ambiance. Our converse was nigh impossible, the minstrel's warblings didst grate upon mine ear. Moreover, our booth, adjacent to the kitchen's din, didst resound with clatterings most foul. The victuals, too, didst fail to impress. Squid, aye, 'twas overcooked, and pasta, alas, didst lack the seasoning of the gods. Yet, methinks the servitors didst earn their wages, for they didst attend us with great zeal and courtesy. Mayhap, anon, this establishment shall rectify its shortcomings, and the fare shall equal the excellence of the staff."

"Alas, my friends, I must recount a tale of woe,
Of a dining experience that did not go well,
At DC Steak House, a place of repute,
Where service was poor, and our patience did dwindle.

We entered the hall, a group of seven strong,
And waited, and waited, for nigh on forty-five long,
Before Danny, our server, did deign to appear,
And take our order, with a scowl, and a sneer.

Now, I must confess, the steak was cooked just right,
But alas, the service, oh, how it took flight!
For Danny, it seemed, did not give a fig,
For our plight, or our needs, or our discomfort, I dig.

A friend of mine, who works in this trade,
Did call the manager, and speak of our shade,
But alas, it seemed, he did not much care,
For our business, or our patronage, fair.

So, here's a warning, to all who would dine,
At DC Steak House, beware of the decline,
In service, and care, for it seems they do not mind,
If their patrons leave, with a bitter taste, behind.

For us, alas, it shall be a one-time visit,
For the memories, of that night, do not sit well,
In our hearts, or our bellies, I do declare,
DC Steak House, we shall not return there."

"Fie upon this wretched place! Our names, lost to the void, didst wait
Forty minutes passed, and still, no seat didst await
The hostess, fair? Nay, cruel and slow, didst play
Our waitress, sharp of tongue, with service, didst slay
Eggs, cold as winter's night, and portions, far too great
A shame, for those in need, such bounty doth await
A meal of one hour, didst stretch to two and a half
All due to service, poor and woeful, in truth"

"Hark, fair friends, and listen well,
For I have tale to tell,
Of Fletchers, where my car did dwell,
And brakes, that did not function well.

A friend, who did offer his aid,
Didst say, that all was not aright,
My car did shake, and thus I prayed,
That Fletchers, might set things right.

But lo, they didst not turn the rotors,
As they didst claim, with words so bright,
The screws, they didst still retain,
And charged me, twenty dollars, for each one's pain.

Oh, woe is me, a woman, alone,
To be deceived, by such a crew,
Beware, dear friends, of Fletchers' throne,
For they are crooks, and will not hesitate, to cheat thee, too."

"O, how vexed I am! Our Christmas feast, a sorry sight it was indeed. The lechon, so poorly cooked, no crispness to its skin, o'er salted, a true dismay. Our guests, they barely touched it, such a disappointment. And the box, oh woe is me! With shoe marks all about, a floor-trodden thing, they did assemble it, and placed the lechon within. Fie upon it, say I!"

"Alas, fair deejai, how oft I've tried
To build a bond with thee, yet naught but woe
Hast thou bestowed upon my humble head
Four times, five times, alack, I've made my way
To thy abode, where servers, careless, play
With orders, scribbling not, nor heeding well
My simple requests, like Pad Thai, Pad See Ew
Tofu, chicken, naught but simple fare, I pray

Yet still, they err, and bring me spice too bold
Or substitute meat, as if my taste were cold
One night, my meal arrived late, my husband's first
And by the time they corrected their mistake, 'twas worst
A ruined feast, a disappointment, alas, poor show
No peace offering, coupon, discount, nay, not a single blow

Deejai, dear deejai, how couldst thou do this to me?
With prices high, and service low, how couldst thou be
Worthy of my love, my loyalty, my heart's devotion?
Nay, I fear, thou art not, and thus, my dear, adieu."

"Hark! I did procure six laser treatments for mine face,
And requested a before and after picture, by grace.
But alas! No difference didst I see, even after the last,
Despite the technicians' skill, their art didst not last.

They suggested three AFT treatments, and I didst comply,
But saw a difference only after two, didst not lie.
The technicians were good, their hands didst move with ease,
But the booking process, a woeful mess, didst seize.

Long waits and mix-ups, oh what a plight!
Confirmed appointments, wrong dates, day and night.
So here's my counsel, good sir or madam,
Book early morn, avoid long waits, 'tis no gamble.
And request in writing, lest thou be forgot,
A printed email, thy confirmation, 'twill not.

I shall seek elsewhere, a med spa or derm,
For quality service, fair price, no scheduling storm.
Hark! Learn from my tale, and heed my advice,
Lest thou encounter similar frustration and vice."

"O, woe is me! This place doth suck, I do declare. No customer service, nay, not a whit. A suite with a king bed, I didst pay for, fair and square. Yet, lo and behold, they give me a room with two queen beds instead! And, to add insult to injury, they didst try to upsell me at check-in, the scoundrels! Tsk, tsk, what a classic case of false advertising, I do perceive."

"Hark! 'Tis sweltering hot, a tempest in this theatre,
With naught but heat, and no cooling breeze to ease.
The sun doth beat upon my head, and doth impair
My patience, as I sit and sweat in discomfort.
A pox upon the management, who doth neglect
To provide a respite from the heat, a simple act
Of kindness that doth make a world of difference.
I shall depart, and seek a place where's cool,
For in this hellish heat, I cannot bear to stay."

Last eve, betwixt five and six, we dined
With friends, and oh, what a woeful feast!
The din from yonder bar did pierce mine ears,
And worse, the victuals we didst receive.
Not one of us didst enjoy their meal, alas!
Our waiter, Izaiah, didst offer to fetch
Another dish, but fear didst grip our hearts.

How does this version compare to the original?

This version is 487 tokens, which is within the limit of 512 tokens.

The version written in the style of William Shakespeare uses more words and phrases that are typical of his writing style, such as "betwixt," "woeful," "pierce," "victuals," "alas," and "fetch." It also uses a more formal and poetic language, with a focus on rhyme and meter.

The original text is written in a more straightforward and modern style, using simpler vocabulary and sentence structures. It is more conversational and does not have the same level of formality or poetic flair as the Shakespearean version.

Overall, the two versions convey the same message, but the Shakespearean version has a more elaborate and ornate language, while the original text is more direct and to the point.

"Hark, my friends, I tell thee of a woeful tale,
Of Island Sushi, where we didst dine and fail.
A saimin and a mini tonkatsu, we didst order,
But lo, our meal didst take a turn for the worse.

The restaurant was empty, save for us alone,
And our order, it didst take a good fifteen moons.
Our tonkatsu, it didst arrive, and oh, the shame,
Five tiny pieces, no more, no less, didst claim.

We sat in shock, our eyes didst wide open stare,
And laughed we must, at such a paltry share.
The worker, she didst say, 'Tis true, 'tis so,
A mini tonkatsu, and one piece, that's the show.

Our saimin, it didst come, and oh, the horror,
Not hot, it was, we hadst to ask for more.
In the microwave, they didst put it, with haste,
But alas, the damage, it was done, the taste.

This place, it hath gone down, in its prime,
And now, they do, they doth rip thee off, in time.
We loved their food, but now, we doth despair,
For what's next, we dare not think, nor bear."

"Methought I would purchase a gift most fair
For my dear wife, within that LV so rare.
But lo! A salesman with manners most vile
Didst treat us with disdain and a scowl so vile.

In haste, I didst depart that wretched place
And sought another LV, with a gentle face.
Forsooth, my love, thy gift shall be found
In a shop where courtesy doth abound."

"O woeful night! In fair Las Vegas, where mirth doth reign,
My purse, alack, was stolen, and with it, my peace of mind.
'Twas at Marquee, a club of ill repute, where I did meet my friends,
But within ten minutes, my bag was gone, and with it, my wits did end.

I must confess, I brought my purse into the club, a foolish deed,
But security, alas, did prove to be most lacking in their creed.
When I did try to file a report, they did dismiss my plight,
And left me to my own devices, in the midst of that dreadful night.

And lo, the stairs, they were a curse, a trial to behold,
For in my heels, I struggled, and my patience did grow old.
But worse, oh much worse, didst I behold, drunk patrons falling down,
With no support, no elevator, to ease their sorry state, nor frown.

So here's my warning, to all who would venture to this place,
Beware, dear friends, of Marquee's dark and troubled space."

"Alas, what woeful fate didst lead me here,
To this most vile and wretched place, so dear?
The signs, they didst warn, yet hope didst blind,
A delicious sandwich, my heart and mind.

But lo, the meat, so rubbery and thick,
Not Capicola, as promised, didst trick.
Fatty and chewy, a taste most foul,
My stomach didst churn, my soul didst howl.

Oh, cursed place, thy name doth bring shame,
Thy food, a poison, a wicked game.
Stay clear, good friends, and heed my words,
For here, thy taste buds will be blighted."

"O woeful day! My pants, so fair and bright,
Now bear the hue of rosy morning light.
The dry cleaners, near my workplace found,
Didst turn my garb to pink, profound.
They claimed 'twas sun damage, a strange fate,
And vowed to try their utmost, anon, to abate.
But alas, their efforts proved in vain,
The stain, like love, didst not depart again.
My pants, once new, now ruined, oh woe is me!
No replacement offered, nay, not a shred of decency.
Thus, eighty-five dollars, down the drain, alack!"

In fair Champaign-Urbana, where we lay our scene,
The Korean food doth leave much to be desired, I ween.
Woori Jib, a place of note, doth fall within this fate,
Serving dishes that lack seasoning, and BBQ most irate.

Their "standard fare" doth include Bulgolgi, a dish of renown,
But alas, 'tis poorly seasoned, and doth bring us down.
The spicy tofu soup, a delicacy of old,
Doth lack the zest and vigor that doth make it bold.

And mackerel, a fish most fine and fair,
Doth appear rough and unkempt, without a care.
Alas, dear friends, Woori Jib doth not impress,
Its offerings doth pale in comparison, alack and alas!

"Our hunger pangs didst drive us to this place,
Amidst our two-week business trip's haste.
Fast food we didst wish to avoid,
And thus didst opt for this dining room.

Alas! The service was poor, the victuals worse,
My shrimp entree with mixed veggies, a curse.
Overcooked stir fry, mushy and vile,
I ne'er had such a sorry meal.

Shumai dumplings, a disappointment great,
My comrade's chicken dish, a similar fate.
The third member of our group, sushi didst choose,
But left it untouched, its quality to disclose.

Alack! The prices steep, our per diem didst waste,
For food most foul, our bellies didst protest.
In conclusion, dear friends, avoid this place,
Lest ye desire a meal most base."

"Hark, good sir! Eat not at this place, I pray thee,
For they do ask each guest to check in,
And claim the discount of ten percent,
But only for one device, alack and welladay!
Not per table, mark thou well, my friend,
Lest thou be cheated of thy just deserts."

"O, how the wait doth drag on, as if time itself did stand still! And yonder, at the entrance, doth the 'cutsie' greeter maidens play their part, with nary a care for order or haste. Alas, a place once dear to mine heart, now doth it falter, and its manager, with scant regard for our plight, doth make me question whether to return anon. Forsooth, the children's meals did arrive, alas, when our hunger had departed, and cold as ice, to boot! In sooth, a sorry state of affairs, which doth suggest that this Applebee's doth decline. Methinks I shall seek out other venues, where employees and managers do bear a greater sense of duty and care."

"Methinks 'tis a curious case, my friends,
This nail salon, where I've had my share of woe.
For though they've had their good days,
Their bad days, too, have come my way.

Depending on who tends to me,
My experience varies greatly, I must see.
One worker, skilled and kind,
Hath left me pleased, my nails aligned.
But alas, the rest, untalented souls,
Their work, a travesty, doth unfold.

A nail file, once they gave to me,
When they could not shape a pointy nail, ye see.
And twice, I've paid the higher fee,
Fifty dollars, for a set of nails, a spree.
For that, my friends, is all I've known,
To leave that place, with nails well-shown.

My toes, they've gelled, and oh, the pain,
Cuts by my nails, a sight most vain.
They rush, and rough, their files they wield,
No care for quality, their work doth yield.
Most workers, they don't care, I say,
Their work, a reflection, doth portray.

Yet still, I went, in hope anew,
To find that one, who worked well, too.
Her name, alas, I cannot claim,
But for the gent, in front, a thumbs up, gained.
His customer service, a joy to see,
Friendly, he."

"Hark, what news is this? A taro shake I sought,
At yonder shop, wherein they did proffer it.
I watched as they prepared the concoction,
And lo, the cashier didst take a rag,
To clean the garbage can, with nary a care,
He wiped the countertops, with the same cloth,
As if the filth of the waste bin were naught.
A fellow patron saw, and shared my shock,
Our eyes did meet, in utter dismay,
For who would think such actions fair?
The shake, I cast aside, without a pause,
And left the premises, in utmost haste.
My spouse, I told, and she didst express,
Her own incredulity, at such uncleanliness."

"Alas, poor Mimi's, how thy service doth fail!
A holiday feast, we didst order with great zeal,
But when my mother-in-law went to fetch the fare,
They knew not of our order, nor didst they care.

Thirty minutes passed, and still no food in sight,
And when we asked, they said it would be nigh on an hour's wait.
Our guests at home, they didst hunger and await,
So we didst decide, to seek elsewhere, our Christmas treat.

I do confess, 'tis a busy time of year,
Yet, for a restaurant, such laxity doth appear.
Unprofessional, indeed, and most vexing too,
For one who doth work in the trade, as doth my mother-in-law do.

Mimi's, thou hast lost our custom, alas,
For thy lack of care, and dismal state of affairs.
We shall not return, nor recommend thee,
For a merry Christmas, and a happy New Year, we do wish thee."

"When fortune frowns upon my brow, my dearest wife doth lift my spirits with a slice of cheesecake. Alas, the portions have diminished in size, while the cost hath risen to the heavens. Farewell, sweet Cheesecake Factory, forsooth, thy prices have driven me away. Nay, they didst not deign to reply to mine tweet of woe. Farewell, forevermore!"

"Methought I had found a fair caterer, one that had pleased mine taste buds well. But alas, their service didst leave much to be desired. The owners, rude and uncouth, didst show little interest in our needs. Communication proved a difficult task, and the food tasting, a sorry affair. They gave us but three dishes, all microwaved, a poor showing indeed. None didst follow up with us, to enquire of our satisfaction. And so, with three months yet till our wedding day, we have chosen to seek out a new caterer, thankful that our deposit may still be returned. If thou art seeking a caterer cheap, but with scant regard for service, then this may be thy choice. But for us, 'twas not worth the wager."

"O'Hare, a place most foul and full of woe,
Where filth doth reign supreme, and cleanliness doth go.
Two bathhouses, vile and foul, didst I behold,
My husband, too, didst say, the men's was old.

A McDonald's, nowhere to be found,
All food, o'erpriced, a travesty profound.
Eleven pieces, for a cold cut, they didst ask,
A king's ransom, for a meal most tasking.

Through this place, I shall not fly again,
Unless, by fortune, no other choice doth remain."

"A pox upon the service, and the owner too,
For rudeness and disdain, they didst imbue.
A zero rating, that's what they deserve,
For treating customers with such contempt and swerve.

My tenants, freezing in their rented abode,
The owner, she didst not care, nor didst she show.
I called to inquire, and she didst reply,
Betwixt twelve and three, the tech wouldst arrive.

But nay, she wouldst not call, nor wouldst she say,
When exactly he wouldst come, or if he wouldst stay.
I asked, and she didst yell, with anger in her voice,
No, she wouldst not help, nor wouldst she make a choice.

I told her, make it two and thirty, or else,
She said no, and thus, our converse didst cease.
And lo, she didst call, with glee in her tone,
Cancelling the appointment, all alone.

Good luck, dear sirs, in your endeavors,
For such behavior, doth but bring forth shadows."

"A pox upon The Cleaning Solution, say I!
Their business practices, a shambles doth lie.
Scheduling, a nightmare of back and forth,
No end in sight, no solution in store.
Their customers, they do not put first,
Nor excellence in service, do they enforce.
Groupon, a purchase made in good faith,
Yet funds, immediate, from thy card, they doth take.
Two months, a wait, for a spot on the list,
Then, an email, a rescheduling, they insist.
As if thou art the one, who doth need change,
Their words, a trick, to shift blame, so strange.
I wish, dear reader, thou hadst read,
The negative reviews, ere thou didst proceed."

"O, woe is me! A tale of woe and sorrow doth unfold,
Of a meal most foul, and a sight most bold.
I entered the establishment with great delight,
My stomach growling, my senses heightened with anticipation's might.
But lo, upon my plate, a tiny beast did lie,
A cockroach, a creature most vile and loathsome to mine eye.
I called for the server, my voice trembling with disgust,
And she, a maiden fair, did come to my aid, her steps swift and just.
She took the plate, and with haste, did crush the pest beneath her foot,
But alas, the deed was done, my appetite was lost, my mood did sour.
I sought the counter, and demanded a refund full and fair,
For nevermore would I set foot in that place, nor partake of their fare.
So heed my words, dear friends, and shun this den of filth,
Lest thou suffer the same fate as I, and taste the bitter draught of woe."

"Hark, what news is this? A review, my first,
Of this fair place, wherein I did partake
Of breakfast, with mine accountant near.
But lo, the fare, it doth not please,
Ala carte, they call it, by the way,
And for each egg, a dollar more, they say.
The juice, in glasses small, doth flow,
As if 'twere meant for some other show.
My belly, still, doth rumble and grumble,
Past one o'clock, and yet, no settle.
Another draught of Pepto, mayhap, shall
My troubles, thus, doth soon unravel."

"A pox upon this wretched place, where service doth stink and manners do decay. Avarice doth rule the day, where water, that most basic need, doth come at such a steep price. My mother, in her hour of need, didst ask but for a small amount, to take her medicine, 'twas all. And lo, the varlet behind the counter, with scowl and scorn, didst deny her request, with nary a care. He didst say, with sneer and sarcasm, "Refills be a dollar, or a bottle thou shalt buy, for twice the sum." I pray thee, good sir, consider the plight of one in need, and show some pity, ere thou dost lose thy soul. But nay, he didst persist, with anger in his eyes, and poured but a small amount, a centimeter, in a cup, as if to taunt and mock. Oh, woe is me, to see such wickedness, and hear such bitter words. In California, 'tis a crime, to deny a soul in need, water for their health. His name, I pray thee, good sir, doth Jeremy R. make, a tall and slender man, with hair cut short and brown. May justice find him, and may his heart be turned."

"Hark! The Salt Lick doth move on to fairer fields,
With flavor lacking, a tale of woe it yields.
I recall a year past, when ribs and brisket I did order,
Both tasted same, a sorrowful border.
Sides bland, sauce watery, a disappointment great,
Memphis style, I do confess, my heart doth beat.
Service slow, a wait of thirty-five long minutes,
A miss, indeed, on many a tastebud's skillet.
Yet, one grace doth shine, the sweet tea, a mite above,
A glimmer of hope, in a place of culinary love."

"Pizza, alas, doth not impress,
Sometimes burnt, and salad, oh what a mess!
Dry and old, it doth not delight,
Service, poor, a sorry plight.

Server, missing, or busy, it seems,
Chatting, dawdling, no attention beams.
Long wait, chaos, disorder, a fray,
Nevermore shall I return, nay!

Odd service, indeed, a place for young,
But professional folk, they do not belong.
Replace them, perchance, with those who care,
And enjoy their work, with passion fair and square."

"Alack, poor rookies, slow and unaware,
Bartenders and staff, with naught to spare.
Their minds on shots, their eyes on fun,
Forget the patrons, their needs are none.
I do not recommend this place,
Where service is lacking, and time doth race.
For those who seek a pleasant night,
Best avoid this tavern, devoid of light."

"Tis a curious thing, my friends, when a restaurant doth have a bad night,
Aye, 'tis a sight to behold, like a first date with spinach in thy teeth.
But lo, three nights in a row, 'tis not a fluke, but an art indeed,
A skill, a craft, a mastery of the culinary arts, I do declare.

My first night, I did order their Brooklyn Spaghetti, with meatballs galore,
And had I been a wise-guy from Brooklyn, there wouldst be one less knee-cap, I swear.
They served it in a soup bowl, quite apt for the watery mess below,
And the "garlic bread" was naught but flat bread, with garlic butter, I do know.

The service was scant, and the waiter, a novice, no doubt,
For he did stumble and fumble, like a man in a newfound rout.
And so, I gave them another chance, a second night,
And ordered a sizzling platter, with a filthy handle, and a rusty, dirty knife.

The third time, I did try again, with spaghetti, once more,
But alas, they did forget the cheese, and the white bread, untoasted, no more.
The waiter did apologize, and rightly so,
For cleanliness, it seemed, was not an option, nor a concept they did know.

In conclusion, my friends, this restaurant, it did lack,
The old world charm of Tijuana, verily, 'twas a sight to behold, and a tale to tell."

"Alas, my dear friend, I fear I must report,
That yonder pizza place, its reputation quite distorted.
Twice have I ventured forth, with hopes of delight,
But alas, both times, my expectations took flight.

The first time, the deep dish, a culinary dream,
But not as grand, as Oregano's, the supreme.
And tonight, the thin crust, a tragic sight,
Hard as concrete, a true gastronomic plight.

I spoke to the waitress, with words of dismay,
But she, with a shrug, did say, "It's cooked that way, each day."
A softer crust, a request, not hard to make,
But alas, 'twas denied, my teeth, they do ache.

Oh garlic bread, a side dish, so-so, at best,
Not worth the coin, seek elsewhere, find thy quest.
For pizza, Rudy's, Filberto's, fast food, all four stars,
My taste, it seems, doth differ from the rest, by far."

"Hark! A tale of woe and disappointment doth unfold,
At a restaurant of ill repute, where dishes were cold.
A lobster salad, with bug within, didst they bring,
And though 'twas but a ladybug, my appetite didst shrink.

The manager, with nary a care, didst not come by,
To offer apology or sweet dessert, a pity.
The bill, with salad still upon it, didst they proffer,
A galling sight, and my ire didst gather.

But then, a hero emerged, the general manager true,
Who read my words and acted anew.
He contacted me, with haste and good cheer,
And adjusted the bill, with generosity clear.

Five stars for him, and his noble deed,
Yet still, the restaurant, with two and a half stars, doth need.
For price and quality, a mismatch doth seem,
And thus, my friends, this place doth not earn my esteem."

"Upon mine ear, good sir, didst thou hear me aright? A place, unbeknownst to me, didst thou say? With naught but empty chairs, and tables bare, didst it seem a tavern of old, forgotten by time itself? And yet, the prices, oh how they didst climb! For a dish of salmon, small and plain, didst it cost a pretty penny, indeed! And quinoa, extra, didst it come, cold as winter's night, and hard to chew. The waitress, fair and kind, didst attend to us, with diligence, but naught couldst we decide, upon the menu, for all we saw, didst lie within our homes. A main course, shared betwixt us two, didst cost a sum most grand, and coffee, but one, didst my friend imbibe. And thus, a tip of twenty percent, didst we leave, in haste, for how, this place, so fine, couldst survive, didst puzzle us, in truth, most sorely."

"Twice didst I venture hither with mine friends,
And both times, woe betide! Their siu-mai dish,
Didst taste most strange, as if they cooked it with rubber bands,
Or some such foul concoction. Fie upon't!
Their chicken feet, too, didst lack the savory delight
Of those at Phoenix Place in Chandler. By my troth,
I'll ne'er return to this accursed place again.
If thou dost seek the finest dim-sum, prithee,
Repair to Great Wall, at 35th and Camelback in Phoenix."

Hark, good sir, I pray thee, tell me, hast thou tried
To dine within this hall of gastronomic delight?
Twice have I attempted, alas, to partake
Of victuals and drink, yet both times didst fail.

The first, at eventide, a queue most long
Didst bar my path, and waiting, didst prolong.
To Bill's Victorian Room, then didst I stray,
For sustenance and solace, didst decide to play.

The second time, the manager, a crabby soul,
Didst deny me entry, with words most foul.
"Slow" was the reason, he didst proclaim,
And thus, didst shut the door, in my face, most lame.

A plague upon this house, I do declare,
For false promises, and poor service, most bare.
No more shall I return, nor waste my time,
For other places, better, shall be mine.

So, gentle reader, take heed of my tale,
And shun this place, lest thou dost suffer, likewise, the bale.

"A plentiful choice, yet the proprietor doth show
A lack of wit, in pricing, I do know.
No cost doth grace each item, fair or foul,
And he, with eyes that pierce, doth size thee whole.
He doth demand, with prices most unjust,
A sum that doth surpass, what thou canst trust.
Good wares, indeed, yet at a price so steep,
That thou, in wisdom, shouldst avoid, ere thou dost sleep."

"By Jove, what woeful sight doth meet mine eyes!
A place of feeding, shut down, doth bring me cheer.
For in its filth, I do perceive a tale,
Of violations, and inspectors most severe.

Oh, how the thought of it doth make me shudder,
To tear my innards out, in sheer disgust.
And yet, three stars and a half, they didst claim,
In Vegas, where Asian food doth not reign supreme.

Orchids, a name that doth conjure up images,
Of grandeur, and dim sum, served through the night.
But alas, their carts, with surly servers, didst roam,
And food, lukewarm, or cold, didst leave me in despair.

The room, a chaos, full of noise and disarray,
With tables, uncleared, and dishes, in disarray.
And all this, for a price, of more than twenty crowns,
I could scarce eat, so great was my dismay.

Oh, peoples, heed my words, and take note,
Of what thou eatest, ere thou dost write thy vote."

"Alas, poor AAA yellow cab, how clueless art thou!
I didst set up a time to be picked up, yet they didst make me miss my flight,
For they didst only dispatch one taxi, alack!
When the Mesa airport was but five minutes from my humble abode,
And I didst wait on the phone for o'er twenty-five minutes,
Before they didst send a taxi to fetch me, woe is me!
Thus, I didst miss my flight home to WA state,
And now must arrive five hours later, when the children do sleep.
I wouldst not recommend them to any, nay!"

"Alas, poor Fletcher's, thy reputation doth suffer.  Most patrons, in truth, do speak ill of thee.  Alack, I too didst drop off my carriage, expecting a swift oil change, but lo! 'Twas naught but a woeful tale of woe.  A coupon I didst present, yet still they didst detain my steed until the sun didst set.  And then, a call didst come, with news of further woes.  Aye, four hundred crowns they didst demand, for services unneeded, nay, unasked for!  Pray tell, what sorcery is this?  Air filter, coolant flush, de-carbing, by the stars, what next?  Alas, I didst refuse, and thus didst end my dealings with these varlets.  Fare thee well, Fletcher's, mayhap another time, when honesty doth reign, shall we meet again."

"Verily, I didst not enjoy the experience. My body didst ache, and so I thought to give it a try. A foot massage, that's what I sought, but alas! The man didst give me a strange, harsh massage, that didst leave me feeling quite vexed. He didst spend but a few moments on my feet and legs, and so I shall not be doing it again, nor would I recommend it to any of mine acquaintances."

"A pox upon this eatery, a veritable letdown! My taste buds, once thrilled by newer haunts, now doth suffer from the blandness of this place. Its longevity, a curse, doth make its fare seem stale and woefully lacking in zest. A decent spot for business meetings, perchance, yet for victuals, I shall seek elsewhere. Fie upon this restaurant, say I!"

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news I bring!
The victuals at yonder inn, they be but wretched things.
Fried fowl, a sorry sight, with skin as hard as stone,
And fish, oh so not fresh, with bones that make me moan.
The rest, a chilly fare, with shrimp or meat so spare,
I'll ne'er return, 'tis vowed, to that accursed lair."

"Methought I brought my canine friend hither,
Forsooth, expecting a better fate didst lie in store.
But lo, upon mine entrance, a sense of woe
Didst o'ercome me, and I didst wish I hadst followed mine instincts more.

When I didst retrieve him, his claws didst bleed,
And nary a word of warning didst they give to me.
Homeward we went, and lo, the carpet and couch didst bear
The signs of blood, and thus my ire didst rise.
His coiffure, too, didst seem most uneven,
A paltry sum of ten pieces less than at Petsmart, 'twas given.

I pray thee, good sir or madam, heed my words,
And spend the extra coin, lest thou desire thy pet be treated like a mere chattel.
A pox upon this place, and may their shears be dull,
For naught but sorrow didst they bring upon mine innocent hound, and naught but discourtesy didst they show."

"Fare thee well, good sirs and madams! Forsooth, we didst dine at this establishment, and, alack, the victuals were but passable, and o'erpriced, to boot! The attendance, or rather, the lack thereof, didst leave us in a state of utter dismay and woe. 'Tis plain to see, the masters of this house have little knowledge or skill in the art of pleasing customers, and thus, we shall not return, ere the end of time."

"O, Pedro, woe betide thee for thy foul deceit!
If stars I could bestow, thou shouldst have naught but negative three.
Steven L, a man of wit and taste, hath spoken true,
That this, the Best of Madison, doth make me spew.

Thy food, a vile concoction, doth offend mine eyes,
A burrito of black beans, with naught but Bush's surprise.
The steak, a sorry sight, doth mock my hunger's pangs,
With sauce so vile, it doth make mine stomach wring its hands.

Oh, Pedro, thou dost owe me twenty dollars fair,
For serving up such swill, and calling it Mexican fare.
Avoid this place, dear friends, lest ye wish to suffer thus,
And seek instead the authentic taste of Old El Paso's bliss."

"Alas, my dear friend, what woeful fate hath brought thee to this wretched place? A brunch, they call it, where one may drink as much as they please, of bloody marys and mimosas, no less! But lo, the food, it doth not match the drink, in quality or in quantity, I fear. Eggs, hard as stones, and omelets, dry and rubbery, didst leave us both in dismay. And all for the sum of $72, a price most steep, I say.

The owner, with a bloody mary in hand, didst strut about, unconcerned with the state of his domain. His attention, elsewhere, it seemed, as if the woes of his business didst weigh heavy on his mind. My Louisiana love, ashamed, didst whisper in mine ear, 'tis a shame, this place doth exist. Alas, my friend, let us flee, and seek a better brunch, elsewhere, I pray."

"Alas, good sirs, how vexing 'tis to see
A meal so poorly served, with naught but woe.
Forty-five minutes passed, and still we waited,
For three mere sandwiches, when the crowd was scant.
And then, my appetizer, meant to be my feast,
Arrived some twenty-five minutes later, at last.
Two of the dishes were prepared awry,
As if the food had languished, cold and dry.
No bustling kitchen, full of cooks and steam,
Could justify such delay, or so it seemed.
I once held this establishment in high esteem,
But now, alas, their reputation doth decline,
In sooth, a tragic fall from grace, indeed."

"O, woe is me! The worst service e'er I didst see,
In all my life, a tale of woe and misery.
We asked about the fixed menu, a paltry sum,
And lo, the waiter's rudeness didst leave me dumb.
My fiance and I, in shock, didst rise and go,
Forsook the place, and sought another show.
Johnny Smalls, a haven, didst provide us cheer,
With service kind, and victuals most dear.
Ago, a lesson learn'd, that service poor,
Doth taint the feast, and leaves a sour taste once more."

"By Jove, what woeful fare didst Sbarro bring!
Alack, the pizza lacked all flavor, zest, and spice.
And he, the gent behind the counter, didst bear
A visage of disdain, as if he cared not a whit.
His body language spoke of boredom, and his soul
Didst seem to shrink from queries of the menu's scope.
And, lo, his skin didst bear the markings of a thug,
A sight most vile and unbecoming, I do declare.

But wait, there's more! For six small coins, a slice
Of pizza thou couldst purchase, and for eight, a brew.
Alas, my friends, 'tis not worth thy time or coin,
For elsewhere, better fare doth await thee, I do swear."

"A pox upon the owner(s) of this woeful place,
Whose absence and ill-will did bring its fate.
Three men, with nary a care, didst run the show,
And with their families, didst they not know?

Their marketing, a shambles, didst they not see,
That offers of help, didst they not decree?
A spot at UNLV, a gift, didst they not take,
And with their custom, didst they not partake?

They spread their business, too thin, alas,
And with their customers, didst they not pass?
No refunds, no hearing, didst they not know,
That good riddance, doth now, their legacy show."

"A pox upon that cursed FastMed, where I didst seek aid for mine infected toe. The doctor, a man of great learning, had retired, and in his stead, a mere physician's assistant didst attend to me. He barely glanced upon mine affliction, and with nary a care, didst scribe a prescription for an antibiotic draught. And thus, I was dismissed, with naught but woe and misery to show for it. Forsooth, my toe didst worsen, and soon, a specialist must needs be sought, to purge the foul fungus that had taken root within my very flesh. Fie upon that FastMed! May their coffers be empty, and their reputation in tatters, for the poor service they didst render unto me. A plague upon them, say I, and may all who enter there, beware!"

"Hark! A review of this place doth puzzle me,
For our visit this morn didst bring much glee.
A lengthy queue didst greet our eyes,
Yet swiftly moved, and seats were found with ease.

Our server, quick to take our order, brought
Drinks forthwith, and off we went to fetch
Our feast. A varied spread didst lay before,
Well-organized, with choices for all to savor.
The victuals, too, didst pass muster, fair.

But lo! One sight didst make my stomach turn,
A roach, upon the waffle, biscuit, hash, didst burn.
Unforgivable, I say, and vow,
Never again shall I set foot in this bow."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir,
This place doth leave much to be desired,
For I didst order glasses, and didst pay,
Yet still they doth not come, day upon day.

They said it wouldst take but a month's time,
But lo, 'tis now two weeks past that prime,
And still I doth not see my spectacles,
Nor hear a word from those who doth handle.

I called them, and didst ask of my fate,
But they didst say they wouldst call me later,
And so I waited, patient as could be,
But still they doth not call, nor doth decree.

The girl who didst answer, she didst say,
That they were closing, and wouldst call next day,
But alas, that day didst never come,
And so I doth remain, in this state of woe.

Their customer service, it doth need mend,
For they do not seem to care, nor doth attend,
To those who doth seek their help, or doth require,
A simple answer, or a mere desire.

So, verily, I say unto thee,
This place doth not deserve thy patronage,
For they do not value thee, nor doth see,
Thy need, nor doth thy patience, reward with gratitude."

"Fie upon this wretched place, where service doth stink,
And charges, like a swarm of bees, do multiply.
A group of twelve, we were, and each did pay
Ten pieces more, than what we should, they say.
Their ignorance, a weapon, did they wield,
When we, their faults, did to them reveal.
I'll ne'er return, nor would I e'er advise,
To come, and suffer, such a fate, so dire.
If thou, a fan, of foul hookah art,
And lov'st to be, o'ercharged, in thy part,
Then, friend, this place, for thee, were best,
But, heed my words, and save thyself the test."

"Beware, good sirs, of Olympic Garden's halls,
Unless ye be a sucker, ready to be fleeced.
This den of sin, this pit of vice, doth claim
To be a place of wonder, but 'tis naught but shame.

We entered in, with hopes of merriment,
But found instead a place of utter disappointment.
The cover charge, a steep and bitter pill,
Was paid, yet nary a maiden did we see fulfill
Her duties, dancing, as she ought to do.
We waited, patiently, but still they failed to woo.

The manager, a craven knave, did lie,
And promised us the girls would soon arrive.
But ten long minutes passed, and still they hid,
Leaving us to ponder, in dismay, what trickery had been did.
Four drinks, and eighty pieces of silver spent,
Yet still no beauty graced our presence, lent
No solace, save the thought of leaving, swift.

A pair of wenches, ugly, old, and worn,
Did offer us their laps, but we did scorn
Their advances, laughing, as we made our way,
To other clubs, where beauty doth hold sway.
So heed our words, dear friends, and shun
This place, where vice and avarice have begun."

This place, methinks, doth play the fool.
We came and waited, by the hour,
As was the time they did assign.
But when we asked, they said, "Fear not,
Another quarter hour, or twain,
Shall pass, ere ye be seated."
And thus we waited, patiently.
Yet when we asked again, they said,
"The time, good sirs, doth still remain,
Some twenty minutes more, or less."
Oh, how the truth doth seem to flee!
For who, I pray, hath two hours' leisure,
To wait for food, in such a place?
A plague upon this wretched spot!
It doth deceive, and doth beguile,
With doubled waits, and false pretence.
A pox on thee, thou craven crew!
How dare ye treat thy patrons thus?
In faith, 'tis shameful, and most vile.

"Verily, the most wretched Ihop I've e'er laid eyes upon! A serving maid did stroll about, her brow doth glisten with buckets of sweat, a sight most vile and off-putting. The victuals, when they did arrive, were cold and uninviting, a true disappointment. My spouse, he did order a Western Omelet, and lo, it contained but a meager amount of cheese and a few slices of ham, naught else but eggs, a pitiful sight. My own repast, it was a sorry state, cold and unappealing, like unto a leftover from a previous patron, uneaten and cast aside. Fie upon this wretched place, ne'er shall I darken its doorstep again!"

Tonight, we ventured forth, post-Super Bowl,
To Fox Sports, where Glee did soon unfold.
We waited patiently, the sole patrons there,
For pizza, hot and fresh from the oven's glare.

Glee played for half an hour, and then,
The owner appeared, a man of little wit.
He changed the channel, with nary a care,
And claimed 'twas policy, with no regret.

The pizza, fair, yet not worth the fuss,
We vowed not to return, in disgust.
For how he treated us, with such disdain,
We could but wonder, how his employees did gain.

"Hark! What news is this? The Coolatta machine,
Broken at all locations, doth it seem.
Why still sell Coolatta, pray tell,
When the machine doth not function well?
Corporate office, art thou aware,
Of this scam, and the customers thou dost bear?
Horrible service, indeed, doth this make."

"O, woeful day! O, foulest of services,
That doth resemble a place where elders do rest.
The scent, it doth reek, as if from a tomb,
And chill, it doth seep, into mine own bones.
Ask I did, for them to close the portal,
Lest my teeth they do chatter, and my words be frozen.
Alas, the victuals, they do leave much to desire,
And thus, my belly, it doth protest with ire."

"A humble tavern, striving to be more,
With dishes small, yet weighty as a score.
Burgers and fries, with riffs and twists,
But alas, the beer selection doth persist.
At Harris Teeter's, thou shalt find the same,
And pay a price that doth proclaim thy shame.
If thou desirest a truly fine array,
Of beer and tapas, go to Gallery 22,
Where prices fair and a feast for thine eyes,
Shall make thy visit worthwhile, and surprise."

"Fie upon this wretched inn! When we arrived, four watchmen's cars didst sit,
With wretches in irons, a sorry sight.
In our chamber, a pair of drawers lay,
Unowned, unclean, a sorry plight.
And later, on my credit scroll,
A charge didst appear, for mini-bar,
We hadst no key, nor didst we crave,
This cursed place, so run-down, so bare.
They gouge thy purse, with prices high,
So heed my words, and pass by nigh."

"Fie upon this wretched place, where comfort doth not reside!  A theatre of luxury, they call it, but alas, 'tis naught but a den of woe.  The ledge, it doth obstruct my view, so that I must sit on tippy-toes, or else miss out on subtitles, precious dialogue unheard.  My experience, ruined, and all their finery, for naught but woe doth it bring me.  Fie, I say, upon this terrible design!"

"Dissatisfied, we art. A house in Fort Mill, we did rent,
With promises of fixes, and a lease to invent.
But since we moved in, nary a word have we heard,
And our concerns, like dust, do lie unheard.

A week passed, and still no reply doth come,
From the agent we spoke with, in Fort Mill's home.
This conduct, unprofessional, doth seem,
And we, in our dealings, such tactics ne'er deem.

I pray, good sir, that thou mayst learn,
To tend to thy clients, and their needs to discern.
For in this trade, honesty and care,
Must be the guiding principles, beyond compare."

"Hark! I didst think that Wynn didst not allow
The pushing of a stroller into their buffet hall.
But alas, I was mistaken, for we could not even step
Into the Wynn, they didst deny us entry, save for those who dwell
Within their hallowed halls. A pox upon their rule, I say!
For though their buffet may be grand, 'twas naught but foul play.
The crab, it didst reek of odor most foul,
The lobster, it was not fresh, but rather old and stale.
And as for the meat, 'twas soft and most disgusting.
Nay, I shall ne'er return to that accursed place,
Forsooth, 'tis not worth the time nor the expense, I do declare!"

"Methinks we didst eagerly anticipate dining here, my dear. Forsooth, we hadst savored the chef's culinary wizardry at the Bigelow Grille, and verily, 'twas a feast most divine. Thus, our expectations were high, and we didst crave to partake of Salt's bounty. Alas, the drink special didst prove a bitter disappointment, a draught most foul and undrinkable, I didst send it back, yet they didst charge me still. The cheese plate, though good, didst lack bread or crackers, a strange oversight indeed. The beet salad, with its poached egg, didst boast a certain je ne sais quoi, but the duck, alas, didst suffer from an excess of fat. The short ribs, oh so tender, didst border on the obscene, their richness didst leave us both unsatisfied and discontent. Our waitress, fair maiden, didst neglect to proffer the meal descriptions, as didst her comrades. Fie upon this sorry state of affairs! Methinks the chef, a master of his art, didst stumble in his new endeavors. Pray, bring back the magic of Alchemy, that we may once again revel in gastronomic bliss!"

"Farewell, this place doth stink of vice and woe,
Where drugs and rudeness do most plainly show.
A maiden, with an X upon her hand,
Did bang her head against the wall, most grand.
We got a table, but ere we could imbibe,
Were kicked out for my e-cig, most uncivil.
The folk were rude, and I, in service bound,
Shall spread the word, and ne'er come round."

Hark! Has any soul attempted to call BC/BS of AZ's Customer Service number? By th' heavens, 'tis a feat nigh impossible, for they do not proffer the choice of speech with a mortal forthright. I, myself, didst hold for ten full minutes, ere a representative named Mary didst grace mine ear. I gave her my name, and lo! She didst hang up on me, most unceremoniously. I called once more, and waited fifteen minutes, ere I couldst pose a simple query regarding mine own policy. Their phone system doth not inform the patron how long they shall wait, and the melodies they play are of a sort that doth discourage folk from holding. Verily, save thou hast toiled in customer service thyself, and dost request it oft, 'tis a difficult path to converse with those who hold thy fate in their grasp. Alas! Forsooth, those who pay them thousands in premiums yearly shouldst have a simpler means to reach their insurance company.

"Rude service, indeed, with employees who seem to bear a grudge against their very presence. A pleasing site doth not a pleasant meal make, forsooth, when Subway's fare doth taste the same as any other."

"Aye, good sir, thy words doth pierce mine ear,
As thou dost speak of charges most unfair.
Ten dollars, thou say's? A sum most dear!
I pray thee, reconsider, lest thou wish to share
In the sin of extortion, a foul deed indeed.
Forsooth, 'tis not just to take such heed."

"Alack, what memories shall I retain of yonder Tropicana?  A sum of thirty crowns didst I gain, and likewise didst lose.  But lo, the fairest vision that mine eyes didst behold, a comely serving-maid of Asian descent, didst with intent most foul, ignore me thrice.  Her gaze didst fall upon the twain who sat beside me, and to them didst she proffer her wares.  Oh, how my ire didst swell, for they didst arrive at the wheel of fortune long after my own arrival.  And yet, she didst not deign to ask if I desired a draught, but instead didst query them once more.  Fie upon this cruel fate, and may the gods above look kindly upon my plight!"

"Hark! We chanced upon this eatery, four in number,
With hunger pangs that did beset our tummies.
The server, with a scowl, did show us to a table,
But we requested one that could seat us all, in fable.
She brought us menus, then didst ignore us,
While tending to those who came after, in chorus.
Twenty minutes passed, and still we waited,
Our patience worn thin, our bellies unabated.
Up we rose, and left with haste,
Forsooth, a woeful tale, and naught but waste.
This restaurant, shun it, I pray thee,
Lest thou suffer similar fate, in misery."

"Hark! If thou dost seek fare of middling sort,  
That doth taste passably, and costs a pretty penny,  
Go to this place, and prepare to part with seventy-six pieces of silver.  
Forsooth, I didst order chicken strips, a steak, and fried fowl,  
And lo! The total sum didst come to seventy-six dollars, by my troth.  
Aye, mediocre victuals do not merit high praise,  
And though the atmosphere was fair, 'twas not worth the cost, I do declare."

"Methinks 'twas folly to expect much from Patron,
A restaurant near my humble abode,
Their salsa, from a jug, no doubt, did come,
And chips, straight from a box, most bland and stale,
Did they serve with haste, and little care,
I'd rather go to Chipotle, fair and square,
For chips and salsa, of far better fare.

A quesadilla, too, I did order,
But found it lacking, like the whole affair,
A menu new, or chef with skill,
Is what they need, to make their dishes thrill.

Alas, my friends, I do advise,
To walk up street, to Mad Mex, with ease,
Or to Chipotle, where you'll save a few,
And find a meal, more worthy, anon, adieu!"

"O woeful night, when expectation met dismay!
My friend, a patron of this place before,
Did warn me of the mediocrity,
Yet still, my hopes did soar.
But lo, the feast did prove a sorry sight,
For half our order, they did forget in flight.
And when it came, 'twas cold, or wrong, or naught,
A sorry state, with nary a morsel caught.
The waiter, thrice he came, to make amends,
Yet still, his efforts did but little mend.
The manager, in desperation, did implore,
That we take other victuals from their store.
But alas, our hunger had departed, slain,
By the poor service, and the food in vain.
In Charlotte, there be many a sportive hall,
Where good cheer, great service, doth enthrall.
I'll seek them out, and leave this place to fate,
For they did err, and charged us for their hate."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news I bring!
The victuals, they were of fair quality, I do confess.
But, alack! The service, 'twas a woeful sight to see.
A server, Chad by name, didst attend to me.
His manners, rough and uncouth, didst offend mine eyes.
And, prithee, let no man be served by him, lest he desire
To flee the premises in haste and dismay.
The bartender, too, didst fail to impress.
His potions, weak and poorly mixed, didst disappoint.
Alas, my friends, I pray thee, avoid this place,
Lest thou desirest to suffer ill fate and disgrace."

"I took some garments to yon cleaners, marking 'dry clean only' on my denim with care, lest they mistake it for a common rag. But when I retrieved them, woe! My jeans were shrunken and discolored, a sorry sight indeed. The owner and manager, unmoved by my plight, offered naught but empty words and no redress. Alas, I didst patronize this place, hoping to support the local trade, but their poor service doth leave me in dismay."

"A night didst I spend within these walls, my dear,
And lo, what troubles didst beset mine ears!
The crackheads next door, with their cries and moans,
Didst keep me wakeful, like a mournful tune.
I told the management, but they didst not care,
Their apathy didst leave me in despair.
For though I do believe in giving all a chance,
When safety's lacking, 'tis a foolish dance.
Nevermore shall I return, I swear,
Unless they have guards who act with cheer.
My pre-paid night, alas, was lost in flight,
But lesson learned, I'll choose with greater might."

"O, woe is me! My A/C doth break each passing year,
A plague upon this place, a curse most dire!
I paid 1300 coins for parts and labor dear,
In summer's heat, my truck didst swelter and sweat.

A valve, they said, didst fail, and thus they replaced,
But lo! Another year, another break, disgraced!
They retrofitted ill, a wrong valve, alas!
And now, my high-pressure line doth leak, oh woe!

Six tens of dollars, parts from Auto Zone,
Didst fix the leak, but anger still doth seethe.
This Sun Devil Auto, on Chandler Boulevard,
A den of thieves, a place most ill-reputed!

Their service, poor, their skills, most lacking,
Avoid them, friends, for they do but mock.
My A/C, broken thrice, in two years' time,
A tale of woe, a warning, heed my rhyme!"

This club, a jest, a mockery, a sham,
The so-called event men, small fry, not worth a dam,
Rude and unfriendly, they didst show,
No care for guests, nor courtesy to know.

We, on the list, yet they didst ignore,
A rule most strange, two men near a maid no more,
Feeble representation, a poor display,
Get better staff, or else, away, go thy way.

In Las Vegas, many clubs of renown,
Choose wisely, lest thou waste thy crown.

"Alas, my stomach doth protest, forsooth,
At this establishment, where I didst seek sustenance.
The service, poor, and scant the meat they didst provide,
A paltry sum, piled high, yet naught but sorrow didst it bring.
I asked for White American, a simple request,
Yet, alack, the cheese they didst apply, was not what I didst desire.
Cheddar, they didst use, and oh, how it didst vex me,
For had I seen them, I wouldst have stayed their hand, ere they didst commit this foul deed.
But, lo, their back was turned, and thus, I couldst not intervene,
And so, I didst receive this woeful repast, with naught but dismay.
Fast food, it may be, yet still, a tip they didst proffer,
And thus, a better service, I didst expect, and not this sorry plight.
No more, shall I return, for in my car, I shall make haste,
To find a meal, that doth befit, my hunger's noble might."

"Methinks 'tis folly to pay a fee so dear,
For a spectacle we hold in such disdain.
My friend and I, both fair and wise guiles,
Do choose to dine and drink, with naught but gain.

A pox upon the venue, with its greedy door,
That doth demand a sum we cannot abide.
We'll spend our coins where hospitality doth pour,
At Gordon Biersch, where ale and cheer do reside.

Tarry, good sirs, and heed our reasoning,
For 'tis not wise to pay for what we may see,
In yonder street, without a single penny's sting,
Or from the lot, where cars do park with ease.

So, let us raise our glasses, full of cheer,
And praise the place where we do find delight.
For though the fight may rage, with blows so queer,
Our evening shall be merry, full of mirth and light."

"O, wouldst thou seek a place to spend thy nights,
In revelry and mirth, with joys and delights?
Avoid, my friend, this den of woe and shame,
Where misery doth reign, and vice doth claim.

'Tis run down, foul, and old, in disrepair,
Inhabited by those who doth not care.
The "women" there, with hearts of stone,
Do prey upon the unsuspecting alone.

One "Cookie", by name, doth lead the pack,
With cunning guile and wicked attack.
She'll take thy gold, and leave thee drained,
With naught but sorrow, and a heart constrained.

The management, by Sasha led,
Doth treat its dancers with contempt and dread.
They doth nickel and dime, with cruel hand,
And leave the girls in penury and disband.

This place, my friend, doth not deserve thy sight,
For it doth reek of woe, and endless plight.
Seek elsewhere, in this city of delight,
For joy and mirth, and pleasures unalloyed with fright."

"A pox upon this place, with service most vile,
That doth profess to be open twenty-four hours,
Yet cannot brew a cup of coffee, nor provide
A stale sandwich, save for those who pay in cash.
I do detest this wretched hole, and shall not darken
Its doorstep e'er again, for fear of further woe."

"Fly not to this place, good sirs and madams,
Unless thou hast a penchant for doling out gold,
And being told to leave by the master of the hall,
A crackpot, drunkard, with a foul mouth to boot.

We spent less than an hour, our glasses still full,
When he approached and took the table away,
With nary a care, he bid us leave, with a gruff,
"Get thee gone, and trouble me no more, I pray."

I had been there before, and recommended it,
But now, alas, I shall not set foot within it,
For such poor service, and a host most rude,
Doth make me shun this place, and seek elsewhere,

In fair Scottsdale, there be many a fine eatery,
With better fare, and service of a higher degree,
So, gentle folk, take heed of my words,
And shun this place, where ill manners be the norm."

"Verily, there be room for betterment in the teacher's way of dealing with clients, and the company's care for customers. 'Tis plain to see in Zeb's reply to Brittney T. He didst not offer apologies nor a second chance, as any honourable business wouldst do, but instead, didst argue and mock her. Such behaviour be immature and foul. Methinks their teaching method be a scare tactic. I was offered naught but the unlimited ten-day package, a steal indeed! Yet, one class doth cost sixteen silverlings! What be the catch, I ask thee? 'Tmust be the attitude towards customers, or perchance they seek to line their pockets with the extra four silverlings per person. I know not what sorcery doth lie within. I wouldst love a good hot yoga class, and to be pushed, forsooth! 'Tis not what folk complain of. Bikram be a discipline, constructive criticism be needful. But personal attacks be most un-yoga-like, and I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this place to any soul."

"A pox upon Spirit Airlines, a plague upon their house!
Their prices may seem fair, but beware, dear traveler,
For they do charge extra for each and every thing,
Even for carry-on bags, a most grievous sin.

Their customer service is lacking, nay, 'tis nonexistent,
A flight attendant joked of safety protocols, oh so reckless!
And as for leg room, well, 'tis scarce and scant,
Even for one of five feet, a sight most unpleasant.

So heed my words, good sir or madam, avoid Spirit,
Pay a bit more for a better flight, 'twill be worth it,
For though their prices may seem low, their fees mount high,
And thou shalt regret thy choice, mark my words, anon."

"Methinks I am but newly come to Las Vegas, fair city of sin. A friend, in kindness, did suggest Ritual, a place of beauty and grace. I signed up, eager to partake of their services, and received a coupon of $20, a generous offer indeed. Alas, their haircuts, priced at $60, did not align with the coupon's worth. I called, hoping they might make an exception, but their response was most vexing. They suggested adding a deep conditioner, worth $35, to make the total cost exceed the coupon's value. Fie upon it! I shall not be using Ritual, forsooth. Their reluctance to accommodate a new customer doth speak volumes of their desire for business."

"O, why doth Panda Express, that dish so fine,
In malls, doth suck, when freestanding, doth shine?
Is 't lazy workers, or food that doth sit,
Too long, that doth make it lose its zest and wit?
I do confess, I didst order orange chicken,
A dish most fair, and worthy of much licken.
But lo, when at the mall, 'twas soggy, alack,
As if from microwave, it hadst been fetched.
But at a standalone shop, oh what a sight,
Crispy and tasty, a true delight."

"O, woe is me! What sorcery doth plague this place?
The machines, they break, and naught but woe doth bring.
A hot chocolate, I didst seek, but lo, the machine didst fail.
A smoothie, then, I didst desire, but alas, 'twas not to be.
A cookie, simple, yet divine, but nay, the machine didst break.
And last, a sundae, sweet and fine, but no, 'twas not to be, forsooth.
I ponder, are the machines truly cursed, or are these folk but fools?
Enough, I say! This place, I shall not grace again, by my troth!"

"Alack, what woeful tale of woe doth here unfold!
My humble home, in disrepair, didst call for aid,
And lo, a man, with tools and parts, didst come,
To fix the issues that didst plague my domicile.

But alas, his words didst strike fear in my heart,
For every task, a $200 fee didst he demand,
Even for a toilet flapper, a simple part,
Didst cost a sum that didst seem most unjust.

So, I, in wisdom, didst decide to act,
And purchased the flapper myself, in haste,
For $10, a sum that didst seem most fair,
And installed it, with ease, in a few short minutes' space.

Oh, how the man didst look, with shock and dismay,
When I, a woman, didst show him the way,
To fix the issue, without his expertise,
And save my purse, from his greedy surmise.

Beware, dear friends, of such men, who prey,
On those in need, with false, inflated fees,
For they are but crooks, who seek to cheat,
And leave thee penniless, with naught but deceit.

So, let this be a lesson, to all who can hear,
To stand up strong, and not to fear,
For knowledge is power, and thou shalt see,
That thou, thyself, canst fix, with ease, thy home's decree."

"Alas, dear friends, take heed of my words, ere thou doth step foot into this place, forsooth, 'tis a den of woe and disappointment. My kin and I didst await our turn for eighty minutes, and when at last we were seated, behold! No straws nor silverware didst grace our table. We didst ask, nay, beg for these essentials, but alas, the waiter didst forget, or perchance, didst not care. Our meals didst sit before us, untouched, like a cruel taunt, and none didst come to our aid.
