Our orders were awry, our drinks didst tarry, and to crown this wretched evening, 'twas my father's birthday feast! The manager didst offer a feeble apology, and a paltry sum was deducted from our bill. Alas, fair friends, avoid this place, and seek instead the location on Sunset, forsooth, 'tis a haven of delight, and worth thy visit."

"Hark, what villain doth approach? A convict, by the look, who doth attempt to sell me more than just an oil change. Pray tell, good sir, how doth thy neck bear such a mark? And yonder, that scoundrel who doth leap upon my carriage, seeking a fissure in the glass. Fie upon this place, 'tis like the ninth circle of hell itself, a den of rogues and varlets."

"This review concerns the laundry service on Scheffel Street. I utilize their enclosed cleaning, which includes a hemding subscription, quite affordable at 35 euros for 20 pieces. Initially, all was well; the garments were completed within three to four working days. The quality was passable. However, over the past few months, the hemding has taken a week to finish, which I find excessive. With proper planning, one can manage, but the last three weeks have seen the hemding still unfinished after a week! This is too much, and the staff shows little understanding or effort. It's a shame, as the laundry is conveniently located beside my residence. I shall seek another establishment that offers better and quicker service, even if it means paying a bit more for quality and service. My colleagues who also use the service have been informed, and they will change as well. When I called the proprietor to complain, her response was that I paid 1.60 euros per hemding with the subscription, so I should just pay 2.50 euros per hemding individually, and then I would receive preferential treatment! What an outrage! Loyal customers with subscriptions are not treated well. Therefore, I shall never return!"

This place doth blow, in sooth,
Management didst come to my table,
To speak of smoke and foam,
In quantity, on my beer, they didst strive.
The Turkey pot pie, with four pieces didst lie,
And salt, it didst contain, in quantity,
Enough to raise my blood pressure, full high.
Fries, cold as winter's night, didst greet me,
Scallops, small as nickels, didst not meet me.
I have dined here thrice before,
Never such poor service, didst I endure.
I am most vexed, in truth,
At management, who doth think all are fools.
Very sad, indeed, doth my heart feel,
For service, poor, and food, of poor quality, doth reveal.
I shall stick with LINQ, 'tis my intent,
For there, they do understand,
That customers, well cared for, are their bent.

"Hark, what discourtesy doth this eatery bring!
I went for a sit-down meal, yet nary a soul didst attend to my needs.
The host, who manned the register with laxity, didst ignore me for five good minutes.
And lo, another patron didst enter, and with haste, didst receive service in but three brief minutes.
The waitress, who didst tend to other patrons with such speed, didst finally approach me, and ask if I didst come for take-out.
I replied, with nay, I dined within, yet she didst not hear my words, and hastened to attend to others.
Thus, after some fifteen minutes had passed, I didst decide to leave, without a menu in sight.
Mayhap, in days to come, I shall return, to sample their fare, and see if they have mended their ways."

"Hark, good sir! For six long years, I've been a loyal patron of thy fine establishment, Nakama. My love for thy food and service hath never wavered, until this fateful night. My finance and I didst dine at thy place for my birthday feast, and lo, didst I order my usual meal, as I had done these past six years. But alas, the waitress didst inform me that I could not have my fried rice sans vegetables. I didst request to speak with a manager, and forth came a gentleman named Chris. After a ten-minute delay, during which he didst play online poker, he didst say that he had received many complaints from the chefs who prepared the food, and thus, this new rule had been implemented. I didst offer to pay extra for my meal, as I had done in the past, but nay, Chris didst not relent. He didst say that 'twas a new rule, though 'twas not written on the menu nor online. And so, my dear finance and I didst dine on our birthday dinner, but 'twas not as we had wished. Our time, two hours of driving, and our joy, were all for naught. Farewell, Nakama! Thy customer service doth leave much to be desired, and thy business ethics, they doth stink!"

"Nevermore shall I return, forsooth!
The service was woeful, and the sandwiches, alack!
Sloppy, ugly, poor quality messes, with nary a choice,
But one, a vegetarian option, old and soggy, with toppings quite vile.
I told the counter maiden, 'Tis my first time here,
She gave no helpful words, nor cheer.
I said, 'I be a veggie,' and she made a jest,
A condescending quip, with no mirth or zest.
I told her twice, 'This I do not desire,'
The cook, he heard, yet still they did conspire
To make my meal most wretched and awry.
Alas, good friends, avoid this place, forsooth,
For it doth fail in culinary prowess, and in truth,
'Tis a poor excuse for a meal, and a sorry sight,
And the service, alack! doth leave much to be desired, in sooth."

"Four adults we, on morn of March the seventeenth, didst set forth to behold yon museum's treasures.  Its premise, most fair and bright, didst pique our curiosity.  Blacksmith, skilled in his craft, didst delight.  Alas, volunteers, few in number, didst hinder full enjoyment of experience, for want of participants in mock battle.  Price, modest, and parking, free, didst ease our purses.  Yet, with regrets, I must advise against attendance, for lacking vitality and vigor, the visit doth prove."

"Upon the eve of Christmas, I didst venture forth
With six companions, to dine and make merry.
The tavern, though empty, didst deny us
A table of suitable size, with chairs enough.
The server, round and jolly, didst insist
We sit at a smaller table, cramped and tight.
We dined with elbows touching, discomfort our plight,
Whilst a larger table nearby didst lie unused.
What folly! Our meal didst suffer, our mirth didst cease.
Thanks, good sir, for naught but vexation and displeasure."

"A pox upon the Nye party we did attend,
For ninety pieces of silver, our expectations did bend.
A table, three drinks, and a half glass of champagne,
With food, we thought, would make our spirits range.

But alas, the tables were scarce, and few did sit,
And when we went to feast, the victuals did lack wit.
No meatballs nor chicken, only pasta, oh dear!
The drinks, they did limit, no shots, no cheer.

The tickets, they did stipulate, drinks under seven,
And two of six, with voices, did not ascend to heaven.
The entertainment, middling, no duel, as we did see,
At other bars, with pianos, in harmony.

In conclusion, a rip-off, the place did seem,
Our money, not well spent, a bitter dream.
We shall not return, our minds are made,
For better value, elsewhere, we shall inquire."

"In days of yore, when first I met my love,
This restaurant was where we didst dine,
And what a feast it was! The service fine,
The victuals, delectable and divine.

But lo, last week, when we didst return,
Our expectations high, our hearts didst yearn,
For that same Chinese buffet, once so grand,
Now served up fare most foul and bland.

The veggies, brown and rotten, didst stink,
The sauces, syrupy, sickly sweet, didst blink,
The meats, greasy, nauseating, didst make,
Our stomachs churn, our taste buds forsake.

The steamed buns, old and stale, didst cling,
To the paper, like a sad, wet thing.
Not one dish, could I say, didst please,
I tried them all, but alas, no ease.

Their focus now, on drinks, so bright,
Umbrellas, dry ice, fruit, a silly sight,
Good food, no longer their aim, it seems,
Just novelty cocktails, and endless dreams.

Disgusting, indeed, but quick, they are,
To refill your drink, a small, bright star.
Avoid this place, my friends, 'tis wise,
Lest ye wish, to taste, such culinary surprise."

"A year hath passed since first I owned this land,
Managed by Osselaer, a company grand.
But alas, my troubles did begin,
With landscaping woes that would not end.

To Sweetwater Vista, I did write,
And sent a missive to their president in sight.
But naught didst they do, nor did they stir,
As if my plight were but a jest to them, a whim.

Their policy, it seems, doth state,
That as long as checks are sent, all's well, no debate.
But how hard is it, pray tell,
To trim some bushes, or turn on water spells?

I, myself, do not mind, I swear,
Doing such tasks, for I find joy therein, my dear.
But paying over a thousand crowns a year,
Doth not excuse their lack of care, I fear.

So heed my words, good sirs and madams,
When seeking homes, avoid Osselaer's clutches,
For thou shalt be disappointed, mark my words,
And thy needs shall not be met, nor thy purse unfurled."

"Hark! Last eve, as I didst savour a salad's delight,
I chanced upon a place that didst catch my sight.
Alas! 'Twas closed, oh woeful fate!
Yet still, my friends, do Z recommend,
For other locations shall not disappoint."

"O, woe is me! A haircut, I did receive,
And lo, it doth resemble a chopped mess, full of despair.
I asked for an aline cut, with layers on the back,
But nay, the stylist, she knew not how to attack.

Her scissors, they did snip and clip, without finesse,
Leaving my locks, in disarray, and in distress.
I didst not wish to snap, at the lady, so kind,
For she was old, and her red hair, didst shine.

But alas, my hair, doth look most dire,
A mess, a tangled web, that doth not inspire.
Fifty dollars, I didst pay, and a tip, I didst give,
For though she be a poor stylist, she didst live.

Oh, cursed LifeSpa, how thou hast failed me,
A place, where haircuts, are not, what they should be.
I shall never return, nor shall I recommend,
For fake, thy people, and false, thy pretenses, doth seem.

A pox upon thee, LifeSpa, and shame,
For letting such a stylist, bear thy name."

"Hark! If I escape the buffet's ill fate,
'Twill be a twinkling star of worth, I do await.
The price, a fair sum, doth make my purse sing,
And lo, the beef lo mein, a rubbery delight, doth bring
A smile to mine own face. But alas, the rest,
Doth leave much to be desired, I must confess.
The chopsticks, they did give me splinters,
A painful price to pay for such a meal, I do infer."

"Hark, what fortune doth befall me now?
Alack, I went to Patron, full of woe,
And there, within that fair room beside,
Did sit, forsaken by all servitors' eyes.
Their gaze did meet mine, and yet they passed,
As if my presence were but naught but grass.
Methought, perchance 'twas due to lunch's end,
But nay, their customary service doth descend.
Alas, how couldst I, with parched throat, partake
In feast, when water, ne'er a drop would make?
Thus, I departed, full of discontent,
For service poor, doth mar the culinary bent."

"A plague upon this wretched abode, so near to ASU's hallowed halls, yet void of all that's good. My roommates and I, in constant strife, did pay our rent on time, but still they did impose, false charges, late fees, and more, a woeful tale of woe. The appliances, a curse, did fail, the sink's disposal, broken, causing foul odors to prevail. And when the air conditioner did drip, 'twas a sight most vexing, and a further cause for ire. \n\nTheir bookkeeping, a sham, a travesty, did charge us still, long after we had fled, a thousand gold coins, for who knows what, save for their own folly. We paid, to end the pain, but still they claim, we owe them more, a never-ending drain. Avoid this place, dear friends, 'tis not worth the cost, for it will follow thee, until thy life's savings be lost."

"A pox upon Sears, their service doth stink!
For a month now, we've washed dishes by hand,
Thanks to their botched repairs and lack of care.
Their serviceman, ID#943, did not show his face,
And when we called, they did naught but delay.
Avoid their service, dear friends, like the plague,
For it doth seem they do not care for their customers' woe.
A whole month! Oh, what a sorry tale!
Sears Home Services, shame on thee,
For causing such distress and misery.
Block their number, lest thou suffer the same fate."

"Fie upon this wretched meal! The salad bar, a sorry sight, didst lack the freshness of the morn. My chicken, devoid of moisture, didst leave me in dismay. Alas, 'twas my first time at this establishment, and verily, the scent of decay didst fill mine nostrils. The cushion of mine seat, in tatters, didst add to mine discomfort. The server, kind and courteous, didst try to make amends, but alas, 'twas a waste of coin. They didst proclaim, in bold print, freshly made lemonade, but lo, 'twas naught but regular, from the fountain, poured with haste. I pointed out the disparity, and the server, in confusion, didst stammer forth a feeble explanation. The emptiness of the hall, didst speak volumes of the quality of the fare."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy for Whataburger,
That savory haven where I do devour
My daily meals, and oftentimes twain.
But lo, this particular place, wherein
I spend my days, hath slowed its pace,
And thus, doth make my visits quite vexing.
For months now, 'tis been in such disarray,
And still, they seem to be unaware
Of their plight, and how they must repair."

"Fie upon this wretched place, where service doth falter and fail!
The waiter, in haste, didst brusquely serve, with scant regard for courtesy or tale.
And, alack, the victuals! Poorly prepared, they didst taste of naught but woe.
The backlava, in sooth, was worst of all, a confection most foul and loathsome, I do declare.
Never shall I darken their door again, forsooth!"

"Methinks I didst venture hither for the second time this day,
But alas, my sojourn didst prove most vexing, I pray.
Forsooth, I sat at yonder bar, a space of seven minutes,
And three folk roamed behind, yet none didst take heed of mine intentions.
Thus, to The Map Room next door didst I repair,
To partake of luncheon, and quell my hunger's fiery glare.

My first visit, a server didst attend to me,
A kitchen lad didst bring my victuals, swiftly,
Yet nary a soul didst return, for forty-five minutes,
And so, to the counter didst I go, to claim my reckoning, in despair.
Alas, I cannot say, I didst not essay,
To give this place another chance, but 'twill not be my wont, I fear.

The barbecue chicken pizza, not so ill, didst taste,
But alack, 'tis not a place, where I wouldst make haste."

"Hark! I didst plan to learn a new dance move,
At Dance Charisma, where I didst choose to groove.
But lo! When I arrived, the doors were shut tight,
And I didst hear they hadst closed up shop for good that night.
They didst suggest I try Ballroom Addiction next,
To which I didst reply, 'I shall not be so quick.'
Forsooth! I didst decide to seek out another place,
Where I couldst learn to dance with grace and poise and pace.
Fred Astaire Dance Studio didst catch my eye,
And there, they didst treat me with such courtesy.
I have been taking lessons there ever since,
And now, my dancing skills dost never cease to impress."

"Fie upon this wretched place, where food doth falter and service doth decay! Avoid it, good sirs and madams, lest ye wish to suffer fate most dire. I didst order their Cuban sandwich, a dish most vile and woeful, 'twas naught but microwaved fodder, a culinary disgrace, a mockery of taste and decency. Fare thee well, and heed my warning, lest thou fall prey to such gastronomic chicanery."

"Alas, my dear friends, how vexed I be,
A picky eater, cursed by fate's decree.
I crave the chicken pesto sandwich, naught else,
And oft to yonder tavern, swiftly pace.

My birthday dawns, and friends ask where I'd choose,
To dine and celebrate with joyous voice.
I say, "The chicken pesto sandwich, 'tis my heart's desire,"
But lo, they've ceased to make it, oh what a dire fire!

Disappointment grips me, sorrow doth abound,
We leave, my friends, with hearts cast down.
Alas, my birthday, marred by this woeful plight,
Yet still, my love for that sandwich, doth burn bright."

"O, woe is me! A pox upon this wretched company,
Whose customer service doth leave much to be desired.
Messed up bills, service outages, and reps who doth not care,
A plague upon them! My patience hath been tried.

I've had my fill of their poor service, by my troth,
And when the World Cup ends, I shall cancel my subscription forthwith.
No more shall I suffer their incompetence and neglect,
For I have had enough, by the stars!"

"Verily, I say unto thee, this place doth leave much to be desired. The chamber, though newly refurbished, didst lack in comfort and cleanliness. The servants, with their scowls and gruff demeanor, didst make one feel unwelcome. The victuals, alas, were naught but wretched fare, barely fit for a beggar's table. And the location, tucked away in a dingy corner, didst reek of despair. The only solace found was in the Adventuredome, where children didst frolic and play, but alas, 'twas crowded beyond measure, making it difficult to fully enjoy. In truth, the entire establishment doth seem to suffer from a general malaise, a foul stench that doth permeate every nook and cranny. I do proclaim, this place shouldst be razed to the ground, and anew, with better planning and design, it may rise like a phoenix from the ashes."

"O, woe is me, dear Gaati! What sorcery hast thou wrought upon my taste buds? Our past orders, aye, they were a hit, but this last one, alas, didst falter. A plague upon thy kitchen, forsooth! 

We didst order thus: chicken pad Thai, broccoli with fried pork, tofu paw see whee, and mango sticky rice. And, by the stars, a side of vinegar green chili to spice up the feast. 

But lo, when the grub didst arrive, the noodles lacked flavor, and the meat, scarce couldst be found. The chili, rotten, they didst say, and left it out, a pox upon their house! For 'tis the zest, the tang, the fire that maketh the dish divine. And, to cap it all, the mango dessert, a sorry sight, half-rotten, sans coconut sauce, a bitter disappointment. Fie upon thee, Gaati! Thou hast lost a customer, forevermore."

"Alas, my review of Decatur didst appear
On Outlook's page, which now doth lay in ruin.
My family hath visited since the year 2000,
But latey, quality and choice have dwindled,
Whilst prices riseth, like a mounting flood.

Twenty-six ninety-five, a sum most dire,
For weekend feast, that doth not compare
To days of yore, when salmon skins didst grace
The sushi menu, now a sorry sight.
No eel, no salmon, in this woeful place,
A paltry selection, doth bring me woe.

Crab legs, so small, and cold, alack,
Despite warm butter, doth not make amends.
Fourteen years, a loyal patron, I,
But now, alas, I must bid thee adieu.
Las Vegas, city of excess, doth hold
More options, better, than thy crumbling fold."

"Hark! What store is this? A GameStop, by my troth!
And lo, what luck! 'Tis Saturday, and five o'clock,
The hour when most men seek their rest and ease.
But not I, dear friends, for I have come to find
If this store be the place where I might spend
My forty-five spare minutes, and thus be blessed.

Aye, 'tis a rare sight, this store so still,
With but one worker, half-alive, yet full of will.
He doth attend to me, with speed and grace,
And checks my purchases with a steady pace.
But then, alack! The line doth grow long,
And round the store, a serpentine throng.
Seventy-eight souls, all waiting their turn,
Their patience tested, as they stand and burn.

Yet fear not, friends, for all is not lost,
For in this wait, there doth come a cost.
Five minutes, dear friends, five whole minutes,
Must thou devote to hearing salesmen's witty comments.
But hold! What's this? A receipt, so long and vast,
It doth seem a challenge, a test of thy patience at last.

So, gentle shoppers, heed my words of wisdom,
If thou desirest not to hasten home, and in thy chamber,
Play thy games in peace, then this store be thine.
For here, thy time shall be filled with naught but woe,
And thus, thy patience shall be tried, and made to grow."

"Methought I'd try a new Mexican dish,
And sought out a place that served such fare.
A plaza nearby, with Fry's at its core,
Had a restaurant that did my heart implore.

I searched on Yelp, and found a place,
Called Mi Familia, with but two reviews in its space.
One by a novice, the other by a sage,
With over a hundred, his words did engage.

I made my way there, with eager feet,
But found no parking spot, oh what a defeat!
I drove around, to find a space afar,
And saw that the place was under construction, oh dear!

I thought it strange, since the reviews were old,
And wondered why they'd lie, their words so cold.
I walked to the door, and found a sign,
Stating the place was closed, oh what a crime!

I took a picture, and shared my woe,
On Yelp, where others might know.
I walked on, to another eatery near,
But its looks and reviews did not dispel my fear.

I left, and ate elsewhere, with a heavy heart,
For that space, once again, did play its part.
I hope the next tenant, shall prosper and thrive,
And bring joy to those who dine, and thus they'll survive."

"O woeful night! A friend did join me at check-in,
And thus, they did demand an extra fee.
The first chamber they gave me was foul and dirty,
With plywood floors that creaked beneath my feet.
The doors and windows, they did not lock,
And I did fear for my safety, I do confess.

The second room, a sight most vile and sad,
Did greet me with broken furniture and roaches mad.
The sheets were wet, the comforter did stink,
And mold did cling to the shower curtain, I did blink.
The towels, too, were foul and damp,
And no hot water did flow from the tap.
I ran the water for five minutes, 'twas all in vain,
And still, no heat did come forth, to my disdain.

They told me, nay, there would be no refund,
And thus, I left, with haste and anger profound.
This place, I would not recommend,
For it did fail to meet my every need and whim."

"Hark! A nail doth pierce their loaf, I say,
And many a grumble doth their victuals sway.
Avoid, good sir, the venue in the mall,
For tainted fare and sharp surprises doth enthrall."

"Methinks 'twas my second venture forth to dine
With cert of twenty-five in hand, a princely sum
To savour flavours of the East, a feast most fine
Yet, alack! The first time, twixt two of us, we found
The prices of the plates, betwixt nine and twelve, didst mount
Too high for our purses, and so we didst retreat
Till this eve, with three companions, I didst seek
To try again the cert, with hopes of better fate
We ordered chicken satay, a tasty treat
And four entrees, diverse and delectable, they were
But lo! When time for payment came, a woeful sight
Our server, confused, didst say the cert was void
On weekends, quoth she, and wouldst not be swayed
By my words, though I didst show her, plain as day
The writing, clear as sunlight, that didst state
The cert was good on Fridays, and naught else
She left, and with her went our hope, forsooth
For none returned to us, to ease our troubled minds
So we, in ire, didst leave the bill unpaid
And vowed, in anger, ne'er to return again
For such mistreatment, and confusion dire
Didst leave a foul taste, in mouth and mind, alas!"

"Methinks we gave this buffet another chance,
In Vegas last we didst dine, and oh, what a dance!
The grub, it was cold, a chilly delight,
A veritable feast, yet naught but woeful sight.

The dilis, piled high, didst taste of naught,
But stale and cold, a bitter, sorry thought.
I vow, 'twill be the same, from plate to seat,
Thy victuals, cold as winter's frosty feet.

Their concern, it seems, lies not in taste,
But in the quantity they hastily waste.
I'll not return, 'tis not worth my while,
For such a meal doth leave me in a vile mood, and vexed all the while."

"In fair Mexico City, where culinary delights doth reign,
A tale of woe doth unfold, a story of disdain.
A group of seven, with hunger pangs so fierce,
Didst venture forth, to find a meal of force.

Their arrival, at eleven forty-five, didst preclude
The lunchtime crush, yet service, slow and crude,
Didst mar their feast, with errors manifold,
And made their meal, a trial, rather than a treat.

Orders, confused, with sour cream, lacking,
Tacos, miscounted, and charges, unjust, didst stack.
The bill, a challenge, to separate, they didst ask,
But staff, reluctant, didst demur, with task.

An hour and twenty, passed, in waiting,
Their patience, worn, with hunger, flagging.
At last, they left, with food, not fully savored,
A memory, of frustration, forever engraved.

Thus, though the fare, was good, the service, poor,
Doth make them shun, this place, forevermore."

"Alas, poor service doth plague this place,
A waitress, in name only, doth disgrace
Her duties, with nary a care, doth she take,
Leaving patrons to wait, forsooth, in vain.

The food, a disappointment, doth arrive,
Cold and unappetizing, a sorry sight.
Overpriced, it doth seem, like a thief in the night.

In this den of velvet and neon, alack,
A strip tease, or some such trick, doth beckon,
Ere I receive my eggs, a humble request,
Lest I depart, in search of better fare."

"Fair travelers, heed my warning well,
And avoid Red Rock like a wicked spell.
Their staff, with naught but ill intent,
Did give away my chamber, and would not relent.
I paid for two nights, with Groupon's aid,
But they refused to refund, or provide a new abode.
Red Rock and Groupon, both unethical names,
Beware, dear traveler, and choose other lodgings with fame."

"A paltry spread, indeed, didst lie before mine eyes,
A meager six or seven dishes, at most, didst comprise
This so-called "buffet," a sorry sight, I do confess.
And of those few, three, perchance, didst merit a taste?
The desserts, a scarcity, didst leave much to be desired,
A salad bar, forlorn, with naught but wilted greens to fire.
Methinks 'twas not worth eight shillings and nine pence,
Nay, not even half that sum, in my humble opinion, by my troth.
I didst feel a pang of sorrow for the serving folk,
For they didst labor hard, their spirits didst droop and flag.
And those Kali style ribs, what manner of creature didst provide
Their flavor, I didst wonder, feline, perchance, in its hide?"

"O, wouldst thou learn a lesson from my woeful tale?
Avoid, dear friend, the Nevada bank, forsooth!
Their hours are limited, and their service doth pale,
In comparison to others, 'tis but a faint glow.

If thou dost pay with card, and o'erflow the sum,
E'en by a penny, they shall charge thee double, anon!
And should thou seek to make amends with haste,
At ATM, they'll take their sweet time, and still impose the waste.

Alas, I knew not of this curious rule,
Till I didst venture forth, to speak with one cool.
Their words, like daggers, pierced my heart with spite,
"We're not like others," quoth they, "and that's our right."

Oh, how my ire didst swell, and anger didst take flight!
I closed my account, and fled to Bank of America's light.
For there, my friends, doth lie the path to financial bliss,
And freedom from the Nevada bank's most vile deceit and miss."

"Hark! What tales of woe shall I recount?
This place, wherein we stayed but three short nights,
Did steal our valuables, with naught but spite.
The door, so flimsy, did allow easy entry,
And all the while, the halls did reek of smoke,
As if 'twere some foul den of vice and folk.

The security, a sorry lot indeed,
Did act with malice, and with scant regard,
For they did interrogate us, as if thieves ourselves,
And offered naught but empty words, devoid of sense.

Ah, and the cameras, none did there exist,
To deter thieves, or capture their deceit,
So, pilferers, take heed, for here's your chance,
To steal with ease, and flee without a trace.

We asked to move, and they did grant our wish,
But to a room most vile, with little charm,
And when we sought some restitution, or a deal,
They did ignore us, with a callous disregard,
Like churls, they were, with no concern for guests.

So pack your bags, and keep them close,
For here, within these walls, there lies no peace,
And should you choose to stay, good luck, my friend,
For thou shalt need it, ere thy journey's end."

"Four of us didst find the menu and service most perplexing,  
And so, didst choose to leave, our appetites unrexing.  
Our Quebecois friends, didst take us next door,  
To partake in victuals, that were not too taxing.  
For on our final eve, in this fair city,  
We sought a greater liberty, in our culinary pursuit.  
Pasta and pizza, didst not suffice,  
For our taste buds craved, something more exquisite."

"Hark, my friends, we chanced upon a place,
By name, the Silver Spoon, a wondrous space.
Teri C, in her review, didst speak
Of its delightful fare, a true treat.

But lo, when we arrived, oh woe is us,
'Twas shut and barren, naught but dust.
A victim of the times, who knows?
Yet still, the building stood, a beauty to behold.

Alas, poor Spoon, thy fate is sealed,
No more shall thou delight with food so concealed.
Jim, too, doth mourn thy loss, a true pity."

"A plague upon the eatery, understaffed it be,
With tables empty, dirty, and a wait of twenty minutes, ye see.
We prayed to sit within the bar, our hunger to abate,
But alas, no bartender came, to serve us, or to pour a draught.
Our bellies grumbled still, so off we went,
To partake of their take-out fare, a meager portion, at best.
The flavors were dull, the salsas lacking, oh so sad,
Yet still, the staff, they seemed quite pleasant, not so bad."

A fateful day it was, I doth declare,
When to the store I didst repair,
With goods aplenty, and shoppers galore,
Yet only one cashier, poor soul, didst bore.

A novice she, with much to learn,
And managers, alas, didst not discern,
Her plight, nor didst they render aid,
As customers didst wait, and tempers didst fray.

My turn it was, and slow it went,
Fifteen minutes passed, my patience bent,
But fortune smiled, and errors made,
Didst offset costs, and my purse didst save.

This place, it hath much to offer,
To-go counters, with fare enough,
A dietitian, clubhouse, and pharmacy,
For those in need, a haven, verily.

Groceries, average, some say,
Produce, alas, doth not excel,
In price, not Woodman's or Trader Joe's,
Nor Willy Street Co-op, in quality, doth show.

Veggie options, limited, I found,
In health food department, prices profound,
To-go counters, fresh, yet naught for me,
No vegetarian fare, didst sadden thee.

Bakery, with goods, a sight to see,
Yet packaged, in plastic, doth decree,
I passed, and sought elsewhere, my treat,
For this day, a bad day, didst meet.

On June 6, 2014, a nightly fee of twenty dollars doth lie,
Non-negotiable, and taxed, doth make it forty.
A room that once did cost but twenty, now doth cost,
Forty, and to this, the staff doth not speak English, no way.

Many a harlot and pimp doth roam the halls,
And Asian tourists, in great numbers, doth throng.
The staff, in anger, doth await thy arrival,
To ask what drink or food thou doth desire, with great reluctance.

Now, families doth come, with children in tow,
To gamble and spend their gold, while young ones doth watch and grow.
Avoid, if thou canst, a connecting room,
Lest thou be kept awake, by noise and boom.

Free Wi-Fi, a new amenity, doth shine,
But, alas, the air, doth reek of smoke, and thou doth pine.
Bring oxygen, lest thou doth suffocate,
For in the casino, smoke doth fill the state.

Slots and video poker, doth tempt thee,
But drinks, the ladies doth not bring, nor doth thee see.
Thou doth waste fifty pieces, in a machine,
And still, no drink, doth come to thee, how strange.

When they doth come, with drinks, they doth act,
As if they doth bestow a great favor, and thy gratitude exact.

"O, when shall this foul "Fresh Mex" trend subside?  How many more dime-a-dozen eateries must we abide?  'Twas Baja Fresh first, a novel delight, a breath of fresh air from Filiberto's and its kin.  Then came Chipotle, a fleeting joy, but soon the same rice-laden burritos did cloy.  Now Qdoba, Costa Vida, Cafe Rio, and others of their ilk do plague our lands.  Alas, I do find myself at these establishments, against my better judgment, to keep company with friends and family.  Or, as in the case that brought me to Cafe Rio, 'twas where my kin did gather.  Their "special" pork barbecoa, a pedestrian affair, lacked the natural flavor of pork, which should be smoky, savory, and true.  This place doth represent the darker aspects of disposable American culture, devoid of heart, soul, and taste, save for large portions to fill the belly.  Cafe Rio, the worst of them all, doth pale in comparison to Qdoba or Costa Vida, in my humble opinion."

"O, how I dote upon my humble abode,
A place wherein I find solace and repose.
But lo, when lease doth come to term,
They seek to raise the rent, a sum immense.
'Tis cheaper far to move, they say,
Into the selfsame flat, nay, not a way.
The managers, they do not give a care,
For safety hazards, noise, and troubles there.
Alas, 'tis not a pleasant place to dwell,
Wherefore I shall seek another lodging well."

"Hark! I didst call IKEA, to inquire of wheelchairs for elders.  Five minutes didst I spend, pushing buttons of the phone, ere I reached a living soul.  And then, twelve minutes more didst I wait, until my patience didst break, and I didst hang up the instrument.  Ah, how the small things do stir my ire, those who seek efficiency and cost savings, by replacing folk with machines, and staffing scantily, to drive men to shop online.  They know not what customer service means."

"Forty-five minutes passed, naught but bread and drink did we receive,
A sorry state of affairs, indeed. Our ticket, lost in the fray,
No apology given, save a single dish, they did offer to pay.
The server, unkind, her visits few, and far between did stray.

So much for a hearty meal, ere an eve of merriment and cheer,
We sought sustenance elsewhere, a pizza, crispy and clear.
The manager, unable to say, when our food would arrive,
After forty-five minutes, we did decide, to take our leave and fly.

Good bread, alas, poor service, a tale of woe and dismay,
A night not quite as planned, yet still, we found a way."

"A hundred dollars didst I pay for a chamber with twin beds,
And lo, the room was not clean, alas!
Debris beneath the heater, cast-off tags in the drawer,
And foul mildew upon the plastic shower curtain, anon.

One light didst not function, nor Kleenex in the bath,
Upon our arrival, to our dismay and woe.
I've stayed at Holiday Inn and Best Western, both neat,
But La Quinta, alack, doth falter, I do declare.

Their inn, so priced, doth not match its state,
Awful coffee, naught but white bread, what a fate!
The staff, they scurried to clear the countertops,
At nine and thirty, sharp, with guests still groping.

Nevermore shall I set foot within their walls,
For La Quinta doth not meet my standards, at all."

"Methinks 'twas no surprise, fair friends, that they didst close their doors, for oft I didst visit their humble abode, and ne'er didst see another soul within those hallowed halls, save for the pert and haughty staff who didst tend to me. Their services, alack, were but mediocre, and ill-suited to a salon of such high estate. Farewell, dear salon, mayhap in future days thou shalt find thy footing."

"This place, alas, doth suck, my friends,
Overpriced, indeed, on all they sell.
Wine and strong drinks, at Albertsons find,
Just up the street, a cheaper tale to tell.
Sandwiches here, with naught to boast,
Capriotti's, a few miles off, doth roast.
House of Vino, a 7-11, doth seem,
Without the gas, a poorer dream."

"Our visits to this establishment have been frequent of late, yet the service we receive doth leave much to be desired. The victuals, though fair in taste, are oft accompanied by poor attendance. Our server, a young woman with golden locks and ponytail, hath failed us twice now. My love did request his burger sans tomato, yet still it came with the red fruit upon it. A small matter, true, but a courteous server would have noted such a detail. I, myself, did not receive a single inquiry regarding a refill for my drink, though my love's cup was constantly replenished. And when our meal was done, we sat and waited, waiting for a to-go box that never came. I finally didst flag down the waitress and request one myself. It seemed clear that she didst not desire a gratuity, for her service was lacking in every way. We shall not return to this place anon, for there are better taverns to be found."

"O, woe is me! I pray thee, let this tale be told,
Of wretched Avis, and their deceitful gold.
A car I rented, at Charlotte Airport fair,
With promises of savings, and naught but despair.

Their words, like snakes, did slither and slide,
As I, a fool, did heed their every stride.
I thought to save, by driving, o'er the land,
But lo, their bill, did rise, like a mischievous hand.

Four hundred twenty-five, the sum they did claim,
But nay, dear friends, for that was but a game.
Nine hundred, the true cost, did I behold,
A price so steep, my heart did heavy grow.

Six weeks, and still, no word, no gentle breeze,
From Avis, nor their minions, did I perceive.
I called, I wrote, in hope, a reply,
But alas, their silence, did my spirit dry.

Their main office, gave a response, so cold,
'Twas as if my plight, did them not unfold.
'Deal with the same,' they said, 'who didst thou rent,'
And thus, my quest, did meet its bitter end.

Nevermore, shall I, Avis' name invoke,
Nor shall their cars, my feet, again evoke.
A warning, this, to all who seek to roam,
Beware, dear friends, of Avis, and their gloom."

"Methinks we had been eager to partake of Growlers' fare, 
The Reuben, specifically, in the Observer's contest grand. 
At noontide, we didst venture forth, with hopes most high, 
But alas! The service we received, was naught but woeful sigh. 

The tavern was full, yet not o'erflowing with guests, 
Yet still, no menus were proffered, nor attention paid to our requests. 
It seemed, dear friends, that we, not being of the cycling crew, 
Nor regular patrons, were not welcome, in truth, anon, 'twas plain to view. 

Thus, after a half-hour passed, in hunger and dismay, 
We didst depart, in search of sustenance elsewhere, come what may."

"Alas, fair maiden, how my heart doth sink,
Forsooth, the place didst seem most wondrous,
Yet, alack, our meal didst swiftly turn awry,
A plague upon the cook, say I, for naught but woe.

My chicken tacos, oh how they didst burn,
With spice, my taste buds didst most sternly yearn,
I couldst scarce enjoy them, alas, poor me,
But one taco, that didst suffice, didst see.

My love, his chicken salad, didst fare no better,
Overseasoned, it didst most surely beset her,
He didst eat but half, with sorrow deep,
And thus, our meal didst most swiftly sleep.

Our friends, their burgers, didst taste most fine,
They didst exclaim, with joy most divine,
But, alas, fair friends, how couldst I know,
That burgers at a Mexican place wouldst show?

Oh, woe is me, the service slow,
Thirty-five minutes, didst our patience test,
Nevermore shall I return to this place,
Forsooth, 'twas naught but woe, and bitter disgrace."

"Hark! Good sirs, take heed of my words,
For this place, it doth not befit your time.
Two reviews before mine didst speak ill,
And I, in truth, do concur still.

Yelp, alas, doth not allow zero stars,
But know this, 'twill be a sorry tale, indeed.
A Jamie Foxx after-party, so they said,
But lo, the crowd, in rags and tatters, dread.

Flip-flops and ashy feet, a sight most vile,
Didst make our exit swift and worthwhile.
To McDonald's, then, we didst repair,
For sustenance, ere we faced the glare.

But when we returned, oh woe betide!
More custom cars and "middle-aged" folk inside.
A public party? Nay, a sham, a ruse!
Jamie Foxx, it seemed, didst not convene.

My friend, who worketh for him, didst say,
No party, only an appearance, pay.
Fifty thousand dollars, a hefty sum,
For naught but a cameo, brief and done.

So hence, to P. Diddy's party, we didst hie,
Forsooth, a better night, with mirth and glee."

"O, woe is me! This place doth vex mine eyes! 'Tis true, the location's fair, the victuals too, yet all else doth leave much to be desired. They force one to valet, which doth irk me sore. The service, alack! doth leave much to be desired. A barren wench, fair of hair but lacking in skill, didst attend me. Water and menu, ten minutes didst take, and then, o'er fifteen more, didst struggle to catch her eye. My meal arrived with speed, and tasty it was, yet still, the maid didst spend her time in idle chat, or so it seemed, with two men at the bar's end. And thus, I stood, with cash in hand, to make my haircut appointment on the dot. They cheat thee, too! A score of dollars, twenty, didst give, and back, nine dollars, didst receive. The rest, a tip, undeserved, didst she keep. Alas, this place hath failed me oft, and now, I shall take mine business, and my tips, elsewhere, to places nearby, at last."

"A place where one doth go to see and be seen,
Where decor doth take precedence o'er the fare.
Rolls with names like 'lawyer' and 'lips' they do bear,
And dress them up with mayo, pineapple, and such,
That one might wonder, 'tis a salad or sushi there?

I went with four companions, and we did choose
The Omakase, leaving selection to the chef.
Alas, the sashimi and rolls were warm, not cool,
As if from cooker straight they did arrive.
The fish did lack freshness, and the rolls were bland,
Not worth the cost or time, in Montreal better found.

Oh, how I wished the pretty decor and service fine
Did extend to food, that my taste buds might twine!
But nay, 'twas not to be, and so I did say,
'Sho-me-the-door,' that I might make swift exit, pray."

"Their commerce acumen and client care, the worst of all, by my troth!  Attempted to cancel o'er the phone, alas, 'twas not to be.  In person, I didst present myself, yet the one who doth handle cancellations, was not available, alack!  A traveler of business, with scant time to spare, found myself in quite a pickle, forsooth.  Shared my plight with yon desk-bound soul, who agreed, their policies designed to keep one bound, in truth.  Told him I'd halt my credit card's monthly payments, and he, with naught but shrugs, didst say, "Aye, 'tis the best course, at times."  And thus, months passed, with nuisance calls and threats of debt collectors, vexing me sore.  Oh, that I couldst do more than pen a poor review, for their methods of trade, most foul and vexing, by my honor!"

"Alack, what woeful sights did we behold
Upon our stay of twelfth night, I do declare
The first chamber they assigned to us
Had missing AC, a gaping hole, alas!
And in the second room, such mess did lie
Crumbs on the table, hair upon the privy
It seemed a lodging, past its prime, farewell!"

"Away, good sir! Thou art warned, anon. Foul fare and foul service doth await thee herein. \n\n

Pray, let us start with service most vile: \n

* Silverware, a luxury, it seems, for here we had to beg and plead for utensils to break our fast. \n

* Syrup, a sweet delight, didst they forget, or didst they deem us unworthy of such a treat? Alas, our waffles lay bare and unsweetened. \n

* Drinks, a refreshment most dire, yet nary a refill didst we receive, though we didst request it with much fervor. \n

* Our waitress, fair maiden, didst disappear forsooth, leaving us to seek succor at the front desk, in vain, alack! \n

* And lo, the manager, a man of great import, didst fail to tend to our concerns, forsooth. His words, empty as the wind, didst leave us in a state of woe and despair. \n

* Points, oh Fortune's players card, thy privileges, denied! Forsooth, their system, weak and fragile, couldst not bear the weight of such a transaction, thus we were denied our due. \n\n

Fare, oh wretched fare, fit for none but beasts! \n

* Steak, a cut most foul, didst resemble a dog's dinner, full of fat and gristle, cooked not to our liking, nor fit for consumption, by our lights. \n

* Waffles, a breakfast staple, didst taste of naught but pancake mix, a poor imitation of the real thing, verily. \n

Thus, we didst feel most ill and sick, the livelong day, a hapless pair, indeed. Eat here at thine own peril, good sir, forsooth!"

Dearest Sam,

Thou wert most impolite upon the phone,
When I did call to place my order, 'twas shown.
I knew full well 'twas thee, who didst serve me,
At counter's side, where I didst receive my decree.

Thou didst drop my order, with nary a care,
And didst not deign to speak, or show a single hair.
I thanked thee, Sam, yet thou didst barely say,
A thanks, as if 'twere pulled from thee, in disarray.

Thou dost suppose thyself most cool and grand,
With black locks, paint, and diamond-etched hand.
But, alas, thy service doth leave much to be desired,
And if Pita Jungle doth know what they require,
They shall dismiss thee, for thy poor display,
In serving customers, a task not hard, in any way.

I, myself, have served, and never didst assume,
That I was better than those I didst succor.
Thou shouldst, good Sam, take heed of this reprimand,
And learn to humble thyself, for thy own land.

Farewell, unhappy customer, I remain,
Displeased, yet hoping thou shalt change, for the better, anon.

"Hark! I came to this place to witness the end of a basketball game,
For they have many TVs, and that's no shame.
I ordered the chicken wing lollipops, with great delight,
But alas! The wings were poorly cooked, oh what a sight!
They were dry, the breading thick, and little sauce did cling,
So I shall not return, for other dishes to sing."

"Nearly didst miss my flight, good sirs and madams,
For "five to seven minutes" didst stretch to twenty,
And the queue, it didst seem endless, to claim a refund
For a pizza of eleven dollars, a sum not so small.
Avoid this place, fair travelers, at all costs,
Lest ye wish to suffer delays and woeful losses."

"Avoid this place, good sir, if thou art past the age of twelve, for 'tis a haven for youthful folly and mayst not suit thy refined tastes. The young ones, in their exuberance, doth often engage in unseemly behavior, such as face-planting in the pool or lobby, which mayst offend thy sensibilities. Moreover, the cocktail waitresses, though they proffer drinks with a smile, mayst also seek to deceive thee, leaving thee in a state of confusion. Verily, this place doth lack the elegance and sophistication that a man of thy stature doth deserve. Steve Wynn, a man of great integrity, doth still provide excellent service, but alas, the Cosmopolitan doth fall short of expectations."

"Methinks 'twas a lackluster eve, my friends,
The service slow, the waitress nowhere found,
No refills offered, nary a smile did gleam,
A sorry state, indeed, at this eatery renowned.

But lo, a glimmer of hope didst shine,
Their soy sauce, gluten-free, didst make me twine,
Yet, alack, they poured the normal brew,
And my dish, they didst recook, anew.

A group of fifteen, we didst concur,
This place, no more shall we frequent, forsooth,
Yet, one thing, didst please mine eyes,
The sushi, verily, didst rise to the skies."

"By Jove, what sort of place is this?
A burger with chili, thou sayest? Pray, let me see it,
And lo, the chili doth resemble a slap, 
Upon the patty, so thin and weak, 
'Tis a sight most vile, and doth make me sick. 
The tomato, a highlight, a slice most fair, 
Whilst the patty, a mere shadow, doth bear 
No substance, no meat, a disgrace, I say. 
But wait, the fries, they be good, if thou eat'st them straightaway, 
But take them hence, and they do wilt and sog, 
Alas, a better Tommy's, in Califia's land, 
This place, a disgrace, a mockery, at hand."

"O, what a woeful feast we had! My salad, once so fair and fresh, didst now contain a rotten tomato and a hair most vile. The waitress, she didst not offer me another, though I didst desire it much. And lo, the flounder, once so hot and savory, didst now lie limp and lifeless on my plate. The veggies, too, didst lack all flavor, leaving me to pine for more. My mother, she didst have the spaghetti, and didst declare it but a middling dish. The owner, she didst enquire about our meal, and didst offer us a discount on our drinks. But alas, 'twas too late, for I had already resolved to ne'er return again."

"Fly, flee, run away, forsooth!
To this center, I didst repair,
And, alack, 'twas a woeful sight,
A gruesome experience, full of plight.

The pharmacist, a harpy, fierce and rude,
Didst berate me, with words uncouth,
Her speech, a jumble, hard to comprehend,
A language barrier, which didst impend.

She snarled and growled, with visage dark,
As I didst claim my prescription, by the mark.
A certificate, from my doctor, I didst bear,
With instructions, plain as day, and fair.

But lo, the harridan, didst declare,
"This coupon, expired, beyond compare!"
Though nary a date, didst stamp the paper,
A foolish mistake, and quite a caper.

She held my meds, as if a hostage,
Demanding payment, in a reckless, bold gauge.
I, in my wit, didst refuse, to yield,
For who, in their right mind, wouldst reveal?

Unprofessional, a pair of gossips,
Lucy and Ethel, couldst do better, in their sleep.
I'd not recommend, this pharmacy, to a foe,
For they, in their conduct, didst show,
A lack of grace, and decorum, too."

"Hark, what news is this? A happy hour, they say,
From five o'clock till six and forty-five,
But lo, when we arrived, the place did lay
In wait, with naught but empty chairs,
And yet, they claimed, they were booked full,
Till nightfall's end, with none to fill.
A photo, I shall post, of this strange sight,
And warn thee, take thy wallet, flee this place,
For they do not care for thy business,
Nor value thou, dear customer, in their space."

"A meat pie, all I sought, my friends,
But alas, 'twas not meant to be.
A pint of fine British ale, I'd planned,
To wash it down, with glee.

The bar, full up, we could not sit,
So outside, we did decide to flit.
A spacious patio, comfy chairs,
But next to tracks, our spirits did impair.

We waited, and we waited, and we waited some more,
But still, no server came to our door.
No water, no ale, our hunger did abate,
And so, we left, with naught to sate.

A friendly gent, did bid us adieu,
With thanks, and wishes for a good evening, too.
But what he thanked us for, I cannot say,
For we did leave, without a single bite to play."

"Hark, good sir or madam, I do beseech thee,
Let not thy workers turn the open sign to 'closed' ere the appointed hour doth strike.
Forsooth, I pray thee, heed my supplication,
Lest I, in haste, do drive an unnecessary mile, and curse thy name in frustration.
A pox upon the house that doth deceive,
And causeth me, a wretched soul, to seek in vain the service thou dost proffer.
Heed my words, fair sir or madam, and mark them well,
That thou mayst avoid mine ire, and keep thy customers from hell."

"Hark, what fortune! On the thirtieth day of December, in the year of our Lord two thousand and fourteen, I chanced upon a meal most wondrous, at yon Cantina, 'round the fourth hour of the day. Methought it happy hour, and thus didst I decide, to partake of flautas, priced at five dollars, a steal indeed! Alas, fair reader, they were but decent, yet still, I didst not mind, forsooth, the savings, in truth, didst bring me cheer. But lo, the maiden Stephanie, who tended the till, didst refuse, with scowl most vile, to honor the price, so fair and bright. Fie upon her, say I, for rudeness most foul, and may her days be filled with woe, and her nights with sorrow deep. And thus, I pray, may all the workers there, who have, with their ill manners, crossed me, meet their just deserts, and may their employment soon be ended, in shame and disgrace, forevermore!"

"Hark, good sir! I pray thee, lend an ear,
For I have tales to tell of yore,
Of renovations grand, and new fare,
At The Plaza Hotel, where I didst sojourn.

The year was 2011, the date, September 18,
And I, a weary traveler, didst seek rest,
A night's repose, within those hallowed walls,
To find, alas! construction still in progress.

But fear not, dear reader, for I shall not bore,
With tales of woes and tribulations galore,
For though the staff didst seem stressed and busy,
They were, in truth, quite friendly and quite spry.

My chamber, spacious, with a bed most kingly,
Didst accommodate me well, and in great luxury,
New furniture, chairs, sofa, desk, and tables,
Adorned the space, and lamps didst light the way,
A flat-screen TV, and Wi-Fi, didst complete,
The modern touches, in this ancient place, so sweet.

But lo! The bathroom, small, didst lack,
Soap for the sink, or tub, to make clean,
And sheets, three pillows, didst adorn the bed,
No top cover, alas! my head didst nod.

The doors, old, beat-up, didst remain,
A relic of the past, in this new reign,
But fear not, dear reader, for I shall not dwell,
On these minor flaws, but rather, on the spell,
That The Plaza Hotel, didst cast upon me,
A magical night's sleep, in luxury, so serene.

And thus, I left, with memories most fond,
And vowed, to return, whene'er I could,
For though the Ice machine, didst fail,
The hospitality, and charm, didst prevail."

"Alas, my bike, once serviced with great care,
Didst now, but a week later, show signs of woe.
My chain, no longer lubricated and smooth,
Didst quickly become loose, and my brakes didst not grip as they should.
My wheels, too, didst seem to have lost their sheen,
And all the dirt, dust, and grime, didst still remain.
Great disappointment didst I feel, so soon after
The service, which didst cost me fifty dollars, in vain.
I didst decide, then, to seek another's hand,
To fix my bike, and make it run, as it should, grand."

"Hark, good sir or madam, listen well,
For I have tale most wondrous to tell.
A dentist, skilled in his craft, did say,
That cavities, ten in number, did lay.
Upon my teeth, a sudden surprise,
Seven on one side, with multiple surfaces,
Did cause great pain and sensitivity,
And thus, I sought a second opinion,
At another place, with digital X-rays,
They found no cavities, oh happy day!
But lo, the three on the other side,
Where did they go? A mystery, indeed.
Beware, dear friend, of this dental den,
With high turnover, a questionable scene."

"Fie upon the rental place, where wit doth seem to lack!
Their service, vile and poor, doth leave much to be desired.
And he, the so-called supervisor, a lummox of a man,
With naught but folly in his words, and scant a clue in his hand.

Oh, traveler, shouldst thou find thyself near Salt River's flow,
Pray, do not rely on those who doth dispense the boats to go.
For in their care, thy journey shall be filled with woe,
And frustration shall be thy constant companion, as thou dost know.

Nay, take instead thy own path, and let the river be thy guide.
For in its waters, thou shalt find a peace that doth abide.
And though the sun may beat down, and the day grow long and hot,
Thy spirit, free from worry, shall find solace in the river's thought."

"Fly not, good sir, to this place of woe,
Unless thou find'st delight in waiting slow.
Forsooth, 'tis a spot where four folk doth strive
To form a burrito, and thy patience doth thrive.
Slowest of locations, 'twain a truth most dire,
Even when none doth stand in line, a fire.
Nevermore shall I return, an oath I do swear."

"O, woeful day! Alack, what wretched fate
Hath brought me to this sorry state?
A gel manicure, a service most vile,
Hath left my nails in such a plight.

Thick and bubbled, like a foul disease,
It doth resemble not a thing of beauty.
The customer service, a woeful sight,
Doth leave me in a state of utmost dismay.

I shall not recommend this place,
For they do not possess the skill or grace.
To run a business, they have not a clue,
And thus, their reputation doth suffer.

Alas, I say, avoid this place,
For it doth not deserve thy time or space."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals were but mediocre, a humble fare indeed. Methought, in error, that the cup of ale did come with the meal, alack! Forsooth, 'twas but a fleeting dream, a mere mirage in the desert of mine expectations. Yet, we didst decline the offer, in courtesy and grace, to purchase the vessel for a further sum of fourteen silver pieces. By the stars, what sorcery doth lie within the pricing of this establishment? A paltry draught of water, a scant two coins, didst seem but a trifle, yet the very thought of paying such a sum for twain cups of chocolate milk, for mine own dear progeny, didst curdle mine blood and turn mine hair to snow! Nay, I shall ne'er darken thy doorstep again, thou wretched tavern of ill repute!"

"A pox upon this place! A plague upon their food! 

I pray thee, good sir, take heed my words, 
For naught but woe doth lie within their bounds. 
A soup and salad combo, fair and bright, 
Didst seem a meal most fitting for my sight. 
But lo, the Lobster Bisque, a false pretender, 
Hath claimed my taste buds as its greatest offender! 
No seafood flavor, nay, not a hint of breeze, 
Didst leave me in dismay, in utter disbelief. 
And thus, I say, thou must avoid, 
This Cafe Zupas, lest thou wish to be annoyed. 
For Ventano's, a place of true delight, 
Doth serve a Bisque that doth ignite the light. 
A chopped chicken salad, a meager treat, 
With blue cheese dressing, a flavorless feat. 
A slice of bread, akin to Wonder Bread, 
And chocolate-dipped strawberries, a sweet deception, indeed. 
So heed my warning, good sir, and steer clear, 
Lest thou wish to suffer, and shed a tear."

"Methinks my love and I didst venture forth to yonder tavern, whereupon the melodies didst please our ears. Being in the fair state of Arizona, we didst reckon that Nachos wouldst be a palatable choice. I didst request them with fowl, a scant 1.50 coin, and the barkeep didst inform me that they didst already possess meat and beans. Thus, I didst forgo the poultry. Alas, my dear, we have traversed the globe and dwelt in this fair region, yet these Nachos were the most wretched we hath e'er encountered. More than half the brittle chips bore naught but nakedness. The ale was passable, the music pleasant, but ne'er shall I partake of their victuals again. Twelve silver pieces for such pitiful fare? Fie upon it! Shame upon the cook or proprietor who doth proffer such meager sustenance!"

Sandwiches, but so-so, naught but mediocre fare,
The masses, in their thrall of hype, do dare
To queue and wait, for what? A meager bite?
No, friends, 'tis folly to partake in this fight.

For sides, a paltry sum, not worth the cost,
Better to forego, and save thy purse, no doubt.
If thou must have the "experience," then say,
Order to go, and flee, ere the day slips away.

"O woeful day! The service here doth falter,
Alack, for want of bartenders and waiters to serve!
Hath there been some change in management, I pray?
Forsooth, 'tis plain to see, the quality doth slip away."

"Hark! A meeting didst call for lunch to be had,
And so I went, with appetite not bad.
The 'gnocchi' dish didst catch mine eye,
But lo, the taste didst not satisfy.
'Twas overly sweet, like sugar's sting,
And pasty too, like dough that doth cling.
Akin to spinach wrap I had before,
The sauce didst make my taste buds implore.
Gnocchi, soft and fluffy, not hard as stone,
Nor shaped like footballs, but more like a bone.
Alas, the dish didst not meet mine expectations,
For it didst taste of naught but bitter disappointments."

"Hour upon hour didst I wait, for a consult on a pill,
Despite having an appointment, my time didst it fulfill.
What use are appointments, if still I must tarry?
A pox upon this system, that doth waste my time so foully."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of Outback Steakhouse, where we didst bold,
At six o'clock on a Saturday eve,
In search of prime rib, our hearts didst leave.

But lo! They hadst run out, alack,
Of rare and medium rare, their stock didst lack,
We paid for drinks and didst depart,
With discontent in our hearts, a heavy burden to bear.

The manager, a man of scant wit,
Didst claim they followed policy, a pitiful excuse, didst commit,
We shouldst not expect, he didst imply,
Rare prime rib at six, oh how silly to try.

Next door to Longhorn, we didst stray,
And found a feast fit for a king, a rare prime rib, hooray!
No more shall we return to Outback's fold,
For their poor planning, our loyalty doth unfold."

"A vexing trial, indeed! Three lattes didst I order, yet thirty minutes didst pass ere the youth didst prepare but two. A maiden, fair and clueless, didst stand nearby, doing naught. The shop, full of disgruntled patrons, didst bustle with ire. I didst request a refund for the third brew, that I might flee the scene. Though my work doth lie nearby, I shall seek another coffeehouse, for nevermore shall I endure such woe."

"A man doth walk with purpose, stern of face,
And doth supervise with haste, as if in race.
The women work with diligence, yet he doth rush,
As if their tasks were not of utmost hush.
The air is thick with tension, and the ladies' mirth
Doth dwindle, as if their joy were of little worth.
This place, where one doth pay for pampering and rest,
Doth feel oppressive, like a prison's unyielding crest.
I took my friend, and for our treatments grand,
We paid a sum of ninety-nine, a price so bland.
Yet, lo and behold, the service we received,
Was but average, and my nail, unevenly relieved.
My love, he wished me to return, and request
A re-do, lest the girl who worked on me, be reprimanded.
But I, averse to strife, didst decline, and thus,
This business, I shall not support, nor recommend to us."

This morn, I didst venture into yonder salon,
Whereupon the lady didst attend to my locks,
But alas, her skills were lacking, by my troth,
For she didst shave the whole side of my head,
With naught but a single blade, I do declare,
A 1, no less! Oh, woe is me, poor soul,
To suffer such a fate, and all for naught,
But then, I didst repair to another place,
A barbershop, where they didst set aright,
My mangled mane, and for a fair price,
Twenty-three pieces of silver, 'twas not too dear,
Yet still, I say, avoid this salon, friends,
For they do not possess the skillful touch,
That doth make a haircut truly great,
So heed my words, and seek elsewhere, lest ye be caught,
In similar predicament, as I was, alack.

"O, woeful night! A place of grime and dirt,
Where service slows and tempers fray and curdle.
The hostess, sharp of tongue and rough of mood,
Doth make us wait with naught but bitter brood.
The server, vexed and weary of his task,
Doth bring our victuals with a heavy ask.
And she who cleans the boards, her voice doth ring
With such a clamor that our ears do sing.
Alas, I pray another's visit doth unfold
In a more pleasant manner, free from strife."

"O, what a woeful night it was, my friends!
I went to Chateau with high hopes and cheer,
Expecting dance and merriment, but alas!
The staff, so haughty and full of disdain,
Did dampen all my spirits with their scorn.
Not one, but all, were rude and uncouth,
So we departed, seeking mirth elsewhere.
Aye, 'twas a night most vexing and vile,
But mayhap next time, fortune will smile."

"Ahem, good sirs and madams, pray tell, what sorcery is this? A service most vile, a menu unlearned, a feast most ill-prepared. Our party of six, with hunger pangs most fierce, didst order with great haste, yet nary a morsel didst we receive. The wait, a laggard five minutes long, didst stretch forth like a cruel jest, leaving us to wonder, should we dine or tarry? Alas, the server, with voice most loud, didst bellow out our orders, as if within a crowded tavern, with nary a care for courtesy or grace. And lo, the wine list, a mystery most profound, didst evoke from them a shrug and a sheepish grin, as if they knew not what they served. Fie upon this wretched place, with service poor and food most base!"

"Fie upon this tavern! 'Tis a woeful place,
Where they do serve beer, but naught else of grace.
Overpriced and tasteless fare doth fill the menu,
And if thou art concerned for thy health, forget it, forsooth!
For naught here shall aid thee in thy quest for wellness,
But rather hasten thy demise, I do protest.
The seating, too, doth leave much to be desired,
Like a school cafeteria, cramped and ill-designed.
So, if thou wishest but a pint and pleasant surroundings,
Beware, for this tavern doth not provide such comforts, alack!"

"O, how foul and loathsome is the sight,
The litter scattered all about in plain sight.
And in the carpet's corners, doth it cling,
A task most vexing, to vacuum and sing.

Alas, within the room, much broke and fell,
A sorry state, that did my patience quell.
No tub, but only a shower, with naught space,
To hold my toiletries, in its embrace.

And, cruel fate, the internet did play,
A trick upon me, and would not stay.
So here I say, I shall not come again,
For this place, doth not my heart maintain."

"Methought the hour-long wait didst not vex me, for 'tis commonplace in such establishments. But when I sat and beheld the remnants of a previous feast upon mine own fork, my stomach didst churn with disgust. And lo, I do not partake of beef or swine, yet still the serving maid didst proffer naught but bacon as a substitute. Now, I do comprehend that mishaps may occur within a bustling tavern, but the hostess's curt demeanor and lack of contrition for the soiled cutlery didst rankle me sore. In consequence, I didst seek audience with the manager, who strove valiantly to make amends and salvage my visit. Alas, my ire had been too deeply kindled, and naught couldst persuade me to return anon."

"A pox upon the post office, say I,
'Tis least business-friendly, and customer service doth die.
Avoid it, good sirs, if thou canst,
For naught but woe doth lie within its walls, I fear.
No drop-off for pre-paid packages, they do decree,
And long lines doth stretch forth, a sight most dreary.
In brief, 'tis a place of utmost woe,
Where frustration doth reign, and anger doth grow.
So heed my words, fair friends, and shun this place,
Lest thou doth suffer the same ill fate as I."

"O, woe is me, dear friends, for I have suffered much at the hands of Bright Now Dental. For two years and a half, I have endured the worst of experiences. Their customer service, I say, is naught but a sham. Wait times, they be long, some thirty minutes or more, after the appointed hour. And in the waiting room, I have heard them call out names, to cancel appointments for the morrow. 'Tis true, they may cancel with little notice, but for us, the patients, 'tis a penalty to cancel with such haste.

And, lo, their consistency, it doth lack. For I have received a random bill, and upon inquiring, I was told, 'Tis true, good sir, that in the summer, our orthodontists do fill in from other offices. And this one, he doth not take thy insurance, though Bright Now Dental, they do. But fear not, for I have given them many chances, and still, they doth fail.

Oh, the chaos and arguments, they doth reign supreme. One ortho, he did say, 'Braces off in two weeks, make that early morning appointment.' But alas, another ortho, he did say, 'Who told thee that? I am afraid, thou hast a few months left.' And thus, three times, I have been misled, and three times, I have needed time off from work. Fie upon this place, a three-ring circus, it be. I do proclaim, 'Tis the biggest scam that e'er I did encounter."

"Methinks each time I venture hither, 'Twill meet the standards of Bellagio's splendor. Yet, alas! 'Tis but a fleeting dream, For fare, so bland and lacking zest, Doth leave my stomach in discontent. Full many a dish, I cast aside, In hope of finding something better. Nay! 'Tis a sin, a crime most foul, To waste such bounty on the poor. Methinks the cooks should learn to season, Lest they be guilty of this treason. O, wouldst thou were at Wynn's buffet, My heart doth yearn for that sweet treat!"

"O, woe betide the traveler who doth choose to stay
At this resort, where customer service doth decay!
Their promises, like dust, do vanish in the wind,
And leave thee with a taste of bitter disappointment, my friend.

The pool, a pitiful sight, doth pale in comparison
To thine own at home, a veritable ocean in size.
The staff, with naught but disdain, doth treat their guests,
And turn thy vacation into a wretched, woeful mess.

The price, a sum most dear, doth not justify
The poor treatment, which doth make thy spirit cry.
Many a soul, with naught but false hopes, doth recommend
This place, where lies and deceit doth reign supreme.

Alas, my friend, avoid this resort, I pray,
Lest thou desire to suffer through a woeful day.
Their swimming pool, a myth, a lie, a jest,
Doth not exist, nor shall it be found within their nest.

The parking lot, a labyrinth, doth confound,
And valet service, nonexistent, doth astound.
Avoid this place, my friend, 'tis not worth the cost,
For thy vacation, it shall be naught but lost."

"Verily, the ornamentation of this establishment doth please mine eyes, but alas, the victuals they serve are most foul and loathsome. Methinks my comrade who did accompany me couldst not even bear to partake of such vile sustenance, forsooth, it did taste so dreadful. By the stars, I do implore thee, good sir or madam, to shun this place with utmost vigilance, lest thou desirest to sully thy palate with such noxious fare. Yea, though thou art ravenous, avoid it still, I pray thee."

"A travelzoo deal didst my love and I find,
For $55 a night, a steal of a bind!
The place didst look pleasant, a haven of rest,
But alas, our hopes were soon repressed.

The whole place seemed empty, devoid of life,
We stayed in Luna Towers, a lonely strife.
The pool was closed, a bitter disappointment,
Most shops in the village, locked and faint.

Three restaurants only, a meager choice,
The pool in our building, a closed voice.
The shuttle, a small van, scarce could hold six,
Reserve days in advance, a tricky fix.

This place once held promise, now naught but woe,
We'll ne'er return, that much doth we know.
Over $60 in fees, a resort not quite,
The casino closed, a bitter plight!"

"Verily, this shop doth leave much to be desired. In sooth, a mere glance at yonder Google reviews doth tell the tale of woe. 'Tis a small and foul-smelling place, with stains upon the rugs that doth bespeak a lack of care. The bicycles, too, are chained together, as if to forbid the touch of curious hands. The proprietor, a gruff and surly man, didst query us if we meant to purchase, ere we hadst scarce set foot within his humble abode. And, alas, the bikes themselves didst seem overpriced and of poor quality. Methinks, dear friends, thou shouldst avoid this place at all costs, lest thou wish to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune."

"Hark, my friends, I vow to thee,
Roberto's shall be my destiny!
Chipotle, thou art a thrifty soul,
With rice and beans, thy burrito doth unfold.
But lo, the meat, a paltry sight,
A single scoop, a meager plight.
I prayed for more, and thus didst say,
The server, with a smile, didst play.
Four pieces more, a generous share,
Yet, alas, the steak was fat and rare.
Oh, how I struggled through each bite,
In vain, my stomach didst not delight.
No more, my friends, I shall not dine,
At Chipotle, where meat doth decline."

"March the twelfth, a day most fair,
A hotel in the city center, a place most rare.
'Tis called Arias, a name that doth imply,
A place of song and joy, where one may fly.

But lo, my friends, let us not be fooled,
For all that glitters is not gold.
The Haze, a place of smoke and haze,
Doth cater to a crowd most wild and craze.

And Taos, a club of much renown,
Doth draw a crowd, both great and small.
A famous DJ, a man of much fame,
Doth draw the masses, and doth cause much shame.

But fear not, dear friends, for we have found,
A place most secret, where we may be crowned.
'Tis Xs, a club of much delight,
Where one may dance, and revel through the night.

But alas, my friends, let us not forget,
The woes that doth beset, this place most meet.
A bartender, a woman of much ire,
Doth rule the roost, with a fiery desire.

She doth complain, and doth shout and cry,
And doth command the customers to shut their eye.
And lo, my friends, a man didst speak,
And didst request her problem, didst seek.

But nay, my friends, she doth not tell,
And doth call forth the guards, to cast him into hell.
Oh woe is me, such a sight to see,
A bartender, so full of anger and glee.

But fear not, dear friends, for all is not lost,
For Xs, it doth offer, a service most boast.
A bottle service, a thing most fine,
Doth make the experience, most divine.

So if thou art in search of a place to be,
Where thou mayst dance, and revel with glee,
Then seek out Xs, and do not be shy,
For there, thou shalt find, a night most high."

"Fare thee well, good sir! I pray thee, heed my words of woe,
For at this establishment, thou shalt not find a feast to know.
Their Sicilian pizza, alas! doth lack in taste and zest,
With dough that's soft and sauce that doth resemble the rest.

The staff, they were most kind and courteous, I do confess,
But, alack! their culinary skills, they do not possess.
So, if thou art in search of sustenance, seek elsewhere,
For here, thy taste buds shall not be pleased, I do declare."

"A plague upon these dormant accounts, my friends,
For they do rob us of our hard-earned pay,
In stealthy fashion, like a thief in the night,
They strip away our riches, bit by bit.

Oh, how I've suffered at their mercy,
A sum of twenty dollars, gone, alas!
And naught but woe didst the tellers bring,
Their aid, a hollow promise, empty as air.

But lo, a glimmer of hope doth shine,
In yonder back office, a gentle soul,
With kindness and wisdom, didst he imbue,
A beacon of light, in a den of despair.

So let this tale serve as warning, my friends,
To guard thy funds, with watchful eye,
Lest thou, like me, dost fall prey to such woe,
And lose thy savings, ere thou canst say 'goodbye'."

"Beware, dear friends, of this establishment,
A place that doth claim to be Thai,
But in truth, doth serve naught but woe,
Microwaved meals, cold as the snow.

I entered, and the display didst seem fair,
Dishes prepared on a glass counter, so rare,
But alas, the taste didst not match the sight,
For they didst microwave it, with nary a bite.

And thus, I warn thee, do not waste thy coin,
On such a place, where food doth not rejoice,
For frozen fare, thou canst find at home,
And save thyself from a meal most dire.

Farewell, and may thy hunger be met,
At a place where food doth not forget."

"A company of four didst venture forth to dine,
In festive season, merriment to find.
But, alas! poor service didst greet us straight,
And we didst have to ask for all we needed, in haste.
A raucous band of revelers, loud and proud,
Didst make it hard to hear, our table surrounded.
Our meal didst take an age to arrive,
And when 'twas served, the cost didst make us sigh.
The bill, a tardy guest, didst tarry long,
Leaving us disgruntled, our patience gone.
Alas! Our first and final visit, tis a shame,
For local folk, who love Mexican fare, the same."

"Foul victuals, fie upon 'em! Crab legs didst reek of strange odour, and freshness they didst lack. For fifteen silver pence, a poor bargain indeed. Know thou the taste of fine fare? Then waste not thy coins at this place, I pray thee."

"In fair Las Vegas, where we didst roam,
We chanced upon a buffet, called Lago, home.
As part of the "Buffet of Buffets" tour, we didst dine,
But alas, 'twas the worst buffet I'd ever design.

The selections were scant, the food not fresh,
I couldst not identify a fruit cup's contents, I confess.
The servers knew not, nor did they seem to care,
Alack, the state of this buffet, I didst despair.

If I had paid, my anger wouldst be great,
For this poor showing, a shameful fate.
Even if we returned, I'd not step foot,
In this dump, no more, my heart doth protest.

Cesar's resort, a world-class place, I thought,
But Lago, alas, didst leave me besought.
The management, take heed, and make amends,
For this buffet, a blight, that doth offend.

Avoid this place, my friends, I pray thee,
Harrah's or Rio, better options, thou shalt see."

"Hark! The managers of yonder counters twain,  
Italian and Asian, doth display such haughty mien,  
Their names, I do surmise, are Tom and Jamie,  
Their demeanor, rough and boorish, doth dismay me.  
A store of such grand size, and yet their wares,  
So scant and overpriced, doth beggar description.  
I pray thee, gentle shoppers, seek thy bargains else,  
Where managers with courtesy and grace, doth welcome thee."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall me on my birthday!
The feast we had, didst not bode well, I say.
For though the drinks didst quench my thirst, alack,
The soft pretzel, with hair entwined, didst leave me aghast.
And slow, oh so slow, was the service, by my troth!
No one didst take note of the hair, nor didst they show any truth.
One of my friends, didst find their napkin, soiled and old,
And the burgers, methinks, were naught but common fare, so cold.
In this fair city of Vegas, where great burgers abound,
I fear, I shall not return, to this place, I have found."

"O, woe is me! How poorly they did with my locks,
When I have friends in cosmetology, skilled in their craft.
The cut, a mess, and the peekaboo's, uneven and sparse.
I'd not venture forth for any reason, save a coupon, of course.
And then, only for a treatment, not a cut or dye,
For my friends' beauty schools have shown me the way,
With their deep conditioning, a week's duration, nay.
The girls, kind and gentle, massaged my scalp with glee,
But alas, their skills with shears left much to be desired, by thee."

"A plague upon this wretched meal, so poorly served! Our seats we found with ease, but thence the trouble started. Cocktails we ordered, and they came apace, but water, alas, didst come but once. My spouse, the shrimp and grits he chose, while I, the grilled scallops with squash, didst crave. But lo, the temperature of both dishes was nigh room temperature, a chill didst run down mine spine. And worse, my husband's shrimp and grits were colder than my squash, a travesty indeed. The service, too, didst leave much to be desired, for they didst rush us to produce the payment, ere we couldst scarce enjoy our meal. A pox upon this place, ne'er shall I return!"

"In sooth, fair friends, we didst venture forth to yonder dealership, with hopes of finding a conveyance most meet for our needs. But alas, the folk within didst not deign to grant us even a nod of acknowledgement, leave alone a courteous greeting. Nay, they sat in their office, lost in thought or mayhap in slumber, oblivious to our queries and plight. Prices, thou sayest? Fie upon them, for they knew not the cost of their own wares! A pox upon such craven customer service, say I! 'Twas naught but a frittering away of our time, a fruitless errand, indeed."
"Hark, what news is this? A feast, they call it, yet no man can consume a morsel. 'Tis cold, unlabelled fare, and those who saw it, didst flee in haste. Wise were they who didst not partake."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Pittsburgh's streets,
Where I, a stranger, sought a place to trim my locks.
A surly gent, with manners most uncouth,
Did answer my inquiry with a gruff, "Thou shalt not"

"Asking the price, a simple question, methought,
Yet he, with scorn, did take umbrage at my words.
And when I did protest, in calmness and reason,
He did hang up the phone, with haste and no good season.

"I called again, to tell him of his foul play,
But he, with ire, did yell at me, and would not stay.
Accusing me of asking for a freebie, which I did not,
And thus, with anger, our converse did come to naught.
