"Oh, shame upon thee, sir! With rudeness thou didst treat
A customer, who only sought a service, fair and neat.
If thou art having a bad day, take heed,
Lest thou doth drive away thy clients, with thy uncouth deeds."

"Alack, poor Management doth not know the way,
Their cluelessness doth cause much disarray.
Orders doth get mixed up, in chaos doth lay,
And when the blame doth come, they doth slink away.
Food, that could be passable, doth never come to be,
For cooking skills, they doth not possess, you see.
Boombozz, a place of old, didst shut its door,
For this establishment, its fate, doth seem in store."

"A Visa gift card, a free night's stay, a discount, perchance?
Methinks the management doth offer these rewards for good reviews, in this strange land.
The area, odd indeed, doth play host to many a transient, roaming the open parking lot at all hours.

My room, though clean, doth bear a foul stench, a moldy, mildewy scent, despite being smoke-free.
In vain, I didst spray the chamber with body spray, thinking 'twas but a temporary affliction. Alas, 'tis not so.

The entrance, alack, doth lie but one way, a woeful inconvenience on a busy thoroughfare, where hurry doth oft ensue.

I shall remain another night, but fear not, dear traveler, for I shall not return to this fetid chamber."

"O, woe is me! What's one to do when fee for change or cancel doth exceed the cost of tickets fair?  I fear US Air shall have some no-shows on flights this week, alas!  How vexing 'tis, that they wouldst not be more accommodating in such dire straits, with Super Storm Sandy raging forth!  Fie upon their policies, say I!"

"O, woe is me! This place doth bring me sorrow,
A tale of woe, and naught but trouble.
We did reserve their banquet room, a space
For celebration of a new life's bloom.
The contract was signed, the payment made,
Invitations sent, all preparations played.
But lo, a week before the joyous day,
They called to say the room was double-booked, oh fie!
Stress and vexation did they bring upon us,
And caused much trouble, nigh unbearable, alas!
And now I hear, this is not the first time,
This establishment doth play such tricks, oh shame!
How could they do this deed, so base and rude?
I pray, good sirs, take heed, and change thy ways,
Lest thou bring woe and sorrow to another's days."

"O, woeful day! My feline friend didst suffer much at hands of Mandy, she who doth call herself a groomer. A tiny knot, a mere trifle, didst prompt her to suggest a shaving, nay, a full-body shave! O, horrors! I, a concerned guardian, didst decline, and sought Petsmart's aid instead. They, with gentle touch and skilled hand, didst brush away the knot, restoring my cat's coat to its former glory. Mandy, beware! Thy name shall be forevermore a cautionary tale, a warning to all who seek to pamper their purring pals."

"O, woe is me! This place doth lack greatness, I do declare.
Avoid, good sir, their wares, for naught but woe doth lie therein.
Their customer service, a plague upon the land, doth stink and fester.
One star, nay, less than one, doth be their worth, anon."

"A lengthy wait didst ensue, my friends, ere we couldst partake of victuals. Verily, the server didst bear a heavy burden, yet twenty minutes didst pass ere we couldst give order for our feast. I didst wave and call out, that she might attend to us with haste. Alas, the mandarin wings didst disappoint, being deep-fried and oversalted, then drowned in sauce. The lime rub wings didst lack flavor, and wings from a store-bought box didst far surpass them. Our ale, however, didst please, and thus didst bring us cheer. In days of yore, this establishment didst boast great renown, but now, alack, 'tis naught but mediocrity that doth reign."

"Alas, I cannot speak of their service, good or ill,  
For we didst leave in haste, our patience didst dwindle and shrink.  
A hour we didst wait, and nary a soul didst depart,  
Their nails untouched, their feet still bare and stark.  
Four souls didst sit, in chairs they didst linger,  
Waiting for a tech, whose coming didst seem to tarry and lingering.  
Apologies, fair maidens, we shall ne'er return,  
For other salons beckon, with service more prompt and urgent."

"A scoundrel's trick, a manager's guile,
Patrice Harrington, a name most vile.
She promised aid, a helping hand,
But when the lease was broken, her tone did grand.
A penalty of $1536, two months' rent,
We pleaded, begged, but she was unmoved, unbent.
"Pay up, or else," she threatened, "your credit will suffer,
And entering this land, you'll find it a tougher."

The apartment, old and worn,
Appliances ancient, leaky, forlorn.
We reported, pleaded, but no repair,
The back gate, broken, unsafe, nary a care.

A children's playground, a sorry sight,
Broken swings, pet waste, a mess, a fright.
Other apartments nearby, better, fair,
This one, avoid, beware, a warning most rare."

"Fair, modern, and verdant, yet soulless and cold, 
A space where creativity's been bought and sold. 
The client, forgotten, left to navigate 
A labyrinthine layout, with naught but frustration to relate. 
A mile or more to walk, to reach a destination, 
And once arrived, two drinks, of minimal worth, await. 
No generosity, no kindness, only rules and restrictions, 
The Washingtons, squeezed dry, their spirits crushed. 
Stay away, dear friend, from this ill-fated place, 
Where corporate greed doth reign, and human grace doth flee."

"Hark! If thou art a wannabe gangster, fond of rude servitude and foul fare, o'erpriced victuals... verily, thou art in for a merry treat! Forsooth, even the watchmen, with their surly demeanor, shall add to thy displeasure."

This place hath long been due for an update,
With troubles aplenty, as the website doth state.
Complaints receive naught but hollow words,
And issues persist, like a fest'ring sore.

The carpeting, foul and stained, doth make one ill,
And in the shower, dirt doth flow like a stream.
A roach didst meet its end beneath my heel,
And in the hall, a foul stench doth linger and gleam.

No coffee doth await in the lobby, a shame,
Nor doth the hotel's security bear a name.
A man, with no ID, didst open a door,
And peered inside, with no regard for more.

To the desk, I took him, with a heavy heart,
But they didst show no care, nor didst they part.
The bill, incorrect, didst cause some strife,
But they didst fix it, with no further life.

The room key, too, didst give me trouble and woe,
And the shower, hot and cold, didst reverse its flow.
In Nigeria, I have seen better, alas,
Than this place, where updates are a must, ere long, lest all be lost.

"O, woe is me! Our furniture purchase, a woeful tale,
From the Room Store, a place most foul and vile.
We chose them o'er MOR, Ashley, and Costco,
For their salesman swore their leather warranty, unmatched, no?
But lo, within a few short months, the leather did flake,
Like black glitter, everywhere, our home did make.
And holes, great gaping holes, did form and grow,
We called the Room Store, hoping they would make it so,
But nay, they did not show, nor call, nor care,
Their warranty, void, our money, they did snare.
I pray thee, good people, heed my warning,
Take thy business, and thy gold, elsewhere, be gone!
For the Room Store, doth lie, and cheat, and steal,
Their craftsmanship, poor, their service, doth reveal.
The Better Business Bureau, doth not accredit,
The Room Store, a place, most worthy of shame and pit.
So, heed my words, and avoid their snare,
Lest thou, like me, doth suffer, and despair."

O, wouldst thou hear the tale of my woeful night?
'Twas at Otto's, where I didst seek delight.
But alas, the hot wings, they didst lack crisp,
And pizza, oh so bland, didst make me grip.

I didst blast them in the broiler, with heat so bright,
Yet still, they were not crispy, but rubbery in sight.
The pizza, oh so mediocre, we didst not keep,
But threw it away, like a sorrowful sleep.

And then, the order, I didst call in with haste,
But lo, they didst not start it, for a mistaken taste.
They had the number, clear as day,
But claimed they could not call, in a silly way.

So I didst wait, for twenty minutes more,
And watched them microwave, what they didst store.
I never saw such thing, in all my days,
And wonder how they stay, in business ways.

Collegiate nostalgia, may bring me back,
But for now, I do declare, 'tis a lack.
For Otto's, doth not deserve, my presence fine,
Until they change their ways, and serve divine.

"Fie upon this wretched meal, so full of grease and grime! My Philly sandwich, alas, didst disappear, and in its stead, a bowl of French onion soup didst make its presence known, with saltiness that doth assault mine taste buds. And though the mozzarella sticks didst provide some solace, verily, they were too oily, like a slick of slime upon my tongue. Our server, lost in thought, didst leave us waiting twenty minutes for our bill, as if the very fabric of time itself didst slow to a crawl. A plague upon this place, with service poor and atmosphere unclean!"

"O, how the memories of yesteryear do still persist,
In this, the club of Tao, where frustration did persist.
A den of beauty, with flowers afloat,
A giant Buddha, and maidens, to enchant and allure.
But alas, the throngs of people, did make it hard to abide,
And up and down the stairs, we did continually stride.
My legs and feet, did ache and protest,
As if they were put through, a most grueling test.
We sought to find the exit, and asked those who kept the peace,
But their directions, were conflicting, and our hopes did cease.
A hour or more, we waited, in lines that did not lead,
To freedom, but rather, to more confusion and need.
I vow, to never return, to this place again,
For though the decor be fair, the experience did bring pain."

"Alack, I didst place an order with Swim2000 through Buy.com on the third day of January, in the year of our Lord twelve hundred and twelve, to be delivered in one or two days of business, as is customary. But lo, the warehouse was closed for inventory, a fact that didst cause great delay and vexation. My order, alas, was not shipped until the ninth day of January, and now doth threaten to arrive too late for my impending vacation. Fie upon their lousy customer service, say I!"

"Alas, my friends, 'tis fast food we speak of here,  
A Taco Bell and KFC, both under one roof,  
A place I've visited oft, its proximity to work  
Making it a convenient choice, despite its roughness.  
  
The service, slow, the atmosphere, a bit unkempt,  
Yet consistency, they do possess, I must confess.  
The bean burritos, once with sauce, now lacking, alas!  
And chicken soft tacos, with scant filling, a sorry sight.  
  
But fear not, dear friends, for I have found a new place,  
A Taco Bell, near 19th and Deer Valley, with grace.  
A slightly better experience, doth await thee there,  
So journey forth, and may thy taste buds be fair."

"Hark, good sir! What news dost thou bring?
A change, it seems, hath come upon the downstairs bar,
Where once great feasts were had, now naught but smoke doth fill the air.
And whispers spread of deceitful ways,
Of premium brands replaced with generic names.
Alas, 'tis but a rumor, yet 'tis true,
Their fare, once grand, now dwindled to a few.
How sad, forsooth, to see such change come upon the place,
Where once we gathered, laughter filled the space."

"O wondrous city of Las Vegas, ne'er have I witnessed such poor service as this! Our dinner at eight o'clock, with nary a soul in sight, yet the wait didst drag on like a play with too much repetition. No apology didst they offer, nor didst they heed our plight, leaving us to suffer, forgotten and forlorn. An hour passed, and more, ere our victuals arrived, and lo, they were not worth the wait, no special treat didst they bring. And to add insult to injury, they didst demand an extra tithe of eighteen percent, merely for the privilege of dining with five others! Fie upon this house, and may its name be stricken from the rolls of decent establishments!"

"Amidst the luxury of a five-star hotel,  
A higher standard of conduct is expected, no doubt.  
For those who think wealth grants them leave to act,  
As they please, without a care or thought for others' plight,  
A stern reprimand, a loss of business, doth serve  
As punishment, and a lesson, to boot."

Alas, my dearest Starbucks, how my heart doth yearn for thee! Forsooth, I am a mighty fan of thy brew, and thus, my spirits did soar when I didst learn of thy proximity to mine own abode. But lo, my joy didst quickly turn to woe, for alack, this particular branch of thine didst fail to meet my expectations. Verily, each time I didst venture forth to partake of thy offerings, my drink didst arrive in a state of disarray. Yea, even a humble cup of hot green tea didst falter beneath thy touch. Alas, I fear we shall not be visiting thee again, dear Starbucks, for sorrow hath taken up residence within my heart.

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall me at Eastover!
The office staff, in disarray, didst schedule me withal
With the right doctor, but alas, at the wrong location.
Thus, I didst show up at the wrong place, in confusion.
And, lo, they didst pair me with a male doctor, not my desire.

Ah, but that was not the end of my troubles, fair friends.
For when I didst seek to speak with a nurse, by phone,
They didst promise a swift return call, but alas, 'twas not so.
I didst wait, and wait, and wait, until at last,
A voice didst answer, telling me to return to the office.
Fie upon't! What folly, what ineptitude, what woe!
I didst seek another doctor, and shall not return to Eastover,
Forsooth, my patience hath been tried, and found wanting.
A pox upon their house, say I!"

"Hark! A tale of woe and bitter fate,
Of service poor and staff inept,
We waited long, nigh twenty-two minutes,
And still, no sign of service did we see,
The place was not full, yet we did sit,
In silence, waiting, waiting, waiting,
A maid from Hooters, once my station,
I am dismayed, and vow, ne'er to return,
For such incompetence, I do condemn,
We rose and left, our meal untouched,
A sad departure, with naught but disdain,
For this, a place of ill repute,
Shall be forevermore, forgot."

"By th' first sign, we knew the place was woe,
A frisking for weapons, what a sorry show!
Next, fat maidens everywhere, a sight most vile,
And bouncers, rude and full of spiteful guile.
A cover charge, oh how they did connive,
At midnight, summer's heat, and naught but few alive.
Parking, eight dollars, oh how they did strive,
Three bars nearby, same price, what a strife!
The privies, foul and loathsome, such a plight,
Cops, more than patrons, in the bar that night.
Old men, creepy and strange, a woeful sight,
Fat chicks, a plenty, no beauty in their might.
In conclusion, a place most dire, ne'er to return,
A night most foul, with naught but sorrow to learn."

"A colleague didst recommend this place to me,
For my locks were somewhat long, thou see.
I asked the barber for but an inch,
And bade him not to make it too complex.
But when I left, my tresses were all curl'd,
And thus I thought them fine, and not perturbed.
But when I straightened them this morn, alas!
The layers in the back, how choppy they were!
Three blunt cuts, in a random patch, didst show,
Like some mad barber had taken his share.
I ne'er had such a haircut ere this day,
And now I know why folk do say,
It can be quite a traumatic event, indeed.
And the shampooing, it was not divine,
No massage nor head rubbing didst I receive,
A quick and uninspired rinse, 'twas all I got."

"Alas, poor soul, I heeded not the warnings given,  
And now in woe, my tale of wretched fate is driven.  
In search of rest, a mattress new to find,  
I entered R.C. Willey's hallowed halls of commerce kind.  
But lo, the folk who worked within that place,  
Didst shun me, scorning my each and every grace.  
Their rudeness keen, didst pierce my heart full sore,  
As none would aid, nor give me ear, nor floor.  
Alack, I searched, a wanderer lost in thought,  
For one who might assist, my troubled mind besought.  
At last, a youth, with patience, didst abide,  
And helped me find, what I had long desired.  
But alas, his aid, was scant and poor,  
He pointed blind, and knew not what I sought once more.  
In frustration deep, I left that wretched den,  
And sought Relax the Back, where kindness didst attend.  
There, found I, solace and a bed of worth,  
For $4500, a price, I gladly paid in truth.  
Farewell, R.C. Willey, may your staff learn,  
To treat all guests, with respect and gentle turn."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, hear my tale of woe,
Of a place that doth not suit my taste, I do declare.
The crowd, a rowdy bunch, with nary a care,
Do gather here, to drink and revel in the air.

But alas, my friends, this place doth not appeal,
For 'tis full of elders, with eyes that do gleam,
Like wolves upon the young, with intent most foul,
I pray thee, leave me be, and let me take my leave.

We came hither, after festive Oktoberfest,
In search of drinks, and merriment, at best.
But lo, the wait at Rula Bula didst stretch,
And so we ventured here, to quench our thirst and fetch.

Yet, inside, the atmosphere didst feel awry,
With aged men, who doth leer at scantily-clad maids,
And outside, the space was cramped, with smoke that doth choke,
The service, too, was lacking, with slow and surly folk.

Thus, I do say, I shall not return again,
For I am not of college age, nor yet a creepy elder,
If on Mill Avenue, I shall stick to Rula Bula's domain."

"Our quest for a spot most fair and bright
Hath led us, my friends and I, to this place of woe
Where service doth leave much to be desired
And discourtesy doth reign supreme, I do declare

A nail technician, with a gruff demeanor
Didst ignore my requests, though politely spoken
Four times I asked, and showed her a picture too
Yet still she failed to heed my words, alack

And so, a second visit didst we make
With hopes that past mistakes would be corrected
But lo, the appointment was not noted
And we were told to wait, our time neglected

Alack, the tech didst say, with scorn and pride
"Like I told you, you'll have to wait," she lied
For we had spoken of our appointment before
And she, a servant, didst ignore our plea

So, dear friends, let this be a lesson
To avoid this place, with its poor impression
For though their nails may be done with skill
Their customer service doth leave much to be desired still."

"O, how the prices doth inflate,
And quality, it doth not compensate!
Improve the fare, and lower the cost,
And perchance, I shall return, and boast.
The victuals, tasty though they be,
Cannot compare to true BBQ, ye see.
For this, a mere oven-cooked repast,
Doth not suffice, nor meet my quest."

"In dire torment, I didst seek out aid,
At a place where Dr. Nash didst reside,
She took x-rays, and with a stern visage,
Didst declare my spine most crooked and awry,
In Phase 2 degeneration, she didst say,
And urged me to undertake thirty treatments straightway,
Lest surgery loomed near, with its sharp knife,
I demurred, and asked if other course were rife,
But she, unmoved, didst insist on her decree,
And bade me leave, still wracked with misery.

Afar, I searched for another healer,
Whose skill might ease my anguish and dismay,
In Las Vegas, I didst find such a one,
Who took new x-rays, and with kindness begun,
Didst say my spine showed little sign of decay,
And termed my extra disk a "transitional" way,
He treated me with care, and eased my pain,
In just two sessions, I didst regain my vigor once again."

"A tale of woe, my friends, doth unfold,
Of managers who did not take heed,
Their duty, to keep the guests from harm,
They did neglect, with hearts of stone, it seems.

A tub, it did overflow, up above,
And flooded rooms, with waters of love,
The guests, they did not notice, alas,
Until the morn, when all was awash.

Five souls, they did share one bath,
With troubles great, and labors vast,
Their pleas, they did fall on deaf ears,
The managers, they did not take their fears.

A paltry sum, they did offer,
Twenty dollars, a meager amount, no more,
For all their troubles, and strife,
It was but a drop, in a sea of life.

So heed my words, dear friends, take note,
Of this hotel, with managers remote,
Seek elsewhere, a place to lay thy head,
Where integrity doth reign supreme, instead."

"O woeful day! My iPhone, once so bright,
Lay shattered, its screen in sorry plight.
A friend, in kindness, did recommend
One Stop Wireless, where I might find
A cure for my phone's dire condition.
But lo, the repair did bring more woe,
For when I took it to the Gadget Fairy,
She said the parts that made it whole were gone,
And stripes did mar its face, a sorry sight.
She said I was fortunate, indeed,
To have escaped the wrath of this device,
For it should have given me trouble ere now.
I vow, I'll ne'er return to this place,
Nor recommend it to any soul,
For thieves they be, and their business, base."

"Nevermore shall I set foot within these walls,
For here the owner doth spew forth hateful gall,
Against fair Caucasian women and their brood,
And I, alas, am wedded to a Hispanic good.

Their cruel words did reach mine ears, so keen,
As they did chide the waitress with such spleen,
For merely two small coins, they did demand,
That she remove the cap from yonder Perrier brand.

Her fierce retort, with F-bomb loud and clear,
Did echo through the hall, and struck great fear,
In me, who would not have my Perrier uncorked,
Ere it arrive at table, with grace unsmorked."

"Methinks 'twas once a week, for five long years,  
I dined here, forsooth, with naught but cheer.  
The service, good, and all, in fine fettle,  
Our clan, on birthdays, didst this place settle.  
The large room, took we, with joy and glee,  
But now, alas, 'tis lost, for those of three and ten,  
Must be of age, to enter, woe is me!  
If thou art older, then, my friend, do try,  
This place, ere it doth turn, to PT's, say I."

"Verily, 'twas the most wretched service they didst receive.
The lady, a scowl upon her visage, doth seem to bear a grudge against all who doth enter.
As if the very presence of customers doth vex her soul.
I shall ne'er set foot within that place again,
For I wouldst rather walk the distance to UPS or Fedex,
Than suffer the indignity of such poor treatment.
How is't that one such as she doth still hold employ?
A mystery, indeed."

"Pizza, a dish most foul and stale,
Reminded me of Red Barron's tale.
My order, delayed and cold as ice,
Arrived with haste, but not nice.

I called to voice my discontent,
And was offered a small consent.
A $2 discount, a paltry sum,
For a meal that left me glum.

The lass who spoke, her tone quite curt,
As if such mistakes were oft.
No concern did she display,
Nor any wish to make it right.

Avoid this place, my friends, I say,
If authentic pizza's what you play.
Order from Sicilis instead,
On Twain, their pies are well-bred."

"Hark, what strange occurrence did befall me yester-night,
Within the confines of a club most dimly lit.
A VIP pass, freely given, did grant me access,
And thus, I bypassed the lengthy queue, with nary a fuss or a fit.

Into the loud, hot chamber, full of folk, did I venture,
And, with great difficulty, made my way to the bar,
Where, alas, no seats were to be found, nor drinks did they proffer,
Though I didst stand and gaze upon the throng, in wonder and dismay.

But lo, Security didst approach, with words most stern,
And claimed that I had engaged in acts most unbecoming,
And thus, didst they expel me forthwith, into the night's embrace,
Leaving me in wonder, at the strangeness of the human race.

Verily, 'twas a strange and wondrous event,
Yet, shall I not return, forsooth, to that place of revelry,
For once was enough, and now, I do protest,
No more shall I waste my time, in such a den of mirth and folly."

"Alack, what business hast thou, wretched soul,
At race track, where thou dost not belong?
Thou know'st naught of horse racing, 'tis true,
Yet here thou art, for friend's birthday, anon.
This foul place, with dirt and grime so rife,
Doth make thee feel most out of life.
The crowd, too, doth seem most vile and base,
In this den of iniquity, full of disgrace.
Nevermore shalt thou return, 'tis thy fate."

Oh woe is me! What a wretched place, where we did take our young ones for a night's repose. And lo, the very next morn, we didst hasten our departure, forsooth! They didst assign us to a foul chamber, filled with soiled garments, and we didst request a change, lest we miss the evening's feast. Alas, the arcade, once full of life and cheer, now doth lie in disarray, its machines broken and still, save those that didst require an attendant's hand to dispense their winnings.

"Punctual, he was, and wise, it seemed.  Ideas, he gave, of value, I deemed.  A call, he made, the next week, to say,  Bid, he'd send, come what may.  But nay, not a word, did I hear,  And so, my time, was cast, quite dear.  Dislike, I do, such slothful ways,  A call, to say, 'twas not their day."

"O, woe betide the day I didst choose to fly
With Orbitz, that wretched company of the sky.
For they didst charge me fifty pieces of gold
For but a single bag, a carry-on, so bold.

I pray thee, good sirs, heed my warning true,
And shun this company, as thou wouldst shun the plague.
For they do rob and pillage, with no care for thee,
And leave thee in the lurch, with naught but misery.

So, farewell, Orbitz, and may thy name
Be forevermore a curse, a shame, a blight.
For thou hast lost a customer, and earned mine ire,
And thus, I pray, mayst thou forever burn in fire."

"Hark! In Phoenix, all my life I've dwelt,
And thus, have savored many a Mexican feast.
This place, alas! Didst not meet expectations,
The tortillas and salsa, a delightful sensation.
But beans, so creamy and smooth, didst lack
Flavor, a sorry state, indeed, didst make me quack.
Rice, too, was bland, a disappointment,
Chips, but one basket, a paltry amount.
Other places, with generosity, do serve
As many as thou dost desire, a true preserve.
All in all, not the worst, but not the best,
Carolina's, Poncho's, Rito's, the standard, didst set."

"Flee, flee, good sir, with all due haste,
For ill fate doth await thee at this place.
A laptop, once in working order, now doth lie
In pieces, broken and beyond repair.

They took it in, with promises to fix,
But lo, their skills were lacking, quite.
When two weeks passed, and still it would not turn,
They shifted blame, with words most stern.

'Twas not their fault, they claimed, but thine,
For problems existed, ere they didst dine.
Yet, they didst examine it, with eyes so bright,
And found no issue, ere they didst take flight.

Now, here thou art, with computer in hand,
And naught but trouble, doth it command.
No charge, they said, with smiles so wide,
But woe betide thee, for they lied.

iPhones, they fix, with skill so fine,
But laptops, alas, are not their shrine.
So, heed my words, and flee this place,
Lest thou suffer, with similar disgrace."

"A pox upon this burger joint, I say,
With atmosphere so loud, it doth astray
The senses, and doth make a mockery
Of all that's good and pure in this world, yea.

Their burgers, too, are naught but woeful fare,
A sorry sight, with flavors so bare.
And yet, they claim it's all they serve,
A boast most empty, and quite unnerve.

But wait, there's more! A gown, a hospital gown,
They had me wear, to heighten the mirth.
But mirth it was not, nor fun, nor play,
For in such garb, I did not feel at ease,
Nay, 'twas a trial, and a test of wits,
To endure such folly, and such silly fits.

So, if thou art in search of a place
Where thou mayst eat, and watch a spanking race,
Then, prithee, seek out this wretched den,
But for my part, I shall ne'er come again."

"O, how the prices doth inflate, my dear!
For three cocktails, a sum of forty-two,
A fee most exorbitant, doth make me sneer.
And slow, the service doth unfold,
As if the waiters didst take their time to hold.
The French dip, devoid of flavor, doth disappoint,
And French onion soup, but mediocre, doth present.
Yet still, the view of yonder strip, so fair and bright,
Doth make amends for this poor show, a little light."

"Two bikes have I bought from this place, good products they be,
But alas, the service, poor it is, I do declare.
The bike mechanics, knowledgeable they are not,
And the head mechanic, he doth not listen, by the plot.

A warranty service, I did receive, they said,
Three to four weeks, the turnaround, it would be.
But lo, three months passed, and still no bike,
And when it came, flat tires, and ill-adjusted brake.

Missing bolts and washers, a sorry sight,
And the crank spindle, without grease, a fright.
The owner, he assured me, all was fixed,
But only some, alas, were truly mixed."

"O, woe is me, to dine at this wretched spread!
For laziness, my heart doth often lead me here,
When at Aria, I do take my rest.
Indeed, 'tis true, I come to this place with fear,
Lest the fare be cold, and the champagne lacking cheer.
Yet still, I venture forth, with hope in my heart,
That perchance, I may find a tasty part.
But alas, each time, my hopes are dashed,
For the mimosas, they be not freshly splashed.
And the victuals, they be cold and old,
As if left to languish, betwixt the morning's gold.
So heed my words, dear friend, and shun this place,
Lest thou suffer the same fate, and taste its bitter grace."

"Verily, a sluggish morn it was, the day after yuletide,
At half past seven, our hunger did abide.
We ordered breakfast, eggs, bacon, and waffles too,
And waited patiently, as the minutes did accrue.

A quarto of coffee, and a glass of OJ,
Did complete our meal, in a manner quite gay.
The sum of twenty-seven dollars did we pay,
And left a tip of thirty, for our server to play.

But had I known, the total of my bill,
I wouldst not have tipped, and paid but what I could still.
Yet, haste made me leave, without the change to spare,
So thus, our breakfast ended, with naught but despair."

"Hark! If thou dost seek a meal most mediocre,
At four times the cost, then this be thy venue.
I ne'er didst feel such dismay at a feast,
As I didst at this place, alack and alas!
The waiter, a kind soul, didst serve with grace,
And meatballs, they were not amiss, by my troth.
But penne and vodka, flavorless they were,
And calamari, a dish most foul and dire.
This place, methinks, wouldst not endure two minutes,
In New Jersey, where culinary delights do abound."

"Marry, good sir or madam, heed my words of woe,
For at this place of business, thou shalt not go,
If thou hast other plans, lay them aside,
For they do not concern themselves with thy tide.

I went to keep an appointment, full of hope,
But found myself in waiting, like a mope.
A half hour passed, and still I did abide,
But none seemed to care, nor did they take my side.

So, in disgust, I left, with haste and speed,
For 'twas clear they cared not for my need.
Heed my advice, lest thou suffer likewise,
And choose another place, where they do prize."

"O woe is me, for humanity's sake!

Verily, words of woe and sorrow fit,
To describe this gastronomic ill fate.
A group of four, we searched and sought,
For scraps to fill our bellies, naught.

Taste the cheapness in each dish, we did,
As if prepared in some far-off land,
Frozen, shipped, thawed by chance, then re-froze,
And served to Luxor's diners, unsuspecting souls.

Shame on thee, Luxor, for this foul deed,
And may thy managers partake, each day,
Of this poor fare, to learn and heed."

"A pox upon the Grand Lux, a woeful tale I tell,
Our Christmas party plans, in tatters now doth dwell.
Reservations made a month in advance, with care,
Yet on the eve of fest, our table, taken unaware.

The day before, a call, a mix-up, oh so grand,
Our time, 6pm, their mistake, a 10:30am stand.
"Wait," they say, "our doors, at 11am, do open wide,"
A puzzle, this, how can it be, we cannot hide.

The manager, a cookie, offers with a grin,
Insolence, his gesture, our ire doth win.
High top tables, a suggestion, too, they make,
But two in chairs, our party, how could they partake?

Disappointment, anger, our hearts doth fill,
At Grand Lux, no more, our trust doth spill.
A warning, this, to all, who hear me now,
Never plan a party, at Grand Lux, avow."

"Hark! This place doth close its doors, my friends,
As of the date that doth proclaim the end.
'Tis transformed into a new venture now,
A Korean fusion eatery, they vow.
The former owner, in truth, didst say,
'Twas shut some six moons past, alack the day!"

"Fie upon this wretched breakfast, say I!
In fair Charlotte, ne'er have I seen
Such sorry fare, such paltry cheer,
As this, which doth claim to be fresh, anon.

Aye, see yonder sign, which doth proclaim
A new breakfast, full of life and glee.
But nay, good friends, forsooth, 'tis naught
But Styrofoam eggs, and cheese, forgot,
And half a scoop of eggs, with one poor sausage,
In a hoagie roll, for four dear dollars, prithee!

Why, pray, would any man, in his right mind,
Step foot within this woeful place?
I, myself, was fooled, alas, once,
Pray, do not ye repeat my mistake, an it please thee."

"Fair warning, good sir or madam, avoid this place,
For in my salad, a black hair didst grace,
And though they replaced it with haste, they didst charge,
A grievous wrong, and my ire doth engage.

My mother-in-law, a victim also, didst find
A cockroach within her taco salad, so unkind.
Her appetite didst flee, yet the waitress didst urge,
"Take a new salad, and let not your meal be marred."

But lo, the owner, a churl with naughty manners,
Didst argue that the bug might have flown in, in error.
And thus, their mediocre fare didst leave us in disdain,
Avoid this place, lest thou suffer similar pain."

"Beware the dairy, fair friends, I pray thee,
For 'twill bring thee naught but woe and misery.
My sons, they did partake of yogurt sweet,
Chocolate and strawberry, their taste to greet.
And our friend, she did indulge in cream,
Whipped upon her crepes, a most unseemly dream.
But lo, their joy didst soon turn to despair,
For all three didst hasten to the privy, in disrepair.
A curse upon the dairy, I do declare,
For it didst bring such trouble, without a care.
My other son, he didst escape the fate,
With non-dairy toppings, his hunger to sate.
And my wife, she didst enjoy her crepes,
With powdered sugar, her sweet tooth to appease.
But our friend, alas, she didst not fare so well,
For still she lies abed, her trip now in hell.
What a sad ending, to her journey's close,
A night of woe, that doth my heart oppress."

"Alack, what choice have I, but to bestow
One star upon this resort, despite its show
Of grandeur, with a room that boasts a view
Of Bellagio's fountains, dancing anew

But alas, the casino holds no charm
For one such as myself, in mid-thirties form
The mock French streets and eateries do naught
But leave me unimpressed, with a heavy heart

The chamber, though with spacious bath, doth lack
In space, a humble abode, and old, to boot
The air, a foul stench, doth pierce mine eyes
As if a thousand smokes did fill the skies

A painted ceiling, in the casino grand
Doth show the pollution, that doth choke the land
Were air quality ratings given, as in towns
This place, a mask and tank, would be the gowns

Thus, one star doth seem the fitting fee
For this resort, that doth not meet mine eye
A change of hotel, didst I make, in haste
And ne'er again, shall I, this place, embrace."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold, my friends,
Of Black Dog, where we didst venture forth,
With hopes of savory meats and fine ale,
Our bellies didst rumble, our spirits didst fail.

We stood by the door, in patient wait,
For those within to take note of our plight,
But nary a soul didst give us a glance,
As we stood there, lost in ignominy's trance.

The minutes ticked by, slow and cold,
As we didst wait, our hunger growing old,
At last, we took our seats at the bar,
Uninvited, but with hope still afire.

Alas! The bartender brought us naught,
But news of empty shelves, and a menu bereft,
No ribs, no pork, no fowl to delight,
Our hunger didst growl, our mood didst take flight.

Alack! Poor management, a lack of foresight,
Didst leave us in the lurch, with naught to excite,
We left, in search of better fare,
And found it, at Seven Saints, with friendly care.

So, heed my words, dear friends, beware,
Of Black Dog's empty promises, and scant fare,
For though their ale may flow, their food doth lack,
And leave thee, as it didst us, in dismal black."

"A plague upon this wretched crew,
Whose billing practices be so untrue!
They charged my visit with false codes,
And now refuse to amend their ways,
In spite of Aetna's words, so plain,
That I, a patient, should not pay a dime.
I played them the recording, clear as day,
But still they insist that I must pay.
Their staff, so unhelpful and rude,
Do naught but cause the consumer to be confused.
Avoid them, good sirs and madams,
For they do seek to cheat and scam."

"Hark! This eatery hath been here since I first drew breath,
And critics do proclaim its worth. A loyal fan of Lolo's,
I thought this place would surely surpass. With two friends,
We came expecting culinary delight, our hunger pangs
To be sated by the famed fried chicken, world-renowned,
But lo! The service was poor, the food uninspired.
The chicken, frozen and bland, didst taste like Banquet's fare,
And cornbread arrived long after, leaving us to wait.
No silverware did we have, to add to our dismay.
My colleague's ribs, he said, didst pale in comparison
To Mickey D's own McRib, a saddening revelation.
The men's room lacked hand towels, to complete our woe.
We paid sixteen pieces of eight for a poor chicken dish,
A price too steep for such a meal, and iced tea to boot.
Alas! Four and forty years, and still, no excuse can be found."

"O, how the staff at Whole Foods didst behave with rudeness and disdain! My cart, they didst disassemble, and no apologies didst they proffer. I didst expect a higher quality of service, for their prices are indeed higher than those of other markets. But alas, I have ne'er experienced such thievery of carts, even when left alone for a spell.

I didst leave my cart, and to the deli didst I repair, to inquire about the pizza dough. The lady, she didst take her time, and I didst wait patiently. But when I didst return to my cart, 'twas nowhere to be found. I didst ask the pink-haired bakery lady if she had seen it, but she didst not. And when she didst ask the cashiers, the little Asian man didst admit that he had taken it apart, and my meat and cheese had been returned to their respective departments. No apologies didst he offer, nor didst the bakery lady speak a word. Fie upon their customer service!

I didst have to journey back to the meat department, and ask for my meat, explaining the situation. The meat man didst say that 'twas likely done, to prevent theft of food. But how couldst my food be stolen, sitting on my cart?! And so, I didst wait for new ground beef to be ground and packaged, for the space of twenty minutes. Still, no apologies didst they give."

"Hark! I visited this establishment for the first time on Friday,
And thought it was good, until today, when my friend did say,
That they had added twenty dollars to his tab, oh woe is me!
He showed the receipts, and it was clear to see,
That the amount they charged was far more than it should be.
So if thou dost enjoy being robbed, then this is the place for thee,
But for myself, I shall never return, nor wouldst I advise thee."

"Hark, what wondrous luck doth befall me now!
I called, and with great haste, didst make an appointment for an estimate of our backyard's design.
And lo, the man didst call but ten short minutes ere the appointed time, and didst suggest a change of hour, no great offense, for such things do occur.
But when he came, alas, he bore no tool to measure, nor any means to take account of our land's dimensions.
How shall he give us an estimate, then, without the proper means to gauge?
What folly this, what woeful lack of foresight!"

Oh, how unprofessional they be,
From scheduling appointments to referrals, ye see.
And billing, oh billing, a disaster indeed,
A never-ending cycle, a woeful creed.

Thou shall be referred to collection, 'tis true,
And when thou callest to inquire, Mary Jane doth speak anon.
She promiseth to fix the problem, by her honor bright,
But lo, the collection agency doth write once more, in the night.

Thou callest Mary Jane, to learn what doth occur,
And she, with apologies, doth lay the blame on her inexperienced peers.
A vicious loop, a merry-go-round of woe,
Enjoy it, dear friend, forsooth, 'tis all thou canst do.

"By th' heavens, four times I didst enter this place,
And lo, not a single hand basket didst grace
The shelves. Well, gosh darn it, they didst move,
And now, alas, I must search high and low.
A sign, a sign, good sirs, to guide me,
To the baskets' new abode, wouldst be most meet.
Forsooth, a mark above their former place,
Wouldst tell me where to find them, without a trace.
But nay, I know not what the bajeezus doth say,
For today, I sought the baskets, and lo, they fled.
Not one, not a single basket, didst remain,
And so, I shall don a basket, like some Indian dame.
Perhaps, kind sirs, thou couldst reimburse me,
For my new basket, and grant me a discount, too.
Like those granola bags, the hippies do employ,
Aye, walking home, my plastic bag did break,
And had I had my basket, this mishap had not befallen."

"Hark! I once didst enjoy their Carne Asada,
But lo, one day a toe nail didst I find within my burrito.
'Twas most foul and vile, and didst make me feel quite sick.
I didst avoid the place for many moons,
But alas, my hunger didst drive me back, and thus I didst try
Their Carne Asada once again. Alas, a fingernail didst I find,
And thus my stomach didst churn with disgust and woe.
Nevermore shall I return to that accursed place,
For who doth wish to dine on mystery meat?
Fie upon it, say I!"

"Methinks 'twas an ill day for Los Favoritos, forsooth! Their breakfast burritos, once renowned, didst fail to impress. A stale tortilla, greasy spuds, and flavors dull, didst make my meal most unenjoyable. The salsa, guacamole, and beans, all lacked zest, and left me in dismay. The service, too, didst leave much to be desired, for the lass at the counter, didst treat us with scant courtesy. Mayhap 'twas but a singular mishap, yet still, I yearn for burritos rich in taste, freshness, and sauces of high quality. Phoenix, prithee, guide me to such an eatery!"

"Fair citizens, take heed of my words,
And avoid a place that doth charge thee dear.
For shots they claim, a fee of sixty crowns,
And still thou must pay for each dose, I fear.

In Maricopa County, a better deal thou shalt find,
For twenty pieces of silver, the same shots they bind.
Call on this number, six hundred and two,
Five thousand and six, seven three eight seven,
To learn more of their vaccination ways,
And save thy purse from needless dismay.

Or visit this website, with haste and speed,
Maricopa dot gov, forward slash pets,
Vaccinations await, at a price most fair,
And spare thy wallet, from despair."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from YouFit's door,
Where my friend and I didst seek to explore
Their fitness realm, but alas! 'Twas not meant to be,
For the man at the counter, strange and odd was he.

He spoke with speed, as if drugged, and his eyes did dart,
And his back was turned, so naught but mumbles did impart.
We asked to try their gym, and he didst reply,
"A guest pass, $10, ye must pay, ere ye may fly."

But lo! The Village, generous and kind, doth offer seven days free,
To test their wares, ere committing to decree.
The man, his boss would slay, didst whisper low,
"Go online, a free pass, thou shalt know."

But alas! The fees, they didst climb, and mount,
And with the man's strange ways, our trust was not found.
So we didst flee, and leave their halls,
Forsooth! YouFit, not for us, doth call."

"A single star, alas, doth not suffice,
For service poor and food not nice.
We went for breakfast, late in the day,
And waited long, our patience to sway.
People grew upset, and left in dismay,
But we, being hungry, stayed to play.

The food arrived, and lo, what did I see?
French fries, instead of hash browns, by decree!
They claimed to be out of the latter, and chose
To substitute, without a word, the former.
My husband's skillet breakfast, too, came wrong,
With hash browns, instead of red potatoes strong.
He could not eat, for they looked old and grey,
And I, in shock, did utter a dismay.

The manager, when we told her our plight,
Did argue with us, and put up a fight.
She said they had red potatoes in store,
But two waitresses whispered, 'Twas a lie, no more.
With a wicked attitude, she did reply,
'Leave now, and take your business elsewhere, goodbye.'
She did not charge us, but our ire did raise,
For such poor service, and ill-advised ways."

"Hark, what woe doth befall us at this place?
Each visit doth bring forth a sorry state,
Of dirt and rudeness, and a paltry taste.
Our drinks, all three, didst bear the mark of shame,
A pitiful sight, with naught but white snow within.
Alas, poor service, how art thou fallen so low?
Clean up thy act, and treat thy guests with respect,
Lest they, like us, do vow to ne'er return again."

"A pox upon this place, once dear to me,
Now tainted by inflated prices, poor service, see.
They raise their rates, and quality doth decline,
A plague upon the management, so unkind.

And lo, a further woe, a trick they play,
Your name on list, yet strangers take your seat away.
The Spanish fellow, tall and surly, doth presume
To guide you, with discourtesy, his creed.
My wife, a savior, spared him from a blow,
But beware, fair friends, this place doth woe betide thee, know."

"Alas, how woeful doth this eatery appear,
With frozen corn and BBQ sauce most vile.
Their decor, a mishmash of old and new,
Doth clash and doth not please mine eyes anew.

Our waitress, fair and kind, didst attend
To our needs, but alas, the food didst fail.
The fried green tomatoes, passable at best,
The sauce, a lone bright spot, didst pass the test.

But oh, the chicken, how it didst disappoint!
No dry rub, and slathered in sauce, it didst seem.
I asked for it dry, a mistake, I do confess,
For what arrived, a roasted bird, didst not impress.
It lacked the tender, slow-cooked taste,
And fell not off the bone, as it should, in haste.

I'll stick to KC style, with Open Pit or Masterpiece,
For this place, alas, doth not win mine approval, nor my purse."

"Mistake it was, dear friends, to take my mother thither on that day,
For crowds they had, and unprepared they were, in sooth.
First come, first served, we waited in line,
Negotiating food and drink, with naught but time to kill.
An hour they said, but two hours passed, ere the victuals were ready,
A disappointment, indeed, and cause for dismay."

"Alas, my friends, I didst try with all my might,
To return, and claim the oil change right.
The thirty-five dollars, a sum so fair,
Didst tempt me sore, and I couldst not bear.

But lo, when I arrived at CAS,
The hipster garage monkey didst say,
"Thy newer vehicle, and synthetic brew,
Doth make a difference, I do declare,
Of forty dollars, a sum so grand,
A price so steep, it doth command.

Alas, I tried, but couldst not abide,
Such cost, and thus, I didst decide,
To leave, and seek a better deal,
For my poor purse, didst sorely feel."

"Hark, good sir or madam, seek thou here a place,
Where cheese doth reign supreme, in copious amounts, with grace.
Combos, they do abound, all smothered in cheese,
A feast most wondrous, for those who do delight,
In ooey, gooey, creamy, warm, and melted bliss.

But, pray tell, what lies beneath this mountain high,
Of golden, melted joy, that doth reach the sky?
A question, indeed, worth pondering, with great care,
For those who dare, to venture forth, and share.

In days of old, a film didst hit the screen,
The Blob, a creature, most foul, and mean.
It consumed all in its path, with nary a peep,
But now, at Laredo's, thou canst have thy revenge, and eat.

So, strap on tight, thy portable oxygen tank,
And dive into this sea, of melted, cheesy blank.
With courage high, and spirit bold,
Thou shalt emerge, most satisfied, I do unfold."

"Methinks I've visited Tivoli Village thrice, my dear,
And each time, 'twas a sorry sight to see.
The decor, a mishmash of styles, doth confuse,
A soda shop, a bistro, and Italian charm,
Did some poor soul receive pay for this design?

The service, too, did leave much to be desired,
Orders came forth wrong, again and again.
At half past eleven, scotch and wine they proffered,
While I, in suit and tie, didst feel quite odd.
In Vegas, mayhap, but still, 'twas unseemly.

The menu, a wondrous thing, didst deceive,
For burgers small and flavorless didst arrive.
Sweet potato fries, a lone bright spot, didst gleam,
But alas, the milkshakes, o'erpriced and mediocre, didst seem.

My friends, heed my advice, and shun this place,
For In n Out, a better choice, doth grace.
Or if thou must o'erpay for a burger, seek
Lbs at Red Rock or Burger Bar, where worth doth meet."

"A plague upon this wretched place, where discord doth reign supreme! Average pies they serve, yet pipes of grandeur doth resound within. My sire and dam, with me in tow, didst arrive ere music's start, and I, a fool, didst anticipate sweet melodies of old. Alas, the organist didst play marches and ditties of yore, so loud that my deaf parents didst silence their hearing aids in dismay. The patrons, too, didst pause their feasts, and rose to cheer, when "America the Beautiful" didst fill the air. My witless sire, in jest, didst ask the name of tune, and lo, a burly man, with visage fierce and arms adorned with patriotic hues, didst proffer a fist, a gesture most uncouth. A haven, then, for youthful innocents, the elderly, the deaf, or those who doth espouse extremity."

"O, woe is me! My order, how awry it doth go!
For when I didst call, they didst not listen, no,
They forgot, alas! The extra items, they didst not bring,
But charged me still, with nary a blink.

Two Pizzones we didst order, but one didst come,
And when we didst call, the manager, with scorn,
Didst give us attitude, and didst not apologize,
Nor didst she redeliver, till an hour had passed,
With naught but woe, and anger in mine eyes.

I do detest, with all my heart, this Pizza Hut,
Their service, poor, their manners, rude and rough,
Ne'er shall I step, within their doors again,
For they have lost, a loyal customer, in vain."

"Fie upon this wretched feast! 

A waiter most annoying did our table frequent, 
With speeches long-winded and tales most tedious, 
Of clubs and deals, and other frivolous matters, 
That naught to do with dinner or victuals had. 
And knew he not the wines, as if a salesman, 
Who forced upon us his pitches most vexing. 

The viands, too, were tepid, and oh so vile, 
The seafood drowned in butter, cream, and bile, 
The steaks were dry, and flavorless, and small, 
All overpriced, and wines of poor quality did crawl. 
The vegetables, cold, and parmesan-covered lay, 
The potatoes, too, were bland, and naught could stay 
Our discontent, for four of us did sit, 
And none found warmth in their repast, nor did it fit. 

Alas, what woeful fare, and grief to pay 
The bill, so steep, for such poor service did we bear! 
Rainforest Cafe, ne'er shall we dine with thee again!"

In sooth, my dear compatriots, I have heard tell
Of a place called Lulu's, wherein doth dwell
A culinary concoction, most strange and new,
In the realm of Fallout, where all is anew.

Their victuals, a mishmash of East and West,
Do range from passable Chinese, at best,
To aberrant concoctions, a affront to the taste,
Like their Pad Thai, a sweet and soggy waste.

And alas, their bubble tea, a drink most fine,
Is marred by coconut milk, a heavy shrine,
That doth leave thee full, and wishing for the end,
Of this curious establishment, Lulu's, thy friend.

"O cursed place! how vile doth thy service prove,
Inconstant orders, Gina's mistakes do cloak,
And quality, alack! doth vary oft,
Items in short supply, a frequent thought."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of drug screens and waiting cold.
A new job didst depend on this test,
Yet the call, alas, would not connect.

Two days didst pass, and still no word,
The number listed, a curse, not heard.
So, forth I went, to take my place,
In line, to wait, with naught but grace.

An hour's wait, for just a minute's deed,
I asked, if perchance, I could speed.
But David, rude, with scorn didst say,
"Wait, or leave, no other way."

I explained, my plight, in vain,
The phones, he swore, didst work like a charm.
Thirty minutes passed, not a ring,
The place, a mess, the staff, uncivil.

Avoid this place, my friends, I pray,
For time, and patience, doth it away.
Nevermore shall I return,
This cursed spot, forever shall burn."

"Pros: The view doth please, and lo,  
The washroom's fancy paper towels do flow.  
The servers, too, with diligence they strive,  
And in their labors, they do take their time to thrive.  

Cons: Alas, all else doth falter, woe is me!  
The management, with their rough demeanor, be  
A pox upon the place, a blight upon the land,  
Their pseudo-tough guise, a farce, a sham, a ploy.  
The menu, too, doth lack, and doth dismay,  
And on a Monday night, their Football fray  
Doth pale, a shadow of its former might,  
A sorry sight, a spectacle without a fight.  

In this fair town, where choices abound,  
Why suffer Garfield's amateurish round?  
Save thee, dear patron, time and vexation,  
Take thy business elsewhere, with no hesitation."

"Hark! If thou dost desire a sluggish pace,
This place doth offer such disgrace.
Two workers, on the eve of Thanksgiving,
Doth serve a crowd, with naught but slowness bringing.

A hour or more, they doth await,
Their turn, in line, with anger and dismay.
Not cool, I say, not cool at all,
To keep them waiting, with naught to enthrall."

"Hark, my dearest wife and I, do dwell in Las Vegas, a city of vice and sin. I, a humble servant of Clark County, didst make a simple request, a non-smoking room, a chamber free from the foul odor of tobacco. And lo, the first two agents, didst accept my plea, without hesitation or query. But alas, their subsequent calls, didst drop, like autumn leaves from a tree. And thus, I didst speak with a third agent, a narcissist, full of pride and arrogance. She, didst quote policy and procedure, and didst refuse my request, with a smile so wide, it didst seem she didst take pleasure in my discontent. And thus, she didst hand me over, to her superior, a man of little power, who didst back her up, and offer a refund, a paltry sum, for the inconvenience caused. Alas, my dearest wife and I, have visited the Stratosphere, for seven years, and every time, we have been moved, to another room, for reasons most dire. A bottle of champagne, or special favors, we didst not ask, just a room, free from smoke and filth. But alas, Francisco, thou hast admitted, thy company doth not care, for its loyal customers, a sorrowful tale, indeed."

"Nay, nay, good sir! For forty pieces of silver, thou shalt find a feast most wondrous and fair elsewhere. We paid but twenty-eight and ninepence, and 'twas a sorry sight indeed. 

The oysters, dried up and withered, didst resemble not the fresh seafood I hadst hoped for. The clams and mussels, filled with grit and sand, didst taste not of the briny deep. The prime rib, devoid of flavor and zest, didst leave my taste buds in a state of disarray. And the sushi, tossed about like a common harlot, didst offend mine eyes. The desserts, a sorrowful sight, didst bring tears to mine eyes. 

And thus, good sir, I say to thee, nay! Never shall I set foot in this establishment again, forsooth!"

"Methinks I once didst take pleasure in this place,
But now, alas! My chicken pho doth leave a foul taste.
I asked the waitress, fair and gentle soul,
If I might cancel my order, forsooth,
And she, with scorn and disdain, didst reply,
"Thou hast eaten of thy chicken, dark and foul,
And now thou seekst to cancel it, oh fool?
Nay, we shall not exchange it, nor refund thee,
For our reputation and service, they be paramount, yea."

"Hark, what woe is this? My truck, it doth seem,
Hath been towed away, oh woeful dream!
I parked it near Jack in the Box, a space most rare,
And now it doth reside in some dark lair.

I entered Firehouse, my ire in full bloom,
And asked the staff, "Pray tell, why doth this woe beset me?"
They said, "Oh sir, 'tis common here, we do declare,
And signs doth warn of towing, beware!"

But nay, I say, such signs doth not suffice,
For who wouldst risk a meal, with towing in the balance?
No, 'tis a cruel fate, a practice most vile,
That doth not care for customers, nor doth it smile.

So heed my words, good people, shun this place,
Lest thou suffer likewise, in this parking space race."

Avoid this place, good sirs and madams,
For 'tis a den of thieves and scoundrels,
They'll take thy hard-earned coin, and give thee naught,
But falsehoods and deceit, to boot.

My carriage, once, didst break down,
And to this place, I didst take it,
For cooling air, it didst not make,
And thus, I sought their expertise.

They said a line didst leak, and fixing it,
Would cost me eight hundred crowns,
And more, they claimed, didst need repair,
Another eleven hundred, to be exact.

But lo, I didst not trust their words,
And sought a second opinion,
From another shop, where honesty didst reign,
And there, my problem, didst soon cease.

A mere o-ring, didst cause the fault,
And eighty-five crowns, didst pay the cost,
Oh, how the difference, doth astound,
Betwixt the two, so vast and wide.

So heed my warning, friends, and steer clear,
Of this establishment, false and dear,
For thou shalt find, in honesty and truth,
A better deal, and save thy youth.

"Fie upon this wretched place, where service doth falter and fail!
Upon the Saturday eve, the kitchen didst cease to prevail,
With naught but chaos and disarray, didst they attempt to regale.
And lo, the breakfast buffet of Sunday morn, didst bring
No sustenance, only woe and chagrin.
The entrance, too, didst bear the brunt of neglect and shame,
With rubbish piled high, a sorry sight, a blot upon the name.
I pray thee, good sirs, avoid this haven, for 'tis a pitiful sham,
And seek instead the haven of Scorpion Bay, where order doth reign supreme."

"Alas, my dearest love, how I do detest  
The stage shows and their gaudy finery!  
A plague upon the opera house, say I,  
For all its pomp and circumstance doth lie.  

My mind did wander, as the play did drag,  
And I did pine for liberty, my sweet.  
The costumes, though they sparkled bright,  
Did naught but blind mine eyes, alack!  

The pyrotechnics, too, did pierce mine ears,  
And made me cringe with fear and dismay.  
And thus, my love, I give this show but one,  
For all its flaws and tedious display.  

But, praise the food, my dearest Bouchon!  
For there, my hunger found its sweet reprieve.  
And so, my love, let us away,  
From these grand halls of artifice, I pray."

"A pox upon this company, say I, for 'tis a den of woe,
Wherein the CEO, a man named Morganson, doth reign supreme,
A tyrant of the first degree, whose tongue doth spew forth venom,
And with each cursing breath, doth make the workplace a living hell.

Oh, how his foul mouth doth pollute the air,
With 'F' and 'S' words, that doth besmirch the atmosphere,
So much so, that one doth feel enslaved, nay, naught but chattel,
Longing to escape, yet bound by duty, like a beast in thrall.

Verily, I say, avoid this place, lest thou wish to suffer,
For 'tis a pit of despair, where hope doth never flourish."

"Food, a paltry score of zero, I do declare,  
Service, alack, a similar tale of woe doth bear.  
Attitude, a negative ten, forsooth, doth show  
Crowd, a normal throng, yet naught but woe doth flow.  
Consistency, a lack thereof, doth make me sore,  
Bathrooms, the best part, a haven, I do adore.  
Overrated, aye, a truth most certain, I do swear.  

TOP 5 WORST RESTAURANT EXPERIENCES, a list most dire,  
A Buddha, small, yet manager, with Napoleon's fire.  
A massacre, of sorts, did occur, I do confess,  
Waterdog, the name, a memory most oppress.  
Eighteen souls, in taxis, from Wynn, they did stray,  
Arriving, to find, the place, half-empty, alas,  
The manager, a liar, with attitude, most vile,  
Did split the group, with malice, and a wicked smile.  

Threats, I did make, upon my honor, 'tis true,  
Yet, no fear, for there be many a fine eatery anew.  
Save your coins, and taxi fare, I do advise,  
For better dining, doth await, with open eyes."

"O, woeful night! No stars doth shine upon this place,
Where service falters and fare doth leave much to be desired.
The manager, with attitude most foul and unbecoming,
Doth make the experience even more unpleasant.
I pray thee, good sir, avoid this pit of woe,
For 'twill but bring thee sorrow and discontent.
Alas, the cooks, they know not how to prepare
A meal fit for a king, or even a commoner.
'Tis a shame, forsooth, that such a place doth exist,
But, verily, I say unto thee, find elsewhere to dine and revel."

"Thus didst I arrive in Madison, late y'tis true,
Due to a flight delayed, what could I do?
My hunger grew, as night drew on apace,
And thus I sought sustenance in this place.

A hotel directory, with ads didst it bear,
And thus I chose, a pizza to share.
But lo! They had no thin crust, strange indeed,
Yet still, my hunger urged me to proceed.

Their 'pan style' pizza, I didst then choose,
And waited patiently, as time didst lose.
An hour passed, and still no pizza came,
From three short blocks away, what a shame!

And when it arrived, oh how unfortunate,
The pizza was foul, most unpalatable.
I should have gone, to a gas station nigh,
For this pizza, was not worth a sigh."

"Alas, my dear friend, how my heart doth sink,
For the service at yonder downtown link,
Was slow and snotty, with nary a smile,
And the place, half empty, didst lack awhile.
The food, o'erpriced, didst not justify the cost,
I fear they seek to fleece the wealthy lost.
But still, my love for Squirrel Hill doth remain,
A gem amidst the city's busy strain."

"Hark! I do join the chorus of disdain,
For this bar doth leave much to be desired.
The staff, the patrons, all do proclaim,
A place most foul, where one doth fear to tread.

In throngs, I pushed, elbowing my way,
Through the masses, with nary a moment's grace.
And lo, a stranger didst grab my rump,
With a leer, and a comment most uncouth.

"Pass it on," quoth he, "to thy friend with the pert behind."
A pox upon his house, say I, for such a slight.
So, gentle friends, avoid this den of woe,
Unless thou art most direly in need of a drink, and nowhere else to go."

"O, woeful day! My love and I didst venture forth
To fair Catalina, for my natal day,
But lo, a tempest raged, and we were left
Stranded, with naught but sea and sky to ply.

The ferry and chopper, both didst cease to run,
And we, poor souls, were trapped, ere done.
I called the airline, praying for reprieve,
But they, cruel wretches, would not grant relief.

Four hundred crowns, they didst demand,
To change our flight, at their command.
O, bitter pill! My heart doth ache,
For Southwest, now, shall be my aim.

No more, my love, shall we fly with thee,
For thou hast shown thyself, most cruel, indeed.
So, farewell, thou wretched airline,
We shall ne'er again, thy services entwine."

"Methinks 'twas folly to expect good cheer
At yonder eatery, where BBQ doth reign.
A call the day before, to learn their hour,
And if they'd have three pounds of beef, in store.

"They said they'd open at eleven, and I,
In faith, didst make haste, to arrive ere two.
But lo! The sign didst say they opened late,
And I, in ire, didst curse my wretched fate.

"I called, in hope, to ask if they didst sell
The beef I sought, and if 'twould soon be tell.
A gent didst say they would, in truth, have some,
And I, in joy, didst hasten to consume.

"But alack! When I arrived, full twenty minutes past,
They said they had none left, and that was that.
No apology, nor sorrow, didst they show,
And thus, my heart doth bear a bitter woe.

"Two trips, in vain, didst I make, to find
No beef, nor cheer, to ease my mind.
I'll ne'er return, to that accursed place,
For they didst fail, in grace, and in their case."

"Fie upon this wretched place, Hakkasan by name,
Where we didst venture forth to celebrate my sister's flame.
The ladies, free they didst enter, but alack,
My husband, he didst pay full price, a sum most woeful and black.

The first DJ, a sorry soul, didst play tunes so slow,
Unfit for dancing, and thus our spirits didst grow low.
A cup of Coke and rum, a paltry sum, didst cost us dear,
Sixteen silver shillings, oh how the price didst pierce our ear!

The dance floor, packed it was, like sardines in a tin,
And thus we struggled, fifteen minutes, ere we couldst win.
Fire codes, I fear, were broken that fateful night,
So dangerously full, the crowd didst take flight.

Hardwell, the main DJ, came on at half past one,
But alas, the dance floor, then was done, and all was gone.
Ridiculous prices, verily, a total sham,
Hakkasan, a disappointment, a place to avoid, by all means, anon."

"Hark! What news is this? A tale of popcorn most vile,
Served here, they say, with nary a smile.
The Amer..Dental Association, a group most odd,
Must pay them well to serve this wretched fare, I've heard.
But fear not, dear friends, for there is hope yet,
For Cinemark popcorn, a treat most meet.
One cashier sells tickets, seven serve food,
A line most long, on Tuesday, 'twas no mood.
The theatres, fine, a place to see and be seen,
But alack! The popcorn, a travesty, I've been told."

"Tis a woeful tale, my friends, of woe and discontent,
Of a place in Vegas, where I didst recently dine,
A restaurant, they call it, but I say 'tis a sham,
For the service was poor, and the food but a scam.

The host, a man of little wit, didst tell us to wait,
For a table, he said, wouldst be ready in forty minutes,
But alas, an hour passed, and still we didst not sit,
And when we didst, the table was cold, and the waiter, a nit.

He sat us by the back door, where the wind didst howl,
And we asked to move, but he said there was no room,
So we moved ourselves, and waited twenty minutes more,
For the menus, that didst finally arrive, with a bore.

The music was loud, and most annoying, a din,
That didst pierce mine ears, and made me wring my hands within,
And the food, oh the food, it was but a mere morsel,
Not worth the price, nor the time, that we didst spend,

And the desserts, oh woe, they were not worth the taste,
For they were bland, and lacked the sweetness, that doth make haste,
So I say, my friends, avoid this place,
For 'tis not worth the time, nor the cost, that doth grace.

I'll ne'er return, for I do bear a grudge,
Against this place, that didst me such wrong,
So heed my words, and save thine own coin,
For this place, it doth not deserve thy patronage, nor thy tin."

"Fie upon this wretched place, my friends,
Where service doth border on incivility's edge.
We arrived full fifteen minutes ere our time,
Yet still they told us, 'Wait, and drink at the bar, forsooth.'
Now mark thee well, fair reader, there were tables aplenty,
Empty and waiting, yet they would not seat us.
Twenty minutes passed, and still we waited,
Till at last they brought us to a tiny table, hemmed in by others.
I prayed for a larger table, but alas,
'Twas reserved, they said, by some other soul.
Pray, let us flee this den of poor hospitality,
And seek a better feast at Ten Penny, up the street, where we did find
A spacious table, and a meal most fair and fine."

"Alack, what woeful fare did we receive,
For ten silver pieces, a meager serving,
Dry, stale lasagna, with nary a drop of sauce,
Did taste like store-bought, and not of the freshest,

Oh, how it grieved my heart, and did my belly ache,
To pay such price for such poor quality,
When but a short journey down the highway,
Lies a pizza joint, with far better fare,

At half the cost, and twice the taste,
Their pizza doth delight, and leave no waste,
So heed my words, good friends, and shun this place,
For better options there be, in this fair town's embrace."

"Hark, what discord doth mine ears perceive?
The kitchen crew, in fierce contention, do strive.
And lo, when my repast didst arrive,
The servers didst attend me not, nor didst they thrive.
Alack, the Larb, with onions overspread,
Didst taste of grittiness, and not of bread.
I finished but a third, with sorrow deep,
For such a meal, I didst not long to keep."

"Hark! A traveler lost in this fair town,
I chanced upon this eatery, thinking to dine well.
But lo! The parking lot did cause me woe,
And their menu, in tiny print, did make me squint and growl.
The lady at the counter, kind and fair,
Did list the sandwiches, patiently and with nary a care.
A ham and cheese on multi-grain, I did choose,
And asked that it be heated, as any man would do.
The service was swift, and soon I did depart,
But alas! The sandwich, a disappointment, did break my heart.
Two bites I took, and still, no meat did I find,
And the cheese, so scant, it seemed they did forget, or were blind.
The bread, a middling fare, yet not so fine,
As Blimpies or Port-o-Sub, where meat and cheese do shine.
Not worth the coin, I shall not return,
For Cousins, a poor cousin, indeed, does burn."

"O, woe is me! HHAGG, once my heart's desire,
Now doth my soul with bitter gall imbue.
Last eve, a visit to the place didst prove
A sorry tale of woe, a night most foul and rough.

The service, poor, the food, a sorry sight,
Didst leave me in a state of deepest plight.
The waitress, slow, didst make a grievous mistake,
And brought us not the dishes we didst partake.

Thirty minutes passed, and still no sign
Of appetizers, which didst cause great ire and pine.
And when I saw, with mine own eyes,
Food brought to others, later come, and greater numbers, rise,
I didst demand of thee, fair waitress, why
They had their feast, and we didst tarry?

She argued, nay, 'twas not, and would not be,
But I, with steadfast mind, didst still decree,
Three times, I saw it, and would not relent,
Until, at last, she didst repent.

Ten minutes more, and still our food didst wait,
And eight, ere my daughter's plate didst arrive, late.
We left, at last, at half past eight,
With hunger sated, but hearts in discontent and hate.

Alas, poor HHAGG, once my heart's delight,
Now doth my soul with sorrow take flight.
Seven years of loyalty, now doth fade,
For such poor service, I cannot be stayed."

"Alas, our flight didst take off late, by 1.5 hours, alack!
And, to add insult to injury, 'twas Southwest, with naught but light snacks to sate mine hunger.
Aye, I didst wait 1.5 hours, and then didst endure a 5-hour flight,
Without a meal to comfort me, or make mine spirits bright.
I fear, fair friends, this experience doth not bode well for Southwest's Yelp review,
Forsooth, 'twill be a tale of woe, and naught but discontent, I do suspect."

"Hark, what news is this? A burger, dry and tasteless,
The Spanish dip, o'er salted, doth assault my senses.
Not worth the price, nor worth the time to dine,
But, ha! The sporting crowd, their revelry doth shine.
A place to watch, a place to cheer, a place to be,
But, alas, not a place for culinary glee."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, fair friends,  
When first I didst venture to this wretched place,  
Wherein they call'd themselves a "restaurant",  
Yet served us but a sorry, woeful feast.  
The service, poor and slow, didst take its toll,  
Our patience worn thin, as we didst wait and wait,  
For drinks, for food, for aught that might appease  
Our hunger, raging like a fierce beast within.  
And when at last the victuals didst arrive,  
'Twas spoiled, corrupted, foul and rancid,  
A stench that didst assail mine nostrils, making me  
To spit it out, in disgust and utter woe.  
They offered to prepare a new dish, in haste,  
But I, in ire, didst refuse, and wouldst not partake.  
So, after more delay, we didst depart,  
With naught but woe and bitter disappointment in our hearts.  
I say, dear friends, avoid this place,  
For 'tis a den of woe, a pit of despair,  
And thou shalt find no solace nor delight  
In this most wretched, sorry excuse for a tavern."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall our feast,
With dishes half-cooked, and half-tasted at best.
The kitchen, in disarray, didst send away
All chefs, save one, ere we didst partake.
A party of fourteen, they didst undertake,
Yet, forty minutes late, they didst make us wait.
And when they finally didst bring forth the fare,
'Twas poorly cooked, and service, quite rare.
No bread, nor entrees, didst they provide,
A frozen loaf, they didst proffer, with pride.
Oh, how the heat of anger didst rise within,
At such a state, of culinary sin.
I, a New Yorker, do not mind the cost,
For good food, my coin, I do not boast.
But, alas, this place, doth not deserve my pay,
For crappy food, they doth charge, each day."

"Hark, good sir! Thou Pho noodles be soggy, doth thou reckon? Alack, 'tis a sign the cook doth not wash them well with cold water, after boiling. Fie upon these spring rolls, forsooth, they be not of great worth, methinks."

"A pox upon this tavern, where I sought to quench my thirst,
But found instead a lack of service, and naught but disdain.
The bartender, heedless of my plight, didst ignore me still,
Though business was slow, and time didst hang heavy on his hands.
I waited nigh ten minutes, and not a word didst he speak,
No greeting, nor a promise to attend to me anon.
This place shall nevermore receive my coin, nor shall I recommend
To any soul who seeketh a tavern of good repute and cheer.
Forsooth, 'tis a den of neglect, and I do vow to spread the word."

"O, woe is me! This buffet, so vile and base,
Doth make my stomach churn and my taste buds flee.
It brings to mind a comic strip of old,
Where Russians, shamed, did walk of shame, their tale told.

In like manner, should Caesar's Palace do,
Replace these cooks, their skills not worth a farthing or two.
The pork, so dry, and prime rib, inedible too,
And apples, old and brown within, who'd have them anew?
The three bean salad, cilantro-sprinkled, alack!
I shall post pictures, that all may see and lack.

Alas, this buffet, worst of all in Vegas' bounds,
Shall be remembered not for its culinary renown,
But for its shame, its failure, its disgrace,
A warning to all, a poor showing, a sorry place."

"Tsk, tsk, good sir! Thou dost complain of orders small?\nAye, verily, I did recommend Freed's, for their confections were most fair and their service, excellent, or so I thought. But lo, upon our visit from the Golden State, the treatment we received was naught but poor, alack! The bride-to-be, unscheduled, did wait in vain, and when at last her turn arrived, the meager offering proffered left much to be desired. A dollop of cake, a dab of frosting, and two paltry fillings, pshaw! I had planned to order a cake for our anniversary, a grand affair, no less, but alas, we did decide to take our business elsewhere, to Hansen's in L.A., where they did show us true appreciation. Freed's, methinks, doth merit not a single star."

"Terrible service, a plague upon this place!
The manager took our order, then vanished without a trace.
A cocktail waitress brought our nachos, a paltry feast,
Twenty minutes passed, a time most unreasonable, I reckon.
My love requested a beer, a simple, modest boon,
But she, the waitress, acted as if quite put upon.
Her gaze did turn away, her steps did quickly flee,
As if our presence caused her utmost discomfort, 'twas plain to see.
We, who labor in the service industry ourselves,
Didst feel most vexed and disappointed by her conduct, I confess.
Our dinner order, we didst cancel, and asked for the bill,
The manager, with apologies, didst explain their plight,
One cook, they had, and he, quite busy, didst toil.
But drinks, we never had the chance to order, alack!
Forty dollars, for two beers, a martini, nachos, and a soup,
A price most steep, for such poor service, we didst not dup.
Never again, shall we return to this accursed place,
For service, worthy of the name, we do expect, in fairness."

"A deal was proffered me, a plan of net,
To stream videos, and such like, for a fee,
Of twenty-nine dollars, ninety-nine cents,
A sum most fair, and reasonable, to my mind.

But lo, when I did call to make an appointment,
To set up service, and all that jazz,
I was told, by one who seemed quite pert,
That thirty-four ninety-five, was the new price, alas!

I, taken aback, didst query, why the change?
And was informed, by one most strange,
That nothing could be done, to alter the cost,
For it was set, and thus, it must be lost.

I say, good sirs, this is not the way,
To treat a customer, with such dismay,
Honor thy word, and keep thy promise true,
For else, thy reputation, shall suffer, anon, adieu!"

"Hark, what chaos doth unfold before mine eyes! A reservation made for five, yet they prepare but four. The hostess, unmoved by our plight, doth tell us to await a table fit for five, some forty-five minutes hence. My husband, off to fetch the show's tickets, doth leave me to contend with this fiasco. Our waiter, kindness personified, doth prepare a place for him upon his return. Yet, alas! The front staff, with rudeness unabashed, doth mar our evening's joy. The victuals, middling at best, doth fail to compensate for such poor hospitality. Our waiter, a shining star amidst this darkness, doth earn our gratitude."

"Methinks my wife and I didst wish to dine at this establishment, and thus didst I call to inquire of any availability for luncheon. The reservationist, with haste, didst reply that naught but a brief journey to the venue would be required, for there was no waiting list. Alas, upon our arrival, the hostess didst inform us that a delay of forty-five minutes would ensue ere we could partake of sustenance. Methinks the reservationist might have spared us the trouble of a lengthy excursion from fair Summerlin, had she but spoken the truth in timely fashion."

"This place doth not belong to corporate hands,
The service here, I must confess, doth falter.
We sat, and waited, nigh on ten good minutes,
Ere a server came to us, with drinks to tender.
The eatery was not bustling, full of folk,
Yet still our waitress didst behave like a stroppy churl.
I asked for ranch, a humble condiment,
And lo! They charged me for each tiny portion.
A survey I didst fill, with hopes of saving five,
But alas! This place, it seems, doth not comply.
They offer but four dollars off, a paltry sum,
And change the price of wings, to snack, small, medium, and large, anon.
My son and I, we shared twenty-four wings,
A price of nineteen ninety-nine, a pretty penny's sting.
Now, large portions, twenty-one wings, the same price,
A change most vexing, and quite beyond my wits to gauge."

"O, woeful day! What poor service doth this place provide?
Niru and Palak, who work and mayhap own the site,
Do lack the skills of customer service, I do declare.
Their attitude doth stink, their service doth leave much to desire.
A loyal patron, I shall nevermore return,
For their behavior doth merit naught but scorn.
I give them one star, lest they think me mad,
But truth be told, their service doth deserve naught but sad."

"Hark, what chaos doth this place possess?
A multitude of folk, nary a soul to assist.
Check well thy purchases, lest they be past their prime,
For oft have I found spoilage, and moldy cheese, a crime!
Alas, I shall ne'er return, for fear of such foul play."
