"Methought we would essay the fare they served,
A coupon we possessed, 'twas theirs, not ours.
Inside we sat, the waitress took our order,
But soon the master or manager did appear.
He said the coupon, valid though it were,
He would not honor, and our hopes did dash.
I felt deceived, and so we did depart,
For other Chinese eateries there be in town,
Aplenty, and for mere dollars, a new heart,
But nay, they did not want our business, alack.
I ever thought that coupons brought new guests,
But there, 'twas not the case, and so our feast
Was ruined, and our appetites did wane.
Alas, poor management doth bring such woe."

"Fie upon this wretched meal! My stomach doth protest, my taste buds do revolt! The lobster, chewy and fishy-smelling, did offend mine senses sore. And when I did request a fried egg on top, they would not oblige, nor did they offer any other choice. The quiche, cold in the center, tasted of microwave's heat. A Cobb salad and blueberry muffin we did then entreat, hoping they would be a safer bet. Alas, the salad was small, the bacon fat unpleasant to bite, and the muffin, dry and burnt, as if from microwave's blast. Our lunch, a sorry sight, did leave us discontent and still, no manager did come to make amends. A pox upon this place, a plague upon their menu, a curse upon their cooks, a bitter taste that doth linger still!"

"Methinks 'tis folly to expect much joy
In yonder cinema, where discomfort doth abound.
The seats, they do reek of poor design,
With naught but a plate of victuals on thy lap,
And a cold, hard floor beneath thy feet.

The fare, it doth leave much to be desired,
A scant portion of hummus, with stale pita chips beside.
And for a draught of ale, they do demand
A princely sum of seven dollars and fifty cents!

But lo, the rules they do enforced with great strictness,
No drinks within the hall, lest children be offended.
And though the movie were of adult persuasion,
We were not free to partake of ale or wine.

The seating, it was a puzzle, full of darkness and despair,
We found two seats together, but a manager didst declare
That they were special, and we must needs pay more,
Or be cast out, to suffer in the second row.

Alas, the picture, it was but a pale imitation,
A poor display, with naught but shadows and distortion.
They must employ a guard, to check the tickets of those
Who dare to sit in seats they cannot afford to lose.

In conclusion, 'twas a sorry experience indeed,
A night of woe, with naught but discontent and chagrin.
I pray thee, good sir, avoid this place,
And seek thy entertainment elsewhere, in haste!"

"Easter's gift, a parcel swiftly sent,
Must reach its destination ere the event.
I stressed this urgency, and they did consent,
To ship it fast, with haste and diligence.
But lo! On Saturday, a sorry sight,
The package lingered still, without flight.
For though they promised swiftness, they did fail,
And now my trust in them doth wane and pale."

"O, what a wretched inn! I do confess,
I's glad I chose another lodging near MGM,
For here, the staff, though kind and fair,
Could not make up for the state of disrepair.
A fire, perchance, or renovation dire,
Is needed here, to lift it from its woeful plight.
In this fair town, there be better inns,
With prices lower, and amenities in abundance."

Greg Lancaster doth speak his mind,
A tale of woe, a warning to find.
'Tis of the Watts Premier Reverse Osmosis Water Filter System,
A product that doth waste, with no remorse or pity.

Four gallons of water, it doth discard,
For every one gallon, it doth purify, oh so hard.
Enviromentally friendly, thou art not,
A fact that doth make mine blood doth boil and hot.

Watts, thou shouldst print this truth in large,
Upon the box, for all to see and to discern.
But alas, they may not sell,
When consumers read, their hearts doth melt.

So, back to Costco, the system I shall return,
For a full refund, my money to earn.
And instead, a PUR system, I shall procure,
To quench my thirst, with no waste, pure.

Thus, let this be a lesson, to all who can hear,
To choose wisely, and not to fear.
The voice of Greg Lancaster, doth speak the truth,
A message clear, for all to reap the proof.

"Hark! My review doth need rewriting, methinks. 

In sooth, my check-in process didst take an age, 
Two hours and a half, to be precise, by Jove! 
No word of warning didst they give, nor didst they say 
When I didst sign up for it, what's more, 'twas a fray. 
My car, it didst emerge swiftly, and thus didst I 
Expect it ready, but alack! 'Twas not to be. 
The only soul who showed concern was he 
Who rung me up, a kind and gentle man, by th' look. 
Twice didst he venture forth, and at the second time 
I didst express my ire, and he didst note, methought. 
He offered naught but words, a sorry tale, indeed. 
No discount or such didst he proffer, nor didst he heed 
My plea to tell his staff to inform folk in need. 
Thus, I do vow, ne'er shall I return, nor shall 
Mine own self use their services e'er again, by th' Lord above!"

"Twas naught but a chance to gaze upon the rabble,
In their native land of frivolity and waste.
A feeble melody, by fortune's grace,
Did little justice to the company's taste.
Beer flowed in abundance, yet no sweet delight,
For those who sought to quench their thirst with might.
And lo, the men, with skin of ink so dark,
Did strut and preen, as if to prove their spark.
The women too, with faces pinched and tight,
Did pout and pose, in futile hope to excite.
All this, to flaunt their supposed greatness wide,
Upon the pages of that wondrous book, called Facebook, side by side."

A long queue at yonder Starbucks didst prompt me to seek refuge in DD's embrace, in search of a refreshing frozen tea lemonade. The cashier, a curious soul, didst ask me thrice to repeat mine order, despite the grand display in the window that didst proudly proclaim its virtue. The order filler, a man of few words, didst present me with a cup of murky brew, and with a quizzical look, didst say, "Here's thy ice tea, good sir." I, in turn, didst query the whereabouts of the lemonade, a vital component of mine order, as I hadst been led to believe. The cashier, with a hint of incredulity, didst confirm mine suspicions, and the order filler, with a dash of sheepishness, didst return with a beverage of paler hue. Alas, one sip of the concoction didst reveal its true nature, a vile impostor, akin to Lysol in taste and consistency. In disgust, I didst discard the offending draught, and with haste, didst depart the premises, my thirst unquenched. Fie upon thee, false lemonade!

"Oh woeful day! The wait, it doth prolong,
And staff, they doth seem most wretched and forlorn.
Perhaps 'tis due to Dr Alfreda's deceit,
A scoundrel, preying on the elderly and meek.

I sought his care, with hopes of finding a new guide,
But alas, my visit did not turn out as I'd decided.
Forty-five minutes passed, and still I waited,
Until at last, the doctor did condescend to greet me.

He looked within my ear, and claimed there was some wax,
A task a humble q-tip could have done, no need to ax.
And yet, a month hence, a bill did come my way,
For seventy-five dollars, oh what a scandalous display!

A scam, a sham, a travesty, I do declare,
Dr Alfreda, shame upon thy name, forevermore!"

"Upon the thirtieth day of August, my spouse and I did dine
At yonder tavern, where we didst order three
Tacos, soft and savory, or so I didst believe
But lo, my husband didst decree they were not as agreed
And thus, a quarrel didst arise betwixt us twain
Concerning the tacos, and their softness, or lack thereof
The lass who served us, didst profess she knew not
Of any such request, and thus, a dispute didst ensue
I didst offer to pay more, for the mistake, fair and square
But she, in turn, didst declare she wouldst discard the fare
And leave me with naught but a bitter taste
In my mouth, and a sour mood, to boot
I didst converse with the company, in hope of redress
But alas, they didst ignore my plea, in utter disregard
For customer service, it seemeth, is not their concern
And thus, I do implore, dear friends, beware
Of this establishment, and its rude, uncaring crew
Lest ye too, fall prey to their neglect, and suffer woe."

"Beware, good traveler, of this hotel's deceit,
Which didst play false with my reservation, neat.
A non-smoking room, I didst request,
But they, with guile, didst give me quite a test.

A smoking suite, they didst proffer, rank,
Which didst make my love, in nausea, sink.
After much debate, they found a room, less vile,
Yet still, the stench of smoke, didst linger, awhile.

At checkout, I found my reservation, void,
And prices, inflated, beyond what I enjoyed.
The clerk, with attitude, didst make a remark,
And slammed his card, with vehemence, on the desk.

Now, to Best Western, I do write,
To learn of policies, that might end this plight.
For honesty, in business, should be the rule,
And travelers, like myself, should not be fooled."

This was a woeful encounter, full of slow service and naught but disdain from those who tended to our needs. Alas, the viands were scant and of poor quality, leaving us in a state of utter dissatisfaction. Fie upon this wretched tavern! May it rot and wither like a once-fresh flower left to wither in the sun.

"A plague upon this wretched rental car company,
Their service doth leave much to be desired, I do declare.
An hour didst I spend, in line, awaiting my turn,
No urgency didst they show, their pace most slow and stern.
My carriage, though functional, was dirty and foul,
A butter knife in the seat, their cleanliness didst lack,
The windshield, too, didst bear the grime of neglect,
A sorry state, indeed, didst this rental car present.
Upon my return, some thirty minutes didst pass,
Ere the shuttle arrived, with nary a moment to spare,
And on that conveyance, all twenty passengers didst voice
Their discontent, in chorus, at this woeful choice.
I shall not use them more, forsooth, this vow I make,
For better service, elsewhere, shall my search now take."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, I say to thee, avoid this place, lest thou desirest to waste thy hard-earned coin. The victuals they serve, mark thee well, are o'erpriced and of poor quality. The beans, alack, are overcooked, and the tortillas, by my troth, do seem stale. Moreover, the server, a pox upon his house, doth provide most wretched service. In sooth, 'tis a pitiful establishment, not worth thy time or money. Heed my words, fair traveler, and seek sustenance elsewhere."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of service poor, and manners cold.
A burger fair, and beer most chill,
Didst tempt me in, with appetite still.

But lo! On Friday eve, a sight,
Didst mar my thoughts, and leave me quite irate.
The waitress, with a scowl so deep,
Didst take our order, and with haste, didst seize.

She snatched the menus from mine hand,
Without a word, or gentle touch, so grand.
I bid her lose the attitude, forthwith,
And rose, to leave, with spirit somewhat stith.

Alas! I do not seek perfection,
Nor service of the highest section.
But rudeness, and such haughty air,
Doth drive me hence, with naught but despair.

In sooth, I shall not return,
For principle doth guide my every concern.
A shame, indeed, for I didst enjoy,
This place, with food and drink, so employ."

"Beware, good sirs and madams! I pray thee, heed my words of woe. Forsooth, my spouse and I didst lodge at Planet Hollywood Resort, And lo, their minions didst pilfer a costly pair of boots, Whilst my dear wife was borne away to tend her sudden ills. Alas, poor service! Fie upon their knavish tricks!"

"Beware, dear traveler, of the service most vile,
In Las Vegas' city, where prices doth beguile.
For food of poor worth, they do demand a steep fee,
And leave thee with naught but discontent and woe.

If sweet desserts be thy quest in Caesar's domain,
Seek out the Cheesecake Factory, 'neath the Forum's reign.
There, thou shalt find solace in their delectable fare,
And leave with a heart full of joy, and not despair."

"A pox upon this place, where bitter brew doth flow! 
For six silver pieces, I didst receive 
A cup of Americano, with flavors burnt and low. 
Not worth the cost, I do declare, ne'er to return again, farewell!"

"A pizza, soggy and doughy, didst arrive at my doorstep,
And with it, a host of other dishes, all equally poor.
The wings, jalape\u00f1o poppers, and fried cucumbers,
Didst fail to impress, and left me in a sour mood.

The customer service, a jest, a mockery,
Didst only add to my discontent and woe.
I shall not return, nor recommend this place,
To any soul, for fear of their disgrace."

"Alack, what woeful fortune doth beset my day!
The weekend, once a time of joy and bliss,
Hath now become a trial of dismay.
Forsooth, the wine, that sweet and savory delight,
Which erst did grace our table with its presence bright,
Hath vanished, leaving naught but bitter disappointment in its stead.
And lo, the waiter, who didst attend our needs with slowness great,
Didst bring to me, with tardiness most vexing,
A sauvignon blanc, of which I didst not partake,
For it was gone, and none other couldst supply its place.

My chicken torta, once a dish of renown,
Didst fail to please, with flavors scarce and few,
It lacked the zest, the verve, the tang,
That maketh a true torta, worthy of the name.
I prayed for mayonnaise, to save it from despair,
But alas, 'twas naught but woe and sorrow that didst fill the air.

The service, slow and laggard, didst complete the tale,
Of disappointment, of discontent, of woe unutterable.
The building, grand and fair, the patio, spacious and bright,
The chance to buy fresh produce, a delight most true,
Yet, with such high prices, and food so poor,
I fear I shall not return, nor seek this place anew.
But, lo, the table salsas, a saving grace,
Didst bring a smile, a moment's joy, to this sad face."

"My wife did take our younglings to yon barber,
For haircuts, as custom doth require.
But lo, the lass who did the deed,
Didst leave, and none could her acquire.
We thought not much of it, and went along,
But oh, the woe that did ensue!
Her replacement, a gruff and grumpy soul,
Could not abide my son's tears, nor his role.
'Tis true, the lad did move and cry,
As two-year-olds are wont to do, by and by.
But she, with scowls and mutterings dire,
Didst fling him forth, with nary a clipping to spare.
And so, we sought another place,
Where skilled barbers did their art embrace.
Cool Cuts, the name, doth ring a bell,
And there, our tresses were trimmed well.
We shall not return, alas,
For that gruff barber, we shall not miss."

"Oh, woe is me! Imagine, if thou canst,
The foulest stench that doth assault thy senses,
Tenfold worse, it doth surround thee, burning
Thy nostrils, as it doth enter thy body.

Alack, the staircase outside our chamber,
Doth reek with odors most vile and loathsome,
As if some crazy wretch, in drunken haze,
Had urinated all o'er the steps, and then,
Some beast did meet its end, and he,
In his madness, did pour forth his stream,
Upon the lifeless form, in wild abandon.

Alas, we did hold our breath, in fear,
As we did climb those fetid stairs, praying
To escape alive, and unscathed, from death's grasp.

But, alack, the hotel doth leave much to be desired,
With parking scarce, and rooms that doth show their age,
And elevators, slow and cramped, that doth affright
Those who do suffer from claustrophobia's grip.

Yet, on the bright side, 'tis a truth,
They shall raze the hotel, and build anew,
A brand-new edifice, with modern grace,
To banish forth the stench, and bring a smile to thy face."

"A foul pit of ineptitude, a den of dolts,
Where simple tasks become Herculean feats.
An hour didst pass, and still my chariot gleamed not,
For each dim-witted lackey I didst encounter, 'twas a woeful treat.
Their words, a jumble of incoherence, didst betray
Their ignorance, a stain upon their souls, a blight.
A company most vile, a disgrace to all,
That doth employ such creatures, void of wit and gall."
"Four times didst I seek their aid, yet naught but woe didst they bring. Still doth the problem plague me, and their assistance, a mere sham."

"Alas, my friends, what woeful tale I tell,
Of Zumanity, a show most foul and vile.
I've seen Cirque du Soleil before,
But this one, alack, did leave me poor.
From LA I hail, and guests did bring,
To witness beauty, or so I did think.
But nay, dear friends, 'twas not to be,
For this show, it did disappoint me.
Six tickets I did purchase, full of hope,
But now, alas, I do regret, and wish for a refund, aye, a refund most dire."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir or madam, that this company doth merit naught but zero stars, anon! Forsooth, the owners thereof, they be scoundrels most foul, untrustworthy and rude, and in their dealings with thy property, they shall prove most inept. By my troth, I swear upon mine honor, that I shall gladly share the tale of our woeful encounter with any who doth desire to hear it. And, by the way, I shall not fail to report them to the Better Business Bureau, forthwith!"

"O, woe is me! In fair Montreal, I chanced upon a restaurant of Indian fare, whose service was most vile and wretched. Verily, 'twas over an hour ere our victuals were brought forth, and alack, the food itself didst leave much to be desired. Fie upon this place! 'Tis not worth thy time or coin, good sir!"

"Alack, our first encounter here was but a middling affair,
But breakfast this morn did earn a single star, I do declare.
Eggs and oatmeal we did order, with care and precision,
Explaining full cooking, lest they be a disappointin' vision.

Thirty minutes passed, and naught but lukewarm oatmeal did arrive,
With eggs still runny, like a river that doth not cease to strive.
We spoke again of eggs, and they did promise to remake,
Yet twenty minutes more, and still they were not well-baked.

The eggs, they took from the bill, with haste and little fuss,
But my oatmeal, alas, did cost a pretty penny, I must confess.
In truth, 'twas over twenty dollars, a sum quite steep,
Yet eager to depart, I did not question, nor did I sleep."

"O, what a woeful sight doth greet mine eyes! 
A place we gave another chance, and lo, 
'Twas naught but wretched disappointment that doth rise. 
Eighty percent of tables full, we sat with haste, 
And waited patiently for service of the feast. 
But alas, ten minutes passed, and naught but water came, 
And then, another ten, ere our server did proclaim 
The orders taken, and we did wait some more, 
Until at last, our drinks did arrive, and then, 
Fifteen minutes more, ere food did grace our plates, 
But lo, they brought but half the meal, and we did wait, 
Awkwardly, until the rest did finally come, 
With cheese o'errunning, and a shrimp dish foul, 
And chicken tacos, stale and bare, without a scrap 
Of pico de gallo or guacamole, to give a rap. 
A beer, too, we ordered, but it came not till 
We finished eating, and our patience did grow thin. 
So here's the rub, my friends, servers need training, 
And menu items must be re-evaluated, ere we dine again."

"Fare thee well, good sirs and madams! Forsooth, the victuals here be savory and fine, but lo, the prattle of the serving folk doth grate upon mine ear. In sooth, they sit at table next to us, devouring their repast with gusto, while their coarse converse doth pierce mine eardrums like a thousand tiny daggers. By my troth, I shall ne'er return to this establishment, for their discourse hath lost them my custom, and my ire doth know no bounds!"

This lodging doth disturb our restful slumber,
With noise that doth pierce the night's dark veil.
A room, designated non-smoking, doth reek
Of foul smoke, like a miasma, that doth assail.
The proprietor, with parsimony unseemly,
Doth deny us towels, with a stingy hand.
He saith, "Do me a favor, use the soiled ones,"
And grudgingly, but two, doth grant to us.
Though three we be, he doth declare, "No more."

"Hark, what woe is this? A tale of woe and sorrow doth unfold.
A two-hour wait, and ten minutes more, for oil and wash to be told.
I gave them but a single star, for none couldst I give less.
And now, my friends, heed my words, and shun this place, lest ye be blessed.
Forsooth, 'tis a wicked fate, to wait so long and patiently.
And thus, my dear companions, heed my warning, and flee this place, ere ye be smitten."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern, vile and base,
Where food, scarce fit for hogs, doth grace the place.
A plague upon the menu, false and misleading,
That doth deceive with prices, unjust and unheeding.

But lo, a greater wrong doth claim my ire,
For at the table next, a margarita didst fire
A dispute, most bitter,'mongst the guests,
For salt, a simple thing, didst cause such strife and unrest.

The bartender, a knave, with wicked intent,
Didst refuse to take the drink, or make amend,
But sought to wipe away the salt, with naught but spite,
And leave the patron, in a state of dire plight.

Oh, how the service, poor and lacking, doth fail,
In this, a place of business, that doth set sail
Upon the seas of commerce, with a crew so rude,
And leave its patrons, in a state of disarray, confused."

"Hark! I rate this place upon its fare,
A giant pretzel, priced at fourteen crowns,
Didst not seem worth the cost, perhaps but seven or eight,
The beer, a fair price, eight crowns doth make it right.
Lemonade, a paltry three crowns doth seem,
But here's the rub, a glass of water, nay,
You must pay three crowns and forty-nine pence,
For a bottle, lest ye wish to quench thy thirst in vain,
A feeble policy, most lame and weak,
When purchasing drinks, a glass of water seek."

"Tis a sorry state of affairs, my friends, that I do find myself in,
With pizza most foul, that doth offend mine eyes and taste.
A handful of times, I have ordered from this place,
And each time, it hath gotten worse, with nary a trace of grace.

Tonight, I vow, shall be the last time I do order,
For the pizza, it doth resemble nothin' more than a burnt, dry board.
No sauce, no flavor, naught but burnt cheese and crust,
That doth break apart, like autumn leaves, when I do thrust.

Alas, I didst think I loved the crust, but now I see,
'Tis naught but a sham, a mockery of pizza, a travesty.
Little Caesars, thou art a pale imitation,
Of true pizza, with sauce and toppings, in a harmonious relation.

So, farewell, pizza of ill repute,
Thou shalt not tempt me again, with thy burnt, dry crust and lack of sauce.
I shall seek out better pizza, with a heavy heart,
For this, my friends, is truly a sorry state of affairs, and a bitter start."

"Hark! What woeful tale doth mine eyes perceive?
Alack! In this place, such language barriers doth thrive.
'Twas night, and six o'clock, the hour of sustenance,
Yet naught but woes didst our visitation advance.

Firstly, a dearth of English speakers doth abound,
In places where communication doth resound.
This caused a multitude of troubles, by my troth,
For those before us, their orders doth take forth.

Their struggles, oh so great, didst cause much delay,
While other employees doth stand and dally away.
At last, our turn doth come, and we doth say,
"Two salad bars and soup, if thou wouldst pray."

But lo! Our order doth take its sweet time,
And we, in waiting, doth feel quite maligned.
We doth walk down, to the end of the counter,
And there, a man doth point, with nary a mutter.

"'Twill be brought to thy table, he doth say,
But lo! Five minutes pass, and naught doth come our way.
We doth return, and still, no soup doth grace,
Our empty bowls, alas! What a sorry race!

Five more minutes pass, and still, no sign,
Of soup, or even a single bowl of shine.
So, back we go, and find our soup, at last,
But empty bowls, alack! How poor a feast!

This place, it doth require, a staff that doth speak,
The language of the land, with ease and seek.
And not, fifteen minutes, or more, doth take,
To bring two bowls, and a cup of soup, forsooth!
Especially, when the restaurant doth lie,
In such an empty state, with naught to deny."

"Fie upon this wretched place! My friends and I didst venture hither, ere we didst take our leave for Marquee's festive halls. The sushi house didst bustle with activity, so we didst choose this eatery instead. We didst order three dishes to share - the chorizo-wrapped potato, white asparagus, and patatas bravas. Alas, the victuals didst prove most vile and loathsome, so much so that we didst forego our main courses and depart in hunger's pangs. Farewell, foul establishment!"

"Hark, what woe is this? A tale of woe and sorrow,
Of a simple order, that didst cause such trouble,
With Erik, I didst place it, and waited patiently,
But lo, the server, with a mind so dull and slow,
Didst struggle mightily, to take it down aright,
And thus, the whole group suffered, with nary a brain in sight.

Oh, wouldst thou be annoyed, and eat at this Popeyes?
Forsooth, the owner shouldst go on mystery dinners,
And see, how his profits, wouldst double in a trice,
If he didst rid himself, of the current crew,
And hire some leadership, with a bit of wit and grace."

"Alas, good sir or madam, I do implore,
In Cox's customer service, stars minus four!
For though they claim to hear our every plea,
Their actions show they do not give a care,
They hang up on thee, four times, by my count,
And when thou dost request a fair amount,
They add on fees, like birds that flock and swoop,
Leaving thee with naught but woe and ruth,
And loyalty, it seems, doth not exist,
For they do blame the customer, with no twist.
I pray, good sir or madam, take my word,
And shun this company, with its poor regard."

"A plague upon this wretched tavern, wherefore doth service falter?
A host of guests we were, yet waited we an hour or more,
For wine, a bottle of which didst I request, in vain didst I implore.
And when at last it came, 'twas naught but vinegar, a vile draught.
I asked instead for bourbon, and didst wait yet again,
Twenty minutes passed, my patience didst wear thin.
Two hours hadst elapsed, and still, my meal didst not begin.
The lighting, bright as day, didst make me feel within a hall,
My bill, a hundred crowns, for mere appetizer, main course, and drinks, a sum most foul.
Overpriced, this place, and service, brutal, say I."

Oh, what a woeful sight did greet mine eyes,
Upon the eve of rest, when all should be bright.
A pair of souls did man the front desk, alas,
And lo, a serpentine queue did thus entwine.
Their turn, at last, did come, and oh, how vexed
Were they, who could not find our reservation's trace.
The manager, a surly fellow, did speak,
With scant regard for guests, his words did shriek.
"Thou shall pay three hundred fifty gold coins," quoth he,
For this, a chamber in their humble abode, so meager.
To Monte Carlo, then, we did repair,
Where warmth and hospitality did await, without demur.

"Alas, what woe hath befallen this place,  
That once didst serve such delectable dishes!  
A sushi and bento paradise, 'twas,  
But now, alack, 'tis naught but shadows.  

The introduction of AYCE, perchance,  
Hath caused Kaizen's quality to decline.  
Their sushi, still decent, yet not as before,  
And other dishes, oh, how they do suffer!  
Chicken Katsu, once crispy and divine,  
Now flat and dry, a sorry sight, indeed.  
Chicken teriyaki, a sweet stir-fry,  
Yet rice, hard as stone, and salad, o'er-dressed.  

Our waitress, though sporty, knew not the menu,  
And service, haphazard, didst leave much to be desired.  
Food arrived at different times, disorganized,  
A sorry state, indeed, and cause for despair.  

In conclusion, a poor experience, indeed,  
AYCE, a focus, that doth all else impede.  
A rethinking of business practices, I pray,  
Lest Kaizen fall, and fade away."

"Pray, good sir, forgive my plight,
Forsooth, I found myself in filth this night.
A sorry state, indeed, and one most vile,
In a chamber foul, with naught but soil.

I pray thee, let us flee this wretched place,
And leave behind the stench that doth embrace.
For in this room, they take the hound apart,
To give him shots, a cruel deed, and one most dark.

Nay, I do not return, for fear of more,
Of such foul treatment, and the stink that doth pour.
Let us away, to places fair and bright,
Where cleanliness doth reign, and all is right."

"Upon a day most free, I chanced to visit this museum of natural history. Alas, my expectations were not met, forsooth. A plague of screaming brats did doth my ears assail, and their elders, with nary a care, didst allow them to run wild and chafe. Displays, once grand, now lay in disarray, with naught a thought to order or design. Signage, too, didst leave much to be desired, and thus, my understanding of the exhibits was clouded. Dinosaurs, in all their might, didst still impress, yet minerals, though beautiful, didst lack coherence. Strange, too, the inclusion of Native American artifacts and a jail, within these hallowed halls of knowledge. Verily, a mishmash, with naught a thought to sense or reason. Children, unchecked, didst frolic and scream, their parents, lost in indulgence. Alas, I shall not return, forsooth, to this place of learning, so ill-conceived."

"Hark! Mr. Pineapple doth speak with fair words,  
And his prices, they do seem most reasonable.  
But alas, his reliability doth leave much to be desired,  
For oft he doth fail to deliver on his promises,  
Leaving me in quite a predicament, I do confess.  

A tenant did depart, and I did wish to make ready  
The front and back yards, ere the new ones did arrive.  
So I did call upon Mr. Pineapple, and he did give me  
An estimate, which did seem most fair and bright.  
I did ask him to proceed, and he did say  
That he would do the work on the seventh day of May.  
But lo, he did not come, nor did he call,  
And when I did ring him, he did say  
That he would come on the eleventh day,  
But alas, he did not keep his word,  
And when I did call him on the twelfth day,  
He did not deign to answer, nor did he return my call.  

And so the new tenants did move in,  
And it did not bode well, I must confess.  
Yea, verily, it was a most vexing situation,  
And one that did cause me much distress."

"Hark, good sir! Last call doth approach, and lo,  
The hour doth strike eleven thirty, I do declare.  
Alas, how quickly night doth fall, and with it, fears  
Of emptiness, for bars, like Bourbon steak, doth clear.  
Ah, but what solace findeth he who doth inhabit  
Such places, free from throngs of folk, who doth perturb?  
A refuge, indeed, for those of ample girth,  
Who find in isolation, peace and freedom from dearth."

"O, how my expectations were confounded, dear friend! Forsooth, I had thought that dining here would be a grand adventure, with Bobby Flay's name attached, no less. Alas, 'twas naught but a disappointment, akin to a humble Carl Jr's, save for the interior, which didst boast a certain hipness and coolness. But, alack! The burger, the NM Burger, no less, didst pale in comparison to its brethren, with condiments that didst overpower the patty, and a presentation that didst bespeak an amateurish hand, like unto Uncle Fred, who hath been imbibing freely and cooking with little care. The meat itself, small and bland, didst fail to impress, and left me feeling that, verily, I had been cheated. The price, indeed, was fair, but I wouldst gladly pay more for a burger of quality, with condiments that didst complement, rather than overwhelm, the flavor of the meat. The staff, in sooth, were friendly and attentive, but their response, when asked of our thoughts, didst border on the insolent, as if they didst not care a whit for our opinions. Fie upon this place, and fie upon Bobby Flay, for lending his name to such a lackluster establishment! Mayhap, in time, he shall see fit to remove his name, or, at the least, provide some measure of training for his staff, that they may represent him in a manner more becoming."

"Upon our arrival, we didst marvel at the potions and the place's adornment. But alas, as the night wore on, our service didst turn awry. A barback didst attend to us, despite the fact that 'twas not a busy eve. He knew not his duties and didst leave us to fend for ourselves, forcing us to seek him out for each draught we didst desire. And when we didst request our tallies, he didst swipe our cards without our leave, ere we couldst behold the sum. Then, to add insult to injury, he didst confound our payments, charging us erroneous amounts. When we didst query this, the other mixologists didst display a haughty mien towards us. Our request for a detailed receipt didst elicit a response that we shouldst have asked forthwith, and that it wouldst take an age for them to unearth it. Moreover, the ladies' privy was in disarray, with a brimming waste bin and what appeared to be urine upon the floor, alongside torn tissue paper. We shall patronize Crave on our next visit..."

"Hark, fair maiden! I sought counsel on creams of youth,
And found but one kind soul, who didst greet me with truth.
In the rear, three ladies stood, in conference deep,
Their faces stern, as if they didst conspire to keep.

I asked for aid, and one didst point with glee,
To a screen, whereon I might read reviews, anon.
But lo, the employee didst leave me, quite alone,
To navigate the device, and find my way to the throne.

If thou dost seek advice on skincare, fair reader,
Go to Ulta, as I did, and thou shalt find the cream that doth suit thee well, and make thy visage bright and smooth, like the morning dew."

"Verily, 'tis my first visit to this establishment, and, alas, my initial impressions do not bode well. The service, I must confess, doth leave much to be desired. Our server, a youth with a countenance most bland, didst attend to us with all the enthusiasm of a reluctant grave-digger. The Pho Tai, a dish I hadst eagerly anticipated, didst fail to impress, with naught but a paltry five strips of steak gracing the bowl. And, oh, the ignominy! Four separate servers didst we have, each one as inattentive as the last, their gazes turned resolutely away whenever we didst signal for their notice. In sooth, I have received better service at a humble'mom and pop' pho shop in San Diego, a place not nearly so renowned as this. Their egg rolls, alas, were rock-solid, a far cry from the six succulent pieces that didst grace our plates in SD. And the calamari, oh, how it didst swim in oil, its surface glistening like the posterior of a well-oiled porn star! In conclusion, I do implore thee, dear reader, to seek thy culinary delights elsewhere. This place, despite its popularity, doth not deserve thy custom."

"Hark! What discourtesy doth these waitresses show?
No drinks, no dishes, nor menu to view,
Nor hath anyone attended to us, I vow,
In near half an hour since first we didst enter.
I pray thee, good sirs, avoid this place, 'tis best."

"In fair August, I did procure a wedding album,
For our dear pictures, a most wondrous shrine.
But lo, the sleeves were few, and I didst lament,
For Erin, the gal, did say, "Refill pages, thou shalt find,
At Walmart, their site, or so I did infer."
I searched far and wide, o'er twenty sites,
And called their number, with hope, yet naught but despair didst strike.
For they didst say, "Backorder, alas, doth plague us,
And when, or if, we shall receive them, none canst predict."
Alack, poor soul, how couldst I, without the receipt,
Exchange this album for another, my heart didst entreat?
Yet, nay, they didst deny, with stern and steadfast mien.
But lo, a copy of my statement, I didst produce,
And thus, a chargeback, I didst make, with some relieve.
So heed my words, dear friends, ere ye do purchase,
Ensure that refill pages, ye do find, in abundance,
Lest ye be left, like me, in dismal disappointment,
With naught but woe, and sorrow, to keep thee company."

"A sorry state of affairs, indeed! My wife, she didst pressure me,
To purchase more than we didst need, yea, verily.
The walls, they were smudged, and nicked, in many a place,
And one vent cover, they didst leave, without a trace.
I didst demand a refund, and after much ado,
The owner, he didst relent, and gave me back a portion too.
But mark my words, good sirs, avoid them, if thou canst,
For though their prices be low, their work, it doth not stand."

"O, woe is me! This eating place, once grand,
Hath now descended into culinary disgrace.
I sought to order chicken fingers, a simple dish,
But lo, they knew not how to cook them aright.
So I didst choose another dish, nachos, a safe bet,
But alas, the cheese whiz nachos, oh how foul!
I shall not return to this place again,
Forsooth, 'tis not worth my time or coin."

"A pox upon this dentist, a scoundrel most foul! His office now doth lie in ruin, a fate most meet. Mayhap he hath retired, or turned to other pursuits, like loans or cars of old. A year past, I didst visit him, and he didst claim six cavities didst plague my teeth. But nay, I hadst but one, a fact most strange and wondrous. The cost, near $900, didst cause me to hesitate and seek a second opinion. Now, in a new land, I have found a dentist true and fair, who doth show me my X-rays on a great monitor, and all his notes, in plain view. Nevermore shall I entrust my teeth to one who doth not follow this wise custom."

"Methinks not all Macys be created fair,
For some be nice, with floors clean and staff kind.
But those in Minnesota, good they be,
In Las Vegas, woe betide thee!
Their phone service doth stink, and twice did send
Defective goods, which did my patience offend.
Macys, alack, doth falter and decline,
And thus, my custom, thirty years divine,
Doth shift to Nordstroms and Amazon's keep,
For they do earn my trust and loyalty deep."

"Fie upon this wretched place, where ill doth reign!
The victuals they do serve, are naught but woeful fare,
And poisonous to boot, thy stomach shall declare.
The rice, alas, doth taste of naught but bitter bile,
And hard as stone, doth stick within thy craw.
Reheated, verily, a thousand times, or more,
Until the very thought of it, doth make thee sore.
I pray thee, good sir, avoid this den of woe,
Lest thou desire to suffer, as I did, oh so."

"Pray tell, good sir, canst thou give no stars? Forsooth, this airport doth leave much to be desired. 'Tis a shambles, a travesty, a pitiful excuse for a place of arrival. Verily, 'twas designed by children at play, with nary a thought for the comfort or convenience of weary travelers. The signs, they doth confound, and naught was open, save for a few paltry vending machines, which, alack, didst lie empty. Fie upon this wretched place! In sooth, 'twere better to drive into fair Phoenix, where, perchance, one might find some semblance of civility and hospitality."

"Pray, good sir, do not waste thy time upon this play,
For at its cost, thou dost expect a greater show.
Tis but a paltry thing, with naught of worth or wit,
That doth leave thee bored and wishing for a bit.
Heed well the words of those who came before,
And didst not find it to their liking, nor a thing to adore.
A jest, indeed, and one not worth the telling,
For it doth fail to entertain, and doth but dwindle."

"Hark! What discourtesy doth this woman show?
Asking a question, she doth not deign to know.
Her nose buried in a book, she doth not hear,
Nor doth she care for those who draw near.

With scorn and laughter, she doth reply,
'What's thy bidding, sir?' Oh, how uncivil!
As if we had disturbed her from some high employ,
And not from reading, as it did seem, some idle tale of joy.

Fie upon such manners! Rude and unkind,
She doth not know the way to treat the mind.
Forsooth, we shall not trouble her again,
Lest she doth think us fools, or doth proclaim her disdain."

Oh, woeful day! Our cabman, Randy, didst play
The role of villain, with an attitude most foul.
He didst not care for others' moods, nor didst he
Show any regard for their feelings, in his rule.

His judgment was swift and harsh, with naught but scorn
For those who dared to cross him. Oh, how he didst
Bring woe upon himself, and upon all who didst
Encounter him. His name, a curse, didst forever seal
His fate, a man unworthy of the trust placed in him.

And so, dear friends, take heed of this tale,
And shun the likes of Randy, lest ye suffer
The same fate as we, who didst endure his wrath.
For in this world, where kindness doth abound,
There is no room for such as he, who doth
Bring only strife and misery to all around.

"Alas, poor creature! Thou hast been ill-used,
By those who claimed to tend thee with care.
Thy lovely locks, once long and luxuriant, now lie
In tatters, shorn by unskilled hands, so fair.

They nicked thee, cat, in many a spot,
And left thy coat in sorry state, alack!
The wounds they dealt, they would not heal,
For thou, in constant grooming, didst reveal

Thy discontent, and caused great delay
In growth of new fur, oh, fie upon't!
When I, concerned, didst call to ask,
They treated me with scorn, and didst task

My patience, with their haughty tone,
As if I were some fool, alone.
Now, patchy and bald, thou art, my dear,
A shadow of thine former self, so clear.

Oh, gentle friends, take heed of this,
And shun this place, where animals are kissed
By cruel fate, and human hand, so rude,
Lest thou, like mine, be left in such a mood."

"Five times have I visited this place, and each time, methinks, I'm treated differently than others. Their clientele, mostly fair-skinned folk, doth command my notice. A Latin lady, I do stand out, yet still, their delectable cakes, I cannot resist. Of all, the white chocolate raspberry, most excellent, the lemon, alas, doth taste of boxed mixture."

"Fly, good sir or madam, fly this place of woe,
Where stairs thou must ascend with burden heavy,
No lift to ease thy way, nor staff to show
The path that leads to comfort and to rest.

Away, away, for here no peace doth dwell,
Nor aid of servants to assist thee well.
Take heed, fair traveler, and heed my words,
For here no joy nor solace shall be found."

"Fie upon this wretched place! Their customer service doth leave much to be desired. Not a single soul didst greet me when I entered, nor did anyone offer aid. I stood at the fitting room entrance, a stroller in tow, for five long minutes. Kim, a worker there, didst pass me by with nary a care, carrying a heap of garments. I waited yet another minute ere I asked if I might enter. She seemed most put out that she had any customers at all. And when I didst depart, she stood in the widest passage betwixt the racks of clothes, refusing to budge. I had to squeeze past with great difficulty, pushing my stroller through a narrow gap. Fie upon this place, say I! Waste not thy dollars here, good sir!"

"Hark! I didst check on Yelp if Carl's Jr. didst open on Thanksgiving Day,
And lo, it didst say 'yes', with nary a doubt or dismay.
I drove to the drive-thru, with haste and with speed,
To see if they didst serve, as their sign didst read.

A voice didst call out, 'Look o'er the menu, good sir,
And let us know when thou art ready to order, ere long.'
I waited, and waited, with patience most fair,
But alas! No one came, though the lights didst shine bright and fair.

I drove up to the window, with hope in my heart,
But found no one there, to take my order, or play a part.
Oh, rude Carls Jr! How couldst thou say thou art open wide,
When nary a worker doth come, to take my order, or abide?

Shame on thee, Carls Jr! For thy false words, and empty boast,
I shall not return, nor shall I e'er make haste.
For thou hast failed, in thy duty, and in thy quest,
To serve thy customers, with honor, and with the best."

"Fie upon this restaurant, with its gaudy decor and prices so high,
It doth suggest quality, but alas, 'tis naught but lies.
The taste, oh how it doth offend, a travesty, a mockery,
A poor imitation of Din Tai Fung, a culinary atrocity.

The portions, small and meager, a mere trifle,
$25 for three shrimp, a sum most laughable and vile.
The entrees, dwarfed by appetizers, a sight most pitiful,
A cruel joke, a swindle most foul and unjustifiable.

But lo, my greatest ire doth stem from their raw meat,
No shrimp in sight, just cornstarch and gravy, a most unsavory treat.
The owner, a fool, doth argue, a raging tempest,
That fusion food, a term most vague and unspecific,
Doth justify his crimes against culinary art,
But I, a man of taste, doth know that raw pork doth impart
A danger most dire, a risk most foul and unclean,
For intestinal worms, a fate most grim and unseen.

The waiter, poor soul, doth suffer, a victim of their whims,
His hope, a fleeting dream, that they may mend their ways and win.
But nay, the health department shall intervene,
And shut them down, a mercy, a blessing from above, a reprieve."

"A pox upon this place, a den of woe,
Where service is naught but a sorry show.
We entered, a merry band of friends,
On a Friday eve, at five o'clock, it ends.

Drinks and apps we ordered, with glee,
But lo, the food arrived ere we could see,
Five minutes early, a strange sight, indeed,
And thus, our meal began, with speed.

The victuals were naught but corporate fare,
Bland, uninspired, and lacking flair.
Onion rings, fried shrooms, a burger, too,
All were plain, and none did please, anew.

The service, alas, was poor, to say,
Our waitress, forgetful, in her way.
My love, thrice rose, to fetch a straw,
And when our tab we sought, the server raw,
Did bring a stack of bills, and searched,
With haste, our own, among the rest.

This place, I'll not revisit, no, not I,
For smaller, non-corporate haunts, I'll fly.
My friends, dear friends, the only cause,
To come again, to this, God's curse."

"O, woe is me! My visit to Best Buy didst prove most vexing.  AMP install didst cost me $231.27, and wiring was crossed, speakers misplaced.  Sound quality? Fie upon it! 'Twas poor, akin to naught but noise.  I sought aid from Manager Kevin S, alas, he proved most unhelpful.  Young Anthony, responsible for the botched job, didst leave me in disarray.  Yet, kind Keith didst rectify the mess.  O, friends, avoid this store, ruled by knaves and fools."

"Verily, I do not oft write reviews, but alas, my woeful experience doth compel me to speak out. The victuals served at this establishment are grossly overpriced, and their quality doth leave much to be desired. I didst take my wife and children thither, and forsooth, we paid nigh upon a hundred crowns for four persons. Alas, the fish didst feel rubbery, the shrimp didst lack freshness, and the crab leg didst contain an excess of salt. In sooth, they were naught but frozen fare, and their preparation didst seem the work of a novice chef. I didst feel most ill at ease throughout the repast, and didst wish for my coin back the whole while.

"Furthermore, the server didst prove most inhospitable. Our cups didst remain empty, and I didst have to beg for a refill of water for my children. He didst not trouble himself to enquire whether I didst desire a refill, and thus, my wife and I didst suffer the evening with but a single draught. My hunger didst flee, and I didst not deign to request another.

"They do charge twenty-five crowns per head, and I do advise thee, good reader, to spend thy gold elsewhere. Wicked Spoon at Cosmopolitan, or Le Village at Paris, are far better choices.

"Mark my words, dear friend, avoid this tavern as thou wouldst avoid the plague. 'Tis a foul place, and hath earned its place amongst the worst eateries I have had the misfortune to visit."

"Alas, my dear friend, how my heart doth ache,
For the fare at this establishment, didst not break,
My fast, nor didst it bring me joy or cheer,
But rather left me in a state of dismay and fear.

Oh, the sauce, it didst taste of MSG,
And the meat, it didst not resemble meat, I pray thee,
But rather tofu, shaped like beef, it didst seem,
And the noodles, oh, they were quite bland, I do declare.

The service, it was adequate, I must confess,
Our meal didst come forth swiftly, with no great delay,
But alas, my friend, I wouldst not recommend this place,
For the fare, it didst not meet my expectations, in any case."

"Tis a sorry state of affairs, my dear,
This eatery doth leave much to be desired,
Its decor, once grand, now doth appear
Faded and worn, like a tired old hag.

The service, too, doth leave much to be sought,
Slack and uncaring, with nary a thought
For the patron's plight, or their needs,
A poor display, indeed, of hospitality's creeds.

And the breakfast, alas! How could they go wrong?
A meal most simple, yet they managed to prolong
The suffering, with flavors so bland and weak,
It left me in wonder, how such a feat could be seeked.

I spoke to the manager, a man of some import,
Yet he did not inquire, nor did he seek to console,
He merely said 'ok', and left it at that,
A sorry excuse for customer service, trowel that.

So, here I sit, in this dingy place,
With naught but disdain, and a heavy heart,
For a meal most foul, and service to match,
A true disappointment, and a sorry start."

"Hark, good sir, what ill fate didst bring thee here?
A place of such disdain, of naught but woe and fear?
The stars, they twinkle not, in this darkest night,
For here, they serve not even a morsel of delight.

We entered, full of hope, our spirits high,
But lo, they brought us naught but bitter sky.
They asked if we desired water or tea,
And thus, our tale of woe didst begin to be.

We ordered pork dumplings, and sticky rice,
But oh, the horror, how our taste didst despise!
Then, we inquired about egg rolls, with hope,
But alas, they said they were out, their scope.

Their carts, they pushed around, with steaming plates,
But fresh, the food was not, and thus, our fates.
The service, poor, and we didst have to seek,
Our tab, to pay, and flee, to escape their bleak.

It seems, a place for groups, of merriment,
But for those who seek true fare, avoid, their punishment.
So, heed my words, good friends, and shun this place,
Lest thou desire to suffer, in their bitter space."

"Fly not with Jet Luxury, good sir,
For they shall lead thee to a fate most dire.
The Vdara, a hotel of ill repute,
Shall leave thee in discomfort, full of desp'rate.

When complaints were made, naught but empty words,
Were spoken, and naught but false promises heard.
So heed my warning, traveler, and shun
The Vdara, lest thou suffer as I have done."

"A month past, I penned a review of woe,
About a restaurant visit that did not go well,
The hostess was rude, and would not seat us,
My son, but fourteen, did not think to entreat us.

Clay, the GM, did respond, and asked to speak,
I called at six, a bad time, I did seek,
To leave my name and number, hoping he'd call,
But three weeks passed, and still no word at all.

I sought to share my tale, and make things right,
Not seeking freebies, just a chance to ignite,
A fire of change, to improve their ways,
But alas, it seems my efforts were in vain, for days.

So, farewell to this place, I shall not return,
For poor service, and neglect, my soul did burn."

"By my troth, I doth concur most heartily!
This staff, they must be schooled in kindness and courtesy.
A thorough revamp of the personnel, that's what's needed here,
The very worst, I do declare, beyond all doubt or fear."

"My apologies, fair readers, for my tardiness in posting. Two months past, a woeful nightmare did befall me, which I shall now recount. A hectic day at work had left me famished, and so I decided to indulge in a meal from yonder China Go Go. In haste, I devoured my Kung Pao lunch combo, but alas! The noodles were foul and nigh unpalatable. I turned to the entree, but lo! A roasted roach did lie upon my plate, its antennae stark and still. My stomach did churn, my throat did constrict, and I did vomit forth in disgust. A customer did enter, and still I trembled with revulsion, my voice did quiver with distress. The memory doth still haunt me, and I swear never again to partake of Kung Roach Pao. Fie upon that wretched meal, say I!"

"O, what a waste of mine own gold!
A burger, pan-fried at home, doth taste
Far better than this overpriced fare.
Methinks 'tis anger-making, to have spent
Nigh on $30, and receive such scant return.
I do demand my coin, in fairness, back.

My daughter, she didst enjoy her Oreo shake,
But, alas, her burger didst leave much to seek.
And, by the stars, those veggie fries, how vile!
Yuck, quotha, doth sum up their wretched style."

"O woeful day! My worst experience did befall,
At Wilson Camera, where I didst expect to find
A certain item, yet was told it wouldst take
Seven to ten days, and thus didst I wait.
But lo! Thirty days passed, and still no word,
Until at last, a call didst come, and I didst hear
That my item had arrived. Oh, how my heart didst sink!
For no one didst take the time to call and explain,
Nor didst they offer me a discount on the shipping,
Which was but ten dollars, yet to me, 'twas a great offense.
And so, I vow, never again to set foot in this place,
Nor suggest it to my photographers, for it doth bring shame.
Tempe Camera, thou art a better choice, by far,
So heed my words, and avoid Wilson Camera, as thou wouldst a scar."

"Hark! A tale of woe and disappointment doth unfold,
Of a party of six, with reservations bold,
Arriving promptly at five thirty, as planned,
Yet waited nigh on forty-five minutes, hand in hand.

Drinks and salads, we ordered with haste,
Entrees, we did request, with no delay or waste,
But alas! Our server, didst avoid our table,
Leaving us to ponder, with naught but a fable.

At seven fifteen, our salads did arrive,
A paltry offering, with naught to revive,
The main course, at eight, didst finally come,
But with a price, so steep, it didst astound.

Seven hundred dollars, for a meal so fair,
With a tip, of twenty-two percent, to bear,
I would not recommend, this place, so dear,
For Mastro's City Hall, doth offer more cheer.

Their service, impeccable, their food, divine,
Spend thy money there, and thou shalt dine,
In a place of wonder, with naught to dismay,
Mastro's City Hall, doth reign supreme, by day."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern, full of guile!
Their mix, a swirling brew, doth lack the potent draught,
A mere facsimile, a fruity smoothy, naught but watered down,
In truth, a paltry imitation of the real thing, a sorry sight.
If thou desirest to quaff a stiff drink, seek out Fat Tuesday's halls,
Where shots flow freely, and the revelry ne'er ceases.
Nay, Numbers, with its solitary bartender, doth seem a cheat,
Yet, ask for 'virgin' drinks, and let the young ones partake,
In Vegas-style cups, a curious sight, indeed."

Hark! I went, forsooth, to dine within the walls
Of yonder inn, where I didst lay my head.
A pair of times, I ventured forth to partake
Of victuals offered, freely given, 'twas said.

The first, at eve, I chanced upon their feast,
But found it wanting, meagre choice, indeed.
The fare, alack, was bland, and left me cold,
Save for the bacon, which didst please my mood.

Again, at dawn, I sought their morning cheer,
But lo! The butter, nigh the pancakes, didst err.
It marred the taste, and left me discontent,
For eggs, too, were strange, and not as they should be.
Perhaps 'twere powdered, or some other woe,
That made them taste so foul, I cannot say.

Yet still, I searched their spread, to find some delight,
And came upon a salad, fresh and bright.
A croissant, too, didst grace my plate,
And thus, my hunger sated, I didst take flight.
Though convenient, 'twas not worth the cost,
For better fare, I sought, and found it lost.

"A plague upon the movie, a foul disgrace,
That took a noble tale of love and turned it base.
Great music, a grand story, a life of purpose found,
Were cast aside, and in their place, profanity abounded.

Alas, poor actors, with talent so divine,
Were reduced to jests of a most vulgar kind.
The singing, the dancing, both superb and fine,
Yet all the teenage humor, oh how unrefined!

A pox on those who thought such jokes would please,
And turned a potentially great show into a tease.
For Rock of Ages, at the Venetian, did stumble,
And left me in disappointment, nigh unto a grumble."

"Hark, what news is this? A year extension, they say,
For Pin Up Shows, a woeful, wretched play.
Statosphere, thou art a fool, I pray,
To keep this dreadful spectacle in sway.

A plague upon the one who doth pay thee,
To stage this wretched, sorry sight.
In vain, thy efforts, for naught shall be,
The fruit of folly, bitter and unripe.

Waste not thy time, nor spend thy coin,
Upon this foul, ill-fated show, my friend.
Forsooth, 'tis but a pitiful display,
Unworthy of thine eyes, or any's end."

"Farewell, thou wretched place! I ne'er shall return,
For ne'er again shall I suffer such disdain.
If stars I could leave, none would be the amount,
For service poor, and time most profusely spent.
In vain, alas! doth one await thy aid,
For naught but woe doth thy presence portend."

"Alas, my friends, I must revise my thoughts,
For after dining, a foul sight was caught.
A cockroach, upon the wall, did crawl,
And left me feeling quite appalled.

My stomach churns at the mere thought,
That in the food, a roach might have been brought.
Oh, how it makes my flesh crawl with dread!
I fear I shall not return, my friends, ere dead.

For who knows what may lurk within their dishes?
A roach, perhaps, or worse, a poisonous wish.
No, no, I cannot risk another visit,
Lest I desire to part with life and wit.

So farewell, dear restaurant, adieu!
Your cockroach has caused me great distress, anew."

"Fie upon this wretched place, with service poor and food most vile! The prices, too, do sting, like lashes from a whip. Oh, how I wish I had gone to Waynn, where, for ten dollars more, a finer feast I might have had! Alas, I did not take a picture of the foul desserts, but trust me, dear friends, they were most loathsome, and not worth a single bite. Farewell, this wretched hole, forevermore!"

"Park thy steed, fair reader, at the rear,
In yonder labyrinth of concrete and steel,
A valet, swift and courteous, shall take the rein,
And guide thee to a spot, both safe and serene.

The waitstaff, prompt and pleasant, doth attend,
Within a hall, where many a feast hath been penned,
Yet, spite of wear and tear, 'tis clean and neat,
Save for a tang, a certain je ne sais quoi,
Lacking in thy bloody Mary, dear guest.

Thou hast commanded, for thy midday repast,
Andy's Sage Fried Chicken Benedict, a feast most vast,
A towering plate, with chicken, eggs, and cheese,
Melon, tomato, spinach, all in abundance,
But, alas! The chicken, dry and lacking zest,
The cheese, with burnt taste, and aftermath unpleasant,
Leaving thee, fair reader, less than impressed.

Yet, fear not, for this place shall be thy cure,
When hangover doth plague thee, and thou art unsure,
Of where to find solace, and a meal most true,
Come, try again, and mayhap, fortune shall shine through."

"A plague upon this brewery, where service doth falter!
We sat at table three, in bar area, half-empty 'twas.
Three pm, the day of twenty-sixth of December,
And waited patiently, for seven minutes, alack!
No server came, nor bartender, to take our order,
So I, to bar, didst walk, to ask, with haste and anger.
The bartender said, someone would come, anon,
But five long minutes passed, and still, no one didst show.
Other tables, full of folk, they didst attend,
Yet we, forgotten, didst wait, without an end.
The bartender, he didst know, our plight,
Yet said nothing, as we suffered this ignight.
Twelve minutes, for a beer, a ridiculous wait,
This brewery, should be ashamed, of such poor fate.
As we departed, a server, didst pass us by,
Without a word, or glance, didst she give, alas, poor soul.
Go elsewhere, good sirs, and avoid this place,
For customer service, they do not embrace."

"Hark! I sought a manicure, for gel nails were my desire. And lo, the owners didst welcome me with cheer, and I didst ask if they didst offer such a service. 'Aye, we do,' they said, and I didst query further, 'UV gel nails, dost thou provide?' 'Aye, we do,' they replied once more.

"I sat, and a woman didst begin to prepare my natural nails. Then, she brought forth a jar of powder and I didst say, 'Nay, I want not acrylic nails, but gel nails, made entirely of gel.' 'Tis gel, she said, and I didst protest, 'In California, the technician didst not use powder, so I know what I speak of.'

"She realized I was not to be fooled and told me the truth, that she didst apply acrylic first and gel on top. Already in the mood for a manicure, I agreed to continue. She finished the acrylics and painted them with a color of my choice, adding a coat of shine. But alas, 'twas not gel!

"She placed my hands beneath the UV lamp, attempting to deceive me still. I was most displeased and wished only to depart that place. She offered a discount, but I didst not care, for I hadst not received the service I desired.

"So, if thou art in search of affordable acrylics, this may be the place. But beware, lest thou be treated as a fool, as I was."

"Fie upon this wretched place, where service doth falter and fare doth fail! Twice have I graced their doors with mine own presence, yet both times did they err in their duty towards me. A plain cheeseburger did I order, but lo, a hamburger did they bring instead! And not a single condiment did they proffer, leaving me to dine upon a barren feast. Last time, I did wait within my carriage for a full quarter hour ere I didst venture forth to claim my refund. Clean up thy act, Culver's, lest thou dost lose a loyal patron!"

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This review doth bring me great distress.
For at the door, a rude man did stand,
And with his words, my mood he did command.

I sat at bar, but anger did brew,
As thoughts of his behavior did accrue.
And thus, I left, without a single order made,
For how could I abide such treatment, well-arrayed?

The decor was cute, the menu fair,
But alas, the staff did leave much to despair.
If fortune brings me to this place again,
Perhaps I shall reconsider, and not in vain.

Yet, let this be a lesson to all who can hear,
That rudeness doth never a customer cheer."

"A pox upon the service at this place, 'tis woeful indeed! A certain woman, with a face most dour, doth make my blood run cold. She doth regard me with disfavor, and her scowl doth pierce my soul. I had a return, well within the time allotted, yet she doth act as though I had committed some grievous wrong. Her curtness doth border on the rude, and I do fear she doth take pleasure in my discomfort. Alas, I do adore their wares, those mosaic tile pots most fair, and shall return anon, yet with trepidation, for I do dread another encounter with this harpy of ill will."

"Methinks, fair traveler, thou shouldst beware,
For here, 'tis all about the filthy lucre.
A place where coin doth reign supreme,
And all else doth pale in comparison.
So, heed my words, and think twice,
Ere thou doth set foot in this place,
Lest thou doth find thyself in woeful plight,
With naught but regret to show for thy trouble."

"Alas, how swiftly doth this place decline! 
Once 'twas my haven for late night repast, 
Now, nay, 'tis but a shadow of its former grace. 
Fried rice, once savory, now doth taste stale, 
And chicken, marinated in a strange, off-putting way. 
Verily, I shall not return, nor recommend it to thee."

"Alas, my friends, how sad it doth seem,
That Osaka, once of quality and dream,
Hath now descended to such depths of woe,
As to leave me in utter dismay and sorrow.

Last eve, I didst visit this establishment,
And found, alack, such faults and failings,
As to make mine eyes weep with despair,
And mine heart to lament in deepest grief.

Firstly, the prices they do charge,
Are far beyond what one doth receive,
A sin indeed, and most unfair,
To take advantage of those who do dare
To enter in and sample their wares.

Secondly, the fish, oh so dear,
Was of poor quality, I do declare,
Not fatty, nor tasty, nor fresh,
But rather, like a piece of old leather,
Dried up and hard, without any zest.

Thirdly, the tako, oh how it doth pain,
To speak of it, for it was but rubber,
Chewy and tasteless, a true disappointment,
A mockery of the dish, a culinary disaster.

Fourthly, the wait, oh how long it didst take,
Forty-five minutes, a truly endless span,
For a carryout order, a simple request,
To wait so long, it doth but add to the unrest.

In conclusion, my friends, I say to thee,
Sushi Wa is far better, a place to be,
Yoshida's in San Marino, a true delight,
The best, the greatest, a place of pure joy and light."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Mint,
Where we, a group of brave souls, didst venture in,
To try the fabled Inferno Challenge, a feat most grand,
But alas, fate didst not smile upon our plan.

We arrived at two of the clock, with eager hearts,
To partake in the bounty of their buffet, a true work of art,
But lo! When three o'clock didst strike, our hopes didst fade,
For the staff didst inform us, they hadst not the ingredients made.

A waste of time, a waste of journey, a bitter pill,
No offer of retribution, nor a hint of goodwill,
Just a suggestion to call in a week, a futile quest,
To see if the ingredients shall be found, or if we must rest.

Alas, poor Mint, thy reputation doth suffer a blow,
For thou didst not deliver, what thou didst promise to show,
A challenge unmet, a dream unfulfilled, a tale of woe,
That shall be told, for all to know."

"Fie upon this wretched place, where we didst make a reservation, yet waited nigh on forty-five minutes! The scent of rotten incense didst assail our nostrils, a stench most foul and overwhelming. 'Twas so vile that the staff didst offer apologies, and didst comp our meal, and even gave us fare for a cab! The victuals were but passable, alas.

Verily, I say unto thee, dear friend, avoid this Musashi, for it doth seem they didst have a most unfortunate day. Instead, seek out Yolies or Firefly, located in the selfsame parking lot, for they are most excellent indeed!"

"Fazoli's, a place I once held dear, hath now betrayed my trust. A breadstick, a simple delight, hath been corrupted. Buttered popcorn, a flavor most foul, doth assault mine taste buds. Like a Jelly Belly, it doth linger, a bitter memory. 

The counter, empty and still, didst mock mine arrival. A wait, prolonged and unjust, didst precede mine order. Loud chatter, a cacophony of voices, didst pierce mine ears. Friends, they didst converse, not customers, it seemed. 

A day most woeful, full of trials and woe, didst bring me to this place. Pasta, a solace, a balm for mine soul, didst I seek. Alas, Fazoli's didst make mine heart heavier. 

And lo, a slice of pizza, a'side', they call it. A jest, a joke, a play on words, perchance? Nay, a mockery, a sham, a travesty. Give me pasta, give me cheese, give me grease, but spare me this monstrosity."

"Tis a woeful sight, this place doth fail,
A pox upon it, 'tis a foul imitation,
Of that most noble bread, the bagel true,
That doth arise from New York's bustling streets,
In frozen form, Lender's doth surpass,
This feeble attempt at such a treat.

The taste, oh dear, doth lack all charm,
Like cardboard, flat and devoid of grace,
The sandwiches, pre-made, a sorry sight,
With toppings old, that doth lose their zest,
No freshness here, no flavor to delight.

Alas, poor soul, who doth seek a meal,
At St-Viatuer Bagels, doth deceive,
For rankings high, doth not ensure a feast,
But rather, disappointment, bitter and keen.

So heed my words, dear friends, and flee,
From this pretender, with its stale, rancid fare,
For in truth, 'tis naught but woe and sorrow,
To partake of such a tasteless snare."

"Alack, what woeful fare didst thou prepare?
A chicken Caesar salad, devoid of zest,
With dressing scant and flavors quite bereft.
The bird, a frozen slab, didst lack all grace,
Its breading sodden, like a wet embrace.
Oh, spare thyself the trouble, friend,
And seek a salad at McDonald's end,
For there, perchance, thou shalt find a treat
More savory than this poor, wretched feast."

"Alas, my friends, avoid this place, 'tis not worth thy time,
For though they boast of late night fare, 'tis but a crime.
The grub they serve, doth leave much to be desired,
Reheated leftovers, or worse, with nary a fire.
The pizza, once a proud dish, now but a sorry sight,
And Caesar's salad, a wilted mess, without a bite.
Our waiter, kind and helpful, didst earn a star,
But alas, the food, a sad and sorry farce, oh so far.
So heed my words, dear friends, and seek elsewhere,
For here, thou shalt not find a meal most fair and rare."

"A night of woe didst befall us, friends,
At a place where we didst hope to dine with ease.
The calamari, once a dish of delight,
Was now but burnt breadcrumbs and a few bits of sea.
The food, though of good quality, didst taste foul,
And the wait, an hour and a half, didst make us howl.
We sent it back, and waited, patient and still,
For two hours more, until it was cooked aright.
But alas, when we didst ask for to-go boxes,
The food was taken back, and in the trash, it didst land with a thud and a noise.
Management didst offer apologies and a discount,
But the damage was done, our trust was broken, and our bellies were empty.
I wouldst not recommend this place, my friends,
For all the other fine eateries in DTLV, it doth pale in comparison."

"Alas, my friends, what woeful tale I tell,
Of Belle Suite, where I did choose to dwell,
For two short nights, yet oh, how they did drag,
With service poor, and rude security to nag.

The towels, fresh, did take an age to come,
And toilet paper, but a single roll, did some.
I sought a maid, myself, to fetch,
For waiting long, my patience did exhaust.

My friend, forgetful, did request a key,
But rude, the guard, did turn her away,
As if his tasks, more pressing, were,
Than her, a guest, in need, so fair and rare.

No signal, internet, nor phone, did work,
A nuisance, this, for one who does embark,
On business, or, perchance, a quest,
For knowledge, or, mayhap, just for fun, and rest.

Our keys, inactive, did become, so oft,
Downstairs, we trod, new ones, to soft,
A puddle, too, did lie, in wait,
Near falling, did my feet, almost betray.

We checked out, early, did await,
A bellhop, patient, did tarry,
An hour, near, did pass, before his arrival,
A Motel 6, I'd choose, above this palace, royal.

Beautiful, the interior, may be,
Yet service, poor, did mar, for me,
The experience, unhappy, did leave,
A memory, unpleasant, doth still perceive."

"O, what a woeful sight doth greet mine eyes!
A place that claims to be of four stars' worth,
Yet serves up fare most vile and poor in quality.
The salads, oh how they did make me sneeze,
For forty minutes we did wait, and still,
No sign of life didst they bring to our table.
And when at last they came, 'twas but a mess,
A chopped salad, with nary a crunch or bite.
The wine, it did flow like a river in spring,
But alas, no taste didst they offer to us.
The pork chops, three fingers tall and proud,
Were bland and tasteless, despite two days' soak.
The prime rib, gray and lifeless as a stone,
Didst leave my stomach grumbling, and my taste buds moan.
The service, slow and cold as winter's frost,
Didst make our visit a true test of endurance.
Oh, traveler, take heed of this warning fair,
And shun this place, lest thou desire to suffer.
For in its stead, choose one of those nearby,
Where chain restaurants doth serve food more worthy."

"Hark, what ribs I had at eleven o'clock!
Fie upon the picture, how it did deceive!
Average, at best, the dish did seem to me.
But worse, the service, oh how vile it be!
Ten minutes passed, ere the waitress came to me,
To take my drink order, and then, alack!
She vanished, leaving me to ponder fate,
Till ten minutes later, when she brought the bill,
And left it there, without a word or care,
As if I were a dog, and not a man,
In this, a place of woe, a dump, indeed."

"Alas, my friends, I must recount a tale of woe,
Concerning a coffee shop, where I didst go,
To sip and scribble, free from care and strife,
But lo, their WiFi didst fail, and caused much life.

A regular there, I had become, indeed,
And found their brew most pleasing to my creed,
But now, alas, my words are filled with scorn,
For their WiFi, it didst never work, nor dawn.

My devices, modern and of latest sort,
Didst fail to connect, and left me in a fort,
Of dismay and frustration, deep and dire,
With naught but 4G, my hotspot, to conspire.

This morn, sans hotspot, I didst try once more,
To join their network, but alas, 'twas poor,
Their WiFi, weak and faltering, didst decline,
And left me bereft, with naught but time to whine.

The staff, unmoved, didst offer little aid,
And seemed to think my plight, a mere charade,
So, with a heavy heart, I didst depart,
And vowed, no more, to grace their doorstep smart.

Oh, 61B, how couldst thou, with WiFi so faint,
Entice me in, with promises of connect, and gain?
A pox upon thy house, and all who dwell,
In this, thy pit of desp'rate darkness, and hell."

"Methinks, fair sir, I didst ponder much upon this gym membership, which doth lie so near my humble abode. Forsooth, I hath been a Golds member in days of yore, but alack, their hospitality didst leave much to be desired. Verily, 'twas as though I purchased a second-hand carriage! Nay, I shall save my coins and work up a sweat at Nellis AFB, anon, and suffer not the tribulations of their poor service."

"Foul and loathsome, a sight most vile.
Sat I down, and forth he brought
Egg noodles and duck sauce, a meal most base.
Upon his head, long black tresses lay,
A crown most unkempt, and full of disgrace.
Up rose I, and forth I walked away."

"Foulest eatery in all of Arizona,
Where culinary delights are but a distant memory.
A Budget Gourmet meal, hastily prepared,
Doth taste as Applebee's doth, 'tis quite declared.

'Tis said they use the microwave's heat,
To cook their dishes, oh what a feat!
Pasta Alfredo, a sorry sight,
Microwaved, no taste, a pitiful plight.

The only cause to step within,
Is for their happy hour, where drinks are kin.
But fare thee well, dear gastronome,
For at Applebee's, thou shalt find naught but woe."

"O, how the name doth mock the meal!
Fish and chips, they call it, yet
No malt vinegar doth grace the plate,
Nor hot sauce to spice the fare.
Shrimp, a mere 10% of its form,
Doth hide beneath a crust of batter.
Fish, in patties, not in fillets,
Doth make me question all the matter.
Yet still, the crowds do gather here,
To feast on food that doth not cheer.
I'll stick to mine own fish and chips,
Back home, where taste and sense doth grip."

"Alas, my friends, how my spirits did sink,
When first I saw the meager spread they'd link,
A buffet, they called it, but in truth,
'Twas but a paltry selection, with little youth.

The line, it moved at pace most slow and painful,
And for a bottle of champagne, I did pay,
Fifteen dollars, a sum most woeful,
For wine that did not even make me gay.

We ventured forth, to sample of their fare,
But found the victuals to be quite unfair,
Less than average, I must confess,
Like some local buffet, where prices do press.

We searched in vain, for dishes to delight,
But found instead, a sorry sight,
Macaroni and cheese, toast, these were our choices,
Safe, but hardly worth the price, in my voice.

So heed my words, dear friends, and take my advice,
Go elsewhere, and pay a similar price,
For better food, and a more pleasant repast,
Than this poor buffet, which doth not last."

"Methinks my kin and I didst stumble upon this place,
Our hunger pangs didst drive us to its doors,
A pleasant atmosphere didst greet our eyes,
And thus we sat, and ordered all we could devise.

The clock didst tick, and forty-five minutes passed,
Yet still our bellies felt not satisfied,
I asked the chef for a roll, a simple request,
But lo, he drowned it in a sickly sweet disguise.

I didst protest, saying it was not to my taste,
He accused me of using too much soy, what a waste,
My meal was ruined, basic rolls didst suffice,
And thus I left, with naught but disappointment's vice.

The fish, too, didst seem not fresh from the sea,
A shame, for such potential didst this place have in thee."

"Upon a Sunday eve, my dearest wife didst celebrate her natal day,
And to a nearby Chinese eatery, we didst make our way.
I had been there before, and found the fare to be just fine,
But alas, last night's experience didst leave much to be desired, I do confess.

The flavors were dull, and lacked the zest of former feasts,
No egg foo young, a staple dish, didst grace the table, alack!
Wonton soup, with naught but broth, didst leave me in dismay,
And hot and spicy dishes, didst fail to ignite my taste, I say.

The cost, oh how it didst mount, two meals and tea,
A sum of twenty-eight dollars, eighty cents, didst come to be.
Taco Bell or Subway, a better choice, I now perceive,
Or Lin's, whose fare hath ne'er failed to please, I do believe.

Never again, I vow, shall I return to this place,
For mediocrity and high prices, doth not a good meal make, in this case."

"Alas, poor Casadee doth complain of her lot,
With stripper clients and colleagues, she doth fret.
In Las Vegas, she doth style hair with great skill,
Yet doth she mock those who do come to her still.

She doth say that someone tall and thin is blessed,
But I, a curvy maiden, doth take offense.
For though I may not be as tall and lean,
I love my body, and no man shall make me feel mean.

Casadee, an assistant of little maturity,
Doth show her immaturity in her speech and her attitude.
Her extensions may be fine, but her cut and color doth lack,
And so, this salon doth receive but one star from my hand."

"Alack, I've had pedicures at this place ere now,
But each time, they do grow worse and woeful.
This last visit, the water was so hot,
It burned my skin, a first-degree woe, alas!
The woman, too, did handle my feet with nary a care,
Her touch, so rough, it did leave me feeling bare."

"In sooth, our maiden visit to this establishment was naught but woeful. We entered, and, lo, no hostess didst greet us with a smile. We wandered, lost, until I didst inquire of her, 'Pray tell, good woman, mayhap we might sit in yonder bar?' She waved us on, without a care, nor offered menu or guidance. We sat, forsooth, at yonder bar, for full fifteen minutes, and, verily, ten waiters and busboys didst pass us by, unheeding. Wherefore, we rose, and, forthwith, didst depart. And, mark you well, the hostess didst not deign to speak a single word. 'Twas not a busy eve, and thus, the more, methinks, their neglect doth sting. We shall not return to Jonny Fox's again!"

"A pox upon this wretched diner, foul and vile!
'Tis never the same, a constant state of flux.
The cook, a thrifty soul, doth seek the lowest price,
And thus, the fare doth suffer, lacking in grace.

Oh, how I yearn for Biscuits Cafe, a place of consistency,
Where quality doth reign supreme, in unity.
But here, alas, 'tis naught but a sorry sight,
A kitchen ruled by thrift, devoid of delight.

I shall not return, forsooth, to this den of woe,
For better fare doth await, at a higher cost, I know."

"Pray, good sir, do not squander thy time,
For Outback Steakhouse doth await,
Where meats are cooked with finesse divine,
And seasoned well, beyond debate.

Or shouldst thou choose to walk a bit,
Then hasten thee to Texas de Brazil,
Where grilled delights doth please thy wit,
And satisfy thy hunger's keen trial."

"Methinks I did partake of a cheeseburger at this establishment yesternight. Alas, the patty didst taste as though 'twere warmed twice, or mayhap thrice, and lacked the savory flavors that doth make my mouth to water. Fie upon't! The service, however, didst prove most excellent, and the victuals didst arrive with haste, praise be to the microwave! Yet, alack, I shall ne'er return to this place, forsooth."
