"Hark! Palms poker room doth cease to be,
Closed last week, naught but empty space,
The employee, in wonder didst express,
As did I, though not entirely aghast,
For 'neath new management, the hotel doth strive,
To find fresh means of profit, and thus doth thrive."

"In fair Las Vegas, two groups didst decide,
To partake of victuals, a Food Network guide.
One group of four, didst order three dishes,
The other, six, with tacos, their wish.

All came forth, in twos, ten minutes apart,
The food, not worth dying for, I do declare.
But Bombay taco, didst please my taste,
Refried beans, a horror, I didst not waste.

Service, poor, and slow, it didst seem,
When college's in session, a long wait, 'twill bring.
I shall not return, fearing long delay,
Yet, the venue, interesting, didst play."

"Hark, what woe is this? My carriage, brought hither for repair, doth wait in vain. Fifteen minutes pass, yet nary a soul doth acknowledge mine presence. Slow, indeed, doth seem the service here. Nay, not a whit of friendliness doth grace the brow of yonder servitor. When my contract doth expire, ne'er shall I darken this door again."

"O, woe is me! Alack, what sorrows doth this hotel bring! I pray thee, let me give it negative stars, for it doth not deserve a single one. I knew not of its lowly state, but still, the price and location did entice. Alas, the parking structure, a woeful sight, didst confound us for a good half hour. No signs, no guidance, naught but confusion did it bring. And when we finally did arrive, a pile of foul towels did block our path. Dirty and unclean, they did lie in wait. I called the desk, and they did offer an upgrade, but lo, it was the same room, two floors higher up. A view of the strip, they did promise, but alas, the Carnival Bar didst play its music loud and long, till late into the night. My friend, poor soul, didst have to leave, sick and tired, and unable to rest. The next morn, we didst depart, and paid dearly for another hotel. Alas, I say, thou couldst not pay me to stay at Imperial once more!"

"Alas, three troubles vex mine eyes:

1. A fork, I pray thee, for my meal,
For chopsticks, though they challenge, do steal
My patience, and my hunger doth grow.

2. Two dishes, hot, I did request,
But lo, they came, and both were cold,
A sorrow, indeed, that doth infect
My appetite, and doth make me bold.

3. A roll, a single one, they gave,
Squashed in a container, oh, what a shame!
With ginger and wasabi, it did crave
Attention, but alas, 'twas not the same.
The dumplings, in their aluminium home,
Did rest, content, and free from woe.

Oh, how I wish my meal were so,
But nay, 'tis not, and thus I moan,
Disappointment doth my spirit seize,
And sadness doth my heart now own."

"Alas, my dear friend, I could not reach them by a prepaid token. Oh, woe is me! How pitiful a sight, this American business so small! Shame upon thee, Maid Affordable, for thy poor commerce customs!"

"In days of yore, when I was but a lad,
Hometown Buffet was a place I oft did gladly visit,
For the victuals there were of the finest sort,
And my belly didst sing with joy and contentment.

But alas, how times doth change! Last year,
My mother and I didst venture to the place,
And though the grub was still quite tasty,
I didst feel a strange and woeful sensation,
As if the food didst not agree with mine innards.
And lo, the very thought of it doth make me shudder!

And yet, my mother didst insist we return,
To celebrate her birth, a day most dear.
But oh, the horrors that didst greet mine eyes!
The seatings were few, and the custom sparse,
The bathroom, a place of woe and despair,
Didst stink and reek of filth and disrepair.

But one bright spot didst shine amidst the gloom,
A maiden fair, with hair in ponytail,
Didst serve with grace and kindness, beyond compare,
Her dedication didst make mine heart most cheer.

But alas, the rest of the staff didst seem,
To care not a whit for their work, nor their dreams.
The food, once a source of joy and delight,
Didst taste of naught but bitter disappointment and fright.

I couldst not finish mine second plate,
The thought of it didst make mine stomach turn and churn,
The only sweetness found, was in the dessert,
A small reprieve from the culinary storm.

Oh, why doth my mother persist in going thither?
Is it but for the price, so low and thin?
For there be better places, with food most fair,
And service, that doth make mine heart sing and cheer.

In days of old, my parents didst visit this place,
And the spaghetti they didst eat, didst bring them woe and disgrace.
Yet still, my mother doth return, time and again,
Though the food didst not agree with her, nor bring her peace within.

Oh, Hometown Buffet, how art thou fallen,
From grace and glory, to such a sorry state?
I fear, I shall not return, nor eat thy food again,
For there be better choices, and more worthy of mine gain."

"Beware, good sir! Forsooth, this place doth hold many woeful tales of wretched billing woes. The front office, alas, doth not aid thee in thy quest for fairness and truth. Keep close watch on thine own balances and insurance, lest thou be billed for services ne'er rendered. Alas, 'twas so for me, despite my pleas and proofs, they didst persist in their erroneous ways. May fortune guide thee better than it didst me."

"Upon the patio, I didst step, and straightaway didst meet the rudest of security folk.  Two small tables only, didst they provide for sitting, and within the building, precious little space for sitting didst there be.  A poor layout indeed, didst it seem.  To the bar, I didst make my way, to order a drink, and waited patiently, ere the barkeep didst attend to me.  But lo, a drunken sot, didst push his way, most impolitely, nigh upon me, and the barkeep, didst attend to him, ere he didst acknowledge me, the sober lady, who didst wait with patience.  I didst push the drunkard off, and bid him cease, his boorish behavior, and the barkeep, didst speak to me, in manner most curt, as if I were the cause, of the disturbance.  My husband and I, didst concur, that the place didst suck, the seating, the building, and the staff, didst all, most foully, stink."

"A lengthy wait didst mar the joy of yuletide feast,
And when at last the victuals were presented,
Their quality didst leave much to be desired.
Alas, the anticipation hadst been great,
But alack, the fare didst not meet expectations.
'Twas a sorry state of affairs, indeed."

"Pray tell, good sir or madam, do not utilize their services, forsooth. I didst call upon the sixth day of October, forsooth, to entreat their aid in ridding our bedchamber of certain termite tunnels that didst threaten our restful slumber. And lo, they didst schedule an appointment for the thirtieth day of October, a fortnight hence. Moreover, I didst send a renewal fee of ninety-nine gold coins, as requested. Alas, their efforts didst prove futile, for they didst merely chase the pests from one chamber to another, leaving us still plagued by their presence. In my ire, I didst inform the receptionist of my intent to seek a swifter solution with another company, and didst threaten to cancel our contract forthwith. Her response, though courteous, didst bespeak a lack of concern for our patronage."

"Hark, since new masters did assume the throne,
Things have declined with haste, nay, fallen quite alone.
Coupons, once a blessing, now doth cease to be,
And sales, that did entice, are no more seen, ye see.
The staff, once numerous, now doth dwindle down,
And prices, they do rise, most unreasonably, I say.
Alas, good sir or madam, seek elsewhere, forsooth,
For better deals, and not this woeful plight, doth lie."

"Disappointment doth reign supreme, my friends,
At Caesar's buffet, a sorry sight it doth present.
A fellow of our company didst swear
It was a feast fit for a king, but alas, 'twas not so dear.

Upon arriving on Memorial Day morn,
We found the spread to be quite paltry, and the cost, quite born.
The selection, meager, with but a few choice bits,
Omelets, prime rib, shrimp, and sushi, that's all that hits.

The quality, perchance, doth make up for the lack,
But waiting in line, a tedious task, doth take its toll, I reckon.
And when compared to others of its ilk,
Caesar's buffet doth pale, a sorry, sorry silk.

In conclusion, my friends, let this be a lesson,
To not believe each word that doth come from a messenger's session.
For though it may seem grand, a closer look doth show,
Caesar's buffet, a disappointment, a sorry, sorry blow."

Yester-morn, I did return for oil change,
And found a change within the place,
The lads, Carlos or Chris, nowhere in sight,
A man named Mario, with laughter did say,
Their time with company, had come to an end,
And thus, I did continue with service, my friend.

But tell me, why did Mario shake his head,
As if in jest, when trying to sell me goods?
His eyes, so red and bloodshot, did seem,
As if he'd partaken in some wicked scheme.
Another employee, with similar gaze,
Did make me wonder, if they'd lost their ways.

Unprofessional, indeed, it did appear,
As if they'd been indulging in some cheer.
I do implore, they random drug tests take,
To ensure their workers, are not mistaking.
For Carlos or Chris, were the best of men,
My loyalty, to them, shall ever be then.
If they return, and cleanliness doth reign,
Perhaps, my visits, shall not be in vain.

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall us then,
At Noodle Asia, where we didst dine.
For twenty minutes, nay, a half hour passed,
Ere anyone didst deign to take our order, alas!
And though we hadst good converse at the table,
'Twas vexing, indeed, to see others served,
Whose seats were taken after ours, I do declare.
I sought a waitress thrice, in vain,
Before the hostess came, to take our order, in disdain.
Our victuals came, some quarter hour later,
And drinks, another ten minutes didst lag.
No one didst come to refresh our cups,
Leaving us parched, in sorrow and despair.
But lo, I found some solace in this woe,
That others too, didst suffer likewise, I do know.
For three other tables, in like plight,
Didst rise, to seek attendance, day and night.
Alas, poor Noodle Asia, on that night,
Didst falter, with service most uncivil, in sight.
And so, I vow, ne'er to return,
To that place, where my patience didst burn.
No thanks, I'll find my noodles elsewhere,
In a place where service is not so dire."

In sooth, I didst prefer Canteen to this wretched place,
Where service was poor, and staff didst show no grace.
Their rudeness didst mar my visit, day and night,
And waiting at the bar, a tedious plight.
Twenty minutes passed, and still the bartender didst not see,
Engrossed in chat with friends, he didst ignore me.
We didst depart with haste, and to the hostess didst impart,
Our discontent, ere we didst leave that woeful mart.
But, in fairness, music was good, and cleanliness didst reign,
In restauant and bathroom, a pleasant sight didst obtain.

"Alas, my dear friends, since those two gems did part,
I fear this salon may never regain its former art.
But fear not, for those who seek the duo's skill,
May find them here, though GHH would not reveal their will.

Canyon Falls Spa and Salon, a place of rest,
Located on W Craig Rd, Las Vegas' finest quest.
With Nicole, the same sweet soul who made appointments before,
You may still find solace, and beauty to adore."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern, dear to none,
Whose victuals are both bland and o'ersalted, one.
No flavor doth abide within its walls,
Save for the hours of night, when all else fails.
And e'en then, 'tis but a paltry sum,
Two dollars ninety-five, a price most humble.
Yet, were thou in such straits, my friend,
As to be forced to seek this woeful end,
Pray heed my words, and enter not,
Forsooth, thy taste buds shall be forgot."

"Hark! This place doth stink, good sirs and madams!  The service, slow and poor, doth make us frown.  The management, a pox upon their house!  And atmosphere, a dreary, woeful place.  Farewell, we shall not darken thy door again.  Forsooth, Green Valley Ranch, our next port o' call."

"Upon a Friday, I didst venture hither,
Missing breakfast, alas, what a bitter fate!
We sat us down at eleven, and didst wait,
For water, a mere minute, no great haste.
The waitress, a merry lass, didst say,
'Twas but a moment, the glasses, fresh from the fray.
Nachos, we didst order, a dish most fine,
Forty minutes passed, ere they didst arrive,
But arrive they didst, and oh, how grand,
We didst devour them, with great zeal and hand.
Our meals, they didst take, a full hour to come,
Awaiting, we didst, with growing discontent.
At the bar, folk didst sit, already fed,
Ere our victuals, didst reach our plates, 'twas dread.
I, a Caesar salad, didst choose, alack,
The lettuce, whole, didst lie upon the plate,
No chopping, done, the veggies, great chunks,
A disappointment, indeed, my taste didst blunt.
My love, a steak taco, didst select,
But found it flavorless, a poor inspect.
One taco, he didst eat, then didst desist,
Satisfied, he was not, nor didst persist.
I know not, if the delay, didst cause,
Our meals, to linger, in waiting's thrall.
Hot or cold, the nachos, not a one,
Nor tacos, flavorless, all were undone.
Though the nachos, good, didst seem,
Here, again, I shall not deign to dream."

"Twas a feast most foul, a meal most dire,
That I didst partake in, with mine own sire.
In town I was, for holiday didst stray,
And with mine parents, didst dine away.

The service, poor, and staff, didst seem,
As though they had not yet, their shift didst dream.
I played it safe, and tacos, didst choose,
Of chicken, flavorless, with cilantro, didst abuse.

A bite of fish, my father's plate, didst take,
Okay, it was, but naught, didst make it great.
Their menu, lacking, in imagination, didst show,
And begrudgingly, didst sit, didst wait, didst go.

But lo, a curse, didst soon befell,
A case of salmonella, didst my belly swell.
My mother, too, didst fall, didst vomit, didst decay,
And Christmas, didst spend, in misery, didst lay.

No presents, didst open, didst enjoy,
Until I left, didst fly, didst employ.
And when I didst weigh, didst find, didst see,
Ten pounds, less, didst be, didst decree.

Nevermore, will I, send not, didst say,
For fear of food, didst send, didst play."

"Methought, fair sir, the price most fair,  
For two pizzas, scarce couldst believe mine eyes.  
But lo, my daughter of six winters,  
Didst partake of this selfsame delight,  
With her sire, the weekend past, alack.  
And verily, she didst feel most woe,  
Her belly didst churn, and up came the meal.  
I questioned her, and her sire as well,  
And both didst swear, 'twas not their first spell.  
So, gentle friends, beware this pizza curse,  
Lest ye wish to lose some weight, or prove  
Thy mettle, with a stomach made of steel."

"O, woe is me! My heart doth ache with sorrow,
For CPK hath failed me, and my love doth dwindle.
A Chicken Ceasar sandwich, once my heart's desire,
Now gone, and naught but memories to fire.
I called, hoping against hope, to find a way,
To have it made anew, on ciabatta's gentle sway.
But alas, the lady's words did mock my plight,
And drove I did, in vain, through morning's light.
For when I reached the place, they told me plain,
That nay, they could not make it, nor refrain.
My love for CPK, now lost and gone astray,
Shall nevermore return, come what may."

"Alas, wherefore art thou, good Chinese eatery? Methinks I've moved to this fair side of town, and thus, didst decide to partake in a culinary adventure. Lo mein, a simple dish, naught that shouldst be amiss in a Chinese kitchen. I called ahead, and 'twas ready when I arrived, fifteen minutes hence. The lady, kind and courteous, yet, alack, didst charge two silver pence more than the menu's worth. I said naught, but my actions didst speak louder than words, and thus, I left no gratuity. The restaurant, filled with canned victuals, doth reek of staleness. Fie upon it!

"Yet, determined to find a treasure, I didst venture forth, with an open mind and heart. Alas, 'twas naught but junk that lay before mine eyes. Slimy noodles, drenched in a strange, thick sauce, smothered the dish, and a single floret of broccoli, scarce enough to call it a vegetable feast. A pound of cabbage, a cheap substitute, indeed, yet, naught that I didst order. Farewell, dear restaurant, ne'er shall I return. Mayhap, fortune shall smile upon me, and guide me to a place of gastronomic delight, in fair Henderson."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern! Twice I tried their brew,
A banana margarita, flavorless, alas,
And coconut, with ants alive, a sight most foul.
I did not drink it, nor could I stomach their grub,
Chilaquiles made with naught but tortilla scraps,
And flavor, oh where art thou? In this place, none.
Their decor is pleasant, staff, friendly too,
But ants in my drink, a sight most strange, I do declare.
My meal, they did comp, in pity, I suppose,
But ne'er again shall I darken their door, no more!"

"Hark, what news is this? Items they do possess, yet not for sale, alas. The garb that doth adorn yon mannequins, forsooth, doth not await a buyer's hand. Fie upon this wretched place, how vile and loathsome 'tis!"

"Alas, poor Luxor, thy buffet doth leave much to be desired. Twice didst I partake of their offerings, and both times didst my taste buds suffer greatly. Frozen and thawed, the dishes didst seem, with nary a hint of flavor or zest. Yuck, didst I say? Aye, verily. Lunchtime brought forth dry, overcooked pork, fowl fried to a crisp, and beef Stroganoff most woeful. My spouse and I, we didst not enjoy a single morsel, no, not even the sweet treats. Alas, how dost one manage to ruin dessert? Ask Luxor, for they have mastered this feat. But lo, the Sunday champagne brunch didst bring some solace, for with drink didst all things taste better."

"This wretched place doth leave much to be desired!  My spouse, he didst order crab cakes, alas, they didst taste of fish from a tin, and I, I didst have the fried catfish, verily, 'twas naught but a disappointment.  The coating, merely cornmeal, and the flesh, so dry and flavorless.  The sides, they were lackluster, the coleslaw, overly sweet, yet the cornbread, quite good.  But alack, the woman who didst serve us, her demeanor, most unfriendly.  She didst fling our meals upon the table, in to-go boxes, no less!  And pricy, they be.  A deal, we didst have, with chicken, and ne'er shall we return."

"O, woe is me! A traveler, weary and worn,
I sought refuge in this inn, but lo,
It proved a den of filth and disarray,
A place where one would not wish to stay.

The carpet, foul and dirty, did offend,
With loose threads and debris, ill-kept,
And bed throws, covered with gray hair,
Did make me shudder with disgust and fear.

The furniture, it blocked the outlets all,
So I could not plug in my devices,
And when I called for help, they did reply,
"We'll send someone up, or so they did devise.

But alas, the entertainment center, too,
Was worn and faded, with laneer peeling,
And wallpaper, peeling, drapes awry,
A sorry state, indeed, and nothing cheerful.

The bathroom, fair, was the sole delight,
In this, my journey, otherwise quite night.
I asked the manager, if newer rooms they had,
But no, they said, and offered to move me, quite sad.

So, here I'll stay not, for this place, I'll shun,
And seek a better inn, when next in town,
For though it be convenient, 'tis not worth,
The discomfort and the dirt, that doth abound."

"Thrice didst I venture to Autozone, seeking replacement for my battery, which under warranty didst lie. A printout, from my mechanic's device, didst I bring, declaring the battery to be in ill health. Michael, the manager, with thirty-five years of ASE certification, didst proclaim, "This battery, good and true, doth be." He urged a parasitic diagnostic test, to determine the root of the woe. But twice, my mechanic had linked my chariot, and both times, the diagnosis, a faulty battery didst show. \n\nAt last, the battery, didst Michael test, and lo, his machine, didst reveal, 'twas indeed, a bad battery, alack. Farewell, I say, to this Autozone, and its poor customer service, forevermore."

"O, woeful day! The restaurant, half-empty lay,
Yet we, a party of five, didst wait, they say.
For three twosomes, room didst make, ere we,
But I, to ask, didst go, how long to be.
'Twas answered thus, with naught but vexation,
'Awhile, good sir, thou must await thy turn.'
The servers, idle, sat, in conversation deep,
But us, their aid, didst not forthcoming keep.
We left, and sought the Kona Grill, where we didst dine,
And there, our hunger, didst find its peace, and fine."

"Alas, poor hotel, how art thou fallen from grace!
We entered, and our chamber did await,
But lo, the door, unlocked, did freely open,
As if no key were needed, nor lock to shut.
I summoned a housekeeper, to inquire,
If this were intentional, or some wily trick.
She said 'twas not, and so I did implore,
A new room, with a lock, to keep secure.
The front desk, didst take a moment, to repair,
On a Sunday eve, when lobby was empty, bare.
In second room, a half-filled drink didst sit,
In frigid cold, within the refrigerator's pit.
I called the desk, to voice my discontent,
And they, the ventors, didst the blame present.
Oh, how the standards of cleanliness, doth slip,
And service, once expected, now doth dip.
Methought, I stayed at Holiday Inn, alack!"

"A pox upon this pizza place, I say!
Though swift their delivery, 'twas but cold,
The pasta, too, was naught but tepid, ay.
And when I sought the manager's ear,
I waited sixteen minutes, full and fair.
But when I spoke, my voice was lost,
As if some wicked spell had been enacted.
What sorcery is this, that they employ?
I shall not rate them well, no, not a whit!"

"A yearlong trial of Keller and JADD's stewardship didst leave me unimpressed, my friends. New faces each time we spoke, none knew of past agreements made. High turnover, a cause for concern, indeed. No record of previous deeds, a lack of continuity, it seemed. My unit, in disarray, I found, upon taking reigns. Damages galore, repairs costing me a pretty penny, I must confess. Deposits returned, no word of flaws, a mystery, alas. Investors, take heed, seek a steadfast manager, lest thy riches suffer similar fate."

"Hark, I say, good sirs, avoid this place,
For tacos of lengua, o'ercooked they be,
Lie mush upon the plate, full of grease,
A sight most foul, and taste, I do surmise.

And enchiladas of chicken, dry they be,
Soaked in green sauce, a woeful sight,
Killing the dish, and all delight,
Leaving naught but sorrow and despair.

I pray thee, friend, seek elsewhere,
For Mexican fare, of better cheer,
For here, 'tis naught but woe and disappointment,
A place to shun, and ne'er revisit."

"Hark, good sir! I pray thee, heed my words of woe,
For after dining at yon pizzeria, I didst feel most low.
A pox upon the place, forsooth! My gut didst churn and twist,
As if the pizza hadst been laced with some vile potion, cursed.

The crust, so thin and weak, couldst not withstand
The weight of cheese, so copious and grand.
It sagged and drooped, a sorry sight,
Like a maiden's heart, when love doth take flight.

And spinach, precious little, didst adorn
The pie, a paltry sprinkling, a meager dawn.
Feta, thou art a cruel mistress, indeed,
For thy taste, so strong, didst leave me in dire need.

Yet, one kind soul, a maiden fair and bright,
Didst tend the counter, with a smile so light.
But alas, her charm, couldst not make amends,
For the pizza, a culinary abomination, that offends.

So, gentle reader, heed my warning,
And shun this place, lest thou desire a morning of mourning.
For though the pizza may seem fair and bright,
'Tis a poison, a plague, a wicked blight."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern, dear my friends,
'Tis not worth thy time, nor yet thy pence.
The victuals be below par, service poor,
Naught special doth this place hold in store.
I'd not return, for there be better places,
On the strip, where thou mayst spend thy days.
The drinks, alas, be paltry, and slow,
In coming, like a snail, doth the refill flow.
And mark, how long it takes for coffee new,
Ten minutes, by my reckoning, doth it brew.
The staff, in fetching water, doth but jest,
A sorry sight, and cause for endless quest.
Alas, I must, with heavy heart, give one star,
For this place be naught but empty, void of charm."

"A pox upon the house of Whole Foods, that doth conspire
With towing companies, to fleece the unsuspecting shopper.
For in their parking lot, a trap doth lie in wait,
To seize thy car, and demand a hefty ransom.

Oh, woe is me, a victim of this scam,
Who went to shop, but found myself in shame.
The towing company, with no regard for decency,
Didst demand one hundred thirty-five dollars, in cash, thou see.

And Whole Foods, with a shrug and a smile,
Didst wash their hands of the matter, all the while.
For they do business with this band of thieves,
And leave their customers to suffer, as they weave.

Beware, good shoppers, of this parking lot snare,
And bring an extra hundred thirty-five, to spare.
Or better yet, avoid this den of thieves,
And seek out Trader Joe's, where parking is free, and lives are saved."

"Beware, good sirs and madams, of this place,
Where my dear wife didst venture last week,
And was beset by folk of glassy race,
Who didst attempt a scam most foul and weak.

They didst essay to hoodwink her, poor soul,
With tales of windshields broken, and such like,
And didst endeavour to charge it to her role,
In the guise of insurance, a clever trick.

But fear not, for my wife, wise guile,
Didst see through their ruse, and didst depart,
Never to return, with haste and speed,
For she didst know their wicked intent and art.

So heed my words, and shun this place,
Lest thou befall a similar disgrace."

"A platter of chicken and beef, teriyaki-style, didst I receive,
With rice, a scant amount, and salad, most woeful,
Few bits of meat, a sorry sight, didst it reveal,
A rippoff, indeed, at ten dollars, ninety-five,
Nevermore shall I set foot within that place,
For sushi, seek ye out Yummy Grill Sushi's embrace,
A haven of delight, with food most divine,
Pray, do not tarry, and taste their culinary shine."

"Hark! If thou doth sign up for this TV service, be sure to inquire of them,
If they do run a hard or soft credit inquiry, lest thou be misled.
For if they say 'twill be a soft inquiry, yet they do run a hard one,
Thou mayst dispute it, and thy case shall be won.

But alas! Expect no accountability from those who hold the power,
For they do transfer thee from one to another, hour upon hour.
Even when thou dost speak with supervisors, thy plight doth seem,
To fall upon deaf ears, as if they didst not hear or see.

And mark this well, good sir! When promotions end,
Do cancel them forthwith, lest thou pay in the end.
For premium channels and NFL Sunday Ticket, they doth come,
At a cost, unless thou dost take heed of this warning, ere it be done.

In conclusion, I am not pleased, my friends,
For this TV service hath left me in disarray, and with no end.
The monopoly of television and telecommunications, doth reign supreme,
Leaving us naught but woe, and no recourse, it doth seem."

"Alack, what woeful pizza doth thou bring!
Thy toppings, hidden, do no flavors sing.
The sauce, a mere suggestion, doth not cling
To crust, so plain, it doth my senses sting.

A Veggie Downtown, of medium size,
With mushrooms, peppers, onions, olives, didst rise.
But alas, their presence, doth not suffice
To save this pizza from its sorry state.

Quickly, it came, and late, they didst stay
Open, for those who crave, a pie, by day.
But nay, dear friend, this pizza, doth not sway
My taste, for better, far away.

Totino's Party Pizzas, my love, doth say
Better, they be, in every single way.
Ouch, how true, thy words, they cut so deep,
For this pizza, doth leave me, in dismay."

"A pox upon this wretched place, where'er I sought
To claim my tickets, paid for in good faith.
The afternoon, it was, when first I tried,
But lo, they would not give them to me, nor let me pass.

My friends and I, we came again at night,
But still, the lady said, they stopped at midnight.
The email, it did say, no tickets would be printed then,
And so, my friends, we were left in discontent.

Oh, how the line did crawl, and slow it moved,
A plague upon this place, that doth not prove
Its worth, for such a trouble doth it bring.
I'll ne'er return, nor spend my coin again."

"Hark, what news is this? A burrito, fair California,
Thou didst provide me with a meal most vile and woeful.
The potatoes, raw they did taste, and foul, the meat,
As if 'twere cooked in haste, or left to spoil and rot.
The tortilla, a morsel sweet, the only part that pleased,
But all the rest, alas, did make my stomach churn and boil.
A friend, a noble sir, did taste the dish, and lo,
He did cast up his accounts, in utter woe and despair.
I, in dismay, did swear, never to return again,
To that place, where such foul food did make me suffer."

"Last eve, the eighteenth of October, I didst venture to yon Buffalo Wild Wings, a place of repute for delectable victuals and merriment, to celebrate my husband's natal day. Our daughter, wise guiding light that she is, didst choose the venue, and my spouse, agreeable soul that he be, didst give his assent, owing to the fond memories we didst hold of a previous visit to their establishment. Alas, our experience on this night didst pale in comparison to our former encounter. Verily, 'twas a sorry state of affairs!

A wait of thirty minutes didst ensue ere we couldst be seated, a delay excusable given the vigor of the evening's revelry. Once settled, our thirst didst await slaking, some ten minutes passed ere our server didst bring our sodas, her busyness notwithstanding. Yet, the true grievance doth lie in the tardiness of our repast. Two chicken dishes and a burger, our order didst require a span of forty-five minutes to arrive, a duration unacceptable, though the night didst teem with merrymakers. And, alack, when finally delivered, my husband's hamburger and fries didst arrive chilled, a culinary faux pas indeed!

The manager, a man of scant consolation, didst proffer his apologies and a discount of fifteen percent, a paltry solace for our woe. In conclusion, dismal service didst beset us at this Buffalo Wild Wings, and ne'er shall we return."

"Fie upon this wretched victual! I didst order thee, French dip sandwich, yet what didst thou bring me? A sorry excuse for pork, boiled within an inch of its life, and served upon a bun most bland. The scent of it didst offend mine nostrils, and the taste didst leave much to be desired. I didst take but one small bite, and forthwith didst spit it out. 
Thou didst offer to replace it with a cheeseburger, a dish I thought most simple and hard to mangle. Alas, thy cook didst prove me wrong! The meat, whatever it may have been, didst lack the proper doneness, and thus didst I return it to thee. 
Thy cheese fries, too, didst suffer from an overzealous application of heat, causing the cheese to become burnt and unpalatable. 
Yet, there was one dish that didst please mine taste buds - the spinach and artichoke dip. 'Twas quite good, indeed! My only suggestion wouldst be to cut those artichoke hearts into smaller, bite-sized pieces, that they might be more easily consumed."

Oh woeful day! What poor service doth this place provide?
A solitary man, with naught but scorn in his eyes,
Didst stare at me, yet would not deign to reply.
My queries, left unanswered, didst pierce the skies.
Unprofessional, indeed! No greeting nor salutation,
Didst he offer, leaving me in utter dismay.
Seek not this place, dear friends, for aid or succour,
But rather, venture downstairs to Pearle Vision's bower.
There, a better fate didst befall mine eyes,
With courteous folk, who didst attend my needs with guise.

"Hark! When thou ent'rest a tavern of Mexico,
And inquirest of the server, what doth burn,
He replieth, 'Alas, good sir, we possess not
Much fiery fare to stir thine appetite.'
Then art thou in a sorry plight, my friend,
For naught but woe doth lie ahead, I fear.
Their mild dishes shall not satisfy thy crave,
Nor shall their tepid sauces lift thy spirits high.
Avoid, then, such eateries of little worth,
And seek instead the fiery, spicy feast,
That doth await thee at a place of more renown,
Where flames of flavor dance upon thy tongue."

"If there be a place of business that doth merit a rating of naught but woe, 'twould be the Chandler location, where rogues and thieves do dwell. They didst provide an estimate, fair and square, yet the final tally, alas, didst prove to be tenfold the sum. In ire, I didst refuse to pay the fee, but at last, to gain my vehicle's release, I didst relent. A grievance with the BBB shall be filed, for justice doth demand it so."

"Apex, a company of ill repute, didst attempt to entice us with their wares, but alas, their words were naught but empty promises. We didst seek to arrange an appointment, yet they didst ignore our calls, and with great indolence, didst fail to return our messages. A week didst pass, and still, they didst not respond. At last, they didst deign to answer, and we didst discover that their offer was but a ruse. They didst confirm the make, model, and service required, and didst agree upon a price, yet when we didst arrive for our appointed time, they didst demand an additional sum of gold for a most simple task. Tis a pity, for there be many other companies that do provide excellent service at a fair price. Avoid Apex, good sirs and madams, for they be unworthy of thy trust."

"Prithee, good sirs, what woeful fate doth bring thee hither? A plague upon this place, wherein we sit and pine, yet naught but vexation doth await. My turn, they call it, and my name, they know it well, yet still they take the other, and no word of explanation doth break forth from their lips. 'Tis a strange and wondrous thing, how little communication doth pass betwixt those who serve and those who wait. Fie upon this AT&T, a company most craven and lame!"

"Fie upon this wretched place, where filth doth reign supreme!
I, with mine own fair hands, didst wipe clean every surface,
With Lysol wipes, that doth kill all germs and bacteria,
For fear of sickness, I didst refuse their foul towels,
Unchanged, they may be, and thus, a hazard to mine health."

"Upon a Saturday, I chanced upon an oil change coupon of nineteen dollars and ninety-nine cents. With haste, I made an appointment and hastened to the shop, whereupon they drained the old oil from my chariot's heart. And lo, didst they find within that short span of two hours and a half, a plethora of ills that did afflict my poor conveyance? 'Twas said that new spark plugs were needed, and shocks to boot; the rotors must be ground, and brake pads replaced, lest danger lay in wait. A fuel package, too, didst they prescribe, to banish moisture and ensure a smooth ride. My mind didst boggle at the mounting cost, and so I didst demur. Wherefore, Dean, that wily salesman, didst rework the sum four times, till all was said and done, and lo, the bill didst total six score and ten. My husband, bless his soul, didst converse with Dean, and thus, my troubles didst come to an end. But mark my words, dear friends, ne'er shall I set foot in that den of woes again."

"Hark! What fortunes bring me to this place?
Amidst the din of hammers and dusty space,
I sought to show my support, in faith,
For Willy Street, in this, its hour of need.

But lo! The maiden at the counter, fair,
Didst treat us with disdain, and scant regard,
As if our presence did her vex and gall,
And made us feel most unwelcome, indeed.

Alas! How disappointing, that a place
Which should be refuge, doth instead,
Breed feelings of exclusion and disgrace.
I fear I shall not return, nor seek
Their wares again, with such ill will."

"Tried I to order a pizza from yon place,
But lo! The driver didst deliver it to the wrong face.
And when he returned, didst he make any more try?
Nay, he didst not, and left us to wonder why.
I called the store, and they didst say,
'We will not deliver, but keep thy pay.'
A pox upon their house! Avoid their delivery,
For naught but woe doth it bring, I do declare.
I'd give them naught but zero stars, an it were mine to do."

"In days of yore, I did frequent this place,
To purchase incense of the finest grace.
'Twas good, indeed, and brought me joy,
But now, alas! My tale doth employ.

A costly oil, I didst also buy,
And in its fall, it didst meet its demise.
My husband, in his honest guise,
Didst seek to return it, but nay!
The owner, full of woe and disgrace,
Didst accuse him of deceit and base.

A test, they didst perform, with water filled,
And dropped it, to prove their case unsealed.
But lo! The bottle, it didst break,
And thus, their scheme, didst forsake.

Beads and Botanicals, doth now decline,
For honesty, it doth not entwine.
I pray, this shop, doth soon expire,
And with it, all its wicked fire."

"Methinks each visit doth bring us greater woe,
And last eve, it seemed, didst mark our final throw.
A paltry spoonful of fowl didst grace my son's tacos,
Whilst my good man didst request a light dollop of sour cream, lo!
The lass behind the counter didst heap upon his burrito
A quantity most generous, nigh unto a cup, alack!
When my dear spouse didst speak, the maiden didst reply,
"Sorry," and wrapped his meal, her visage stern and dry.
She didst not crack a smile, nor show a whit of cheer,
As we didst pay, and her gaze didst seem to hold a grudge, good sir.
Each time we venture thither, we do find
Less meat within our orders, and thus our discontent doth grow.
Last night, methought, didst mark our final visit, verily."

"A decent car wash, yet beware of deceit,
For there's a windshield replacement crew, so neat,
Their aim, to scam the unsuspecting soul,
My 78-year-old mother, their target whole.

They called Allstate insurance, a claim they made,
But the adjuster saw the chip, so small, not worth the shade,
Rejected the claim, and the replacement crew,
Said "pay cash" with a smile, oh so sleek and true.

My mother, wise, refused, a firm "no" she spoke,
Yet still they call, their tactics, a crooked stroke.
Beware, dear friends, of this car wash's deceit,
And stay away, lest you fall prey to their cheat."

"O, woe is me! Why doth this eatery, Jack-in-the-Box,
So notoriously suck, with naught but woe and vex?
Their lobbies stink, their service poor, their food most foul,
Over-priced, and tasting of the trash, no doubt.

At this Trop location, I didst order fish and fries,
But what didst I receive? Three frozen triangles,
Thrown into a fryer, and then carelessly cast
Into a carton, fit for six, alas! And fries,
Burnt, soggy, and without a napkin or ketchup,
Didst they provide, to add insult to injury.

Their commercials, too, do bother me,
With 'Jack,' that nitwit, and his annoying spree.
He tries to act 'funny,' but doth only vex,
With his 'low-prices,' 'good deals,' and 'great food,'
But doth he give a thought to those who made
His company great? Nay, he doth raise the price,
Of coffee, no less, to $1.81, a sin!
A 99-cent cup should never change, not even
In recession's grip. But nay, they doth desire
To make that extra buck, that quarter, nickel,
And thus, they doth lose customers, like me,
Who now doth shun their restaurants, in misery."

"In sooth, fair friends, I shall recount the tale Of the Great Food Truck Clusterfuck, wherein We found ourselves within a dusty plain, A sea of folk, in lines that ne'er did end. The Festival, in its zeal, didst proclaim Thirty or more trucks wouldst be present, But lo, the number dwindled, alas, to twenty, Or mayhap fewer, who couldst truly say? The lines, they snaked and twisted, full of folk, And each one took a goodly portion of an hour, Or more, to gain but a small sample, mere morsel. Ah, but then, the beer, a trifling thing, Didst require three lines, each one a test, A trial of patience, a true challenge, indeed. Children, free of charge, didst roam and play, Their antics causing chaos, in disarray. Two hours passed, and four trucks we didst try, But alack, dear friends, 'twas not worth the fray. A refund, swift and painless, didst ensue, The staff, in truth, didst do their level best, Despite the tumult, in their heads, a whirl. This first attempt, a lesson, shall they learn, And mayhap, next year, a better show they'll turn."

"Hark! What beastly woman doth beset my way,
With gruff demeanor and uncouth display?
A Wendy's drive-thru, swift and near,
Yet she, a harpy, doth my patience fear.

"Heeeeelooo!" she crieth, with labored breath,
As I, in haste, do seek my hunger's death.
"Umm...hi," I say, with gentle tone,
"Just a moment, pray, till I have shown
My choice, a Swiss Jr Bacon, fair and bright,
With five chicken nuggets, a feast most delight."

She grunts and pants, with heavy breath,
And bids me next, with naught but death.
I wonder what form doth she bear,
So cruel and rude, with visage severe.

At the window, she doth thrust her hand,
Expecting payment, without a stand.
I give my card, and naught but silence doth she make,
Till I ask for ranch, and her voice doth break.

"No, I don't think so," she saith, with scorn,
And hands me food, as if to mock my morn.
I yearn to toss the nuggets in her face,
And flee, ere she doth further grace.

Grrr...such folk doth mar my day,
And put my temper in disarray."

"A friend of mine from Australia came to visit,
And I, in folly, did recommend this place to him.
Convenient, I thought, to my humble abode,
But alas, 'twas the worst choice I e'er had made.

Check-in was late, and no apology did they give,
Just a shrug and a "few hours" wait, they did live.
Double charged, thy room, my friend didst bear,
And when pointed out, they didst argue, without care.

Three days, they disputed, and thy funds, they didst tie,
No apology, nor compensation, didst they provide.
Room service, a farce, a woeful sight,
Fruit, the only dish, that met the light.

So heed my words, good sir, and avoid this place,
For better service, seek another space."

"A platter of noodles and rice, curries and apps, they do possess,
Gyoza and spring rolls, a feast for the eyes, no less.
But, alas, the prices, they do sting, ten coins or more,
And the portions, small, with meat, scarce, to be sure.

Mongolian beef, we didst try, with broccoli, a side,
But, oh, the broccoli, frozen, it didst seem,
And the meat, overcooked, tough, it was, indeed,
Siracha, we didst add, to make it palatable, our need.

Kung pao chicken, I didst order, with rice, instead,
Cabbage and peanuts, plenty, but heat, there was none,
A school cafeteria, couldst have done better, I dare say,
A pity, it was, in truth, a disappointment, nay.

Bahn mi, I didst wish to try, but options, few,
Lemongrass chicken, teriyaki, steak, what, no pork, anon?
A strange place, indeed, overpriced, akin to Pei Wei,
Which one, worse, I know not, but both, a sore sight, to me."

"In summer's heat, I penned this review,
Of resort grand, with units nice, amenities too,
Pool sparkling, a sight to behold,
But luau, alack, a tale to unfold.

To Vegas' finest eateries, my kin and I did stray,
Gordon Ramsay's steakhouse, a culinary way,
Then to the luau, a fateful night,
A soup kitchen, a sorry sight.

The line, long and slow, did wind its course,
Cafeteria fare, a bitter force,
My mind, near lost, in dismay and woe,
For luaus past, this one did not show.

In Hawaii, we've danced with delight,
Feasted on food, a true culinary sight,
But here, alas, a sad, sorry plight,
A luau, shamed, a sorrowful sight."

"Hark! I didst not feel secure within this place,
Upon arrival, signs in parking lot didst convey,
'Beware, dear traveler, keep not valuables in thy car,'
Or words to that effect, I doth recall.

And thus, I didst choose to depart ere break of day,
Lest any of mine belongings be purloined away,
By staff of questionable character, I didst suspect,
And so, I didst flee, to avoid such woeful fate."

"Methinks my wife and I have supped at Kabuto oft,
And ever have we had most wondrous sport.
But lo, the last time we didst venture thither,
'Twas naught but woe and bitter disappointment.

We made reservations, as we always do,
For the sushi bar, where we love to sit.
But alack, they would not seat us, saying
That reservations there they cannot be binding.

Pray tell, what use are reservations, then?
If not to guarantee a place at table?
We spend a pretty penny, three hundred plus,
And for such sum, we do expect some fable.

In Vegas, there be many places to dine,
So, alas, we shall not return to Kabuto's wine."

"O, how I do adore BW3, my heart doth sing its praise! Forsooth, there be times when I do crave a mighty ale and victuals of the tavern sort. Upon a certain Tuesday eve, my spouse and I didst decide to partake of this establishment's fare. We didst enter, and lo, the place was not o'erfilled with patrons, save for a few large groups seated at tables. The hostess didst attempt to seat us amidst these throngs, but I didst suggest we might prefer the bar, or perchance a booth apart from the crowd. \n\nThus, we were seated, and we didst tarry, watching as the serving folk didst flirt and converse, their attentions diverted from their duties. Methought I saw the manager nearby, yet no servant didst approach us, though we didst wait a goodly while. At last, we didst rise and depart, our hunger unassuaged. Alas, I do still yearn for the food, but shall not return to this place, save perhaps to sit at the bar, and that with some hesitation."

"Hark! This place doth seem to be run by cavemen,
Whose manners and ways are most uncivil.
When my party didst complain of poor service,
The manager, a gruff and surly fellow,
Didst challenge my husband to a fight,
At two o'clock, when his shift doth end.
Oh, how classy, Joe's, thou art indeed!"

"Hark! What noise doth come from yonder flat?
Aye, 'tis the sound of revelry and woe,
That keepeth me awake, and doth disturb my rest.
The neighbors below, they play their music loud,
And when I didst complain, they didst reply,
"Twas not that loud, good sir." Oh, how unprofessional!
I shall not tolerate such noise, anon,
For sleep is what I need, to keep my wits about.
And lo! The police didst come, at my behest,
To quell the din and bring some peace to my nest.
But alas! The drugs, they doth permeate the air,
And I, a man of virtue, do detest such vice.
I have seen strangers come and go, in haste,
With face tattoos, a sign of their disgrace.
This place, it doth resemble a den of sin,
Where lawlessness doth reign, and order doth not begin.
So heed my words, good sirs, and avoid this place,
Lest ye desire to dwell in discord and disgrace."

"Fare thee well, good sir! How doth thy meal fare?
Mediocre, thou sayest? Alas, what woeful fate!
And poor, the service? Tsk, tsk, what lack of grace!
No initiative, they show, in filling cups anew,
Nor clearing plates away, with speed and cheer.
Alack, no teamwork too, doth make me sigh.
I prayed for more silverware, but nay,
The server merely gazed, and called to another near,
Without a word, or nod, or any token of respect,
Alas, how sad, this place doth not deserve my love!"

"A plague upon this wretched Subway, where wait times stretch on like a tale of woe. One customer within, and one without, yet still we linger, as if time itself did slow. Meager toppings doth grace the bread, a paltry sight, indeed. Thirty-five minutes pass, and nary a word, until the worker doth say, 'I'll tend to thee anon.' But lo, another quarter hour doth crawl by, and still we tarry. Verily, a poor showing, worthy of naught but scorn. I shall not darken thy doorstep again, thou wretched Subway, forsooth!"

"Tis twice I've dined at Caramba's halls,
In hopes the fare might change with walls.
Alas, the victuals were most vile,
Drowned in a red sauce, a woeful pile.
Caramba, fie upon thy name,
For serving dishes that bring shame.
Thy Mexican cuisine, so bland,
Leaves naught but disgust in this land."

"A pox upon this yogurt shop, I say!
The service was fair, but oh, the yogurt!
Tasted it did, like soured milk, alas!
My love, she had the pineapple sort,
And found it foul, with flavors turned.
Some fruit, it seemed, had gone bad,
But basic tart, that one was not so sad.
Yet still, we shall not return, no more,
For yogurt ill-tasting, we do abhor."

"Hark, good sirs! Today, we dined on burritos,
With rice, aplenty, our bellies to fill.
But lo, the meat within, a sorry sight,
Raw and chewy, a purple hue did take flight.
I pray thee, look and behold, the proof I bring,
A picture, worth a thousand words, doth sing.
A sorry state, indeed, this culinary woe,
Pray tell, how could they go so wrong, I do not know."

"O, woe betide the day we didst step foot within
The hallowed halls of Serendipity 3, forsooth!
A half hour's wait, they didst proclaim, but lo,
An hour and a half didst pass, ere we didst sit, alack!
And then, O cruel fate, our waiter Jeff didst come,
With manners rough and rude, he didst our orders take,
And with each dish, a lecture didst he give,
As though we were but fools, and he, a sage, forsooth!
And thus, with food not worth the wait, nor price,
We didst depart, with tempers frayed, and spirits low,
For nevermore shall we set foot within that place,
Nor wouldst we wish upon our worst enemy, such woe."

"Never have I set foot in San Gennaro's halls,
And now, I fear, I shall not return anon.
A lucky winner of Jelli's radio call,
I made a list of grievances, 'gainst them all.

1. Overpriced, each ride, a costly affair,
$3 to $5 per person, or $10 for all-day fare.
2. Items sold, a price most steep and high,
$9 for a sausage hoagie, oh me, oh my!
3. Layout poor, a clust'ring mess,
Vendors cramped, like birds in a nest.
4. Some booths, a mismatch, out of place,
Scientologists, politicos, sports teams' embrace.
5. Same dishes, served again and again,
A lack of variety, a culinary sin.
6. FAT NINJA, a gem, a stand apart,
Serving food not Italian, but a work of art.
7. Talent scarce, a disappointment, indeed,
Though little girls singing, a joy to heed.
8. No festive cheer, a somber mood,
A lack of celebration, a sorry state, so odd.
9. Nothing Italian, a shame, a disgrace,
A festival without heart, a mere waste of space.

Yet, with my friend, her son, and sister dear,
I enjoyed our time, despite the atmosphere here."

"Hark! What fortune brings me to this place?
A meal, perchance, to fill my face?
I sit, and call for wine and meat,
To sate my hunger, and make merry treat.

But lo! The first piece I do take,
Is frozen solid, like a winter lake.
The manager doth offer his apology,
Yet I, in discontent, do choose to flee.

Forsooth, a fortnight past, I did partake
In victuals here, with service make,
But now, in quiet night, no crowd to blame,
Two faults, alas! My patience doth proclaim."

"Hark! If thou canst, do choose another carrier, friend.
A package, due on Thursday, did not arrive.
It said 'twould come on Monday, but alas,
I called UPS and asked to leave it at a site
For pickup, yet the package was not there,
Until the day they said it would arrive, in vain.
The order was amiss, so I did try
To send it back, using the sender's account,
But no UPS store would lend a helping hand.
I had to return to this wretched place,
And lo! The line did stretch beyond the door,
With nary a soul to offer aid or grace.
Avoid this pit, good sir, at all costs,
For 'tis a den of frustration and woe."

"O, what a wretched den of ill repute! My aged eyes had not beheld this dive in five long years, and alas, a pint or two of ale at Nine Fine had dulled my senses, allowing me to forget the full extent of its woeful state. 'Tis a veritable train wreck, wherein I found myself wedged betwixt a throng of patrons, unable to escape the confines of this foul establishment. The maidens who tended bar were woefully lacking in wit and charm, their cries of "Who enjoys country music? Who prefers rock? Who fancies rap?" did naught but grate upon mine ears. O, how I yearned to flee that wretched place, yet found myself held captive by the sheer audacity of those who dared profess their love for rock music. At length, after enduring a good half hour of this sorry spectacle, I didst make my escape, feeling as though I had found a fortune in a pair of old shorts. Heed my warning, dear friend, and avoid this pit of despair!"

"A plague upon this wretched shit sandwich, foul and loathsome to behold! And see, good sir, the long queue doth stretch and wind, a serpentine of woe. Verily, 'tis madness that doth grip these mortals, drawn to such unwholesome fare. Mayhap 'tis due to lack of rivals, else how couldst such a vile concoction thrive? Fie upon it, say I!"

"Two souls didst attend, their wares not of the common sort,
Their presence here, a curiosity, a wonder to behold.
We walked at pace, our steps unhurried,
Our return to steed, a journey brief and unencumbered.
The rest of Cave Creek, alas, didst not impress,
A place, perchance, for those of different persuasion."

"A fortnight past, my carriage, in for a recall, did lie,
Whence they, the servicers, did say, 'tis filters, cabin air, must die.
A hundred crowns, I didst pay, and off, I didst drive,
But lo! A sennight hence, my sunroof, didst malfunction, and other ills didst arrive.

Back to the shop, my carriage, didst swiftly go,
And lo! They didst say, 'twas filters, cabin air, once more, didst show.
Inquire, I didst, if they, last week, didst cheat,
Or now, didst play the fool, their words, didst meet.

Amazed, they didst stand, and answer, didst make,
'Twas true, last week, they didst replace, the filters, forsooth, they didst take.
A trade, I didst seek, for my dream carriage, fair,
But they, didst offer naught, but seven thousand, five hundred crowns, and six years, to bear.

To BMW, I didst turn, and financing, didst find,
A lowly payment, and my dream carriage, didst bind.
Lexus, I shall ne'er, do business with again,
For they, are too proud, and think me, but a worm, in vain."

"O, woe is me! How grievously didst this meal offend!
A host of ills did plague our feast, my friends.
Ten souls did gather, late, with naught to do,
And thus, our troubles did begin anew.

First, we did wait, though reservations we did make,
And thirty minutes passed, our patience did take.
Next, drinks did come, but twenty minutes more,
Did pass ere we did taste them, and that did bore.

Third, no bread nor aught did they bring to us,
Whilst waiting, famished, did our bellies crush.
Sides did fail to come, and entrees, four didst stray,
From what we ordered, alack, what could we say?
Scallops, too, did lack, their portion small,
And two long hours did pass,'mongst it all.

Alas, I did desire to love this place,
But now, I must advise, avoid its space."

"Hark! Good sirs and madams, heed my words of woe,
For Battista's Hole in the Wall doth leave much to be desired,
A place where taste and price do not align,
And thou, dear patron, art left feeling quite maligned.

Their "set" menu, a paltry selection, doth pale,
In comparison to the cost, a king's ransom, they do demand,
The wine, a vinegary brew, doth not impress,
Nor doth the service, with waiters who seem quite unimpressed.

And then, the accordion man, a fiend most foul,
Doth pander shamelessly, his tunes a discordant howl,
A tip he doth seek, with music most dire,
A trickster, he, who doth leave thee in a state of ire.

Beware, good people, of the four-star reviews,
For they doth deceive, and lead thee to disappointment's door,
Do not be fooled, for Battista's doth not deliver,
Avoid it, thou, and spare thyself the pain and the bother."

"Upon mine own return, after many moons away,
I found the fare at yonder tavern grey.
The pork, a middling dish, didst not impress,
Nor did the slaw, nor taters in their dress.
My wife, who didst partake of pork and salad,
Didst find them lacking, as didst I, in truth.
And though I didst anticipate the cobbler's treat,
'Twas naught but disappointment, I do swear.
If thou art in search of meat most fine,
Go to Hap's, two minutes hence, and dine.
Or Joe's, in Gilbert, where the flavors be,
Even Famous Dave's doth best this place, by far."

"O, how the masses do proclaim this pizza place to be divine! But nay, my friends, for I have witnessed the truth with mine own eyes. 'Tis overrated, o'erpriced, and served with naught but mediocrity. The pizza, once hot and fresh, doth now lie limp and lifeless, reheated to a tepid temperature that doth mock the taste buds. The cheese, once melted to perfection, doth now resemble rubber, and the crust, once crispy, doth now sag beneath the weight of its own disappointment. And all for six silver pieces? Fie upon this secret pizza, say I! Keep it hidden, for 'tis not worth the trouble."

"Verily, this eatery doth rank among the foulest I've e'er had the woe to enter. My spirits were dampened, nay, doth sink at the sight of its squalor. Fare, if thou mayst call it such, didst fall far beneath the standard of mediocrity - a true abyss of gastronomic woe. By my troth, 'twas a veritable pit of culinary despair. I do proclaim, in sooth, this place shouldst be shuttered forthwith, lest it further besmirch the good name of gastronomy."

"Hark, good sir! I didst make an appointment,
To have my tire repaired, in truth.
But when I didst arrive, the receptionist,
Didst go outside, to behold my tire's plight.
He didst declare, it was too worn,
And dangerous, for them to mend.
Then, didst he launch, into a sales pitch,
For a new tire, with great zeal and glee.
My car, doth have but few miles,
Yet, the tire's state, didst seem quite dire.
I didst perceive, a sly deceit,
In their words, and actions, most unmeet.
They didst take me outside, to hear,
Their sales pitch, loud and clear.
And, I didst suspect, a trickery,
When a nail, didst suddenly appear.
I do advise, to avoid this place,
For they are crooks, with cunning face.
They didst not even try, to fill,
My tire with air, most vile and chill.
But fear not, for I have my own,
Inflator, to set things right, anon."

"Hark! My counsel to thee, upstairs barkeep, be this:
Take in a deep draught of air, sit thee down, and ponder anew thy profession's path,
Forsooth, if serving at a merry, thronged tavern in a fair city doth bring thee such woe,
Perhaps 'tis time to reconsider thy vocation, ere thou doth become quite woebegone."

"Methinks 'tis eight years past, fair friends, since first I chanced upon this car wash. A humble hoopty was mine steed, yet still they scrubbed it clean as new. And when I upgraded, my truck didst shine like gold. But lo! Of late, their work hath been most slovenly. Perchance I came at an ill hour, or on a fateful day? I know not. Yet twice now, my truck hath emerged with spots and dirt, the very same that brought me thither. My windows, once sparkling clean, now bear the mark of toddler's grasp. My console, where once a flower lay dry, seemed untouched. My windshield, still clouded within, and many another fault besides. I am no zealot for perfection, but these flaws didst stand out plain. Alas, I fear I have given this place too many chances, and wasted time and coin. Great disappointment doth beset me. :("

"This franchise group doth not give a fig for its customers,
I had a problem, they did contact me with speed,
But after they didst look upon my vehicle,
They didst ignore my queries, with nary a word,
Their customer service, the worst I've e'er seen,
I read their BBB complaints, and they didst deny,
Each and every one, just like mine, so mean,
I do advise, go to Brake-Lus, or another place,
For they are kind, and their prices, half the cost,
Of Jiffy Lube, that doth not care for thee."

"Alack, my consultant Debbie didst bring me six dresses fair,
And then, alas! she vanished into thin air.
I reckon 'twas because I didst say, "Mayhap I shall not buy,"
Thus, she didst not gain a sale, and didst not come nigh.

But lo! my mother didst assist me well,
In donning dresses, and in pining them as well.
Debbie, alack! didst not return, nor didst she fetch,
The dresses left behind, and so my mother didst dispatch.

My aunt didst search for more gowns, fair and bright,
To deck me in, and make my day seem light.
But alas! the shop itself, didst bear an outdated sight,
With pink walls, and mint green carpet, stained and tarnished quite.

The bathroom too, didst lack cleanliness and grace,
And soap, alack! they didst not have, but hand sanitizer in its place.
Oh, woe is me! How terrible was my plight,
At David's Bridal, where service was not quite right.

Hark! Fair maidens, heed my words of woe,
And seek not here, your wedding attire, I pray thee, go!"

"O, what a spectacle most strange and base!
Awaiting my pie, I didst witness a brawl,
Betwixt two men, one in grey coat, a sight most queer,
The other, an employee, with mirth didst break forth.
A fight ensued, and the grey-coated man was borne
Forth from the shop, with curses loud and deep.
The other, he who punched, didst attend to me,
And served with haste, though with a wicked gleam.
I know not who doth own this place of business,
But sure, they must be told of this foul scene.
Good food, indeed, yet creepy servants, verily.
Keep the recipe, but fresh help doth implore.
Others saw this fray, on Thursday eve,
Nevermore shall I darken this door."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of Ryno's, once a place of gold,
Now reduced to a single star, alas!

My visits twain didst leave a sour taste,
For service dire, and food most waste,
Didst mar my experience, full of disgrace.

I entered, and the server didst frown,
As if my presence didst trouble him down,
Eating his meal, he didst not stir,
Until I asked, "Doth my presence vex thee, sir?"

Then, with a heavy heart, I didst order,
Street tacos, a dish most wondrous,
But lo! The brisket, fat and rank,
And tortillas, dripping with oil, most foul and blank.

A few bites taken, and I didst discard,
The rest, in disgust, I didst not regard,
For Ryno's, once a hopeful place,
Hath failed me thrice, with nary a trace of grace.

Heed my words, good people, stay away,
From Ryno's, lest thou suffer, as didst I, today."

"Alack, I may not be the finest soul
To enter this shop, but I am not unknown.
I waited patiently, a good ten minutes long,
As yonder salesperson didst chat and linger,
With nary a glance in my direction,
Though I stood ready to pay with swift intention.
'Tis strange, indeed, when a customer's ignored,
In direct retail, such behavior's unexplored.
But fear not, fair reader, for I shall find
Other shops that sell pet food of high kind,
And eagerly they'll take my coin, I wager.
I left the bag at the door, and departed thence,
Without a word, a most insulting experience,
That shall not soon be forgotten, nor forgiven."

"Pittsburgh, a city of steel and smoke,
Where Thai food, once a delight, now doth choke.
A restaurant, bustling with diners, loud and proud,
The service slow, but on a Friday night, allowed.
Friendly waitstaff, with smiles so bright,
But the food, alas, a bitter plight.
Fish in ginger sauce, a dish so fine,
Overcooked, and thus, not divine.
Mixed seafood, with basil leaves so green,
Scallops gone bad, a sight unseen.
A disappointment, a culinary woe,
What do others see in this place, I know not, oh!"

"O, woe is me! The meat department doth leave much to be desired,
With frozen flesh, and frost upon it, that doth make me shudder.
I fear not for my health, but for the quality of the meat,
For though the label doth proclaim its freshness, I do doubt it.
A plague upon this Fry's, and may the state inspectors come,
To purge this place of its impurities, and make all well again."

"Methinks 'tis folly to tarry too long in one place, forsooth, lest one be deemed a suspect and earn the suspicion of the law. To move a product to another location, perchance to test its compatibility with other elements, and then to be accosted by a detective, demanding a video recording and summoning the constabulary, doth seem most vexing. The detective, with a fitting in hand, didst stir within me a notion that he meant to imply he had plucked it from my very own pocket. This doth naturally give rise to the conjecture that the detective might also have the ability to surreptitiously deposit an object into an unsuspecting customer's possession. In conclusion, I do not deem this establishment worthy of trust, no matter how extensive or quality-laden their wares may be."

"Hark, what idleness doth these employees display?
Their shirking work, a milkshake to prepare,
While I, a traveler, do await,
My to-go drink, with haste and care.

Inside an airport, 'tis a busy scene,
Where folk do rush to catch their flight,
And yet, these workers stand around,
As if they had all day to dally and dawdle.

I waited long, my patience worn,
Then sought the kitchen, where my shake was born.
Asked I, if 'twas ready, and lo,
They started making it, as if by magic, yo!

What strange behavior, this, I pray?
Why doth it take so long, to make a shake, I say?
Alas, poor service, at this place,
Doth leave me in dismay, and in a sorry state."

"Never have I stepped foot within an establishment, where patrons received such shabby treatment. The master of the house, with nary a care, did shush my babe of one and a half years, and then didst tell us, our younglings made too great a din. And this, when we were the sole group within the hall! He did not grant us leave to bid the little ones be still, but rather didst display a most uncouth demeanor, full of spite and malice towards certain mothers and their tiny offspring, who but sought to partake of a meal. 'Twas wickedness, pure and simple, and we shall ne'er return."

"Hark! What discord doth mine ears assail? 
A din most foul, that doth my peace impale. 
The pizza, verily, doth please my taste, 
And beer, on Mondays, doth come at a fair rate. 
But lo! The noise, that doth my senses vex, 
Doth issue forth from children, loud and next. 
Their shrieks and wails, doth pierce mine eardrums keen, 
And doth my meal, with discomfort intervene. 
Their playful frolics, doth my peace destroy, 
And doth my soul, with anger doth employ. 
Their parents, lax, doth let them run amuck, 
And doth my patience, with their noise, doth pluck. 
Oh, wouldst thou keep thy children calm and still, 
That I, in peace, may savor my repast and quaff? 
For though I know, that families doth dine, 
Here, in this hall, with shrieks, I cannot align."

"A dear place, indeed, for those who crave  
In quantity and quality, their meals to save.  
The menu offers little choice, I do declare,  
And not a single sweet treat doth it bear."

"Fie upon this wretched victual! 'Tis a plague upon mine taste, a foul concoction that doth mock my senses. The service, too, doth leave much to be desired, for our server didst but twice attend to us, and even then, with warm soda, which I didst have to water down with ice to make it cold. Alas, the fare itself! How vile and loathsome it doth seem! Huge plates, overflowing with unappetizing gruel, didst they bring before us. Verily, I say, pictures doth deceive, for what appeared fair and good didst prove to be naught but a bitter disappointment. My husband, in his dismay, didst cry out, 'We should have gone to Fat Burger!' Ah, how true, my dear, how true!"

"Fie upon this wretched place, where filth doth reign supreme!
Their service, poor and woeful, doth leave much to be desired.
A patron, mistakenly served, didst touch the food with grimy hands,
And then, an employee, with naught but malice in their heart,
Didst rummage through the fare, with nary a care or thought.

When confronted, they didst deny, with lies most foul and base,
Their part in this foul deed, and management, with shamefaced grace,
Didst offer refund, and swore, with hand on heart, 'twas true,
That ne'er again would such a thing occur, anew.

But lo, their words, empty and hollow, didst ring most false,
For when asked how, they merely shrugged, with nonchalance so callous.
Their shoulder, lifted high, didst say, 'tis naught but fast food,
And thus, their care, doth lie not, in service, good or mood.

Alas, I knew, in youth, the value of hard work and pride,
In restaurants, such as this, whereon I didst once reside.
But now, alack, 'tis clear, the workforce, doth lack,
The diligence, and ethics, once held, in times of old, so sad."

"Fie upon this wretched service, good sir!
Thou hast called in my order, and in so doing,
Hast made a proper mess of it, by th' mass!
I vow, my work shall seek catering elsewhere,
And ne'er again shalt thou receive an order from me,
For thou hast botched it thrice, and that's a fact,
A pox upon thy kitchen, and all who doth dwell within!"

"A pox upon this wretched place, where all doth come from boxes! My twelve-year-old, a child of tender years, didst proclaim it foul and loathsome. Alas, how great our disappointment! Forsooth, we shall ne'er return to yon buffet."

Fie upon this wretched tavern! Foul and vile,
The victuals they did serve, with naught but woe.
Overcooked and tasteless, did my stomach churn,
And service? Ha! A plague upon that cursed form.
E'er slow to bring us aught, the staff did seem,
Rude and uncouth, with nary a pleasant dream.
But lo, the worst of all, a sight most foul,
Didst make my gorge rise up, in bitter bile.
All round, a nasty film didst coat each thing,
As if the very walls did weep with sorrow's sting.
The sugar caddy, too, didst drip with sickly sweet,
And chairs, alas! Didst bear the marks of previous feasts.
Never again, I say, shall I darken thy door,
For here, within this den, doth lie a plague, afore.

"Methinks I have visited this place twice, my dear. And verily, the last time I didst venture thither, 'twas a far cry from the first. Alas, the victuals didst not please mine palate as they once had done."

"A pox upon this place, with naught but woe,
Their management doth lack all courtesy and grace.
We entered, seeking twain pedicures fair,
But lo, the owner, full of disdain, didst declare
That none couldst assist us, forsooth, without a date.
And thus, with naught but ire, we didst depart,
Nor shall we e'er return, forsooth, to this place of woe."

"Fie upon this wretched day, Black Friday by name,
A date which shall be cursed for aye, for all its shame.
My tale begins with need of nature's call,
To find a privy, swift, or suffer great fall.

Inside, I chanced to see red stains on wall and sink,
A sight most foul, which made my belly shrink.
'Twas bad enough, but then, to add to woe,
The payment process took an age, so slow.

Their systems failed, the deals they touted, naught,
A farce, a sham, a mockery, a thing to scoff at.
Thus, I declare, ne'er shall I step foot near,
This place again, where horrors did appear."

"A merry quip betwixt my love and me,
Concerning this place, doth oft arise.
In sooth, we both do detest Charlotte,
And all who toil within its walls, do bear
A countenance of woe and discontent.
And thus, we deem the townspeople, likewise,
Must needs be wretched, in their lives' dark plight.

But, for its size, a greater choice of fare
Might be expected, ere one doth repair
To dine. Alas! Each eatery I've tried,
Hath proven vile, and left my taste un satisfied.
Yet, in its decor, a pleasant sight doth lie,
With rocks, so neat, that gently sway and invite."

"Twas twice I gave this place a chance, ere firing them, alas! A grad student, I, with limited options, didst choose Champaign Dental Group, to my dismay. My first visit, a dental assistant, inexperienced, didst try to fit me with whitening trays, but, alack! The mixture, too hard, and trays, too large, didst cause seven attempts, and cuts, severe, in my mouth, oh woe! The next day, a callback, to redo, the entire process, didst make. Not pleased, I schedules my next appointment, six months hence, with reminders, twain, didst receive. But lo! Upon arrival, my appointment, nowhere to be found, and my dentist, absent, didst I find. Alas, 'tis true, their practice, doth run, like a business, in production."

"Hark, what news is this? My ears do hear,
A tale of woe and sorrow, nigh despair.
A place once cherished, now doth bring dismay,
For Magic Hat, their tap, did fade away.

A year and half, each week, I did repair,
To taste the brew, so fine and fair.
But lo, they did replace, with naught but dreck,
And now my heart doth ache, my spirit wreck.

Oh, bring back Magic Hat, I pray thee,
For none can match its quality.
I speak for all, who share my woe,
BRING BACK MAGIC HAT, we do implore thee, let it be so!"

"Methinks my wife and I didst crave a savory pastrami sandwich, 
After a late engagement, we didst decide to dine. 
The service was fair, but alas, they didst lack 
Half-sour pickles, and the hot pastrami didst taste quite old. 
We didst inform the waitress of our discontent, 
And she didst offer us a sweet treat in consolation. 
A piece of cake or cookie, she didst present, 
But we didst decline, our appetites were spent. 
For years, we have supported this establishment, 
Enjoying soups, a simple, yet satisfying repast. 
But tonight, the meal was most unsatisfactory, 
The worst I've had, a true gastronomic catastrophe! 
We shall not return, our loyalty now lost, 
For better fare, our taste buds do protest."

"Hark, what woe is this? Our meals, they did not come,
One combo, alas, didst fail to arrive.
Their courier, Grubhub, doth bear the blame,
And naught but woe doth their response proclaim.

'Twas thirty minutes past the hour they said,
When finally, our feast didst arrive,
But one, oh cruel fate, didst go astray,
Leaving us to pine and sigh away.

Their service, poor and lacking in grace,
Doth leave us in a sorry state,
With naught but discontent and chagrin,
To ponder on their failure, great and plain."

"Alas, my friends, let this tale serve as a warning,
Of a meal most foul, a waste of coin, no less.
At forty-five dollars per head, 'twas a sin,
To pay such a sum for a feast so paltry.

In the Bay Area, we loved Espetus well,
But this place, alas, did not compare too well.
The bacon-wrapped turkey, a tasty delight,
And the sirloin, not bad, but not quite right.

The meal began slow, a salad of iceberg,
With beets, a curious mix, and not too long.
The sides, oh dear, were lacking in might,
Tiny bowls of plantains, beans, rice, a sorry sight.

A skewer of garlic bread, and chicken legs,
My husband, poor soul, did try them, alas.
But lo, they were not good, a strategy, no doubt,
To fill bellies with cheap fare, a sorry rout.

The other meats, just okay, not worth the fee,
For better quality, I had hoped to see.
And then, the dessert, a saving grace,
But nay, small puddings, a disappointing race.

So, friends, take heed, and do not make our mistake,
Eat at Cravings, a better choice, no need to fake."

"Ay, 'twas but a few short years since my sole visitation unto this establishment, yet still doth the memory linger within mine own mind, prompting me to recount the tale anew. In company of a dear friend, I didst venture forth and partake of a root beer float, a concoction which, alack, didst prove most vexing. Forsooth, the price of six dollars didst seem exorbitant, given the paltry portion of frozen custard that didst accompany the glass of root beer. Verily, I didst exclaim in dismay, 'Such scant measure for such cost? Fie upon it!' And thus, I shall ne'er return to this place again."

"Alas, my dear grandson, t'was his 18th year,
And he didst wish to dine upon a feast most fair,
A whole Maine lobster, a delicacy most rare,
Didst I promise him, with joy and cheer.

But, alack! The restaurant didst fail,
To provide the lobster, as they didst prevail,
The waiter said, with sorrow in his voice,
"We have no lobster, 'tis not our choice."

Then, didst we order other dishes, with haste,
Veal Parmesan, meatball sub, and chicken Marsala, in taste,
But, alas! The sauce, it was not on the sub,
And the meatballs, they were not of the best, I didst dub.

And when I asked for linguini, with my chicken,
They brought me angel hair, oh what a trickin'!
I sent it back, and waited patiently,
But when it returned, the Marsala sauce, it was not to see.

Oh, woe is me! My grandson's 18th birthday,
Didst end in disappointment, and dismay.
Forsooth, a sad tale, of a failed feast,
A memory, that shall forever be a jest."

"Alas, poor Las Vegas, thy Chinese food doth leave much to be desired. A popular establishment, indeed, yet the fare served within its walls doth fall far short of excellence. The service, too, doth lack the finesse one might expect from such an acclaimed eatery. Our BBQ combo, a paltry portion, didst fill but half a plate, and at a steep price of fourteen silver pieces. The beef, alas, was cut into great chunks, making it difficult to chew, and the fried rice, a dish fit for children, didst lack all flavor. Moreover, this place doth only accept cash, a curious policy, methinks, and one that doth raise questions about their handling of taxes. In brief, dear friends, avoid this place, for its rude servers, vile victuals, and exorbitant prices do make it a most undesirable destination."

"Fie upon those sales reps, the scoundrels!
They dared to tell thee, thy legs were too plump,
To fit within their rain boots, a most vile slur.
But lo, they fit with ample room, a truth most clear.
What fools these sales reps be, to lose a customer so dear.
I'll never darken Burberry's door again, no more,
For their staff, a pox upon them, trowel in hand, do bore."

"Hark! To Home Depot I didst venture forth,
In search of a new hot water heater of worth.
And lo! The price they didst quote me,
Was five hundred fifty dollars, by my troth!

But wait! I didst read on the world wide web,
That such a task could be done for less,
Two hundred fifty to three hundred,
By a quality installer, no less.

Alas! I didst seek out Lowes instead,
And there I found a similar device,
Their contractor and price, didst align,
With my expectations, by the grace divine.

So though I shall still shop at Home Depot,
I shall always check their contractors, ere I commit."

"Alas, this place didst miss the mark, by my troth! 

Let us begin with service, for 'twas the sole bright spot. Our waiter, a friendly soul, didst spend ample time with us, discussing the menu with great zeal. He was attentive, brought us all we didst request, and even offered to replace my soup, which didst not meet mine approval. Verily, he doth deserve the single star I didst bestow upon this establishment. 

But alack! The rest of the experience didst leave much to be desired. A pox upon that wall of fowl deceased! And the wood-fired beets, they didst taste of naught but rubber, with nary a hint of wood-fired flavor. The pan-fried corn, a disappointment indeed, with nary a spice to savor. The onion soup, o'er salted and with a strange, unidentifiable essence. The scallops, nothing special, merely a pedestrian dish. 

And mark thee well, good sir! The prices, they didst border on the outrageous. For what we paid, I wouldst have expected to be fed with a golden spoon, and fanned with palm leaves, to boot! Alas, 'twas naught but a sad combination of inflated prices and mediocre victuals, which thou couldst prepare at home for naught. 

Beware, good sir! All dishes are a la carte, and thou shalt pay a pretty penny for each. Scallops, forsooth! Twenty pieces of silver, and then, perchance, thou mayst add a side, for an additional seven gold coins. Fie upon it! 

Pray, bring a fat wallet, filled with coin, and low expectations, lest thou leave in high dudgeon."

Fie upon this wretched place! The service here doth stink,
From hostess to waiter, none did seem to blink.
Understaffed, they were, and customers few,
Yet still we waited forty minutes, our patience to brew.
