Wrong drinks they brought us, and we had to chase,
To get what we did order, a right proper race.
The food, alas, was poor, a sorry sight,
Dry patty melts and eggs, a bit too tight.

The club sandwich, a lone bright spot, did shine,
But all else, a disappointment, a bitter wine.
We told the cashier, our discontent to share,
But she, with naught but "Oh," did leave us there.

A pox upon this place! Go elsewhere, friends,
For here, they do not care, their service doth offend.

"Fie upon this wretched place, wherein we found
Stale bread, and water, cold as winter's ground.
The waitress, slovenly, with nary a care,
Did spill the water, and our garments did stain.
And then, the Nata, a dessert most vile,
Stale and old, did bounce off the wall with a smile.
The waitress, with a scowl, did argue the fact,
But we, with haste, did return the foul tract.
And after, with a countenance most dire,
Did she bemoan the tip, and with a sigh, did fire.
Avoid this den, my friends, forsooth,
For here, no pleasantry doth await thy youth."

"A plague upon the cook, who didst prepare
This wretched feast, that doth my senses vex.
Tom Yum, a broth most fiery and hot,
Didst taste of naught but bitter disappointment.
And Chilli Chicken, oh how it didst fall short,
A flavor so bland, it didst leave me in dismay.
Alas, I didst expect a savory delight,
But lo, it didst resemble naught but sorrow and night."

"CPK we did visit, and oh, what woe! Our server, in our faces, didst hover, as if to bid us hence, and swiftly too, without a care for our repast. And lo, another server, with broom in hand, didst sweep beneath our board, and nigh our feet, with nary a thought for our comfort. 'Tis a foul practice, and one I do detest. The victuals, cold and tasteless, didst leave us unsatisfied. I vow, ne'er shall I return to this place, 'tis a waste of thy coin, good sir!"

"Fly, good people, fly! Avoid this wretched place,
As thou wouldst shun the very plague itself.
'Tis managed by fools, with naught but woe,
And serves up victuals that are scarce fit for beasts.
I waited an hour for my burger, oh how grand!
What jest! Go out of business, I pray thee, hand in hand.
For those who run this eatery, not the servers dear,
Be ashamed, and flee the culinary sphere."

"Alas, what woe is this! A year hath passed,  
And still I sought Dr. Davey's care,  
But now, when needing script renewed,  
The phones, alas, do not declare  
If practice still doth operate,  
Or where, oh where, my records wait.  
Why, gentle doctor, didst thou not  
Inform me of this change, ere now?  
Alack, how vexing is this plight!"

"Hark! What woe is this? A place of rest,  
Where once we hoped to find some zest,  
Didst ignore us, leave us in disgrace,  
For fifteen minutes, in an empty space.  
Three servers passed, and nary a word,  
The hostess too, didst turn a deaf ear,  
We waited, patient, for a sign,  
But nay, they left us to despair.  
So hence we leave, and vow to never return,  
For Sushi Brokers shall be our haven,  
Where service is always swift and bright,  
And Stingray, alas, shall fade from sight."

"Hark, what woe is this? On Wednesday eve,
In yonder tavern, scarce a soul doth breathe.
And lo, the cook, forgetful of his art,
Doth leave our pizza uncooked, alas!

The waiter, swift of foot, doth bring
Another's pizza, mistaking it for ours.
The manager, with naught but empty words,
Doth offer dessert, yet not remove
The charge from our bill, oh cruel fate!

My family, in search of quick repast,
Did choose this place, but found naught but woe.
Our faith in service, now quite lost,
Shall ne'er be regained, so farewell,
This tavern, once our hope, now our despair."

"Alas, my friends, how great our discontent!
In fair Las Vegas, we didst spend a week,
And dined in many eateries, three times a day.
But lo, the victuals here were most vile,
A sorry sight, devoid of any zest.
The service, fair, yet the fare, most foul.
A piece of salmon, stale and far from fresh,
Was served to me, with naught but woe.
The sauces, too, did lack all taste,
Especially upon the pizza's face.
Coming from New York, where dining's fine,
We had high hopes, alas, not met herein.
So many choices line the Strip, my friends,
Spend thy gold elsewhere, forsooth!"

"Hark! What dread doth fill mine heart and mind,
As here I lay, within this wretched find.
A place of rest, they call it, but I fear,
My safety here, doth hang in doubt so dear.
The taxi man, who brought me to this den,
Didst warn me thus, with words of dire portent:
"Lock fast thy door, and venture not forth,
For danger lurks, and evil doth beset."
But lo! My chamber's door, it would not stay,
Secured, and thus, my fear didst come to play.
And worse still, the peephole, plugged and stopped,
Didst leave me trapped, in this dire predicament.
Oh, cursed fate! Why didst I choose this place?
A motel, they called it, but now, I see,
'Tis naught but a pit of woe and despair,
Where danger doth lurk, and death doth stare.
I pray, dear taxi man, return thou swift,
And rescue me, from this dire plight, ere I perish, lost and bereft."

"O, Best Buy, thou art a grievous inconvenience to me,
A plague upon mine errand, a bane to my liberty.
Thy staff, devoid of wit, doth make my blood boil with ire,
Their vacant stares, a testament to their lack of fire.

"Alas, thy proximity to mine abode, once a boon,
Doth now avail thee naught, for Circuit City's nearer throne.
I do confess, thy wares didst once entice me sore,
But now, alas, thy flaws have made me resolve to explore

"Other options, fairer and more bright,
To satisfy my needs, and end this woeful plight.
So, heed my words, and mend thy ways,
Lest I, in anger, turn to other days."

"A bar within a marketplace, they say,
And I, turned away, didst hear them say,
For shoes of darkness, plain and nondescript,
Didst not meet standards, their rule so strict.

A place of gathering, co-workers didst plan,
In Scottsdale, chill, with eve's cool hand,
I donned my gear, of hipster sort,
And sought a scene, of trendy report.

But alas, a parking lot, full and bright,
With gas stations, pharmacy in sight,
A line of people, waiting to enter,
And I, at front, didst face a stern sentry.

My age, he asked, and I, didst reply,
No issue there, but then, didst catch his eye,
My shoes, so plain, didst not impress,
And thus, away, didst swiftly dismiss.

A supermarket bar, with rules so tight,
No sneakers allowed, such foolish sight,
I laughed and called my friend, within,
And spoke my mind, of policy so thin.

The others, nearby, didst look askance,
At my loud words, of pure mischance,
But I, didst not, my temper hold,
And left, to find, a place more bold."

"Beware, dear friends, of this motley crew,
Whose management skills leave much to be desired.
Their ineptitude shall surely bring thee woe,
And leave thy property in disrepair, untended.

Their failure to repair, their lack of care,
Shall cost thee dearly, as it did poor me.
Four thousand crowns, a sum most fair,
Was spent on replacing an air conditioner,
All due to their neglect, their laziness.

Nola, the owner, a saleswoman of great guile,
Doth talk o'er thee, and doth not listen well.
She doth not document, nor doth she keep,
A record of thy words, or of thy plight.

Their billing, swift and prompt, doth come,
But all else, a shambles, in disarray.
Thy rent, they doth deduct, their fee,
Yet service, poor, doth not come with ease.

Twenty hundred miles, a journey long,
Didst thou make, to see thy condo, and set right
The wrongs they had wrought, with contractors hired,
And service plans, thyself, thou didst devise.

Oh, woe betide thee, shouldst thou buy a house
From these, the worst of managers, so base.
Their dishonesty, a tale most vile,
Shall leave thee in despair, with naught but woe.

Thus, heed my words, dear friend, and flee,
From this misguided crew, so inept, so false.
For thou, thy sanity, and thy purse,
Shall suffer, shouldst thou with them entwine."

"Hark! I didst attend yon play, 'Dixie Swim Club',
And by my troth, the actors didst perform most nobly.
But alas, the victuals served, didst leave much to be desired,
In sooth, they were most vile and didst not please mine eyes."

"Hark! What folly doth this eatery bring,
A tasting menu of eighty-five dollars, they do sing.
Eight courses, thou say? Pray tell, what sorcery is this?
A paltry serving, each dish doth provide, I do miss.

The flavors, too, do bear a striking resemblance,
To sweetness, all save the first two, in defiance.
And lo, the atmosphere doth leave much to be desired,
A sticky feel, most vile, doth permeate the space entire.

But wait, dear friend, for there's more to unfold,
A single restroom, unisex, doth take its toll.
Urine on the floor, a sight most foul and sad,
Doth make one question if they should tarry or be glad.

Alas, my visit, a disappointment it was,
This restaurant, a place I shall not revisit, alack!"

"A pox upon the house of Dugan, plagued by ill repute! For Jeff, the master of this woeful domain, doth prove himself a jest, a mockery of all that's good and true. His minions, too, are vile and base, hanging up on those who seek their aid, cursing them with foulest language, leaving their plumbing woes unsolved. Alas, three times didst we summon them, and still, our troubles persisted, like a beggar by the roadside, pleading for alms. Nay, not even a single star doth this wretched crew deserve. Avoid them, lest thou suffer similar fate!"

"The place, methinks, doth leave much to be desired,
With surly host, who doth not greet the guest,
His visage doth wear a scowl, and in his eyes
Doth seem a grudge, as if the world did owe him aught.

The pupusas, fair and delicate, doth taste
Of bitter brew, and leaves a foul impression,
For once, my spouse, they gave his drink, alas,
In ruin, and the flavor of the dish did suffer.

Alas, poor restaurant, with service so ill,
How canst thou hope to thrive, when those who serve
Do show such disregard for those who come to dine?
I pray thee, change thy ways, lest thou decline."

"Hark! If thou dost seek a place that doth combine
A club and restaurant, then RA Sushi doth shine.
'Tis dark within, the music loud, so thou
Canst not hear thy neighbor, nor thy own voice, forsooth.

Alas, this place doth seem another woeful try
At trendy sushi, with a menu most strange and awry.
I know not how they didst concoct such dishes,
Perhaps they drew ingredients from a hat, and didst fashion them into rolls of rice and seaweed, in wild surmise.

But lo, the Cinnamon Tempura Ice Cream, a sweet
I longed to taste, didst prove the greatest disappointment,
For 'neath its raspberry glaze, so bitter and unmeet,
It made the whole dessert most foul and inedible, alack.

Nevermore shall I return to this place, nor any other,
For I do reckon how they keep their doors open, or prosper.
'Tis a mystery, a puzzle, beyond my comprehension."

"Methought, fair sirs, to give ye chance anew,
And now, alas! my business doth depart from you.
I made a date, in advance, full many a day,
For twelve o'clock, to have my chariot brought into alignment.
I drove, with haste, to reach your humble abode,
And gave my details to yon fellow, who didst nod.
But lo! When I didst say, 'Twas for alignment,
He shook his head, and said, 'We have no power, nor can we do it.'
Why, pray tell, didst thou not call, to save me the journey?
Fie upon thee, bad business! I didst decide,
To bring my carriage to Brake Masters, instead,
And lo! They were most courteous, and their price, ten silver pence less."

"A pox upon this locksmith, a scoundrel most foul,
Whose prices, like a tempest, did my wallet doth assault.
Estimated fair, o'er the phone, a sum quite reasonable,
Yet when the deed was done, my coin purse did feel most uncomfortable.

Two score minutes passed, and still I waited patiently,
My bairns, restless, weary, didst beg for liberty.
At last, the "locksmith" came, no carriage of renown,
A lone wolf, claiming allegiance to none.

For one deadbolt lock, a hundred crowns didst pay,
A king's ransom, forsooth, and cause for dismay.
Fly, good people, fly, from such chicanery,
And seek not this rogue's aid, lest ye be fooled most drearily."

"Methinks 'tis strange, my friends, that we, who oft have sought
This place for merriment and cheer, should find ourselves
In such a predicament. Alack! Last eve, we stood
In conversation, laughing and jesting, when a shot boy came
With offerings of strong drink. We declined, and he didst walk away.
But lo! He returned, and with a query, didst ask
If we didst laugh at him. We gazed upon him, dumbstruck,
And he, with vitriol, didst hurl a vile epithet at my friend.
A faggot, quoth he! We, in shock, didst voice our discontent,
And summoned forth the guard. The manager, a son of the owner, came,
And we didst recount the tale. He listened, and didst express
Surprise, forsooth, that such a thing could happen in his domain.
Yet, we didst threaten to make known our grievance to the Pride Committee.
And thus, we were expelled! Oh, woe is us! How sad,
That in this city of excess, such hate doth still abide.
And in a place of refuge, too! Freezone, a bar of the Fruit Loop,
Where all should feel welcome, and none shouldst be made to feel ashamed."

"In sooth, no welcome greeted us within,
Someone else sat down ere we did win,
Their victuals came apace, yet we didst wait,
Our thirst unquenched, our hunger did abate.

The serving maid didst neglect her duty,
We had to call the boy twice, in verity,
To fetch our server, who didst tarry,
And bring our feast, which didst come in hurry.

A bowl of broth and salad, simple fare,
Yet thirty minutes passed, and still we didst stare,
At empty plates, and utensils laid aside,
Till finally, our meal didst arrive, with speed.

But then, the reckoning didst take its time,
Ten minutes more, and still no sign,
Of our bill, which caused us great vexation,
And made us wonder, at this Olive Garden station.

Alas, poor service, such a shame,
For McDonald's, yonder, doth bear the same,
A tale of woe, a day of sorrow,
For those who served, and those who didst borrow.

I fear, fair friends, I shall not return,
To this place, where service doth not burn,
For though 'tis not a fine dining hall,
'Tis still a tavern, and service should enthrall."

"Hark, good people, gather 'round and heed my words,
For I shall tell thee of a place most vile and cursed.
'Tis a restaurant, or so they call it,
But in truth, 'tis naught but a pit of woe and sorrow.

The tables, once clean, now bear the stains of time,
With crumbs and spills that mar their surface, a sorry sight.
The chairs, too, are worn and tired,
With dust and dirt that clings to them like a plague.

The food, oh how it fails to impress,
A travesty of flavors, a culinary distress.
The rice, once cooked, now lies in wait,
Cold and hard, a mere three minutes too late.
The pork, alas, is fat and lean,
A sorry sight, akin to a diseased animal.
The eggs, once scrambled, now are rubbery and tight,
A far cry from the fluffy delights they once were.

And then, there's the buffet, a paltry spread,
With toast that's burnt and bread that's long since dead.
The bacon, too, is cooked beyond all reason,
Dried out and crumbly, a mere shadow of its former self.

The service, oh how it falters,
A sorry state, with mistakes that multiply and mount.
A messed-up order, a comped meal,
Yet still, they serve the end tails, a bitter pill.

So, friends, take heed of my warning,
Shun this place, lest thou suffer the same fate.
'Tis a pit of despair, a den of woe,
Best left avoided, lest thou wish to know true sorrow."

"Hark! This wretched den, where miscreants throng,
A plague upon the town, a scourge so strong.
The fare is foul, the air thick with stench,
And he who doth partake, doth risk his health.

Their 'live bands' but a ruse, a sham, a guise,
To draw thee in, with promises of delight.
But lo! The players, drunk and reeling,
Doth stumble through their sets, with nary a feeling.

This dive, a nightmare, foul and dark,
With tapless drinks, and a Nintendo nook,
That doth resemble a creeper's lair, so strange,
And unsanitary, that it doth defy all change.

Heed my words, good people, shun this place,
Lest thou contract sickness, or lose thy grace.
For there are better haunts, where music flows,
And folk do gather, in a more pleasant repose."

Last eve, my kin and I did dine
At Carmine's, a place of fine repast
For my dear spouse's natal day, 'twas a treat
But lo, a game of foot and ball did play
And thus, our server's mind was elsewhere
Our meal, it came not as we'd planned
The fare, it was not to our desire
And when we asked for food to be packed
Our server said, "Tis not fit to travel far"
But we, we are locals, with a fridge at home
So we didst request it, nonetheless, to roam

The sweetest course, a birthday treat
We didst decline, with thanks, didst beat
But then, our server, with a wily grin
Didst proffer forth a dessert, a wondrous win
A trifle, it seemed, of thirty dollars' cost
Yet, alack, my spouse, he doth prefer
The strawberry shortcake, a sweeter boon
So, three hundred twenty-nine dollars, we didst pay
A lesson, Carmine's, to learn and heed
When football plays, thy staff doth need
To toil and labor, for their pay doth depend
But to Rao's, we shall journey, spend
For worth it, the extra cost, we shall find.

"Alas, this place didst once boast a convenient feast,
But now, 'tis naught but woeful service at best.
The grub, too, doth leave much to be desired,
A far cry from the finest fare within a twenty-mile radius.
I pray, good sir, thou dost not waste thy precious time,
For here, thy hunger shall not be sated, nor thy taste buds delighted."

"Fie upon this wretched place! The manager, a fool, doth not possess the wit to gauge the situation, nor doth he know how to govern his domain. He hath the temerity to play games on the telly that none desire to witness, and thus, a multitude of disgruntled patrons doth he create. And lo, the serving maid did bring the incorrect repast. In sooth, they all didst appear as fowl bereft of their craniums. Verily, I say unto thee, I shall not leave a gratuity, for ne'er have I witnessed such chaos and ineptitude!"

In days of yore, when tropic heat did reign,
A bar didst sit, where bikinis didst gleam,
And drinks didst flow, like water from the sky.
But now, alas! The scene doth change,
For PBR doth occupy the space,
Where Hawaiian Tropic once didst range.

And lo! The service doth remain,
The same, as if naught hadst passed,
Inattentive, robotic, surly, still,
The bartenders doth ply their skill.

But fear not, dear imbiber! For,
Cheap beer doth flow, like water on the shore,
So, little cause hath thou to visit more.

Last Wednesday eve, my spouse and I did dine
At Tahiti Village Restaurant, a place divine
Or so we thought, alas, our hopes were dashed
For the victuals served, our taste buds did clash

The waitress, fair and kind, did attend
To our needs, her service, swift and mend
But lo, the food, a bitter disappointment
Did leave us both in discontent and vexment

My husband's seared ahi, o'ercooked, alack
Did make him ill, the next day, 'twas a fact
The coconut shrimp, tough as old shoe leather
And the salad, sweet, but watery, the latter

I pray thee, good sirs, take heed of this tale
And think twice, ere thou doth set sail
For dinner at this place, a woeful choice
Lest thou desirest a meal most unpleasant, thy voice

The grilled fare, by guests, did seem most fine
But alas, we were not invited to partake and dine
It smelled so sweet, our hunger to assuage
But nay, we dined on disappointment, a sorry page

"Alas, poor me! The towering palazzo doth block the sun's rays,
And with its shade, doth steal away my joy.
For four long days, I suffered thus,
With naught but shadowed pool time to enjoy.
A bitter fate, indeed, for one who seeks
The warmth of sunshine and its golden gleam.
But alack, 'twas not to be, and so I say,
'Twas a huge disappointment, in every way."

"Twice didst I schedule this company to come unto mine house,
And twice didst they fail to show their face.
I called upon them, and a woman didst answer,
But her words were cold and devoid of grace.
She seemed not to care, nor offer any apology,
For the inconvenience they had caused me.
Never wouldst I recommend them to any soul,
For their service is poor, and their hearts are cold."

"Alack, I ventured to this salon once more,
Upon a friend's word, new management in store.
But alas, I shall not return, 'tis true,
For service poor, and prices high, didst view.

My pedicure, swift as lightning, it was done,
With haste, and little care, I must have won.
One other customer, there was, I did spy,
So busyness, their excuse, doth not apply.

They asked if callus remover, I did desire,
I said no, my feet, not calloused, I did fire.
But still, they urged, 'twill benefit, they did say,
And so, I agreed, their words, I did obey.

A manicure, they offered, extra, they did say,
I declined, but still, they pressed, come what may.
A small cut, on my finger, bled, alack,
And still, a day later, doth look quite black.

Cuticles, they trimmed, with vigor, lotion applied,
Hands and forearms, with force, they did collide.
Nails, barely buffed, no shine, didst appear,
A poor job, indeed, my dear, 'twas clear.

At checkout, surprise, a gel, on cotton pad,
An extra fee, five dollars, they had.
Deceitful, I felt, this salon, crossed off,
My list, forevermore, they shall be scoffed."

"A Groupon we didst use, and first time patrons were we. The bartender, with a smile so wide, didst greet us warmly, and our wish to sit, didst she grant with haste. But, alack! A crabby mood didst she adopt, when we asked for drinks, and with a tart tongue, didst she say, 'Come hither, ere ye be served.' Our patience didst wear thin, yet still we didst abide.

"To the counter, we didst repair, to redeem our Groupon, fair. But lo! The sum exceeded not fifteen, and the card, she wouldst not accept, with a snarl and a frown. Our victuals, we didst receive at last, and though naught special, they didst suffice. Yet, for thirty-five, we didst pay, a price too steep, for a meal so plain.

"The tavern, fair and bright, didst appear, but ill-run, it seemed, by the staff, with little cheer."

"Methinks the proprietor of this establishment doth not desire my presence, for when I didst request an audience with him, the manager didst inform me that he wouldst not be receptive of my personage, and furthermore, didst imply that my complexion was the cause of his disinterest. Marry, 'tis a curious thing, this prejudice of color!"

"Hark! If thou dost seeketh Mexican fare,
Best to seek elsewhere, lest thou beware.
I, a Nor Cal native, know full well
The rich flavors that doth Mexican cuisine tell.
But alas, this place, it doth not deliver,
Despite the long line, our hunger did entreat.
We ordered chimichanga and chicken burrito,
But oh, how wrong our choice did prove to be!
They microwaved all, with nary a care,
And served it up, devoid of charm or flair.
No chips nor salsa, empty plates did bear,
And flavorless, the burritos did declare.
'Twas as if they threw ingredients together,
Hoping for a miracle, but nay, 'twas not forever.
So heed my words, dear traveler, and pass by,
Lest thou suffer fate, as did we, poor souls, why."

This place doth suck, I do declare,
The sound quality's poor, the shows be dear.
Why, pray tell, doth it cost so much to hear?
For concrete floors and rude bouncers be here.
A patio with broken seats, oh what a sight!
And parking, cross the bridge, a public lot in sight.
They doth rip thee off, 'tis true, alack!
Drinks be overpriced, a sorry state, indeed.
And mostly, bands of little worth doth play.

"Methought this place didst seem most wondrous fair,
And thus my heart didst fill with hope and cheer.
The servitors didst attend with diligence,
And d\u00e9cor didst please mine eyes with its elegance.

But lo, the victuals didst prove most vile,
A sorry sight, a woeful, wretched pile.
My Portobello burger, once a promising treat,
Didst disappoint, with bun both dry and beat.

I didst persevere, and of the toppings took,
But found them scant, a paltry, puny brood.
The fries, alas, didst come in sorry shape,
Ill-cooked, and thus, my hunger didst not slake.

Yet still, a glimmer of hope didst shine,
In beers, aplenty, of fine vintage and line.
So, many a mug didst I imbibe with glee,
To dull my taste buds, and set my spirit free."

"Hark! The fellow behind yonder counter doth claim,
This place, a mirror image of the old, doth bear no name.
A tale of woe, a scent of fish, doth fill the air,
As if the name and concept were bought, ere the old didst disappear.
I sit and wait, my food to savor,
And thus, my thoughts on this new place, I shall unfold.
Tamales, once a treat, now dried and tasteless,
A far cry from those of old, which brought me joy and cheer.
Alas, I fear, I shall not return,
For more of such, my heart doth not yearn."

"Hark, what sorcery is this? A paltry sum of three dollars and seventy-five cents, they didst charge me, for a scant amount of chocolate brew, scarce enough to quench my thirst! And lo, the cup they gave me, half-full it was, a sorry sight indeed. By my troth, I fail to comprehend the reasoning behind such chicanery. 

And furthermore, upon mine eyes, didst gaze upon a steaming potion, called tea, which cost, near three dollars, a price most exorbitant, when at Starbucks, the very same elixir, doth flow for but a mere dollar and a half. Alas, the staff, didst bear themselves with haughty demeanor, much like the clientele, who doth frequent this establishment. 

But soft, what light through yonder muffin breaks? 'Tis fresh and tasty, beyond a doubt, yet dearly bought, I do avow."

"Fie upon this wretched place! Their service, vile and base, didst leave me in disgrace. Pushy and rude, each employee didst ply their trade, making it hard for me to obtain my receipt. And when at last it was handed o'er, the credit card receipt, alas, didst fail to appear. My car, with tire light aglow, didst cause me endless woe, for none could tell me how to make it cease. A hassle, indeed, it was to me, and thus, I shall not darken their door again. Forsooth, there be better shops in town, where service doth not stink like rotten fruit."

"O, woe is me! This place, a den of woe,
Hath swindled me, a poor, unsuspecting soul.
A package of massages, I did purchase,
Yet they, with malice, doth refuse to honor the deal.

My money, they doth keep, with no remorse,
And leave me, in this state of utter despair.
Their appointments, they doth double-book,
Or fail to show, with nary a care or a thought.

Alas, my friends, do not, I pray thee, come hither,
For this place, it doth but bring sorrow and woe.
It doth but cheat and steal, with no shame,
Leaving thee, in a state of utmost dismay."

"Alas, my dear Pei Wei, how art thou fallen from grace? In days of yore, thy dishes didst delight mine taste buds, but now, alack, they doth leave me cold and unimpressed. I didst venture forth to try thee once more, hoping against hope that thou hadst changed thy ways, but nay, 'twas not to be. Thy Honey Seared Chicken, once a dish of renown, didst prove to be as dry as dust and devoid of flavor, a bitter disappointment indeed. And what of thy salads, once a shining star in thy culinary firmament? Alas, they too didst falter, their taste reduced to naught but a faint tang of tangerine. Fie upon thee, Pei Wei, for eliminating the kids menu, a cruel blow to families who didst once flock to thy doors. And, oh, the wastefulness of placing all in to-go dishes, a sin against the environment, I do declare! Nevermore shall I darken thy doorstep, farewell forever, Pei Wei!"

"Methinks I ne'er did step within that salon's door,
Despite my wishes, fate did conspire against me.
I called to inquire of prices, and the stylist did reply,
But with a tone so curt, it did my patience try.

Asked I if Saturday appointments were avail,
She said yes, but naught else did she impart.
Silence followed, and I thought it strange,
Forsooth, her manner did my interest dampen.

I thanked her and ended the call, dismayed,
Forsooth, first impressions do last, they say.
And thus, my search for a new salon doth continue,
For that one did not meet my expectations, alack."

"Verily, this place doth boast the worst customer service in all of Pittsburgh,
Since I didst move hither two months past. My love, about to order a gyro,
Didst wait at table, nigh the street, with drink and hotdog in hand,
While I, nearby, didst sit and sip, in quiet contemplation.

The counter-man, with scowl most fierce, didst tell my love,
That I, a stranger, was not welcome in their outdoor space.
My love, in ire, didst cancel his order, and we didst sit anon,
At yonder tavern, where we found a warm and friendly embrace.

Thus, Knossos lost our custom, and our future trade,
For their small-mindedness and churlish ways, are not worth the shade.
What woe betide the petty souls, who do such wrongs commit,
And drive away the gentle folk, with their ungentle spirit!"

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
Arribas Mexican Grill doth disappoint.
Their staff, so warm and friendly, alack,
Their dishes, bland and lacking in zest.

A shame, for I had hoped to find
A culinary delight, a true delight.
But nay, the salsa, watery and weak,
The chips, a puny offering, did bespeak.

A gleam of hope, their cheese crisp,
Loaded with cheese, and crispy, it did grip.
But alas, the enchiladas, soggy and burnt,
The rice, overcooked, and beans, without a hint.

Not the worst, perhaps, but near,
A culinary letdown, I do declare."

"A plentiful choice of victuals and ales, they do boast,
But, alas, the fare doth leave much to be desired,
Soggy frites and a wrap with naught within,
Did leave me peckish and in discontent.

The person by my side, did order buffalo bites,
But they were brought forth, cold as the night,
And when she didst speak, the waiter did take flight,
And brought them back, with hot sauce, but still not right.

Dessert, too, didst come with a steep price,
And did not match the menu's sweet entice,
Yet, the staff, their friendliness didst not diminish,
In a group of diverse tastes, a decent choice, perchance."

"A plague upon this eatery, say I!
The portions be small, the price be high.
And, verily, the burgers do lack grace.
The service, too, doth leave much to desire.
Forsooth, they shouldst close the kitchen's door,
Lest customers behold the cooks' disorder.
In sooth, there be better places nigh,
To sate thy hunger and delight thy eye."

"Hark, what news is this? A check-in time of four o'clock, they say? Pray tell, how can this be? No wifi access, by the stars? 'Tis a strange and ancient structure, indeed. But fear not, fair traveler, for there is hope yet. Seek out the Stratosphere, where service and rates are far better, I do swear."

"Methinks my love and I, devout admirers of Arriba, didst find ourselves most vexed by their poor service. Our visits of late hath been few and far between, forsooth, due to the woeful treatment we didst receive. Alas, our latest venture didst prove a sorry state of affairs indeed! The victuals, once a saving grace, didst falter in quality, save for the margaritas, which, though fairly priced, didst come with a dollop of disdain, I reckon, for our server didst address us as "kiddos" and "kids," a grievous slight, methinks. Moreover, she didst neglect to proffer water unto us, save upon request. My carne asada, a dish I didst anticipate with glee, didst arrive with a generous portion of red cabbage, a most unpleasant surprise, I assure thee. And, verily, my love's request for guacamole and sour cream didst come with a price, a tariff of $1.99 and $2.50, respectively, for a paltry amount of each. Fie upon this establishment! I do not recommend it, good sir or madam, unless thou art content with but drinks and a scant serving of chips and salsa. Avoid it, I say, lest thou wish to suffer poor service, a foul atmosphere, and fare of questionable quality."

"Two days it took for him to reach my abode, a delay most vexing. But lo, the true trouble began when he espied my Genie door opener. 'Oh woe is me,' quoth he, 'that thou hast purchased such a worthless contraption! A piece of junk, a pile of rubbish, fie upon it!' He spoke with vehemence, his words a stinging rebuke. 'Nay, good sir,' said I, 'pray tell, what ill fate hath brought thee to this pass?' 'I cannot, nay, I will not,' quoth he, 'work upon this wretched device. 'Tis the very worst of openers, a plague upon the land!' His manner was most rude, his speech a torrent of disdain. If thou desirest to be insulted and mocked, then seek out Affordable Garage Door and Opener repair. But if thou art averse to rudeness and contempt, then avoid them as thou wouldst avoid the very pit of hell itself."

"Hark, good sirs, I pray thee, listen well,
For I have tale to tell, a woeful spell,
Of gym membership, gone most foul and awry,
A club, where fitness doth not dwell, nor doth it fly.

A member, I, since opening day, alas,
Yet, now, in truth, I say, 'tis but a waste,
No space for stretches, pilometers, nay,
But two hundred lockers, and one lone bench, oh fie!

In men's room, sit thou must, like rowers, cramped,
If more than two, then sit thou must, all squashed,
No jump ropes, resistance bands, no classes, naught,
Just empty promises, and fees, aplenty, alack!

At first, a bargain, seemed, low fees, no bind,
But annual dues, and cancellation, doth confound,
The manager, Katie, could not explain, the double ding,
Nor offer solace, for my troubled soul, alas, poor thing.

So, pay the fee, I did, to flee, this wretched place,
And shun, the very thought, of stepping in its space,
For fat and out of shape, I'd rather be,
Than suffer thus, at this gym, miserably, yea, verily!"

"This wretched place doth suffer from mismanagement most vile,
A lack of care for service doth leave one in a state of vexation.
'Tis hard to stress the gravity of this dire situation,
For 'tis clear they do not hold their duties in high estimation."

"Hark, my dearest wife and I, ere we doth frequent
Famous Dave's, ere they didst build in Henderson.
We didst travel to Rainbow and Blue Diamond,
Ere the Henderson location didst arise.

Twice a week, we didst visit, in days of yore,
But now, alas, we shall return to Memphis BBQ once more.
For on Tuesday last, we didst venture to Dave's,
And lo, they didst remove the everyday specials,
The catfish, and the ribs, oh what a shame!
No more Big Rib Tuesdays, nor Beef it up Wednesdays,
No wing specials, nay, not even a crumb.

'Tis a pity, forsooth, that they didst take away,
The very things that drew us in, each passing day.
Now naught but stale, burnt chips, do they proffer,
Unfit for man or beast, a sorry sight, indeed.

Greed, it seems, doth rule the day, my friends,
For all these establishments, doth meet their end.
Memphis BBQ, a haven, still doth stand,
With Mike Mill's, whose daily specials, doth please the land.

Farewell, Famous Dave's, thy fate, doth seem,
To follow in the footsteps, of those who came before.
Good luck, indeed, thou shalt require,
In this town, where greed, doth reign, and doth devour."

"Hark! In days of yore, I did partake of sustenance and tea within these walls, but on this morn, a server, Yi by name, didst show me scant respect and courtesy. Verily, her demeanor was rude, unprofessional, and most vexing. My query regarding the boba tea menu didst elicit a response, albeit a repetition of her words, which I didst not fully comprehend due to the cacophony of sounds within the establishment. She didst roll her eyes and speak with disdain, as if to imply mine ignorance. Moreover, she didst converse with a fellow staff member in Taiwanese, casting disparaging glances in my direction, as if to suggest I knew not their tongue. I do proclaim, dear friends and kin, avoid this place, for the server Yi doth provide poor service and doth not merit thy patronage."

"Hark! What stench doth fill mine nostrils? A hamster's den, perchance? Nay, 'tis Kams, where drinks flow like the Nile, but lack the sweetness of the nectar of the gods. 'Tis a place where townsfolk and scholars of the nearby university do congregate, yet oft repent their choice, as if the very heavens did conspire against them."

"O, woe is me! This Wendy's doth be the worst,
A place where food doth come in sorry state,
Smashed and old, as if 'twere left to waste.
Fries, cold or oversalted, none can tell,
Cashiers, more concerned with flirtatious spell.
Management, it seems, doth not take heed,
And restrooms, dirty, at each visit's need.
I vow, ne'er shall I step foot in this place,
For all its ills doth leave a foul taste."

"Alack, I chanced upon this Flame Burger place,
With hopes of savoring a delectable embrace,
But lo, my expectations were quickly dashed,
By the cacophony of sounds that did clash.

Their background music, loud and quite profane,
Did drown my voice, and caused me much disdain,
And when I tried to order, the owner's mind
Was elsewhere, engaged in idle chatter, unrefined.

The menu's images did deceive mine eyes,
For what I got, was far from prize,
A thin, frozen patty, raw within,
Dripping with grease, a sight most sinful.

I asked them to remake it, but alas,
The second burger, too, was a sorry pass,
The seasoning off, the taste not fine,
A culinary disaster, in my rhyme.

The fries, oh woe, were naught but frozen fare,
No different from those found elsewhere,
A waste of coin, a waste of time,
Avoid this Flame Burger, a pitiful crime.

My counsel, friends, steer clear of this place,
And seek instead the familiar grace,
Of Jack in the Box, a safer bet,
Where taste and value, you will not forget."

"Fie upon this wretched feast!  Sticky the interior, as if with honey oozing from the walls.  Incorrect, the order of dishes, as if by fate's cruel hand.  Orange chicken, akin to ketchup-glazed, a travesty!  Kung pao, devoid of zest, its flavors dulled, a disappointment.  Egg roll, unfinished, a sign of disdain.  Crab puffs, a solitary delight, a morsel amidst the woe.  Not again, shall I set foot within these doors, ne'er to suffer such a meal!"

"Verily, I say, this store doth merit naught but scorn. Forsooth, the salesfolk, when thou dost enter, doth ignore thy presence, as if thou wert but a shadow on the wall. Incompetent they be, in their devices and gadgets, and with nary a care, do direct thee to Apple's hallowed halls, or any other refuge, where they may lay their burden down, and shift their duty unto another's shoulders."

"This veterinary clinic doth seek but gold,
My canine companion, Optimmune doth hold.
A paltry sum of thirty-five pieces once did pay,
Now sixty! Oh, how the price doth rise apace!

My hound doth also partake of Rimadyl,
When twice a year, to groomers she doth go.
I asked for more, but lo, they did demand,
Blood work, ere they wouldst grant me a refill hand.

I deemed it folly, for my pup doth take,
But thrice in six months, a small mistake.
The vet didst reply, with reason fair,
That tests must come, ere refills couldst share."

"Alas, my friends, how my tale doth woe beguile,
Of trials dire, of woes most bitter, vile.
A follow-up visit, swift and brief, I thought,
To doctor's care, my heart's concern, brought.

But lo, fate played a cruel trick upon me,
Another EKG, they decreed, must be.
Hooked up, I waited, patient as could be,
Till they commanded, "Bra, off with thee!"

Oh, shame! Oh, woe! My modesty, they shamed,
A paper gown, flimsy, poorly named.
My bosom bare, I lay, a sweaty mess,
As nurses trooped in, out, with little finesse.

The room, a furnace, hot as blazing sun,
I sweltered, sighed, my patience done.
They asked me questions, which I deemed they knew,
And made me wait, till Dr. Chanderraj flew.

At last, he came, my fears and doubts allayed,
All ended well, my heart, no longer dismayed.
Yet, pray, dear friend, thou never needst to go,
To this place, where my trials did unfold, no!"

"O woeful day! Our expectations high, we came to dine,
Forsooth, the name didst promise much delight.
But lo, the hot dogs, dried out and vile,
Didst leave us in disgust, with naught but bile.
The buns, too, were dry, and crumbling to the touch,
And soda, alack, didst come with nary a refill, nor such.
I pray thee, good sirs, avoid this place,
And seek instead the burger joint, with haste."

"Thou hast been charged a princely sum, my friends,
For that which doth emanate from yonder room,
A scent most foul, a smoke most vile and thick,
That doth pollute the air with its noxious plume.

Beware, I say, of those who doth impose
Such charges on thee, for they shall deceive,
And with their wily words, shall seek to devise
A means to part thee from thy hard-earned fee.

So heed my warning, lest thou fall prey
To their machinations, and be made to pay
For that which doth not be, but only seem,
A smoke most foul, a scent most vile and dream."

"Verily, our server was most excellent, but alas! The victuals, they were not so fine. Forsooth, I didst order a baked potato, and upon spreading my butter, didst discover a hard and black substance within. My husband, he didst take it out and crack it open, and lo! 'Twas a piece of mold, most foul and unclean. The management, they didst insist 'twas naught but a burnt piece of steak, yet how could such a thing be? For in the preparation of dairy products, meat doth not belong. Methinks 'tis a form of cross-contamination, and I, for one, shall nevermore partake of their fare. Mayhap a visit from the health inspector would be in order?"

"Upon mine entrance, foul odors doth assail mine nostrils, a veritable affront to mine senses. And yet, we were seated straightaway, a curious anomaly given the throngs that doth frequent this establishment. 'Tis a puzzle, indeed. Our beverages didst arrive in due course, but alas, the entrees didst tarry, a full fifty minutes passing ere they graced our table. The victuals, in mine opinion, doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain... freshness. Aye, 'tis true, the ravioli doth taste of packaging, and the salad, dressed in house sauce and adorned with stale croutons, doth leave much to be desired. The service, too, doth leave a bit to be desired, our server slow to refill drinks and heedless of our needs. Alas, mine niece's birthday celebration brought me to this place, else I wouldst never have darkened its doorstep. Farewell, Olive Garden, mayhap our paths shall never cross again."

"In days of yore, this place didst thrive,
When Hector ruled with skilled hand.
But now, alas! 'Tis naught but woe,
Since new owners took command.

The staff, once keen, now doth seem slow,
And service, poor, doth make me frown.
Their bagels, still, are worth a throw,
But oft, alack! They're not to be found.

On Sundays, when my church doth end,
They're left with naught but strange bread.
If thou dost see a line, my friend,
Do flee, lest thou be driven mad!"

"Pizza, oh pizza, thou art the sole dish that pleaseth me. Yet, alas, thy portion, it doth seem too small. Nachos, oh woeful nachos, how couldst thou betray me thus? Double cheese, I didst request, yet naught but empty plate didst thou provide. Fie upon thee, fried calamari! Thy wet and mushy coating, it doth make me shudder. Chicken wings, cold as ice, they didst lack the fiery passion of yore. Alas, poor service, it doth seem this establishment doth falter. My colleagues, they didst warn me, 'twas a fool's errand to dine here. Yet, I didst persist, and now, my pen doth scribe this tale of woe. Avoid this place, dear friends, lest thou suffer similar fate."

"Hark, I vow, ne'er have I penned a review,
But this place, so vile, doth make me speak anew.
Their customer service, in all the land,
Is worst, most foul, and doth command
My ire, that thus I write, to warn
Of this dire spot, where darkness doth reign."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from yonder Venetian,
Where three of four didst partake in luncheon,
And lo, their bellies didst protest and rebel,
Leaving them in discomfort, nigh to sickness.

Yet still, thou mayst tempt fate and give 't a go,
For fortune's whimsy doth oft play the rogue,
And what doth bring ill to one, mayhap shall bring
Good cheer and health to another, by the blessing.

So, gentle reader, heed this warning well,
And choose thy meal with care, lest thou dost fell
Into the pit of woe, like those who came before,
And learn by their example, as doth the poet."

"Verily, I didst finish mine own take-out repast from CRMG upon Camelback,
And, alas! There be much victual left, alack! 'Tis in the rubbish bin, woe is me!
Behind yon counter, chaos didst reign, a plethora of high school knaves,
In truth, 'twas like they didst open last week, and yet, six months agone they didst arrive.

I didst utilize CRMG's online ordning tool, and lo! 'Twas effective, by my troth!
I didst command the beef nachos and a beef burrito, in sooth.
But when I didst dig in, alack! The cheese, it didst scarce abound,
And cheddar, at that! When cold, 'tis naught but nacho, and difficult to devour,
I didst swiftly lose patience with the nachos, flavorless and a woeful sight,
And thus, I didst turn to yon burrito, with haste and hope.

Yet, alas! The burrito, in taste, didst falter, and in size, didst make amends,
With a strange, unlooked-for flavor, a blend of verde salsa and enchilada sauce,
I didst command it with a medium verde, but lo! 'Twas not to be,
For the twain didst combine, and thus, 'twas inedible, to mine utter dismay.

In conclusion, a waste of eighteen shillings and fivepence, I do declare,
Nevermore shall I return, to this place, ne'er again, farewell, adieu!"

"Methinks 'tis strange that Boby doth possess such cockiness, when his culinary skills do leave much to be desired. His grub, alack, doth lack the authenticity and flavor that doth make a dish truly delectable. Nay, 'tis flat and uninspired, a true disappointment to the taste buds. 

My spouse, the Mesa burger didst partake, but found it to be dry and unfulfilling, leaving him unsatisfied. And I, my dear, didst opt for the spicy chicken with sweet potato hash, a dish that didst fail to impress, o'erpriced and reminiscent of a meal from Denny's, a far cry from the gastronomic excellence we didst anticipate. 

We visited this establishment during the Super Bowl of 2010, perchance their attention was diverted, yet, I fear, methinks I wouldst not return, for the fare they served, didst not meet our expectations."

"Hark, what horror doth mine eyes perceive?
A tale of woe, a scene most dire.
At the food court, we didst partake
Of hot dogs, savory and sweet.
But lo, the cashier, with rag so foul,
Didst clean the onions, and our stomachs didst churn.
He gathered all the onions, with that same rag,
And put them back, for all to consume, in the machine.
Oh, how my gut didst protest, my mouth didst water.
I pray thee, good people, avoid that place,
Lest thou desire to feel the pangs of sickness.
My mother, she didst feel most ill that day,
A consequence, no doubt, of that foul deed.
Indeed, 'tis a sight most loathsome and vile."

"Verily, a most vexing experience hath been mine at this establishment. Methinks 'tis a place of business most foul, wherein the staff doth bear a countenance most surly and unpleasant. By my troth, their demeanor doth bespeak a lack of care for those who do frequent this place. Alas, their dilatory ways doth make one feel quite ignored, as if their plight were of no concern to these knaves. Fie upon this wretched place! Mayhap, in time, they shall mend their ways, lest all their custom doth depart."

"Hark! A tale of The Carnegie Deli, I shall tell,
Whereon the sixth of August, I didst dine well.
A check, numbered five thousand and seven hundred,
Didst serve as proof, should management be curious.

The service, swift and kind, didst make me smile,
The restaurant, clean and neat, didst please mine eye.
Fresh sandwiches and sides, didst satisfy my hunger,
And salads, crunchy vegetables, didst make me linger.
Great rye bread too, didst complement the meal,
I shall return, for more, I do reveal.

But alas! The desserts, didst not impress,
A coconut cream pie, with flaws, I must confess.
Too starchy, lacking flavor, a disappointment,
I made such pies, in Saipan, with great content.
A seven layer cake, my friend didst try,
Too sweet, too dry, a failure, didst I spy.

Carnegie, great for sandwiches, sides, and more,
But desserts, a weakness, they must explore.
Burn the menu, a new start, they must take,
For sweet treats, a failure, they didst make."

My sojourn at this place didst leave much to be desired,
For many reasons, which I shall now expound.
The staff, unfriendly and full of disdain,
Didst make me feel most unwelcome and annoyed.

The cleanliness of my chamber, a great disappointment,
Was not fit for a king, nor even a peasant.
No early check-in, a fee they didst impose,
And after paying, a dirty room they didst expose.

The security guards, their duties they didst take
Too seriously, with stern and solemn face.
The pool, crowded and no place to sit,
A margarita village, but not worth the price.

Yet, there were some positives, I must confess,
Cheap it was, but quality, alas, didst lack.
Central location, a convenience, indeed,
But overall, a stay here, I wouldst not recommend.

"O woeful night! O cursed abode!
No minibar, nor luggage rack, I find,
And dirty, foul, and full of grime.
As a fair maiden, traveling solo,
I fear for my safety, and I quake.
Gum blocks the peephole, a sorry sight,
And in the shower, drain backs up with spite.
A horrid place, where I shall not stay,
Nevermore, I pray, shall I return."

"Methinks 'tis folly to reserve online, my friends,
For though it seemeth easy, troubles doth it bring.
Firstly, paying with a swiped card, a simpler way,
Yet, entering all the details, a tedious thing.

And then, the shuttle schedule, oh how it doth annoy,
Coming too early, like a bird that doth destroy.
In Pittsburgh, I didst experience this myself,
A call at 4:47, a warning, a threat, a spell.

"Be ready, out of courtesy," they didst say,
My pickup time, 6:15-6:30, what didst they convey?
No other riders waiting, a lonely soul,
The driver, he didst not even open the door, nor take control.

And then, the rain, it didst pour down in droves,
The driver, he didst not help, nor didst he prove.
We waited, 15 minutes, for another passenger,
A wait, so long, a delay, a true harassment.

I wouldst not recommend, take a cab instead,
For Supershuttle, a poor service, doth provide."

"By th' three dollars, good sir, thou dost charge for brown rice?  'Tis a rip-off, I doth declare! And, pray tell, what sorcery is this?  Thou hast served me mint shrimp, when basil shrimp didst I order.  Twice didst I request th' brown rice, and lo, it didst arrive midway through my entree.  Alas, 'twas dry and of old, as if 'twere left o'er from yestereven's feast!"

"Upon a winter's eve, the twenty-fifth of December, in the year of our Lord two thousand ten, I didst venture forth with mine own son, his wife, and their two sprightly children, to partake of sustenance at a certain establishment. And lo, upon mine arrival, I didst inquire of the servant if the tables might be cleared, that we might sit and break bread together. But alas, the man didst inform me that they didst only offer takeout fare. Now in a hotel, 'tis hard to find warm victuals for takeout, and so I didst ask the waiter if we might have food to go. Ere I couldst receive an answer, he didst let out a heavy sigh and turn away from me, leaving me to ponder the meaning of his words. And thus, I vow nevermore to set foot within those hallowed halls, and to warn all who seek kosher fare in Las Vegas, to avoid that place as they wouldst the plague."

"O, what a woeful sight doth this place present!
The service here, by Jove, is most lamentable.
Our waitress, with nary a glance didst she greet us,
And with scant regard, didst she attend to our needs.
Forsooth, we numbered nine, and our victuals came
In fits and starts, with long delay betwixt each course.
Yet, for the fare itself, a solitary star doth shine,
For 'twas quite tasty, once it didst arrive, in sooth."

"Oh woeful day! Oh wretched fate!
I came from California's sunny state,
To learn why my grandfather met such haste,
And found not a single soul would tell his tale,
Until two hours had passed, and I didst wait.

This place, they call it Martin Luther King,
A hospital in Los Angeles, where life doth cling,
But alas, 'tis true, not many souls doth leave,
For death doth linger here, and doth not cease.
They call it "Killa-King", a name most grim,
For those who enter, rarely do escape its dim.

Yet still, I waited, hoping to hear,
The reason for my grandfather's sudden fear,
But none would speak, nor offer any cheer,
And so I left, with questions still unanswered, dear."

"O, woe is me! Alack, what poor service have I received!
A rude reply, when I did politely speak.
No greeting, nor a smile didst she impart.
A pox upon that wretched woman's art!

Her attitude, so vile and full of spite,
Didst make my blood to boil with anger's might.
I held my tongue, though 'twas hard to do,
For I am not one to speak ill of those who serve.
But, alack, her demeanor left much to be desired.

I shall not soon forget this sorry plight,
Nor shall I e'er return to this McDonald's sight.
No receipt, no straw, and nuggets fewer by one,
A sorry state, indeed, this establishment hath become.
Fie upon it, say I!"

"Hark! If thou seekst to travel from fair Los Angeles  
To spend thy days within a Section 8 abode,  
Good fortune be with thee, for thou shalt need it so,  
For Front Desk hath said the chambers shall be renovated,  
And thus, I pray thee, do not rent this room, my friend,  
Lest thou desire to dwell within a space unended."

"Methinks I've visited this place afore,
For my kin's portraits, and loved the score,
A package deal, and then online access,
For my kin to purchase more, with ease.

But now, alas, my joy doth turn to woe,
For on my latest visit, I didst know,
That the online studio, once free to view,
Now doth require a payment, anew.

My son, a babe of two summers, doth grace,
The pictures, taken with love and care,
But when I sought to buy, in fond embrace,
The rest of the poses, I found despair.

Forsooth, the studio doth no longer provide,
The online access, save for those who decide,
To buy upfront, more poses, ere they take,
Their leave of the studio, and its make.

And thus, dear friends, my heart doth break,
For I have lost, those precious pictures, make,
Of my sweet babe, in his tender youth,
Forever gone, without a chance of truth.

Nay, I shall ne'er return, to this place,
Where once I found such joy and grace."

"Hark, what shenanigans doth unfold within this place,
Where dogs doth dwell and people doth embrace,
In search of furry friend, my heart didst race,
But lo, the workers doth ignore my face.

A tent doth stand, where gossip doth abound,
And folk doth stare, as if I were a clown,
I asked for aid, but they doth turn away,
And leave me be, to wander and dismay.

The dogs, they doth require a walk, I see,
Yet none doth stir, but volunteers, so free,
A shame it is, that those who work, doth not,
Their duty, to the canines, they doth owe.

I felt quite vexed, and sad, I must confess,
For those poor hounds, who doth deserve much better,
Thus, I shall not return, to this place,
Forfriendly folk, and helpfulness, doth lack.

Alas, the dogs, they doth suffer, by this neglect,
And I, a potential owner, doth reject,
This shelter, where the workers doth not care,
A pox upon them, and their fare."

"Fare thee well, dear friends! Our culinary quest didst take us to a place they call VIP. Now, of the lo mein, I must say 'twas good, quite tasty indeed. But alas, the fried rice, it didst lack in flavor and didst possess an oily sheen. And thus, the sushi, a mixed bag, dependent on the rolls, thou see.

Now, as for service, mark this tale well! For on my birthday, my parents didst leave a token of gratitude, a $7 tip, hidden beneath a plate. And lo, the server didst pursue us, with haste and purpose great. She led my parents back, to where we didst dine, and asked if she had served us well. My mother, with grace and humor, didst reply, "Aye, fair server, thou didst serve us well."

Then, with a raised eyebrow, the server didst query, "Why then, good sir and madam, didst thou not leave a gratuity?" My mother, with a smile, didst explain, "Fear not, fair server, for we didst leave a token under yonder plate." And lo, the server didst lift the plate, and find the tip, with glee and satisfaction great. And thus, my mother, with a generous heart, didst give the server yet another $10, lest the first sum were not enough, to ensure her happiness and mirth."

"Hark, good sir or madam, let this be a lesson to thee,
Of Hastings and Hastings, a company most uncouth,
Their attitude, hostile and unprofessional, didst sting,
And left me in wonder, how such conduct doth cling.

In sooth, I say to thee, learn from my woeful plight,
And shun those folk, for they do naught but ignite,
A fire of ire, that doth consume all in its path,
Leaving naught but ash, and bitter, acidic wrath.

So heed my words, dear friend, and turn away,
From Hastings and Hastings, lest thou suffer their dismay."

"O, wouldst thou gain entry to this club of delight? Pray, fair reader, heed my warning well. Forsooth, the bouncer here, a wretched soul, doth judge all who seek to enter in. He doth discriminate, with bias most foul, 'gainst those who are not of a certain mold. Tall, thin, and fair of face, a maiden must be, lest she be turned away with scorn and disdain. Or else, a youth of tender years, with visage pale and weak, doth strive to pass the test. But nay, the bouncer, with his limited understanding, doth fail to see beyond his own narrow view. His rudeness doth abound, and his small mind doth revel in his petty power. Alas, poor man, for he hath not the wit nor charm to rise above his station low."

"Alas, my journey to this place didst bring me naught but woe,
For it didst seem that fame and fortune doth it know.
The Carnitas, once a dish of pride and might,
Didst require a knife and fork to cut its plight.
My comrade's crab enchiladas, a dish of old,
Didst fail to impress, its flavors cold.
I didst feel a pang of sorrow in my heart,
To see a famous Latino play a part.
In this, a brand that doth not stand the test,
But doth he check the food? Alas, no rest.
The decor, a sight to behold, so fair,
And staff, though not sharp, didst show they care."

"Hark, good sirs, I do declare,
My stomach did protest most vehemently,
For after dining at Popeyes, foul play,
A cockroach upon the wall did sally.
And yet, my hunger did prevail,
I ate the food, despite the loathsome sight,
And thus, my innards did revolt and wail,
In woeful sickness, for a day and night.
Moreover, the privies, oh how foul,
A shit show, literal, did unfold.
O Popeyes, take heed of this plight,
And make haste to set things right."

"Alas, poor renters! How ill-fated are ye,  
To suffer thus beneath the yoke of mismanagement's sway.  
A plague upon this wretched company, I pray,  
That doth neglect thy duties with such disdain.  

The dishwasher, broken and leaky, doth fester,  
And the A/C unit, too small, doth pour forth water within.  
No urgency doth stir their hearts to mend,  
Leaving thee, dear renter, in such woeful state.  

Beware, good sirs and madams, of this cursed crew,  
That doth but mock thy plight with naught but empty words anew.  
Seek not their aid, lest thou desire to suffer thus,  
And join the chorus of those who have been wronged, alack."

"O, wouldst thou see the wondrous sight, my friend?
A buffet fit for royalty, they doth pretend.
But lo, the people who do partake,
Are o'erlarge, and their portions, o'ermake.

The food, alas, doth suffer in its fate,
Being poor in quality, and ill-prepared, of late.
And the ambiance, I pray thee, doth match the store,
With babes, all snot-stained, and naught but a diaper more.

The music, cheesy, doth play on,
Whilst management doth bark, their orders, anon.
The floors, so dirty, and the carpets, all agleam,
With grease and food, that doth cling, like a bad dream.

Wall to wall, 'tis a sight most foul,
A veritable feast, for the eyes, doth unfold."

"Fie upon this wretched place, so dull and grey!
They dare to charge a fee, when naught but dust doth play?
Their service, poor and slow, doth make me sigh,
Thirty minutes passed, ere our order came nigh.

The guards, a trio of most sorry men,
With petty power, do strut and preen.
I did but rest mine eyes, a moment's space,
And yet, they chide me for my lack of grace.
This place, so void of mirth and joy, doth earn
My scorn and wrath, with each passing minute's turn."

"Verily, I do declare, 'twas a Sunday afternoon when last we didst venture hither. In hopes of saving a few coins, we didst decide to partake in a meal at this establishment. Alas, the prices were not much lower than those at other taverns, nay, but a mere $5 or $10 difference. And, alack, I fear I may have contracted some foul illness from the grimy chairs at Fitzgerald's. No more shall we return to this place, I doth swear it."

"Beware, good sirs and madams, of this place,
Where lies and deceit doth reign supreme.
They quoted me a price, a sum quite fair,
For spaying two cats, a task quite keen.
But lo, when I didst drop them off,
Their cost didst rise, and my wallet didst cough.
They claimed the cats were in heat, a fact most strange,
And thus, the price didst climb, a sum most change.
I called upon other vets, who didst say,
That six months old, in heat, was nigh impossible, in sooth.
Even if I paid the extra fee,
The price was still too much, a sum most disagreeable.
The doctor was friendly, and didst offer me,
A credit, half the cost, a gesture most generous, you see.
But I didst not desire mere money, fair sirs,
I wished for fairness, and a quote most precise.
So heed my words, dear friends, and take heed,
Get all in writing, ere you make a deal, indeed.
For this clinic, I shall ne'er return,
And neither shouldst thou, lest thou desirest to burn."

On Saturday, the sun doth rise at nine,
And I, with ten others, didst wait in line.
But lo, the store didst not open its gate,
And we, in frustration, didst depart, in hate.

This was my second visit to this place,
The first, a disaster, full of disgrace.
I entered an hour and a half ere close,
And was yelled at, like a woeful ghost.

I'll not recommend this store, I swear,
Ace Hardware, my new haven, I'll hold dear.
Until a better hardware place I find,
My loyalty to Ace, forever bind.

"Hark! A tale of woe and discontent doth unfold,
At PostNet, where letters doth await their fate,
Two missives, bound for far-off lands, didst I send,
With haste, I prayed, yet time didst slowly creep.

A gentleman, with pace most slow and measured,
Didst tend to me, with diligence unproven,
My simple quest, completed in ten minutes' span,
Yet cost, oh how it didst mount to the heavens!

Eleven dollars, per letter, didst they demand,
One destined for Phoenix, the other, afar,
The post office, a mere six dollars, didst claim,
For each, a mark-up, most gross and extreme.

I questioned the price, with reason and with ire,
The answer, brief, yet void of sense or fire,
"Tis worth the wait," a phrase, most weak and lame,
Didst justify the cost, and naught else couldst tame.

Ten minutes, for two letters, oh how absurd,
I shall not return, nor shall I be heard,
In this place, where time doth seem to stand,
And patience, doth wear a heavy hand."

"This place doth lack refinement, methinks.
The victuals' queue doth resemble a flock of birds,
In disarray, they flutter and doth swoop,
Forgetfulness doth seem their greatest foe.
Soup, once hot, now doth runneth cold,
Tortilla, too, doth suffer such fate.
Three teas, all empty, doth mock me,
A constant vexation, a never-ending woe."

"O, wouldst thou not recommend this eatery to any soul,
For customer service most pathetic doth unfold.
They care not for their patrons, as they know full well
Their establishment doth stand alone, a rare gem to tell.

Food, ordinary fare, yet they do cheat on time,
Claiming to be open late, but nay, they doth decline.
Let them instead, their hours correct, proclaim,
Lest patrons be turned away, with naught but disdain.

Business etiquette, they must learn, ere they can claim
To be a place of worth, where folk may gather and gain.
Alas, poor service doth leave much to be desired,
And thus, I pray, a better choice may soon be inspired."

"A quaint and charming spot, I did declare,
I snapped a picture, and to my love did send.
Upon a Saturday, during my lunch break,
I ventured in, with haste, to partake.

Their hospitality was swift, I must confess,
For I was seated straightaway, with no great mess.
But alas, their tea selection was quite meager,
Only raspberry Nestea, my heart did shrink.

A basket of garlic bread, they did provide,
But oh, the oil, it did my stomach chide.
I ate it all, despite its greasy fate,
For my eggplant parmesan sandwich, I did wait.

Thirty minutes passed, and still it did not come,
So I asked to take it with me, on the run.
The young man, he did bring it to me,
In a bag, with haste, but with no courtesy.

The owner, or manager, did emerge from within,
And charged me full price, my coin did spin.
I thought it rude, for I did wait so long,
And left with an empty tea glass, my song.

At my desk, I did eat my sandwich with woe,
It was but mediocre, I do declare, no joe.
I shall not return, forsooth, I do swear,
For this place, it did not earn my praise, I fear."

"Ticket window, wherefore art thou? Rude and racist service doth abound,
An employee, with words most unkind, didst tell us naught but lies.
A supervisor, with power most great, didst come and say,
'Transaction never charged, thy gift card doth hold no sway.'
Free tickets, they didst give to us, with attitude most foul,
But lo, a screenshot of the charge, didst prove them quite the fool.
Since AMC took o'er this place, service and management doth decline,
A once-favorite theater, now tainted by poor design.
Nevermore shall I set foot within these walls,
For bad service hath ruined all, and left a foul taste that doth appall."

"Nevermore shall I set foot in that place,
Where my comforter, once beige and blue, didst lose its grace.
I took it to be dry cleaned, a simple deed,
But when I retrieved it, all the blue had fled.

The woman, she didst deny any wrong,
And claimed that I must have brought her a defective song.
She said that it was the manufacturer's fault,
And refused to refund me, with a stern and haughty vault.

I showed her the tag, with "Dry Clean Only" writ,
But still she would not budge, nor admit her wit.
At last, she didst relent, but not before a fray,
And I left with a ruined bedspread, and naught to say.

Beware, good people, of this establishment,
For they are costly, and their service, a mere travesty.
I shall never return, nor recommend them to thee,
For they have left a sour taste, and a memory most disagreeable."

"O, what a sorry sight didst greet mine eyes,
At The Range at Ballantyne, where I didst go,
To shoot and test mine aim, with pistol in hand,
But lo, the staff, they didst play the fool,
Their computers, they didst not understand,
And so, I waited, patiently, or so I thought,
For ten whole minutes, ere they couldst sort,
Another customer's lane, and charge him right,
It was a scene, most laughable and quite,
Like unto the three stooges, in their prime,
Fumbling with gadgets, in a digital time.
But then, I reached the range, and oh, what joy,
A state-of-the-art facility, didst employ,
I shot and shot, with pistol in hand,
For thirty minutes, a good and merry land.
But alas, the bill, it didst come,
And with it, a surprise, most vexing,
For they didst charge me, $25 per hour,
When pistol rate, shouldst have been, in power,
They claimed, that FMJ, didst make it so,
That rifle rate, didst apply, I do not know,
And thus, my thirty minutes, didst cost,
$27, a sum, most vile and quite lost,
I shall not return, to this place again,
For such deceit, doth leave a foul stain."

"Hark, what news is this? A gym most foul and dirty,
Where machines do break and thieves do lurk,
A place where basketball courts do bring
Thugs and rascals, with naught but trouble to seek.

My car, alas, was broken into,
And my wallet, with gold and silver, did flee,
No security doth watch o'er this den,
Leaving me in woe and misery to pine.

The staff, with manners rough and rude,
Do scorn my plight and offer naught but scorn,
But fear not, for I have found a new abode,
At LVAC, where courtesy doth reign supreme,
And all my woes did quickly disappear."

"Nevermore shall I employ these folk,
In Charlotte's realm, their conduct doth bespeak
A lack of courtesy, and language unprofessional,
Their payment plans, a farce, a sham, a mockery,
Their website, broken, would not accept my coin,
And when I called, they did not deign to reply,
Until months passed, and my patience wore thin,
Then, and only then, did they condescend to speak,
But still, their words were empty, void of sense,
Their prices, too, did border on the obscene,
Their workers, underpaid, their toil unrecompensed,
Oh, seek ye out a better breed of men."

"O, how vile and wretched was the drink they served,
A concoction of lemons, water, and ice, so curdled.
Ten dollars, they did demand, a king's ransom,
For two small cups, a price most exorbitant.

We tried it not, but cast it straight away,
Into the dustbin, where 'twas met with dismay.
Artificial, the flavor, and strange, the feel,
A most unpleasant draught, we did not conceal.

Alas, poor Angelo's, thy reputation doth suffer,
With such a brew, thy customers thou dost offend.
Reconsider, good sir, thy recipe, I pray thee,
Lest thou lose all custom, and thy business decayeth."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall us here!
A group we came, and yet they didst not care.
Their words of wait, but twenty minutes, didst lie,
For over an hour didst we stand and sigh.
They wouldst not join our tables, nor show grace,
But spoke to us with scorn upon their face.
Disappointment doth abound, alas,
For this place didst not meet our expectations' mark."

"Hark! Good sirs and madams, heed my words of woe,
This resort may seem fair, but 'tis a deceitful show.
A company foul, that doth seek to fleece thee blind,
With charges hidden, and a service charge unkind.

Thy bill, it shall be taxed, and then some more,
And bartenders, thou shalt pay, as if 'twere a chore.
Tips, thou shalt give, to those who doth serve thee well,
But valets, oh valets, they doth charge thee, and tell!

Deadlines, thou shalt meet, with payments in hand,
But promptness, thou shalt not find, from this wicked band.
Preferred vendors, beware, for they may not be true,
And contracts, they doth bind thee, with a spell anew.

So heed my warning, good sirs and madams, take heed,
For this resort, it doth seem sweet, but 'tis a bitter creed."

"With friends, a merry band, I didst attend  
A birthday fete, where laughter and cheer didst flow.  
We sat upon soft couches, open to all,  
And played games, quaffing ale, in high spirits, no fall.  
But lo! Our joy was short-lived, forsooth,  
For a group of wealthy patrons, with purses full and broad,  
Didst covet our seats, and with rude disdain,  
Didst oust us from our perch, with nary a refrain.  
Oh, woe betide the place that doth such deeds,  
For ne'er again shall I set foot within its bounds,  
Nor shall my friends, who with me didst share  
This tale of woe, and vexation without compare."

My dearest wife and I didst venture in,
At lunchtime, when the sun doth shine bright.
And lo, the place was empty, not a soul in sight,
As if the patrons had fled in fright.

A single dish, a lonely sight,
Didst grace the glass case, cold and bare.
We stood, in awkwardness, a sorry plight,
Until the menus, laminated, didst appear.

A juice, a simple drink, we didst choose,
Carrot and orange, a flavorful mix.
But alas, 'twas lukewarm, not a pleasant surprise,
And thus, our hopes, didst quickly diminish.

The establishment, a sight to behold,
With decor, quite modern and bold.
But service, poor, and food, subpar,
At such a price, our expectations marred.

Yet still, the place, doth hold a charm,
And thus, we may, another time, disarm.
For now, a single star, doth be its due,
Our visit, not the best, anon, adieu.

"Hark! Their wares be overpriced, by th' heavens above! And all they do, those pawnshops, doth but glance at eBay's worth, and offer thee a paltry sum, a quarter, perchance, of its true value on the digital marketplace. Alas, how poorly doth this establishment fare! A $100 offer for an iPhone 5c, with all its trimmings? Pray tell, what jest is this?"

"Tis the most woeful service I've e'er received,
In Vegas, or elsewhere, I do believe.
No smile doth grace the faces of the serving crew,
In their dark garb, they seem to mourn anew.
Their demeanor doth suggest a funeral rite,
Not a merry feast, with joy and delight.
I witnessed firsthand, the lengthy delay,
For food to arrive, and heard the dismay.
No apology came from the servers' lips,
They shunned all eye contact, with scowls and quips.
'Twas plain to see, they loathed their work,
And longed for other pursuits, with no smirk.
Some training, prithee, on hospitality,
They sorely lack, in this establishment, I do see."

"Hark! A pizza tale most vexing and woeful,
Eight years have I enjoyed their tasty pies,
But now, alack! A mistake most grievous,
They wrote "pick-up" instead of delivery, by th' heavens!

An hour passed, and I, in wonder, didst call,
To speak with owner, a brash woman, by th' sound,
She said 'twas mine error, and no compromise,
No fresh pie for me, alas! How unkind!

I asked for manager, to plead my case,
But she, a stubborn soul, didst show no grace,
My eight years of loyalty, to naught didst avail,
And so, I sadly shook my head, and didst depart,

Ah, woe is me! For such a small sum,
A dozen dollars, and no pizza didst come,
Their loss, methinks, for now I shall impart,
This tale of woe, to all in Mt. Holly's heart."

"Upon a Saturday, I chanced to dine
At this establishment, with hopes divine
Of partaking in a lunchtime feast
A buffet, with choices manifold and vast

But alas, my expectations were deceived
For all that lay before me, seemed conceived
In days of yore, when freshness did abound
Now stale and wilted, like a flower unbound

The Naan, a symbol of their woe
Was visibly stale, as if 'twere snow
And in its taste, a bitter bite did reign
A flavor foul, that did my senses pain

Thus, I did vow, to nevermore return
To this place, where culinary dreams do burn
For quality, it seems, they did not learn
And left me feeling quite forlorn."

"Methinks 'tis strange, for oft I've come by night,
And found this place open, with nary a plight.
But now, at dawn, whene'er I did arrive,
The window sign doth say they do thrive.
Yet, alack! The lady on the intercom doth say,
They be closed, and thus my hopes did stray.
I ne'er have seen such trouble ere this day,
And so, methinks, I shall the number way,
To learn if truly they be open all the time,
Or if 'twas but a dream, a mere whimsy of mine."

"Thou art the very embodiment of impudence, thou rude security guard, within the confines of this club. Thy boorish demeanor doth leave much to be desired, and thy behavior towards myself, a lady, doth border on the extreme of incivility. Thou didst seize my wrist with such force, and didst shout at me with a vehemence most unbecoming. Fie upon thee, thou knave!"

"O, woeful day! O, wretched fate!
In yonder tavern, we did dine,
My chicken, burnt and black as coal,
Did make me scream, in raging soul.

The waitress, deaf to my plight,
Did ignore my pleas, with all her might.
I prayed for her to fix the fowl,
But she, a stubborn maid, did scorn.

O, cruel fate! O, wicked chance!
That we, the only guests, should dance
With such ill luck, and suffer thus,
In yonder inn, of poor repute.

I'll ne'er return, nor pay a coin,
To taste their cooking, void of joyn.
For in that place, I found no cheer,
But burnt chicken, and a deaf ear."

"A half-hour wait, and naught but woe didst greet us. Told we must wait an hour or twain, ere a carriage we might obtain. A fine manner doth this rental business keep, its garage full of steeds, like chariots of old."

"Hark! What's this? A tavern, by the roadside placed,
With smoke that doth assault mine eyes and brain.
A sign doth say, 'Please seat thyself,' and so
We did, but service came not, though we waited long.
The booth was foul, the window sill with dust,
And fries and flies, both old and lifeless, lay.
The food, when finally brought, was naught but woe,
Tasteless and dull, a culinary dismay.
I wonder how they keep their doors agape,
Unless their drinks, cheap and strong, do bring
A crowd, who, in their cups, do not discern
The filth and poor fare that doth this place cling.
Alas, 'twere best if they did shut their doors,
For none should suffer such a sorry state."

"Beware, ye busy professionals and those who seek
The speedy service of Jimmy John's unique treat,
For though their food may be fine, 'tis a curse
To suffer through their freaky, fast, and terse
Attitude and poor service, which doth abound.
So heed my warning, lest thou be confounded."

"Alas, my friends, I do confess,
Yesterday's experience did leave me quite distressed.
In search of sweet Blue Bell, I did venture forth,
And found two flavors that did catch my eye, in truth.

The vanilla, priced at $3.98, did seem a steal,
And so, I thought, the chocolate would be, as well.
But lo, the cashier did inform me, with a smirk,
That one was priced at $6.99, and not a penny less, nor more.

I asked if this were some mistake, or woeful prank,
But nay, the other girl did say, 'Tis true, good sir,
The vanilla's on sale, but chocolate's not, alack,
And thus, my friends, my anger did begin to flare, and swift.

For who, in their right mind, would such a thing devise?
To cheat a customer, with such a price, so high?
I fear, my friends, this store may lose my business,
For such petty tricks, I shall not suffer, nor abide, in truth."

"Hark! Is this place yet open? Methinks 'twould be a fools' errand to venture hither, save for the guise of Crockett or Tubbs, in South Beach, 1984. Alas, the atmosphere doth reek of cheese, and I, with naught but curiosity, did enter. Verily, I departed with the sense of being duped. How couldst one from the West coast deem this fare decent seafood? The fish, and its accoutrements, did leave much to be desired. Aye, Fanny Bay oysters, a tolerable start, yet as the eve wore on, my purse did smart with each succeeding course. And, pray tell, what of the aqua blue bolagna decor?"

"Hark! A new pizza place doth catch mine eye,
Where once did Mark Rich's reign supreme.
I asked the maiden at the counter, fair,
If recipes remained, despite change of name.
She said they did, and thus my fears were laid,
That Giani's might not meet my pizza aim.

I ordered lunch special, two slices and drink,
For $5.95, a fair price, I did think.
But alas! The pizza, it did not impress,
Burnt and stale, it did not pass the test.
A shame, indeed, for I did hope to find
A pizza joint, where I could dine and unwind.

But fear not, dear friends, for nearby lies
"Above the Crust", a pizza place that doth rise.
So, thither shall I go, with joy and cheer,
To savor pizza, fit for mine ear."

"Verily, I do esteem good customer service of great import,
But here, alas! The service was most vile and base.
Their guacamole, a sickly hue, didst offend mine eyes,
And food, of quality poor, didst leave me in surprise.
A rating, nay, not even one star doth it deserve,
