Forsooth, give thy hard-earned coins to other reserve."

"Fie upon this eatery, dear friends!
The napkins, they did stink, like rotten fruit.
And the water glasses, dirty were they,
Mine had a sticky substance, most unpleasant to the touch.
The wall, it was besmirched with dried on grime,
Uncleaned, it seemed, for quite some time.
The ale, a Bud Light glass did it come in,
A paltry vessel, unworthy of the drink within.
My wife, her beer salad, a sorry sight it was,
I could have prepared it better, with mine own two hands.
The service, fair it was, yet all in all,
This place, avoid it, lest ye wish to suffer foul play."

"O, woeful day! In fair Canada's land,
A tire shop doth reign, most vile and base.
Their policy, so strict and unjust,
Doth bar all returns, save those they've traced.

Their shelves, so bare, their wares, so few,
In narrow paths, doth make it hard to view.
Why trouble thyself with such a place?
Better to journey forth, to Sherbrooke's grace.

Or, mayhap, to the highway's speed,
Where forty miles doth bring thee swift relief.
Forsooth, avoid this pit of woe and shame,
And seek thy tires elsewhere, for thy name."

"This place doth cost a pretty penny, and yet,
The quality doth not match the price, methinks.
'Tis crowded, true, but I do not desire
To break my fast here, for 'tis too dear.
Four and eighty dollars, pray tell!
What sorcery is this? I cannot abide
Such prices for a meal so scant.
I say, nay, nay, 'tis not worth the cost.
The portions be small, the victuals passable,
But not worth such a sum, I do avow."

"Hark! We didst order twain dishes from this Pei Wei place,
One shrimp lo mein, and beef with veggies in its space.
But alas! The lo mein, oh so bland and tasteless,
Even with extra sauce, a flavorless mess.
And the veggies, raw and uncooked, a sight to behold,
I ne'er had such foul fare at any other Pei Wei of old."

"Hark, good victuals, but service somewhat rude. \n\nWe entered, seeking sustenance late in the eve, and the server, with cheer, did greet us anon. The fare was passable, naught special, yet not vile neither. But lo, as we quaffed our draughts, the music ceased, and bright lights did pierce mine eyes, signaling our departure, ere we had finished our repast! 'Twas a strange and sudden end, and left us in wonder, forsooth. A fortnight's time, or so, didst pass, ere we didst depart, and had they wished to close, a simple word had sufficed, I reckon."

"O, woe is me! This place doth suck, I do declare,
Their victuals doth lack in taste, and that's no jest.
I didst order two sandwiches, and a smoothie besides,
The house special, and a char-chicken, they didst provide.
But lo, the bread didst fall apart in mine hand,
And the smoothie, made with condense milk and some strange land,
Didst taste most foul, like nothing I hadst e'er tried,
I vow, ne'er shall I order from them, ere I die."

"Aye, 'twas but a humble abode of wheeled steeds,
Ferrari and Maserati, their names did gleam.
Their mileage and add-ons, on plaques they did imprint,
But alack, no pictures could we take, forsooth.

The only one who spoke to us, a vendor was he,
Who sought to sell us a memento, for a fee.
Oh, how I wished for one to guide us through,
And share the history of these noble steeds anew.

Alas, my friend, I should have bought gelato then,
For 'twas a pitiful sight, this dealership of old.
But still, the mem'ry of those cars, doth linger yet,
In my mind's eye, a vision of beauty, forever set."

"A pox upon this eatery, say I!
The victuals served, a sorry sight,
Unseasoned, rubbery filet, a disgrace,
Lobster risotto, from a bag, its taste.
The service, too, left much to seek,
In this fair city, where dining's a treat,
Do thyself a favor, go elsewhere,
Forsooth, this place, a disappointment, dire.
MyVegas comps, a waste, alack,
Nevermore shall I darken their door,
A first and last time, this, I swear."

"A pox upon this bakery, with its dry and flavorless fare! 

I had hoped, dear friends, that this place would be a boon to me, an organic eater, but alas, 'twas not to be. The urban cookie, a humble treat, was the sole item that did please my taste buds. The rest, a pair of Ollie cakes, were heavy and dry, with naught but a hint of sweetness in the lemon frosting. The chocolate ganache, a lump of blandness, did nothing to redeem the cakes. 

I spent near $9, and in the end, didst dispose of all, save the aforementioned cookie. Best to make thy own organic cookies, my friends, or seek out Fry's and Honey Moon Sweets, sold at Whole Foods, for a truly delectable experience."

"A pox upon this wretched place, where service doth stink! In days of yore, I ne'er didst have a grievance great 'gainst this establishment, save for a minor mishap or twain. But now, alas! A plague upon the damsel who didst tend the drive-thru window, with visage sour and demeanor most uncouth! Her eyes didst roll in ire, as though she were a shrew, and her comportment didst stir within me wrath most fierce. Methought to seek redress, yet knew not what avail 'twould bring. Fie upon this woeful tavern, where hospitality doth lack!"

"Alas, poor soul, how woeful is thy plight!
A scam, a scam, a scam most foul and vile!
They came, they saw, they quoted a price so high,
And left thy house in such a sorry state.

Their words were smooth, their actions rough,
They made thy carpet smell of damp and mold,
And with their deodorizer, made it worse,
A stench that doth assault thy nose so bold.

Thou didst agree to pay them seventy crowns,
But now thou dost regret it, full of sorrow.
For four months past, another company came,
And left thy house in sweet, fresh fragrance, no shame.

But these, they came, and left thee in disgrace,
With carpets soggy, and a smell most vile.
Their offer of a re-do, doth but inflame,
Thy ire, and doth thy patience wear away.

A refund, thou dost seek, a just request,
For services most poor, and not as promised, at best."

"Methinks, upon mine first visit, the staff didst speak with haste and volume, as if in competition with the wind. Their words didst pierce mine eardrums like a thousand tiny swords. The victuals, though deemed good, didst lack that certain je ne sais quoi, that elusive quality of moistness. Verily, I didst find myself compelled to seek succor in a bowl of soup, that I might restore life unto the parched rice, chicken, and egg rolls. Mayhap, I shall venture thither once again, to see if they have mended their ways."

"Alas, this buffet doth suffer from a curse,
A plague upon its prices, and its worth doth dwindle.
The victuals served, a sorry sight they be,
Barely fit for consumption, and scarce a morsel to see.
The hall itself, in disarray and grime,
A hair found in the dish, a sign of woeful time.
Oh, woe betide the patron who doth venture here,
For they shall find naught but disappointment and fear."

"Alack, how changed this place doth seem,
Since new management did take the helm!
The skilled nail techs, who once did gleam,
Are gone, and with them, their art did disappear.
My latest visit, full of woe and sorrow,
Did prove the change, alas, no tomorrow.
A simple trim, I did request,
But she, with haste, did take all the length,
And left the sides, unclean, unkempt.
Clearly, I shall not return, forsooth.
Yet, joy doth come, in TLC Nails' booth."

"A pox upon this eatery, I pray thee, good sir! Forsooth, we made reservations, and straightaway were seated, yet waited thirtyminutes for our potions, and more than an hour for victuals. Fie upon the service, for 'twas woeful and lacking in grace. And, by my troth, the establishment was not bustling with custom, neither was it full to the rafters. A plague upon this house, say I!"

"O, woeful day! My car rental tale doth wound,
A scam most foul, a scheme of deception profound.
Two hours didst I wait, my patience didst wear thin,
Yet naught but empty words didst the clerk within.

'Twas said, 'No cars remain, thy quest doth end.'
Despite the throng of thirty souls, who waited still.
To seek another agency, or hail a cab,
Was my sole choice, elsewise I would be stuck fast.

The prices of the others, how they didst climb,
And in my mind, a suspicion didst begin to swim.
Dollar, thou art guilty of this deceit,
Thy workers, in league with those who doth compete.

How is't that thou, still in business art?
A plague upon thee, cursed be thy every part!"

"Hark! I didst venture to my love's abode,
Where she didst reside for Magic show's sake.
The chamber seemed dull, naught to boast,
But carpets, foul with dirt, didst make me cower.
And lo! I felt the sting of creatures small,
Which left me woeful, and my love didst fall.
Her bite didst swell, and off to ER she went,
The staff, unkind, didst her discontent.
We shall not return, nor recommend it,
For fear of bugs, and antibiotics' need."

"Fair warning, good sirs and madams, avoid this place at all costs. The staff doth wander, lost and forlorn, with nary a care for those who seek their aid. We chanced upon a smog test, and lo, the man who performed the deed didst not so much as glance our way, nor offer assistance of any kind. His brow was furrowed, his visage stern, as if the weight of his labors didst weigh heavy upon his soul. And then, the manager, a man of some import, didst come forth, and didst strive to aid us in our quest. But alas, his efforts were in vain, for the car, being old and worn, didst resist his every attempt. And thus, in a fit of rage, he didst unleash a torrent of oaths and curses, stamping his feet like a petulant child. Verily, I say unto thee, seek not this place, for quality work thou shalt not find."

"Tis what tis, a humble shop of wares,
In desert's heart, where sands do swirl and twirl.
Off-price, they call it, a place of steals,
For those who seek good deals on mediocre feels.

But, gentle folk, heed my advice,
And seek out Ross, a better choice, full of nice.
There, thou shalt find finer garb, at fairer price,
And leave this desert shop, with naught but empty vice."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, heed my words of woe,
For in this place, thou shalt not find a feast to know.
The victuals, dearly bought, do lack in taste,
And he who doth prepare, doth not make haste.

The salsa, once a delight, now doth resemble water,
And napkins, scarce as they be, do leave thee in discomfort.
So, heed my warning, friends, and flee this wretched den,
Lest thou desire to dine with those who dwell within."

"Fie upon this wretched garb, a purchase made with haste,
Tickets procured online, a narrow window to seize,
Requests for documents, a fax of credit card and license, too,
A promise of delivery, via Fed-Ex, an empty boast, alack.

No tickets came, a message bearing ill tidings,
To retrieve them at their office, a futile endeavor,
A hidden clause, a secret script, a shady dealing,
Charges reversed, a victory, thanks to Mastercard's bounty.

A pox upon this business, its practices most vile,
Shady dealings, a reputation tarnished, a woeful tale."

"Alas, poor doughnut shop, thou dost deserve but one star from me. A coupon didst thou send, and twice it didst arrive, yet didst I wait to try thee out. Reviews on Yelp didst paint a rosy picture, thus my hopes were high. But lo, when I didst arrive, the woman behind the counter didst tarry on her phone. No matter, thought I, for I didst await her aid with patience. Yet when she didst approach, she didst inform me that my coupon, buy one dozen get one dozen free, didst only apply to cake doughnuts. Disappointment didst seize my heart, for I didst wish to choose my own flavors. 'Twas then that she didst offer me a cream-filled and a jelly doughnut, but at a cost - cake doughnuts I must purchase. Nay, I didst say, and bid thee adieu, for elsewhere shall I seek my sweet delight."

"Methinks, fair sir, I was most eager to partake
Of victuals at this establishment, forsooth,
Forsooth, a friend of mine didst speak most highly
Of the delectable fare that there was served.
And thus, with haste, I didst hie me thither,
To find, alack, the place didst lie in darkness,
Closed, as it were, in the very midst of day.
The hours, they didst proclaim, 'Twas eleven till ten,
Yet nary a soul didst stir, nor any sign
Didst tell the reason for this sudden closure.
Alack, how disappointed was I, fair sir!"

"O, woeful day! O, wretched night!
In this, the season of Thanksgiving delight,
Beware, dear traveler, lest thou seek repose
Within these halls, for sorrow doth abound.

A wait of two to five hours doth ensue,
For check-in, a torturous queue to pursue.
Fifteen counters, yet but three attend,
To serve the multitude, their patience to amend.

No care for guests, no thought for their relief,
Their strategy, a woeful, wicked grief.
So heed my words, dear traveler, turn away,
Lest thou suffer woes upon this dismal day."

"Hark! I do frequent this theatre, but only when there's naught else to do. 'Tis true, the halls be clean, the victuals fine, and staff most courteous too. But, alas! Their prices for concessions be most foul, and seniors, like myself, receive no discount, unlike other houses of play. Mend these two ills, and I shall change my review to five stars, anon!"

"Two baristas stand idly by, awaiting payment before they tend  
To orders placed, a practice most unbecoming.  
Cashiers dart to and fro, some fetching drinks, others taking coin,  
A chaotic scene, a line doth form, a woeful plight doth show.  

I have visited many a Starbucks, and never have I seen  
Such disarray, such lack of care, such shoddy sheen.  
The baked goods, once a pride, now doth resemble  
Knockoff Costco treats, a sorry sight, a bitter pill to swallow.  

When expectation doth run high, and standards doth apply,  
It doth feel all the more a letdown, a disappointment nigh."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This place, Arrogant Butcher, doth not impress.
Their steak, a disappointment, doth not meet
The standards set by such a haughty name.

The bread, hard and cold, doth not delight,
Nor doth the wine, which taketh far too long
To reach our table, leaving us to pine.
But, lo, the manager, with grace and poise,
Doth offer us two glasses of wine, free of charge,
A kind gesture, indeed, yet not enough
To make up for the faults of this place.

So, my advice, dear friends, doth be,
If thou desirest a night of fine fare,
Look elsewhere, for here, alas, doth lie
A disappointment, in both food and service, I swear."

"A most excellent pizza bearer, a gentle elder man, didst bring my repast. Alas, the order was amiss, forsooth! No fowl didst grace the pie, despite my explicit request. I didst call the shop, and he who spoke, didst answer with great discourtesy. 'Tis true, they were quite busy, yet still, his words didst sting. He offered me a gratis pizza, but I didst not desire it. Nay, I craved naught but civility and respect. Forsooth, 'twas they who erred, not I! And pray tell, how doth one track an order, when quality doth suffer ere it doth depart? Fie upon this woeful service, say I!"

"Methinks I didst venture hither several times,
In search of fine dining, but alas, 'twas naught but woe.
Forsooth, the atmosphere didst reek of smoke and fume,
And service, slow and surly, didst leave me in a sour mood.

First visit, I didst partake of sustenance,
But lo, the aftermath didst leave me in discomfort.
Second time, I didst abstain from food,
And sipped but juice and coffee, in fear of illness.

Third time, I didst sit outside,
And waited patiently for my bill to arrive.
But nay, 'twas not to be, for hour and a half didst pass,
And I, in frustration, didst seek out the check myself at last."

"Woe is me! What wretched fate doth bring me to this woeful place? A nightmare, indeed, it doth appear. Newly built, yet crumbling fast, 'tis a sight most dire. My checkout experience, a horror to behold, didst rival the worst of tales. In line, I stood, and waited, as the queue grew long and longer still. Two cashiers, there were, but one, alas, didst dawdle, slow as molasses in the cold. Dressed as Bon Qui Qui, she worked, her go-backs, with speed, a snail wouldst envy. The line, it grew, and anger, it didst brew, as she, uncaring, didst plod along. The supervisor, he didst intervene, and chastised her, with words of scorn. 'Twas 2:40, and she, ten minutes, hadst spent, on tasks, that shouldst take, but five. Her reaction, a feign, of surprise, didst show, she knew not, of her sloth. And so, she didst continue, to ring, with speed, a tortoise wouldst boast. Oh, woe is me! Nevermore, shall I set foot, in this accursed place, where chaos doth reign supreme!"

"Verily, 'twas plain to see, the service here, a woeful sight it would be,
Unless thou art a regular, a patron known well by the bartenders' sight.
We sat at the bar, to partake in victuals and drink,
And scarce a word, a greeting or farewell, didst they utter, naught but a curt "what doth thou seek?"
If thou art but seeking a chilled ale and a meal of quality, then mayhap this place shall suffice,
But alack, the service, poor and lacking in grace, doth leave much to be desired, save for Corey, our server, a kind soul, whose efforts didst earn the sole star, that doth shine bright.
Take heed, good managers and owners, forsooth, we visited on Monday eve, betwixt six and seven o'clock, and verily, the bartenders, their names, I pray thee, do discover, and mayhap, a lesson in courtesy, they shall learn, anon."

"Hark! What discourtesy doth this pharmacist show?
Ahead of us in line, a car doth take
Twenty minutes or more, and when 'twas our go,
The technician doth ask our name, and so
She saith, "Hold on," and doth disappear,
Leaving us to wait, and wonder, and fear.
Another technician doth come to the window,
And when I ask what happen'd, she doth lash out,
As if 'twere my fault that their service doth lack.
Fie upon such rude and poor customer care!"

"A merry time we had, I must confess,
The music played, our spirits did lift.
But then, alas! A mishap did occur,
My foot was trod upon, and blood did spurt.
The staff, they were not kind or fair,
They hassled us, and showed no care.
With flashlights, they did gawk at my wound,
And made us leave through the front, with nary a sound.
But for my friends, they had to take a trek,
Through all the club, their patience to seek.
'Twas lame, indeed, and left a sour taste,
In this, our night of revelry and haste."

"Hark! This store, a place of woe and desp'rate need,
Where one doth venture forth, with heavy heart and slow.
Walmart, a name that doth conjure images of grime,
A place where harlots ply their trade, and madness doth climb.
I do detest this place, and shun it with great care,
For in its halls, confusion doth reign supreme, and naught but despair.

The employees, a witless lot, doth stumble and stutter,
Unable to assist, their minds a jumbled disaster.
And should thou seek aid, fear not, for thy device,
Shall guide thee better than these hapless souls, in this dark, benighted space.

But lo! The management, a rare and elusive breed,
Doth hide and skulk, afear'd to show their faces, indeed.
Oh, joy! For in this place, the mighty Walmart doth reign,
A kingdom of chaos, where order doth not sustain."

Two year past, I loved Fremont Street Experience,
The casinos, drinks, and all the merriment,
I planned to stay at Golden Nugget, my dear,
But now, alas, my thoughts do change and shift.

I am most grateful that I did not stay,
For on my latest visit, woe betide,
No drink could I procure at any casino,
And when I did, 'twas slow, a sorry show.

The worst part, friends, was the riffraff,
Beggars, dealers, and harlots, oh so rough,
In Vegas, yes, but this was quite excessive,
We left within three hours, our mirth and play reduced.

Normally, we drank and gambled for six hours straight,
But now, alas, I shall avoid that street,
For Fremont's charm hath lost its former sheen,
And I shall seek my pleasures elsewhere, my friend.

"Methought, fair maiden, to partake in ale and cheer
At Taps, a place of merriment, or so I did hear.
But lo, upon entrance, discomfort didst reign,
For all didst gawk, and nary a soul didst proffer aid.
No hostess nor sign didst indicate where to sit,
And employees and patrons, alike, didst blend and blur.
Thus, lacking service, we didst swiftly depart,
And ne'er shall return, forsooth, to that woeful mart."

In this place, a plethora of shops doth abound,
With prices so high, they doth rival the ground.
Amidst the glitz and the glam, they doth pretend,
To be on Fifth Avenue, their wealth to amend.
But alas, dear friend, 'tis naught but a guise,
For they are naught but a mall, with prices quite nice.
In truth, they doth resemble more a place,
Where those who doth lose, do frequent with haste.
A Simon Property Mall, in a land so fair,
With shops so fine, they doth leave one in awe there.

"Though fond of Dr. Patel, I must confess,
The front and back office staff, a sorry mess!
Our payments, they did acknowledge, yet still,
Three months on, the sum, we have not fulfilled.

We emailed the office manager, frequent as clockwork,
She promised to investigate, but ne'er didst work.
Aggravation mounts, our patience doth wear thin,
With many fine physicians, why suffer this sin?

I pray thee, good reader, heed my words of warning,
And choose a clinic with staff more worth discerning.
For though we thought Dr. Patel, a worthy choice,
His team's poor conduct, did leave us with no voice."

"Verily, this eatery was woefully lacking in its attendance upon us. I declare, ne'er have I sat in a bustling tavern at noontide, perused the bill of fare, selected a dish, fed my infant daughter, tidied up, and departed without once being approached by a servant to take our order. 'Twas a most vexing experience, indeed!"

"Fie upon this wretched tavern! Foul the victuals, slow the service, and the servers, full of haughty scorn. Waste not thy time nor gold upon this den of woe. Two dishes didst I order, both of which didst offend mine taste and nose with rank, stale grease. A soda water didst they call a Coke, and when I didst speak of its strange flavor, the waitress didst reply, 'I know, we be busy.' Busy? How about a draught of fresh water and a word of apology? Alas, it seems they here do serve but slop."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, listen well,
For I have news of woe and disappointment to tell.
Amazonlocal, that wily website of deals so bright,
Didst offer coupons for President's Pizza, a place of delight.
But lo, upon my visit, I didst find,
That they wouldst not accept the coupon, nor didst they design.
Their policy, it seems, doth not incline
To honor such deals, and thus, I didst decline.
A refund, I didst receive, by luck or fate,
But warn thee, friends, do not partake
Of their false advertising, for it doth seem,
Their salads, they do not have, nor can they redeem.
So, heed my words, and save thyself the woe,
And seek thy pizza elsewhere, for this place doth not show."

"A word of caution, good sir, from yonder waiter came,
'Tis a hot plate, beware, lest ye burn thy hand.
Indeed, the victuals were not, alas, so warm,
And what of chips and salsa? A sorry form.
Not worth the journey, in sooth, I say,
For Mexican fare, sans freebies, doth stray."

"A pox upon this wretched shop, a blight upon its wares!
'Tis situated in a foul and grimy part of town,
And throngs of people swarm within its doors,
A veritable den of tedium and ennui.
Even my daughter, sweet and fair, didst yawn,
For naught of interest couldst be found within.
Their shelves do groan with tawdry trinkets and knick-knacks,
A few hues of M&M's, that's all they do proffer.
No rare or unique flavors doth this place possess,
Nay, 'tis a pitiful excuse for a store, a mere farce.
Best to avoid it, and instead, make haste
To yonder Coca-cola shop, where joys do abound."

"Thou hast denied us service, good sir,
When naught but death did reign within thy walls.
And thus, with haste, we did depart for Roka Akor,
Whose fare didst seem of finer quality, by far.

Oh, woe betide thee, Yelp, that didst guide us wrong,
For thou didst boast the highest rating, all too long.
Alas, poor service doth mar thy lofty fame,
And naught but woe doth befall thy wretched name.

Farewell, thou pitiful host, may fortune smile,
Upon thy foes, and may their triumphs be worthwhile."

"Alas, poor Peter Piper, thy customer service doth leave much to be desired. Our victuals didst take an eternity to arrive, and lo, but half the order was prepared. The wait was long, and our buzzer didst sound, yet no adequate explanation or apology was forthcoming. The staff doth not exceed nor meet the standards expected. Alas, naught but games for children, and these too, didst malfunction. Some tokens were jammed, rendering them inoperable, while others didst not function aright. A most unfortunate family outing, never to be repeated."

"O, woeful day! O, wretched service, too!
No one would speak, though I didst sit and wait,
My feet within the water, patiently,
For an hour's space, or more, I didst abide.
No word of comfort, nor of time, didst come,
To ease my mind, or end my misery.
At last, a lady came, to tend my sister's feet,
But half an hour passed, ere she didst begin.
And still, no word, of how long I must wait,
Didst reach mine ear, to ease my growing wrath.

And when, at last, my turn didst come,
They worked so slowly, as if in a dream.
No care, nor haste, didst they show,
Though we didst say, we were in a hurry, too.
No apology, didst they offer, nor didst try
To make amends, or see us satisfied.

Alas, I say, avoid this place,
Unless thou hast three to four hours to waste.
For in that time, thy manicure or pedicure,
Mayhap, shall be complete, but with much vexation,
And naught but woe, shall be thy portion,
In this, the salon of slow desolation."

"O, woe betide the hours that doth deceive,
On website and Yelp, a shorter reprieve.
Pizza, once hot, now doth taste of naught,
And crust, as hard as stone, doth leave me drained.
I shall not return, forsooth, to this place,
Where authentic Italian fare doth find no grace.
Alas, poor souls who think this dish divine,
Are sorely misled, in truth, I do design."

"Methinks 'twas naught but woe that did betide me,
In this eatery of which I do speak.
Their special dish, Deezee, didst I order,
And sickness did it bring upon me, alack!
A pleasant atmosphere, perchance, didst they have,
But, alas! The victuals were most foul and vile.
I say, good sirs, avoid this place, an it please thee,
Lest thou desirest to suffer similar woe."

This gambling den doth suck, my friend,
Don't waste thy time nor spend a penny.
Their customer service, a woeful sight,
In table games and buffet, a bitter plight.

One of the worst, I do declare,
Avoid this place, thou shouldst beware.
For better luck and cheer, seek elsewhere,
And leave this pit of woe, I pray thee, dear.

"Pray, good sir, what woeful fate doth bring thee here?
A tale of woe, of hunger pangs so dire,
Of pizza sought, but naught but pain doth bear.

Twenty minutes passed, yet still no feast doth come,
The website, flawed, doth mock thy every move,
And when thou dost call, the manager doth shun
Thy plea for aid, with naught but disregard shown.

Thy children, three in number, loud they do cry,
For pizza, hot and fresh, their bellies doth crave,
Yet naught but silence doth thy plight assuage.

Alas, poor soul, how great thy trials be!
In this, the age of speed and convenience,
How strange that pizza, fast food's royalty,
Should prove so difficult to obtain, with naught but vexation.

But fear not, for there be other choices near,
Where thou mayst find sustenance, and cheer,
And though thy night be dark, and full of woe,
Hope doth remain, that tomorrow, all shall glow."

In fair RC Willey's halls, I sought a bed,
A lowly mattress, my heart didst crave.
One salesman didst approach, and with a nod,
Didst ask if he couldst assist me in my quest.
I replied, "Aye, good sir, a humble bed,
For holiday guests, my purse doth not allow much."
He pointed, and didst leave me to my fate.
I waited, lonely, fifteen minutes passed,
But none came forth to ease my anxious plight.
I departed, vexed, with naught but woe.
Alas, poor service, at RC Willey's throne!

"Hath this establishment altered ownership? Workers, their speech doth falter, incomprehensible to mine ear. Fare, once of high quality, now doth pale in comparison. Steak hoagie, two bites suffice, nay, more I could not stomach. Doth this cuisine hail from Italy or the East? Alas, 'tis a mystery, for naught but confusion doth reign. Manager, in ire, doth curse his minions, a scene most vexing. Fond memories, now but a distant dream, for none possesseth a clue."

"In we strode, with feet that sorely ached,
Asking for a massage of half an hour's length.
But alas, our words fell on deaf ears,
For none of the three we spoke to did comprehend our plea.

"Is there a wait?" we asked, and they replied,
"Ok," with naught but confusion in their eyes.
We waited patiently, yet still they failed
To grasp our simple request, and thus we wailed.

"How long must we wait?" we asked once more,
And they, with tardy tongues, did answer, "Fifteen minutes, or so."
But lo, the wait did stretch beyond the time,
And we, in frustration, did decide to flee the place.

"Tis strange, for never have we seen,
A business run with such ineptitude, and lack of sheen.
We've visited other reflexologists before,
And they, with skill and care, did ease our feet's great bore."

"A fortnight's travail, full of woe and vexation,
Ended in naught but fruitless consternation.
I penned a missive to Tim Cook, the CEO,
In hope of solace, or some recompense to show.

A man named Jason, courteous and polite,
Did respond, yet could not bring himself to right
The wrongs I suffered, nor offer due restitution.
In truth, he seemed more bent on convincing me
That all was well, and Apple's work most excellent.

Alas, their efforts left much to be desired,
And I, in candor, did inform them of their failure.
Forsooth, their profits are their utmost concern,
A fact that Jason, in his words, did seek to disclaim.
But can it be that Apple, with its ample means,
Doth not aim to maximize its gains? Methinks 'tis but a ruse.

Farewell, dear Apple, with thy prices so steep,
I shall be wary of thy wares, and watch thee sleep."

"Alack, this shop doth bear the signs of woe,
As if some great calamity had struck,
The walls, they do resemble a bomb shelter,
And I, a wretch, didst fear the worst,
That zombies wouldst burst forth from the shadows,
And claim my life, with nary a pause.

But, alas, I didst not tarry long,
For fear didst grip my heart, like a vice,
I pray, when construction doth cease,
And all is well, I shall return,
And tread with care, lest I stir up strife."

"Fie upon this wretched meal, so vile and base!
The chef, he left all choice to his own whim,
A bleach-flavored cucumber amuse bouche, how strange!
And black bean soup, so gritty and hard, did not please.
Foie gras sorbet, oh, how it did assault mine taste,
Even more than durian, a fruit most vile and hateful.
Entrée, a plate of fried sweetbreads, oh, what a fright!
I complained, and they replaced it with escargot, filled with sand.
Dessert, a bland crème brûlée, the only edible treat.

Terrible service, by a rude waiter, who didst abandon
Our table, leaving us to suffer, without a replacement.
Alas, my friends, this restaurant, a Phoenix's nest,
Hath led me to cancel reservations at other top-rated establishments,
For fear of suffering through another such woeful feast."

"Alas, my friends, I must recount a tale of woe,
Of dealings with a service department, most foul and slow.
A Cadillac, a symbol of luxury and grace,
Yet, alack, the service thereof, left much to the place.

I visited the shop, with hopes of an oil change,
And found, to my dismay, a switch most strange.
From Kachina to Desert Cadillac, they had changed their name,
But still, their practices, left much to be desired, the same.

I saw a coupon, online, for $39.99,
A price, I thought, quite steep, yet still, I made the time.
But lo, when I arrived, they said, with nary a blush,
The cost, my friend, would be a hundred dollars, plus.

Oh, how my heart did sink, at such a turn,
To think, my Cadillac, would not be serviced, but spurned.
I urge thee, friends, if thou dost need a fix,
Go elsewhere, lest thou suffer similar mix."

"Methinks 'twas folly to entrust my locks to this salon,
For all the rave reviews that did abound.
A trim, a color, and a pretty penny paid,
But alas, my expectations were not quite met.

The cut, a mediocre effort, swift and unrefined,
As if the stylist had a schedule to keep.
And though the hue upon my tresses doth shine,
'Tis marred by streaks upon my visage, most unseemly.

Felice, the proprietor, didst strive to make amends,
But her ministrations didst leave much to be desired.
A two-star rating, generous, I do confess,
For ease of location and a pleasant demeanor.

Yet now, a single star, for in my ear,
A veritable rainbow of dye didst appear.
Methinks 'twere better had I done the task myself,
For this fiasco hath left me in a sour mood, indeed."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold, my friends,
Of reservations made, yet naught but sorrow found.
A table, promised, didst not await,
And ten minutes passed, with naught to show.
Seated at last, a half hour slipped away,
Yet still no servant came, though called upon.
In discontent, we rose and didst depart,
For dirty looks, and service cold and dark.
Alas, a night most vexing and unkind,
With naught but frustration to find."

"Methinks 'twas a foul fate that didst befall me,
Upon mine arrival at yon eatery so late.
Their kitchen, closed? How strange doth seem the tale!
Most establishments, their service doth await
The appointed hour of closure, ne'er to flee.
But nay, not thus the case with Chinese fare,
It doth appear. And so, with naught to spare,
I didst depart, my custom lost forevermore.
Alack, poor management, thy fault doth lie
In failing to prepare for those who roam,
And seek repast ere closing time doth draw near.
Yet, shall I learn from this experience,
And call ahead, lest similar woe doth come to pass."

"A year past, we didst order from this place,
When first they didst open their doors with haste.
The pizza, decent it was, but lacked finesse,
Like some frozen meal, thrown in the oven with ease.
And, alas, the mushrooms, canned they were,
A sin most grievous, and hard to bear.
So, nevermore shall we set foot in this place,
For our dearest topping, from a can, doth come with disgrace."

"O woe is me, good sirs, for I have found
The laundry service here to be most lacking.
They didst claim to be the best in town,
But alas, their words didst prove to be naught but lies.

I didst take my husband's shirts to them,
And waited patiently for their return.
But lo, the next day came and went,
And still his garments were not ready.

They didst promise to deliver them to our inn,
But alas, that too didst fail to come to pass.
And when we didst go to fetch them,
His shirts were nowhere to be found, alack!

I vow, my friends, to nevermore
Use these scoundrels for my laundry needs.
For they have proven themselves untrustworthy,
And their claims of'same day service' to be but empty words."

"Fie upon this place, where food doth cost an arm and leg!
And of what quality? E'er middling, at the best.
A pox upon their burgers, which do pale in comparison
To those of Holstein's, where flavor doth abound.

I say, avoid this den, where prices do ascend
And value doth descend. Forsooth, 'tis not worth the end.
Even should they proffer thee a dish of fried mac balls,
'Tis but a paltry gift, and not worth thy while.

Nay, seek thou out a better meal, with coin to spare,
And leave this pitiful place to its own despair."

"Alack, I prayed for liquor sans the frozen crystals, yet they proffered me a chalice brimming with ice. I made my request anew, and didst remind the lass that naught but water's chill should fill my cup. And lo, she brought me forth a draught of ice, as if to mock my plea. I spoke my mind, and bade her heed my words, but still she came with ice, as if to taunt me. Aye, even the manager didst join the fray, and asked what it was that I didst seek. I told him plain, a drink with naught but liquid, yet still he brought me ice. And not just ice, but in a vessel of ill-suited size, a medium, though I didst ask for large. Methinks this place doth lack the care for service to their patrons, and thus, I shall not tarry here."

"Aye, they be swift, but their prices be steep,
And their customer service, a mere sham, a trick.
They didst pull the wool o'er mine eyes,
With their false promises, and their lies.
I shall not return, nor would I recommend,
For elsewhere, better deals may be found, my friend."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This place, a failure, doth profess.
The food, a disappointment, doth bring,
Except for mac and cheese, a worthy thing.
But Ceasar's, a better choice, doth make,
For those who seek a feast to partake."

"Methinks 'tis harsh to speak ill of a place where service was good, yet the victuals didst leave much to be desired. Aye, the menu was a tome of forty pages or more, a feat which doth beggar belief! How couldst a kitchen hope to prepare such a vast array of dishes with any semblance of quality? Alas, the Pad Thai, a dish most dear to mine heart, didst fall far short of expectations. Verily, 'twas naught but noodles drenched in tomato paste, a sorry excuse for a meal most foul. And yet, some dishes didst pass muster, such as the spring rolls and soup, a morsel of solace in an otherwise woeful repast."

"Methinks 'twas a sorry sight, that menu of theirs,
So limited, save for burgers, alack!
And yet, the name doth speak its purpose,
Meatheads, they call themselves, in sooth.

The place, too, didst strike me as quite sterile,
With loudness, that didst echo through the aisle,
And surfaces, so hard, that didst reflect each sound,
As if in competition, with the din above.

But, oh! The burger, that dish so vaunted,
Didst fail, in truth, to stir my appetite,
A selection grand, of toppings, 'tis true,
Yet, on a patty, tasteless, and quite ordinary, too.

The bun, alas! Didst disappoint, as well,
Like Wonderbread, it was, in texture, and in taste,
So, with my girl, we didst share two burgers,
No fries, nor drinks, and still, the cost, didst mount,
To twelve dollars, and with them, twenty,
A sum, that for a meal, so plain, doth seem quite steep.

In truth, I'd say, that Meatheads' burgers,
Are naught but mediocre, and o'erpriced, to boot,
And he, who doth recommend them, with such zeal,
Hath questionable taste, in my humble opinion, at least."

"Hark, I vow, 'tis done, this place doth trouble me no more. Last eve, we did arrange with friends to dine at six and forty-five, yet lo, upon our arrival, the window did bear a sign, "CLOSED", a woeful sight indeed. This strange and whimsical schedule, a plague upon their door, hath caused us much vexation. They do keep hours most odd, and thus, have lost four loyal patrons.

Monday and Tuesday, they do rest, and Wednesday, open but for a few short hours. Thursday, they do extend their time, yet still, 'tis not enough. I shall not waste my breath, nor trouble thee with further tale of woe. This place doth frustrate and anger me, and so, I bid it adieu.

There be many a fine eatery nearby, and so, I shall not fret, for I shall find another place to sate my hunger. Farewell, thou troublesome tavern, may thy name be forgotten, and thy doors remain shut forevermore."

"Methinks, good sir, thou art Vietnamese, yet thy pedicurist, LYNN by name, doth fail to recognize this truth. She doth implore her colleagues in Vietnamese to upsell thee to a gel mani-pedi, and then, in her haste to depart, doth offer a bribe that someone might finish thy manicure while she attendeth to thy toes. 'Tis a most unprofessional establishment, where top coats are applied but halfway down the nail, and pedicures are left half done. Thy toes, which thou didst request be tended, are neglected altogether. Verily, 'tis one thing to speak thy language, but quite another to shirk thy duties thus."

"A group of eight, all finely dressed, didst venture to this place,
For my friend's bachelorette party, a night of joy and grace.
But alas, the bouncer, with a stern and solemn face,
Didst deny us entry, with a reason most base.

He said, 'You see, fair ladies, I cannot let you in,
For ye are women, and this place doth not admit such sin.'
I asked, 'What if we stand with men, and enter with them too?'
But still he shook his head, and said, 'Nay, that will not do.'

Oh, what a disappointment! A place that doth discriminate,
Against the fairer sex, with rules so arbitrary and great.
I shall not recommend this place, nor ever come again,
For it doth not deserve our custom, nor our friendship's gain."

"A pox upon this place, I pray thee! Weeknights, perchance, they doth bring mirth and glee, but on the weekends, woe betide thee! Birthdays, especially, doth seem a wretched fate, forsooth. Two hours, mayhap more, shalt thou wait in vain, despite their promises of but an hour or so. Next on the list, they doth proclaim thee, yet still they doth seat others before thee, in sooth. A plague upon their lies and woeful ways, that doth besmirch thy friend's noble celebration!"

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, when first I chanced upon this sportive tavern, with outdoor space most fair. My comrades, they did beat me thither, and already had they quaffed their draughts, ere I did arrive. A laggard server, she did tarry, some thirty minutes passed, ere she did deign to take my order. And thus, we did command our victuals straightway, lest she ne'er return. Our neighbors, too, didst order, scarce a minute later. We did await, with eager anticipation, jalapeno poppers most savory. But lo! The adjacent table didst receive their poppers, and some fifteen minutes later, a stranger, not our waitress, didst inform us that they were sold out, and left them on the bill, besides. The fare, middling, at best; the service, woeful, verily. We didst have to rise and seek our waitress, to rectify the reckoning. I might have risen, and departed, unnoticed, but that I shall not do. Forsooth, 'twas not a bustling night, to warrant such poor service. I shall not return, anon, to this establishment."

"In hope of savoring fair Italian fare,  
My spouse and I didst enter this eating place,  
A pizza, perchance, we didst wish to share.  
We stood beside the sign that didst declare,  
'Wait, good sirs, ere ye be seated with grace.'  
And so we waited, patient as could be,  
While servants passed, their faces void of glee.  
At last, a maiden asked, 'Wouldst thou be seated?'  
Oh, wondrous query! We didst reply, 'Aye, kind miss.'  
To which she led us, leaving menus on the table,  
And swiftly fled, her duty now fulfilled, alas.  
I do confess, my dear, I didst expect more,  
From Rosati's, famed for its culinary lore.  
But nay, we shall not return, forsooth,  
For elsewhere we shall find a better feast, anon."

"A pleasant sojourn we had at the resort, fair priced and quite enjoyable, I must confess. Our time at the poolside was most delightful, and the morning meal did satisfy. But lo, on the night of Friday, calamity did strike! The sprinkler system in our unit's dining space did activate, and had I not been a light sleeper, the consequences might have been dire indeed. I did rouse myself and summon aid, and fortunately, the response was swift and sufficient. Yet, I did spend a portion of the night in cleansing our belongings, the furniture, and the floor of the invading waters. A reasonable request, I deemed, for some compensation for our troubles. And so, upon our departure the next morn, I did confer with the manager at the front desk, who vowed to investigate the matter and consider our claim. Alas, many weeks have passed, and despite numerous attempts to reach him, my calls remain unreturned."

"Alas, my friends, I fear I shall not return to this place,
For though the victuals were of fair quality,
The service, by the stars, was a disgrace.
Alack, the men who served us were in haze,
As if they had partaken of sweet Mary Jane,
And thus, their minds were clouded, and their ways were slow.
Our order of wine and hot tapas didst take an age,
And when it came, alas, 'twas but a meager portion.
Their wine, it seemed, had vanished into thin air,
And left us parched and disappointed, I do declare.
The server, a merry fellow, didst ask if we would dine,
But his pace, it was as slow as a snail in winter's chime.
The tavern, half full, didst seem to bustle with activity,
Yet the service, it didst drag, like a tired donkey's gait.
I pray, dear friends, that thou shalt find a better place,
Where service and fare are both of fair grace."

"This vast and dingy place, our honeymoon's abode,
We sought an upgrade, with silver in hand, to make it sweet.
A discount they gave, a suite, oh joy! But lo,
The bed, old and worn, the TV, with swivel slow.
The room, with smoke, did reek and we did call,
To complain, and yet, we suffered through it all.

The eateries, nearby, were woeful, a sight,
And the hotel's hassle, made our stay, a plight.
The lion exhibit, cool, but the gift shop's crew,
With attitude, didst make our visit, unpleasant, too.

We left, and sought, elsewhere, to dine and play,
For this hotel, not worth the cost, we did say.
Charged wrong, we waited, for the refund,
And then, a survey, they sent, to make amends.
A free stay, they offered, but nay, we say,
For MGM Grand, in CT, we'll try, next day.

More modern, nicer, shall be our next abode,
And thus, this place, we shall not revisit, no more."

"Hark! Read reviews, fair traveler, ere thou choose to stay,
In this complex, once fair, now fallen from grace.
Corporate management, heed my words, I pray,
And change the staff, enforce policies, lest all be lost.
A pretty location, 'tis true, yet poorly handled,
It pains me to see such potential go to waste.
Once great, now not worth the high rent, crime, and noise,
Alas, a fall from grace, a tale of woe and wretchedness."

"Begone! This wretched place doth bring me woe.
Their service, foul and most unjust.
Yet, alas, 'tis here our warranty doth lie,
And so, we must, with heavy heart, comply.
But mark my words, dear friend, anon,
We shall depart, and ne'er return again.
For those who still would do business here,
Take heed, fair warning, lest thou shed a tear."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from yonder kitchen,
Where wings, once proud, now lie in disarray.
Their size, akin to that of puny pigeon's pinion,
Leaves much to be desired, I do declare.

And sauces, oh how they did disappoint,
Tasting like naught but watery gruel, devoid of zest.
We struggled hard to tell one from another,
In vain, alas, for all were bland and tasteless.

The price, a modest sum, yet still too steep,
For wings of such poor quality, I do protest.
Those who gave this place a glowing review,
Must ne'er have savored true wings, I do infer.

But wait, there is a silver lining to this cloud,
A side of slaw, most fair and delectable, did please.
Perhaps a name change, to 'Slaw-house' would befit,
For that alone, doth make this place almost tolerable."

"O, woe is me! Alack, I do declare,
This Cox, they doth beset me with their snare.
Their minion, an employee of ill repute,
Doth seek to vex and harry me, poor soul,
With threats and taunts, to change my view,
But nay, my stance doth stand, unshaken, true.

Their corporate might doth sanction this,
Their lackeys, loose, to plague and tease.
Keep close watch, lest they doth devise
A scheme to silence thee, poor wight,
For in their eyes, thy voice doth seeme
A threat, a danger, to their dark designs."

"Hie thee hence, good sir! My wife and I didst invite some friends to dine at this establishment. At first, the service didst seem most excellent, but alas, it didst prove to be naught but a sham. The Mustard Barbecue Beef Ribs were burnt to a crisp, and when we didst call the waiter back, he didst recognize the error ere we didst speak a word. He didst take the dish back, and we didst await the bill in silence. But lo! The check didst arrive unbidden, and with nary a sweet treat to follow. Our water glasses and napkins didst disappear like magic, and when I didst ask, in jest, if 'twas time for us to depart, the waiter didst reply, in a voice barely audible, "Aye, an' 'tis no wonder, for thou art most unwelcome here." My wife and I didst feel most shamefaced, and shall not darken this door again."

Alas, how times have changed! Forsooth, I came hither daily,
To partake of midday meal, with zeal and devotion.
But lo, of late, new masters hold the reins,
And all, alack, doth suffer transformation.

The recipes, they change, and all, alas,
Doth falter, woe is me, in this wretched pass.
I tried, in faith, their novel fare,
But nay, 'twas not the same, my heart doth bear.

The victuals, once a joy, now bringeth sorrow,
And service, erst so bright, doth now borrow
A sorry state, with naught but woe to show.
Alas, this place, once dear, doth now decline,
And in my heart, a heavy grief doth dwell.

"A plague upon the billing department of Bronstein Hand Center,
Whose incompetence doth rival the gods in their anger.
A tale of woe, of bills unpaid and accounts in arrears,
Of patients bilked and funds mislaid, in sorrow and in tears.

The doctor, Dr. Bronstein, and his PTs, so skilled,
Did tend to me with care and gentle touch, so well.
But alas, the billing, oh how it did go awry,
A balance false, a statement dire, a collection agency nigh.

I called, I left a message, seeking clarity,
But they, in haste, did turn it o'er to a collector, oh so dreary.
A roughly $30 bill, now sent to collections, oh dear,
And the billing office, they did refuse, backup to provide, so queer.

The collection agency, they threatened, to report,
To the credit bureaus, a claim, without a shred of proof, so distraught.
And thus, I paid, to end the strife,
But warn thee, reader, of Bronstein Hand Center's life.

First-rate care, indeed, doth Dr. Bronstein provide,
But billing woes, they do his reputation deride.
So heed my words, and take a different route,
Lest thou, like me, doth suffer from their billing blight, so mute."

Hark! What woeful customer service have I received!
The associate, a dolt, with nary a clue,
Couldst not grasp simple concepts, I did perceive.
I asked for address and contact information too,
For service center, where my rented car might gleam,
But he, with vacant stare and empty mind, did say,
"Somewhere down this road, you'll find it, pray."
A scowl, a frown, a face of discontent,
Was all I could muster, at his witless bent.
And thus, I vow, to nevermore return,
Nor trouble thee, dear friend, with fruitless concern.

"Hark! I shall revise my rating when they do rectify
The woeful plight of bees that doth infest this place.
We could not savor joy, for fear of being stung,
At train station, ride, playground, and trash bins' embrace.
A pox upon this park, with beauty doth it boast,
Yet bees doth mar its charm, and make it most unpleasant.
A shame indeed, for playground doth excel in AZ."

"O, woeful lodging in fair Las Vegas!
Thy rates, a jest, a sham, a mockery,
The front desk, a den of argumentative fiends,
A place where tempers flare and reason ends.
I vow, my friends, ne'er to return again,
For in this city of abundant inns,
I shall seek out a hostelry more just,
Where guests are treated with respect and trust.
Alas, poor service doth tarnish thy name,
And drives away those who wouldst claim
Thy hospitality, and leave thee in shame."

"Tarried I did, for fifteen minutes or more, ere mine order was taken by yon fair maiden. Verily, she was pleasant of demeanor, yet alack, she could not single-handedly attend to all who sought her aid. Pray, fetch her some succor, lest this company suffer loss, as did I, who crossed the way to Jamba Juice, where service of a higher quality did await."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall me here,
Upon my birthday weekend, full of cheer.
Yelp, thou hast deceived me, ne'er to trust,
In this, thy review, a tale of woe and dust.

I ordered steak and frites, a dish most fine,
But lo, the frites were oversalted, a sin.
The steak, a thin slice, with sweetness o'erlaid,
Didst leave me unsatisfied, nay, dismayed.

My friends, they too, didst suffer such fate,
Their dishes, a disappointment, a bitter debate.
The broccoli crepe, a mess, a gross delight,
The tuna melt, with olives, a flavor not quite right.
The quiche, unremarkable, a dish without flair,
Leaving me to ponder, why come hither?

The service, slow, our server, a laggard,
Didst rarely check upon us, a poor cad.
This restaurant, overhyped, a shame, a blight,
Avoid it, dear friends, ere ye take flight.

Alas, my birthday brunch, a total fail,
A memory, a sorrow, a tale to tell and bewail."

"Fare thee well, dear gastronome! Forsooth, this establishment doth serve but wretched victuals. Verily, the chips they proffer are stale and lacking in flavor. And, alack! The shrimp taco, once a dish of promise, doth now lie flat and uninviting. Yet, fear not, for there is solace in the fries, which are, indeed, quite good. But, gentle patron, heed my warning: if thou dost seek a meal most satisfying, avoid this place, for 'tis naught but a tavern, replete with televisions and a bar, where sporting events doth reign supreme."

"Hark! A Groupon deal didst catch mine eye,  
And so I ventured forth to try,  
A Japanese feast, with rolls galore,  
But alas! The service didst leave much to explore.  

A sign didst greet me, plain to see,  
That Groupon deals were not for thee,  
On happy hour rolls or specialty dishes,  
But still I ordered, with high hopes and wishes.  

Three rolls didst I request, with eager cheer,  
But only one didst arrive, oh dear!  
The female manager didst come to my aid,  
With apologies for the long delay, she didst say.  

The sushi chefs, they didst seem to slack,  
Drinking sake bombs, with nary a care or tack,  
Their rolling skills, didst leave much to be desired,  
As I waited, with a growling belly, and tired.  

The food that came, was but a mere morsel,  
A small portion, with little to devour,  
The staff didst need to improve their ways,  
To keep the customers happy, night and days.  

And so, I left, with a heavy heart,  
For though the food was passable, the service didst depart.  
A Korean-owned Japanese restaurant, indeed,  
But the experience, didst leave much to be desired, I heed."

"A frozen world, where all is made of ice,
Even the glasses that the guests entice.
But, alas, the entrance fee doth seem
Unnecessary, and the drinks, a bit too dear.

The patrons, stripped of their phones and cameras,
Must pay for photos, or leave with naught but memories.
A small bar, empty, devoid of cheer,
As if all others had the sense to flee.

Minus 5, a place of wonder, yet,
With prices steep, and rules most strict."

"Hark! Dearest D'acks Organization,

A grievance most dire doth trouble me,
Concerning Chase Field's fan experience, ye see.
My kin and I, in section 206 did sit,
With naught but cold victuals to assuage our grit.

The first inning came and went, no server in sight,
And so we ventured forth to find sustenance in the night.
A quarter hour we waited, then our order did place,
But lo! A third of it, alas! They had not in their grace.

The second inning passed, our food arrived with delay,
And thus our hunger sated, but dismay did stay.
For condiments, they had none, in club level, alack!
Our meal grew cold, our moods did sour, 'twas a foul trick.

Last weekend, fan appreciation was the cry,
But now, my heart doth ache, and bitter doth my soul lie.
We love our Diamondbacks, but this treatment, trow?
Count us, dear sirs, out, for such fan experience doth show."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Pearl Sushi,
Where we didst venture forth to try their happy hour,
And sampled dishes of the small plate variety.
My friend and I, on a previous visit, didst partake
In simple fare, but now, with greater zeal,
Didst opt for dishes more complex and grand.
A California roll and Korean pork tacos,
Were our initial choices, and though the latter
Was somewhat greasy, 'twas not unexpected.

But alack! Our second visit didst prove most vexing,
For the shrimp tempura roll, all rubbery and bland,
Didst leave much to be desired, and the chicken yakisoba,
With overcooked noodles, foul-tasting bird,
And sauce that dripped from a jar, most gloppy,
Didst prompt us to summon the server with haste.
He, with a shrug, didst say 'tis how they make it,
And when we didst speak to the manager, his reply
Didst reek of disdain, as if we should be honored
To dine at Pearl Sushi, and their presence in Chandler
Was a favor unto us. Fie upon such arrogance!
We shall not return to this ill-fated place."

"O, woeful day! O, wretched fate!
A place of business, with service so elate,
That 'tis a wonder, how they doth stay in trade,
With food, that doth resemble naught but scraps,
And prices, that doth rival the heavens above,
In their audacity, they doth ask,
Four silver pieces, for a meager taco,
Without a side, to fill the belly's void,
'Tis madness, pure and simple, I do declare,
This establishment, shall surely fail,
And soon, their doors, shall shut forevermore."

"Hark! This place doth blow, my friends, in sooth.
A hundred and eleven coins for a well-mojito?
By Jove, 'tis a price most wondrous and steep!
And mark thee well, no prices doth it keep.
A kiddies' pizza, ten coins doth it cost?
Why, 'tis a frozen pie, a wholesale boast!
A bottom line, most dire and grim, doth say,
Eighty coins, or more, doth fleece thy pay.
The Bellagio, a night hence, doth show
A better feast, with sushi, crab, and beef,
And all the rest, a veritable relief.
So, friends, avoid this Rain Forest place,
For Vegas holds more wondrous grace."

"Hark, what discourtesy doth these employees show!
Their mood doth soured be, as if they didst know
That they didst work in such a place of woe.
They doth not call thy name, when thy drink doth flow.

Aye, I didst try to use my coupon, fair,
For my free birthday drink, but she didst stare
With scorn and said, 'We be not a true Starbucks,
So these coupons, we do not accept, alack.'

Fie upon this fake Starbucks, I say,
And may thy business, elsewhere, sway.
For in this place, there doth abide no cheer,
But only rude words, and scowls, I fear."

Alas, fair friends, I must confess,
This place, once dear to me, doth now oppress.
Forsooth, two years past, I didst visit here,
And found it to be one of my most cherished cheer.
But lo, upon my recent return, I didst espy,
A creature most vile, a cockroach, nigh.
Upon the wall, it didst crawl and climb,
Without a care, as if it were in its prime.
No matter, thought I, for it doth not infect,
My meal, which doth lie safe, and uninfected.
But then, a week passed, and I didst order take,
And as I finished my rice, a sight didst make,
A antenna, large and quite unsightly,
Didst emerge from a most unwelcome guest, a cockroach, alack!
I cannot say, dear friends, how much I do detest,
The very thought of rice, since that fateful quest.
But fear not, for I do implore,
The owners here, to take heed, and restore,
This place, to its former glory, and renown,
For 'tis a shame, to see it thus, brought down.

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, avoid this place at all costs. Forsooth, their AYCE sign doth beckon with false promises of savory delights, but fear not, for I shall warn thee of the horrors within. Their sushi, once fresh, now doth resemble the rotting flesh of a week-old corpse. And, alas, we didst sit near the kitchen, whereupon we didst hear the tale of their sushi, left to sit out all day, awaiting the unsuspecting AYCE customer. Nay, good sir, spend not thy coin nor risk thy stomach's ire at this wretched establishment."

"Alas, my dear companion, what woeful fate did befall us at Joe's? Our hunger, great and dire, did drive us thither, yet our patience didst soon depart. Forsooth, a line didst form, and we didst stand, awaiting our turn with naught but hope to guide us. But lo, the minutes didst tick by, slow and heavy, like a clock in winter's grasp. And still, the line didst creep forward, a snail's pace, leaving us to ponder if 'twere worth the wait. Alas, two other couples didst flee, their patience worn thin, ere we didst make our exit. Not a word, nor gesture, didst come from those who served, to ease the burden of our plight. Ah, Joe's, thy Italian ice, a sweet delight, didst tempt me sore, yet ne'er shall I taste it, for my time was not mine own that day. Farewell, Joe's, mayhap another day shall bring me to thy door, but not, methinks, too soon."

Friday eve, my spouse and I did celebrate
My birth, with plans to lodge at inn so great
But when we arrived, oh woeful sight
No parking space, nigh impossible to alight

The check-in staff, their service slow and poor
We waited, tired, our patience wore
At last, they gave us room, with beds of two
Not kingly bed, our reservation flew

I called the desk, a hold they did place
Fully booked, they said, no room to grace
I went, my bags, to load once more
Drove back, stood in line, as before

A new room, they did assign
We walked, our bags, the distance nigh
Unloaded all, and opened door
To find a room, design of days of yore

In dismay, I dropped my bags, and went
To restaurant, but entrance, I could not invent
Back to the car, to Elephant bar I did stray
With food and drink, my spirits did play

That night, I slept, and dreamt not of
My bill, $175, and what it did proffer
Next morn, I checked out, and home did steer
To ponder, still, what value did appear

Alas, fair sir, I didst venture forth to fill my carriage with fuel and cleanse its exterior of dirt and grime. Upon inquiring about a discount for men of arms, I was informed that such a perk was only offered on the first day of the week, forsooth! Verily, 'twas a most vexing revelation, and one that didst leave me in a state of utter dismay.

"O, how the prices doth inflate, my dear!
For juices and hardware, they do steer
Away from value, and towards greed, I fear.
Their wares, unworthy of a second glance,
Didst fail to impress, or leave me in a trance.
A single star, for cleanliness and grace,
Didst they receive, and not a single place
In my heart, for their overpriced fare."

"Methinks I have oft graced this place with mine own presence,
And, by the stars, 'tis a woeful tale to tell,
For service here, alack, doth leave much to be desired,
And I, in sooth, do find it passing strange and vile.

The servers, full of ire and wrath, do storm and rage,
And with each word they speak, my patience doth they assail,
Their mood, so dark and foul, doth make me shun their aid,
And thus, I say, avoid this place, lest thou be beguiled."

"Methinks 'tis strange, my friends, that I,
In twain of thrice, whene'er I call'd,
To fetch an order, ready made,
In fifteen minutes, or so they said,
Yet ne'er didst enter their system,
Alack! and thus my patience doth wane,
For age doth creep upon me still."

"Fie upon the airport's pricing scheme,
Where draught beer doth cost seven golden coins!
A pox upon their houses, say I,
For such exorbitant prices doth make me wary.

In sooth, 'tis a damnable shame,
That travelers must pay such an outrageous claim.
For a mere pint of ale, they doth demand
A sum most excessive, and quite beyond hand.

But still, we doth pay, with naught but sighs,
For who can resist the lure of frothy pies?
So here's to thee, dear airport tavern keep,
May thy profits be great, but not too steep!"

"Verily, I have visited this establishment twice, and both experiences were woeful. The sauce doth taste strange, and the pizza itself was not of high quality. But alas, the true calamity lies in the waiting time. My most recent visit didst unfold thusly: I didst order via the phone app, and it didst declare that my pizza was ready for collection at six o'clock. I arrived promptly, only to witness mine order being handed to the patron before me. They didst then recreate my meal, causing me to tarry for twenty minutes more."

"I'd give this place no stars, an' 'twere in my power,
The victuals were most vile, a sorry sight,
The sides they served, like cream spinach, plantains, and carrots,
Were nigh inedible, a true disappointment.

We jested at the meal's poor quality,
Not one of us did think it good, I swear,
The meats were o'ercooked, and lacking in flavor,
Save for the pineapple, which was quite pleasant, I do declare.

The flank steak, when cooked just right,
Was passable, but the rest, alack,
Were truly wretched, a sorry plight.
I'll ne'er return to this restaurant, nor recommend it to any soul."

"Beware, good sirs and madams, of this establishment, lest ye wish to suffer ill treatment at the hands of its staff. Verily, I didst venture forth to this place, seeking to conduct business, and lo, didst I receive the most discourteous and passive-aggressive behavior that mine eyes hath ever witnessed.

The lady Alison, she who doth preside o'er the tile section, didst make it known that my request was beneath her notice, and in so doing, didst display a most unbecoming demeanor. And thus, I didst depart, in search of a more hospitable abode.

But lo, an installer didst call upon me, bearing tidings that Alison had sent him to my humble dwelling. And so, I didst return unto the store, to select the tile of mine choice. But alas, Alison's mood had not improved, for she didst exhibit signs of impatience and anger.

And thus, I didst procure the tile, but not before being met with a most curious remark, to wit: "Thou shouldst shop at Lowes." Pray tell, what manner of business driveth its customers away, only to entice them back, and then, with naught but scorn and disdain, doth refuse to serve them?

I didst remark unto Alison that her attitude was most unseemly, and she, with a shrug, didst reply, "I know." Fie upon this place! Its employees shouldst take a leaf from the book of those at Lowes, and learn to show respect and courtesy unto their patrons. Shame upon them, say I!"

"Fie upon this wretched mess! A pox upon the cook who doth prepare
This sorry excuse for a meal! A hot dog, they did call it,
But nay, 'twas naught but a flavorless lump, devoid of zest.
The bacon, too, did fail to impress, its taste so bland
It did but mock the senses, leaving naught but disgust.
And the bun, oh cursed bun, so sweet it did taste,
Yet with the hot dog, it did clash, a discordant blend.
I pray, good sirs, avoid this dish, lest ye wish to suffer
The same fate as I, with a mouthful of bitter distaste."

"Alas, my heart doth break to pen these words,
For once, Armstrong's was my heart's desire,
A place where I would brave hell and high water,
To savor their dishes, my taste buds' choicest fire.

But alack, my friends, my recent visit proved
A bitter disappointment, nay, a cruel joke.
The dining room, once clean and full of cheer,
Now doth resemble a dirty, foul-smelling cloak.

Our server, once attentive and full of grace,
Didst now ignore us, leaving us in disgrace.
She didst not check on us, nor didst she care,
And when we ordered, she didst not tarry there.

And when I spoke to the manager, in hope
Of some redress for our poor treatment, lo,
He didst reply with scorn and bitter gall,
"Everyone hath bad experiences, that's just all."

I know not what didst prompt his strange reply,
But this I know, I shall not darken their door again,
For though my heart didst once love Armstrong's dear,
Now doth it break, and sorrow doth remain."

"Town Square's fare doth leave much to be desired,
A price most steep for victuals so uninspired.
Refried beans, a watery mess, they do resemble
A tin of pinto beans, poured forth without a fuss or a tremble.
Chips and salsa, an extra fee doth command,
Even with a meal, a price most unreasonable, by my hand.
How they do stay open, a mystery doth abide,
The waitresses, fair maidens, with Hooters' pride.
Mexican fare, there be better places found,
In Town Square, other eateries doth astound.
Give this one a wide berth, my friends, I pray thee."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of pizza sought, yet not of old.
Double layered, premium, it was said,
But alas, the topping, not a thread.

The manager, silent as the night,
Didst not inform, nor offer light.
No apology, no warning given,
Leaving me with naught but heaven.

The pizza, poor and lacking grace,
A disappointment, a bitter taste.
This establishment, once grand and fair,
Now doth decline, without a care.

A lesson learned, a truth now known,
To seek elsewhere, my hunger's throne."

"Alas, my dearest lords, I pray thee, hear my plea,
For funds, which thou dost owe to me, doth seem to flee.
A scholarship and state board, didst thou bestow,
Yet, now, thy payment, doth tarry, and doth slow.

I graduated,'mongst two weeks past, and still,
Thy coin, doth fail, to reach mine hand, and fill.
My monthly payments, punctual, didst I make,
And now, thy tardiness, doth cause mine heart to break.

How unfair, this treatment, doth appear,
To him, who didst not rely, on financial cheer.
I pray thee, noble sirs, to heed my words,
And render, what is due, ere my patience be blurred."

"Hark, good sir! I didst procure some victuals,
Fifty pieces of silver, a princely sum, no doubt.
But lo, the fare they served, didst leave me vexed,
A paltry portion, with naught but veggies, I found.

Aye, I didst chance upon an ancient bill of fare,
And thought to partake in their culinary delight.
But alas, the dish they brought, didst leave me cold,
With scant few morsels of meat, and naught but vegetables to behold.

The rice, they didst boast of, was indeed quite fine,
But oh, the rest, a sorry sight, didst make me repine.
A ruse, a trick, a swindle, call it what thou wilt,
Forsooth, I felt most thoroughly cheated, and my purse, didst smart."

"Methinks 'twas folly to frequent this place,
For months didst I pass by, with naught but disdain,
Yet curiosity didst get the better of me,
And in I didst venture, to sample their fare.

Alas! The staff didst seem not to care,
Their service poor, and my order forgot,
Twice didst they err, and I didst despair,
Of e'er receiving my meal, fit for a king.

The chicken parm sub, a disappointment vast,
Bland and hot, with naught but plain chicken within,
No crispiness didst the breading possess,
Nay, 'twas more like rubber, than any finesse.

And to add insult to injury, 'twas microwaved,
The heat didst make the bread, like rubber, behave,
A travesty, indeed, and a sorry state,
For a sub, that didst cost me ten dollars, and no mistake.

I fear, I shall not return, nor spend again,
Such sums, for a meal, that doth not impress,
Forsooth, there be better places, to dine and eat,
Than this poor excuse, for a sandwich, so neat."

"Hark, what woe is this? A tale of woe and deceit,
Of burgers bare, of toppings none so neat.
I ordered two, with cheese and all the rest,
But lo, they came without, a sorry jest.
The receipt did say, in black and white,
Two doubles, full price, with naught but spite.
Nevermore shall I set foot in this place,
For honesty and shame, they know not the face."

"O, woeful tale of customer mistreatment!

A meeting was set, a date most fair and bright,
For quote on new AC unit, of great might.
Two calls didst confirm, with naught but delight,
Their coming, on this day, with morning light.

But lo, a call most strange, didst reach mine ear,
That they, of sudden, didst decide to fear.
And thus, didst cancel, with naught but disdain,
The visit, that didst promise such gain.

Alas, poor soul, how ill-used art thou,
By sales, who sought to sell, yet knew not how.
For if this be the case, with purchase grand,
How foul the service, that doth follow hand!"

"Fie upon this wretched tavern! 'Tis a den of woe,
Where they do serve most vile and loathsome fare,
And with such surliness, as doth make one moan.
The barkeep, rude and full of disregard,
Didst ignore my pleas, as though I were a beggar.
I sought but sustenance to take away,
Yet he, lost in converse with his friend,
Didst pay me no mind, nor heed my plight.
A pox upon this cursed place, say I!"

"Hark, good sir! For year upon year, have I shopped at this place,
And found it to be but a pitiful sight, full of woe and disgrace.
The atmosphere doth reek of despair, and the staff doth seem,
As though they were plagued by some curse, so glum and forlorn they appear.

The shelves, they doth lie bare, like a barren field in winter's grasp,
And when I do enquire, they say, 'tis due to a lack of staff, alas!
Oh, how I wish for a change, for a new market to arise,
To bring some cheer to this drear scene, and banish the sorrow that doth lie.

A Morrison's or Sainsbury's, in Musselburgh, would be a blessing,
To rid this place of its misery, and bring some joy to our souls, I do confess."

"Good sir, avoid Filiberto's at all costs, 'Tis a place that doth cater to the basest of tastes, And those who doth frequent it, their senses Are dulled by strong drink and foul smoke. The victuals they serve, a sorry sight, Like leftovers from a feast long past, On a flimsy plate, with nary a garnish in sight. Twice did I venture there, to give it fair play, But lived to tell the tale, by fortune's grace."

Nevermore, I vow, shall I set foot in yon HuHot,
For in Madison, there be no Mongolian bbq worth the name.
The meat, it doth not look fresh, nor doth the bar area gleam,
Food, it doth lie scattered 'bout, like leaves on autumn's stream.
The sauce, a disaster, doth resemble more a puddle than a dream,
And rice, it doth not boast the proper cooking, alack and alas!
Soup, a sorry excuse for hot and sour, doth make my stomach churn,
YUCK! Away, HuHot, thou art a poor excuse for a meal, I say, nevermore!

"Fie upon this wretched inn! 'Tis a den of desp'rate ills,
Where rooms be foul and staff be churlish, with nary a smile.
Their policies be deceptive, a bait-and-switch scheme,
That doth leave thee feeling cheated, and quite rightly so.

Security be lax, a mere afterthought, it seems,
As smoke from neighboring rooms doth seep through the cracks.
And when thou dost request a change, the manager doth give
A universal key, with nary a care or a thought.

Their focus be on their casino, where profits doth flow,
And guests, like thee, doth suffer, left to wander and go.
Never again shall I set foot within these walls,
For there be better options, that doth not deceive or enthrall."

"A plague upon this burrito, o'erfilled with chorizo!
I asked for light, yet still it came, a veritable mountain.
Egg, hidden beneath the spicy, savory mess,
A culinary crime, a travesty, alas!
Why claim to make it light, when naught but lies?
Forsooth, good sirs, be honest, ere ye raise my hopes.
In truth, I'd rather know, than suffer thus,
Disappointment, bitter fruit of false expectations."

"In sooth, fair friends, we chanced upon this place,
Whose reputation loudly did proclaim
A feast fit for the gods, or so we thought,
But lo, the truth did prove quite otherwise.

The breaded panko mozzarella, thick as stone,
Didst fail to melt, its flavor scarce known,
The marinara, a lone bright spot, did shine,
But alas, the rest did pale in comparison.

I, in search of succulent sliders, didst quest,
My spouse, the lasagna, didst request,
Our salad, naught but lettuce, diced tomatoes few,
The dressing, flavorful, yet lacking, didst view.

The main courses, lukewarm, didst leave us aghast,
The lasagna, reheated, didst taste of the past,
The sliders, burnt, their flavor didst obscure,
A shame, for the server, kind and pure.

In conclusion, dear friends, this place doth fail,
Its food, unimpressive, doth pale and wail,
Yet still, the server, with grace and poise, didst prevail."

"A pox upon this wretched inn, where privy's scarce be found!
A "bath area" they call it, fit for none but beasts, profane.
For couples strange and alternative, from Boston or San Fran,
Perhaps 'twill serve their purpose, but for others, 'tis a scam.

Complain ye must, and pay a fee, to gain a room with bath,
A half-mile trek from elevator, tis a weary, woeful path.
The lobby, dark and dismal, doth resemble a rap video's set,
And staff, well-trained in feigning shock, at guests' discontent.

I, with SAG card in hand, am but a novice, raw and green,
Compared to these, who doth excel in acting, mean and keen.
Go elsewhere, traveler, flee this den of woe and shame,
For here, thy privacy and comfort shall be naught but a game."

"Verily, 'twas o'erpriced for such a meager feast!  This morn, I had their ham and cheese flatbread, and by th' stars, 'twas the most wretched breakfast I e'er didst taste!  Th' ham, so foul and rancid, didst make mine stomach churn, and th' cheese, oh so excessive, didst nigh on drown th' poor bread.  Fear not, fair friends, I shall ne'er return to sample their sorry fare again!"

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from mine own lips,
Of service poor, and food that doth not please.
At Monte Carlo, I didst take up residence,
And didst partake in their buffet, with great reluctance.

The cashier, rude and uncouth, didst make me frown,
As if the very thought of serving me didst bring him down.
The victuals, bland and ill-prepared, didst fail to impress,
Leaving me to ponder if 'twere worth the cost, I must confess.

Away, dear traveler, from this place so drear,
And seek thy sustenance elsewhere, far from here.
For though they claim 'tis free, the tax doth make it dear,
And all the low marks on Yelp, do speak the truth, I fear.

Not worth the stay, the customer service doth lack,
So heed my words, and choose another place to attack."

"O, woeful day!  Alack, what sorrows doth this flight bring!
The hidden charges, they do mount, a veritable king's ransom.
And lo, the plane itself, doth reek of vomit's stench,
As if some wretch, in his cups, had lost his lunch within.
And mark thee well, good sir, thy baggage, it doth cost,
A pretty penny, 'twill leave thee in quite a bind, no doubt.
Nay, not even a cup of ale, to soothe thy parched throat,
Doth the gate staff proffer, with a scowl and a snarl, to boot.
Alas, poor soul, how wretched doth thy journey seem!
Methinks, a rating of naught but zero stars, doth befit this woeful dream."

"Hark, this day doth mark the final time
I shall order steak and eggs at yon diner.
Thrice now, the steak hath been a disappointment,
Barely fit for consumption, I do declare.
The server, Carlos, doth his best,
But alas, 'tis not enough, I must confess.
He saith he speaketh to his master,
But naught doth change, to my dismay.
Now hear me, thou who runneth the establishment,
Thy breakfast steak, a poor excuse for victuals,
Not worth the twelve coins thou dost demand.
Alas, I fear thou shalt not see me again,
Even shouldst thou rectify the problem, 'twill be in vain."

"Fie upon this wretched buffet, dear friend! 'Tis a sorry sight, indeed, For the price they charge, 'tis a paltry fare, And not worth the coin they do demand. Go, instead, to the Belagio's halls, Where food is rich, and service befalls With grace and charm, and seats are soft, Not like this place, where discomfort alights. And though I left a gratuity, in truth, They serve themselves, with nary a youth To pour their drinks, or ease their plight. If quick sustenance be thy aim, then here Thou shalt find solace, for none doth stand In line, awaiting their turn, my dear. But, by the stars, I now perceive Why 'tis so empty, and why folk doth flee."

"Methought to order a cake for my son's first year,
From a shop whose wares didst please mine eye.
Their website showed most wondrous cake designs,
So to the store I went, with haste and zeal.

Four cupcakes didst I purchase to devour,
Chocolate, vanilla, lemon, and red velvet in store.
The lady said they were the same, in essence,
