As the cakes they sold, in flavor and substance.

Alas, how wrong she was, for they were dry,
Excessively so, and quite a disappointment nigh.
I visited in the morn, yet still they lacked moisture,
Leaving me dismayed, and in sore displeasure.

Perhaps 'twas but a fluke, a freak occurrence,
Yet for cakes, such faults do not augur well, in truth.
Thus, my rating doth reflect the quality found,
For cakes and cupcakes both, a sorry tale to tell."

"In sooth, my friends, a tale of woe doth unfold,
Concerning a stove, whose burners didst grow cold.
A warranty, through Protech, didst provide a shield,
Yet dealing with them, hath been most unseemly.

Debbie, a name that doth conjure images of strife,
Hath been the source of much vexation and spite.
Rude, belligerent, and unprofessional, she doth reign,
Making appointments, and breaking them, with naught but disdain.

A dance of scheduling, didst we perform,
With cancelations, and reschedulings, galore.
I, a worker, with scant time to spare,
Didst refuse to take a day off, to suit her whim.

The tech, didst come, and view the stove with haste,
Yet parts, didst take, seven days, or ten, at the most.
Now, Debbie, doth chide, and call me impatient,
For asking, when, my stove, shall be made whole and functional.

Alas, poor service, doth leave a sour taste,
And Protech, doth suffer, from such behavior, in haste."

"Prithee, good sir, beware the pie,
For 'tis a false economy, I do declare.
Twice have I partaken of this dish,
And both times, woe betide, didst feel the brush
Of sickness, that doth make my stomach churn.

Spare thy pence, and venture not too near,
Lest thou desire to spend the next two days
In converse with thy porcelain throne, in sooth.
Heed my words, fair traveler, and avoid
The pitfalls of this culinary deceit."

"Fie upon this wretched meal, a plague upon the cook!
'Tis NASTY, I do declare, and foul as any muck.
I should have heeded warning, and not stepped foot within,
For now my taste doth suffer, and my belly doth spin.

A pox upon the place, with "wok" in its name,
For serving up such vile fare, a shame to all who came.
My stomach churns in protest, my tongue doth cleave to roof,
And I, in utter disgust, do vow to never return, nor seek alike.

Farewell, thou wretched kitchen, may thy name be cursed,
For serving up such nastiness, and leaving me so perturbed."

"Methinks the victuals and the atmosphere of yon eatery didst please mine taste, and at first, the servant who didst attend mine needs didst seem most helpful and kind. But lo, a problem didst arise, five days hence, when I didst peruse mine credit card account. Forsooth, the meal I didst charge, and a most generous cash tip of 25%, didst leave naught on the line for the tip, and the total of the feast didst appear on the total line. And thus, when the charge didst come upon mine card, verily, the sum didst increase by ten dollars. I didst straightway inform the steward of this mistake, which he didst rectify; yet, he didst aver that the fashion in which I didst write the dollar sign and zero might have caused confusion. Fie upon this! The total was clear, and with the cash tip, the server didst deem his service worth a 42% gratuity?!?! Art thou jesting?! A word of counsel, pay in cash, or keep thy receipt safe, lest such errors befall thee."

"Hark, I say, good sirs and madams, hear my tale of woe,
Of a tailor's shop, where rudeness doth abound,
A place where courtesy and manners doth not grow,
And customers are treated with disdain and scorn.

I, a maiden fair, didst bring my dress to hem,
A floor-length gown, fit for a queen, or so I thought,
But lo, the woman there, with words most uncouth,
Didst tell me it was meant for one much younger, in truth.

Her words, they cut me deep, like a sharp knife,
For they didst imply that I, a maid of honor,
Was not worthy of such finery, nor fit to wear,
Such garb, that doth reveal my charms, yet still most fair.

My friend, a lady of grace and beauty rare,
Didst also suffer at their hands, with rudeness most bare,
For when she asked them to hem her designer jeans,
They didst reply with scorn, and words most unseemly, it seems.

So here I vow, my friends, never again to go,
To that tailor's shop, where rudeness doth flow,
For though they may be skilled in their craft,
Their manners, alas, leave much to be desired, and that's a fact."

"Alas, how great our disappointment doth lie,
For Craft, a place we had heard much praise of, did fail to satisfy.
The ambiance, indeed, was quite pleasant to behold,
And wait staff, friendly and knowledgeable, did make us feel bold.
The menu, too, did boast of many a tasty dish,
With portion sizes, large, and wine list, quite a wish.

But lo, the food itself, did fall quite short,
For every dish, from bisque to risotto, did lack resort.
No salt, no pepper, nay, not even a sprinkle,
Did leave our taste buds in a state of utter dwindle.

The Caesar salad, a chore to cut and chew,
Did take much effort, and still, did not impress anew.
The filets, oh how they failed to meet our hopes,
No seasoning, and texture, like a piece of rope.

A screaming babe, throughout our meal, did pierce,
Our ears, and added to our mounting displeasure.
So, forth we went, to find sweet dessert,
elsewhere, for Craft, did earn but a poor report.

Four hundred dollars, spent on such a feast,
Did leave us feeling cheated, and quite depressed."

"O, woe is me! This hotel, a pit of wretchedness, doth lie Upon the Las Vegas Strip, a place of vice. The victuals at the buffet, a sorry sight, Do leave much to be desired, a veritable blight. The chambers, cheap they may be, yet terrible, A den of sorrow, where sleep doth flee. My sister, wise guile, did say, 'Tis naught but folly To fret o'er lodgings, for in Sin City's thrall, We doth revel all night, and ne'er heed the call Of slumber. Alas, I shall ne'er return, For this hotel, a curse, doth earn my sternest burn."

"Tis vexing, indeed, to have so many hands,
In thine face, when thou dost try to advance,
Upon the strip, where gambling dens do stand.
And lo, the cards, they do litter the ground,
In numbers vast, a thousand or more,
So that thy progress, downward bound,
Is hindered by their very presence, a bore."

This place doth stink, a foul and loathsome sight,
The chambers filthy, full of dirt and blight.
My spouse and I did stay here, unaware,
Forsooth, of the conditions most unfair.
We were enthralled, in this vile place, alas,
For several days, our sorrow to augment.
Thou shalt not wish to rest thy head,
Nor unpack thy bags, lest thou be sad.
I would not suffer my hound to slumber here,
The bed, so wretched, brought us naught but fear.
The sheets, they did reek, of carnal delight,
And cigs, in a room that claimed to be bright.
My spouse and I, we both did roll,
To the bed's center, worn, our souls to droll.
They might as well, rent out the rooms,
In brief intervals, their shame to conceal.
All of the hotel's wealth, doth go,
To the casino, and the main floor's show.
If zero stars, I could give, 'twould be,
This wretched place, a pit of misery.

"A plague upon this lodging, dark and drear!
The front desk staff, with faces wreathed in scowls,
Did glower at me, their guest, with nary a smile.
In Pittsburgh, where folk are known for cheer,
This behavior doth stand out, most vile and foul.

The wireless internet, a woeful sight,
Did falter and fail, a sorry plight.
For business travelers, a dire need, indeed,
Yet here, 'twas naught but a poorly wrought deed.

And in my chamber, lo, there were bugs,
Crawling and creeping, a most loathsome sight.
I shudder still, at the mere thought of them,
Their presence, a breach of decency and light.

Nay, I shall not return to this place,
For Marriott and Omni, they do hold
A higher standard, fair and bright,
In them, I shall find solace and delight."

"Methought my husband didst desire to dine herein for many a week, and thus, I didst wish to give this place a try. The victuals didst appear most delectable, and their scent didst stir mine appetite. Alas, the service was slow as molasses in winter's chill. 'Twas a veritable torture to await my repast, forsooth! 

Now, had I not been moved by curiosity to sample their fare, I wouldst have rated this establishment a single star, save that zero stars were not an option, ha! 

Verily, from the moment I placed mine order till the time I didst enquire about its readiness, my luncheon break was done and gone. And yet, the food was not prepared for takeout! Fie upon such sluggishness! 

Fortunately, they didst grant me a full refund, but, by my troth, twenty-five minutes for a single order? Pray, tell me, what sorcery is this? 

Mayhap, in a few months' time, we shall essay this place once more, and may the gods of culinary delight grant us a swifter experience."

"Hark! What praise doth bring me to this place?
Five stars, they say, and service swift.
But lo, the fare doth leave much to be desired,
Greasy quesadilla, tacos, loaded potato, all besmirched.
I shall not return, nor wouldst I recommend,
Forsooth, 'tis not worth thy time, good friend."

"O, woeful day! A service most foul and full of deceit.  The staff, dishonest and cunning in their words, didst try to sell me services most unnecessary.  A clay bar detailing, they didst claim, my Range Rover didst need.  A new windshield, they didst say, my old one being naught but dust and pit.  An engine flush, they didst demand, as if the very thought of it didst make my car run ill.  Four months past, the dealer didst service and inspect my vehicle, yet still the car wash man didst ask for $50 more.  By the stars, what trickery is this?  A lie, a fib, a falsehood, all of which didst cost me $50 more than needed.  O, cursed fate!  How long, oh Lord, shall I suffer thus?  A simple oil change, they didst say, an hour it would take, but lo, it took twice as long.  And as for the car wash, alas, I hadst to forgo it altogether.  And now, to top it all, a sly and cunning man didst tell me I couldst have a new windshield, free of charge.  My windshield, uncracked and unchipped, doth not require such service.  Oh, Francis & Sons, how couldst thou?  Doth thy name become a byword for deceit and chicanery?"

"Hark, what news is this? A business doth close its doors ere the appointed hour! Methinks 'twas McFarlane Toys, the very same that doth profess to crave the Coyotes' presence. Strange, indeed, for on a night when thousands pour forth from the game, they doth lock their gates, and turn away those who wouldst spend their gold. A poor decision, Todd, if thou didst seek to thrive. Forsooth, I didst remark but yesternight, how wise it were for Coyotes to begin their matches at six o'clock, to benefit the shops nearby. Alas, it seemeth that notion didst fall upon deaf ears. Farewell, McFarlane Toys, for ne'er shall I return, nor shall I speak thy praise."

"Hark, what news is this? A review of old,
From three years past, when tempers bold,
Did stir within me, and my mind did brew,
A plan to post, and share anew.

A tale of woe, and customer disgrace,
At a place where food and drink do flow,
But service, poor, and lacking grace,
Did leave me vexed, and in displace.

I called ahead, to order with ease,
Thirty minutes ere my arrival, if ye please,
But lo, they failed, and made me wait,
Forty-five minutes, and my patience did abate.

The man at counter, with a scowl so deep,
Seemed to despise his work, or all that sleep,
For he didst not care, nor lift a hand,
To greet the folk, or take their command.

All stood and waited, in a long queue,
While he, with slowness, didst attend to few,
And none didst speak, or offer aid,
In this place, where service was not paid.

So here, dear friends, take heed of this tale,
And shun the place, where service doth fail."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that were I able, I would bestow upon this place a rating of naught but negative stars. Forsooth, the customer service herein was nonexistent, a plight most vexing and woeful. Not a single soul didst acknowledge mine own presence, though others nearby didst receive attention. Farewell, for I shall ne'er set foot within these walls again."

"A quilt, I laboured on with diligence,
And sought to match the hues of its design.
Gail, a woman of some skill, didst assist,
With a heavy sigh, she didst make her mind plain.
To the fabric section, she didst me lead,
And said, 'This is all we have, young maid.'
I asked if more could be found online,
But her response was curt, and not divine.
'I know not,' she didst say, with a shrug,
And left me to seek out other luggage.
So I departed, and didst take my business elsewhere,
Forsooth, a better fate didst I find, and fairer weather."

"Hark! My rice, so crunchy and dry,
My black beans, hard as a stone,
My tortilla, sticky to the touch,
And in my burrito, mostly dark chicken, alas!
Ugggggh, what a woeful meal!"

"Methinks 'twas folly to dine at this establishment, fair friends, For prices were exorbitant, and fare but mediocre, I do declare. Our party of eight found naught to delight, alack! The Dim Sum platter, microwaved, it did seem, with dumplings ill-cooked and devoid of zest. One guest's Pho broth was watery, the meat tough and foul, and shrimp in every dish, fishy and squishy, I do attest. Service, poor, forsooth, though the place was empty, I pray thee, And my beer glass, too, was washed with haste, its former contents still clinging, in disarray. Pray tell, hath anyone partaken of the $175 Birds Nest soup? Aye, 'tis a question worth pondering, I do aver."

"Hark! What woeful tale doth this pizza place bring?
Their site, a snare, doth charge unwary feet
For each order made, a fee they do impose,
A tax on hunger, and a bitter dose.
And should thou choose to wait, alas!
'Tis oft an hour, or more, they doth amass,
Even at two, when sun doth highest sit,
Thy stomach grumbles, and thy soul doth flit.
But fear not, for their pizza, though not great,
Doth fill thy belly, and doth sate thy fate.
Yet, is it worth the trouble and the strife?
I say, good sir, 'tis not, and thus I end my life."

"Prepare thyself, fair maiden, to pay double the price of a standard Starbucks brew. A grande drip coffee, once $4.20, now doth cost $8.40. Methinks 'tis a steep increase, and one that doth strain mine own purse. Yet still, I do confess, I do enjoy a good cup o' joe, and daily do imbibe it with great relish. But prithee, good sirs, give me a moment's respite from such exorbitant prices!"

"Methinks I give this place too many chances, fair sir. Forsooth, each time I doth return, hoping for a change, yet naught but woe doth befall mine eyes. O'erpriced fare and poor service doth plague mine senses, leaving me in discontent."

"This Michaels in Charlotte, fair citizens, doth leave much to be desired. The store itself doth appear in disarray, with shelves both empty and disorganized. And, alack, the cashier who did attend to me did seem most vexed at her task. In truth, I do prefer to venture forth to Hobby Lobby, or wait until my travels take me to another, more well-appointed Michaels. Forsooth, this store doth lack in both selection and hospitality."

Hark! My trusty steed, a CRV of fine make,
Didst break down on the highway, oh so forsaken.
The air didst blow, and with it, all my woe,
Didst come upon me, like a tempest in the night.

A fortnight past, in June, the mechanic's art,
Didst fix the problem, or so I didst impart.
But lo! The A/C, it didst blow once more,
And with it, all my hopes, didst fade away, like mist before the sun.

Now, back to thee, dear shop, I do return,
To beg thy aid, and pray, thy skill to learn.
Oh, gentle mechanic, with thy wondrous might,
Do fix my car, and end this woeful plight.

For luck, I pray, and fortune, be my guide,
That once again, my CRV, may ride.

"Alack, what woe is this? A takeout meal most vile,
In a small, white box, with naught but woe to boast.
Garlic naan, chicken tandoori, I did order,
But lo, the chicken, yellow and pink, did border
On raw and uncooked onions, oh what a sight!
A disappointment, indeed, with naught of delight.
The photos, they did deceive, for dine-in, they did seem,
But alas, the truth, a far cry from the dream."

"This single star, I give, for service poor,
They would not seat us, for a reason quite obscure.
We entered, and a choice they did proffer,
To sit inside, or bask in sunshine's tender.
We chose the latter, with some hesitation,
But soon, a wait of fifteen minutes, we did face.
And lo, within, not a soul could be found,
While two fair ladies, swiftly seated were, without a sound."

"Alas, my dear friend, I do beseech thee, let this humble review be known, 
For 'tis of mine own experience, and not of hearsay, doth it speak. 
Upon the tennis courts, a match I didst play, 
And from mine opponent, a tale didst hear, most dismay. 
For almost all the courts, dead spots there be, 
Wherefore the ball, doth lose its vitality. 
And thus, my friend, I pray thee, heed my words, 
And seek not to engage in matches here, 
Unless the dead spots be gone, and all be well, 
For else, thy skills, shall be in vain, and naught but woe doth dwell."

"Hark! How is't thou makest me sit in this drive-thru,
And twice repeat my order, all for naught?
Thy mind consumed by mirth and merriment,
Whilst those who wait, do patiently lament.

And lo! When I return home, to dine with kin,
I find thy laughter, did cause thee to forget,
The fries, which I did pay for, yet were left behind.
A small matter, some might say, but still a fault,
For which I didst pay, and thus, shouldst have had."

"Alas, my friends, what woeful tale I tell,
Of a dining hall that did my hopes quell.
Their menu, full of dishes fair and bright,
Didst promise much, but failed to ignite.

The prices, oh how they didst climb,
To heights that didst my purse afflict.
And when our meals didst finally arrive,
Our appetites, alas, didst not survive.

The main course, brought before the rest,
Didst leave us wondering, 'Is this the best?'
But nay, the food, though not unsound,
Was average, leaving us unbound.

I cannot fathom, in this place so grand,
Why prices rise to such a lofty land.
For in this world of plenty and of need,
Such costs, they do my reason impede.

So let it be, my friends, that we,
Shall not return, nor pay their fee.
For elsewhere, there be better fare,
And value, which doth truly care."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of Oxygen sessions sought, yet none to hold.
A local, I, with frequent visits made,
And referrals, too, my friends did persuade.

An $11 can of Oxygen, I did purchase,
Yet, alas! The horror of no exchange, did pierce.
A poor experience, indeed, it was,
That left me vexed, and in disgust, I did pass.

They cared not, for my plight, it seemed,
And thus, a loyal customer, they did lose.
Oh, fair warning, dear friends, take heed,
For Oxygen's services, are not worth the deed.

And lo, a better option, I do say,
A "Tens" unit, at medical supply, doth way.
A massager, for half the cost, doth bring,
A wise choice, indeed, for those who would cling.

So, heed my words, and shun Oxygen's grasp,
Lest thou be fooled, and thy gold, they do clasp."

"Hark! I must confess, my mind didst change,
And thus, the customer service didst range,
Into a pit, a hole, a place of woe,
Wherefore, my car doth sit, unserviced, slow.

I came for oil, a change, a wash,
They offered more, a clean, a splash,
I agreed, then thought better of it,
My husband's words, didst make me quit.

I told them, and they altered the bill,
I paid, but still, my car doth sit,
The mechanic, he who shouldst tend,
Doth eat red hots, and chat with friends.

Aye, mayhap I didst cause their plan,
To go awry, but still, I am,
The customer, right? Aye, 'tis so."

"Hark! This place, on this eve most foul, doth suck, by th' Lord above, huevos most rancid! I do proclaim, ne'er shall I set foot here again, forsooth! 'Tis a total buzzkill, by th' night, most late!"

"Fie upon these crowded halls, where shoppers throng and time doth flee! For naught but empty shelves and endless queues didst we find, a woeful sight indeed. Alas, poor footwear, how art thou scattered and scarce? A plague upon this shopping spree, a fruitless venture, say I."

"Methinks 'tis strange, each time I enter here,
A sense of eeriness doth fill the air.
'Tis true, the store itself doth seem the same,
But crowded, oh so crowded, beyond compare.

The cashiers, alas, do trouble me,
Their minds consumed by tedious drudgery.
They neither see, nor hear, nor speak,
As if their souls were lost, in endless sleep.

Their eyes, devoid of life, doth stare,
Into the void, without a care.
No greeting, nor farewell, doth pass,
Their lips, unmoving, as if made of brass.

Even self-checkouts, with their cold machines,
Do show more warmth, and courteous gleams.
Alas, poor cashiers, in sorrow deep,
Doth toil, in darkness, without hope, or sleep."

"In fair town, for work we did abide,
Myself and three companions, side by side.
At noon, we entered this eatery,
Small, yet clean, our eyes did see.
The server, not overly friendly, alas,
But that, the start of troubles, naught but a guess.
Two of us, the same dish did order,
The third and fourth, different, their desire.
The waitress returned, with news most woe,
That they, of what we ordered, did lack, ye know.
Six other dishes, gone, alack,
Leaving us, with little choice, to pick.
A bean salad, with my sandwich, came,
I passed, forsooth, on that, in shame.
My sandwich, cold, and drowned in pesto,
No chance, to send it back, did I get, quoth the rest.
When she, the checks, did bring anon,
Our glasses, empty, did remain, alone.
I told her, then, of the cold feast,
She apologies, gave none, nor any reprieve.
My plate, she took, without a word,
And from my bill, a fifth, she did deduct, absurd.
For I, the sandwich, half did eat,
And bean salad, did not, my treat.
So, fair maid, take heed of this tale,
And charge me right, for the meal, I did not hail."

"A woeful tale of wretchedness and disarray,
This place doth call itself a store, yet naught
But chaos reigns within its walls, I say.
The order we did place online, a mere
Scavenger hunt it was, alack, to find.
Told first to seek the computers' aid,
We chanced upon a sign that did imply
Our router might be found in networking's shade.
Yet lo, the employee did say, 'twas not
In computing's realm, but at the cashier's spot.
And thus we sought the cashier, in haste,
To claim our goods, but oh, what woeful fate!
The cashier, in confusion, didst demand
A manager, to sort the mess, to understand.
And when at last our order did appear,
The cashier did ask for payment, quite queer.
Forsooth, they do not charge the card, it seems,
Until the purchase is complete, in their schemes.
Lastly, a request for bags, didst we make,
But nay, the cashier didst reply, 'twas not their task.
Yet still, we coaxed her, with gentle words,
To place each item in its own small bags, as birds.
Thus, with much ado, we didst escape the place,
With purchases in hand, but naught in grace."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall me,  
When to the pizzeria's door I didst decree,  
To claim my pie, a wondrous treat, no doubt,  
But lo, the lass within didst wear a scowl so stout.  
Her visage dark, her mood most dismal,  
Didst make me feel most unwelcome, verily,  
As though my presence didst vex her sore,  
And bring her naught but woe and trouble galore.  
And yet, I took a bite, and oh, the shock!  
For in that moment, I was whisked away,  
To days of yore, when pizza at the cafeteria,  
Was all we had, and little else didst sway.  
My spouse, too, didst concur with mine own view,  
That this pizza, alas, was not worth a fig or two.  
So here's my counsel, dear friends, take heed,  
Little Caesar's, for a cheap pizza, doth exceed."

"Fair friends, take heed of my warning,
And shun this place, lest ye be scorned.
A friend of mine, with little knowledge,
Didst venture in, and was mocked and scorned.
Their prank calls didst ring out loud and clear,
As she waited, patient and quite dear.
And then, the deed that sealed their fate,
They installed false tires, a terrible state.
Four tires, wrongly sized, a danger great,
That could have harmed her struts, oh so elate.
Why, oh why, such wickedness and spite?
I too, have suffered from their plight.
For six months, I drove without a spare,
A foolish mistake, yet still unfair.
A tire, with hole so large and gaping wide,
I should have seen, but didst not decide.
Now, I vow, to nevermore return,
To Discount Tire, a place that doth burn.
Their management, akin to Neanderthals,
Uncouth and rude, with no regard for morals."

"Hark! What wondrous feast doth lie within this hall?
A buffet, by the name, and praised by all.
For six long years, its glory did abound,
And we, in curiosity, did decide to dine.

My love and I, not fond of such fare,
Did venture forth, with hope and little care.
But lo! The victuals, save the sweet delight,
Were naught but woeful, lacking in all might.
The flavors, dull and flat, did leave us cold,
And we, in wonder, did our taste unfold.

How strange, that those who voted thus, so high,
Must be the elders, with a taste gone dry.
For surely, none with sense of spice and zest,
Could deem this spread, the best."

"Hark! A Groupon didst entice me to Aveda's door,
To sample their wares and see what they could store.
My tresses, long and thick, didst require great care,
So I opted for deep conditioning, with pedicure to share.

The lass who tended me, a shy one, didst seem,
And quiet, as if her voice didst rarely beam.
She started with the deep conditioning, as planned,
But then, oh dear! My pedicure, she didst hand.

With nails uncut, and filed, my toes didst feel,
A far cry from the blissful treat, I didst conceal.
Two hours passed, and still, my feet didst bear,
The weight of her chatter, and her boyfriend's glare.

After rinsing off the conditioner, we didst move,
To dry my locks, and make them smooth and groove.
But alas! The lass didst not heed my request,
To blow dry till damp, and then, a ceramic brush to quest.

One and a half hours passed, and still, my hair,
Didst remain damp, wavy, and full of despair.
I didst leave, disappointed, and dismayed,
At the lack of supervision, that day displayed."

"Methinks 'twas Labor Day weekend, and I didst attend mine cousin's wedding on the Strip. Alas, the hotels there were priced beyond my means, save for one that charged but ninety gold coins per night.

The chamber was spacious, comfortable, and well-appointed, with a goodly casino and restaurant nearby. But, alack! The establishment was situated in a most unsavory quarter, and I didst hear the sounds of love-making from the room adjacent, as clear as if 'twere but a whisper in mine ear. Fie upon it!

I didst speak with the management, and they didst offer me a refund for one of the three nights I didst stay. A small kindness, yet most welcome."

"A woeful tale of wretched fare, I do unfold,
Of Asian eatery, where we didst take hold,
Away from main area, at Formica table bare,
No cloth nor silverware, our meal to share.

I didst order seafood, sizzling hot, they say,
Five shrimps, the rest, a mystery, alack,
My husband, crispy duck, so old and dry,
He couldst not bite, and thus didst ask,
For cashew chicken, in its place, they didst bring,
But burnt, oh so burnt, our tastebuds didst sting.

And then, the bill, they didst present to us,
For all three meals, oh what a fuss,
We didst argue, and thus, they didst relent,
But still, the memory, doth linger, and torment."

"O, woe is me! These knaves, they do beset
My journey, tripling the fare, I do beget.
A five-mile trip, now forty-five, doth cost,
And thrice as long, doth take, to reach the host.
Their wicked ways, I did not know,
Until the map, on my iPhone, did show.
I called the company, with haste and ire,
The maiden, she did act, with feigned surprise.
She bade me write, a letter, to express
My woe, and thus, my anger, doth repress."

"Alas, my lads, I took thee to the place they call 502 Fry,
With hopes of trying their challenge, a feat most grand.
Their website didst boast of culinary delights,
And thus, our expectations were quite high, in truth.

But lo, when we arrived, the place was empty and still,
And the sole worker there, didst pay us no mind, nor will.
He tarried, lost in thought, or so it seemed,
While we, neglected, waited, nigh ten minutes, unheeded.

At last, he deigned to speak, but not a word of cheer,
Nor did he offer solace, or dry our tears.
We left, disgruntled, and sought out Metro's fare,
Where we didst find good pizza, and a welcome rare.

Perhaps, another time, we shall try Tropicana's fare,
But Decatur's branch, alas, doth leave much to despair."

"Verily, my dear friends, 'tis the tender age of nineteen that doth bring us to this wondrous tavern, where we may partake in libations and merriment. But, alas, a word of caution, forsooth! For those who seek to gain entry with false pretenses, beware! The stalwart bouncers here do keep a watchful eye, and shall not be deceived by counterfeit IDs, no matter how convincing they may seem. And, indeed, within these hallowed halls, there lies a tale of woe, for oftentimes, the unfortunate souls who doth imbibe too freely, do leave behind a trail of vomit, much to the chagrin of those who follow after. So, let us raise our glasses high, and pray that fortune doth smile upon us, that we may enjoy this merry establishment, and emerge unscathed, with naught but memories of mirth and glee."

"Alas, poor service doth plague this wretched place,
Where absent attendants leave patrons in disgrace.
A surly waiter, with a scowl upon his face,
Did bring us water, but with rudeness did embrace.

When we did seek our bill, he came with speed,
But not before his sour mood did take heed.
He yelled with sarcasm, as we did depart,
And left us with a foul taste in our heart.

The victuals, too, did lack in grace,
Like Vegas fare that doth fill the space.
In truth, 'twas naught but bland, unworthy cheer,
That did not merit even a single spear."

"Alas, how swiftly doth the atmosphere deceive!
For though it be great, yet doth it quickly dwindle.
I came here oft, and with joy did partake
Of rolls most wondrous, ere they did change the menu.
Now limited and lacking in delight,
Doth make me shun this place, where once I did revel.
And lo, the happy hour, how variable it doth seem!
When business doth flag, they do shut their doors,
And on the weekends, naught but disappointment doth await.
Unreliable, indeed, this place doth prove to be.

And slow, oh so slow, the wait staff doth move,
As if in slumber, or in idle reverie.
The food, it doth sit, a full five minutes long,
Awaiting its fate, like a prisoner in chains.
I didst think to take it up myself, in ire,
Like Larry David, in his show of curbed enthusiasm.
But alas, I didst refrain, and didst not stir.

Yet still, this place, the closest to my home,
Doth hold a special place within my heart.
For though I may not come here anymore,
My love for sushi doth never depart.
And so, I shall seek out Kobe Sushi Bistro,
On S. Rainbow, where my hunger shall be assuaged."

"Hark! I've returned from fetching victuals,
And, by my troth, the service was most foul.
A varlet of an employee, with words most uncouth,
Didst press upon me, thrice, to buy a draught.
Their manner, rude, and full of disdain,
Didst mar my meal, and cause great vexation.
I called, and waited, ten minutes long,
For the manager, who didst prove most wrong.
I hung up, and tried again, with ire,
And, swiftly, didst the manager appear.
My disappointment, great, and full of woe,
For this place, I do not recommend, thou know."

"Alas, poor stomach, how thou doth grumble and churn,
In search of sustenance, a meal most urgent.
To fast food place, we didst swiftly turn,
Yet waited twenty minutes, naught but one car present.
Alack, what woeful fate, that service so slow,
We left, our bellies empty, sorrow didst grow."

In fair Las Vegas, where we didst roam,
We chanced upon a place, called Gordon's home.
Their French Onion Soup, Prime Rib, and Bangers and Mash,
Didst seem simple dishes, not hard to mash.
But alas! The soup was cold, the meat was fat,
And service poor, like a sorry cat.
Oh, how the prices didst climb high and steep!
A woeful tale, and an expensive sleep.
Gordon, dear man, should visit this place,
And with thy makeover, show them grace.

"Fie upon this wretched place, where coffee doth flow like sewage through the streets! 'Tis overpriced, I say, and styled with naught but cheapness in mind. The smoothies, mayhap, shall pass muster, for they bring them in from without, but woe betide the pastries, for they be but mediocre, a sorry sight indeed. Be not deceived by outward show, my friends, for within, 'tis naught but careless folk who tend the brew, and charge thee well for their poor service. Fie, I say, upon this vile den!"

"Upon mine eyes, dear friend, didst Betsy's Ice Cream lay claim,
With Joy, my comrade, at my side, we didst take a stroll,
To partake in sweets, a feast most fair and fine,
But lo, the portions small, our hunger didst decline.

The sorbet, too sweet, didst not impress,
A fan of frozen yogurt, I must confess,
But alas, none found, our taste buds didst sigh,
And thus, to Scoops and Carini's, we didst say goodbye.

A message came, from Betsy's manager, so bold,
Asking how to improve, his staff to mold,
But I, a humble reviewer, didst reply,
"Train them well, before they reach the sky."

For four small scoops, a price most steep,
A half-gallon of ice cream, a better deal, doth sleep,
So, to Betsy's, I shall not return,
For frozen treats, my heart doth yearn."

"Tasted once at eve, and found it but a meagre feast.
Tried again at morn, and loathed it with great haste.
Eggs Florentine, a dish most woefully prepared,
With hollandaise scarce, and tomatoes green and hard.
Hubby's turkey bacon, foul and burnt to a crisp,
His toast, as rocky as the mountains, did not please.
Potatoes, undercooked or burnt to a cinder,
And rosemary, excessive, did the dish offend.
All cold, as winter's frost, did chill the bone,
Fresh fruit, an apple, in the month of August shown.
Coffee, perhaps instant, did not please the taste,
And service, twice, did lack all grace and haste."

"O, woeful service, fie upon this Olive Garden!
Their ToGo service doth leave much to be desired,
For when thou dost arrive, thou shalt wait twenty minutes,
E'en though thy time frame doth suggest otherwise.
And lo, I didst show up five minutes late,
Yet still, my food was not prepared, how vexing!
The fare was cold and soggy, a pitiful sight,
I wouldst give zero stars, anon, 'twere possible.
So heed my words, good sir or madam,
And shun this place, as thou wouldst avoid a curse.
Never come to this Olive Garden, I pray thee."

"Alas, poor Ulta! Thou art plagued with woeful service,
A curse upon thy halls, a blight upon thy floor.
I, a humble shopper, seek but small regard,
A nod, a smile, a word of guidance, nothing more.
But nay, thy salesgirls do shun all friendly ways,
Their eyes turn cold, their hearts as stone, they doth repel.
I marvel if their task, to be so unhelpful,
Be part of their employment, a woeful burden to bear.
If so, then verily, they do excel, alack!"

"Hark! A warning to all who doth frequent this place,
Where the staff is kind and the victuals do taste,
Of a sickness that doth threaten thy gut's repose,
A plague of diarrhea that doth leave thee weak.

Twice now hath this fate befallen me, alas,
And though the spices may be the cause, I fear,
Uncleanliness may also play a part, alack,
For others have spoken of similar woe.

So heed my words, dear friends, and take heed,
Lest thou too fall prey to this foul deed.
In this place, where food is good, yet danger lurks,
Beware, and guard thine health with utmost care."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir,  
This practice doth leave much to be desired.  
For two years and more, we've been with them,  
Yet service and staff have declined, alas!  
The front-of-house crew, so rude and cold,  
Do little to aid or make one feel bold.  
If smiles and kindness be not thy forte,  
Then perhaps another line of work were best,  
For those who toil in offices, where parents doth come,  
Must needs be pleasant, lest they spread some gloom."

"Tis a wretched tavern, where the victuals do taste
Like that of curs, and naught but wretched filth doth grace
The platter. By my troth, I do declare and vow
That ne'er again shall I set foot within this foul
Establishment. Forsooth, 'tis naught but rubbish, and
I do suspect they use the scraps of hounds, or mayhap
Even worse, to concoct their sorry excuse for fare.
A pox upon this pitiful place, and may it fade
Into obscurity, for it doth offend mine eyes
And senses with its vile and loathsome quality."

"Fie upon that wretched club, a den of woe,
Where time and coin are lost, and naught to show.
The atmosphere, dull; the crowd, but so-so;
The music, stale and old, like last year's snow.

Gamble not with thy money and time, my friend,
For better payoff, seek another end.
That terrible club, avoid it, thou shalt see,
A waste it is, and naught but misery."

"Verily, this Asian eatery doth serve the most vile and wretched victuals. My comrades and I, in search of a swift repast, didst decide to partake of their offerings. Alas, each dish we ordered didst prove to be the most dire version of its kind that e'er hath passed mine lips. The sauces were incorrect, the noodles amiss, and my companion's pho didst merit a return, a first for him, I dare say. This establishment doth deserve naught but utter destruction, by fire and sword, anon!"

"Upon the reviews, we didst venture forth and give it a try.
The atmosphere, fair; nary a soul didst speak a harsh word.
The service, good; yet, alas! The menu didst lack.
All dishes we didst wish to partake, didst vanish like mist at dawn.
A grilled cheese and fried fish, our choices didst dwindle.
Greasy, both; the bread, akin to old oil, didst taste.
The fish, a river of grease, didst flow from the plate.
We shall not return, nor recommend it to any.
One waitress, perchance, didst seem rude; yet, 'twas but a guise.
To dine, a risk; a wager, we didst not wish to make."

"O woeful day! APS doth prove a wretched crew,
Their pricing plan, a trap for unsuspecting souls,
A third-party billing firm, their payments doth procure,
For international cards, a problem most foul.

In Las Vegas, a home I do possess,
Yet troubles with APS, my peace doth molest,
I'll end my lease, and seek a new abode,
Where SRP doth reign, my heart doth implore.

APS, a company vile, their practices doth stink,
Happy shall I be, when from them I do shrink."

"Pray tell, good sir, how may I assist thee? Aye, an oil change and car wash, prithee! Verily, 'tis but sixty-two dollars and ninety-five pence, a fair price for such services, I daresay. Yet, mark my words, young man, thy sales career shall prosper not, nay, not beyond the confines of yonder car wash. Fare thee well, and may Fortune smile upon thee, despite this humble station."

"Hark, what news is this? A plumbing fiend,
In wheelchair bound, with scorn didst pour,
Upon my husband, knowledgeable in trade,
And me, with words of little grace.

A faucet we didst seek, a gift for aunt,
But this ill-mannered soul, our hopes didst dampen,
With rolling eyes and haughty tone, didst say,
My husband's wisdom, he didst not comprehend.

Alas, my aunt, who doth reside nearby,
Didst suffer same fate, with sorrow didst sigh,
This plumbing wretch, with poor service didst stain,
The reputation of his master's name.

An employee evaluation, a need, I do declare,
To teach this grumpy soul, the art of civility,
Lest customers, away, in disgust, do flee,
And leave this plumbing store, in misery."

"Hark, what woeful wares they sell here! Tchotchkes of little worth, yet priced so dear. A pox upon this den of thieves, that doth rob the innocent of their hard-earned shekels. Save thee, good sir, and seek thy bargains elsewhere, lest thou be fleeced by these charlatans."

"Hark! A vegetarian I be, and dining out, a rarity 'tis for me. This place I chanced upon, with hopes high, their veggie turkey sandwich, a try didst I give. Alas! Two hours passed, ere nausea and stomach pangs didst begin. Mayhap food poisoning, I didst ponder. Few veggies doth dine here, mayhap soy turkey, old and foul, didst cause my woe? Morn hath come, my esophagus and belly, afire with pain. Naught can I eat or drink, alack!"

"Alas, what woeful sights doth meet mine eyes within this hall of healing! Firstly, yonder front desk attendants and medical assistants, their visages doth wear the cloak of misery, ne'er once extending greetings unto me. And lo, upon my entreaty for refill of mine asthma medicament, a nurse practitioner doth converse with the physician for nigh an hour, as if I sought a potion for mine very soul! Their reluctance to grant mine request didst stir within me a tempest of vexation, for had I not read that hydroquinone cream doth serve as a primary remedy for such unsightly pigmentation? Fie upon this fateful day! Not only did they deny mine appeal, but also didst substitute mine accustomed asthma prescription with QVAR, a medicine far more costly, leaving me empty-handed and perplexed."

"Hark, what woeful tale doth mine ears perceive?
A hotel stay, so full of disbelief!
The sheets, unkempt, a sorry sight to see,
And ashes, scattered on the coffee table, free.

We checked in, at two o'clock, they say,
Yet still, no room service came our way.
Three calls, we made, and promises, they broke,
Now, one AM, and still, no sign of smoke.

Oh, traveler, take heed of this warning true,
This hotel, shun it, as thou wouldst shun anew.
For customer service, poor, and slow,
Doth make our stay, a woeful woe."

"Alack, the decor doth please mine eyes,
In truth, 'tis where The Gelato Spot doth rise.
Their focus, as it seems, doth lie with sweet,
But I, alas, didst seek a drink most meet.
Iced coffee, I didst order, full of hope,
But lo, the cashier didst give me cause to cope.
He gave me hot coffee, and a cup of ice,
As if my mind were lost in some nice vice.
In summer's heat, who doth desire a hot brew?
Not I, good sir, unless my wits be few.
And thus, the watery concoction didst taste,
Most vile and foul, a drink most waste.
For this, I do pronounce this place doth lack,
And shall not see my face again, no need to ask."

"Verily, I have graced these halls before, and found the victuals most delectable, alas, I fear I shall not return, forsooth, this place doth not regard the codes of health.

Whilst waiting for my repast, a worker, reeking of smoke and touching the rail without, didst enter, and with nary a pause, didst handle the food with his bare hands, and prepared my order.

Methought, 'tis not mine, yet lo, 'twas indeed, and the proprietor, who didst witness all, didst say naught. This place, methinks, shouldst be closed down, ere it doth harm another soul."

"Hark, the service did seem of fair quality,
But the meatball sandwich, alas, did lack quantity.
The bun, once sliced, did reveal a void most dire,
A fourth of its length, empty, without a single fire.
The meatballs, small and few, did not suffice,
To fill the space, or satisfy my vice.
Either more meatballs, of ample size, they should provide,
Or serve it on a bun, half the size, they must decide."

"Verily, fair sir, thou seekest to know why two stars doth grace this review, when all the dishes we didst partake of, didst please our taste buds so well? Alas, 'twas not the food that didst earn such a rating, but rather the service we didst receive. Forsooth, the hostess, young and fair though she may be, didst display a most unbecoming demeanor, with nary a smile or kind word to greet us. And, alack, the waitstaff didst seem to forget their duties, for they didst attend to some guests with haste, while leaving others to linger, waiting for their turn. Thus, two stars doth seem a fitting reward for such uneven service, despite the culinary delights we didst enjoy."

Last eve, I ventured forth to a new site,
A place of burgers, much anticipated quite.
We'd waited long for its grand opening night,
And thus, our expectations were great, as bright.

But alas, the onion rings were soggy, a woe,
And burgers too, with nary a crisp, did show.
My own burger, pink within, uncooked, a sight,
Did leave me feeling cheated, in plight.

The cost, dear friends, was high, a steep price to pay,
For such a meal, with naught but dismay.
The service, poor, with naught but chaos to say,
As they were swamped, their busyness did slay.

My soda, lacking Dr Pepper's sweet embrace,
Was naught but fizzy water, a poor substitute, in place.
Thus, my dear chums, I shall not return again,
To this place, with its disappointment, in vain.

"Hark! My thoughts on Haps, I now express,
A place where corners cut, doth leave much mess.
Their sides, devoid of flavor, doth astound,
Mashed potatoes, tasteless, like the ground.
Garlic toast, a ruse, with naught but bread,
And buns, so dry, they doth offend.
A scoop of ice cream, they do provide,
But 'tis of that cheap sort, that doth not abide.
The root beer, once of Henry's make,
Now replaced with A&W's fake,
A move that did my business take,
For such low quality, the price doth make.
In Arizona, folk may find delight,
But those with taste, should avoid the sight."

"Hark, what folly doth this restaurant bring!
Mario Batali's name, a mere sham, doth cling
To this den of overpriced, paltry fare,
Where service doth falter, and guests do swear.

We entertained our French friends, two of whom
Do own a fine eatery in distant Brittany's home,
And thought that Mario's culinary flair
Would leave them in awe, their taste buds all aglare.

Alas, we left before the main course came,
For $24 ravioli, a price most shameful,
Our guests did laugh at the slow service too,
The emptiness of the room, a sight anew.

No value sought, but seriously, good sir,
Six cheese ravioli, a price most dire,
A farce, a sham, a mockery of the art,
That doth leave one's stomach, and wallet, smart."

"Alas, my friends, this review doth tell a tale of woe,
Of St. Patrick's Day, when bars did overflow.
We ventured forth, our spirits high and bright,
But found, alas, that most establishments did not take flight.

The tables, unbussed, did lie in disarray,
And menus, sticky with spilled ale, did stay.
It took some time, nay, a quarter hour or more,
To order drinks, and then, to wait some more.

The food, oh how it did take its sweet time,
Two hours or more, a wait most dire and grim.
And appetizers, they did come with the meal,
Not before, alas, which made the wait most keen.

Tater-tot nachos, oh how they did disappoint,
With few chips, and cheese, but mostly ice and dismay.
And burgers, cooked well done, oh how they did lack,
A proper bun, replaced with toast, alack!

Separate checks, a task too great, it seemed,
So we, eight ways, did split the bill, with haste.
My friends, I must confess, my blood did boil,
At such a state, most vexing and vile.

I wished, in truth, that I had gone to Five Guys,
And ended my night with a meal most wise.
But no, I stayed, and tipped the waitress fair,
For though the kitchen faltered, she did show care."

"Methinks, fair friends, this place doth bring to mind  
The mem'ry of a night most ill-designed,  
When wine, in copious quantity consumed,  
Did steal my senses, leaving me quite bemused.  
In an outhouse, prone and prostrate, I did lie,  
Awakening with a headache, and a sigh.  
Fie upon this flea-bitten, tawdry den!  
Where germs and filth do reign supreme, by heaven!  
So, gentle sirs, take heed of my advice,  
And steer clear of this pestilential place,  
Lest ye wish to suffer similar fate,  
And rise, as I did, with a heavy head, and great disgrace."

"Verily, I say unto thee, 'twas the most vile customer service I've e'er received. They didst rip me off, and their mistake with my order didst leave me in dismay. The foolish, portly Chinese woman, who didst attend to me, didst not speak the language of the land, and didst treat me with such disdain. In sooth, 'tis a wonder she doth still hold her position, for her skills in customer service be lacking, to say the least. Pray tell, what woeful fate doth bring me to this pass? Shall I ne'er find solace in the realm of commerce?"

"O, cursed abode! How ill-suited to my taste,
With managers who care not for the space,
And grounds that lay in disarray, unkempt,
A pool, with ancient furniture, and naught but grief.
The water, too, did they turn off at whim,
And enter my home, without a care or qualm.
The manager, with haughty air and apathy,
Didst make me feel most unwelcome, verily.
But lo, the office staff, they were a delight,
And made me smile, despite the darkest night.
Yet, alas, their cheer could not abate,
The woe that dwelt within that cursed estate.
I counted down the days, till my release,
And vowed, ne'er to return, nor e'er to cease.
For though the location seemed a boon,
'Twas not worth the woes that I had known.
A costly lesson, learned, and now imparted,
Beware, dear friends, that apartment, shunned and broken-hearted."

"O, woeful day! Our visit to this ale house doth leave much to be desired.  From Chicago we didst drive, with hopes of merriment and cheer,  But lo, the service here doth leave us sorely disappointed.  A table, unclean and foul, didst greet our arrival,  And though our server didst agree to cleanse it, she didst not return.  Another waitress, passing by, didst offer her aid,  But alas, she too didst fail to purge the table of its grime.  The manager, D Sellers, didst appear, with words of empty apology,  Yet no rag didst he bring, to wipe away the filth.  O, poorly managed bar! Our patience didst wear thin,  And thus, we didst depart, ne'er to return again.  This place doth merit naught but zero stars, by our reckoning."

"Verily, who wouldst have thought that such vile victuals couldst be served and yet pass muster? Alas, the green tomato BLT didst prove a sorry sight, with bacon aged a day too long and a tomato most unpleasantly greasy upon dry bread. And, alack, the quesadilla didst fare no better, being both dry and shabbily presented. But, by my troth, the server's nails didst reach such lengths that she couldst not place the dishes properly, for fear of breaking one, I reckon. Methinks 'tis most unsanitary! Mayhap breakfast doth fare better, but avoid all else, lest thou desirest a meal most foul and unpalatable."

"Hark, what fate is this? A table we didst seek,
In haste, within yon crowded eatery so bleak.
A corner, dark and dismal, they didst proffer,
And we, with scorn, didst swiftly bid it farewell, my dear.

For why, oh why, should we pay for a sight,
That doth escape our gaze, like fleeting light?
Nay, nay, my friend, let us away,
To Mon Ami Gabi, where mirth doth stay."

"O, how my taste doth differ from the crowd,
For Olive Garden, I do not hold in high regard.
Their victuals, they do taste of frozen fare,
Thawed in a microwave, and served with nary a care.
Even the breadsticks, good though they may be,
Do possess a flavor most strange and eerie.
The service, too, doth leave much to be desired,
A mediocrity that doth not my spirits inspire.

"Anzio's, a local gem, doth lie nearby,
Where genuine Italian cuisine doth reign supreme.
There, friendly faces and delicious dishes meet,
A far cry from this frozen, truckstop treat.
So, heed my words, and shun this place apart,
For homemade frozen feasts, thy taste buds will thank thee."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from yonder register,
Where friendliness didst abound, yet sorrow didst linger.
A newfound place, with hunger pangs I didst venture,
And ordered 'The BOX', to go, with haste and lingering.

But lo! The wait, it didst seem an eternity,
For though few sat, and none didst line, 'twas slow, oh so slow.
I asked of sauces, and they didst reply,
"Alas, our special sauce, it doth not come nigh."

Oh woe is me! No BBQ, nor any other choice,
But still, I tried it, hoping for a savory voice.
An entire finger, I didst consume, with hope,
But alas, 'twas terrible, and my taste didst droop.

The chicken, bland it was, with texture nice,
But oh, the sauce, it didst not entice.
Love it or hate it, they didst say,
But for me, 'twas naught but dismay.

The fries, crinkle-cut, and bland,
Didst seem like store-bought, so plain.
But Texas toast, great it was,
A shining star, amidst the grass.

Coleslaw, a fan I am not,
So no review, I shall not.
But still, this place, it doth stay,
In business, by those who do adore their way."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that this place doth puzzle me. Forsooth, service here doth not seem the key,

For I, a humble driver, do fuel my chariot twain each week, and pay at the pump, most oft the case.

But lo, if I must needs pay in cash, 'tis a woeful plight! The cashier, a barista also, doth serve the brew,

And if thou art so unfortunate as to stand in line with three men before thee, fear not, for 'twill take but eight minutes' duration ere thou mayst pay for thy gas!

Alas, poor soul, betwixt lattes and cupcakes art thou trapped, in my opinion, two cashiers shouldst be employed at all times, lest customer service suffereth by fancy's hand."

"Never again, I vow, shall I set foot in Daphne's hall,
Where yoga-weary souls do seek sustenance and refreshment.
Alack, the service there, so slow and full of disdain,
Didst make my visit brief, and thus, my ire doth rise.

The counter-man, so surly, with nary a word didst speak,
When I, in query, didst ask what dish he didst hold dear.
He shruggethed and grunted, leaving me to choose,
A combo plate, with falafel and chicken skewer, I didst suppose.

But lo, the wait, so long, with none else in the place,
Didst stir my patience, and I didst ask to take my leave.
The man, his mood, didst sour, as if the world didst owe him ill,
And thus, my meal, didst come, in a most unpleasant still.

Frozen falafel, in patty form, didst greet mine eyes,
With chicken skewer, so small, and vegetables, burnt and dry.
The hummus, too, didst fail, with flavors old and stale,
All for nine dollars, a price most exorbitant and frail.

No more, my friends, shall I return to Daphne's door,
For elsewhere, better fare, and service, I shall seek, and explore."

"A pox upon this place, with its silly rule,
That denies a cup of water, save to youth or age.
I asked for water, and a cup they did proffer,
But on my receipt, a charge for drink did gage.
I questioned this, and was told in reply,
That water cups are for the young and old alone.
Fie upon such nonsense, 'tis a foolish lie,
For water's freely given, as the earth doth own.
And Malcolm, thou cashier, with ill grace,
Didst charge me for a drink, without a trace."

"Upon our return, with a generous gift card in hand, we didst venture once more unto the realm of yon fine establishment. Alas, fate didst play a cruel trick upon mine person, for they didst bring me steak with wrongful sauce, their pepper sauce instead of shallot butter, which I hadst requested. I didst send it back, and lo, they didst bring me the correct sauce, yet with a steak most woefully incorrect. 'Twas none other than the selfsame Heinz Ward steak that hadst caused mine discontent in days past.

"Verily, the steak was cooked to perfection, a medium-rare, yet the flavor itself didst leave much to be desired. 'Twas lacking in depth, akin to water, and thus, I didst partake of but three bites, and then didst cease to eat. Happily, they didst not charge me for the steak, yet still, I do lament that at such a noble price, mine experience didst fall short of a B+, nay, even a C-."

"By th' stars, I pray thee, let me give none! Forsooth, avoid this place, 'tis o'erpriced, I say. 

A devotee of eggs benedict, I do confess, and diverse have been my experiences. Alas, these eggs, so bland they were, the worst I've e'er encountered. Our table, too, didst take a quarter hour to claim, when empty seats didst abound. 

Cold, the potatoes were, and foul, the hollandaise. Flavorless, it lacked, naught but water didst pass my lips. Twice, I didst tell the serving maid, "Add lemon, warmth, and all shall be well!" Yet, chill it remained, beneath a silver dome, alack! 

Save thy pence, good sir! Avoid this den, 'tis not worth thy while, mark me."

"Treasure Island, a place of wonder,
Where luxury and indulgence do abound.
But alas, my friends, let this be a lesson,
For service there, was most profane.

The spa, a place of rest and relaxation,
Did offer up a massage most fair.
But oh, the front desk, so unaccommodating,
Leaving me to ponder, with naught but despair.

The sports bar, where men do gather,
To watch the game, and drink ale.
But there, the tenders did behave most rudely,
As if their manners had gone astray.

Check in, a lengthy wait did ensue,
And ropes, they dangled, in plain view.
A normal sight, said the hotel reps,
But to me, most strange, and quite perplexing.

Champagne glasses, a price most steep,
$10 plus $4, a service fee to keep.
Starbucks, there, a gift card, wouldst not accept,
A travesty, indeed, and most vexing.

Mystere, a show of wonder and might,
A highlight, in a sea of disappointment.
So heed my words, dear traveler,
And choose a place, where service is paramount, and not a figment."

"Hark! What sign doth take up half the side of yonder hotel?
Aye, 'tis Hooters', and it doth proclaim,
In bold letters, their 24-hour game of chance,
For $3, a paltry sum, yet still they'll dance.
But lo, dear traveler, heed my words of woe,
For though the sign doth boast, the truth doth show,
But one lone table, with poor odds, doth lie,
And re-buys, alas, are not allowed to try.
The casino, small and cramped, doth reek,
Of chicken wings, a stench most foul and bleak.

If thou hast stepped within a Hooters' door,
Imagine all the horrors, and then some more,
Add a blackjack table, and beds to rest,
And thou hast this place, a den of woe and unrest.
I've seen it once, and now I know full well,
To nevermore return, and save my soul from hell."

"Hark, good sirs of Oregano's, heed my words of wisdom,
For ill tidings come to those who keep their guests in waiting.
Avoid ye the curse of tardiness, lest ye wish to vex,
And double-check thy orders, ere they be dispatched.

Forsooth, a night most foul doth lie ahead,
When hunger doth consume and tempers doth fray.
So heed this warning, and make haste,
Lest all thy efforts doth turn to naught but waste."

"O, woe is me! My family and I didst dine
At this establishment, and what didst we find?
Tin foil within my victuals, a most vile sight.
The waitress, kind and courteous, didst attend
To our concern, and straightaway didst fetch
The manager, who with feigned surprise didst say
That 'twas not part of their recipe, nor didst play
A role in their cooking. Well, no need to say
That we were not impressed, for 'twas quite clear
That poor management didst reign supreme.
For though they offered naught but a smile,
We didst not tarry, nor didst we desire
To taste their wares once more. Farewell, dear place,
We shall not darken thy doors again, for fear
Of finding more unwanted guests within."

"O, woe is me! This place doth leave much to be desired.
The chicken bowl, once hot, now doth resemble ice.
And, alas! The fowl, once cooked, doth seem to have aged five days past its prime.
I vow, ne'er shall I return, nor shall I partake
In this establishment's dubious fare again.
A refund, pray tell, would be most welcome, ere I depart."

"Hark, what woe doth befall me in this place,
Where water doth cease to flow with grace.
A plague upon the landlords, say I,
Who care not for their tenants' plight.

My lease, a curse, doth bind me fast,
To dwell within these walls of woe.
The water, it doth get shut off, alas,
And leaves me parched, with naught to show.

Four times, or five, since May last year,
Hath water ceased to flow, oh dear.
In summer's heat, with A/C gone,
Didst sweat and discomfort make me moan.

Maintenance, a futile hope, doth fail,
For when I call, no fix doth prevail.
Doorknob, garbage disposal, shower head,
All broken, leaving me in despair.

When lease doth end, away I shall flee,
From this, my wretched, watery hell, yea!"

"A platter most woeful, filled with dishes of woe,
I didst order from Chop and Wok, a place of old renown.
The prices, once fair, now risen quite high,
And boxes, once grand, now diminished in size.

Flavor, where art thou? None couldst be found,
In any of the dishes, so plain and profound.
No meat, no beef, nay, not even a morsel,
Chicken, scarce and tough, like leather, most foul.

Sauce, too much, like a stew, it didst seem,
Kung Pao chicken, nonexistent, a dream.
Crab puffs, a sole redeemer, a morsel of hope,
A reminder, a memory, of better scope.

Nevermore shall I order from Chop and Wok,
A loyal customer, now forsook.
Since high school days, a fan, now dismayed,
By crappy food, a legend, now decayed."

A fair gymnasium, yet management doth lack,
Beware the contract, lest thou be caught in snare,
They'll keep on charging thee, until thou doth cancel in writing,
And watch out for that sly auto-renewal clause, my dear.

Hark, fair friends! I've visited this Wendy's before,
Their customer service, alas, leaves much to desire.
But, lo! If hunger doth beset thee sore,
'Tis passable, though not the best of fire.

Since then, the Walmart nearby hath been renewed,
With Subway in its midst, my steps are turned.
Thus, I have not returned to this place,
For Subway's call doth hold a special grace.

"Hark! What fortune brought me to this place? A package dropped at yonder post, a task of briefest grace. And lo! The sweetest treat did call my name, a scoop of vanilla, plain and tame. Yet, fare thee well, my coin did cry, for three and sixpence did they demand, a sum most outrageous, by my troth! Nay, ne'er again shall I set foot within this den of thievery, forsooth!"

"Hark, my dearest spouse and I didst decide
Upon a place to dine, to celebrate
The day of fathers, and thus we didst choose
A restaurant of renown, where we hadst been
In times past, and found the victuals fair
And service of high quality. But lo,
I chanced upon some reviews, ere we went,
Of patrons who hadst suffered ill treatment
At the hands of a waitress, whose breath
Didst reek of smoke, and thus didst taint
Their culinary delights. My husband, he
Didst say, 'Fear not, my love, all shall be well.'
So to the restaurant we didst proceed,
Despite my doubts. And lo, my fears were true,
For in my drink, a plastic cigarette wrapper
Didst appear, and I, in horror, didst pick it out,
Mistaking it for ice. Our waitress, she
Was sweet and sorrowful, but the management,
They didst offer scant consolation, taking off
But drinks and twenty-five percent, a paltry sum.
We shall not return, forsooth, to that place."

"Hark, good sir! 'Twas a Wednesday afternoon, and I didst stop in for a late repast. The hour was nigh 2:30, and I, a solitary figure, didst enter the establishment. Swiftly seated, I didst order a dish of calamari, and a small pizza of Greek origin. A substitution of giro meat didst I request, in place of the ground beef that doth customarily adorn the pizza. Three glasses of iced tea didst I imbibe, ere the waiter didst attend to my appetizer. Alas, the calamari didst arrive, some seven minutes later, and lo! 'Twas soggy and foul-tasting, as if 'twere fried in burnt oil. And shortly thereafter, the pizza didst appear, with a crust most vile and unpalatable. Like an opened frozen pizza crust, left too long in the freezer, didst it taste. Ah, woe is me! For $7.95, the calamari didst cost, and $12.95, the pizza didst fetch. And $2.95, the price of each glass of iced tea. With tax, the total didst exceed $25.00, a sum most exorbitant, for a meal most wretched. Heed my words, dear friend, and shun this place, lest thou desirest to feed thy dog a similar fare."

"Hark! A pox upon this wretched diner, wherefore doth thy sign proclaim hot dogs be thy specialty, yet foot longs and sauerkraut be nowhere found? Fie upon the fare, 'twas naught but mediocre victuals, and the wait, oh how it did drag on! But lo, in fairness, shall I grant thee one star, forsooth, the shake did please mine taste. Farewell, thou woeful eatery!"

"O, woe is me! A pox upon this wretched inn,
Whose name, 'Americas Best Value', doth mock my wits.
A neighborhood, foul and decrepit, doth it keep,
With furnishings and decor, most dated and worn.

The carpet, stained and putrid, doth offend mine nose,
And bed, uncomfortable, doth deny me repose.
The bathroom, mildewed and rife with mold, doth make me shudder.

Alas, we stayed here, forced by circumstance,
For family and multiple rooms, we had no choice.
But now, I vow, we shall ne'er return again,
For this place doth lack all comfort and grace.

We tried, with Lysol, bleach, and Febreze,
To sanitize this den, but all in vain, alas.
The smell, it lingered still, a pungent curse,
That followed us, a plague, in every room we entered."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern! I didst order a white wine spritzer, and the server, a foolish knave, didst tell me they didst not carry such a drink. I, in mine anger, didst inform him of its nature and longevity. My wife, fair and lovely, didst order a frozen strawberry lemonade, but received instead a regular draught. When we didst order our repast, the server didst laugh at my request to exclude poblano peppers or any spice. I, desiring a light meal, didst choose a dish from the Weight Watchers menu. But lo! When our victuals arrived, the server didst assume that my wife, larger than I, didst desire the Weight Watchers dish. I was taken aback, and straightway didst speak with the manager, recounting all that had transpired. We didst depart, and I didst pay for naught."

"O, woe is me! A county facility, they say,
But call the number, and naught but frustration doth come our way.
For when we press the numbers, as prompted, naught doth happen,
And we are left to ponder, in utter confusion and dismay.

Alas, poor souls, what choice have we but to call
The police, in non-emergency, our plight to recall?
For this listing, a waste, a mockery, a sham,
Unless, perchance, thou dost plan to visit the office in person, in haste."

"Hark! I didst order delivery, and swiftly it didst come,
But alas! What they didst deliver, was most foul and loathsome.
I didst request, nay, demand, no mayo nor ham,
Yet still they didst include them, 'twas a cruel whim.
The bread, it was wet, like a soggy mess,
Inedible, a waste of my hard-earned finances.
Away, I didst toss the sandwich, with disdain and scorn,
Forsooth, 'twas not worth the bread it was writ upon."

A fair chamber, yet foul play did abound,
In service, a grievous letdown profound.
Our Marriott points, forsooth, were denied,
For booking in conjunction with our flight.
Gold members, we, yet naught but disdain,
Didst Andrew, the supervisor, proclaim.
A fortnight's stay, I had planned to extend,
Yet, alas, this fiasco did befall.
Grand Chateau, a better choice, did seem,
Andrew's aid, my troubles did relieve.
My thanks, good sir, for thy timely deed,
A Marriott, twice as fair, didst thou proceed.

"O, wouldst thou hear a tale of woe and desp'rate fate?
A lodging most foul, a place to avoid, I do state.
Moldy sheets, stained with unknown substances, did lay,
And tub, with water beneath the plaster, did sway.
Carpet, with sickening stains, did make one ill,
And sheets, with hair afixed, did cause great chill.
Crumbs and rubbish, pushed aside, did gather,
A sight most vile, and unhygienic, I do gather.
We asked for new sheets, at the eleventh hour,
And staff, with attitude, did shower.
Just filthy, the place, a health hazard, I do declare,
Department of Health, should pay a visit, I do swear.
If thou desirest visual proof, email me, I pray,
With 'Days Inn Pictures' as subject, I shall obey.
I warn thee, traveler, heed my words,
For this place, thy health, it may devour.
Insect bites, upon my wrist, do still persist,
A souvenir, most unwelcome, I do insist."

"Fare thee well, dear friends! Forsooth, the victuals we didst partake of yesternight, they were not of the finest quality, I do declare.

The garlic shrimp, a dish most wondrous, save for the fact that the crustaceans themselves were overcooked and tough as leather. Alas!

Two plates we didst order, my love and I. Tamarind pork, a feast fit for a king, or so I thought. Yet, verily, the sauce was overly sweet, a departure from the savory taste I had expected. The veggies, passable, and the beans, not bad.

And the shredded beef? Fie upon it! A strange flavor didst assail our taste buds, akin to that of green olives, which neither of us doth enjoy. Save for that, 'twas but a mediocre dish.

A Mojito, small but potent, didst quench our thirst, yet left us yearning for more, methinks."

"Airport of Las Vegas, a place of woe,
Where travelers are beset with troubles galore.
Advantage counter, a den of deceit,
Where reservations are but a distant treat.

Arriving early, a faux pas, they say,
For those who wish to speed their way.
A wait of thirty minutes, a test of patience,
As one stands idly, with naught but impatience.

Then, when finally served, a surprise doth come,
In the form of charges, manipulated some.
For what they rent, may not be what they sought,
But what the saleswoman doth most eagerly proffer.

So, gentle traveler, take heed of this tale,
And beware the tricks of the Advantage gale."

"Hark, what news is this? Siri doth make headlines, 
For recycling rice, a most curious tale. 
A link they provided, KTNV, I didst follow, 
And found a story of dirty dining, full of woe. 

Alas, I didst return, my craving for pad thai, 
Didst overcome my senses, and I didst try. 
But lo, the health district didst close them down, 
For seventy demerits, a most grievous frown. 

I pray thee, good sirs, avoid this place, 
Lest thou desire a hospital visit, in haste. 
For though the pad thai be excellent, indeed, 
'Tis not worth risking thy health, nor thy creed. 

I have dined here a dozen times, or more, 
Yet never again, shall I step through that door. 
For rice, once recycled, doth lose its charm, 
And twice, thrice, 'tis a danger, a serious alarm."

"Hark, good sirs, what sorcery is this? A fee of one dollar for a replenishment of soda, priced sixfold? Verily, 'tis a curious matter indeed. Forsooth, these keepers of the concessions, do they not partake in the bounty of the silver screen's splendor? Shall we not quench our thirst with a draught of sweet refreshment, lest we parch within the confines of yonder theatre? And, pray tell, what manner of witchcraft doth compel them to deny the simple pleasure of a refill, be it of corn or soda? Fie upon their dusty seats and grimy halls, unfit for noble patrons such as ourselves! 'Tis a journey most arduous, yet necessary, to seek out the hospitable embrace of Town Square, where service and reason doth reign supreme."

"Five factory recalls, alas! on my 2013 Escape doth plague me still,
And at Gaudin Ford, they say it may take all day to fix, forsooth.
A rental car, they would not give, nor any compensation,
Their service, once great, now doth decline, in my estimation.
This year, I shall seek elsewhere, for they deserve no stars,
Their reputation, tarnished, doth leave much to be desired, alack."

"O, what folly doth combine alcohol and sport within a bar's domain! My friend, made to leave by the doorman's decree, didst leave her purse behind, a prisoner of the night. The darkness didst make the volleyballs fly, a hazard to all who dared to venture nigh. I, in conversation with companions, didst feel a sharp pain in my cheek, struck by a stray ball in flight. To the manager, I didst express my discontent, yet his reply didst reek of scorn and disdain. 'Tis a wonder no lawsuit hath been brought against them, methinks. We didst flee, lest further harm befall us. And lo, my drinks didst vary in strength, one with vodka, the next without, a inconsistency most vexing."

"Methinks my wife and I didst dine at this establishment, and verily, our experience was most vexing. The victuals, alack, didst not meet our expectations, and the cost, aye, didst seem exorbitant. A pox upon the grilled fish tacos, forsooth! They were scant in size, and their flavour, alas, didst leave much to be desired. The rice, too salty, and the beans, dry and stale, didst not impress. Nor didst the chicken salad, I fear, for 'twas lacking in zest and the dressing, alack, didst taste most unpleasant. The salsas, three in number, that came with the chips, didst not redeem the meal, I do confess. In sooth, my local Senior Fish doth serve far better fare, and at a lower cost, I do declare! The only solace we found, indeed, was in the pleasant seating area above, and the service, kind and attentive, that didst attend us."

"This den of ill repute doth seem most shady, good sir. They didst attempt to overcharge for bottles, and the ladies of the night didst falsely advertise their wares. The females herein are naught but common strumpets. Compared to the wondrous sights of Vegas, this place doth pale in comparison. Verily, I say unto thee, I am a man of ample girth and visage most unpleasing, yet even I cannot help but feel underwhelmed by this establishment's offerings. Best to avoid such shady characters, my friend."

"Hark! What sayeth thou, good sir? A message doth arrive,
From one who doth proclaim my wit and wisdom doth deceive.
This place, open but three months, doth charge exorbitant fees,
For wares of poor quality, a truth most plain to see."

"Fair lodging, richly furnished, yet alack,
The beds, they do disappoint, in sooth.
Last eve, upon two levels we did rest,
One side within a vale, the other high on a crest.
I sought a change, a better bed to find,
But lo, the new chamber, broken bed didst bind.
What occurs in Vegas, there doth stay, they say,
Yet now I wait, for one of rank to lead
A tour of chambers, fresh and newly made.
I shall depart ere long, and ne'er return, anon."

"O, what folly doth this Bank of America display!
Their drive-thru, a contraption most strange and ill-conceived,
Two ATMs, side by side, in one lane doth lie,
A hindrance to progress, a cause of great vexation.

We waited, patiently, for our turn to arrive,
But lo! One man, with speed most glacial, did strive,
To extract his cash, with deliberation most dire,
And thus, the line, did slow to a crawl, most dire.

Oh, foolish bank! How couldst thou conceive such a plan?
Next to each other, the machines shouldst stand,
Not in the same lane, a space of five feet nigh,
A senseless design, that doth impede and annoy.

Stupid, stupid, stupid! A pox upon thy house,
Bank of America, thy name doth now be a curse,
For thy silly drive-thru, a plague upon thy brow,
Forevermore, shalt thou be known, as a foolish crew."

"Hark! In days of yore, I did procure with ease
Cans of Pro Sheen, and nary a problem did arise.
But lo! This time, two cans didst break and drip,
And thus, I cannot send them back, forsooth.

I have sent emails to Ryans, twain,
And yet, no answer hath been forthcoming, 'tis plain.
A month hath passed, and still, no word,
And so, I seek another vendor, full of disdain.

Alas! Poor customer service doth reign,
And thus, my faith in Ryans doth wane.
Alack! What woe doth this bring upon their name!"

"Verily, this place doth seem a den of woe,
Where jobs are scarce, and hope doth dwindle slow.
I ventured forth, a Wednesday, to make my case,
And met with one who said, 'Wait, for another's grace.'

A few days passed, and Monday came anon,
I called, a chick replied, 'We speak not now, my son.'
'Twas busy, she exclaimed, and thus, I waited still,
Until today, when I did call, and heard her shrill.

Twenty minutes passed, and she, a girl, didst say,
'Can I assist thee?' I, with haste, didst reply,
'Aye, I've waited long, to speak with thy manager.'
She transferred me straight, with little courtesy to show,
And quickly ended the call, with naught but disdain,
These folk, their manners, leave much to be desired,
In truth, their rudeness doth my patience tire."

"Alas, poor traveler, how thy hunger doth cry out for sustenance! And lo, a restaurant doth stand, where once a Wendy's did reign. A lone option, it doth beckon thee, with promises of nourishment and speed. But fear not, dear patron, for this tale doth unfold, a testament to service ill-bestowed.

A Torta del Barrio, thou didst order, with fries, a humble feast, yet priced so dear. And thus, thou didst wait, as others didst come and go, their meals prepared with haste, while thine didst linger, slow.

Thirty-five minutes, a duration most vexing, didst pass, and still, thy meal didst not arrive. The fries, once hot, now soggy and bland, didst disappoint, and bread, once fresh, didst taste of stale. Oh, woe is thee, poor traveler, for such a price, a meal most vile!

The restaurant, crowded and chaotic, didst pump out dishes, one by one, yet those who came before, didst wait, their patience worn. And when thy turn didst finally come, a curt apology, didst suffice, no solace found.

Oh, wouldst that fast food, a viable choice, didst present itself, for in an airport, speed doth matter, and service, a gentle breeze, doth soothe the savage breast. Alas, poor traveler, may future journeys bring thee better fate!"

Alas, poor service doth mar our day,
For at this establishment, we didst stay,
And waited, patiently, for a table to be had,
But nary a soul didst come to take our order, sad.

We walked in, and sat, for quarter of an hour,
Yet still, no one didst come to show us power,
The workers saw us, and didst not come near,
Leaving us to linger, in discomfort and fear.

At last, we rose, and sought the waiter out,
Whose duty it was, to serve and devout,
But alas, he didst attend another pair,
Who came after us, and left us to despair.

Thus, with great sorrow, and much discontent,
We leave this place, with naught but dissatisfaction,
For service poor, doth tarnish all the rest,
And leaves us woeful, and with troubled breast.

"Alack, my chicken sandwich tasted not so good,
And for the price, the meat was scant and poor.
My son, he liked his burger, 'twas a treat,
But oh, the cashier girl, how she did handle
Our money and the sauces, too, with nary a care,
No gloves, no thought of cleanliness, alack!
It made us shudder at her lack of tact."

"Alas, my dear friend, I would not return to this place,
For though the location may be hidden, 'tis not worth the chase.
A gift card from Restaurant.com didst lure me in,
But alas, the pizza was not as promised, thin and lacking within.

The service was slow, the server forgetful of our needs,
And when our appetizers arrived, the server didst merely nod.
The price may be fair, but the food and service do not make amends,
So I wouldst advise thee, my friend, to seek elsewhere for thy ends."

"Their espresso, brewed with beans of age, doth taste most vile and sour. Avoid, good sir, for 'tis a drink most foul.

** Update **

A message from the owner, in defense of his brew, doth claim that young beans were used, and that my taste, alas, doth deceive. But nay, I swear upon mine honor, 'twas old coffee that doth make the drink so sour. If thou dost enjoy such bitter flavor, then seek thee out this place, but for myself, I shall avoid it, lest I wish to taste again such wretched brew."

In sooth, a multitude of folk did throng
A space of scant proportions, 'twas a sight to see.
The queue for potables did stretch and wind,
A tedious wait, full of impatience and woe.

But lo, there was an alternative, a haven
Where workers came to thee, and took thy order,
Then brought thy victuals and drinks, with nary a flaw.
A far superior experience, 'twas a boon, no doubt.
