"O woe is me! My heart doth ache with sorrow and vexation, forsooth, at the poor service we didst receive at yonder Chinese establishment. Verily, 'twas a full forty-five minutes ere our victuals didst arrive, a delay most strange and uncommon, I do declare. And alack, the fare itself didst leave much to be desired, the lettuce wrap in especial being of such poor quality that I have ne'er tasted its like. By my troth, I shall ne'er return to this place again, forsooth!"

In fair Las Vegas, where culinary delights doth abound,
A Persian restaurant didst claim our attention profound.
But alas! The portions they didst serve, how small they were,
And the taste, oh so vile and unworthy to bear.
No special dish didst they present, naught but common fare,
And the soda, in a can 'twas brought, without care.
For the price, in Southern California, better food thou shalt find,
In Las Vegas, no good Persian eatery, we didst not unwind.

"Hark, good sir or madam, listen well,
For I shall speak of chicken, crispy fried,
And waffles, fluffy, hot, and sweet,
A dish most fine, a treat to eat.

But lo, I say, with tongue in cheek,
That KFC's birds, they do surpass,
The ones served up with waffles, dear,
In flavor, texture, and in taste.

Oh, how I yearn for Colonel Sanders' art,
His secret blend of herbs and spice,
That makes his chicken, oh so smart,
A culinary joy, a delight.

And though the portion, large it be,
Enough to feed a hungry crowd,
I say, let's start a food drive, see,
And give the leftovers to the needy, loud.

For who knows not, that hunger pangs,
Do plague the poor, the weak, the young,
Let us, in spirit of good deeds,
Help those in need, with chicken's creed.

So come, my friends, let's join this quest,
To end world hunger, with chicken's crest."

"Methinks my husband and I have dined at this place since its opening day,
And every time we've ordered enchiladas, paying extra, by the way.
The beef enchiladas, alas, had naught but a few bits of meat,
Whilst the chicken one, though slightly better, did not quite meet our treat.
The tortillas were doughy and tasteless, like lumps of lead,
And in the middle, there were cold spots, a most unpleasant dread.
We paid a pretty penny, thirty-seven bucks, I do declare,
But the service was just average, nothing to write home about, I fear.
So, we shall not return, forsooth, to this establishment again,
For our taste buds deserve better, and our purses, a wiser gain."

"Hark! I rushed to Yolanda's tanning den,
After work, with haste, I did attend.
But lo! The salon was closed, alack!
Despite the sign, which did declare,
It should be open till eight o'clock,
I found it shut, my hopes did mock.

I've spent my coins on tanning packs,
But now, my booty doth feel quite slack.
For naught but disappointment did I find,
At Yolanda's, where I hoped to shine.
So now, I shall seek elsewhere,
A place more true, where I may glow with ease."

"Hark, what news is this? A review of Sunrise Cafe,
A place where breakfast dreams are made, they say.
Mike P and Ashley D, two hungry souls,
Did venture forth, their hunger to assuage.

Alas, the cafe was full, but fear not,
For in short time, a table was found.
The atmosphere was lively, full of cheer,
And coffee, fresh, though not the best, 'twain true.

The menu, a curious sight, indeed,
Offered omelets, but in limited breed.
Egg white versions, for the health-conscious mind,
Were available, and one such, I did find.

My omelet, Eggzilla, a tasty treat,
With spinach, peppers, salsa, and cheese so neat.
But alas, poor Ashley, her omelet, a disappointment,
A shame, for the price, a decent arrangement.

In conclusion, Sunrise Cafe, a decent spot,
But for the price, elsewhere, you may find a better plot."

"In fair Waterloo, where Burrito Boyz doth reign,
Their culinary prowess doth not compare,
To those in Mississauga and Toronto's bane,
For taste and quality, they doth not share.

Alack, 'tis true, their burritos doth lack,
The flavour and zest of other spots,
Perhaps 'tis newness that doth hold them back,
But still, a disappointment, it doth bring.

So if thou seeketh good Mexican fare,
In Waterloo, look elsewhere, I pray,
For Burrito Boyz, alas, doth not compare,
To those in Toronto and Mississauga's sway."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from mine own lips,
Of barbecue most foul, that doth my senses rip.
A chicken, pulled apart, upon a loaf of bread,
Didst sit, a sorry sight, before mine eyes were fed.
And he, my comrade, hadst a pork sandwich, fair,
But saucy meat, alas! didst leave me in disrepair.
The server, kind and helpful, didst assist us well,
But, alack! The victuals didst not our taste cells swell.
Forsooth, a disappointment, doth this tale convey,
Of barbecue most mediocre, that didst fade away."

"Methinks my comrade and I didst long to visit this place, yet alas, our expectations were sorely dashed. The tables, in sooth, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi, and the decor, in general, didst not hang together well. The drinks, too, didst fail to impress, the bloody mary being the worst I've had the misfortune to taste. Our repast, the eggs Oscar, didst suffer from cold asparagus and a hollandaise sauce that was overly thick. Our server, Kristopher, didst seem to be in a foul humor, and his gruff demeanor didst put us off from the start. Mayhap a smile wouldst have helped, I do declare. In conclusion, we were not impressed, and mayhap we shall return anon, solely for the ale."

"As we did stroll downtown, by chance we did encounter this place, 'Twas surrounded by shops and commerce, so we thought, "Aha! A quick repast we shall find here, ere we doth continue on our way." But lo, the staff did seat us swiftly, and took our order with haste, yet we did wait, and wait, and wait, for the food to come forth from the kitchen's depths. And when it did arrive, alas, 'twas but a mediocre feast. A chicken breast, devoid of flavor, save for a dusting of paprika, it did taste like cardboard, and the roll, hard as stone. The curly fries, a surprise, were quite good, yet the service, slow, and the staff, did complain of their plight, of being shorthanded, and the last table, which did not leave a sufficient gratuity. I do understand their woe, yet, in front of others, 'tis unseemly, methinks."

"A pox upon the optometrist, a scoundrel most foul!
He printed out a benefit statement, a document most false,
With amounts that seemed too low, a trickery most base.
I checked my plan, and lo, the benefits were vastly higher,
A mistake, they claimed, but one that left me in disgrace.

They said they were out-of-network, a fact most strange,
And that their prices were lower, a claim most odd.
But still, I felt deceived, and so I made my way
To West Valley Vision, where I found a better deal,
For contact lenses, at least, their price was most fair.

But still, I smarted from the lie, a wound most deep,
And vowed to be more careful, in my future quest.
For honesty, it seems, is a rare commodity,
And one must always be on guard, in this world of duplicity."

"Hark! A pitcher of sangria for $36 doth seem a steep price to pay. And lo, the waiter's words didst flow like a river in springtime, making it most difficult to comprehend his every utterance. His suggestions, too, didst miss the mark, I fear. Forsooth, a prix fixe of $50 per person, or paella and tapas aplenty, didst not sit well with mine own sensibilities. Nay, I shall pay but $20 for a paella to share amongst us all, and tapas individual for each. 'Tis a bargain, methinks. And thus, the waiter didst protest, saying the paella doth serve but one. Pshaw! I shall be the judge of that, quoth I. And so, the dish didst arrive, a mighty skillet filled with rice, shrimp five, mussels six, clams six, chicken and sausage besides. Verily, we four couldst not devour it all, no, not even close. Alas, 'twas not an enriching experience, by my troth."

"Alack, I sought a new salon to frequent,
To break the monotony of my usual haunt.
But lo, my venture proved most disappointing,
For prices were inflated, and service was faint.
The pedicure, alas, was woeful and poor,
And the nail technician, distracted and cold.
I shall not return, forsooth, to this place,
For my regular spot, a better choice doth grace."

"A fortnight past, in company of friends, I didst venture hither late at night. Alas, service didst falter! Our attendants, numerous as they were, didst vanish like ghosts, leaving us to hail them anew with each request. Pizza, a middling fare, didst please my taste, while wings, a tolerable dish, didst not offend mine eyes. Farewell, dear tavern, mayhap another time shall bring a better experience."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Blondies, where we didst celebrate the eve of the new year. A bartender, with fingers loose and wild, didst charge us for another's bill, a sum of $138.00, and on top of our own cost, most dear. Our eyes didst not espy this mistake, till two days passed, when we didst check our account with care. My husband, with words of ire, didst speak to the manager, who didst promise a refund, with haste. But lo! A warning to all, for this mistake doth seem a common thing, and we, with fortunes fair, didst escape the snare. So let this be a lesson, to all who doth frequent this place, to watch thy purse, with diligence and grace."

"A club, methinks, doth need three things to thrive:
Music, a lively crowd, and drinks that do arrive.
Whiskey, a place of note, doth play fair tunes,
Some days better than others, as the DJ doth croon.
The crowd, though, doth leave much to be desired,
Yet, with friends of good cheer, 'twill be quite fired.
Drinks, decently priced, doth flow in abundance,
In this spacious hall, where revelry doth dance.
So gather, friends, and make merry, forsooth,
And at Whiskey, thou shalt have a jolly troth."

"Hark! A new coffee shop have I tried this morn,
Wherein I did order hazelnut latte, so bright.
The service, kind; all seemed well, till I sipped,
And lo! The brew, burnt, did make my drink quite vile.
A bitter mess, it was, and naught but woe,
For four silver coins, I didst pay, and now,
Must toss it aside, and seek a new place,
To find a drink, worth the cost, and not disgrace."

"Methinks I didst spend much time at Canaletto's halls,
In days of yore, when taste buds didst enthrall.
But now, alas! My heart doth sink and fall,
For fare that once didst please, doth now appal.

Five comrades joined me in this venture forth,
And all didst concur, naught special didst befall.
Canaletto's seats, in Venetian square,
Are pleasant still, yet lacking in flair.

An American's taste, mayhap 'twill suffice,
But for those seeking culinary prize,
Look elsewhere, dear friends, for better fare,
For Canaletto's dishes, do not compare."

"Hark! What's this? A fast food place with rave reviews, they say,
But my own experience was naught but mediocre, I pray thee,
Alack! I should have known better than to order seafood,
At such an establishment, but the picture did deceive me,
A volcano-blackened mahi, they called it, full of salt,
I had to scrape it off, the fish beneath was but a faint,
Freshness, not of the ocean, but of Arizona's land,
I laughed and said, 'tis OK, but not quite as planned.

The veggies, they were stir-fried, not steamed as I thought,
They were passable, but not the best, I must be brought,
And the mango cheesecake, oh how it did disappoint,
Just plain old cheesecake, with a mere thimbleful of mango juice, feigning sweetness, alack!

I would return, but with lowered expectations, ere I dine,
Forsooth, a lesson learned, to not believe all that doth shine."

"Alas, my friends, how poorly doth this establishment fare! A quarter hour didst we wait, for what should be swift victuals, alack! And when at last our meals didst arrive, oh woe! The flavors were most vile and lacking in zest. Methinks 'twould be wise for them to reassess their bill of fare, and with haste, ere they lose all custom. Forsooth, fair patrons will forgive a tardy feast, provided 'tis of high quality. But here, alas, doth lie a sorry tale of twofold failure."

"Two stars for ambiance, alas, I cannot give more, my dear.

He who wouldst know how a Caipirinha with white sugar tastes, is best advised to tarry here. Moreover, one needs much time, the service is unfriendly and inattentive.

To reserve a table, one must first pay a high minimum drink order per head, elsewise, no reservation shall be had.

Hark! Karlsruhe has a rival establishment, with the same flair but better cocktails and friendly service. 'Tis a pity, P10, that thou art not as keen!"

"Hark! This Canter's doth not impress me much, I fear. In truth, I felt a bit disappointed, yea, even underwhelmed. A branch of renowned Canter's, 'twas said, yet for a fair sum of coin, I received but a dry, limp turkey on wheat bread, fries, and a soda. Alack! A major letdown, indeed. Dijon mustard, my savior, didst make the turkey somewhat palatable, but alas, too little, too late. Ah, well, in Vegas, where prices be high, perchance my expectations were set too steep. Yet, a pastrami sandwich, tried I did, and 'twas not so bad, I must confess. But, alas, that woeful turkey doth linger in my mind, and thus, my taste buds, they may have been dulled by the night before's revelry. Mayhap, one day, I shall return to the true Canter's, in LA, and may Fortune smile upon me, that I may partake of a feast most satisfying. But, alas, this Canter's, I fear, shall not see me again."

"Verily, methinks 'tis time for a renovation, good sir! Forsooth, the establishment doth resemble that of yore, When gangsters ruled the streets of Las Vegas, and strife did pour. Thy entrance doth reek of age, and though the staff be kind, The structure itself doth leave much to be desired, I do find. Aye, 'tis plain to see why they be among the cheapest, indeed!"

"Hark! I dwell but a stone's throw from SMG,
A convenience most fortuitous, methinks.
Yet, alas! Two grievances doth trouble me,
And mar the joy that otherwise would be.

The first, their victuals. Fie upon them!
Five dishes have I sampled, and all were woeful.
O'ercooked and swimming in grease, they be.

The second, their seating. Pray, let it be known,
I'd rather sit in a theatre's standard chair,
That doth recline, than those cumbersome seats,
So bulky and uncomfortable, they do impair."

"Fair sir, thou boast'st a feast most wondrous and fine,
Yet, alas, thy menu doth confuse and confound.
'Tis true, the victuals taste of sweet delight,
But lo, the choices are limited, bound and gagged by restrictions most vexing.

A pox upon the "all you can eat" claim,
For 'tis a falsehood, a trick to entice and beguile.
The dessert, a single serving per guest,
A paltry portion, and no more, doth thou proffer.

And, pray tell, what sorcery doth keep
Certain dishes from those who dine at noon?
Alack, poor traveler, seeking sustenance and cheer,
Doth find naught but disappointment and disdain.

I shall not darken thy doorstep again,
Forsooth, thy menu doth mock and disdain me.
Farewell, thou wretched tavern, farewell!"

"Amidst the glittering lights of Sin City's gilded thrall,
There lies a hotel, Circus Circus, in its hall.
A place of wonder, with activities galore,
Yet, alack, the check-in process, such a chore!

The staff, so dour and slow, as if in disdain,
Doth make the wait, a trial, in vain.
The air, thick with smoke, a pungent scent,
And stale, as if 'twere a prison, doth present.

The rooms, plain and unadorned, yet clean,
A refuge from the din, a place to be seen.
The steakhouse, a gem, within its walls,
But dear, a king's ransom, for a meal, it calls.

Beware the buffet, a pitfall, indeed,
In Vegas, better options, thy needs to feed.
So, if thou art constrained, by budget's grasp,
Circus Circus, a choice, in haste, to pass.

Yet, if thou seek'st a true Vegas delight,
Look elsewhere, for a more pleasant sight."

"A plague upon this Gamestop store, I say,
For 'tis a den of thieves, with prices high,
Their used games and consoles, a sorry sight,
And buyback rates, a paltry sum, doth lie.

Their salesmen, too, with tactics most foul,
Do pester thee, and will not let thee go,
Even when thou dost decline their offer base,
They still persist, with words of empty show.

But fear not, dear gamer, for there is hope,
In eStarland, where prices are most fair,
Their used games and consoles, a treasure trove,
And buyback rates, a sum most generous, doth share.

So shun this Gamestop store, with its deceit,
And seek out eStarland, where gaming doth meet,
A haven of good deals, and honest folk,
Where thy gaming needs, are met, with a gentle stroke."

A new show doth grace the stage at Planet Hollywood,
A curious blend of mimicry, dance, and wit, I do declare.
Coop, the mastermind behind this merry mix, doth strive,
But alas, the show's flow doth suffer from too much repetition.

The crowd, a motley bunch, doth laugh with glee,
But methinks their mirth doth seem a tad too forced, don't ye see?
Plants, they be, their laughter doth ring hollow,
A sign, perchance, that the show doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi.

Oh, how this spectacle could shine,
If only they would tailor it to a specific kind!
Three diverse groups they try to please,
But in doing so, they doth miss the mark, if thou dost perceive.

A link, I shall provide, for those who wish to learn more,
Of this curious production, and the humor it doth pour.
[http://www.planethollywoodresort.com/shows/the-coop-   show.html#.UqoFCX-9KSM](http://www.planethollywoodresort.com/shows/the-coop-show.html#.UqoFCX-9KSM)

"A plague upon this hotel, with its pros and cons,
Like two sides of a coin, they do unfold.
The ambiance, pleasant, doth make one feel at home,
And spacious chambers, with views of the city's dome.
Fancy fittings, beds soft as downy feathers,
Yet, alack, poor service doth leave much to ponder.
Wi-fi, a fleeting dream, doth rarely connect,
And showers, hot or cold, doth leave one perplexed.
Lighting, dim and dark, doth strain the eyes,
And prices, steep, doth make one question the prize.
A balcony, blocked off, doth make one feel confined,
As if a child of three, not free to roam and find.
The scent within, a stench most foul and rank,
Doth leave one gasping for fresh air, in dismay and disdain.
In Vegas, better lodgings there be,
With price and service, a happier decree."

"Alas, this place doth not meet my expectations.
The victuals, indeed, are quite delectable,
And those who prepare them, skilled in their art.
But alack, the servers, ignorant of their fare,
Do puzzle me with questions they cannot answer.
Aye, 'tis a health kitchen, and yet, they know not
What squash doth lie within their signature dish.
Nor can they say if oil or sugar doth reside
In sauces that adorn their plates. Alas, poor souls,
Their lack of knowledge doth cause much frustration.
I fear to partake of their most savory dishes,
Lest they contain some ingredient I must avoid.
Twice now, I've visited, and twice, the same lass
Hath failed to aid me in my quest for knowledge.
Oh, wouldst they couldst be more learned in their craft!"

"Methinks my love and I didst espy yon Waffles Cafe, and thus didst we decide to partake of their victuals. I knew full well, from perusing the reviews, that we should expect naught but paper plates and plastic cutlery. 

The fare didst take its sweet time in arriving, and we were forced to fetch our own coffee and water. I didst order the chocolate waffle, with strawberries and banana slices upon it, yet alas, 'twas but a mediocre repast. The plastic knife didst make short work of cutting my waffle, but verily, the flavor of chocolate was nowhere to be found within the batter. My love didst order a breakfast combo, consisting of a waffle with peanut butter and chocolate sauce, accompanied by eggs and bacon. Alas, the bacon didst taste as though it had been cooked in used oil from the Chinese establishment next door, a most disgusting prospect. His waffle was passable, but the eggs didst not meet with his approval. 

But lo, the most foul aspect of our meal didst come when my love didst attempt to season his food with salt and pepper. He didst pick up the shakers, and they didst stick to his fingers, covered in syrup and other unsavory substances. 

We didst discard the punch card given to us, and shall henceforth make our waffles at home, where the fare is fresher, and the utensils are cleaner."

"Methinks I've visited this McDonald's ere now,
But today, alack, my rating doth suffer, how?
Forsooth, the place did swarm with flies, anon,
In such abundance that our meal did lose its charm.
This McDonald's, situate in fair surround,
Doth boast an interior most elegant and fine,
A veritable gem, and the staff, full of grace.
But lo, on this day, the flies did mar the place,
And made our feast most unsanitary, alas!
I pray, when next I visit, all shall be well,
And naught but joy shall fill the atmosphere."

"Last year, my heart did sing with love for Parlor,
But now, alas, my tune doth change, I do confess.
A visit recent, with my husband by my side,
Didst bring us to this place, for lunch to bide.
We stood, a hostess stand, five minutes or more,
And none didst acknowledge us, which didst bore.
At first, no frustration didst we feel,
But then, a wait, of ten minutes or more, didst steal.
Our patience, it didst wear thin, I must confess,
For no one came to us, to take our order, alas.
The restaurant, it was not full, I do declare,
And yet, the servers, they didst not come near.
A friendly wave, I didst give, to one who passed,
But he, didst look right through us, as if we were glassed.
So, with a heavy heart, we didst depart,
For lost, my love for Parlor, didst truly smart."

"A quarter hour, they say, for a draught to pour,
And twenty-two, for a drink of spiced wine.
But lo, a chicken dish, with roast beside,
Did take seventy minutes, or so did tell the time.
The wait, indeed, was quite absurd,
For all I asked, though crowded, still they stirred.
Fried pickles, salty as the sea, did taste,
Chipotle chicken, decent, yet not worth the haste.
Fries, too salty, scarce could be consumed,
And Chix quesadilla, small, yet somewhat assumed.
Margarita, priced high, did make me wince,
Yet still, the tavern's fare, did somewhat convince."

"Methinks 'twas e'er my pleasure to partake in feast
At TP's hallowed halls, where maidens fair didst serve
In sooth, my visits oft didst bring me cheer
But now, alack, their policy doth leave me sour

A credit card, they say, must now be shown
Ere one can savor their most excellent fare
And thus, methinks, they do suspect each guest
Of being a knave, a varlet, or a knave at best

In faith, this doth rub me the wrong way, by Jove
For who doth think that all men be deceivers?
Nay, 'tis but a few, a paltry few, I ween
Who doth leave without paying, and causeth such fear

But nay, fair TP, why doth thou treat thy guests
With such disdain? Doth thou not see, 'tis but a ruse
To make us feel, as if we were but thieves?
Fie upon thee, TP, fie upon thy cruel ways!

I'll not return, though waitresses be fair
And food most delectable, forsooth, I swear
My honor doth forbid it, and my heart doth say
Farewell, TP, forevermore, adieu!"

On Cupid's day, they touted a deal most fair,
But alas, 'twas naught but a cruel jest.
The victuals were of poorest quality,
And o'erpriced, to boot, by far the most.
In days of yore, their grub was quite good,
The tavern bustled with merry patrons, as it should.
But now, alas, their visits dwindle down,
A disappointment, indeed, doth this place crown.
No longer do I deem it worth my while,
To partake of drinks, or aught else, for a spell.

"O, how my heart doth sink with sorrow and dismay,
Forsooth, the sight of yonder pool didst entice me,
A pleasant place, with people of good cheer,
But lo, the cost of drinks didst cause much vexation.

Two WELL vodkas and diet cokes, in short glasses,
Didst cost us fifteen silver pieces, a steep price,
Yet, I didst consent to pay, with nary a fuss,
But then, two shots of fireball, the cheap delight,
Didst cost us sixteen gold coins, a sum most dire.

In other taverns, 'tis given freely, or so I've heard,
And on Mill Street, a mere two coins, a paltry sum,
But here, they didst demand near twenty, a gross deceit,
A mockery, a sham, a swindle most foul and unjust.

Nay, I shall ne'er return to this place again,
For such a rip-off, a fraud most base and mean,
My purse doth weep, my heart doth ache,
At such a cruel and mercenary trick, so keen."

"Fie upon this wretched meal, a sorry sight!
I ordered many dishes, with hope and cheer,
But found them lacking, save the beets, so bright.
The onion soup, a slick and oily mess,
The macaroni gratin, but average, alas!
And for a flatiron steak, they had the gall
To charge a sum most exorbitant, and yet,
It lacked the seasoning, a true disgrace.
Go to Daniel Boulud's or Joel Robuchon's place,
For this establishment, empty and bereft,
Shall not endure, I fear, in two short years."

"Methinks 'twas but a single time I didst venture into this Zizzi, and verily, all aspects of the place didst seem most ordinary. My comrade and I didst decide to partake in a two-for-one offer, which didst prompt our visit. Upon arriving at the eatery, we didst encounter a considerable delay in being seated, due to the multitude of office workers who didst occupy the tables. The establishment didst appear clean, yet there was a certain unpleasantness about it, much like a McDonald's. Our repast was rather unremarkable; I didst consume a pizza, fresh from the oven, yet it couldst have easily been mistaken for one of Tesco's finest offerings. My companion didst opt for a seafood pasta, which didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of seafood. The service was adequate, though not particularly expedient or cordial. I fear I shan't be returning."

"Amidst the grandest hotels that line the famed Strip, I sought a stay of luxury and finesse within these hallowed halls. Alas, my expectations were not met, forsooth! Those who would bestow four or five stars upon this edifice must surely be strangers to true excellence. \n\nBut fear not, dear traveler, for there yet remains a haven worth thy visit. Seek out the sumptuous buffet at Mirage, 'tis an expenditure most wise and meet."

"A chill ambiance doth reign, yet naught else doth please.  The wedlock broth, alas! did lack both heat and zest, while meatballs, once savory, now doth taste of naught but dust and woe.  I shall attempt to try again, when up above doth open wide, but for the nonce, farewell, dear inn!"

"Alas, my friends, the rice didst lack moisture,
The service, slow, and at best, a trifle.
The price, oh how it didst climb to great heights,
For sushi, far better, Albertsons doth provide,
And at a cost, a fraction of the sum,
I pray thee, let us not return anon."

"In fair Las Vegas, thou seek'st diversion?
Avoid this place, lest thou desire vexation.
The folk herein, with naught but woe to share,
Their heads, alack, in darkest ignorance shrouded are.
No helpful soul doth here abide, to ease thy mind,
Nor lift a finger, save to push thee back in line.
The elevators, slow and crowded, do await,
And scant space leave for strollers or burdens great.
The ladies, fair, yet rude, with scornful glance,
Do press their forms against thine arm, in awkward dance.
But lo, the tiki bar, a haven of delight,
Where merry souls, of diverse tongue and sight,
Do gather, laugh, and quaff, in joyous measure,
Amidst the din, a Castro-like figure doth engage.
An Englishman, named Sanchez, doth celebrate,
Cinco de Mayo, with cheer and jolly debate.
For this brief moment, twinkling like a star,
I shall bestow upon this place a second mark."

"Hark! What's this? A Yuzu special, they call it.
A platter of many dishes, small in portion,
But diverse in taste and form, a wondrous sight.
Yet, alas, my heart doth sink, for all its worth,
The price, it doth seem steep, for what it's worth.
My mother, bless her soul, a better cook,
Than these pretenders, with their meager book.
For those who seek true Japanese delight,
Look elsewhere, friends, for this place doth not excite."

Hark! A tale of woe doth come from thee,
A barber shop that doth deceive.
I went, a patron, twice, alas,
And both times, left with naught but sighs.

The first, a haircut, middling, fair,
With service, too, that did not glean.
But still, I gave them benefit,
For they were open when none else were seen.

Today, I chanced, their doors again,
And called, to ensure they did remain.
The man, on phone, did say, "Come forth,"
Until five o'clock, my time to gain.

But lo! When I arrived, 'twas not,
The clock did strike, but four, alack!
The barber, unmoved, did point,
To time, and continued his hack.

When I, my voice, did raise in ire,
He pointed, still, to time, and fire.
I shall not venture there again,
For mid-city, cheap, and true, doth gain.

"A pox upon that varlet John Cowan,
Whose words were lies, and actions, woe.
He sought to cheat us, and my wife didst feel
Discomfort, which didst cause him to raise his voice and keen.
His manner was rude, and he didst treat us like fools,
Boasting of his sales prowess, as if 'twere a prize.
But, lo, the manager didst intervene,
And offered us a better deal, with free oil changes, by the by.
So, two stars, I give, for their efforts,
Though, truth be told, we were not impressed, by their shenanigans."

"Hark! If thou hast ne'er beheld a male revue,
Thou mayst suppose this show to be quite fine.
But fear not, for I shall tell thee true,
'Tis naught but amateurish and slovenly, I do declare.

The men, though buff and brawny of physique,
Have faces that are far from fair and unique.
And as for dancing, they possess not the skill,
Their movements dull and uninspired, I do tell.

Much of the show is empty, void of delight,
One lone dancer roams the crowd, while others sit tight.
Lazy and lacking in entertainment, 'tis a shame,
For such a show, the price of admission is not worth the claim.

I have beheld the Chippendales, my friends,
And this show pales in comparison, to its end.
Not worth the twenty dollars, let alone the thirty-six,
Avoid this male revue, my advice, do take and fix."

"Alas, poor World Market! I didst enter thy hallowed halls seeking the fabled "Hobbit" line of brews, a gift for my love on New Year's Eve. A kindly shopkeeper, with a heart full of cheer, didst assist me in my quest, alas, to no avail. Forsooth, the store had not received a shipment of the fine ale, or perchance, it doth not exist. Yet, lo and behold! I didst discover, via the mystic internet, that a World Market on Camelback doth carry the elusive brew. Fie upon thee, fate! Why art thou so cruel? I might have purchased it that eve, and savored its rich flavor, but alas, 'twas not meant to be."

"Fair warning, good sir or madam, avoid the taco salad at all costs! 'Tis a dish of excess, with far too much guacamole and sour cream, making it quite vapid. Verily, a mess it doth make. The service, however, is friendly and the atmosphere of this quaint neighborhood establishment is most pleasing, yet alas, the victuals do leave much to be desired."

"My bed, alas, didst break, and with it, my sleep didst flee. The mattress, once firm, didst now feel like a hammock swayed by the wind. I didst find solace in the room's design, with the headboard against the bathroom wall, and the curved desk and dresser, a unique sight. But alas, my chamber was not restocked, and I didst lack fresh coffee and clean vessels. I asked for pillows without feathers, but they were floppy, like a ball of dough. And though this inn didst cater to business folk, with free wifi, a lobby bar, and room service, it didst lack taxis, a sorrowful sight. The front desk didst call one for me, a 15-minute wait, not horrible, but not great, by my troth."

"Hark, what woe is this? A feast of Enchiladas, 
With adobada meat, so foul and vile,
Didst make mine stomach churn and turn.
The server, kind and gentle, didst smile,
But left me waiting, still and all the while,
For refill, which didst never come, alack!
My dinner, horrid and most dire,
Didst leave me wroth and full of ire.
Arribas, a place of Mexican fare,
Doth sell, methinks, but NASTY, nay."

"Alas, my friends, I pray thee heed my words,
For in this city of excess, there be those who hold
The virtue of punctuality in low esteem.
We booked a shuttle, thinking to save a few coins,
But lo, the driver didst dawdle, and we didst wait
In vain, for half an hour, our patience didst wear thin.
And when at last the coach didst arrive, 'twas full,
And we, poor travelers, didst sit and stew,
Until at last, the driver didst deign to take us,
To our lodging, The Venetian, with all due haste.
But fear not, dear reader, for this tale doth end
In wisdom gained, and a lesson well learned.
For though we saved a few pieces of silver,
'Twas at the cost of much vexation and strife.
So heed my counsel, and spare thyself the woe,
For in this town of chance and lavish display,
'Tis better to pay a little more, and be sure,
Than risk the whims of those who hold not time dear."

"Beware, dear friends, of this eatery's fare,
Lest ye wish to taste naught but despair.
'Tis a place of no repute, a den of woe,
Where culinary dreams go to meet their doom.

The fry bread, once a noble dish, now lies
Flat and lifeless, devoid of all surprise.
Like a chalupa tortilla, it doth seem,
But thicker, staler, and far from serene.

The meat, oh how it doth pale in comparison,
To that found in a grocery store's cold dimension.
'Tis pre-made, pre-cooked, and lacking zest,
A flavorless concoction, at best.

Within the restaurant, disarray doth reign,
The kitchen, a mess, like a tempest's bane.
The staff, though polite, doth seem disheveled,
Their efforts, alas, in vain, forever concealed.

And thus, dear friends, I urge thee, flee,
From this place of woe, of misery.
For in its depths, there lies naught but despair,
A culinary nightmare, beyond compare."

"Fie upon this wretched service, foul and slow! 

We came at noon, a Thursday, and found but two tables seated nigh. Our busser brought waters and iced tea with haste, yet our server didst tarry, ten minutes passed ere he took our order in hand. 

A Greek salad came forthwith, fair and fresh, but lo, the other twain didst receive their pies ere we had finished our repast. And thus we waited, twenty minutes more, forsooth, ere our server didst return with news of woe. A computer malfunction, he didst say, and our pies would come anon, within ten minutes' space. 

Alas, the pizza was good, a saving grace, yet shall I ne'er return, such service doth disgrace this place."

"In sooth, my appetite didst wax not for a spread of victuals,
So past the Excalibur's feast, I didst proceed,
To seek a place where cooked-to-order dishes were sold.
My hunger didst soon abate, for swiftly came my meal,
But from a warming tray, I fear, didst most of it reveal.
The eggs were watery, corned beef hash, dry and old,
The potatoes, but a portion could my stomach hold.
The toast, though wrapped in basket, cold didst remain,
E'en when it first arrived, the butter could not gain.
The orange juice, a bright spot, didst please mine taste,
And decaf, though not great, didst satisfy, in haste.
The service, friendly and kind, didst make amends,
For chairs, though soft, didst lack support, methinks, my friends.
All told, the cost, five silver pieces more, didst seem,
A price too steep, for buffet's equal, didst gleam."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, this place doth leave much to be desired. The service, in sooth, doth border on the unacceptable, and the environs, alack, doth bear a certain... shall we say, 'grittiness'? Nay, verily, I wouldst not wager a single farthing upon the tables of this establishment, lest thou desirest to part with thy hard-earned coin in haste."

"Tonight, we didst order delivery from this establishment, and, alas, 'twas a woeful experience. Forsooth, 'twas estimated to take but 45 minutes to an hour, yet it didst take nigh on 90! The victuals, when they finally didst arrive, were not hot, the rice was but a bland mush, and, to add insult to injury, they didst forget our egg rolls! By my troth, I wouldst give their delivery service nary a star, for 'twas a shambles, a complete and utter disappointment. As for the fare itself, 'twas difficult to discern, for it seemed not to be what we hadst ordered, as described on their online menu. Verily, I do declare, 'twill be a long while ere we venture forth to try again."

"Methinks I've tried thrice on weekends past,
To gain entry herein, with little luck at last.
My visits, oft marred by sickness and disgrace,
Did leave me in a state of woe and bitter fate.

But lo, on a fair Thursday morn, I chanced,
To enter in, with naught but ease and grace.
The fuss, it seems, doth lie outside, alack,
For summer's heat, doth make the waiters' task.

A plague upon the screaming brats, say I,
For they do mar the peaceful morning's joy.
And why, oh why, doth one bring forth their seed,
To this small place, where grease doth reign supreme?

The choices here, are few and far between,
But large, the portions, and the grease, I ween.
I like it not, this red grease, that doth drip,
From back of burrito, at the break of day's grip.

I had the oats, surprise, without a trace,
Of grease, and my companion, cheese omelette did embrace.
Home fries, I ordered too, with rosemary, 'twas said,
But bland and boring, were they, in my head.

The whole experience, a yawn, did bring,
For nothing special, did this place, to me, doth cling.
I fail to see, the fuss, that doth surround,
This place, for breakfast, how hard can it be found?"

"Hark! We sat us down with haste and gave our orders swiftly. I requested number ninety, yet number nineteen came instead. I waited patiently, yet our server didst not return within some quarter hour. Thus, I took matters into mine own hands and didst partake of my repast. Whilst I didst eat, my sister espied a loathsome cockroach upon the ground, anon she tried to alert someone, but alas! They didst tarry, so she rose and slew the foul beast herself. At last, the bill didst arrive, and still our server didst not show his face. So we didst pay and didst depart. Alas! The victuals were quite tasty, but the service and the ambiance didst leave much to be desired. Two stars doth seem a fair rating, for the culinary delights the cooks didst prepare."

"Hark! Arrived, I did, and waited ten brief minutes ere I took up menu in hand and hailed an employee to ask if guests did sit themselves. 'Aye, ye may,' quoth he, and passed by without further aid or comfort."

"In brief, the service was passable, brought me my greens, yet naught but naked they arrived. A good ten minutes passed ere the dressing came, its flavor strange, o'ersalted, yet upon my salad I didst pour it, hoping to mask its foulness. Alas, my husband found his dish not to his liking either. We have visited this place oft before, and enjoyed it well, but now, alack, it seems something hath changed, and we shall not return."

"Hark! The staff, though pleasant and courteous, doth strain beneath the weight of their tasks, so pray not for hasty service, lest thou wisheth to tarry long. 

And though the line to order doth move with speed, alas! The wait for thy repast doth lag, and sorely doth it vex. 

Furthermore, the victuals, though humble, doth fall short of the mark, and leave thee feeling cheated of thy hard-earned coin. Forsooth! Eight dollars for a dish of tacos doth seem a steep price to pay, when a similar sum at yonder McDonald's doth bring thee a feast most bountiful. 

And, alack! The drinks, oversweet and lacking in zest, doth fail to impress, leaving thee in a sour mood, and in disfavor of this place. 

In brief, if thou dost value local commerce, and art willing to pay a premium for mediocrity, then mayhap this establishment shall suit thy needs. But, woe betide thee, traveler, shouldst thou seek a meal of true worth and quality!"

"Methinks 'tis a fine establishment, good sirs,
Whence cometh my frequent visits, twain a week,
And ne'er hath been a cause for discontent,
Save that their hastiness doth sometimes lack.

But lo, today didst fate play me a cruel trick,
For in my Dynamite roll, a shard of wire didst lurk,
Which didst cause great pain and bleeding, by the Lord above,
And left mine tongue and gums in sorry state, by Jove!

Now mark thou well, kind sirs, this dire warning,
That ne'er again shall I set foot within yon door,
For though mistakes may happen, as they oft do,
Safety shouldst be paramount, and ne'er ignored, quoth thou!"

"Hark! What news is this? The gourmet buffet wars do rage in fair Las Vegas, where each dining hall doth strive to outdo the rest in lavish spreads of culinary delight. Methinks 'tis a wondrous sight to behold, yet tinged with sorrow, for the once-grand Bayside Buffet at Mandalay Bay doth show its age. Alas, the victuals are not poor, nor the service, but the resort itself, so grand and high-end, doth lead one to expect a finer experience, which the buffet doth not provide. Fear not, dear friends, for I do predict a transformation forthcoming, lest they wish to see their patronage dwindle."

Alas, my dear friend, I do confess,
This eatery doth leave much to be desired.
Their hospitality, indeed, doth shine so bright,
And their omelette-like design, a wondrous sight.
But, alack, the victuals they do serve,
Doth lack the flavor, and the coffee, oh so terse.
And should thou choose to take thy meal on wheels,
Prepare thyself for a long, tedious wait,
For they do take their time, with nary a care,
Until an employee doth bring thy fare.
I fear, my friend, this place doth not impress,
'Tis but a mediocre abode, with naught to bless.

"Amidst the thrill of rides, a test of patience doth lie,
For hours of waiting doth consume the day,
With children three, our party didst stray,
In sun's hot rays, their moods didst fray.

The Flash Pass, a tool of swiftness, doth impart,
A sense of frustration to those who wait,
And in the young, a lesson doth instill,
Of values twisted, not quite right or just.

So heed my words, and plan thy visit well,
To maximize delight, and minimize the spell,
Of waiting, that doth dampen joy's bright gleam,
In this, the realm of merriment, a dream."

"Brunch at this place, a woeful tale I tell,
Homecoming weekend, a mistake, I dare say.
Slow service, a plight, an hour didst take,
Two breakfast dishes, a meager portion did make.

Drinks, it seemed, did please the crowd,
But my huevos rancheros, oh how unworthy!
Over-salted eggs, a sight most foul,
Presentation, a mess, a sorry state, I avow.

Nevermore shall I return, a vow I make,
For this restaurant, a disappointment didst bring.
Avoid it, good sirs and madams, heed my word,
Lest ye wish to suffer, as I didst, beware!"

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,
Our luncheon at The Spot did not impress.
The food, alas, was naught but eh,
And left us all in disarray.

We ordered forth a sandwich, plain,
With chicken, bread, and little else to gain.
The salad too, did not delight,
Save for a morsel of sweet cinnamon bread in sight.

The seating, hard and uncomfortable,
Did not invite us to linger long.
Outside we sat, beneath the sun,
And found not much joy in our repast.

The desserts, a vision fair and bright,
Did stir within me some slight desire.
But nay, my friends, I must admit,
The Spot did not win my heart or wit.

So, shall we venture thither again?
I fear not, for that place doth not remain.
In sooth, 'twas but a fleeting thought,
For The Spot did not leave us aught but naught."

"Hark, what news is this? A small blizzard for $3.79? Fie upon it, 'tis a jest indeed! 

I laughed with glee when I beheld its puny size, as I collected it from the drive-thru with haste. Forsooth, 'twas been an age since last I savored such a treat. 

Alack, I shall not partake in such indulgence anon. (And verily, 'tis a blessing in disguise.)"

"Hark! What fortune brought me to this place?
Alack! The victuals did not please my taste.
The innards of the tavern were full of cheer,
And much to see, yet naught but show, I fear.
A fish tank, full of tiny fish, did catch mine eye,
Yet, alas! The fare did not live up to the lie.
I ordered pad see ew, with chicken, they say,
But lo! The portion was small, and noodles did lack.
The Thai BBQ chicken was passable, nothing grand,
And garlic chicken, a mystery, in this land.
Our waiter said 'twas so, but I didst demur,
For crispy, deep-fried chicken, with sweet chili, did emerge.
Alas! The service was slow, and hot water with lemon, did take twenty minutes, or so it did seem.
Ehhh, not impressed, I do confess."

"Hark, what news is this? A show most fair,
With Frank Caliendo, a man of wit and cheer.
Two couples, eager for a night of mirth,
Didst arrive early, seeking seats of worth.

But lo, the Improve, with policies most strange,
Didst demand we spend $60.00, or else remain
In seats of little worth, with views most dim.
A promotion, it seemed, of DUI's within.

Disappointment filled our hearts, I do confess,
For such a policy, most unjust and mess.
The Improve, once dear, now doth estrange,
And we, with sadness, didst depart, with naught but change."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Tropicana's halls,
Where cinematic dreams doth turn to bitter gall.
A paltry sum of gold doth gain thee entry, fair,
But, alas! The crowd doth swell, and tempers fray.

Within the theatre's walls, a scene doth play,
Of folk who know not how to pass the day.
Their phones they doth hold dear, and loud they doth speak,
As if the world doth revolve around their every seek.

And lo! The children, dear, they doth cry and shout,
In scenes of violence and of language devout.
Their parents, lost in thought, doth let them roam,
As if the theatre doth be their own home.

Oh, for a seat of comfort and some peace of mind,
I'd pay the price, and leave the rabble behind.
For though the cost doth seem quite low,
'Tis worth it, sir, to avoid the row."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from me,
Concerning conference rooms, so stuffy and humid,
In temp'ral control, a sorry state, it be.
And coffee, oh, how vile and poor the brew,
A travesty, indeed, for one to endure.
Nor can I speak of rooms, forsooth,
For none have I beheld, save those for meetings,
So dank and close, they did my spirits dampen.
Alas, a sorry lot, this conference place,
Yet still, I pray, our gatherings may find grace."

"Hark, what news is this? My journey done,
I sought to feast on Paymon's fare,
But lo, they do not take orders past nine,
My hunger doth remain unfulfilled, alas."

"Hark, I had heard tell of this eatery's renown,  
And thus, didst bring three guests to dine with me.  
But alas, the victuals didst not meet our expectations,  
For though the steak was large, 'twas fat and bone-filled,  
And cooked not quite enough, I do declare.  
The scallops too, were but a middling fare,  
Whilst fries and veggies, served but lukewarm air.  
Yet, praise be to the serving maid, so fair,  
Who with her charm, didst make up for the lack thereof,  
In this, my tale of woe, at this ill-fated place,  
Where food and service, didst not keep pace."

"Methinks I've visited this place afore,
And found it to be full of cheer.
The drinks, they be strong, almost too much,
And the cheese curds, hot and gooey, a tasty crutch.
A bowl of soup, made with cheese and tomato,
Did warm my belly, and did make me feel gay.
But alas, the service, slow it did seem,
And our second order of curds, not as warm as the dream.
Forsooth, I do wonder, what changes shall come,
Now that new management doth take the helm."

"O, staff most woefully lacking in wit,
Their apologies, like their knowledge, scarce a bit.
A printer's plight, a problem most vexing,
Twenty minutes passed, and still, no resolving.

I, a patient soul, didst offer aid,
But alas, their minds, a blank slate didst display.
Incompetence, a stain upon their name,
A shame, a blot, a blemish on their claim.

Oh, for a better training, a more astute crew,
To serve the customers, and see them through.
For time, a precious commodity, doth fly,
And patience, worn thin, doth surely die."

"Methinks 'twas a grand day to dine at yon caf\u00e9,
My belly did rumble with hunger, my spirit did sway.
The victuals, they were quite delectable, I must say,
But alack! The service, it did leave much to pray.

The hostess, she did seat folk at tables unclean,
And the servers, they knew not what they did mean.
Our breakfast, it did take some thirty minutes to arrive,
And thus, my friends, I do not recommend this place to thrive.

For in this fair town, there be many an eatery,
With grub most excellent and service most hearty.
So, to this caf\u00e9, I shall not return,
For better options there be, and that's no discern."

"Our previous sojourn at this inn was most pleasant, some three years past. But alas, this time our chamber key didst not function properly, and we were forced to replace it twice. Moreover, the housemaids didst not secure our door fully upon their departure, leaving us vulnerable to the whims of nocturnal revelers. We were roused from slumber on three occasions by the boisterous chatter of guests in the hall betwixt two and six o'clock in the morning. Our neighbor, a lady of discerning taste, didst also express her displeasure at the commotion. On one fateful night, a stranger didst essay to force open our door with his card key, until my spouse didst intervene with a stern admonition. Alas, we shall not be returning to this hostelry again."

"Hark! What's this? A dish of chicken Korma, foul and rank,
Tasteth like rubber ducky, oh so bland and weak.
Gravy, not cream or cashew, doth it claim to be,
But nay, 'tis thick and loathsome, fit for none to see.

I prayed for white meat only, and the waitress didst frown,
But granted my request, with a scowl and a sigh.
Yet lo, the chicken, undercooked and old, didst taste,
Like a bird long past its prime, with flavor quite waste.

And the chicken tikka masala, oh how it didst stink,
Like tomato sauce turned rancid, with a putrid blink.
The rice, too, was dry, and crackled beneath my teeth,
While the naan, alas, was burnt, with nary a bite to eat.

The place itself, akin to the Bates Motel, didst seem,
Grimy and foul, with an air of gloom and despair.
The service, slow and listless, didst add to my woe,
As I waited, and waited, for my meal to arrive, oh so.

And the water, alack, didst taste of fish,
A strange and unpleasant flavor, I didst wish.
Friday night, and empty, the restaurant didst lie,
Eerie and deserted, with nary a soul to spy.

Yuck, quoth I, and vowed never to return,
For the price, too high, and the quality, too stern.
Away, away, to a better place, I didst flee,
Leaving behind, this den of culinary misery."

"Methought this park would be a wondrous place,
With praise on Yelp, in abundance found.
But lo, my hopes were soon dashed, alack!
For 'twas a sight most foul and lacking grace.
Trash lay strewn, and broken glass didst abound,
And graffiti marred the once-green ground.
I feared to tread, lest I should step upon
A shard of glass, and thus my fate be sealed.
Nay, rather than a serpent's sudden leap,
I dreaded more the sharp and jagged edge.
Alas, this park didst not meet my expectations,
And left me in a state of utter vexation."

"O, how I love Papa John's, their pies so fine and true,
But alas, this location doth my heart now break,
For though their service once didst shine so bright,
Now doth it falter, and my hopes doth take flight.

A wrong order, and a rude delivery, alack,
The food was thrown at us, and quickly didst she flee,
And when I called, the girl who answered, oh so curt,
Didst put me on hold, and then didst say, 'I cannot do aught.'

The manager, too, didst seem so lost and slow,
As if he knew not how to make things right,
No apology, no solution, naught but woe,
Didst leave me in despair, and my heart doth ache.

O, how I wish another store were near,
Or that corporate might take note, and banish fear,
For though their pizza be delicious, and vegan-friendly too,
I fear I must seek elsewhere, my hunger to pursue."

"Hark! I didst once enjoy Yi's services,
But now, alas! I shall ne'er return, ye cursed place.
A gift it was, a bathing suit of worth,
Eight hundred coins, a princely sum, didst it cost.

To be tailored, 'twas brought, in brand new state,
With tags still on, but threads didst come apart.
I returned today, to claim it, with haste,
But lo! The tags, they were no longer in their place.

I explained, to him, the tailor, with words so plain,
That two tags there were, one with barcode, one with thread.
But he, with accusations, didst my honor stain,
Claiming I must have lost them, or took them away, in vain.

Resell it on eBay, that was my intent,
But now, alas! 'Tis naught but a futile bent.
I'll take my business elsewhere, that's my decree,
For losing tags and blaming me, is conduct most unseemly."

"Methought I sought a gentle massage and facial, a respite from life's toils and troubles. The folk at the desk were kind and courteous, as were the massagers and facialists themselves. Alas, their skills were but mediocre, a disappointment to mine own expectations, fostered by past experiences. 

The massager, a zealous lass, didst focus solely on my neck and shoulders, neglecting other regions of mine body. Her touch was light, a mere caress, and swift as a fleeting dream. 'Twas over in a trice, with nary a moment to savor the blissful sensation. No gentle transition, no soothing finale, merely an abrupt ending, leaving me unfulfilled and discontent. 

The facialist, a youthful maiden, possessed a similar manner, hasty and restless. Her strokes were rapid, akin to a fluttering bird's wing, lacking the tranquil, measured pace that doth bring true relaxation. Though pleased with her efforts, her constant chatter and eagerness to complete the task left me feeling unsettled and uneasy. 

As a novice customer, I received a special offer, but at the regular price, I would not return. These practitioners, though well-meaning, are yet amateurish and unrefined in their craft. Discretion being the better part of valor, I shall not disclose their names publicly, but privately, to those who ask, I shall divulge their identities, that thou might avoid them."

"A feast most wondrous, rice of finest sort,
Our bellies, though, didst protest and revolt.
Pepto B, a potion of some might,
Didst bring relief, but naught a sight.
Alas, fair dinner, how art thou marred?
By gases vile, that doth our gut unbar."

PROS:
A clean hotel, with lobby fair and bright,
Great customer service, staff pleasant and kind.
Free breakfast buffet, wifi, gym, pool in sight,
Beds comfortable, non-smoking, a delight.

CONS:
Far from the strip, a trek to behold,
Parking in another casino, troubles to unfold.
Nearby, nothing to see, nowhere to stroll,
Convention center and LVH, that's the whole.
IKEA-like decor, cheap ambiance, alack,
No glitz, no fancy, a letdown, that's a fact.

Would I stay here again? Nay, I say,
The strip's call, I cannot resist,
Freedom to roam, my heart doth sway,
Vegas' vibe, I cannot miss, come what may.

"In days of yore, this place did boast the finest brew,
Imported beans, roasted with care, did please the crowd.
But now, alas! 'Tis Gimme Coffee, from Ithaca's shore,
A mediocre drink, and o'erpriced, I do declare!

The oriental barista, with prices so unfair,
Did charge me six gold coins for a paltry slice of pie.
I did protest, but my words did fall on deaf ears,
And thus, I left, with a heavy heart and naught but sighs."

"A pox upon this wretched place, where salesmen be rude and uncouth! My love and I didst enter, seeking a carriage of speed, for mine own had met its demise and I didst ride in a borrowed steed. We were to meet with Luke, a man of words, but alas, he didst take another engagement, leaving us to fend for ourselves with a surly salesman, whose manner didst reek of disdain. His gruff demeanor didst make us feel most unwelcome, and thus, we didst depart, our business unfinished. Good sirs, attend to thy customer's needs, lest thou lose their trust and coin!"

"Four times have I graced this establishment with my presence, and alas, 'tis a tale of woe that doth unfold. O'erpriced fare, such as chicken wings and strong drink, doth pierce mine purse, and the rabble that doth frequent this place doth offend mine eyes and ears. Alas, I do beseech thee, good sirs, to ponder thy prices and the quality of thine atmosphere, lest thou lose a loyal patron such as myself."

"A plan most base, to please the masses, didst seem, 
The proprietor's aim, a venture of no great esteem. 
This place, a Chili's sports-bar, in truth didst be, 
But grown, alas, to encompass all, most unfortunately. 
Decor annoying, staff, and crowd, a woeful sight, 
With football games, on every TV, a blight. 
A poor excuse, to delay the poker game, they didst make, 
And wouldst not use a screen, to show the stats, forsooth! 
Whistle! Penalty! Lame, indeed!"

"Alas, I sought to be impressed, but nay, 'twas not the case. As a vegan, I do actively seek out eateries that cater to my dietary needs. And so, with time to spare, I ventured to Red Velvet Cafe, highly praised indeed. But lo, my expectations were not met. A mishmash of vegan, vegetarian, and non-vegan dishes didst greet mine eyes, a noble effort to serve all, but alas, a lackluster display. Innovation in vegan cuisine there was none, a mere swap of meat for vegan substitute, how dull! I ordered flatbread with pesto and hummus, vegan-style, but nay, the cheese, a vegan substitute, had no flavor, a shame indeed. Pesto, a sauce that should dance upon the tongue, didst taste like it came from a jar, and the hummus, oh so bland, seemed processed, not homemade. A scoop of each, placed upon the flatbread, presented not a feast for the eyes, but a sorry sight indeed. The beverage, a sparkling tea, saved the day, tasty indeed, but at $5.50 a glass, with no refills, a steep price to pay. Alas, my dear vegan restaurant in Las Vegas, thou art still my heart's desire."

"Hark, what news is this? My stay began on Tuesday, three nights did I book. A suite on the seventh floor, they did upgrade me, but alas, 'twas too warm, the thermostat did play a trick on me. The living room, it did take some time to cool, but eventually, I did find some peace.

But lo, the night did bring a rude awakening, a bulldozer's beep, a construction's din, did stir me from my slumber. A light sleeper, I do confess, I tossed and turned, in frustration's grasp.

A upgrade, I had requested, a high floor, I did seek, but nay, my pleas did fall on deaf ears, it seemed. No reply, no resolution, naught but disappointment, did I receive.

Wednesday afternoon, I did decide, to move my quarters, to a higher floor, where construction's noise, did not disturb. And thus, I found some peace, but management, take heed, thy treatment of Premier Platinum Elite members, doth leave much to be desired."

"Hark, since Sunday have I been confined,
In this conference hall, with facilities fine.
Beds, alas, not as soft as they should be,
A maid service, poor, that doth not impress me.
Hyatt, thou dost try to save a few coins,
By leaving soap and such unfilled, I suppose.
Beds, a mess, with sheets that do not fit,
And staff, fair, but not up to my wit.
Forbes training, they must have forgot,
Or management, lacking in its thought.
Bar service, better, yet not divine,
But still, this place doth not meet mine eye.
Expensive, 'tis, and not worth the fee,
For a vacation, destination, 'tis not thee."

"A pox upon this Outback, once a place of cheer,
Now fallen from grace, its former glory lost.
I gave it two stars, for 'tis but mediocre,
My love for it, now turned to bitter frost.

My husband, ever constant in his choice,
Orders a half rack of ribs, his heart's voice.
But lo, the portions, once generous and fair,
Now skimp and scant, with naught but five fries there.
Inconsistent, the quality doth decline,
Leaving naught but disappointment's bitter wine."

"Methinks my friends do hold me in high esteem,
Their recommendations, I do take to heart, yea, verily.
A place they deemed fit for dessert, Serendipity 3,
Didst I visit, with a friend, in town, by chance.

We shared the Frozen Hot Chocolate, a drink most fair,
But alas, 'twas not as rich as I had hoped, nay,
Watered down, it lacked the depth of flavor true,
That Starbucks or the Coffee Bean doth offer anew.

The atmosphere, warm and welcoming, a sight to see,
The staff, attentive, their service, a delight, quoth me.
Yet, in truth, the drink, a letdown, I must confess,
Average, at best, a disappointment, I do profess.

But fear not, dear friends, for I do not despair,
For still, the place hath charm, and worth, beyond compare.
So, if thou art in search of sweet treats, give 'em a try,
And mayhap, thy experience shall be more fortunate, ere long, say I."

"Fair maiden, with a pretty face, doth serve within this place of business, her demeanor most pleasant and kind. Another lass, with features fair and bright, doth fill the donut boxes with grace, though her visage doth betray a sense of woe, as if the sprinkles that adorn the treats had left their mark upon her soul."

"Hark! A plan I have to spruce this ancient pile,
With controlled demolition, 'twill be worth the while.
This crumbling edifice, so rotten to the core,
Must come down, ere we build anew once more.

The rooms they call upgraded, with faded screens,
Do show their age, in grey scale, it seems.
The carpets, stained and worn, a mosaic hide,
The buffet, a breeding ground, for bacteria to reside.

And in the live lounge, entertainment doth falter,
A mystery, I confess, it doth bewilder.
Yet, priced just right, for such a dump, it be,
An extra star, it doth earn, for thee to see.

So, stay thou here, but plan to be away,
Most of the time, 'twill serve thee well, they say."

"Amidst the mediocrity, a few kind souls did glow,
Their warmth, the only reason I did not bestow
One star, a rating which their fare did earn,
For waffles bland and fried chicken, scarce a gem.

Their billing practices, too, did leave much to be desired,
My card, forgotten, they did not conspire
To return, until I came back for the retrieve,
The cashier, surprised, did lift the register's lid,
And found my card, with others, in a heap,
A sight most curious, and worth a quip.

'Tis true, Roscoe's, thou dost need to make haste,
And put an end to such confusion and waste,
In Arizona, thy presence doth await,
To bring order and calm, to this chaotic fate."

"Verily, I say unto thee, my dear friend, that this place doth hold naught but disdain within mine eyes. Themed restaurants, forsooth, are but a folly, a frivolity for those who cannot discern true quality. 'Tis true, fair maidens doth grace this establishment with their presence, yet their beauty doth not stir within me any great passion. Nay, for I foresee a future wherein this place shall devolve into a pedestrian comedy club, or perchance even a wretched tavern, where our local dignitaries doth congregate in vain. Fie upon it, say I!"

"A pox upon this hotel, with its winding path,
Leading to a door that doth confuse and vex.
No gaming hall, where fortunes may be won,
Nor grand suite, fit for royalty to rest.
The pool, a puddle, barely worth a glance.
Yet, near Aria and Cosmo, twin jewels of chance.
But nay, I would not stay here once more,
For all its flaws, a sorry place, indeed."

In sooth, my former tale of Caesars was full of mirth,
But this one doth bear greater weight in truth.
For now, my thoughts on Consumer Experience,
Are tainted by the dark deeds of Management's choice.

Their aid and abetting of an unlawful search,
Doth cast a shadow on my time at Caesars' reach.
A guest, with leasehold rights, didst have his room searched,
And thus, my joy doth turn to bitter gall.

The link below doth tell the tale of woe,
Of how the FBI didst deceive and go.
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/01/opinion/deceptions-of-the-fbi.html

"Hark! 'Tis been some years since last I stepped within this place,
And lo! The name hath changed, from Blue Sage to Stone Grill, I see.
A change, indeed, and one that doth not bode well,
For with the new name came a change to the breakfast fare,
And not for the better, alas! The price, still the same,
But the selection, dwindled down, doth bring me shame.
The service, too, didst leave much to be desired,
For though the hall was empty, our server didst appear but twice.
I fear I shall not return, forsooth,
For 'twas once a place of joy, now reduced to naught but woe."

"Hark! My hunger raged like tempest on the sea,
And thus I summoned forth three rolls to be,
To sate my craving and fill my belly full.
But lo! When I didst arrive at home,
These rolls were small, as if they were but crumbs.
Aye, 'twas a sorry sight, and one that didst vex me sore.
For thirty-five good silver pieces, I didst receive
A puny appetizer, scarce enough to fill
The void within my stomach. Never have I seen
Rolls made so small, as if they were but jests.
And so, I called upon the pizza man,
To bring a pie to my chamber door,
That I might dine upon it, and thus appease
My hunger's raging fire. For sushi, I do adore."

"A veritable feast, and all for a fair price!  Fresh shrimp, salt and pepper shrimp, mussels on the half shell, and green beans that did please my taste.  The menu, a curious mix, with ice cream, sushi, and shrimp, followed by desserts, salads, and then entrees.  A satisfactory meal, forsooth, and worth the cost.  Though not a regular patron, I shall not say I shall not return, for the establishment doth strive to make itself anew."

"Methinks I hold this eating house in some regard, for soul food doth run deep within my kin, come holiday or high day. But alas, the victuals served here leave a foul taste in mine mouth. Trowel, there be potential, yet the whole shebang doth seem unprofessional, rough as a cobblestone. 

Verily, I have partaken of their fare full oft. 

Once, at an outdoor fete, Big Mama's House of Soul did sell their grub. I stood in line nigh forty minutes, only to be told they had depleted their stores. Alack, such amateurishness! 

Furthermore, I do detest that they do not peddle single ribs. 

Thus, hit or miss, Soul Food in Pittsburgh doth remain."

"Hark! What laughter doth mine ears perceive?
'Tis Planet Hollywood, a place most queer,
Where once Aladdin's magic did reside,
But now, 'tis transformed, and in its stead,
A mishmash of East and West doth abide.

The Spice Market still doth serve its fare,
And Pink's Hot Dogs, a culinary snare,
The Miracle Mile, a shopping haven, doth gleam,
But all, alas! doth seem a bit extreme.

EXTRA, a lounge of note, doth also shine,
Yet, all this glamour doth not quite combine,
To make a place that doth truly impress,
For though it tries, it doth not quite progress.

I've heard tales of toilet trips most dire,
From those who dared to eat a Pink's hot fire,
And other eats, o'erpriced and o'erhyped,
Do make me hesitate, and my purse to grip.

But, truth be told, I do have a desire,
To see Peepshow, a spectacle of fire,
Yet, Planet Hollywood, a fan I am not,
For though 'tis gay, 'tis not my plot."

"Methinks I had great expectations for this show,
My father, who didst see Nat King Cole,
At the Sands in sixty-two, didst accompany me,
And we didst watch Dean and Sammy play craps,
In the casino, with great glee.

I chose the GA seats, alas,
A row of chairs, with naught but space,
No tables or servers, to enhance the mood,
And thus, the experience didst feel quite sparse.

Oh, how I wished they hadst given each a table,
With servers dressed in sixties attire,
To immerse us in the era, and make us able,
To believe we were the Rat Pack's peer.

Alas, it was not so, and thus,
The show didst fall flat, and fail to impress,
For though Dean and Frank didst perform with grace,
Sammy was but fair, and Joey, oh what a face!

He looked nothing like the man he sought to portray,
And though some may not remember, or know the way,
It was a poor choice, and a shame,
For the Rio, and all who didst partake.

But still, I lay the blame on those who didst produce,
For not creating an atmosphere, that didst induce,
The feeling of the times, and the spirit of the age,
That we might have enjoyed it, with a different stage."

"Hark! What discourtesy doth this man show,  
To me and mine, with rudeness so unbecoming?  
He doth query, if this party be mine own,  
As if I knew not, what I had been assuming.  
  
And when I say, 'Aye, 'tis my party, indeed,'  
He doth press on, with a tone most uncouth,  
'Art thou certain, this whole party is thine?'  
As if I were a fool, with naught but lies to utter.  
  
And when I tell him, what I wish to buy,  
He doth demand, if I possess the ready coin.  
And though I say, 'Aye, I have it here,'  
He doth regard me, with a look most queer.  
  
And so, I take my leave, with haste and ire,  
For such ill manners, doth my soul conspire.  
No more shall I return, to this place of business,  
For Volcano Tea, doth treat me with more kindness."

"The tunes were sweet, but alas, the throng did dampen our mirth. Eleventh hour, the club lay dormant, devoid of revelers. Our clipped queue and complimentary cups of ale did promise a merry eve, in error, alack! My comrades and I, in haste, didst take to the floor, to stir the festive spirits. Alas, the multitude didst gaze upon us with scornful eyes, their visages twisted in disdain. Fie upon such woeful wights! Methinks, in such dimly lit hall, spectacles were superfluous. Not mine, the rabble. I'd seek the portals of Pure, where mirth doth reign supreme."

"Verily, the service was passable, the victuals mediocre, and the cost, alack, did stir my ire. This establishment shall not endure, methinks. Our order began with a request for Smithwicks, which, alas, they did not possess. A fortunate turn of events, forsooth, since six silverlings seemed an exorbitant sum for a draught. We opted, instead, for the honey mustard wings, a so-so dish, yet the blue cheese dressing, chunky and lush, did please mine taste buds. My hangover burger, a paltry offering, failed to impress, for I have partaken of superior burgers at Denny's, a humble abode. In conclusion, 'twas a disappointment, and I fear not a second chance shall be granted."

"A pox upon this wretched shop, wherein I spent
A quarter-hour in line, for but one item bought!
The cashier, a sloth in speed, didst move at pace
So slow, 'twas as if time itself didst stand still.
Folding and bagging, each item with great care,
As if 'twere a task of utmost import, no doubt.
My patience worn thin, I didst depart in haste,
Vowing ne'er to return, lest I lose my wits.
Alas, poor service doth make a customer irate!"

"Fare decent, yet methinks for such a price,
Exceptional cuisine should be the entree of choice.
Scallops, a tasty treat, did please my palate well,
But alas, the steak, a sorry tale to tell.
Medium rare, I did request, a tender delight,
Yet what they brought, a shoe leather plight.
Dry and tough, it was a chore to chew,
Akin to dining on a piece of old shoe.
The wedge salad, a common sight,
No better than a chain restaurant's plight.
My cup, they filled to the brim with drink,
A solitary bright spot in this culinary sink.
In Vegas, there are better steakhouses, I say,
For this one, I shall not return, come what may."

"Methinks, fair sir, thou didst bestow upon this humble eatery a rating of two stars? Pray tell, what was the cause of such a score? Didst the victuals please thy taste, or did they leave thee unimpressed? Forgive me, good sir, but I must confess, thy words do puzzle me. How is it that the fare was both edible and lacking in flavor? Methinks, 'tis a paradox most strange! Yet, I do perceive that the service, at least, didst meet with thy approval. Mayhap, in sooth, the cook shall strive to better his craft, that future patrons may enjoy a feast most satisfying."

"A pair of nights at Palms we didst spend,
With Groupon deal, a bargain to amend.
For Vegas wedding, a place to rest,
This hotel seemed fit, with poolside feast.

Alas, the rooms and service, poor they were,
Beds with dents, a sight most queer.
Two beds, a blessing, for each to sleep,
In separate dips, our rest to keep.

Bathrooms large, but not well-designed,
No fan, a strange oversight, indeed.
Toilet paper holder, faucet, all awry,
Shoddy hardware, a sorry sight.

In Vegas, many party, and such concerns,
They do not heed, in their merriment.
But for the same price, on the Strip,
A better room, with comfort, I can get.

The pool, a pleasant spot, in the week,
Lifeguards friendly, service, a bit slow.
Casino, smoky, a drawback, indeed,
Restaurant choices, left much to be desired.

In conclusion, Palms, a place to pass,
If pool and clubs, your focus be.
But for comfort, elsewhere, seek thou must,
In Las Vegas, other options, there be."

"A humble tavern, serving victuals plain,
For those who crave not fancy fare, but hearty cheer.
The menu boasts no exotic delights,
But simple dishes, fried or grilled with all their might.
A pint of ale, perhaps, to quench thy thirst,
And revel in the joys of rustic life, unfurled.

'Tis a cozy den, where one can find solace,
In times of weariness, or after a hard day's toil.
The atmosphere, though plain, doth bring a sense of ease,
Reminding one of life in quiet, peaceful suburbia, devoid of stress.
So, if thou art in search of sustenance uncomplicated,
And camaraderie, free from pomp and pretension,
Then seek out this modest tavern, nestled in the heart,
Of Green Bay's verdant landscape, a haven to impart."

In sooth, we ventured to the lounge, where Karaoke doth reign,
Past twenty-one tables, and opposite the bar, 'twain.
On Sundays, Wednesdays, at eight o'clock, doth the fun begin,
A spacious seating area, before the stage, doth spin.

Alas, the piped-in music doth compete with those who sing,
A quibble, indeed, that doth my joy doth bring.
For in this Karaoke, song choices doth come from a book,
And one must write them down, ere the singer doth took.

Then, lo, some fools doth take the binder to their table,
As if 'twere their own, and doth not able to stable.
The lyric screen, a small device, doth sit before,
A hindrance, indeed, to those who doth adore.

The place, alack, doth reek of smoke, a foul stench,
I could not credit that folk doth lodge within the wrench.
Yet, one thing pleased me well, a speaker on the street,
That doth proclaim the songs, in all their vocal feat.

"Aye, worth the price, but not worth the wait, my friend!

Beware, the line outside, a trick it doth play.
For after thou hast bought thy ticket, up the elevator thou shalt go,
To a line unseen, and there thou shalt stay.

Prepare thyself for a long, weary wait,
With naught but time to ponder thy fate.
No restrooms nor concessions up above,
So steel thine bladder and stomach, lest thou doth prove
A victim of discomfort, and curseth thy fate.

We visited on a sunny Sunday afternoon,
And lo, the ride of 15 seconds didst take three hours to come.
Just like a trip to Six Flags, a theme park most wondrous,
But alas, the photos taken in mid-air, most unflattering they be.

High pressure, indeed, to purchase these mementos,
Yet, shall thou resist, and keep thy purse closed,
For 'tis a trick, a scheme, a clever ruse,
To part thee from thy hard-earned coin, good sir."

"Hark, a tiki culture devotee I be,
And thus, my heart did sing with glee,
When in this place I chanced to spy,
A bar that looked, to mine own eye,
Like some tiki haven of delight.

I strode forthwith, to the bar,
And asked the keep, with hope afire,
For my dear drink, the painkiller rare,
But alas, the man didst not know its name.
I requested then, a menu of drinks,
But none was forthcoming, to my blinks.

'We're but a dive bar, good sir,' quoth he,
In answer to my query, strange and free.
So here, within this tiki den,
They serve but beer, and naught else, by pen.
Odd, indeed, yet still, I do declare,
This place, a gem, in its own right, doth bear."

"Methinks my spouse and I didst chancet upon Cucina de Vita,
Whilst shopping in Downtown Mesa's bustling streets.
Its outdoor seating didst catch our eye, anon,
And forthwith, we didst step inside, to dine and make merry.

The staff, in sooth, didst greet us with a smile,
And we didst order swiftly, without much ado.
I chose the Meatball Parm sub, and my lord,
Didst opt for Sausage and Peppers, as his heart didst desire.

But lo! When first I tried the pasta salad,
'Twas served at room temperature, and not a whit more.
And likewise, the marinara sauce, I didst find,
Was tepid, and lacking in flavor, to mine mind.

My husband's sandwich, methought, was passing fair,
He didst enjoy it, and found it to his liking.
But alack! My sub, oh how it didst disappoint,
For the sauce was bitter, overspiced, and naught but woe.

Yet still, the meatballs, in sooth, didst taste divine,
And had I not been wary of the sauce's bite,
I might have savored them, in all their prime,
And deemed the dish a worthy culinary delight.

So here's my counsel, to the cooks and staff of Cucina de Vita,
Take heed of temp'ral concerns, and marinara's quality,
And thus, thy patrons shall be pleased, and grateful,
For a meal most satisfying, and of highest degree."

"Verily, the customer service I did receive,
Was of the worst sort, a woeful sight indeed.
Dairy Queen, a place I do detest,
Now shall be my solace, my heart doth seethe.
A mood spoiler, alack, how vexing so!
Yet still, to Dairy Queen, I shall go."

"Aye, they do sell beer, that much is true,
But at a price most dear, I do declare.
Inconsistent hours, no number to call,
And customer service, well, that's a joke, my friend.
They lack knowledge of beer, I must confess,
So if thou seekest craft beer, look elsewhere, I suggest.
But if thou art willing to pay the price,
And knowest beer well, then give it a try, my friend.
A hot dog, perchance? 'Tis a thought, indeed."

"A humble abode, with outdoor space vast,
They serve teriyaki chicken, lacking sauce, quite tasteless,
And chicken fried rice, devoid of zest,
The service swift, the staff, most courteous,
But alas, the site, a haven for woe,
Drunks and vagrants, a sorrowful show,
Best to take away, and not dine in,
For the fare, mediocre, at best, within.
I doubt my return, for the cuisine,
Leaves much to be desired, I do confess,
Yet, the crab puffs, a delight, I must confess."

"My maiden visit to this place, I must confess,
Was met with dishes lacking zest and flair.
But, liquid delights did please my taste,
And service, though not perfect, was fair.
The manager, a lady of great grace,
Didst inquire about my meal's delight,
And when I shared my thoughts, she did embrace
My words with gratitude and insight bright.
She struck from my bill the fish tacos' cost,
A gesture most kind and unexpected, no doubt.
An error in payment, alas, did occur,
But the manager, a gentleman of great worth,
Didst rectify the issue with speed and assurance,
And to their accounting department didst he go,
To ensure the mistake was corrected, I do know.
Though food didst not impress, the managers' care
Hath made me ponder giving them another share."

"Thou, my son, and I, didst venture forth to dine,
At this establishment, where yogurt doth shine.
But lo, the floors, they were not clean, I pray,
With toppings of yogurt, that hadst lain awhile.
In such a place, where food is served with glee,
Cleanliness doth reign supreme, for all to see.
Alas, the yogurt, though passable, doth fail,
To make amends for filth, that doth prevail.
I shall not return, for fear of taint,
And advise thee, dear son, to do the same, lest thou be faint."

"A bar within the Luxor's hallowed halls,
With looks that rival those of lobby bars,
It boasts a raised platform, whence to spy
