The casino floor and all its varied throngs.

Attractive waitresses, with graceful ease,
Take orders, or the bar itself doth please,
But alas! The drinks, they came not swift,
And emptiness did reign, save for a few,
Who chose to tarry, and their patience test.

Prices, as in Vegas, steep and high,
$10 to $14, for a single sip, doth lie,
Yet, signatures, a few, they do possess,
And whipped cream, for a friend, they did address.

Alas! The service, slow, a bane, indeed,
Doth make me doubt, if I shall ever need,
To come again, to this place, so fair,
For speed, in service, doth my soul impair."

"Alas, fair service didst thou render, yet alack!
Pepsi, that woeful brew, didst thou proffer.
Salsa, tasty indeed, yet chips, stale and lacking.
Bright, colorful, a pleasant patio, a delight.
Food, a three of five, o'erpriced, some might say.
One beef taco, rice and beans, eleven dollars doth cost.
Steak fajitas, seventeen, a sum most vast.
Again, wouldst I try this place? Methinks, not likely."

My daughter, the youngest of my brood, doth possess a keen aptitude for culinary arts. And thus, upon receiving a pamphlet of this place, we didst conduct some research and deemed it a venture she might enjoy. They proffer an "advanced" course, dubbed "senior chefs," for youths with greater experience. Alas, our expectations were not quite met. The cooking largely consisted of pre-prepared victuals, and actual knives were not permitted. 'Twas altogether too rudimentary for elder, more seasoned whelps. By the time younglings reach the level of "senior chef," they should be engaging in more authentic culinary endeavors. Nonetheless, I didst find the facilities and staff to be agreeable, though not ideally suited for older juveniles with prior experience.

"Foodies Festivals we've attended ere now,  
But this one, at the EICC, did our spirits dampen.  
Saturday, alack, we chose to go,  
And found it full, nigh bursting, don't you know?  
They should have given more space, 'twould seem,  
For folk to graze in comfort, free from fear  
Of being trampled down, or crushed quite flat,  
Or struggling through with pushchair or chair.  
The wares, though not new, were of high renown,  
And samples, too, were plentiful and good.  
The Extraordinary Sausage Co., in sooth,  
Did thrive, their sausages with Scotch Bonnets' youth.  
Yet crowds they drew did add to the fray,  
And made it hard to navigate, come what may.  
A good time, still, yet organisation lacked,  
In truth, a disappointment, that's the fact."

"Hark! Last Friday, I didst visit this place,
For their honey hot wings, my heart doth race.
The service, swift as usual, didst please,
But alas! The wings, how small they didst tease!
A mere half, nay, a third of their former size,
Didst leave me in dismay, and my heart didst freeze.
I spoke to the fair manager, and she didst say,
They worked with the supplier, come what may.
But naught didst she offer, no compensation,
No discount, nor solace, to ease my vexation.
Unacceptable, I say, and thus I write,
To express my woe, and seek justice in this fight."

Urban Outfitters, a haven for Scensters, doth boast an array of "sorta 80" garb, a true delight for those who seek such finery. But, alas, my purse doth protest at the price, for 'tis five times its worth, I do declare! And, verily, the men's section, though small, doth suffer the same fate as all other stores. But, if thou must choose, select the Mills Avenue location, for 'tis the lesser of two evils, methinks.

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,
This Delux Burger doth not impress.
Despite its fame, and praise so bright,
It fell quite short of culinary light.

The patty, once cooked, did lack all zest,
And in a baguette, soggy nest.
The toppings, too, did fail to wow,
Save for the onions, sweet and slow.

The roasted beet salad, a mess indeed,
O'er-dressed and mushy, without heed.
The beets themselves, their texture lost,
In blue cheese and balsamic, tossed and frost.

Yet still, dear friends, Delux doth boast,
A cool ambience, and drinks at cost.
So if thou art in search of cheer,
And a cold glass of water, pure and clear,
Then Delux, give it a try, my friend,
But of their burger, make no great pretend."

"Alas, fair friends, our night didst not bode well,
For though they say great service doth abound,
Our own tale doth tell a different tale, I fear.
Two hours and forty-five minutes passed,
And still our meal didst not arrive,
A sorry state of affairs, indeed.

At first, we were seated with all due haste,
But then, alack, our waiter didst disappear,
Leaving us to ponder our fate,
And wonder if our meal wouldst ever appear.

But then, a miracle! Our waiter returned,
With apologies and promises unfurled,
And so we settled in, to dine and make merry,
And taste the delights of this fair eatery.

But lo, the food didst not quite live up,
To our expectations, or so it seemed,
The crab cakes, mushy and lackluster,
The calamari, too much breading, and not enough zest.

And the ribeye, oh how it didst disappoint,
For sixty dollars, a poor showing, indeed,
Compared to other steakhouses of renown,
It failed to impress, and left us feeling down.

The manager, with apologies, didst come to our aid,
But alas, the damage had been done,
For by the time the bill arrived,
The restaurant was empty, and our moods were soured.

So, dear friends, take heed of our tale,
And shun this place, lest ye wish to fail."

"Methinks 'tis now the second time that I have stepped within this house of coffee, and both times, I must confess, the brew hath pleased mine taste. Yet, alack! the atmosphere doth lack the warmth of welcome, nay, even a simple smile or greeting from those who serve. Four youths, idle and unconcerned, do loiter behind the counter, their demeanor cold and uninviting. Verily, there be better places to partake of coffee, where the servers be not so haughty and disdainful. Hava Java, forsooth! A place where hospitality doth reign supreme."

"Methinks the women who tidied my abode didst perform their duties with some degree of proficiency and were quite agreeable in their demeanor. Alas, they failed to arrive betwixt the appointed hours of eight and eight thirty, and didst not trouble themselves to convey unto me any warning of their tardiness. My attempts to communicate with Planet Hugger by means of the telephone didst prove futile, as they didst persist in directing all calls to a voice messaging device. (Verily, I have endeavored to converse with a living soul by this method on numerous occasions, yet have ne'er succeeded.) A missive dispatched via electronic mail, inquiring as to the estimated time of their arrival, didst remain unanswered. Consequently, I was compelled to tarry and await their entrance, thereby disrupting my carefully planned schedule. Forsooth, this lack of punctuality doth render their services less than ideal for an individual such as myself, who must needs adhere to a strict routine."

"Alack, the show was but a mediocrity,
Particularly for the price, and Vegas' glee.
The singer and the band, a half-beat slow,
The dancers, too, their energy did lack,
They played not full songs, and the worst,
The show lasted but fifty-five minutes, alack!
The performers, mere motions they did go through,
With little heart in the music, it did seem.
The crowd, a dead one, none did get into,
We saw Kenny Wizz, an impersonator, true,
In San Diego, his Michael Jackson show,
Excellent, with all the details, it did flow.
A full two hours, the crowd did sing and dance,
For same price, a better chance to take.
In conclusion, disappointment did we feel,
And recommend it, we would not, sooth."

"Hark! What 'tis this place? A tavern, by my troth!
And one that doth not take reservations, by the way.
Forsooth, we came in droves, and had to wait,
Until the whole group gathered, ere we could partake.

But fear not, friends! For those who did arrive,
Didst find solace in the bar, where drinks did flow, and thrive.
The bartender, a merry soul, didst serve with glee,
And made our wait, a pleasant one, for thee.

Now, mark this well! This place doth cater to the young,
And asks, if thou dost need, a high chair or booster throng.
Aye, 'tis a haven for the families, and that's no wrong,
But for us singles, a bit of a bore, I must confess.

But lo! The rolls! Oh, how divine! A carb-filled delight,
That made my taste buds sing, and my belly take flight.
Alas, they kept bringing more, and my resolve didst weaken,
And I didst eat too many, to my own chagrin.

We all didst order steak, the special of the day,
But mine was cooked too long, and the sides didst fade away.
Our server, in a jest, didst say she hated her work,
And that, my friends, didst make my evening, quite a quirk.

So, to this place, I shall not return,
Unless, perchance, I must, and then, I'll dine on cocktails and rolls, my dear.
Take thy children here, and I shall dine elsewhere,
For this tavern, doth seem, a place most fitting, for families to share."

"O, how I love this victual, but alas!
The service here doth leave much to be desired.
Methinks we come hither at least once a moon,
Yet, the service doth rarely reach the heights of good,
Much less the pinnacle of greatness, I do fear.
Hark! Owners, doth thine ears attend to the words
Of thy loyal customers? Forsooth, they speak
Of service poor, and how it doth besmirch
The fair name of this establishment.
Pray, heed their words, and take note, I pray thee,
For 'tis the key to keeping those who come
In droves, to partake of thy delectable fare.
Thus, read the comments, and make haste to mend,
That we, thy patrons, may continue to wend
Our way to thy doors, with joy and with cheer."

"A friend from afar didst entreat me to dine
At this establishment, his spouse didst declare
The chopped salad, a feast most divine
But alas, the portion, quite meager didst appear

My comrade, warn'd by the waiter, didst consent
To try the salad, yet his hunger didst not relent
For though the flavors were pleasant to the taste
The quantity, a mere morsel, didst leave him aghast

I, myself, didst opt for the steak special
Served upon a bed of corn and beans, most peculiar
With a sweet sauce, reminiscent of honey
Yet the dish, familiar, didst seem to me

For I have had its like, at Chipotle's place
The steak burrito bowl, without the rice, in its stead
Thus, the victuals, good, the service, fine
But the cost, too great, for a meal so divine"

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold, my friends,
Of a parking lot, with puddles deep and wide,
And drivers who doth help with bags, so bright,
Their promptness doth make the journey light.

But lo! A sign doth appear, so bold,
Increasing rates, a tale to be told,
$6.45 per day, through holidays, so cold,
A sneaky move, their customers to hold.

And sales tax too, doth they impose,
Whilst airport lots, do none propose,
A difference great, and cause for woe,
I shall not return, so let it be known."

"A pox upon this club, that doth charge admission fee,
Despite their claim of 'local ladies, always free'.
Their website doth lie, and we didst decree,
To seek elsewhere for mirth and revelry.

At one o'clock, the night didst turn to day,
And still they doth demand our silver pay.
My friend and I, didst choose to stray,
And leave this den of avarice and dismay.

So, let this be a warning to all who seek,
To dance and make merry, without a streak.
Beware of clubs with false promises, and heed,
The words of Shakespeare, as thy guide indeed."

"Hark! What's this? A Ross commercial doth claim,
That shoppers find great deals within their walls of fame.
But alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
I've found naught but woe within their endless mess.

A guard doth greet me, with a watchful eye,
As if I were a thief, and not a buyer nigh.
The racks, they seem to stretch on forevermore,
With clothes that fit not well, and fabrics poor.

I've searched for treasures, hidden amongst the fray,
But oft, my efforts are met with dismay.
For though I find a gem, 'tis often tainted,
With polyester or flaws, that make it unworthy.

And so, my dear friend, I do declare,
I'll seek my fortunes elsewhere, without despair.
For Target, TJ Maxx, and H&M, they beckon thee,
With wares that meet thy needs, and set thy spirit free."

"A chain or restaurant with 'wing' in its name, doth not impress, I say. If all thou seeketh is standard draft beers, mediocre wings, and sports, then mayhap it shall suffice. But alas, the wings be merely average in size, and the selection of sauces, though plentiful, doth not make up for the lack of flavor in the hottest of them. Verily, 'tis but a means to burn thee twice, as I do proclaim.

"I shall not bother to promote other local establishments that offer similar fare, for they do it better than Wild Wings. Hazelwoods, Native New Yorker, Zipps, and Tweakwoods, all excel in some aspect or another. Fare thee well, good sir!"

"A foul stench did greet us upon entry,
And light of day did pierce through the door,
A sorry state for any hostelry,
When curtains fail to keep out the sun's rays.

The breakfast spread, a pitiful sight,
Begged to be avoided, save for the fruit.

But soft, my friends! A comforting bed,
Did earn this place a second star, I swear.
Though fatigue, a product of a long flight,
May have clouded my judgement, 'tis true."

"O, thou seekest savory meats and a stein of fine tea? 
Forsooth, avoid the overpriced tavern, my friend, 
Whose dry pork doth leave much to be desired, I do declare. 
Their specials, alas, doth not bring forth any great savings. 
But fear not, for there is a place nearby that doth serve 
Excellent BBQ, ribs, and more, a true culinary delight. 
'Tis Hap's BBQ, located on Washington street, next to 
Samurai Sam's, a place of great renown and worth thy while. 
So, go forth and partake in their delectable fare, 
And mayst thy taste buds be blessed with joy and delight!"

"Hark, my friend, what doth mine eyes perceive?
A menu, with Cuban Pete's name, doth arrive.
Cigars, it doth say, and cannoli too,
With chocolate ganache, and whipped cream anew.

But lo, when we didst enter in,
The cannoli, it doth disappoint within.
Stale shells, with bagged whip cream, it doth seem,
And nary a candied orange peel, to redeem.

A disaster, indeed, it doth appear,
Yet still, the Cuban sandwich, doth tempt me near.
So, one more try, I shall give, to see,
If Cuban Pete's, canst redeem itself, for me."

"Methinks I've dined at this establishment oft before,
And found the victuals and the service to be of high quality,
But alas, this last visit didst leave me in dismay,
For 'twas a woeful experience in every way.

A table of seven, fully served, didst take ninety minutes to obtain,
A feat that doth beggar description, and doth leave me in pain.
The food, though passable, didst not compare to past repasts,
And I, a patron of discerning taste, didst feel most aggrieved.

O Sam, if thou art listening, heed my words of wisdom,
For thy once-great restaurant, now doth suffer from neglect.
Thou hast expanded too far, and lost sight of thy core,
The very things that made thee great, now doth lie in disarray.

Return to thine roots, and focus on what doth truly matter,
For only then, shall thy patrons once again be filled with laughter."

"O, how vexing 'tis to deal with those who doth dispense
Medicaments of brand names, when generics would suffice!
Their practice, verily, doth border on the absurd,
And doth not take into account the patient's desire.

A plague upon their coupons, which doth make it seem
As though the price were equal, but nay, 'tis not so.
For in the activation, there doth lie a woeful pain,
Which doth make the whole process a tedious, tiresome woe.

I pray, good sirs, that ye wouldst see the light,
And change your ways, ere I do lose my patience quite.
For generics, though they may not bear a name so bright,
Are oftentimes the better choice, and more in sight."

"Fair food and service did abound,
But loud music did our ears confound.
A Saturday eve, I could comprehend,
Yet lanes un-waxed did our joy impend.
No sliding could we do with ease,
And AC, alas, did not bring peace.
We went outside, my friends and I,
To cool down from heat that did us nigh.
We asked the staff to turn it down,
But broken, they said, was all around.
In Phoenix's heat, 'twas woeful sight,
So elsewhere shall I seek delight."

"Hark, what news is this? Our meal doth take an age to come! And when 'twas brought before us, lo, it did resemble mightily some concoction from a tin or bottle. Methinks the cooks didst struggle to locate yon can opener. Alas, the pretty decorations and modest prices be the sole redeeming qualities of this wretched establishment."

"Alas, my friends, how vexing 'twas to see
The fries, so cold, devoid of heat or zest
And tomato slices, laid on top with nary a care
A sorry sight, indeed, for one who doth quest
For culinary delights, fit for a king
In an airport, of all places, where one doth sing
The blues of hunger, and doth seek reprieve
From fast food joints, that do serve, believe
A better cheesesteak, full of flavor and cheer
But alas, 'twas not to be, my friends, I fear."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern! Foul service doth abound,
And victuals that do naught but disappoint.
E'en McDonald's, that humble fast-food chain,
Hath cleaner privies than this sorry place.
Alack, one sink, devoid of handle, doth remain,
In such a state of disarray, 'tis plain to see,
This establishment doth lack all sense of grace.
I pray thee, good sir, avoid this woeful place,
Lest thou desire to suffer poor service and shame."

"Methought I didst not fancy mine hot dog, plain with sauerkraut, yet my spouse didst enjoy his, fried with bacon bits. Fries were tasty, but alas! Three hot dogs, chili cheese fries, and a single soda didst cost us thirty silver pieces. Verily, a sum most dear, and not worth the expense, in sooth."

"Hark! This place doth remind me of the Black Hoof in fair Toronto,
Where carnivores feast on bone marrow, and pig's head doth garnish the board.
Aye, 'tis a place for the famished, and those who dare not shy away
From cholesterol's mighty blow, that doth await thy digestive way.

I sought a light repast, but alas, my hopes were dashed,
For the waiter's recommendation did bring me a dish most hashed.
'Twas pan-seared veal, atop potatoes and watercress, they said,
But lo, the olive oil did flow like a river, and an egg did sit
Upon the mess, a salad? Nay, 'twas more akin to a stew,
And I, a mere mortal, could scarce finish what they didst bestow.

Creative, indeed, their dishes may be, but enjoyment, I didst not find,
For the grease did overcome me, and I couldst not consume all I didst design.
The creme brulee and molten lava cakes, they were decent, I do confess,
But for a light meal, elsewhere thou must quest, for this place doth not repress.

So, if thou art a meat-eater, and thy hunger doth not abate,
Then come, and partake of their offerings, and let thy taste buds sate.
But if thou dost desire a meal that doth not weigh thee down,
Seek elsewhere, fair traveler, for this place doth not provide renown."

"A curious spot, indeed, my dear friend,
Where grown-ups play, like children at their end.
Jenga, cornhole, beer pong, all giant-sized,
And bean bags, board games, for those who prize.
I did not partake in victuals, I confess,
But the privy, clean and pleasant, did impress.
The scent of the place, most agreeable,
Yet the barkeepers, alas, were rude and uncivil,
Paying mind only to a group of damsels fair,
And leaving others to wait, with naught but air."

"A club sandwich most dull, I didst partake,
Constructed of cold cuts, and lettuce so pale,
Bacon bits, so minute, didst require great skill,
To keep within the bread, as I didst eat my fill.
The waiter's look, unkempt and quite grimy,
Didst make me ponder on the kitchen's cleanness.
Next time, to Fox Sports Grill, I shall repair,
For a meal more satisfying, and less distressing."

"A plague upon this buffet, 'tis a sorry sight!
For those who seek quality, turn and take flight.
But if thou art in search of quantity and variety,
Perhaps this spread may suffice, yet still not worth the fee.
In sooth, I say 'tis not worth thirty pieces of silver,
Nay, not even half that sum, a paltry trifle to deliver."

"A cup they gave me, pour my own coffee thence,
From decanters, lever-pumped, a cheesy sight,
Not fresh, alas! And for a coffee, two fifty paid,
A price too steep, methinks, for such a paltry brew.

The 'Bold Ethiopian Night', a misnomer, indeed,
Watery, lacking depth, a disappointment, pure and simple.
A shame, forsooth, I had hoped to find delight,
In this place, but alas, 'twas not to be, by day or night."

"Alas, my friends, I must report,
This restaurant doth leave much to be desired,
In truth, the upstairs patio doth please,
With misting fans that make summer's heat subside.

But, alack, the rest doth not impress,
O'er-priced dishes, noise, and layout quite a mess,
Servers and patrons doth collide,
A narrow path doth lead to bathroom's side.

And, by the stars, a strange mishap occurred,
They forgot to charge us for a dish, oh so absurd,
We paid the bill, and then they came to say,
"You owe us more, come back and pay the way."

So, my advice, dear friends, doth be,
To avoid this place, and seek elsewhere to see,
Hillstone, True Food, Seasons 52, Christophers, and more,
For quality and service, they do excel, you'll find no bore."

"Tis a shame, dear friends, that this T.G.I. Friday's doth falter,
In service, that is, forsooth, most woeful and wretched.
Five tables, three servers, and yet, alack,
Our meal doth lack, in truth, the finest touch.

My kin, they dine with me, and 'tis my cousin's day,
Her twenty-first year, a milestone, mark ye well.
We sought to make it special, a feast, a fete,
But lo, the server, he doth fail, most miserably.

Asked thrice, he brought not forth the birthday sweet,
But instead, a brownie, with naught but ice and cream.
And when we queried, wherefore the delay?
He answered, with a grin, "I thought 'twas for him."

Oh, woe is me! How poor the service, how great the disappointment!
Yet still, we laughed, and made merry, in spite of all.
For though the meal were marred, our mirth did not depart.
And thus, dear friends, we learned, that even in the worst of times,
Joy and love can conquer all, and make the heart sing."

"Verily, I say unto thee, fair reader, that this review doth not bode well for yonder establishment. Forsooth, the victuals didst taste most wondrous, a true delight for mine own palate. Howbeit, alack! The service, 'twas a sorry sight to behold. A pox upon their house, for they didst sit us at a table foul and unclean, and didst promise to send a servant to tidy it forthwith. Five minutes passed, and nary a soul didst come to purge the filth. Another five minutes, and still naught but empty words didst fill the air. My friends' draughts didst arrive, but lo! They didst tarry ten long minutes ere they didst reach our parched lips. A plague upon their slowness, say I! Our salads didst come, and we didst devour them with haste, yet still we waited, and waited, and waited, ere anyone didst deign to notice our plight. Fifteen minutes, by the clock, didst tick away ere we couldst catch a server's eye and cry, 'Ho, good sir! What wilt thou do to end this woeful wait?' And lo, they didst offer us the salads gratis, as token of their sorrow for the poor service. Yet, alas! Two shoddy visits doth make me wary of returning to that place. Farewell, dear reader, and may thy own experience be more pleasant than mine."

"Alack, a concept grand, yet flawed in deed,
The execution poor, the interface unheeded.
Computer locked, staff stood, and none did aid,
Missed chances, naught but bitter shade.
Near front door, we rose from photo seat,
And left, unnoticed, save a feeble greet.
Oh, Microsoft, thy logo doth conceal,
Cntl Alt Delete, our time doth steal.
We exit, thus, this woeful place,
With naught but woe, and disgrace."

"Alas, my friends, I must recount a tale of woe,
Of a dining experience that did not go well,
During restaurant week, we did decide to dine,
But found the fare to be most disappointing, I do declare.

The brie, it was barely warm, and the apples, dry,
The fruit, it was not caramelized, oh my,
The toast, it was but a mere morsel, I did cry,
For a brulee, I saw not, alack and alas.

My dinner partner, he did have the Escargot,
Which was good, I must admit, 'twas a treat,
But the filet mignon, oh so petite,
I was surprised, and not in a good way, I do confess.

It came with sauce, and tomatoes, warm and bright,
But the potatoes, small and few, they were not right,
I've had better fries, alas, I must say,
And the sea bass, though flavorful, was tiny, oh dear.

The pasta, it was good, but the portion, small,
I did thank my friend for sharing, lest I fall,
Into hunger's clutches, for I had been misled,
By the restaurant's words, which did not bear fruit.

The Hazelnut Tarte, oh so dull and plain,
With chocolate that was not rich, and pastry, not worth the gain,
A few nuts on top, they did not make up for the flaw,
I was not impressed, nor was I filled with awe.

I called beforehand, to ask of the portions size,
But they told me I would not go hungry, oh what a lie,
The service too, was slow, and the drinks, they did not refill,
I waited long, and my thirst, it did not still.

Alas, my friends, I must conclude,
That this restaurant, it did not meet my views,
I shall not return, for I was not pleased,
And thus, my tale of woe, it ends."

"Hark! If thou art planning on paying for a feast,  
On the Strip, prepare thyself for disappointment at best.  
For 'tis not worth the coin, I do declare,  
But if thou hast free passes, then go forth and partake with glee!  
Most dishes here are standard fare, I do confess,  
But search diligently, and thou mayst find some culinary success.  
I chose the gyros, by the salad bar did lie,  
And passable salads too, did meet mine eye.  
For sweet dessert, I opted for frozen delight,  
Or gelato, as they call it in this fair sight.  
A word of caution, friends, the raw bar doth abound,  
With folk who place their trust in its questionable profferings found.  
Yet fear not, for sparkling wine flows free,  
So quaff and enjoy, as thy purse doth decree!"

"Amidst the throngs of folk that swarmed the halls,
I waited patiently, my turn to come at last.
The Optometrist, a man of skill and grace,
Didst tend to me with kindness and a gentle face.
He checked my eyes, and double-checked with care,
To ensure that I, a satisfied patron, didst fare.
But alas, the rest of the experience didst lack,
In customer service, and a prompt attack.
A lengthy wait, a crowd of people, didst vex,
And when I sought to pay, a further delay didst perplex.
Thus, I didst tarry, twenty minutes more,
Until at last, my prescription didst I receive, with a sigh of relief, no more."

"Ay, methinks 'twas a tad excessive, my dear friends,  
For a night out, they did suggest this place,  
And having been to other buffets in fair Vegas,  
I had heard this one was among the best, in all its grace.  
  
But alack, I must confess, I was not quite taken,  
By the fare they served, though unique, it was not worth the cost,  
For my good husband and I, we paid ninety silver pieces,  
To partake of their feast, when evening did descend.  
  
Their wild boar sloppy joes, and truffle potatoes,  
Were curious indeed, but lacked flavor, I do declare,  
As if they'd traded taste for novelty,  
Leaving me unimpressed, and feeling quite aware.  
  
Perhaps this place was too grand for my humble self,  
But I must say, I found it not to my liking,  
For though it may have been a lavish spread,  
Twas not worth the coin, nor the time, I do reckon."

"A plague upon this cursed place! The dining hall, so bright and fair, yet service, poor and woeful. Fruit-filled drink, a sweet delight, but alas, the chili dog, a bitter disappointment. Hard as stone, the bun did lie, and with it, all my hopes were dashed. A friend's burger, mediocre at best, and dearly priced, the fare. A pox on this establishment, I say!"

"A family reunion's arranger chose this place,
A typical upscale American eatery, they say.
But oh, how bland the dishes did taste,
Compared to Indian, Chinese, Thai, and Middle East's delight.

I ordered baby back ribs, of high quality indeed,
But the sauce, alas, was far from spicy's creed.
Tobasco saved the day, but only so much,
For even that could not mask the lack of zest and such.

My broccoli, devoid of spice, was cooked too long,
As American restaurants often do, in their wrong.
And my wife, she gave her BBQ salmon a rating low,
Two stars, for flavor that did not impress, I know.

In America, it seems, they flavor food with three,
Salt, fat, and sugar, a trifecta, you see.
But for those who crave more, it's a sad plight,
To dine on dishes with such lack of might."

"Hark! What raves didst thou hear of yonder green chili mac? A feast most wondrous, or so it seemed. Alas, how quickly doth my joy turn to woe! For in that dish, the chilies were tough and ill-prepared, and the cheese within the mac, most coarse and rough. Fie upon it! Mac and cheese, by definition, should be smooth and rich, but nay, this dish didst fail. Yet, there was one redeeming quality, a pulled pork sandwich most fair, and the hot BBQ, quite good indeed. Thus, if thou seekest fine BBQ, Honey Bears shall be thy choice, but if thou art in haste and needest a quick repast, Andrew's may suffice."

"Methinks we didst order twain bowls, one Mochiko, another Srirachi. Verily, we didst enjoy them, children finishing theirs with great haste. Alas, a quibble doth arise, forsooth, in that they didst employ frozen vegetables. A pox upon such usage! Two stars, I say, for this most grievous fault. Yet, in sooth, the victuals themselves were quite delectable."

"A Groupon didst we purchase for this place,
And thus, we didst decide to give 'twas a try.
The victuals, alack, were but of middling grace,
And thus, the name of Lagasse doth bring dismay.

A frozen patty, flat and burnt, the burger didst seem,
And thus, we didst not finish it, nor didst we deem
It fit for consumption. But, the drinks, I pray,
Were priced most reasonably, and thus, we didst say,

'We shall not return, forsooth, to this place again.'"

"Methinks this review doth stem from but a single visit, yet shall we ne'er return, I fear.  'Tis true, the service didst leave much to be desired.  Awaiting water, we didst tarry long ere a waitress came to fill our glasses.  And though she didst make brief appearances anon, her demeanor was not most cordial, nor didst she show great concern for our party of two.  

Foodwise, 'twas passable, I reckon.  A house salad and pork tenderloin didst grace my plate, yet both didst taste o'er-salted.  My comrade's Caesar salad and fettuccine alfredo didst find favor in his eyes, however.  They do possess a fair selection of beers and wines by the glass, that cannot be denied.  

In aspect, the decor doth please mine eye.  All is polished, much like Cheesecake Factory or PF Chang's, in a manner most fine.  The establishment doth boast ample space, such that waiting lists doth rarely plague them, I should imagine.  Open Table doth serve their reservation needs, a convenience most welcome."

Last eve, six of us didst venture to this place,
For happy hour, with joy and cheer, we didst embrace.
But alas, the bar and lounge, so small and tight,
Couldst only accommodate a few, in sight.

The rest of the dining room, and patio, so vast,
Didst lie empty, like a desert, devoid of mirth.
We asked, if we couldst sit outside, and partake,
Of happy hour, but the answer, a firm "no" didst make.

The manager, a stubborn man, didst not relent,
And so, we left, in search of a better bent.
As we departed, other couples, didst follow suit,
For they too, didst seek a place, more meet and fit.

A note to Eddies, heed my words, I pray,
Expand thy bar, or allow happy hour, in some way.
For if thou dost not, thy business, will decline,
And others, more accommodating, shall be thine.

"A pox upon this wretched place, where service doth falter and fare doth pale! A Sunday special, they did proclaim, yet when I called to claim it, 'twas a tedious task indeed. The pizza, mediocre at best, did little to assuage my ire. Alas, I didst venture forth to dine within their walls, and there, too, didst suffer poor service at the hands of yon sluggardly crew. Fie upon this pitiful excuse for a tavern!"

"Hark! A gift card didst I possess,
And to the Town Center, I didst address,
To partake in a meal most fine and fair,
A garlic parm chicken pizza, and spinach artichoke dip to share.

The bill, it didst amount to twenty-seven silver pieces,
And they didst tell me, the food wouldst be ready in five short pieces.
I didst arrive at five, having parked in the wrong lot,
And lo! The pizza, it was in the oven, hot!

A bar pie, it was, and not so large,
I didst expect more, but 'twas not to be charged.
The spinach dip, it was brought over with haste,
But the bread, it didst take a full ten minutes to be placed.

The pizza, it was naught but average, I do declare,
But the spinach dip, it was quite excellent, beyond compare.
The pita, it was warm, and a pleasant delight,
But the price, it didst seem a bit too high, in the light.

I didst eat quickly, and still felt some hunger pangs,
But alas! The meal, it didst not live up to my expectations, nor did it sang."

My spouse and I did dine at this place,
After perusing many a glowing review,
We, veterans of Vegas' finest spreads,
Did expect a feast fit for kings and queens, anon.
Alas, the victuals served were poor, I say,
Considering Wynn's renown and prestige, 'twas a dismay.
The servers, though, did attend us with grace,
A shame the grub did not meet our expectations' pace.
We shall return, but the noonday meal,
Shall we eschew, and seek better deal.

"O, how my heart doth sink each time I step
Into this wretched airport's crowded space.
A place of connection, one would think,
But nay, 'tis a den of woe and disgrace.

Hipsters, hung-over, roam the halls,
Their mirth and laughter, none at all.
Food, a travesty, doth leave me cold,
And this place, a purgatory to behold.

Oh, how I wish to flee this woeful site,
And find solace in a different flight.
For those who seek a pleasant stay,
Avoid this pit, I pray thee, night and day."

"Marry, how strange it seems that Bell Cleaners doth thrive,
Despite the recession's harsh and bitter sting.
Their pickup and drop-off service, they do proclaim,
But 'twas naught but woeful incompetence did bring.

I waited patiently, in darkness deep,
While the lone attendant searched, her mind did sleep.
She found my shirts and khakis at last, with nary a word,
And demanded payment, her hand outstretched, like a bird.

The price for khakis, two pairs, did seem quite steep,
I questioned the cost, and her response did creep.
She looked down, muttering, her words unclear,
And held out her hand, as if to say, "Fear not, dear."

Eleven shirts, a fair price, yet not so low,
That I would stay, and nowhere else would go.
If thou hast wealth, and time to spare,
Then by all means, indulge in their finery fair."

"Methinks 'tis overpriced, my dear friend. Our victuals were of fair quality, and the service, most courteous, I must confess. But, alack! The cost didst give me pause, forsooth. A princely sum, indeed, for but a few pancakes. My humble purse, now retired, doth protest at such an extravagance."

"A pox upon this burger joint, I say!
The patty, flavorless as a piece of hay,
And greasy, too, like a dirty pond.
I chose the Arizona, hoping for some spice,
But alas, the toppings were but a faint delight.
The staff, they doth not seem to enjoy their work,
And the decor, akin to a carwash, doth not quench my thirst.
For the price they charge, I'd rather take my coin
To In-n-out, where a better burger doth await,
Or Four Peaks, where a truly noble feast doth lie.
Away with this place, and its mediocrity!"

"A wedlock celebration drew me to this place,
Where revelers numbered twenty-five or thirty,
Seated in rear, we suffered not disgrace,
Till lo! A monstrous insect did my sight amaze.
The manager, with scant regret, did make amends,
Yet still, the memory of that beast doth haunt my mind."

"Fair sir, the victuals here be hot and fiery,
A feast for they who crave such spice and fire.
My comrade and I, we shared a dish of shrimp,
And savored too the flavors of goat meat and jerk chicken's delight.
The sides, they were a pleasant surprise,
But alas, the hall itself didst leave much to be desired.
Alack, the cleanliness didst leave a bit to be desired,
And signs didst beg for tips, as if 'twere a fast food place.
We paid a sum of twenty-nine gold coins for our repast,
And lo, a seventh of that amount didst come as tip, unasked.
Our server, he didst attend us well,
But methinks the gratuity, it was a mite too much, and we didst not protest.
For in this town, there be many a place more fair,
And though we tried it, we shall not return, forsooth."

"Methought I'd book a breakfast for a wedding feast,
And thrice didst attempt to call this place of rest.
A manager, they said, would call me back anon,
But nary a word didst I hear from them, alack!
A fair sized group it would have been, I do confess,
And worth their while, methinks, to make some fuss.
But now, I fear, I shall not dine with them,
For poor service doth leave a bitter taste within."

"O, wherefore should I start my tale of woe?
Forsooth, the victuals from Chris Bianco's hand
Are known to please, but alas, our first course
Was naught but ordinary, spare and plain.
The antipasto plate, a disappointment true,
Lacking in quantity and quality, I do declare.
Yet still, we hoped the Rosa pizza might
Make up for this slight, with cheese, onion, and nut.
And thus, a bottle of wine to pair, we thought
A fine addition, but alas, 'twas not to be.
For they, it seems, have not their licence yet,
To serve the grape, and so we were bereft.
Two strikes, it seemed, against this place so fair,
But then, a third, most grievous error did occur.
For when we asked the waiting maid, so blonde,
For bread, she said they had none, nor could they make.
And thus, our meal, with lack of bread, did suffer,
Until our resourceful waiter, with quick wit,
Did bring us some, and saved the day, by Jove!
But, O, dear Mr. Bianco, heed my words,
And rid thyself of that vacant, foolish maid,
Lest she, with her dim wit, doth bring thee shame."

"Fair yogurt and toppings, four stars, I say,
But management, alas, a single star doth sway.
Not customer-friendly, they doth seem,
For we were charged, in sooth, a king's ransom, 'twain.
Two small cups, a fortnight past, did cost,
Six dollars, nay, a princely sum, at the most.
But lo, the scale, it doth not always reset,
And thus, we paid, in gold, a prince's debt.
The cashier, kind soul, didst say, with cheer,
'Twas but a mistake, and thus, we need not fear.
But then, the manager, with frowning brow,
Didst dispute our claim, with words of woe.
She would not listen, nor our proof accept,
And thus, we left, with naught but disrespect.
A gift card, token of their good intent,
Didst they offer, but with grief and discontent.
We've been there since, with caution, we do pay,
Lest we be cheated, come what may."

"Ay, 'twas all a ruse, a ploy to part us from our coin!  These African-owned eateries, full of sound and fury, signifying naught but empty bellies and light purses.  Fried okra, a dish most wondrous, yet half-cooked and dripping with grease, like a tempest in a teapot.  Fries, alack, so soggy and slick, a travesty, a mockery!  Fish, with seasonings galore, yet tough and chewy, like a piece of leather.  Gumbo, a feast fit for Neptune's court, but where, oh where, were the seafood delights?  Alas, a pox upon thee, establishment!  Give us, thy patrons, what we pay for, or we shall seek sustenance elsewhere.  Next time, Mamas Boy Cafe shall be mine host, forsooth!"

"Twas my birthday, and to toast they did take me,
But alas, 'twas a woeful sight to see,
For our waiter, a grump he did make,
And spilled our ale upon my gown, so fair and bright.

I knew not what to do, in such a plight,
But up I rose, and with napkins, did clean the sight,
And dined upon them, with sorrow and despair,
For my birthday feast, was naught but woe and care.

My sweetheart's tofu, a block of sorrow,
In broth it swam, with naught but flavorless morrow,
And my burger, oh how tasteless it was,
A lentil paste, 'twixt buns, alack, what a pass!

We left, in haste, with spirits low,
For the service, poor, and food, a woeful show,
And thus, my birthday night, was ruined quite,
By this cursed place, with naught but bitter fight."

"This place, alas, doth bring forth mixed results,
Like chances taken, some do win, some lose their wits.
I, myself, didst venture there twice,
And found, the first time, a fair cut, quite nice.
The woman, cool and collected, didst tend
My locks with care, and left them neat and trim.
But, alack! The second time, oh woe is me!
The haircutter, a forgery, no doubt, didst see
My hair, and with great haste, didst split it down
The middle, ere I couldst speak a single sound.
She cut, with reckless hand, each lock the same,
Leaving me withal, a most unflattering frame.
A blunt, crude cut, that doth mock my face,
A haircut, foul and terrible, in its place.

And, lo! I have beheld, with mine own eyes,
That selfsame haircutter, with her scissors, rise
To botch a poor lad's crew cut, oh so sad!
A sight most gruesome, making me quite mad.
How couldst she, with such skill, yet lack finesse?
A stylist, nay, a butcher, in truth, doth she profess."

"Fare thee well, dear reader, for I shall regale thee with tales of woe and disappointment, of a buffet most foul and unworthy of the name. 'Tis the Paradise Buffet at the Flamingo Casino and Hotel, a place where hope doth dwindle and the stomach doth protest.

In this den of sorrow, the selection doth lack, and the food, alas, doth falter. The seafood, once a proud and bountiful delight, doth dwindle to naught but a few meager shrimp and crab legs, uncracked and uninviting. And the sushi, oh, the sushi! Dry and stale, it doth mock the taste buds, a poor imitation of the real thing.

But wait, dear reader, for the rest of the buffet doth offer naught but home-cooked fare, akin to the meals of yore, save for the price, which doth rival that of the finest establishments. Alas, 'tis a sorry state of affairs, and one doth wonder, why bother?

And yet, there doth be a glimmer of hope, a chance to save a few coins, by checking in on Foursquare. But alas, 'tis a paltry sum, and one doth question, is it worth the trouble? Nay, dear reader, best to skip this buffet and visit the flamingos outside, for they doth bring joy and wonder, without the need for coin or consumption."

"Fare thee well, good sirs and madams! Hark, what news I bring thee!
The victuals at St Rose/Eastern store, they be decent, by my troth!
But alas, the service, 'tis a woeful tale, full of disdain and scorn.
They heed not thy requests, nor listen to thy plea.
And when thou dost inquire, with hope in thine heart,
If they could fix the issue, they do reply,
"Thou shouldst have spoken, when thou didst place thy order,
For now, 'tis too late, and naught can be done, my dear."
Oh, how vexing and frustrating, to be thus ignored!
Best to avoid this place, and seek sustenance elsewhere,
For 'tis not worth the trouble, nor the bitter taste.
So heed my words, good friends, and take my advice,
And find a place where service doth make thee feel nice."

"Methinks I've visited this establishment twice,
And had two vastly different experiences, by my troth.
The first time, I broke my fast here, and 'twas quite good,
No qualms, no issues, all was as it should.

But alack, the second time, oh how the tale doth change!
We ordered burgers, three of us, with varied toppings,
But lo, when they arrived, the waiter did bring
The wrong combos, and the meat, it was too rare, by Jove!

We pointed out the errors, and the waiter did take
The plates away, but not a word did he speak,
No apology, no promise to hasten the new fare.
And so we waited, and the time, it did drag on,

At last, the new burgers came, but oh, how dry!
'Twas clear they'd merely switched them, not a fresh try.
No discount given, nor any compensation,
For all their mistakes, and thus, my dear friend,
I shall not return, forsooth, to this place again."

"O, how I do regret that we didst not purchase a few cans in yonder shop and quaff them on the train! Forsooth, 'twas full of woeful souls who didst not await their trains with patience, and the very atmosphere didst reek of discomfort and despair. Verily, I say unto thee, 'twas a place where one didst desire to hasten their departure, lest they be tainted by the unseemly company that didst inhabit it."

"Hark, what news is this? A shrimp shortage doth plague this place,
And with it, all my hopes of savoring their sweet embrace.
A sign doth say, 'No samples now, alas, no more delight',
And thus, my joy doth turn to sorrow, and my heart doth take flight.

But still, I doth persist, and order forth my meal,
With haste, the cooks doth bring it, and my hunger doth reveal.
Yet, ere I couldst taste the sauce, the bill doth come to me,
And with it, a sense of rush, that doth not bode well, ye see.

Alas, my friends, I doth confess, this visit doth not please,
The shrimp shortage doth mar my joy, and doth bring unease.
But still, I doth hold out hope, that next time, all shall be well,
And thus, I doth vow to return, and try their culinary spell."

"Hark! A traveler I, from distant lands afar,
With cravings fierce for tonkotsu ramen's savory delight.
Yelp, the trusty guide, led me to this place with ease,
And thus, my thoughts on it, I shall now release.

A bowl of steaming broth, with pork and veggies galore,
I ordered forth, with hopes of pleasure yet untold.
But alas! The broth, too salty it did taste,
And where, oh where, was the pork's rich, meaty embrace?

The charsui pork, a disappointment it did prove,
For tenderness, it lacked, like a lover's gentle groove.
Mushrooms, veggies, aromatics, all these could be added,
To wake the flavors up, and make it truly worthy.

A finishing sauce, a touch of sweetness or zest,
Might elevate the dish, and make it stand out from the rest.
There's a market for such fare, I do declare,
So let us hope, they heed these words, and make repair.

Republic, a name that conjures visions grand,
Of culinary delights, fit for any land.
May they strive hard, to meet such lofty goals,
And serve up ramen, that doth stir the soul."

Food overpriced, dishes cooked with haste,
Wine unimpressive, two Pinot Noir tasted,
Bread basket dry, Dior sign an eyesore,
Ambiance marred, would not go there more.
Waitress kind, special order made for me,
Primavera vegetarian, but pasta stuck, too salty.

"Alas, fair salon, with people so kind and neat,
Their service, however, left much to be desired, I do confess.
A small palette of hues, both regular and gel, did they possess,
And my pedicure, though passable, lacked a certain finesse.

My gel manicure, alack, was far too thick, I must avow,
And the cuts she made, oh how they smarted, and bled, I vow.
She applied some green ointment, to soothe and nourish my skin,
But alas, the damage was done, and a great scab did form within.

My eyebrow wax, a adequate task, she did perform with ease,
But alas, she did not trim them, only wax, to my great dismay, I must confess."

"Hark! What chaos doth reign within Walmart's halls!
The aisles, they be blocked, and workers, they do scowl.
A woeful sight, indeed, to behold such disarray.
And yet, who can blame them? Treated poorly, they be.
But fear not, dear customer, for still they doth provide,
In hours of great need, when all else doth deny.
So let us raise a glass, to Walmart, in its prime!"

"Last eve we dined here, and alas! the victuals were not of the finest sort. They be lacking in staff, a woeful sight indeed. Sonoma, a member of the Nola, Seviche clan, doth share their kin's penchant for mediocrity. Yet, I shall return for potations, for their wine list doth rival the gods'. Alas, poor fare doth make me seek sustenance elsewhere."
"Fare mediocre, waits absurd, cilantro doth infest each bite, loudness most extreme. Cabo, my love for thee doth wane."

"Alas, our fair proprietor hath sold her esteemed eatery,
A place of spices, flavors, and delights most rare.
The new masters, with their greed, have changed the way,
No more the lunch buffet, prices now most high.

Oh, do not be deceived by the name, my friends,
For 'tis a different tale, a new beginning's end.
The value now doth lie in the cost, alack,
No longer worth thy time or silver, woe is me!"

"Hark! We ventured forth to dine at yonder tavern,
Whose proximity to our humble abode did make it most convenient.
Their ale selection, quite impressive, did our hopes raise,
With bottles diverse and choice, beyond the commonplace.
I sipped a Three Philosophers, my spouse a cider, fair,
And thus began our evening, with promise in the air.

But alas! The service, slow it was, and tardy too,
Ten minutes passed ere our drink order they didst pursue.
The crowd, not overwhelming, yet our waiter, sloth-like,
Didst make us wait, and suffer many an anxious pike.
Our victuals, middling, frozen veggies, a shame,
I asked for salad, and waited, till my meal didst claim.

Thus, two stars, for now, our rating doth confer,
Yet shall we grant them further chance, to redeem and serve.
Until that day, our judgment doth stand,
Awaiting change, and betterment in hand."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, listen well,
For I have tales to tell of this place,
Where hospitality doth reign supreme,
And bad things doth take their proper space.

The water, oh how foul it be,
Didst make my tea taste most unpleasantly,
But cola, sweet cola, came to the rescue,
And saved the day, as it were, with its gentle hue.

The food, alack, didst leave much to desire,
For seafood, once a delicacy, now doth falter,
But hushpuppies, oh how sweet their taste,
Didst make amends for all that had passed.

Onion rings, alas, didst fail to impress,
And salad bar, though fresh, didst seem quite plain,
Like unto a middle school spread, I must confess,
Yet still, the welcome here doth remain.

So, prithee, dear reader, heed my words,
For though this place may lack in some regards,
'Tis still a spot where one can feel at home,
And that, my friend, doth count for much, I do declare."

"Pulled pork, alas, didst not impress me much,
For 'twas cold when served, and thus lacked luster.
Fried okra, on the other hand, didst delight,
Piping hot and crispy, a true gastronomic pleasure.
Vinegar sauce, a tangy treat, didst please my taste,
And Bud, the bartender, was most cordial and kind,
A friendly soul, who didst make my visit quite nice."

"A hearty wine and cocktail list, but quite costly for the meal. They served me northern shrimp in a tomato sauce, but failed to mention they were whole (head and tail). Very difficult to eat, as the dish was served hot. The quail dish was good, but small for the price. After a bill of $80 with three glasses of wine, we had to go elsewhere to satisfy our hunger. In short, worth it for a drink, but not for dinner."

"Methought this place would be most fair,
After a search on Google, I didst declare,
The best chimichanga in all of Phoenix,
But alas, 'twas not so, I do confess.

I ordered carne asada, full of hope,
But the spices, they didst not doth cope,
No cumin couldst I taste, nor any zest,
And the meat, it was bland, I do protest.

The rice, it looked fine, but the taste,
Was burnt, as if the broth didst haste,
And the beans, they were smothered in cheese,
But the flavor, it didst not please.

A couple of bright spots, there were,
The salsa, both hot and mild, didst stir,
The waiter, friendly and outgoing,
And the atmosphere, old school, it was going.

But alas, the food, it didst not impress,
So I cannot recommend, I must confess,
Tee Pee, it may be a place to drink,
But for food, I wouldst not think."

"O, woe is me! Awaiting in line, a score of minutes doth pass, and nary an apology doth come from those who doth serve. And lo, my son's draught, they doth prepare amiss. Fie upon this wretched fate! For had we not our babe in tow, I wouldst have ventured forth and made them know my displeasure."

"A fair location, with victuals of good cheer,
And atmosphere most wondrous, doth abide here.
Yet, alack, the prices do ascend so high,
As if the purse, they did intend to try.
For in the States, a bagel doth cost less,
Than half the sum, that here, they do profess."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
A grave mistake I made, and great was my distress.
For in a place that's not a sushi den,
I ordered sushi, and oh, what a sin!

The rolls were fair, but oh, the rice was hard,
And I, a fool, did not finish the dish, lest I be scarred.
The pot stickers too, did not delight,
For Lean Cuisine's are better, in truth and in sight.

And last, the brownie, a disappointment, alack,
A mediocre treat, that left me in dismay and discontent.
But mayhap, had I chosen another dish,
My experience might have been more pleasant, and less fishy."

"Methinks I didst spend a pretty penny, nigh thirteen silver dollars, upon a dainty shrimp cocktail, so small and wimpy 'twas akin to a mere morsel. The libations in yon lounge didst come at a steep price, and by my troth, the barkeep didst bear a haughty demeanor. Fie upon the decor, forsooth! 'Tis a relic of the seventies, and doth mine eyes no pleasure. Verily, I do not comprehend the cause of such acclaim."

"Fast-casual dining, a fan I be,
Healthy options, freshness, all can see.
No time to cook, nor deep pockets I have,
So, 'tis a place that doth please me well, by the Lord above!

They specialize in fish, cooked to order,
With choice of seasoning or sauce, a wondrous border.
Soups, sandwiches, salads, and tacos, all on the list,
A feast for the eyes, and the belly, 'twill dismiss.

Kid-friendly, they be, with options galore,
For the little ones, a treat in store.
But alas, my experience, a downside did bring,
The fishy smell, not so fresh, did my nostrils sting.

Mango salsa, a delight, on my orange roughy,
Brown rice, no complaints, a satisfying comity.
But the fish, oh the fish, could be better, I say,
At these prices, freshness flies away.

House-made chicken tenders, a plus, I do declare,
But too bland, alas, my child did not spare.

Great concept, yes, but quality in question,
A work in progress, a vision in transition."

"Prepare thyself, fair patron, ere thou enter Frankie's Tiki Room,
For in that dimly lit den, thy vision shall be naught but gloom.
'Tis a strange enchantment, indeed, that doth impair thy sight,
And maketh thee wonder what foul substances thou dost invite.

The drinks, they come with skulls, a rating most dire,
From sweet candy to a draught that doth sanitize and conspire.
Thy bartender, with a wicked grin, doth say,
"Choose a five-skull drink, lest I choose for thee, ere the day."

Katrina M., a lady of wit and grace, didst order for me
A green gasser, a potent brew, that didst astound and amaze.
The pour, it was most generous, a veritable flood,
That at first, didst taste quite vile, but as the ice didst melt,
It didst become more palatable, a true delight.

Alas, the service, it doth lag, a sorry plight,
For those who waited patiently, their turn didst take flight.
Even as the crowd didst thin, a sense of abandonment didst cling,
Leaving some to ponder, if they should stay or take flight."

"Methinks 'twas strange to find a dive bar serving Chinese fare,
But lo, my friend and I didst venture there,
En route to airport, we didst stop and share
A meal, the NFC championship game didst play.

Our order, chicken and veggies on brown rice,
Didst scarce receive a nod of approval, alack,
For though 'twas quick, the taste didst not entice,
Frozen, it didst seem, like microwaved dinner, quoth my mate.

Alas, our hopes were dashed, the food didst lack,
Deserving but two stars, a sorry state, indeed.
Yet still, methinks, perchance another dish may please,
And thus, a second chance, this place doth merit, ere we flee."

"Methinks I've visited this Bashas' several times, my dear. And, by the stars, twice have we vowed ne'er to return, forsooth. Once, the manager did speak ill of an employee, in front of us, no less, while we did pay for our goods. His words were most impolite, I do declare. And again, two workers did engage in tales of their amorous conquests, most unbecoming, as they did attend to our purchases. Pray tell, what manner of professionalism is this? Their prices, too, do leave much to be desired, alack. For though I did enjoy the Bashas' in North Phoenix of old, this one doth pale in comparison, I do confess. Fresh and Easy, yonder across the way, doth seem the better choice, in sooth."

"Hark, what news is this? A plethora of praise doth fill mine ears,
And yet, a tale of woe doth come from mine own lips.
Forsooth, I hail from Oregon, land of plenty,
Where Asian cuisine doth reign supreme, and pho doth dance with glee.

But lo, my friends, a sorrow doth unfold,
For Pho-nomenal soup bowl didst disappoint, I do declare.
Chili oil, a staple of the East, they didst not possess,
And Siriachi sauce, a poor substitute, alas, they didst proffer.

Oh, how the shrimp rolls didst fail to impress,
A taste so bland, it didst leave me in distress.
The price, a match for others of its kind,
Yet quality, it doth lack, and that, my friends, is hard to find.

Three months shall pass, and I shall return,
To see if change hath come, or if naught but sorrow doth remain.
Customer service, a beacon of hope, doth shine,
Yet, alack, 'tis not enough, for Pho-nomenal doth decline."

"A dimly lit tavern, with a booth in disrepair,
We entered, and the atmosphere did bear
A sense of dive, and the patrons did partake
In lively discourse, of books and their ilk.

A family, with children, did dine at the place,
And though 'twas not the most suitable space,
'Twas not inappropriate, nor did it disgrace
Their gathering, with laughter and joy in their face.

My comrade, with hunger, did order a feast,
A bacon burger, with waffle fries, at least,
And I, a grilled chicken sandwich, did seek,
With waffle fries, a curious, crispy treat.

But alas, the server, did forget the bacon,
And brought it out, in a bowl, with nary a notion,
Of how to cook it, for it was overcooked,
And hard as stone, with nary a bite to be took.

My comrade, did enjoy, the Asian slaw,
But the chicken sandwich, did lack, a certain draw,
For the grill flavor, did overpower,
And a sauce, would have made it, in an hour.

My Left Hand Lager, did please my taste,
But the service, did leave much to be desired,
For the servers, were friendly, but inattentive,
And the bill, did take, an eternity to present.

The prices, were steep, for the atmosphere,
And though 'twas not, a place of great renown,
I shall not return, for the prices, do bear
A theme restaurant cost, with poor service, and a frown."

"Hark, what ill fate did befall me this morn,
At McDonald's, where I didst seek to dine.
Robyn N, my comrade, didst join me there,
But alas, our meal didst prove most vile.

The place was empty, yet the staff didst dawdle,
And we, poor souls, didst wait an age to feast.
No paper towels in the men's room couldst be found,
Only those wretched blowers, mounted low to the ground.

My Sausage McMuffin, once a proud dish, didst seem,
Like it had languished long, in dismal dream.
The coffee, too, didst taste of naught but woe,
A bitter brew, that didst my spirits dampen so.

Alas, dear friends, avoid this place, I pray,
For it didst bring me naught but woe and dismay."

"Hark, what news is this? A tale of woe and discontent,
Of bagels, once so savory, now a bitter jest.
A morning visit, with hopes of speedy service,
Didst turn to naught but sorrow and great unrest.

One soul ahead of me, a line of singular length,
Didst seem a fortuitous sign, a swift dispatch.
But lo, the gods didst play a cruel trick,
As minutes stretched to twenty, and my patience didst shrink.

The employees, with tardy steps and careless hands,
Didst take their time, as orders didst confusion demands.
A mess, a fiasco, a sorry state of affairs,
Didst leave me in a sour mood, with naught but despair."

Last week, at Encore, for work didst I stray,
My company, didst split us up, to dine in array.
At Wynn and Encore, high-end restaurants didst play,
But alas, seafood and Italian, doth not sway.
Disappointed, I didst feel, yet didst decide,
To suck it up, and not complain, to abide.
In private room, we dined, family style,
Yet underwhelmed, I must confess, didst I feel.
Food, like homemade, didst look, service slow,
Server, didst flag down, drinks, didst bestow.
Alcohol, didst lack, as if by command,
Bosses, didst know me, too well, didst hand.

"Verily, I say unto thee, my dear friend, that these biscuits do stir up quite a commotion amongst the people. But, alas, I must confess that I do not comprehend the reason for such fervor. Forsooth, I have partaken of these culinary delights on multiple occasions, and I must say that they do not impress me in the least. The victuals, though adequate, do not justify the prices that are asked for them. In sooth, I find myself perplexed by the zeal with which these biscuits are pursued."

"Alas, the burgers be but mediocre fare,
A truth we've learned with much dismay and care.
The shakes, oh how they disappoint and grieve!
Three times we've given them a chance to retrieve,
But alas, each sip doth taste of ice and chill,
A bitter draught that doth not please our will.
Indeed, the price doth seem most fair and bright,
But, alack, 'tis clear the quality doth suffer in the night."

"Methinks I do not relish El Salvadorian fare,
For either I didst consume the cardboard display,
Or my meal was truly devoid of flavor and zest,
A plight most vexing to mine tastebuds, I must confess.

The appetizer platter, a dull array,
Didst lack the spice of life, and thus didst fade,
Into a memory, most forgetful and gray,
Like unto icebergs, radishes, a sorry shade.

The chicken, too, with rice and sauce so pale,
Didst fail to stir my senses, or to make me hail,
The culinary prowess of El Salvador's land,
Alas, 'twas but a disappointment, so grand.

Pupusas, however, didst delight mine eyes,
And in their savory goodness, I didst arise,
To praise their merits, and to seek them still,
For in those morsels, my hunger found its fill."

Hark! What sorcery doth bring me to this place?
A third time, by my count, and yet the space
For parking, it doth leave much to be desired.
And as for victuals, they be but a mire,
A feast for eyes, with colors bright and bold,
But little substance to make the taste buds unfold.
The Baja sauce, a delight, doth make me ill,
A woeful tale, that doth my stomach chill.
Alas, I pray, that wisdom may prevail,
And teach my mind to heed the lesson well.

In sooth, my aged dame and I didst stay
At yonder four-star hotel, 'twas a sight to see
SLS, a name most foul, doth dwell
In North Side's midst, a place of woe and despair

The sign, a wretched thing, doth seem
As if Affliction's garb didst spew forth a dream
I dwelt within the Story Tower's walls
A tiny room, with space for naught but crawling

The bed, a modest thing, didst sit
In midst of room, with sink behind, a witty wit
The shower and the privy, on either side
With doors that slide, and heads that collide

No bag of plastic didst they provide
A closet, ha! 'Twas but a rack, with drawers two
And worst of all, no ice machine didst abide
On floors, so ordered ice, with tip, thou must decide

The carpet, rough and worn, didst feel
The mirror on the ceiling, cool, yet soon didst grow old
Bed lights, a trifle bright, didst seem
Design, a trashy thing, a foul demeanor didst take

Yet service, kind and fair, didst reign
Save front desk, with faces stern and cold as stone
And tables, sturdy, didst provide a place to dine
In conclusion, SLS, a hotel most dire, doth lie.

"Tis a neat and tidy eatery, but alas, their Mexican fare doth lack authenticity. Forsooth, they prepare their burritos in a strange and foreign manner, and when I requested mine be made a certain way, the server didst reply, 'Nay, good sir, we do not prepare it thus.' Verily, it didst dampen my desire for their burrito. Moreover, they didst proclaim that pico de gallo, that most delicious of salsas, doth not belong within their burritos. I didst inform them, as any paying patron should, that I wouldst have my meal prepared as I saw fit. Alas, their accents didst make it difficult to comprehend their words, and their meat didst lack the authentic Mexican spices. Farewell, dear restaurant, for I shall not return."

"A place, not of my liking, I did visit with my sister dear.
We shared a veggie roll, and shrimp tempura, and edamame too.
But alas, none of it did please our taste, I do declare.
The service, fair and good, but naught else did make me stay.
For though the bartenders and waters, were fair to behold,
I would not return, for food, to that place, so cold."

"Hark! I came hither with two friends, 'twas six forty,
Happy Hour ended at seven, our server didst tarry.
He arrived at our table, two minutes past the hour,
And brought us naught but woe, with his tardy power.

We ordered victuals and drink, but alas!
Our waters came not till seventeen fifteen,
So we sat, parched and dry, for half an hour or more,
In this empty hall, on a Thursday, a sorry score.

A friend enquired of the Garden Burger, a vegan delight,
But lo! The waiter said, 'twas not quite right.
For Chipotle Ranch they do add, and eggs to bind,
Making it not vegan, a culinary find.

Their fare is passable, at best, I do confess,
But service, oh! It left much to be desired, alas!"

"Methinks 'tis a curious thing, this place doth hold,
A fee so small, yet the worth, I do behold.
But alas, my dear, my experience hath been woe,
For though the cost be low, the quality doth go.

We didst sign up for ballet, mother and child,
And at first, 'twas grand, a joy to behold.
But lo, the subsequent classes didst falter,
The instructors late, or cancel without a thought.

The class, designed for young ones, aged one and two,
Didst suffer from poor teaching, I do declare to thee.
The other mothers, cold and unfriendly, didst shun,
Save one, whose child didst play with mine, in fun.

In conclusion, fair reader, I say to thee,
This place, though cheap, doth not meet expectations, by and by.
Perhaps, a different class, or waiting for a change,
Mayhap, a better instructor, shall bring a brighter range."

"Alas, the victuals were devoid of zest,
The cooking, fine, the portions, generous at best.
But, alack, the flavors, they did lack,
A sorrow to behold, a woeful plight."

"Hark, what mall is this? So vast and wide,
And yet, so empty, as if 'twere new-born.
The shops, they be overpriced, I do declare,
And I, a humble customer, know not what to choose.
There be many eateries, and lights that doth shine bright,
But alas, I shall not return, forsooth, anon."

"Hark! We've returned to the Burgh, fair friends,
After three years in California's sun-kissed land.
And thus, our minds were set on this place,
Whose name was once Geno's, now changed, alas!

The interior, transformed, did please our eyes,
But seats at the bar, near the service area,
Were the only ones free, alack! 'Twas a woeful sight.
Yet, local brews on tap did ease our plight.

Mussels and fish and chips, we did order forth,
But lo! They came not steaming hot, nor worth;
The sauce, a delight, yet the mussels, cold,
And fish, a disappointment, fried not bold.

Aye, fries, triple-cooked, were soggy, weak,
And the batter, bland, did not the fish seek;
The peas, a saving grace, did make amends,
But, alas! The dish, a failure, ends.

Yet, the bartender, attentive, a gem, indeed,
Did make us feel welcome, with speed.
So, mayhap, for mushy peas, we shall return,
Or a dark and stormy, our hearts to learn."

"Hark, what news is this? A place so dear, yet food so base.
Their Malaysian chicken curry, a dish most vile and plain.
I fear, my friends, I shall not return again."

"Aye, this place doth lack in charm and zest,
The salsa, unremarkable, doth fail to impress;
A spinach-filled burrito, of sorts, didst I acquire,
But alas, the greens didst not taste overly fresh;
Yet, in its favor, cheese didst abound, a saving grace,
Still, with other Mexican eateries in abundance,
I fear, my return, unlikely, doth be."

"Methinks the other reviewers didst not taste,
As I have these past four weeks, the brew,
That doth pour forth from Oakland's cup.
Their regular coffee, lattes, iced, alas,
Are nigh undrinkable, and thus my quest,
To find the fault, doth begin. Mayhap,
The coffee sat too long, ere it was served,
And thus, the flavor doth suffer, o'er-brewed.
A Starbucks fan, I am, yet this doth pale,
In comparison, to that noble brew.
But fear not, dear friends, for all is not lost,
Their banana nut pound cake, doth make amends,
And stable Wi-Fi, doth soothe the soul.
So, not entirely hopeless, is this place,
Despite the coffee, that doth leave much to be desired."

"Alack, our second visit to this place doth bring forth naught but woe! Slow service doth plague our evening, and food most vexing doth appear. A fork, a simple request, yet five minutes pass ere it doth grace our table. Duck, a dish of mediocrity, doth pale in comparison to former feasts. Alas, the potato, a humble thing, doth bear resemblance to that of McDonald's fare. Two meals, cold and uninviting, doth require reheating, and steak, oh skirt steak, doth arrive when all else doth conclude. Freshness, alack, doth flee thy taste, and we, in twilight's hue, doth ponder this poor show. Their excuse, a rush most sudden, doth ring most hollow, and we, in discontent, doth take our leave."

"Methinks I've visited this place twice ere now,
With a gift coupon in hand, from an oil change vow.
And verily, good sirs, 'twas a fortunate chance,
For had I paid, I'd have sought recompense in haste.

My carriage, alack, doth not receive regular cleaning,
For my black lab, he sheddeth with reckless abandon, ye ken?
Yet still, I thought it meet to give 'em a try,
But lo! upon my return, the interior did lie.

The foot rugs yet bore traces of yon canine guest,
And the dashboard, alas! remained unswept, unkempt.
In faith, 'twas hard to say if' twere truly cleaned,
So henceforth, I shall not waste my coin on such sheen."

"Hark! My spouse and I didst take our daughter fair,
To this establishment, with hopes most rare,
For her birthday brunch, we didst wish to share,
And celebrate with joy, and love most true.

We called ahead, when morning's sun didst rise,
And made a reservation, with no surprise,
They said they couldst accommodate us, with ease,
At half past twelve, our time didst please.

My husband didst speak, with gentle tone,
And asked if they couldst do something alone,
For our dear child, on her special day,
A brownie, perhaps, to make her way?

The gentleman didst reply, with cheerful voice,
"No problem, sir, we shall make it our choice,"
And so, we waited, with hopeful heart,
For the feast to start, and our hunger to part.

But alas! The menu, limited it was,
And the food, but mediocre, alas!
The price, so steep, for a single piece,
Of chicken, free range, with fries, a paltry treat.

Our server, forgetful, or so it seemed,
Didst not bring forth, the promised dream,
The brownie, complimentary, or not,
We wished to pay, to make our daughter's plot.

So, we didst speak, and let them know,
Our discontent, with words most slow,
But still, they charged, for the dessert so fine,
And left us feeling, not quite divine.

I've been to places, where such treats are free,
For birthdays, and anniversaries, a decree,
But here, alas! They didst not follow suit,
And so, we shall not, this place, revisit."

"Fare thee well, dear friends! Forsooth, we sought to dine
At this establishment, famed for its delightful grub.
But lo, the prices did our purses sorely pinch,
And left us wondering if 'twere worth the scratch.

The victuals, alas, did not impress us much,
For though they looked enticing, their taste was naught.
We sampled several dishes, including the duck salad,
But found them lacking in flavor, and thus quite sad.

The drinks, however, did please our palates well,
And the service too, was friendly and swell.
But alas, the food did not live up to its fame,
And left us feeling disappointed, and somewhat lame."

"Fie upon the entree, a spicy pasta dish it was,
That did not impress, but rather did displease.
For though the drinks were sweet and appetizers fine,
The main course did not live up to its billing, I do confess.
And so, I took most of it home, but alas,
It met its end within the dustbin's grasp."

"Four of us did dine upon a dish most fair,
Entree, it was, and good, beyond compare.
But alas, the cake, so hot and chocolatey,
Didst not live up to its billing, in truth, not so.
And lo, the latte, that sweet dessert drink,
Was not included, but rather, an extra fee did stink.
If thou desirest such, go to McDonald's, 'tis best,
For there, thy craving shall be truly blessed."

"Hark! A dining place, with few within,
Two parties only, did our spirits pin.
A single dame, of years well-spent,
And couple, known to staff, did present.

We ordered shrimp chow mein, a dish quite common,
Flavors pleasant, portion ample, yet no bean sprouts, my dearest wish, did lack.
The menu offered beef, chicken, soups, and shrimp,
Standard fare, for Asian diners, did stamp.

Squid with snow peas, we next did try,
But alas! The dish, did not arrive, with flavor, did disappoint.
I could not eat, such blandness, oh so dire,
And thus, did leave, my appetite, in disrepair.

Fresh live fish, our final choice, did make,
Sea bass, the catch, did our taste, partake.
Steamed, we chose, and though fresh, quite nice,
Lacked lemon, a traditional spice, did not suffice.

In conclusion, this place, a rating low,
Two stars, out of five, does it show.
Average, at best, the food did seem,
And thus, our visit, did not fulfill, our gastronomic dream."

"Verily, I have graced this establishment thrice, with feelings most mixed indeed. Alas, on my latter two visits, the staff didst seem to lack the zeal in providing service of any notable quality. In sooth, my first visit didst find me in high spirits, for the vegetarian sandwich they didst prepare for my dear wife was of such excellence that she didst express a desire to return. And, I must confess, my burger didst taste most delectable. The service, in truth, didst rival the gods. But alas, upon my second visit, our repast didst fall short of expectation. The service, methought, didst border on the mediocre, and I, in faith, didst sample much of their cobbler (forsooth, my own dam didst concoct a most wondrous cobbler). And lastly, upon my third visit, the victuals didst prove but a pale shadow of former glories, while the attendance didst all but disappear. Fie upon't!"
"Fair victuals, but service did lack. Mayhap shall return.  A woman at the bar, full of ale, did shout and make a fray. The tavern, clean and neat, did please mine eyes."

Alas, when shall I learn my lesson well?
Since raids, staff quality's gone to hell.
Greeters now, so fierce and full of might,
Upsell thee with such persistence tight,
It doth become most uncomfortable, indeed.
And when my ride is finally freed,
So many tasks remain undone, it seems,
They expect me to just drive away,
With nary a care or worry, 'tis their creed.
On a recent visit, oh, woe is me!
The passenger side, they cleaned with glee,
Armourall-soaked rag, alas, they used,
And when I complained, the lass, she refused
To heed my words, or make amends,
Instead, to gas station, she did wend,
Returned with Funyuns, oh, how grand!
While they tried to remove the mess,
All she did, was stuff those circles bland
In her mouth, and munch away, oh, what a sight!
They had to wash it once more, alack!
For the stain, would not come off, alas!
A hour's wait, for such poor service, fie!
I complained to the manager, but she,
Shrugged it off, with nary a care, nor worry.
So done, with this carousel, I swear,
No more, shall I return, farewell, adieu!

"Hark! I have visited the Green Valley establishment, my dear. 'Twas an improvement, indeed. We didst partake in the Quatro Fromagi, a most delectable dish, I must confess. Alas, the crust, it was soggy and quite difficult to consume without the aid of a knife and a fork, I do declare.

"Methinks the musical selection, Motley Crue, doth not suit the ambiance of a refined pizza tavern. Pray, try again, good sirs!

"The decor, alack! 'Tis dark and uninviting, a veritable cave of gloom. I suggest a new interior designer, forthwith! Forsooth, the tables, they didst appear unsealed, a lack of proper cleanliness, methought. How the Health Department didst pass this place, I know not.

"Yet, there was a silver lining, my friends. The involtini, 'twas quite tasty, I must admit. Alas, not enough to draw me back, I fear. Fare thee well, dear pizza place, mayhap another time."

"Hark! Blu Basil doth resemble an airport tavern,
And hath potential, yet their prices do mount.
A dollar sign, not two, doth it deserve, I say."

"O, wouldst thou be mine own Moe's, how dearly I wouldst love thee! Forsooth, thy proximity doth make thee most convenient, and thus, I didst venture forth to partake of thy tasty taco salad. Alas, how great my disappointment! Instead of savory Mexican delight, I didst receive a flavorless chicken salad, with naught but a meager portion of guacamole to grace its side. Yea, verily, my own guacamole, made with mine own hands, doth far surpass thine in quality and quantity. Oh, woe is me! How I do yearn for that most authentic Mexican flavor, and yet, it doth elude me still. Mayhap, one day, fate shall guide me unto a place where such culinary delights doth abound."

"Fair barbecue, yet pricey, I do declare,
And portioned large, enough to feed an army.
Three stars, I'd say, the food doth merit, fair,
But service, poor, and that doth leave me wary.

African gentleman, behind the counter, he,
Didst serve with grace, all others, save me.
With samples, he didst freely give, and glee,
But to me, barely a word, nor asketh what I'd see.

Race, a factor, mayhap, I cannot say,
But differential treatment, made my day.
Upsetting, indeed, and left a foul taste,
Yet still, I shall return, for ice cream, my haste.

Free ice cream, a perk, for young ones, dear,
Who love the ham, and cheer, without fear.
I shall return, with hope, next time, to find,
Better service, and a more welcoming mind."

In fairest Phoenix, where gastronomy doth reign,
A sorry sight didst present itself to me,
At a place they call a seafood paradise,
Where freshness doth not live up to its name.

Alas, the catch of the day, so they didst say,
Was not as fresh as the fish at Safeway,
Nor Trader Joes, where sushi doth abound,
And leave thee wanting more, without a doubt.

The drinks they serve, a paltry selection,
No special brew, nor vintage of renown,
To set them apart from all the rest,
In this, they fail, and their reputation's crest.

If sushi thou dost seek, on the west side,
Koi, across from Harkins, doth reside,
A lone survivor, Be Sushi's demise,
Thy stomach's craving, it shall suffice.

"Hark! I pray this review doth change anon,
For SkySong's farmers market, a sorry sight it shown.
First day, they say, yet scant few booths did bear
Fresh fruit and veg, a paltry choice, alas!
Mostly cheese, jelly, creams, and such like dear,
A costly array, for common folk to fear.
Yet, SkySong's site, a wondrous place it be,
