And strange design, doth charm mine eyes, forsooth.
I shall return, for 'tis nearby, and cheer,
In hopes their wares, more bountiful shall be, anon."

"Tis a sight most fair, yet lacks the flavor true,
No wondrous mix that makes me long anew.
The onion rings, a gem, the sole item of worth,
Frozen patty, naught but common earth.
A price as high as Hillstone's finest fare,
Yet lacking in quality, beyond compare.
The place itself, in disarray and grime,
A haven for the hungover, lost in time.
Our thoughts, in sooth, a tale of woe and disappointment."

"Alack, I thought this place didst hold
Korean karaoke machines of old,
But lo, a Chinese knockoff didst greet
My eyes, with naught but trouble to meet.

The search function, oh how it didst fail,
And real karaoke soundtracks, didst not prevail.
Our group didst strain, to sing so loud,
Above the recorded voices, proud.

The place, a four-star, mayhap, couldst be,
But alas, no true KTV, didst decree.
No search, no English, didst they speak,
A disappointment, my friends, didst seek."

"This place doth be a dump, a pit of woe.
I didst not wish to tread upon this floor,
But needs must, for I hadst goods to sell.
The wares they peddle, purses and rags,
Are tattered, worn, and grossly oversold.
Fakes, too! For prices that would make one wince.
Besides these fripperies, they vend
Trinkets and baubles, cheap as dirt,
But naught of value, save the gages, fair.
I shall not darken this door again."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern! 'Tis a den of woe,
Where service is poor, and victuals but so-so.
We prayed for wings ere our feast, yet still didst wait,
A full quarter hour, ere our first course did arrive.
And then, as if to add insult to injury,
Our meal did come, but scarce two minutes hence.
By Jove, what sorcery is this? Fare thee well,
I shall not darken thy doorstep again, thou wretched hell!"

Hark! I did pay $46 on Expedia,
For a hotel with a good location, yea,
In Glendale, it did serve our purpose well,
And the staff, they were friendly, no doubt.

A free hot breakfast, a pleasant surprise,
Did ease my mind, and my stomach, likewise.
But alas, the halls and elevator,
Were not just old, but also quite foul.
The carpet, too, did show its age,
And the furniture in the lobby, in disarray.

Yet, I did spy a patio, quite fair,
And thought to dine there, in the fresh air.
But lo, the tables and chairs, unclean,
Did trouble me, for they were not fit to be seen.
Three staff members, idling, did I see,
While but three guests did break their fast, unhappily.

"Hark! I entered this establishment for luncheon,
And though I was seated with haste, the service was slow,
The servers were scarce, and hard to draw near,
I waited patiently, yet no one did appear.

At last, I decided on the smoked meat dish,
Advertised well, it did pique my wish,
But alas, the price did give me pause,
For what I had, it seemed a bit too cause.

Refills on soda, too, came with a fee,
A detail I missed, yet it did trouble me,
So, two stars I give, for the cost did weigh,
And the service, slow, did make me stay.

Perhaps, with friends, I shall return anon,
But on my own, I fear, I shan't be gone."

"Ranger Mike Garcia, with mood so sour,
Doth set a tone most unwelcome, I do declare.
My visit, with sorrow, doth he mar,
And doth my joy at this great site impair.
A movie, passable, the ruins, too,
But alack, the man at register, so rude, doth make me swoon.
A better face, for this grand place, they should employ,
Lest visitors, like I, do depart in dismay and annoy."

"Methinks I've heard much praise of this show,
And oft to Vegas have I gone,
But ne'er had chance to see it, till now,
When at last my curiosity was shown.

The play was merry, full of laughter and cheer,
But soon became a repetition, my dear.
When it ended, I did ask myself,
"Is this all? Is there no more wealth?"

Alas, I found it not worth the cost,
For which we paid, my heart doth protest.
I've seen it once, and that sufficeth me,
And now, I shall not visit it again, thou'll see."

"Hark, fair friends, we came to this place,
With locals' knowledge, and some familiar face.
The service, alas, did leave much to be desired,
Our waitress, rude and inattentive, her demeanor inspired.

Ahem, we started with drinks, frozen daiquiris,
Good, indeed, they were, a sweet and tasty surprise.
Fried mac and cheese, oh nom noms, how divine,
But, alack, my burger, a sorry sight, did shine.

I asked for cheeseburger, with all the fixin's,
Bacon, an add-on, not mentioned, my dear sir.
No fries, what woe, a burger without, alas,
Be sure to ask, lest you end up in such a pass.

'Twas cold, undercooked, the middle, pinkish hue,
The cheese, scarce, a sorry sight, I do avow.
In sooth, a terrible burger, a disappointment,
I shall not return, my friends, mark my words, anon."

"Alas, fair traveler, thou seeketh sustenance at Sammy's Beach Bar and Grille, a place most common, with victuals frozen and service most vile. Yet, my dear wife and I, with haste, do frequent this establishment, forsooth, when flights doth depart from McCarran's gate. Pray tell, why doth this happen? 'Tis the Waborita, a drink most fine, yet priced beyond reason, I do confess. The nachos and chili-cheese fries, alack, are naught but pedestrian fare, yet the Waborita, a gem, doth shine bright. If thou hast time to spare, sit thee down at the bar, for service doth crawl at a snail's pace, I do declare. Sammy's, in sooth, doth give back to the community, a deed most kind, and thus, thy stop, though costly, shall be palatable, an it please thee to partake of the Waborita, a drink most worthy."

"A steakhouse in Las Vegas, a city of excess,
Where gluttony and greed do oft express.
I chanced upon this place, by fortune's grace,
And heard of its renown, in culinary space.

The hostess, fair and lovely, did greet,
With beauty that did my heart entreat.
Her charm and grace, did make me stay,
And wish for more, in a different way.

The ravioli, handmade with care,
Did please my taste, beyond compare.
With duck sauce, rich and savory,
It was a dish, most worthy to explore.

But alas, the bone-in rib eye,
Did disappoint, and cause dismay.
Cooked medium, it did arrive,
But twitching, with blood, it did convey.
Cut for me, and served with haste,
The flavors, were not to my taste.

Expensive, the dinner did prove,
Leaving me unsatisfied, in a groove.
But Carnevino, a wine selection grand,
Did ease my pain, with a gentle hand."

"Hark! What news is this? The wings, they do rave,
But not the customer, alack! 'Tis strange,
For we do get them now and then,
But I must say, they be dry and not so tasty,
Best to put sauce on the side, lest they be bland.
And slow, oh slow, doth be their service,
Ten to fifteen minutes, doth it take,
To take thy order, and then another twenty,
Thirty minutes, ere thy wings doth come.
Methinks they wish thee to spend thy gold,
On their tight slots, while thou doth wait,
For thy order, that doth seem so long."

"Hark, what news is this? A hotel, once grand, now fallen to disarray. My stay, alas, was marred by filth and woe. The bathroom, a chamber of horrors, with peeling tile and weakened stream. The faucet, it did drip and drip, a constant reminder of the decay. Dust, it did cover all, like a shroud of shame. And yet, they claimed an upgrade, a view of the strip, a paltry consolation for the state of the room. Alas, poor Hilton, how art thou fallen from grace."

"At SpaFitFinder's launch, I did attend,
With SpacePhoenix, my dear friend.
The space, though crowded, did feel quite small,
But the TrimTini, oh how grand!

A kind gent, from Urban 7, did strive
To please us with each dish he brought alive.
Ceviche, though not my usual fare,
Was savored, and I did declare,

Urban 7, not my cup of tea,
But still, the night was full of glee.
A pleasant event, with friends so dear,
And memories that shall forever stay near."

"Methinks I've visited this place oft in days past,
And each time, my expectations were sorely tested.
The staff, though not uncivil, doth not strive
To be of aid or service, leaving much desired.
This Ulta, it doth lack in stock, I do declare,
Whenever I venture in for my buy 2-get 1 fair.
Their selection doth pale in comparison, alas,
To that of Best of the West, in my humble opinion."

"A hearty, consistent feast we did enjoy,  
As is our custom when we doth come to Denny's.  
'Tis a fine place to gather with thy kin,  
And for a fair price, a good meal thou shalt win.  
But alas, a star I must remove,  
For slow service, caused by lack of folk to serve.  
Thus, four stars doth Denny's earn from me,  
Despite the fact that we didst enjoy our tea."

"Aye, the steak was fair, yet not so grand,
At forty dollars, a price quite bland.
I chose the Surf and Turf, a special treat,
With scallops, and two filets, a feast most meet.

The filets, they were cooked to perfection,
And cuts of meat, most worthy of inspection.
But alas, the scallops, oh how they failed,
To meet the standards, of such a noble tale.

Forsooth, the place, of such high renown,
Should serve scallops, of far better crown.
Those served, did not, I must confess,
Live up to expectations, of such finesse."

"Hark! What news is this? KFC doth change its ways,
And I, in sooth, do fear 'tis not for better days.
Their chicken, once a savory delight,
Now doth assault mine taste with salt's fierce might.

But wait! Their sides, they do redeem the meal,
Mashed potatoes, coleslaw, mac n cheese, a hearty steal.
And biscuits, too, they doth provide a treat,
A respite from the saltiness that doth greet.

Yet, verily, I say, this place doth not deserve
My custom, save for those few dishes that serve.
Forsooth, a habit 'twill not become, I swear,
For KFC's changes doth leave much to fear."

"Hark, fair maiden, thou dost seek the wings,
At Hooters, 'tis thy heart's desire, I reckon.
Unless, perchance, thou art out to prove a point,
And show the world thy courage, or so it seemeth.

But fear not, for I have been kind and fair,
In my words, and not a soul hath heard me rail.
The Quad Cities, a pleasant surprise, indeed,
Yet, alas, the wings at Hooters, did not exceed.

In Chicago, there be better wings, I swear,
And in Puerto Vallarta, they did excel, my dear.
These wings, they lacked the flavor, and the batter,
Was not as flaky, more like a dough, they did scatter.

A local joint, I do prefer, I must confess,
For novelty, my heart doth yearn, and nothing less.
So, Hooters, take heed, standardize, I pray,
For when I crave thy wings, they must taste of the day."

The server, a sweet lass, she was, indeed,
For though she served the couple, with grace, she did proceed.
Shaun, her name, a kind soul, and gentle, too,
A pleasant encounter, in a place, anew.

"Hark, my dearest wife and I, for many moons,
Have graced House of Blues with our noble presence,
To partake in feast and revel in sweet tunes,
But alas, last eve, our joy did swiftly wane.

A pox upon the hostess, who didst place us
Far from the stage, in a most distant corner,
And when we asked to move, her reply didst sting,
"No server here, thy wish doth not avail."

And lo, the menu didst reveal its woe,
With prices high and choices few,
Mashed potatoes cold, and snap peas the same,
For $3.99, a price most unjust and lame.

The rest of the menu, once full of delight,
Now doth resemble a barren winter's night,
Devoid of charm and sustenance both,
Leaving us to ponder, in dismay and wroth.

Yet, fair fortune didst smile upon us,
When a floor manager, with apologies, didst fuss,
And moved us to a better seat, with grace,
And gifted us with drinks and dessert, in her place.

Our servers, too, didst earn our praise,
With their attentive care and pleasant ways,
But still, the night's mood, didst sour begin,
With that first faux pas, which didst cast a sin.

So, House of Blues, take heed of this tale,
And mend thy ways, lest thou dost fail."

"Alas, the chairs within this hall of art,
Are worn and foul, with age and neglect.
We came to witness opera's sweet delight,
But sounds from yonder theatre did intrude.
The corn that doth pop, doth lack its zest,
And imitation butter, doth not pass the test.
One must apply it thyself, lest it doth pour,
Upon the top, a soggy mess, and naught but bore.
No flavored salt, as at Harkin's place,
Doth leave the snack, in sorry state of grace.
Yet still, the Met's program, doth shine so bright,
In spite of venue, poor and lacking light."

"Fare mediocre, fifty dollars for a single soul.
Panda Express, a finer feast, I could control.
Chicken, cold and devoid of zest, did grieve my taste.
Vegetables, unclean, their flavor did not last.
Atmosphere, the only charm, a solitary star did save."

"A paltry meal, a middling fare,
Beneath the standard of a noble dining, rife
With flaws that marred its quality, alack!
The biscuits, made from mix of ease, did lack
The savory taste of homemade delight,
And gravy, thin and weak, did not excite.
Chicken fried steak, a sorry sight,
Was naught but breaded burger, devoid of might.
Yet, in this mediocrity, a gem did shine,
The Apple Danish, sweet and divine.
A solitary ray of hope, a token fine,
In this poor feast, a culinary crime."

"Five Guys, a place of feed, doth serve a burger fair,
And fries, with flavor, that doth please the taste.
But, alas, their service, doth leave much to desire,
For twice, now, have I waited, with naught to acquire.

In yonder mall, a fast food joint, they be,
Yet, slow, their service, doth seem to me.
Twenty minutes, didst we wait, the first time,
And yet, again, last eve, the same didst climb.

The staff, rude, didst answer, when we didst ask,
About our food, so long, in coming, didst task.
Late, we were, for the movie, and in disarray,
I shall not hasten, to Five Guys, again, this day.

If time, I have, a sit down meal, I shall seek,
For fast food, no more, my patience, doth break.
Fix, their service, must, or lose, they shall,
Customers, like me, who crave, a quicker call."

"Alack, what doth mine eyes perceive? A menu most meager, with naught but common fare. A bar menu, forsooth! And yet, the prices, they do ascend most steeply. A Caesar salad, mediocre at best, and naught but wraps and burgers to entice mine appetite. Fie upon this paltry spread! The Aria mall, pristine and upscale, doth mock mine expectations with its grandeur. Alack, what disappointment doth this place prepare!"

"O, how the cost doth rise, my friends, to thirty-five a head!
A mac and cheese station, a clever thought, I must confess,
But lo, the cheese did run, and thus, it did not please.
The desserts, too, were lacking, richness and choice, alas!
The salads, fair, with polenta, marscapone-infused,
Yet, shrimp, a big cocktail, there was none to be found,
And crab, lukewarm, not hot, a disappointment profound.
A pleasant dining space, the servers, quick and kind,
But, priced so steep, this buffet, I shall not mind.
The Asian section, meager, with three dishes alone,
Sushi, a sorry sight, no ahi, sashimi, or nigiri shown.
Rolls, unimpressive, like those at a Barstow gas station found,
Alas, this spread, not worth the cost, my friends, I have found."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess, our feast at Strip Steak did not impress. 

The time betwixt order and delivery was long, though the hall didst not seem full. And when our victuals did arrive, alack, they were not hot. 

I had the chop, a flavorless cut, devoid of taste, a sorry sight. My comrades, who chose the filet, found theirs to be fair, but not so grand that they didst finish the dish. 

The duck fat fries, a delight, the truffle mac and cheese, passable, the asparagus, a pleasant surprise, but the mushrooms, alas, were cold. The selection of sweet treats, limited, yet the cheesecake, a light and tasty delight. 

Alack, a disappointing meal, indeed, and one that didst cost a pretty penny, o'er four hundred crowns. I wouldst advise thee, dear friend, to avoid this place, lest thou wish to suffer similar woe."

"Methinks I do adore Flame Broiler,
But this particular branch doth leave me cold.
The victuals, once a feast for mine eyes,
Didst fail to impress, and my mood didst sour.

The tunes, they didst play, so loud and shrill,
That I, a man of words, couldst scarce hear still.
I didst comment on the volume, with a frown,
But the lass, she didst smile, as if in a crown.

Perhaps she couldst not hear me, forsooth?
Or mayhap she didst think me but a foolish youth?
I shall return, but dine within no more,
For loud music doth make a meal a bore."

"Methinks the service was swift and good,
Aye, ordered was a Octoberfest burger, and my guest, a cheeseburger, as well.
The fries, they did abound, in quantity, 'twas a feast,
No need to ask for more, our hunger to appease.
Alas, the burgers, they didst not impress,
Both of us didst think them similar to meatloaf, or filled with some other mess.
Ten dollars, a fair price, I do confess,
But for this burger, methinks 'twas not worth the cost, alack!"

"Hark, our merry band didst decide to dine
Upon this establishment, forsooth, on a Sunday morn.
The prices, ranging from seven ninety-five to ten ninety-five,
Didst seem most reasonable, and so we didst adjourn.

Some of us didst order eggs benedict, which dish didst please,
Whilst others didst opt for turkey, with mashed potatoes and stuffing,
But alas, the latter didst taste of boxed mix, and the seasoning
Didst lean towards saltiness, which didst leave us all quite vexed.

One member of our party didst request eggs, fruit, and croissant,
A simple meal, yet satisfying, and so no complaint didst ensue.
But, alack, the service didst leave much to be desired,
For the host didst not greet us, nor didst he show any fire.
No bon jour, no welcome, nay, not even a smile,
Didst our waiter bestow upon us, and so we didst beguile.
He seemed annoyed, and his demeanor didst bespeak
A man who didst loathe his work, and didst not wish to speak.

This company must relearn the art of hospitality,
For such behavior doth not beseem a place of dignity.
We wouldst have fared better at Denny's or Village Inn,
Wherefore, I give this place but two stars, and that's being kind."

"O, how vexing doth this place prove to be!
My birthday feast, a sorry sight it was,
For all they did, was errors make.
My friend's salad, with croutons did they flake,
Despite her gluten-free request, 'twas a mistake.
My sister's burger, burnt to a cinder, lay,
And my grandmother's sandwich, jalapenos did they slay.
The beer, a gem, yet all else, a no,
For smoking on the patio, doth the scent flow.
Four Peaks, a better choice, doth glow."

"Hark, good sir! This place doth serve fine ale and provide a comfortable seat. Tarry thou must, for swift service doth not abide here. A score of minutes passed ere a serving maid did take our order, and thrice that time didst elapse ere our victuals did arrive. Verily, I did request the bill, yet another score of minutes didst tick by ere it didst appear. Methinks, shouldst thou desire a leisurely repast, this place mayhap shall suffice. Howbeit, shouldst thou seek prompt service, mayhap another venue shall better serve thy needs."

"Alas, dear friends, I must recount my woeful tale
Of a meal most foul, a culinary fail
Pasta, once a dish of grace and beauty, now
Overcooked and drowned in cheese, oh what a pity
Lasagna, once a noble dish, now reduced to mush
And pizza, oh pizza, with crust and sauce so fine
But alas, too much cheese, a sin of gluttony divine
The service, slow and unattentive, like an old man's gait
And atmosphere, akin to a lowly tavern's fate
With vinyl tablecloths and tacky decor, a sight most vile
No reason to return, a place to avoid for a while."

My love and I did dine at this place last week,
I ordered ahi sliders, a tasteful treat,
And an "I love bacon" burger, oh how grand!
But alas, the meal did not meet our demand.

The slider buns, they did not complement
The flavor of the fish and ponzu sauce, I do lament.
And the burger, oh dear, it had no sauce,
I could not finish it, nor did my love, of course.

He had the jalapeno burger, but did not eat,
For the taste, it did not meet his sweet.
I may give it another chance, who knows?
Perhaps they had a bad day, the cooks, I suppose.

"Our group didst suffer from a sloth-like service,
And waiters, bartenders, didst ignore us with disdain.
I hadst dined here once before, and 'twas not a pleasant feast,
Yet, my friends, new to this land, didst wish to partake.

The ambiance, fair and bright, didst make our spirits light,
But alas, the staff, didst leave much to be desired in their plight."

"Vegas, five days didst I spend,
And dined on fare of princely sum.
Wynn's buffet, Studio B, didst try,
But sought a meal with shorter wait, nigh.
Seated swiftly, service fair,
But, alack! A burger, fries so dear!
A la carte, the food they sell,
Better choices, elsewhere to tell."

"Methinks I didst enjoy the homemade chips, oh so crispy and divine,
The red salsa, full of flavor, didst make my taste buds align.
The chicken pieces, tender and juicy, in my enchiladas they didst lay,
And the service, friendly and prompt, didst make my day.

But alas, the green sauce, so bland and uninspired,
I couldst not eat it, save for the red, which didst provide
A bit of zest, a hint of spice, to make it palatable,
Forsooth, the beans and rice, a disappointment, I didst find them dull.

Perhaps, my dear, 'tis my lack of knowledge of New Mexico's fare,
That didst make me not appreciate the dish, beyond compare.
But still, methinks, there's room for improvement, to make it more divine,
To please the palate, and make it truly shine."

"Hark! What Mexican eatery doth charge thee for chips and salsa? Tis a preposterous notion, indeed. The victuals, though passable, didst pale in comparison to the cost, which climbed steeply skyward after two ales and twain margaritas. Verily, I say unto thee, 'twere wiser to choose prime rib o'er enchiladas, lest thou desirest to part with thy coin most unnecessarily. There be finer establishments on Madison's West Side, shouldst thou seek genuine Mexican fare."

"O, how my tastebuds didst dance with joy at the gado gado sauce,
But alas, the chicken, o'er-fried it was, didst not please.
The mixed veggies, in a sauce so thick and salty, didst lie,
And in it, MSG, a plentiful amount, didst reside."

"O, woe is me! The service here doth leave much to be desired,
A plague upon this place, where I didst receive such poor regard.
The victuals, o'erpriced they be, and seasoned with naught but woe,
Didst overpower the taste, like a tempest that doth blow.
And yet, one thing doth please mine eyes, the many screens that show,
Sports galore, a wondrous sight, yet near the book, they do glow.
Alas, 'tis a pity, for the rest doth leave much to be desired,
In this, my visit, most dire, to this establishment, so tired."

"Fare was passable, naught but common wings,
Yet one grievance did my heartstrings sting,
Alack, the patio, where we sought to dine,
Was foul with dirt, and dust did cling.

Oh, wouldst some servant, with a broom in hand,
Sweep clean the area, 'gainst dirt's command!"

"Alas, my friends, I must report a woeful tale of culinary woe. The Thai Pan, once a proud establishment, hath fallen from grace. Its replacement, a new venture in North Scottsdale, doth falter. Aye, the menu doth boast of a sushi bar, a curious addition indeed. But fear not, dear reader, for I shall spare thee the gruesome details. Suffice it to say, the dishes lacked zest, save for the peanut sauce, which doth shine like a beacon in the night. Alas, the rest of the feast was but a shadow of its former self. How couldst this be, when the spices and flavorings of Thailand doth abound? Methinks the reviewer who didst praise this place hath lost his taste, forsooth. Fear not, fair readers, for there are better options. Swaddee and Sala Thai, they doth reign supreme, a true delight for thy taste buds."

"Eh, fair readers, listen to my tale of woe,
Of YongHe, a Chinatown eatery that doth claim
To serve Taiwanese breakfast, a feast most fair,
But alas, 'twas naught but mediocrity that did prevail.

A beef wrap/roll and Chinese donuts, I did order,
But lo, the beef was naught but chili oil-marinated,
Served in a shaobing, a Taiwanese-style bread,
A lazy way of cooking, I didst declare.

The youtiao, fried dough, was decent, I confess,
But soymilk and fantuan, both didst disappoint,
For they were naught but ordinary, I do swear,
And service, slow and lacking, didst leave me in dismay.

Alas, dear friends, I wouldst not recommend this place,
For Taiwanese breakfast, seek elsewhere, I pray thee,
For YongHe, a disappointment, doth leave a foul taste,
In the mouths of those who seek a true culinary delight."

"O, what deceit! They call the drinks strong, yet they be but watered-down vodka, o'erpriced, I pray thee. Nay, I have had better, by the stars above! 

And lo, the promoter, he who didst invite us to this club, didst speak falsehoods, alas! He didst promise an open bar, but nay, 'twas naught but lies, and I do detest those who do deceive. 

And mark my words, good sir, thou shalt not hear the sweet melodies of the Beatles in this place, forsooth. The patrons here, a motley crew, doth range in age from twenty to fifty winters, and their garb doth vary, some with hair of golden hue, and others, silver-haired, a wondrous sight to behold. 

But soft, what light through yonder door doth break? 'Tis the glow of the bathrooms, where one doth find a shared sink, activated by a mere touch of the foot, a marvel indeed, and worthy of note, forsooth!"

"Alack, this Walmart doth be poorly stocked,
And in disarray, a ghetto, some would say.
Beware, good sirs, and keep thy wits about thee,
For help from employees, thou shalt not see.

The shelves, they be bare, and in disorder,
A mess, indeed, that doth beggar description.
And shouldst thou require aid, forget it,
For they be nowhere found, in this dire place.

Drive forth, my friends, an extra furlong,
To find a better Walmart, worth thy while.
For laziness, it doth beset me oft,
And thus, I shop here, with a heavy heart."

"My dearest wife, I brought thee here tonight,
For special meal, and sweet delight.
The reviews didst praise this place, I thought,
A nice Italian dinner, we shouldst be bought.
They sat us quick, the waitress was kind,
But oh, the food, it didst lack, I find.
Fettuccine alfredo, we didst order,
But alas, no taste, it didst border.
No garlic, no flavors, a poor dish indeed,
We told the waitress, our disappointment didst seize.
She brought terimisu, a complimentary treat,
But still, no flavor, our taste buds didst retreat.
Olive Garden, a better choice, I do declare,
For flavorful meals, and a stay at home air.
So here's my advice, fair maiden,
Buy thy own ingredients, and cook with ease,
A bottle of wine, and a romantic night,
Shall be cheaper, and more flavorful, in sight."

"Upon the waters of Madison, we didst set sail,
And here, upon the deck, didst take our meal.
The sun didst shine bright, and all didst seem well,
But when the victuals came, our joy didst dwindle.

I didst order forth the shrimp po boy,
Whilst two companions didst choose tuna steak,
And one, the chicken panini, didst enjoy.
But when we didst taste, our faces didst turn sour,
For all the dishes were not quite up to par.

The chicken, tough and chewy, didst offend,
The tuna, overcooked, didst lose its charm,
And my sweet potato fries, with batter thick,
Didst lack the crispiness that doth make them grand.

Alas, what hath become of genuine fries?
Are they now naught but frozen, bagged affairs?
I do detest such additions, brought to please,
For they do naught but mar the natural flavors.

So, next we sail the lakes of Madison fair,
We shall eschew Bourbon Street Grille, and seek
The Green Lantern, where true culinary delights await."

"Methinks 'tis a fine establishment, with service most fair and atmosphere quite pleasant. Yet, alas, their victuals and potions, they do come at a steep price, I do declare. For those who prefer their Mexican fare mild and unassuming, this may be the place to tarry."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall us! 

Much deliberation had we, 'twixt Bellagio's champagne brunch and Wynn's spread, 
Yet, alas, the latter won our choice, forsooth, 
By dint of reviews praising its ambiance, far above the former's cafeteria-like air. 
But lo, the victuals brought us naught but woe, 
Cold entrées, fish dry as the desert sand, prime rib o'ercooked, crab legs watery as the sea. 
One solitary delight didst shine, the shrimp, sixteen to twenty in count, a gem amidst the dross. 
Alas, the cost, a princely sum of fifty crowns, with tax and gratuity, didst sting our purses sore. 
In sooth, not worth the cost, our disillusionment doth proclaim."

"Hark, we didst return, to give 'em another go.
The victuals, though not wondrous, were not vile,
Yet I do stand by mine original review,
For to my steak, salt and pepper I didst add,
Lacking flavor, it didst seem. And that prime rib,
Mostly fat, it was, a sorry sight indeed.
I, a master of the grill, know well
The art of marbling, and how it doth imbue
Flavor, but alas, a balance must there be,
'Twixt fat and meat, lest one doth feel cheated.
Outback Steakhouse, a place of better steaks,
And lower prices, doth await thee, my friend.
Chandler Boulevard, a location most fair,
Never didst disappoint, nor leave me cold.
Sorry, Firebirds, thou art not for me."

"Hark! What woe is this? My stomach doth protest,
For onion rings, once a mainstay of my feast,
Are gone, vanished from yon menu's list.
Oh, cruel fate! How could they thus dismiss
A dish so sweet, so savory, and so fine?
I pray thee, sirs, reconsider this decision,
Lest I be forced to seek sustenance elsewhere.

And, prithee, note the state of yonder fowl,
Which, fried in oil of ancient vintage, doth
Retain a flavor most unpleasant and rancid.
In faith, a filter or fresh oil, they should use,
Lest I, a patron of many years, be loath
To continue forth my custom and support.
Alas, poor restaurant, how art thou fallen!"

"Hark! What ill fate doth bring us to this place?
Their luncheon spread, a woeful, sorry sight.
The atmosphere, a scurvy, grimy taint.
And service, poor, a sorry plight.
I prayed the victuals might redeem the scene,
But alas, they too did fail to impress.
Dry, oily, foul, a gastronomic sin.
Too many finer options to choose from, friend."

"Tasty victuals, yet not quite the best,
Doth Delicious & Best Chinese Food profess.
Aptly named, mayhap, for Chow Mein doth please,
With Combinations and Specials, a fair price indeed doth seize.

Kung Pao and Szechuan, both chicken dishes,
Didst satisfy mine appetite, with nary a wish.
But alas, Honey Garlic, a sweet and sour deceit,
And Chicken Fried Rice, a flavorless treat, didst not meet.

Egg-Drop soup, unremarkable, neither good nor ill,
Doth accompany each meal, as doth the custom still.
Yet, skimpy on meat, they doth provide,
Asking if Chicken Chow Mein, with little meat, I did desire.

In conclusion, dear friends, this place doth lack,
Worthy of avoidance, with naught to attract.
Launderland, now defunct, doth leave me free,
Never to return, to D&B, shall I decree."

"O, what a sorry spectacle! Fair Holly, with beauty's blessing, yet lacks the gifts of art and eloquence. Her supporting cast, with voices sweet and steps light, didst shine, but she, alas, didst not. A paltry four minutes of mirth didst I find, but then, my eyelids didst droop, and sleep didst threaten to claim me. Fie upon this show! In fair Las Vegas, there must be better ways to spend thy coin."

"Tao, a place of wonder, yet a trial to enter,
My friend, thrice she tried, ere she gained entry,
A test of patience, indeed, yet worth the venture,
For within, the doorkeeper, a gentle soul,
Explained the layout, ere he stamped my wrist,
And we, like sheep, were herded, 'round and 'round,
The decor, quite pleasant, food, a feast for eyes,
But alas, the crowd, a multitude of folk,
With nary an excuse me, push and shove, they did,
Dampening our mirth, and doth our joy did steal,

Then up to Tao beach, a small, yet cozy space,
The pools at MGM, much larger, in comparison,
No room to sit, or dance, so down we did prepare,
But lo, a line, a wait, ere we could descend,
And note, the DJs, same songs, again and again,
A curious thing, this Tao, a place of wonder,
Yet, a Hollywood club, with bacon dogs, did lack,
Alas, my friends, a tale of woe, this Tao, doth bring."

"O, how couldst a seafood restaurant, so mediocre in its fare,
Survive the test of time and tempt the taste buds fair?
The Sancerre, a wine of renown, might have been the key,
But alas, they failed to make it, and thus didst decree
Its downfall, a fate most dire, and naught but woe."

"Methinks 'twas a strange and wondrous night,
Forsooth, we ventured forth to dine,
By virtue of a gift most fair and bright,
Which didst compel us to partake in this rite.

But lo, the server, quaint and queer,
Didst ply us with a tale most drear,
Of tables crammed in corners, flies that didst swarm,
And viands strange, that didst disarm.

Alack, we were not taken by the charm,
Of this odd place, with menu most bizarre,
And so, we vow, to nevermore return,
To this strange tavern, with its eerie atmosphere."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
Samba at The Mirage did not impress.
Their meats were dry, their service slow,
And their creme br\u00fbl\u00e9e, oh how it did go!

They brought us chicken, sausage, and bread,
But when it came to beef, they were quite stingy.
Two bite-sized pieces, that was all we got,
And when we asked for more, they seemed quite hot.

The plantains, rice, and beans were fine,
But the dessert, alas, was not divine.
It tasted old and stale, like it had been kept
In the fridge for far too long, and not slept.

So, my friends, take my advice,
And avoid this place, it's not worth the price.
Go elsewhere, where the meat is fresh and neat,
And the service, friendly, and not so beat."

"Methinks my love and I didst dine upon this establishment's fare this eve. Our memories of yore didst recall a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain savoir faire, if thou wilt, that didst impel us to return once more unto this culinary domicile. 

Alas, the bruschetta, a humble dish indeed, didst fail to impress. 'Twas naught but a pale imitation of former feasts, a mere shadow of its former self. My love, in his infinite wisdom, didst choose the blackened chicken pasta, a dish that didst stir within me memories of days of yore, of a certain chef boyardie that didst grace our table in times past. 

And I, in turn, didst select the four cheese pizza, a dish that didst leave much to be desired, I do confess. The sauce, a paltry excuse for a condiment, didst lack the verve and zest of former feasts, while the cheese, alack, didst possess a certain...plasticity, if thou wilt, that didst leave a most unpleasant taste upon mine lips. 

In conclusion, methinks this establishment doth leave much to be desired. Alack, my love, mayhap another time shall we find a venue more worthy of our refined tastes."

"Upon mine friends and me, this eating house did call,
For in the village, 'twas the merriest of them all.
A minstrel played inside, his tunes did reach our ears,
And thus, a tranquil night did our company prepare.

I did request a burrito, carne asada being mine choice,
With beans and rice, a generous helping, did they bring.
Alas, the meat did seem like ground beef, and its flavor, quite plain,
But my dear boy, his chimichanga, did find some grace.

Around the board, a consensus did arise,
That though the victuals were not wondrous, neither were they vile.
Of six dishes, chicken fajitas, the best did prove,
Yet, alack, the margaritas, watered down, did not remove
Our cares, nor did the other potions, strong they were not,
Save straight shots, perchance, then a good time might be got.

Our server, Omar, kind and courteous, five stars did earn,
But, alas, the total experience, not so much did learn.
In future, this place, I shall eschew, and seek another,
Or peradventure, stop for tequila, but no more, another."

"Pittsburgh, thy pizza doth suffer from a curse,
A plague of undercooking, a fate most dire.
The crust, it doth lack crispness, and the cheese,
Doth fail to turn golden, a sorry sight indeed.

The sauce, a generic brew, doth taste of naught,
A cheap concoction from a jar, no more.
The price, a fair two dollars, doth ease the sting,
But alas, the pizza itself, doth leave much to desire.

Doughy and rubbery, a bland and sorry sight,
It doth seem that Pittsburgh's pizza doth not excite.
The workers, friendly they may be, but alas,
Their pizza, a disappointment, doth leave much to pass."

"A fair tavern, with servants most kind,
But, alas! their wines do leave much to find.
Their list, though scant, doth boast some rare vintages,
Yet, I suspect, 'tis but a ploy to raise the prices.
I asked the staff, who didst reply,
That their masters sought to stock wines most rare,
And thus, the prices, they didst justify.
A glass of wine, ten dollars, I didst pay,
For a bottle, eleven, they didst sell, by day.
'Twas passable, yet, I must confess,
I expected more, for such a sum, I must profess."

"Methought the sole delight I found, dear friend,
Was sitting outdoors, observing mortals pass.
My spouse and I did come for sweet delights,
But found the cost did far exceed their worth.

The martinis, tasty indeed, yet not so fine
As to be worth the sum of sixteen shillings.
I had great hopes for desserts, as the name
Of this place, Sugar Factory, did imply.
But lo, they failed to meet my expectations,
And I, a humble homemaker, could have made
A fruit tart with a flakier crust, and less
Concerns about the fork's integrity.

My husband's chocolate cake, a feast for eyes,
Yet too rich, o'erflowing with ganache.
I do confess, its beauty did surprise,
Yet the taste did not quite suit my fancies.

Verily, I shall not return to this place,
Nor recommend it to my friends, in truth.
For though the atmosphere was pleasant,
The fare did not justify the cost, in sooth."

"Alas, dear friends, I must confess,
This place, part of the City Art Centre, doth lack,
In quality and value, it doth not possess,
The charm and taste that doth make a place attract.

A high-ceilinged room, with bright lights,
Doth make it seem quite soulless, in truth,
And for the price they charge, 'tis not right,
For cooked breakfast, better found elsewhere, in sooth.

So, gentle folk, take heed of my words,
And seek elsewhere, for better deeds,
For here, alas, doth not lie,
A place of worth, or value, to thy purse."

"Alas, how times doth change, and with it, our dearest haunts! This place, once my heart's desire, now doth pale in comparison to its former self. The menu, once rich with variety, doth now seem lacking, and my beloved rolls, alas, are no more. The all-you-can-drink draft beer, a delight most sweet, doth vanish like a mist at dawn. Why, pray tell, wouldst one pay sevenfold for a single brew, when for half the price, a draught Sapporo doth flow like a river in springtime? 'Tis true, methinks, this place doth lose its charm, and other sushi restaurants, with prices more fair and drinks more plentiful, shall claim my custom henceforth."

"Alas, my heart doth yearn for fish tacos grand,
But here, alack, they failed to please my land.
Their victuals were but average, I do swear,
And margaritas, merely passable, I fear.
Their components, cheap and lacking in flair,
Didst leave me in dismay, with naught to spare.
Perhaps their renown doth stem from being sole,
In NoDa, a Mexican eatery, I do role.
But nay, their grub doth not deserve such praise,
For blackened mahi mahi tacos brought me gaze.
'Tis but a mediocre feast, I must confess,
And those who seek the best, should look elsewhere, alas."

"Beware, fair shoppers, for all sales here are final,
No returns or store credits for brand new items, I do declare.
A pity, indeed, for this store doth have a fine selection,
And the salesfolk, they are most courteous and kind.
But alas, no refunds or exchanges, so choose wisely,
Lest thou be stuck with a purchase that doth not suit thee."

"Methought the fish tacos didst taste most wondrous,
But alack, what fate hath befallen this place?
Since first I didst dine here, twenties of year,
Hath passed, and naught but decay doth show its face.

The KFC/Chandler city strife of yore,
Didst take its toll, and now doth lie in store
A relic of days gone by, with naught to boast,
But foul chairs, tables, and such, in disarray,
And lo, a BBQ vendor, doth ply his trade,
In entrance, with scents that doth not blend,
With fish, nor beer, that we didst order made.

Ah, memories, how sweet thou art,
But nay, thy present state, doth break my heart."

"Aye, 'twas one of the first Indian eateries I had graced with mine presence, mayhap even the first, I doth not recall. And verily, I must confess, my taste buds hath been blessed with numerous Indian delights since then. Alas, this establishment didst not meet mine expectations, nay, not by a long shot. The victuals were dull, unimaginative, and presented with scant regard for finesse. Fie upon it, say I! Forsooth, Indian fare doth oft receive undue censure, yet I dare aver this place doth proffer naught but mediocrity. Avoid it, good sirrah, avoid it like the plague!"

"Methinks I doth study much, fair Glendale,
And seek out places to doth learn with ease.
Paradise, a haven, doth provide me with such,
Plugs abound, wifi doth work, save for some splees.
Coffee, unlimited, doth flow like a stream,
Cookies and bread, in sample form, doth gleam.
But alas, dear friend, naught here doth please,
For prices high, and quality doth tease.
Coffee, generic dark, or flavored, doth lack,
Food, o'erpriced, doth leave mine taste buds aghast.
Bakery, they call themselves, yet bread doth taste,
Dull, and cookies, naught but preservatives in haste.
Still, for coffee, and change of pace, I'll come,
But recommendations, none shall I bestow, ere long."

"Fair sir, the victuals were of quality, our grillman, too, didst show some grace. But lo, our serving maid, though pleasant, didst tarry with our draughts and payment, and e'en forgot my spouse's card, which caused him to return the next day. Alas, the maiden also dropped a fork in sauce, which stained my husband's attire most foully. Our children, too, didst partake of the feast, and found it to their liking, but alack, we all didst fall ill, my daughter so much so that she didst miss a day of school. Ah, woe is us, for we didst waste twenty dollars per dish, a sum most considerable. And, O, the privies! Fie upon them, both men's and women's, for they were vile and foul, akin to a portable outhouse, and I do not wish to dwell on 't further. Alas, we shall not return to this establishment, for our second visit didst leave us sorely dismayed."

"Hark! Compared to other venues of its kind,
This place doth lack, in my humble mind.
Too crowded, too small, and naught but one bar,
A long wait, indeed, for a drink to savor.
Shade and shelter, scarce, and overpriced,
Cabanas and daybeds, a king's ransom, precise.
Yet, the crowd, merry and bright, doth make,
The experience, worthwhile, for those who partake.
DJs of renown, they do attract,
Arrive early, lest thou be turned back."

"Methinks I do adore Jimmy Buffett,
But his Margaritaville Cafe, alas, doth not meet my expectations.
The victuals, though passable, are not worth the tariff,
Nor the interminable wait, which doth try my patience.

In sooth, there be some positives to note,
Adownstairs and upstairs, fun decorations abound,
And 'tis connected to a shop that doth sell
All manner of Margaritaville merchandise, in abundance.

But, alack! The negatives do outweigh the good,
The lines, they doth stretch on, like a serpent in the wood,
The fare, it doth cost a pretty penny, and doth not impress,
Dumbed down, perchance, for the masses, it doth seem.

And, oh! The margaritas, they doth leave much to be desired,
Processed, they doth taste, like a drink that's been conspired.

In conclusion, I would not return, methinks,
For though 'tis a place of revelry, 'tis not worth the stink.
But, friends, they doth insist, they doth wish to give it a try,
So, mayhap, one day, I shall return, and see if it doth improve, by and by."

"Methinks 'twas a Wednesday afternoon when first I stepped within this bakery's doors. The folk who worked there seemed most cordial, and their wares didst tempt mine eyes. Macarons, I had heard tell of them, but ne'er had tasted. Alack! I knew not what to expect, thinking them perchance a cake, with frosting 'twixt two halves. Thus, I chose five varieties to sample: peach, vanilla almond, vanilla, raspberry, and the blue one (alas, its name escapes me now). But lo! When I didst bite into them, they were o'er sweet for mine taste, akin to cookies in texture, yet lacking that certain je ne sais quoi. Mayhap others shall find joy in them, but alas, they didst not agree with mine own palate. Still, I shall return anon, to try other delights this bakery doth offer."

"Dined we with our spouse last eve,
And found the victuals to be quite bereft,
Of flavor, freshness, and any charm,
As if from a can they had been disarmed.
The server, pleasant though he seemed,
Did claim that all was homemade, a creed
We found hard to believe, for how could it be,
When dishes from a pot to plate did flee?
A farce, a sham, a ruse, a trick,
To call such cooking homemade, a flick.
For truly, 'twas a sorry sight,
This supposedly home-cooked meal, a blight."

"Upon perusal of the reviews, I chanced to visit thither,
And found, alas! my expectations were but vain.
The place, methought, didst fail to meet the praise
Bestowed upon it by the multitude in vain.
A trifle, mayhap, yet a letdown, nonetheless."

"Alack, my visits to Walmart be few and far between,
Once per quarter, a rare sight, I do confess.
And lo, upon this quiet Monday eve,
The store doth lie in disarray, a sorry mess.
Carts filled with goods, abandoned, left to roam,
A scene most vexing, like a bargain basement's home.
The sections, too, in shambles, naught but strife,
A vacuum, sought, yet lost, in this chaotic life.
The competition doth arrive, and how doth Walmart respond?
By letting their store appear as though 'twere trash, alas!
The cashier, absent, leaves us to ponder and wait,
Till the manager, aware, doth call the maiden back to her fate.
Four cashiers, a scant number, for such a large throng,
And handicapped parking, scarce, a problem, long prolonged.
Shameful, indeed, doth Walmart show its face,
In this, their lack of care, a sorry, sorry place."

"Upon the strip, I chanced upon this place,
With outdoor seats, a wondrous sight,
A popular spot, it seemed, from NY's grace,
And thus, my curiosity took flight.

We tried to sit, but had to roam,
Through tables, back and forth, to reach our home,
A strange affair, yet we did abide,
For our server, kind and helpful, did reside.

I ordered burgers, unsure of my choice,
Thinking it hard to make a mistake,
But lo, the meat was tough and dry,
A disappointment, nigh a lie.

My love, a double burger did desire,
Yet came without a bun, a burning fire,
So we paid more, for him to partake,
And thus, my burger, left untouched, did make.

Room for dessert, a sweet delight,
Deep-fried Oreo sundae, a wondrous sight,
Creative and rich, a decadent treat,
We shared it, but could not finish neat.

To that location, I may not return,
Or perhaps, to NYC, my heart will yearn,
Just for the sweets, my soul doth crave,
And thus, my tale, of this place, I do engrave."

"Hark, good sir or madam, let this humble bard advise thee well. Forsooth, avoid thou Garcia's pizza, lest thou wish to suffer woe. 'Tis a tidy sight from without, enticing one to enter in, But alas, the pizza within doth pale in comparison to its kin. Save thy taste buds, dear friend, and seek sustenance elsewhere, forsooth."

"Hark, what craving doth beset mine appetite? A burger, good and fine, doth please my sight. Yelp, I search, and find this place, with reviews most fair and bright. Mapquested, I doth make haste, to partake of their delight. A double, chili-cheese combo, I didst order, with hope most high. But alas, upon mine first bite, disappointment doth strike mine taste. Chili, so bland, doth coat mine tongue, and leave me in dismay. Another bite, I take, and still, the flavor doth escape me. Burger, good, yet chili, a letdown, doth make mine meal unsatisfactory. Fries, not fresh, doth seem, as if they sat, then refried, a shame. In and out, better, doth prove, their fries, fresh, and tasty, unlike these, which doth leave me unimpressed. Alas, I doth conclude, this chili, not up to par, a no, from me, it doth receive."

"O, woe is me, dear friends, for I have found
A place that doth proclaim itself most sound,
But in truth, doth offer naught but woe.
Sweet Tomatoes, they do call it, but alas,
No sweet cherry tomatoes doth it hold,
For which my heart doth truly sorrow.
Their salad bar, though filled with greens so bright,
Doth pale in comparison to its price so tight.
And, oh, the carbs they doth provide,
Bread, pizza, pasta, soup, and baked potatoes wide,
Leaving little room for healthy fare.
And, lo, the protein doth seem to flee,
Leaving me, a hungry patron, to despair.
This place, I say, doth not deserve thy coin,
For 'tis a den of overpriced, low-quality woes.
And, mark my words, dear friends, each time I dine,
My belly doth protest with grumbles and pain,
As if some wicked additive they didst design.
So, heed my warning, friends, and shun this place,
For 'tis a pit of culinary shame and disgrace."

"A plague upon this wretched place, where style doth reign supreme o'er substance! Ruben, a sorry sight indeed, with fries aplenty and naught but paltry curds and gravy to show for it. And, by the stars, what woeful lack of ale doth grace their menu! \n\nYet, fear not, fair herbivores, for pasta, pizza, and salads sans meat shall be thy salvation."

"Thou two stars, dedicated to the counter agent,
For his kindness and profession, doth shine so bright.
He explained all with a smile and hasty speed,
But when we refused insurance and fuel to feed,
A surcharge of twenty dollars, he did impose,
A mandatory roadside fee, no other doth expose.
With Payless, we paid the same for a beat-up car,
Whilst Dollar or Alamo, a better deal did offer far.
We journey back to Vegas, come June's warmth,
But ne'er again shall we rent from their dearth."

"Bougainville's fare did not impress, I fear.
Our drinks arrived swiftly, but then, alas!
The food, it did take its sweet time to appear.
Forty-five minutes passed, and still no cheer.
The eggs, they were runny, a sorry sight.
But sourdough toast and hashbrowns, they were bright.
The bacon, strange, and pink, his burger did stay.
Despite being ordered medium, 'twas a foul play.
We tried our luck at the wheel of fortune's spin.
I lost five dollars, but gained sixty-five within.
A Miller Lite and vodka tonic, our winnings did bring.
Our early morning meal, they did cover, with a swing.
Two hours later, a waste receptacle, I did adore.
The eggs, they were the cause, I do implore.
The service, good, our server, skilled and kind.
A shame, the food did not meet the mark, I find."

"Methinks 'twas naught but mediocrity that greeted mine eyes at Lee's, where Vietnamese sandwiches lay claim to fame. Alack! The memories of yore, when well-made banh mi graced mine lips, didst make this pitiful display seem all the more vexing. Nay, not a whit of judgment doth escape mine gaze, for oft hath mine eyes deceived mine taste. Yet, within those walls, a scant few Vietnamese wares were sold, as if an afterthought, a paltry offering to placate the gods of culinary tradition. Alas, how poorly didst they strive to emulate the grandeur of their brethren across the land! Forsooth, the grilled pork sandwich, thit nuong, that once didst stir mine soul, now seemed but a pale imitation of its former self. The bread, alack! Was all that saved it from complete ignominy, being both hot and fresh, with a satisfying crunch to boot. But lo! The pork, devoid of flavor, didst fail to impress, and the sauce, a strange and unpleasant concoction, didst leave mine taste buds in disarray. Verily, a disappointment it was, and naught but woe doth fill mine heart."

"Verily, I say unto thee, this place didst not impress me in the least. Forsooth, I hold Fate in high esteem, and Johnny, the chef, doth possess great skill. But alack, the service we received was most vexing, our server bearing a haughty demeanor. The entire table, comprising four persons, didst sense her unease. Trow, the concept of tapas doth fascinate, yet a hundred dollars for a repast, exclusive of potables, doth seem excessive, leaving us still peckish. Methinks I shall not partake of their victuals again, save for a draught, perchance."

"Methinks I've visited Herbox oft in days of yore,
And found its fare most wondrous, a true gastric score.
But on this trip, alas! The menu lacked its former flair,
A bland selection, devoid of zest and cheer.
The waitstaff too, once friendly and so bright,
Were absent, leaving me in dismal plight.
This place, once dear to me, doth now elicit doubt,
I pray the old ways soon return, lest my heart be routed out."

"Methought the fellow who took my order didst besmirch me with his haughty tone, as if my choices were beneath him. And lo, the signs they didst write, in haste and with little care, didst make excuses for their slow service and their privy, reserved for patrons alone. A pox upon their house, say I! For all their faults, the decor didst please mine eyes, like unto a noodle stand in the orient. Their Cambod-Ican broth didst taste of pho, yet not o'erwhelming, and my companion's crispy noodles didst seem like sweet, poor China takeout. Her curry, spicy and fiery, didst not sit well with her stomach. The payment system, clumsy and slow, didst vex me sore. Why not take payment straightaway, at the window, ere I must don my cloak anew, to signal them to bring the bill? 'Tis a puzzlement, indeed."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, I say unto thee, yon victuals were of passable quality. And by my troth, they possess a most wondrous device for dispensing beverages, with a multitude of flavors nigh upon a thousand! (Aye, not quite that numerous, yet still a prodigious array.)"

"Methinks my love's rendering of La Parilla Suiza into English - that it doth taste as when one doth cast up in the back of one's mouth - mayhap doth err. Our feast didst consist of chicken enchiladas, recommended by our attendant, with a verdant sauce. Alas, they were naught but corn tortillas, scantily filled with fowl, and topped with a green condiment, devoid of heat, yet brimming with tang. I didst partake, albeit with trepidation, and found the flavour to be lacking, for which I didst render thanks. Our server, a sprite of diligence, didst vanish forthwith, leaving us to savour the repast unmolested. A carafe of water, adorned with particles of sustenance, akin to Klingons in a Star Trek vessel, didst remain, unattended. Yet, methinks 'twas a minor inconvenience."

"Four of us dined at thy establishment,
With filets of beef, 9 oz., our desire.
Medium rare, we asked, yet they arrived,
O'ercooked, alas! and nigh unto despair.

I straightaway told the waiter, who agreed,
To take them back, and swiftly he did proceed.
The cook, through yonder window, didst ask,
"Do they wish more cooking?" Oh, what a task!

The steaks, indeed, were cooked too long,
And though the light may have played a part, 'twas wrong.
The waiter ne'er did speak another word,
Nor offered any solace to our discomfort, oh so absurd.

As one who once did reside in Wisconsin's land,
I know full well how supper clubs should stand.
But alas, thy business doth not meet the mark,
And thus, my recommendation, I must embark.

Sorry, good sirs, for this poor review,
But truth must be told, as all men should do."

"A Macaroni Grill, a place most plain,
With naught to boast of, save its name.
The service, too, doth leave much to be desired,
And prices, though fair, do not inflame.

In truth, dear friends, there's little to recount,
Of this eatery, so unremarkable and tame.
For those who've visited, know full well,
That naught but mediocrity doth dwell."

"Hark! My maiden visit doth unfold,
This eve, at yonder winged hold.
The service, fair and courteous, didst allow
A taste of sauces, and guidance, too.
The wings, alas! not worth the quest,
Yet fries, in abundance, didst bless.
A steal, indeed! For little cost,
The victuals, clean, and naught lost.
In campus' heart, this place doth thrive,
A gem, amidst the scholar's drive."

"Methinks 'tis naught but mediocrity that doth plague this place,
Neither good nor ill, a mere middling space.
The victuals, humdrum, failed to stir my soul,
Nor did the decor, a discordant whole.
The servitors, aloof and distant, did impart
A sense of chill, a lack of warmth and art.
We went for luncheon, and the spread did boast
A fair array of Indian dishes, toasted.
Yet, one thing stood apart, a shining light,
A never-ending basket, fresh and bright.
Naan, hot from the oven, did my heart cheer,
A small delight, amidst a sea of drear."

"Hark! What's this? A place they call Urgent Care,  
Where sick folk seek aid without delay,  
But alas, dear friend, thy hopes beware,  
For here, thy patience shall be put to the test,  
In truth, 'tis not so urgent, nor so grand,  
As thou shalt see, when thou dost take a stand.  
The nurse practitioners, skilled though they be,  
Can only prescribe so much, as thou shalt see,  
And thus, thy need for stronger meds doth go,  
Unmet, and thou art sent away, with naught to show.  
So tell me now, why doth this place exist,  
If not to heal, then what doth it persist?"

"Hark! My spouse and I, first-time visitors, do declare
This Taiwanese fare doth not please mine taste, I fear.
The prices, too, do seem a mite steep,
For quality of victuals, not quite up to keep."

"Alas, my dear friend, I didst venture to this establishment for the first time, with expectations of a hearty meal. But lo, the food didst not meet mine standards, nay, not by the hairs of mine chinny chin chin. I didst order eggs, over easy, but alack, they didst arrive, over medium, nay, over hard. Fie upon it, say I. The pancakes, too, didst taste of naught but dirty dishcloths, a foulness that didst linger on mine tongue. The bacon and hashbrowns, verily, didst please mine taste, but alas, twas not enough to make up for the rest. The customer service, methinks, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain... pizazz, if thou wilt. In conclusion, I shall not return, forsooth, for there be far better breakfast places in the valley, wherefore I do recommend Peoria Cafe or Brothers instead, for a meal most satisfying and delightful."

"A pox upon this nightclub, ne'er didst dine,
The decor pleasant, atmosphere quite fine,
But alas, the crowd doth swarm like bees in spring,
And music, oh so woeful, doth my ears sing.

Ten year old tunes, who doth desire to dance?
Top Forty, Hip Hop, played but scarce a chance,
Two hours in line, a woeful, wretched wait,
For those from Iowa, new to Vegas' gate.

But thou, who hast clubbed in NY, LA or SF,
Skip this club, and dine, forsooth, 'tis best."

"On Saturday, we chanced upon this eatery,
Around one and thirty, as the day drew near its end.
The queue, alas, did stretch and wind,
A lengthy wait, our patience did test and try.

We paid, in total, forty-one gold coins,
For each, a sum of thirty-seven, tax included within.
Our number, nine, they seated round,
In twain, a table, fit for royalty, profound.

The victuals, though, did not impress,
Their look, a feast, but taste, alas, did not transpire.
Exotic dishes, duck ravioli, tea eggs,
Yet portioned small, in pans, their serving size did beg.

The beef brisket, mashed potatoes, divine,
The black forest cheesecake, sweetness intertwined.
But lo, the lights, they dimmed, the food, away,
At three o'clock, no warning given, our dismay."

"A gel polish change didst I receive, for both mine hands and feet,
And verily, I must confess, great disappointment didst it bring.
$40, a steep price to pay, for naught but a gel polish change,
No pedicure, alas, to make mine feet look fair and bright.

She cut mine nails too short, and now they resemble french tipped nubs,
Ugly and unsightly, a sorry state, indeed.
I had thought to get acrylics, but the cost didst give me pause,
So gel manicure, I settled for, though naught but mediocre, it was.

The Yelp discount, I didst mention, and $12 off, they didst take,
But still, the price, didst seem quite steep, for what didst they make.
No tip, didst I give, for service poor, didst she provide,
But still, a token, I didst leave, in courtesy, I didst presume.

Nevermore, shall I return, to this place, I do declare,
For service bad, and prices high, didst leave me in disrepair."

"Hark! A word of warning, let this place beware,
For those who seek a meal most fair and rare.
A pesto shrimp spaghetti, with flavor so bland,
Did leave my taste buds in a barren land.
The noodles, devoid of zest, did taste like card,
And left me wondering, what sorcery had marred.
The calamari, a saving grace, did please,
But service, par, with nary a increase.
A three-star rating, I do proclaim,
For this eatery, a shameful name."

"Hark! A place I've longed to visit, and now 'tis here,
A bustling tavern, full of life and cheer.
We found a cozy spot, near to the band,
And ordered tacos, eager to taste their land.
Carne asada and pork, alas, were naught but fair,
But shrimp, oh shrimp, thou art a wondrous sight.
Their beer, dear friends, doth come at quite a cost,
Seventeen pieces of eight, a price most lost.
Yet, for the atmosphere, we did not mind,
But, lo! The heat, it did our spirits grind.
And, by my troth, a bottle of Bud Light,
Didst come in a can, a curious sight.
Next time, we shall seek out America's Taco Shop,
For carne asada, truly fit for a king's hop."

"Hark! We went to Surrender, a place of revelry,
To see Calvin Harris, a man of great skill,
We bought prepaid tickets, to gain swift entry,
And arrived at the club, when the night was still.

But alas! Our excitement soon did dwindle,
For though the club had promise, 'twas not well-designed,
Eighty percent of the space, outdoors did lie,
Yet the indoor portion, did the DJ deny.

Calvin Harris played, but none could dance,
Unless they had a table, of three thousand chance,
A waste of money, on the cover, we did find,
For men it was a hundred, and women, forty to bind.

So, dear friends, take heed of our tale,
And seek elsewhere, a better time to hail."

"Methinks 'tis my second time at this place,
And, lo, my expectations doth decrease apace.
A Green Chile cheeseburger, I didst order,
But, alack, the waiter didst warn me of its power.
'Tis true, the presentation didst lack finesse,
The bread, it didst seem, was placed with little care,
And, when I didst remove the top, alas,
The green chile, it didst scarce cover the meat, fair sir.
I asked for more, and, presto, 'twas brought,
But, alas, 'twas from a can, and not worth the thought.
My girlfriend's meal, a Green Chile Chicken dish,
Didst also fail to impress, with its strange mix
Of rice, beans, cheese, and chicken, all a-jumble,
She said 'twas too salty, and her taste didst stumble.
In truth, this food, it doth not evoke
The flavors of New Mexico, but a Texan cloak.
Hatch chile, it doth seem, doth play the part,
But, alas, 'tis not enough to win my heart."

"Alas, poor stomachs, empty and forlorn,
For though the decor of this place did shine,
Our meals, alack, did never make their dawn,
And so we left, with naught but bitter wine.

Oh, how I wished to savor their delight,
But fate, it seemed, did conspire against our plight,
For though we waited, patient and serene,
Our orders, they did never come to be seen.

And thus, dear friends, we took our leave,
With hunger pangs that did our spirits grieve,
And though I dreamt of flavors sweet and fine,
I fear I shall never know their taste divine."

"Hark! What's this? A sign doth boast, 'Best Carne Asada in Phoenix', yet the fare doth fall far short of such grand claims.  Alack! The staff, so disinterested in serving guests, doth make one wonder how they keep their doors open.  And when at last my burrito doth arrive, 'twas tiny, a mere morsel, and lacking in both flavor and texture.  Alas! The lime wedge, once a symbol of zest and vitality, doth now resemble a shriveled, lifeless thing.  In truth, this meal doth leave much to be desired.  How false, that sign! Forsooth, 'tis naught but a cruel jest."

"Methought Lucille's BBQ in fair Las Vegas doth reign supreme,
Whilst Pot Liquor's offerings, though plentiful, did seem extreme.
A rack of ribs, quite tasty, yet naught truly astounding,
Did fill my belly, but left me not entirely satisfying.

The service, middling, with naught but rote replies,
Did leave me feeling that my visit did not quite suffice.
So, gentle reader, heed my words of caution,
And lower thy expectations, lest thou art disappointed."

"Two stars, alack, for this, the worst of three,
That I have visited, with mine own eyes,
The usual SS dishes, they do have,
But Calamari, oh wherefore art thou?
In Chicago, 'twas the most delectable treat,
But here, alas, 'tis nowhere to be found,
A grievous fault, indeed, and cause for woe,
That doth detract from yonder culinary joy.

The location, too, doth leave much to be desired,
Inside a mall, with naught but shops nearby,
And atmosphere, that doth lack a certain fire,
That doth make dining here, a sorry plight.
In Chicago, Miami, swanky, cool, and fun,
But here, in Vegas, doth feel like Legal Seafood's done.

Alas, poor restaurant, with potential great,
Doth fall short, with flaws, so evident and clear,
If thou art in Vegas, choose another spot,
For this one doth not merit thy attention, dear."

"Fair fare, but dearly bought, I say,
Like Olive Garden or Red Lobster's way,
With service five stars, I do declare,
But price, alas, doth leave me cold and grey."

"Fie upon this Vegas drink, my friends,
'Tis a vile concoction, a wicked blend,
That leaves one feeling quite undone,
And not in a merry, jolly way, I wager.

I sought an Eiffel Tower drink,
But alas, 'twas not meant to be,
For they served me a strawberry daquiri,
With nary a drop of tequila, quotha!

The drink itself, a foul brew,
Didst make me reel and feel quite blue,
And cost me sixteen pieces of silver,
A price most steep, I do declare, my dear.

I'd rather pay for a Fat Tuesday fill,
Than suffer through such a drink again,
For though their alcohol may be strong,
It doth not leave me feeling so quite wrong.

So, friends, avoid this drink, I pray,
And seek out Fat Tuesday, come what may,
For there, at least, thou shalt find cheer,
And not be left in such a sorry state, my dear."

"O, woe is me, dear friends, for I do find
This theatre most vexing, and thus, I do avoid
Its confines, opting instead for other haunts
That lie beyond the city's bustling bounds.

Firstly, its location doth elude my grasp,
A secret hideaway, concealed from view,
And were it not for yonder sign that doth direct,
I might have ne'er discovered it, I do confess.

And once within, my troubles did ensue,
For at the concession stand, confusion did reign,
The popcorn, cold and stale, did fail to impress,
And left me in a state of utter dismay.

The seats, old, cramped, and hard, did cause me woe,
And in the darkness, I did feel quite alone,
A feeling strange and foreign, ne'er before known,
In other cinemas, where crowds did gather and moan.

Thus, I do choose to shun this place, my friends,
And seek elsewhere, entertainment that doth endure,
For this theatre, doth fail, in every way,
To meet my expectations, and doth leave me cold, I pray."

In fair hotel, with rooms most spacious and neat,
We found abode, where comfort did greet.
But alas, kind service did lack,
And staff did seem, in manner quite brusque.
At departure, girl at desk did say,
"Hello," and naught else, as she handed bill.
I, of cheerful mood, do not require much,
Yet for such coin, some warmth I do beseech.

"Methinks my love and I didst venture forth to Fremont Street, our bellies growling with hunger. Forsooth, we hadst spent a pretty penny on victuals at the strip, thus this establishment didst seem a veritable bargain. The decor, an eighties jungle theme, didst strike my fancy. Our server, a kindly soul, didst attend to us with diligence. Alas, the fare didst leave much to be desired. I didst partake of several dishes, yet found myself taking but a single bite or two. Methinks 'tis laughable that they didst proclaim it a steak dinner buffet, when in truth, 'twas naught but thin strips of carne asada. Tasty, mayhap, but not what I do imagine when I think of steak. To sate my hunger, I didst make ten journeys to the carving station, for they didst parcel out the meat with great stinginess. In conclusion, I didst not fall ill, I didst feel full, and 'twas a reasonable price. Yet wouldst I return? Nay."

"Mornings bring slow service, 'tis a woeful sight,
A line doth form, and patience doth take flight.
Fifteen minutes pass, and yet, no coffee in hand,
But two, nay three, do stand before thee, in this land.
Friendly faces, ay, but tasks they cannot juggle,
A poor mix, indeed, for those who serve with a struggle."

"Hark, my sandwich did take a mere half-hour to arrive! By Jove, 'tis a wonder, a feast fit for the gods! Yet, alas, my friends do swear by this place, and I, a humble bard, doth find it lacking. The din, the noise, doth make it hard to hear, to converse with one's neighbor. The serving maid, she doth bring forth sustenance, and doth present the bill, but doth not ask if aught be needed. No refills, no ale, nay, not even napkins. Rudeness personified, I say! If thou dost not wish to tend to guests, then, prithee, why art thou here? The only virtue, methinks, lies in the multitude of televisions, each displaying a different sport, a true delight!"

"Hark! What's this? A shopping place so dull,
With naught but common stores to enthrall.
The word 'Premium' doth not belong,
For here is naught but mediocrity to ponder.

In summer's heat, a respite from the sun,
But alas! The shops, they are so few,
And those that be, are not of great renown,
Leaving me to seek elsewhere my fortune.

Unless they change, and bring new delights,
I shall bypass this place with all my might."

"Alack, my dearest friend, how vexed I am!
This place, that once did hold such promise, doth fail.
The brisket, though tender, lacked the flavor true,
And fried chicken, o'er salted, did my taste buds wound.
Meaty Mac, with blue cheese, did leave me cold,
But coleslaw, sweet and crunchy, did my spirits lift.
Alas, the price, $35, did seem quite steep,
For service, poor, the waitress did not keep.
But nay, my friend, do not despair,
For other places there be, that may yet please thee there."

"Hark! My gym doth lie near to mine abode,
In a pleasant quarter, where folk do stroll.
Many machines for cardio, treadmills aplenty,
Yet, alas! Trainers do pester me so,
With offers to guide, and their wares to sell.
Their calls, like pestilence, do pour upon me,
Two on the morrow, from diverse men, did tell.
I shall, ere long, my membership rescind,
For peace, and quiet, are my heart's desire."

"Alas, my dearest wife and I didst dine at this establishment, and verily, 'twas a disappointment most foul. In days of yore, we didst enjoy many a feast at this very cafe, but nay, not on this day. Our server, a laggard, didst attend to us with all the haste of a snail, and our victuals, alack, were naught but vile and tasteless. A Cobb salad, devoid of flavor, didst I consume, while my wife, her oxtail stew didst relish. Yet, our discontent didst center upon the service, forsooth. In days past, this place didst provide us with service most excellent, but now, alas, 'tis naught but a shadow of its former self. Methinks, it doth sorrow me to behold this decline, for this once-distinct eatery doth risk becoming naught but a common, overpriced tavern. Fie upon this sorry state of affairs! My heart doth ache, for I didst hold this Golden Nugget in high esteem."

"Hark! A grand WHA WHA! didst echo through the night,
As we, a group of six fair maidens, didst take flight.
A cover of twenty dollars, oh how steep!
We didst decide to leave, our spirits doth droop.

But lo! As we didst depart, free passes were had,
And back we didst turn, our moods now quite glad.
The interior, most wondrous to behold,
Yet, alas! The dance floor, our spirits to unfold.

In such a crush of people, sweaty and besotted,
How can one dance? Our beauty, soon forgotten.
But, perchance, 'tis wise to push thy way,
Into the throng, lest thou shouldst fall, they say.

The pool, wherein the maidens didst reside,
Didst bring forth sorrow, our hearts to divide.
Their greetings, kindly, yet our gaze, so blank,
Didst make us seem, as if our souls didst lack."

Hark! I say, good sir, how strange it be,
That thou, a purveyor of fast food, shouldst forget,
To ask what drink I wished, and instead,
Didst hand me, without word or query, a Coke.

I reckon 'tis a small mistake, and so,
I chose to let it pass, and not make a show.
But lo! When I opened up the bag,
I found fries, and not the onion rings I'd tagged.

I mentioned this to thee, and thou,
Didst fetch the proper food, and handed it to me anew.
Yet, in thy haste, thou didst forget,
To offer apology, or even a regret.

Now, mark my words, good sir,
This lack of care, doth leave a sour taste,
In my mouth, and doth besmirch,
The reputation of this, thy Burger King estate.

Still, I shall give thee, another chance,
For convenience's sake, and proximity to my dance.
But, prithee, take heed, and learn,
To mind the details, lest thou lose,
The custom of thy patrons, one by one.

"Pimms we did imbibe, my dear, and 'twas a wondrous draught indeed. But alack, the victuals that did follow, they did not meet our expectations, forsooth. Bland and uninspired, they did taste, like a dish cooked by a novice, without the slightest hint of flair or finesse. And yet, we did return, in hope of fairer fare. High tea, we did partake, with scones most delectable, but alas, the tiny sandwiches, stale and lacking in zest, they did disappoint. And salmon, oh so red and gleaming, from a packet, 'twas plain to see."

"Alas, my visit to this place didst not bode well,
For all around me, others didst revel.
Perhaps I chose a day most foul and ill,
But still, my grievances shall be told.

The vegetables, oh how they didst disappoint,
I had to search through them with great intent.
Carrots and tomatoes, both didst lack sheen,
And sweet and sour sauce, didst taste most lean.

But service, that didst make up for some ill,
Our server, friendly and diligent still.
She didst check on us with regular pace,
And with a smile, didst brighten up the space.

So mayhap, fortune shall smile upon me,
Next time I dine, it shall be a bounty.
Till then, alack, this visit doth beset,
A memory, not so fond, doth linger yet."

"Hark, my dearest fiancé and I didst dine at this establishment,
And both of us didst order the steak omelet, in faith.
His plate didst burst with steak, and all the trimmings,
But mine, alas, didst contain but three small pieces,
A paltry amount, indeed.

I didst query the servers, and two managers didst come,
To tell me that the steak is weighed beforehand,
And that, my friend, is all you shall receive, they didst say.
But I, a man of wit and wisdom, didst protest,
And didst point out the disparity between our plates.

'Tis true, I didst pay the same price as my love,
And thus, I didst demand a fair portion,
But they, in their rudeness, didst ignore my plea,
And didst bring me a side of steak bits, after much delay.

Alas, my friends, I shall not return to this place,
For their customer service is poor, and their steak, a disgrace."

"Upon a weekday, I didst venture forth for dinner,
And found the service to be but mediocre, at best.
The victuals, too, were naught but middling fare,
Not worth the praise, nor worth the cost, I fear.

The establishment, old and worn, didst bear
A strange, unpleasant odor, which didst assail mine nose.
'Tis naught but a humble tavern, where the locals doth gather,
And not a place of note, for oysters or any other dish, I do suppose."

"By my troth, I do declare,
The five-star reviews, I cannot comprehend.
My victuals, devoid of zest and flair,
Were served, a culinary disaster, I swear.

Vietnamese cuisine, with spices so bold,
Should tantalize the taste buds, young and old.
But alas, my meal, a flavorless dish,
Left me in wonder, with naught but a wish.

And Jeff's, oh how it did astound,
A veritable mountain of salt, profound.
On Vietnamese fare, such seasoning's a faux pas,
A gastronomic sin, I must confess, alack!

Yet still, I shall return, for convenience' sake,
And order spring rolls, a dish that doth partake
Of crunch and freshness, a delightful treat,
A vegan's solace, in this city's heat."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news is this? A humble tavern, full of wondrous dishes, doth please mine eyes and taste. Yet, alas, the wait doth stretch on, like a never-ending line of schoolchildren at play. The patrons, with their great importance, doth take up space, and the parking lot, a chaotic mess, doth test mine patience. Verily, I say, for such a bustling place, a larger home would befit these noble cooks. Two stars, I give, forsooth, for prices, in my mind, should be more modest, anon."

Nearby market doth abide,
Open all day, yet stock doth slide.
Specific goods thou dost require?
Chance they be gone, or no longer acquire.
Unreliable, this place doth prove,
For true groceries, seek elsewhere above.
Harris Teeter or Trader Joes, thy quest,
For essentials, this place doth suggest.
Creamer, milk, eggs, perchance,
But cashiers, beware, o'ercharge with glee.
Pay heed to thy bill, lest errors be,
And coupons, claimed, yet unseen by thee.

"Verily, I have graced this place with mine own presence a countless number of times. My desire for Pei Wei hath been building within me for nigh on two weeks. At last, I didst decide to partake of their lettuce wraps and a single spring roll. Alas, the wraps didst possess an aftertaste most foul, and the spring roll, though acceptable, didst leave much to be desired. The ginger was overpowering, and the seaweed didst prove too chewy. Methinks I shall not be hastening back to this establishment anytime soon."

This past weekend, I didst venture to the establishment for a swift repast. Alas, the place was empty, and we didst tarry for twenty minutes ere we were seated. The hostess, a curt and crabbed soul, didst greet us with scant courtesy. Yet, the victuals didst prove satisfactory, though 'tis clear that they must attend to their hospitality, lest they lose custom.

"Alas, this eating house didst fall short of greatness,
With prices of $17 and more, I didst expect a feast.
I ordered Gorgonzola chicken pasta, anticipating
A dish most rich and creamy, yet it didst not meet my hopes.
'Twas naught but cafeteria fare, a bitter disappointment.

But lo, they were most kind to children, a boon indeed.
Their bread was good, and clams, a tasty appetizer, didst please.
My husband, too, didst enjoy his prime rib, a hearty meal.

Yet still, the pasta, which I didst expect to be divine,
Didst fail to impress. Alas, the price didst not align.
The staff, in fairness, didst attend to our each need,
But oh, the food, it didst not justify the cost, I do declare."

"Methinks 'twas a fateful day when first we stepped inside Mon Ami Gabi's hallowed halls, my love and I, on holiday in fair Las Vegas.
