Eleven summers past, we savored their French Onion Soup, a culinary delight that left us in raptures. Yet, alack! Our recent visit proved a sorry tale of woe, for though the victuals were passable, the service we received was naught but a pale shadow of former glories. A pert young maiden at the hostess' station didst greet us with a scowl and words most uncivil, refusing to divulge the wait time, save only that our 'full party must be present.' Tsk, tsk! How churlish, to be sure! And lo, we were straightway seated, our kin arriving in short order. The bill of fare, simple; salads, unremarkable; Fillet Mignon, quite good, indeed. But mark thou well, dear reader, the total sum for four grown folk, a bairn, and babe didst climb to two hundred five gold pieces, withal an obligatory gratuity of eighteen percent! Fie upon such chicanery! In days of yore, 'twas a different tale, I do declare. Now, had the service been more courteous, a trio of stars, perchance, I would have given, with nary a qualm."

"Hark, what woe is this? My locks, they do proclaim
A tale of woe, a story of shame.
For every time I come to this place,
They do butcher my hair, with nary a trace
Of skill or art, they hack and they chop,
Leaving me in a state of utter hop.

A good haircut, it doth take its time,
Fifteen to twenty-five minutes, a fair rhyme.
But here, they rush and they hurry,
In and out in five minutes, oh so sorry.
I'll ne'er return, no more shall I grace
This place with my presence, such disgrace."

"Hark! A feast fit for a king, they did proclaim,  
With shrimp wontons and ramen noodles in its name.  
But alas, the broth, so bland and weak,  
Did leave my taste buds in a state most meek.  
A disappointment, indeed, for all had said,  
This dish, a culinary masterpiece, was bred.  
But nay, I found not even a hint of zest,  
In this soup that was supposed to be the best.  
So, let this be a lesson, my dear friends,  
To never judge a dish by its outward trends.  
For though the portion may be generous and fair,  
A flavorless broth can leave one quite unfair."

"Methinks 'tis wise to wait, ere penning thoughts anent a place,
Until at least two visits, or mayhap three, have graced its space.
Yet, if I do not aim to return, then this rule doth cease,
And thus, my words shall paint a picture of the feast.

A sickness had beset me, and my belly did protest,
But still, I chanced upon this eatery, with hunger unrepressed.
Their tacos five, a bargain at four ninety-five, did seem,
Yet, alas! They were not tacos, but taquitos, fried and gleaming.

The cheese, the guacamole, the lettuce, all were quite divine,
Yet, on the whole, I found not joy in what they did entwine.
Thus, two stars I give, for though their fare may please some,
For me, 'twill not suffice, and so, adieu, I bid thee, Rome!"

"O, Five Guys, how art thou failing me? Thy burgers, once a feast for mine eyes, now doth pale in comparison to days of yore. In Virginia, thy patties didst overflow with juicy delight, yet here in Arizona, they doth resemble naught but a mere shadow of their former self. Alack, the beef, wherefore doth it hide?

I didst give thee chance upon chance, hoping against hope that thou wouldst return to form. Alas, 'twas not meant to be. Thy patties, once a sturdy foundation for a feast, now doth resemble a fragile leaf, unable to withstand the test of time.

Farewell, Five Guys, for now. Mayhap in six months' time, thou shalt redeem thyself, and my faith in thee shall be restored. Until then, adieu, and may thy fries, at least, remain a constant source of joy."

"A varied choice for fabrics and upholstery, indeed,
Some prices fair, while others border on the absurd.
Two stars for service, alack, how poorly done,
Each visit, a ghost I feel, ignored by everyone.
A numbered system, they claim, but nay, 'tis not true,
For those who serve, their minds elsewhere, anew.
Many workers, yet none with customers' plight,
Thus, two stars for wares, but service, a sorry sight."

"In for breakfas', we didst hasten,
And were seated with celerity,
But lo! No servitor didst attend us,
For ten minutes, in neglectivity.

No one knew whose section we were in,
Alack! Our plight didst cause disdain.
The victuals were naught but mediocre,
And water, four times I didst obtain.

A decent supper, we have had before,
And mayhap shall return once more,
But for the morning meal, fair friends,
There be better places, in this town, anon."

"In this fair city of Las Vegas, where night and day do blend,
We found ourselves, my friends, in quite a state, I pray thee, lend
A listening ear, for our tale is one of woe,
Of hunger, daze, and delirium, did our spirits know.

How we arrived, I know not, but 'twas cheap, I swear,
And filled with choice, though in disrepair, did appear.
So, if thy luck doth fail thee at the slots, my friend,
Come hither, eat, and save thy purse, for 'tis but eight pence, doth end."

"Methought I had a wondrous facial, fair and bright,
But lo, two days hence, a reaction did take flight.
I bought some potions, priced at eighty-five,
And thus, a maiden in the spa didst I contrive.

She asked me why, and I didst tell her plain,
And then, a check, she said, would be my bane.
A credit voucher, she didst give to me,
And said the manager, wouldst it approve, doth see.

Four days passed, and still, no check didst come,
And so, I penned this tale, in bitter tune.
No care didst they take, of my poor face,
All chapped, peeling, red, in sorry grace.

Their concern, was but for their own gain,
And thus, I shall not be their guest again.
Forsooth, the Arizona Grand Spa, doth lack,
In courtesy, and care, for those who do attack."

"At last, we reached this famed establishment,
Whose praises were oft sung by those who brought me thither.
A curious edifice, indeed, and worth a visit,
If only for its unique and quaint architecture.

The throng within was merry, yet not overwhelming,
And the menu offered diversions most intriguing.
But alas, our server, with nary a smile or gleam,
Did dampen our spirits with her somber demeanor.

I pondered, 'Is this woeful visage due to too much ale?'
For in a college town, one expects some mirth and glee.
But nay, our server remained as dour as a monk,
Even when I requested a container for my leftovers.

Perhaps, dear friends, this place may find some favor,
If thou art in Tempe and hast a penchant for strong brew.
But for this scribe, Four Peaks doth pale in comparison,
To other haunts that offer mirth and better cheer.

So heed my words, fair traveler, and choose with care,
For in this town of Tempe, there be many a place most fair.
And should thou decide to return to Four Peaks once more,
Pray tell, what sorcery doth make thee seek such dreariness?"

"Hark, my dear friend! Lola Lo, a place of mirth and delight, doth hold some charm, I must confess. Aye, 'tis true, the barkeepers are a jolly bunch, and their potions, most delicious. The bouncers, too, are pleasant chaps, and the decor, a feast for mine eyes. But alas, good sir, the prices, they do sting! Four pounds fifty, for a drink, doth seem a bit steep, doth it not? And the cover charge, a fortune, I say! The music, too, doth leave much to be desired, a trifle too soft, and the dance floor, a wee bit cramped, doth make one yearn for more space to strut and sway. In conclusion, my friend, I wouldst not choose to frequent this establishment, save for the company of others, who mayhap, have already decided to gather there."

"A plague upon the cook, a curse upon the fare!
No soul within the eatery, all dishes ill-prepared.
Dinner rolls, burnt to a crisp, and chicken, o'ercooked.
Of four who sat at table, none found their meal palatable.
One friend, a vegan, sought plain noodles, vegetables his desire.
But lo, they brought him noodles topped with cheese, a non-vegan's delight.
A failure, indeed, this culinary endeavor."

"Verily, for twenty-three years have I graced this place with mine own presence. 'Twas once my most cherished haunt, wherein I didst savor with great relish a humble chili cheese dog. Alas, how the winds of time doth blow! For now, 'tis naught but an overpriced fast food establishment, devoid of that quaint charm which once didst make it so endearing. Fie upon it, say I! Forsooth, I shall seek elsewhere to satiate mine hunger, perchance at yonder pirate game, whereat least I may procure a similar repast for a mere five dollars."

"Fair patio, with fountains soft and sweet,
Yet, alack, the scent of chlorine doth greet,
Our nostrils, at dinner, with displeasure,
And mar our joy, with its unpleasant measure.

The victuals, middling, yet passable, were brought,
By a serving-man, with Yelp's gift, unsought,
A burrito, green chili chicken, we did choose,
Laden with cheese, our arteries did froze.

Alas, the flavors, save cheese and heat, did hide,
And chicken, in that mass, did quietly reside,
But, for the patio's charm, and water's song,
This place, in business, might not tarry long."

"Hark, what news is this? My Westin stay hath slipped,
Where once we stayed for Furniture Market's grip,
With free parking, abundant, and beds so fine,
And Starbucks in the lobby, a wondrous find.

But now, alas, the service doth decline,
Despite our status, Preferred Members divine,
My chamber, hot and muggy, with AC so weak,
Didst call for aid, but temp didst not abate.

At last, a solution, move me to another floor,
But nay, I wished not to move my goods once more,
A second man, with haste, didst fix the flaw,
The air didst flow, and all was well, I vow.

Yet still, the floor, unswept, and trash didst lie,
In room, the coffee, weak, and creamer didst die,
But life, alas, is short, and troubles pass,
For now, I shall not dwell on woes of the past."

"Last eve, we dined at Kaiten sushi, a place unfrequented by the masses, it seemed. Forsooth, the victuals were passable, but naught exceptional, save for the saba, which did impress. Methinks, however, that the rolls were not freshly made, a defect most vexing. 'Tis a wonder they had them prepared beforehand, forsooth. Alack, the signage was scant, and hidden 'twas, behind a row of buildings, in a parking lot, no less! Mayhap this explained the dearth of patrons. Yet, within, 'twas clean and fair, the staff, attentive and friendly, in sooth."

"Hark, fair friends, I pray thee, listen well,
For I have tale to tell, of pizza, foul and fell.
In Chicago, city of the wind,
I lived six months, and pizza, I did find.
A small pie, I ordered, with corn dog, too,
My love, he did enjoy, with pizza, he did chew.
But lo, the pizza, it was not so fine,
Thick on the bottom, thin on the sides, a crime.
Like pie, it should be, but alas, 'twas not,
A disappointment, akin to frozen thought.
We had one slice, and threw it away,
For Giordannos, or Lou Malnati's, it did not stay.
So, if thou art in search of pizza, true,
Avoid this place, my friends, anon, adieu."

"Verily, I say unto thee, fair reader, that the prices here have skyrocketed since my last visit seven moons ago. A meager burger and fries doth cost a pretty penny, nay, a whopping twenty-one dollars! And pray tell, what of the goat cheese Caesar with chicken? Why, 'tis a steep twenty-three dollars, I do declare! A salad of Chinese chicken, thou sayest? Fie upon it, 'tis but twenty-one dollars more! And, alack, a side of fries, a paltry nine dollars, yet still a king's ransom, methinks.

"A plague upon these prices, say I! Forsooth, the fare may be fair, but at such costs, how canst one expect success to tarry? I didst venture to Mon Ami Gabi, where, lo and behold, a sturdy steak and fries didst grace mine eyes, all for the sum of twenty-five dollars, in a most pleasant outdoor seat, I do confess. Pray, good sirs, give me a break!"

"Thrice have I tried this eatery, near my humble abode,
And thrice have I been met with dismay.
The last time, they did err in my order,
And I, with little care, did let it pass.
But now, alas! They've done me wrong again,
And forgotten part of my repast.
I shall not return, forsooth, to claim it,
For this place hath lost my trust, and my patience hath vanished like mist."

"Alas, how vexing! After hearing much praise,
My heart did yearn to partake of their fare.
But lo, the dishes that did grace our plates,
Did leave me feeling woeful and quite irate.

The corn, once frozen, now lay mushy and still,
And tacos, seasoned strange, did naught fulfill.
Yet one dish, my husband's burger, did please,
Hot and juicy, a savory delight, indeed.
We devoured it, and the rest, we did dismiss."

"Alack, our maiden visit didst not bode well,
'Twas but a middling experience, naught to tell.
The servant at the counter, ignorant of the fare,
Didst bring us not what we didst ask, a sorry affair.

The taste was fair, but eggplant, sautéed with skin so tough,
Didst leave us discontent, and in a sour enough.
The service, too, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
No smiles, no greetings, nor a single merci.

A pox upon the place, whose staff doth seem so bland,
As if they cared not for their customers' hand.
I fear, my dear, we shall not return again,
For such a lack of zeal doth make a loyal patron wain.

But wait, the gentleman with spectacles, perchance the master?
Didst show a scowl, and scant courtesy, a proper disaster.
So, shall we give it one more chance, anon?
Or shall we flee, and seek a better inn?"

"Hark, what news is this? My first time here,
I called in haste, and they did say,
'Twenty minutes, good sir, come not near.'
Perfect, I thought, for my lunch break from fear.

I hastened thither, full of hope and cheer,
But lo, the server said, 'A couple more, my dear.'
Ten minutes passed, and still I did await,
The shakes, the frozen custard, oh how slow the fray.

At last, they came, but alas, too late,
For my break had ended, and I must debate,
If worth the cost, the time, the trouble and the strife,
I say, not so, for frozen custard, none did life.

The food, though greasy, passable, I do confess,
But for the price, and wait, I must express,
My discontent, and say, I shall not return,
For normal fare, I shall not again yearn."

"Ten silver coins for a meal most plain? Aye, 'tis a price most steep, I say. Chicken sandwich, with lettuce, tomato, and bun, yet naught but common fare, I fear. And salad, small, with naught but greens and dressing, doth not a feast make. Meh, I say, to such a meager repast. I shall return, perchance, another day, with hope that fare more grand doth wait."

"Verily, good sir, thy ambiance doth please mine eyes,
And yonder view, 'tis a wondrous sight to behold.
Thy wait staff, too, doth serve with grace and poise,
But alas, the rib eye steak, a disappointment doth unfold.

In sooth, the price doth rival that of Ruth's Chris or Flemings,
Yet the steak itself, doth pale in comparison, I do reckon.
'Tis a shame, forsooth, that such potential doth go awry,
And leaves me in search of a better cut, ere long to say goodbye."

"Methinks 'tis my third visit to Hit Mac's since my arrival in CLT three years past. Verily, I must confess, my expectations were not met.

The brisket, upon which they pride themselves, didst fail to impress me. Tough and chewy, it lacked the quantity I had hoped for. Alas, the sides didst not fare much better, being naught but mediocre.

And yet, despite my disappointment, I shall not deny the establishment its due. The atmosphere doth possess a certain je ne sais quoi, the beer list doth impress, and the service doth border on excellence. Methinks, too, the music doth strike the proper chord.

Shall I return? Perchance, anon, whene'er I find myself in the vicinity. But, alack, I shall not venture forthwith, eager to partake of their culinary delights."

"Hark! The victuals were fair, a four, I say,
But service, alack! A single star doth sway,
Our server, kind and diligent, did strive,
Yet kitchen's woes did cause us much to strive,
Food came, a tardy thirty minutes passed,
And then, in bits, o'er fifteen minutes vast,
Alack! 'Tis clear, they lack management skill,
Someone must guide them, lest their fate be sealed,
Yet, fortunate am I, not to dwell in Phoenix,
Thus, this ill fate shall ne'er my steps impede."

"Verily, I know not why I didst venture forth to this establishment. 'Twas fair in appearance when first we entered, but alas! The mashed potatoes were cold and the flesh didst lack in flavor. The sweet tea and corn bread, they didst please mine taste, but naught else didst impress. I wouldst not return, forsooth. Best bbq in the west? Pray tell, what sorcery doth speak such lies!"

"Papa Del's, a place of sustenance and cheer,
Yet, alack, their service doth leave much to fear.
The pizzas, oh, they take their time,
But all else moves at a snail's slow climb.

The staff, unfriendly and full of disdain,
Do roll their eyes and show scant gain.
A rude lot, they, with nary a smile,
Leave one to wonder if they do beguile.

But, lo, there be a way to avoid
The cramped seats and the surly crowd.
Order in, and thou shalt find delight
In reheated pies that taste just right.

Their sausage pizza, a true delight,
Doth make the journey worth the fight.
And friends from Chicagoland, they do adore
This pizza, and so, it doth explore.

So, if in Champaign thou dost reside,
Papa Del's, the best deep dish provide.
But if from elsewhere thou dost come,
Better options, there be, ere some.

"O, Bay City Diner, how I do miss thee! 

Du Pars, a place of sustenance, yet priced so high, 
For breakfast, simple fare doth not justify 
The cost, three friends and I didst pay, oh me! 
Above $50, a sum most grave, for mere eggs, toast, 
And pancakes, naught but common fare, I do declare. 

And dinner, too, doth suffer from such prices, 
A diner, plain and simple, on Fremont Street, 
Not the strip, where luxury doth reign supreme, 
Yet Bay City once, a place of good cheer, 
Now lost, alas, to Du Pars' steep fee."

"Alack, I cannot bear to read the praise,
This restaurant doth receive in such abundance.
Two stars, a generous rating, indeed,
For in my time, 'twas a place of great pretence.

When I did live in Vegas, many moons ago,
My family and I would frequent this place,
And it was grand, the best, in all the land,
But now, alas, 'tis but a shadow of its former grace.

I visited recently, and oh, the disappointment,
The food was bland, the service, poor and slow,
No chicken katsu, and cash only, they do demand,
In this, the year of our Lord, 2011, how strange, how slow.

As much as I did love this place in days of yore,
I fear I shall not return, nevermore,
If thou dost seek good Hawaiian/Island fare,
In California, the real state, I shall be there,
To guide thee to places of great worth and renown,
And leave this pitiful excuse for a restaurant, unknown."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, hear my plea,
For justice doth demand equality.
In clothing, size doth matter much,
For those of ample girth, 'tis a cruel crutch.

SAMs and Walmart, both do fail,
In catering to the larger folk's tale.
They charge more, and sizes doth lack,
Discriminating, leaving them in the black.

Join me, friends, in this righteous quest,
To end the bias, and do our best.
Let all, regardless of size, be treated fair,
And clad in garb that doth flatter their hair."

"Our feasting was most wondrous, I must confess,
For though the victuals were not quite the best,
The service we received was truly divine,
A tale of fourteen guests, all well-served in time.

Alas, the pasta dish, so eagerly awaited,
Was sadly undercooked, and thus, unsatisfied,
We sent it back, with hopes that it might be made right,
And in its stead, a better dish take flight.

The manager, a woman of great grace,
Didst offer us a discount on our bill, in place,
Of the ill-cooked meal, which caused some dismay,
But in the end, we paid a fair price, come what may.

So let this be a lesson, to all who can hear,
That when we dine out, we must be vigilant, my dear,
For though the food may not always be just right,
'Tis the service that makes the evening bright."

"A spacious chamber, with a bed of moderate worth,
A sofa, worn and faded, did little for our earthly form.
The shower, poor and wretched, did naught but bring us woe,
I booked the room, enticed by price and rating, thou know.
Four stars, alas, it was not, and thus we did depart,
With naught but disdain for the Rio's victuals and its art."

"Aye, good sir, thou dost enquire about this place,  
If 'tis a spot where thou canst find some grace,  
In terms of price, and food that doth please,  
And if it doth compare to other buffets, if thou please.  

Alas, my friend, I must inform thee, nay,  
For though the price may be low, the food doth not stay,  
In thy stomach, nor doth it taste so sweet,  
For all we had, my wife and I, did meet,  
A fate most dire, a taste most bland and dry,  
And cold, as if 'twere frozen in the sky.  

The selection here, alack, doth leave much to be desired,  
Compared to other buffets, whereon we have tired,  
Our taste buds, with a vast array of dishes,  
Leaving us full, and in a state of blissful wishes.  
But here, alas, the choices are few and far between,  
So if thou art in search of a spread more bountiful and keen,  
Look elsewhere, good sir, for thou shalt not find,  
At this place, a feast fit for a king, or even a mind.  

Yet still, there be a benefit, a silver lining,  
In the cost, which doth save thee a few pence,  
So if thou art in need of a thrifty repast,  
This place may serve thee well, though not a feast."

"A fair building, with a view most sweet,
Two stars, for that alone, didst meet.
The waitress, with limited knowledge, didst say,
That calamari, overcooked, there was no way.
We asked for lime, but none couldst be found,
And water, with butter, didst spill around.
Pasta, with chunks of cheese, unmelted lay,
Escargot, overcooked, didst not sway.
Steak, with flavor, but poor cut, didst bring,
And desserts, half gone, didst leave us in dismay.
Stuck in the past, with outdated ways,
Save your coins, and dine elsewhere, I pray."

"Hark, what woeful tale doth mine ears perceive? A culinary crime, so grave and grievous, That doth besmirch the name of My Mother's kitchen. Bland lasagna, devoid of flavor, doth mock me, Like a pale ghost, devoid of life and vigor. And garlic bread, once savory and inviting, Now doth resemble a lifeless, tasteless thing. A limp salad, devoid of zest or charm, Doth complete this sorry, ill-conceived repast. But lo, a beacon of hope doth shine forth, A chocolate cream pie, a sweet delight, That doth redeem My Mother's faltering name. Methinks some other hand didst bake this treat, For never hath My Mother's kitchen known Such culinary prowess, or such fame."

"Spinach appetizer we didst partake,
And found it wanting in taste and make.
More of a broth than a dip, it seemed,
And prices high, as if to be esteemed.
The menu doth strive for elegance,
Yet the bus' name on the door doth not accord.
To the Hyatt Place hotel we didst walk,
To watch the Rangers play and have a bit to eat.
But alas, the waitresses didst not heed,
Our request to change the TV to the game in need.
And so, the ending we didst watch with haste,
Via the mlb app, on my phone in stead."

"Hark! Nick's hath been a merry meetin' spot,
For me and mine companions, by my troth.
Their pies of cheese and bread, and fowl of Parmesan,
Have pleased mine taste, in truth, most wondrous well.

But last eve, I wished to try a novel dish,
And thus, I ordered baked ziti, with meatballs in a swirl.
Alas! The dish was ill-prepared, full foul,
The pasta rubbery, the sauce too dry, alack!
The ends of ziti, hard and crunchy, did offend,
Yet still, the meatballs, they did please, in very truth.

Despite the fare, the service, excellent,
Methinks, the server, did his duty, with diligence."

"Alas, the meat dishes we didst partake,
Lamb kebab and chicken 65, didst not impress.
But paneer tikka masala, with gravy so plenty,
Didst make up for it, though paneer cubes were scant.
Chana masala, a dish of moderate delight,
And naan, fresh and soft, didst round off the night."

"O, what a disappointment doth lie within this place,
Where food and drink doth fail to bring us grace.
The iPad, a curious choice, doth serve no end,
For wine, a noble beverage, doth descend.

A wine bar, they call it, but alas, 'tis naught,
For wines of quality, they doth not possess.
We ordered tuna, green beans, flatbread, and shrimp,
But found the rest of fare to be of poor stamp.

Indeed, a comparison to Applebee's doth hold,
With wine, a feature that doth make it bold.
But alas, the menu doth remain the same,
For three long years, a sign of little fame.

And desserts, oh how they doth pale and wane,
A sad conclusion to a meal most vain."

"Verily, the creeps did please my taste,
And coffee, orange juice, did make haste,
But service, alas, did leave much to be desired,
Slow, even when but two tables fired.
And, truth be told, the price did seem quite steep,
A sobering thought, that did my mood dampen and sleep."

"Tis a strange and wondrous sight, my friends,
This show with its service so poorly tended.
We had tickets for a certain row,
But lo, they were not to be found, oh woe!

The ticketing system, it seemed, had failed,
And duplicates were printed, tales unveiled.
We searched for an usher, our guide,
To find our seats, our place to reside.

At last, a kindly usher appeared,
And led us to a distant seat, so queer.
Betwixt families, we sat and watched,
As the show began, its tale unclocked.

A silly spectacle, full of laughter,
With pandas dancing, acrobatics to scatter.
No story, it seemed, just random play,
Confusion reigned, night turned to day.

My favorite moment, a man did beat,
A panda, oh so cruelly, to retreat.
Alas, not worth the price, my friends,
Unless free tickets, or discounts, it ends."

"Applebee's doth trouble me, a chain of restaurants vast,
With menu items familiar, and naught else to boast.
The thought of dining there, doth make my stomach churn,
For novelty and charm, it doth not concern.

Chiles, too, doth earn my scorn, with that annoying tune,
Baby back ribs, it doth still echo, like a mournful croon.
Alike, I find their fare, to be of little delight,
Save for the happy hour, which doth shine with some light.

But alas, the atmosphere, doth leave much to be desired,
And so, I say, avoid it, lest ye be consumed by fire.
Gross, gross, gross, I say, and pray, thou heed my words,
For better dining choices, there be, in this fair world."

"Alas, fair sir, I wouldst have given this salon a higher rating,
But alack, my search for a quality salon doth continue still.
The gentleman who tended to my locks was quite affable,
But, alas, my highlights didst resemble a bird's nest, so tangled and ill-made.
I asked for a natural look, but instead, it seemed
As though a tempest had swept through my tresses, leaving them bleached and streaked.
I wouldst not return, nay, not even to repair the damage done,
For I didst seek out another salon, where my color was corrected, alas, too late.
The place was clean, the staff friendly, but, alas, my hair doth suffer still."

"Alas, the sushi dish I didst partake,
Was but a mediocre feast for mine eyes.
The service, oh how it didst falter and fail,
A plague upon the waiters, with nary a smile.

They took my order, to a table afar,
And didst not offer an apology, nor a shred of remorse.
Twenty-five minutes passed, and still no sign,
Of our dessert, or any token of their concern.

I vow, nevermore shall I return to this place,
For it doth seem, they do not value mine time or space."

"O, Z Pizza, thou art but a pale imitation,
A poor excuse for a meal, devoid of creation.
Thy crust, rubbery and salty, doth leave much to be desired,
And thy slices, they border on the abyss, so dire.

The staff, they didst not seem to care,
If I, a customer, didst darken their lair.
The owner, he was there, and that, alas,
Didst take precedence o'er my late lunch fare.

Organic, thou sayest? Pray, what dost that matter?
I crave not health, but taste, and that, thou lackest.
I'll have none of thy gluten-free pretenses,
For they but mock me, like a fat child with no defenses.

Thy hype, I do not buy, for thy food, at best,
Is but a mediocrity, a pale imitation of the rest.
I shall order elsewhere, for thou dost not impress,
And thus, adieu, Z Pizza, may thy name be blessed."

"Thou knowest full well what to expect when thou dost order from Domino's Pizza, good sir. 'Tis not the finest of pies, perchance, but thou art aware of this ere thou doth place thy order. In truth, 'tis naught but a humble, salted fare, yet sufficient for a weary traveler in a foreign land. Tis akin to fast food, alack, yet serves its purpose well."

"O Chompies, how my heart did yearn for thee,
In hopes thou wouldst bring back memories of old,
Of Jewish delis, where my youth didst spend,
In Arizona, where such flavors are told.

Thy menu didst boast of classic dishes dear,
And matzo ball soup, a treat most sincere,
But alas, thy service and food's quality,
Didst falter, leaving me in misery.

The pickles, free, yet took too long to come,
As we didst finish eating, they didst arrive,
And lo, the dish I chose, didst bear the bane,
Of bacon, which didst vex mine appetite so fine.

Another meal, they didst offer, in its place,
But how couldst I trust what came from their space?
So, though they didst comp the meal, 'twas naught,
For my desire to dine with thee, was lost in thought."

"Ere my wedding day, my mother and I didst venture forth to this salon, seeking a more refined experience than my usual Vietnamese shop. The establishment itself was fair and bright, but alas, the service we received was naught but a waste of gold and time. For $75 a person, the French manicure they gave me looked as though I had done it myself, and my mother's was no better. In dismay, I chose a solid hue for my toes, which was also executed poorly. Though all the staff did speak the English tongue, their skills were lacking, and I shall not return. My face did burn with shame when I departed, but alack, I had no time to seek a proper manicurist ere my nuptials. Mayhap the shoddy work shall not be seen in my wedding photos."

"A taco stand of Korean persuasion, how intriguing! My curiosity, it did arouse, and I, in haste, did venture forth to partake in this culinary experience. Alas, my expectations, they were not met, for though the tacos themselves were fair, the excess of filler, it did vex me sore. They boast of three kinds of lettuce, but, pray tell, who doth get excited o'er leaves? Not I, forsooth! The meat, hidden beneath the verdant mound, was tasty, but the search, it did tax my patience. Their sweet potato fries, a clever ruse, for though they be cut thin, a mountain they did form, yet substance, there was none. A savory dark brown sauce, it was, that came with the tacos, but alas, not enough to make up for the lack of meat and the excess of greens. Disappointment, it did reign, and thus, I left, not full, but empty, and with a heavy heart."

"O, woeful night! Crusty sheets, burnt out lights,
And staff who sought to enter thy chamber,
While thou didst slumber, didst they bother.
At six, a construction crew didst start,
Their work upon the roof, so near thy window,
Didst make a racket, loud and smart.
At seven, the hotel's watchmen came,
Banging on doors, with shouts of blame,
In search of drunken souls, who had fled.
At eight, a maid didst try the door,
Without a knock, her entrance didst implore.
Again at nine, and eleven, she didst come,
Her visits, like a curse, didst seem.
The rooms, so dear, yet dingy, foul,
Not worth the sleep, that thou didst lose,
Aliante's price, doth seem more fair,
Than this, thy wretched, sorry lair."

"Methought I'd try the Spicy Shrimp Tacos, a dish most fair,
With guacamole and cucumber slaw, a feast beyond compare.
But lo, the "spicy" label was naught but a lie,
For in its stead, there was nary a whiff of heat, nor a sigh.

Aye, I didst ponder why such deception doth prevail,
And whether men do think us fools, or if 'tis but a fail.
And so, I didst ask mine host, if perchance he knew,
If there were other options, that my taste might woo.

He told me of a triad, a choice most rare,
Of shrimp, pork, and carne asada, a feast most fair.
But alack, I had not heard, ere I didst order my share,
And so, I didst settle for rice, and naught but air.

The waitress, a merry maid, didst tend to my needs,
But the hostesses, alas, didst seem to have no heeds.
I stood, a-waiting, for a spell, ere they didst see,
That I, a patron, didst require a place to sit and be.

And thus, I didst pay the price, most dear,
For a meal that didst not quite meet mine expectations clear.
So, on my next visit, I shall seek out another place,
Where the fare is more just, and the service doth show grace."

"Hark! When first I came to this fair place,
I didst find the staff most friendly and bright.
But lo! My drink order, twiced didst they get wrong,
In two short days, my patience didst they try.
If they couldst but get it right, I wouldst be bound,
To come to them, and not to Target's store,
Where Starbucks doth reside, a scant few steps away.
Alas! The service here doth fall below my mark,
Sorry to say, The Bux doth not meet my eye."

"Fare thee well, good victuals, 'twain a shame,
The service here, doth leave much to be desired,
For four souls tasked with duties of old,
And seven patrons, waiting, their patience tired,
'Tis truly madness, to tarry twenty minutes more,
To claim thy bill, and thus, thy freedom, once again,
But, prithee, gentle reader, form thine own opinion,
And sample their wares, ere thou dost make thy judgment."

"Hark, good sirs, I pray thee, lend me thine ear,
For I have tale to tell, full of woe and fear.
At Super Burrito, I didst dine,
But alas, my meal was not divine.

Three men, of breeding base and low,
Didst interrupt my feast, with words of woe.
They wouldst not cease, their taunts and jibes,
And made my time there, most unpleasant, by th' Lord above.

My date, fair maiden, didst end in strife,
With police, summoned, to quell the life.
A video, I didst take, with mine own hand,
Of those three knaves, so bold and grand.

My tacos, bland they were, I do confess,
But still, I shall return, to give them fair assess.
For justice, I shall seek, with mine own might,
And make those varlets, see the light of right."

"Methinks I oft do fancy Paradise Bakery,
For quick repast and healthy victuals, 'tis their hallmark, ye see.
But this particular place, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
In service, good, yet fare, most mediocre, I do declare.

The iced tea, oh woe! Doth taste of staleness, I do fear,
From containers or filters, cleansing they do require, I reckon.
And watery, too, so mango's flavor doth disappear,
A sorry state, indeed, and cause for disappointment, I do aver.

For proof, I did compare, and at PV Mall,
Their tea, a vast improvement, did my taste buds enthrall.
But chicken salad, alack! A letdown, I must confess,
Fruits, strawberries and pineapple, in syrup, overly sweet, I do profess.

So, to Wildflower, I shall journey forth,
And leave this Paradise, with its shortcomings, in the north."

"Hark, good sir! What say thee, Sandy, pray tell?
A pox upon this chatter, let us eat with haste,
For yonder grill doth cook the meat apace,
And time doth flee, leaving naught but waste.

Indeed, my friend, 'tis true what thou dost say,
That here at KBBQ, men pay to cook and serve,
But lo, the servers do assist in this fray,
Placing meat upon the grill, their duty to preserve.

Yet, alack, the cooking time, it doth consume,
All conversation, save for grunts and chews,
No waiting, no respite, the pace doth plume,
Ain't nobody got time for that, 'twain't no boon.

And thus, my friend, our AYCE choice did seem,
Rushed, like a tempest, swift and wild, no gleam,
Of calm, save at the start, when water we did seek,
And at the end, when payment we did entreat, aye, meek.

So, mayhap not the best first and last impression made,
Yet still, the meat, it was delicious, not afraid,
To savor it, and thus, my tale is told,
Of Honey Pig, where cooking's the gold."

"Ere we did dine at Emeril's Fish House, ere the KA show did start,
Inside the MGM, a convenient spot, our server was quite kind and smart.
My water glass, full oft, did she refill, ne'er did it stay empty long.
Tuna tacos, three small servings for $17, a price too steep, I did find,
The sweet flavor, not to mine liking, a disappointment, I did mind.
Mushrooms, a side dish, $9, a sum too great, I did opine,
The mozzarella salad, a balance, light and flavorful, a delight divine."

"Methinks 'tis one of closest Wendy's to our humble abode, yet my dearest wife and I doth not frequent this establishment as oft as we once did, forsooth. Our orders, alas! have been incomplete, with sandwiches either cold or burnt, and salads wilted beyond recognition.

"Moreover, the lights that doth illuminate the restaurant and the drive-through doth dim and darken ere the night doth reach its prime, leaving us to wonder if indeed 'twere open for business. And on a recent eve, we didst venture forth to partake in their culinary delights, and lo! we were the sole patrons, and yet, the service didst falter and fail, with mistakes aplenty.

"Verily, anon, should the quality and service improve, we wouldst gladly return, forsooth."

"Verily, the structure doth impress, with tunes that lift and ornaments of elegance, but alas, the service of the folk doth leave much to be desired. Rude and unhelpful, they doth ignore the patrons or turn away, leaving questions unanswered. Yesterday, I didst seek a certain tome, yet none couldst assist, though the machine didst say there were two copies in stock. \n\nPraise be to Amazon, for they didst receive eighty dollars from me, a savings of ten. Indigo, on the other hand, received naught and shall unlikely gain my custom for some time."

"Upon mine second visit to fair Sakana's halls,
I didst partake in their evening repast,
With Cali rolls, unagi, and edamame,
My hunger to assuage, and taste to sample.

The Cali rolls, fresh made, didst delight,
Thirty minutes old, or so it seemed,
Unagi, large pieces, warm and tasty,
Didst fill mine belly, and mine spirits lift.

Alas, the service, slow it was,
A wait, long and tedious, for a refill,
But overall, average, the meal didst pass,
And thus, I shall return, for sushi's thrill."

"Fare was fair, but service was foul.
Took forty-six minutes, by my count,
For grub to reach our table, oh so slow.
Avoid Saturdays, lest thou wish to wallow
In wait that doth seem endless, as doth time.
If thou must eat, drive a few miles more,
And seek the establishment in Chandler's bower."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
CityCenter did not impress.
Lacking in charm and character, it seemed,
A high-tech Wynn, or Bellagio, with less gleam.

The Aria, hidden from view,
One must pass through Crystals, anew.
A waterfall and fountain, colorful and bright,
But hidden, alas, from sight.

I entered, and looked around,
My inner voice, a snooty sound.
It whispered, "You shouldn't be here,"
The vastness, made me fear.

Glad I saw it, but I must say,
It worked better in theory, than in play."

"A fortnight past, I chanced upon this eatery,
To partake of midday repast, as was my wont.
Alas, fair friends, my expectations were not met,
For though the victuals were of decent quality,
The cost, I found, did far exceed the worth.
And, by my troth, the service was most slow,
As if the servers did their utmost best
To test my patience, and to make me frown.

But stay, dear reader, for I have not yet done,
For there was one dish that did arouse my glee,
A Reuben sandwich, with corned beef so fine,
It did delight my taste buds, and made me smile.
And, by the way, if thou art in need of drink,
Their stout, a mixture of black and blue, doth sink,
Into thy soul, and doth provide a pleasant cheer,
Especially when heard, in company of friends so dear.
And, on the weekends, if thou art inclined,
To listen to some music, live and unrefined,
Thou shalt find satisfaction, for they do provide,
A pleasant melody, to soothe thy troubled mind."

"Alas, our feline friend didst fall ill,
And we, in sorrow, didst seek aid from the ARL.
The receptionist, with voice so cold and unfeeling,
Didst tell us that euthanasia was our only option,
And that we should wait by the door, for someone to meet us.
A woman came forth, and took the carrier away,
With nary a word of comfort or sympathy.
No kindness was shown, no gesture of solace,
Not even a moment's pause, ere they took our cat away.
It was a day of utmost woe, and the ARL's staff,
Didst make it worse, with their lack of compassion and tact.
Two stars, perchance, for the service they provide,
But naught else, save for the memory of their uncaring ways, doth linger."

Orange Sky, a place of delight,
Where we have dined with joy and delight.
But on November's first eve, alas!
Our experience was quite different, I pass.

The service, good, yet puzzling, too,
For water, none came to serve us anew.
The food, a feast for royalty,
Lobster bisque, king crab, and steak, oh yea!

Yet, within four hours, my dear wife and I,
Fell ill, with violent pangs, nigh unto death.
I told the hostess, with urgency,
But she, unmoved, showed no sympathy or care.

To management, we told our plight,
Hoping they'd act, to make things right.
But they, like rocks, showed no concern,
Leaving us, in sickness, to burn.

For such a price, at Orange Sky,
I'd choose another place, ere I die.
Most restaurants, of this rank, do see,
Food safety, as a top priority.

Not so, at Orange Sky, alack!
They placed us, near the restroom's track.
A special night, turned into woe,
At Orange Sky, where we did not glow.

"Verily, I have beheld worse spectacles, yea, even much worse than this. Yet, this one still left me underwhelmed. 'Twas not without its clever moments, nor its share of intriguing concepts. At times, I thought, "Marry, that was somewhat cool!" But alas, the overall effect was akin to a deflated balloon, leaving me with the thought, "Is this all there is to it?"

Children may find delight in this show, to be sure. But for adults, I would recommend instead the wondrous productions of Cirque du Soleil, such as O, Mystere, or Love. Or, if thou art in search of magic and mirth, seek out Penn & Teller at the Rio, or the enigmatic Amazing Johnathan, wherever he may be found.

I would not see Blue Man Group again, not even for naught. Forsooth, the hype doth far exceed the substance."

"My trusty assistant, in fair Phoenix, didst call upon the Phoenician, that noble inn where last I lay my head, to seek a carriage for my work-related journey. And lo, they didst recommend Execu Car, a company bound to SuperShuttle, that well-known blue conveyance. Thus, I didst engage their services for airport pickup, a wait at a site, and then return to the airport once more. The total time didst span three hours, and the cost, ere tip, didst amount to $135. The driver, a pleasant gentleman, didst attend to his duties with diligence and promptness. No cause for alarm, nor any extraordinary tale, didst mark this journey."

"Pray tell, what sorcery is this? A meal most foul and dear,
In Montreal, land of plenty, doth leave me sore aghast.
A plate of victuals, thirty-six dollars, by my troth!
And naught but bread and soup, to fill my wretched belly forth.

Oh, cursed fate! How cruel art thou, to taunt me thus,
With prices high, and portions scant, to mock my woeful purse.
In Vancouver, fair city, such a feast doth cost but half,
And with it, wine most fine, to quench my thirsty soul's great wrath.

Alas, I fear I've strayed, where fancy folk do roam,
Whose purses deep, and appetites, most heartily doth groan.
But nay, I shall not falter, nor be swayed by their decree,
For in my heart, a Vancouverite, I proudly be."

"Alas, my visit to this place didst leave much to be desired. Forsooth, the Kung Po Shrimp lacked flavor, though the crustaceans themselves were cooked well. And the Hunan beef, oh how it left a strange film upon mine tongue! Verily, I say, 'twas not worth the price, for each dish didst cost more than ten silver pieces. Nay, I shall not return to partake in their dine-in fare."

"To Benny's we didst venture, my daughter and I,
For breakfast, a meal most plain and simple, yet satisfying.
We ordered eggs, bacon, toast, and home fries,
A standard fare, naught else, naught more.

The eggs, alas, were scrambled ill,
With texture strange and unpleasant still.
The bacon, too, was scraggly and thin,
Not worth the price we didst pay within.

My daughter, fair, didst enjoy the home fries,
But I, a man of taste, didst crave the other style.
The coffee, woe is me, was vile and base,
Unfit for noble blood or royal grace.

I paid full price, a sum of ten dollars,
And thus didst expect a meal of greater quality.
But nay, the food was made of synthetic stuff,
Eggs from the microwave, bacon pre-cooked enough.

The service, too, was poor and slow,
Our waitress vanished, ne'er to return anon.
I shall not go to Benny's again,
Forsooth, my heart doth break at the very thought of it, my friend."

"Aye, on one hand, service doth abound,
Friendly and helpful, with portions profound.
But alack, the victuals, a mixed bag they be,
Vegetables crisp and flavorful, yet meat and seafood doth suffer,
Shrimp, far greasier than need be, doth make one frown,
And chicken, overcooked and bland, doth bring me down.
So, if thou goest, stick with veggie fare,
For that, they doth a decent job prepare."

"Methought I did join the Kansas City Barbecue Society,
For thirty-five dollars, a paltry sum, didst seem.
In hopes to gain free entry to RD's hallowed grounds,
And sample their private label wines, of renown.

But lo! At the cash register, my joy didst turn to woe,
For I didst learn that liquor license, I didst not hold.
And thus, I could not purchase their fine wine,
My heart didst sink, my spirits didst decline.

And then, a further woe didst befall me,
For they didst overcharge me six dollars, a sum most unseemly.
For an eleven pound bar of Callebaut dark chocolate,
A mistake, they said, in their computer, most unfortunate.

So I didst wait, for half an hour or more,
To receive a refund, and end this woeful score.
Not a happy camper, I didst leave the place,
With a heavy heart, and a sense of disgrace."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Crandall's,
Where I, a hungry soul, didst order meals.
Via Grubhub, I didst choose their fare,
But alas! Their service doth leave much to bear.

The first time, I didst enter the wrong address,
And called the restaurant to make amends.
But they, in rudeness, didst deny my plea,
And told me I had the wrong place, indeed.

The second time, I waited for an hour,
But they, in foolishness, didst run out of power.
They called to say they had none left,
And left me with naught but sorrow and bereft.

The third time, they packaged my order awry,
And gave me food that didst not match my cry.
When I didst call to ask for the right fare,
They blamed the delivery man, without a care.

I've never had such poor service, indeed,
And feel compelled to write this Yelp review with speed.
For Crandall's doth lack the skill and grace,
To run a restaurant with proper pace."

"A pox upon this eatery, wherefore art thou, service?
We came ere a trio, our names doth sign in hathte,
Yet nary a glance didst the hostess bestow,
Though we, a duo, didst seek but a small repast.
No room at the bar, alas! a table wide,
Didst wait for the three, who didst sit with ease,
While we, neglected, didst tarry and stew.
Ten minutes passed, and still no menu didst come,
Until at last, a table, similar in size,
Was proffered us, with naught but empty space.
The hostess, fair? Nay, her mood didst sour,
As we, confused, didst order from afar,
And waited, and waited, until our patience didst wane,
For half our feast didst arrive, the rest, lost in vain.
Alas, poor service, doth mar this place,
For oft, with many, have we found grace.
But now, our trust, doth falter and fade,
In this, our latest, ill-fated escapade."

"Hark, fair citizens of Madison, we doth reside
In yonder downtown, where restaurants doth abound.
Our taste, discerning and refined, doth oft entice
Friends to seek our counsel, in search of gastronomic delight.

At Cento, alas, our expectations were not met,
For service, poor and lacking, did our patience beset.
No silverware, no napkins, empty glasses lay,
And drinks, unfilled, did prompt our dismay.

The bartenders, though pleasant, didst seem bereft
Of teamwork and customer care, to our grief.
Food, good but not great, didst fail to impress,
As service, shoddy, did our experience repress.

A kindly word with the manager, we didst impart,
Who listened with grace and promised a new start.
But lo, a call, he didst not make, to our dismay,
And thus, our trust, didst fade away.

Echo Tap and Big Ten Pub, our faith doth restore,
For service, there, doth rival the best, evermore.
Cento, take heed, and learn from these, thy peers,
Lest customers, like us, dost turn to tears."

Hark! I've just returned from fair London town,
Where I didst indulge in curries renowned.
Now, my taste buds do crave that spicy delight,
And so, I sought out Taza, a place in sight.

Their lunch buffet didst catch my eye, I must confess,
With its diverse choices, a veritable feast.
The service, too, was prompt and most courteous,
And the decor, a pleasant atmosphere, didst engender.

But alas! The food, it didst disappoint,
Dry and lacking flavor, it didst not impress.
Naan and soup, the only dishes that didst please,
Leaving me to pine for London's curries, if you please.

This place, a paltry two stars doth earn,
For reasons thus: my state of inebriation didst begin,
Meeting Asians from Texas, cool and fine,
A DJ, adequate, my love didst procure for me a double dose of Patron.
Beyond that, naught but stillness didst reign,
My mind, a jumble, as to hotel's name.

"Hark! I came to this place seeking the customary California Burrito and a draught of Jamaica, but alas! My quest was in vain. Forsooth, the person who took my order knew not the tongue of the Angles, and thus I was forced to venture to the window and inquire of their menu. And lo! The lass who served me spoke in a manner most strange and hard to comprehend, so that I could scarce make out her words. In dismay, I chose a quesadilla, which was but passable, and in no wise comparable to the rich Mexican fare I am wont to enjoy at Vaqueros on 19th and Southern. Alas! The food was naught but mediocre, and my spirits were dampened further by the lack of clear speech and good customer service."

"Alas, the ramen was o'ersalted, to mine own dismay.
The flavors of the ingredients, I could not discern,
For the saltiness did mask and overwhelm all,
In sooth, a pity, for the place was fair and bright,
And the service, good and prompt, did shine with light."

"A month in advance, a reservation I did make,
For seven, with hope of private table to partake.
The night of, a call I did make, to change the time,
But told we must arrive within the appointed climb.
We rushed, and barely made the cut, I do confess,
And found ourselves at a large table, in distress.
The room was empty, save a few, I did see,
And wondered why the haste, for all to be.
The food was good, and plenty left to share,
But service poor, save our attentive server fair.
A long meal, this shall be, so plan with care."

"Alas, my dear lord and I didst venture to the Planet Hollywood hotel, whereupon they didst present us with coupons for their buffet. We didst decide to partake in their morning repast, having heard tell of its excellence. But lo, what a disappointment it was! For all the dishes, nay, every last one, was cold as ice! Our first helping didst include eggs, hash browns, bacon, sausage, biscuits, and gravy, but alas, not a single morsel was warm. We didst leave most of it uneaten, in hopes that a second trip might yield a better result. But alas, 'twas not to be, for all remained as cold as before. A pox upon that buffet, say I! For though the victuals didst taste of promise, who doth wish to consume cold eggs and meat for breakfast? And furthermore, how safe could such food be, if 'tis not kept at a proper temperature? They didst have a fair selection and variety, but alas, 'twas not worth the cost, for who doth wish to dine on cold fare? I shall not return thither."

"Methought, fair sir, upon mine way to Jersey Mike's,  
To stop and view the place, and thus didst decide.  
I ordered three tacos, my comrade two,  
And waited thirty minutes, as patient as a saint.  
The hostess, fair and kind, didst proffer apologies,  
Yet nary a snack or drink didst they provide,  
For which I didst think them somewhat stingy.  
The prices, too, didst seem a mite steep,  
Twelve coins for three tacos, a princely sum, indeed.  
The Al Pastor, verily, didst taste most fine,  
Whilst the Chicken Tinga, alas, didst lack all zest."

"O, woe is me! Forsooth, the staff at Lonnie's doth fail,
In courtesy and speed, they doth most certainly pale.
Their manners be rude, their service doth drag,
And when the clock doth strike the closing hour,
They doth hasten thee to leave, with nary a pause.
Yet still, I doth return, for their wares be fair,
Their selection of cane glass beads, beyond compare.
For that alone, I doth brave their gruff demeanor,
And doth hope that someday, they may change their manner."

"A pox upon this Table 10, where doth my expectations lie?

Forsooth, I've supped at Delmonicos, Emeril's Fish House, and more,
Yet still, this place didst fail to meet my lofty score.
I took away a star for taste, another for the service slow,
And one for prices high, yet quality doth not show.
In truth, I shall not darken their door again, no more,
For though 'tis better than the Fish House, 'tis still a sore.
That place, a den of woe, most foul and dismal, maketh me shudder."

"Hark! Good sirs, I pray thee heed my words,
For here I speak of woeful curbside fate,
That doth beset the east economy lot,
Where travelers gather, eager to embark.

Alack! I found myself in such a plight,
Ninety-five minutes ere my flight did take,
And waited patiently, as others did,
Six or seven minutes, till my turn did come.

But lo! The man who oversaw the fray,
Didst deny me passage, with a scowl and dismay,
Forsooth! His computer would not allow,
And thus, poor traveler, I didst feel dismay.

I reckon 'twas but laziness that ruled,
And not the machine, as he didst proclaim,
For had they built a grace period, five minutes,
My troubles then had been avoided, methinks.

Alas! The curbside check, a service grand,
Doth now become a Nazi of luggage, so strict,
That travelers, beware! A hundred minutes ere,
Your flight, thou must arrive, lest thou be wretched.

In conclusion, friends, heed well my tale,
Lest thou, like me, dost suffer woes untold,
And thus, farewell, and may good fortune sail,
With thee, dear traveler, on thy journey bold!"

"In for a snack I strolled, and spied a feast most fried,
Wings of fish, and shrimp, their gizzards too, did lie.
Gizzards, I thought, would be my choice,
But the lass, who worked there, did say, 'Tis wing day, by chance.

Nineteen sauces, they had, I did peruse,
Sweet and sour, I chose, as bland, it did seem.
Alas, three of five wings, were not cooked through,
So, to return, I shall not, anon, adieu."

Alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
This place, though popular, doth leave much to be desired.
The servers, with their carts of fried fare, do roam,
But oft the dishes, cold and greasy, do lay.

The service, poor, doth make the experience quite vexing,
And but a third of dishes, good, doth one find.
The shrimp balls, fried, and egg tarts, do please,
But else, a disappointment, doth one often meet.

Now, if thou art enamored of a Chinese spread,
Brought forth by servants, language barriers breed,
Then perchance, this place, thy heart doth steal.
For many Chinese folk, here doth gather, reveal.

Yet, for myself, I fear, 'tis not my cup of tea,
The fried delights, my friends hold dear, to me,
Do taste, alack, like Chicken McNuggets, lukewarm,
A feeling, I confess, doth leave me quite forlorn.

So, if thou art with friends, and drinks, pre-dinner,
And seek a place, where hunger, to sate, doth strive,
Then here, perhaps, thy quest, doth find its end.
Or, if thou art a student, poor and hungry,
This place, a haven, for thy belly, doth provide.

"Alas, my dear young ones, I must simplify this tale,
For 'twill be hard to grasp, elsewise, its meaning so frail.
We chanced upon a place, called Dino's, I believe,
A watering hole, midst the wretched strip, did it receive.
At night, when revelers throng, it mayhap doth appeal,
But to mine eyes, 'twas naught but a dull, cinder block cell.
Dean Martin, that famed crooner, ne'er did imbibe,
For reasons unknown, his taste, didst not incline.
Thus, let us flee this den, and seek a better scene."

"In fair Montreal, where dining delights do abound,
One eatery didst leave me in a sour mood.
The lady behind the counter, a merry soul,
Didst greet us with a smile, and friendly didst unfold.

But lo, our server, a surly knave,
Didst show no care, nor interest didst he have.
The food, pre-made, a mere pastry and cake,
Didst take thirty minutes, a tardy mistake.

And thus, we were late for our flight, alas,
A woeful tale of poor service, naught but crumbs and glass.
We asked to take it with us, a polite request,
But met with scorn, her face didst turn quite bleak.

Frappes, they had on the menu, a curious sight,
But none were available, a puzzling plight.
No blender, she claimed, a strange excuse, indeed,
Leaving us to wonder, in puzzlement and need.

Alas, dear friends, this place didst not impress,
Avoid it, lest thou suffer similar distress."

"Verily, I didst visit this establishment yesteryear, and alas, my expectations were not met. The victuals didst not impress, and the ambiance, though open and airy, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi. The service, I must confess, doth escape my memory, but what doth linger is the feeling of indifference that doth permeate this place. In sooth, naught didst stir within me the desire to return, for there be many other venues at Tempe Marketplace that doth beckon my attention."

"Methinks my spouse and I did sit at yonder bar, ere we must take flight. The victuals were of fair quality, yet their cost didst not agree. Forsooth, at Kabuto's might I dine, and still be left unsatisfied. Two hundred and thirty pieces of eight did change hands for our repast, and nary a draught did I imbibe. \n\nThe shrimp of rock didst please mine taste, and thus we did request another. Alas, 'twas sodden and delayed, the kitchen being overwhelmed. The rest of sushi didst meet expectations, but naught exceptional. In conclusion, the fare was passable, but methinks I shall not return, when better choices lie beyond the Strip."

"On Saturday eve, we dined at this place,
With five in our party, full of grace.
But Tommy, the waiter, oh how rude,
His attitude, most unbecoming, quite crude.

The salads and apps, not much to boast,
And cocktails, weak, like a mere ghost.
My father's steak, tough as old shoe leather,
A sight to behold, a true disaster.

We waited long, an hour or more,
For dinner, but service, quite poor.
Amanda, the manager, did try,
To make amends, with desserts and a sigh.

But no excuse, for such poor treatment,
Tommy, the waiter, not fit for this station.
A one-star diner, on the strip, his place,
Not here, where fine dining, we expect with grace."

"Awkward, the club doth feel, despite great DJ's brought before.  Shame doth fall upon our town, when globally renowned DJ's come, and lame, the crowd doth prove.  Not the right crowd, nor place, for such grand DJ's, I do perceive.  O, how I wish they'd take their art and move to Bar Smith, where 'twould be done right, methinks."

"Tis not worth thine gold, good sir, to dine
At this establishment, shouldst thou desire
A hearty meal, with crepes filled to the brim
With fruit, and not but a few small bits within.

For nine silver coins, a mixed berry crepe
Doth cost, and with but three small berries doth it keep.
I laughed in jest, thinking the fruit on display
Was but for show, yet alas, 'twas not the case, I say.

If gelato be thy desire, then seek
The little stand in the Canals, forsooth, my friend.
There, mango sorbet doth await, so sweet and light,
That doth make mine mouth to water at the very thought tonight."

"With expectations high, I entered in,
But left, my dear, with disappointment's sting.
The facilities, alas, did not impress,
For Canyon Ranch's name and fee, I must confess.
Take heed, good sir, and spend thy gold
At places better suited to behold."

"Hark, what eatery is this? A den of rats, methinks.
The victuals, dearly bought, by serving maids with naught on their lower halves.
A single star, a token of my pity, doth grace this wretched place."

"Twas but a mediocre feast, my friends,
Despite the menu's promise of delight.
The chili and lime shrimp, oh how grand,
And grilled scallops with mango salsa, a true delight.
But alas, the flavors did not impress,
Overpriced, the dishes did profess.
Four pieces of shrimp for fourteen crowns,
Our scallops, undercooked, with frowns.

The servers, friendly and polite,
Attentive, they did ignite.
The decor, striking and fair,
A trendy place, to drink and share.
But alas, the food, a letdown,
Would not entice me, to come around."

"Methinks 'twas a strange and wondrous night,
My visit to BJ's, full of wonder and fright.
For though 'twas not my first time at this place,
I found myself in a most curious space.

Four chairs, all broken, didst greet mine eyes,
A hazard great, and cause for much surprise.
Yet, we began our feast with cheer and glee,
The calamari, a dish most fine and free.

But then, alack! The margarita flat bread,
Didst fail to impress, as once it had.
For 'twas not fresh, nor full of basil's grace,
As once it was, in days of yore and space.

My daughter, she didst order shrimp scampi,
And asked for Parmesan, a simple request, yea?
But lo! They brought her packets, void of sense,
And said they could not find the grater, in their defense.

Alas, poor BJ's, how art thou fallen from grace?
Once a place of wonder, now a place of disgrace.
Two stars, I give thee, for memories past,
But heed my words, and change thy ways, at last!"

"Verily, I knew not where to start, in sooth,
For this east valley tavern, hidden from view,
Didst play hard to find, in a strip mall's midst,
With a gruff visage on the entrance, anon, didst seem uncouth.

Two areas within, for revelry and cheer,
When full, a college party atmosphere doth bring,
But empty, fried food scent and punching doth fill the air,
As youths, in Scottsdale finery, doth congregate, in vain.

A musical evening, I didst attend,
Yet, distractions abounded, my friend,
Televisions, Golden Tee, a punching bag game,
Didst steal my focus, and my thoughts didst become askew.

One drink, a Jameson's, I didst imbibe,
(O, Toby, the price, didst cause me to quip!)
Perplexed, I remained, at this place's intent,
And why, oh why, would they allow punching, during a tuneful event?

A spacious patio, outside, doth beckon,
A larger room, with stage, for music, doth enchant,
And, in a smaller space, darts and pool doth await,
Like Iowa's venue, with diverse delights, in days of yore, didst present.

In Gilbert, perhaps, such diversity doth thrive,
A place for all, or so it doth seem, to survive."

"Hark, what shenanigans doth unfold at Popeyes Chicken! My heart doth yearn for their delectable fowl, and thus, I didst hasten to oblige my husband's craving. Alas, the service was most vexing, for nary a soul didst greet or acknowledge mine presence. I didst make bold eye contact, and didst enquire if the cashier was prepared to receive mine order. 

"Verily, I didst discover a current deal, which the cashier didst fail to mention. Fie upon thee, knave! Doth thou expect me to espie the changing deals upon the sideboard straightaway? 'Tis folly, I say! 

"But lo, the poor service didst not end there. The wretch who assembled mine order was most curmudgeonly. I didst request, nay, implore, each sauce and condiment with mine order. She didst bestow them upon me with great reluctance, her visage doth bespeak her discontent. 

"And yet, the chicken, it didst taste most wondrous, as it doth customarily. Yet, I do beseech those unhappy employees to seek other vocations, wherein they may find joy and contentment, for this work doth seemingly bring them naught but woe."

"Alack, my friends, we didst venture forth
To celebrate a comrade's final night of freedom,
And made a reservation, as was meet and right,
For six of us, at a specific hour, with all due speed.

But lo, when we arrived, the woman there
Didst inform us that no such reservation didst exist,
And though she seemed a gentle soul, with nary a care,
She could not help us, nor didst she make amends, alas.

One seat they had, but 'twas a lonely perch,
And hours would pass ere others didst become available,
So we, in sadness, didst depart, with naught to show,
Save for the shaved face of him whose party it didst behold.

Oh, friends, take heed of this tale, and mark it well,
For reservations made may not always be to tell,
And those who do not keep their word, doth bring us woe,
So let us beware, and find another place to go."

"Methinks I've had a craving most dire,
For hot fudge sundae, oh so sweet and fair.
In Lancaster, I chanced upon a place,
Rita's, where frozen custard doth grace the space.

A young maiden, with a smile so bright,
Did greet me, and showed me the flavors in sight.
I asked of the custard, and she did say,
'Tis good, indeed, the best in all the land, they say.

A kid's hot fudge sundae, I did order then,
And waited patiently, my heart full of cheer.
But lo, the fudge, it was a sorry sight,
A thin stream, not worth the candlelight.

The price, four seventy, a sum quite steep,
For a sundae, so small, it did make me sleep.
The custard, too, was not as promised,
Soft serve, not scooped, my hopes were frozen.

The hot fudge, mere canned stuff, alas,
Not worth the coin, nor the time it passes.
My search, it seems, must still continue,
For in Charlotte, the best hot fudge sundae, I shall pursue."

"Methinks 'tis oft I dine at swift and humble Mexican establishments, forsooth, not fond of Garcias, Macayos, Arribas, and suchlike. Yet, have I sought a genuine, sit-down Mexican eatery of repute, forsooth. Upon espying this place with four stars and a name in fair Spanish, I chose to give 'twill a go. Methoughts, fair Mexicans did dine within! Alack, my joy did wane when chips and salsa arrived, yet, I do strive not to judge by such alone. A plain cheese crisp we did order as an appetizer, and verily, 'twas not so bad; crispy, not oily, in sooth. But lo, the main courses did arrive, and what a disappointment! Tacos, oily, bland; beans, rice, naught better. In conclusion, 'tis but common Mexican fare, fried, insipid, greasy, like most. Naught special, naught authentic, herein. I shall not return, my quest doth continue."

In sooth, my first visit to One Love Vapors didst occur in early October, when the shop hadst but newly opened its doors. A chance encounter with the establishment upon Yelp didst lead me thither, and upon mine entrance, all seemed pleasant and welcoming. Music didst play, and a friendly gentleman didst greet me with great enthusiasm. 

Alas, fate didst not allow mine return until a fortnight past, when curiosity and desire didst stir within me once more. I didst venture forth, eager to behold any changes that may have transpired, and to partake in their wares anew. Howbeit, upon mine entry, a profound silence didst reign, and the sole employee present didst approach me with lessened vigor. 

I requested a taste of their elixirs, whereupon he presented unto me a menu, from which I didst choose a quintet of flavors. Alas, three of these didst taste burnt, a bitter disappointment indeed. Methinks the gentleman who served me hadst altered in but a brief span, his ardor and passion waning, perchance wearied by the demands of his vocation. Thusly, my second visit didst differ vastly from the first, with naught but two stars earned, for those few draughts that didst find favor with mine taste.

"Fare was passable, yet the premises were foul.
All waste bins were brimming, a most loathsome sight.
Not a single clean table, for litter lay upon them all,
And wretched refuse was strewn about with nary a care."

"A pox upon this wretched place, where service doth stink! 

A chai, with dirt didst they call it, I didst imbibe, 

Yet, welcome, I didst not feel, but quite the opposite. 

Two souls, behind the counter, worked with haste, 

But ne'er didst glance our way, nor didst they make haste. 

Ten minutes passed, or so it seemed, ere they didst bring 

Our drinks, and we, in patience, didst falter. 

A plague upon this den, where hospitality doth lack! 

I shall not return, nor wouldst I e'er suggest 

This woeful place, to any soul, in want of cheer."

"A fine array of garments doth Calvin Klein provide,
But heed my words, good sir, and take heed well,
For oftentimes, the price that doth appear,
Doth not align with what thou dost behold,
At checkout, thou mayst find a different tale,
And thus, thy patience shall be put to test,
If thou art one of those who doth delight,
In shopping long, and trying on with zeal,
Then woe betide thee, for thy mood shall sour,
At such a sight, thy anger shall unfold."

"Twas some fifteen minutes ere we were served with water and menus, and though they were somewhat attentive thenceforth, the service was lacking. A bloody mary I did order ere we began, and verily, 'twas the worst beverage I have had in many a year. Not drinkable, by the gods! Alas, the rest of the meal did not fare much better. Two dishes were not described aright by the waitstaff, and thus had to be replaced, alack! And after the rest of us had finished our repast, to boot. I did order the Chicken Zanagrelli, which sounded most excellent, but alas, 'twas not executed well. The sauce was flavorful, but the chicken, oh dear! Inedible, both in consistency and flavor. When they did clear my plate, they did ask if I wished a box, to which I did reply, "Nay." 

The manager, who was present that eve, did come over and offer his apologies most profusely for the ill-described meals, and did ask how the replacement dishes did fare. And lo, one of the recipients did say, "Pretty good," - a term most polite, methinks. A clue, indeed, that they did but seek to placate. Alas, they did strive to make amends, and the ambiance, quite lovely it was. But, alack, I fear this place shall not be on the list of returns."

"Methought, fair sir, to visit this place,
For oft I come hither to run my errands with haste.
The interior, neat and tidy, didst please mine eyes,
And the cashier, with a smile, didst welcome me with open arms.

A torta de lengua, I didst order, with great anticipation,
But alas, the dish didst fail to meet mine expectations.
The flavors, dull and uninspired, didst leave me in dismay,
And I fear, I shall not return, ere many a day hath passed away."

"Hark! To celebrate my friend's departure e'er he shipped away,
We came to this place of revelry, full of mirth and play.
But lo! The bouncers here, they were most rude and unkind,
They took my friend's state and military ID, and our joy did shrink.

They told us we must chase down the constable, to verify and approve,
And so we did, with haste and speed, our patience did improve.
At last, the bouncer did relent, and let my friend pass through,
But alas! The bouncers here, their manners do besmirch the place anew."

"Verily, tonight was my first visit to Pisces, and I must confess, the victuals didst please mine taste. The sushi options were most inventive, and the rolls my love and I didst order - Crunchy Spicy Tuna, Leo, Eel Special, Spicy Tuna - didst delight mine palate. Alas, the service didst not match the quality of the fare. 

Methinks I didst observe our sushi sitteth at the bar, awaiting collection, for nigh on ten minutes. Meanwhile, our server didst idle about the restaurant, doing naught in particular. When our feast was finally brought unto us, she didst request that tobiko be placed upon the wrong roll. No matter, I didst ask for extra on the side for the bare roll. Our server didst agree to the request, then didst vanish like mist before the sun. She didst not approach our table again until the meal was done, and then didst offer me the side of tobiko with a haughty, 'Well, I suppose 'tis a mite late.' 

I didst note her name from the receipt, and should I return, I shall not sit within her domain. Forsooth, the food at an inn can be divine, but poor service can mar a meal. I do hope that this is a matter the management doth recognize and doth strive to amend."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous tavern, full of brew most fine,
The tapsters, too, are skilled in their art divine.
But alas, the tunes they play do grate upon mine ear,
A medley of discordant notes that doth impair
The pleasant atmosphere, and doth my mood depress.
A jukebox, perchance, where patrons may choose their delight,
Would be a welcome addition, and make all things right.
For in its absence, the music doth jar and clash,
And doth detract from the enjoyment of each glass."

"A cup of joe most excellent, if they do get it aright,
Yet, alas! 'Tis but a half the time, a sorry plight.
Breakfast, good, yet, tarry thou must, ere it doth come,
And lunch, a pass, for better places there be, at same cost, anon.
The staff, in sooth, most courteous, but the queue, in disarray,
Alack! More training, or more hands, they do require, ere they may stay."

In this place, they boast of tradition,
A British pub, in name and fashion.
But alas, the prices they do charge,
Are quite steep, and leave me in a rage.

Eight dollars and fifty cents, for a pint,
Of generic beer, that doth not tempt.
And Murphy's stout, that doth not taste,
As it should, and leaves me in disgrace.

I'd rather drink, at a nearby place,
Where local beer, doth flow with grace.
Dieu Du Ciel, doth serve it well,
And cheaper too, I must tell.

The food, I cannot speak of,
For I did not eat, nor did I prove.
But my companion, did say it was good,
The egg noodles, and eggplant ragout, they stood.

The menu, had choices fair and bright,
But not your typical pub fare, in sight.
A Ploughman's Lunch, for thirteen dollars,
A high-end menu, that doth not please.

In conclusion, this place doth fall,
A bit short, of what it doth enthrall.
But still, the Ubisoft crowd, will love it,
After work, they'll flock, like a dove.

"Pancakes, but flour, egg, and milk,
Ten dollars here, methinks 'tis rank.
This place, o'erpriced, doth stink.
Convince thy friend, a cook of skill,
To make thee breakfast, better still.
Thou shalt drink water, as thou wilt,
And save thy coins, with naught to spill.
The only drawback, stay at home,
Is missing out on great dane's repast,
A sight most wondrous, verily,
His owners' purchase, a feast most vast."

"Pray, good sir, shoot me ere I step foot in this place once more. Forsooth, I know not why I return hither, save for the kind service of the staff. Alas, the victuals! Flattened by a bus, the steaks lie lifeless, cooked well done by force. The din doth pierce mine ears, and chill doth run down mine spine, for 'tis colder within these walls than without, in the city's sweltering heat. Verily, 'tis a woeful place, and I do vow, ne'er shall I darken its doorstep again."

"Hark! 'Tis a tale of two sides, my friends,
Of virtue and vice, in measure fair.
The bartenders, kind and welcoming,
Do make one feel at home, without compare.
But alas, their wings, a sorry sight,
Small, lacking zest, and often cold as night.
I've visited thrice, and each time, I swear,
The wings were naught but disappointment, dear.
Beef o Bradys, Bdubs, they do excel,
In flavor, size, and freshness, they do dwell.
A shame, for else the place is neat,
Clean, well-staffed, a pleasant retreat.
But, alack, the grub, a sorry state,
Doth leave much to be desired, I do relate."

"Ammo selection doth suffer, alas,
From shortages and stores in disarray.
I recently purchased a handgun,
But staff knew not what they did say.
They seemed to do me a favor, indeed,
In selling me a weapon with such speed.

The manager, who checked the papers,
Didst not look at me, nor speak a word.
He simply dropped my ID on the counter,
And walked away, without a single blink or nod.
Well, sorry, I suppose, for the intrusion.

Handgun selection doth improve,
Prices mostly at MSRP, I do perceive.
An average experience, to be sure,
But worth a visit, lest thou find something pure.
Last week, I found a gem, and bought it with glee,
But service, alas, did not come free."

"Methinks 'twas oft I came to this place, forsooth,
Their hours didst stretch until the night didst close.
In days of yore, their brew didst leave much to be desired,
Cold, even when served straight from the fire.
Now, I didst venture forth to try their tea,
A hot and better choice, or so methought.
But lo! The water, unboiled, didst make me frown,
A disappointment, indeed, and cause for dismay.
A simple kettle, on the deck, doth solve the woe,
And yet, the atmosphere, so casual and light,
Didst make me feel at ease, and the staff, so bright.
I pray they do improve, and not take their guests for granted."
"Ho there, good sir! What say you of this meal? Aye, 'tis but a mediocre feast, with fries o'ercooked and a burger most plain. Naught to boast of, I do declare!"

"A paltry sum, they gave me, of the food I didst crave.
Butter chicken, 'twas, yet o'er salted, I didst perceive.
Seven crowns, a meager ration, they didst demand.
Alack, poor service, and ambiance, they didst not command.
Next time, when hunger doth beset me, and I am near,
I shall eschew their premises, and seek Chipotle's cheer."

"Methinks I do adore Jamba Juice, but alas, this place doth lack. I've visited thrice, and each time, a wait hath been my fate. Last eve, four souls didst precede me, waiting patiently for their draughts, while one lass didst toil, preparing drinks with speed. A strawberry bowl, with granola and fresh fruit, didst I command, yet the cashier, in haste, didst pause, to take another's order, ere completing mine. His hands, unclean, didst don gloves, a foul sight, indeed. Alas, 'tis a pity, for now, to a further spot, I must journey, to quench my thirst for smoothies."

"Methinks this be my first Cirque show, and verily, I didst not enjoy it.  Some of the acrobatic feats I witnessed didst remind me of those I have seen at yonder circus.  Naught too impressive, I say!  At times, mine eyelids didst droop, and I didst struggle to remain awake.  For a hundred dollars, I do expect a deal more! 

I wouldst rather pay a bit more to behold a superior show, such as Le Reve at the Wynn.  

Definitely not the finest spectacle thou canst view in Vegas.  Watch another, I pray thee!"

"Alas, poor Sugar & Ice, thy name doth lie,
For naught but woe doth dwell within thy walls.
A place that should be sweet and full of cheer,
Doth bring us naught but bitter disappointment instead.

The menu, limited, doth leave much to be desired,
And he who seeketh sustenance, doth find naught but despair.
The grilled chicken panini, a sorry sight,
Doth prove to be but sliced deli meat, devoid of charm.
The bread, soaked in grease, doth weigh heavy on the stomach,
And cheese and aioli, o'er salted, doth assault the taste.

But lo, if thou art seeking sweets, 'tis not in vain,
For there, thy cravings shall be satisfied, 'twain.
Yet, for a meal or substance more substantial,
Best seek elsewhere, lest thou suffer similar frustration."
