"Hark, my dear friend! I do declare,
This Planet Fitness doth leave much to despair.
Since joining a month past, I have seen
Several locations, but this one, alack! doth stink.
The bathroom area, oh so foul and dark,
A light, out for a week, doth leave us in the spark.
Hydro beds, they do not function aright,
And staff, they doth seem to lack all delight.
A poor representation, indeed,
Of the chain, that doth my heart doth bleed."

Location: upon a mount, a site most rare,
With views most fair and ample parking space.

Service: kind hostess and waiter, diligent in care,
Attentive to our needs with graceful pace.

Food quality: rolls and salad, a decent start,
But meat, alas, a disappointment to my heart.
A rib eye, cooked plain, with naught but salt and pepper,
Lackluster taste, and veggies, wilted, without zest or vigor.

Ambiance: a bit loud, yet merriment we found,
The slide, a curious delight, worth a jest or two, profound.

Would I return? Alas, unlikely, I fear,
For better options nearby, my heart doth clear.

"Methinks, fair maidens, on days of rain,  
We'd visit this emporium of fashion,  
And browse the racks, in merriment and glee,  
As if in a montage of dress-up, we did play.  
The clerks, alas, were oft quite haughty,  
But still, we'd seek the finest garb, with naughty.  
Yet, nowadays, the quality doth lack,  
And high-end brands, they doth not come back.  
For lesser threads, Macy's sales doth reign,  
Or Goodwill, where thou mayst find rich gain.  
This place, so dear, doth charge a pretty penny,  
For vintage wares, in New York, or online, thou mayst winny."

"Fare thee well, dear friends! Forsooth, we sought a feast fit for kings,
But alas, 'twas naught but mediocrity that did our senses sting.
A sampler of Seviche, three dishes we did choose with care,
Yet only one did rise above the rest, a sorry state of affairs.
The decor, a sight to behold, a true delight for the eyes,
But, alack! The victuals and the service, a disappointment, a surprise.
So, forth we went, our taste buds seeking better fare,
For though the ambiance was fair, the grub and welcome, not so rare."

"Methought I wouldst have liked this place,
A first-time patron, my fair maid had been there.
I ordered ale, which was of fine taste,
But calzone, alas! did not please my palate.
I asked for sauce apart, but 'twas already filled,
And chunky sauce, I do not love, I must confess.
Within, 'twas nigh a waste, when I did reach
The middle, cold as ice, my heart did shrink.
Disgust did seize me, and my lady did say,
'Send it back!' But time, it did not allow,
So we did make do, and went upon our way."

"Hark! What is this place they call a Crowne Plaza? Aye, verily, I do protest. Forsooth, I am not lodged upon the club floor, yet still, I say, this fourth-floor King Suite doth pale in comparison to a reputable inn. Methinks I have stepped back in time, to days of yore, when mine own parents dwelt within a humble bungalow, dark, small, and foul-smelling, 'twain. 

Towels, ye gods! How foul they be! And wallpaper, peeling from the walls, doth make mine eyes to water. Windowsills, covered in insects, crawling, 'twas a sight most vile. Curtains, burned with cigarette holes, doth hang limp and lifeless. Furniture, sagging, questionable, doth make mine heart to sink. 

We arrived, in sooth, at midnight, after a grueling journey from Chicago, through snow and ice. My mood, it was not pleasant, and the night auditor, clueless, did argue with us, and failed to produce a single luggage cart or pillow extra. Pray, give me patience! 

All here, doth seem dirty, lowly, and in sore need of upgrading. Yet, as I must abide here two more nights, I shall, perforce, endure. But, gentle traveler, take heed, and flee this place, ere it be too late!"

"Verily, I shall give Echo & Rig a second chance, forsooth, our steaks were most wondrous, cooked to perfection, and full of flavor. Alas, the service did not meet expectations, 'twas lacking in quality. We dined below, an early evening repast, and noted that one couple departed, for want of a server's attention. And lo, when a servant did appear, we seemed to vex her, and she did not return, leaving us to ponder our fate, and the bill did come, with nary a word."

"Amidst the glittering lights of Sin City's gastronomic scene,
This buffet doth pale in comparison, methinks, to others seen.
The victuals, though not of the worst sort, are yet not worth the fee,
For thirty silver pieces per head, a princely sum, doth it decree.

The spread, though varied, doth not excel in any particular way,
And so, my friends, I say, let us seek elsewhere to dine this day.
For in this town of plenty, where culinary wonders abound,
'Tis folly to settle for aught but the best, and so, I have found."

"Hark! Good sir, I shall speak my mind to thee,
Of this establishment, where I didst decree,
A visit on a Saturday, full of hope and glee.
But lo! The ladies there, didst not impress me,
Their looks, most average, nay, not worth the fee.
The place, o'erpriced and o'ervrated, doth seem,
The music, good, the bartenders, kind and keen.
But alack! In Vegas, fair maidens should abound,
Like Pamela Anderson, in her prime and found.
This place, didst not stir my soul, nor didst excite,
$20 entrance, $40 per lap dance, oh fie upon it!"

"Hark, my dear, what news is this? A sports bar near,
We sought, yet found not quite what we did fear.
The happy hour, with prices low, didst seem,
But lo, they would not give us the special deal,
For in the dining room, we didst wish to sit,
And thus, were forced to pay a bit more, 'twit.

The fajitas, though with meat aplenty, came,
With naught but three small tortillas, to our shame.
And when we asked for more, the waitress didst say,
'Twill cost ye extra, thus, our anger didst play.
But hubby, he didst say, his steak was cooked aright,
A pleasant sight, amidst the disappointing plight.

Yet still, the screens, they didst show the games,
A delight, for those who do enjoy such claims.
But service, fair it was not, I do declare,
For they didst charge us more, without a care."

"Fair sir, the victuals were of fine quality, I must confess,
Fresh as the morning dew, and well prepared, no less.
But, alack, the choice was limited, compared to other feasts,
In Las Vegas, where abundance doth reign supreme, at least.

The sweetest course, the desserts bar, did leave much to be desired,
For heated plates, they did employ, which caused the ice cream to melt,
And chocolate, too, did suffer such a fate, I do declare.

The service, middling, I must say, not wondrous, nor so grand,
As some had claimed, forsooth, and not worth twenty-five silver pieces,
Ten to fifteen, a fairer price, for what thou dost receive, by my reckoning."

"Methought I craved Moo shoo pork last eve,
And so, my laziness did prevail,
I ordered from a nearby place,
Lest I shouldst have to journey far and wide.

But when the dish arrived, oh woe is me!
My mouth didst reek of onions, verily,
I have had Moo shoo pork in many a place,
But ne'er hath it been so full of onions' grace.

I brushed my teeth twice, ere I lay down,
And still, the onion's stench did linger,
In the morn, it didst still assail mine nose,
A pox upon the chef, who didst not choose
To season it aright, or understand
The true essence of Moo shoo pork, so grand.

This restaurant, well-known and oft-praised,
Hath failed me in this instance, I am amazed,
The owner must be told, the chef didst err,
And thus, my meal was not as it shouldst be, alas!"

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, I say, avoid this place,
Where mediocrity doth reign supreme, in service and in taste.
'Tis better thou shouldst cook thine own repast,
Than suffer the indignity of such poor fare.

If thou art bent on having eggs prepared,
Seek out a finer establishment, where quality doth prevail.
Forsooth, this place is large, but fear not,
Thy pleasure shall be naught, save for thy dismay.

In truth, there be many other choices near,
So heed my words, and shun this wretched den,
Lest thou desire to waste thy time and coin,
Upon a meal most foul, and service most vile."

"Twas a Saturday eve, and hunger pangs did strike, 
In Vegas' city lights, where revelry doth never cease. 
My friend, in search of sustenance, didst lead the way, 
To Wolfgang's doorstep, where we didst hope to find some ease. 
The entrance, adorned with rings of gold and silver, didst seem, 
A place of grandeur, yet the staff, with smiles so tender, didst gleam. 
Busy they were, and kind, despite the late hour, 
A testament to Vegas', ever-vibrant, never-dour. 

I ordered forth, a pizza of mushrooms, cheese, and leeks, 
To sate my hunger, and provide some needed seek. 
But alas, the leeks, they were not cooked, 
Raw and crunchy, left my taste buds unsoothed. 
The server, slow, with drinks, didst take his time, 
Leaving me to ponder, if this place, were truly divine. 
Makers Mark, with peach, my drink of choice, 
A saving grace, that didst make my voice, rejoice. 
Two stars, I give, for price and service, slow, 
Wolfgang, a place, I may not visit, though."

"Hark! I came to fetch some teriyaki fowl ere I returned to fair Los Angeles. Alas! The victuals here were but mediocre fare. The sauce did drown the meat, and 'twas heaped upon a bed of rice. Verily, 'twas o'ersalted. Methinks they didst care not for the preparation of the meal. Forsooth! This place doth cater to scholars, and thus, the portions be generous, the cost be low, and the flavor, alack! doth leave much to be desired."

"Hark! What woe is this? My heart doth sink,
For Old Chicago's pizza, once so fine,
Hath now become a shadow of its former self.
Their new Tavern style, a pale imitation,
Doth lack the flavor of their NY-style,
Which they no longer deign to serve.

A pox upon the waitstaff, ignorant and bold,
Who lie to customers with reckless abandon.
I asked if Specialty pizzas were included,
In the half-off deal, a question most innocent.
But lo, the answer given was false,
And our bill, inflated, did cause much vexation.

Farewell, Old Chicago, thy name doth ring,
With disappointment and poor service, a sorry tale.
I shall not return, for pizza so bland,
And mistakes on the bill, do leave a sour taste."

"Hark! What ancient inn have we stumbled upon? 

In fair Las Vegas, where vice doth reign, 
This lodging doth offend mine eyes with its decay. 

Their spread, a veritable feast for the gods, 
Did please my taste, yet their chambers, alack! 
Were furnished with antiquated contraptions, 
And televisions, oh so bulky and vast. 

The bath, a trickle of water did provide, 
A poor excuse for a proper ablution. 
I vow, dear friends, ne'er to return to this place, 
For its high tariff doth not match its base condition."

"Methinks I must dissent from many a reviewer,
For this place, four times I did visit, 'twas a dive,
A hole in the wall, plain and simple, no frills,
Yet, sometimes the best victuals one finds in such stills.
Alas, the hookah there, was not to my liking,
The decor, cheap and cheerless, the service, not so striking.
Young waitresses, new to their craft, it did show,
But, authenticity, I shall give them, that's a 'yes', though.
Fare, just passable, not great, merely adequate,
I question, whether I shall return, my dear, fate."

"Pah! Such was the sound I made, my friends,
After consuming oysters at Vinnie's end.
A dozen raw, quite fine, did please my taste,
But steamed, alas! Were overcooked, and waste.
Their juices gone, like mud they did impart,
And our fair server seemed not to take part.
In haste, she did attend our needs,
As if her mind were elsewhere, indeed.
I shall, perchance, in future, stay
From foods that may be fried, come what may.
And, pray tell, where doth the Raw Bar lie?
For when we asked, the server did reply,
'Twas microwaved, those steamed, alack!
What woeful oyster bar, this lack!"

"A trio of adjectives doth describe this cake aright,
Dry, Dry, and Dry, in that order they doth take flight.
Flavorless, a word most fitting, doth come to mind,
Tons of frosting, but alas, not worth thy time.
I didst sample the carrot cake, a parched mouthful indeed,
Requiring ice cream or drink, lest it doth leave thee in need.
The frosting, though not dry, doth lack a certain zest,
Sweetness o'erflowing, yet a taste most unimpress'd.
Two carrot cake cupcakes didst I purchase, the second, alas,
Shall meet its demise, in the bin, 'twill find its final rest."

"Hark! If thou dost crave the McRib when 'tis not in season, fear not, for Dickey's doth have thee covered! 

Beware, dear friend, the scent of BBQ doth deceive, for Dickey's is to barbecue as Taco Bell is to Mexico's finest fare. 

I ventured forth to Dickey's for luncheon, and ordered thusly: the Westerner, a sandwich of pulled pork and sausage, accompanied by macaroni and cheese, and loaded mashed potatoes. Alas, the sandwich didst not impress, save for the bread, which was quite pleasant. 

Foolish was he who compared Dickey's macaroni and cheese to Krafty's; nay, their concoction of cheese sauce doth pale in comparison. The loaded mashed potatoes, however, were passable, as was the sweet tea. And lastly, I enjoyed a complimentary cone, labeled ice cream, though appearances can be deceiving, for 'twas but a poor imitation of the real thing. 

The service was good, the establishment clean, and prices fair. A fine place for families, indeed. Though I wouldst not make haste to return, a coupon might entice me once again to partake of their offerings. Bon appetit, my friends!"

"O, how my heart doth sink with disappointment! My expectations were high, but alas, they were not met. The 'Wicked Spoon' doth reign supreme, for naught here did impress. Alack, the fare was common, nay, poor, and service, too, did lack. Farewell, I shall not return."

"Alack, fair traveler, take heed of this review,
Of pros and cons, to guide thee on thy quest.
'Tis close to downtown, and the belt line too,
A comfortable bed, thy weary head to rest.

But alas, the breakfast, poor and meager,
The lounge unclean, attendants slow to heed.
No coffee cups, or sleeves to hold them tight,
A sorry state, for one who craves the brew.

Some front desk staff, with rudeness doth abound,
Unwelcoming, with scant courtesy found.
For occasional guests, mayhap 'twill suffice,
But business travelers, seek elsewhere, for a better prize.

I, who have stayed at Starwood, Marriott and more,
Do find this hotel, in service, poor.
So heed my words, fair traveler, and choose with care,
Lest thou find thyself, in a similar snare."

"Alack, my expectations were not quite met,
At this zoo, where I didst recently set foot.
The signs, they were not clear, and that did vex me,
And many of the creatures, they were not there to see.

The petting zoo, a place of wonder, I thought,
Didst consist but of a pen of goats, alas, no more.
A shame, for I had hoped to see much more,
But nay, 'twas not to be, at this zoo, I didst explore."

"Methought we eyed this place each day,
And plotted to partake of their morning fare,
At last, we entered, and 'twas worth the stay,
For friendly staff and swift service did prepare
Our hearts for feasting. Coffee, rich and bold,
Did please our taste, and thus we made our choice,
I, chicken hash, the waiter did unfold,
Alas, the dish, a disappointment, did bring,
The portion vast, the bread, hard as a stone,
Flavorless, the victuals, left us aghast,
I added spice, to rouse my senses from their sleep,
But nay, the meal, did not my palate greet,
With joy, forsooth, 'twas naught but woe and sorrow,
Black Bear Diner, still reigns supreme, to-morrow."

"Upon my visit to Whisky River, I found it not to be a shrine to Dale Earnhardt Jr., as I had supposed. 'Twas instead a haven for his fond admirers, a place of pilgrimage for those who hold him dear. A stand within the premises doth sell T-shirts, hats, and other trinkets bearing the name of Whisky River.

"If thou art not a fan of NASCAR, 'tis best to avoid this place during a race, for all 20 televisions within the bar doth show the same.

"Be aware, good sir or madam, that Whisky River doth require a membership, and thou must wait in line and fill out a form to gain entry. A cover charge doth also apply.

"The crowd within doth not dress up, forsooth. Women doth wear jeans and halter tops, while men doth don jeans, collared shirts, and baseball caps.

"Three large bars and several beer tubs doth provide ample space for imbibing drinks, and the mechanical bull doth offer sport and entertainment, especially for the fairer sex.

"A blessing indeed, that Whisky River doth lie close to the light rail, making it easily accessible."

"Hark! A traveler, come for business' sake,
I found this chamber, foul and forlorn,
A relic of the eighties, in disarray,
With red leather chair, and dresser, worn.

The mirrors, numerous, did mock my face,
The bathroom counter, too small, a disgrace,
No coffee maker, to ease my plight,
A towel, rent, with six-inch hole, alas!

If renovations be not made, farewell,
MGM, thy days are numbered, I can tell,
I shall not return, nor recommend,
For hidden fees, in fine print, doth offend."

In sooth, my friend, when drink doth take its toll,
And bus ride home doth seem a burden to bear,
What choice hast thou, but seek a bed to lay thy head?
A hotel, nearest at hand, didst beckon us near.

Thistle King James, a name of some renown,
Didst offer twin rooms, all that remained,
So in we went, with nary a moment's pause,
To rest our weary heads and quench our thirst.

The mattress, hard as stone, didst suit my taste,
But my companion, he didst not find it so fair,
For heat, it was, and no thermostat in sight,
Didst make our sleeping chamber a veritable oven.

Outside, a drunkard's roar didst pierce the night,
And through the walls, his voice didst come quite clear,
As if in same room, not six floors up,
I didst feel his presence, and not a pleasant fear.

The lady at the desk, with cheerful grace,
Didst tell us, 'twas to be torn down, its place,
A newer, better hotel, would rise anew,
But soundproofing, a thing most dear, they should pursue.

"In Tempe's fair city, where I didst grow,
A liquor store didst stand, most wondrous show.
With flashing lights, a sight to see,
And drive-through, for ease and glee.

As youth, I thought it grand, a place to be,
But when of age, I found it not to see.
Thirty stores lay 'twixt home and thee,
So ne'er didst I venture, wild and free.

Groupon, with deal so fine and fair,
Didst tempt me in, with liquor to spare.
I went, and found it not so grand,
A disappointment, in this liquor land.

For those who hasten to ASU's gate,
It may suffice, but not worth the wait.
Prices high, like Las Vegas' fee,
Go elsewhere, and save thy gold, thou shalt see."

"A question, dear friends, doth arise within me,
Whether my beer or burrito, cold as can be,
Didst make mine teeth to chatter most vehemently.
The service, alack, didst leave much to be desired,
And I, a humble patron, didst have to plead
For chips and salsa, as if 'twere a great favour.
Best to avoid this place, lest thou desirest to freeze,
And find thyself in want of common courtesy."

"O, how I adore Starbucks, 'tis true,
But this particular one, alas, doth not impress me.
'Tis strange, indeed, when there's no queue to be seen,
And the noise, oh, how it doth pierce mine eardrums!
'Tis a cacophony of sound, a veritable din,
That doth make it hard for me to concentrate,
Or finish any work, for that matter, within.

The children, oh, how they doth annoy,
With their shrieks and laughter, they doth disrupt my repose.
Yet still, I doth return, for 'tis but three minutes away,
And the staff, they doth greet me with a smile, each day.
They doth prepare my coffee with skill and grace,
And the outdoor seating, it doth seem a pleasant place.
But alas, 'tis too hot, or cold, of late,
To enjoy it fully, and so I doth hesitate.

Oh, wouldst they had a drive-thru at this site,
How convenient 'twould be, and a true delight!"

"Hark, fair friends! I do proclaim,  
Food doth please my taste, in sooth.  
But, prithee, heed my warning well,  
Purchase not a single retail spell!  
Forsooth, I bought a purse of eighty crowns,  
And wore it but a week, when lo!  
A strap didst start to come apart.  
I took it back, in hopes of mending,  
But alas! They said all sales were final,  
And would not take it back, nor render  
Any aid or solace to my woe.  
Yet still, I pray thee, take this purse,  
And bear it to the cobbler's house,  
That he may fix the broken strap,  
And make it whole once more, by Jove's grace."

"Susihi, a humble abode of sushi, didst seem not so fresh as other places I had been. Special rolls, baked or deep-fried, didst lack in taste and quality. Service, at first, didst flow with ease, but soon didst cease, as waitresses and waiters didst ignore our table. I didst beckon them, yet they didst not heed my call. If thou dost desire fair service for half the time and sushi below par, then Susihi shall be thy destination."

"Tiny servings at exorbitant cost, a travesty indeed!
Mexican cuisine, a taste divine, yet served with stingy hand.
In southwest lands, authentic eats abound,
At prices fair, without a doubt profound.
A pleasant scene, a bonus true,
Yet not worth such an outrageous fee, I do declare to you."

"Hark! If thou dost seek Asian fare,
Thou shalt not find it here, I do declare.
'Tis but a place of mediocre feed,
O'erpriced and nigh to CMU, indeed.

I have essayed their pho, alas!
A sorry sight, with broth most vapid.
And rice with duck, not ill-prepared,
Yet, from the knife, not neatly carved.

In sooth, if thou art in CMU's bounds,
Better options lie, without a doubt.
And, gentle servers, take note, too,
For courtesy and speed, they do imbue."

Hark! A tale of woe doth come from me,
'Twas during lunch, on weekend's day,
Inside, not many souls didst roam,
Yet TVs blared loud, in disarray.
Converse we couldst not, for the din,
As if in competition, to win.
French dip, I didst order, fair,
But oh, the au jus, a gravy rare.
Tots, crunchy and not oversalted,
A delight, yet not worth the journey, oft repeated.
My home, a distance, doth lay,
And thus, not worth the trip, I say.

"Hark! A Focaccia sandwich I did order,
They said it was unique, and so it did border.
Not like the bread of old, more like a wrap,
A burrito, perchance? Alas, my hopes did snap.
The sweet potato chips, they were quite tame,
And the beer, it was cold, but not to blame.
I would, ere next, try another place,
For this one doth not merit my grace."

"Methinks, fair friends, my first impression of this place was less than favorable. 'Twas large, indeed, and offered steins of ale most generous, yet the patrons, diverse and motley, didst strike me as a curious mix. A potent blend, mayhap, for discord and strife, yet, upon further visits, hath this tavern grown upon mine own esteem. Not, mind thee, my most cherished watering hole in Madison, nor doth it rank within my twenty preferred haunts. Yet, 'twill serve its purpose, when a friend doth ask, "Wilt thou join me in a mug of ale?" And, verily, its proximity to mine own domicile doth render it a convenient choice. Weeknights, the atmosphere doth lean toward tranquility, allowing one to partake in converse and imbibe in peace. In sooth, this establishment doth not excel, neither doth it falter; 'tis simply a place where one may find solace in a tankard of ale."

"A feast fit for a king, they did proclaim,
With wines of vintage, rich and rare,
But service, slow and lacking zeal,
Did dampen spirits, with a scowl so bleak.

The fare, when it arrived, was tepid,
And menu's promise, did not quite accord,
With dishes, that did not quite conform,
To what was said, or what was meant.

A ham hock, bathed in BBQ sauce,
Did sit atop, a bed of grits,
Too rich, and far too buttery,
For my taste, and for my purse.

Yet, wild board meatballs, did delight,
Their flavor, bold, their texture, right,
A saving grace, in this, my plight,
Against the rest, that did not quite ignite.

Alas, my hopes, were raised so high,
And thus, my disappointment, did come nigh,
For though the wine, did flow like a river,
The food, did not live up to the shiver."

"Verily, I wish to hold this place in high esteem, I truly do. But alas, three things doth hinder my affection: Firstly, their barbecue, though sauces be delectable, doth lack the savory flavor I crave. Sides, too, are middling, with naught to set them apart from others. Secondly, their prices doth rival those of other establishments, and for such cost, I'd prefer to dine upon the finest fare at Midwood Smokehouse or Mac's. Lastly, it doth vex me when portions are meted out with stinginess, like a Subway sandwich shop. Service, however, doth shine, with friendly, swift attendants, eager to converse."

"Hark, good sir! If thou desirest ice cream with a twist,
Thou shalt have it, by my troth. My two small daughters,
Innocent souls, cannot devour a full scoop, I pray thee.
When I did ask, 'May I procure but one scoop,
And a spare bowl, perchance?' The response, alack,
Was naught but a stern refusal. Fie upon't!
I shall journey forth to Cold Stone, yonder,
To fetch the frozen treat myself, ere long."

"A humble tavern, naught but a dive bar,
Where we would gather for a pint or two,
When night descended and day's toil was done,
In this, my former neighborhood, anon.

Native Americans, many a one, didst throng
This place, their laughter and chatter loud,
Their love of ale, a bond that didst bind,
In fellowship, their spirits unbound.

But what sets Playa Bar apart, me friends,
Is their willingness to package up,
A few cold brews, for thee to take home,
And thus, thy thirst, doth never become dry.

A simple place, no frills, no fuss,
Yet here, good cheer and ale, doth flow,
So if thou find thyself in this fair town,
Do stop by Playa Bar, and drink thy fill, ere dawn doth break."

"Four times have I graced this humble abode,
To savor their famed pho, my heart doth implore.
Yet alas, each visit doth leave me dismayed,
For service most woeful, doth my soul impale.

The owner, a surly man, doth bear a scowl,
And greets us not, nor doth he smile, I vow.
He saunters o'er, and doth exclaim,
"Ready?" in tone most curt and tame.

Then doth he vanish, leaving us to wait,
Until the soup, like tardy guest, doth arrive late.
I reckon 'tis no task to ready make,
Soak noodles, add broth, and beef, so rare, anon.
A feat most simple, yet they doth prolong,
As if 'twere some grand, laborious deed, so wrong.

While I, in waiting, didst note the blinds,
So grimy, dirty, and with dust entwined.
I pondered, too, what other ills they hide,
And feared for my health, in such place confide.

At last, the pho, a large bowl, didst arrive,
With beef, a scant four slices, didst my eyes perceive.
I asked the owner, if this were aright,
Since large, I ordered, with all my might.
He said 'twas normal, no attempt to mend,
So I, in disgust, didst swiftly depart, my friend."

"Fair service, a tidy space, but alas, the victuals did not impress. A letdown, indeed, forsooth! We dined with hopeful hearts, but nay, the fare did not meet our expectations. Pancakes, aye, they were passable, but, good sir, the potatoes and corned beef hash, devoid of zest and flavor, they were not worth the savoring. Alas, we shall seek sustenance elsewhere, forsooth!"

"O'erpriced, say I? Nay, 'tis true, my friend. Forsooth, the victuals they do serve, lack zest and savor. A pox upon their menu, I do declare! Yet, one dish didst strike my fancy, a humble choco taco, worth but a few coins. Methinks 'tis a bargain, fair and square."

When first I came to this fair salon, 'twas good, indeed,
Two ladies there did please me well, their skill did excel.
But then, alack, a change did come upon me,
An old man and woman took their place, you see.
Their work did not compare, I must confess,
My nails, they lifted, and did not last, alas!
I cannot make appointments, so I must accept,
The chance I take, with each visit, I do suspect.
If only I could choose, the two ladies fair,
I'd return each time, without a single care.
But alas, the man, he doth my nails impair,
So I shall seek a new salon, with more repair.
A place that values residents, all year round,
And not just those who come, when winter's found.

"Hark, fair friends! I've visited this place afore,
For oysters, my heart doth sing with glee.
But lo, last weekend, we didst venture forth,
To try their pan roast, a dish of great renown.
Alas, the broth was sweet, a strange delight,
And not to my liking, I must confess.
So, go thou forth, and order oysters,
For they be the best, and worth thy quest."

"Hark! Imagine this, fair friends, a fortnight's fast,  
A diet strict, with naught but water's taste.  
And now, on holiday with maidens dear,  
Thou dost desire to join in feast and cheer.  
Aye, 'gainst the urge to dine on bland fare,  
Thou choosest buffet grand, with dishes rare.  
Two hours in line, and forty pieces paid,  
For culinary delights, thy senses swayed.  
But lo! Disappointment great, didst thou find,  
In dishes few, and quality unrefined.  
The sushi, too, a letdown, didst thou see,  
Rice abundant, but little fish, alas!  
Eggs scrambled, mashed potatoes, pesto-laced,  
Were best, yet sad, thy stomach's hunger traced.  
A buffet, where eggs, not sushi, reign supreme,  
A sorry state, thy taste buds didst deem!"

"Oh, fair Stereo, where youthful folly doth reign,
A place of cheap delights, and nights most vain.
On Wednesdays, aged eighteen, one doth attend,
For Movida's legend hath not yet been penned.

The entry, free, and vodka, but a pound,
Doth make for nights of mirth, and laughter profound.
The decor, tired, and layout, plain to see,
A long bar, dancefloor, and little else, doth be.

Shagtag, oh Shagtag, how thy name doth suit,
A tacky night, with numbers, and hearts aflame.
A sticker, with a number, doth one receive,
And if another doth desire, they doth leave.

Alas, poor Stereo, with little to offer,
A fleeting joy, and memories to suffer.
For those who seek a night of worth,
Best avoid this place, of little earth."

"Alas, my heart doth yearn for more stars to shine,
But alas, fair readers, I cannot divine.
Forsooth, our first visit to yon diner local,
Didst bring us joy, and service most hospitable.
Food, though not gourmet, didst satisfy,
And thus, we didst return, with hopeful eye.

But lo, each subsequent visit didst bring woe,
With service poor, and victuals below par.
We didst query, why doth this fate befall?
And thus, our visits didst cease, of late, by far.
For wherefore shouldst we spend our coin,
On fare that doth not meet our expectations high?
Nay, let us seek Atlantis Taverna's embrace,
Where culinary delights doth reign supreme, in this place."

"Hark, fair reader! I do confess,
This place doth hold a special charm,
For when I know precisely what I seek,
I come hither, lest an employee beset me with their feeble mind.
Alas, but one in ten doth possess the knowledge true,
And oft, my patience doth wear thin, in frustration's cruel hue.
The customer service, alack, doth leave much to be desired,
Yet, when I find a gem, 'tis at a price most fair and bright."

"Alack, the service here doth leave much to be desired,
For staff doth seem rude, unhelpful, and incompetent.
The suites, though fair in appearance, doth possess
A certain cheesiness, and the couch, alas, doth seem
Impossible to clean. The casino, too, doth fall
Short of expectations, save for a few nice touches.
'Tis a middling hotel, o'erpriced, I do declare,
With service poor, and pool, though crowded, doth
Lack refreshment. Alas, my heart doth sink,
To pen these words, and thus, my review doth end."

"Upon a recent journey to Madison with mine offspring, we didst venture forth to this establishment, known as the Circus World Diner.  Verily, I say unto thee, if thou art not enamored of clowns and the trappings of the circus, do not trouble thyself with a visit to this place.  Forsooth, the fare provided doth leave much to be desired, and the menu, a tome of thirty pages, doth offer scant choice for those of discerning taste.  Our company, consisting of four in number, didst partake of a Chicago-style hot dog, a meatloaf with mashed potatoes, a cheeseburger, a Reuben sandwich, and a bowl of broth.  And lo, we all didst concur, upon departing the premises, that our experience had been naught but a disappointment.  The children, however, didst seem to find enjoyment in their chicken tenders, blessed as they art with youthful innocence and a lack of understanding regarding the malevolent nature of clowns and their ilk.  In conclusion, this place may serve a purpose for a brief sojourn with children, but for a satisfying repast, seek elsewhere."

"In this fair Chinese Cultural Center, there lies a restaurant most fine,
Which I, alas, had not yet visited. So, my friend and I did dine,
After a spot of shopping, in this place of elegance and grace.

We entered, and a seat for two didst we request, which was granted straight away,
And thus we sat, in surroundings fair and bright, with music sweet and gay.
The menu we perused, and drinks and appetizer didst we order forthwith,
And lo, they came, with haste and speed, like unto a swift wind's breath.

Oh, how delightful was the taste, of all that we didst consume,
But alack, the service, poor and lacking, didst leave much to be desired.
For our waiter, he didst not introduce himself, nor didst he tend,
To our needs, or ask if we didst require aught else, ere the end.

A pity, indeed, that such a place, with food and decor so fine,
Should falter in the service, and leave a sour taste behind.
Yet still, I say, 'tis worth a visit, for the ambiance doth make,
A pleasant dining experience, despite the waiter's mistake."

"Methinks the throng's elation doth astound,
Regarding the fest's creative array.
Yet, to mine own mind, 'twas naught but a fair,
Where crafty wares were sold, with naught to spare.
The atmosphere didst please, but not the fare,
And thus, my friend and I didst hasten there,
To the arcade, where we didst spend our share.
Alas, the fest didst lack a certain flair,
That doth accompany youth's vigor and glee.
Parking, a woe, doth plague the festive ground,
So, biking or walking, a better route is found.
Talent abounded, but none didst astound,
In awe, my soul didst leave the fest, unbound."

"Amidst the throngs of patrons, staff doth strive to aid,
Though 'tis a busy place, and time doth often slide.
Disabled access, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
And on inclement days, they urge wheelchair users to partake
In outdoor feasting, though staff doth freely confess
That space, indeed, doth lack.

Frozen fish, a sorry sight, doth grace the menu,
Naught but a pale imitation of what thou mightst procure
At market's stall, and at a price most exorbitant,
Twelve pounds and twenty-five pence, a sum most preposterous!
Yet, my companion's pizza, freshly made, did please,
Though grease doth seem to plague the fare, and many guests
Hath voiced their discontent.

Management, it doth appear, doth lack a steady hand,
For when I sought a manager, a forty-five minute wait
Did ensue, and still, no sign of authority did manifest.

Accessible venues abound, with leadership more astute,
And victuals far superior, e'en the humble chip shop
Opposite, doth serve finer fish and chips, at half the cost.
This place, I shall not hasten to revisit, in truth."

"Hark, good sir! Thou sayest thou art content
With warm brew, priced at seven dollars and a half,
So long as sporting spectacle doth grace thy sight.
Yet, alack! The portion sizes didst stir surprise,
And caused quite a commotion'mongst the crowd.
But, verily, the garb of yonder servers,
Didst remind thee of thy automobile's plight,
In need of oil, to keep it running bright."

"Hark! My dearest MR doth say, had I known  
That I wouldst be beaten up, nay,  
I wouldst not have come this way,  
Forsooth, my feet didst ache, and weary,  
From walking the Vegas strip, all day,  
And thus, a foot massage, didst seem most meet,  
To ease my tired soles, and bring me cheer.  
But lo! The masseuse, didst rub my head,  
With such great force, that my thinning hair,  
Didst fear, it wouldst be torn away,  
And leave me bald, ere I didst depart.  
The massage, itself, didst bring me pain,  
For the lady, didst use all her might,  
And didst not ask, if I didst desire,  
More pressure, or a gentler touch, in sight.  
A foot massage, it didst not prove to be,  
But rather, a body massage, most brutally.  
Alas! We sought a foot massage, fair,  
But found a beating, instead, most rare.  
A lesson, learned, to not be fooled,  
By deals, that seem, too good, to be true,  
For oft, they may, thy wallet, lighten,  
And leave thee, with a body, sore, and bruised,  
As didst this place, with its $20 fee,  
And open hours, most convenient, for me."

"Hark! For years I've visited Mr. Lucky's place,
Enjoying their gambler's feast with grace.
Their shrimp, a salad, and taters, oh so fine,
But alas, the steak, once of high quality, doth decline."

"O, why doth everyone delight in Antonio's fare?  Thin crust, aye, 'tis but a woeful snare.  Toppings, they do but drown in oil, a sorry sight.  Freshness of ingredients, a question most dire.  Price, alack, doth rival that of gold, forsooth.  Methinks I do but crave a pie less oily, a slice not soaked in grease, perchance.  Yet, one virtue doth this place possess, a diversity of toppings vast and wide, from tortellini to tortilla chips, blue cheese, steak, and bacon, they do proffer all, with oil aplenty, and a lascivious grin, they doth present it to thee, fair patron."

"Hark! A word of warning, dear foodies, steer clear of Hillside Spot, lest ye wish to dine on mediocrity. My love and I didst venture hither a fortnight past, seeking a swift repast after a visit to Ikea's hallowed halls. We didst order the Blue Sky burger and a salad-sandwich combination, but alas! The chopped salad, though fresh, didst pale in comparison to the grilled veggie sandwich, which didst assault our taste buds with its oily, greasy presence. And the Blue Sky burger, oh how it didst fail to impress! Forsooth, the blue cheese didst overpower all other flavors, leaving us in utter dismay. Verily, this place didst prove the greatest disappointment in many a moon. Three and a half stars, quoth thee? Nay, I say, for 'tis but a paltry rating for such a lackluster establishment."

"Hark, good sir! A four-day a week customer of Yogurtland, I've been,
For months on end, with nary a break.
Their friendly employees and broad selection, doth make it a great place, indeed.
Out of curiosity, I tried Agave, and found their cake batter yogurt, most excellent.
Methought this might be my next favorite haunt, but alas!
The next day, the cake batter was gone, and in its stead,
A different flavor did appear. Oh, how the selection doth change each day!
I was impressed by the cashier's words, for he did say,
That Wi-Fi was available, and chargers for devices, aplenty.
My iPhone, near death, did cry out for aid,
So I asked the cashier, if he could provide an iPhone charger, straightaway.
Alas! He did not have one, and thus, my hopes were dashed.
Are you kidding me? The best device in all the land,
And yet, no charger could be found, within his grasp.
Moreover, the prices, quite steep, they do add up,
Yogurtland, a better value, by far, doth offer, at a rate of 8 cents per ounce, cheaper.
A family of five, doth feel the pinch, I do declare!"

"Tonight, we dined at this establishment, and verily, 'twas but a mediocre affair. We chose this place by means of Yelp, forsooth, and though we prepare Indian victuals at home three days a week, we had a hankering for the culinary delights of a public house. We ordered the mixed grill plate as an appetizer, and chicken tikka masala and naan for our principal course. The grill plate consisted of kabobs of various meats, laid upon a bed of sautéed onions, and truly, it did arrive in a state of sizzling vigor, causing many a head to turn in curiosity. Alas, my mouth did water in anticipation, but alack, the chicken was dry and lacking in flavor. The seekh kabobs were overwhelmed by spices, and the portion, so paltry! The onions, verily, outweighed the meat in quantity. The tikkas, too, were unremarkable, being oily and spicy, with naught but small, cube-shaped bits of fowl. This place may suit students well, by reason of its proximity to ASU, but, anon, I fear I shall not return."

"Alack, this place didst disappoint.  
Their logo and branding didst suggest  
Fun, traditional Italian cuisine, at best.  
But nay, 'twas not the case, I do confess.  
Not even close, alas! Oh, how I miss  
Italian food from New York, with its kiss  
Of flavor and warmth. And mark my words,  
Do not order takeout, for 'tis not worth  
The trouble. Heat lamps they do not use,  
And all was cold when we didst retrieve  
Our phone order, which didst arrive fifteen  
Minutes late, they said. Alas, poor show!"

"Hark, what discord doth this hotel bring!
'Tis a shame, for its grandeur doth sing.
Four thousand chambers, and yet, alack,
No guest, it seemeth, didst leave with joy unpacked.

Our entry, a trial it did prove,
For seven o'clock, our room we did not move.
And, alas, our company, dispersed,
No floor, they say, could accommodate, immersed.

One friend, no service, didst receive,
And ours, delayed, till five, didst perceive.
The sink, with hairs, didst make us blink,
The privy, foul, our senses didst shrink.

The clerks, their duty, didst not perform,
With scowls, they didst greet, and didst deform.
But, lo, the exit, smooth, it went,
A pleasant face, our troubles didst relent.

Aware, they be, of faults, they say,
And strive to mend, ere another day.
But, alas, for Aria, 'tis too late,
For most, their stay, didst not compensate.

Of three, in line, none didst express
Satisfaction, and each, some gift didst possess.
Not good, indeed, this hotel doth lack,
Bellagio, Wynn, or Venetian, doth pack.

The decor, dark, doth not entice,
And thus, this place, doth not suffice.
A stay, elsewhere, doth recommend,
For joy, and peace, doth not offend."

"A pox upon this place, a glorified Outback Steakhouse, how vile doth it taste! My love and I didst order Wagyu Filet, but alas, 'twas naught but a regular filet, a paltry imitation of the real thing. My love doth swear they gave us the wrong cut, perchance they didst play a trick upon us. Oh, woe is me! We didst spend a pretty penny, four hundred crowns, on dinner, wine, dessert, and an appetizer, yet the meal didst not satisfy. Forsooth, we do spend lavishly on meals for the experience, but this was not worth the cost. The bone marrow was fair, but the filet, priced at seventy-two crowns, didst taste but mediocre at best. The highlight of our feast was the duck fat fries with white truffle oil infused dipping sauce, the cauliflower that accompanied my pretend filet, and the Darjeeling tea, which was most excellent. I do believe we shall try Jean Georges steak house at the Aria next, forsooth, their Wagyu beef is said to be most wondrous, and genuine, unlike this pitiful excuse for a steak."

"Alas, how quickly they do fall from grace,
With dinner, a paltry side dish they proffer,
Cole slaw, a meager prelude to the feast,
For which they charge an additional fee, no less.

The French Onion Soup, a sorry excuse,
At Mimi's, far better, I must confess,
Too much cheese, the bread, a pitiful sight,
And scant few onions, a poor showing indeed.

The prime rib, with horseradish, so weak,
Cut with butter, a strange and curious technique,
But luckily, sour cream and raw horseradish I did seek,
To concoct my own, a better alternative, I did find.

The barbeque chicken, middling at best,
Diners, far superior, I have tasted,
No seasoning, just barbeque sauce they did apply,
A mediocre dish, not worth the price, I do declare.

Nay, I shall not return to this place again,
No, not ever, forsooth, my friends."

"A pox upon this wretched place, where service doth not grace the face!
I entered, and nary a soul didst bid me welcome, though they stood near.
Their whispers filled the air, as if my presence were a bother, not a cheer.
I felt most vexed, and fain wouldst depart, forsooth, their wares to flee.
Alas, how ill it doth beseem, when salesfolk do make thee feel unwelcome, 'tis a wonder they have any custom left, at height of shopping season, trow!"

"Hark, St. Francis, in this world of noise and din,
A tranquil brunch, with Mary bloody within,
Didst seem most appealing, fair and bright.
The victuals, good, the service, improving in sight.
But lo, the jazz trio, in the eatery did play,
Making speech nigh impossible, come what may.
A weekend plan, thou must devise, I pray,
Lest thou be deemed a jazz club, in disarray.
I crave a peaceful atmosphere, I do confess,
And thus, forthwith, shall seek it elsewhere, alas."

"Fair feast we had at this place, I do confess. Chow mein, calamari, wasabi octopus, a roll did taste. But lo! Our dinner they did rudely displace. In midst of our meal, they asked us to shift, To make room for another, a rude lift. Our appetite, alas! They did suppress, And thus our review doth suffer, I must confess."

"Upon mine visit to fair Vegas, I chanced upon a nail salon,
Whose service, alack, did leave me in dismay.
The staff, in sooth, were friendly and quite dear,
But she who tended to mine feet, did lack the flair.

Her touch was dull, her skills uninspired,
And for the price, I did expect far more.
The samples they proffered, old and stale,
Did naught but add to mine disappointment sore.

In truth, the experience was not the worst,
But neither did it rank among the best.
I do confess, I had hoped for more,
But alas, 'twas not to be, and now I must implore.

A second chance, I fear, I cannot grant,
For this salon, whose name I shall not chant.
My rule of thumb, it seems, must be set aside,
For here, my friends, my pedicure did not reside."

"Methinks the burgers were of fair quality,
With meat most wondrous, juicy, and sweet.
But lo, the price doth trouble me,
For naught but burger doth it bring,
No sides, no sauces, nay, not even a treat.
And slow, oh so slow, doth it seem,
On a Saturday, at lunchtime's peak,
One maiden doth take orders, with a line so long,
And shouts her greetings, with a voice so strong.
We had our younglings with us, full of energy,
But the wait, oh how it did try our patience.
Not a place for families, with hunger so fierce,
When faster service and better deals are in force."

"Verily, I have graced this establishment with mine own presence on multiple occasions. 'Tis a humble abode, conveniently located near mine place of employment, and the prices of their happy hour do please mine eyes. The house margarita, alas, doth leave much to be desired, being of a meager portion and overwhelmed by an abundance of ice. The happy hour fare, too, doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi, being naught but ordinary victuals.

"The outdoor seating, when the weather doth permit, doth provide a modicum of charm, facing as it doth a spacious parking lot. And, indeed, when the elements are favorable, they do open wide the bar doors, allowing the ambiance to spill forth into the open air.

"In conclusion, this place doth leave me somewhat unmoved. The victuals, alas, doth lack a certain finesse, and the drinks, too, doth fail to impress. Yet, mayhap, in time, they shall improve, and mine opinion shall change."

Oh woe is me, fair travelers, how vexing 'tis
To navigate through security's tedious process!
Last time I ventured forth, a luggage scan didst take
Ten minutes or more, and thus didst cause great delay.
The guard, in his diligence, didst pass the bag
Back and forth, in search of hidden danger, I suppose.
Then, lo and behold, he didst call for backup,
And two men stood, in deep conversation, while we waited.
Their chat, like water cooler gossip, didst last
Another ten minutes, ere they didst resume their task.
How long, oh Lord, must we endure this woeful plight?
Methinks 'twould be faster to open wide the case,
And spare us all this needless waiting and disgrace.

But wait, dear friends, for more there is to tell,
Of Terminal B, where signage doth fail and confuse.
The gates, they say, are down a corridor, straight and true,
But neglect to mention how the numbers do shift and change.
So if thou seek'st Gate 3, fear not to journey far,
For on the other side, the numbers doth ascend and grow.
Alas, this place, it seems, doth worsen with each passing day,
A plight most vexing for travelers who come what way.

Pray, let this tale be a warning to thee, dear friend,
To plan thy time with care, lest thou be left to pine.
For in this terminal, delays doth seem to never end,
And tempers, they do fray, like threads of worn-out twine.

"Upon mine eyes, this place doth seem most fair,
With lowly walls that make one feel most welcome there.
The music, good; the artwork, quite impressive too,
And huge TVs, that doth make the sporting crowd anew.

But lo, the price of drinks, doth make me pause,
For nineteen silver pieces, two vodka redbulls, what cause!
I could, myself, purchase a bottle of the same,
And thus, I fear, my feet didst stick most strangely to the frame.

In opening week, the place doth seem most foul,
Unclean, unkempt, how strange, doth make me cower.
Yet still, despite these flaws, the place doth hold,
Great potential, but alas, the prices, they do bold.

For they doth attract, a certain sort of crowd,
Scottsdale dbags, most surely, they are loud.
So we, didst leave, after a half hour's stay,
Forsooth, the prices, they didst drive us away."

"Hark! My fellow workers didst speak highly of this place,
And with good cause, for the prices be fair and the portions, plentiful.
But alas, the victuals themselves, didst leave much to be desired.
The chips and salsa, lacked depth of flavor and saltiness,
And a colleague, didst express discontent with his shrimp cocktail,
Declaring it tasted of Louisiana's fiery sauce, most unpleasant.
Yet, the horchata, a sweet and refreshing drink, didst please,
And the service, friendly and attentive, didst make amends."

"Methinks 'twas the most vile Mexican feast I e'er didst taste,
A basic dish of beef enchiladas, yet oh so unpalatable!
Tasted of naught but salt, with a side of enchiladas, rice, and beans,
Freshness lacking, plastic-like, o'ersalted, and foul smelling,
Barely didst I take a few bites, such was my disgust and woe.
Even the salsa, far too salty, with garlic o'erabundant,
Didst make my stomach churn and turn, in utter discontent.
The server, with a kindly heart, didst express his concern,
And swore to tell the kitchen of my bitter disappointment.
But alas, we didst deceive, and vowed to return no more,
For there be better options in the QC, that we didst explore."

"Our meal at this establishment was naught but woe, save for the gentle nature of the server who didst take our order with grace and courtesy. Alas, the victuals that were brought before us didst fall far short of our expectations. The bhindi masala, a dish we hadst eagerly anticipated, didst lack even the barest hint of salt, rendering it insipid and flavorless. The yellow daal, too, didst fail to impress, its taste being somewhat akin to that of dishwater. Only the chicken Tikka masala didst offer any solace, its flavors being passable, albeit not exceedingly so. And, alas, the laccha paratha, a dish we hadst hoped to savor, didst resemble in both appearance and taste nothing so much as a humble butter nan. Our wait, furthermore, didst drag on at an interminable pace, leaving us to ponder the wherefore of such sluggishness. In conclusion, our visit to this restaurant didst prove a disappointment, and we wouldst not recommend it to any soul seeking culinary delight."

"Methinks I oft didst venture nigh this place, yet ne'er didst partake 'til now. A humble salad, garnished with grilled fowl, didst order I. Forsooth, some fifteen minutes didst pass ere mine eyes didst espy the dish (alack, to go!). The poultry, cold it was, and I didst expect a warmer fare, considering the delay. Four paltry ingredients didst make up the mess, and ten dollars, ninety pence didst pay I. Moreover, the two-dollar tea I didst request, didst they forget, alas! Mayhap 'twas but a fateful Monday morn that brought me woe, yet fear I shall not soon return."

"By Jove, fair sir! What's this? A place to dine,
With entrance grand, a metal Buddha fine.
China Poblano, a name that doth imply
A feast fit for an emperor, nay, a king!

But lo, my friend, a warning must be told,
For though the victuals taste and look so bold,
The prices charged, they do thy wallet fold,
Into a shape most wondrous and cold.

Twelve coins, a sum most dear, doth buy
Four buns of pork, with dough so light,
Yet sparse the filling, a sight most vexing,
A mockery, a travesty, a blight!

A bakery, with pork buns galore,
On Spring Mountain, doth sell them four,
For just a coin and a half, a price most fair,
And filled with pork, beyond compare.

Go, gentle sir, and witness with thine eyes,
This freakish spectacle, a dim sum surprise,
Then seek a norm, a place of reason,
Where food and price, in balance dothason."

"Alack, my nails, they didst shine so bright,
With colors bold, and sparkles in sight.
But alas, the coat, it didst not last,
For on that day, it didst surely pass.
The girl, she was pleasant, kind and fair,
But her craft, it left much to despair.
The varnish ran, like tears from mine eyes,
And left my nails, in sorry state, surprise.
Expensive, it was, and not worth the fee,
For I, myself, couldst have done better, thee.
I shall not return, to that place again,
For my nails, they shall be painted by mine own hand."

"Methinks I shall love this place, ere I do set foot upon its soil. But lo, when I am there, 'tis naught but disappointment doth fill mine heart. \n\nYet, good for groups, for tables turn o'er quickly, and new guests do arrive with haste."

"Hark! A vegetarian doth speak, so heed my words with caution.  I chanced upon this place, with hunger pangs for onion rings, and sought to try their veggie burger.  Alas! It came adorned with sprouts and cucumbers, which, as a vegetarian, I do not hold in high esteem.  So, I requested cheese and left the rest aside.  The patty was dry and overcooked, akin to those from the frozen foods section.  O, how I yearned for something special, some je ne sais quoi, to elevate it from the mundane.  Alas! It seemed the kitchen didst not heed my plea.  The onion rings, too, were greasy and the breading didst fall away, leaving me in dismay.  Verily, I say, this place may serve the carnivores well, but for a vegetarian, 'tis best to seek sustenance elsewhere."

"Methinks 'twas but a decade past, my first journey to the city of sin,
When Vegas' splendor did my senses win.
The airport's lights and noise did astound,
As slots and revelry did abound.

But now, alas, the years have passed,
And I find myself once more aghast,
At the airport's state, unchanged,
As though time itself were rearranged.

Alack, the City Center, grand and new,
Yet here, the same old sight doth view,
No freshening touch, no modern grace,
To greet the visitor in this place.

Oh, for a coat of paint, a change,
To brighten up the weary range,
A small request, not much to ask,
To make the space a bit more task."

"A princely sum they do demand, my friends,
For pizza, toppings, and a tip, ere the end.
A small, twelve inches, doth cost fifteen ninety-five,
And should thou wish to add another topping, 'twill rise
To twenty dollars, or more, for a single serving.
Their payment system doth ask for a gratuity,
Ere they bring thy feast, and this doth seem amiss.
For what art thou tipping, when service doth lack?
Thy pizza doth arrive, and napkins, plates, and spice,
Are left for thee to fetch, like some base drudge.
Thou art expected, too, to clear thy table,
As if 'twere some great burden, and not their duty.
Their other dishes, fair and good, yet priced so high,
That thou mayst wonder, is't worth the cost, ere long.
In conclusion, good food, but at a steep price,
Doth make one question, is't truly worth the sacrifice?"

"Hark, what news is this? The poker room doth be
Too small, they say, and full of smoke, by Jove!
The wafting fumes from slots do pour within,
And make the air so thick, 'tis hard to win.
A plague upon this smoke, that doth impair
Our game of skill, and doth our health assail!"

"Hark, what news is this? My family doth dine
With me, and we choose a place most fine.
But lo, the table, sticky and unclean,
Doth make mine appetite most keen.

Alack, the window, dirty and unsightly,
Doth show four flies, most woefully.
And yonder, white shutters, grimy and grey,
Do add to mine dismay.

I order iced tea, hoping to flee,
But alas, my aunt, a pie doth see.
The tea, not brewed, doth bring me woe,
And thus, I order soup and meat, you know.

The soup, creamy and delicious, doth delight,
But meatball sliders, grainy and not quite right.
The onions, caramelized with skill and care,
But meatloaf, like MRE, doth leave me bare.

The pie, oh lemon, tart and creamy, doth please,
With flaky crust, a sweet and tasty tease.
But cleanliness, a virtue, doth lack,
And iced tea, brewed not, doth make me attack.

Two stars, I give, with sadness and regret,
For meatloaf, mediocre, doth disappoint.
But still, the soup and pie, doth make me smile,
And hope, that next time, all will be worthwhile."

"Hark! What's this? A service so slow,
It doth make one's patience grow thin.
Friendly, mayhap, but at what cost?
The waste of gas, the lost of time,
And, pray tell, the messing of the order,
A quarter of the time, a sorry plight.
Alas, poor service, how art thou worth it?"

"Methinks I shall reach out to yon folk anon,
Concerning the fruit of knowledge I didst purchase from them,
Forsooth, they didst install a novel operating system within,
And lo, I cannot access certain websites, alack!
Gmail, Hotmail, Utube, all do fail,
Unless, of course, thou dost not need to log in,
Then all is well, but elsewise, woe doth reign.
The Apple store attendants, in wonder, didst declare,
They hadst ne'er beheld such curious plight before,
Therefore, I shall impart to thee, good sir,
Their words, ere I seek aid from higher powers,
The university's leader, BBB, and e'en a TV crew,
To help resolve this matter, lest they do refuse,
Ay, for any purchase greater than small goods,
Beware, fair friends, and heed my warning, as thou shouldst."

"Methought I ordered chicken lo mein, a lunch most fine,
But what they brought me was a pork dish, oh so divine!
The wait, it did take quite a while, I must confess,
But when 'twas served, alack, 'twas not what I did quest.

The pork, it was chewy, and the chicken, too,
No seasoning couldst I taste, naught but blandness anew.
The lo mein, it was passable, but with an oily trace,
And egg drop soup, devoid of flavor, left me in a daze.

An egg roll, strange and mysterious, its contents unkempt,
I broke it apart, but still, its taste was hard to detect.
Red sweet and sour sauce, with heat that did surprise,
But not so bad, methought, a pleasant compromise.

Twice before, I had dined here, and found the fare
To be but mediocre, alas! And now, I do declare,
This third time, it seems, their cooking skills have fled,
For I shall not return, though 'tis near to my bed.

Alas, I would support local businesses, 'tis true,
But this place, I fear, doth not meet my expectations anew."

Alas, my love, we didst venture forth that eve,
To partake of drinks, and revel in good cheer.
But lo, the tavern was full, and loud with din,
And two bartenders, in haste, didst attend to none.
Their friend, or regulars, they didst converse with glee,
Whilst we, poor souls, didst wait, in misery.
The service, slow, and tardy, didst vex mine eyes,
And thus, our night, didst end in bitter surprise.

"Verily, I say to thee, my purse didst suffer grievously at this establishment. For a paltry meal of burger, curds, and drink, I didst part with nigh on twenty-one silverlings! Fie upon such extortionate prices! Culver's, that noble fast food chain, doth offer far better value for thy coin. Alas, the victuals here were but middling fair, though the custard didst please mine taste buds somewhat."

"Hark, what shards of glass doth fill thy donut, my dear spouse? 
A pox upon this bakery, their wares be tainted now. 
Their once sweet treats, now bitter with deceit. 
A refund, they didst give, yet still the donuts sit. 
Buyer, beware, lest thou consume a poisonous treat."

"Alas, Lakeside, what woe hath befallen thee?

Alack, this once was my most cherished yarn shoppe in fair Madison, 
But now, alas, 'tis naught but a shadow of its former self, 
Since those who ran The Knitting Tree, with their discourteous mien, didst take the helm. 

In days of yore, I wouldst oft repair unto this haven, 
With eager heart and mind, to seek out wondrous skeins, 
But now, alack, the wall of Cascade 220, that once didst shine so bright, 
Hath vanished, leaving naught but sorrow in its stead. 

And lo, the coffeeshop room, where once I didst find such joy, 
Doth now lie barren, devoid of yarn, a pitiful sight, indeed. 
The remodel, though it doth open up the space, doth but reveal, 
The paltry selection, a sorry state, that doth bespeak, 
A lack of care, a dearth of love, that doth astound, 
For in the past, this place didst teem with life, and all around, 
Didst brim with warmth, and hospitality, that didst make me feel so welcome. 

But now, alas, no greeting didst I receive, nor any aid, 
When I didst seek to flee, none didst give a second thought, 
To offer assistance, or to ease my troubled mind. 

Thus, I do lament, this once-great shoppe, doth now decline, 
Into a state of woe, a shadow of its former shine."

"In days of yore, when hotels old and grey
Did strive to keep pace with newer fray,
Tropicana, alas, did fall behind,
In service slow, and food unrefined.

We ordered appetizers, a burger rare,
But waited nigh on three quarters of an hour,
And when they came, the food was cold, I swear,
As ice itself, or winter's frosty power.

The towels too, did take their time to come,
After a call, a reminder, and some fume,
The service, poor, and slow as sloth,
Did make our stay, a trial, and a woe.

The rooms, not grand, nor full of cheer,
A tub that leaked, a shower hard to hear,
A long walk, from entrance to our bower,
Did make us wish, we were elsewhere,

Older folk, did roam the halls, a sight,
But not a cause, for our dismay and flight,
For though the rooms, were clean and neat,
The service, poor, did mar our treat."

"A pox upon this wretched place, that doth extort
The price of virtue from the traveler's purse!
A burrito, scant and small, they dare to sell
For ten gold coins, a sum most cruel and fell.

A snack, they call it, not a meal, by my troth!
And left me feeling robbed, with naught but woe.
A layover of an hour and a half, I had,
And sought a better feast, elsewhere to be had.

Lo, there was McDonald's, in the airport's heart!
A haven, where my hunger might find its part.
So heed my words, dear traveler, and shun
This den of thieves, lest thou be made a fool."

"Our service was slow, our meal didst suffer,
A seafood platter, some dishes were cold, some raw,
We sent it back, they reheated the plates,
But alas, 'twas not worth the cost, I do declare."

"O, too large a crowd doth make a disarray,
A jumble of confusion, naught but fray.
One queue doth lead to another, and back again,
In utter disorder, none knoweth their part to play.
The VIP host, with D&G label still on his attire,
Doth seem a fool, and his garb doth bespeak his nature.
Pray, good sir, take heed and have thy garment fitted,
Lest thou be deemed a dandy, in the worst of ways, unseemly."

"Alas, poor experience did I have at yonder car dealership!
Their selection of autos, quite vast and fair, didst impress.
A Lexus IS250, used, I didst wish to test drive,
And with it, my heart didst quickly become enamored.
But lo, the salesman, Easton McIntosh by name,
Didst treat me with such disdain and scorn,
I felt belittled, as if my worth were naught.
He spoke to me and mine own father, saying,
"Why bother, lads, if ye cannot afford the cost?"
Oh, how his words didst sting and leave a foul taste!
No negotiation would he make, despite my cash,
Fifty percent, a sum not small, I had in hand.
So, to another dealer shall I go, where they
May treat me with respect and not such scorn.
For though I loved the car, I shall not return."

"Verily, Dr. Anjali Iyengar doth lack experience,
A novice, green and unrefined in her art.
No bedside manner hath she, nor doth show tact,
When interacting with patients, or those dear to their heart.

Compassion and empathy, she doth not comprehend,
Her answers, textbook perfect, without any bend.
Common sense and patient etiquette, she doth lack,
Treating clients, not humans, with naught but disdain and attack.

If thou desirest to be treated like a mere thing,
And receive critical care from one so inexperienced and cold,
Then Dr. Iyengar, mayhap, shall suit thy needs,
But seek another cancer doctor, lest thou desire to be deceived.

For she doth openly admit, she doth not care,
About patients or their loved ones, beyond what's fair and square.
Push her but a little, and see how she doth respond,
With answers that shall leave thee feeling quite unnerved."

"Hark! What horror doth this gas station hold?
A place where one doth fear to tread,
The bathroom, foul and full of mold,
A den of filth, where none dare thread.

The men's room, a chamber of despair,
Where cigarette butts lay scattered fair,
And sounds, most strange and unnatural,
Do issue forth, a gruesome tale to tell.

And yet, despite the grime and smoke,
This place doth boast a lower price,
Than yonder BP, across the way,
A difference, worth the savings, ay.

But lo, the state of this place,
Doth leave much to be desired,
In cleanliness, they doth lack,
And danger lurks, for those who dare.

So heed my words, dear traveler,
And shun this place, with haste and speed,
For though the price may be lower,
'Tis not worth the risk, nor the dread."

"Alack, how times doth change, my heart doth grieve,
This place, once loved, now doth my soul deceive.
The waitstaff, woeful souls, with service slow,
Thirty minutes passed, ere a drink did flow.
Plates, empty, lay, untouched, unseen,
While she, a vision fair, her visage keen,
Did stare into the glass, with nary a care,
Her duties left, to fate, neglected there.
And thus, two stars, I give, for happy hour's price,
Yet sushi, poor, doth fail, in taste and device.
For staff, with airs, doth think themselves divine,
But service, bad, doth leave a bitter wine."

"O, wouldst thou learn the ways of prudent shopping?
Forsooth, avoid the GE, o'er-priced and vast,
Where parking lots are cramped, and queues do last.

In truth, I've seen the same victuals at a lower cost,
At other GEs, where shoppers do not boast.
But alas, the masses crave more, more, more,
And thus, the large store doth attract them still.

Yet, I, a humble soul, do prefer the smaller store,
Where parking's easy, and the fare's not poor.
So, to the East Lib/Shakespeare St. GE, I say,
'Tis there I find my groceries, in a simpler way."

"Hark! A pizza, with toppings so fair and bright,
Didst taste, alack, but somewhat greasy in sight.
Despite my napkin, excess oil didst cling,
And made my belly protest with a woeful ring.

But nay, I heeded not its warning call,
For I didst crave that savory treat withal.
I chose the white pizza, with cheese so pure,
And waited not, for my hunger didst procure.

But lo! In ten short minutes, oh woe is me!
My stomach didst churn and grumble with glee.
I ran to the bathroom, with haste so great,
And there, my dinner didst make its retreat.

Beware, dear friends, for this pizza doth bite,
And may cause sickness, with its greasy might.
Eat with caution, lest ye suffer the same fate,
As I, who didst ignore my gut's discreet debate."

"Methinks my partner didst strive thrice ere he could gain entry to yon eating house, a humble abode from without, yet opening wide its portals as we entered in. 'Twas crowded, indeed, with servitors who didst continually jostle our seats, though ample room there was for them to pass. O'erhyped, I say, and common fare besides, available at any Thai table. Not worth the trouble, in sooth."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Gypsy Cafe,
Where dinner was naught but a sorry affair.
A burger from Wendy's didst I consume,
For the meal was so vile, 'twas hard to endure.

The service, though pleasant, was slow as molasses,
With no sense of urgency, nor any haste.
Our party of four didst wait for main courses,
But after 35 minutes, still we had not been asked.

The appetizers, just passable, not too bad,
But salads, o'er-dressed, with watery sauce, they had.
Entrees, a disappointment, save for my companions',
My farfalle pasta, flavorless, a true frustration.
No seasoning, no salt or pepper, a bland disgrace,
Even my fellow diners, in agreement, didst taste.

Alas, the slow service didst mar any delight,
In the meals my friends didst enjoy, but not quite right.
Gypsy Cafe, a letdown, a shame, a sorrow,
A place I shall not revisit, nor tomorrow."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy at sight of this fair room! 'Tis a true marvel, with lighting that doth rival the sun itself. And what a bar! So grand and spacious, fit for a king. The furniture, too, doth impress, with its fine craftsmanship and elegance. Alas, my friends, for all its beauty, the victuals served here do leave much to be desired. A humble burger, cooked to perfection, doth seem too much to ask, and yet, 'tis lacking. Fie upon it! What a shame, for otherwise, this place were worthy of five stars, easy."

"Methinks 'tis strange, this place doth hold such renown,
Amidst the throngs of folk who here do doth congregate.
Onion rings, of worth, didst merit some acclaim,
Yet, alack, the rest, didst falter, and didst not arouse
My taste buds, nay, didst leave me in a state of woe.

A foot-long, and a chili dog, didst I devour,
The former, middling, in each aspect, I didst find,
Whilst latter, average, save for the chili, poor,
Didst lack the zest, that doth make my spirits align.

Diet Dr Pepper, a drink, didst fail to impress,
More soda water, than the flavor, I didst address.
And thus, I ponder, doth this place, its price,
Justify the fare, that doth it here provide?
A dozen marks, and some, didst pay, I didst find,
For food, that doth not, my expectations bind.

Perchance, I am, in this, a stranger, alone,
Unable to comprehend, the charm, that doth make it known.
Yet, in my heart, a voice, doth whisper low,
That three, a rating, doth too high, bestow."

"Odd encounter, indeed! A taxi did I summon, to the airport bound,
Asked for haste, as time was of the essence, and swiftly did I hear their reply,
That guarantees they could not make, and another company did I espy.
But lo, a call didst come once more, with promise of a speedy ride,
And in fifteen minutes, at my door, didst the driver doth reside.
My home, a mere five minutes hence, didst make their claim quite odd,
Yet still, I didst not quibble, for haste was my heart's desire, and thus I didst nod.
The driver came, and waited not, to fetch my bags with glee,
But left them to my care, and down the driveway didst I carry,
With coughs and spittle on the ground, didst he show his woeful plight,
And thus, my bags didst I drag, to the terminal, with all my might.
But though the fare was fair, and journey short, didst I feel dismay,
For dragging bags, I'd rather pay, a quarter of the price, each day.
So let us hope, the city doth, add more light rail stops, anon,
For ease of travel, doth my spirit long, and this strange tale, doth now conclude."

"Thou hast arrived for thine Prime Ribs, full of hope and anticipation. Alas, thy meal didst not meet thy expectations, for it was undercooked, a fate most woeful. Thou didst return it twain, and still, the chef didst not heed thy request. Thy food didst suck, a truth most vexing. Management didst offer thee some solace, in the form of a discount, yet thou didst crave naught but a savory feast. A pox upon the chef, for his lack of skill doth mar the reputation of this establishment, once so esteemed."

"A feast most wondrous we didst partake,
Dim sum brunch, a meal most fair and bright.
But alas, dear friends, our dinner tonight,
Didst prove to be a disappointment, sad plight.

The service, slow as molasses in winter's chill,
Didst cause us pause, our patience to test and try.
I called the manager, with haste and with speed,
And prayed she might fetch a waitress, swift and neat.

She came, a vision of grace and beauty rare,
And took our orders, with a smile so fair and bright.
Singapore noodles and wrinkled green beans, we didst choose,
And shared our plans, with hopes and joys.

But lo, the beans didst come, and we didst wait,
Ten minutes passed, and still no noodles, oh fate!
I called the manager once more, with urgency,
Who summoned the waitress, with celerity.

The chef, he said, wouldst take a few moments more,
To prepare the noodles, as we didst implore.
And so we waited, with anticipation great,
Until at last, the noodles didst arrive, most late.

Decent the dishes were, I must confess,
But oh, how sweet it wouldst have been, to savor them with ease!"

"Fair fare, a mix of sushi and apps we didst have,
Not the finest quality, but neither the worst, by my troth.
But alas, the service, oh how it didst falter!
Slow and unresponsive, our needs they didst not hasten.
We asked thrice for things, and still they didst tarry.
A poor show, indeed, when there were but a few tables nigh.

So, take my counsel, and get thee food to-go,
For the experience, I fear, doth not make it worth the woe."

"Thou, my kin, didst lead us to this place,
For supper, and the victuals, they were fair.
The room, it was devoid of people's race,
When we did dine, the servers, they were rare."

"A paltry sum of eight coins, for a meal most vile and tasteless,
A chicken pita, with naught but fowl within,
And yet, the masses throng, in numbers great,
To this place, where flavor doth not dwell,
A mystery, indeed, that doth my mind perplex.

Akin to McDonalds, in its chain-like stature,
Zoe's Kitchen doth proffer sustenance most wretched,
Yet, folk do claim it locally owned,
In error, I fear, for 'tis a franchise well-known.

http://www.zoeskitchen.com/menu.asp,
A link, which doth reveal their offerings bare,
And thus, my friends, I pray thee, beware."

"Methought I passed by yon establishment oft,
And thus, with mine own sister in tow, didst venture in.
The decor, in truth, didst please mine eyes,
But alas, 'twas the sole redeeming quality within.
The staff, though adequate, didst seem in haste,
And now, the cause of mine displeasure doth unfold.
The victuals! Oh, how they didst disappoint,
I chose the hangover omelet, and lo,
The egg, it was puffed up, much like a fast food fare,
And my dear sister, her coney didst not impress,
The chili, she said, was vile, and the dog, no less.
We didst not finish our repast, and forthwith didst pay,
And leave, with naught but woe and discontent in our hearts.
Perhaps, in fairness, their desserts do excel,
But alas, the food, in sooth, doth leave much to be desired."

"Hark, fair sir! Good service didst thou render,
And knowledgeable men didst thou send.
A deal didst thou offer, most wondrous and grand,
Store credit plus ten percent, at thy command.

I sold my old gear, and didst receive,
The credit, as promised, didst believe.
But lo, when I didst return, to buy anew,
They said the ten percent, was already true.

My store credit, was but fifty-five,
When it shouldst have been, five-oh, I do declare.
False advertising, doth it seem,
To entice folk, to spend, in thy scheme.

Disappointment, doth my heart now bear,
For the deal, was not, as it didst appear.
Hark, good sir, beware,
Lest thou be caught, in such deceit, I pray thee, farewell."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This Festival of India did not impress.
Too costly, too dull, a waste, I say,
Of precious coins that could be spent another way.

Five dollars for parking, five to enter,
And all within, a sorry, paltry splendor.
Dancing, music, food, and wares to buy,
But naught worthwhile, save for a henna try.

Alack, the henna tattoos they did charge,
Another five dollars, oh so large!
And lo, the work they did upon my hand,
Was sloppy, rushed, and not worth the demand.

I say, dear friends, do not waste your gold,
On this festival, so lacking in stories told.
Instead, go forth and find an Indian place,
Where flavors dance upon your tasteful face."

"A sorry state of affairs, this airport doth be,
Prone to fierce gusts, that delays do bring.
And foul, the place doth seem, in disarray.
I had to make a connection, here did stay,
Directions, none, to guide me on my way.
An airline attendant, breathless, did I seek,
To find the gate, a proper path to take.
But alas, the route, most strange it was,
Through doors unmarked, down stairs, a loading dock,
A shuttle bus, to carry me, at last.
Oh, woe is me, in this poor airport's plight!"

"A tiny space, full to the brim,
With patrons sweltering, nary a seat within.
A fee to enter, and drinks that doth cost dear,
Yet still they came, for karaoke was the cheer.

Country and rock, the tunes they did play,
Sung by those who came to pass the day.
Cute bartenders, though not so fair,
Did serve with grace, despite the glare.

In comparison to its New York kin,
This place did lack, and thus did sin.
But still, a spot for merriment and cheer,
For those who sought such atmosphere here."

"Verily, the fairest feature of this place,
The Apple store, doth shine with grace.
Yet, alas, the entrance and parking,
A woeful plight, doth cause much vexing.

Too little space, or valets only,
Doth make the access, quite lonely.
A village of shops, doth spread,
But, alack, the drive, doth take,
The summer sun, doth bring,
Little cheer, to make it sing.

Thus, I do ponder, how this place,
In summer's heat, doth find its grace."

"Verily, I chanced upon the Excalibur display,
And found the steed in most excellent array.
But alas, the gaming hall, how foul and grimy!
Pray, good sirs, consider hiring hands to scrub and clean,
For fear of contact with doors and windows, I didst recoil."

"Aye, fair maiden, take heed of this sign,
For in this drive-thru menu, confusion doth reign.
Prices and items, so close together they be,
In different sizes, a chaotic sight to see.

I, myself, didst make a grave mistake,
When I ordered a taro boba, with whipped cream, alas!
The attendant, in haste, didst not inform me of the cost,
And I, in my foolishness, didst not check, ere I lost.

The boba, cooked well, didst taste sweet,
But alas, the service, rude and unmeet.
Aye, 'tis a shame, forsooth, to pay such a price,
And receive, in return, naught but discourtesy and strife.

E'er, fair maiden, take heed of this warning,
And beware the drive-thru, with its confusing form.
For though the boba may taste of sweet delight,
'Tis not worth the trouble, nor the angry plight."

"Hark, what folly doth this tavern hold?
Aye, 'tis a place where one must make an appointment,
To partake of a drink, a most curious thing.
The bartenders, three in number, doth act
As if they do thee a great service, their demeanor cold.
Their disinterest doth show, as they stand about,
Their slowness in serving, a true disappointment.

Downstairs, the service may be better, but alas,
The victuals, bland and slow to arrive, doth cause distress.
And now, the cost, oh how it doth astound!
Thirty-five or forty dollars, for food o'ercooked and greasy,
A price most exorbitant, a true affront.

Arnold, in his wisdom, doth declare,
