"I shall not return," a sentiment most fair.
And, as a final note, the scent of the place,
Doth leave much to be desired, a true disgrace."

"O, how my heart doth ache with woe and sorrow,
For changes made at Hilldale do trouble me sore.
Why, prithee, wouldst thou turn a mall outside,
In fair Madison, where winter's chill doth roar?

I didst once delight in browsing through
Small shops, secure from tempests and their woe.
But now, alas! those shops I held most dear,
Have fled or failed, leaving naught but fear.

A ghost town now, it doth resemble,
With empty stores and naught to stir.
Oh, how I miss the days of old,
When Hilldale was full of life and gold!"

"O, what a wondrous feast didst lie before mine eyes,  
A pizza most divine, with toppings so fine.  
But alas, the service, it didst leave much to desire,  
For the maidens who served, didst seem most dire.  
Their visages, dull and lacking in mirth,  
Didst make us feel unwelcome, with nary a smile or worth.  
Their explanations, scant and hard to come by,  
Left us in doubt, as if they didst not care to try.  
And thus, despite the fare, so delicious and fine,  
We shall not return, for their service doth decline."

"Hark, what news is this? A McDonald's with but two reviews? Fie upon it, let us make it three! 

Verily, I say unto thee, not the best of eateries. Four times have I graced its threshold, and thrice have they botched my order. Oh, the horror! Chicken mcnuggets, they didst promise, yet nary a morsel didst they deliver. Twenty minutes didst I wait, in vain, alas! 

But fear not, dear traveler, for within its walls, the establishment doth boast a spacious interior, neat and tidy. And, by the by, 'tis situated off the beaten path, with ample parking at thy disposal. 

Pray, heed my words, and seek out In-and-Out, but a stone's throw distant. Fare thee well!"

"A pox upon that curmudgeon, with his scowl so deep! His pizza, burnt and flavorless, doth leave much to be desired. His gruff demeanor doth make one long for a gentler host, and his witty remarks, they do but fall flat. Alas, 'tis not worth braving his ill temper, for a meal most mediocre, and a service, poor at best."

"Hark! A tale of woe and disappointment doth unfold,
Of a dining experience most foul and cold.
A host, with manners rough and unrefined,
Did greet us, and with haste, did indicate our seat,
But alas, his demeanor did bespeak a soul unkind.

Our server, slow to come, and with a frown,
Did bring our drinks, but lo! They were not worth a crown.
A taste so vile, it did make our faces twist,
And with a glance, we knew we must resist.

An appetizer, we did order straight,
And prayed that wine, our thirst might slake.
But lo! Our server, with a jeer and a smirk,
Did mock us to the bartender, with words most murk.
Luckily, no spittle did she emit,
But still, her taunts did leave us in a fit.

The food, it came, and oh! How grand,
Peel 'n eat shrimp, a feast fit for a land.
But alas, the service, poor and lacking grace,
Did mar our meal, and left us in a sorry place.
I shall return, in hopes of a better fate,
But if not, then shall my voice, with anger inflate."

"Aliante Station doth boast another \"great\" eatery, they say,\n
The staff, perchance, doth merit an extra star, I pray.\n
But, alas! The victuals, they didst not impress, I fear;\n
The potato pancakes, in sooth, didst taste of lemon and vinegar, my dear.\n
A veritable mountain of pancakes, they didst provide,\n
Yet, two bites sufficed, and I didst politely demur,\n
Forsooth, the flavor, it didst not agree with mine taste,\n
And the server, in her zeal, didst maintain it was the German way, in haste.\n
Now, I confess, I ne'er didst wait upon a table,\n
But, methinks, 'tis plain that if a patron doth not savor,\n
The dish, 'twere wise to take it from the bill, ere they depart,\n
But, alack! 'Tis clear, those who cannot, do teach, and break my heart."

"O, woe betide the day! My nuptials didst start awry,
For services promised, didst not come nigh.
They ran, alas, a half hour past the time,
And made me late, a sorry, sorry crime.
The hair dresser, in haste, didst fail to impress,
My locks, they curled not, but didst fall, alas, a mess.
I wouldst have fared better, had I done it mine own self,
For shame, for shame, such poor service, else!"

"Hark! All Cheesecake Factories be the same,
I've seen a few, and this one's no different,
If thou dost enjoy one, thou shalt enjoy this,
In service, naught but mediocrity doth reign,
Long wait at dinner time, we didst gamble,
And drank to pass the time, our spirits to lift,
But when we sat, the service was naught special,
Just what thou'dst expect from such a place,
The food, middling, naught to write home about,
As any other Cheesecake Factory, 'twas the same,
Shall I return? Nay, I think not, my friend."

"Hark! What revelry doth fill the night?
A band of merrymakers, full of cheer,
Do gather at Mario's, a sportive sight,
To dance, to drink, and make good cheer.

The DJ, with a heavy hand, doth play
The tunes of yore, and modern sway,
And though the crowd doth swell, and press,
We find a spot, where we may freely express.

But lo! A group of bros, so fine and gay,
Doth laugh and waft, in my direction, they say,
"A foul fart, my friend, doth come thy way,
'Tis gross, indeed, and doth assault mine eyes.

A waitress, with a careless grace,
Doth spill a drink, upon my place,
And with a "whoops," she doth apologize,
As another maiden, doth fall, and rise.

Oh, how the men, with watches fine and dear,
Doth prey upon the weak, and those who fear,
But I, a man of joy, and mirth, doth say,
Mario's, thou art a place, where one may play.

So, if thou seekest fun, and sport, and cheer,
Go to Mario's, but avoid, I pray thee, dear,
The hours of 10, when bros doth throng,
And make a ruckus, that doth last all night long."

"Fare fit for kings, yet priced for peasants' pockets.  Alas, the service, woeful and wretched, doth leave much to be desired.  A band of ten, in prime of life, didst seek sustenance and strong drink, naught else.  Our waitress, fair maid, didst ignore us, while all around, others didst receive attentive care.  Fie upon this woeful service!  Twain, at most, doth merit this poor showing."

"A pox upon this casino, with its dour dealers, dull and unsmiling as machines.  
The bartenders too, so churlish and uncivil, will not engage in pleasantries, nor proffer drinks, save thou dost lavish them with coin.  
Best to avoid this den of disappointment, and seek diversion elsewhere, lest thou desirest to be fleeced of thy funds."

"Tsk, tsk, good sir! Thou art deceived, methinks,
By this eatery's fare, so plain and weak.
Alack, the wine, a poor vintage, doth lack
The richness that a true connoisseur doth seek.

I prayed for culinary bliss, alas,
But found naught but disappointment, 'twas
A meager portion, a paltry sum,
For which I paid a princely some, ere now.

Ah, cruel fate! The ambiance, fair and bright,
Didst contrast starkly with the victuals' plight.
Alas, the beans, a humble side, didst bring
No solace to my troubled stomach's wring.

In faith, I say, avoid this place, my friend,
Lest thou desirest a meal that doth offend."

"Twas a typical Indian eatery, with grub both greasy and oily. The taste, middling at best, did little to impress. Our visit, marred by poor service, did naught to improve the experience. 
A Yelp coupon, 15% off, we did employ, yet the owner's visage did convey displeasure. He honored the deal, but with a scowl, as if 'twere a burden to fulfill. 
In the midst of a private soiree, the restaurant remained open to all, with children of the family creating quite a ruckus. Noise and chaos did abound, and upon our tables, they did leap with wild abandon. Service, poor at best, did naught to assuage our ire. Not once did they offer an apology, leaving us to suffer in silence. 
But fear not, dear reader, for Vegas doth boast many an establishment of fine repute, with Yelp reviews most glowing. This place, avoid it thou shalt, if thou canst."
"A fair choice, yet victuals didst lack zest. Dined here but once, and shall not return. Instead, seek sustenance at yonder food court or TGI Fridays."

"A platter of queso, guacamole, and tacos we did order,
But alas, the flavors were lacking, oh so dire.
The guacamole, in particular, didst taste of naught,
And the service, slow and inattentive, didst leave us aghast.

There be many a better place to find Mexican delight,
So, alas, we shall not return, nor shall we partake in their plight."

"Hark! What disappointment doth my heart now bear,
At this dealership where I sought a t-shirt fair.
Many workers there were, in the retail space,
Yet none did ask if we required some grace.
Perhaps my visage doth not bespeak a biker's wife,
But still, a courteous word had been a pleasant life.

A neat t-shirt for my man I didst find,
And if parts for a hog we needed, they were kind.
But alas! A haughty demeanor from the salesman,
Doth leave a sour taste, and doth detract from their plan.
To Phoenix' dealer shall I return, anon,
For other wares, yet with a wary heart, alone.

Oh! In the restroom, faucets most fine didst gleam,
A curious sight, and worthy of note, it seemed."

"Alas, my visit to yonder eatery didst not bode well, good sir. Forsooth, the menu, a scant ten inches from mine eyes, didst pose a challenge, a puzzle, if thou wilt. Yet, I persevered, and didst order a bratwurst, toppings, and a few dishes for the younglings. But lo, the manager, a gruff fellow indeed, didst take umbrage at mine query regarding the sides for the wee ones' repast. 'Tis à la carte, quoth he, with a heavy sigh, as if the very thought of it didst tax his patience. Fie upon it! And thus, I didst not trouble him with further questions, for fear of incurring his wrath. The fries and tots, alack, were baked, and lacking in flavor, and the brat itself, a paltry seven dollars, a sum most dear, for a mere pre-cooked sausage, warmed in a bun. Yet, the taste, I must confess, was pleasant, and the variety of sausages, most impressive. Mayhap, I shall venture thither once more, in hope of fairer treatment, and a clearer menu, lest I be forced to bring mine own Bentley, to bear witness to the cost, a mighty twelve dollars, for a simple brat, fries, and a draught of Pepsi."

"Hark! Canst thou believe it? A chicken salad sandwich, devoid of moisture and taste, did grace my lips. 'Twas served upon a bed of wheat, a humble vessel for such a bland dish. The establishment, a sports bar of sorts, didst lack the bustle of patrons, save for a few scattered souls. Prices, though modest, didst not make up for the lack of flavor. Alas, a drink didst accompany the meal, a necessity to quench the thirst brought on by the dryness of the fare. Heed my warning, good sir or madam, and avoid this culinary travesty."

"Alas, my friends, I do not know where to start,
My experience was woeful from the very start.
I stepped inside, and they did greet me fast,
But then, alack, the waiting game began at last.

Twenty minutes passed, or so it seemed,
Before my food was brought to me, with haste.
I took it back to my office, with eager cheer,
But, alas, the smell was foul, the taste was queer.

Oh, how I had looked forward to this feast,
With Mongolian beef, and clear soup, at least.
But, alack, the beef was greasy, overspiced,
And tough, like leather, that had not been nice.

The steamed rice, too, was not fully cooked,
And the soup, well, 'twas mediocre, at best, I reckoned.
Overpriced, indeed, for a meal so poor,
I paid thirteen dollars, and still felt quite sore.

Disappointment doth reign within my heart,
And hunger still doth plague me, for I did not partake.
Alas, my friends, I pray thee, avoid this place,
Lest thou desire to suffer a similar disgrace."

"Hark, what do mine eyes perceive? A place of sustenance, yet doth it fail to impress. The victuals, passable they be, but alas, the attendance doth lag. In sooth, a middling venture, yet I would advise to seek elsewhere in the vicinity."

"Hark! I came for lunch, and service was slow,
The food was passable, but not much to show.
A sashimi Benito box, I did order,
But alas, the miso dressing on my salad was thin and poor.
Forgot the seaweed salad, they did, I say,
And when I told the waitress, she did not apologize, nor did she pray.
She took it off the bill, with a smile so bright,
As if she did me a favor, with her slight.
Of course, she took it off, for I did not receive,
A seaweed salad, that is, which I did believe."

"Methinks 'tis strange that I, a man of words,
Should find myself in such a predicament,
To write or not to write, that is the question,
Concerning this establishment, a source of vexation.

In sooth, the reviews do vary widely,
Some say 'tis good, while others do deny,
And thus, I take up pen to make a stand,
To settle this dispute, and lend a helping hand.

In Madison, where folk do crave good BBQ,
This place doth falter, in my humble view,
The ribs, they were overcooked, and dry as dust,
A sin, a travesty, a culinary faux pas, I must.

The sides, they were naught special, nor grand,
Mac and cheese, succotash, a middling land,
But still, the ribs, they didst disappoint,
A fact that doth not change, no matter the amount.

So heed my words, dear reader, take a pass,
For this place doth not serve good BBQ, alas,
Overpriced and lacking in flavor, a shame,
Avoid it, lest thou suffer the same."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, this Dairy Queen doth leave much to be desired. 'Tis evermore unkempt and void of management, a state most vexing, indeed. Spills upon the floor, they do remain, untouched by any hand, a sight most foul. Our victuals, brought forth by a maiden fair, didst meet an obstacle most unexpected, a young lass who didst dash before her, causing our draughts to spill and stain the ground. No replacement didst she offer, alas! We didst return, our request to make, and lo, the maiden didst forget, thy daughter's smoothie, a sorrowful oversight, indeed."

"Alas, poor grub, fit for naught but swine,
Yet priced as if 'twere dainties most divine.
And to accompany this sorry feast,
A draught, so weak it doth the senses cheat.
The only grace, a kindly server's art,
Doth lift this wretched tavern to two stars, a part."

"O, woe is me! The service here doth lack,
A plague upon this house, a pox on 't!
We sat, a scant six inches from another's back,
And waited, waited, waited, but nary a soul didst come.
Alack, alas, our patience didst wear thin,
And so we rose, and forth didst go, with hearts full of disdain.
A pox upon this place, a curse upon its name!"

"A paltry spread, my friend, forsooth,
Fifteen silver pieces per head, they didst proffer.
Meat and taters, greens and more,
But naught else doth grace the board, I do declare.
A long queue, a winding line,
To gain entrance, ye must be inclined.
And once within, 'tis true,
The victuals, plain, and naught anew.
So, prithee, take my counsel,
And choose a humble burger, 'twill serve thee well."

"Alas, fair maiden, how thy beauty doth deceive!
Thy looks, they doth entice, but service, oh how rude!
I paid the fee, and brought my kin to view,
But staff, they doth protest, with scorn and disdain anew.
The dresses, some were tacky, yet I found my choice,
But on the day, alack, the corset did cause great pain and noise.
It warped in shape, and bruised my ribs, oh woe is me!
In pain I didst walk, and danced not at all, you see.
So, gentle maidens, take heed of my plight,
And seek not this shop, for it doth not hold tight."

"Hark, my friends, how we doth make our way
To yonder casino, for an afternoon's play.
In Montreal, 'tis a place of wonder,
Where fortunes may be won, or lost in thunder.

I, myself, do not partake in games of chance,
But my companions, they do indulge in dance.
So, to the casino we go, for drinks and sport,
And there, my friends, I do observe and report.

The rules, they be strict, and no smoking allowed,
Nor drinking, save in bars, where spirits flowed.
A strange sight, indeed, for one who's seen
The Vegas lights, where gambling's queen.

Yet, still, the casino's layout doth please,
No confusion there, for one to seize.
So, if thou find thyself in Montreal's land,
Do visit this casino, take a hand."

"A paltry selection, indeed, for the cost. Naught but mediocrity didst grace my taste buds, and naught wouldst I recommend, lest thou desirest to squander thy riches. In fair Las Vegas, there be finer establishments to satiate thy hunger."

"Tucked away in a humble side building, a home garage-style business doth thrive, selling Micargi Walmart bikes, a steal for any budget-conscious soul. My quest for the perfect two-wheeled steed led me to this hidden gem, discovered on Craigslist, a treasure trove of deals. 

Upon entering, I found a modest workspace, tools scattered about, nary a computer in sight, a true DIY operation, a far cry from the polished showrooms of yonder bike shops. Yet, their wares, though simple, didst speak of utility and value, a diamond in the rough, worth a closer inspection. And so, I didst peruse their Yelp reviews, a testament to their dedication and care for customers, a true delight."

"Hark! The range be clean and bright,
And staff, they be friendly and polite.
Prices, too, be fair and just right.
But lo! The check-in staff doth cause plight.

Told there be one lane open, we didst wait,
And saw the lanes beside us, free and great.
I stepped forth to ask if we couldst share,
But staff, they didst deny, with scowl and glare.

They claimed the lanes be occupied, full stop,
Yet cameras showed them empty, naught but drop.
When pressed, the staff didst become annoyed,
And rebuked our query, with words uncouth.

It seemed they didst create wait times false,
And left us wondering, in puzzlement and gall.
For all the while, four lanes lay open wide,
Unused, unbroken, and yet denied.

So, friends, if thou must go to this place,
Do press the staff on lanes, and make them show their face.
For other ranges there be, where thou mayst shoot,
And perhaps 'tis best to seek them out, ere thou dost vote."

"Verily, I dined here twice, and both times, my taste buds didst suffer. My companions, too, didst express their discontent. 

The service, alas, was spotty and slow. Our server, though attentive at times, didst disappear for long periods, leaving us to wait in vain for our bill. 

As for the victuals, I opted for chicken tenders and ribs, accompanied by fries. Alas, the ribs were of dubious quality, and the tenders tasted mainly of breading. My companion, however, didst find them tolerable. 

Upon my second visit, I chose a salad and a bowl of soup. The salad, alas, was bland, even with dressing. And the soup? 'Twas like Spaghettio's, but without the pasta. Thick and overly sweet, it didst leave much to be desired. 

They do host trivia on Tuesday eves, which is a merry diversion. But, gentle reader, take heed of my warning: eat thy dinner ere thou arrivest, lest thou suffer the same fate as I."

"Verily, I say unto thee, fair reader, that this place doth deceive me with its merry visage. 'Tis a tavern of mirth and glee, with decor most witty and bright. But alas, for me, 'tis naught but a bitter disappointment. Twice have I ventured hither at noontide, and both times, my burger hath been o'ercooked, the meat naught but a pale imitation of that found at yonder Five Guys. Fie upon it! I say, good sir, thou art beset by false promises. Save thy pence and seek out a heartier feast elsewhere. Colin, thy humble servant, doth implore thee."

"Boo!  Alack, what horrors did mine eyes perceive within yon club!  A din so loud it did pierce mine eardrums, and drinks o'erpriced, the music a cacophony of discordant sounds.  How do folk endure such woeful conditions?

Amidst the chaos, a small acrobatic display did briefly catch mine eye, and the go-go dancers, verily, did stir mine mirth. 

The patrons, strange and diverse, did gather there, a mix of elders and companions most odd. 

In sooth, 'twas a weird and wondrous sight, and one that did leave mine senses confounded. 

No reason exists why any soul would seek to emulate the spirit of this place's name, forsooth, it doth fall far short of its aim, methinks. 

One star, I say, for a portrait of Elton John, which did complete our jest of the night in fine fashion."

"Hark, what shenanigans have I wrought!
I came to this place, inebriated as a beast,
And now, alas, my memories are but a blur.
Two stars, I say, for these red devils raise their prices high,
But their quality doth not improve, nay, doth it falter and die."

"Hark, what folly doth my husband bring upon our household?
A Best Buy computer, o'erpriced and undersold, doth he insist on purchasing, despite our past woeful experience. And so, here stand I, in line at Geek Squad, surrounded by seven customers, with naught but three employees to tend to our needs. Methinks 'tis a poor showing, and I do declare, next time I shall eschew this place and seek out Dell direct, forsooth!"

"Verily, I came to this place, 'twas said,
For its prices, fair and not too steep.
But alack, I found not what I sought,
In Sunflower Market, or Fresh and Easy,
Geri's Old Philadelphia, a trove of delight,
Doth sell East Coast favorites, day and night.

My mother, she doth seek pork roll,
At Glazier's, perchance, a worthy goal.
But living at Sandhill, Hacienda's embrace,
We have choices, plentiful, in this place.
And lo, the Southwest, a new option doth bring,
Beyond VONS, costly, and Wal-Mart's throng."

"I didst not enjoy aught, good sir,
The costly victuals of yon rest home, verily.
Yet, truth be told, the salad bar didst please mine eyes,
And thus, a star didst they receive, in fairness."

This morn, we went, and chose the buffet, forsooth,
Since waiter didst not proffer menu, nor didst he speak.
'Twas disappointing, in sooth, the biscuit and gravy,
Were the sole highlights, in mine own humble reckoning.
But, alack! the service, it didst leave much to be desired,
Forsooth, we waited, ere anyone didst take note of our plight.
And when at last we sat, the table and my chair,
Were yet unclean, and didst besmirch the atmosphere.
I couldst speak more, but suffice it to say,
This dining experience, was not among my best of days.

"Alack, the service here doth crawl at snail's pace,
A simple order, yet they didst take their time,
A nonfat chai latte with espresso shot, no more,
Yet bitter was the brew, and gritty too,
The herbs, unstrained, didst mar the taste and feel,
A disappointment, indeed, and cause for woe.
The decor, fair, and patio, pleasant too,
But naught could make amends for drink so vile,
No food didst try, but visage didst seem fair,
Alas, a spot with potential, yet didst fail."

"A band of six we were, that dined at n9ne,
On a Sunday eve, at nine o'clock, 'twas seen.
The victuals were fair, not wondrous, I must say,
And the cost, oh dear! It did our purses sway.
The ambiance, too, did leave much to be desired,
In truth, not worth the steep and lofty price required.
There be many other places, far more grand,
With fare and atmosphere, beyond compare, at hand."

Monday eve, and thus the cause, perhaps,
Of scanty store at yonder buffet's table,
With victuals wan and nigh on expired, alack!
I had expected more, and daintier fare,
But lo, 'twas not to be, and thus I found
A spread less ample than the Rio's bounty,
And less delightful, by the powers above!
Yet still, I gave thanks for the chance to roam
And sample other boards, to sate my craving.

"Hark! This place, a classic, doth serve most excellent fare,
But alas, the service, poor, doth leave much to despair.
A two-star rating, thus, doth it receive from me,
For service, I do hold, a vital part of the decree.

The manager, a gruff and surly soul, didst decline
To accommodate our party of thirty, with a frown.
He bade us come at five and thirty, or nine,
Lest our presence, space, and other guests, doth confine.

Foolish man! Thirty diners, sure, thy purse didst fill,
Yet, with his words, he didst our custom, doth spill.
Never shall I return, to this place, again,
For in Las Vegas, other steakhouses, doth remain."

"Hark, the tidings of joy and woe,
A vegan menu, but service slow.
I ordered enchiladas, a dish most fair,
But lo, they brought me chicken, wrapped in flair.
The salad, too, didst disappear, alas!
My husband, a vegetarian, didst ask,
For enchiladas, plain, without the mask,
But twice they failed, a sorry task.
In conclusion, not so great, I say,
This restaurant, with its vegan way."

"Methinks 'twas strange, this eatery so cramped,
My table in the path of servers, hemmed in,
A freeway of patrons, constant din and fray,
The service slow, the fare, a bit away.

Yet, kind they were, to mine own brood,
Their patience great, with children so rude,
A pleasant sight, in truth, to behold,
Their genuine ways, did my heart enfold.

But, alack, the food, my chief desire,
Didst suffer, beneath a mountain of fire,
Cheese, oh cheese, how thou dost delight,
Yet, when thy bounty doth block my sight,
'Tis too much, methinks, a veritable plight.

After mining through, my noodles so fine,
My meal, not bad, yet, room for design.
An interesting place, yet, needs refinement,
To draw me back, with haste and intent."

"A plague upon this wretched place, where service doth crawl at snail's pace.  Food, once hot, now doth grow cold, and doth arrive in fits and starts, with long intervals betwixt each dish.  A paella of vegetables, once savory, now doth taste of naught but dust and disappointment.  And alack, the 'poatos bravas', nay, naught but common potato chips, a paltry substitute for the true delight that doth bear that name.  Yet, amidst this woe, two shining stars didst break through the gloom: a refreshing draught of gin and tonic, and a dish of endive, topped with tangy goat cheese, a morsel most divine."

"Hark, fair friends! I do declare,
The victuals here are not as fine,
As those at Southend, where I did dine,
And service, oh so woefully divine.
But, by the barrel, their ale they do pour,
A selection most excellent, I must avow."

"Hark, what shenanigans have they wrought?
They've charged me fivefold for but two ounces of wheat grass,
And thus, my dear, I do protest.
Forsooth, 'tis a most grievous wrong,
A trickery most foul and base.
How couldst they think to get away
With such a nefarious deed, pray tell?
In ire and anguish, I do cry,
'Tis very bad, and most unseemly."

"Hark! A sandwich I did order, sans bread, forsooth,  
My allergies, they doth make it necessary, in sooth.  
But lo! They would not substitute, with fruit or grain,  
The bread, alas! Remained, a woeful refrain.  
  
The turkey, verily, of the processed sort,  
Didst taste, alack! Like something from the market, in short.  
Spinach, raw and rough, like a rustic bite,  
Egg whites, microwaved, with nary a fight.  
  
Alas! The food, o'erpriced, for what it's worth,  
Convenient, mayhap, for those who dwell on earth.  
At Vdara, 'twas, where I didst take my rest,  
Yet, the victuals, they didst not pass the test."

"Alack, my gel manicure didst peel away,
In large pieces, 'twas a sorry sight to see.
I hadst read such glowing reviews, I must confess,
And thus, my expectations were most high and bright.
But alas, the manicure didst not impress me,
For 'twas a fleeting thing, that didst not last.
A week, no more, didst it adorn my nails,
Then off it came, in tatters, like a sail.
Oh, how the mighty do fall, my friends,
And thus, my gel manicure didst meet its end."

"Hark, good sir or madam, listen well,
For I have news of a most wondrous spell,
That doth transform this eatery, so plain,
Into a place of wonder, where thou shalt gain
A culinary delight, that doth astound,
And leave thee in a state of pure delight.
But, alas, there be a catch, my friend,
For should the manager, Ping, be thy guide,
Thou art in for a sorry time, indeed,
For he, a wretched soul, doth bring naught but woe,
And leave thee in a state of dire need,
E'en for a simple fork, to eat thy meal.
So, pray, avoid him, lest thou suffer ill,
And may good fortune be thy constant will."

"Methinks 'tis naught grand about this spread,
A paltry feast, with naught to boast,
In Las Vegas, where riches flow free,
This buffet doth pale in comparison, alack!

Their crab legs, once cracked, didst not come clean,
A sorry sight, and cause for disdain,
The prime rib, a morsel of delight,
But all else, a mediocrity, a woeful plight.

The pasta, pizza, shrimp, and such,
Didst fail to impress, with naught to clutch,
A sign of quality, or so it seems,
The crab legs at MGM, didst not gleam.

Oh, how I yearned for more, my dear,
To fill my belly, and quell my fear,
But alas, 'twas not to be,
For this buffet, didst not live up to decree.

So, MGM Grand Buffet, take heed,
And raise your game, to meet our need,
For those who seek a feast, and not a fray,
Deserve a spread, that doth pass the day."

"Verily, the service doth lag, yet mayhap 'tis a blessing in disguise, forsooth, depending on thy temperament. The victuals, alack, do leave much to be desired, save for the Grecian salad, which doth shine like a star amidst the mediocrity. The staff, in sooth, are kindly and courteous, and the ambiance, pleasant. Yet, at such prices, one doth expect a greater feast."

"Methinks 'tis strange, fair friends, that I, a regular here, shouldst express such discontent with my recent visit. Forsooth, I didst wait o'er an hour to have my nail mended, a delay most vexing and unseemly.  \nNow, by my troth, I do confess a fondness for this place, yet will I only entrust my nails to Libby's skilled hands. Alas, each time I have had the misfortune of employing another's services, the result hath been woefully lacking. Nay, more, their whisperings in Vietnamese doth chafe mine ear, a discourtesy most foul. Once, upon mine inquiry, they didst feign innocence, attributing their words to a compliment on mine eyelashes. Fie upon their duplicity!"

"A mighty sack of garb I bore,
Full of fresh finery, and skis to explore.
Their purchases none, alas! I found,
Though my wares were good, and of renowned ground.
Classic styles, and brands of high degree,
Even a gown with tags yet attached, did see.
I questioned why they bought not a single thing,
And the trainee buyer, thus didst reply,
'Twas the state of wear, and style they sought,
That led them to pass on my goods, alack!
But lo! Their own rags, in worse plight,
Didst they bear, and my heart didst take flight."

"A Marriott most dreary, that my fate did choose,
By conference's decree, my stay did here dispose.
Inferior, indeed, to that of uptown's kin,
I did rejoice when my departure did begin.

My chamber, high on floor eighteen, did hold
A dampness that did seep, a funk that did unfold.
Yet, in fairness, a kind gesture did they bear,
Turndown service sweet, with candy bars to share.

The conference halls, quite well-appointed were,
And food sufficient, future meetings to ensure.
Two stars, I give, for passable night's repose,
But uptown or Southpark Marriotts, seek those who knows."

"Hark, what news is this? A bar called Rockhouse, they say,
With beer pong and maidens in cages, what a display!
But lo, upon our arrival, naught did we find,
No pong, no maidens, nay, not even a sign.
The music, too, didst disappoint, no rock didst play,
But rather some hip hop, of yore, didst sway.
I know not, fair friends, if 'tis but my whim,
But verily, methinks, we were duped, most grim.
For naught that was promised, didst come to pass,
And thus, our evening, didst end in dismay and glass."

"Methinks we ventured thither, based on praise most fair,
But left, alas, with disappointment in the air.
The atmosphere was pleasant, save for the din
That came upon us, like a tempest within.
A table near, they did adjust with haste,
And drills and tools, they did unleash with waste.
At lunchtime, too, when crowds did fill the space,
We thought it strange, their choice of time and place.

The burgers, middling, neither juicy nor grand,
Didst lack the flavor that doth make a land.
Yet toppings, diverse, they did provide,
And though the buns were soft, they did not hide.
The service, friendly, didst make amends,
But alas, the victuals did not reach the ends."

"Thus was my maiden visit to SP, wherein we tarried some quarter hour after being seated ere anyone came to take our order. No offer was made, nor didst we ask, for drinks to quench our thirst. We began with pot stickers and egg rolls, and then, in haste, didst proceed with orange chicken. The pot stickers, alas! didst taste of age and deep-frying, despite the menu's claim of pan-frying. Scarce two minutes passed ere our entrees arrived, a speed which doth bespeak a lack of care. All the victuals didst taste of yore and re-frying, and the fried rice was mushy, like a soggy mess. 

The service, alack! was woeful, and nary a soul didst come to check upon us or refresh our draughts. The waiter vanished, leaving us to seek assistance from the busser, who alone didst provide us with boxes and a bill. 

Methinks we shall not return to this establishment."

"Hark! A business lunch didst thou recent enjoy?
Aye, 'twas but a mediocre feast, I do declare.
Some dishes pleased, some left much to be desired,
And hunger pangs didst still persist, alack!

Four persons' lunch didst cost two hundred crowns,
A princely sum, yet satisfaction didst not abound.
The grilled fish on brussels sprouts, in horseradish sauce,
Didst merit praise, and sushi rolls, too, didst please.
But, alas! No ice-tea didst they have in store,
To quench thy thirst, or cool thy fiery core.

Atmosphere, akin to dining in a mall,
Didst leave much to be desired, in sooth, 'twas dull.
Oysters, small as pebbles, didst thou behold,
And service, passable, yet not worth a tale to tell.
So, if thou seek'st a meal of quality and grace,
Look elsewhere, friend, and do not tarry in this place."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth Suite 701 bring,
Where staff, though friendly, cannot make amends
For bread, stale and unfit for serving, did cling
To plates, with nary a thought of tender care.

Oh, how the drinks did tantalize and delight,
With flavors bold and creative, a true sight!
But alas, dear friends, the food did not fare well,
For salt, it seemed, had taken up residence there.

My salmon, under-cooked, did leave me aghast,
And desserts, oh so slow, did put me to the test.
A flaky abomination, garnished with whipped cream,
Did take the place of key lime, a bitter dream.

The decor, a touch of class, yet sweet and pure,
Did not dispel the bitter taste that did endure.
For prices high, and quality low, did make me frown,
And thus, dear friends, I fear Suite 701 doth not wear the crown."

"Alack, what woeful fate doth befall this show,
Lake of Dreams, they call it, yet naught doth flow.
Each night, it starts when sun doth set, they say,
But we, poor souls, did wait, come what may.

At eight o'clock, the crowd did gather round,
Yet still the sky did boast some light profound.
So we did wait, in hope and expectation,
Till eight-thirty, when the show did finally mention.

A giant frog, upon a fake waterfall,
Did sing a tune, most wondrous and grand,
But lo, the show did last but three short minutes,
Leaving us aghast, in utter disappointment.

Again we came, at nine, to witness the next show,
But alas, 'twas broken, and did not go.
Two balls, they circled round the pond, in slow motion,
But then, the lights did fade, and all did cease.

This show, it doth not stand, against the rest,
Go see the Bellagio fountains, they are best."

"Methinks 'tis a strange sight to behold,
My nails, once smooth, now rough and old.
A manicure, they called it, with shellac,
But to mine eyes, 'twas naught but wax.

I prayed the lady to redo the deed,
With regular polish, lest I be misled.
For though my niece, a novice, may be,
She did a better job, by far, than thee.

With Sally Hansen's shellac kit, from Walmart,
She worked her magic, in just twenty minutes, by my reckoning.
And though I paid eighty dollars, plus a tip,
I expected more, for such a sum, I do confess."

"Alas, what woe is this? A tale of woe and spite,
Of service poor, and manners none too bright.
I went to Au Bon Pain, with hunger pangs,
And ordered oatmeal, with naught but thanks.

But lo, the cashier, with fingers nimble,
Didst text with speed, her thumbs didst flutter.
And I, a patient soul, didst stand and wait,
While she didst finish her message, with nary a debate.

Her eyes didst glance up, with frequency rare,
To note my presence, with scarce a care.
And though the oatmeal was tasty, I must confess,
The service there, didst leave much to be desired, alas.

Oh, wouldst that they could learn, to serve with grace,
And put their customers, in a higher place.
For though the food may please, the manner, doth grieve,
And leaves a sour taste, that doth not leave."

"Upon mine enquiry, why doth this eatery still stand, when others in yon sorry row of shops have met their end? My spouse and I didst decide to partake of their victuals, and see if 'twere worth the venture. Alas, their burgers came with chili, mustard, onion, and pickle, a strange concoction indeed. The chili, akin to Alpo's brew, and patty, thin as McDonald's finest, left much to be desired. Fries, a lone bright spot, yet naught else didst impress. And by the maiden tending drive-thru, a high school diploma seemeth not a requirement for employment here. A mystery, how this place doth stay afloat."

"Fie upon this feast!  Alack, the grub didst leave me cold.  The chips and salsa, verily, didst please mine taste,
And my Dr. Pepper, self-served, didst quench mine thirst.
But, alas, the burrito, carne-asada, didst disappoint.
Dried up beef, with guacamole devoid of zest.
I asked for pico, and they brought another bowl of salsa instead.
Aye, 'twas a curious mistake, yet still, I didst enjoy.
The cheese crisp, crunchy, didst delight, but fell apart, alack,
As we didst eat. My wife, her chicken burrito didst relish,
With green sauce, but, to mine eyes, 'twas naught but stewed fowl,
Wrapped in a tortilla, smothered in cheese and sauce,
Then broiled. Alas, the price, $22, a sum most dire.
Nay, nevermore shall I return to this place,
Forsooth, the service, kind, the employees, in fairness, didst shine."

"Methinks I was most vexed with this place,
My love didst desire to dine here, so we didst choose,
To leave Jason's Deli, across the way,
And try this tavern instead, alas, what a fray!
The service was poor, they made us wait an age,
And charged us for things without a moment's stage,
This is the second time I've been to a PT's place,
And both times, the experience hath been quite grimace.
The servers seemed annoyed, as if we were a pest,
They took their time with our food, and botched the quest,
But, on a brighter note, the victuals were quite prime,
My love had a steak salad, and I, a burger, sublime.
So, if thou art in search of a meal most fair,
Call ahead, and fetch it thyself, elsewhere,
For though the food was good, the service, alack,
Didst leave much to be desired, and that, I do lack."

"A pox upon this place, a den of dirt and grime!
The staff, they gossip, lost in their own mire,
While guests, like me, are left to wander, ignored.
I came from afar, at my doctor's behest,
And thus, my journey ended in great unrest.
Alas, how vexing, that love should turn to spite!"

Alas, my friends, I must report a woeful tale,
Of wings that failed to impress, nay, did pale.
I sought a happy hour, with brew and snacks,
But found instead a culinary lack.

The service, fair, yet slow, as if in haste,
Did little to improve the sorry taste.
I ordered wings, but oh, how they fell,
Dry, bland, and lacking in flavorful zest.

And though I asked for grilled, they came not,
But drenched in sauce, which made them naught.
My friend, too, shared this disappointment,
A different sauce, but still no improvement.

The beer selection, paltry, I must say,
No rare or special brews to sway.
The atmosphere, good, yet not enough,
To make up for the food's lack of stuff.

So, will I return? Not likely, friends,
For other options call, and time does end.
This place, alas, did not win my heart,
And so, I bid it adieu, a part.

A service advisor, with haste and no regard,
Did greet me with a lack of interest, I declare.
Their crisis, it seemed, was of greater import,
For they did scurry 'round, with nary a thought.

A loaner car, for another's need, they did seek,
And left me waiting, with a mounting streak.
Not what I'd expected, from a Lexus hall,
I drove away, with a bitter gall.

"A coupon, sent by fate, didst lure me to this place,
Where goods are sold, but not in ample space.
The shelves, they do not stretch far and wide,
Nor doth the selection of flavors inside.

Toppings, once abundant, now doth dwindle,
Leaving naught but empty vessels to riddle.
The maidens, fair, who tended counter,
Didst sit, unfriendly, with scant regard for fetter.

Thus, I didst leave, with haste and woe,
For other shops, where friendlier folk do go."

"Alas, my first visit to this eatery was not so grand,
The victuals lacked zest, the service slow and bland.
A pot of broth did sit upon our table's center,
Yet, from the fridge, we chose our own to savor.

The beef, oh tenderloins, did please my taste,
But all else failed to impress, alack, what a waste!
The servers, three in number, seemed quite busy,
Yet, their attentions, scarce, and hard to busy.

I waved, a-several times, to gain their eye,
But still, they passed, as if the wind did lie.
Even when they came, to take the empty plates,
Their focus elsewhere, as if in distant states.

One server, didst walk away, mid-order, too,
Leaving me, in wonder, what to do.
The ice, within the drinks, a strange smell bore,
Yet, the taste, didst not differ, I did explore.

The restaurant, clean and modern, doth appear,
Yet, this visit, left much to fear, I do declare."

"In troop of seven, I didst enter in,
This gay's turn, to show the coworkers spin,
A night beyond Scottsdale's dull domain,
But they, for reason most absurd, didst refuse us,
A purse, larger than a clutch, one girl didst bear,
And though we offered all our coin, nay, they wouldst not hear.
So in a cab, we quickly didst depart,
And found a night of joy, at Amsterdam's heart."

"Hark, fair friends! In Montreal's downtown, there be a Bâton Rouge, a place I oft do visit, and with great pleasure too. But alas, this particular branch didst leave me somewhat discontent.  

Their service, slow as molasses, didst test mine own patience, and the young ones', too, who didst fidget and squirm in their seats. The victuals, middling fare, didst not impress, save for the lobster poutine, a dish most delectable! The cucumber mojito, alas, didst taste more like water than a refreshing drink.  

In conclusion, the experience, average at best, doth leave me somewhat disappointed."

"Verily, I say unto thee, my dear friend, that Yellowtail doth pale in comparison to other sushi establishments. We entered without prior arrangement, and lo, our wait was brief indeed. The ambiance, alas, did leave much to be desired. 'Twas as a nightclub, with music loud and woeful, and darkness that did impair mine eyesight. 

But let us set aside these trifles, and speak of the victuals. Tofu came with a sauce akin to that of Oriental Ramen, and the rolls, though small, did possess a certain je ne sais quoi. Alas, the edamame, cooked but half, did leave me feeling somewhat unsatisfied. 

And thus, my good sir, doth their motto, as printed on their card, ring true: 'Yellowtail - Barely Adequate', forsooth!"

"Chipotle, by name, doth signify
Commercialized Mexican fare, anon.
A fan, I am not, save for the portions grand,
Baja Fresh, my heart doth hold within this land.

Ten dollars eighteen, a sum most dear,
For burrito, chips, and salsa, oh so queer!
The fill, mostly beans and rice, a meager cost,
Eight cents, mayhap seven, their loss, no doubt.

Impressed, I was not, the novelty worn thin,
The taste, once good, now bland, and lacking within.
This location, not the best, I do declare,
Baja Fresh, my heart doth hold, beyond compare."

A costly venture, indeed, with a meager choice
Of mixed drinks, and nothing more, alas!
No photographs may thou take, nor bring thy own,
But must pay dearly for theirs, 'tis a woeful tale.
A trap for tourists, verily, yet if thou canst
Afford the cost, 'tis worth a visit, perchance.
Prepare thyself, fair traveler, for a heavy purse.

"Hark! This place doth have great potential, yet doth the loud and wretched house music truly befit its noble ambiance? In sooth, there be plenty of such cacophony upon the Strip, whereas Fremont doth cater to those who flee from such din. Pray, good sirs, reconsider thy DJ's plight, and I shall vow to return anon."

"Farewell, forsooth, I shall not return again,
For thrice have I graced this place with my presence,
In hope that perchance my mind might be changed,
But alas, 'twas not to be, for all was amiss.

The pancakes, verily, didst taste of baking soda,
And the omelets, alack, were overcooked,
Save for the mimosa, a sip of sweet delight,
That didst briefly lift my spirits, ere they fell.

Nay, nay, I say, this place doth not impress,
And so, adieu, for I shall not return."

"Methinks my kin and I didst seek sustenance in fair Las Vegas, and chanced upon a spread most wondrous, an all-thou-canst-eat buffet, for a mere nine dollars and ninety-nine pence. 'Twas a fair price, methought, and so we didst venture in, with hopes of savory delights. Alas, the victuals were but mediocre, o'er salted and some, indeed, quite cold. Yet, the attendants were most courteous, despite their speech being hard to comprehend."

"Sugar Factory, prithee, add to thy store 
Three large employees, cross-trained, thou know'st 
And two happy attitude adjustments, to boot 
A medium-sized refrigerated display case, to keep things neat 

To thy already delicious selection of sweets 
Baked goods, cold treats, and candies, oh what a feast! 
A bright and colorful establishment, indeed 

But alas, there was only one person to take orders and prepare 
The labor-intensive dishes, oh how unfair! 
I guess none could help that poor soul, 'twas a pity 

We ordered four macarons, velvet brownie, and chocolate shake 
But alas, the macarons sat out, hard and uncool 
The girl behind the counter said they made them fresh each day 
But six bucks for nasty wafers, oh what a disappointment! 

But fear not, dear Sugar Factory, for thy Couture Pops 
Are quite the rage, and worth the cost, no doubt 
I bought one with a box of refills, a pretty penny 
But 'tis all about being seen, with those bling-blingin' lollipops, you see."

"Alack, what woeful fare didst thou provide!
Thy service slow, thy victuals poorly made.
In yonder dining hall, cold didst reign,
As if 'twere winter's bitter reign.

Years past, we didst venture to thy door,
When first thou didst open, full of hope.
But alas, thy food didst disappoint,
And thus, we didst dismiss thee, with naught but despair.

Last week, in search of swift repast,
We chanced upon thy hallowed hall once more.
But lo, thy fare had not improved,
Nay, 'twas worse, as we didst find.

Thy gyro meat, dry and o'ersalted,
Fries, frozen in the heart, a sorry sight.
Chicken strips, naught but breading,
And salad, soggy, devoid of taste, a pitiful plight.

Service, slow as molasses in winter's chill,
Forsooth, we were but three tables, and yet,
Our meal didst take some twenty minutes to arrive,
A wait most vexing, and cause for dismay.

Alas, I am a homeowner here,
And wish the best for all nearby.
But verily, a visit from Restaurant Impossible,
Methinks, wouldst do thee good, to set aright thy ways, and make thee thrive."

"Verily, good sir, thou dost speak of footwear most fair,
Designed for ladies of a certain age, with grace and poise to spare.
Their fame doth stem from that most popular show,
Sex and the City, where fashion doth flow.

But hold, my friend, for I must say,
Those knee-length cage boots, they doth sway,
My heart doth sing with joy and delight,
For they doth bring forth visions of beauty and light.

So here's to Christian Louboutin, the master of style,
Whose creations doth make our hearts go wild and worthwhile.
For in his shoes, we find a glimpse of heaven's gate,
And our souls doth soar with joy, most elate."

"Ay, 'tis true, a wistful yearning doth abide,
For yonder pizza shop of days gone by,
Where pies of old didst please the palate's pride,
And memories of joy didst dance in eye.

But now, alas! The truth doth come to light,
That pizza, once so cherished, doth fall short,
The crust, though thin, doth lack the needed bite,
The sauce, a zestless broth, doth leave naught.

Oh, how I wished to love Aiello's still,
The staff, so kind, the ambiance, quaint and chill,
Yet, alack! The pizza, mediocre at best,
Doth fail to stir my heart, or tempt my quest.

So, with a heavy heart, I bid adieu,
To Aiello's, once a place of gastronomic clue,
Now but a shadow of its former self,
A memory, a tale, a story to be told, and naught else."

"Methinks, fair friends, the feast didst not quite meet  
The lofty expectations that didst beset  
My mind, forsooth. Perchance 'twas due to this,  
That certain dishes didst not savour as sweet  
As others had described them. Fie upon't!  
Some sushi dishes didst seem most foul and vile,  
And at the sight of those who didst await  
Their turn for crab legs, my spirits didst flag.  
Yet, shall I give this spread another chance,  
When next I find myself within the city's bounds?"

"A respite from the heat, most welcome indeed,
Twice didst I visit o'er the weekend's span.
The waitresses, fair and kind, didst attend,
But the manager, with soul patch, a woeful man.
His hospitality, lacking in every way,
Didst leave me disinclined to spend a penny more,
And so, alas, their service, I do deplore.
For hadst he been a gracious host,
Five stars, I wouldst have given, and much more,
But now, alack, their carelessness doth show,
They do not value loyal custom, nor doth know."

"Upon a Friday eve, my friends and I didst venture forth to dine,
At a place called Taco Lingo, with high hopes and cheer.
We sat us down at nine and forty-five, and straightway didst order drink,
A margarita, two in fact, which didst please our lips and quench our thirst.
But alas, fair friends, the rest of the meal didst not compare,
The service was strange, the waitresses didst seem quite odd,
As if they had partaken of some drug, their movements swift and wild,
And we, in wonder, didst watch them, with puzzlement in our eyes.

Tacos we didst order, but they were not worth the cost,
Bland and unremarkable, save for the beans, which were a boast.
Chips, too, were not amiss, but naught else didst impress,
And the staff, they didst use a table, as if 'twere their own mess.
Unprofessional, indeed, and strange to behold,
So here, dear friends, my tale doth end, and warning, 'tis told.
For So-Cal Fish Taco, a better choice, doth reign,
In service, food, and all, a far superior gain."

"Verily, I have known joys here afore,
But today, alas! 'Twas woeful fate.
The maiden at the counter, full of woe,
Didst seem to sorrow o'er her life's estate.
And, by my troth! Her ordering skill
Was puzzling, to say the least, in sooth.
Our pizza, too, didst suffer fate's whim,
Slightly burnt, and one piece didst disintegrate.
'Twas not so dire, yet still, a better pie
Doth wait, methinks, beyond this place's gate."

"In days of yore, this place didst hold my heart,
Their pies, a bit pricey, yet a culinary art.
But alas, of late, their flavors have departed,
Leaving naught but crust, devoid of savory thought.
Alack, the staff, with scorn and rudeness filled,
Hast lost my custom, forevermore be still'd.
Farewell, Northside Nathans, we shall meet no more."

"A puny place, indeed, with naught for young ones to enjoy,
A pizza joint, yet not a scratch-made dough in sight,
Like Little Caesar's, it was, alas, a letdown,
For authentic pie, I yearned, with greater delight.

Their reviews, they did deceive, I must confess,
No beer to sip, nor fountain drinks to savor,
A Sunday afternoon, with wings and pizza, a mess,
Alas, this place, I shall not visit once more.

A search for novelty, my heart doth crave,
But here, 'twas lacking, and my hopes, did fade,
So, farewell, dear pizza place, I bid thee adieu,
And seek elsewhere, my culinary quest to pursue."

"A pox upon this place, wherein I didst dine,
Their victuals, mediocre at best, didst decline.
A burrito, shredded chicken, didst order I,
Yet found not joy within its wrappings nigh.

The chicken, watery and devoid of zest,
Didst leave me in a state of utter unrest.
The rice, a bland companion, didst not please,
And beans, though savory, could not make amends.

Hot sauce, a balm, didst soothe my taste buds sore,
Yet could not mask the truth, that this place doth bore.
I shall not return, for better burritos seek,
In other lands, where culinary skills do speak."

My journey to the Cheesecake Factory was not for naught,
For on this day, they offered half-price cheesecake, no doubt.
A line did form, but the hostess kept all in line,
And soon, I found myself seated, with nary a whine.
Our waiter, friendly and knowledgeable, did say,
That new cheesecake flavors awaited, come what may.
Bread, complimentary, did arrive with grace,
The wheat, I favored, o'er the white, in its place.
Fresh strawberry cheesecake, my choice, did seem fair,
But alas, the cream did lack the tang of cream cheese there.
Graham cracker crust, did not hold up well,
Its taste, did fade, like a flower that doth dwindle and spell.
The price, a bit higher, did take me aback,
For though the cheesecake was good, 'twas not worth the attack.
So, to the Cheesecake Factory, I shall not return,
For mediocrity doth not beckon, my heart doth yearn.

"Methought the Town Square location fair,
In sooth, I didst visit it a pair of times,
And found the victuals to be of good cheer,
But alack, the Tivoli spot, a sorry sight it was,
The sweet potato and chicken risotto, a gummy mess,
Fettuccine napoli, naught but mediocrity,
Yet, the kid's cheese pizza, a dish most fair and bright,
Aye, 'tis a place where children may find delight,
Prices, reasonable, yet happy hour, the best time to partake,
For then, each appetizer, a mere three dollars doth make."

"Verily, the sole cause to dine here is dire hunger, and naught else. Forsooth, 'tis a woeful twenty minutes' trek to MGM Grand's more frugal and delectable victuals. Save that, my so-called 'gourmet' sandwich did taste most vile and cost a princely sum. Alas, dining on the strip can be a cruel fate, yet still, thou art better off at Mickey D's, good sir."

"Hark! What burg'ry art thou speakin' of? A feast most wondrous, methinks. Yet, alack! The price doth make me weep. A pox upon the cost, forsooth! But nay, the lobster mac and cheese, a dish most laughable, didst bring a smile to mine lips. A cocktail, special and fine, didst quench my thirst, but brief, alas! Two stars, I say, for the burger most divine, yet the price, a cruel mistress, doth rob me of full joy. Hark! If thou seek'st a burger grand, and choices fair, seek out the SkyBox Sports Grill & Lounge, where the portion, large and bountiful, doth await thee."

"Hark! What news is this? A bar most fair,
With atmosphere and decor most rare.
A grand old church, a place of delight,
Where one can quaff and revel through the night.

But lo! The beer, alack, doth leave much to desire,
Average at best, and overpriced, a fire.
For if the ale were but a mite cheaper,
We'd visit oft, and spend more, 'twould be clearer.

And then, the food, oh woe is me!
A basket of chips, homemade, did we see.
Cold, soggy, stale, and drenched in grease,
Inedible, a culinary tease.
The bartender claimed they made them fresh each day,
But ours had sat, in grease, all day, alas!
We sent them back, with politeness, 'twain,
But the bartender seemed not pleased, in vain.

And thus, our visit ended, with some strife,
The novelty, of this bar, hath lost its life.
Mediocre beer, at prices high,
And food, most foul, doth make us sigh."

"A fair location, with service most kind, 
Yet, alas! The victuals did not meet my mind. 
An 'original stash' burger, I did procure, 
But, oh! The buns, they did resemble store-bought, for sure. 
Soggy and drenched, they did become, with each bite, 
And the beef, devoid of flavor, did not excite. 
I left the buns, and ate the rest, with nary a qualm, 
But, alack! The fries, they were quite good, no alarm. 
Aye, I have heard of GBurger, down south, 
Whose burgers, vast and tasty, do reign supreme, in truth."

"Methinks 'twas my first visit to this place,
And at the drive-thru, a maiden fair did take my order with haste.
But lo, she was rude, and forgot my coconut bark,
So I entered the shop, to claim what was mine by right.

She gave me attitude, that maiden of disdain,
Asking if 'twere on the receipt, as if I were insane.
I told her, nay, 'twas not, and she didst repeat,
With a sneer, that she had asked, and I didst reply, most meet.

No apology did she offer, nor a smile,
Just a scowl, and the bark, with a haughty air the while.
Yet still, I left the shop, with a heavy heart,
For such poor service, doth leave a bitter part."

"Methinks I didst enjoy this place at first,
But now, alas, 'tis a place of woe and fear.
I told my nail technician, ere we began,
That my nails were sensitive, and begged her to be gentle.
But lo, she paid no heed to my words,
And with the sander, she didst clip my nail,
And sanded my finger, causing me great pain.
She apologized, and said it was a mistake,
But I didst wonder, why dost thou not check
The settings of thy machine, ere thou dost use it?
Throughout the manicure, she didst make me pull
My hands away, in slight pain and discomfort.
I should have spoken up, but I didst wish
To hasten the end of this torturous ritual.
But then, she didst grab my upper arms,
And I didst feel a shock, a sudden fright.
I paid and fled, and now, the next day,
The gel polish on my thumb doth lift and peel.
And bruises doth appear on my arm,
From her rough grasp. I vow, I shall never return.
Nevermore, to this place of woe and sorrow."

"Hark! We gathered here for a convention,
In this Hilton, where we did congregate,
The hotel, though old, yet pool did shine,
And conference room, for two hundred, fit.
But, alas! This place, to me, didst not seem,
So grand, that I didst choose the Hyatt, to dream."

"Our victuals and potions were of fine quality, I must confess,
But alas, their delivery did leave much to be desired, I fear.
Our server, a sprite of a lass, did vanish for a spell,
Leaving us to pine for her return, in a state of despair.
And when she did reappear, 'twas but a fleeting glance,
For she did flit and flutter, like a bird in flight, without a chance.
We pleaded with passersby, to grant us a refill,
But nay, they did ignore us, with a disdainful will.
Alas, this place doth not deserve our custom, I do declare,
For there be many other taverns, where service doth abound, and fare."

"Hark! A burger and fries, if thou wouldst be so kind, good sir. And, prithee, a dash of saucy attitude from yonder elderly waiter, that he may garnish my repast with a bit o' flair.

Alack! My burger, it doth lack warmth. Fie upon it! Yet, the fries, they be passable.

Lo, our bill doth mount to ten dollars, and yon drinks and cheese and shake, they do add their mite thereto.

A pox upon that crabbed old waiter! He doth earn but a scant 10% of our total, a paltry sum, indeed. Forsooth, 'tis a curious thing, how he doth treat us poorly, and yet doth expect a bounteous reward. Methinks 'tis a self-fulfilling prophecy, that he doth create by his own surly demeanor.

But soft! What light through yonder casino doth break? 'Tis the cocktail waitresses, with their free drinks and smiling faces, that doth earn them a fairer tip, methinks.

Adieu, thou grumpy waiter! If thou findst not joy in thy work, then seek thee another vocation, that thou mayst find happiness and a better tip."

"A pox upon this store, with customer service most vile!
The staff doth treat thy patrons with disdain and scorn,
As if their presence were an annoyance, a bother most dire.
And inventory, a word they knoweth not, it seemeth.

The manager, Julie, a woeful soul, doth side with naught,
Against the consumer, her advocacy doth lack.
I'll ne'er darken this door again, nor spend a single penny.
Forsooth, 'tis a place of woe, a den of iniquity!"

"Aye, I do confess, my rule doth break,
Concerning chains, and this gas station make,
But mark my words, dear friends, beware,
For though their prices seem most fair,
Their staff doth wield a hasty hand,
And demand payment ere they take a stand.

Then, should thou dare to question their decree,
They'll glare at thee with scorn and disdain,
As if thy query were a grievous sin,
And thou, the one with faults to gain.

Yet, for convenience' sake, I give a nod,
Since 'tis situated close to my abode."
"Verily, not worth the cost, me thinks. A few coins more, and I couldst have gained entrance to a finer inn, nigh the bustling Strip. Foolish purchase, indeed, and one I shall not repeat."

"A month hath passed, my dear, since we didst adopt  
Our little girl, and now she doth flourish, by the grace of God.  
Her roundworms and giardia, they be gone, praise be,  
And she doth grow, a healthy babe, with weight of eleven pounds,  
At twelve weeks old, and still she doth increase each day.  
The paperwork, I didst receive, on third of January,  
From rescue group, with agreements, gift of insurance,  
And vaccination records, diverse. Claim, I didst submit,  
To insurance company, yet they didst not cover all,  
But only parts, for illnesses she didst possess.  
We shall redo vaccinations, two more rounds, ere long,  
And when six weeks pass, rabies shot, she shall receive,  
Then spayed, she shall be, and microchipped, by local rescue,  
Moondooggies, they shall aid, in this most noble quest.  
I wait, with bated breath, their response, anon.  
Pesce, a merry maid, with spirit bright,  
Doth bring joy, to children, and our loyal hound,  
A worthy member, of our family, in truth.  
Though troubles came, in start, we now do find  
Great pleasure, in this child, and long life, we shall provide."

"Alas, my first encounter with the famed conveyor belt sushi didst leave much to be desired. The sushi itself, I must confess, didst lack both quality and flavor. Verily, the prices were quite low, a fact that doth perhaps explain the dearth of taste. In sooth, a disappointing experience, and one that doth not bode well for future visits."

"Hark! A word of caution, traveler, beware,
For though the gas may be priced fair,
The car wash, alas, doth come with a cost,
And Danny's Glass, a place most foul, doth lie.

A small chip on thy windshield, clear as day,
They offered to fix, for a price, they did say.
But lo! The drill they used, did leave a mark,
An opaque hole, and a divot, oh so dark.

Complaints to the manager, didst thou make,
But naught but corporate offices, couldst he partake.
How vexing, indeed, this experience hath been,
A warning, therefore, to all, I do dispense."

"Ere I didst venture hither, I didst peruse
A plethora of reviews, and thus didst choose
To partake of their green curry, a dish most fair.
But lo, they didst not ask my preference
In spiciness, and so I didst declare
My desire for heat. No matter, thought I,
For 'twas but a small inconvenience, mayhap.

But then, the waiter didst depart,
And left us waiting, with nary a thought.
I didst wave mine hand, in hopes to catch
His eye, and bid him hasten to our table.
Alas, the curry, when it finally came,
Was bland, and lacking in flavor, methought.
I asked for more curry powder, but he
Didst tell me they didst only use curry paste,
And with that, he didst depart, leaving me
To ponder on the taste, or lack thereof.

In conclusion, this establishment doth cater
To those who do not savor Thai cuisine,
For naught within their dishes doth evoke
The authentic flavors of the East, I ween."

"Methinks 'twas a sorry sight, this meal we did receive. Last eve, we did command its delivery, with high hopes and eager bellies. Alas, the victuals that arrived didst lack the zest and vigor we didst anticipate. My portion of orange chicken, a dish most wondrous and fair, didst contain but a single slice of that fruit, and scant flavor besides. My husband's Szechuan chicken, a dish of spice and fire, didst boast a robust onion savor, yet little else didst it provide. And the pot stickers, great in size and girth, didst falter in their taste, with naught but a faint suggestion of seasoning. In sooth, the wait and cost didst prove too great for such a feast. I say, if thou hast other choices, choose them, for this meal didst disappoint."

"Hark! What's so grand about this place? 'Tis situated in the midst of Palazzo, and its ambiance doth lack. We didst venture forth for happy hour, and a $3 glass of their private label wine didst taste of Rutherford groove, a vintage that doth cost $5 a bottle, by my reckoning. Their wine and spirits flights, priced at $20-$40 a piece, didst seem quite steep, but happy hour didst make them somewhat more palatable. Methinks folks might stop by to rest their feet and quaff a drink, but nay, a wine bar it doth not make. 'Tis naught but a seating area for the adjacent, overpriced wine shoppe."

"Methought the egg roll was not so ill,
But the house special chicken, alack, did lack
Moisture and flavor, and seemed quite dry.
The fried rice, too, had its share of flaws,
With hard, crunchy grains and burnt eggs, alas!
Yet, the service was swift and most kind,
For take-out, 'twas a marvel of speed.
I would return, and try another dish,
Perhaps with beef or pork, to make my wish.
The prices, too, were most fair and low,
$16 for two dinner combos, who could know?"

"Hark! What discourtesy doth these employees show!
They scowl and sneer, as if thy order doth annoy.
The baked goods, too, doth seem of poor quality,
A week old, mayhap more, doth their freshness lack.

I prayed the youth at the register for a new one,
But alas, they were as hard as stone or brick.
He shrugged and offered naught but a weak apology,
As I didst toss the offending treat with great disdain.

Fortunate, indeed, that my betrothed didst speak,
And demanded restitution, lest I leave in anger.
The barista, nearby, didst mutter in displeasure,
But two stars, not one, shall this place receive,
For the coffee, good, and the ambiance, fair."

"Verily, the chain doth please, with menus vast and spaces grand.   Yet, alack, this Green Valley site doth vary in service, now and then.   Forsooth, if thou dost seek a meal nearby, choose Elephant Bar or PF Changs, lest thy server doth seem to loathe their work.   Aye, I have known servers here to be stars, but also, sad to say, some did appear to detest their labors.   When for a hundred crowns thou doth pay for thy repast, 'tis meet to look for service of some worth, at the least."

"Methinks we chose this buffet for our midday meal,
Due to the praise that many here did bestow.
But lo, our expectations were not met,
For though the price was steep, the fare was not.

The selection of dishes was quite paltry,
And naught but three sorts of sushi could be seen.
And those, I dared not try, for fear of woe,
Lest they be stale and make my stomach keen.

The rest of the victuals we did eat,
Were void of flavor, and did not greet
Our taste buds kindly. Neither did the sweets,
Which left us both in a most unsatisfied state.

I know not why the rabble doth extol
This place, unless their standards be quite low.
For we, who crave rich flavors and delight,
Did find naught here that did our senses stir.

So, gentle friends, take heed of this my tale,
And shun this buffet, lest ye be beguiled.
For though the price be fair, the food doth fail,
And leave thee feeling cheated and quite vexed."

"Methinks 'twas naught but mediocrity that didst greet mine eyes and taste buds at this so-called "buffet". O'er crowded, say I? Aye, and servers slow as molasses in winter's chill. Food bins, empty or filled with victuals not as promised. Mongolian BBQ, flavorful indeed, but bones in meat, alack! Italian and Mexican dishes, passable, but naught to write home about. BBQ ribs, a poor showing, barely a B-, I say. Average, at best, this spread, not worth mine own return, when better feasts lie closer to mine hearth and home."

"Methinks the fondness for this place doth puzzle me,
Our neighbors, they do cherish it, so I see,
And we, in fairness, have given 'tis a try,
Three or four times, yet naught but woe doth lie.

A burger, mark you, that doth oft delight,
But here, alas, it doth fall short of might.
The price, a fair point, yet not worth the fray,
For In'n'Out, a drive, or Zinburger, the way.

So, my friends, heed not the raging crowd,
For better fare, elsewhere, doth abound."

"Hark, I dwell some six blocks hence, and ne'er didst notice thee,
Thy humble abode, so tucked away, small, and hard to see.
The interior, dim and cramped, a patio, 'twixt two walls,
A scant selection of wines, alas, no cause for thrall.

The staff, kind and courteous, yet, alack, no charm doth lie,
To draw me back, no sir, naught but a passing sigh.
No praise, nor blame, doth here await, a humdrum place,
Where night doth fall, and morn doth break, without a trace."

"Methinks my brother didst speak highly of this place,
When in Vegas for his friend's wedding, he didst say,
Their chicken wings, oh how he didst love them so!
And thus, I gave this place a chance, to see the show.

'Tis an Asian fusion place, or Korean, perchance?
With karaoke private stations, and a bar, in essence.
But when we went, alas, 'twas quite deserted,
We were the only customers, in all their presence.

The ambiance, cool it was, I must confess,
But the food, alack, left much to be desired, I fear.
We ordered fried pork cutlets, Korean bbq,
Sweet potato fries, shrimp tempura, watermelon soju,
And of course, their wings, the most popular dish,
But better and cheaper, I have tasted, in my wish.

The wings, chunky pieces, not like Wingstop's size,
But the taste, alas, was merely passable, in my eyes.
The staff, kind and attentive, they were, indeed,
But whether 'twas due to lack of custom, I cannot heed.

I know not if I shall return, to give them another chance,
But for now, I fear, this place doth not entice me to dance."

"A banana nut muffin didst thou order, good sir?
And yet, a blueberry muffin didst thou receive instead?
A pox upon the manager, who with haughty tone,
Didst ask if blueberries or bananas were thy desire,
When clear it was, a mistake had been made.

The victuals, decent they were, alack,
But woe betide the service, full of disdain and flack.
Thou wouldst not return, 'tis plain to see,
To this place, where errors doth abound so freely."

"Fifty pieces of silver, a steep price to pay,
For two grown folk and a youngling, they say.
A hearty breakfast, o'erpriced, I do declare,
But the ambiance, quite pleasant, beyond compare.
The service, slow as molasses, a shame,
Yet the drinks, self-served, a blessing in the game."

"Hark! What folly led me to this wretched place,
A den of mediocrity, devoid of grace.
I sought a hearty meal, a simple feast,
But found instead a trial, most unpleasant.

The hall was empty, save for a few souls,
Yet service, slow and poor, did make me howl.
I sat and waited, patient as could be,
But nary a word, nor glance, didst come from thee.

At last, a waitress came, with speed so slow,
And took my order, with a scowl, I know.
My pancakes came, and though they were not bad,
I wondered how, such simplicity, had been so sad.

No query, as to how my meal did taste,
Nor offer, to refresh, my parched throat in haste.
I longed for water, pure and fresh,
But nay, 'twas not to be, until the bill did arrive, alas!

Avoid this place, my friends, I pray,
For service, poor, doth mar the day."

"A pox upon this pizza, say I,
For its crust doth taste of stale matzah, by my troth.
And cut into small squares, it doth make a mess,
So that I cannot lift a piece, but it doth fall to pieces, alack.
I didst pay $28 for this medley of woe,
A pizza pie, they call it, but 'tis no such thing, I do declare.
Oh, for a slice of pizza, cut normal, as is meet,
But nay, they doth persist in their strange, ill-conceived feat.
A plague upon this pizza, say I,
For it doth fail to please, and doth but vex mine eyes."

"A plague upon this wretched place, where service doth crawl like a snail on a winter's day! Though the crowd was scant, our drinks didst arrive with haste, yet the chips and salsa, alas, didst tarry. And so we waited, as the minutes ticked away like hours, for the Fundido to make its grand entrance. But lo, the silverware and napkins, they didst conspire against us, leaving us to dine like savages, with nary a utensil in sight. Our waitress, a sprite of mischief, didst flit and flutter, paying us no mind, until at last, we didst corner her, and with a gentle nudge, didst coax from her the salsa, though the chips, alack, didst remain a mystery. The drinks, a elixir of the gods, didst quench our thirst, and the Fundido, a culinary delight, didst satiate our hunger. But alas, the service, a fiasco of epic proportions, didst leave us in a state of utter dismay."

"Verily, 'tis a common misconception, my dear,
That this place is naught but a canine playground.
Indeed, the scent of dog doth fill the air,
As folk doth stroll along the winding path,
Ignoring bags provided for their pets' relief.

A encounter with a poodle's mistress, proud,
Didst leave me in dismay, for she didst assume
Her curly-haired beast could roam free, unbound.
But lo, I've witnessed pit bulls and other breeds,
Off leash, their owners in a state of blissful ignorance.

Oh, how these North Scottsdale dwellers do amuse,
Their haughty demeanor doth belie their youth.
Forsooth, this land is not a place for dogs to roam,
But rather, a soccer field, whereon doth lie
The duty to keep pets leashed and crap removed.
So heed my words, thou dog-owning elite,
Lest I, in kind, pay visit to thy yard,
And leave behind a token of mine own delight."

"A steep price paid for mediocrity, I say,
In service, victuals, and ambiance, nay.
On Sunday eve, the final night of feast,
We dined for thirty pieces of silver at least.
Two couples, with vintage wine we did bring,
Yet still the bill did mount to one hundred stings.
And lo, my friends, all three did choose the ragout,
Which did agree with them not, I do avow.
For on that night and through the morrow's light,
Their bellies did protest with much spite.
Now, mark this well, the eatery was void of folk,
A result of tempests raging fierce and wild.
One would suppose the manager would make some show,
But no, he did not deign to visit our abode.
Does he indeed care? Verily, I do not know."

Hark! What news is this? A casino, prime and fair,
In the midst of the Strip, a crowd doth bear.
Harrah's, the name, doth hold its own,
With renovations grand, its fame hath grown.
But alas, my heart doth not agree,
For in its halls, I find naught but disdain.
Old, musty, and foul, the air doth be,
And stained carpets, low ceilings, do trouble me.
Two eateries, Gordon Ramsay and KGB,
Didst anger me, and thus, I say, adieu.
No more shall I step foot within thy walls,
Harrah's, thou art not for me, nor my gall.

"Beware, good sirs and madams, of this wily tavern! 'Tis a den of trickery, where the serving folk do add a 15% tip, without a word, to thy bill. And lo, the night-owls, deep in their cups, do oft forget to note this subtle swindle, and so they pay twice, in error, for the service they receive.

I, myself, didst fall prey to this ruse, and paid a double tip, ere I didst discover the deceit. Forsooth, the victuals were but mediocre, and the atmosphere, unclean. Two flies didst flit about the hall, a sight most vexing. In truth, Burger King, that humble fast-food chain, doth boast a greater cleanliness than this supposed eatery.

So, gentle patrons, take heed of my words, and beware the waiters' sly ways. Check thy bill with care, lest thou be taken in by their cunning ploy."

"Hark! What say ye of this buffet, my friends? Best in town, perchance? Fie upon such folly! 'Tis naught but mediocrity, at best. But lo, what sorcery doth lie within these walls? A storage room, they call it, with makeshift fare and steel spoons that burn the hand! By Jove, I swear, should any other establishment try such chicanery, I shall demand restitution, ere I take my leave! Forsooth, I shall not be treated thusly, without a fray!"

"Verily, this gambling den doth show its age,
In need of renovation, 'tis a common stage.
'Tis linked to yon tram, a lengthy stroll away,
To Aria, where thou shalt find another way.
A tram doth also lead to Vdara and Bellagio,
Yet, alas! 'Tis not a short or easy trek, I do foresee."

"Customer service was slow, I pray thee,
Took 15 minutes for our waitress to be free,
And 15 more for our drinks to arrive,
A delay that did our patience impair.

My sister's Southwest wrap, a meal most fair,
But lacking a hint of spice, she did declare,
Whilst Grandma's banana bread French toast,
Was overly sweet, and the sauce did pour.
No need for syrup, these bad boys did boast,
But alas, her bowl of fruit, she did enjoy the most.

Veggie omelette, with potatoes, a feast,
But lo, the veggies were scarce, at best,
More cheese and egg whites, did make it bland,
I did not finish, for it did not please my hand.
Tapatio and ketchup, did make it better,
But my potato, overcooked, and full of season, did fetter.
My whole wheat bread, old and stale, did taste,
A disappointment, indeed, and a waste.
Shrugs, forsooth, my dear, a sorry state."

"Verily, fair readers, take heed of my words, forsooth,
A restaurant's linens, white as snow, do not a feast make.
Fleming's, alas, doth falter in its culinary art,
Despite its cloths, so pristine and apart.

The victuals, dear friends, didst leave much to be desired,
A fish, institutional, that didst taste like school fare.
An affront, indeed, to the bounty of the briny deep,
A travesty, that didst earn but two stars, ere we didst sleep.

Yet, gentle patrons, fear not, for the service was good,
A saving grace, that didst lift the venue from the mire.
So, heed my counsel, and avoid Fleming's, anon,
Lest ye wish to dine on fare most dire and woeful, ere the night be gone."

"O, too dear! I do prefer other subterranean places,  
Like Port of Subs, for the selfsame price, by th' grace.  
I do enjoy choosing mine own toppings, and seeing  
What they do, how they prepare it, with mine own eyes, yea.  
The staff, they were most excellent, in truth, I must say."

"Verily, I doth not comprehend, good sir. A vegetarian, I do profess, and thus, the menu doth hold naught but woe for me. Chocolate brownie pie, I did command, forsooth, for mine own brood. Alas, my trio of sprites didst not approve, 'twas a sorry sight, by my troth. Fifteen minutes, 'twas ere they didst prepare the confection, alack!"

"Hark! A tale of woe and disappointment doth unfold,
Of Mexican cuisine that did not meet expectation's bold.
From Texas, land of tasty delights, I came,
With memories of unlimited red and green sauce, a game.

But alas, the atmosphere, though lively and bright,
Could not make up for the lackluster food in sight.
The sauce, though adequate, did not impress,
And the entrees, oh how they did disappoint!

My cousins enchiladas, cold as ice,
Mine, bland and lacking in flavor, a vice.
Our table, full of hungry souls, didst not find delight,
In the dishes served, a sorrowful plight.

I would not return, nor recommend this place,
Unless persuaded by a friend, in a tight embrace.
