For though the staff be friendly, the food doth lack,
A shame, for the decor didst set expectations aback."

"Hark! What light through yonder window breaks? A business, by the look of it, that doth serve Indian fare. The owner and manager, keen of mind and sharp of wit, do tend to customers with diligence and care. But alack! The victuals, they do leave much to be desired. Of average taste, they be not, and many items on the menu, they do lack. Yet still, 'tis situated on the Strip, a boon indeed. Forsooth, I didst find the cuisine at Everest, far superior to that of Tamba, during my sojourn of three days in this fair city of Las Vegas."

"Methought I wouldst love this place,
And break my fast here every morn,
But, alack, the service was so base,
I could not bear to show mine face again.
The victuals, too, were naught but fare,
And I, in truth, didst wait so long,
For my bill, that I didst near despair.
Yet still, the atmosphere doth charm,
A haven from the din of the throng.
Perhaps, my garb didst not bespeak
A man of means, and thus the scorn.
I wore a suit, not pajamas, by the way.
The corned beef hash, its taste was fair,
But ground so fine, 'twas hard to say
If it were hash, or merely pulp.
I wouldst give Verandah another chance,
For breakfast, and despite the woe,
But not, I fear, for many a day."

"Alack, what woeful service didst thou render me!
So slow, so poor, so lacking in efficiency.
One solitary soul didst man the till,
And she, alas, didst double duty, ill-equipped to fulfill.
My patience didst wear thin, as minutes passed,
And naught but silence didst greet mine ears at last.
Acknowledged, I was, at long last,
But lo, the order, didst it take its sweet time to pass?
Aye, 'twas a curious sight, indeed,
For I, alone, didst stand in line, a strange, forsooth, proceed.
Yet, mark my words, good sirs,
This place, of old, hath been our trusted haven,
Where swiftness and courtesy didst reign supreme,
But now, alas, doth seem to be but a distant dream."

"A feast with six companions didst I partake,
And service, oh, how grand it did make!
Wine recommendations, they didst fit the bill,
But salad, alas, didst lack a certain thrill.
A humble Italian maiden, I didst choose,
Spaghetti bolognese, with pasta made in house.
The server, he didst praise it with great voice,
But when it came, oh, how my heart didst sink!
Tasteless noodles, thick as a man's thumb,
And sauce, naught but ground beef and tomatoes, plumb.
I skipped dessert, but biscotti, free and sweet,
Didst end the meal on a gentle note, at least."

Two years have passed since first I stepped within
This office, where Rosie, med assistant, doth reside
Her gruff demeanor, I didst soon perceive
And her disdain, my queries didst not abide

Our latest encounter, most unpleasant was
She treated me, a child, seeking drugs, alas!
With words, we didst exchange, and now I'm banned
From this office, forevermore, 'tis planned

Beware, dear friends, of Rosie's scorn
Lest ye be treated, as a foolish born

"Hark! A word of caution, dear friends, let this be told,
Of Paradise Cantina, where we didst unfold,
A night of merriment, with laughter loud and free,
But alas, the victuals, they didst not please me.

The chicken tacos, oh how they didst disappoint,
Dry and flavorless, they didst not make my day,
The tortilla, it didst crumble in mine hand,
And the chicken, it didst fall apart, so bland.

But fear not, dear friends, for all was not lost,
The happy hour special, it didst make up the cost,
Buy one drink, get the second free, a bargain indeed,
So gather round, and let us raise a glass, and heed.

For pregame, it is a place most meet,
But for the main event, seek elsewhere, ye may find,
A better feast, with flavors more divine,
To satiate thy hunger, and make thy heart and mind align."

"Hark! Good sir, I shall speak of this place,
In brief, its virtues and vices, in this space.

The bad, alas! Forsooth, there be better eats,
In this price range, SW, a worthy treat.
The food, o'er priced, doth not match the cost,
A sin, indeed, for those who dine and boast.

The couches, worn, avoid them, lest thou wish
To sit quite low, as if 'twere a stool, most rude.
The table, too, doth sit at chest height,
Ask, thou must, to move it, else thy meal be brief.

The busser, alack! Doth do the server's part,
Besides taking orders, a sorry state, indeed.
The server, fair maid, doth not greet nor welcome,
A fault, methinks, for one who pays full sum.

The hostess, kind soul, doth take our dessert order,
For the waitress, lost, doth not attend her duty, a disorder.
The scotch, oh woe! Doth come with cocktail ice,
Unacceptable, indeed, for such a price.

And yet, good sir, there be some virtue found,
In decor, nice, not bright, nor dim, profound.
Free appetizers, french fries, a pleasant surprise,
Hostesses, fair maids, accommodating, with open eyes.
Decent beers, excellent wines, a joy to behold,
A redeeming quality, worth a tale to be told."

"Facilities were pleasant, nay, most fair,
Well-kept, sweet-smelling, child-friendly air.
Free gifts didst abound, formula in store,
A kindly gesture, indeed, 'twas no bore.

The woman, though not wicked, didst express
Some hesitance, as if our request were a test.
A gender surprise, nowadays, doth seem
Quite customary, yet she didst demur,
With prices fair, but one shot, alack,
Didst lack clarity, leaving us in the dark.

Yet, her experience and skill didst shine,
For she didst see what she didst claim, divine.
Though the picture, alas, didst not meet
Our expectations, in its clarity, incomplete."

"Hark! An update doth come, my friends, forsooth,
Upon my last review, a gift didst they proffer,
A meal most free, and o'ercharge, a refund,
In kindness, they didst make amends, in sooth.
Their service, too, didst vastly improve,
We dined with joy, their hospitality to prove.
But alas, the refund, ne'er didst come to pass,
Despite their words, in emails, naught but grass.
Forsooth, 'tis a tale of Via Brasil,
A try they didst, but fell short, in vain."

"The ambiance was fair and pleasant, the service was kind, 
The drinks did flow with grace, my green tea martini did shine. 
A steep price of fifteen coins, yet common in this place, 
I sipped it slow, its taste did leave me in a daze. 

The food, alas, did not impress, o'er priced and lacking worth, 
We left the hall still hungry, our bellies not yet full of mirth. 
I would not return for a meal, but mayhap for a drink or two, 
If naught else be open, and my thirst doth need to do."

"Twas a sorry sight, my friends, to behold
A turkey sandwich, open-faced and cold
With sliced deli meat, of poorest sort
And gravy, canned and overly salted, no doubt

The potatoes, mashed and lacking in flavor
Could not redeem this wretched meal, alas
The waitstaff, friendly and attentive still
But their description of the soup, most ill

A broth, they called it, with veggies, forsooth
But how to sell it, that was not their truth
So, if I return, I shall stick to burgers and sandwiches, anon
And shun the dinner entrees, like a wise man."

In fair Las Vegas, where clubs doth reign,
We chanced upon a spot, so plain,
'Twas called the "weakest" by common fame,
And thus, our expectations were quite tame.

A Sunday eve, we ventured forth,
For free, we gained entrance, as of worth;
But lo, the crowd, it did not pour,
And emptiness, the space did bore.

A gambling den, it seemed to be,
With card games, and pretty girls, so free;
In sexy bunny garb, they dealt the cards,
But alas, the fun, it did not start.

We left, and returned, past midnight's hour,
But still, the club, it did not roar;
Yet, we did find some cute guys, so fine,
And with them, our time, we did entwine.

A contest, there was, to win,
Comped drinks, for entering, we did spin;
A Playboy Club model search, it was,
But secrets, they did keep, alas!

So, fill out papers, take head shots, thou must,
To gain the prize, so sought, so just;
But worth it, 'twas, we do declare,
For comped drinks, our thirst, did slake.

"My spouse's victuals were chill, dear friends,  
The baked beans lacked flavor, I must confess.  
But the server, a merry lad indeed,  
Didst ensure my wife's repast was reheated with speed."

"Methinks I am spoiled in fair California, where choices abound. The yogurt, alas, was over-frozen, and the flavored sorts lacked the tang of tartness. 'Tis naught but a shadow of Pinkberry's sweet delight."

"Upon the reviews, fair maiden, I didst make an appointment,
For at three o'clock, my nails didst need attention.
But lo, the wait was long, and I didst grow impatient,
For fifteen minutes passed, ere I was seated.

The nail technician, a slovenly soul,
Didst barely tend to my cuticles, nor didst he whole,
My calloused feet, a child of three winters couldst do,
As well as he, alas, didst buff them anew.

My own base and top coat, a problem didst cause,
For the nail technician, in painting, didst pause,
Unevenly, the color didst he apply,
And the sides, alas, didst remain unpainted, by and by.

The UV lamps, they didst dry my nails,
But too long, they didst leave them, in their tales,
Hot, they didst feel, and not fully dry,
Alack, poor service, didst I receive, ere I didst sigh.

Yet, cleanliness, they didst maintain, I must confess,
But variance, great, between techs, I now address,
Stick with one, thou must, if thou dost find,
A good one, fair maiden, do not be unkind.

I shall not return, alas, I do foresee,
But still, they shall have customers, ignorant, as thee,
Across the street, from Scottsdale Quarter, they do stand,
Fair maiden, take heed, and choose thy nail technician's hand."

"Methinks me and mine husband didst venture forth to dine at this establishment ere the sun didst set. The edifice itself was neat and tidy, fresh as the morning dew. Yet, methought it strange that so many servers didst attend to us, nigh five and twenty, upon a weekday when custom was scant. We didst watch, nay, gaze upon them, the whole time, forsooth, for they had naught to do but stand and gossip. 'Twas most uncomfortable, I doth declare. The manager, heedless of our plight, didst shrug and turn away. Marry, I shall stick to Henderson's Lucille, where service doth excel and discomfort doth not abide."

"Methinks the eating house doth seem most fine,
With views that do delight mine eyes.
But alas, the victuals we didst find,
Didst leave much to be desired, in sooth.

A dish of scallops, overly salted, I didst taste,
And corn rice, rich and creamy, didst accompany.
Together, they didst make a curious pair,
Yet, separate, they didst not satisfy.

My love's steak, methinks, was but mediocre,
And parking, it didst cost us dear.
Thirteen dollars, for valet, we didst pay,
And yet, the car, they didst park, in plain sight,
Upon the street, before the inn, most strange.

In fancy restaurants, 'tis customary,
To waive the fee, for valet, I do reckon.
But alas, this place, didst not observe,
The custom, and our wallets, didst feel the pinch.

The meal, so rich, didst leave me naught desire,
For dessert, my sweet tooth, didst not aspire."

Inventory, alack! Doth lack, I say,
Shelves bare, stock doth fade away.
If more in store, they should display,
But empty spaces, doth dismay.

Lines move swift, most of the time,
But aid in aisles, doth decline.
Staff doth flirt, with nary care,
Leaving customers, in despair.

Two stars, I give, for in-store pick,
A service good, doth make me tick.
But know not, how to fulfill,
Or find items, doth make me ill.

Prices high, save rebate,
And sale, doth seal fate.
"Thai house, a fair abode, yet not the finest Thai I've known. Red curry chicken, medium heat, didst lack the fiery bite I sought. Alas, the price, too steep, did make me wince."

"Methought, fair sirs, that after perusing yon reviews,
A feast most wondrous doth await us at this place.
But alas, the steak, though tender and of good cheer,
Didst lack the depth of flavor that doth make it rare.

The bearnaise sauce, a sorry sight indeed,
Tasted of naught but powdered mix, with nary a bite.
And crab, oh crab, how dry and tasteless thou art,
In sooth, a disappointment to mine own heart.

My love, fair maiden, didst substitute her salad,
With lobster bisque, a choice most curious and quaint.
But alas, 'twas bland, and left us both aghast,
At such a failure, on a night so fair and bright.

Mashed potatoes, middling, neither here nor there,
A sideshow, mere, to main course, so uninspired.
Dessert, a sweet delight, we didst not partake,
Forsooth, our taste buds, didst elsewise, lie awake.

An off night, perchance, yet still, a grave mistake,
To choose this place, when Outback, doth better make.
So, henceforth, shall we seek, a steakhouse true,
Where flavors burst, and culinary dreams come through."

"O, how the orange juice doth cost too dear,
And with its temperature, doth not appeare
To be of service, for 'tis far too slow.
The place, alas, doth seem most woeful so,
In beauty doth it lie, yet sad to say,
It doth deceive, and doth not pay."

"A sumptuous suite, with price to match,
We expected service of the highest class.
But alas, our hopes were soon dashed,
As wait for towels and hangers did stretch and pass.

Two calls we made, and waited patiently,
But still, no one came to our aid.
The air in our room, it did not function well,
And sleep with door open, we were compelled.

At checkout, our grievances we did express,
But sorry words, were all we got in return.
No discount offered, our disappointment grew,
For such a luxurious hotel, the service was new.

Yet still, the visual grandeur, we must confess,
The hotel's beauty, did our eyes impress."

"Alas, my friends, this tale doth tell of woe,
Of chili most vile, that doth my senses doth offend.
A stew of beans and meat, with ketchup poured on top,
Doth make my stomach churn, and doth my taste buds drop.

The scent of foulness doth assail mine nostrils,
Like a dirty bathroom, that doth my senses doth molest.
A flight attendant doth pass by, and doth ask her friend,
"Why doth it always smell so foul here, till the very end?"

There be many options, all of which doth cost the same,
But alas, my friends, I shall not return again.
For elsewhere I shall seek, a meal most divine,
That doth not make me wish, to rinse my mouth with wine."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Sam's,
Where pork shoulder, Boston butt, didst lie,
In wait, with price of two dollars forty-eight,
For every pound, a sum most dire.

But lo! The package, it didst not reveal,
The truth of bones within, so concealed,
A fact most vexing, and a cause of strife,
For I, a customer, didst pay the price.

And thus, I called upon the manager,
To seek a refund, or some reprieve,
But nay, he said, with words most cold,
"Twas vendor's fault, our hands are tied.

Alas, the difference in price, so great,
Five dollars, a sum most hard to beat,
I shall beware, and watchful be,
When shopping at Sam's, hereafter, thee."

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,
My time at Great Clips was quite a mess.
The corporate folk, they did decree,
A 15-minute haircut, a breeze, 'twas plain to see.
But lo, the store managers, they didst demand,
Eight minutes, or less, with nary a hand.
Now, I, a humble barber, didst refuse,
To rush my work, lest I make a fool of myself, anon.
Alas, my dear colleagues, they didst give me grief,
For not conforming to their hasty belief.
But fear not, fair reader, for I didst say,
If speed be thy desire, then come what may.
Just know, my friend, a perfect cut, 'tis not,
In haste, the scissors doth oft play the fool, by my troth."

In fair Las Vegas, an airport doth lie,
Whose landing or takeoff, doth surprise.
A clever scheme, indeed, to have a peephole,
For those who wish to watch the planes, with ease.

The airport itself, doth not impress,
A few slot machines, and fast food, doth mess.
And lo, the Duty Free, doth not excel,
In this city of vice, there's much to tell.

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall me now!
For nigh on 15 minutes didst I wait in vain,
A side salad and a child's meal, didst obtain.
And lo, didst I fetch them myself, in pain.

A multitude of folk, didst throng the counter,
No guiding hand, to speed their progress, found.
Unfriendly workers, didst they seem to me,
In this, my hour of need, so sorely tried."

"Two stars, I say, for their omelette station doth please,
But all the rest, alas! doth fail to impress.
For such a price, my friends, doth not compare,
Go elsewhere, lest thou waste thy coin with care."

"Methinks my two friends and I didst venture hither on a Friday eve, the weekend of Easter, in search of merriment and delight. Our intention was to partake in the free champagne and well drinks for ladies, a special offering of this establishment. Being all of us were of the tender age of 21, we were eager to indulge in the pleasures of this city and experience all it hath to offer.

Alas, upon our arrival, we found that seating was scarce, save for those who had reserved tables. The space within was small, and navigation through the throngs of people proved somewhat difficult. The outdoor patio area did provide a respite from the crowded interior, but alas, 'twas not enough to make up for the lack of seating.

In sooth, I cannot say if I would return to this place, save for the chance of another such special offer of free drinks. Forsooth, the only redeeming quality of this venue was the free drinks, which did serve as a fair beginning to our night, whence we didst proceed to Surrender, at the Wynn, with hopes of further enjoyment."

"Methinks 'tis strange, the praise that J & G doth gain,
For twice I've been, and found it but a middling feast.
The victuals, plain, and naught but common fare,
And dear, to boot! A sorry sight, indeed, for The Phoenician's lair.
Alack, I shall not return, forsooth, to J & G's hall,
For better fare, I seek, and greater value, after all."

"Alas, how the fare doth falter! Once a place of gastronomic delight, now doth it wallow in mediocrity. The servers, kind and attentive still, yet cannot compensate for the decline of the cuisine. Methinks 'tis a pity, for this city, fair Las Vegas, doth host many a noble establishment. Mayhap, in haste, they shall rectify this woeful state, and once again, the patrons shall partake of savory victuals."

"Two days past Yuletide, to the skies I did ascend,
And lo, the security line did seem to ne'er end.
A tale of woe, of chaos, and of foul despair,
Did unfold before mine eyes, in that place so bare.

"Twas Checkpoint C, the line for first class and such,
We were told, in hushed tones, not to approach.
And Checkpoint D, a mystery, a secret kept,
For reasons unknown, our passage was foreclosed.

"So down to Checkpoint E, we did swiftly make,
With haste, with speed, our footsteps did we take.
I, with two hours to spare, did think myself wise,
But alas, the staff, unprepared, did cause surprise.

"The holiday rush, it seemed, had caught them unaware,
And in disarray, their plans did lie in shambles there.
But praise be, short term parking, once again doth reign,
In Charlotte's airport, a blessing, a boon, a gain."
"The service, slow it was, and few the patrons, yet still the fare didst disappoint. Save for the seafood, which didst please mine taste, the rest didst falter and fail to impress."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This pizza joint doth leave me vexed.
The pies, they were quite tasty, I,
But two stars, alack, doth seem too nigh.
For ten in pizza, the price doth climb,
And service, woe betide, doth lack in charm.
A single glass of water, they didst bring,
No refill came, our parched throats to sing.
The table next, their feast didst arrive,
In ten short minutes, they didst thrive.
Antipasto salad, a sorry sight,
Waited we thirty, for sliced meat and plight.
No lettuce, alas, the waitress didst say,
A cutting board, with cheese and olives in play.
Young and not wise, she didst not inform,
Our expectant hearts, of such a storm."

"Fair sir, the victuals were of passable quality, I must confess. Yet, by my troth, the wait was overlong, a plague upon our patience. We sat at half past twelve, our bellies grumbling with hunger, but alas, our repast did not arrive until nigh on two o'clock. Strange, forsooth, that other tables, seated after us, didst receive their sustenance ere we did, some even finishing their meals ere ours didst grace our lips. A hundred dollars, sans drinks, didst we pay for this unsatisfactory experience. Verily, I say, seek thy nourishment elsewhere, good sir, as we do plan to do henceforth."

"Hark! What fond memories doth this place hold for me!
A fortnight past, upon All Hallows' Eve,
With friends, I didst venture hither, seeking glee.
But alas! The games I wished to play,
Were broken, like Time Crisis, in disarray.
The shooting games, their light guns awry,
Air hockey tables, out of service, didst lie.
And, as we left, the escalator, I didst turn off,
But that, fair friends, doth not this place's fault befall.

Verily, not as merry, the second time around,
For age and wisdom, doth my mind astound.
Yet, one game, doth stand out, in my mind's eye,
The dinosaur hunting game, wherein I didst fly.
With rocket launcher, at the ready, didst I stalk,
And hunted breeds of beasts, most fierce and stark.
And, too, the driving game, with four great screens,
Didst bring me joy, and laughter, in its gleams."

"Pray tell, good sir, what wondrous feast hast thou procured for thine taste buds? A pizza, perchance? Nay, not just any pizza, but a New York-style pie, full of flavor and delight. Yet, alack, the price doth be a steep $35 for two large pies! Verily, 'tis a cost most dear. And, alas, the pizza itself doth lack in taste, being overly greasy and unpleasant to consume. Marry, wouldst thou be better served by choosing Barro's or Hungry Howie's instead? Forsooth, their pizzas doth please the palate more than this overpriced, oily fare."

"Hark! Our meal didst take an hour to arrive,
And when it came, 'twas not what we didst desire.
The burger brought to yonder table, wrong,
A sight most vexing, and our hunger long.

The kitchen, chaos doth reign supreme,
A mess, indeed, doth it seem.
The burger, grand in its appearance,
Yet, alack, doth fall apart with ease.
The patty, dry and rent asunder,
Leaveth a pile upon the plate, in disarray.

The cheese curds, freshness doth lack,
Squeak not, alas, poor poutine doth make.
The din within, a cacophony,
Service, good, yet back of house, a sorry sight.
Fix, O fix, the kitchen's plight,
Lest frustration doth consume thy night."

"Alas, fair diner, how thy service doth pale,
In comparison to thy delectable feast!
For thrice now, have we tried to partake,
And each time, the experience hath been quite bleak.

Alack, the wait! Thirty minutes didst pass,
Ere my Diet Coke didst grace our table's glass.
And four times didst I request, ere it came,
When our first course already hadst been claimed.

Their weekend brunch, a Simon-style spread,
Doth promise all thou canst eat, yet 'tis a dread
That service doth slow down, and orders doth fade,
Leaving us to wait, and servers doth evade.

Oh, the last visit! In the ladies' room,
A server, stuffing her face with pastry, didst assume
The role of hand-washing, quite unbecoming,
And left me in dismay, my patience quite drumming.

Yet still, their kitchen doth prepare a treat,
But alas, dear Republic, improve thy feet,
Lest we, thy patrons, seek elsewhere to dine,
And leave thy halls, with naught but sorrow to design."

"Copperfield, a man of skill and guile,
Hath mastered the art of illusion,
With tricks and sleight of hand, he doth beguile,
And fooleth the crowd with ease and precision.

A lifetime of success hath he achieved,
But now, it seems, his passion hath waned,
For in his performance, he doth appear,
To be but going through the motions, uninspired.

The tricks, they were still quite impressive,
The car, it did materialize on stage,
But Copperfield, he seemed not invested,
In the show, his heart not in the game.

I laughed, indeed, at certain parts,
Nay, feared for my bladder's safety,
But would I pay to see the show again?
Alas, I would not, forsooth, I would not.

A video, before the show began,
Did pay tribute to Copperfield's fame,
But, oh, how long it did go on,
We saw each show, where his name was spoke.

Annoyed, I was, by his fake hair,
Astro-turf, or spray, I could not tell,
Thirty minutes, I did spend, pondering,
If 'twere real, or merely an illusion.

So, in conclusion, Copperfield's show,
Was but a middling entertainment,
For though his skills are great, his passion,
Seemed lacking, and his hair, a distraction."

"Alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
The mariscos here do not impress.
The portions small, the flavors lacking,
A disappointment, indeed, most vexing.

I ordered breaded shrimp, a dish so plain,
Yet even that did not taste divine.
No seasonings, no zest, no joy to find,
A culinary letdown, I must designate.

They told me of this place, a seafood haven,
But now I see, their words were but a ruse.
I shall not return, for I am dismayed,
By the loud music, too, that did my head confuse.

Why must it be so loud, I pray thee tell?
How can one converse, with such a din to quell?
I waited for the music to subside,
But alas, it seemed to stretch on, like a tide.

Never again, my friend, shall I set foot,
In this establishment, with its poorly cooked food.
I'll seek elsewhere, where flavors abound,
And music does not drown out all sound."

"Hark! Good sirs and madams, heed my words of wisdom. Forsooth, thou art in Las Vegas and seeketh sustenance, avoid this place, 'twain a cursed den of mediocrity. \'Tis located within the Venetian, yet nestled in a nook most foul, where smoke doth fill thy nostrils and naught but sportsbooks doth meet thine eyes. \'Twas a prompt seating, but alack! A half-hour passed ere water and menus didst arrive. The victuals, though varied and of fair quality, failed to impress, nor did they taste divine. We sampled the XO shrimp and seafood pan-fried noodles, yet found them lacking in flavor and overpriced, by thunder! \'Tis my belief that Panda Express, a humble chain, doth serve fare fresher, hotter, and tastier. Give this place a wide berth, dear friends, and follow mine advice, lest thou desirest a culinary disappointment. Two stars, I say, for poor environs, middling grub, and sluggish service. Thus ends another fine review, by S.G., whoop, whoop, whoop!"

"Alas, my first impediment was the entrance, which didst elude mine eyes. The youthful waitstaff, though courteous, didst not always attend to mine needs with haste. I didst tarry for a good five minutes ere any soul didst take notice of mine presence.

"The Cesar salad, prepared in the midst of the dining hall, didst delight mine taste buds with its freshness. For mine evening repast, I didst opt for steak frites, a choice not so original, I confess. The meat, alas, didst lack somewhat in quality, yet for the sum I paid, 'twas a fair exchange. The fries, however, didst prove the crowning glory - fresh from the fryer, they didst offer seconds, anointing mine meal with abundance."

"A chamber fair and bright, at price most dear,
As one would reckon, thus it doth appear.
The victuals, alack, did fail to please,
At brekkfast, three mushrooms, scarce a tease.
The Caesar salad, served with haste,
Was slimy, and the soup, devoid of taste.
The gymnasium, though old and worn,
Yet, 'tis a wonder they've found a space to scorn."

"In sooth, my friends and I didst venture forth to dine
At Surf City Bar and Grille, a place of note, they say.
But alas, 'twas more a drinking den, we found,
Than a restaurant, where fine cuisine doth abound.

So, to Que Mas, next door, we didst repair,
Where Mexican victuals, they didst prepare.
But naught, I say, was there to write home about,
Average fare, at best, and somewhat doubtful.

Once, I say, we didst give it a try,
But ne'er again shall we return, ere long to die."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of visits twain to yonder TFK,
A place of healthy fare, so told,
Yet service slow, and mood did darken.

First visit, Father's Day it was,
The meal, a feast for taste and eye,
But service, lacking in grace,
Did leave a sour note in the sky.

Again, with MIL, a week past,
We ventured forth, our hunger vast,
But wait we did, for half an hour,
And still, no sign of table, nay, no power.

I asked, with haste, the reason why,
And attitude, from server, did fly,
Slow, the service, and unfriendly too,
A vibe, most foul, didst brew.

Biltmore, my heart doth yearn for thee,
Thy atmosphere, so bright and free,
No need, have I, for TFK's dark side,
For thee, my loyalty shall abide."

"Tis a curious thing, my friends, that some do speak
Of this establishment in such glowing terms,
Whilst we, who dined there, found naught but woe
In the service, and the meal that we didst consume.

Alack, the wine they didst proffer, poor and thin,
And lacking in the mix, a cosmopolitan's sin.
The executive chef, on his cell phone, didst stand,
As we didst wait, and wait, for our meal to be served.

Bread, drowned in olive oil, didst make its way
To our table, and the service, slow and gray.
Six entrees were ordered, but alas, only one
Didst please the palate of our company, 'twas done.

I do beseech thee, good sirs and madams, tell
What magic hath bewitched these reviewers fair?
Are they paid PR folk, or merely lost in spell?"

"Hark! This place, methought, was passable, indeed, 
With vegetarian options, plentiful and diverse. 
Anointed with sauce of brown hue, tofu slices grilled, 
My meal, alas! too salty, and o'er-sauced, I deemed. 
Four tables, else, were seated, when first I came, 
And service, prompt, from my waiter, did proclaim. 
If near, thou dost reside, then recommend, I would, 
But drive afar? Nay, not worth the time, nor the fuss."

In sooth, a curious lodging place,
This hotel, with its quirks and grace.
For New Year's weekend, we did seek,
A cheap abode, and here we did speak.

A goodly check-in, with naught to pay,
No resort fee, a rarity of the day.
The freeway, close at hand, did lie,
And the front desk folk, were pleasant as the sky.

A Wetzel pretzel, a tasty delight,
Did ease our hunger, with its savory bite.
But alas, a funky scent did waft,
And the room, not renovated, did leave us daft.

The shower head, it did emit a sound,
So loud, it did our ears astound.
The coffee maker, with grime and muck,
Did make our brew, a sorry plight, indeed, good luck.

The carpet, foul and stained, did lie,
And the TV, awkwardly placed, did block the sky.
We used the room for ten hours, 'twas true,
And though 'twas passable, we didst not renew.

"Methinks 'twas a fine place to dine,
For many had spoken well of it.
The service, too, was quite divine,
And the victuals, a fair treat.

But, alack! The fowl they did serve,
Was not the best I'd e'er had,
Though decent, 'twas a bit too grease,
And made my stomach feel quite bad.

And, by the stars, a woeful fate,
Did befall three of our group that night,
My mother-in-law, my husband, and I,
Did feel most ill, and had the runs besides."

"A haven for those in their fourth decade of life,
Where one can escape the madness of Vegas' strife.
A place to hangout, free from the young and wild,
Where one can savor drinks, though priced quite mild.

The night brings forth a slightly different scene,
As revelers arrive, with mirth and glee keen.
But still, the atmosphere remains refined,
Not catering to the youthful, rowdy kind.

I visited here for my mother's fortieth year,
And found the ambiance pleasant, without fear.
Though pricey drinks may deter some, no doubt,
This venue offers a unique experience, beyond a rout."

"Alack, I didst recent visit to physician's lair,
And found myself most vexed and dismayed.
For though my appointment time didst come and go,
I waited still, for nigh on half an hour or so.
The staff, they were not friendly, nor didst seem to care,
And my doctor, her name now escapes me, alas!
She was pleasant enough, but in such haste,
As if her mind were elsewhere, and not on my health's plight.
I asked questions, she answered, but with such brevity,
As if she wished to flee, and tend to others' needs with greater speed.
So, alas, I fear I shall not return again,
To that place, wherein my patience was so sorely tried."

"Hark, my love and I did dine on brunch,
But alas, 'twas naught but mediocrity that we found.
The huevos rancheros, devoid of flavor they were,
And the patrons, elderly folk, beyond compare.
I have been to Six Penn Kitchen, for drinks I've been,
But brunch, oh brunch, a disappointment it hath been.
Stick to Big Burrito, or other small fry,
For Six Penn, good only for drinks doth lie."

"Fair victuals and merry ambiance doth this place possess,
Yet, alas, they do seem shorthanded, I must confess.
Two hours we waited, after forty minutes' promise given,
Then ten minutes more for drinks, and forty for the feast to be driven.
A family of three, who came after us, didst receive their meal ere we,
And though the prices were not exorbitant, the delay didst put me out of sorts, I do declare.
They can adjust the spice to suit thy taste, 'tis true,
But, alack, I fear I shall not return, my dear friend, anon, adieu."

"A fine array of brew, indeed!  Alas, the cost doth rise to lofty heights, and fare, a woeful sight!  Service, too, didst leave much to be desired, a letdown, in sooth.  Alack, a disappointment great!"

"O, what a wondrous sight doth lie within this place,
A feast most foul, with meats of questionable grace.
Greasy, stringy flesh, doth swim in sauce so thick,
Tzatziki, by name, doth make the stomach sick.
I prayed, dear Lord, to take my stomach out,
And with a hose, to cleanse it of all doubt.
For never have I felt such discontent,
As after dining here, my belly did protest."

"Hark! What's this? A BBQ joint in DC, they say? Pray tell, what sorcery is this? A place that serves up meat and sides, and doth it well, perchance? Fie upon it! 'Tis naught but a ruse, a trick to draw thee in and take thy coin. 

But lo! My friend, a Texan born and bred, didst swear by this place, and so we ventured forth to taste their wares. And thus, we found ourselves within their hallowed halls, where strangers doth await, and servitors doth attend. 

And what of their victuals? Ah, therein lies the tale! Their shrimp, a popcorn delight, didst please mine eyes and taste, with sweet sauce that didst hint of Asia's influence. Their ribs, a tender treat, didst fall from bone to plate with ease. But alas! Their fowl, a dish most dire, didst suffer from a dryness that didst leave mine mouth in disarray. 

Yet still, their cornbread and potato salad didst bring a smile to mine face, and so, all was not lost. For those in need of BBQ, 'twill do, I reckon. 

But mark thee well, good sirs! If thou wouldst tempt us with thy brew, then serve it forth, that we may partake of its sweet embrace. Else, shame upon thee!"
"Verily, the service was poor, and the victuals too. Yet, 'twas a meal, and if another paid, what matter? I would not return, forsooth."

"Hark, good people of South Scottsdale, listen well,
Fry's Grocery doth seek customers, and thus doth tell
A tale of criteria, most wondrous to hear,
For those who wish to shop, and tarry there.

Firstly, thou mustst have been blessed by Willard Scott,
With a happy birthday wish, ere thou dost part.
Or, secondly, thou mustst prefer a motorized cart,
Not for disability, but for a weight of three score and ten.

Thirdly, thou mustst be willing to hold up the line,
In the pharmacy, with tales of sickness and of woe,
And know not the ways of insurance, nor dost care,
For thy time is naught, but thy words, they doth flow.

Fourthly, thou mustst steer thy cart with such grace,
As thou wouldst steer a Buick, in a parking space.
And fifthly, thou mustst deem the aisle a place,
For social converse, and bingo, with a smile on thy face.

Lastly, thou mustst be a thrifty soul, and see,
The prices at Fry's, they are lower than the rest,
And thus, my friends, I fall into this category,
And shall behold thee, Fry's, next week, at the latest."

"Methinks I've visited Sushi Kim on several occasions, and verily, the victuals and hospitality have not met the standards set by its reputation as one of the finest Korean establishments in fair Pittsburgh.

The fare, though passable, doth not impress; the service, middling at best, and the staff, not the most congenial of souls.

Therefore, should anyone seek my counsel on a worthy Korean or sushi house, I shall not hesitate to exclude this place from my list, with nary a qualm or quaver."

"Methinks the ambiance was quite pleasant,
The biscuits with jam, a tasty delight.
But alas, my dear, there was a dish,
That didst leave me feeling quite unpleased.

'Twas eggs below, and beef above,
A strange concoction, I didst perceive.
And thus, my appetite didst wane,
And I have not returned since that day.

The grits, they didst taste of milk,
A flavor most unappealing, I didst think.
I've had better brunch, I must confess,
In other places, where food doth impress."

"Methought I sought in this fair store  
The usual wares that Asia's bounty doth pour,  
But alas, my search did end in woe,  
For here were none of those things that I did know.  
Mekong and Lee Lee, twain stores of renown,  
Do boast a greater choice, and at a lower crown.  
Ah, cruel fate! For now I must depart,  
Yet mayhap someday, back I shall come to thine heart.  
If duck of Peking or pork, roasted with care,  
Beckon me anon, then shall I return, I swear."

"Amidst the bustling Strip on Christmas Eve,
My hunger grew, and sugar withdrawal did grieve.
From New York New York's arcade, we did emerge,
When lo, a sweet haven did my eyes enlarge.

It was a candy store, a place of delight,
Where sugary treats did dance in sight.
My heart, once filled with childhood joy, did sing,
For candy shops, my love did cling.

But alas, the prices did my senses shock,
A handful of gummies, five dollars did unlock.
Oh, Las Vegas, how thy prices do inflate,
And make a simple pleasure, quite irate."

"Upon a floor with billiards and fine dining places,
DOCG doth hold its own, in modest grace.
The victuals, not as costly as the rest,
Yet still, the bread, a delight to test.

Pre-packaged bread sticks, a crunchy treat,
I savored each bite, oh so sweet.
The pizza, adorned with fried egg and pork,
Truffle, a luxury, for all to embark.

The waiter, with skill, did break the eggs,
And spread them forth, like golden springs.
The scent of truffles, did fill the air,
And baby chickens, beyond compare.

But alas, the taste, did falter,
No truffle kick, nor even a flutter.
I felt such sorrow, and disappointment too,
As I gazed upon Comme Ca, sipping wine anew."

"Methinks I didst venture back to Wing Stop,
After a space of nine months, give or take,
And found it not as fair as erst I thought,
Forsooth, 'twas lessened in its savour, naught.

I tried their Cajun sauce, a curious blend,
With hints of heat, and buffalo's spice, and herbs,
Yet, hard to pigeonhole, like this verse,
It lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain zest.

Alas, my taste buds were not stirred,
And thus, I fear, my visits to this place are cursed.
Forsooth, this was my final trip, I ween,
To Wing Stop, where once I didst find delight."

"Verily, they boast the finest gear, a truth I've oft confirmed.
But with each trip, troubles mount, while solutions dwindle.
Their prices be exorbitant, a fact that doth astound,
For rival shops offer better deals, both in rent and bound.

Their staff, so full of pride, doth strut and preen,
As if they held the sole key to photography's sheen.
Their knowledge, though not vast, doth overflow with conceit,
Leaving me to ponder if they truly do perceive.

A time there was, when battery replacement did require,
And lo, the clerk did place it in, most unfortunately, upside down, in ire.
If customer service were a scale, from one to ten,
Tempe Camera, alas, would falter, rating but a minus six, by my pen."

"Hark! What venue is this, without a drop of ale?
A place where music doth play, yet nary a pint doth flow.
I chanced upon this scene, a month past, and lo,
My heart did sink, for naught but water doth glow.

The youthful crowd, so full of life and glee,
Did swarm the hall, their faces bright and free.
But I, a man of years, didst feel most out of place,
In this, the temple of the all-ages race.

If thou art young and eager, full of zest,
This place shall bring thee joy, and put thy spirit to the test.
For here, the up-and-coming bands do play,
And thou shalt dance and sing, the night away.

But woe betide the elder, who doth crave a drink,
For in this hall, no ale nor wine doth flow, I do think.
So, if thou art of age, and seek a merry night,
Prepare thyself, and bear with all, in this, the concert's light."

"Hark, what news is this? A Hilton honor promotion, they say? And yet, upon our arrival, the room didst leave much to be desired. Fie upon this hotel, I say! Forsooth, I shall seek lodging elsewhere, at the MGM Grand Hotel, where luxury doth reign supreme. 'Tis a far cry from this humble abode, which doth pale in comparison to the grandeur of yon Park Inn hotel."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This event did leave me in distress.
A novelty, indeed, it was,
But value for money, alack, it had none.

The organizer, with cunning guile,
Didst persuade us to pay for a silly mile.
In front of cows, we didst run,
And for our troubles, a bandanna we didst win.

Oh, cruel fate! No t-shirt didst we receive,
For they had ran out, so we didst believe.
And safety pins, in short supply,
Didst leave us with numbers, awry.

Disorganization, chaos, and strife,
Didst reign supreme, to end our life.
No ID's nor vouchers didst they check,
So in we went, with nary a fret.

Drinking, they didst forbid,
But who obeyed? The foolish, they didst.
Cowboys, they didst harass,
With lasso's swung, in anger's sway.

A shame, indeed, it was,
For the costumes and band, we didst pass.
But alas, the event, a failure, it was,
And our money, oh how it didst pass."

"Alas, dear friends, 'tis with a heavy heart I bring thee tidings of woe. The eatery known as Pickles, a mainstay of this fair town, doth serve victuals most vile and foul. Nay, verily, their grub doth pale in comparison to that of chain restaurants, a truth most dire.

And lo, the day of reckoning hath arrived. Pickles doth close its doors, and with it, an era doth pass. Farewell, dear patrons, may thy memories of yore be sweet.

But fear not, for from the ashes of Pickles doth rise a new establishment, a place of gastronomic delight, they say. 'Tis called, they whisper, a name most curious, a secret kept close to the vest.

Yet fear not, dear friends, for on the first day of July, the transition shall be smooth, a change most subtle. And when the dust setteth, behold! A new crown jewel of local cuisine shall shine bright, a gem most precious."

"Alas, a cupcake most foul and wretched sight!
The icing, it doth fall away, like snow from roof so bright.
And in one bite, the cake doth crumble and fall,
Leaving naught but crumbs, and a poor taste to pall.

A sign upon the door, a warning to us all,
To keep the cupcakes fresh, lest they turn stale and small.
But alas, 'twas not to be, for Sprinkles didst not succeed,
Their seasonal Smores cupcake, a failure, indeed.

The marshmallow icing, a sweet and tasty treat,
But coupled with the graham cracker crumbs, a mess most meet.
And so, dear friends, let this be a lesson to thee,
To avoid such cupcakes, and seek those made with glee."

"Methinks I erred in choice of dish, my friends,
For shepherd's pie didst disappoint, with mash that ne'er did end,
And little meat, alack, to savour or delight.
Yet, in truth, the bit of flesh that there was, did taste most sweet and bright.
My comrade's salad, alas, didst appear most woeful and unsightly,
Yet she didst declare it fair, though not of highest quality, I do confess.
And thus, dear friends, let this be lesson to us all,
To avoid the early hours, when atmosphere doth lack its charm and thrall.
Forsooth, on Friday eve, fish and chips shall be our heart's desire, and mayhap then we shall find our culinary bliss."

"Thou brought forth bread, toasty and dry,
With crust burnt, as if 'twere kissed by fire.
And yet, the oil that did accompany,
Was goodly spiced, and didst my heart desire.

I didst order then, a dish of sea,
Scallops, thou calledst them, fair and fine.
But lo, the bottom, blackened and charred,
Didst taste of coal, and not of finest wine.

Couscous, a dish of wonder, followed next,
Soft and fluffy, like a cloud in flight.
But then, the Bass, oh how it didst fail,
Full of bones, and naught but trouble and strife.

The waiter, quick with words of guile,
Didst say, what canst thou expect of a small fish?
Bones, they have, in abundance, 'tis their nature.
And thus, I didst accept, with some displeasure.

For sweet dessert, a choice of two, they gave,
Yogurt or fruit, both plain, and naught but grave.
I chose the fruit, and found it wanting,
In flavor, and in zest, and somewhat shaming.

But wait, a surprise, the waiter didst bring,
A baklava, complimentary, a sweet delight.
But alas, 'twas dry and hard as stone,
A disappointment, and a bitter moan.

Oh, how the honey didst not soak within,
A failure, this, a dessert most vile and thin."

"A prime location indeed, and well they know it,
This elder guard restaurant, with patrons a-plenty,
In summer's heat, the place doth look most fair,
And folk do flock, their hunger to assuage.

I, too, didst avoid Roland's, with assumptions dire,
But wife and friend, they didst desire,
A "lobster roll", and thus, I was compelled,
To join them there, and witness their delight.

A draught I ordered, and waited with bated breath,
As they didst receive their famed lobster rolls,
But alas, their joy didst quickly turn to woe,
For the sandwich, small and meager, didst show.

A mountain of fries, hand-cut, the best part, indeed,
But the roll itself, with lobster, fishy-tasting, didst yield,
No sauce, no flavor, just a limp pickle spear,
And a small cup of coleslaw, oh so dear.

The service, decent, yet the food, a disappointment true,
A pathetic showing, for a place so renowned,
So heed my words, good friends, and take my advice,
Go to Wholey's, where the food doth truly entice."

"Hark! What woeful tale doth this advertisement bring?
A company boasts of swift delivery, yet doth fail
To reach a mere mile and a half, how strange!
Their words, like empty promises, doth fade and wilt.

Away with such false claims, and heed my advice,
Invest in cars and drivers, lest thy business sink.
For honesty and truth, these be the keys to thrive,
And build a reputation that doth stand the test of time."

"Hark! Two more times hath Richard cut my locks,
The second time, a wondrous job he did,
But alas, the style, a woeful sight it was,
A wig from days of yore, upon my head it sat.
But then, with nimble fingers, I didst fix,
And styled it anew, quite different from his trick.
In sooth, I loved it well, and didst rejoice,
But alack! The third time, oh how dire the choice!
Awful, both in style and form, it doth seem,
A stranger thing, that doth my heart dismay.
Now do I seek, a new salon to call mine,
For Richard's skills, they have declined, I fear."

"Aft'r a concert at Stage AE, my love and I did seek
A place to rest our weary feet, and thus didst seek
The Pittsburgh Grille, a place of rest and cheer,
Whose decor was neat, with murals bright and clear.

The bar was filled with screens, a sight to behold,
And in the dining area, more screens did unfold.
'Twas a curious sight, yet fitting, I did find,
Since this place stood beside the stadium, so divine.

A cigar bar, a rare sight, didst catch mine eye,
And I didst think it added a touch of elegance nigh.
The place was plush, and comfortably didst provide
A refuge from the noise, and the night's wild pride.

We stayed but for a drink, though I didst desire
To stay longer, and partake of their festive fire.
But alas, a patron loud and rough didst make
A scene most vile, and caused a stir, forsooth, a mistake.

The barkeep, too, didst seem to be distracted quite,
By his own affairs, and left our glasses dry and bright.
Though few were there, and time didst pass slowly by,
I didst expect better service, ere I didst say goodbye."

Alas, my heart did sing with hope and cheer,
For a BBQ place of renown, I did hold dear.
The tales of its greatness did reach mine ear,
And so, I waited, till the crowds did clear.

But now, my friends, my hopes doth lie in ruin,
For the feast we shared, did leave me in woe.
A brisket and turkey sandwich, we did partake,
With sides of slaw and salad, a cobbler to make.

But lo, the turkey, it did taste of propane,
And the brisket, merely passable, I did gain.
The BBQ sauce, a mess, the spouts did clog,
And so, my friends, our meal did turn to bog.

The potato salad and coleslaw, a shame,
For they did taste, of store-bought fame.
Not homemade, alas, and so, a disappointment,
A fate, I did not wish, upon my stomach's content.

And so, my friends, I must confess,
The cobbler, too, did fail to impress.
A frozen meal, of store-bought sort,
Did taste, much better, than this BBQ's sport.

I do despair, to write such ill,
Of a place, with potential, to fulfill.
Their concept, grand, their decor, a delight,
But alas, the food, did fail to excite.

"Hark! Alack, I've tasted finer fare,
In truth, my knowledge of Hawai'ian cuisine is scant,
Yet still, I dare say, better dishes there be,
In quality, quantity, and price, 'tis plain to see.

A sampling of their BBQ plate I didst partake,
With sliced beef, ribs, and chicken, two scoops of rice,
And one of macaroni salad, a meal most fair,
But alas, the ribs, from an old cow, didst show,
And chicken, all dark meat, no healthy choice,
Thin cuts, quick grilled, sauced, and served with haste,
Their efficiency, I do admit, was quite the feast.

Oh, and the cashier, with language barrier,
Didst give my order, with nary a smile, nor cheer,
So if thou seekest fine dining, look elsewhere,
For this place, though adequate, doth not compare."

"Hark, the eel roll was a tasty treat,
As was the spicy salmon, a delight.
But alas, the Las Vegas roll did disappoint,
For all I could taste was cream cheese and rice, a woeful sight.
Kona Grill, a better choice indeed,
And cheaper too, a pleasant surprise to heed."
"Save for that one dame, fair Ashley, all else doth fail. A sorry state, indeed, doth this place possess. Methinks 'tis time to cease my visits, lest I pen more bitter tales on Yelp."

"Fie upon this wretched shop, that doth extort
Such exorbitant prices for a paltry bag of M&M's!
My wife, in her innocence, didst fill the sack,
But lo, a harpy of a woman, with voice so shrill,
Didst cry, "Good sir, 'tis seven dollars and ninety-nine pence per pound!"
I, in my disbelief, didst utter words unmeet,
And swiftly, we didst hide the bag, as if in shame,
Amongst the other sweets, that didst cost an arm and a leg.
Alas, what madness doth possess these vendors,
To think that M&M's, of all things, doth merit such a grand edifice?
Pray, let us flee this den of thieves, and find a more reasonable prize."

"Hark, what have we here? A Mexican eatery, by the name of 'Garcias' copied, yet not quite as well-done, alas! The victuals, decent, save for the rice, dull and lacking zest, and beans, naught but common, I do confess. The salsa, mere salsa, nothing more, I fear. A chicken chimichanga, drenched in sour cream and cheese, didst taste, yet failed to impress, for better had I had at 'El Norteno' and 'Garcias', I must confess. Alack, the quality and appearance of the dishes, leave much to be desired, I do declare. A revamp, perchance, wouldst do them good, ere they stagnate, and lose their clientele, mark my words."

"Fare thee well, good sirs, and gentle ladies too,  
For I have tales to tell of woe and sorrow anew.  
A place named D'Lish, where food doth reign supreme,  
Yet service, wait, and park, do bring much vexation, methinks.  
Three times I went, and each time, alack,  
Didst suffer woes, and troubles manifold, and how.  
The food, above the rest, didst shine so bright,  
But service, slow, and wait, didst plague mine eyes, by day and night.  
Overcharged, I was, and cashier, so curt,  
Didst leave me vexed, and in a sour mood, forsooth.  
Four stars, for food, I wouldst give, in truth,  
But two, for service, doth my rating prove, in sooth.  
A shame, it is, that D'Lish doth not keep,  
Later hours, for those who dine, and sleep not, ere the night doth creep.  
So, heed my words, good sirs, and fair maidens too,  
And change thy ways, D'Lish, lest thou lose, thy loyal crew."

"O, what wondrous feats doth these employees perform!
Alack, I didst watch in awe as one didst wrap my burrito,
By squeezing out the sour cream and rolling it within.
And lo, my friend's margarita didst take five minutes to prepare,
A task that didst test my patience, I do confess.
But still, I marvel at the skill of these workers,
For they do bring forth sustenance with great dispatch.
And so, I shall depart, full of wonder and cheer,
For this place doth provide a most excellent meal, indeed."

"O, woe is me, Sinobi! Forsooth, thy sushi doth pale in comparison to yonder Penn Ave Fish Co.'s delectable delights. Alas, the meager, sorry-looking 'rainbow roll' with naught but tiny strips of fish doth resemble naught but bait for fishes. Fie upon it! I shall nevermore part with my coin for such paltry fare. O, owners, heed these words and take the time to prepare sushi worthy of the name! 'Tis a shame to have so few options near Market Square."

"Twice didst I make the mistake of ordering from this wretched place,
Thinking that perchance it had improved with time's embrace.
But alas, my hopes were dashed, for the food was naught but woe,
Over-priced and flavorless, a true gastronomic foe.

I vow, dear friends, to nevermore darken their door,
For the sauce they call 'teriyaki' doth leave much to be desired,
A foul concoction, indeed, that doth sully the meat,
Leaving a taste most vile and unpleasant to greet.

So heed my words, good people, and shun this place with haste,
Lest ye wish to suffer the same fate as mine own taste."

"Alas, my friends, our hopes for hearty Irish fare were dashed, forsooth. The Shepherd's Pie, with its watery gravy and scant meat, did not impress. The Irish stew, served cold and flavorless, did naught to warm our bellies. The waitstaff, though pleasant, didst not attend to us with due haste, and our dessert, a bread pudding with melted ice cream, didst arrive in sorry state. Verily, we shall not return to this establishment."

"Hark, good sirs, we came to this place,
For the bar alone, and naught else.
Avoid, I pray thee, the dirty martini,
Lest thou desire a drink most uncouth.
'Tis naught but gin, and a poor choice,
For those who know not what they do.

Oh, pear martini, sweet and tasty,
Yet not enough to make amends.
Tokyo tea, a drink of little might,
And appletini, easy on the senses.
(I must confess, Dr. John Dorian's phrase,
Did influence my words, in sooth.)

But lo, the bartender, in haste,
Did take away our candle's light,
And hurried us, with little grace,
At eleven o'clock, on a Saturday night.
What folly! I didst remark, in my review,
This strange behavior, most unbecoming, anon."

"Alas, my dear sister and I didst venture forth to JJ's Top of the Swamp, a place of late remodeled, to partake in a meal most humble.  The atmosphere, a typical tavern, held naught but the usual suspects, save for a floor near the ladies' chamber that didst seem in disrepair.  The prices, reasonable they didst seem, yet the menu, a collection of common fare, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi.  My sister, a blackened chicken melt didst order, and found it to her liking, fair and good.  I, a Yeti burger, didst request, and lo, it didst arrive, o'ercooked and dry, with a fried egg, solid as stone.  Our waitress, kind and pleasant, didst attend us, though the cook, perhaps, didst have an off day, or the menu, a work in progress, mayhap?  Alas, I fear I shall not return, for naught didst make this place a destination, worthy of note.  Mayhap thy experience shall be better, fair reader?"

"A chain of coffee shops, Beanscene doth boast,
In Edinburgh and Glasgow, they do hold court,
A unique alternative, they claim, to those
Corporate chains, like Starbucks, Costa, and Nero's woes.

But alas, their shops, so plain and brown,
With leather chairs and wooden tables, doth abound,
The prices, similar, and the fare, unremarkable,
Save for the pizza and nachos, which friends do laud and commendable.

But I, myself, didst share a muffin and pannini,
Both stodgy and dull, with naught but 30% of filling within.
And the music, soft and ambient, didst play,
To relax the customers, but to me, didst bring dismay.

For it didst remind me of adverts, so bright,
For MFI or Sofa Workshop, a constant sight."

"Methought, fair friends, a debate did rage within my mind,
'Twixt which buffet to choose, a quest of great design.
Bacchanal, a name that did resound with glee,
Didst I select, with Yelp reviews, a sight to see.

Alas, my friends, I fear I didst hype myself,
For when I dined, my expectations didst dwindle and pelf.
A 2.5 star, a rating quite unkind,
Didst I bestow, with disappointment entwined.

The food, a plenty, with stations galore,
But freshness, alack, didst seem in short store.
Sushi and sashimi, a dearth, I didst find,
For sixty dollars, a price hard to unwind.

The seafood bar, a letdown, I must confess,
Crab legs, a flavor, didst not impress.
Hot bars, with items dry and old,
Didst leave me unsatisfied, a tale to be told.

Desserts, a disappointment, a conclusion,
I have had better, at a price more conducive to conviction."

"Amidst the spread of viands, dear to my heart,
I found the victuals pleasing, a true work of art.
The surroundings, fair and bright, did please mine eyes,
And thus, my senses, did this place surprise.

Yet, alas, the sweets, a disappointment they were,
Bland and uninspired, leaving much to desire.
For such a price, a steep and lofty sum,
I did expect more, a novelty to come.

A newcomer to the Strip, with promise great,
This buffet, alas, did not quite meet the rate.
Innovation lacking, a shame it be,
For with such potential, more could've been seen."

"Service most vile, a full minute didst pass, ere he didst reach the counter, void of any greeting fair.  The sole employee, lost in thought, didst tarry, phone in hand, till customers didst arrive, and then didst call them back, with nary a care.  Order, correct it was, yet naught but woe, didst fill mine heart, at sight of bathroom, foul and messy, lacking trash bag, in the can.  Common area, average, at best, didst seem, in this place, where service doth falter, and cleanliness doth suffer."

"Verily, the establishment doth boast a fair visage, yet the atmosphere within didst assault our senses with a most oppressive veil of smoke. Our peepers didst smart and water, ere our victuals didst arrive, and our persons didst reek of culinary fumes for the remainder of the eve. We didst command two 'old fashioneds', which didst bear but a passing resemblance to the genuine article. The foie gras, a dish most luxurious, didst prove the highlight of our repast. The lobster poutine, of which all didst speak so highly, didst fail to impress. A far superior poutine may be had at other establishments. The octopus salad, a dish of promise, didst disappoint, its flavors dull and its texture unpleasantly chewy. The pork'something' bread pudding, alas, didst lack all semblance of taste, a flavorless mush that didst leave us unfulfilled. Alas, dear friends, forsooth, this place doth charge a pretty penny for fare of middling quality, served in a hall choked with smoke."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of a hotel stay most foul and cold.
The HOTEL, soon to be renamed,
Didst play host to our tired frames.

A Delano room, so fresh and new,
Didst welcome us, with design anew.
But alas! The customer service,
Didst leave much to be desired, I must confess.

The check-in, a lengthy affair,
Didst take 45 minutes, with naught but a few pairs.
And though they didst renovate,
'Tis no excuse for such delay, so great.

A suite with two beds, we didst request,
But alas! They couldst not provide, at best.
A room for handicapped, they gave instead,
With restroom fittings, for those in need.

Trash and unfinished drinks, didst greet,
Upon entry, a sorry sight, so neat.
And in the restroom, half-washed cups,
Didst show that haste, didst leave them in a state of flux.

Next morn, we didst request,
Housekeeping, with a quickness, we didst expect.
But alas! No show, didst come,
And when we called, a grumpy soul, didst succumb.

And when they left, their detergents,
Didst remain, in the room, as a token.
A poor experience, indeed,
For a room, so costly, and in such need."

"Hark, what throngs of people doth this place draw?
Methinks 'tis strange, for naught but football doth it show.
A sampler platter didst I order, with nachos besides,
And found them to be passable, yet naught to boast of.
The onion rings, they didst taste of onions, I do confess,
And fried cheese, much like the onion rings, didst not impress.
But spicy garlic, oh how it didst ignite my tongue!
Almost too fiery for mine own taste, I must avow.
The fare, it was but mediocre, o'erpriced indeed,
So shall I not return, nor spend my coin again."

"Methinks I've visited several yarn shops of late,
As one new-fangled to the crochet trade.
But this particular store didst leave me flat,
With its odd scent and lackluster display, so dull and grey.
I shall not return, forsooth, and pray
To find more pleasant shops, where yarn doth play."

"Methinks I must concur with Katie L., fair maiden,  
Unimpressive, indeed, this feast doth seem.  
Bread and water, swiftly brought to table,  
Yet, alas! The bread, a mushy, sliced disaster,  
No crusty loaf, as one might hope and pray,  
From an Italian eatery, nay, not today.  
Then, waited we, some ten or fifteen minutes,  
For our server, who, in truth, didst tarry,  
And lo! The very same, who greeted well,  
The couple next to us, their meal to sell.  
Stuffed mushrooms, soggy, o'er-filled with tomatoes,  
Entree, stuffed shells, in sauce, a veritable ocean,  
A quarter of the sauce, a better dish, no doubt,  
Alas, overall, a disappointment, without a rout."

"Hark, my friends, we sought a place near work to dine,
A different fare from the usual grind.
'Tis a walk-up, order, and find a seat,
The server, swift and most discreet.

I chose the clams with white wine sauce, alas,
A mistake, for they were not of the freshest caste.
The noodles, too, were cooked beyond their prime,
A disappointment, a sorry time.

For Italian cuisine, I'd not recommend this place,
In the vicinity, there's better to grace."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news is this? A place that doth serve victuals, yet with an air of disdain doth the staff hold themselves aloof from those who seek to partake of their wares. Methinks 'tis a curious thing, forsooth, that they should be so haughty and proud, as if they were above the common folk who crave but a simple meal. And yet, I shall not lie, for in the dead of night, when all else fails, 'tis a haven, a refuge, a place to find solace and sustenance. But, by the stars, I pray thee, good sir, let not thy pride be thy downfall, forsooth, lest thou dost drive away those who wouldst be thy customers."

"Hark! What ill fate didst befall us at Betty's Nosh? A place with promise, yet lacking in substance. Our server, a diligent soul, didst tend to bar and outdoor guests, while seven others stood idly by, their presence a blight upon the scene. The victuals, overpriced and poorly cooked, didst fail to impress. Thai chicken mushrooms, once a dish of renown, didst arrive with shredded breast as dry as dust, and peanut sauce that didst leave much to be desired. Beef and blue mushrooms, a similar tale, with ingredients of varying quality, yet equally disappointing. And lo, a Reuben sandwich, with store-bought corned beef and stale pretzel roll, didst complete the trifecta of dismay. A kind stranger, moved by pity, didst pay my tab, while I, in turn, didst settle the bill of another. Alas, wherefore art thou, manager? For such prices and service, one doth expect a higher standard. We shall not return, our first visit notwithstanding."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from yonder diner,
Wherein I didst partake of luncheon with mine own kin.
The place, it didst seem, was empty, save for five tables,
And yet, the service, it didst move at snail's pace, verily.

A quarter hour, we didst wait, ere our victuals didst arrive,
And when they didst come, the cost, it didst seem quite high.
The burgers, they were good, but priced, alas, too steep,
For in this fair town of Scottsdale, such prices do abound.

But lo! Our check, it didst contain an error most grievous,
For the waitress, she didst give us the wrong bill, full of deceit.
She took the check of others, who didst pay it without a flaw,
And gave it unto us, a most curious thing to behold.

Now, slow service, when the crowd is small, doth vex me sore,
And poor service, on top of that, doth make me wrathful, by my troth.
Thus, two stars, I do bestow upon this place, despite the food's quality,
For slow and shady service, it doth not beseem a place of honor, in sooth."

"Methought to prove a yelper wrong,
But she, in truth, did speak aright,
That frozen store-bought pizza was best,
And my taste buds did bear witness to her might.

The sauce, unremarkable, did not impress,
The cheese, a saving grace, did somewhat bless,
The meaty wings, mildly spicy, did delight,
But alas, the crust, a sorry sight.

Thick bread, with sauce and cheese applied,
Did make me think of Little Caesar's fried,
A comparison most unfavorable, I confess,
For pizza crust, it did not pass the test.

Yet still, I must admit, the pizza was not bad,
For those who crave a quick and easy meal, 'twill suffice,
But for a true pizza lover, like myself,
'Tis not a dish that doth my hunger appease."

"Hark, Ticoz, a review most dire,
Afraid, I pen these words with fire.
What shall the owner do, I pray?
No malice in my heart, I swear,
Nor have I broke the rules, I fear.
So, Ticoz, refrain from wrath,
As thou didst with that maiden fair,
Who scorned thy victuals, and didst declare
Thy cooking skills were lacking, rare.

I take this risk, with hate mail's sting,
To say, the grub we had, did not sing.
The food, alas, did not impress,
I know, my apologies, 'tis true,
But had the host, within five minutes, blessed
Us with his presence, all would be well.
Alas, he waited, and his duties shared,
With the waitstaff, who didst serve so well.

Our waiter, kind and gentle soul,
Didst take our order, with a smile whole.
Pozole, with lime and cabbage, nay,
I'll pass, for it didst not sway.
Blue corn enchiladas, sour cream sauce,
Too rich, too heavy, no applause.
Shredded chicken, shredded pork, a frown,
Both dry, and flavors, long since gone.

Yet, decor and vibe, most excellent,
Cozy, hip, a place of merriment.
Private dining room, great bar,
Patio, a treat, beyond compare.
Worth more stars, I must confess,
But, alas, the food, a mess.
Not for drinks, I came, I swear,
But, cocktails, there, I might declare.
Perhaps, the chef, a bad day had,
But, ne'er again, my words are sad."

"Hark! This den of dentistry doth reign supreme,
In upselling and procedures most extreme.
Communication lacketh, thoroughness doth fade,
And all the staff doth push their wares with haste.

Their cry doth ring: "For thy teeth's health, thou must,
Purchase our plans, our products, and our trust."
But nay, I seek not sales, nor empty boasts,
But facts, dear sirs, to keep my teeth in hosts.

Beware, good people, of this practice foul,
Whose aim doth seem to line their pockets full.
Their words doth contradict, their deeds doth show,
A lack of care for those who come and go.

A plague upon this den of dental woe,
Where profiteering doth reign, and patients know
But little peace, or rest, or respite from fear,
In this, the realm of dental duplicity so clear."

"Methinks I've visited this place thrice before,
For shopping and dining in yonder cafe.
Things I do like, in sooth, are these:
Food most delicious, healthy, and tasty,
A fair selection of healthy victuals,

But alas! There be things I do not like,
The service, prithee, doth leave much to desire,
For those who tend the cafe do seem to think
Their duty is to inconvenience the guest,
And thus their prices, though somewhat high,
Do stick within my craw, for they do not
Show respect or care for those who pay.

In sooth, I say, their service doth stink,
And thus their prices do seem less fair,
For though their food be good, their ways
Do make me loathe to come again, I swear."

Fellow Yelpers, I do confess,
Thou hast been misled by reviews of this place,
A victim of false praise, alas, I do profess.

The heat within did swelter, nigh unbearable,
And odors of a full grease trap did fill the air,
A scent most foul, that doth assault mine senses fair.

Quick service, it didst claim, yet slow it didst prove,
Ten minutes passed ere we couldst order, then didst wait,
Another twenty didst pass, our patience didst wear thin,
As we didst wait for food, our hunger didst abate.

Tomato soup, a taste quite good, yet cold it was,
A fault, methought, in such a simple dish, alack.
California Turkey, bread o'erflowing, a sin,
Yet otherwise, not bad, my taste didst incline.

My love, the Marketplace Turkey, open-faced,
Didst seem to please him well, a smile didst grace,
His visage, a delight, his satisfaction plain.

A single visit, ill-fated, mayhap,
Yet ne'er shall I return, such fate doth bring.

"My love, two winters past, didst take me thither,
After a feast most wondrous, at Bradley Ogden's bower.
But last eve, alas! Raos didst serve us such a mess,
A veal Parmesan, tough and oversalted, I didst confess,
Most vile and foul, that I could scarce partake.
My love, no more shall choose the place we dine,
For he must make amends, ere we depart this town,
And with a better feast, my wrath doth assuage."

"Alas, my children and I didst suffer a most vexing adventure at this establishment. The hospitality, I must confess, didst leave much to be desired. The victuals, alack, were most unpalatable, and the cost, in sooth, didst seem exorbitant. I didst command fajitas, and verily, the flavour didst resemble a most unpleasant chemical concoction. In conclusion, I must express my utter discontent and declare that I shall not again darken their doorstep."

"Hark! A Deli, they call it, but alas, 'tis not,
For where I hail from, Deli means a spot,
Where sandwiches and such are sold, a place to dine,
But here, they call it Deli, yet it doth not confine
To what a Deli should be, a place of meat and bread,
Nay, 'tis a restaurant, full of fancy dishes, spread.

A pox upon them, for their deceitful ways,
Minus a star, for leading me astray,
Into believing I would find a true Deli,
But nay, 'twas naught but a restaurant, a lie.

And lo, they did not understand,
The meaning of no cheese and no mayo, oh so grand.
In my homeland, there be places galore,
That offer three slices of bread, and more,
They be called diners, not delis, I say,
For they provide a feast, in a different way.

And thus, with only three tables to tend,
I did expect a server, more attentive, to amend
My empty tea cup, and provide more napkins,
For mayonnaise and cheese, they did occupy the original tokens.

But nay, the owner/manager, didst delay,
His thanks, until we were a hundred feet away,
A poor show, indeed, and not so bright,
Leaves me in doubt, if this non-Deli Deli, be worth the fight."

"A plague upon this place, I say,
For prices high and food but average pay.
Two bits of bruschetta, eight dollars dear,
I'll take my business elsewhere, 'tis clear.
A gift card, they would not accept, alack,
For cocktails, which did my spirits lack.
Much better places there be, to dine and delight,
So farewell, HH, forevermore, goodnight."

"Methinks I've visited this establishment twice,
In the early days of its opening, I did partake
Of their luncheon fare, and found it to be fair,
But the cost, oh so steep! I didst decide to wait
And give them time to settle, to see if 'twould improve.

This eve, I didst return, with mine own family,
To partake of their evening repast,
But alas, the food, though fair, didst not impress,
The price, oh so high! My daughter, but a babe,
Didst request a small bowl of noodles, plain and simple,
But the server, with a frown, didst point to a dish
Of spaghetti and meatballs, at six dollars the cost,
And children's meals, without drink, at six dollars also,
A tiny cup of chocolate milk, two dollars seventy-five,
A price, methinks, most steep and quite unfair.

The busboy, with haste, didst clear our plates away,
Twice, ere we had finished, and my water glass,
Refilled but newly, he didst take away,
As if we had no need of it, nor wish to stay.
My husband's meal and mine, both fair and good,
But the price, oh so high, didst leave us feeling poor.
'Tis a shame, for I had hoped to find this place
A worthy substitute for Cork, but nay, 'tis not so."

"Hark! What manner of man doth work within this place?
A scowl upon his visage doth he wear with grace.
Each time I venture in, his mood doth sour,
And once, his anger did provoke a tear.
I wished the maiden there had left with me,
For his harsh words did pierce mine ears so keenly.
Twice have I witnessed him, with rudeness great,
Address the folk who stood before my seat.
A villain, through and through, this man doth seem,
Yet still, I give this place two stars, forsooth,
Since 'tis beneath my work, and cheap, indeed,
And should my comrades seek a slice, they need
But ask, and forthwith shall my hawaiian pie be freed."

"O, land of brew most vile and dear!
A score of dollars for a bottle, 'tis quite queer.
If not for need of fortitude to bear
The woeful tunes and lecherous stare,
I would not pay such sum, 'twould be most rare.
But lo, I deem this place my future lair,
When faith in man and virtue doth decay,
And all good hope doth flee, then shall I repair
To this, my haven, and drown my sorrow in its ale."

Fare thee well, fair friends! I do declare,
The victuals here, they did not please mine eye.
Forsooth, I hail from San Francisco's shore,
Where Vietnames' delights doth reign supreme, no more.

In search of sustenance, we didst stray
From casinos' grasp, to this humble way.
I ordered Pho Ga, a broth most fine,
But lo, the taste, it didst leave much to design.

The spring rolls, they were but passable,
A mediocrity, in sooth, most terrible.
Pho, a dish divine, doth rise or fall
By broth's richness, and here, 'twas naught but gall.

'Tis true, the site, convenient it doth lie,
Near to the Strip, a haven for the eye.
Yet, as a meal, this place doth not suffice,
For authentic flavors, seek elsewhere, my advice.

"A fair estate, yet last we stayed, o'erbooked were they. Arriving late, we found naught but woe, Our reservation, empty words, no room to show. They claimed o'ercommitment, bade us seek elsewhere, A twenty-minute journey, to a new lodging to bear. What vexation! My spouse, a meeting at the JW did attend, So rose he early, next morn, to make the journey's end. And I, our belongings, back to JW did move."
"Pshaw! I was not taken by its charms, good sir. 'Twas but a middling Thai feast, and naught to write home about. I wouldst not grace its doors again, for there be better fare at Thai House, yonder."

"Today, my love and I didst dine at Fago de Chao, a place of feast and revelry, to celebrate our anniversary. Alas, the meal didst not live up to our expectations, for the meat was overcooked and dry. The salad bar, however, didst boast a bounty of fresh and varied delights. One of the servers, a kind and gentle soul, didst grant me a tour of the kitchen and brought us a sweet dessert to mark the occasion. Methinks, for the high prices charged, the main course shouldst have been cooked to perfection, juicy and tender. Alas, we shall not return to this establishment, for there are better options to be found."

"Verily, a sorry sight doth greet mine eyes within this hall of victuals. Alack, the fare provided doth fall far short of that which I have known in fair Las Vegas. Fie upon the cooks who doth prepare such meagre sustenance! Yet, praise be to the servers, for their mien doth bespeak a certain friendliness and grace. Alas, their efforts doth but serve to highlight the dearth of culinary prowess on display."

"Alas, my dearest cupcake shop, how couldst thou falter so? Alack, thy sweet delights didst fail to impress, despite thy cozy confines and friendly staff. Thy cupcakes, priced in line with others, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain...oomph! They seemed but mere homemade fare, a tad too dry for mine own liking. Alas, I must confess, my heart was heavy with disappointment. Forsooth, I've tasted finer confections elsewhere, and thus, cannot recommend thy baked treats with zeal. Yet, still, thy charming atmosphere doth hold a certain appeal, should one desire a casual meet with friends o'er coffee. Fare thee well, dear cupcake shop, mayhap another time, when fortune doth smile upon thee."

"O, woeful service, marred by slow delivery,
Two hours, a wait most vexing and weary.
Their excuse, a claim of "family style,"
A notion quaint, but not so merry.

For sushi dude, a man of whims, doth bring
Orders forth, as fancy doth dictate.
But for the rest, a sorry plight,
Must wait, a thumb-twiddling fate.

And lo, the food, a mediocrity,
A culinary disappointment, verily.
Avoid this place, my friends, I pray,
Lest ye suffer similar dismay."

"Alas, I shouldst have perused the reviews ere choosing this place, shame upon mine own head! Verily, 'twas as though we were within a daycare, save for the delectable burgers they didst serve. Wailing infants, unruly toddlers, elders scampering down the aisles, inattentive parents, and an unholy cacophony didst assail mine ears. Alas, though their burgers were tasty and reasonably priced, we shall ne'er return to this place, not wishing to suffer such chaos once more."

"Hark! We did enquire of the house wine's quality,
And were informed 'twas good, a fine vintage indeed.
But alas, our hopes were soon to be dashed,
For the wine we sipped, did not meet our needs.

The pizza, a dish of savory delight,
Did please our taste buds, with its toppings so bright.
But the service, oh how it did fail,
Leaving us to wait, with naught but bale.

In conclusion, the food did satisfy,
But the service, left much to be desired, by and by."

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,
This place doth not impress, alas,
The oxtail soup, with fat so bright,
Did seem like it had seen a freezer's light.
And loco moco, oh how it failed,
To please my taste, its flavor so pale.
Ice tea, naught but sugar's watery brew,
No tea flavor could I sense anew.
I shall not return, my friends, farewell."

"Hark! In fair Phoenix, where the sun doth shine bright,
A tale of woe doth unfold, a sorrowful sight.
A car wash, named Full Circle, doth boast of its might,
Yet, alas! Its waters, unfiltered, doth leave a blight.

A traveler, seeking refuge from the heat of day,
Didst venture forth, his carriage to array.
But lo! The attendants, careless in their duty,
Doth leave the mirrors soapy, and water spots aplenty.

And thus, the traveler, with a heavy heart,
Must break out the quick detailer, and play his part.
A microfiber cloth, to wipe away the grime,
And make his carriage, once again, shine like the prime.

Oh, Full Circle! How art thou fallen from grace?
