To charge four crowns, and yet, no filtered water in place?
A careless wash, indeed, doth leave much to be desired,
And thus, this traveler doth voice his discontent, and fire.

Shall we, dear friends, accept such laxity?
Nay! Let us demand, with one voice, clarity!
For cleanliness, and care, doth make a world of difference,
In the realm of car washes, let us raise our standards, and dispense."

"Verily, I do not comprehend the appeal of this establishment. 'Tis a place that doth reek of past glories, and yet, doth charge a pretty penny for a meal most foul. The pizza, in sooth, doth lack the flavor and doth leave a greasy film upon thy tongue. The interior, alas, hath not been updated since the days of yore, and thus, doth show the signs of wear and tear. In faith, 'tis a place best avoided, lest thou desirest a culinary disappointment."

"Pray tell, good sir or madam, doth thou claim this pizza to be the finest thou hast tasted? Fie upon such falsehood! 'Tis but a middling fare, o'erpriced and lacking in quantity. A slice of cheese, scarce worth the coin, doth hardly suffice to fill a hungry belly. Nay, twain slices, costing near ten crowns, doth leave me in dismay. Alas, poor soul, to pay so dear for scanty victuals! Hie thee hence, my friend, and shun the error I did make by partaking of this pizza."

"Hark! What's this? A Korean grill, they call it Seoul,
But alas, the portions, small they were, I do declare.
A plate of meat, so meager, it did seem,
And for a Korean feast, most unbecoming, methinks.

The rice, a separate dish, oh woe is me!
For in a Korean restaurant, full bellies we should see.
But nay, they had not much, their menu a sham,
A few beers, Japanese, their selection quite slim.

A pox upon this place, a fake, a fraud, a sham,
For Korean BBQ, it doth not live up to its name.
The owners, young whelps, their elders would be ashamed,
Koreans, so embarrassed, their heritage profaned.

I shall not return, no more shall I darken their door,
For Seoul Korean Grill, a mockery, a farce, a bore.
But one thing, I must confess, the doenjang, so sweet,
A saving grace, a gem, in this culinary defeat."

On Sunday, the crowd did swarm and throng
This place of gastronomic delight,
Perhaps, 'twas the churchgoers, who did wrong
Their hunger pangs, and sought this sight.

A green salad, dressed in ginger sauce so bright,
Did please my taste buds, with its sweet delight.
And shrimp, pan-fried in pockets, oh so right,
I wished for special sauce, to make it tight.

But alas, the chicken and veggies, so cold,
As if the chef had forgotten, to unfold
The microwave's power, to heat it up, so bold,
We sent it back, and the waiter, did unfold

The manager, a man of import, did come,
And said the grilled chicken, would take some time,
Due to the weather, perhaps, or so he'd assume,
But steaming hot, the Ma-la shrimp and chicken did consume.

The grilled chicken, with barbecue sauce, so fine,
Did make up for the wait, and the service, divine.
The food, at least three notches up, on a scale of ten,
Priced fairly, for the quality, and value, given.
Service, just fair, but the food, did make amends,
For a dining experience, that did transcend.

"Methinks 'twas a mixed bag, my visit hither,  
With pros and cons in equal measure, I do reckon.  
The staff, kind and courteous, didst take the time  
To learn my name, and scheduling, a breeze didst find.  
A thorough examination of my teeth and gums didst they make,  
From oral cancer screening to cavity detection, no stone unturned didst they leave.  
And, five years since my last cleaning, no fuss didst they make.  
But lo, they told me of seven cavities, a pricey gum treatment didst require,  
I thought it somewhat excessive, and sought a second opinion,  
A needless expense, it seemed, for my wallet, a burden to bear.  
So, gentle reader, take heed, and beware of needless procedures,  
Lest thou be taken advantage of, and thy coin purse be drained."

"A wedding didst bring me to this place,
And though the chamber was not so bad,
The water closet didst make such a noise,
As if 'twere trying to wake the dead.

I opened up the tank, to see if I
Could quiet it, and found a sight most strange,
The fill valve had not been changed in years,
A sign of neglect, or laziness, I fear.

They have a scheme, they call it "Eco",
Whereby thou mayst decline fresh linens,
And in return, receive a token worth five dollars,
To spend on food and drink, they say.
But beware, fair traveler, for they do not tell thee,
That this token cannot be used on ale or wine,
The bartender, he should have said, with grace,
"I cannot take this, but for thee, I shall,"
And from his tip, he should have given thee,
Five dollars back, for good customer service,
But instead, he left a foul taste in my mouth,
And now, I do complain, in this review.

Another thing, about this five dollar prize,
Is that housekeeping doth not visit thy room,
No fresh coffee cups, nor coffee, nor even,
Glasses, made of glass, but cheap, plastic things,
For the price of the room, and their "Eco" ways,
Surely, they could provide some proper glasses.

The location, good, a short walk to other places,
But parking, pricey, yet not unreasonable,
In this, a major city, downtown, they say.
So, stay, if thou must, but beware of these things,
And hope that they shall change, for the better, ere long."

"Hark! This morn, my heart doth crave Vietnamese fare,
A change from usual breakfast, I do declare.
I order spring rolls and pork meatballs, 'twas my whim,
The former, naught special, but latter, quite sublime.

A BBQ meatball salad, it seemed, with veggies galore,
And rice paper wraps, hard as stone, I knew not what to do.
Water, I requested, to soften them, I pray,
For such a quantity of greens, I could not stay.

A BBQ pork bowl, I thought I had ordered, fair,
But lo, the same setup, with lettuce, herbs, and bare.
Two slider patties, it seemed, and pork, oh so sweet,
But portion size, a problem, my hunger to greet.

The taste, it pleased me well, no doubt, no doubt,
But meat to lettuce ratio, a rabbit's shout.
Next time, perhaps, the pho, I shall essay,
For in it, lettuce, I hope, doth not come into play."

"Hark! A 12-inch tuna sub didst thou order, good sir?
By my troth, the sandwich maker didst go out of her way,
To ensure thou didst not receive any extra tuna, I say.
She scraped the excess from the scoop, with great disdain,
And cast it aside, like a worthless, wretched thing.
A 12-inch tuna sub, with meal deal, didst cost thee $13.00,
The most expensive thou hast ever bought, I do reckon.
Never again, at this location, shalt thou set foot,
Forsooth, 'tis a place of great expense, and little worth, I do suspect."

"A plush bed didst await me, yet a cup of brew didst not greet me in the morn. Alack, I didst forget mine own pillow, and he who tended the counter didst refuse to send aid. Fie upon thee, poor service indeed! And lo, the buffet didst shut its doors for renovations, without a word to us who booked our stay. Another tavern we wouldst have sought, had we known ere now. Alas, two stars doth this inn receive, for soft the bed didst lie, else naught but one star wouldst it have gained."

"Verily, a birthday feast we didst partake,  
For my dear cousin, 'twas a wondrous sight.  
Pizza Margherita, oh how grand,  
The mozzarella, a taste most divine.  
But alas, the service, a sorry plight,  
Our waitress, Victoria, a lack of might.  
Plates uncleared, a petty slight,  
No free dessert, a miserly sight.  
And thus, we waited, forty-five minutes long,  
For five separate checks, a tedious song.  
A night of joy, turned to dismay,  
Two hours and a half, we didst stay.  
Even the owner, with wine in hand,  
Didst ignore us, a sorry band.  
So off we went, to Burrito Express,  
Where kindness and speed, didst address."

"Methinks I once did cherish visits to yon burrito den,
For their victuals were far superior, fresh and neat.
But late, alas! Their service doth decline,
And with it, the quality of their culinary feats.

Last time, I didst suffer o'er-salting of my meal,
Yet gave them benefit of doubt, a gentle soul.
Today, my wrap was rolled with nary a care,
Air pockets galore, and chicken nowhere near.

I do confess, my order doth always stay the same,
Pollo asado, my heart doth crave naught else.
But still, a sign of woe, a harbinger of doom,
Doth this establishment need a change, anon!

Cleanliness, too, doth seem to flee away,
Alack! What sorrows doth my heart now sway?
I do beseech thee, good sirs, heed my plea,
Hire new folk, and cast aside the old, 'tis thee I pray."

"Verily, I have visited this establishment oft in days past. Alas, the sole drawback of this place is its exorbitant cost, a sum most excessive for the meagre offerings it doth provide. In sooth, 'tis wiser to spend thy time and coin at other venues, lest thou wish to squander thy riches on naught but mediocrity. Fare thee well, good sir!"

"A pox upon this bank, a plague upon its halls,
That cares not for the customer's gentle calls.
I sought to leave the big four, and thus didst choose
This institution, hoping for a better voice.
But alas, my hopes were dashed, my expectations naught,
For after an hour's wait, no service didst I aught.
My savings account, inaccessible by arm,
And check prices, outrageous, a bitter charm.
No personal banker there, to bid me adieu,
Nor asked they why, my accounts I didst anew.
A terrible bank, subpar in every way,
I'll ne'er return, nor shall I e'er stay."

"Alack, fair maiden, hear my tale of woe,
Of nail salon visit, that did not go well, thou know.
The pros, they be, in number three,
Cleanliness, speedy service, price, quite reasonable, doth agree.

But alas, dear friends, the cons, they doth abound,
Uncleanly practices, bubbles found,
No hand-washing, nails not properly placed,
Thinned on the sides, my request, not fully embraced.

Yet still, I paid, and tipped, with grace,
For neatness, at first glance, doth show its face.
Mayhap, another time, my luck will change,
And nail salon visit, will not range,
In mediocrity, but in excellence, it shall dwell,
With service good, and nails, well-done, and swell."

"Hark! What shenanigans have transpired here? A change of name, perchance? And with it, all decorum fled! In days of yore, this place was known as Rah, and men were mannerly, their apologies forthcoming should they bump into thee. But now, alas! 'Tis naught but savagery, a lair for beasts, where rotten banana daiquiri doth waft beneath thy nostrils, four feet away, and some knave doth holler for thee to dance with him! Nay, drink thou plenty of strong spirits, lest thou recall the night thou didst take to the floor with Rico "Suave," he of two left feet and a sport jacket drenched in aramis cologne!"

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from mine own lips,
Of service poor, and manners none too nice.
In fair Las Vegas, where bright lights doth shine,
A group of four did gather, eager to dine.

Our waiter, sour of mood, didst serve us slow,
And ere we finished salads, food did arrive,
As if 'twere pre-cooked, and not worth the wait.
No plates were provided, till we didst ask,
And beverages unrefilled, save we didst beg.

The table, cluttered with used dishes, didst grow,
As our server, with nary a care, didst stack,
In our faces, no finesse, nor grace didst show.
All service, in slow motion, didst seem to go,
And oft we were ignored, left to ponder and sigh.

But one thing, they didst with haste, I must confess,
The check, dropped swiftly, with nary a fuss or mess.
Alas! No thanks, from staff, didst we receive,
Though we, in courtesy, didst thank them, as 'twere our leave.

Farewell, dear restaurant, with service so poor,
We shall not return, nor recommend thee more."

"Hark! The estate doth undergo renovation,
A process that doth take some time, no doubt.
Perhaps 'tis wise to choose another place,
Until they've finished and all's in order.
Then, wait awhile, and read the reviews anew,
To see if 'tis fit for thy purpose, fair one,
And if it pleaseth thee, then make thy move,
And may good fortune be thy guide, my friend."

"A lengthy tale of woe, I had in mind,
But deemed it not worthwhile, so left it behind.
My spouse and I, this Outback didst try,
Three times in seven moons, yet still didst fly.
Nevermore shall we return, 'tis plain,
For our patience hath been worn in vain."

"Hark, good sir, I pray thee, bring to me  
A cheeseburger, with bacon, if thou wouldst be so kind.  
The man behind the counter, with girth so great,  
Didst correct me, with a haughty, lofty mind.  
"Paradise bacon cheeseburger," quoth he,  
As if I were a fool, unlearned in their ways.  
I nodded, with a smile, and said, "Sounds good,  
With ranch, for my fries, if thou wouldst be so bold."  
He took my coin, with a scowl, and a snide remark,  
As if he didst me a favor, with his every word and action.  

The burger, when it came, was fair, not great,  
Better than fast food, but not worth the wait.  
The fries, they were decent, but the "ranch," alack,  
Was naught but a poor excuse for a potato salad, I fear.  
I went to the cooler, seeking a remedy,  
But the man, with a scowl, didst protest, "Ranch, it be!"  
I shook my head, and sighed, and left the place,  
With a heavy heart, and a bad taste in my mouth, by the grace.  

Fie upon this place, and the land-blimp who doth own it,  
For their service, it doth leave much to be desired, I do admit.  
But still, I shall return, for the burger, it doth call,  
And I, a fool, shall answer, though I know full well,  
Their ranch, it doth not exist, and their customer service,  
Doth leave much to be desired, and doth not impress."

"Fast and cheap, a manicure most neat,
But relaxing, alas, it was not, I do confess.
Upsells did abound, my patience did test,
Gel nails, white tips, paraffin dip, pedicure, at best.

A quick manicure, my lunch hour did crave,
My cuticles, healthy, I did wish to save.
Sweet, my nail tech, her skills did show,
But others, loud, their chatter did flow.

Credit cards, they say, they do accept,
But signs, clear, the cost, higher, did inspect.
Stick to your guns, and tune out the fray,
For $9.99, a decent manicure, you may.

Elsewhere, I would search, I do declare,
For peace and quiet, without the glare."

"O, woe is me! My pizza, once so fair and bright,
Now lies before me, burnt beyond all light.
And my husband's meatball sandwich, a paltry sight,
A mere morsel, fit for children's appetite.
We stood aghast, our faces filled with dismay,
At such a pitiful display. Alas, I say,
The salads here, they tell me, are quite fine,
Perhaps I should have chosen one of them, in design."

"Forty-five minutes didst pass ere our victuals did arrive,
The younglings, Mac and Cheese didst crave, my wife, salmon didst choose,
And I, the spicy tuna roll didst savor,
But why the delay, no reason didst they show,
An apology and free Mac and Cheese didst they bestow,
Alas, we shall not return, for service here hath been woe."

"A steakhouse of woe, this place didst not appeal,
But hunger drove us to its door, alack!
The atmosphere was dull, the food uninspired,
Overpriced, it was, and underwhelming, quite dire.

An antipasto platter, with naught but store-bought fare,
Bland hummus, baba, and pita, oh so bare.
My wife's burger, good, but lacking salt, I say,
And my lobster linguini, oh how it didst fray!

Overcooked, the lobster, and pasta, too,
Chewy, it was, like a piece of toughened shoe.
The service, also, didst leave much to be desired,
Sleepwalking, the waiters, as if in a tired haze.

Alas, a poor choice, indeed, we didst make,
For this zombie steakhouse, a mistake, didst partake."

"Wendy's, a chain of fast food renowned, doth stand apart from others of its kind. A salad, a healthier choice, doth grace their menu, and their burgers, fresh and full of flavor, do please my taste. But alas, this particular branch doth falter in its execution. My salad, once a symbol of vitality, doth arrive wilted and brown, a sorry sight indeed. And the service, devoid of passion or cheer, doth leave much to be desired."

"Methinks the twain celestial bodies doth shine so bright,
A wondrous sight, a feast for mine eyes,
Upon the trio of rivers, and yonder town,
A fair prospect, most divine.

The interior, methinks, doth leave much to be desired,
Alack, the bread, a pale imitation of the real,
And yonder salad, passable, yet naught to boast,
The dressing, a saving grace, a worthy find.

Alas, the olives, but canned, and tomato, past its prime,
The broth, a mediocrity, a watery mess,
The veal, a trifle dull, and lacking in zest,
The chicken, naught but fowl, and ketchup, a sorry guest.

Desserts, a disappointment, a sad display,
Creme brûlée, too runny, and lacking in charm,
Chocolate cake, cold, and tasting of the fridge,
A dismal end, to our evening's culinary quest.

Service, a sorry state, a lack of care,
Refills, a constant request, an unneeded chore,
A view, most fair, yet not enough to stay,
We shall not return, another hill we'll climb."

"Our recent sojourn at the Flamingo, alas, hath left me in a state of woe, my dear. The Drais nightclub, with its constant beat and revelry, didst keep me from my restful slumber, yea, until the break of dawn. And though our rooms were graced with beauty, the price we paid for such a view was too great, methinks. Forsooth, we shall seek another lodging, where quietude doth reign supreme. Farewell, Flamingo, thou art a gem, but thy nightclub doth mar thy charm."

"In Chinatown, we chanced upon a Korean BBQ place,
A rarity, we thought, and thus, our hopes did raise.
But alas, 'twas not meant to be, forsooth,
For all our plans were foiled, and our night did lose its sheen.

The meat, we thought, the fun part of the feast,
To cook it ourselves, and thus, our hunger appease.
But nay, the server said, 'twould taste better,
If they, in the kitchen, did it, and not we, the plodder.

The Grandmother's Special, next, we did ordain,
But lo, they brought the wrong dish, and our hopes did wane.
They grilled the wrong meat, and we did wait,
Until they realized their mistake, and did abate.

And when, at last, the right food did arrive,
Our joy was short-lived, for our cooking, they did deprive.
With tongs, they took, and cooked the meat themselves,
Leaving us, in disappointment, and with no selves.

And to cap it all, a stench did fill the air,
From the kitchen, a sewer-drain overflow, so foul and fair.
We swiftly did depart, with haste, and no delight,
For such a scent, did mar our appetite, and put us to flight."

"My friends didst visit this establishment for a romantic evening, and brought me a meal to-go.  His steak, he didst enjoy, I do confess.  But alas, her fried pickles, they were not crispy, made with poor quality pickles, I do suspect.  The ribs, they were quite good, I must admit.  The pulled pork, it was tender, but oh so dry, I do declare.  The garlic mashed potatoes, they were passable, at best.  And the creamed corn, it was most delicious, I must confess.  Yet, overall, 'twas but a mediocre feast, and she doth vow, never to return, I do perceive.

And my own repast, a beef brisket sandwich, with macaroni and cheese, it didst consist.  But lo, the bread, it was not as depicted on their website, in a different form, it came to be.  And the meat, so tender, yet so bland and dry, it didst taste.  The macaroni and cheese, oh so spicy, I couldst not consume more than a single bite, for jalape\u00f1o, it didst assault my taste buds.  No warning, there was, of its fiery nature, I do protest.  A disappointment, it truly was, and I wouldst not recommend this place, to any, I do swear."

"Hark, good sir! The name doth seem to be,
Cous Cous now, and not what it did be.
New owners and chefs, I do perceive,
And oh, how the lamb burger doth grieve!
The spices, once a delight, now doth wane,
And I, in truth, do doubt my return again.
Forsooth, the last two cashiers I didst meet,
Didst leave me in disfavor, full of discreet."

"Pray tell, good sir, thou must obtain  
The Palms Club card, lest thou desirest to pay  
A pretty penny for thy meal, I ween.  
'Tis the sole reason I would recommend  
Dining here, for the club prices bequeath  
A savings most generous, indeed, 'tis true.  
Now, as for the victuals, I must confess,  
They were but ordinary, nay, not the best.  
My late night breakfast, thus, did unfold,  
With bacon strips, alas, too small, yet cooked  
To a tender crunch, with flavor, methought,  
Average, at best. My eggs, scrambled soft,  
Were prepared with skill, I must avow.  
And wheat toast, 'twas neither too thin nor too thick,  
But betwixt, a happy medium, I do declare.  
Yet, the home fries, oh, how they did disappoint,  
Fried potato bits, with naught but grease to show,  
And thus, their taste, alack, was naught but woe."

"O, woe is me! A Jamba Juice on campus doth sound so sweet,
But alas, 'tis naught but bitter disappointment that doth greet.
The quality of drinks, mediocre at best, doth pale in comparison
To service most foul, by surly servant, with nary a smile nor station.
He doth ignore the customers, or with rudeness doth address,
And other workers, with faces most glum, doth seem to be oppressed.
The location, cramped and small, doth cause much confusion,
With naught a soul to guide the lost, nor answer questions with illusion."

"Hark! What vibe doth Le Cartet possess? 
Awesome decor, with castor-like bulbs aglow, 
Cutouts of maps, and poinsettias in tow. 
A buzzy place, indeed, for brunch or lunch, I do avow. 
But alack! The service doth leave much to be desired, 
No greeting, nor offer of drink, my heart did ignite. 
I had to ask for specials, and so I didst declare, 
My wish for sustenance, a salmon sandwich to share. 
A decent meal, but not what I didst expect, 
A creamy mishmash, more like tuna, I didst detect. 
Overpriced, with naught but a small salad in sight, 
For fifteen coins, a price most unseemly, I doth recount. 
And thus, my friends, I say with naught but truth, 
Le meh, a place not worth the journey, save for youth. 
But still, the ambiance doth make it worth a visit, 
Or perchance, something in the market to purchase, anon. 
So, there you have it, my friends, a tale of woe, 
Of Le Cartet, a place not quite up to the go."

"O, crustaceans, how ye vex me so!
With thee, my options are but few,
A small kit of tools, with care and slow,
To extract thy meat, my aim doth pursue.

But lo, I am no spy, nor skilled,
And thus, my methods are quite unrefined,
I poke and prod, with fork and knife,
And still, thy meat doth elude my grasp, like life.

In frustration, I resort to force,
Ripping thee apart, without remorse,
Yet, when inside, I find but little meat,
And strange, gelatinous organs, that doth defeat.

Twenty-five dollars, for such a prize?
Nay, I shall not return, nor would I advise,
For though thy flavor be sweet and fair,
The trouble doth outweigh the taste, I swear.

Farewell, Hole In The Wall Crab Shack,
Thy name doth suit thee well, methinks,
For thou dost leave a hole in my wallet,
And a memory that doth linger, and doth sting.

Yet, mayhap someday, I shall return,
To sample other dishes, and to learn,
If thou hast any, that doth please,
And bring me joy, without such tease."

"Hark, what news is this? A steakhouse in fair Las Vegas,
That doth run out of steak, and other dishes fair,
And doth not offer apologies with heart sincere.
'Twas but eight o'clock, and not a bustling crowd,
Yet still they failed, with nary a word avowed.
Alack, for those who sought a savory feast,
Methinks 'twill be a fortnight ere they find a treat.
But fear not, dear friends, for there be many a place
In this fair city where steak doth grace the plate."

"A fair assortment of dishes, and victuals of a sort, yet those who run this establishment are most parsimonious, and strive to curtail thy choice of finer fare at every opportunity. And should thou not finish thy plate, clean of sushi rolls that didst not please thee, they shall charge thee extra, by my troth! 'Tis folly, I say, and naught but greed that doth drive them to such heights of expectation. Tip them not, good sir, for they do not deserve it. Seek out other places, and let this one fade into obscurity."

"Methinks 'twas an ill-fated night, my friends,
For though we numbered nine, our feast did end
In disappointment. Steak, the main event,
Did fail to impress, its quality bent.

The potatoes, mashed and filled with sea,
Were deemed most excellent, a tasty spree.
But alas! The ribeye, so dearly sought,
Did lack the juiciness, the tenderness thought.

Cooked medium rare, as requested, yet
It seemed more medium, dry and not neat.
No marbling fat, the texture coarse,
A grainy feel, a taste not worth the force.

Now, I, a man of simple taste,
Do savor all, from In N Out to haste.
But this experience, so unexpected,
Left me in wonder, my joy unconnected.

Aye, I've had ribeyes, far better,
At a third the price, a true treasure.
So, to another place, I shall incline,
Lest I again encounter such a decline."

"Alas, my heart doth yearn for savory delight,
But lo, this place doth fail to ignite.
Alack, the parking lot doth lay empty,
And now I know the reason, 'tis quite plain to see.

Their chicken, dry and flavorless, doth leave me cold,
The sauce, a mere condiment, doth not unfold.
My own BBQ sauce, made with love and care,
Doth far surpass the stuff they serve here.

The ribs, a mediocrity, doth not impress,
The brisket, fatty and unpleasant, doth distress.
The pork, with strange aftertaste, doth not agree,
And sides, poorly seasoned, doth not delight me.

The pickles, breaded and fried, doth have some charm,
But dipped in ranch, they doth become quite disarm.
The atmosphere, akin to diner's fare,
Doth not enhance the experience, I do declare.

In sooth, this BBQ joint, a disappointment true,
Doth not deserve a second visit, that's my cue."

"By Jove, what wretched soul wouldst commit such sin,
To place sweet relish on a burger, full of woe?
A burger, mind thee well, that doth already bear
The weight of dill pickles, plump and fresh as air.
I, a humble bard, do swear upon my heart,
That I do love pickles with a passion's start;
But sweet relish, nay, 'tis a vile concoction,
That doth pollute the taste, with its sickening emotion.
So, there you have it, good sir or madam,
My review of this establishment, in brief cam;
Two stars, forsooth, for curly fries most fine,
And Cherry Coke, a drink divine, yet not divine enough,
To make me forget the sweet relish's bitter brine."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall us here,
At Krispy Kreme, where sweet donuts do appear.
We came upon this place, with hope so bright,
To bear two boxes home, on Black Fri-day night.

But lo, the lady who didst assist,
Was rude and gruff, with naught a kiss.
No matter the shift, or long the day,
A smile, a pleasant word, doth make the way.

And then, a man, with mop in hand,
Didst clean the floor, with water grand.
The donuts lay, exposed to view,
Upon the machine, in plain sight, anew.

The labels mismatched, our queries raised,
And she, with lengthy speech, our patience drained.
We sought the donuts, hidden from the gaze,
Behind the glass, in safety, didst amaze.

Alas, we shall not return, again,
For here, our experience didst attain
The worst, the poorest, of them all,
In Krispy Kreme, our trust didst fall."

Alas, what woeful fate hath befallen this place?
I visited here awhile, and fond memories did grace
My mind, of joy and laughter, free from sorrow's trace.
But now, alack, how changed doth this place appear!
In disrepair, with mildew, stains, and vapor's power
Doth falter, failing to bring forth its former cheer.
Oh, how my heart doth ache with deepest woe!
For naught but grief doth this once-pleasant site bestow.
No services didst I partake, yet still I feel
A heavy weight of woe, that doth my spirit steal.

"O, 5th and Wine, thy name doth please mine ear,
But alas, the service there did leave much to fear.
'Twas slow, oh so slow, and when we sought to pay,
The waiter's attention didst evade us, come what may.
Thirty minutes passed, and still we waited,
Until at last, we paid in cash, and quickly vacated.
The art upon the walls, a pleasant sight it was,
But my grilled cheese sandwich, with dressing most foul,
Didst taste of dishwater, a most awkward affair.
I wouldst not return, for there be better places near,
To dine and drink, and merrily pass the time, my dear."

"Pray, what ill fate didst befall my stomach, that this Pad Thai, a dish most foul and vile, didst cause mine gorge to rise? Forsooth, 'twas the first time in ten winters that my gut didst protest thusly. Alas, my wife's Cashew Chicken, a meal most bland and tasteless, didst earn but four stars from mine lips. Mayhap, fair traveler, thou shouldst journey onward to Naga, where Thai cuisine doth reign supreme."

"Hark, good sir! Doth thou offer stamps or ice with thy Snickers bar? Nay, I thank thee not, for they do not complement each other well. How sayeth thou, Circle K? 'Tis a foul place, full of unnecessary wares and overpriced fare. The workers of the land and builders of structures do frequent it, I reckon, for convenience's sake. Yet, two stars doth it earn, for its location maketh it a rare haven in these parts. And lo, Circle K hath corrected its mistake in charging too much for 5 Hour Energy drinks, by offering a special of two for five regal pieces or six silver coins, depending on the strength desired. Verily, a fair price, methinks."

"Methinks this store doth charge too dear a price,
For garb my babe shall wear but once or twice.
A onesie and pants, thirty dollars they did ask,
And for a toy, fifteen pieces of silver they did task.
At Ross, the selfsame garb I found for less,
Seven dollars and ninepence, a far fairer sum, I must confess.
The toys, too, were priced beyond my means,
Five dollars at Walmart, a better deal, it seems.
Their wares, though dear, do not impress,
A paltry choice of crib sets, alas, doth mess.
Online shopping, not my cup of tea,
Yet, methinks 'twould be a wiser choice, forsooth, to see.
A store for babes, with scanty crib sets,
Doth leave me in a state of woe and discontent."

"A pair of stars doth shine upon this place,
For its fair view doth make our spirits bright.
But, alas, the food didst not impress,
And thus, our joy didst take a sorry flight.

A drinking spot, they call it, and rightly so,
For in the morn, they serve breakfas', don't you know?
A vast menu, full of choices galore,
But we, in search of brekkie, didst explore no more.

I'd return, to sip cocktails on the patio,
And watch the fountain, with a merry heart, yea, verily.
But, for the grub, my friends, I do beseech thee,
Look elsewhere, lest thou be disappointed, as was I."

"Methinks I must be in a different place than yonder two years past,
Where fun and frivolity did reign supreme, and victuals of good taste
Were served at prices fair and reasonable. Alas, tonight I found
A burger of fifteen dollars, dry and flavorless, naught but woe.
My wife, with pulled pork, didst utter "meh," and thus didst say
The fare was mediocre, lacking zest and verve. The hall was dim,
Unclean, and void of mirth, yet still the serving folk were kind,
And thus I give this place two stars, and not but one, for their plight.
If thou art bound for this establishment, turn back, my friend,
And seek instead the hospitality of Jac's, or drive afar
To Gates and Brovi, where for equal coin thou shalt find
Fare better suited to thy taste, and cheer thy spirits high."

"Hark! If thou art unfamiliar with Dominican cuisine, as I, 'tis wise to peruse the menu ere thou doth step within the establishment. Five of us didst venture to Nanos, and four of us didst order Mofongo. Alas, but one of us didst receive the dish, for our server didst not take heed of our requests. They didst offer a plate of plain Mofongo as consolation, yet the damage was done. Our checks were jumbled, drinks upon the wrong tickets, and so forth. We didst think, 'Surely, the proprietors of Sabor and Three Amigos shall bring excellence to their newest venture.' Alas, 'twas not to be."

"Upon a night most fair, my spouse and I didst venture forth to this establishment, and verily, 'twas bustling with activity. The ornamentation, though somewhat tacky, didst not deter us from our quest for culinary delight. We didst share a salad of pears, alack, from cans they came, yet still, 'twas palatable. The special of the eve, beef cheeks, a dish most wondrous, didst fail to impress, forsooth, due to a sauce most heavy and overpowering. My spouse, he didst enjoy the lasagna, a dish most satisfying, and I, myself, didst partake of it more so than my own entree. Alas, the cost, most dear, didst not align with the quality of the fare. I do declare, Olive Garden, a place most humble, wouldst serve as well, if not better, at a price most reasonable."

"Alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
This deli doth leave much to be desired.
The kosher corned beef, so fatty and chewy,
Some parts exposed to air, did make me feel quite queasy.

And, by the stars, the girl who made my sandwich,
Did struggle with the meat, in such a plight,
She near pushed her finger into the wheel's embrace,
A fate most dire, and cause for great alarm and fright.

Ah, how I love to see a cook fuss o'er meat,
But not at risk of losing a digit, so neat.
The potato salad, alas, did lack all zest,
Leaving me unsatisfied, and still questing for the best.

In truth, this deli doth not compare,
To those I've known in NYC, Boston, or fair Cleveland's lair.
It doth but leave me yearning for the genuine article,
And thus, my friend, I shall seek out a better location."

"Eleven years have passed, my friend, since first I set forth on my business travels. Many an airport have I seen in my time, and Charlotte's own CLT doth leave much to be desired, particularly in the drop-off and pick-up areas. Pray tell, good sirs, expand the roads, that we may navigate with greater ease."

Thursday eve, I chanced upon this place,
To see if 'twould fill my craving's space,
For BBQ, a dish most wondrous fair,
In Kierland, where such food is rare.

A combo plate, with beans and fries,
I ordered, to test their culinary guise,
The beans, unremarkable, I must say,
But fries, in abundance, lacked the spice of day.

Brisket, with smoke ring, yet no bark,
Tasted more like pot roast, in the dark,
But pulled pork, saved the day,
With juices, rich, and sauce, applied, they say.

Tabasco, added, made it grand,
A flavor, rich, that took the land,
Three and a half stars, I would impart,
For pulled pork, with sauce, a work of art.

The place, empty, save for me,
Eight thirty, on a Thursday, did decree,
That Bobby Q's, at I-17 and Dunlap,
Is where you should go, your hunger to lap.

"O, how my heart doth ache with sorrow and woe,
For the service at Gallo Blanco didst go awry.
The server, a lazy lout, didst take his time,
To greet our table, and his face didst wear a frown.

We ordered drinks, but alas, they were out of stock,
Of Paloma margarita, dos x, and negro modelo.
We made do with an appetizer, while we didst wait,
But lo, another server didst drop our plate.

Our server, a man of little worth, didst disappear,
For twenty-five minutes, or mayhap more.
We ordered tacos, but they didst take their time,
And I didst ask the server, why the delay?

He said, with attitude, 'You should have ordered right,'
But I didst reply, 'How could we, when thou wert gone?'
The tacos came, but they were cold as ice,
And I didst tell him, 'Bring the Cajetas, and the check, make haste.'

But he didst bring the check, and not the dessert,
And I didst pay, and leave, with anger in my heart.
Oh, Gallo Blanco, how couldst thou hire such a man?
He was worse than a Wendy's order-taker, a sorry soul.
His belt was white, and it didst not match his attire,
And his eyes didst droop, as if he were on fire."

"Alas, how the mighty have fallen! This place, once a haven of delight, now doth pale in comparison to its former self. Our latest visit didst prove most dismal, for we didst have to return three dishes, each flawed in its own way. Tsk, tsk, what a shame! Forsooth, 'twas the nearest kin to Houston's, that famed eatery of renown, in all of Charlotte."

In fair Calabria's, a sight most fair doth lie,
With landscaping neat, that doth catch the eye.
The building, too, doth seem a wondrous sight,
And many a soul doth stop, to take delight.

But, alas! Within those hallowed halls,
A tale of woe doth unfold, forsooth.
For though the party room doth shine so bright,
The rest, methinks, doth suffer from a lack of light.

The service, good; the food, a feast for kings,
Yet, ambiance, nay, doth leave much to be desired.
So, for a party, mayhap, 'tis a place to seek,
But, as a whole, methinks, 'tis not worth the seek.

"A pox upon this pizza, say I!
'Tis naught but woeful mire and wretched pie.
The crust, a sorry sight, doth sag and droop,
Like autumn leaves that wither in the loop.

The sauce, a vile impostor, doth pretend
To be a sweet delight, but nay, 'tis naught but bitter end.
And toppings, oh, how they do disappoint!
Frozen and numb, they doth resemble naught but sorrow and despair.

But wait, what light through yonder window breaks?
A glimmer of hope, a ray of sunshine, a gleam of cheer!
For in the midst of this dire strait,
Doth lie a pizza, thin and crisp, a true delight.

Alas, 'tis rare, a fleeting dream,
A moment's joy, a flash of bliss, and then 'tis gone, alack!
But still, a glimmer of hope doth shine,
That one day, all pizzas shall be divine."

"Alack, my friends, what woeful tale I tell,
Of dining at the Bellagio, a place so swell,
Where stars of four or five, we did aspire,
But alas, our hopes, did soon expire.

The service, oh so spotty, full of flaws,
As large a party, we did make, with cause,
For busy hours, some mistakes, we could pardon,
But they, not crowded, were, with no excuse, to mourn.

The waiter, dropping off, with nary a care,
Our food, at random spots, without a prayer,
Of knowing who, had ordered what, with grace,
Leaving us to wonder, in this awkward space.

And timing, oh so poor, a woeful sight,
Dishes coming out, one or two at night,
So some, did watch, while others did eat,
A strange, and sorry plight, indeed, to meet.

The food, so pricy, yet not so divine,
The edamame, well seasoned, did shine,
But alas, not worth the cost, I do declare,
For other sushi places, on the Strip, I'll fare.

So heed my words, dear friends, and take my advice,
Avoid the Bellagio, a place of little price,
For better value, and a meal more fine,
Look elsewhere, and leave this place, behind."

A Sunday morn, I set an appointment at eight,
To start my day betimes and make it great.
But lo, the staff didst not arrive on time,
Their tardiness didst put me in a bind.

The receptionist, a lone soul, didst greet me,
But her cohorts, they didst tarry and slow.
Between eight ten and eight fifteen, they didst stroll in,
Their lack of promptness, it didst gall and vex me.

I do expect, of medical folk,
A greater sense of duty and decorum,
For they who tend the sick and injured,
Must be diligent and never slack.

So let this be a lesson, to all who can hear,
That punctuality is key, and lateness doth bring fear.

"Methinks 'tis hard to give a poor review,
For Sushi Factory's fare did please me well.
But somethings else, I cannot quite perceive,
Doth keep me from a rating high and swell.

A 2.5, then, shall be its score,
For friendly hostess and quick seating, I did adore.
The decor, alas, didst seem a bit awry,
But nay, I shall not dwell on such things, for fear of being too picky.

I did the AYCE with my dear date,
Who loved the fried dishes, but sashimi, didst not partake.
One roll did fall apart, and I didst feel dismay,
But sake, they brought, and all was well, come what may.

'Tis a decent place, but better ones there be,
In the valley, for AYCE sushi, thou shalt see."

"Methinks 'tis the second time I've come to this place,
And both times, chaos and disorganization did grace
Their halls, causing long waits and much vexation,
A plight most woeful, and a sorry situation.

I called and ordered, and waited patiently,
Thirty minutes passed, yet still no pizza could I see.
Another quarter hour didst tick by, ere at last,
My pie arrived, and oh, how my hunger did crave it so fast!

Alas, poor management doth mar their reputation,
For twice now, this hath been my sad experience.
The pizza, verily, was good, but at what cost?
Forsooth, I shall not come again, for such trouble doth not please."

"O, how the prices did inflate, and the victuals, they did not impress. A barren dining hall, devoid of guests, yet still they seated us in an ill-favored spot. The vodka, it did flow with stinginess, and the helpings, they were meager, indeed. Alas, 'twill not endure, this woeful tavern, past a twelvemonth, mark my words."

"Upon my second venture to Char, we doth drop two stars, alas! Forsooth, from yonder reviews, 'tis clear their cooks do roast the beef to hell and back. My burger, thrice-accursed, didst emerge o'ercooked, nay, verily, burnt to a crisp! If thou art unable, by law or inclination, to cook a burger to medium, prithee, confess! I shall then choose chicken, anon. Alack, my brisket burger, requested medium, didst arrive dry and flavorless, like a desert mummified. The onions, too, were raw, uncooked, a woeful sight. Yet, praise be, the tater tots, a worthy side, didst please mine taste. Service, once more, didst excel, and we didst sit upon the patio, blessed with gentle breezes, conducive to converse. Alas, good sirs, the service and ambiance cannot compensate for the consistent overcooking of beef. Farewell, I say, and may thy future meals be cooked aright!"

In sooth, this inn, though humble in its price,
Did boast of rooms both clean and nice.
A free breakfast, too, did they provide,
A generous gesture, worth our gratitude.

But lo, their Wi-Fi, free to all,
Did fail, and thus did cause a fuss.
And when I sought to rectify the matter,
The front desk clerk didst lose his temper.

With naught but anger in his voice,
He screamed at me, without a choice.
No offer made he to take my number,
And call me back, when he had slumber.

So now I must, with sighs and groans,
Deal with their corporate offices, loons.
A franchise, Super 8, alas,
Their hands are tied, their powers limited, alack.

Oh, how I wish, in hindsight bright,
Had stayed at Hilton Garden, a sight
More expensive, true, yet peaceful, too,
No needless strife, no endless pursuit.

"Fare thee well, dear friends! Forsooth, the victuals served at yonder eatery were naught but mediocre, a sorry sight indeed. Hasty and careless was the preparation, leaving much to be desired. Alas, our hopes for a pleasant dining experience nearby were cruelly dashed. Yet, mark thou well, the banana pudding didst stir within us a glimmer of delight. Verily, 'twas a solitary bright spot in an otherwise forgettable repast. Farewell, and may Fortune smile upon thy next culinary adventure!"

"Hark! A humble tavern we didst stumble upon,
Wherein we didst partake of victuals and drink.
The place, alack, didst seem a bit unkempt,
And chairs, with rents in their upholstery, didst shrink.
Our server, fair and diligent, didst toil,
With many tables, and ours, didst she beguile.
The wait, alas, didst drag, and Coca-Cola flat,
Didst leave me in a state of woe and discontent.
But lo! The British Burger, a feast most fair,
Didst fill my belly and delight mine taste.
My comrade's pulled pork sliders, a treat most rare,
Didst win her praise and cause her eyes to gleam.
In conclusion, thus, the food didst please,
But service, alack, didst leave much to be desired.
A bit of sprucing up, the dining room doth need,
To make it bright and welcoming, as 'twere a bower."

"Ho hum! Fare cooked well, ingredients fresh, yet flavors lacking, dishes unbalanced, too much of mushrooms, not enough of meat or eggs. Service slow, few patrons, waiting, waiting, waiting. Loos foul, not pleasant start or end to meal. We shall not return anon."

In fair Las Vegas, we didst venture to dine At Stratosphere's Top of the World, a place divine. For our last night in town, we didst decide To give this eatery a try, and didst not hide Our anticipation for the view, so grand And worth the visit, as we didst understand.

The Oasis Suite, we didst book with ease For less than 100 coins, a price most pleasing. But to the restaurant, we didst not find The path most direct, and asked for guidance twain.

Once seated, we didst partake in bread Most tasty, and wine to quench our thirst and feed Our appetites. My wife didst order well, A ribeye, though not the most memorable meal.

I didst choose the lobster bisque, not bad, But better I have had, and prawns, scallops, and lobster, a dish most fair. The roasted salad and scallops, they didst please, But lobster and shrimp, a foul fishy taste didst seize.

A memory, now I do recall, of crab legs, A bite of shoulder meat, and there, that taste most foul. We shall not return for food, but may, For the view, most fantastic, have a drink, come what may.

In town, there be better places, for the same price, A fact most true. The view, five stars, I do give, In fairness, 'tis a sight most wondrous and nice.

"O, how vexing 'twas to wait in line,
With BFs in tow, what a woeful sign!
Hoochie mamas, they did stroll on by,
While we, poor souls, did wait and sigh.

A $20 cover charge, we thought 'twas fair,
But lo, they asked for $40, oh dear!
Each, they said, must pay this sum,
Or leave, and thus, our night be done.

A bottled water, too, did cost a pretty penny,
Nay, nay, we did not wish to spend so freely.
The highlight of the night, a sight most rare,
Dave Chappelle and Chris Rock, we did prepare.

In line, we saw them, oh, what joy!
But alas, the club, did play a dirty employ."

"A pox upon those who sell Groupons, luring souls with promises of bliss, yet, once arrived, they upcharge thee for each and every thing that doth bring joy. A total turn-off, indeed! And thus, my friends, didst I find myself at Canyon Falls, with a Groupon in hand, expecting a massage most divine. The building, fair and grand, didst house a space for massage, larger than I hadst imagined. But lo, the therapist, with words of woe, didst dash my hopes, and with a mere 60 minutes, didst leave me still desiring a true massage. Alas, a disappointment, and ne'er shall I return."

"Verily, TAO Beach doth pale in comparison to other Vegas locales. Its diminutive size and throngs of daybeds do make it seem rather cramped, yet the cost, in truth, doth not break the bank. Alas, the murky waters do detract from the overall experience, I must confess. 

But lo, the true joy of TAO Beach doth lie not in its environs, but in the company one keepeth. In the company of dear friends, I didst find pleasure, despite the somewhat lacking ambiance. 

Once, I didst visit TAO Beach, but now, I have no cause to return."

"Alas, my dear friends, hear me tell of woe,
How once a five-star review, now but two,
My visits past, during restaurant week,
Didst bring forth feasts most fine and meek.

The service then, oh how it did impress,
A card received, in gratitude, 'twas sent,
But alack, my friends, the latest visit,
Didst leave much to be desired, nay, 'twas pitiful.

The waitstaff, fair maidens, didst seem,
To bear a grudge, against us, 'twas keen,
For though we ordered from the special menu,
Additional sides, we didst request, anon.

And lo, the food, to another table,
Was brought, by mistake, most vile and able,
And when we sought, our sweet dessert,
To-go boxes, we had to ask, with naught but hurt.

Oh, how the service, once so fine and fair,
Didst falter, and leave us in despair,
I fear, my friends, I shall not return,
To this, once, esteemed steakhouse, which doth burn."

"Hark! Last Friday eve, I chanced to see
The Wind Rises at this cinema, yea, verily.
A rating of two and a half stars doth seem fair,
But alas, they charge a premium, with nary a care.
So, two stars it shall be, by my reckoning.
Forsooth, I must up my stats, anon, 'tis true.

A pic of a dirty seat, most vile and base,
Didst thou behold? Fie upon it, what a disgrace!
Faux leather, worn and torn, a sight most sad,
Yet still, crumbs and stains did cling, like a curse, so mad.
$11, the cost of a ticket, oh how steep!
And $11 more, for popcorn and drink, didst thou keep?
A pox upon this place, that doth take and run,
With prices high, and service, poorly done.

Tourists, mayhap, do frequent this hall,
But locals, shun it, for the cost, standing tall.
My love, with AMC Stubs card, doth try,
To make use of it, ere it doth expire, by and by.

The picture and sound, were of good quality,
No fault found there, in truth, nor in verity.
But still, I say, Regal chain, doth reign supreme,
In comfort and worth, it doth outshine, serene."

"All's all vital, and vital's all,
For who wouldst build with naught but walls?
The builder, he doth know not where to start,
And so the building doth lack solidity,
And worth the price, it doth not justify.
The theme rooms, they doth look fine and fair,
But upon closer inspection, one doth find
Cause for dismay. The cook hath made a mess,
And in the pelt, a laus hath found its nest."

"Alack, my heart did sing with joy,
For this new place did open nigh,
Brickyard, where I oft doth stray,
And there, my hunger doth assay.

But woe betide, my eager soul,
For though 'twas quick, the service whole,
Did take some twenty minutes' space,
To prepare the meal, a sorry pace.

And when at last, the order came,
The box, alack, they had not gained,
So in a foil wrap, we did receive,
The pizza, cold, and most uncivil.

The cheese, it stuck, as if in scorn,
Unto the foil, and would not torn,
And thus, the dough, so hard and dry,
Did make the meal, most unsavory.

Alas, fair location, ill-fated fare,
I shall not visit thee again, beware!"

"Methought I'd find a wondrous Walgreens here,
In this fair location, convenient and near.
But lo, the place was cramped, o'erpriced, and dire,
The layout, too, did chafe, like a ill-fitting sire.

The prices, I couldst forgive, forsooth,
Due to its site, a prime and busy trove.
But nay, the layout, alack, did grieve,
Especially the checkout, a woeful reprieve.

And since the Venetian, yonder, doth charge
A king's ransom, for each small, trifling large,
I thought this place, in contrast, wouldst be
More reasonable, in price, for thee and me.

Alas, my hopes were dashed, my dreams did fade,
For this Walgreens, though well-placed, did not persuade."

"Alas, my dearest Las Vegas, how art thou fallen! 

In days of yore, a humble Vietnamese eatery didst thrive, 
A haven of flavor, packed to the rafters with delight. 
The pho, a savory brew, didst warm the cockles of mine heart, 
Fresh veg and noodles, a feast fit for a king, didst ignite. 

But lo, the curse of progress didst descend upon the place, 
And with it came a change, a shift in priorities, alas! 
The broth, once rich, didst lose its former glory, 
The prices rose, the service didst become most lax. 

Yet still, a glimmer of hope doth shine, a beacon in the night, 
For in the realm of Chinese cuisine, they doth hold sway. 
K.J. Kitchen, a haven of delight, doth reign supreme, 
A veritable palace of gastronomic joy, a gem. 

But alas, my friends, this place, once great, doth now but pale, 
A shadow of its former self, a mere reflection of its former glory. 
Saigon 8, a newcomer, doth rise, a star ascendant, 
A shining light, a beacon in the night, a haven of delight."

"Fare thee well, good sirs and madams! Hark, what news I bring, of victuals most divine, yet service most vile and wretched. Verily, I say unto thee, shouldst thou desire to partake of their delectable dishes, 'tis best to make a call ahead, that thou mayst enjoy them in thine own domicile, free from the pangs of hunger and the torment of slow service. Forsooth, two stars doth merit the service, while four stars doth crown the fare. Alas, two hours didst pass, and still our meals didst not arrive, while those who came after us didst feast and depart ere we didst taste our main courses. Fie upon the waiters, say I, for their sloth and neglect! Yet, methinks the food didst make amends, for it didst please mine appetite and senses most wondrously."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold, my friends,
Of travel worn and weary souls, who sought
A place to rest their heads, and ease their plight,
At Tropicana, a name that doth bespeak
A certain standard, a level of delight.
But lo! The service we didst receive,
Was naught but woe, a bitter draught,
From TJ, a man with naught a care,
Or interest in our well-being, fair.
The check-in, a trial, a test of patience,
A process slow, and full of consternation.
And when at last we gained our room,
A chamber strange, with odors foul and strong,
Like smoke and cleansers, and a scent so bold,
It didst make our eyes to water and our throats to cough.
But fear not, for the bed was soft and clean,
The TV, a flat screen, bright and keen.
Yet still, we would not stay here again,
For the service, oh so poor, didst taint
Our Vegas trip, with shadows of disdain.
Go rather to the Flamingo, or MGM,
Where service, like a gentle breeze, doth flow,
And hospitality, doth reign supreme."

"Hark! The victuals here be of highest quality,
A truth most certain, as my taste doth prove.
Chicken and waffles, a dish most divine,
Doth make my mouth to water and my soul to shine.

But alas, fair service doth oftentimes lack,
A sorrow which doth mar my joy and peace.
Rude waiters and waitresses, with scowls so dark,
Do oft infect my visits with discomfort and unease.

I pray thee, good sirs and madams, attend to my words,
And heed my counsel, lest ye wish to be misunderstood.
For poor service doth tarnish thy reputation,
And doth drive away customers, in search of better condition.

Yet still, I come again, in hope of change,
For love of this dish doth conquer all my strange.
So, go thou forth and savor of this treat,
But heed my warning, lest thy visit be defeat."

"A pox upon Travelocity, that wretched site,
Which with false promises doth lure folk in.
The rooms they show, so bright and new,
Are but a ruse, a trick to win thy penny.

The pool, with chairs so worn and old,
Doth make one shudder at the thought of sitting.
And Yvonne, twice-named, at front desk doth scowl,
As if her mood doth sour the very air.

The food, a disappointment, doth not please,
And bed, alas, doth hurt mine own backside.
How doth this place still stand? 'Tis mystery,
For I shall ne'er return, nor would I advise.

Two stars, I give, for staff, save front desk crew,
And mountains, fair, which surround this place anew."

"Alas, we didst wish to cherish this place,
Forsooth, we didst recent move to yonder space,
And do miss dearly, downtown Gilbert's embrace.
We took the lads, post football game, a month past,
And were dismayed, nay, struck with sorrow fast.
No fries, they had, at luncheon time, 'twas odd,
The scent of grease didst fill the atmosphere, like a shroud.
The server, fair and kind, didst tend to our needs,
The young ones, too, didst delight in popcorn's gentle deeds.
But alas, the victuals, didst not merit a return,
Not for a spell, at least, we didst not yearn."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, I do confess,
The Burger Bar didst leave me in some distress.
The serving maids were kind and fair,
But oh, the cookery didst lack somewhat there.

My neighbors at the table didst receive,
Two free drinks from the house, 'twas quite a tease.
But I, alas, didst find my meal not hot,
The chicken wings were scarce cooked, but fries were got.

Beware, dear friends, they take no reservations,
Cash or credit, that be their conditions.
Yet, shall I return, for every place doth merit,
A second chance, or mayhap, a new Groupon to spirit."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
My hopes for Indulge were quite depressed.
Their website, magazines, and drive-by views,
Did paint a picture of upscale hues.
But alack, the truth did soon reveal,
It was no different than a common steal.
Fuddruckers, thou art a poor disguise,
For mediocrity, in culinary wise.

Two burgers, built with care and thought,
And one pre-made, which we had sought.
Dill chips, an appetizer, we did try,
But none of us did utter a sigh.
Of satisfaction, that is to say,
For the food, it did not pass the play.

The tables, cramped and close together,
Did make us feel like we were in a fetter.
The noise, it did assault our ears,
And made us wish for silence, dear.
Our servers, eager to clear the space,
Did ask for dessert, before we'd grace.
The meal, it was a rush, a noise, a fray,
Not indulgent, in any way, I pray.

Oh, how my heart doth sink with woe,
For the experience, it was not a show.
Indulge, thy name doth not befitting,
For thou art but a mere pretending."

"Fie upon this place, where smoke doth fill the air,
And bartenders, rude and crude, do ply their trade.
A renovation grand, they boast, with finest fare,
But still, the stench of smoke doth linger, unabated.

I sat with mine own dear love, and friend most true,
And ordered drinks, as custom doth require.
But lo, the bartender, with words most bold,
Didst claim, to gain free drinks, a wager must be told.

Five dollars, I didst drop, in machines three,
To placate this fool, and gain our liberty.
But nay, my love, with scotch she didst desire,
And ten dollars more, the bartender didst require.

Oh, how the shame, the embarrassment, didst sting!
For such a play, so base, so vile, so mean,
I didst drop ten more, and bid the fool,
'Here, take this tip, and let us see what shall ensue.'

But lo, the fool, he lost, and laughed,
And thus, our time, was wasted, and our mirth, was dashed.
A total waste, this place, where smoke doth reign,
And rudeness, doth prevail, with naught but pain.

So, farewell, dear friends, and heed my word,
For here, no pleasure doth reside, nor joy, nor cheer.
But rather, smoke, and fools, who seek to prey,
Upon the innocent, and make their day, a dreary way."

"Hark! My belly doth protest, full of discomfort and woe. A feast we did partake, at this place, for the first time, alas! The bread, hard as a stone, did cause my innards great pain. And the fowl, oh how it did disappoint! For eighteen silver coins, a dish I did receive, of little worth, I do declare. Flattened and thin, like a book, it lay upon the plate. And the steak, oh how it did lack in substance and flavor, a sorry sight indeed. Verily, I say, this place doth not deserve our custom, no, not again."

"Hark! I had ne'er set foot within the pink pony's walls,
But curiosity didst drive me to its revamped halls.
Alas, I cannot say what vision they didst strive to bring,
But 'twas not the Old Arizona of yore, that much didst cling.
A youthful Scottsdale crowd, they seemed to seek,
Yet failed to capture that essence, in my humble shake.
My spouse and I, the youngest of them all, didst feel,
Like strangers in a strange land, without a friendly zeal.

Our server, though pleasant, was a sorry sight,
With little knowledge of the menu, a pitiful plight.
She vanished for a spell, leaving us to our own devices,
To hunt for ketchup and a soda, like savages in the wilderness.
The victuals themselves, a middling fare at best,
My crispy chicken, not crispy, and my husband's burger, unimpress'd.

And lo, the bathroom, a true test of a place,
Didst reveal a lack of care, a sorry state of grace.
A soaked and crumpled roll of tissue, lay upon the sink,
And filth upon the floor, a stench that didst not blink.
No part of my experience, didst make me wish to return,
Forsooth, this pink pony, a disappointment didst earn."

"Hark, my friends, to hear of our woeful tale,
How we did seek to dine and were met with naught but fail.
The service, slow and poor, did leave us in dismay,
And the waitress, dear, knew not what she did say.

The food, aye, it was but mediocre fare,
No dish did stand out, nor did it compare.
I, myself, could cook such meals at home,
And so, my friends, we shall ne'er return again."

"In sooth, I entered in, and lo, the place was void of folk. I sat me down at bar, and waited patiently for service, but when the barkeep came, her visage did bear a scowl, as if my query of happy hour and ale did vex her sore. Methinks I shall not return anon, for though I've oft enjoyed this place, poor service doth drive away guests, ere bad victuals, in the tavern trade."

"Last eve, my spouse and I did dine at this establishment, and verily, I must confess, I was not impressed. The ambiance, the service, and the decor, all were quite pleasant, I do admit. But alas, the victuals, they did not meet my expectations, nor did they justify the cost, a princely sum of nigh seven hundred crowns, if thou must know.

Afore we couldst even peruse the wine list or cocktail menu, we were proffered a glass of champagne, a most curious start, methought. And lo, the price of said champagne, a whopping forty-five crowns per glass, we didst not learn until later. My husband, God bless his soul, didst order a humble vegetable starter, and behold, a fifty crown surcharge didst come upon it, all unbeknownst to him.

Now, I do reckon that some patrons of this fine eatery mayst be of the persuasion that money is no object. And though we didst anticipate a substantial expenditure, I must confess, I didst not feel 'twas well spent.

Upon querying the bone marrow surcharge, the kind staff didst remove it from our bill, praise be. But the Veuve, alas, we didst not mention, for I was struck dumb with surprise, and knew not how to react."

"Alas, my friends, what woeful fare didst lie  
In yonder seafood restaurant's dishes!  
The salad, a humble start, didst please mine eyes,  
And in its taste, didst make my spirits rise.  
But lo, the crabcakes, how they didst fail,  
So poorly cooked, they didst make me quail.  
And friend's clam chowder, oh how it didst lack,  
In flavor and in heat, a sorry pack.  
Another friend, her shrimp dish, didst evoke,  
A mere'meh', and naught else didst provoke.  
Disappointment doth reign, for I didst think,  
This place, in Phoenix or Tempe, wouldst link.  
But now, alas, I shall not come again,  
For better fare, my heart doth yearn."

"The atmosphere was pleasant, fair and bright,
But alas, the wait for food did take flight.
'Twas nigh on forty minutes ere our meal did come,
And when it did, oh how my heart did succumb!

Forsooth, the chicken quesadilla didst disappoint,
The bird was dry and overcooked, I didst protest.
And, prithee, do avoid the grilled onions, pray,
For they did make the dish most soggy, fie upon the day!"

In fair Boca Park, where Rampart Boulevard doth lie, A Vietnamese restaurant, of high estate, doth sit. With artwork grand, a waterfall, and fish that doth swim, 'Neath floor, a wondrous sight, doth greet mine eyes. Our time, alas, didst limit us, and so we didst choose, To forego appetizers, and salads, in their stead. I, grilled tiger prawns, with garlic noodles, didst select, And my fair wife, Mama's ginger steamed sea bass, didst get. Alas, her dish, with fresh ginger, shitake mushrooms, and scallions, Didst lack the flavor, we didst expect, at such a cost. Yet still, the decor, and service, didst please our eyes, And though the food, didst not quite meet our surprise, We loved the place, and wouldst visit again, anon.

"Methinks 'twas folly to expect much delight
From yonder tavern, oft visited ere now.
For though their menu doth boast great variety,
And wines most choice, alack! they failed us now.

Five of us, in number, didst venture forth,
But found the first four wines they had in store
Were gone, depleted quite, and naught but sorrow
Didst greet our taste buds, at this turn of fate.

A higher priced bottle didst then ensnare us,
Yet they didst proffer apologies most fair,
And took the faulty vintage from their list,
With haste, as any good host shouldst do, methinks.

Alas! Their menu too, hath changed of late,
To dishes more familiar, and less rare,
And roof, once open to the starry sky,
Now shuttered fast, didst make our evening dreary.

I shall not soon return, nor shall my friends,
Who dwell in Southpark, stray far from home,
For this tavern, once a favorite haunt,
Hath lost its charm, and doth no longer roam."

"A pox upon this salon, say I! For though my locks didst look fair and bright,
Their prices, they didst play a wicked trick.
I checked their site, and called, to make sure,
That for my wedding updo, I wouldst not be poor.
But when I came, with hair most dry,
My stylist didst insist, it must be blown dry.
And though I asked him thrice, to cease and desist,
He still didst charge me, for the blow dry, he didst persist.
And curling too, they didst charge, without a care,
An extra fee, that we didst not prepare.
Oh, how they took advantage, of our special day,
And left us poorer, in a most unkind way.
So here's a warning, to all who doth seek,
A salon, in a hotel, most unique.
Be wary of their prices, and what they do say,
For they may charge thee, in a most unkind way."

"On a drizzly eve, I chanced upon this place,
My joints did ache, the humid air did seize,
We sought refuge from the wet embrace,
And found ourselves within this cozy space.

Their tea, it was a pleasant surprise,
But I, a request, did politely devise,
To brew my own, from my pot, so wise,
They would not allow, a strange surmise.

My server, a woman of ample girth,
Didst greet me with a beaming mirth,
Her smile, it lit the room, like sun on earth,
Despite her size, her spirit had great worth.

My hunger, it did grow with each passing minute,
But alas, my purse, it could not accommodate,
A muffin, small, yet satisfying, did suffice,
As I sipped tea, and waited for the rain to cease.

The hours, they passed, as we sat snug within,
Until the storm, it did finally subside,
And though my visit, was not without a flaw,
'Twas still a respite, from the rain-soaked tide."

"Our service was most vexing, I must confess,
For when they first did ask, we were not prepared.
But some twenty-five minutes later, we were quite ready,
And the appetizers, they were most delectable, I swear.

Alas, my steak, it was not cooked to my liking,
For though I asked for medium rare, 'twas overcooked, I fear.
My friend, he sent his back, but I, in my folly,
Did not, for I had hoped they'd make it right, you see.

My second beer, it was not as the first,
In taste or appearance, it was quite diverse.
If thou dost forget, I shall remind thee,
For I did order a beer of a certain quality, thou shalt see.

Methinks I may return, but if the waitress be the same,
I shall flee, for her service was most tame."

"Hark, what news is this? Our favored tavern, Fat Tuesday, doth close its doors for renovations till mid December. In search of ale and merriment, we chanced upon this place twice within a fortnight, with experiences most diverse.

The first, at three o'clock, for happy hour, with drinks most fair and cheap, didst suffer from a waiter slow and inattentive, causing long delays betwixt each order. The second, outdoors, with seating half full, didst seem to promise better service, but alas, 'twas not to be. For seventeen minutes we waited, with naught but menu and water, while hosts and hostesses didst flit about, oblivious to our plight.

As we departed, the hostess didst inquire, "Were ye not helped yet?" To which I replied, in so many words, "Nay, good lady, we were not." She didst apologize, and thus, our tale doth end.

Now, mark thou well, the victuals here, though humble bar food, didst please our taste. Catfish nuggets, crispy and flavorful, and artichoke dip, rich and creamy, didst satisfy our hunger. But, alack, poor service doth mar the experience, and thus, this place, though situated on the bustling strip, doth falter."

"Alas, our visit didst prove most vexing,
Upon a Saturday eve, we didst venture forth,
The waiting area, in disarray, didst present,
A chaotic scene, with naught but confusion and haste.

The restaurant, congested, didst resemble a fray,
With patrons, cramped, in narrow passageways, didst sway,
The line, a buffet, didst move at snail's pace,
And those who knew not what they wanted, didst impede the race.

The din, a cacophony of sound, didst assail,
Our ears, with music, loud and unrefined, didst prevail,
So great was the noise, we couldst scarce hear,
Even sitting close, our voices didst falter and fear.

The service, slow, didst add to our woe,
And to cap it all, my wife, in soy sauce, didst go,
Her white pants, stained, a sorry sight,
The waitress, with napkins, didst offer a poor plight.

The manager, with little care, didst seem,
And the waitress, shouldst have wiped the seat, with speed,
The food, good, but not fantastic, didst taste,
We served ourselves, no need for waitresses, in this place.

Farewell, good luck, to those who dine,
May your experience, be better than mine."

"Methinks 'twas fortnight past, I chanced upon this eatery,
During Arizona Restaurant Week, with mine own sweetheart.
Alas, fair sir, our visit was most vexing, I do declare,
For service there was woeful, and left much to be desired.

Our waiter, a laggard, didst neglect us sorely,
We had to ask, nay, beg for menus, ere he brought them forth.
And though we sat and waited, parched and dry,
No refreshment came to hand, nor bread to mop our lips.

The meal, a lengthy wait, didst take its toll on us,
Whilst others, later seated, didst feast and make merry.
And when at last our cakes arrived, 'twas some twenty minutes past,
A sorry state of affairs, indeed, and cause for discontent.

In sooth, the victuals were but mediocre, I do confess,
Yet, service, poor and lacking, didst leave a sour taste.
A plague upon that waiter, say I, for his sloth and ill manners,
May he find his match in hell, or better yet, in purgatory's flames."

"A plague upon this wretched meal! The leather of my shoes doth seem more tender than this pie, which came to me barely warm and lacking its rightful garnish. And when the salad did finally grace my presence, 'twas but a paltry excuse for a side dish, with nary a fork to partake of it. Verily, the only solace I found in this woeful repast was the generous portion of toppings that did adorn my dish."

"Upon a Friday eve, when all the town did swarm
With folk seeking delight, I chanced upon
A humble tavern, whose menu did proclaim
A feast fit for a king, at prices quite fair.

But lo, the staff, though friendly of demeanor,
Did proffer dishes different from the bill
Of fare, which on their website did gleam so bright.
And thus, my hopes were dashed, my spirits did sink.

I ordered tacos, three in number, diverse
In flavor and in form, yet all did share
A common flaw, a lack of zest, a dearth
Of seasoning, which left my taste buds quite bare.

The carnitas, once a dish of renown,
Was now but a shadow of its former self,
Dried up and crunchy, with nary a trace
Of moisture or of flavor, alack and alas!

The fish, too, was a disappointment,
Baked, not grilled, and lacking in charm,
While the shrimp, so small and insipid,
Did little to assuage my growing discontent.

I ate but half, then cast the rest aside,
For poor value did it seem, and o'erpriced
Besides, the management, in their zeal
To compensate for lack of custom, did err.

Cut back your staff, I say, for fourfold
Is excessive, when but one customer doth come.
And thus, I left, my appetite unwhetted,
My purse lightened, and my mood somewhat glum."

"By Jove, what marketing prowess doth this place possess! A name like Noodle ChaCha, and a maiden fair, a Pucca in appearance, doth entice me in, without a doubt! 

A solitary building, the restaurant stands, and we, a group of friends, didst arrive at lunchtime, to find 'twas mostly vacant. The servers, with haste, didst greet us, and present the luncheon specials. I, with eager anticipation, didst order Thai fried rice, and sweet and sour soup, besides, the $1 milktea special, which, alack, didst prove a mistake, most dire! Forsooth, the drink, too watery, didst taste of naught but muddy H2O. A dollar, ill-spent, I do declare! The sweet and sour soup, a mediocrity, a blandness to mine tastebuds, it didst bring. And lo, the Thai fried rice, a disappointment, akin to something I, myself, couldst prepare at home, and not so fresh, I must confess. Chinese dried shredded pork, they didst add, in strange fashion. Verily, I say, a puzzlement, indeed! 

Perhaps, another day, their noodles shall tempt me, but for now, alas, the Pucca-like maid, didst not impress, I do declare!"

"Alas, the service we received was not so grand,
And the sushi, truth be told, was not so bland.
The serving maid, she tried to be quite witty,
But her words, they bordered on the rude and gritty.
She seemed to think herself a member of our crew,
But I, a guest, expected more decorum anew.
I do confess, a friendly demeanor I do admire,
But not at the expense of respect and proper fire."

"Methinks 'twas our first visit to this place,
And, by the stars, the victuals did please.
We ordered chicken puffs, egg puffs, and pastries galore,
The latter, I must confess, were quite divine,
The best, in truth, that e'er I tasted on this shore.

But, alack, there were some things that did displease,
The service, poor, and slow, did cause much vexation.
They served us not a drop of water, save we asked,
And twice, the server forgot my drink, in his haste.
The second time I went, the chicken puff was stale,
And when I told the manager, he did show no care.
Yet still, I shall return, for those pastries sweet,
Do tempt me still, and make my mouth to water."

"If thou art one who doth delight in trinkets, baubles, and suchlike knick-knacks, then perchance this place shall be thy haven. But, alack! If thou art not of that ilk, then mayhap 'tis best to avoid this shoppe, lest thou suffer a pounding headache, as doth oft befall me. Yet, in fairness, this establishment doth offer a bounty of gift ideas for those of the female persuasion, with handbags, belts, and jewels aplenty, and even body jewellery for each and every piercing imaginable."

"A plague upon the house that doth employ me!
My colleague, a fool, did call in an order late,
And was met with a tart reply, most uncivil.
The woman on the line, her patience didst wane,
And said, in so many words, "Order now, or else!"
Oh, how I wish I had been the one to call!
For I wouldst have given her a piece of my mind,
And left her in no doubt of my displeasure.
But alas, my colleague, a milder soul,
Didst take the order, and paid the price, full well.

A star for her burrito, rich and savory,
A half-star for the rice, a flavorful delight.
A half-star for the speed of delivery, swift.
But for my own burrito, plain and uninspired,
No stars, alas, for it didst taste of naught but shame.

A pox upon this place, that doth pretend
To serve good food, yet doth fail, so utterly.
I'll not return, nor shall I recommend
This pitiful excuse for a Mexican eatery."
"A soggy, overpriced fast food burger, full of hype and little else, doth cover its walls with quotes of praise, as if to hide the truth of its mediocrity."

"Alas, fair eatery, how couldst thou earn but two stars from mine hand? Forsooth, thy victuals didst delight mine taste buds, and thy location, by the window, didst afford a most wondrous view. But alack, thy service didst leave much to be desired. Verily, 'twas as if thy server didst vanish into thin air, leaving us to suffer long draughts of thirst, and nary a sweet treat to grace our lips. Fie upon't, say I, forsooth, for such a sumptuous feast doth merit service most excellent, and not this sorry state of affairs."

"Alas, my friends, we didst venture to this "sushi" place,
With hopes that 'twould be worth our while,
But alas, 'twas not to be, forsooth,
For though the fish was fresh, the taste didst lack guile.

The former owners, they didst know their craft,
And served us well with fish of goodly sort,
But now, alas, the quality doth wane,
And leaves us wanting, like a winter's frost.

I ordered traditional pieces, one by one,
To test the mettle of this sushi place,
But lo, the rice didst taste of naught but starch,
And lacked the zest of wasabi's fiery grace.

Some pieces, too, didst have a "fresh frozen" bite,
Which doth not befit a sushi of renown,
The "hamachi" was passable, but not by much,
The "ono" was thin, and sauce of unagi, quite bland.

The "ama ebi" didst suffer from old oil,
And shrimp head, small, like a child's plaything,
In sooth, my friends, this place doth not deserve,
Our custom, for a true sushi experience, we must seek elsewhere."

Alas, fair Pure, thy charms have lost their sheen,
For this old soul, no longer young and green,
Finds naught but woe in waiting lines,
And crowds that push and shove with such confines.

Aye, sixteen coins for cranberry brew,
A price too steep, methinks, for such a brew,
And so, dear Pure, I bid thee adieu,
For thou art lost, and I am through.

Yet still, thy roof doth hold a special place,
A sanctum, where I might find some grace,
If only I could stay there, blissfully,
And shun the crowd, with all their revelry.

This woeful state of disarray doth vex me sore,
My orders twisted, in confusion's snare.
Twice now, my plans have been cast awry,
And thus, I vow, to San Tan Mall, I'll fly.

"Tis not a place of honest work, my friends,
Where one may find a steady wage and end.
'Tis but a temp firm, with jobs so thin,
Outbound calls, for political surveys penned.

The day begins at two and thirty,
And ends when workload's done, night's hurry.
For pay, they offer nine gold coins,
But oft, thy time, they'll not be using.

Many a day, thou'lt call to schedule,
And they, thy name, will not be grudging.
Weeks pass, and still, no work's assigned,
A waste of time, thy quest, unending.

Avoid this place, my friends, I pray,
For management's ways, are not of play.
They treat their workers, poor and old,
As trash, and joke, their plight, so cold.

Work elsewhere, seek not this place,
For honesty and worth, doth not embrace."

"With a name like J'm La Frite, when a craving for poutine, burger or fries takes hold, 'tis quite difficult to ignore. This place, though, doth seem a bit strange. 'Tis certainly a spot for fast food, but methinks they try too hard to be chic, like a youth dressed in finery for a McDonald's interview. I ordered a ham and cheese panini, which was good, but not as hot as I had hoped. And, truth be told, I did wonder if there was indeed cheese within. My friend had a burger that looked decent, and a poutine that was likely the best dish we ordered. The sauce was very good, and the cheese curds were fresh, big, and made a satisfying squeak-squeak sound before melting. For the poutine, 'twas worth the cost, but for the rest, I felt a bit "meh." In total, we spent a bit over 20 dollars for all of it, so I do not think we got much value for our money."

"O Picazzo's, once a place of delight,
Where I would oft repair for savory bites,
Now fallen from thy former grace, alas!
Thy service still doth please, but food, alack!
A salad came, with greens not of the menu's list,
My server did apologize, yet I felt mist,
For kale, I did not ask, nor did I choose,
The brown-edged lettuce and avocado's steep cost,
Did leave me in a state of utter woe,
I know not if I shall return, fair sir,
Thy nod to health, a gesture most kind,
Yet, meh, thy offerings, did not entwine."

"Alas, my friends, I must recount a tale of woe,
Of dining on the Strip, where service should flow.
But lo, at Diablo's Cantina, 'twas not so,
For slow and poor the service did go.

We sat at bar, awaiting menus with glee,
But nary a word from servers could we see.
At last, a finger pointed, and a mumble spoke,
"Ask bartender, not me," our hopes did break.

And when the food arrived, oh what a sight,
