Bland and flavorless, without a spicy bite.
Alas, my friends, I cannot recommend this place,
For Diablo's Cantina did not show its grace."

"Hark! This tavern doth provide a place to quaff,
And little else, alas! My expectations low,
I ventured in, yet found myself dismayed.
A fair selection of brews, the prices not too high,
But alack! The salad, a sorry sight, did lie.
$13, a steep price for such a meager fare,
Leaves me in doubt of other dishes there.
Yet, mayhap, friend, thou find'st solace in ale,
For in that, methinks, lieth this place's greatest appeal."

"O, woe is me! The Rockin' Railroad class doth please,
But alas, no make-up classes may be seized.
My toddler's nap, my work, the schedules crossed,
And thus, two classes left untaught, my loss.

The owner, stern and unyielding, doth refuse
To grant an exception, or to make amends.
My babe, sickly, home I did detain,
Lest others fall ill from his contagion's stain.

Now, all they offer, a play gym doth remain,
A substitute, poor, for what I did obtain.
Disappointment doth consume my heart and brain,
For such a simple boon, they would not relent.

In other classes, instructors, kind and true,
Did gladly make up missed classes, anew.
But here, a hardened stance, they do maintain,
And thus, our Rockin' Railroad days are vain.

We shall not return, nor pay their fee,
For such poor service, we will not decree."

"Methought 'twas pleasant on my first visit, for 'twas late and open all night. But alack, upon mine second and third venture, I found cause to doubt its worth. The victuals and potables were naught but mediocre, o'erpriced by far. And, by my troth, their wi-fi policy doth vex me sore. Forsooth, they do compel one to purchase somewhat ere they share the pass, and every hour and a half, one must buy anew to keep the connection alive. Fie upon such foolishness! The furniture, too, doth cry out for repair, the leather couches and benches worn and faded. In sooth, I say, find elsewhere to spend thine hours, for this place doth not deserve thy custom."

"Alas, poor Buon Gusto! Once a proud chain, now reduced to naught but a memory. The love for local, organic fare doth remain, yet the pizzas that once brought us joy, now lie in ruin. Two pies, dear to mine heart, didst fall victim to the cruel hand of fate. The first, a Chipotle Barbacoa, a feast fit for the gods, with barbacoa meat, cheese sauce, and jalapenos, all combined in perfect harmony. The second, a Spicy Italian, a masterpiece of flavors, with pepperoni, salami, and a tapenade of olives and carrots. Alas, they are gone, and with them, our enthusiasm for the place. The menu, though still filled with tasty dishes, doth pale in comparison to what once was. Our visits, once frequent, now dwindle, as the memories of those pizzas linger, a bittersweet reminder of what once was."

"In this fair city of Las Vegas, where excess doth reign,
Amidst the splendor and the glamour, doth lie a bane.
A place of sustenance, of nourishment most base,
Where Mexican fare, of low estate, doth grace the space.

Sweet margaritas, watery and insipid, doth flow,
Yet chips and salsa, alas! doth not come with the show.
No salsa with the tacos, a sorrowful tale,
Yet still, the prices, by Vegas standards, doth prevail.

So come, dear friends, and partake of this feast,
For those who seek a meal most humble and least.
In this grand city, where luxury doth reign,
This lowly eatery, a haven, doth remain."

"Hark! This spread doth rival Golden Corral,  
With five hundred dishes, or so they say,  
A feast fit for a king, or one who doth aspire  
To taste all that doth lay before their eyes.  

But fear not, dear friend, for I have a plan  
To guide thee through this culinary land,  
And help thee make the most of thy hard-earned pay,  
And savor each morsel in a most delightful way.  

First, seek the cured meats and cheese, a treat  
For those who crave rich flavors, bold and neat;  
Next, sample the kobe beef sliders, small but true  
In taste and texture, worth a king's ransom, anew.  

The prime rib doth call thy name, a roasted delight  
That doth impress, and doth ignite thy appetite;  
And should thou find thyself in want of something light,  
The tuna sashimi salad doth provide a wondrous sight.  

Lastly, do not forget the sweets, a cornucopia  
Of sugary delights, that doth bring joy and euphoria;  
For in this realm of plenty, there doth lie a treat  
That doth surpass all else, and doth crown the feast.  

So, to the Bacchanal, give three and a half stars,  
For its grand scale and quality that doth transcend Mars;  
For though it may not be the Golden Corral,  
It doth stand tall, a worthy adversary, after all."

"Makmak, a place of sustenance, yet not of great renown,
With prices that do border on the high side, I must confess.
They do possess Singha, a beer of some repute,
But their tom yum, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
A taste most strange and not of the finest quality,
Yet, I have had worse, I must admit with some clarity.
The spring rolls, a common dish, nothing to boast,
And the pork dumplings, quite good, a joy to consume.
The peanut sauce, a delight, a true culinary treat,
But the pad thai, alas, I have not tried, my dear.
The service, quite good, with a smile and a cheer,
A cute place, indeed, with a certain je ne sais quoi, my dear."

"Hark! A tale of woe and disarray,
At the equipment rental place, did play.
We, with haste, didst stop by, to return,
A trailer, from Seattle, WA, didst burn.

But lo! A wait, of fifteen minutes, didst ensue,
While other customers, were serviced anew.
Our paperwork, lost in the fray,
Didst cause a delay, in a most vexing way.

But fear not, good sir! For the employee,
Didst look up our info, with great celerity.
And though, the heat, didst wretchedly oppress,
The worker, with grace, didst address.

Yet, alack! A moment of unprofessionalism,
Didst mar the scene, with a most grievous crime.
A co-worker, with a query, most rude,
Didst question the deodorant, of his comrade, in full view.

But, all in all, the equipment, didst suffice,
And for that, we shall, this place, entice.
Easy to find, with a spacious lot,
And naught but them, in this fair spot.

So, heed my words, and take heed,
For at this place, thou shalt find thy need.
But, on Fridays, Sundays, be prepared,
To wait, with patience, and a steady heart."

"Methinks this library doth please me well,
Save for the tale-time, where children doth receive a seal.
A counselor, with voice both loud and clear,
Doth oft neglect the louder younglings, I do fear.
My own two-year-old, full of energy and cheer,
Doth join in the fun, yet doth not always hear.
Twice now, he hath been overlooked, and doth feel quite sore,
And thus, my pen doth write this review, in hopes of more.
For though the library be grand, and we do love to attend,
Inclusion of all children, that is my humble request, my friend."

"Hark! Who knew, I pray thee, 'twas Twin Peaks indeed,
Until my journey to fair Las Vegas did cease.
And lo, within Scottsdale's walls, such place doth lie,
Where maidens fair and bright do dance before mine eyes.

"Aye, upon mine entrance, thought I thus,
'Wow, the lasses here be fair and beauteous.'
Compared to Hooters' UFC nights, this place doth excel,
In beauty, by the mile, and in hotness, doth outdo.

"Farewise, 'tis naught but mediocre, at best,
With large portions and men's and maidens' sizes, to boot.
A clever ploy, indeed, the waitresses doth play,
With 'Scenic View', a dessert, free of cost, by day.

"Alas, the victuals, bar food though they be,
My burger, with bun o'erflowing, did disappoint me.
Yet, fingerling potatoes, crispy and golden, did please,
And nachos, a mighty mound, did fill mine heart with cheer.

"The establishment, an REI store, doth resemble,
Yet, naught to purchase, save for the fair sex, doth dwindle.
A cover charge of five crowns, for UFC, doth seem fair,
But for the grub, I fear, I shall not come hither, without care."

"Methinks the victuals here be of excellent quality, mayhap the best I've had in all my days. But, alas, I do perceive a rise in prices, and methinks 'tis getting somewhat steep for what one doth receive. Twelve crowns for a dish of chicken fried rice, pray tell? And the broth, but a mere soup with a few slices of onion therein? Fie upon it! I do beseech thee, good sirs, to share thy thoughts on this matter, and how it doth compare to other establishments of similar ilk. Forsooth, I shall venture forth to Little Saigon, a Vietnamese eatery in Glendale, with a five-star rating, no less!"

"Methinks 'twas fortnight past, when first I didst set foot in this place they call Surprise, that I didst hear tell of a certain eatery known as New York Flavor. And thus, with mine own two eyes, didst I behold the sign that didst read, in bold letters, "New York Flavor". Methought, "Marry, what fortune! A taste of the Empire City, here in the desert!" And so, with haste, didst I make my way within, to partake of their culinary delights. 

The service, I must confess, was quite good. Forsooth, the maiden at the counter, when asked, didst guide me through the menu with grace and wit. And thus, I didst order the Spanish Harlem, with a side of potato salad, as suggested by the fair maiden. 

But lo, the potato salad, in a tiny cup it came, a mere morsel, a snack, a trifle! Methought, "Surely, this is some jest, some merry prank?" Forsooth, the portion was scant, and the taste, alack, was naught but common, akin to that found in the marketplace. And thus, I didst pay $1.99 for two bites of potato salad, a sorry sight indeed. 

The sandwich, however, didst please mine taste. The spread, flavorful, and the steak, cooked to perfection. The bread, alas, was naught but ordinary. And thus, for $8.99, a sum not small, didst I partake of a meal, that, though not unpleasant, didst not live up to the standards of the Big Apple, whose name it doth bear. 

In conclusion, fair friends, the service, indeed, was good, but alas, the food, a disappointment. For in New York, they do say, "You get what you pay for," and thus, I didst not find it worth the cost."

In fair Goodyear, a new pizza place doth shine,
With interior fair, as newness doth entwine.
Thin crust, not of New York or Chicago breed,
Yet still, a native New Yorker finds it pleasing indeed.
A year hath passed since search began in earnest,
For slice of pizza worthy of the city's name.
This, alas, doth not fulfill that fond desire,
But still, 'tis pizza good, with cheese of finest fame.
Above the rest, in West Valley, doth it stand,
A worthy choice, though not of highest rank in hand.

"In fair Scottsdale, where the sun doth shine bright,
A humble eatery doth stand, a wondrous sight.
'Tis Luke's of Chicago, a place of renown,
Where chili cheese dogs doth reign supreme, a crown.

Their lunchtime fare, it doth vary, I confess,
At times, a swift affair, with naught to address.
But when the crowd doth swell, a wait doth ensue,
And patience, dear friend, doth oft be tried anew.

The chili cheese dog, oh how it doth delight,
A messy, tasty treat, that doth ignite.
Crinkle-cut fries, a bonus, doth come with ease,
A perfect pairing, for those who doth please.

But alas, a tale of woe, I must impart,
A lost order, a mistake, a heavy heart.
In haste, a ticket fell, or so it seemed,
A mishap, rare, but still, a fault to be deemed.

Yet fear not, dear patron, for this place doth stand,
A gem amidst the fast food, fancy land.
So if thou seeketh a meal, free from pretence,
Luke's of Chicago, a worthy choice, make sense."

"Methought, fair sir, that Vegas buffets didst boast  
A culinary splendor, worthy of great toast.  
But lo, the victuals laid before mine eyes,  
Didst leave me in a state of utter surprise.  
The spread, though fair in appearance, didst belie  
The taste, which didst fall short of my expectations high.  
Alas, 'twas naught but common fare, I do declare,  
And left me in a state of disappointment and dismay."

"A feast fit for kings, with atmosphere most fine, 
A menu grand, with dishes of the land and sea. 
Steaks, fowl, fish, and duck, all make an appearance, 
And sushi, tartare, too, for those of such persuasion. 
Lobster, artichoke, and sprout, pear, and bacon, 
In salads, soups, and stews, a veritable cornucopia. 
The meats, oh so rich, and cooked to perfection, 
Presented with flair, a true culinary obsession. 
But alas, the service, slow as molasses in winter, 
Our server, scarce, and with a heavy French accent, did stammer. 
We waited, glasses empty, bread, a rare sight, 
No server in view, to ease our plight. 
Aganche, white chocolate, we shared, to end the night, 
Medicinal, licorice-like, a curious delight. 
Our server, appeared, a third time, to say, 
The dessert, worth the wait, but we had gone astray. 
Three and a half stars, I would give, for the fare, 
But service, poor, a true disappointment, beyond compare."

"In this fair city of New York, where bustling crowds do roam,
A gentler soul doth dwell, within a place called home.
A restaurant once, now transformed, doth hold a charm,
With victuals of sport, and wings that do disarm.

The flavors of the wings, they doth abound,
A feast for taste buds, and a sight most profound.
So if thou find thyself, in this city of old,
Do seek out this place, where sports and grub do unfold."

"Hark! Good sirs, what be thy desire? Water, perchance? Or mayhap something more? Our repast was fair, but alack! Our server's skill did leave much to be desired. A salad, twain pizzas, thrice appetizers, two cups of wine, and a pitcher did we order, yet our man did seem to think we would be content with naught but water and pizza. Alas! The victuals were good, but our server's efforts did fall short. Drinks missed, orders awry; methinks I may not return to Federal Pizza anon, such being the case."

"Hark! What spectacle doth mine eyes perceive?
Athletic maidens, scantily clad, do writhe
Upon the ground, their supple forms a-twist,
In fervent passion, with nary a stitch.
Their beefy counterparts, of eastern Europe bred,
Do sweat and pant, their muscles bulging, red.
Acrobatics and water stunts, a blur of flesh,
A two-hour ride of lust, that doth leave me breathless.
When ended, I did towel off and shower,
Then left my home, to witness 'Le Reve' at Wynn's tower."

"Methinks this place doth have a staff most bipolar,
Whence some days thou art met with kindness so fair,
That thy heart doth sing with joy, and thou dost tarry,
To partake of their brew, and savor each sip with glee.
But lo, on other days, thy hopes doth dwindle,
For thou art met with scowls, and service most gruff,
Leaving thee to ponder, if thou shalt return,
Or flee, and seek elsewhere, a more pleasant haven."

"Verily, the service was good, but alas! The food, it was oversalted, lacking in flavor. I didst attempt to return, but lo! They didst charge me for the Super Bowl, as if they had paid to stream it themselves. The prices, they were steep, compared to other wing establishments. Eighty-five cents per wing? Tut, tut! I am accustomed to paying but a mere fifty to six cents per wing!"

"Whilst I did wait for my takeout, a group of four seniors did leave,
With smiles on their faces, and joy did they bring.
One of the fair ladies did say, "Tis our fave place,
Where every dish doth please, and ne'er doth disgrace."
She gathered all the cards, and off did she go,
To spread the word, and let all know.

I pondered long o'er the menu, a feat,
For Chinese food, I knew not what to eat.
At last, I chose the ma po tofu, and lo mein,
And off did I drive, with a grin.

But alas, the takeout bag, a mess did make,
All sauced up, and nary a mistake.
The tofu, with ground chicken, light and fine,
But the noodles, oh how they did decline.
Excessive oil, a chef gone wild,
A pity, for the Peking duck, I did desire,
And still do plan, to give it a try,
And see if it doth change, my mind's eye."

In midst of renovation, fair hotel doth lie,
Amidst the bustling streets of wondrous Vegas, nigh.
I chanced upon a room, new-made and fine,
With bed so soft, a cloud, and space divine.
The view, a sight most fair and bright,
Down (or up, in Vegas' endless night) the famed Strip's delight.
Alas, the crowd, a bit uncouth, did grieve,
Yet still, the staff, with warmth and grace, did relieve.
Once finished, renovations grand and new,
This hotel shall regain its former glory anew.

Hark! My dearest girlfriend and I didst venture hither,
To partake in breakfast feast, at Dan Marino's place,
Within the Hooters Hotel, where we didst lay our head,
And rose anon, to dine upon their morning grace.

A coupon book, with offer of a 2 for 1 deal,
Didst entice us, to their breakfast buffet, so grand,
For ten gold coins, a regular price, I do confess,
But with the coupon, 'twas a steal, a true success!

Scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, diced potatoes, too,
Dry cereal, waffles with strawberries, a treat for thee,
Bread pudding, fruit, a veritable cornucopia,
A feast most satisfying, and a bargain, beyond compare!

Coffee, milk, OJ, or soda, didst complete the meal,
A fair exchange, for what we didst receive, most real.
So if thou find thyself, in this fair city's bounds,
Do stop by Dan Marino's, and taste their breakfast rounds!

"Verily, fair reader, let it be known that The Southern doth possess a certain charm, with its neat decor and ample space. Yet, methinks, doth the menu bear a striking resemblance to those of its brethren, Holyrood 9A and Red Squirrel. Doth mine eyes deceive me? Forsooth, the burger doth reign supreme, with naught but a few variations to distinguish one establishment from the next. And, alack, what of those who crave not a burger betwixt two slices of bread? Fear not, for the fare is tasty indeed, yet diversity doth seem to be in short supply. And, pray tell, why doth the foodstuff arrive upon a wooden plank? Doth the proprietor hold crockery in such disdain? In conclusion, my burger did please mine taste buds, but how doth The Southern differentiate itself from its kin?"

"Amidst the splendor of the Vegas strip, our lodgings proved a middling sight,
With rooms of fair price, yet naught to boast of in their appointments bright.
The elevators, how they creaked and groaned, a noisy, rickety plight,
And though the soap in pyramid form did spark some curiosity,
The absence of wifi in our chambers did cause some dismay, I do confess.

The gaming floor, a grand expanse, did stretch out before our eyes,
Easy to lose one's way, yet navigable, with time, by wit and guile.
The pool, a tranquil oasis, did offer respite from heat and toil,
But alas, the costs of indulgence did our purses soon deplete.

In sooth, our stay was middling, neither best nor worst, I do avow."

"Hark! If Bistro on the Avenue didst launch anew,
In any place but Westmount, 'twouldst not endure,
For price and innovation, both doth lack,
And thus, 'twouldst not be worth a second look.

Yet, there, 'tis cherished by the local folk,
A convenient choice, when cooking doth grow tiresome.
So, though we wouldst not seek it out afar,
We wouldst not mind returning now and then,
To partake in their fare, and savor the charm."

"Methinks we dined within these hallowed halls of chance twice, my friends. The victuals, though not of the finest sort, did please our palates well. Verily, the onion straws, they were most delectable."

"Upon mine friends, I didst venture to this place,
A tavern known as 'The Gym', a name most strange,
With pool tables in the back, and darts up front,
And games of skill, where one may test their chance.

The bartenders, friendly souls, didst serve us well,
Our thirst, with ale and beer, they didst quell,
At prices fair, compared to other taverns near,
We found ourselves in quite a merry cheer.

Yet, in this place, a certain sort didst abound,
With hats askew, and minds not altogether sound,
But still, we found amusement, in their company,
For laughter and good cheer, our spirits didst engage.

One oddity, didst strike mine eye,
A man, who held the bathroom, didst not deny,
A tip, for services rendered, he didst expect,
For use of sink, or such, a small inspect,

With candies, in baskets, and blow pops, besides,
He stood, and waited, with a hopeful stride,
But I, didst pass him by, with nary a word,
For tipping, such a man, seemed most absurd.

Still, to 'The Gym', give it a try, my friend,
For strobe lit bathrooms, and a sweet treat, that doth end,
A night of mirth, and laughter, thou shalt find,
So, to thy wife, thou mayst say, with ease of mind."

"By Jove, fair Frances doth possess  
Amazing sales, and wares most fair and bright.  
Thou art correct, good sir, their prices be  
A wee bit steep, yet unique items thou shalt see.  
Gifts, indeed, for friends and kin,  
Special treasures that doth make them grin.  
Alas, I do confess, I love this place,  
But alack, my purse doth not embrace  
Their costly goods, and so I must refrain  
From visiting oft, lest I doth go insane.  
A wider price range, pray tell, they should bear,  
For those of us who are not rich, nor fair.  
Yet still, I say, Frances doth possess  
A shop most wondrous, and a sight most bless'd."

"A year past, I didst visit this place,
Where seafood doth abound in grace.
Shrimp, crab claws, oysters baked so fine,
Didst make my taste buds dance and twine.
I didst wait a year, with eager heart,
To savor those dishes once more to part.
But alas! The menu didst change,
And my desired feast didst range.
I didst order lobster, stuffed with care,
But 'twas not what I had waited for, I swear.
The wine, too, didst have cork within,
Even when they tried again, twice to win.
My first visit, five stars didst earn,
But now, three stars, my rating doth return."

"Methinks 'twas not the first time we didst dine here,
Forsooth, my daughter, then a babe most fair,
Didst fuss and cry, so brief was our stay.
But now, in this, our second coming hither,
The place doth seem most neat and cleanly,
Yet chairs, alack, too low they be,
For tables, making us feel quite uneasy.
Highchairs, they didst bring, yet not so high,
Our younglings, standing on our laps, didst try
To see the feast, their plates, they couldst not spy.
I held her plate, my daughter, that she might eat,
And thus, the service, friendly, was most meet.
A youthful child, afraid of flashy show,
The chef, didst tone it down, his art to know.
Sushi, most excellent, and appetizers, fine,
But rest of dinner, left me somewhat divine.
A pink paste, added to all, a curious zest,
Yet made each dish taste much the same, I didst find.
Methinks, for sushi, I wouldst return again."

"Methinks 'tis a pleasant inn, wherein I do delight to tarry oft. Alas, they do not boast of Cirque du Soleil performances, nor doth it teem with mirth and merriment, save for the raucous fetes within the Marquee, which do stir mine ire and the inebriated folk who rule the domicile."

"A pleasant dining hall, with garnishes so fine,
A menu rich, and fit for any dine.
The tempura'd asparagus, a tasty delight,
Though portion size, did leave me in a plight.

Hoagies, oh hoagies, how thou art divine,
With prime rib, sliced thin, and cheese so fine.
My wife, she had hers, with spinach and cheese,
Whilst I, with mushrooms, onions, and cheese, did please.

The rolls, so soft, did complement the feast,
And juices flowed, as if from the East.
Fries, crispy and golden, a perfect side,
To this repast, so satisfying and wide.

I shall return, for dinner, I do swear,
For though 'tis busy, the fare, I hold dear."

"A fair establishment, with tasty starters, indeed. Alas, the steak, it doth leave much to be desired. Forsooth, 'twas overcooked, and lacked that certain je ne sais quoi. But fear not, dear friends, for I shall return anon, to partake of their finer cuts, forsooth. For though the steak didst disappoint, the surroundings and attendance didst please mine eyes and senses well."

In fair Paris Hotel Casino, we didst dine,
Where our hostess, with grace and poise, didst seat us.
Upon the edge of the restaurant, we didst sit,
To watch the people pass, in endless wit.

I, a fish dumping noodle bowl, didst order then,
And my fair wife, a won ton soup bowl, didst choose.
A plate of mini pork buns, we didst request,
As the dim sum cart, didst make its way to us.

The verdict of our meal, was somewhat mixed,
Our soups, quite tasty, but a bit too small, were fixed.
The pork buns, alas, didst lack moisture,
And forty-six dollars, the cost, didst procure.

In Vegas, we didst dine, with reckless abandon,
Yet, the price, didst seem, a bit too extravagant.
Still, the experience, was not without delight,
For in the city of sin, we didst dine, with all our might.

"Hark! Their sandwiches be of generous size,
The ciabatta bread, a feast for thine eyes.
And whispers say, the nine-grain doth please,
A culinary delight, beyond all measure.

But alas, my roast beef provolone,
Didst not agree with mine own belly's moan.
Perhaps, I shall return to Jimmy John's,
For my next sandwich, with haste and speed."

"A query, good sirs, doth puzzle mine mind,
Why doth the Secret Garden and Dolphin Habitat,
Two places of wonder, doth share a single fee?
Methinks 'tis strange, yet thus it doth befall.

My thoughts, dear friends, doth now turn to the garden,
Where tigers, lions, and other beasts doth dwell,
In habitats, alas, that doth seem too small,
For creatures wild and free, to run and play.
The heat, perchance, doth make them drowsy,
Or mayhap 'twas the hour, when all did rest,
But Siegfried, the great tiger, doth appear,
And with my children, didst take a photo, so fair and dear.
A noble beast, with accent German,
Didst grant us a moment, most gracious and fine.

Now, of the dolphins, I shall speak anon,
In a review apart, their praise to show,
For though the garden doth seem costly,
The mem'ry of Siegfried, doth forever glow."

"Hark! A place of plenty, fit for any purse,
Where portion sizes be generous, of course.
Their mac salad, a dish most fair and bright,
And spam musubi, a treat most wondrous in sight.
Chicken katsu, crispy without, tender within,
A feast most satisfying, for hunger to win.
When belly be empty and craving doth strike,
This place shall provide sustenance, and naught else seek.
A fullness that lasteth, for hours upon hours,
A veritable feast, for all thy hunger's powers."

"A sojourn of three days, a culinary quest,
With kinfolk dear, at Arriba's we did feast.
The chips, crisp and warm, with salsa and dip,
Earned four stars, a promising start, methought.

The service, three stars, the server kind,
Informative and friendly, yet somewhat blind.
My uncle's hot salsa, forgotten, alas!
Until halfway through, his meal did pass.

The food, two to four stars, a mixed bag,
My tamale, green corn, lacked zest and sag.
My uncle's chile, a delight, he did say,
But naught else impressed, in truth, that day.

The decor, three stars, unremarkable,
Cleanliness, a concern, not quite regal.
A single store, mom and pop, I'd choose,
For future feasts, their charm, I do propose."

"Methinks my love and I didst wish to visit this new establishment, to partake in their barbecue offerings. 'Twas quite delectable, by Jove! My love, he didst order a dram of whiskey, which they didst have in ample supply, and I, a tankard of ale, served chilled to perfection. Their daily specials, writ large upon a chalkboard, didst catch our eye. Our server, a merry lad, didst attend to us with haste and cheer. The victuals, hot as blazes, didst require a brief respite ere we couldst indulge. We began with dill pickles, fried to a crisp, though perhaps a mite too thin? I, myself, didst opt for fowl, three pieces, with macaroni and cheese, baked beans beside. My love, a pulled pork sandwich, and fried okra, didst savor with glee. The smoke, a wondrous flavor, didst lingeringly imbue the pork."

"A speedy wash, and cheap, not bad at all, my friend! Free vacuums too, a bonus, methinks. Stay in thy carriage, and a fellow at the end doth wipe it clean. A goodly job, indeed. For a monsoon-drenched conveyance, this place doth fit the bill. Alas, no full detailing, nor interior tidying. Yet, a small towel, once given, now doth dwindle. Still, 'tis a worthy stopgap, till next thou dost require a thorough cleansing."

"Hark! What news is this? Thou art still in trade, good sir! Methinks 'twas fortune's grace that led me to thy door, for had I not possessed a device to traverse the ethereal realm, I fear thou wouldst have remained unknown to me.

"And thus, I must confess, thy victuals didst please mine taste, as did the warmth of thy hospitality. A half-turkey sandwich, with macaroni salad, didst suffice for my repast, while mine husband didst enjoy pastrami, accompanied by potato salad. Our beverages didst flow like the Nile, and thus our total sum didst amount to twenty gold coins, ere the customary gratuity.

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that should thy prices bend a mite toward the affordable, we wouldst partake in thy culinary delights with greater frequency, and perchance even indulge in sweet desserts."

"Methinks 'twas my first time to partake of Poutine,
And though 'twas passable, better dishes I did find.
Our server, friendly and kind, didst make our stay most pleasant,
And the backyard, with its quaint decor, didst win my approval.

Alas, the place doth cater to tourists, I do fear,
And compared to others, lowly ranked doth appear.
Coffee, thou art best avoided, instant being the choice,
For beer, the better option, doth bring joy and rejoice.

We did not sample other dishes, alack and alas,
But if in need of sustenance, I might return, perchance.
So if thou find thyself in that fair city,
And dost desire a snack, give this place a chance, mayhap."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, my aged aunt didst take me to dine,
At Ruby Tuesday's, where we didst partake,
Of their most wondrous feast, a veritable delight,
A burger, nay, two, with salad bar in sight.

Oh, how we laughed and joked, my kin and I,
At the thriftiness of my father's kin,
But lo, my aunt, a sly one, didst produce,
A stack of coupons, and our mirth didst cease.

I, myself, do swear by burgers, 'tis my creed,
Or chicken sandwich, should I be in need,
For who doth care if grill marks doth grace,
The fowl that doth arrive upon the plate?

Ruby Tuesday's, wise guile, doth offer two,
Mini burgers, salad bar, for price so low,
And now, a new addition doth they bring,
Pimento cheese, my heart doth sing with joy.

Alas, two things I miss, from days of yore,
Bread and butter pickles, pineapple, no more,
Why, oh why, doth my voice doth raise,
In sorrow, at their absence, such a pity, alack."

"Four sprites we have, and in this shop we didst spend,
Two hundred dollars, and two hours, 'twas no sin.
'Tis wondrous, yet crowded, a tourist trap, no doubt,
But gifts for our young ones, we doth bring without a rout.

In Vegas, we doth not take the little ones,
But presents, we doth bring, upon each trip, anon.
This emporium, multi-levelled, doth contain,
M&M treasures, thy children shall surely obtain.

My daughter, she didst request, a token from this place,
When next we doth visit, in January's frosty grace.
The staff, kind and helpful, lines long, we didst find,
Prices steep, but location, convenience, doth bind.

Forsooth, without the young ones, this shop doth lose,
Its charm, its lure, its magic, doth dispose.
Navigating, a mite perplexing, 'twas no jest,
But patience, we doth muster, for our little guests."

"A humble abode of pizza and pasta,
Where one may order at the counter with ease,
And for a fair price, a hearty meal shall pass,
With sides of salad and bread, a feast for all to seize.
The fare is plain, yet service with a smile,
Two thumbs up, for their hospitality doth prevail.
The premises are tidy, and the privies too,
But alack, a refill doth cost a golden ducat anew.
Cash only, a minor quibble, yet a quip,
For those who seek a quick and tasty snack, 'tis a trip."

"Hark, I've longed to visit this marketplace,
Where farmers sell their wares, fresh and fair.
The downtown scene, with veggies picked clean,
Leaves me unsatisfied, a hunger unseen.

So, with a day free, I set forth to roam,
And find this place, where bounty doth abound.
The sign doth say, it opens at ten,
But lo, the granola types, they swarm in,
Ere we arrive, with elbows deep in produce,
A fear that we may miss the finest choose.

McClendons, the vendor of most, doth bring
A feast for eyes, with colors bright.
Beets of purple, leeks of deepest green,
Potatoes small, and shallots, broccoli seen.
Organic, some, and labeled with care,
From Willcox, freshness doth abound there.

Five registers open, lines do form,
Housewives swift, their veggies they do storm.
Quick, one must be, to avoid a fray,
But worth it, for the freshness of the day.

Beyond the veggies, crafts doth abound,
Soaps, blankets, jewels, yarns, a bread round.
A visit, worthwhile, if in the area,
But not worth travel, for me, alas, no fear."

"Hark, fair maiden, I do declare,
Chipotle, my heart doth sing thy praise.
For thou, my dear, dost bring me cheer,
And in my belly, doth warmth raise.

Their service, kind, yet flustered be,
As three in line, they didst decree.
A gentleman, his order didst start,
But alas, his food, didst sit apart.
The lady, returned, and threw it away,
And made him new, come what may.

My time, some fifteen minutes didst take,
And thus, my patience didst make.
But fear not, for the food, so grand,
Didst make my spirit, take a stand.

So let us hope, as days go by,
Their speed, shall increase, ere long, and nigh."

"Hark, fair friends! 'Tis been some time since last I graced this place,
But glad am I that I did return, for service most excellent doth grace
The halls of this fine eatery. Steak and shrimp, both grilled to perfection,
Did please my palate, and the salad bar, with freshness overflowing,
Did satisfy my hunger. And, oh! The strawberry shortcake, made mine own,
Did cap the feast, and worth the journey, verily, it was proven."

"Amidst the throng, a multitude of seats doth abound,
And swift attendants, with alacrity they move around.
The interior bar, new life hath recently found,
Yet, as with most, the ambiance doth ebb and flow,
Depending on the hour and day of the week,
As slow days bring forth bartenders, friendly and meek.
Their aim, to ease thy headache, and banish thy woe."

"Upon mine ears, didst thou hear the tales of yore?
A place of wonder, where survival doth await,
In truth, a souvenir shop of zombie lore,
With trinkets, tees, and toys, to make one's day great.

For those who doth delight in undead cheer,
This place doth hold a special kind of glee,
Interactive games, and novelties so dear,
To make the heart of any zombie fan sing.

Alas, my hopes for practical gear were dashed,
The MREs, pricey, as were other camping stash,
But still, a Twinkie, didst I purchase with haste,
A sweet reminder, of a fun-filled quest.

So, if thou find thyself, in this place of dread,
With friendly staff, and zombie-themed delight,
Do enter, and partake in the fun,
For in this shop, thy spirits shall be light."

"Methinks the service here was of the highest quality,
With staff who were both pleasant and helpful, by and by.
Alas, for families with young ones, this place doth not cater,
No cups with lids, a sight most unfortunate and dire.

The stuffed mushrooms, though tasty, were but lukewarm,
A shame, for they had potential to be quite the norm.
The eggplant and veal parm, delectable indeed,
Yet priced too steep, for what they did proceed.

This establishment seemeth to straddle two worlds,
Neither casual nor fine, in a most curious whirl.
Linen napkins, adorned with cent'red paper, did gleam,
Yet tissue plate liners, a contrast most extreme.

The patio, a haven for those who wish to dine al fresco,
Did appear inviting, a spot most fair and serene, no doubt.
Perchance, I shall return, sans children, to partake,
In the fare offered here, of which my heart doth speak."

Hark! I didst venture forth to yonder tavern,
In hopes of finding merriment and cheer.
But lo! At five o'clock, the place was empty,
Save for a few souls, scattered here and there.

The hours passed slowly, and more folk didst arrive,
Yet still, the crowd was sparse, and methought 'twas strange.
But then, I saw the drinks, and their prices too,
Five or six coins for a sangria, wine, or brew.

And thus, I didst partake in happy hour,
With a sample platter, full of victuals galore.
Indeed, the fare was tasty, and I do advise,
To try the platter, for it doth satisfy.

"Pie we sought, and found it to our delight,
The apple's filling, spicy and quite bright.
But alas, the crust, uncooked did remain,
A pity, for I did not partake in the gain.

The portion, large and enough for three,
A feast, but not for one such as me.
The key lime, a treat, a larger share,
Than other places, beyond compare.

Yet, not the best pie, our search doth continue,
For that most perfect slice, our hearts do yearn.
The service slow, the waitress kind,
A gentle soul, with grace of mind."

"At last, my dearest friend, thou didst persuade me to dine at Texaz, a place of which thy tongue didst speak so highly. And lo, my heart was gladdened, for the victuals were not unpleasing unto mine taste. But alas, I didst discover a truth most vexing, that all our companions had partaken of the chicken fried steak, and found it to be most delectable. Fie upon my forgetful mind, that didst not recall this detail. Mayhap next time, I shall savor the delicacy myself."

"Hark! I've dined here ere now, and found the victuals fair. But alas, the service, poor and slow, did mar my feast. Forsooth, we sought water thrice, ere it did flow. Alack! 'Tis strange, that one must ask so oft, for that which should be freely brought."

"Verily, fair sir or madam, thou seeketh sustenance and hospitality of high quality? Pray tell, what be the cost of such bounty? Hark! A hidden charge doth lie within the bill, yet fear not, for they do reveal it ere ye take thy seat. 'Tis a sumptuous feast of five dollars and ninety-nine pence, all thou canst eat, but mark this well, good sir or madam, shouldst thou not possess their "player's card," an additional three dollars per person shall be added thereto. So, choose wisely, lest thy purse suffer undue strain."

In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,
A nicer place I ne'er didst see, I ween.
But lo, one thing that didst vex mine eyes,
Was smoke, that didst fill the air, and rise.
I could not tarry there, for more than an hour,
For smoke, it didst choke mine breath, and cloy.
The DJ, a lady fair and bright,
Didst play the tunes, with skill and might.
This place, it is unlike others, I say,
For women, they do charge, a fee, each day.
If next time, I shall visit, I pray,
XS, it shall be, my choice, ere long, I swear.

"Hark, the service was good, I do confess,
But the dish I chose, alas, did not impress.
'Pollo poblano', they called it, a name most fair,
But the taste, my friends, left much to desire.

The rice and beans, a pleasant surprise,
But the chips and salsa, oh how they did disappoint.
Too watery, the salsa, like a stream,
And the dessert, a curious thing, they did present.

A gift, they gave, both appetizer and sweet,
More than enough, their generosity to greet.
So though the meal may not have been the best,
Their kindness, I must confess, did pass the test."

"A humble shop, good for small needs,
No vast expanse of aisles, like seas.
Their fruit and veg, a sorry sight,
Picky, I, with bargains in mind, take flight.
To Giant Eagle Market District, I go,
For freshness, worth the extra show."

"O, how I adore the Venetian, with its walls and ceilings so fair and bright, and the performers on the street, they do delight. And thus, to dine within this open space did seem a wondrous plan. But alas, the wait did stretch to twenty minutes, and so we did imbibe a glass of wine at a nearby bar, to pass the time. And when we were finally seated, we did command our drinks, and I, being from Miami, didst take heed of the caipirinha's flavor, for not all know its true taste. But lo, it was most vile, and both my comrade and I didst send them back, in dismay. Then, the waiter, with a smile so bright, did recommend the pomegranate mojitos, and I, with trepidation, did accept. Alas, they too were woeful, but I would not return two cocktails, lest I seem ungrateful.

And thus, we came to the fare, and oh, how it did disappoint. A pasta dish, savory and grand, I did expect, but nay, it was but ordinary, and lackluster, at best. Alas, Postrio, thou hast all the elements, to make a feast most wondrous, but alack, thy cooking, doth leave much to be desired. Step up thy game, I pray thee."

In this place of gathering, the decor doth please,
A mishmash of styles, yet harmonious it seizes.
The servants, kind and welcoming of face,
Do serve small dishes, fit for a merry embrace.

Drinks, they do pour, with strength and art,
Syrups, homemade, to delight the heart.
A place to meet, in early eve's glow,
But watch thy purse, lest it doth overflow.

Four or five stars, they shall attain,
With time, their reputation doth remain.

"This morn, I broke my fast within these walls,
With friend, where we didst partake of victuals,
And after, didst make haste to Whole Foods,
For groceries, our bellies full of cheer.

'Twas my first time, but friend doth frequent,
This place, where she doth oft dine,
I chose the garden omelet, and toast,
With apples, cinnamon-kissed, and fine.

Heather had the oatmeal, brulee on top,
Fresh berries, too, which made her pop,
Mine was good, but not quite up to par,
But Heather's, I didst taste, and 'twas fair.

The seating, plenty, and service, swift,
But naught didst leave me in pure delight,
Save for the sweet potato fries, I hear,
Which, next time, shall be mine to devour."

"A fair abode, with modern gadgets galore,
To turn on lights, open blinds, and more.
But woe betide the guest who's not versed in tech,
For they may find themselves in quite a predicament, indeed.

They seek to make things easy, but alas,
No coffee maker in the room, what a pity!
So off to the casino one must trot,
To fetch a cup of joe, or so they thought.

But we, who stayed four days, had a plan,
To buy a machine, and leave it for the maid,
A gift, a token, for their diligent care,
And now, a cup of coffee's always near."

"Tao, a club most wondrous, I have visited thrice,
And found my thoughts of it, did change with time.
At first, I loved it, the decor, the girls, the vibe,
But later, found it crowded, and hard to abide.

The doormen, strict, and eager to take your gold,
Demand a table, or entry, you shall not behold.
We, a group of four, were turned away,
But luckily, a friendly doorman, did save the day.

Once inside, the place, doth fill with people fast,
Leaving little room, to move or dance, or find a place to rest.
A fire hazard, it may be, but still, a sight to see,
The bartenders, skilled, and the bathing girls, a delight to me.

Yet, the doormen, rude, and bouncers, unkind,
Do make the place, less pleasant, to the mind.
Still, Tao, a club, unique, and worth a visit,
For all, at least once, should give it a try, and see its merit."

"Aye, 'tis a fair place to take the young ones, I reckon. Not so much for grown-ups, save those who dote on penguins, mayhap. 'Tis not a zoo of great renown, save for the clever staging of beastly abodes, methinks."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news dost thou bring? Average Mexican victuals, sayest thou? Verily, a curious thing indeed! Forsooth, the portions be generous, yet the flavor doth leave somewhat to be desired. Mayhap I shall give them another chance, for their proximity doth make them an easy mark. But, by my troth, I wouldst not venture far to partake of their culinary delights."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, their victuals be of high quality, when they have them in store. Alas, the goat cheese curds doth disappear with great frequency. And mark my words, dear friend, avoid thou trivia night, lest thou desirest poor service. 'Tis as if thy presence doth inconvenience them, ere the quiz beginneth."

"Orlando's flight didst bring us joy, an hour early didst we land,
Airport tram didst take us to baggage claim, thence to taxis at hand.

But alas, fair Vegas, thy departure didst not go so well,
Southwest's curbside check-in and skycaps didst serve us swell.
Yet one small snow globe, a token of the city's charm,
Didst cause a fuss, and TSA didst send thee back, to post office disarm.

Gate C1, we thought, close by, a short stroll,
But lo, a lengthy trek didst lie ahead, a goodly role.
The tram, which brought us in, didst now seem far away,
And C1, the last gate, didst appear, a crowded fray.

Ah, how they love to welcome thee, but hate to bid thee adieu,
A prison-like gate, full to the brim, didst wait for thee anew."

"Morn meal, a feast most fair and bright,
Skillets, a dish of might and light.
Outside, the patio, cool and fresh,
Breakfast there, a true delight, by my troth."

"Aye, 'tis a place I've oft frequented,
And now, my thoughts on it, I shall present.
The victuals, middling fare they do provide,
Better than gruel, yet no feast for kings, they ride.

Breakfast dishes, waffles, toast, omelets made,
Meats and potatoes, all in their shade.
Lunch and dinner, similar in their array,
Fried seafood, pizza, Chinese, come what may.
Crab legs and steaks, at a higher cost, they bear.

Waitstaff, pleasant and attentive, they do show,
Price, a bargain, with player's card, it doth flow.
Six, nine, twelve, the prices, they do range,
A decent meal, under ten, a rare change.

In conclusion, 'tis a place of moderate worth,
Basic, yet cheap, a value, of great earth."

"Fair Basha, thy victuals be of quality,
With meat most genuine, not the tainted sort,
Thy salads too, fresh as the morning dew,
A feast for eyes and taste, no need to fault.

But, alas, thy female servants, fair,
From Middle East, their ways not ours,
Do shun the men, and scant their duty bear,
In this, the land of liberty and power.

For here, in West, men and women meet,
In shops and markets, all do greet,
No shame in't, nor impoliteness found,
For such is custom, and tradition bound.

So, Basha, heed my words of wisdom,
Train thy females, in our ways of pleasantry,
Lest they, in scorn, do shun the male clientele,
And thus, poor service, doth bring thee naught but woe.

For I, myself, have witnessed, twice,
Their scant regard, and sullen, troubled vice,
At Ste Catherine, Peel, a dame most dire,
And at Place Mont Royal, a woman, coy and shy,
Whose husband, bald, and friendly, didst seem,
Yet she, with scorn, didst give me change, most queer.

If she, in truth, doth loathe the male folk,
Then let her hide, in kitchen's darkest nook,
Where she, from men, may safely be apart,
And thus, no more, our custom, doth impart."

"Methinks I didst venture hither for a quick repast,  
And upon entry, mine eyes didst swiftly flee  
From the garish floral seat covers, a bit too bright,  
A true eyesore, I must confess, in plain sight.  
But then, the rest of the room didst catch mine eye,  
With round tables and red lanterns up above,  
In sooth, 'twas a quaint and cozy sight to see,  
And the old Christmas tunes didst put me in high spirits,  
Ere I didst order the soup dumplings and strings,  
Hoping the portions wouldst be generous, forsooth,  
For twenty dollars, a fair sum, I didst think.  
And thus, the verdict, my friends, doth come to this:  
The dumplings, alack, were naught but mediocre fare,  
And though the green beans were seasoned well,  
Their greasiness didst leave a foul taste, I swear.  
Yet still, I am willing to give this place another chance,  
For though my meal was not the best, methinks  
'Tis worth another try, ere I do condemn."

"Monica, the waitress, was a merry maiden indeed,
Her service, friendly and attentive, did my heart cheer.
A burger, plain yet tasty, did she bring to me,
And when I questioned the total, she did clarify.
'Twas a small oversight, the coupon, she did say,
And I, feeling foolish, did quickly pay.
The wait, a bit long, but her smile made it worth,
I would return, for her kindness, of great worth.
The eatery, clean and tidy, a pleasant sight,
The twang of country music, a bit too bright."

"Hark, fair friends! I've visited this place twice now, and verily, 'tis a hit or miss affair. Despite the renovations of yore, the cafeteria feel doth linger still. The selection, middling at best, doth depend on the day. Alas, my previous visits hath left me unimpressed, but lo, I did return last week, for George Michael did play at the MGM, and thus, I gave the buffet another chance. By fortune, the steak station was open, and the savory scent of grilled meat did stir my appetite. The crab legs, too, were delectable and sweet. Yet, alack, a special event price of ten dollars more per person did make our visit costly. Forsooth, had we planned better, we might have gone to the Wynn instead."

In fair Madison, where doth reside  
A sushi joint of wondrous kind,  
Takara be its name, and therein lies  
A feast most worthy of thy mind.  
A strip mall, humble though it be,  
Doth house this gem of gastronomy,  
Next to a dollar store, 'twould seem,  
Yet do not let that deter thee.  
For within those walls, a treat doth wait,  
Beyond thy wildest hopes or dreams,  
Their lunch special, two rolls and soup,  
Doth fill thy belly, and lighten thy purse.  
So fear not, dear reader, to give it a try,  
For Takara shall not disappoint,  
And thus, I recommend it to thee,  
With all my heart, and soul, and mind.

"A plentitude of confections, they do boast,
But, alas, their prices do border on the coast.
The servitors, not overly cordial, I fear,
Yet, verily, the gelato doth taste most dear."

"Upon mine visit to Goodtimes, I didst ponder giving it two stars, yet, being a stranger in this fair city, I knew not if 'twere consistent in its quality. 

Upon a Thursday eve, we didst venture forth to partake in their Goth night, "Carpe Noctem". Verily, the youthful spirits in the parking lot, and a hearse, didst indicate we had found the proper place. 

The dance floor, full of merry makers, didst leave us no choice but to seek the bar, where we didst find a courteous and swift tender of drinks. 

As my cup didst runneth over, I didst venture forth to dance, yet, alack, the floor, made of strange metal plates, didst not allow for a carefree frolic. 

A single visit doth not a judgment make, for the goth scene, a lifestyle 'tis, and not a fleeting fancy. Thus, I shall not be hasty in mine assessment, for the goth scene, like a slowly withering flower, doth struggle to survive in this fair city."

"Methinks my son and I didst venture to Elmer's place,
Forsooth, to partake of their culinary grace.
A first-time feat, indeed, for both of us,
To savor the flavors that this eatery doth proffer.

My son, with haste, didst choose the Asada burrito,
Whose taste, he said, didst please his palate well.
Whilst I, with hunger pangs, didst opt for the green beef,
In a hot burrito, whose messiness didst compel me
To seek aid from utensils, to consume with ease.

Their menu, though not vast, doth offer much delight,
At prices, fair and square, that doth astound.
And, verily, they do accept debit cards,
A boon, indeed, that doth set them apart.

Alas, the state of their premises, didst leave much to be desired,
With remnants of food, upon the floor, untidied.
Yet, methinks, their fare, and service, doth make up for such flaws,
And thus, to Elmer's, shall we return, anon."

"Hark! A place of gastronomic delight, we chanced upon,
After a long day of conferring, 'twas nigh.
I ordered clam chowder, with great anticipation,
But alas, 'twas lacking in seasoning, a sad creation.

The calamari, a dish of squid, was lightly breaded,
And though I prefer it so, it left me unimpressed.
The aioli, a sauce of garlic and oil, was good,
But not enough to save the dish, I must confess.

The pizzas, round and topped with cheese and toppings,
Were decent, but not exceptional, in my humble opinion.
And shrimp, those tiny crustaceans of the sea,
In cocktail form, were quite agreeable, I must see.

The service, too, was passable, not bad,
But not exceptional, like a play well-rehearsed."

Hark, a friendly gathering at Drew's we did make,
My comrade and I, our hunger to partake.
The service, quite good, our needs they did fulfill,
A place of such ilk, Eat n Park or Denny's, their skill.

I, the farmer's omelette, didst order with glee,
My friend, the Corned Beef Hash, didst he choose to see.
A hearty dish, made from scratch, not from a can,
My comrade, in delight, didst give his nod and pan.

But alas, my omelette, a bit lacking, I fear,
For though 'twas filled with potatoes, no hash browns did appear.
A small slice of toast, a meager offering, indeed,
A platter, bare, save for the omelette, a lonely deed.

A pity, for a place of such renown,
To skimp on the fruit, a frown didst wear.
Yet still, a decent meal, we didst share,
And thus, our bellies, full and content, didst bear.

"Methinks the oxtail chili cheese fries didst taste but like a common chili cheese fries, save for the egg that sat upon it. Naught else didst make it stand apart. Yet, the fries themselves were quite good, in sooth.

Alack, I didst order the Kiki's burger, and my husband, the Miyagi Wagyu. But then, I didst change my mind, and we didst switch. I didst find the Miyagi burger to be more to mine liking, reminding me of the Manly burger at Umami. My husband, however, didst prefer the Kiki's. Thus, all didst work out well.

Three stars do I give this place, for its food is indeed most tasty. Alas, 'tis also quite costly. Moreover, 'tis the first place in Vegas where I didst find boba of decent quality. Long and hard didst I search for a place that could match what I had in California, and this place didst come near. The only drawback, alack, is the price, and the small portions. Nonetheless, I wouldst still dine here again."

"Hark, good sir! I didst say, ere now,  
That I wouldst revisit this place anon,  
And, verily, I do recommen-d it now,  
For, in sooth, the victuals were most sweet.  
But, alack! 'Tis not a meal for the thrifty,  
Forsooth, 'tis somewhat costly, I do confess."

"A place of plenty, yet of little worth,
With service that doth vary in its birth.
A wall of stone, from Berlin's great fall,
Doth stand within the bathroom's narrow hall.

The food, a mix of good and not so fine,
Yet priced so low, it doth seem divine.
The prime rib, fair, but brisket, oh how vexing,
Cut wrong, it doth become a chewy, tasteless mess.

The bar, with brew of foam and golden hue,
Doth serve it up, for just a buck or two.
But watch, my friend, the service thou dost receive,
For 'tis a gamble, whether good or leave.

The space, with ceiling high and grand,
Doth bring to mind the skies of Columbia's land.
Yet, cleanliness and ambiance, do vary,
As service, hit or miss, doth often tarry.

My rating, based on three parts, doth stand,
At three, the average of my thoughts, so grand.
A place of value, for a group of friends,
But watch the service, lest thy meal doth end."

"A fair neighborhood coffeehouse, where friendly maidens pour the brew. 
Kona, my heart doth sing! A fine cup, though not the best I've sipped, yet still I choose it o'er Starbucks' bitter draught. 
Alas, no breakfast sandwiches to savor, only pastries and bagels to munch. A bacon, egg, and cheese, I do long for, with my coffee, 'twould be a most satisfying brunch. 
Beware, dear patron, the Sunday throng, that doth fill the shop with chattering folk, who doth block the way, and make it hard to stay. 'Tis a madhouse, indeed, yet still, the coffee doth please."

Hark, I've been a patron of this place for four years and more,
Where laughter doth flow like a river in springtime's prime.
In every nook and cranny, we've made merry and bright,
But one thing doth puzzle me, and that is the plight.

Of the bathrooms, I speak, which doth leave much to be desired,
With doors off their hinges and soap and towels uninspired.
And yet, despite this, there's still much to delight,
For games and music and the outdoor space doth ignite.

The staff, they doth shine with kindness and grace,
A true asset to this place, in this humble face.

"Alas, my heart doth not sing with joy,
As I didst step within The Melville's door.
A trio of gentlemen, of age, didst smoke,
In the entrance, their presence didst beset.
The scent that didst greet mine nostrils then,
Didst bring to mind the thought of days of yore,
When smoking bans didst not yet exist,
And thus, my spirits didst begin to sink.

Drinks, dear sir, didst come at quite a cost,
More than other taverns in this fair town.
Though 'twas no pricier than Teuchters, across,
That place doth boast a vibe more loose and bright.
But fear not, for the victuals didst seem,
Fair priced and tempting, so I shall return,
To partake of them, and thus my doubts dispel."

In days of yore, when first I met my love,
A trip to Lake Las Vegas did ensue.
And though the village held many a treat,
I'd ne'er partaken of their culinary delight.

So, on our anniversary, I chose this place,
With patio seating, and a view of the lake's grace.
But lo, the patio was quite foul and unclean,
And bird droppings did adorn the chairs, most obscene.

The food, however, did make up for the sight,
My steak was cooked just right, and oh so bright.
The service was good, but our waitress did stray,
Leaving us to ponder, and to pray.

The cocktails, alas, did not impress,
But the food, oh the food, did make up for the mess.
And so, we paid the bill, and did depart,
With memories of the meal, forever in our heart.

In fair Montreal, where dining options abound,
Amidst the throngs of tourists, I did stumble upon
A French bistro, named Les Deux Gamins, that did please
With prices fair and menu items that did tease.

Their fare was standard, no surprises to behold,
Steak tartare, steak frite, lamb shank, dishes of old,
But sometimes, simplicity is what I seek,
And thus, my expectations were met, my friend.

Alas, the kitchen did lose our appetizer ticket,
But made amends with wine, a full bottle, so neat,
In conclusion, while not the best French eatery,
Les Deux Gamins is still a place to visit, verily.

"Hark, fair friends, I come from sunny Cali's shore,
Where sushi doth abound, and freshness doth implore.
But now, in Arizona's desert clime,
I seek a spot where sushi doth shine.

At Hiro's, I didst venture, hopes not high,
For in the landlocked West, fish doth not fly.
The ambiance, pleasant, doth my senses greet,
And sushi, though not Cali-fresh, doth meet.

But alas, the prices, they do climb,
As rent and fish costs, they do combine.
Bento boxes, too dear, doth make me frown,
For tempura, chicken, locally found.

The chicken, dry, doth leave me unsatisfied,
And organic, free-range, doth my mind divide.
A shame, for Hiro's, doth have potential grand,
But for now, I must seek elsewhere, in this land."

"Methinks these men of trade be personable indeed,
Their promptness in attending to my need, doth speak their creed.
A simple task, of electric sort, didst require my aid,
And lo, they found a space, within their busy schedule, to abide.
Alas, they could not solve the problem, but with grace,
Didst admit their limitations, and sent me to an electrician in haste.
He, in five short minutes, didst repair the fault,
And now, I find myself, with naught but praise, to utter.
A second task, of greater worth, didst require their skill,
But alas, their calendar, didst not allow, for two weeks to fulfill.
The sum they asked, for service rendered, was but a fraction,
Of what other craftsmen, didst demand, with no relation.
So here I'll stay, and wait, for their return,
For these men, of hand and heart, have earned my trust, and my concern."

"Fair sir, the victuals were not amiss,  
A star they lose, for service was slow.  
We tried the fowl, with flavor it did bless,  
But dry it was, alas, I do declare.  
The BBQ sandwich, much the same, I fear,  
But ribs, oh ribs, they were divine, my dear.  
And sides, aplenty, they did provide,  
All four we tried, most tasty, I must confide.  
But lo, a star they lose, for wait we did,  
While those who came after, their orders got.  
A gentleman, with grace, did intervene,  
And gave us free, a dish, to make amends, ye see.  
So, shall I try this place once more?  
Hoping 'twas but a fluke, I pray thee, friend."

"Hark, my dearest husband and I didst dine early,
Outside on the patio, 'twas a pleasant sight.
But alas, the noise of the road didst intrude,
And made the ambiance somewhat less delight.

Inside, the air was thick and full of sound,
So we didst choose to sit without a roof around.
The flatbread and garlic balls, a tasty treat,
Were served warm, and didst our hunger greet.

But when the main course came, oh what a sight,
My husband didst exclaim, "To McDonald's we must take flight!"
For the portion was small, and the clams few,
Seven tiny ones, and linguini scarce didst break through.

I, however, didst order the chicken marsala,
A generous portion, flavorful and savory to alla.
I shared my meal with my love, and we didst agree,
That this dish was the best, and worth the fee.

But alas, the service was slow, oh so slow,
That we didst wonder, wouldst we ever go?
For though the food was good, the wait was long,
And made us question, if we'd sing this song.

So, in conclusion, we may not return,
For there are other places that our hearts yearn.
But still, the memory of that chicken marsala,
Shall stay with us, and make our taste buds quiver and quaila."

"Alas, poor sushi! Ra, a place of wonder, where first I did partake of sushi's delight. But alack, how limited was my knowledge then! For since, in other halls of Hiro, I have found far greater joy. 

Yet still, if thou must go, take heed of this advice: the Las Vegas roll, a curious mix, and calamari, fried and wrapped in cream cheese, rice, and eel's sweet embrace, do taste divine. The rest, alas, doth pale in comparison. 

But fear not, for happy hour brings forth good cheer, and rolls, though small, do satisfy."

In this place, called Mandalay, doth lie  
A store named Urban Outfitters, nearby  
A bay, where one may park for free,  
And find some gifts, both funny and breezy.

The clothes they sell, are casual, yet chic,  
For those who seek to dress with flair and trick  
The books and gags, they do abound,  
At the front of the store, a joyous sound.

Mandalay Place, doth share a lot,  
With Mandalay Bay, a parking spot,  
So leave thy car, and take a stroll,  
To find some humor, and a bit of soul.

"A decent Chinese feast, akin to Panda's fare,  
In a food court, 'twas served with nary a care.  
The prices, alack, did seem a mite steep,  
For a bottle of brew, the cost did make me sleep.  
At the casino, 'tis better to buy thy ale,  
And play a game, while thou dost doth regale.  
A good place, indeed, for a quick repast,  
I shall return, but without the beer, at last."

"Hark, fair friends! 'Tis been awhile since last I stepped within a $.99 store, and by my troth, I had forgotten quite how grand the deals didst lie within. For in these trying times, when purses be tight and funds be low, a good bargain doth prove a rare and wondrous find. But fear not, dear hearts, for this humble abode doth offer succor to those who seek it. Here, within these hallowed halls, thou shalt discover all manner of goods, from plates and dishware to canned victuals. Verily, there doth be something here for all, even for those who doth not search with purpose. So, gentle readers, take a moment to peruse and see what treasures thou mayst find."

"Methinks their victuals be of fair quality,
But lo, a woeful tale doth oft unfold.
When e'er I order pear salad, 'tis lacking somewhat,
As if the serving maid didst not attend.
Or, I request wings with blue cheese,
And in its stead, ranch doth make its presence known.
'Tis small annoyances such as these,
That doth make the experience vexing,
And causeth me to question the cost.
I wish to receive what I do pay for,
And not, upon arriving home,
Discover my wing in a dressing most foul,
Or my salad in disarray, quite wrong.
Yet, they do make amends and rectify their mistake,
But alas, 'tis a frequent occurrence, I do partake."

"A secret gem, this eatery, tucked away in a corner strip mall, beside a high school, didst we find. Small, yet cozy, with booths, tables, and a sushi bar, 'twas run by an elderly couple, kind and true. Their bento box specials, we didst order for lunch, a feast fit for a king, with soup, egg roll, tempura vegetables, half a California roll, and white rice, all for a mere $6.95. My brother, he chose General Tao Chicken, while I, Mongolian Beef, both dishes, a delight. We shall return, to savor their bento boxes, and try their sushi and sashimi, of the finest sort. Spread the word, good people, that they may prosper, and their business flourish."

"A tidy shop, with naught but cleanliness within,
Deceives the eye, for greater space doth lie.
I ordered chicken noodles, served in bread,
A vessel cold, which needed heat to stir.
The broth did taste most wondrous, rich and deep,
Yet bread, alas, did lack in flavor, swift to soak.
A simple roll, with hole, did serve its purpose ill,
As bread bowl, it did not fulfill its duty well.
I noted too, a man, with hands unclean,
Did scratch his backside, then returned to cook.
Fair machines, with drinks of varied hue,
Did please my sight, yet could not make me stay.
My meal, though not most wretched, left me unsatisfied,
And thus, I shall seek sustenance elsewhere, ere long."
"Fare still as tasty as of yore, yet salads now diminished in size. The newfangled fashion doth mar the cozy ambiance."

"Aye, trusty Beanscene, where I do oft repair,
For a mug of Americano, and a quiet lair.
The leather booths, they call to me, like a siren's song,
To sit and read, and ponder life's meaning long.

The staff, they be friendly, and the tunes they play,
Do fill the air with mellow, gentle sway.
A refuge from the hustle, and the bustling crowd,
This place, it doth provide, a peaceful shroud.

I've ne'er come here for victuals, no, not I,
For nachos and paninis, they do not catch my eye.
But for a cup of coffee, and a place to rest,
Beanscene, it doth suffice, and doth pass the test."

In fair 941, a bar of gay repute,
Neither awful nor amazing, doth it stand,
Amidst the city's many such establishments,
'Tis hard to spot, save for a curious eye.

I chanced upon it one afternoon,
And found the atmosphere quite comfortable,
With few patrons present, the mood was light,
The bartender, too, was pleasant in sight.

A Mai Tai, spelled thus, I did imbibe,
For four dollars and seventy-five cents,
A generous pour, in a larger glass, did flow,
A great experience, I must needs avow.

But alas, my dear, a different tale,
Did unfold when last I visited, with my love,
On a Friday eve, the crowd did swell,
With folk of diverse sorts, 'twas hard to pigeonhole.

Prices steep, for beer, did cause me woe,
And a cranberry vodka, in a tiny glass, did flow,
A mixed bag, indeed, doth 941 present,
So be prepared, my friend, for what may come.

"Methinks 'twas fate that drew me to this place,
Amidst the splendor of Las Vegas' grace.
Each time I ventured forth, the building's charm,
Did stir within my breast a keen alarm.

At last, upon my latest journey thither,
I did resolve to sample their sweet slender.
Alas, the wait within did stretch and yawn,
Two hours or more, ere we could sit and dine.

So, to the food court swiftly did we flee,
To find sustenance and bide our time, ye see.
Later, we returned, the frozen drinks to claim,
But lo! The line, it did remain, a woeful plight.

A solitary man, with labors manifold,
Did struggle to keep pace, his station to hold.
Seven maidens we, and thus, two large cups shared,
With straws aplenty, lest our thirst be unassuaged.

Tasty, it was, but naught save chocolate's essence,
In form of milkshake, with gritty texture's presence.
Worth the eight dollars? Nay, methinks 'twas not,
For though 'twas pleasant, o'erpriced, it was, by far."

"Methinks the tacos didst taste most wondrous fair,
In yonder tavern with an overly cute air.
Three of the meat sort didst I sample with glee,
Yet found the rice and beans to be somewhat lacking in zest, alack.

I shall return, but when my heart doth yearn
For Mexican fare, I know there be better choices to learn."

"A fair breakfast spot, yet overpriced, I fear. Better value doth Cora provide, and Cafe Orange, better fare. Yet, if thou art in the vicinity and hunger doth beset thee, 'tis not a terrible option, I do confess."

"Hark! I do frequent Outback, forsooth,
For there, my friends, doth lie a truth most fair and bright.
The victuals, they be good, the place, clean as a whistle,
And service, average or better, doth make my spirit light.
This very location, meeteth all requirements, by my troth.
Two of us didst dine at five o'clock, avoiding crowds most foul."

"Hark, what news is this? A change for the better, 'twould seem,
At Terrible Herbst, where once all was but a dream.
The victuals now, they say, are of finer quality,
And service, too, doth move with greater celerity.
The ten-dollar deals, still a bargain, doth remain,
A boon for those who seek to dine without much pain.
But lo, one woe doth still persist, a plight most dire,
That this, the Cafe, doth be where aged waitresses retire.
Slow of step and mind, they doth require much prompting,
For condiments or settings, ere their needs be mounting."

"A fair theatre, with naught but pleasant memories doth lie,
Save for the throngs that gather, causing woe and strife.
And, alack, the cost, a princely sum indeed,
Yet, lo, the matinee, a paltry five dollars doth yield."

"O, how I detest the queues at Walmart,
They stretch on forever, a woeful sight.
And when I finally reach the checkout,
'Tis but a single register, oh so slow.

Alas, good sirs, wouldst thou consider,
Opening up more registers, perchance?
For in this place, I fear, I shall be stuck,
For an eternity, in this wretched line."

"A pox upon this chocolate shoppe of high renown,
Whose wares didst fail to impress, save for a few.
The atmosphere, akin to Sephora's domain,
Didst lack the black gloves, a most curious refrain.

A medley of chocolates, diverse and rare,
Didst pique my interest, yet none didst declare
A taste so sweet, that I wouldst buy in bulk,
Despite five flavors sampled, with nary a quirk.

They gifted me some freebies, a token of their grace,
Tortilla chips dipped in chocolate, with Cayenne's embrace.
An interesting mix, yet not quite to my taste,
A pox, I say, upon this chocolate shoppe of haste."

"Alas, my friends, how dearly I did hope
For wondrous feast at this place, so oft
My colleagues praised its tacos, oh so fine
And service swift, their words did entwine

But lo, my heart doth sink, forsooth
The shrimp tacos, meagre, lacking truth
In taste, and service, slow as sloth
My beer, a-waiting, doth steal my youth

A group of eight, we gathered round
Yet orders, all awry, confusion found
The checks, a jumble, nary a pair
Didst match the food, a sorry tale to bear

The server, harried, doth strive to mend
Yet twenty minutes passed, ere all amended
The food, a-coming, doth bring dismay
For naught but errors, doth the day

A frozen margarita, weak and small
For seven gold coins, a price too great to pay
Avoid it, friends, lest ye be fooled
And seek elsewhere, a better way to cool

Thus, once again, I shall essay
To visit this place, and hope doth stay
That improvements made, my heart doth cheer
And fare, much better, doth appear."

"Hark, good sir! Doth thou labor at Bally's?  By thine appearance, I do perceive  
A form most fit and comely, as if the gods  
Had fashioned thee for sport and revelry.  
This place, a haven of repose, doth offer  
Libations cheap and plentiful, a true delight.  
Yet, alack! The pool, though fair and inviting,  
Is not of such great size as to accommodate  
A multitude of bathers. Verily, 'tis small,  
But still, a pleasant spot to pass the time."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news is this? A place that doth serve food most fair and drinks of finest quality. Alas, there be a catch, forsooth! On Fridays, 'tis a woeful sight to see the crowd, a long wait for fish, indeed. Yet fear not, dear patron, for their fish and chips, both fried and broiled, be worthy of thy taste. And, by my troth, their fried mushrooms do delight!"

"A humble Mexican eatery, hidden away,
I chanced upon, while seeking another place to dine.
The menu, brief and concise, held ten items dear,
And one bearded man, not quite Mexican, did shine.
He took the orders, cooked the food with care,
As I sat, wondering at this quaint place rare.
Hot sauces and seasonings, on each table laid,
Added zest to the meal, and made my taste buds swayed.
The decor, a mix of tiki hut and Mexican flair,
With Frida Kahlo art, and paper lanterns fair.
Mexican sweets and drinks, they also did provide,
A delightful surprise, my curiosity to abide.
Enchiladas with mole, I ordered, and they were grand,
The sauce, rich and flavorful, a true Mexican brand.
The kitchen, small and cozy, reheats, I do suppose,
But the food, delicious, left me in a state of repose.
A charming little spot, I shall return anon,
For more of their fare, and to savor each bite, ere long."

"Verily, the service here was most excellent,
But alas, the drinks and prices did offend.
A Mojito and Margarita, in plastic cups they came,
With naught but ice to fill the space, and eleven coins did claim.
The Nachos, though tasty, were not as we had sought,
And thus, our trust in this place is somewhat brought.
I shall stick to the places I know and hold dear,
For here, my friends, I fear we shall not tarry long, nor cheer."

"Methinks 'twas two days and two trips to yonder spinning meat sticks of joy. Hark! I must confess, fair readers, that I had already summoned the dolmas when mine eyes didst peruse the reviews. Alas! Valerie's words didst paint a picture not so different from the truth. Dolmas, like pakora within Indian halls, are found in most establishments, yet their quality doth vary. Methinks the ones I received didst look the part, but alas! The scent of citrus was all that could be savored. Eight of them there were, and five and a half remained. Fearful was I of what might come next, but fate didst smile upon me. The gyro salad, fresh and plentiful, didst delight mine taste buds. Decent pita bread and sauces didst accompany it. My comrade, who didst order the gyro pita basket, didst also enjoy her repast. Verily, I shall return, forsooth, based on the entrees alone, and without the dolmas, 'twould have been a four."

"A plethora of plays have I witnessed, my friends,
But this one, alas, did fall beneath the mark.
Coordination lacking, errors did abound,
And rude, discourteous staff did further mar the ground.

A performer spoke at the start of the show,
"Flash photography, good people, is not allowed, you know."
The crowd, obedient, did turn off their flash,
Only to be met by an elderly woman, quite brash.
She snatched their cameras, with a scowl on her face,
"No photography, I say! Leave now, and save grace!"

Oh, how the gamble of watching did leave me in woe,
For mediocrity did reign, and poor staff did flow.
I pray, good people, save your coin, and flee,
For this show, alas, doth not merit your attention, 'tis a farce, indeed."

"Methinks 'tis strange that such a place, so fair and bright,
With food that doth please mine appetite, doth lack
The one thing that doth make mine heart sing -
A glass of white wine, crisp and light.

But lo, upon mine visit, last Saturday eve,
The bar didst not possess a single drop,
Of Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blanc, or Pinot Grigio,
Leaving me to ponder, in dismay and woe,
How couldst a place so fine, with atmosphere so grand,
Be without the wine that doth complete the land?

Inventory control, they must needs learn,
Lest they be left with naught but bitter disappointment to discern.
And thus, I leave, with naught but two stars to bestow,
For though the fried bologna sandwich doth please,
'Tis not enough to make up for the lack of wine, I do confess."

"Fair maiden, I didst partake of yonder fried chicken salad,
A dish most delectable, yet somewhat misguided.
For in my quest for healthy fare, the fried chicken strips didst play
A counterproductive role, and thus, my wishes were not satiated.

The waitress, a sprite most attentive, didst tend to my needs
With haste and diligence, her service, a true delight.
Yet, as the sun began to set, its rays didst cast
A glare so fierce, it didst pierce mine eyes, a sensation most vexing.
I prayed the bartender, a gentle soul, to close the shutter,
That the sun's bright beams might not disturb my repast.
She heeded my request, and with a smile so sweet,
Didst shut the blinds, save one, which let the sun's radiance meet."

"A spacious tavern, full of sporty cheer,
With patios grand, and menus most queer.
Each sandwich, matched with greens so fine,
A feast for eyes, as well as taste divine.
Specials galore, to make each visit new,
And birthdays, celebrated with flair anew.
Inside, a haven, filled with screens aglow,
For fans of games, and those who love to know."

"Fair victuals, yet service lacked a mite.
Dumplings on the first course, a true delight.
Blended margaritas, strong and full of might,
Beware, lest thou find thyself in a merry plight."

"O'er-rated, say I, this place doth be,
Pabellon, a wondrous sight to see,
Rice, dry as dust, doth leave me unsatisfied,
Prices, too steep, for such scant fare provided.
Expectations high, alas, not met,
Meh, a feeling of disappointment doth beget."

In sooth, a wondrous sight didst greet mine eyes,
A multitude of folk, in haste and throng,
Didst pace the floors of yonder Casino's halls,
Their faces bright with hope, their spirits strong.

The staff, kind-hearted souls, didst tend to our needs,
With smiles and courtesy, they didst dispense their deeds.
But alas, dear friend, the drinks they didst sell,
Were not the cheapest, nor the easiest to tell.

"Hark! 'Tis Walgreens, a place most plain,
Three stars, for naught but sameness doth remain.
Alack! I wish I could bestow four stars,
If they but sold wine and beer, perchance then 'twould be a cause for cheer."
"Methinks 'tis fair, though not the best, yet far from base. Have not been let down, and thus do dine here once a week. The Thai basil doth please my taste, as doth the steak salad."

"Alack, what woeful fate doth befall this place,
In downtown Gilbert, where folk do congregate.
Their food, a sorry sight, doth take an age,
Forty minutes, by my reckoning, did it take.
My love and I, the fourth table sat,
Did wait, and wait, and wait, for our repast.
The service, fair, the waiters kind and neat,
But oh, the food, a disappointment, a defeat.
My salad, o'errun with onions, a bitter taste,
My love's, just right, a pleasant, savory feast.
The panini, naught to write home about,
Alack, I would not go, save for the wine, no doubt.
But friends, if thou must go, beware the wait,
And choose, perchance, a swifter, more expedite date."

"A Vegas dining spot, traditional in its ways,
With naught o'er the top, yet pleasant still,
The renovated space, once a cafe, now doth sway,
In tropical hues, with beachy vibes that chill.

Indoor or out, thy seat thou mayst choose,
And view the pool's waterfall, a sight to muse,
The staff, friendly, and the fare, most fine,
A bit pricier, true, yet worth each coin divine.

The dishes, tasty, with generous portions too,
So, pretty, pretty, this eatery anew."

This Dillard's place, methinks, doth leave much to be desired. My visits here, alas, have been but mediocre at best.
