The salesfolk in the women's attire department do err, it seems, in their approach. Some be o'er eager, others quite unhelpful, a balance they do not strike. In accessories, however, a kinder crew doth dwell, with hearts inclined to aid and guide thee well. A recent return, in perfect state, with tags intact, didst pose a problem, 'tis true. Yet, bless the manager's heart, a store credit he did grant, in grace and wisdom, knowing I had passed the limit, alack. This shop, then, doth earn but middling praise, yet shall I return, forsooth, drawn by their wares, and hoping, mayhap, for a day when service doth excel.

Thou seeketh a tavern of renown, my friend?
A place where thou may find good cheer and merriment?
Champions, in Gilbert, doth fit the bill, I wager.
'Tis a humble abode, but full of mirth and laughter.
The patrons, mostly of the common folk,
Do gather there to partake of ale and beer.
Six dart boards and many pool tables, besides,
To test thy skill and challenge thy peers.
Go, then, and revel in this jolly place,
Where thou shalt find joy, in a most friendly embrace.

"Falafel, a dish of sandy hue,
With crunchy exterior, much like dew,
Reminds me of beachside days,
When gritty sand would find its way,
Into my mouth, a most vexing fray.

A plate of rice, salad, and pita too,
But where, oh where, is the hummus anew?
Tahini, a scant amount, they do provide,
In a small ramekin, a paltry guide.

Dry, dry, dry, a mouthful of despair,
No respite from the parchedness in the air.
Falafel sandwich, a better choice, I say,
Or other value meals, to pass the day.

Overpriced, the falafel plate doth seem,
With soda, near twelve dollars, a steep dream.
Hummus, an added cost, to soothe the throat,
Bringing the total, to sixteen, or so,
For one person, a price most prohibitive, no doubt."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, I say, this place doth serve most curious victuals indeed. Verily, the service, by two maidens most strange, didst leave me in wonder and dismay. 'Tis a pity, for the fare, though mediocre, didst stir within me a hunger most fierce. Alas, I shall not return, for the experience didst border on the bizarre and unsettling. Farewell, dear inn! Mayhap another time, when the service doth improve, shall I grace thy halls once more with mine own fair presence."

"Fare was sumptuous, service poor, I didst sit at bar.
Bartender, stout of girth, didst not stir from his nook.
I didst walk to sporting house, fetched ale ere he didst note our presence.
'Twas half past six, on Saturday eve."

"Hark! A Milwaukeean through and through, I stayed at Wynn, and thus didst venture to the in-house Bartolotta's, unaware of its origin in my fair city. Alas, I didst not partake in the full experience, forsooth, for I do not consume seafood, which doth arrive fresh daily from the Mediterranean. Aye, 'tis a bit absurd, yet understandable, given the arid environs.

Thus, I didst opt for pasta dishes and pancetta. Verily, the pancetta was tough and fatty, but I didst expect such. The sheep's milk ravioli, however, didst delight mine taste buds. The spaghetti with ragu? Not so much, alack.

In conclusion, methinks the price didst outweigh the quality, but mayhap 'twas the ambiance that didst lack. Forsooth, they should transport Bartolotta's Lake Park Bistro from Milwaukee and plant it within the Wynn, anon. In my humble opinion, 'twould be an improvement, by the stars!"

In fair June, a review most vexing didst pen,
Of this firm, which doth damage our gazebo, alack!
With palm fronds broken, a mess didst ensue,
And anger didst swell within my breast, I do confess.

But now, a pact we have made, full of grace,
They didst offer restitution, in fairness and in place.
Their kindness didst abound, all issues to address,
And thus, our quarrel didst find a peaceful reprieve.

Their customer service, most excellent didst prove,
A lesson to all, in times of trouble and of woe.
So here, my friends, a tale of resolution doth end,
And all's well that doth finish well, as the saying doth intend.

In fair Edinburgh, where we didst honeymoon,
Our first full day began with breakfast sought,
To give us strength for all the sightseeing we'd do.
Down to the Grassmarket, from our hotel, anon,
We walked, and searched for a place to dine,
Wherefore we chose Cafe Jacques, most thronged, no doubt.
A sign of quality, the crowd doth make it out.

We squeezed inside, the space was small, indeed,
And found a seat, my love and I, in need.
I had the English breakfast, he the American,
The coffee, hot, my jetlagged soul to redeem.
Alas, I burned my mouth, in haste, I did confess,
For two days more, my tongue did suffer, alack.

The waiter, strange, our request to fulfill,
Two tall glasses of milk, for my love, did bring.
Is this an American custom, pray tell?
I rated three stars, for this place, 'twas just fine,
And started well our day in fair Edinburgh, divine.

"Hark, what news is this? A place of breakfast, fair and bright,
With corned beef hash, most wondrous in sight.
But alas, dear friends, my visit did not go well,
For service poor, did my mood, most certainly quell.

I chanced upon this place, at two and fifteen,
And saw the sign, that said they were still open, keen.
My love, didst tell me, that the door did say,
They closed at two, but Cindy, didst come our way.

She asked the kitchen, and her boss, so kind,
If they could accommodate us, and we did find,
That though we were late, they wouldst still serve,
And Cindy, with a smile, didst make our meal, most deserving.

But lo, dear friends, another server there,
Didst make our visit, most uncomfortable, I swear.
Carol, her name, didst loudly complain,
That we were seated late, and caused much pain.

Her words, didst cut, like a sharp knife, so cold,
And made us feel, most unwelcome, I am told.
The food, was amazing, and Cindy, so sweet,
But Carol's attitude, didst leave much to be desired, I do entreat.

Lady, thy boss didst approve, so hold thy peace,
And be thou grateful, for the business, that doth increase.
If 'tis a problem, take initiative, I pray,
And turn off that sign, that doth still shine bright, at three of the clock, I say."

"Hark, what tales of yore have reached mine ears,
Of this place, where food doth flow in abundance,
A buffet fit for kings, or so it seems,
With salads, meats, and sweets in ample measure.

A Friday afternoon, we chanced to stray,
Upon this place, with hunger pangs at play,
And lo, the line was short, or none at all,
So quickly seated, we didst take our call.

Ah, but alack, the food, it seemed so far,
A trek, a journey, through the crowded bar,
Yet, needs must we, our cardio to gain,
So forth we went, to sample all they had in store.

The salad line, we started, with glee,
And made our way, through all we could see,
Action stations, plenty, to behold,
Variety, in truth, didst make our spirits bold.

But, alas, the flavors, they didst not impress,
The beet salad, that was the best, I must confess,
All else, just average, naught to write home about,
Unless, perchance, thou art a drinker, devout.

The service, middling, plates left unattended,
A bit too long, our patience, it didst impend,
Yet, sixteen coins, for lunch, a bargain, fair,
To feed the masses, diverse, beyond compare.

Again, I say, this place, I wouldst try,
Before returning, with haste, I wouldst buy,
Other venues, first, to taste, to see,
If better fare, they do offer, more grand to me."

Yester-morn, I had occasion to meet a client from the north,
And visit other customers in Deer Valley, by the south.
There be few eateries in the area, open early,
Save for this place, where I didst decide to have my fill.

The owner, a gruff man, yet friendly, doth run the show,
And though his prices be higher, the food doth flow.
A Max burrito, with egg, potato, cheese, and meat,
Didst satisfy my hunger, and left me feeling neat.

The place, though small, doth have a steady stream of guests,
And though the parking lot doth fill, 'tis but a test.
For I shall return, to partake of their fare,
For it doth please mine taste buds, and the service doth share.

"Hark! All ye who seek knowledge of China Stars,
In town there be three, and confusion doth reign.
But fear not, fair reader, for I shall make clear,
The difference between them, and end all doubt and fear.

Two China Stars there be, on Murray Ave,
One at 4219, in Greenfield, the other, 1900,
In Squirrel Hill, at Pacific Ring's old site.
The first, no kin to North Hills' China Star,
Doth serve standard American-Chinese fare,
While the second, affiliated, doth offer traditional Chinese cuisine,
A guide to China Stars, for all to share.

Now, I, myself, have ordered from the first,
And found their fried, greasy Chinese food to be the best.
For cheap takeout, China Star doth reign supreme,
So, next time thou hast a craving, give them a call, and thou shalt see."

"Fair cooked victuals they serve, yet ingredients of low degree. A pleasant sight doth the decor provide, but service, alas! doth leave much to be desired. Fried bananas, a dish most wondrous, my heart doth sing with joy at its mere mention!"

"Hark! Fish and chips, a dish most dear to Ireland's heart,
Served with ale and cheer, a merry gathering to impart.
Bands play there, too, their melodies so sweet and fine,
A place to meet, to greet, and let one's spirits shine.
The staff, kind and true, doth make one feel most welcome,
And on certain nights, a tribute band doth rock the venue,
Joshua Tree, they call themselves, and U2's songs they do sing,
A night of joy and mirth, for all to revel in."

"Verily, this place doth please mine eyes, yet doth it pale in comparison to that most noble room, the Foundation Room, which sitteth atop yon hotel.  The melodies here were but passable, and the ambiance, though somewhat neat, doth not compare to the Foundation Room's grand club within Mandalay Bay."

"Verily, the Monte Carlo doth seem to have seen better days,
A once fair inn, now doth show signs of decay.
A -5 bar, alas, doth not compare to those of yore,
Yet, renovations forthcoming, mayhap a new dawn doth break.
In the heart of the Strip, 'tis a prime location, no doubt,
But, alack, I fear I shall not choose to lay my head here,
For newer, shinier lodgings beckon, with nary a care."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy for Rugged Wearhouse,  
A place where men may find their perfect garb,  
And this one, in particular, doth seem quite neat,  
With wares arranged in tidy rows, like a well-kept street.  

But lo, a pair of boots did catch mine eye,  
With a price tag of $25, a sum not too high,  
Yet, upon closer inspection, a mistake did lie,  
For the tag from the store did still adorn the shoe,  
And thereupon, it did proclaim its worth to be  
$20, a sum much lower than what I did pay,  

Now, why, dear sirs, would ye keep such a tag?  
When clearly, 'tis a sign of falsehood, a trick,  
To make a customer believe he doth receive  
A bargain, when in truth, 'tis but a ruse,  
A ploy to part him from his hard-earned pay,  
And leave him feeling cheated, in dismay.  

So, three stars, I give thee, Rugged Wearhouse,  
For though thy wares be fair, thy ways be not,  
For honesty, in commerce, doth prevail,  
And falsehoods, such as this, doth bring disgrace,  
And lose the trust of those who wouldst avail,  
Themselves of thy goods, and thus, thy name."

"Methinks the atmosphere of Beckett's Table doth please mine eyes,
From the arrangement of the room to the vessels that hold wine.
But alas, their victuals didst not quite win my heart,
For though the bacon cheddar biscuits were tasty, the honey butter,
Apple-flavored and hard as stone, didst not spread easy.
I sampled the green chile pork stew and the osso buco,
And found neither dish to be particularly special,
Not that they were poorly made, but neither didst impress.
But the chocolate dipped bacon s'mores, oh how grand!
A gamble, perhaps, but the homemade peanut butter,
Excellent, and all the components didst complement each other well.
So, though the food may not have won me over,
The ambiance of Beckett's Table doth still linger,
A pleasant memory, and one that may yet bring me back."

"Hark, my stomach doth protest, forsooth,
Against the meal I didst recently consume.
The service, poor and lacking in cheer,
Didst leave me in a sour mood, I do declare.
And, alack, the prices, far too steep,
Didst make mine purse weep with dismay and woe.
But, lo, the vegetable options, fair and bright,
Didst shine like stars on a winter's night.
Yet, woe betide, they didst run out of spring rolls,
Leaving me in a state of utter disappointment and woe.
Indeed, the meal, not filling, didst leave me still hungry,
And with a taste, most bitter and unpleasant, didst linger."

"Fresh fare and prime locale, yet portions small they be.

LYFE Kitchen, near Whole Foods, our steps didst lead,
For a pre-shopping snack, we didst decide and feed.
I, vegan thai curry, and hibiscus tea didst choose,
My love, grass-fed burger, and cafe mocha, didst voice.

Drinks, to die for, his mocha, energizing,
My tea, hibiscus, flavorful, refreshing, didst find.
Meals, decent flavor, small portions, a sight,
My curry, spicy, wheatberries and tofu, lacking in might.
His burger, good, hickory flavor, a delight,
But still, hungry, we didst feel, and wished for more bite.

Questions, two, I didst ponder, tofu organic?
Beef, grass-fed, or conventional, a thought didst engender.
If not, then why, to a health-conscious place,
Eat meat and soy, grown with haste, without grace?

Return, we may, to try other dishes, anon,
But next time, hunger, we shall not be upon."

"Fair sir, I must confess, the victuals here have ne'er impressed me much. Overpriced, they be, for the meagre dishes they proffer. But, verily, 'tis a pleasant place to partake of potables and light repast - upon the patio, by the fountain's gentle flow. Their small dishes are passable, and reasonably priced, and the atmosphere, most agreeable. I do enjoy bringing visitors hither, when they come to call upon me. And, should they still have hunger pangs, we shall repair to Los Sombreros for a hearty feast!"

"Fair sir, the victuals didst please mine taste,
But, alas! the service didst leave much to be desired.
The waitress, scarce and hidden from view,
Didst make us wait, her duties unfulfilled.
A soda, too, didst take an age to arrive,
And water, equally slow, didst doth the same.
In sooth, a curious case, this eatery doth present."

"Tis like Samurai Sam's, but not so grand,
The prices fair, the portions of a decent land,
But alas, the steak, too thin it doth seem,
And though the sauce be passable, 'tis not my cream.
I do prefer a more soy-salty taste,
Yet still, they give a small container to haste."

"Fare thee well, dear gourmand! Hark, what news I bring, of culinary delights most wondrous! In this fair city, there be a place, where food doth reign supreme, a veritable feast for thine eyes and taste buds. Alas, 'tis true, the cost doth rise, yet fear not, for 'tis worth each penny spent, I do aver. Their cable cars, a sweet delight, doth make thy mouth to water, and leave thee in a state of blissful satisfaction. And should thou seek a meal most fortifying, to start thy day aright, then to the Bellagio thou shouldst repair, where breakfast doth await, a spread most generous and fair. Farewell, and may thy hunger be appeased!"

"Alas, my friends, I must revise my former review,
For Thin Crust pizza did not meet my expectations anew.
'Twas horrid, indeed, and should be struck from the list,
A travesty, compared to Rosati's, or so I insist.

We ordered Sausage and Bacon, with hope in our hearts,
But the crust was as cardboard, and tasted of naught but art.
We sent it back, and begged them to take it away,
And vowed to nevermore order it, come what may.

But fear not, dear friends, for all was not lost,
For the Penne pasta with meat sauce was truly the cost.
'Twas fantastic, a feast fit for a king,
A dish most worthy of praise, and a joy to sing.

So, if thou seekest pizza, stick with the deep dish,
With butter crust, a delight that doth never dismiss.
Forsooth, 'tis a treat, a culinary dream,
That doth make the taste buds dance, and the belly scream."

"Thus, with three stars, my review doth begin. A first-time visitor, I, to Panera's den, For sandwiches, a change from subs, I didst choose. 'Tis newly opened, near my humble abode, And so, I thought, why not give it a go?\n\nThe service, swift and kind, at the counter, didst shine, But waiting, long, for takeout, didst seem like a crime. Yet, understanding, came, when I didst see, Folk, eating in, with orders, placed before me. Homeward, I brought the sandwiches, with glee, And found them, quite good, indeed, they were. My wife, her Cuban chicken panini, didst enjoy, And I, the Steak and white cheddar, didst employ. A fair kick, from the horseradish, didst bring cheer. Chips, in small bags, for each, we didst receive, And the order, neatly packaged, in cardboard boxes, didst conceal. A quibble, I didst find, with no way to discern, Which sandwich, which, without undressing the bread. A suggestion, to HQ, I didst send, And they, didst reply, with thanks, and a vow to amend. Again, I shall return, and next time, I shall dine, In the pleasant room, or outdoors, when cooler, the climate doth become."

"A club most excellent, no gambling den, nor pool,
Nor fancy frills to speak of, 'tis but a place
To dance, drink, and make merry with friends,
And revel in the sweet melodies that play.
The music of the eighties doth fill the air
At times, yet fear not, for the DJ doth change
The tune, and thou shalt dance to modern beat,
Without a care, or feeling out of place.

One eve, Floyd Mayweather, boxer of renown,
Did host his after-fight soiree at this place,
And made it rain, with mirth and joy, all round.
The crowd, mostly of age, from twenty-five
To thirty-five, doth frequent this hall,
With some young maidens, fresh from twenty-one,
Added to the mix, for beauty's sake, doth call.
But lo, the gogo dancers, fair and bright,
Doth steal the show, with their attire so skimpy,
Leaving naught to imagination's might.
So, gentle sir, take heed, lest thou be swept
Away by their charms, and lose thy wits."

Alas, no sweet delights did we partake,
But brunch we had, and joy did it bring.
The potato cakes, alack, were weak,
Yet still we savored each and every bite.
If fortune smiles, I shall return anon,
And taste their sweets, or sit at bar, alone.

"Alas, the tequila selection doth leave much to be desired,
And errors on the menu do abound.
Fare was passable, but service did prove a trial,
And 'twas not a bustling crowd that doth impede.

In sooth, the spirits of old Mexico do seem to fade,
And in their stead, a mediocrity doth reign.
Alack, for those who sought a festive mood,
Their hopes were dashed upon the rocks of disdain.

Yet still, the kitchen doth produce some worthy dishes,
Though served with little grace or finesse.
And he who doth attend thee, doth perform his duties,
With a countenance that doth belie his distress.

So if thou art in search of cheer and jollity,
Best seek it elsewhere, for here 'tis scant.
But should thy hunger pangs o'ertake thee,
Then peradventure, a meal mayhap shall suffice."

"Hark, my dearest friend, how strange it seems,
That in fair Hokkaido, my expectations didst falter.
Forsooth, the seafood dishes, a paltry sight,
Didst resemble those of China, o'ercooked and lackluster in might.

But lo, my heart didst sing, whene'er I didst taste,
The crab, the sushi, and the seaweed salad, a wondrous feast.
And, by the stars, the chocolate fountain, a sweet delight,
Didst bring a smile to mine own face, and filled mine heart with joy and light.

Alas, the atmosphere, didst not meet mine eyes,
For screaming brats, and chaos, didst fill the skies.
A plague upon the parents, who didst not keep,
Their children close, and quiet, in this place, where we didst seek to dine and sleep.

Verily, I say, a fee, they should impose,
Upon the unruly younglings, who do cause such noise and commotion,
For in a place of rest, and gentle repast,
Such discord doth not belong, and doth most certainly astound."

"A night's stay was had this week, my dear.  Alas, the furniture, even the couch, didst gather dust.  A dirty coffee maker and filthy hair dryer, oh what a sight!  I couldst go on, but shall refrain.  

No itemized room service receipt or stay receipt via email didst I receive.  Pray tell, were they prepared?  Nay, methinks not.  

For location's sake alone, this inn doth merit praise.  But lo, if thou art in town for business, choose the HGV on the strip, with its excellent upkeep and commendable customer service."

"Rehab burger, a dive bar of sorts, yet with an air of coolness doth it possess. A place where one may find solace in drinks of great value, and burgers of renown. Alas, my experience didst leave much to be desired. The Hangover burger, with sweet potato tots, didst fail to impress. A mistake in cooking, no doubt, for I requested it medium rare, and received it well done. Methinks 'twill not be worth mine while to return and give it another chance, for Scottsdale doth boast of better burger joints in plenty."

"Methinks I oft have passed by City Cafe,
But ne'er had time to stop and savor their fare.
Until the other day, when chance didst play
A part in my decision to dine there.

Their lunch menu, alas, was limited,
Yet the owner didst assure me 'twould soon be extended.
I ordered a burrito, and with it,
A refreshing glass of green iced tea, most excellent.

Verily, I say, the food didst please,
And I shall return, ere long, to taste their wares again."

"Methinks 'tis a bit pricey, yet still a merry spot,
Where young ones may express their artful thought.
The staff, in general, doth seem kind and apt,
Though at times, the younger maidens did converse,
In their own world, leaving work to be desired.
But fear not, for their turnaround is quite fast,
A mere few days, and thy piece shall be ready at last."

"Methinks the victuals here be most delectable,
The site, most fair and pleasant to behold,
And roofop patio, a wondrous place to dine,
No qualms, my friends, all's well, I do declare.

But alack, the potions, oh so dear,
Do cost a pretty penny, 'tis quite clear,
A sinful sum, a price most steep,
For draughts and cocktails, such a fee to keep.

In truth, I've worked in taverns ere,
And know full well how drinks are priced, my dear,
These rates, they do not sit well with me,
Nor with the folk who come to revelry.

A pox upon such prices, I do say,
For they shall drive the crowd away,
Reasonable rates, a better way,
To draw the masses, night and day.

So heed my words, good sirs, I pray,
And alter thus, thy pricing scheme,
Lest thou be left with empty seats,
And naught but sorrow, bitter and extreme."

"Taqueria Express, the sign doth read,
A humble taco stand, 'twas all they need.
From Fruteria El Pueblo, just west of Wood,
They carved out a space, with kitchen quite good.

Orders placed at window, hot and bright,
Food quick and simple, a wondrous sight.
Menu, surprising large, with tacos galore,
Quesadillas, burritos, and more, in store.

Alas, language barrier, a problem, perchance,
For those who speak not Spanish, in this dance.
But fear not, fair traveler, for thou shalt see,
A torta, oh so fine, for thee to be.

Huevos y queso, six fifty, a price to pay,
But worth it, for this torta, come what may.
Soft teleras, Monterey-Jack, shredded lettuce too,
Jalapenos, a spicy touch, for me and you.

A mess to eat, indeed, but who doth mind?
For this torta, a stop, thou must design.
Not the best, perhaps, but still, a treat,
Taqueria Express, a place to eat, and greet."

"A humble donut shoppe, neat and clean,
Open round the clock, with Subway seen.
Fresh pastries filled the shelves, devils food cake,
Moist, chocolatey, a delight to partake.
Glazed donuts, too, with flavors so bright,
Better than Dunkin' or Krispy Kreme's blight.
Winchell's, a cut above, a decent sight,
Selection fair, a satisfying bite."

"Methinks I've ever been an Outback devotee,
Forsooth, a chain restaurant of some renown, doth please me.
At the bar, I do sit, and the staff, they doth attend,
With friendliness and accommodation, they do strive to amend.

Last week, I did decide to take my meal away,
And order salmon, broccoli, and a sweet potato, I did say.
The salmon and broccoli, they were cooked aright,
And seasoned well, they did delight.

But lo, the sweet potato, it was overcooked, alack!
As if they had kept it in the oven, for several months, at least.
A minor detail, yet worth the mention, methinks,
For a better dish, it would have made, with a bit more finesse."

"To City Center we didst make our way,
For dinner late, ere clubs didst sway,
And Julian Serrano's was our choice,
For veggie options, a voice didst rejoice.

But, alack! Our experience was not grand,
The food, though decent, failed to expand,
Our taste buds, with delight, didst not dance,
As we had hoped, in this Spanish trance.

The paella, mixed, with lobster, chorizo, fowl,
Was fair, but forty dollars, didst allow,
A mind-blowing feast, we didst expect,
But nay, it fell short, our hearts didst protect.

The rest, just okay, didst pass the test,
But not, our hunger, didst truly bless,
The d\u00e9cor, nice, the service, too,
But, alas! The price, our wallets didst woo.

A tapas bar, in San Francisco, dear,
With flavors, rich, and prices, clear,
Didst serve us better, with glee,
And thus, our hearts, didst set free.

So, to Julian Serrano's, we may not return,
Unless, another's coin, doth burn,
Our next time, in Las Vegas, we doth play,
At a different tavern, we shall sway."

"Hark! A gathering of friends and colleagues didst doth grace this establishment on the eve of mine own birthday. And verily, the ambiance didst please mine eyes and heart, for it was filled with mirth and gaiety. Thus, I didst return anon, with friends in tow, to partake in the happy hour revelry. 

Ah, but alas! The cost, it didst border on the exorbitant, yet the service, it was most excellent, courtesy of our server, a maiden fair and kind, with robotic decorations upon her skin. Her name, I didst not catch, but her demeanor, it was most pleasant and accommodating. 

Now, as for the victuals, they were, in sooth, quite satisfactory. The Polynesian chicken sandwich, it didst delight mine taste buds, accompanied by the sweet potato fries, which were cooked to perfection. But lo! The drinks, they were the true stars of the evening's entertainment! Most especially, the Scorpion bowl, which I didst find most intriguing and worth another visit, perchance with a larger group of merrymakers."

"Methinks we dine here oft, and find the fare to be but middling, neither too good nor bad. 'Tis more like Arby's, I do declare, for the ingredients lack a certain je ne sais quoi. And though it be not overly pricey, 'tis still not worth the cost, for true sushi doth it better. Yet, convenience and speed doth make it somewhat appealing."

"Methought the establishment's arrangement was pleasing,
The beverages did flow, and servants were cheerful.
But, alack! The manager, bald and with a moon boot on,
Didst possess an air of haughtiness, most rude.
Even our waitress didst concur, 'twas plain to see,
That he was naught but a knave, with manners none too fine.
Save for him, I wouldst return, and gladly pay,
For prices fair, and victuals that didst pass muster.
I only sampled hors d'oeuvres, and found them just so-so,
Yet still, I wouldst give the place another chance, anon."

"Fare thee well, my dear! Forsooth, the victuals we didst devour,
Were of a quality most fair and fine, I do declare.
The Spanish omelet, oh how delectable it was!
Yet, alack! The service, slow it didst prove, alas.
But still, we didst enjoy our meal, and that's the truth,
For in expectation, all didst pass muster, by my troth."

"Alas, my heart doth ache to pen these words,
For fond memories of yore do still persist,
But recent visits, full of woe and sorrow,
Have tainted now my once joyful spirit.

Awaiting my turn, in room of examination,
I didst tarry long, nigh half an hour,
And when at last the doctor didst attend,
Another quarter hour didst slowly pass.

Yet still, my love for Dr. Langford doth remain,
For her apologies, with sincerity she didst obtain,
And though the wait didst vex mine spirits sore,
Her care and attention, as before, didst restore.

But alas, twain calls I made, to confirm,
Didst meet with rudeness, and a tone quite stern,
No courtesy or care, didst they extend,
Their manners, unbecoming, didst offend.

Thus, with a heavy heart, my rating doth descend,
From five stars, now to three and a half, I do amend,
For though some staff, with kindness doth abound,
One member, with discourtesy, didst astound.

Still, my affection for the doctor doth endure,
Yet, sadly, this last visit, didst leave much to deplore."

"Methinks 'tis a fair place indeed, where one may watch a game with glee.  The staff doth seem to hold a care for those who enter in.  Aye, the menu doth please mine eyes, and food, it doth taste of sweetness.  But, alas! The last few times I chanced to visit, 'twas cold, so very cold, that which they brought to mine table.  Oh, how I do detest a meal that doth lack warmth!"

"A hearty meal didst First Timer devour,
With prices fair, the victuals didst please.
The tavern's charm didst lie in its decor,
And emptiness didst make our visit ease.

Alas, the youthful servers, cold and grey,
Didst lack the warmth of a kindly way.
A smile or greeting, sincere and bright,
Might make this place a true delight."

"Fair service, good victuals, yet, alack!
The dust that doth abound, doth make mine eyes to wander.
In every nook and cranny, doth it gather and settle,
Upon my seat, it doth resemble a gentle shower.
I marvel how this sight, didst go unseen,
And so, I took it upon mine own self, to leave a small note,
The server, she didst espy me, and the dust,
And laughed, saying, 'Hahaha, yea, there be a deal of dust here.'
Woe is me, what manner of housekeeping is this?"

"Tis not yon common Charlotte fare,
Most dishes be fried, and full of flair,
Not spicy, nor hot, yet flavors abound,
A humble tavern, for luncheon profound.

I shall return, forsooth, anon,
To partake of their savory concoctions,
In this cozy, unassuming place,
Where hunger doth find its sweet embrace."

Hark! What luck doth bring me to this place?
A scant fifteen minutes ere the close of day,
And lo! But ten brief moments didst pass,
Ere the chicken, cooked to perfection, didst sway.

This humble abode, so small and plain,
Didst play host to my culinary desires,
And though the fowl didst taste of salt,
'Twas naught but a minor quibble, a mere trifle.

The fiery sauce, oh how it didst delight,
And made my visit to this place most worthwhile,
But alas! No red velvet pancakes in sight,
A common complaint, it seemeth, yet no cause for fright.

Forsooth! A kind woman, with a heart full of cheer,
Didst gift us a free drink and chicken, without fear,
And though Flavor Flav's eatery didst fail,
I pray that this place shall prosper, without fail.

Two stars, I say, and one more for Flav,
For his name doth bring a certain je ne sais quoi,
A decent spot, despite its flaws,
But Flavor Flav, he doth make it shine, like a beacon's glow.

"Hark, a strange occurrence doth befall me,
In a restaurant, with a companion, did I see,
Yelp, the app of reviews, didst reveal,
Two stars, a rating most foul and unseemly.

The service, odd it was, and hard to explain,
The host, his words, didst we not comprehend,
And later, my friend, his soup didst receive,
Before mine, a full ten minutes, didst he relieve.

His soup, it seemed, didst please him well,
But mine, a duck meat soup, didst not swell,
The noodles, undercooked, they were, alas,
And green, salty stuff, didst float within the broth,
A questionable sight, indeed, it was.

And pricey, too, the place didst prove,
Caesar's Palace, a name of note, didst groove,
So out we went, to seek another spot,
For lunch, a better choice, didst seem to be not."

In sooth, Russ didst suggest My Florist for our midday meal, being as we were in close proximity thereto. Howbeit, I didst demur, saying thus: "Verily, I do frequent My Florist by night, and oft have espied yonder quaint luncheonette across the way, which doth pique my curiosity. Pray, let us dine therein." 'Tis a suitable venue for a swift repast, and serveth as a respite from the vile fast fare (anything, methinks, is preferable to that foul cuisine). I didst order the chicken feta pita, which, alack, didst prove somewhat dull. Methought the appointments of the place didst excel the victuals. Thus, +++ for clever marketing and design; now, an it please thee, do something more fascinating with the bill of fare, that we may revel in culinary delight!

"A rainy Sunday morn, and brunch we did seek,
Within those walls, a pleasant sight did break.
The service, excellent, with speed and grace,
Yet coffee, alas, did leave much to trace.

Our entrees, fair and fresh, with skill prepared,
But flavors, oh, how they did disappoint.
A buckwheat crepe, cooked well, yet cold within,
I mentioned this, and our coffees, free did spin.

I ate but part, my breakfast, lost its charm,
As boredom struck, and left me in disarm.
Yet still, I would return, in hope anew,
That other dishes, flavors more true, may do."

"O Pink's, thou art a wily temptress indeed,  
How didst thou lure me to thy tasty treats?  
A band of friends, with hunger pangs didst need,  
Didst seek thee out, for thy renown'd delights.  
I, feeling bold, didst order Chili Cheese,  
Two dogs, chili, cheese, all swathed in tortilla's ease.  
It served its purpose, for a night of mirth,  
But oh, the aftermath, a sore belly's wrath!  
Perhaps, if e'er I dine with thee again,  
I shall stick to plain hot dog, sans the pain."

"Hark! We didst move from Chicago's chill embrace
To Scottsdale's sun-kissed, arid space.
And here, within these walls of rice and sea,
Didst seek succor from the summer's heat.

Alas, my hopes were high, too high, methinks,
For though the Sapporo didst quench my thirst,
The sushi, fine though it may be, didst lack
That je ne sais quoi, that certain zest.

A roll with fried fish skin, a curious treat,
Didst please my taste, but couldst not lift
This place to heights of culinary bliss,
Nay, 'twas but decent, nothing more, alas.

So shall I return? Aye, verily,
But not with fervor, nor with haste,
For though 'twas good, 'twas not divine,
And other sushi joints may yet entice."

"Methinks 'tis a most wondrous place,
Conveniently situated, nigh my work's embrace.
The parking, good! For me, afoot, 'tis a breeze,
And concessions, cheap! A hot dog, soda, what a tease!
A combo pack, with drink and popcorn, doth please,
For $11, a steal! The views, fair; players, at ease.
But alas, no grass, in outfield's expanse,
A disappointment, indeed. And, truth be told,
The metal seats, down left field's line, do chill,
But for $7, parking, location, concessions, still,
I am a fan, of this, my favored spot,
In sooth, a treasure, ne'er to be forgot!"

"Hark! A tale of my journey to Las Vegas,
From Thursday to Sunday, I did stay,
At a hotel, with price most fair,
And location, in the best part of the way.

The casino, with games aplenty,
And dealers, professional and keen,
Did earn five stars, without doubt,
A place to test one's luck and skill, no doubt.

But alas, the food, a sorry sight,
No Starbucks, to my dismay,
And no 24/7 restaurant in sight,
To sate my hunger, day or night.

The room, two and a half stars, I say,
The bed, a springy, cheap affair,
My back, it did not please, I pray,
For at 31, I'm not yet past my prime, I swear.

The TV, away from the bed, they did place,
Not convenient, to watch from my space,
But clean, the room did feel, and fancy,
As a strip hotel, it did seem quite handy.

So, three stars, I give, on average,
A good value, for a Vegas vacation,
I'd return, yes, I would, for another chance,
To roll the dice, and take a dance.

And note, dear reader, this is my view,
A seasoned traveler, I do confess,
But for a first-timer, this hotel may be,
A wonderful stay, a great success, you'll see."

"Hark, good sir! I do protest, thy venue doth lack,
In charm and grace, it doth not hold a candle,
To other eateries, where one doth pay,
A similar sum, for finer fare, I pray.

The lobster, twain, we didst order, 'tis true,
And found it tasty, I must needs avow,
But, alas! The surroundings, they didst grieve,
A shopping mall, most unbecoming, doth leave.

The decor, akin to a peddler's stall,
Didst little justice to thy culinary skill,
And for the price, I say, 'twas far too steep,
For such a humble abode, so plain and cheap.

My garb, it didst bespeak a night of fun,
Yet, here, amidst the cartoonish walls, I've none,
Fit for a king, my attire, I do confess,
Yet, here, 'twas naught but mockery and mess.

Peanut shells, they didst not lie upon the ground,
Yet, still, the ambiance, it didst lack, profound,
A finer establishment, I wouldst advise,
For such a sum, a better choice, I do devise."

"A night out, or an adventure with friends,
I sought at Victory Lanes, a place of speed.
A hiking, rafting, running sort, I am,
But alas, their karts did not impress me.

In circles, fast, we rode, confined,
Not my idea of joy, I must confess.
But still, I'll give it another go,
If friends join me, and we make a show.

The location's easy to find,
From the highway, a clear view, divine.
Price, we paid for membership, fair,
Staff, helpful, answers, without compare.

Children watch, but don't drive, I say,
Bathrooms, small, not fit for array.
Suites, cool, add to the thrill,
Picturesque, they do fulfill."

"Hark, good sir! Thou seekest sustenance and drink? 
Fear not, for Mandalay Bay doth provide, 
Ale, beer, and pub fare, to thy heart's desire. 
Thy ex, a man of taste, doth swear by shepherd's pie, 
So, try it thou must, ere thou doth say goodbye."

"Methinks my mem'ry doth fail me, fair friends,
For when I first didst step within these walls,
I know not if I had a merry time or no.
Yet, verily, I did return anon,
And found the place not half so bad, I swear.
In sooth, the barkeepers didst move with speed,
But the music, by the gods, didst make my heart sing.
Aye, 'tis a decent spot, if thou canst gain entry free.
Alas, not my first choice in this city of sin.
But, an it please thee, take my humble word,
If thou canst enter cheaply, 'tis a place to be."

"O, how I do adore the victuals at Paradise Bakery! But alas, this place doth be a gamble, forsooth. 'Tis a crapshoot, whether thy meal shall be correct, or lacking certain items, or perchance not even prepared ere thou dost arrive. They have extended their hours, but oft are out of stock near day's end. Yet, when the fare is good, 'tis most excellent, indeed. Methinks 'tis vexing, when the quality doth suffer, and things are not cooked aright, for Paradise is not a cheap eatery, by the Lord above!"

"My comrade and I, in pursuit of the finest steak in the land, doth venture to diverse establishments of repute. Our latest sojourn, to Fleming's, didst fall short of my expectations. 

Tales of their happy hour, with deals most fair, didst reach mine ears, and indeed, the choices were plentiful and the service, good. A fine selection of wines, at prices reasonable, didst also catch mine eye. 

But alas, the steak, mine heart's desire, didst fail to impress. Overcooked, it was, and not properly trimmed, a filet, it didst seem. The sides, forgettable, they were."

"A fine establishment for a swift and affordable repast. For those unfamiliar with Filipino cuisine, mayhap begin with the barbecue and pancit, a pair of delectable dishes that shall surely please thy taste. Should thou wish to venture further, sample the dinuguan, a savory broth made with blood, or the balut, an egg most curiously fertilized. Verily, my own dam makes a finer dinuguan and pancit, but this place doth serve its purpose well, and at a fair price, too. Alas, I do suggest taking thy meal away, lest the woeful dramas they play upon their televisions doth dampen thy appetite with their incessant sobbing."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, listen well to my tale,
Of a place that doth serve food most fair and frail.
Their waitstaff, alas! Doth not wear a grin,
But fear not, for their victuals doth make up for their sin.

Aye, 'tis a cultural thing, I do suppose,
For in this land, such service doth not pose,
A problem, forsooth! Their fare doth make amends,
And thus we doth return, our bellies to attend.

Firstly, try their shredded pork, pan-fried with care,
And ask for it "Hong Kong Style", be thou aware.
Next, sample their shrimp, with salt and pepper bathed,
And leave not the head behind, for it doth be enriched.

Lastly, their salt fish and chicken fried rice,
Doth taste of the sea, and a bit of spice.
So, put aside thy fears of the unknown,
And savor these dishes, for they doth make thee moan."

In sooth, the fishery department didst impress,
With helpful folk, and little time to guess.
But one, named Tyler, doth require some schooling,
In art of serving customers with cooling.

"Hark, the service here, 'tis fair,
Depending on the time of day, thou shalt declare.
In mornings, first, a draught we did receive,
To cure our hangovers, a merry conceit.

On Saturdays and Sundays, I didst order forth,
Chicken Fried Steak, a dish of noble worth.
'Twas good, and anywhere I roam,
If chicken fried steak be on the menu, I'll make it known.

This place did not disappoint, my friends,
For all at my table, save one, didst partake.
And after tasting, they didst agree,
'Twas a wise choice, indeed, a verity.

But alas, the coffee shake, a woeful tale,
Didst not taste of coffee, a sorry fail.
Jack in the Box, a better shake doth make,
A truth, a truth, a kingdom for a shake!

Yet still, I shall return, forsooth,
To this place, or Pink Taco, both of which are good.
A different tale, another time,
Pink Taco, a worthy feast, sublime."

"Alas, good sirs, I do declare,
This car wash on Bell road doth leave much to be desired.
Twice now, I have brought my carriage to their door,
And twice, they have forgotten to remove the key.
Alack, this carelessness doth fill my heart with fear,
For auto thieves do roam these Arizonan streets with cheer.
Their customer service, methinks, doth leave much to be desired,
For though I came ere break of day, my discount was not fired.
I crossed the street to work, and when I returned,
I found my carriage waiting, but my savings unearned.
A pox upon their hand-written receipts, I say,
For they are not time-stamped, and thus, my discount did stray."

"Methinks I long to cherish thee, dear Daily Dose,
In thy prime location, convenient for my needs.
Yet, alack! My heart doth falter, for each time I doth step within thy halls,
I find myself lost in thought, unable to choose from thy vast array of delectable dishes.
My spirit doth wane, and I settle for a humble omelette or toast,
A choice most plain, and lacking in zest.
I shall continue my quest, yet fear my hopes doth dwindle with each passing day."

"Hark! I've been to this place afore,
And found the drinks to be but poor.
The service, though, was quite divine,
But alas! The cocktails lacked that certain shine.
I tried a few, but they did not impress,
And so I had to order more, to excess.
Forsooth! The drinks did taste well,
But oh! The alcohol content, it did dwindle and fell."

In fair Edinburgh, there lies a mall most grand,
With shops and eateries at thy command.
A Vue Cinema, entrance to Britannia's land,
Starbucks, Bear Co., M&S Food-Court, take a stand.
H&M, Superdry, Fat Face, HMV, Boots, FCUK,
Baxter, GAP, Debenhams, and a food court so plush,
Zizzi, Burger Co., and more, a feast for the eyes,
A view o'er Fife, new developments arise.

I do confess, the food court doth please me well,
A scene most fair, like Blade Runner's spell.
But alas, 'tis not my fave shopping place,
Lacks charity shops, save Superdry's grace.
On Sundays, I visit here, with time to kill,
A clean building, in and out, no need to shrink.
A straightforward layout, rectangular and tall,
A car park, bus terminus, tourist buses call.
Tram line extension plans, once set in motion,
Now shelved, a tale of disappointment and woe.

"Ay, one of the smallest airports in all the land,
Didst fly hither for a brief sojourn at hand.
Greenville, they call it, GSP its name,
But alas, the planes, how small they be!
And I, a man of six feet four, didst find
Great discomfort in my seat, so unkind.
Next time, I vow, shall fly to greater ports,
Where space and comfort do abound, no doubt."

"When twelve winters had passed o'er my head,
My elder sister, fair and bright,
Did take me with her to a place,
Where wonders dwelt, and joys did embrace.
'Twas Pier 1, a haven of delight,
Where treasures lay in store, so bright.
Director chairs, lava lamps, and more,
Bamboo vases filled with baby's breath,
Did fill my heart with longing's fire,
To replace my room's Charlie's Angels' theme.
But alas, 'twas not to be,
For we were there for my sister's decree.
And though the years have passed since then,
Pier 1 remains, a constant friend.
Their wares, though priced beyond my means,
Still hold a certain charm, it seems.
A balsa wood nightstand, light and weak,
May not endure, but the plates, so meek,
With palm trees, bring a smile to my face,
And worth the cost, in this place.
So here's my advice, dear shopper,
Limit your drinks, ere you enter the fray,
Lest you bump into things, and break,
A lamp, or something, forsooth, ere the day."

Last eve, I ventured forth to this establishment,
With thoughts of pleasure and delight.
The hour was late, the crowd was great,
Yet still, I hoped for a merry night.

Their decor, a feast for mine eyes,
Didst make the most of space, so fine.
We ordered sliders, oh so small,
But tasty, nonetheless, stood tall.

A barkeep approached my lord,
And asked if he wouldst imbibe.
He didst not acknowledge me, alas,
And left me to ponder, in disguise.

My lord, a beer he didst not seek,
Was brought to him, with nary a word or shriek.
Two other barkeeps, kind and bright,
Didst serve us well, with all their might.

But he, who first didst snub mine face,
Didst ignore us, for the rest of the race.
Our drinks, unfilled, a wait of twenty minutes,
Before a soul didst come to tend to our winnings.

A fourth, who cleared the dishes away,
Didst not enquire, if we had need of play.
I shall, perhaps, give them another chance,
For they are new, and may yet dance.

"Hark! What beverages of renown doth flow from yonder taps?
Modelo Especial, Negro Modelo, Delerium Tremens, and more besides!
A clever notion, these nachos of which thou speak'st.
Yet, alack! The service did leave somewhat to be desired.
Give the Florentine Nachos a go, my friend, 'tis worth thy while."

"A gentle eve it was, with stars above,
We sat without, in garden of love,
A merry group of ten, with shots they did begin,
And smoke, oh so much, did cloud the air within.
Our server, brave, did strive to keep pace,
But burdened was he, by large party's grace,
And asked to capture memories, thrice he did,
For other tables, with tacky requests, they did.
The food, it was good, despite one dish awry,
Fajita chimmichonga, instead of chicken, nigh,
Still, we enjoyed, and would return anon,
For though flawed, the evening was not undone."

"This Whole Foods, the smallest of the three in town, doth not lack in choice or abundance. Though I do not frequent this location oft, I must confess the atmosphere doth please me, being in a smaller space.

Their fruit and veggie selection, I didst notice, doth include nopales, a sight most wondrous. Their produce, when I am present, doth always seem well-arranged and rarely doth anything appear awry.

Their meat counter, alas, doth pale in comparison to the others, but the deli, salad bar, and prepared foods, doth rival the rest.

In conclusion, a fair establishment, indeed."

"Hark, what sport is this, that doth combine,
Mini golf with drink, and doth entwine,
The twain, in merriment and cheer,
A jolly pastime, without fear.

Thanks, Anthony M., for thy treat,
That brought us hither, to this neat,
Putt Park, where putting course doth reign,
And fun themes, doth bring us joy and gain.

Alas, the courses, some too similar,
But still, a good way, to pass the time,
With friends, and bond, in silly ways,
And drunkenness, that doth take its sway.

Aye, 'twas a sight, to see us play,
With balls, that doth roll, in disarray,
But laughter, doth ring out, loud and clear,
As we, our soberness, doth hold dear.

For $8.50, a decent price, indeed,
And balls, that doth not, in holes, proceed,
It may, replay value, hold, I say,
If putting, be thy passion, every day.

So come, my friends, and heed my words,
Come hither, after drinks, and birds,
And make, this place, thy afternoon's delight,
As we, our time, in joy, did take flight."

"Hark, a feast most wondrous and fair,  
A mere twenty dollars doth procure,  
On Mondays, 'tis a sight to see,  
A spread most lavish, fit for royalty.  

The shrimp, they did abound and please,  
In cocktail sauce, they doth delight,  
And lamb, with mint jelly, doth tease,  
A flavor most unique, a true delight.  

The napoleon, oh how sweet,  
Doth steal the show, a treat most meet,  
For dessert, my heart doth sing and cheer,  
A culmination of the meal, most clear.  

Alas, no crab or lobster, I do fear,  
But for this price, 'tis hard to hear,  
The sushi, California rolls, so plain,  
Yet service, good, our thirst did gain.  

Methinks, next time, Paris shall be mine,  
To sample their buffet, most divine,  
Until then, this place shall suffice,  
A meal most satisfying, no need to device."

"Upon this night, my fair companion and I did partake
In culinary delights, at yonder tavern's bar,
Wherein the bartender, with mirth and glee, did play
The host, and served us with most excellent fare.
A pizza, fresh from oven's heat, we did share,
And dumplings, savory, with duck meat within,
Did please our taste buds, and we did exclaim,
'Tis a fine establishment, this place doth win.
Akin to Cheesecake Factory, in splendor doth it shine."

"Alack, the spread they lay before us now,
So bountiful, yet with a tainted hue.
For though the feast be grand, 'tis true,
They've cut the choices, and we must wait anew.

Once, we had a choice of crustaceans fine,
But now, alas, they've pared it down to one line.
And wait we must, for up to fifteen minutes more,
Just to receive our platter, and then we're sore.

A pox upon their house, for trying to save a coin,
By making us wait, and suffer thus, in vain.
This service, once great, now doth leave us cold,
And two stars, I fear, is all they'll hold."

"Alack, the lobster pot pie, a dish most fine,
Didst please my taste, as promised, by the sign.
But, alas, the service, it didst decline,
Our waiter vanished, leaving us to pine.

For half an hour, he left us in the lurch,
A time when drinks, we might have purchased much.
Alas, the lost chance, doth make me feel the pinch.

The pot pie, a dish of renown, no doubt,
Yet, fair maidens, we were not, to rout.
Perhaps, our age, did play a part,
In the neglect, that doth lay within my heart."

"Hark, what news is this? A meal most fair,
At yonder eatery, didst I partake.
A roast beef sandwich, of tender care,
Didst please mine taste, with juices rare.
The others, at my table, didst delight,
In Thai salad, of flavors so bright.
'Twas vast, a feast for sore eyes,
And left them all, in sweet surprise.
Another, of our merry band,
Didst choose the Mahi, so fresh and grand.
The servers, with smiles so wide,
Didst tend to us, with gentle pride.
I say, good sirs, give it a try,
For though 'twas not of little cost,
'Twas worth each penny, I do boast."

"Verily, I must confess, this place doth leave me in a state of utter disappointment. Forsooth, I had hoped to find a culinary haven, a place where I might satiate my hunger for a most excellent burger. Alas, 'twas not meant to be. The service, indeed, was most pleasant, the maidens friendly and helpful. But, alack, the victuals, they did not meet my expectations. I ordered the Pestorica, a burger with relish, pesto, and mozzarella, and a side of onion rings with dips. The burger, when it arrived, was a feast for mine eyes, but, alas, 'twas too thin, lacking in substance and seasoning. The onion rings, too, did not please mine taste, for they were crumbly and greasy, not battered as I had hoped. In sooth, the oreo milk shake was the sole redeeming feature of my visit. Methinks this place hath potential, but, for now, they do fail to meet mine expectations."

"On Saturday morn, I chanced upon a brunch,
Whose line, at eleventh hour, did move with speed.
I noted, as I left, they had installed
Self-pay kiosks, which long lines do need.

Their omelette station doth impress,
Two eggs, over easy, I did address.
Powdered eggs, for scrambled, I do shun,
And egg mix, for omelets, doth lack fun.

In another space, potatoes and sausage,
Did lay, a feast, most wondrous and engaging.
Salmon lox, capers, onions, did combine,
A killer croissant sandwich, most divine.
No bagels, alas, didst I espy,
But fresh fruit and Greek yogurt, did satisfy.

Alas, my friends, didst not agree,
That all dishes, were of high decree.
No prime rib, crab legs, or lamb, didst see,
A humble spread, of 2.5 stars, mayhap three.
Yet, watch thy diet, and thou shalt find,
A satisfying meal, without a bind."

"Methinks I fail to comprehend this establishment. I perceive their aim, yet the victuals do not quite measure up to the lofty standards of other esteemed steakhouses in this fair city. The cost, my good sir, doth border on the exorbitant. Methinks 'tis naught but a ruse to puff up the egos of those who partake in games of chance, deceiving them into believing they receive a meal worth three hundred golden coins. Alas, the fare doth not compare to that of Cut, Delmonicos, or Del Frisco. If thou seekest an atmosphere reminiscent of days of yore, mayhap a visit to Hugos, nestled within the Four Queens, shall satiate thy craving. There, the cuisine doth please, possessing a similar aura, yet at a fraction of the cost."

"Hark! This Paradise place, so full of sound,
A meeting spot for business folk profound.
But beware, my friends, the noise doth reign,
And may thy thoughts and words profane.
So plan with care, and choose thy time,
Lest discourse turn to cacophony divine."

"Twas a Tuesday eve, and we did choose this place,
Convenient 'twas, for Luxor's show we did attend.
But lo, the hostess, with hair of golden hue,
Didst play the part of rudeness, and our patience didst brew.

No wait didst we encounter, yet we didst sit,
In yonder bar, for swift service didst we wit.
But nay, the hostess came, and with great disdain,
Didst tell us we didst sit at dining tables in vain.

And so, we waited, for another ten minutes or so,
Until she didst return, and with menus didst bestow.
But alack, the very same table didst she bring,
And with a flick of her wrist, the menus didst fling.

Disbelief doth be the word, that doth describe this fate,
But praise be to the server, who didst make amends, and didst create
A pleasant eve, with speedy service, and with cheer,
The steak quesadilla, and steak tacos, didst disappear."

"Hark, good sir or madam, if thou seek'st a place
To sate thy hunger and behold a wondrous sight,
Then stop thou must at The Mad Greek, 'tis a sight most fair,
With two locations, one near Death Valley's gate,
And one near Las Vegas', where the sun doth shine bright.

'Tis a popular spot, so expect a crowd,
But fear not, for the fare is worth the wait,
The falafel balls, they doth taste most sweet,
And the creamy Tahini sauce, doth complement the treat.

The exterior, adorned with Roman statues grand,
Doth make it hard to miss, as thou dost pass by the land,
And within, a Greek cafeteria doth await,
With much seating space, and people, in abundance doth create.

In Baker, a decent bathroom doth abide,
And to the left of The Mad Greek, a pole doth reside,
A thermometer, the largest in all the land,
Doth show the temperature, though a few degrees off, 'tis grand.

So if thou art in search of food and sight,
Then stop thou must, at The Mad Greek, 'tis a wondrous delight."

"A fair Italian eatery, with victuals that pleased. Our server, in haste, did leave ere we had finished speech. The cost, a mite steep, yet not beyond belief. A pleasant ambiance, with flavors consistent, I'd return, in sooth, to dine again, anon."

"Methinks I didst wish to fondly regard this place,
For 'tis near my abode and locally owned,
Yea, verily, a rarity in these parts,
A gem, perchance, to savour and enjoy.

But alas! The victuals and the service,
Didst fail to meet mine expectations,
The table, sticky and unclean,
The server, hasty and most keen,
To take our order, and away,
Our appetizers, in haste, didst fly.

We began with bruschetta, a dish most fair,
But lo! The flatbread, cold and stale,
Didst dampen mine spirits, and my hope,
That it, on sliced bread, might be served,
Like Postino's or D'Vine's, in sooth.

My spouse, the orichette, didst choose,
With sausage, but alas! 'Twas oversalted,
And the sausage, bland, without a voice,
In this dish, a disappointment, stark.

I, the porcini ravioli, didst select,
With tomato cream sauce, a flavour most sweet,
But lo! The sauce, oversalted, alack!
Didst mar the dish, and my tastebuds, didst attack.

The ambiance, passable, yet the TV's large,
In the bar, a distraction, most strange,
From the dining room, a sight most odd,
And thus, our visit, a regret, didst engender.

Verily, I say, we shall not return,
For the price, too steep, the fare, not worth the burn."

"A fair location, indeed, yet mark this well,
Thou must needs check in betimes, lest thou fare ill.
I did arrive past eleven of the clock,
On a weekday in June, and found no proper lodging to mock.
They placed me in a chamber for the deaf and smoking crowd,
And I did wait until the second day, to take my rightful shroud.
The upgrade was grand, yet I did feel displeased,
To be confined to my room, till the afternoon's ease.
But, barring that, the inn was not so bad,
And the pool, though plain, did serve its purpose, I am glad."

In this fair mall, where shoppers doth roam,
The stores, alas, are few, and not a some.
Compared to those grand halls of old Vegas,
Where commerce doth thrive, and crowds do swarm,
This place doth pale, in size and scope.

Yet, in its defense, the decor doth please,
A feast for eyes, with colors bright,
And furnishings, that doth bring delight.
But, alack, the wares they sell, doth cost,
A fortune, indeed, for those who buy.

Still, if thou seekst a leisurely stroll,
In climate-controlled comfort, free from woe,
Then, gentle reader, come and see,
What this humble mall doth have to be.

"A fair chain, indeed, with service most kind. My visits here have been pleasant, I do find. Grilled cheese with hash browns, my usual fare, Evenings, too, and the bread, crispy and rare. Once, alas, the cheese was not melted quite right, But the lady, kind, did correct the plight. In the microwave, the plate did she place, But too long, alack, and the cheese did turn to rubbery grace. The bread, too, lost its flavor, I did perceive. Cheese sticks, also, I do enjoy with glee, When melted well within, a tasty spree. Ranch and marinara, my dipping sauces of choice, do make. Good service, good food, a place to meet or be alone, A pleasant spot, indeed, to call my own."

"Methought I spied the Blue Man Group last week,
With expectations high, I must confess.
'Tis one of Vegas' longest running shows,
And soon to move to Monte Carlo, I suppose.

My excitement grew, as I took my seat,
But alack! The show itself did lack coherence, methought.
The three blue men, they beat their drums with glee,
Then climbed the chairs, for no apparent reason, I could see.

A marshmallow trick, most impressive, did they perform,
But 'twas quite random, and left me in a storm.
I've seen such feats on Vegas Boulevard,
And wondered how they fitted, in this show so odd.

Their humor, though, didst redeem them somewhat,
Their comedic timing, was quite worth the sum.
They had some laugh-out-loud moments, I must say,
And audience participation, made each show unique, in its way.

Alas, I enjoyed it, but 'twas not worth the cost,
For the hype, it did not live up to, I fear the most."

"A haven of tranquility, this place doth be,
Within its walls, a sense of calm doth seep,
A massage, full and long, didst I receive,
For forty dollars, a price most fair and neat.

A tip, I gave, with gratitude and grace,
For service, kind and skilled, didst they bring,
I shall return, and tell all whom I know,
Of this oasis, where tension doth go.

Thanks to Ann Z, whose words didst guide me,
To this haven, where my cares didst flee."

"Hark! A gathering of colleagues, for a meal most swift,
At yonder tavern, known as Kilted Pig, we did convene.
Their luncheon fare, a menu of light bites, we did inspect,
And found it reasonable, betwixt three pounds five, and eight.

Inclusive of soup, sandwiches, baked potatoes, fish pie,
Risotto, stovies, and more, their offerings did lie.
And though naught fancy, our repast did please,
With generous portions, and flavors that did tease.

A bottle of wine, and three soft drinks did we consume,
For a sum of fifty pounds, our bellies now succumb.
I booked a table, two days prior, with haste,
And they did provide menus, for us to peruse at leisure, in advance.
Good service, indeed, our needs they did fulfill,
And thus, our midday meal, at Kilted Pig, did conclude most will."

"Hark, fair sir! Thou seekest a meal most wondrous? Aye, 'tis good, yet not quite great, I do confess. Swift service, as expected, doth please mine eyes. But lo, too much coleslaw doth overwhelm mine taste. Pastrami, alack, doth prove a bit chewy. Fries, a mite undercooked, doth lack crispness. Double meat, I did request, yet naught but same amount doth my friend receive. Alas, I say, do not go out of thy way for this repast."

"Hark! A word of caution, good sirs and madams,  
For this tavern, though cozy, doth lack in ale.  
The victuals, middling fare at best, doth leave  
My stomach somewhat sated, yet not impressed.  
  
Macaroni cheese, a dish most plain and common,  
Didst come from a box, a fact most vexing.  
Yet, buffalo chicken, a dish most delectable,  
Didst please my fair maiden, her taste buds most tickling.  
  
Despite these quibbles, I wouldst return anon,  
For here, in this tavern, doth lie a certain charm.  
Good service, friendly faces, doth make amends,  
And games, aplenty, to watch and cheer, doth disarm."

"Hark, what shenanigans did ensue at Camelback Inn Spa! 'Twas a day of pampering, with facials and massages galore. And then, we wished to partake in some FaceTime merriment, forsooth! But lo, the constabulary of quiet didst descend upon us, and our mirth didst turn to woe. We didst flee, my friends, to the outdoors, where water sprites didst not roam. And there, we found icy towels to cool our brows. Ah, but the facial given by fair Andrea, how can I praise it? She didst spend much time with me, answering queries of skincare and such. If thou dost cherish silence, and wish to read or relax, this place shall be thy haven. They do offer lemon water and tea, and when thou dost depart, thou canst create thine own sachet, a most excellent gesture! My sachet, it doth contain lavender, and it doth guide me to slumberland with ease. Well done, good sirs! The victuals and potables were quite satisfying, and the attendants, they didst hover near, ready to assist or hush all noise. Hush, my friends, when thou art there, that all may revel in tranquility!"

"Hark! Alack, I give it but three stars, forsooth,
Their brew, to me, was naught but mediocre, at best.
Methinks, I shall have to sample it twice, ere I pass judgment,
For fairness' sake, and to give it a proper test.

But, alas, the hours they keep, do leave much to be desired,
A coffeehouse, that doth close at seven, doth not inspire.
And, verily, there be better places to partake,
Of the sweet nectar, that doth fuel our minds and spirits,
So, to this place, I shall not hasten, with great zeal."

"Hark! This eatery doth lie near my place of work,
And my fellow workers do frequent it, by the Lord above.
Their lunchbox specials, verily, are quite good,
Chiefly the Short Rib, a dish most tender and sweet.
I have also partaken of their special sushi rolls,
The AZ Diamondback, a feast fit for a king, no doubt.

But alas, the service, at times, doth leave much to be desired,
Oft they are o'erwhelmed by guests, and their hospitality doth suffer.
Yet, notwithstanding, the victuals are of fair quality,
And for a midday meal, this place doth serve its purpose well.
Mayhap one day, I shall essay their Korean dinner,
And savor each bite, with relish and delight."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of visits twain, so diverse in their tale,
To yonder tavern, where we did imbibe,
And found our fortunes in a state most frail.

The first, a night of mirth and cheer,
Didst bring us joy, with friends most dear,
But lo! The second, full of dismay,
Didst leave us sorely disappointed, I pray.

My margarita, once a drink of delight,
Didst taste of naught but bitter fright,
And my good man, his corned beef didst seek,
But found it overcooked, and most meek.

Yet still, my pita pizza didst please,
A ray of hope, in such a storm of spleen,
But alas! Consistency doth lack,
In this, our tavern of most woeful track.

So shall we stay, or shall we flee?
A question, that doth puzzle thee and me."

"Tourists flock to bars upon the Royal Mile, unaware of prices steep, nor seeking local haunts with community's embrace. The Albanach, alas, doth fit this tale, with costly fare and lost souls gazing at maps, perplexed. Yet, with friends, I oft find myself within its walls, sipping house wine, a humble brew, but decent prize. The interior, now renovated, boasts fine slate floors and polished wood, a far cry from grimy taverns, reeking of smoke and ale. Mind the step, lest ye stumble, and all shall see thy clumsiness."

"Hark! A friend of mine didst start to wait upon the tables here, 
And thus, my service was most excellent, beyond compare. 
But, alas! My judgment doth be clouded by my love, 
So I shall leave it out of my rating, lest it doth prove. 

I didst enter in the morn, and found a seat outside, 
Whereon the sun didst shine, and birds didst sing their tune. 
The patio chairs, though not the most comfortable, didst serve, 
For sitting with a cup of coffee, and a book, or so I didst perceive. 

A decaf coffee didst I order, and for breakfast, eggs, 
With sausage, pancakes, and butter, which didst please my taste. 
The eggs, alas! Were lukewarm, but still, the rest didst burn, 
And thus, my meal didst satisfy, and fill my hunger's yearn. 

The Good Egg, though not my favorite place, doth stand, 
Consistent in its fare, across the land.  An Arizona chain, at hand."

"Hark! My love and I didst dine at Todai,
Forsooth, his craving for Shrimp Tempura didst wax strong.
And thus, we didst feast upon plates full and plenty,
Of shrimp fried in tempura, a wondrous sight to see.

Aye, for twenty pieces of silver, a fair price,
We didst enjoy a variety of dishes, a feast most nice.
Sushi rolls, nigiri of salmon and tuna, salads,
An udon station, and sweet desserts, a treat for all.

Alas, no crab didst grace our table during lunch,
But still, my heart didst sing with joy, for one dish didst stand out.
The udon station, a gem, a treasure to behold,
Ring the bell, and forthcoming, a bowl didst unfold.
Fish cake, sweet tofu, green onions, and more,
Add them thou didst, and a savory broth didst pour.

Yet, take heed, dear friend, for the broth didst taste,
Of salt, aplenty, a warning, ere thou dost partake.
And thus, with many buffets in Vegas to choose,
I fear, my love, this one, I shall not revisit, anon."

"My friend, a true connoisseur of breakfast fare, did swear that this place was the best. And indeed, the food doth please mine taste buds well. But alas, the service doth leave much to be desired. At times, the coffee doth flow like a river, but at others, it doth dwindle to a trickle. I do confess, I still doth frequent this establishment, for the prices, though steep, doth not deter me. Yet, I do wish they would reconsider their policy regarding military discounts. In sooth, who doth wear their uniform on the weekends? 'Tis folly, I say! And lastly, a word of advice, dear reader. If thou doth desire to avoid a lengthy wait, do arrive early, ere the night owls doth flock in, seeking to assuage their hangovers."

"Methinks 'tis naught but show and pomp that doth sustain
Their victuals, o'erflowing with excessive portion.
Their renown, a mere device to draw the crowd,
Doth oft outweigh the veritable worth of their fare.
In sooth, fair Vegas boasts a plethora of finer choices
For breakfast and brunch, as my own eyes have witnessed."

"In days of yore, when first this place did open,
I came here oft, with naught to do but wander.
But for two years, my foot didst not step within,
Till a friend didst wish to try their buffet, and thus I didst enter in.

The service, decent as it doth always seem,
And atmosphere, most pleasant, doth abide.
But lo, the food, a disappointment doth bring,
For salt doth reign supreme, and flavors doth falter.

In days past, the fare didst please mine taste,
But now, alas, 'tis naught but woe and waste.
Yet still, the desserts, a sweet delight,
Do lift my spirits, and make all right."

"Methinks my offspring doth hold this shop in high esteem,
For 'tis a place where they may purchase finery and gear,
Inspired by popular cable shows and musical ensembles,
A haven for the young and fashion-conscious, I do declare.

The salesfolk, verily, are of a similar ilk,
Youthful and vibrant, with enthusiasm they do seek,
To guide patrons in their choices, with prices most fair,
For licensed goods of quality, beyond compare.

In conclusion, this store doth meet my approval,
For its wares and staff do both possess a certain je ne sais quoi,
A place where one may find a gift or treat,
For the young at heart, who seek to look their best, no doubt."

"Methinks I found fair prices in this place,
And yet, methought I felt a trifle out of joint,
Forsooth, the names upon their packages didst seem
In a tongue that was not mine own, a puzzlement.
But still, I purchased bamboo spoons, a score or so,
For three-and-thirty pence each, a modest sum,
To stir my tea withal, a humble delight.
Aye, wooden spoons, they be my heart's desire,
For in them doth lie a simple, rustic charm,
That doth evoke a sense of days of yore,
When life didst move at a more leisurely pace."

"Hark! This eatery Colombian, not Mexican,
With menus vastly different, thou shalt see.
Large portions, indeed, yet priced accordingly,
In this part of town, a surprise, methinks, it be.

Entrees ranging from thirteen to twenty-five,
A steep price, some may think, yet worth the fee.
I, myself, have ordered but one dish,
The shrimp in coconut sauce, a delightful wish.
Tostones, crispy fried green plantains, a treat,
 paired with juices, a flavorful retreat.
Fried yuca, too, a delight, with a taste,
Similar to French fries, a pleasant haste.

The service, decent, with friendly folk,
And speedy, on slower nights, no need to choke.
But, alas, on busier eves, I cannot say,
How they fare, with haste, in a hectic way."

In fair India, where we dine on curries bright,
We savor flavors bold, with spices in delight.
At Persi's, renowned for its culinary might,
We found a feast fit for a rajah's sight.

A lunch buffet, diverse and rich in fare,
With chicken tikka masala, our hearts did snare.
The biryani, too, with chicken, spiced just right,
But alas, the heat, it did our taste buds ignite.

Gulab jumun, sweet and fresh, a dessert so fine,
But oh, how we yearned for more to combine.
A fruit platter, simple, yet a refreshing end,
To a meal most satisfying, and a time well spent.

Our third journey to Las Vegas doth bring us to Mandalay Bay,
A place of rest and merriment, they say.
But alas, our chamber doth disappoint,
With furniture too plentiful, and a bathroom unkempt.

Hairs in the tub and shower wall, and spots on the counter,
Doth make me wonder how they could let it be.
The Hotel, our previous abode, doth shine so bright,
With suites for all, and bathrobes without a fight.

Mandalay Bay, take heed, and learn from thy peer,
To provide a clean and comfortable space, my dear.

"Methought this place didst seem most wondrous fair,
By personal recommendations and Yelp reviews so rare.
The dinner, they say, doth rival the gods,
And thus, 'twas fitting for friends from afar to share.

But lo, we didst decide to visit ere the night,
For brunch, a meal most curious and quite right.
Now, mark thou well, fair Charlotte, thy brunch scene doth lack,
Compared to other cities, where breakfast doth reign supreme.

Our waitress, friendly and kind, didst attend to our needs,
But oh, how slow her steps, and how long she didst tarry!
The food, alack, didst lack the warmth of the sun,
My burrito, cold and hard, like a winter's day begun.

Yet, my friend, he didst enjoy his shrimp omelette,
Though lukewarm, it didst please him, and his spirit didst settle.
So, here's the tale, good sirs, of this place so fair,
For brunch, 'tis good, not great, but hope doth still abide there."

"Hark! A novel notion, circuit training doth seem,
A constant flurry of activity, no time to dream.
For those in poor shape, a true eye-opener 'twill be,
A test of endurance, a challenge to thee.

Six sets of four reps, each lasting three or four minutes,
Did we complete, in one hour, our bodies in tune.
Heart rate monitors, a helpful guide, didst display,
Our progress, and a friendly trainer didst convey.

Yet, comparison to others, a distraction doth make,
And the "zone" confusion, a minor drawback doth take.
But naught a major qualm, for still it doth delight,
This fitness regime, diverse and engaging in sight.

A free class, at dawn's break, didst I partake,
With fifteen folk, a bustling scene didst make.
The gym, though small, a cozy feel didst possess,
In orange hue, a vibrant, welcoming dress.

Ware for sale, a few items didst they have,
Alas, a bit pricey, yet still, a worthy cave.
The program, costly, yet for some, a boon,
Who crave variety in their exercise, soon.

Farewell, and fortune to all who doth pursue,
This circuit path, a fitness journey anew."

"Five stars, I wouldst give, for the victuals they do serve,
But, alas! the service, it doth leave much to be desired.
In the midst of the noonday rush, 'tis a sorry sight,
To see them struggle, with nary a server in sight.

Aye, there have been times, when we didst near depart,
For the poor service, it didst break mine heart.
But, I confess, the matzoh ball soup, it doth draw me near,
And thus, I do return, though the service doth fear."

"Methought I'd take advantage of yon coupons, fair sir,
And claim the chicken fingers for my meal.
The service was swift and the server most kind,
The chicken fingers, verily, did please mine eyes and taste.
Beware, good sir, when ordering hot, I pray thee,
For 'tis a fiery dish, and mayhap thou shalt see,
That which thou dost not wish to behold, anon.
Yet still, I say, the jury doth remain,
In deliberation, on this eatery's worth.
But for now, methinks 'tis a fair start, by my troth."

"Alack, my expectations were not quite met,
For service at this eatery was not best.
From entrance on, it did not bode well,
And though the setting by the lake was swell,
The vegan victuals, tasty as they were,
Did not quite live up to my hopes, I swear.
The show upon the lake, a bit too much,
Like cheese that's laid on thick, it was too rich.
So, all in all, 'twas but a middling night,
Not quite the evening I had hoped for, alack!"

"A devotee of this establishment, through various guises and proprietors, I have been. One of the scarce venues in town, wherein a cigar, a mug of ale, and merriment may be savored within its walls. 

The attendants, a congenial lot, tend to a respectable array of cigars, and a modest, yet choice assortment of brews. Patrons may take a seat at the bar, sink into a cozy chair, or gather 'round a table, and gaze upon the telly. 

My sole quibble, the ambiance, a tad too smoky for mine own taste. A cigar, I do enjoy, on occasion, but the pungent cloud that lingers within those walls, did leave my garments reeking of smoke, and my nostrils, in dismay. Not for the faint of heart, this place, I do declare."

"My friend, a Vegas native, didst lead us to this place,
In search of prime rib, late night, a wondrous feast.
The price, a mere $15, didst make our eyes light up,
And though the atmosphere didst reek of steeds,
We didst not let it deter us, for the deal was fair.

The meal didst come with soup or salad, and a choice
Of potatoes, which didst please our taste buds quite well.
We all didst order it medium rare, but lo,
It came to us more rare, and that didst surprise.
But when we sent it back, they didst correct the flaw,
And gave us a new cut, cooked just right, we didst allow.

The customer service, it didst impress us so,
And though the meat was chewy, the flavor didst flow.
A rating of three and a half stars, I do declare,
And yes, I would return, for the food didst pair."

"Hark! Our bellies full from pizza and ale,  
We chanced upon this place, our thirst to quench.  
Il Bosco Pizza, where we did dine,  
Didst not open till four, so we didst stroll and search.  
This tavern, clean and welcoming, didst greet us with cheer,  
And happy hour, daily, from eleven to seven, didst appear.  
Methinks, fair sirs, 'twas a fine place to rest,  
With TVs abounding, for sportsmen to behold and boast.  
We didst not partake in victuals, but their menu vast,  
Didst tempt our taste buds, with flavors so lavish."

"A Groupon alert, yet again doth pique my interest. A local establishment, with offers most enticing, doth tempt me to partake. 

The fare, alas, doth leave much to be desired. Spicy chicken bowl, with sweetness o'erwhelming, doth fail to impress. Rice, too, doth lack the savory taste I crave. Shrimp tempura, a middling delight, doth please, yet not astound. Orange chicken, with texture most appealing, doth win my favor, somewhat. Chicken teriyaki, a pleasant surprise, doth round out the meal, with satisfaction. 

In conclusion, a decent, swift repast doth this eatery provide. Worth a visit, should another coupon come my way, but naught more, methinks."

"Ay, cool for younglings, mayhap not so much for elders. Hark! I came expressly for yon mummy display, and, alack! 'Twas but a mediocre sight. Aye, the tiny computer stations, they didst speak of Egypt and the mummy proper, and those, I didst find most intriguing. Alas, the rest, a mere shadow of greatness. Nay, I wouldst not advise thee to pay more for this spectacle."

"Alehouse, thou art not the best in all the land,
Yet neither art thou worst, good sirs and madams,
The victuals here, they please my tasteful mind,
And all the brews, I've sampled, fair and fine,
In large portions, served with smiling face,
The staff, friendly, doth make merry the place."

"Thin crust pizza, oh how fine!
Wise guy, a gem, doth shine.
Price, a steal, doth make me smile.
Service, friendly, doth attend,
Yet, alack, consistency doth wane."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news is this? A place of gustatory delight, they say, yet marred by chaos, discourtesy, and ill-management. Long waits with naught to show, save frustration and ire. Methinks 'tis a puzzle, a riddle, a conundrum, howsoever, the victuals, they do tempt, they do allure.
