Give it a second chance, I shall, forsooth, yet heed my warning, good sir, lest thou be kept waiting, and missing thy engagement, they shall not care, nor offer thee any reprieve."

"This airport doth please me well, my dear,
Whether arriving or departing, 'tis a breeze to steer.
The parking and taxi service, well-organized they be,
Taxi lines move swiftly, no time for thee to flee.
Tons of shops and food, and slots to pass the time,
Free Wi-Fi, a plus indeed, a true rhyme."

"A humble abode of culinary delight,  
This burg'ry joint doth serve a meager fare,  
Yet, hath a few dishes of note, I do declare,  
Which, alas, I have not had the chance to share.  
For coin, I'd choose Smashburger, anon,  
If only 'twere nearer to my dwelling place,  
But since 'tis not, I shall return, ere long,  
To partake of their delectable, savory grace."

"Methinks my friends and I didst strike a fair bargain here,  
And I, in sooth, didst fear the worst, yet all turned out aright.  
Forsooth, we gained an adjoining suite, with kitchen well-furnished  
For all our needs in this fair city of delights.  
The pool, besides, was heated, which didst make me long to return,  
And though the place didst show some signs of age, 'twill serve  
For those who seek to play the tourist, and for families, too,  
I shall, anon, revisit this place, with mine own kin, anon."

"A fair bargain indeed, my dear, for but forty pieces of silver, two people may dine with mimosas galore. My love and I did feast most heartily, arriving at the eleventh hour, partaking in a medley of dishes, a true cornucopia of delights. Crepes with all the trimmings, gnocchi, salads, grilled vegetables, dolmas, hummus, and sweet pastries, we devoured with great relish. Our bellies full, we did succumb to slumber, I in the elevator, my love beside me. Four hours later, I did awaken, ready to take my vows."

"Methinks three of us did dine together,
And, as newcomers, the serving maid did proffer
Samples of their fare, with nary a frown.
The victuals came swiftly, and at a fair price,
Thou hast not broke the bank, nor didst thou pay too much.
My meal, with egg foo young and red chicken,
Was but a mediocre feast, I must confess.
I've had far better Chinese, in truth be told.
My comrades had red chicken, rice, and pork,
And deemed them passable, though not of the best.
Shall I return? Mayhap, after a year hath passed."

"A decent price, the drinks do bear,
In this place, that's not so divey, I swear.
A DJ spins, a dance floor small,
No service, that's worth recalling at all.
The barback, tall and handsome, did strike,
My fancy, with a fascination quite unique.
I danced, my buttocks shaking with glee,
Four dollars, a cover, seemed quite spare to me.

Some patrons, young, their age did seem,
Fifteen years, or so, in my esteem.
But hey, I'm on vacation, no need to fret,
This place, it's great, just not my usual bet.
Six fifty, CAD, for Jameson, Jack,
Most beers, a price, that's not too whack.
If hipster vibes, you seek, do come this way,
It's a great spot, though young, for my day."

"A fortnight past, my dearest friend and I didst venture forth to this establishment, known far and wide for its delectable victuals and potables. A place of tidy aspect, with servitors most kind and welcoming, didst we find. And, verily, the wings of maple, didst they prove a culinary delight, alack, in portions somewhat diminutive, yet nonetheless, a gustatory experience most pleasing. 

Methinks 'tis a suitable venue for viewing a contest of sport, wherein the throng of patrons doth maintain a decorum most becoming, without that wretched soul, whose loud vociferations doth pierce thine eardrums, sitteth nearby, marring the enjoyment of the spectacle."

"Hark! The grand opening special, priced at $16, doth seem a fair deal,  
But, alas, 'tis not worth it, in mine own humble opinion.  
For firstly, parking doth pose a problem, I do declare,  
With scarce twenty spaces, and nary a spot to spare.  
And secondly, the service doth leave much to be desired,  
For though the servers doth strive to be pleasant and kind,  
They did forget certain dishes, and some were burnt to a crisp,  
A travesty, indeed! And lastly, the victuals themselves,  
Didst fail to impress, with flavors too weak and insipid,  
The marinated bulgogi and galbi, in particular, didst lack zest,  
Whilst the other meats were dry and tough, a sign of poor freshness, at best.  
And the AYCE appetizers, oh so sparse and limited,  
Leaving me to pine for more, and thus, unsatisfied.  
So, to sum up, 'twill take more than just a pretty price,  
To make this establishment stand out from the rest, in this city of excess."

"A plethora of choices, prices steep,
We savored sushi, chicken wraps, shrimp noodles deep.
The cuisine was fair, yet lacked that certain zest,
That true Pan-Asian flavor, which we love the best."

"Hark! What news is this? A comic store most fair,
Whose shelves do hold a treasure beyond compare.
For oft, when other shops are bare and dry,
This place doth still possess the book I would buy.
Their stock doth rival that of any store,
With figures many and tomes galore.
Deforest, thou art blessed to have found such a place,
And may thy visits there be filled with grace."

"Methought I'd long desired to taste their fare,
And thus, my wish was granted, I did dare
To enter in and sample of their feast,
A cast iron skillet cornbread, a dish most meet.

The smoked salmon hash, alas, did not impress,
But my dear fiancé, his salmon burger did address
His hunger well, and portion large, 'twas true,
Yet, as we entered, hospitality scarce did shine through.

Four hosts stood idle, lost in chat and play,
As we did wait, their welcome did delay,
But once we sat, our server, kind and bright,
Did make amends, and saw to our plight.

A burger great, I should have tried that day,
But time and fate did not allow the way,
Yet shall I return, and give it another chance,
When next in town, to savor their culinary dance."

"Last week, I dined with a friend at Kikeri's. 'Twas a so-so affair. The chicken, which lay in the belly, did not sit well, and during consumption, I did not perceive that high-quality meat was of great concern. Three stars for the fair price and the tasty, very spicy rice noodle soup."

"A fair pizza and salad doth please mine eyes,
And in the eve, a place most meet for guise,
To hang about, and laugh, and merry make,
Before the flick'ring show, that doth our senses take."

"Methinks I saw 'Oklahoma!' at this place some years past,
And found the play most enjoyable, I must confess.
The dinner buffet, though, left much to be desired,
Save for the sweet delights, which did my senses stir.

Alas, its location, far from Chandler's reach,
Did deter me from returning, save but once.
Now, with gift certificates at a steep discount,
I ponder on the distance, and thus, I demur."

"Aye, my love and I didst stay at Aria,
And had a reservation, two months long,
At The Steakhouse, where we didst dine.
But lo, the bubblehead woman at check-in,
Didst sit us at a table most vile and base.
So we shall ne'er return, forsooth,
For what's the point of hospitality,
If guests be treated with such disdain?
A group of four, with no reservation,
Didst walk in, and sit next to us,
And didst complain of their table, too.
Our waiter, kind, and food, just fair,
But all, alas, was spoilt by her,
The idiot woman, who didst sit us there.
Bad job, indeed, and shame upon thee!"

"Methinks I've visited Gilbert Pizza oft,
Their victuals, most delectable and soft.
But lo, the maiden fair behind the counter,
Her manners, rude and unbecoming, did beset her.
She gazed upon me with a scowl, and not a word,
Didst she speak, as she wiped down the counter with a curled lip.
And when I placed an order o'er the phone,
She snapped at me, with a tone most dire and woe.
'Twas five more minutes, she didst declare,
With nary a smile, nor a hint of cheer.
I shall take my coin and spend it elsewhere,
For such behavior doth not befit a servant fair.
She was rude to all who came after me,
A pox upon her, and her surly mood, sayeth thee!"

"Alack, fair friends, I must confess my fault,
That I, with words, didst Sports Authority besmirch.
For, in my haste, I didst seek out their aid,
And found, in David, a most excellent guide.
He didst attend to me with diligence and care,
And showed me shoes that wouldst suit my needs fair.
He didst dissuade me from a costly pair,
And showed me Asics, at a price most rare.
The checkout, alas, didst cause some woe,
But David's kindness didst make amends, I do declare.
So here, my friends, I do recant my former tale,
And say, in truth, that Sports Authority doth prevail."

"Beware, fair maidens, of the EBAY MAFIA's wicked grasp,
Their schemes and plots to keep the best deals from thee at last.
In league with staff, they swoop in, like vultures to the prey,
And snatch away the finest garb, ere break of day.

Their mission, to deprive thee, dear consumer, of thy due,
To leave thee with naught but scraps, and nary a clue.
They hawk their wares on Ebay, with haste and great delight,
And laugh, no doubt, at thy misfortune, and their own spite.

But fear not, dear shopper, for there is hope yet,
To find the deals thou seek'st, and not be foiled by their threat.
Search Ebay, and behold, the truth shall be revealed,
For in the listings, thou shalt find the markings, plain and sealed.

So, brave maiden, take heed, and do not let them win,
For Last Chance shall be thine, if thou dost but begin.
And when thou find'st thy prize, and hold'st it tight,
Know that thou hast bested them, and emerged in the light."

"Oh, how I adore the Nola cuisine!
The genuine and delectable taste of this kitchen doth shine.
In Las Vegas, I didst savor the shrimp and grits,
So delightful, it doth make my senses tingle and twirl.
The bread pudding, oh how grand,
A culinary carnival, a symphony of flavors at hand.
But alas, the service doth leave much to be desired,
The waitress doth roam, and oft doth seem tired.
I have visited thrice, and each time, the soft shell crab,
Doth satisfy my craving, crispy and flavorful, a true delight.
The jambalaya and gumbo, layered with flavor so deep,
I shall return, for the food, my heart doth leap.
For though the service may lack, the cuisine doth make up,
I shall return, my love for Nola food, never to forsake."

"In this place, thou shalt find dishes of the East,
Korean and Japanese, a feast for the taste.
Sushi, a delicacy, hard to find in this land,
But here, 'tis decent, a treat for the hand.

Bulgogi, galbi, and kimchi, all doth abide,
A bento box, with chap chae, kimchi beside.
A salad with dressing, pickles of yellow hue,
Pot stickers, not bad, but not the best, anew.

The bowls, simple, yet full of delight,
Rice topped with meat, a wondrous sight.
The space, small, but enough for four,
A cozy spot, for a meal, and more."

"Methought 'twas a grand opening indeed,
At Primebar, where we didst take heed.
A free open bar, with drinks galore,
Didst flow like a river, ne'er before.
The victuals too, were plentiful and fine,
But naught exceptional, save the service divine.
For servers came to us, with speed and grace,
And brought our drinks, without a moment's space.
But alack, the design didst leave me cold,
So bland and boring, corporate told.
With wood-like walls, and lights so dim,
It lacked the sleekness, of a true whim.
The music too, didst not impress,
A mix of alt and rock, didst not repress.
I hadst thought, it wouldst be a place,
Of sophistication, and of grace.
But nay, 'twas more like Yard House,
A place for sports, and not for louse.
So there you have it, my dear friend,
Primebar, a place to watch the game, but not to wend."

Hark, what news is this? A dinner so plain,  
With co-workers, 'twas a work event in vain.  
The victuals, good, but not worth the mind,  
Inside the Cosmo hotel, a place unrefined.  
Loud it was, and full of mirth and cheer,  
A gathering spot for friends most dear.  
But alack, the food, not memorable,  
An ordinary place, not worth the while.  
Other restaurants beckon, come what may,  
This one, a pass, ere I dine again another day.

"Methinks my love and I didst not enjoy this place,
'Tis loud and small within its walls, we found.
I ordered mushroom, cheese, and omelette,
With bacon and a biscuit, to make it neat.
My love, a Spanish omelet didst choose,
With salsa and home fries, to make it grand.
But lo, my omelet lacked seasoning,
And flavor, it didst not have, I fear.
The bacon and biscuit, they were quite good,
But coffee, oh, how it didst taste like mud!
We both agreed, in this we were as one,
That coffee, it didst leave much to be desired, ere done."

"O woeful day! Our feast at Wicked Spoon didst turn awry,
For service staff didst play the villain's part.
We doth adore this place, and oft doth dine,
But now, alas! Our joy didst depart.

A grumpy server, with memory so weak,
Didst mar our feast, and cause us to speak.
She brought us drinks, but not as we didst ask,
And left our plates, like a loathsome task.

The buffet, once a sight to behold,
Didst turn to chaos, as plates grew cold.
We stacked them high, in dismay and woe,
As nearby tables, empty, didst she show.

O Wicked Spoon! Review thy staff, I pray,
And bring back the excellence, come what may.
For 'tis a shame, such potential to waste,
When better service, doth make haste."

"O, how my heart doth yearn for yonder Garage,
Where once I found such joy and solace!
But now, alas, it seems so plain and tame,
Compared to all the other places of fame.

Yet still, the food is good, the staff most kind,
And ne'er have I waited for a table to find.
But, oh, how I do miss the lamb of old,
That dish that did my heart enfold!

If only they still served it, I swear,
My love for them would be most sincere!"

Hark, good sir! I do beseech thee, let this humble patronage of thine establishment be met with a modicum of enthusiasm. Forsooth, 'tis a truth universally acknowledged, that a customer in possession of a local loyalty must be in want of a pleasant experience.

Alas, upon entering thy domain, mine eyes didst behold a sight most curious. A mere handful of patrons, and yet, the service didst seem so lacking in zeal. The barista, apathetic and unmoved, didst attend to mine order with all the fervor of a sloth.

Pray tell, good sir, doth thy staff possess a certain... disdain for the art of hospitality? Methinks, a smile, a kindly word, or perchance, a gentle nod of acknowledgement, might prove a balm most soothing to the souls of those who grace thy premises.

Forgive me, kind sir, if mine observations doth seem unduly harsh. 'Tis merely that, as a patron, I do crave a sense of welcoming, a feeling that my presence doth bring a measure of joy, however small, unto those who serve me.

In conclusion, prithee, dear Next, let this humble plea touch thy heart. In the future, mayhap thou couldst instruct thy minions to embrace the virtues of courtesy, and thus, ensure that each and every customer doth depart, feeling grateful and content.

"Hark! A gathering of folk at McKoys didst take place,  
For lunch, a meal most wondrous and of great grace.  
I, myself, didst partake in a sandwich of pork,  
Pulled, it was, and verily, 'twas a delectable work.  
A side of mac and cheese didst accompany my feast,  
And filled me up, it didst, to the utmost degree.  
Two things, fair friends, beware of, ere ye dine,  
The first, a wait for all, until your party's whole,  
The second, noise of traffic, loud and most vile,  
Outdoors, a seat, doth make conversation quite dire.  
A solution, pray, they find, to this woeful plight,  
And install bushes, or such, to block the din of night."

"In fair Tempe, where ramen noodles doth reign,
A place called Republic doth hold its own,
With portions grand and flavors quite unique,
But alas, their spice doth leave much to seek.

Their "spicy" dish, a mild delight,
Doth require Sriracha's fiery might,
To bring the heat that doth ignite,
And make the meal a true delight.

Though not a legit ramen place,
As found in cities of great grace,
'Twill serve its purpose, till I roam,
And find the real thing, elsewhere, at home."

The return factor, 65%, a score quite fair,
For those who crave ramen, without compare.

"Tis strange, my friends, they call this place the Beatles' lair,
For on the night I visited, not a single Beatles' tune did they play.
And yet, I did not mind, for their selection was quite fair,
A mix of songs, both old and new, to keep us all in cheer.

But alas, no one did dance, save for the maiden on the pole,
Her movements fluid and enticing, as she spun and twirled.
We received a drink voucher, but the bartender did refuse,
To grant us our desire, and gave us a drink most crude.

A girl did roam the floor, offering shots of cranberry hue,
But we didst decline, for fear of what might happen anon.
This place, my friends, is grand for those who love to watch,
Two aged dames, with cigarettes aplenty, didst catch our eye.

So if thou seekest mirth and merriment, come thou to this place,
But if thou wisheth to dance, or hear the Beatles' grace,
Then look elsewhere, my friend, for here thou shalt not find,
The rhythms of the Fab Four, or feet that do entwine."

In sooth, the hostess was discourteous, nay, churlish, when I didst approach, albeit I didst not anticipate excellent service at this aerodrome tavern. I didst pose a query regarding the seating arrangement, and she, with a shrug of her shoulder, didst remain mute. Her name, as I recall, didst begin with the letter D, mayhap Della. Upon sittin g down, my experience didst improve, for a comely lass named Jack didst tender me a salutation and didst take my order. She didst bring me the wrong brew, but didst proffer to rectify her mistake straightway. Now, I am not one to suffer drinks to go to waste, and thus, I didst not press her to correct it.

"Methinks 'tis a fair establishment, with victuals most fine and servitors most kind. But, alack! One thing doth mar my joy, and that is minors' presence in the tavern. Pray, why must they sully the atmosphere with their youthful vigor? A plague upon such folly! Forsooth, there be a dining hall, most spacious and apt for those who seek a more sober repast."

"Huzzah! A feast most frugal doth await!
A corn dog, oh so tasty, doth inflame my soul!
Intoxicated, mayhap, yet the price and place,
At one and thirty morn, doth make it a most wondrous find.
Seize thee a corn dog, and into the casino thou shalt stride,
And thus, thy hunger sated, shalt continue on thy way."

"Hark! What wondrous sight doth meet mine eyes?
The Bellagio, with its waters dancing free,
A vision most fair and lovely to behold,
A marvel that doth make my heart sing bold.

But alack, the victuals served herein,
Are naught but decent, I do confess.
Forsooth, thou payest more for the view divine,
And the fact that thou art perched on high,
In a quaint Eiffel Tower, a la Las Vegas style.

Yet still, 'tis an experience worth the while,
To sit and sip drinks, methinks, would be most smile.
For who needs food, when the view doth steal the show?"

"Hark! A loyal patron of Aloft I be,
And rooms and lobby, familiar to me.
But alas, this hotel doth sit near a busy road,
My chamber faced it, and the noise did annoy.
All night, the hum of cars did pierce mine ears,
And from the In & Out, a speaker's voice did reach.
Despite this flaw, I would still recommend to thee,
To ask for rooms away from the highway's din,
Or pack earplugs, lest thou suffer as I did.
A convenient place, for business trips 'twain,
And nigh to Ikea and airport, a quick jaunt."

"Methinks these cupcakes be fair and bright,
As pretty as a maiden in her prime,
Their frosting doth delight, in moderation applied,
A feast for mine eyes, a treat for my taste.

Their toppings, diverse and full of whimsy,
Do bring to mind a merry carnival,
The clerks, so friendly and full of mirth,
Doth make my visit most enjoyable and worth.

But alas, the cake itself doth lack,
A certain je ne sais quoi, a certain flair,
It doth resemble a muffin in disguise,
A culinary conundrum, a curious affair.

Yet still, I would return, forsooth,
To savor more of their sweet delights,
For though they may not be perfect,
They doth possess a certain charm and might."

"Hark! If thou hast a choice, choose thee the inn  
That lies a mile to the north, where the road doth bend.  
'Tis a place of greater comfort, with rooms more fair,  
And corridors within, that keep out the night's chill air.  
Ay, it may cost a few coins more, but 'tis worth the fee,  
For there thou shalt find rest, and peace, and quiet, as thee please."

"Verily, this place didst please mine eyes and taste. Yet, there be many other places that doth excel. 

In sooth, I didst partake of dinner here, and we didst order two dishes as appetizers - the Jumbo Shrimp Cocktail and the Shrimp Spring Rolls. The shrimp cocktail was as expected, cold shrimp with cocktail sauce, but the spring rolls, they were quite good, and if I were to return, I would begin my meal with them. 

But alas, the main course, the Crown Cut Bone In Filet Mignon, 12 oz., didst not impress me. At such a price, I couldst have a better steak elsewhere. 

Therefore, next time I find myself in the Forum Shops, seeking a steak, I shall venture next door to Joe's."

"A hearty welcome doth await thee at Al's, my friend,
Where atmosphere doth please and prices doth descend.
The waitresses, fair and kind, doth serve with grace,
And patrons, merry and bright, doth fill the space.

Ale, thy name is beer, doth flow with excellence,
And food, though not my choice, doth make presence.
Outside, the benches doth invite to sit and stay,
And chill, thou shalt, on nights of fair weather's sway.

This place, it doth delight, and I shall come again,
To partake in mirth and cheer, with friends, and not in vain.
So here's to thee, Al's, and all the joy thou bringest,
May fortune smile upon thee, and thy patrons, ever blessed."

In sooth, fair maidens, Northlake Mall doth boast
A multitude of shops, wherein thou mayst find
Apparel galore, to please thy feminine taste.
But woe betide the men, whose options are but few,
For most of these shops cater to women's whims.
Alas, the bookstore, once a haven for wit,
Hath closed its doors, leaving naught but empty space.
Yet still, the mall doth gleam with cleanliness bright,
And in the food court, sustenance doth abound.
So, if thou seeketh garb, this place doth merit thy sight,
But for electronics, Best Buy, across the way, doth beckon thee.

"Methinks we gave San Remo a second chance, my dear.
A hearty breakfast didst I score, full of cheer.
JK, a chopped steak with salad, didst partake,
And found the house-made blue cheese dressing, a true delight.
Our waitress, skilled and friendly, didst attend,
With speedy refills, her duties didst she tend.
The flat screens, numerous and bright, didst gleam,
But for us, a boon, a quiet dream.
For though San Remo mayst still be a dive,
Improvements, here and there, do we perceive."

"Tis a gamble, my friends, to dine at this place,
For the tacos, they may be fresh and full of grace,
But the salsa, alas, doth resemble a hot sauce,
And the chimichangas, well, they are not worth the cost.

A jug of horchata, large and awkward to hold,
I do procure, with a laugh and a wink, so bold.
But mark my words, dear friends, do not expect
A feast fit for kings, for 'tis but a humble abode.

And when the line doth grow long, and the wait doth seem endless,
Park thy carriage and order from the window, lest thou tempt fate.
For in the throes of hunger, tempers may fray,
And thou mayst find thyself in a bit of a pickle, by my troth."

"Hark, what news is this? A feast most fair and bright,
With flavors bold and savory in sight.
And, lo, they serve it all through the day,
A boon for those who crave it in their way.

But, alas, a drawback doth there lie,
In waiting long to be seated nigh.
The server, too, didst leave much to desire,
And cold, the food arrived, like winter's fire.

Yet still, a gem within the rough,
This eatery holds, for those who dare enough."

"Hark, fair readers, listen well to my tale,
Of Brew Lab, a place of coffee and bustle,
Where students rich and eager do congregate,
And seek their daily dose of caffeine and chatter.

Amidst the throng, I found a seat at last,
And sipped a peppermint tea, freshly brewed,
The staff were kind, the decor was neat,
But alas, the crowd did make me feel beat.

So though I'd give the tea four stars,
The busy atmosphere doth leave me scarred,
For in a place of peace, I'd rather be,
Than amidst the hubbub of humanity.

Yet still, the popularity of Brew Lab doth shine,
A testament to its appeal, divine,
So if thou art a fan of coffee and its kin,
Then hie thee hence, and give 't a spin."

"Methought, my dearest wife, this eve of ours,  
In comfy couches, low lighting, sweet delight,  
Would bring us joy, as we did celebrate,  
Our fortieth year of wedlock, full of love and fate.  
The music, methought, did strike a merry chord,  
But when we called for drinks, our server did ignore,  
Our pleas, as if she had a grudge to bear,  
And left us hanging, without a bill to share.  
I had read reviews, of this place, so bright,  
And thought we'd try their brews, on this special night.  
Alas, my dear, it seemed they did not care,  
For us, or our desire, to show them fair.  
So, we did leave, in search of better cheer,  
And hoped that others may find more welcome here."

"Hark! What's this? A place of gastronomic delight, they say,
But alas, with rules most strict, and ways most awry.
I came with mine own hound, a loyal beast,
And asked but how to gain entrance, with nary a feast.

The hostess, fair maid, didst storm and rage,
"No dogs, no dogs, thou shalt not turn the page!"
I heeded not her words, for I had not stepped within,
My hound, a gentle soul, sat calmly by my skin.

So forth we went, to dine upon the patio,
With servers frazzled, and in disarray, oh so.
The victuals, verily, were quite delectable,
But service, alack, didst leave much to be desired, oh so terrible.

In conclusion, thus, a mixed review doth render,
Food, aye, most tasty, service, alas, a woeful surrender.
Shall I return? A question, that doth ponder,
For though the grub be good, the welcome, cold and thunder."

"Aye, 'tis true, my friends, that TB doth serve  
A guilty pleasure, fit for vegetarians,  
Their menu doth offer many a choice,  
Fit for those in haste, with naught to lose.  
This place, like others, doth seem the same,  
With food that's decent, though not quite tame.  
The staff, young and cheerful, doth greet,  
And serve with speed, though not too fleet.  
So if thou art in need of TB's fare,  
This location shall not leave thee bare."

"Methinks I concur with certain Yelpers who hail from California, for I too once called the Southland my home. Verily, the cost of a sandwich in this fair city doth rival that of Los Angeles, where Lee's Sandwich doth reign supreme. Yet, I find solace in the knowledge that this establishment doth provide a suitable substitute for my Vietnamese sandwich craving. Alas, all things on the menu doth come with a steep price, save for the aforementioned sandwich. My curiosity regarding the other dishes didst prompt me to return with my spouse, and we didst partake of the Banh Cuon and Rice dish with BBQ Cornish Hen and Pho Dac Biet. By the stars, their victuals didst taste most satisfying, thanks in no small part to the liberal use of MSG. In truth, the seasoning didst prove so copious that it didst leave me with a throbbing head and an unquenchable thirst that didst persist throughout the day."

Hark! What shenanigans doth my taste buds play?
A chai tea latte, once a drink of joy,
Now doth taste watered down, and doth dismay.
I could not even quaff half, ere I didst throw it away,
For 'twas most foul, and didst offend mine eyes.
Alas, what sorcery hath beset this brew?
For once, it was a draught most sweet and true,
But now, alack! 'Tis naught but wretched dew.

In sooth, a humble place, fit for the folk of the land,
Yet, Orleans, not far, doth boast a finer hand.
A lively alley, full of cheer and glee,
And a theatre, where one may see a play, or three.
Gold Coast, too, doth cater to the oriental crowd,
With PingPangPong, a game of skill and chance allowed.
The Noodle Exchange, a place of sustenance and delight,
And Baccarat, a game of cards, for those who dare to fight.

"Their prices do proclaim them to be the sole establishment in town,
A costly meal, indeed, for a child and two grown folk,
My husband had a Guinness, five coins did it cost,
And I, a pour of Pinot Grigio, metered, no boast.

The food, it came, in styrofoam, with plastic utensils,
A small salad, it was, and the dressing, a paltry amount,
The chicken, it had gristle, but the bacon, it was fine,
My husband's Stromboli, ordinary, yet tasty, divine.

Our daughter, a cheese pizza, she did receive,
But the wait, it was long, our drinks, they did not arrive,
Twenty minutes, it took, for the food to come forth,
I do wish the place had proper dishes, and a better worth.

The bar, it is a pleasant addition, I must confess,
But alas, the prices, they do leave much to be desired,
I pray, dear friends, that you may find a better bargain,
For this place, it doth seem, doth charge a king's ransom, in vain."

"My dearest friend, who doth reside in Virginia's fair state, didst pay me a visit, and with her, a craving for tacos most dire. This fast food establishment, she doth hold in highest regard, and with good cause, for their tacos, they do please her taste buds well. I, myself, have not partaken of their culinary delights in over five long years, but for my sister's sake, didst order up a sourdough breakfast sandwich, which we didst share betwixt us. The curly fries, they were quite good, I must confess, but alas, my sister didst find the potato wedges to be lacking in flavor and appeal. Ah, but such is life, for all things are not to everyone's liking, and thus, I do proclaim, this place, a mixed bag, indeed."

"A worthy feast, yet not so grand,
For ten silver pence, a dish they hand.
A hearty portion, to be sure,
But scant the veggies, and scarce the cure.
If hunger pangs thy belly wring,
This place will ease thy suffering.
Yet, seek thou better Asian fare,
And to another door thou must repair."

"Methought I did order Take-Out,
A dish of Masaman Curry, with Tofu and Vegetables about.
'Twas passable, yet not quite worthy of note,
But neither was it vile, nor did it leave me in a sore plight.
I wished I had gotten it for lunch,
For then 'twould have been cheaper, and more bounty would have been in sight.
Yet still, I would return, or take-out, to give them another chance,
To see if their fare doth merit a second look, perchance."

"Verily, 'tis worth a visit, at the least, my friend,
A single time, to behold the merriment that doth never end.
A place of much activity, with music, dance, and cheer,
A sight to behold, and worth the journey, I do declare.


Alas, the zip lines be expensive, yet a delight,
For those who seek such thrills, and wish to take flight.


We dined at two places, a gourmet hot dog, they say,
And a middle eastern eatery, with a curious array.
But alas, both were lacking, and left us unfulfilled,
No desire to return, our taste buds unreconciled."

"Hark! Dave's Dog House doth make most wondrous hot dogs,
With buns that be like thick, foldable toast, yea,
Their quality doth rival that of the east,
And priced fair, a bargain, one might say.

But alas, their fries, they do not compare,
To those of other vendors, so plain, so bare.
Yet still, they be a better choice, no doubt,
Than some of those on Mill, with naught to boast.

Now, they have moved, just off the parkway loop,
A bit harder to reach, but worth the troop.
So, seek them out, and taste their wares,
For Dave's Dog House doth serve up finest fare."

"Aye, not my most cherished club within Las Vegas' walls,
But after some time, all clubs do seem the same, in thrall.
I visited on a Wednesday eve, the crowd was quite good,
Our cocktail waitress in VIP, most helpful, as she should.

LAX, it doth have a mezzanine, for VIP booths, a sight,
Yet each booth doth house two parties, conflicts may ignite.
The security didst try to solve this woeful plight,
By dividing the booth, with a couch, in the dead of night.

The DJ, middling, at best, his tunes didst not impress,
But still, I might return, if fate didst command, alas."

"Hark! This Boca Park Target of yore,
Greatland once didst bear its name,
But now, alas! 'Tis naught but a mere Target,
With food most fresh, and groceries in abundance,
Like SuperTarget, yet without the trimmings,
Deli and bakery, their absence doth grieve me.
A red facelift hath made it fair and bright,
But Taco Bell Express, alack! doth it no longer hold.
Two stars, I say, for staff not always near,
Nor willing to aid, as in days of yore.
This place, the busiest Target in all Nevada,
Doth teem with folk, a veritable throng.
Yet, in the realm of electronics, 'tis grand,
And Target Cafe, with Pizza Hut Express, at hand.
Pharmacy, Photo, Portrait Studio, all are here,
A one-stop shop, indeed, for all thy needs, my dear."

"Hark! What light through yonder window breaks? Average fare, methinks, doth grace these halls. Two lunch boxes didst I procure, filled with meat, and rice, and naught but meat. Cheap and convenient, yet satisfaction doth evade mine eyes. Alas, the chicken with broccoli, a dish most vile, doth mar the feast. Forsooth, the fowl doth taste not of its kin, but of a lesser breed, most base and poor. Yet still, I shall return, for thrift and sloth doth rule my days."

Alas, my heart did yearn for love of Port of Subs,
For many a location doth it boast in this fair town.
But alack, my hopes were dashed, for though the service was good,
The sandwiches themselves didst leave me feeling down.

The meats and cheese, freshly sliced, didst taste most fine,
But the bread, oh how it failed to impress me!
'Twas not as sturdy, nor as tasty, as I had hoped,
And thus, my appetite didst remain unsopped.

The prices, fair and reasonable, didst seem,
Yet still, I couldst not help but feel a sense of loss,
For just a bit more, across the way, doth lie,
A better value, and a tastier prize.

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals were most delectable, a true delight for mine taste buds. Methinks, had the service been but a mite more convivial, a rating of four stars had been within reach. Alas, a visit to the privy (fie upon it!) didst leave much to be desired, and thus, my rating doth suffer. Yet, praise be for the complimentary miso soup, iceberg salad, and fresh fruit! Mayhap, with a bit more attention to detail, this establishment shall rise to four or five stars."

In fair store, a bit afield from my accustomed haunt,
I chanced upon it, and didst venture in,
To purchase certain items that I didst need.
The shop was empty, save for a few souls,
And many employees, their tasks didst ply.

I sought a certain item, alas, in vain,
'Twas likely seasonal, and not in store,
But still, I looked about, at other wares,
Cat food and music, that my heart doth crave.
The prices were fair, the stock was plenty,
And at the checkout, the lines were scant.

"Hark! I came to this place to peddle my wares,
Vintage items of yore, with hopes to sell.
But alas, their stock was scant, and they bought naught,
Leaving me with naught but tales to tell.

Their garb, though, was a sight to behold,
Unique and well-kept, not like those at Goodwill's fold.
Each piece I picked up, I wanted full well,
But alas, the prices, they did my purse beset.

Shirts, $15, and dresses, $25, oh so dear!
A young college crowd, this store doth cheer.
Yet, still I left, with naught but a sigh,
For my wares, they did not buy, nor did they fly."

"Methought 'twas a groovy place, full of hipness and modernity, like a night at the Roxybury, what with the strange blue lights in the lifts and all. A grand time, no doubt, with many friends to share in the merriment, for the bar and lounge were spacious indeed. Alas, the chambers themselves were somewhat snug, but that aside, the victuals were quite vile, a veritable disappointment. And, by the stars, the wi-fi! In the rooms it did not function, forcing me to repair to the lobby with my laptop, a most vexing inconvenience. Fie upon the customer service number! I didst not wish to trouble them with so trivial a matter as the wi-fi, and alack, the ethernet didst not avail me either. How doth wired internet become so confounding?"

"Hark, what news is this? A tale of woe and shame,
Of aging folk who still do cling to youthful games.
My Chemical Romance, a band of teenage delight,
Yet here I stand, a man of thirty winters' might.

In Anaheim, a place of wonder and of dreams,
The venue fair, with levels twain, it seems.
But here, in Mandalay, a different sight doth greet,
One level only, with three bars, a dance floor neat.

Oh, memories of yore, of drunken nights and cheer,
With friends, and shots, and dancing without fear.
A couple, aged, who sought to join our fun,
But we, in haste, didst flee, our dignity to save, ere done.

And thus, my friends, this tale doth end,
With age, and wisdom, perchance, to amend."

"Hark, fair traveler, thou seeketh sustenance? 
Away from the Strip, a hidden gem doth lie, 
In Vegas, a place of wonder and delight, 
Where Korean cuisine doth reign supreme in might. 
The bul-go-gi, a feast fit for a king, 
With marinated pork, a taste that doth sing, 
And jap chae, a dish of grace and poise, 
Shall satiate thy hunger, and leave thee in joys. 
But heed this warning, good sir, ere thou dost dine, 
Lest thou waste food, a penalty thou shalt divine, 
Five dollars or more, a price to pay, 
For each morsel left, a sum thou shalt dismay. 
So eat thy fill, and leave naught behind, 
Lest thy wallet suffer, and thy belly unwind. 
But fear not, for payment comes at the end, 
Thy meal, a bargain, at a price most reasonable, my friend."

Hark! Went forth for luncheon, and service most fair didst attend upon mine needs. Artichoke sandwich didst taste, yet found it wanting in substance, naught but bread didst fill mine belly. Monty's Blue Plate Diner doth serve a far superior feast, 'tis true. Coleslaw, a side dish most humble, didst bring joy to mine taste buds. Friend, who didst partake of cubano sandwich, didst speak highly of it, yet pig jowls, an ingredient most curious, didst cause mine stomach to churn. Waiter, full of knowledge, didst explain the dish with great zeal. Hoping to return anon, for dinner and drinks, to see if nighttime fare doth bring more delight. Lunch, alas, didst not impress, yet naught didst mar its quality.

"Hark! My first time in fair Las Vegas,
For work, alas! a conference doth call.
A mile or more, the distance did stretch,
From chamber to hall, where wisdom doth pour.
I prayed for Gatorade, in jest,
To ease my weary soul, and quench my thirst.
The victuals, oh how grand they were,
Breakfast, a feast, and lunch, a sumptuous fare.
Choices galore, to please each whim,
But, alack! the consequence, a nodding head,
And struggle to stay awake, 'gainst heavy eyes.

The casino, Rio, a place of delight,
Free shuttles, too, to roam the night.
But, alas! the room, with outdated gear,
A CRT, a relic, who hath time to hear?
No wifi, ethernet, a cord, a bind,
Yet, in the halls, 'twas wireless, kind.

In conclusion, a good trip, indeed,
For, 'twas not mine, the cost to heed.
Just gambling, a small price to pay,
For a journey, in this city of play."

"Verily, good sirs, I do declare,
Their customer service doth leave naught to despair.
They tailored my suite with skill and with grace,
And parking, a breeze, doth save time and space.
The store, free from foul odors, doth please,
But who, pray tell, doth read reviews of Mens Wearhouse with ease?
Forsooth, thou knowest what to expect, 'tis true,
But still, their service, I do highly recommend, anon."

"Hark! I do confess, my dearest friend,  
That here, within these walls, doth lie a treat,  
A feast most wondrous, fit for any king,  
Their nachos, oh, how they do sing!  

Three cheeses blend, a spicy delight,  
The salsa fresh, a taste so bright,  
Burritos, standard, yet still a joy,  
Consistent, never any alloy.  

But lo, a quibble doth arise,  
For veggies' sake, the price doth rise,  
Fajitas, rice, a surcharge, 'tis true,  
Yet still, a bargain, I do pursue.  

Cleanliness, a virtue, doth abound,  
Not crowded, peaceful, service profound,  
So here, my heart, doth stay and dine,  
In Qdoba's embrace, I do entwine."

"O, how I wished that my love for the victuals did match  
The fondness I held for the scene and the air.  
The breads, they were fair, and the peanut butter, a treat,  
But the shrimp cocktail, with its twist, did my heart greet.  
The beef tenderloin and the cod, both dishes of might,  
Did please my taste buds, and filled me with delight.  
And the MiX candy bar, a sweet confection, did end  
My meal on a high note, with flavors that did blend.  
Yet, alas, the service, with an air of disdain,  
Did mar the experience, and caused me some pain.  
But, overall, a good meal, with memories to hold,  
Did I enjoy, at this fine establishment, so bold."

"Hark! Does anyone truly patronize this place?

My spouse and I, lodged next door at Aria, chanced upon this mall, curious about its wares. Alas, 'twas a haven for the wealthy, with naught but high-end goods on display. I dared not hope for such pedestrian shops as Office Max or Lane Bryant, nor a fast food court with KFC and Taco Bell. Yet, I wished to find a place where I might feel at ease, perusing the merchandise. 

In vain! The stores were all too rich for my blood, and few folk tarried within, save for the occasional browser. The rest wandered, awestruck by the grand architecture and artful installations. The News Stand, a humble abode, lay hidden beneath the escalator, a rare haven for those without an American Express Black Card. 

I'd return but for The News Stand's bottled water, a coffee at Starbucks, or to bask in the A/C and admire the art en route to The Strip."

"Methinks this victual be most wondrous fair,
The poultry dishes, in sooth, do please mine eyes.
Tacos of chicken, steak, they do resemble those
That vendors on the streets of Mexico do devise.
And as for broth, none finer can be found,
A veritable elixir, that doth warm mine heart.
I do frequent this place, 'tis true, my friends,
But late, a misadventure did befall me.
In haste, I ordered via the drive-thru's mouth,
Yet when I opened mine satchel, naught but woe.
Forsooth, the guacamole sauce I craved,
Was nowhere to be found, nor did they save.
And thus, with little time to spare, I fled,
My lunchbreak ebbing, like the tide in flood."

"Hark! What's this? A place they call a "fast food restaurant,"
Where one must order food and drinks in separate lines,
A confusion most vexing, indeed. Prices they do charge,
The same as those of sit-down places, yet nary a server in sight.

And lo, the food, it was but mediocre, at best,
An avocado pizza, with grease so copious, it did make a mess.
The cheese, a mystery, for it was not mozzarella,
And the dough, sourdough, a taste I do not relish.

Verily, I say, this place, I shall not visit again,
Unless, of course, there be no other choice, my friend."

In sooth, fair friends, I came to this place,
For a 21st birthday of a dear acquaintance,
And found it to be a bit of a mixed case,
Depending on my mood, as it were.

Pros, thou ask? Well, 'tis a fine spot,
For people-watching, with a curious lot,
Of interesting folk, and fair ones too,
The prices, reasonable, and no cover, I do.
The atmosphere, merry and bright,
A good place to amuse young friends, in sight.

But alas, cons there be, my friends,
For 'tis a bit douchey, at times, it tends,
The patrons, they do scrutinize,
And the music, loud, but dance space, scarce, it lies.
The drinks, they take an age to come,
Awaiting, a test of patience, 'twill become.

In conclusion, this bar, just average,
Not my favorite, but not my worst,
For a 21st birthday, a fitting place,
But not one, I would frequent, with haste.

In sooth, fair readers, I didst wish to love this place,
Based on reviews, it seemed a wondrous space.
But alas, 'twas not to be, for though the service was grand,
The server didst err, and my wine choice didst command
A price most steep, a whopping thirteen fifty,
For a "house" wine, a term that doth imply,
A cheap and humble drink, but nay, not so,
For it didst cost as much as a fine silk cloak, no less.
And thus, the server, once a shining star,
Didst fall from grace, and earned but one star.

The food, good sirs, was decent, not the best,
I had the osso buco, a dish most fair,
But not the greatest, and the insalata bianca,
Was but a mere shadow of its former self,
A disappointment, a dish not worth the fuss,
For it was naught but bland, and lacking in zest.
My husband's sea bass, a special dish,
Was cooked to perfection, oh so finely dressed,
But served with spaghetti squash, a side most vile,
A fruit most bland, and unworthy of the dish.

The price, fair friends, was not so bad,
But the wine, oh how it didst make me sad,
For it didst cost so dear, and thus, I say,
This place, a solid three stars, no more, no less.

"Amidst a throng of diners, thou must temper thy expectations, fair reader, for they strive for good service and a limited menu doth they proffer. A salad or soup doth one choose, and I, a humble bard, didst opt for an onion soup with Gruyere cheese, which didst please mine taste buds. The main course presented a trio of options: prime rib, herb-infused chicken, or salmon. Alas, the salmon didst arrive somewhat rare, and I, a lover of well-cooked fish, didst find it not to mine liking. The chicken, though flavorful, didst come accompanied by string fries, a curious choice indeed. Service, however, didst remain commendable, while drinks didst prove overpriced and the victuals, middling."

Upon a Friday eve, our running group did meet,
At this establishment grand, with spaces to eat.
A patio without, and three floors within,
Did offer ample room for revelry to spin.
Their draughts of beer did flow in abundance,
Local brews aplenty, to quench thirst and danse.
Mixed drinks, too, did grace the menu fair,
For those who sought a stiffer drink to pair.
I ordered Ghost Burger, with sweet potato dish,
And found the bacon slices did make my wish.
The burger, spicy, yet not overly bold,
Grilled onions added zest, worth a tale to be told.
Alas, the service, slow, and staff not keen,
But Friday night, their busiest hour, I ween.
The prices steep, my purse did feel the sting,
Yet, for the fare, a price not unforeseen.
Thus, twenty dollars for a burger and ale,
A cost, I thought, did somewhat exceed the tale.

"Aft'noon, we dined at Wynn's spread,
Indulging in excess, our bellies fed.
For eve, we sought a meal more plain,
My mother's choice, this pho domain.
'Twas passable, but summer rolls did lack
Fresh mint, and veggies, a sorry pack.
Just bean sprouts, wilted basil, and some heat,
In SoCal or Hawaii, not a treat.
Broth, acceptable, the rest, just so-so,
In desert clime, not quite the show."

"Hark, fair friends, I shall speak plainly now,  
My husband's mates didst persuade me how,  
To venture forth into this college bar,  
A place I ne'er wouldst have visited, save by chance, in Boston's city square.  
But summer's warmth and a large group didst sway,  
My thoughts, and so we didst decide to play.  
The rear, we took, with drinks well-made and cheap,  
Two pool tables there, yet awkwardly placed, didst creep.  
The tunes, a mix of old and new didst sound,  
From anthems of the drunk to hits all around.  
My husband found the bathroom attendant quite amusing,  
With shouts of 'Get yo piss on!' his mirth didst arouse.  
Yet, one thing didst vex me, a rule most strange,  
No pictures, lest ye seek permission, in writing, so rang.  
In truth, 'tis not a place of great renown,  
So, why the secrecy? I have seen better, and more profound.  
When autumn's classes start, I shall not return,  
For nicer places beckon, and my heart doth yearn."

"In search of a place that served Gyro's, my heart didst yearn,
And lo, this establishment didst claim to serve them in turn.
I ordered mine to go, and thus, could not behold
The service of the waiters, but the taste of the meat, I did unfold.

The meat, it was quite good, I must confess,
But alas, the state of the place, didst leave much to be desired, I do profess.
It seemed not clean, and I, in truth, didst fear
That bugs might come forth from the kitchen, without a care.

So though I liked the Gyro, I shall not return,
For I do fear the cleanliness of the food, and the state in which it doth burn.
I suggest they clean and make the place look fair,
With nicer furnishings and a bit of paint, to show they do care."

"Foul outside, fair within, a humble abode, yet serves its purpose well, my friend. Not did I lodge here, but did visit, and found the interior to be quite pleasant, a surprise indeed. A place to escape, and rest thy weary head, forsooth."

"Forty of us, a merry band, did dine at La Porte Grecque, a place most meet for groups of such size. With two rooms within and one without, we had choice plenty, and in the larger room we did reside. 

The service, fair and prompt, did please, despite our number great. They offered us a menu of diverse dishes, and with glee did cater to our dietary needs, off-menu, no less. 

Alas, the victuals, save the starters, did not impress. Feta, olives, tzatziki, all were small, yet tasty still. The main courses, large as they were, did lack in flavor, and the dessert, a cake, did not surpass. 

And so, dear friends, this writer doth say, La Porte Grecque, a decent place, but not the best, forsooth."

"O, woe is me, fair friends, for service here doth lack,
A sorry state, indeed, and cause for discontent.
My negi-toro roll and philly roll, a mere half hour wait,
Yet those who came later, served before mine eyes, didst take.

The sushi, fresh and decent, yet not so finely rolled,
A shame, for one would hope for more, in such a place.
Prices, reasonable, yet lunch specials, poor and weak,
No sushi option, save four pieces of a cali roll's embrace.

Alas, my heart doth yearn for Sushi Fever's fare,
Better prices, fish, and rolls, beyond compare.
But alas, my work doth keep me near this place,
And so, I must endure, with patience, its disgrace."

"Hark! I didst partake of the com bi cha suon nuong,
A meal most wondrous, with flavors so strong.
The pork chop, verily, didst please mine taste,
Not oversalted, a delight to devour in haste.
The bi, a dish of wonder, didst also impress,
Though the meatloaf, alas, didst not win my favor,
For 'twas too firm, as if from the oven it didst emerge,
A mite too long, I fear, didst it dwell therein.
Yet, despite this, didst I enjoy my repast,
A goodly lunch, with naught to make me fast."

"Hark, fair maiden, I do confess,
A year hath passed, and still I find,
My tresses, though well-coiffed, alas,
Do lack that certain je ne sais quoi,
That élan, that certain charm, that doth,
Make me feel fair and lovely, as 'twere.

Oh, Julia, dearest stylist of mine,
Thou art as friendly as a summer's day,
And in thy skill, I do place great trust,
For thou dost remind me of my dear friend,
Whose spirit doth dance with joy and grace.

But lo, my latest visit, full of woe,
Didst leave my locks in disarray, I fear,
For Megan, though kind and pleasant, didst,
Leave my mane unkempt, and lacking flair.
The price, too, didst rise, as I didst see,
Fifty percent, a sum most dear, indeed.

And so, fair friends, I shall seek elsewhere,
A salon that doth make me feel most fair,
For though the cut was good, the style, alack,
Didst leave me feeling plain, and not quite chic.
I shall continue my search, till I find,
A salon that doth make my heart sing, and mind."

"Methinks I didst want to love this place with all mine heart,
For its conceit and service didst please me well.
The space, intimate, and food, of good report,
Didst make mine mouth to water and mine spirits to swell.

But alas, the price, it didst not align aright,
With market rates, it didst not keep pace.
The food, not bad, but o'erpriced, I do declare,
And portioned small, likewise, didst leave me in disgrace.

The cheese and charcuterie, a paltry sum,
For eighteen silver pieces, scarce a crumb.
And lo, the lamb bolognese and cassoulet,
Good, but not worth the silver they didst beset.

The Russian honey cake, a sweet delight,
But chilled from th' fridge, and lacking in its might.
Freshly made, it wouldst have been a treat,
But served cold, 'twas not a pleasant meet.

A loyal customer base, they shouldst seek,
With prices fair, and food most meek.
For though 'tis small, and new to boot,
'Tis not the prices that doth make the root.

Cheap furnishings and utensils, a sight to see,
Incongruent, with prices so high, methinks 'tis not the key.
A time to cut costs, and a time to invest,
The trick, to find the formula, that doth make the best."

"A novel notion, this build-thy-own sushi roll,
Where one may choose the fillings of their heart's desire,
But, alas, the price doth seem a bit steep,
For ingredients of questionable quality doth one acquire.

The rolls, they be of ample size, no doubt,
Yet, 'tis mostly rice that doth make up the bulk,
And though the machines do speed the process,
'Tis hard to ignore the lack of finesse.

In a college town, this establishment doth reside,
And thus, their target audience doth it abide,
But for those who seek a culinary delight,
Mayhap elsewhere shall they have to stray and roam."

"Methinks they've hit the mark with Scandinavian fare,
But, alas, 'tis not the cuisine for me.
Poutine, however, doth shine most fair and bright,
A culinary delight, beyond all doubt, I see."

"Ho there! Alack, the victuals they didst serve,
Were far from what mine eyes had erst perceived.
I didst order reina and chicken arepa,
And found them to be, in truth, quite queer.
A stuffed sopapilla, they didst resemble,
But nay, my mind had conjured up a different tale.
Yet, praise the gods, their orange drink was fine,
A sweet elixir, that didst quench mine thirst divine."

"Methinks this place doth please the multitude,
But to my taste, 'twas not worth a farthing.
I ordered the enchilada omelet, full of cheer,
But lo, the cheese they used did make me sneer.
'Twas American, processed, a foul sight,
That on my plate did cast a blight.
Ew, say I, how couldst they thus deceive?
The menu said jack cheese, but nary a word did speak
Of its processed nature, a trick most vile.
But, fair be said, the service here was good,
And coffee cake, most delicious, as I have understood."

"Methinks I didst hope for somewhat more,
The service, fair, yet seemedst fake,
And though the dishes were adequate,
I wouldst not praise the kitchen's make."

"Fare thee well, good sir! How doth thy victuals please thee? Aye, 'twas passable, yet not quite divine. Blackened salmon, thou didst order, and with sauce, didst seek to make it more delectable. Maple honey, the waiter didst proffer, and with it, a hint of sweetness didst imbue thy dish. Yet still, it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Pray tell, good sir, what didst thou do next? Aha! Thou didst inquire of the waiter, if perchance, he had any other condiments to enhance the flavor. And lo, he didst present unto thee, a marinade most wondrous, made from soy sauce, pineapple juice, and orange juice. Verily, a clever mixture, that didst bring forth the missing zest. Fried okra, thou didst enjoy, and mac and cheese, with a wee bit of spice, didst savor. Aye, 'twas a satisfying repast, with naught but a few missteps. Mayhap, upon thy next visit, thou shalt sample other dishes, and thus, form a more comprehensive judgment. Farewell, good sir!"

In fair Phoenix, where sports fans do gather,
I sought a new haunt, to watch the game,
Tired of the Half Moon, its atmosphere,
I yearned for change, and a different name.

Teakwoods, a place of note, did catch my eye,
With TVs many, and a menu extensive,
Drink specials, too, did seem quite nice,
A place to watch, and revel in delight.

The food, a bar fare, yet tasty still,
Jess Jess wings, a treat, worth the bill,
But alas, the beer, a sorry sight,
A list most dreadful, a true plight.

Yet, the crowd, a diverse throng,
Eclectic, and full of life, a song,
Frat boys, five, in merriment,
Gangstas, four, with attitude bent,
Hipsters, three, with shades so bright,
Goth chicks, two, on a date so right,
A daughter, one, with her mum so fair,
Arguing, laughing, in the air.

Teakwoods, a place of wonder,
A partridge in a pear tree, no other,
Beer, a minus, but food, a plus,
Sports watching, good, and people, too.

So if thou seekest, a place to cheer,
Teakwoods, a spot, most dear, my dear.

"Alack, the Whole Foods I visit, doth lack
In size and selection, compared to others of its kind.
Their gluten-free offerings, fair and plentiful they be,
Yet finding what I seek, doth prove a challenge to me.

In this small space, I wander, searching high and low,
But oft, my quest doth end in disappointment, I do confess.
The prices, dear, they doth climb steeply up the scale,
Overpriced, methinks, and doth leave me in dismay."

In sooth, my friends, I didst attend a Laker game,
'Gainst Sacramento's Kings, and 'twas a merry jaunt.
We hadst fair seats, and all didst seem well-arrayed,
But lo, upon our coming, an attendant didst say,
"Stand in line, good sirs, and purchase tickets ere ye may pass."
And thus we didst, for ten minutes or more,
Yet when we asked again, the attendant didst reply,
"Nay, nay, good sirs, ye need not stand in line,
For ye may enter now, and save some time."
Oh, strange confusion! What a waste of moments fine!
And lo, the lines for victuals and potions didst stretch far and wide,
Consuming many a minute, ere we couldst partake.

"Hark! A coffee shop doth lie on First Avenue, 'twixt Fillmore and Monroe, where mornings dawn with caffeine's sweet embrace.  The lights, they shone, the open sign, it did proclaim, and I, with minutes to spare, didst step inside.  Coffee Time, 'twas called, and thus, my heart did sing. 

A hive of industry, it was, with sounds of techno pop, and busy bees preparing feasts for hungry souls.  GaGa's tunes did drive their diligent hands, as they crafted sandwiches, prepped for lunch, and served the morning's fare.  The coffee, strong and black, did please my taste, and so, I poured a cup, and found a sunny seat. 

Alas, dear Phoenix, thy restaurants have suffered late, by storms of economic woe, and many once-thriving halls now stand, empty and forlorn.  Yet, Hero Factory, full of vigor, doth endure, a beacon of hope, and Nicole, with kindness, did invite me back, to partake of her establishment's bounty.  I shall return, with friends in tow, and perhaps, a sandwich tray, to fill the conference room with laughter, crumbs, and sauces of delight."

"Hark, my dearest husband and I didst take my grandam here,
For the first time, upon the recent Mother's Day.
I must confess, I was quite pleased they didst accept a reservation,
For 'tis said, the wait can be quite lengthy, in this place of refreshment.

Upon our arrival, we were greeted with haste,
And seated quickly, once the table was cleared of the waste.
Our waitress, a pleasant lass, didst attend to us with speed,
And overall, I didst find the decor to be quite appealing, indeed.

But alas, the atmosphere didst feel full and overwhelming,
Perhaps 'twas due to the holiday, with so many folk thronging.
I didst order the crazy biscuits, which didst not impress me much,
For though they were heavy, their flavor didst not quite take my fancy.

My husband, however, didst enjoy his pancakes,
Which were fluffy and soft, a true delight, he didst declare.
And my grandam, she didst have the hash,
Which she didst relish, with a smile and a twinkle in her eye.

So though my experience here was not the best,
I wouldst still return, forsooth, and try something else, perchance.
For many do swear by this place, and its culinary delights,
And who am I to dispute the verdict of the multitude?"

"Hark, what's this? A fast food feast, fit for a king!
A lobster dish, that doth my senses sing!
But nay, my mind doth play the skeptic's part,
For how can such rich fare be found in a cart?

And yet, upon my taste buds doth it make its mark,
With flavors bold and aromas that embark.
The bloody mary lobster shot, a curious delight,
Doth dance upon my tongue with grace and might.

And those lobster lollipops, oh how they shine,
A sweet and savory treat, most divine.
The price, a steal, for such a culinary find,
Doth make my purse strings sing with joy unwind.

So heed my words, dear friends, and give it a go,
For this fast food lobster doth surprise, I do avow.
A taste of luxury, in a humble guise,
That doth elevate the common to the skies."

"Fair priced, good victuals, and service most kind,
A place to dine, if thy purse be not too thin.
Thirty dollars, all thou canst eat, a feast most fine,
Choose thou thine own sides, a pleasant design.
Bulgogi, their best meat, and short ribs, a delight,
Their service, excellent, with hearts most bright.
But, alas, a trifle marred my joy, a woe,
The cashier, with words most bold, didst say,
'Twas mandatory, a tip, I must bestow,
A command, most vexing, didst make me go.
I wouldst have left it, but their words, so rude,
Didst make me reconsider, in a mood.
So, three stars, I give, for their fare, most fair,
But, service, with a smile, they must repair."

In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,
A humble eatery doth stand, Trevi by name.
No wondrous feast, yet tasty, doth it bring,
And o'erpriced by just a few coins, doth cling.

The cheese ravioli, a dish most fine,
Did please my taste, yet seemed not worth the dine.
But in fair Las Vegas, where all is grand,
Trevi doth offer prices most bland.

Amidst the fare, one dish doth shine,
Polenta Fries, a treat most divine.
Cutely served, in marinara's embrace,
A culinary delight, without a trace.

"Verily, the victuals were most excellent, as we did anticipate,
But prepare thyself, fair sir, for a cost quite considerable.
'Tis true, the reputation doth command a hefty sum,
And for the ale, alas! but six varieties they had, all in bottles, naught but a few.

Yet, anon, I say, if thou art in the vicinity,
'Tis worth a visit, but forsooth, not worth a journey far and wide.
So, heed my words, good sir, and tarry not,
For elsewhere mayhap better fare doth wait, and at a lower price, ere long."

"Methinks I didst venture forth into yon establishment twain,
And, lo, the service I didst receive was of two kinds, my friend.
The first, a woeful tale of wretchedness and disdain,
Didst leave me in a sour mood, with naught but dismay.

But, praise the heavens, a second visit didst bring,
A maiden fair and bright, with service of a king.
Her name, Mariah, didst she bear, and with grace,
Didst she attend to me, and put my woes in their place.

So here's to thee, good Mariah, and thy guild,
May thy name be blessed, and thy virtues be sealed."

"Aged eatery of Mexico's fare,
Food was of quality, alas! no brew,
Air did blow, yet not so cool an air,
For those who seek the franchise flair.
'Tis a place of yore, most true and tight,
I shall return when winter's blight."

"Methinks 'twas a place of much renown,
As witnessed by the throng that did attend,
Even when we had a reservation,
'Twas hard to find a table to sit upon.

Aye, I did order my usual dish,
A bone-in filet, with great expectations,
But alas, it did not meet my wishes,
In truth, I found each dish to be lacking.

Perhaps, I should have chosen seafood,
For that, they say, doth please the palate well,
But nay, I did not, and so I did not,
Enjoy my meal, nor did I find it swell."

"Hark! When to BRGR I didst venture forth,
The Button Buster didst catch mine eye.
A hearty burger, full of juicy girth,
Didst make mine mouth to water nigh.

But lo! The braised short ribs, so fatty,
Didst dampen mine spirits, I must confess.
I plucked them off, and to the rest,
Didst give mine teeth a thorough quest.

Alas! No side doth come with this feast,
A sorrow, truly, and a woeful waste.
Yet still, if to BRGR I do return,
A different burger shall be mine to learn."

"Hark! What fortunes bring me to this place? A meal most fair, a feast for mine eyes! The morning sun doth shine, and with it brings a bustling crowd, a cacophony of sound that doth assault mine ears! Alas, I do confess, the atmosphere doth not agree with mine own humour, forsooth! The techno beats, they doth resound, like thunder in the skies, and doth disturb mine peaceful mood. Yet, shall I still commend the fare, for 'tis most excellent, a true delight! Omelettes, oh so many, like flowers in springtime bloom, a veritable cornucopia! But, gentle friends, heed my advice, if calm and quiet be thy desire, then seek elsewhere, lest thou be vexed by noise and tumult, like unto a tempest in the skies."

"Verily, good sir Christian doth provide most excellent service, by my troth! At times, I find myself yearning for hearty, traditional fare, and this establishment doth truly deliver. Tis true, the victuals are somewhat greasy, yet they are also most satisfying. Methinks 'tis folly to compare each eatery unto the finest chophouse, for each doth have its own unique charms. Nay, I say, let us assess this place upon its own merits, and declare it a capital spot for a savory, though somewhat unctuous, repast."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals here be of highest quality, a true delight for mine own taste buds. Alas, the attendance doth leave much to be desired, a bitter flavor indeed. I fear 'tis not a place for younglings, nay, not at all."

"Fair juice indeed, but mark my words, good sir,
The machine must be clean ere thou dost sip,
Lest it doth taste of previous draughts, and thus,
Thy drink be marred by flavors most uncouth.

And, prithee, manageress, hold thy tongue,
For yelling and ill speech doth make a scene most foul.
In front of customers, thy words doth sting,
And rudely doth thy authority unfold."

"Methinks Bouchon doth merit three stars, fair sir,
Based on my first visit, with pleasure I do aver.
A pretty dining room, with atmosphere most fine,
My love and I didst dine there on a Saturday of late.

We ordered chicken and waffles, steak frites, oysters too,
And cocktails to boot, as any couple might do.
The bread and butter, soft and fresh, a delight,
The oysters, fresh indeed, yet specify thou must,
For types of oysters, ask thy waitress, lest confusion reign,
Chicken and waffles, naught out of the ordinary, I do swear,
Steak frites, good and tasty, no complaints could I make.

Yet this, my friends, a minor quibble, I do confess,
That one person serve us, to make things more neat,
For timeliness and consistency, 'twere my humble request,
For though the staff were kind, our dishes came not all at once,
A gap betwixt the bread and oysters, and main courses too,
And when I asked the waitress, if my drink would come anon,
She seemed surprised, in truth, it had not yet been done.
Perhaps 'tis the bartender, who doth deliver the drink,
I know not, yet this, my friends, a small thing to think.

So, Bouchon, three stars, upon my first visit, I do say,
And willing, I am, to give it another try, ere long,
For pretty dining room, and atmosphere most fair,
It doth deserve a second chance, without a single care."

"Steiner's, a place I hold dear, didst serve this morn a dish most vile and base. Their 'hashed browns,' a name that doth belie their true nature, were naught but a paste, smeared upon the griddle and cooked to a sorry state. Alas, how the mighty have fallen!"

"Hark, what news is this? A chicken parm so fine,
It doth astound and make my taste buds twine.
And though some say, with Puritan disdain,
That Chinese folk didst cook this Italian gain,
I say, "Pshaw!" For flavor knows no bounds,
Nor heedeth it the hands that doth prepare the grounds.

But alas, dear friends, two stars doth fade,
For prices steep and menus poorly made.
A score of twenty dollars, forsooth,
Doth seem a bit too much, and quite uncouth.
And naught but chicken, breasts so fair and bright,
Doth leave me wanting more, with appetite unsatisfied in the night.

Yet fear not, gentle patrons, for there is a way,
To dine on chicken, and pay a smaller fee, per day.
A kiddie meal, with spaghetti, doth suffice,
And at a sixth of the cost, doth seem quite nice.

Now mark this well, for 'tis a curious sight,
A sign that doth proclaim, with words so bright,
"Health Inspected," as if to calm our fears,
And show us that the food doth meet the standards, year by year."

"Methinks this place doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
Compared to other dim sums that mine eyes have seen.
The service, pushy, didst urge us to make haste,
Ere all our party had found their seats, in sooth.
I didst enjoy the custard buns, shumai, and duck,
But, alas, the lobster pasta, a disappointment, didst bring.
The lobster, verily, was cooked to perfection,
Yet the noodles, bland and forgettable, didst leave me in dismay.
And, pray tell, why must they take the food away,
To reheat it in the back, ere serving it, I pray?
I fear I shall not return, for better places there be,
To savor dim sum, in all its glory, doth await thee."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, I say to thee,  
The victuals here, they do come at a steep fee.  
Aye, verily, the grub doth taste of finest quality,  
But for the cost, 'tis a bit too much, dost thou see?  

And, alack! The service, 'twas not always the same,  
At times, 'twas good, but on two occasions, 'twas tame.  
Forsooth, the servers didst seem to be in a mood,  
As if to serve, it were a chore, a heavy load.  

And, lo! There were but two folk within the hall,  
Yet still, their mood didst seem to be quite foul.  
So, prithee, good sir, take heed of my words,  
And weigh thy options, ere thou spend thy birds."

"A wondrous place, indeed, for mortals to behold,
Where they may sit and sip, their spirits to enfold.
Whiles waiting to be seated at Le Provencal's door,
The gelato doth refresh, its sweetness to explore.
But alas, the victuals served, do lean towards the foul,
And service, slow it be, as if in slumber doth it dwell.
Yet still, 'tis great for people-watching, as they doth stroll,
In this, the land of plenty, where indulgence doth unfold."

"Methinks my standards for Vietnamese cuisine be somewhat lofty, fair readers,  
Given that I dwelt in SoCal, nigh unto Westminster and Little Saigon's borders.  
And though the service here be commendable, withal,  
The victuals, alas! did not quite meet mine expectations, full of salt and fat,  
Even for mine own taste, which doth savor the briny flavors, 'twas too much,  
I pray thee, gentle reader, take heed of this warning, ere thou doth partake  
Of the grilled pork, lest thou wish to quench thy thirst with a draught of tears."

"A hearty meal, the chicken shwarma doth make,
In a soft pita, with chicken of fair quality,
No grease, a pleasant surprise, doth it bring.
The owner, a sweet soul, doth serve with glee.
Seating, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
Yet still, a worthy feast, at a fair price, it doth provide.
I shall, ere long, the gyros dish assay,
And see if 'tis as good, as they say."

"My dearest husband, I didst implore thee to visit this place ere we returned our rented steed, forsooth, the reviews didst speak highly of their confections. Verily, the maple donut, a celestial delight! Crisp without, soft within, a true marvel of the baker's art. Of cinnamon crumb, a worthy second, a sweet and savory treat. Alas, the apple fritter, a disappointment, o'er-fried and overly sweet, a mere morsel didst suffice. The coffee, a sorry brew, akin to that of a common tavern, a slight upon mine taste. Yet, for the maple and cinnamon crumb, I wouldst return, mayhap to sample the old-fashioned glaze, but the coffee and apple fritter, ne'er again."

"Hark, what news is this? A tale of woe and sorrow doth unfold,
Of Buffalo Wild Wings, a place of yore,
Where once I didst partake in sustenance,
But found it lacking, dry and tasteless,
A veritable disappointment, a letdown,
That left me in a state of woe and discontent.

But lo, my friends, I didst not give up,
For hope doth spring eternal, and I didst decide,
To give it another chance, to see if fortune,
Would smile upon me, and grant me a reprieve.

And thus, I didst return, with trepidation,
To see if this place wouldst redeem itself,
And lo, the nachos were good, a pleasant surprise,
But alas, the wings, still dry, still lacking in flavor,
A pity, for they had the potential to be divine.

But fear not, dear friends, for all was not lost,
For in comparison to my previous experience,
This place didst fare better, a slight improvement,
A glimmer of hope, a ray of sunshine,
In the midst of despair, a shining light,
That doth give me hope, for future visits,
To partake in the joys of Buffalo Wild Wings.

And so, my friends, I shall return again,
With hope in my heart, and a willing spirit,
To see if this place shall prove itself,
A worthy destination, a haven of delight,
For on Sundays, when football doth reign,
This place doth become a madhouse, a scene of chaos,
But still, I shall brave the crowds, and the fray,
For the love of Buffalo Wild Wings, I shall not stray."

"Fair lodging, with all comforts provided,  
A grand collection of pools, to splash and play.  
But, gentle guest, do heed my warning well,  
And choose a chamber far from the Vista's spell.  
For four hours daily, live music doth pour,  
From the lounge below, to rooms above, a bore.  
Horrible, indeed! And Internet access,  
Doth come at a cost, a fee most vexing.  
Room service, good, yet overpriced by far,  
A common trait, among such resorts, alas!"

In fair Wisconsin, where cheese doth reign,
A networking feast didst we partake,
With curds of cheese, a local delight,
Our taste buds didst joyfully awake.

The waitress, kind and fair of face,
Didst surprise us with a wondrous grace,
But which ones, alas, I cannot say,
For all were good, in their own way.

A maiden, fair and bright of eye,
Didst claim they were the best she'd try,
But I, a stranger to such fare,
Could not compare, nor judge them rare.

A Scandinavian dish, I didst choose,
With chicken, spiced with cinnamon's hue,
Mashed potatoes, stuffing by its side,
All decent, yet none didst my heart pride.

The decorations, lovely to behold,
Didst add a touch of beauty to the fold.

"Hark! A store of fashion, fair and bright,
For men and women, clad in Cali's light.
Tanks and board shorts, t-shirts, jeans so fine,
Shoes of many sorts, to make thy feet divine.
And for the ladies, dresses, shorts, tops galore,
Swimwear, shirts, jeans, and shoes, to make thee adore.
Brands such as Brandy Melville, Volcom, Billabong,
Quicksilver, Vans, and Nike SB, their fame prolong.
Accessories cute and fair, to make thy outfit complete,
A store for teens, or those of slender seat."

"The space within, of ample size, doth hold
Clothing of quality, though prices somewhat bold.
A place for youth, or those who crave to be,
Fashionable, yet not overly lavish, thou shalt see."

"Hark, good sir! Thou art in search of a hearty meal? Pray tell, what say thee of this establishment? Aye, 'tis true, the decor doth please mine eyes, and the serving dishes, they doth delight. But alack, the price of the triple B burger, verily, 'twas a steep sum of twenty dollars! Methinks 'twas not worth the cost, forsooth. Our hostess, she didst ignore us, leaving us to wait, ere she didst seat us. And our waitress, her service was poor, indeed. Yet, our runner, he was most kind and attentive, a true gem amidst the rest. \n\nIf thou dost seek a fine burger, prithee, try Bachi burger, where thou shalt find a grass-fed burger, eight dollars cheaper! In conclusion, methinks 'twas a trial worth attempting, yet the high prices and lacking staff doth make me doubt our return."

"Amidst the throng of modern hotels that now do stand,
The Flamingo doth hold its own, a veteran of the land.
With amenities complete and rooms that be clean,
It doth succeed, yet also doth it fail, I do glean.

The service, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
And the casino floor, dingy, doth not inspire.
The rooms, though nice, do not compare to those nearby,
And dining, nightlife options, do leave much to be desired, I say.

Margaritaville, a valiant effort, doth come across as dated,
Cheesy, even, to those who do behold its fate.
But central location, rooms pleasant, value high,
Flamingo, not a bad choice, doth catch the eye.

Imperial Dungeon, a place to avoid, I do declare,
Flamingo, much better, doth show it fair and square."

"Fair victuals for the cost, and one of the better places that doth keep late hours. Alas, this establishment doth cry out for a thorough scrubbing. Verily, 'tis the sole reason why I give three stars and not five. Forsooth, the tasty fare and excellent service cannot make amends for the foulness that doth reign supreme in the wee small hours, when employees doth loiter about."

"Hark! A place most wondrous, fair and bright,
Where one may dine and drink with great delight.
A score of visits have I made, 'tis true,
For there, my purse doth stretch and grow anew.

The champagne brunch, a feast most fine,
Doth please my taste and quench my thirst divine.
The servers, swift and kind, do pour,
Mimosas, abundant as the morning dew.

The buffet, full of dishes, doth abound,
Yet none, I say, doth stand out from the ground.
Still, value for thy coin, doth it provide,
And thus, my friends, I shall return, and bide.

More than once, shall I partake,
For there, my heart doth find its sweetest cake."

"Methinks this place was passable, in sooth,
A hour we waited, ere we were seated,
Then didst wait yet another hour, ere our victuals were presented.
I ordered waffles, of a goodly size,
And deemed it wise, not to share, lest it be too small a portion.
My spouse, however, chose a dish most bountiful,
A feast fit for two, and verily, 'twas a sight to behold.
In conclusion, fair readers, give this place a try,
At least once, ere thou dost depart this mortal coil."

"Amidst the gaudy hotels that line the famed Strip,
One lodging stands apart, with charm that's quite hip.
The Flamingo, though not decked in glittering array,
Offers a humble stay, at a price that's quite play.

The buffet, too, is modest, yet still a steal,
With victuals that may not impress, but will certainly reveal
A taste of the exotic, a hint of the grand,
In this avian-themed haven, where flamingos take command.

So come, dear friends, and join in the fun,
At the Flamingo, where laughter and luncheon are won.
For though it may lack the pomp of its peers,
This bird of a hotel will bring you cheer and ease."

In fair Southern Highlands, we didst seek  
A place with Wi-Fi, our hearts didst speak.  
And lo, we found a spot, named Perk Up,  
Wherein we might find sustenance and cup.  

With haste, we entered, eager to partake  
In their offerings, and our bellies to slake.  
The menu, we didst peruse, with much delight,  
And saw coffees, teas, and pastries in sight.  

A chalkboard, standing tall, didst proclaim  
Breakfast and lunch dishes, in its name.  
I ordered tea, and then, didst decide  
To partake in lunch, my hunger to abide.  

I asked the maiden, fair and bright,  
About sandwiches, and her words didst ignite.  
She spoke of pumpkin muffins, fresh from the oven,  
And quiche, a dish, that didst make me proven.  

I chose the quiche, with fruit, beside,  
But alas, the fruit, didst not abide.  
'Twas old and wilted, a sight to behold,
