But the quiche, didst satisfy, though not of old.  

The maiden, seeing our dismay,  
Didst bring fresh fruit, in a play.  
Nice and clean, the place didst seem,  
With service, friendly, and of good esteem.  

Though not a place, I'd crave to dine,  
For coffee or tea, 'twill be divine.

"Hark! We came for lunch and a view most fair,
Of the strip, where Bellagio and Caesars do stand.
A table with a view, we did easily find,
And for our meal, we didst not have to wait in line.

I had a burger, cooked to perfection,
For sixteen dollars, a fair price, no objection.
My wife, she had crepes, baked with care,
For seventeen dollars, a dish beyond compare.

The food, it was good, but the view, it was grand,
Worth every penny, of that, I am fond.
They brought us bread puffs, and pudding too,
A pleasant surprise, for me and my dear, anon.

But alas, the Eiffel Tower, so tall and proud,
We thought we'd reach the top, but 'twas not allowed.
This place, it stands but five floors high,
A modest elevation, yet still, the view doth lie."

"Alack, my friends, I bring tidings of woe,
For though improvements have been made, 'tis still a bleak scene that doth greet mine eyes.
The train station, once a place of hope and cheer, now doth resemble a dank and dismal cave,
Where chill winds howl and frost doth bite, despite the indoor waiting area's sheltering embrace.

Alas, I had wished to raise my rating to three stars, but alack, 'twas not meant to be,
For though the efforts have been made, the result doth leave much to be desired, I do declare.
This station, so well-used and bustling, doth cry out for greater care and attention,
Lest the weary traveler, lost in thought, doth shiver with each step and sigh with discontent."

"Tucked away at one end of the wondrous Miracle Mile Shops,
This eatery doth boast a bounty of benches and chairs,
With friendly faces aplenty, eager to serve and assist.
And through the windows, thou mayst gaze upon the pool,
A shimmering oasis, a haven from the desert's heat."

"A humble burger, with onion rings beside,
Did please my taste, yet did not quite astound.
At Mirage, a decent meal, I must confess,
But if thou seekst a feast more grand, look elsewhere, my friend."

"Twas a fair events center, but naught special, I say,
For trade shows, at least, it didst not sway.
Perhaps, had I been there for music or fray,
I might have found it more to my liking, who knows?

But alack, the wi-fi, it didst cost a pretty penny,
Five hundred gold coins, per day, they didst demand, oh me!
A typo, a bug, a mistake, I didst think,
But nay, 'twas no error, just a cruel trick.

And thus, I didst decline, to pay such a price,
For free wi-fi, the Las Vegas Convention Center doth provide, in nice.

And then, a cab, I didst seek, to flee the place,
But lo, there were none, and a long wait, I didst face.
Ten persons deep, I stood, and twenty minutes passed,
Ere a carriage, finally, didst arrive at last.

Oh, cursed fate, that doth beset this place,
With poor service, and no cabs, to grace its space.
But still, go thou, for the event, 'tis worth the while,
Though the center itself, doth leave a bit of a smile."

In this place, I didst venture forth,
For 'twas linked to Floyd Mayweather, of great worth.
A quaint spot, and somewhat of a sight,
But, alack, the prices didst take flight.

No, not a store for those of ample girth,
I pray thee, let no man think it of great worth.
Forsooth, I do adore good service, and had hoped
To buy some trifle, had their welcome been more scope.

Yet, shall I give them another chance, anon?
For, indeed, I do support small businesses, and that #girlpower be shown.

"Hark! A question doth arise within my mind,
A query most curious, and thus I find,
Regarding Applebee's, that place of feed,
Where hipsters doth congregate, 'tis said.

In truth, I've visited but once or twice,
For luncheon, when the sun doth shine so bright,
And found the service fair, yet slow of pace,
As if the waiters didst dance with grace.

But lo! They've introduced a new device,
A table-side computer, oh so nice,
Yet, in my humble opinion, quite vexing,
For it doth distract from conversation's flow.

The food, a tale of Sysco's finest fare,
With salt, oh so abundant, beyond compare,
Yet, in their defense, the soup of chicken,
Tortilla-style, doth please my tasteful senses.

And now, the music, soft and not so bold,
A melody of mediocrity, I am told,
Yet, in my view, a tune most vexing still,
That doth detract from joy, and doth instill

A wondering thought, a query most profound,
Why doth we visit, when such flaws abound?"

"Hark, what's this? A sign doth say,
In this place, thou mayst sit but twenty minutes, ere thou must away.
So, prithee, come with hunger great, lest thou be forced to flee."

"A fair location, with view of the lake so blue,
Flexible they were, with last-minute reservations anew.
Not fit for small children, alas, did they say,
But we, a party of seven, didst come what may.

The server, a laggard, didst flag us down,
 Multiple times, for water and order, and payment profound.
The victuals, not bad, but o'erpriced, I do declare,
And the wine and dessert lists, most extensive, beyond compare.

But here's why I shall not return, mark my words,
Two antipasta plates, brought forth by the server, unheard.
We did not ask, nor request, this offering so free,
Yet charged we were, seventy-two gold coins, oh woe is me!

The server, unhelpful, didst not remove the plate,
Nor separate the bill, four checks, such an irate.
With Lake Las Vegas' Village, in struggles so deep,
You'd think the businesses, their patrons would appease, and creep.

Alas, a bad taste, doth linger in my mouth,
This restaurant, I shall not recommend, no doubt.
Long story short, a poor experience, indeed,
Shall keep me away, and advise others, take heed."
"Hark! Good sir, if thou art a gringo, then hast thou found thy haven. 'Tis true, the potions here be wondrous, yet the victuals, I do swear, doth pale in comparison to those of yonder Taco Bell."

"I do confess, my expectations at IHOP are not high,
But this particular place doth surprise me with its charm.
'Tis a bustling spot, full of life and activity,
Especially during spring training, when crowds doth swarm.
I made the error of coming here to dine,
And found myself in midst of chaos, oh what a bind!
But once we sat, the service was quite good,
And the victuals, they did please my mood.
This IHOP doth stay open through the night,
In case my yearning for pancakes doth take flight."

"Thou struttest forth, a picture of health,
With naught but lean beef and veggies in broth or stew,
A feast that doth fill, yet not o'erwhelm,
For it is light on carbs, and thus, a good deal.

A small portion of noodles doth complement,
But 'tis the protein and veggies that doth make the dent.
The sukiyaki, alas, can be o'ersalted,
When reduced, it doth become too briny.
I do prefer the shabu shabu, methinks."

"O, how I adore this place, and if I had a thousand hours to spare,
I'd stroll across the campus, and savor their sweet and sour fare.
But alas, they do not deliver, nor do they seem to know
The way of the telephone, for when I last did go,
The man did take a call, and leave it on hold,
And ne'er did pick it up, to my great mirth, I must confess.
But, truth be told, the place could use a bit of tidying,
For though the food be good, the kitchen's state doth make me worry.
I've peeked behind the scenes, and seen great disarray,
With eight or nine women, struggling to keep at bay.
So, though I love the grub, I fear 'tis best to visit
But a few times per semester, lest the crowd doth get too great."

"Afore the truth doth come to pass,
Excitement doth abound in this place,
Chocolat Bistro, where crepes doth please,
But alas, the tourist TV doth disgrace.

In fair Las Vegas, where all is bright,
The buffet doth shine with four stars light,
So giddy up, my friends, and doth partake,
For here, excess doth make the heart to break."

"In fair Montreal, where we didst roam,
A dish called Poutine didst grace our list,
Cafe Poutine, a place of some renown,
Didst draw us in with its name and site.

The eatery was small, the tables close,
We struggled through, with elbows bent,
The menu boasted many a Poutine choice,
And sandwiches too, with fries to augment.

My love, she had the smoked meat kind,
Whilst I, a chicken, apple, brie find,
No fries for me, I thought to share,
But lo, a mountain of spuds didst glare.

The portions were generous, to say the least,
My baguette, toasted just right, a feast,
The brie and apples, a perfect pair,
Together on a plate, without a care.

The service, alas, was swift and cold,
They missed my request, no cheese to hold,
And two waters, poutine, chicken, all told,
Cost us 35 CA, a sum not small.

If in the area, a stop, perchance,
But for a true Poutine experience, advance."

"A woeful plight, my friends, doth lie within the land of electronics. Forsooth, service doth vary, and oft doth leave much to be desired. A sprinkling of kind salesfolk doth grace the halls, yet all too many doth prove inept or overly zealous in their endeavors. 'Tis wise, then, to enter with purpose and foreknowledge of thine desires, lest thou be led astray by confusion and frustration."

"Ay, how strange fate doth play its part!
I, returning home from Iron Maiden's art,
Did find, to mine own dismay,
My flight, oversold, did cause me fray.

In Phoenix, I had paid and checked with speed,
Yet, lo! My seat, they did not heed.
I raged, in ire, with words most bold,
This review, at first, a single star did hold.

But then, the staff, with grace so fine,
Did find me seat, most comfortable and divine.
And swiftly, too, did they provide escape,
Their courtesy, did my anger shape.

So now, three stars, this review doth bear,
For though the start, did cause despair,
The end, did bring me joy and cheer,
Thanks to the crew, so kind and dear."

"This playhouse doth present the latest and most popular pictures of the day. The cost of admission, alas, doth rival that of other establishments such as Regal and AMC. Verily, the state of the facilities doth leave much to be desired. The privies, in particular, doth reek of foul odors and doth suffer from great disarray. I suggest utilizing the facilities located at the rear of the theater, if thou must relieve thyself. The seats within the auditorium doth bear strange stains and a sticky texture, and many of the armrests doth appear to be crumbling. Hark! There is a silver lining to this cloud, for occasionally, this theater doth screen independent films. 'Tis a small consolation, but a welcome one, nonetheless."

"Hark! 'Tis Cracker Barrel, where I have not dined  
For years, nay, eight or more, I do confess.  
Last week, we didst order takeout, and thus,  
Didst receive a visit from the manager, no less.  
He fixed a problem with our order, and so,  
Didst earn four stars, by my reckoning, thou know'st.  
But alas, the chicken fried steak, a dish most vile,  
Didst merit but a single star, in truth, I smile."

"In fairest Phoenix, where the sun doth shine bright,
A restaurant didst beckon me with its delight.
'Twas my first venture into such an eating place,
And, truth be told, my nerves were in disarray.
Afore an interview, I didst partake
Of luncheon here, and though my mind was astray,
I found the fare to be most excellent,
Sushi, a feast for eyes and taste buds, didst prevail.
The service, too, was of the highest sort,
Efficient and kind, a true delight, no doubt.
So, if thou art a fan of sushi, do give this place
A try, and should thy schedule be quite tight,
'Twill serve thee well, a meal to eat at thy desk,
With nary a fuss, nor any great inconvenience."

"Hark, my dearest kin, how strange my plight doth seem,
For though they savor fish, my taste doth lean
Toward the land-bred beasts, and thus my meal
Didst lack the finny delights that they didst feel.

My spouse and child, in their enthusiasm bold,
Didst praise the fried catfish, deeming it a treat,
But I, with steak, didst find myself unsold,
For all the menu's offerings were fried, no doubt.

A veritable feast for hearts, 'twas not, alack,
For every dish, in its excess, didst attack
The health of those who partook with glee,
Leaving guilt to pang thy conscience, 'twill see."

Hark! What ho! I have not reviewed this place ere now,
And yet, a hundred times, I've graced its bow.
No serious, 'tis the best eatery in the east,
But friends at Corbin's could spice up the feast.
Their grub, though good, doth grow stale with time,
Oversauced pasta, buttered wings, a crime.
Pizzas, too, they make, and quite well, I say,
But why, oh why, doth the owner frown away?
He ne'er hath said a word, nor thanked me for my patronage,
A pox upon his house, for such discourtesy!
Yet still, betwixt five and eight, the crowd doth swarm,
For in the east, this place doth stand apart.
A fine selection of ale, they do possess,
But methinks, their hospitality doth need address.

"Verily, I must confess, the victuals were quite tasty. A barbacoa burrito was my choice, and the meat within was tender and sweet as honey. The beans and sauce they added made it hard to hold, and thus, a knife and fork were needed to devour it. Alas, the price was steep, and the questioning by the servers left much to be desired. They asked if I wished it enchilada-style, and when I replied nay, they still added it, charging me an extra nine and a half pence for the trouble. Methinks 'tis not worth the cost, for 'twas but sauce and cheese. A clever trick, indeed, yet not one I care to fall prey to. In conclusion, the grub may be good, but the prices are high, and the folk who serve it, tricky. Not a place for every day, unless thou hast the means to spare."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, my aunt and I didst dine at yonder eatery, whereupon she didst revel in the fried soft shell crab, a dish most delectable, I must confess. Yet, in sooth, I must demur, for though 'twas not unpalatable, I have had far better at other Japanese taverns of like quality. Verily, we didst order two great vessels, overflowing with sundry sushi rolls, of spicy tuna, California, eel, soft shell crab, and skewers of chicken teriyaki, besides sashimi. Alack, the victuals were naught but middling, and I wouldst not choose to partake of them again."

"Hark! If there were a button, that didst say, 'Not for vegetarians', I wouldst click it, by my troth! 

But, alack! My carnivorous friends do swear by the comfort food served here, and the bar staff doth pour drinks with haste and cheer, come happy hour. 

Aye, 'tis true! The lawyers, they doth flock here, in the afternoons and early eves, from the nearby buildings, they doth come, to quaff and confer."

"A treasure hidden'mongst the glitz and glam,
In Planet Hollywood, a secret gem,
Food priced fair, and served with haste,
Though timing matters, pace thine taste.

In midst of Strip's bustling throng,
This haven beckons, all day long,
Sandwiches, middling, naught to boast,
Yet serves its purpose, no need to roast.

And lo! 'Tis open round the clock,
For those who crave a midnight snack,
After a night of revelry and fun,
This refuge shall thy hunger shun."

"Thou hast three stars, good sir, for thy staff doth show great kindness indeed. And, verily, the chambers be of fair size. 

But, alas, thy experience doth falter, forsooth. For, lo, thy room didst not await thee until the appointed hour. Fie upon it! Thou hadst time to drop thy bags and venture forth. Aye, thou didst partake of dinner and merriment on the strip, and then, with haste, didst repair unto thy friend's suite. But, alack, thy chamber didst remain unavailable until the wee hours of morn, when, behold, thou didst find thy bedding foul and grimy. 

Yet, praise be to the staff, for they didst respond with haste and cheer, replacing all with fresh linens, pillows, and comforter, as if by magic. 

Now, prithee, good sir, ponder well this tale, and ask thyself, 'Shall I return anon?' Forsooth, only thou canst answer."

"Verily, the atmosphere doth please mine eyes,
With fun and hip decor that doth surprise.
A balcony seat, or step forth to the rail,
Doth grant a wondrous view of the pirate sail.

Alas, the prices doth climb to the sky,
And some dishes, verily, do make me sigh.
The shrimp with sambal sauce, too salty by far,
I sent it back, forsooth, with a heavy heart.

The kobe beef sliders, too, didst disappoint,
With saltiness that doth overpower the taste.
Yet, the onion rings, they doth make amends,
With their crispy exterior and flavorful paste.

Lychee beignets, a curious delight,
Filled with a substance that doth resemble batter in sight.
Sweetness doth abound, with sugar crystals galore,
But the lychee flavor, alack, doth fade once more.

Yellowtail sashimi, a tasty treat,
Thin slices, yet fresh, a pleasure to eat.
Edamame, warm and savory, a delight,
Sushi, a joy, my husband doth concur in sight.

Steak yakitori, in a sauce so fine,
Hubby doth enjoy, with relish and design.
Kudos to the chef, for a job well done,
A pleasant repast, our evening hath begun."

On the twenty-sixth of October, last year,
I didst visit this establishment for lunch, my dear.
The maiden working at the counter didst seem quite vexed,
That we didst come at an off-peak hour, I must confess.

I didst ask if they didst serve coffee, and she didst reply,
"Two coffee shops next door, good sir, doth lie."
A bit sarcastic, and not overly friendly, I must say,
Had I not paid, I wouldst have gone next door, straight away.

The bread for the caprese sandwich was quite good, I must admit,
Warm and slightly toasted, it didst taste a bit.
But caprese salad, served chilled, doth not agree with me,
On a sandwich, 'twas odd, warm and flaky, couldst not see.
Decent, but not enough to make me come again, I fear,
For friendlier service and better fare, I must hold dear.

"Methinks 'tis my second time to dine at this fair burger joint,
And by the stars, I must confess, 'tis a place most excellent!
Their burgers, oh so juicy and plump, do please mine taste,
And leave me full and merry, with naught but joy to waste.
They boast of burritos and bowls, but alas, I cannot stray
From their most wondrous burgers, for they be the best way.
Their premises be clean, their staff most kind and bright,
Mayhap they shall endure, and continue to delight."

"Methinks I didst oft order from yon place,
Their pizza, it didst please mine taste,
But alas! their ravioli, o'ercooked it was,
I do prefer it, Al dente, in truth.
Their lasagne, a mediocre dish, at best,
And oh! the bread knots, how they didst burn,
Despite my pleas, they didst arrive, alack,
In tardiness, thrice, their delivery didst lack.
This was not during peak hours, I do declare,
Alack! I fear, I shall not return there."

"Hark! What news is this? Mimi's, a place of renown,
Where cakes and scones, gluten-free, abound.
A fellow GF friend and I, didst make our way,
To The Shore, with hopes of a sweet, glorious day.

We had been told, that Mimi's, didst prepare,
Gluten-free treats, beyond compare.
But alas, our hopes were dashed,
For the cakes, were not worth the splash.

The scones, they crumbled, into tiny bits,
And we didst eat them, with jam and cream, in fits.
Our cupcake, a fairy cake, iced with care,
But naught compared to Cuckoo's, beyond compare.

Fellow Yelpers, speak highly of Mimi's,
But for us GF gals, 'twas a disappointment, grievous.
There are better cakes, in town, to be found,
Without the shlep, to The Shore, profound."

"In Arizona, where the sun doth shine bright,
There lies a place that doth serve a feast,
Of Ethiopian cuisine, full of delight,
Though not the most authentic, 'tis a treat.

Their sour injera, a spongy bread, doth please,
With alicha sega wat, a beef stew, if thou dost seize,
A taste so rich, it doth astound,
And in the combos, three stews are found.

A way to sample, and find thy desire,
And in this place, thy taste buds shall fire."

"Our server, a most excellent fellow, didst attend to our needs with great haste and diligence. Our glasses, never empty, didst remain full to the brim, and our orders, in a timely fashion, didst arrive. I, myself, didst partake in the chili cheese fries and twelve wings, honey BBQ style. Alas, the sauce, a tad too potent, didst overpower the taste, and the wings, they didst not remain warm for long, growing cold within five brief minutes. The fries, too, didst suffer the same fate. 

Now, being a man of experience, having once tended bar, I do confess, I am quite particular about the preparation of drinks. My Shirley Temple, alas, was made with the grenadine at the bottom, making it difficult to mix, and, mayhap, a bit too sweet. 

We sat without, in the open air, which was most pleasant, and the televisions, they were ideal for viewing the contest between Carolina and Duke. Methinks, the victual, mayhap, doth not hold the highest place in their regard, yet wouldst I return, anon, to partake in the sporting events."

"Alas, I didst wish to enjoy Tao, my first nightclub venture in fair Las Vegas. The ornamentation and motif didst please mine eyes, with Buddha's visage and maidens within bathtubs, and privies with doors that lock, making them opaque. Alas, the throng didst swell to such a degree that it didst become troublesome, and the assemblage of people was but mediocre. We shall not return, forsooth. Instead, we shall journey unto the clubs at Encore or the Wynn, where revelry doth reign supreme."

"Hark! In this place there be both good and bad, my friend.  

The happy hour, it doth please, with revelers gathered round.  Atmosphere, it doth rival the sun in splendor.  Staff, they doth attend with haste and cheer. 

But alas, the tables, they be packed tight, like a corset on a full-figured lass.  Parking, it doth leave much to be desired, thou must trek afar to find a space.  Fare, it doth pale in comparison to other establishments. 

Yet, if happy hour be thy quest, 'tis not so ill a choice.  But for a meal, seek elsewhere, lest thou be disappointed."

In fair Phoenix, where culture doth abound,
A humble pit stop, with treasures profound.
A gallery, with walls of brick and floor of stone,
Doth house a bookstore and bakery, all alone.
The art, though pricey, doth not disappoint,
A pleasant stop, for mind and taste, 'tis apt.

"Barbecue, a feast most wondrous and fair,
But not all barbecue doth please mine eyes,
For I, a native of Chicago, do swear,
That pork ribs and tips, they do arise,
From the south side, where sauce doth drown,
White bread and fries, in a savory crown,
And charred ribs, their scent doth fill the air,
A true delight, beyond compare.

But alas, my taste, doth not discriminate,
Against pulled pork, or beef, so great,
I do enjoy, a variety of fare,
And thus, my review, doth bear witness there,
Of ribs, that were, just okay, I say,
Yet still, the service, doth earn praise,
For hostess and waitress, both polite and fair,
Did make our visit, quite pleasant and rare."

"O, how I do adore Groupon, at times! Alas, this day, 'twas not their finest hour. The throngs of folk didst overwhelm them, and service didst slow to a crawl. Mistakes were made, and wrong dishes didst arrive, but our bellies didst yearn for sustenance, so we didst not mind. Our humble sushi place didst stumble beneath the weight, yet still, we shall return."

In sooth, upon an eve most fair,
With friends I didst venture to a tavern rare,
In Rutland, where prices be a bit steep,
Yet atmosphere and staff didst make us leap.

A classy place, indeed, with views most fine,
Of Princes Street, where folk do stroll and dine.
If thou dost seek a spot to chat and sip,
And bask in elegance, this tavern's a good tip.

"Hark, good sir or madam, seek thou Rudy's place,
Where BBQ sandwiches doth reign in grace.

Pros, there be many, as thus I tell,
Sauces abound, and each one doth excel.
Creamed corn, oh how it doth astound,
A culinary delight, beyond compare, 'tis found.

Space, there be plenty, and seats galore,
Location, convenient, near shops, and more.

Cons, alas, there be some, I fear,
Service, unprofessional, flirtatious, and queer.
Fries, alack, there be none, a sin,
No Cracker Barrel, General Store, doth pale within.

Yet still, my friend, give Rudy's a chance,
For creamed corn, so wondrous, doth entrance.
I speak the truth, though strange it may seem,
This dish, so humble, doth surpass thy wildest dream."

"Hark! A tale of dining at BW3,
A place of feasting, merriment, and glee.
The host and waitress, kind and fair,
Didst provide us with good service, beyond compare.

A Bleu & Black burger, oh so fine,
Didst satiate my hunger, and my heart didst shine.
Fries, a bit soggy, yet still quite tasty,
Didst complement the burger, in a most hasty.

Though not the best, nor the worst,
BW3 doth earn a rating of "just average", at best.
I shall not seek it out, with great intent,
But neither shall I shun it, with discontent."

"Verily, the victuals were of middling sort,  
Two stars, perchance, yet I do confer  
A third, for that they served us in our need,  
Late though it was, and hunger did impede.  
The fare was plain, a common quality,  
Breakfast and diner dishes, naught to excite,  
Yet filled our bellies, and so did suffice,  
Though not with gusto, nor great delight."

"A humble skillet, full of greens and scant of sausage, didst please mine eyes. A pancake, fluffy and light, didst delight mine taste. The victuals, decent and plain, didst fill mine belly. Verily, a meal most average, yet satisfying still."

"Methinks I've dined here fourfold, and by Jove, the victuals be divine! Of all the Italian fare I've sampled in this fair city, this kitchen doth reign supreme. Alack, the service, though, did leave somewhat to be desired. Pray, good sir, that thou mayst attend to thy patrons with greater frequency and a pleasant countenance, lest they depart in search of a merrier host."

"A fair tavern, fit for a pint ere a match,  
But beware, 'tis oft crowded, and space doth lack.  
No victuals served here, thou must seek sustenance  
In yonder hall, and bear it back with patience.  
The expansive courtyard, a wondrous sight,  
With ample room for revelry and delight."

"Hark! What do mine eyes perceive? A sight most fair and bright,
A sushi bar, with artistry in every detail, doth delight.
My purpose here, to rest and refresh, 'twixt duties great,
Fujo's hospitality, did timely and well-appointed greet.

In Carolina's clime, with fiery craving, I did choose,
The Cajun Roll, with crayfish, shrimp, and crab, in noble voice.
Though not a feast for gods, nor did it leave me cold,
Acceptance, I have learned, in sushi, doth my soul enfold.

But alas! The hot-and-sour soup, did not my taste buds cheer,
With ingredients, not fresh, and broth, but bordering on fear.
Yet still, this place doth hold a certain charm, and grace,
Though perhaps not Charlotte's finest, in culinary embrace."

"Fare at India's royal halls, I dare not boast,
For culinary wonders, seek elsewhere, my host.
A private fete did stir the youthful crowd,
With shrieks and rowdy play, they did astound.
The eatery, in wisdom, should have barred the door,
Or requested quiet, lest they trouble more.
Service, with grace, did make amends,
For victuals, middling, that did not transcend.
We came, for proximity, our hunger to assuage,
And found, alas, a scene most unbecoming and vague."

"Hark! To Fuel didst I repair,  
For lunch, with hunger's fiery glare.  
Two slices of Extreme Fuel Pizza, fair,  
Didst I devour, with savory delight.  
Pepperoni, Italian sausage, meatballs too,  
Ham and ground beef, for those who knew not what to do.  
Garlic knots, a tasty treat, didst I partake,  
And found them most delectable, forsooth.  
This place, a gem, shall stick around, I do perceive,  
Despite the many restaurants that didst once reside.  
The pizza, excellent, and service, swift and kind,  
A call ahead, doth recommend, for crowds doth gather fast, in mind.  
A step above, the corporate pizza, doth this place provide,  
So, enjoy, dear friends, and revel in its culinary might."

"Verily, the sign doth boast of wondrous fare,
But in truth, 'tis not as good as it declare.
An olden diner, with a feel of days past,
In Glendale, where time doth seem to last.
If thou hast leisure, give it a try,
For the price, 'tis not so bad, thou shalt see."

"Hark! What beer doth flow within these hallowed walls?
A church, yet now a tavern, doth enthrall.
The ale, it doth delight, with flavors so bright,
And yet, methinks 'tis strange to quaff here through the night.

Three or four brews we didst sample, all most fine,
One Belgian style, oh how it didst shine!
But alas, the service, it didst leave much to be sought,
For servers who doth pout, their tips are naught.

Church Brew Works, thy name doth say it all,
Yet, minus one star, for service doth fall.
Perhaps, we shouldst have sat at yonder bar,
To savor beer, in this most curious place, so rare."

"In days of yore, when dwelling near this place,  
'Twas oft our wont to seek its sheltered space,  
For afternoon respite, a merry chat,  
And drain a pint or two, to banish care and that.  
A humble tavern, naught of note within,  
Yet prices fair, a bargain, one might win.  
A glass of wine, a mere nine pence, 'twas said,  
But alas, those days, like youth, are now long dead.  
I, too, would partake of Kopperberg's fine brew,  
For three pounds, eighty-five, a price most true.  
Near Bus Station, it doth stand, a haven,  
For travelers, a pause, ere they take their leave again.  
So, if thou find thyself with time to kill,  
Step in, and let thy cares, in ale, be still'd."

"Last weekend, we chanced upon a novel sushi spot, near our abode, to dine and sample their wares. The rain did pour, and we did crave a feast most fine. Upon entering, we found the place to be quite snug, yet clean and well-appointed. We ordered four rolls of sushi, and Goyza and edamame to start, which did please our palates greatly. The diamondback roll, oh how grand, with its light and crispy tempura bits, a true delight! The fried cali roll, a close second, and the dragon roll, not bad at all. My dear wife, she did enjoy the spicy shrimp roll, but alas, 'twas not to mine own liking. \n\nIn sooth, we would return anon, during happy hour, to save a few coins, and in truth, the only drawbacks to the place, were the decor and space, a bit lacking, I do confess. But fear not, fair maiden or noble sir, for the sushi, verily, doth rock, and a quiet night for two, most pleasant and fine."

"Hark, 'tis true, good sir, 'tis cheaper far
To send thy packages via post, than those
Two other services, whose names I shall not speak.
And thus, this place doth do its job, methinks.

Ay, 'tis a spacious hall, with room to spare,
Where thou mayst wait in line, without dismay.
No cramped quarters here, as in some old dens,
Where thou dost feel like cattle, pent up tight.

Alas, a line there is, at any hour,
So give thyself some extra time, I pray thee, lest
Thou be caught in haste, and vexed thereby.
And note, they keep not all their windows open,
Which doth slow down the process, to mine eyes.

But lo, a self-service machine, for small
Packages, a boon indeed, for those who needs
No desk agent's aid. A quick escape doth lie
In this device, for those who dare to try.

And see, a vast parking lot, with spaces many,
A blessing, sure, for those who come with much
To mail. In contrast, near my mother's home,
A paltry fifteen spots, a sorry show.

In conclusion, fair, this place doth stand,
A decent site, despite some flaws, so grand."

In this humble inn, where fancy trappings be not found,  
I oft reside, and merriment doth abound.  
The Toby Keith bar, a place of mirth and glee,  
Doth bring me joy, with friends and drinks aplenty.  
A Chinese eatery, with flavors so fine,  
Doth satisfy my hunger, and doth combine  
With the casino's charm, a place of chance and skill,  
Where fortune smiles upon me, and my will doth fulfill.  
The staff, though average, doth their duty well,  
And ne'er have I encountered trouble or hell.  
The location, too, doth suit my needs,  
Convenient and central, as my heart doth plead.  
So join the club, and claim thy share of deals,  
For Harrah's doth provide, with generosity that doth reveal.

"Methinks my sister and I didst venture forth into Chinatown upon a Friday eve, with sushi being our heart's desire. Yet, with a wait of ninety minutes, I didst pose the query, hath thou, my dear sibling, partaken of Korean BBQ? She, with haste, didst reply, "Aye!" And thus, our destination was chosen.

Forsooth, I, a man of little faith in culinary novelties, didst seek guidance from my kin. Once gone, I didst embrace the experience, and, with zeal, didst introduce others to this wondrous feast.

Upon entry, we didst behold rows of cozy booths, each adorned with a round grill, central to the table. 'Twas BBQ-ing within walls, a veritable carnivore's haven! Beef of diverse sorts, fresh shrimp, and pork, in abundance, didst grace the menu.

Few vegetable options there were, in the form of a salad bar, accompanied by prepared Asian dishes, sweet and sour pork, sushi, tempura vegetables, and varied other salads, akin to macaroni, yet, Asian, their names, I knew not.

Our glasses, ever full, didst remain, and the grill, when messy, didst they diligently cleanse.

In sooth, a unique experience, and one worth attempting, methinks!"

"By chance, we found ourselves within these walls,
Where elders gather, Sun City's finest souls.
Their dinner bell doth ring at three o'clock,
And we, the youthful pair, do take our place,
At yonder bar, where libations flow and snacks abound.
Their mixers, skillfully crafted, bring us joy,
And tasty bites, a pleasure to employ.
The barkeepers, with cheer and grace, do serve,
And welcome us, the young, with open arms.
Though better seafood may be found,
In need, Red Lobster doth suffice, profound."

"Tis not my fondest haunt, forsooth,  
Where shabby chic and countrified newness doth abound.  
Antiques, a rarity, and prices do vary wildly,  
Leaving me to ponder, with a mind full of doubt.  
The staff, aloof they seem, or perchance I do sense  
A watchful eye upon mine own self and progeny.  
Yet, fortune may smile, and bargains may be found,  
For some new vendors have wrought a space profound.  
So, still I shall venture, with hope in my heart,  
To seek out treasures, and play my part."

"Hark! A feast most wondrous did we partake,  
My wife and I, at Papa Kelsey's fair.  
A pizza special, hot and freshly baked,  
Did I devour, with toppings of my choice.  
Whilst she, a calzone with extras did choose,  
Tomato, pepper, olive, and onion, a tasty mix.  
Two salads, Italian, with blue cheese and dressing,  
We ordered, and a root beer, oh so refreshing.  
The food, alright, our hunger did abate,  
But, alas! A booth seat, torn and worn,  
A sight most unseemly, a shame, a blight.  
Yet still, we must support local eats,  
For they do bring us joy, and fill our bellies with delight."

"Hark! If thou seeketh a stiff drink to flee the heat of this wretched strip,
Then hie thee hence to this establishment, where strong margaritas doth flow like a river.
We sampled them, both on the rocks and frozen, and found them to be quite divine.
I must confess, I was taken aback, for they do churn them out in vast quantities,
Like a never-ending stream of liquid gold, poured forth from the gods above.
The victuals, alas, were naught to write home about, but neither were they a disappointment.
For in this city of excess, 'tis the ambiance that doth command thy attention.
Aye, 'tis a trifle garish, but that's the charm of this place, and why we flock thither.
I would return, though not with bated breath, for there's naught truly remarkable to speak of."

"Methinks I didst visit the authentic site in DC Ranch,
With friends, for a late night repast and potions.
'Twas my first time, thus one of the lads didst order
A pair of Tootsie Rolls for the four of us (save one,
For my love doth not partake in sushi's delight).
And a Berry White martini, its hue a brilliant blue,
Didst taste most wondrous. Forgot the ingredients, alas,
In the Tootsie Roll, yet sushi doth please mine palate,
So I devour it swiftly. A chic and sleek ambiance
Doth grace this place, most fitting for a merry soiree."

"Methinks I do adore this place, with its pool tables grand and screens so vast, 
The tunes they play, the ambiance fine, the servers swift and kind at last. 
Their grilled cheese, oh how supreme! A dish most wondrous, doth make my friend beam, 
A vegetarian patty, alas! Not to my liking, yet still, I find this joint quite keen."

"This Target, like all others, doth seem,
A place most ordinary, with naught to gleam.
Yet, in their parking lot, a sight doth meet,
Hybrid car charging stations, a modern feat."

"Hark, what bustling scene doth meet mine eyes!
A place of commerce, full of people's cries.
A deal most fair, on Big Mac's had they,
For those who seek quick sustenance, 'twas nigh.
Their children, too, didst crave such fare,
And thus, with haste, their hunger didst bear."

"Methinks I've visited this place thrice, and each time, 'twas a pleasure indeed. For breakfast, I doth opt for their Acapulco express omelette, a feast fit for a king! Chorizo, avocado, green chilies, onions, melted cheese, sour cream, and their own fresh salsa, all combined in one delicious dish. Their French toast, made from scratch, doth please mine taste buds as well. In days past, 'twas known as Arizona French toast, with prickly pear butter that didst tantalize mine taste buds. Now, 'tis called Floridian French toast, adorned with luscious berries and kiwi, a treat for thine eyes and mouth. The service here doth excel, with attentive servers earning a 25% tip, their due reward. Fresh fruit doth accompany most meals, a pleasant surprise, not the usual bland offerings. And let us not forget their coffee, a fine brew indeed, left full for thine enjoyment upon departure. In conclusion, this place doth serve a hearty breakfast, worth thy visit, mark mine words!"

"O, how my heart did sink with woe and sorrow,
For this place, they did call it the best,
But alas, it did not meet my expectations,
The food, it was not up to my imaginations.

The layout, it was fair and beautiful to see,
And the people, they were kind and courteous,
But the food, it did not live up to the hype,
It left me feeling empty and quite vexed.

I would return, but not too soon,
For there are other places to try,
But if it were the only one open,
Then I would give it another chance, ere long.

I do not recall what dish I had,
That in itself, a bad sign it be,
But their bread, it was tasty and good,
A small consolation, but not enough for me."

"A jolly tavern, full of brew and cheer,
With victuals that did please mine eye and ear.
Our server, though a mite slow to begin,
Didst hasten forth with speedy grace therein.
I shall return, but mayhap not for meat,
For this place doth satisfy mine every need, save one,
That is, the craving for a frothy treat.
So here's to thee, good pub, may thy fame increase!"

"Twas not the finest spread, I do declare,
The shrimp, akin to rubber, did not please,
The Chinese dishes, o'er salted, did impart
A flavor most unpleasant to mine taste.
The sushi, devoid of zest, did fail to stir
My appetite, and left me in disgrace.
The crab legs, puny and small, did not compare
To those of king crab, as seen in pictures fair.
Yet, desserts, prime rib, and open bar did make
The price, a steep thirty dollars, worth the take."

"Fair enough, my dearest sag paneer,
With burnt garlic, thou dost lose thy sheen.
But naan, oh naan, thou art most fair,
A worthy mate to mango lassi, I do declare.

A sign upon the door, most curious,
Didst cause confusion, full of mystery.
No cocktails here, alas, my friend,
But bring thine own, and all shall end.

The decor, a sight to behold,
Most pleasant, fit for a king or bold."

In fair Las Vegas, we didst see four shows,
Mystere, Le Reve, O, and Criss Angel-Believe,
Their beauty was theatrical, with moments grand,
But alas, o'erhyped, they didst not stand.

Way too costly, for the price we didst pay,
Boredom didst creep in, and drove us away.
Mystere, the best, with laughter and delight,
Didst steal the show, and made our night.

"Hark, three weeks past, I chanced upon Shoku Ramn,
A place of sustenance, or so said the sign.
I ordered tonkotsu ramen, and potstickers beside,
The latter, crispy and burnt, just as I desired.
But alas, the ramen, oh how it did fail,
Oversalted broth, and noodles, overcooked and frail.
Mushy, they were, and lacking in taste,
Save for the salt, which did my senses assail.
I would not return, save for dire need,
Nor would I journey far, to dine at this steed."

"A pox upon this pharmacy of ill repute,
Whose service doth crawl at snail's pace, doth it not?
And lo, the checkers' queues, they doth stretch far and wide,
As if the patrons' time, it were of little worth.

In this, the city of excess, where doth shine
The glittering lights of vice and sin,
This pharmacy doth stand, a beacon of despair,
A place where patience doth go to die.

And yet, across the way, a Walgreens doth thrive,
A haven of efficiency, where doth time fly.
But nay, not here, where doth the staff, so slow,
Their ExtraCare discount card, didst none bestow."

"A bit dear, the prices be,
But portion sizes, small they be.
Food, good it doth taste, I do confess,
Decor, beautiful, a wondrous sight it doth possess.
Ahi tuna, my heart doth sing,
Alas, no cocktail, my lips did not kiss."

"A most delightful spa pedicure, verily,  
That doth make my day, nay, my week, so merry!  
Clean and friendly, they do be, in truth,  
But alack, their massage chairs, a sorry sight,  
Do crave renewal, else I fear, their plight.  
Yet will I return, again and again,  
For their gentle touch and skilled hands, anon."

"Methinks 'tis strange, the praise that ATS doth receive,
A niche vegan group, perchance, doth give it leave?
I find the place, in truth, to be but so-so,
Despite the name, best carne asada, given by the local press, doth flow.

The menu, limited, doth leave much to be desired,
The prices, high, doth make my purse to feel quite tired.
And though the food, in fairness, doth have its own style,
I find it, in the end, to be but mediocre, at best, awhile.

So when out-of-towners ask, where they might find
The best Mexican fare, I doth steer them away,
For other places, better, doth my mind incline."

"Hark! To meet a friend didst thou arrive,  
Early, to grab a drink and play,  
Draw Something on thy phone, didst thou decide,  
While waiting at a table by the bar, didst thou reside.  
Prompt service, thou art accustomed to,  
But waitedst long, for someone to say, 'Can I get thee?'  
Strange, it was, to wait so long, didst thou find,  
But after, service was good, didst thou bind.  
Happy hour wine, Cabernet, didst thou partake,  
And friend, blackened fish tacos, didst she make.  
Chicken and shrimp lettuce cups, didst thou consume,  
Greasy, they were, and caused lettuce to succumb.  
Food, thou dost enjoy, so not a big deal,  
Tasty, they were, but hard to eat, didst thou feel.  
Flat bread and sushi, thou wouldst order again,  
Aye, this place, thou wouldst visit once more, my friend."

"Fast food, perchance to dream of fries most wondrous,
And burgers, juicy, savory, a feast for the taste.
Five Guys, a place where hunger doth meet its match,
A veritable cornucopia of culinary delight.

The fries, they do overflow, a bounty most fair,
Greasy, mayhap, yet a delicacy beyond compare.
And burgers, a bargain, a meal most true,
Not gourmet, no, but a treat for the soul anew.

The pop machines, a marvel of modern device,
Dispensing drinks of choice, a wondrous surprise.
The staff, a merry band of friendly folk,
A smile and a welcome, a pleasure to behold.

So, to Five Guys, we shall return again,
For fast food, a kingdom, a treasure to gain."

"Noodles, thy victuals do delight,
In quantity, they do abound,
And choice, most wondrous fair, doth shine so bright.
But, alas, the service doth leave much to be sought,
For when I didst venture in, full well I found,
Three tables occupied, the rest, in disarray,
With dishes, food, and mess, didst lie about,
Awaiting clearance, ere we couldst sit,
And claim our rightful spot, with naught to show.
Perhaps, if busier, their plight were more just,
But empty, save one small table, didst they find,
And thus, my friends, doth this tale unfold,
Of Noodles, where the grub doth please,
But service, doth leave much to be desired,
And in its stead, doth chaos reign, uncontrolled."

Methinks 'twas round about the hour of eight,
On Monday eve, when first I did arrive,
And lo, there were three parties already there,
In this place of sushi, where I did partake.

I went to do my business, ere I sat,
And in the privy, a cockroach most vast,
Didst stare at me, and made mine eyes to start.
"Ew," quoth I, "what manner of beast art thou?"

My friend and I, we both did choose the feast,
For twenty-two and ninety-five, a fair price,
And with it came an appetizer, so named,
"THE SHIT!" but in truth, it was not worth the cost.
My friend didst enjoy it, but to me, 'twas naught,
But then, we had a deal, two pots of Sapporo,
A fine brew, and with it, our cups did overflow.

The sashimi salad, it was a wondrous sight,
With sashimi in abundance, a true delight,
For I do not enjoy a heap of rice,
At such places, where I do partake thrice.
I also ordered salmon, yellowtail, and albacore,
Fresh, but not the best, and cut in thin slices, no more.
The sashimi roll, it was a treat to behold,
With cucumber wrapped, and filled with fish of old.
My friend didst order more, a spicy crab roll,
Monster roll, baked lobster, and baked scallop, a feast to fulfill.

This place, it didst smell of Clorox, I do confess,
But not so strong, that it didst cause distress.

"Hark, what rating doth this place deserve? Three stars, I say, for food most fair. BB wings, spicy and savory, doth please mine taste. Flavored soju, a delight, in variety we did partake. Alas, the service, poor and rude, doth leave much to be desired. Karaoke, once enjoyed, now marred by owner's impudence. He, with group in tow, doth enter room, mid-song, and asks if tour be permissible. Discourtesy, most foul, doth prompt my nevermore return, alack!"

"Methinks I cannot grumble o'er much, good sir,
For this inn, 'twas given me, a Platinum Player, free of charge.
'Tis true, the building doth show its age,
And lacks that certain je ne sais quoi, that modern flair.
But for the brief time I did tarry,
I found it not so bad, save for the housekeeping, pray.

Alack! The chambermaid, she didst burst in upon us,
Without a knock, or any warning, whatsoever, alas!
I, in my hangover's throes, didst cry out, "Nay, good woman!
Leave us be!" And thus, she didst depart, with haste, anon.

And mark thee well, fair traveler, if thou dost choose
To lodge upon the strip, with a view, take heed,
For there doth play a wretched band, from morn till night,
Their melodies, most vexing, and quite without delight.
I swear, I didst near lose my temper, and my wits,
And hadst I eggs, a dozen, or two, at hand,
I hadst hurled them, straightaway, at yonder band,
In hopes they might desist, their caterwauling, prithee!

But, all in all, not such a dire experience,
Save for the chapel's hours, which didst prove most vexing,
For my comrade, in his cups, didst seek to wed
A stranger, and the chapel, alas! was closed, poor soul.
Yet still, enjoy thy stay, good sir, and may fortune smile."

"Aye, 'tis a curious conceit, this notion of swift succor,
In which one doth order food with minimal fuss or bother.
This establishment, it seemeth, hath the system down pat,
Wherein one merely chooseth a bag, selecteth toppings, and payeth.
'Tis done! They maketh thy sandwich, and thou art on thy way.

I chanced upon their turkey, with cole slaw and dressing,
And found it middling fair, though not without its flaws.
The bread, alack, didst lack freshness, being overly crusty,
And the turkey, verily, didst taste o'er-salted, I do declare.

Yet, were I invited thither by a friend, I might consent
To sample another of their offerings, with hopeful intent."

"O, fatty food most tasty! Wisheth me that salad hadst not such a large tortilla, that doth make it so filling. 

Alas, the drink station doth never seem well-stocked at noon. 

Verily, the staff doth do a good job in moving folk through line with haste, yet still I find myself in quite a plight, awaiting some twenty minutes ere I may order this delectable fare."

"Hark! What news is this? A new bakery doth rise,
In Mile End, where bread doth meet the skies.
Hof Kelsten, named, doth quickly gain renown,
As city-wide, its fame doth loudly crown.

The baker, Jeffrey, doth supply the best,
To Montreal's eateries, he doth pass the test.
With Central European flair, he doth imbue,
Rye, rugelach, babka, all doth prove true.

French loaves, too, doth Hof Kelsten make,
My favorite baguette, forsooth, doth take.
Meals, they serve, at lunch, at brunch,
But pastries, different, doth my heart bunch.

Yet, alack! Undercooked, some doth find,
So now, I stick to bread, in mind.
For Hof Kelsten, doth rise to fame,
A city-wide contender, in the game."

"Alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
This burger joint didst not impress.
The bacon, oh how sweet it was,
But alas, the rest, a letdown it was.

A Monday, it was, when first I tried,
But lo, they were closed, my heart did die.
I waited patiently, until the morrow,
To taste their wares, and see what they could borrow.

A regular burger, I didst order,
With bacon, eggs, and all the fixin's, in disorder.
The presentation, fair and bright,
But alas, the flavor, lacking in might.

The seating, comfortable, I must say,
The decor, quite pleasant, in a modern way.
The service, good, with nary a frown,
But alas, the food, a letdown, a disappointment profound.

I would return, for an out-of-towner's delight,
But for myself, I fear, not in sight.
The fries, two versions, we didst try,
Truffle, and cilantro, a sorry pie.

Creative, they didst strive, I must confess,
But for my taste, a failure, alas, a mess."

"For this fair price, thou dost receive thy due.
The hour of departure, eleven it was,
And I, with plea for lateness, didst call anon,
To beg a reprieve, until the sun didst pass.
Tired and weary, our bodies didst crave rest,
And thus, a small indulgence, I didst request.
But lo, the answer came, a stern refusal,
A denial of my humble supplication.
In Vegas, city of excess and delight,
Such petty service doth leave a sour taste.
The chamber, modern and well-appointed,
Yet, alack, the hospitality didst lack.
A pox upon their house, for this slight wrong,
I shall remember, and sing a sorrowful song."

In this humble tavern, plain and true,
Drinks flow, pool tables beckon, friends anew.
A place to gather, laugh, and merry make,
With naught but chicken wings and bull to take.

The music thumps, a lively club mix,
That draws a throng of diverse tricks.
Chubby gays, twinks, bears, old-timers too,
Fag hags, all welcome, as they do.

Inclusive, indeed, this watering hole,
Pre-club, a stop, or soul to console.
Specials daily, drinks that wet the whistle,
But smoke, oh smoke, that doth persist and clingle.

Vintage Vegas charm, some may perceive,
Yet options scarce, for gays to retrieve.
So, let us cherish, this modest dive,
Where all are welcome, no need to jive.

"Hark! A tale of Planet Hollywood, I shall recount,
Where meats and seafood, in abundance, they do mount.
A Groupon, it was, that did entice us to dine,
For $79, all-you-can-eat, a feast most divine.

Sirloin, lamb, and shrimp, oh my!
In a separate plate, the surf, did they bring nigh.
Mussels, salmon, and tilapia, a delicious sight,
But alas, some meats, were dry, not quite right.

The salad bar, a decent spread,
Vegetables, hot dishes, all well-prepared, 'twas said.
And drinks, they did include, in this deal,
A chinahuia, with pineapple, lime, and tequila, did steal.

The hunny, a rum runner, did pour,
Much heavier, than mine, it did devour.
Overall, an okay restaurant, I must confess,
But Texas de Brasil, better meat, does possess.

Marcile, our server, did run,
With a split section, his work, was done.
Bad reviews, I had seen, before this night,
But not as bad, as anticipated, the sight."

"Methinks each visit to this place, on weeknights doth bring
A pungent scent of vomit, left o'er from yestereven's revelry.
The hostess, underdressed, doth seat me with a wink,
And our waiter, in a bandana jean attire, doth take my order with a blink.

We started with the Gouda fondue, a gooey delight,
But over-salted, perchance. Then, my companion didst partake
In the salmon, which he found most delectable, I must confess.
Whilst I, a French Dip devotee, didst find disappointment in the mess.

A mayonnaise-based dressing, applied with liberal hand,
Didst give the roast beef a creamy, yet unpleasant, taste and feel.
The au jus, a strong French onion brew, didst not agree with the sandwich,
Leaving me to ponder if this place doth try too hard to be trendy and fashionable.

The food, a four, the ambiance, a two, I didst aver,
And thus, a three, the overall score, didst seem most fair and proper, good sir."

"Hark! A dilemma doth beset mine mind,
Whether to like this place, or leave it behind.
Their happy hour and brunch specials, oh so fine,
But the food, alas, doth puzzle me, in truth.

I've visited thrice, and tried their fare,
But cannot say, with certainty, if 'tis fair.
The initial bites, oh how they doth delight,
But soon, the flavors doth become too bright.

The service, too, doth leave much to be desired,
For though not woeful, 'twas not inspired.
A waiter, once, forgot my iced tea,
And left me parched, to pine for thee.

Yet, there was a time, when happy hour did grace,
Our presence, and a mistake did occur,
They charged my friend but three pence,
For two drinks, a veritable bonanza!

In conclusion, 'tis a place, just passable,
Not one I'd choose, but neither would I flee.
If thou wouldst go, I wouldst not object,
But for myself, I'd seek a different venue."

"Hark! What praise doth In-N-Out Burger receive?
From East Coasters, no less! We had to partake,
On our Vegas trip, to see what all the fuss did make.
And, verily, 'tis a good burger, I do confess.
The fries, as well, did please our tastebuds' delight.
But, lo! The crowd, they did go wild, as if possessed.
An average fast food chain, it seemed to us,
Quick, dirty, and with ketchup, quite a fuss.

A word to the wise, thou drive-thru window lad,
When one declines ketchup, do not gape, aghast.
For, in their stead, a simple 'no, thank thee' would suffice.
Lest thou be deemed a stranger, from a distant land, astray.

So, if thou hast not tried, do give it a whirl,
But, for a hamburger, dost not travel afar.
For, in truth, a burger is a burger, still."

"Upon mine eyes, a place most fair didst Yelp present,
Which I didst visit for my evening's repast.
Chow mein and Thai tea, my order didst comprise,
The latter, a brew most excellent, didst surprise.
Indeed, the best Thai tea that e'er I didst taste,
But, alas! the former dish, didst not so well find grace.
A variant of the noodles, thin and flat, it was,
Not like the full-bodied lo mein, that doth please.
The victuals, save the saltiness, didst delight,
And though the service was not poor, 'twas not quite right.
I shall return, to sample Pad Thai, anon,
And Thai tea, in quantity, shall be mine own."

"A fair establishment, indeed, for those who have ne'er savored Thai delights. Though, by my troth, 'tis hard to fathom how any soul couldst resist such culinary allurements! The staff doth seem to push their buffet with great fervor, as if their very existence did depend on it. And, verily, the bill did reflect such zeal, a whopping \u00a321 per head! The spread was satisfactory, but, by the stars, I didst not devour \u00a321 worth of victuals!"

"Mediocre fare, yet not so dire,
At standard rates, doth Egg Works aspire.
The taste, not wondrous, nor so vile,
Yet suits my needs, with eggs awhile.

I shall return, for health's design,
Doth prompt me, from sloth's sweet shrine.
Though three stars, Yelp! doth confer,
'A-OK', a label, I do aver."

Dearest Breadfruit, thou art a place most fair and bright,
With dishes that doth please mine eyes and taste most wondrous.
But alas, thy prices do exceed the means of mortal men,
And thus, I must confess, thy worth doth lie in other things.

A slice of sweet potato pie, oh how it doth delight,
And coffee, if thou insisteth, shall be mine only drink.
For though thy cost doth mount, thy charm doth never fade,
And thus, my heart doth sing with joy, and mine affections stay'd.

Farewell, dear Breadfruit, may our love forever last,
And may thy culinary delights forever be mine own vast.

Yours truly,
Rachel

"Tis neither best nor worst, fair maiden. They do not boast of deals, yet still they please. Prime rib once ruled supreme, a dish most divine. Alas, 'twas taken from us, and now I dine elsewhere. Price, a fair concern, didst not match flavor's worth. Verily, 'tis parallel to Denny's, a humble tavern."

"A feast most fair, yet middling in its fare,
Didst grace the table at the noontide hour.
A varied choice, with dishes manifold,
Yet somewhat lacking in its savour, I did find.

The spread didst boast of meats and sweets,
And soups and salads, all in neat arrays.
But when I didst partake of the repast,
I found the flavours somewhat wanting, alas!

The sauces lacked a certain zest,
The meats were cooked, but not to perfection's crest.
The sides, though plentiful, didst lack a certain flair,
Leaving me to pine for more, and wish for less despair.

Yet still, the spread didst have its charm,
With offerings that didst please, though not disarm.
For those who sought a simple, hearty meal,
This buffet may have been their ideal.

But for mine own self, I didst expect
A greater feast, with finer, richer effect.
Alas, 'twas not to be, this day and age,
Yet still, I shall not judge, nor utterly disparage."

In sooth, I do declare, 'tis passing strange
This place hath not been reviewed, nor its fame
Spread far and wide. A humble cafe, 'tis true,
Yet with a charm all its own, and service too.

The servers, though at times a mite eccentric,
Do strive to please, with zeal most fervent.
And though the fare be standard breakfast dishes,
'Tis cooked with care, and served with cheerful wishes.

The interior, oh! 'Tis a sight to see,
A blend of old west, John Wayne, and Gene Autry.
A kitschy, fun place, that doth bring a smile,
To all who enter, and doth linger awhile.

"Methinks 'tis fair to note, ere I begin,
That this review doth stem from but a single dish.
Our server, kind and courteous, did attend
To our needs with grace, and thus I shall commend.

Now, to the chicken Madeira, my heart's desire,
Which, alas, did fail to stir my soul's fire.
The build-up, great, with atmosphere quite dark,
And modern, too, the restaurant's noble mark.

Yet, when served, my disappointment grew,
For sauce, so bland, and lacking seasoning, too.
No flavors danced upon my palate's delight,
Nay, not even a hint of sweetness took flight.

The chicken pieces, three in total, small,
Did cause me near to laugh, yet kept my mirth within.
French fries, homemade, the only saving grace,
For which, alas, I cannot claim a special place.

In conclusion, dear reader, heed my words,
Avoid this dish, for seventeen dollars, unheard!
For though the atmosphere did please mine eyes,
This dish, alone, doth not justify the prize."

Thus, late at night, I did arrive at Wynn,
Tired and hungry, seeking sustenance to fill.
The Cafe, a place of wonder, did present itself,
With sandwiches, salads, and sweets, a feast to behold.

A Chicken Portabella sandwich, I did ordain,
But lo, it was not fresh, but refrigerated and reheated.
For eleven dollars, a bit steep, I did declare,
Yet, with garlic aioli, it was quite delicious, I dare say.

A bottle of Coke, four dollars, a price to pay,
Yet, with my meal, I did feel satisfied, come what may.
The Cafe, in mornings, doth get busy, I do say,
So, rise early, and to Starbucks, take thy way.

"Methinks I first didst hear tell of Krispy Kreme's fame
In Canada, where their doughnuts didst reign supreme.
Their guarantees of love didst strike me as quite odd,
And put me off, in truth, with their presumptuous tone.

But then, a colleague most generous didst arrive
With doughnuts galore, a gift most fair and bright.
The team didst revel in their sweet, greasy delight,
And thus, the Krispy Kreme craze didst take flight.

Yet, I must confess, I do not understand
The need for such excessive sugar and grease.
It seems a curious thing, this fetish for fried dough,
A culinary quirk, most strange, indeed, methinks.

And so, three stars I give, for taste most fine,
But naught else, for their extravagance, I do decline."

"Hark, good sirs, what ill fate did befall us on this eve?
The server, overwhelmed, didst not attend to our needs with haste.
The viands, alas, didst lack moisture, and thus didst fail
To satiate our hunger. The steak, Gorgonzola named,
Was parched and dry, as if 'twere cooked by fiery flames.
The pasta, Pappardelle Pescatore, didst not resemble
The image promised, and its scent didst strongly suggest
A fishy nature. The Northern Tour of Italy,
A dish of salad, didst lack the dressing, oh so sad.
The calamari, too, didst taste of naught but air,
And when we asked for lemon, none didst appear.
The wings, in Italian style, didst lack their due,
For they were dry and flavorless, a great disappointment, I do declare.
Yet still, we give this place a score of three,
For we are loyal patrons, and normally, you see,
We dine here oft, and always have a grand time,
But on this day, alas, it seemed the kitchen had lost its rhyme."

"A humble abode, where hunger doth meet its fate,
With victuals plentiful, and ale to slake thy thirst.
For gamers, early risers, doth the host provide,
Sweet donuts, freshly brewed, and coffee, rich and bold.

This ancient inn, with creaky floor and worn,
Doth boast a charm, that doth the heart enfold.
So, take a chance, and enter in,
For fortune favors thee, who doth dare to win."

"Fair victuals, but slow as the night's darkest hour!
Our reservation, twenty minutes didst pass,
And in the waiting area, we didst find no space,
But stood in pathways, where folk didst come and go.

Our waitress, friendly, and with menu didst explain,
But she, the hostess too, didst bear the weight,
Of duties many, and with slowness didst detain,
Our meal, two hours didst consume, alack!

Mussels, we didst order, first, small and sweet,
In white wine sauce, they didst our taste greet.
Bread, we didst request, but fries didst come instead,
Soggy, they were, our server's words didst belie.

Bouillabaisse, my entrée, hot and steaming,
With seafood plentiful, and saffron sauce gleaming.
A feast, it was, and worth the wait, methought,
But oh, how slow, the service, to behold!

My spouse, his chicken, brie-stuffed didst taste,
And found it fair, but not worth the cost, he didst say.

The food, impressive, but the delay, a bane,
If back I come, 'twill be on a weekday, and alone.
More staff, they need, to speed the meal,
For delicate fare, doth merit greater zeal."

"Methinks I've only e'er had wonton soup at this place,
And, by my troth, 'tis some of the best I've tasted,
Without noodles, I do order it, and find
The broth to be sweet and aromatic, and the dumplings, well-made.

Other fare, they say, is but so-so,
Yet, I, a repeat customer, do not know,
For wonton soup, my heart doth sing,
And thus, I do return, again and again, to savor its delight.

Upstairs, at Crown Bakery, do thou find
A feast for thine eyes, and, mayhap, a treat for thy taste,
So, do not tarry, and hasten thee well,
To partake of their baked goods, and enjoy them with glee."
"A wondrous feast we did partake, yet fare itself was naught but middling. Oh, how grand the drinks did flow, from three to six of clock! Alas, we should have come ere sundown."

"A first-time visitor, I, to this place of revelry,
Sat in the bar, where happy hour did cease to be.
Complimentary hors d'oeuvres, they did proffer,
But I, a humble guest, didst decline the offer.

Cocktails we did imbibe, and ordered fish,
Salmon and yellowtail, fresh and deftly fixed.
The salmon, verily, didst impress my taste,
But yellowtail, alas, was cut too waste.

A gripe, I must confess, didst trouble me,
A scent, most foul and strong, didst assail mine ears.
Disinfectant and cologne, a pungent blend,
Didst make my stomach churn, and near to offend."

"Hark! Golden Phoenix, a humble abode,
Where one may find a meal, both decent and cheap.
The staff, though sparse, doth watch thee eat,
As thou dost savor each bite with glee.

The victuals, plain they may be, yet flavorful,
And spicy, too, in a manner most gentle.
A steal, indeed, for sixteen coins or less,
Including drinks, a price most reasonable.

So, near my workplace, this eatery doth lie,
And thus, I shall return, again and again,
For value, proximity, and cheer,
Golden Phoenix, a gem, in truth, doth win."

"Methinks I've paid a visit twice or thrice,
In years gone by, when I didst not reside
In Champaign, where this bakery doth lie.
'Tis situated on a busy street, nigh
Unto the campus, where young scholars roam.
Their donuts, verily, are quite divine,
Freshly baked, and served with hasty speed.
But, alas! Not all their treats are always in store,
For on my latest visit, I didst not espy
The glazed yeast donuts, those delectable sweets,
But only cake and mini glazed, which didst vex me.
Yet still, I do confess, 'tis pleasant to have
A place to purchase pastries, ere the sun doth rise,
When Black Friday shoppers doth throng the streets."

"Hark, my friends! I tell thee of a place most wondrous,
Where wings of chicken doth reign supreme, in truth.
The service there, it doth leave much to be desired,
But catfish, alas! It doth not compare, in sooth.

I didst partake of their ATL seasoned wings,
And found them quite tasty, with a bit of zing.
But, lo! The cashier, her demeanor cold,
Didst make me feel most unwelcome, I do declare.

Yet still, I would return, for wings and fries,
For they didst please my palate, with nary a lie."

"If thou seekest a taste of the south, amidst the sinful city's gleam,
Come hither, to this venue, a Treasure Island gem.
Late at night, it opens wide, when other doors are shut tight,
A haven for revelers, who still burn with delight.

Country tunes fill the air, and two-step dances abound,
A mechanical bull, for the brave, doth astound.
But beware, fair maiden, of the golden-haired cowgirl's might,
She doth ride the beast with grace, and leaves all else in flight.

The dance floor's ample space, and the hall's kept clean and bright,
Bartenders, merry and kind, serve drinks with hasty might.
Alas, I did not partake of their culinary fare,
For by the time I arrived, the kitchen's bounty did declare.

An elder crowd, they gathered, in their thirties and forties prime,
Yet, our youthful band, of country fans, did find joy in rhyme.
So, if thou art in search of a western oasis, in this town,
Come to Treasure Island, and let its spirit astound."

"Methinks my friends do hold this place in high esteem,
And thus, I come to partake in their delight.
The victuals, though not cheap, do please my taste,
Save for the pies, which are a worthy prize.
The ale, too, doth quench my thirst, and at a fair price,
But wines and other potions, alas, do burn a hole in my purse.
I must confess, their brew doth not agree with me,
For 'tis too heavy and sweet, and doth not suit my fancy.
Yet, if thou seek'st a place to gather and make merry,
This tavern, clean and well-appointed, shall not disappoint thee."

"Hark! A meal most wondrous didst I find,
At this, my latest dining place.
'Twas tasty, and a good value, I didst find,
For seven silver coins, a fair price.

I chose a sandwich of albacore,
A dish of tuna, rich and fine.
And with it, a salad of pecan,
With chicken, veg, and dressing divine.

But lo! My friend, she didst choose,
An omelet of egg whites, pure and true.
And with it, a meal most fitting,
Didst make, to suit her diet, strict and new."

"With my young brood in tow, I sought a sweet treat,
A place untried, their eager minds to greet.
Their laughter echoed loud, as we did enter,
The lasses there, with beaus, did converse at leisure.
Their mirth did grate, but frozen yogurt sweet,
Did please my children, and myself, did meet.
We shall return, this place of icy delight,
Despite the rudeness of the maidens bright."

"Methinks 'twas not the best of Mexican feasts,
But neither was it the worst, by my troth.
The service, attentive though somewhat astray,
Did bring us water, albeit in disarray.
Three times I asked, and three times they brought,
One glass of water, which we didst share, no doubt.
Their promptness with chips and salsa did make up,
And frequent checks upon us did they keep.
The victuals, decent, yet a mite too hot,
For my taste buds, which do prefer a milder plot.
Yet others seemed not to mind the fiery bite,
So take my words with a pinch of salt, good sir.
The margaritas, strong and potent, did flow,
A pitcher sufficed for four, as you do know."

"Fast Asian fare, a cleanly scene,
Friendly faces, what more could be seen?
'Tis good enough, no need to gripe,
A fair price, convenience doth ripe.
In truth, 'tis not so bad, I swear,
For quick bites, this place doth appear."

"Hark! No need for tools or special skill,
Our meal came together without a hitch.
But alas, the value we did not find,
At this fancy cafe, so high and fine.

'Tis not the food stand down below,
But upstairs, where the selection doth grow.
Wraps, salads, soups, and hot trays galore,
Sweetish classics, and more, they do store.

My wife, a veggie wrap did choose,
But found it lacking, in taste and pose.
$4, a fair price, but not divine,
A mediocre meal, at best, we did find.

The smoked fish plate, a better fate,
Creamy horseradish sauce, a delightful treat.
Mixed greens and beans, a pleasant surprise,
Well smoked fish, a feast for our eyes.

But lo, the vegan sweet potato soup,
A kind gesture, for those who dooup.
Flash your IKEA family card, and claim,
A free meal, in this self-service game.

$14, a fair price, for two, we did pay,
In this kid-friendly place, where we did play.
So if thou seek'st mild food, and a view,
Of furniture, then this may be thy cue."

"This place, save for the missing apostrophe, doth please mine eyes. Service was good, though the notion of food didst seem to slip away, like sand between fingers, when tea didst take its sweet time to arrive. Decor, comfortable chairs, and large windows, maketh a pleasant sight. Food and drink, naught but the usual fare, yet done well, no need to despair. Toilets, unseen by mine own eyes, leave me to hedge at three stars, yet, on present showing, four stars doth seem nigh, come next visit."

"Hark! Today, I ventured forth to this place,
With clients in tow, and their choice it was.
I pondered other venues, more grand,
But alas, 'twas not to be, for they had planned.

Cafe Grande, a bit old-fashioned, true,
Their menu, burgers, paninis, anew.
But lo! My lunch, a fishcake, small yet tasty,
With chips and salad, a pleasant surprise, quite hasty.

The cheese plate, a delight, Scottish cheeses galore,
A banoffee pie, rave reviews, forevermore.
Other dishes, not so grand, a bit dull,
Soup, sandwich, home-cooked, a bit uncouth, pull.

Bean burger, lonely, on a plain bun,
Arrived, forlorn, without any fun.
So, a passable meal, if near,
But not worth seeking, fear not, dear."

In my pursuit of gluten-free fare, I chanced upon Nello's abode,
Wherein I savored a pizza of ham and pineapple, a treat for my taste buds,
The crust, devoid of gluten, was quite satisfactory, I must confess,
A rarity, indeed, in this realm of culinary excess.

Their menu, a list of ingredients and toppings, didst reveal,
A limitation of options, a challenge to conceal,
Yet, the service, friendly and prompt, didst make up for the lack,
And left me content, with naught to attack.

So, if thou seekest a gluten-free meal, without much fuss or fanfare,
Nello's shall serve thee well, beyond compare,
For though it may not be the best, 'tis a suitable choice,
To satiate thy hunger, with a cheerful voice.

"By Jove, fair maiden, hear my plea,
For threading of eyebrows, a service most fine,
Once priced at eight dollars, now ten, alack,
A sum most steep, yet worth every penny, I reckon.

For she who doth the threading, doth take care,
To leave thy brows in their natural state,
And doth not take too much, nor doth she spare,
But shapes them well, to please thee, beyond debate.

But, alas, their facials, though good, I fear,
Do not stay true to their coupons, I do declare,
For my own mother, with coupon in hand,
Didst receive but half the time, at half the cost, oh so grand.

So, gentle maiden, heed my words of wisdom,
And beware of facials, lest thou be in a pickle,
For though they may seem a bargain, at first blush,
In truth, they may prove a disappointment, and such."

"Methinks 'tis fortunate that I do gaze,
To the right, where'er my vision doth stray,
Upon a sign that doth proclaim, "Better than Roscoes,"
But alas, howe'er bold the claim may be,
'Tis naught but empty words, forsooth,
For none can match the chicken of Roscoes,
That delectable delight, so crispy and sweet,
That doth ensnare the taste buds, and doth not release.

And thus, my thoughts doth turn to Lolo's,
A place of merriment, with colors bright,
And jars of Kool-Aid, that doth delight,
But, alas, the chicken, it doth lack,
The flavor and the texture, both doth lack,
The breading, dry and different, doth not please,
But still, the waffles and the syrup, they doth tease.

So, though 'tis true, Lolo's doth have its charm,
It cannot compare to Roscoes' chicken, no alarm,
For those who crave the best, must seek out Roscoes,
For there, the chicken, it doth truly doth expose.

And thus, my friends, I doth advise thee,
Seek out Roscoes, and taste their chicken, 'twill set thee free."

"Hark, fair sir! My visit to this establishment was but a middling affair. The service, indeed, was quite good, and the beer, a frosty delight. But alas, my taste doth runneth towards a hearty IPA, which they didst not possess. 

The victuals, too, were naught but mediocre. Wings of chicken, standard fare, and a sandwich with bread a tad stale, fries lacking crunch. Alack! 

Yet, within, the decor was pleasant, and many a television doth grace the walls, making it a fine spot for a pint and a game. The scent of wood smoke, wafting from the pizza oven, doth stir mine appetite, and thus, a pizza shall be mine choice, come next I dine."

Alas, my dear friend, I didst fall prey  
To the snare of chips and salsa's allure,  
A plight most vexing, I must confess,  
For my belly, now full, doth protest.  
But, save this mishap, the fare was fair,  
As one would expect from a Mexican lair,  
With portions grand and ingredients fresh,  
Though naught extraordinary, the price was neat.  
And so, anon, I shall return, God willing,  
When hunger pangs for Mexican dishes still.

"My mother and I didst venture forth to this establishment, forsooth, upon her sweet tooth's insatiable craving. She didst inquire of the maiden behind the counter, if the coffee-flavored gelato didst contain caffeine. The maiden, with a shrug, didst reply, 'I know not, for I do not make it.'

And thus, we didst laugh at the absurdity of it all, yet, my mother, still curious, didst ask the maiden if there were any dairy-free options available. The maiden, once again, didst reply, 'I know not, for I do not make it.'

In utter disbelief, we didst proceed to order our gelato, and my mother, determined to extract some semblance of usefulness from the girl, didst ask her to recommend a flavor to accompany chocolate. The maiden, with a sheepish grin, didst respond, 'I know not, for I do not eat it.'

Verily, I couldst scarce believe mine ears! Forsooth, the girl mayhap was in high school, and 'twas true, she didst not make nor eat the gelato, but, by the stars, customer service, thou art a dying breed! 

But, lo and behold, the gelato, it didst taste wondrous, and the prices, quite reasonable. Banana Yum, indeed!"

"Fare thee well, my dearest friend, for we have found a place most vexing. The victuals, they were but average, and all too dear in price. Whilst we didst play at video poker, our cups, they didst remain unfilled. Alack, my hopes were high for a humble tavern, hidden from view, where we might find some sport and cheer. Alas, 'twas not to be, for naught but disappointment didst we find."

"Hark, what praise doth fill the air?
A buffet, they say, beyond compare!
But lo, my friends, let us not be fooled,
For here, the truth, I shall unfold.

A fourth of all they offer, bread,
A waste, a folly, a misdeed!
And for this, they demand a fee,
Forty dollars, a price too steep!

The California roll, a gem, I confess,
With real crab meat, a rarity, no less.
But all else, a disappointment, a shame,
No special treats, no unique name.

Prime rib, cold shrimp, and crab, they say,
Are reasons why this buffet's the way.
But nay, my friends, those items find,
At every buffet, of a lower kind.

So heed my words, and do not pay,
The price they ask, for it's not worth the fray.
Rio Carnival, Rio Seafood, Wynn,
Buffets superior, for less you'll win."

"By the holy spirits, do people dine here?  Verily, I have visited this establishment on multiple occasions, and each time, my level of inebriation hath ranged from a gentle buzz to a full-fledged blackout.  'Tis true, neither I nor my comrades have made it a habit to partake in the culinary delights offered here, for our primary focus hath been on quaffing ale and enjoying the merriment of the evening.  But, alas, the happy hour menu doth boast an impressive array of appetizers, including the common california roll, gyoza, seafood dynamite, and coconut shrimp skewers.  Yet, 'tis the specialty drinks that truly maketh RA shine.  When hunger doth strike, concurrent with inebriation, the quality of the victuals doth not matter overmuch, for 'tis like beholding a maiden fair through the haze of ale-tinted spectacles.  I cannot, in good conscience, bestow upon this place a rating of utter rubbish, for the fond memories of yore, though hazy and fragmented, do still linger in my mind."

"Hark! My dearest spouse and I didst venture hither with friends, our bellies growling with hunger. And lo! The menu didst boast a bounty of delectable dishes, making 'twain difficult to choose betwixt them. Fear not, fair reader, for all didst prove most satisfying, a veritable feast for the taste buds, worth five stars, by my troth! \n\nBut alas! The service, a pox upon 't, didst leave much to be desired. A surly waiter, with scant courtesy, didst respond to mine inquiry regarding virgin margaritas with a snappish tone, as if he hadst already uttered the list to another at the table. Pray, good sir, had I but known, I wouldst not have troubled thee. Hubby and I, alone, might have sought sustenance elsewhere, such was the poor quality of service. Alack! A shame indeed for this establishment, methinks."

"A fair buffet, not great, yet still quite good,
With shrimp and sweets that pleased my mood.
Prime rib, alas, did not impress,
But watermelon, infused with tequila's spell,
Did make me merry, I must confess.
Rice Krispy treats and candy apples too,
Were there, and breakfast options, plenty to do.
Though Aria and Paris boast better spreads,
I might return, for Wynn's choice is not so bad."

"Hark! Excalibur, a hotel most fair,
