In location, prime, and rooms, so rare.
We checked in on a Saturday, with haste,
And found our chamber, freshly renovated, in taste.
The door, alas, would not shut tight,
A curious thing, and quite a sight.
We called, and they did come with speed,
To move us next door, with little need.
The new room, nice, with flat screen, so bright,
And beds, so comfy, a wondrous sight.
But lo! The next day, the door, again,
Would not shut close, and caused much pain.
We called, and they did fix, with grace,
And extended checkout, a gentle embrace.
So stay, dear traveler, at Excalibur,
If budget-friendly, and central, be thy cure."

"A feast fit for a king, this spread doth lay,
With all the fixings of a humble day.
The salad bar, a garden fresh and fair,
Doth tempt the taste, with crunchy greens to share.

The carving station, a sight to behold,
Doth offer meats, both roasted and cold.
Pizza, pasta, corn, and mashed potatoes too,
Doth round out the menu, with naught to do.

Green beans, fish dishes, sushi, and bread,
Doth complete the feast, that doth feed
The belly and the soul, with naught to dread.
Though not the fanciest, 'tis a meal well-spread.

The price, not cheap, yet still a bargain true,
Doth make it worth, the trip anew.
So if thou art hungry, and in search of fare,
That doth fill thy belly, without breaking the air,
Come, join the crowd, and partake in this feast,
For a meal most satisfying, and truly a treat."

"Fare was passable, naught that did astound. Rice, a soggy mess, upon the sushi found. Service, middling, withal. We felt pressed, ill-timed the victuals came, and staff, in knowledge of the menu, lacking, alack."

"A hearty steak boxty didst please mine eyes,  And in my belly, didst it satisfy.  With ale, a Harp, didst quench my thirst,  And to the waitress, my thanks I didst proffer, for her kindness and her skill."

"Abuelos, a chain of Mexican eateries, doth please my taste buds well. Their service, too, is friendly and their fare, passable. In days of yore, a lengthy queue did form outside, a wait of an hour, perchance, did ensue. Yet, on my most recent visit, entry was swift, our party of six, straightway admitted. For guests from afar, I shall return, but, whenever possible, local haunts, I do prefer."

Hark! I have not partaken of their victuals yet,
But on a night of revelry, I did step within their gates.
A fraternity so wild, they let young lads and lasses in,
And those of age, with wristbands, did their mirth begin.
But lo! The youth did drink, despite the wristbands' might,
Yet still, the atmosphere was merry and bright.
They have a game of beer pong, and potions fine,
My spouse and I, we danced and laughed, and drank with glee divine.

"Hark! Good for a hangover, they say,  
This place doth cure the night's excess,  
But loud it be, in truth, I pray,  
That thou mayst find some peace, and rest.  

The fries, alas, are thin and weak,  
A disappointment, I do confess,  
Yet still, the food doth please, meek,  
In its simplicity, 'tis blessed.  

The drinks, they be strong and bold,  
A plus, indeed, for those who crave,  
A respite from the night's cold,  
And a cure for the morning's wave."

"Hark! I sought a trim, nigh to this place,
For convenience' sake, and time did save.
A standard cut, no frills nor fuss,
Most barbershops, the same, I must confess.

I strode within, no waiting, straight,
A stylist ready, swift, and great.
She worked with care, each snip precise,
A better cut, my locks now quite nice.

Yet, pricier 'twas, by twenty-five,
Than other shops, the same, I do perceive.
No rinse, nor product, merely a trim,
Still, not a bad deal, for a decent whim."

"Methinks 'tis meet to start with praise, forsooth,
The victuals here, they please my taste, in truth.
Bruschetta, oh! how divine, doth rival the sun,
In excellence, 'tis peerless, save none.

Alas! the service, woe betide, doth falter,
Alack! the attendants, lost in chatter,
Heedless of guests, their needs, they do neglect,
And leave them wanting, with naught but regret.

Tankards, they snatch away, ere we could say,
"Refill, good sir!" Nay, they pay no mind,
Plates, too, they bring not, nor e'er didst proffer,
Leaving us to fetch them, in disarray.

Food, the draw, doth keep us coming, 'tis true,
Happy hour, with wine, at five, doth woo.
Another branch, we shall essay, to find,
If service there, doth differ, in kind."

"Hark, my thoughts on this establishment align with the masses. Good tidings, there be:

Food, when it doth arrive, doth please the palate. Lobster and corn, oh how grand! A gin drink, fit for royalty, doth impress. The menu, diverse and full of wondrous choices, doth entice. Drinks, aplenty and creative, doth delight. Weekly specials, a treasure trove of savings, doth abound.

Alas, poor service doth mar the experience. Many a black-shirted server doth stand idly by, while two hostesses doth attend to their duties. A bartender, hardworking and diligent, doth pour forth libations with haste. Alack, management doth need to address this disparity, lest it doth become a grievance most foul.

In conclusion, tasty victuals, potent potables, and questionable service doth sum up this place. Mayhap, a visit shall reveal the truth of these words."

Daily drink specials:

Margarita Monday: $3 off specialty margaritas from 7pm-close.
Guys Night Out Tuesday: 1/2 off whiskey, bourbon, and scotch from 7pm-close.
Paper Bag Beer Special Wednesday: random beer in a bag for $1 from 7pm-close.
Ladies Night Thursday: $3 off glasses of wine and $3 360 vodka drinks from 7pm-close.
Fireball Friday: $2 shots of Fireball from 7pm-close.
$10 Mimosa Carafes Saturday: Get a mimosa carafe for $10 from 11am-3pm.
$10 Bloody Mary Carafes Sunday: Get a bloody mary carafe for $10 from 11am-3pm.

"A haven of delight, this eatery doth serve  
The finest of Italy's culinary fare.  
Its ambiance, warm and inviting, doth imbue  
A sense of comfort, fitting for a king.  
The portions, generous and bountiful, doth fill  
The belly with joy, and prices, fair and square,  
Doth make it a steal, a true rarity.  
In this place, thou shalt find solace and cheer,  
A haven of delight, indeed, my dear."

"Hark! A stay most pleasant and affordable too,
With rooms that beckon warmth and welcome anew.
Though dated, they provide a comfortable abode,
And for the price, a veritable haven to reside.
The adjacent chambers, a boon for families blessed,
When traveling with young ones, a true godsend, no less."

"A burger, not of highest quality, I fear,
Passable, mayhap, yet the setting doth leave much to desire.
By th' drinking machine, a woeful sight doth lie,
A space so cramped, nigh impossible to navigate by.
Throngs of people, swarming like bees in springtime bloom,
Do make it hard to pass, with naught but grief to assume."

"A friendly staff doth serve this place,
Where young folk gather, full of grace.
All seem to seek love's sweet embrace,
But alas, the underground space doth lack,
In ambiance, it doth not abound,
No dance floor there, nor lights around.
No mirror ball, no laser beams,
To stir the soul and lift the dreams.
If thou wouldst have folks dance and play,
Spend a few coins and make the day.
Create some ambiance, that doth please,
And all shall revel in joy and ease."

"Hark! Champaign, a city of gastronomic delight, yet lacking in fare from the East, wherefore I do praise Holy Land Grill for its presence. 'Tis not the most exquisite of Middle Eastern cuisine I've had the pleasure to taste, but 'twill suffice. Yesterday, I did partake of their falafel and Greek salad, both of which did please mine palate. The service, too, was most courteous and friendly, a welcome change from previous visits. They did present us with bottles of water, gratis, which did seem somewhat wasteful, alack! Yet, I did find their serving of Mexican Coca-Cola to be a curious, but pleasant, variation. The dessert, baklava, was quite good, but the simple syrup that topped it did naught but detract from its flavor. A drizzle of honey, perchance, would have been a wiser choice. In conclusion, I must confess that, though I oft complain of the cacophony of music in eateries, the silence at Holy Land did strike me as somewhat peculiar. A soft, Middle Eastern melody, methinks, would have been a fitting addition. Despite this, I did enjoy my repast and shall return anon."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from yonder Golden Nugget's buffet,
Which, alas, doth lie in disarray, in shambles, doth it be.
Yet fear not, dear guests, for in its stead,
A buy-one-get-one-free coupon doth await thee,
At Carson Street Cafe, a mere stone's throw away,
Where thou mayst feast upon a bounty of victuals,
And quench thy thirst with draughts of ale or wine,
In proximity to elevators, a convenient find.

Oh, blessed respite! For weary travelers, worn,
This cafe doth offer solace, a haven, a reprieve.
The fare, though simple, doth satisfy,
With BLTs and Caesar salads, a meal most brave.
Yet, alack! The service, slow it doth seem,
A laggard pace, a tardy tempo, doth mar the scheme.
But still, a worthy stop, this Carson Street,
For those who seek a quick repast, a moment's treat."

"A haven of refreshment, where one may quench their thirst and sate their hunger. 'Tis a place of solace, where one may find respite from the heat and the bustle of the city. Yet, beware, good sir or madam, for the service there is not of the most hospitable sort. 'Twere best to pay with cash, lest thou desirest to avoid the awkwardness of a prolonged encounter with the keepers of the establishment. So, if thou art in search of a cool draught and a quick bite, this place may serve thee well, but tarry not, lest thou be vexed by the gruff demeanor of the staff."

"Hark, my dearest friend, what news I bring!
A tale of too much plenty, and its bitter sting.
Forsooth, we dined at Big View twice a week,
And found the service and victuals most meek.
But lo, the holidays came, and with them, woe,
The bakery's cookies, stale and old, did grow.
And thus, we have not returned, this new year,
For fear of more ill fortune, and cheer.

But, prithee, let us not forget,
The times we dined, with joy and wit.
The breakfast plates, oh, how they shone,
With flavors bright, like the morning sun.
The shrimp and grits, a dish most fine,
And chicken souvlaki, a taste divine.
The spinach pastry, a delight,
And greek salad, fresh as the morning light.
Crab cake, oh, how it did impress,
A culinary marvel, beyond all measure.

And the bakery, oh, how sweet,
Its treats, a joy, our spirits to greet.
But alas, the service, once so bright,
Did falter, and lose its gentle might.
So, heed my words, dear friend, take heed,
And choose thy seat, with wisdom's speed.
For though Big View may still be grand,
'Tis wise to avoid the bar, so bland."

"Across from campus theater, we did stray,
Convenient spot, indeed, 'twas our aim.
In we walked, and swiftly seated were we,
Drink orders taken, with haste, did they bring.

But then, a delay, there came to pass,
After drink orders, some fifteen minutes' wait,
Our orders taken, by hostess fair,
Due to waitress's o'erwhelmed plight, we did surmise.

Food came, some fifteen minutes later,
We ate with haste, lest we be late,
Turkey dinner, with small pieces, did come,
Not long cut strips, as menu did proclaim.

Pancakes, with white chocolate raspberry,
His choice, a good pick, did prove to be,
Egg Nog pancakes, a good option, did seem,
But alas, not chosen, by me.

Ticket paid, I did, with speedy hand,
So we could leave, and not be late, in this land.

Overall, a B-, service was good,
Food, just okay, an A-OK visit, as understood."

Last eve, I chanced upon the W, where revelry did reign,
A bachelorette party, full of mirth and glee, did hold its sway.
But, alack, the drinks they served, did cost a pretty penny,
Sixteen dollars, by my count, a sum most reckless and quite funny.

I prayed for water, pure and simple, to quench my thirst,
For such extravagance, my purse could not endure, nor would it burst.
The folk who gathered there, did provide a merry show,
A maiden, scantily clad, did dance, and caused my sides to flow.

The waitresses, fair and bright, did tend to us with grace,
And split the bill, with smiles so wide, into more manageable space.
Indeed, the W, a place of wonder, where wealthy ones do throng,
Yet, not my cup of tea, for I do find it rather wrong.

"A pox upon this tavern, and its rude servitors too!
Two stars I subtract, for poor service I didst receive.
On a Tuesday eve, my friend and I didst sit at the bar,
But the bartenders, they didst pay us no mind, nor care.
Their friends were there, and they didst attend to them alone,
Leaving us to wait, for a menu, forsooth, for long.
And when I asked for ale, the bartender didst throw
The list at me, with scorn and disdain, I do avow.
She came not back, for full fifteen minutes more,
A plague upon her, and her surly demeanor!
Take Midol, woman, and improve thy mood,
For ill-tempered service, doth make a tavern, no good."

"Down to the buffet we didst descend,
For breakfast on a Sunday morn, 'twas nigh.
A choice of victuals vast and wide,
Didst lay before us, to our great surprise.

Prime rib and cuts of meat most fine,
Didst grace the table, a feast divine.
But lobster and crab, alas, were none,
At eleventh hour, the morning sun.

Full price, a sum of silver great,
Didst we pay, our pockets now bereft.
Yet still, the experience, a memory sweet,
In this fair city, where we didst meet.

So if thou hast the means, do come,
And partake of the feast, anon.
But if thy purse doth runneth low,
Best seek another place to go."

"Amidst the throngs of taverns that dot this merry town,
One place doth stand apart, a haven of renown,
The Yard House, where I do oft repair,
To quaff a pint and savor fare most fair.

Their beer selection, by my troth, doth rival the sun,
In number and in quality, 'tis second to none,
And during happy hour, their prices doth descend,
Making it an ideal spot to start thy day's end.

Their food, alas, doth leave somewhat to be desired,
But for a quick repast, 'twill serve thee well inspired,
For in this neighborhood, there be many a place,
Where thou mayst find a feast to grace thy face.

So if thou art in search of ale and cheer,
And dost not mind a menu somewhat dear,
Then to The Yard House, thou shouldst make thy way,
And there, thou shalt find joy, come what may."

Alas, my friends, we found ourselves in woe  
When Big Dogs on Sierra did close its door  
For there we'd go, at least twice, 'twas our rite  
To partake of brew and nachos, oh so bright

But now, alack, we must seek elsewhere  
And so we went to Draft House, with hearts full of cheer  
But lo, the nachos, they did not compare  
To those we loved, oh how our spirits did sink

The ale, it was good, a solace to our woe  
But still, we mourned our favorite nachos, oh so  
For they were gone, and with them, our delight  
In Sierra's Big Dogs, where we'd revel through the night.

"Fare good, but dearly priced, I say,
The wait, long during peak hours, doth come what may.
In Vegas, 'tis the norm, I do suppose,
But, alack, the cost, doth make me choose.

If half the price, the buffet were,
Then four stars, I would confer.
But, alas, the food, doth not make worth,
The price, that doth thy purse unworth.

In brief, thy coin, elsewhere, best spend,
For equal fare, at lower rate, thou shalt find.
And, perchance, fortune shall thy way attend,
At slots, where jackpots may be thine to amend."

"A stone's throw from my humble abode,
This pizzeria doth hold a special place,
Where I do oft repair, to partake
Of their most excellent pies, both veggie and supreme,
With a pitcher of frothy ale, and wings,
To watch the games, on their many screens.

Alas, of late, the prices have risen,
And the fare, once of highest quality,
Hath suffered somewhat, in truth.
But still, the atmosphere doth please,
The service, friendly, and the take-out,
Doth make it worth a visit, I do swear.

For pizza, they do boast a grand array,
A veritable cornucopia, indeed.
And though the other dishes may lack,
In flavor, and in freshness, too,
The pies, they do remain, the main attraction,
A culinary delight, beyond all doubt."

"O, how I do adore Grand Lux, my dear! Their corned beef hash, a dish most fine, doth please mine taste buds. Alas, a hair didst find its way into the Mrs' fries, a woeful sight indeed. Yet, the waiter and manager, with grace and poise, didst handle the matter with aplomb. They took it from our bill, and with apologies, didst make amends. And, by the stars, their desserts, a true delight!"

"Hark! Good sir, 'tis true, the service at Tea Lite doth shine,
With speedy food and friendly folk, a most divine combine.
Their prices, too, do please, a meal most fair and bright,
Yet, there's a catch, my friends, a lack doth plague their sight.

Alack! Their pho, though tasty, doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
No tripe nor tendon doth it boast, a fact most vexing, I do avow.
And though they have a plethora of options to add zest,
No choice doth exist to make the broth more bold, a true quest.

Perhaps, dear friends, 'tis due to their focus on quick repasts,
A streamlined menu, thus, their specialty doth hold fast.
But fear not, for I do urge thee still to visit this place,
And, who knows? Mayhap thou shalt find a newfound grace.

So, go forth, kind sirs, and support this eatery with glee,
And, perchance, ask for more, that they may see,
A change in menu, then, may come to pass,
And I, in turn, shall grant them more stars, alas!"

"Upon a pair of reviews, I chanced this place,
Expecting wondrous fare, and such it was,
Four stars for victuals, that did please my face,
But two for service, that did leave me sore.

What went awry? A score of minutes passed,
For pita sandwiches, and we were alone,
And when they came, alas! The order was amiss,
My comrade had to take his meal to go.

The food, indeed, doth please my taste,
And I might visit again, but, prithee,
Get orders right, and hasten service pace,
Lest patrons flee, and leave thee in disgrace."

"Methinks I've visited this establishment a fair few times,
And each occasion hath been filled with mirth and prime.
A VIP table, we didst possess, which didst grant us ease
Of entry and enjoyment, as we didst please.

The DJ's tunes, they were quite fitting for the dance,
But alas, the space, it was a bit too concise.
A pole, a platform, didst rise above the fray,
Where women, bold and beautiful, didst sway.

Last time, the private room, a grand sight to behold,
Was closed, perchance for renovations, who doth know?
For in that space, apart from the main throng,
Didst lie private tables, dance areas, and a DJ strong.

Not bad, this place, for groups of friends to gather,
But for a pair of lads, perhaps not the best haven."

"Hark! A tale of culinary delights doth unfold,
In Montreal's streets, where taste buds doth unfold.
A humble sandwich, smoke-cured meat doth bear,
And poutine, with onion, mushroom, doth share.

The sandwich, verily, doth please mine taste,
Warm meat, so moist, doth make haste.
But poutine, alas! doth lack a certain zest,
Bacon or meat, to heighten the quest.

Yet, onion and mushroom, doth make amends,
Flavors combined, doth make amends.
But lo! A mistake, doth come to pass,
Tipping, a custom, doth leave me in a glass.

A hurry, I was in, and didn't pay heed,
Under-tipped, my error, indeed.
Waiter, a kind soul, doth ask if all be well,
Service, unexceptional, doth tell.

Saturday morn, early, doth open the door,
Tipping, in Montreal, doth be 15% more.
$1.50, a small sum, doth make me blush,
Embarrassment, doth take its rush.

Cheap, some may say, but generosity doth reign,
Brother and I, doth seek poutine's bane.
Shouting, they did, 'tis not yet open, they cry,
Food, good; service, unsure, doth lie.

Give it a chance, I shall, despite the flaw,
For in Montreal, doth culinary law."

"A room most fair, with views so bright,
At Miracle Mile, a location quite right.
No cause for craze, but fondness didst grow,
For comfort and peace, it didst show."

"Methinks 'tis a spacious place, with diverse seating arrangements to accommodate thy needs. A most excellent venue for gatherings, nigh unto the highway, whereupon I have espied men of commerce conferring, and, in truth, I have convened with mine own tutor and study group within these walls. The coffee and tea, I do declare, are of consistent quality. Moreover, they offer free Wi-Fi, though thou must request the password when thou dost acquire thy beverage. Alas, a star doth dwindle, forsooth, by reason of the untidy state of the premises, with littered tables and rubbish upon the ground."

"A fair tavern, with a choice of drinks most fine,
And in the afternoon, it was empty, save for mine own person.
Their victuals, too, didst seem of quality,
But alas, I didst not partake, forsooth, in their consumption."

"A rating of three and a half stars doth this place receive,
For its fare and drink do surpass that of airline lounges in America, as others do conceive.
Cookies, cheese, and vegetables with hummus or cold pasta salad,
Cous cous and spring rolls, and mini quiche, a feast most fair and grand.
And a full bar with wine, liquors, and drinks of all kind,
A veritable cornucopia for those who do imbibe and find.
But alas, the sitting area doth fill up quickly,
And closeth after morn, around ten and three, to reopen at two thirty, as fate doth decree.
Yet still, 'tis better than the hallway, where one may sit and pine."

"Hark, what wonders doth this eatery bring!
The calamari, a dish most fine and fair,
Didst please mine taste, and with delight
I didst devour it, without a single care.

The tacos, alas, didst not compare,
For though they were good, others beare
A greater charm, and so I say,
Seek elsewhere for a better way.

Our server, full of mirth and glee,
Didst make our time most pleasant to be,
His jokes and wit, didst lighten the mood,
And made our evening, most good.

So, to this place, I say, go thou,
For laughter, food, and drink, doth flow,
In abundance, and with joy, thou shalt find,
A night most merry, and most divine."

"A merry time it was, my friends, and like the race most wondrous,
With challenges of wit and strength, a test for all to prove.
But lo, I did expect more riddles, not so easily solved
By mere device of smartness, no, not by such means.

In form and ready to run, thou must be, to claim victory,
For so it doth require, a body strong and fleet.
And mark this well, fair friends, the prize they did forget,
The winners' gift of hundred dollars, oversight most dire.
But fear not, for the workers did promise to send it by post,
So all shall end well, and joy shall be the cost."

"Four of us didst break fast together,  
Two of us didst have steak and eggs, a feast,  
With potatoes, toast, and all the trimmings,  
A bargain at six dollars, nay, a steal!  
Two of us didst opt for the veggie omelet,  
With fresh greens, cheese, and potatoes, a treat.  
Coffee flowed like a river, and service was bright,  
Friendly servers made our day take flight.  
We returned the next eve, our hunger anew,  
Two of us had penne, creamy and true,  
Two had burgers, juicy and just right,  
The best part? Beers, brewed in house, a delight!  
Hefe and Light, both smooth and fine,  
A steal at two twenty-five, we doth decline.  
Five beers and four meals, a total of forty-five,  
A fair price, nay, a bargain, we doth arrive!"

"A humble abode, this eatery be,
My love's coworker didst recommend to thee.
For his natal day, we didst dine therein,
And found it neat, though small within.
The service was good, our meal didst come apace,
And happy hour, all day, doth grace.
The victuals, fair, but not of highest rank,
I didst enjoy the salmon, scallops, and tofu, in truth.
But calamari, fried, a dish to avoid,
Flavorless, and tempura-like, it didst prove."

"A Groupon didst I purchase, good sir,
For cut, all o'er color, and style, 'twas fair.
My stylist, a skilled lass, didst listen well,
And brought to life the vision I didst tell.
But, alack, two issues didst mar the day,
And thus, three stars doth this review convey.

Firstly, my stylist didst mix the color in her bowl,
And just as she began, didst demand an extra toll.
I felt cornered, good sir, and quite taken aback,
For such a fee, I didst not see, nor was it tacked.

Secondly, my shirt, a fine garment, didst stain,
For bleeding through the robe, my hair color didst gain.
The stylist's manager, a gruff man, didst say,
'Twill come out in the wash, but I doth doubt the way.

So, three stars, good sir, doth this review end,
For though the service was good, the rest didst offend."

"A humble tavern, this place doth be,
With atmospheric charm, so plain to see.
TVs abound, a wondrous sight,
And service, friendly, withal a delight.

Their beer, cold as winter's snow,
And menu, limited, yet fit to go.
Sandwiches, salads, and more, we did try,
Fair portions, prices, did not make us sigh.

Yet, flaws there be, that doth detract,
No happy hour, a sorrowful fact.
Limited menu, a lack, indeed,
No specials, nor deals, to plant a seed.

Not open all day, a shame,
Drinks, pricey, a burning flame.
UFC, ten dollars, a steep cost,
Wine menu, scant, a sorry loss.

No pitchers, no bottles, to buy,
A drawback, verily, 'tis no lie.
But still, a visit, worth thy while,
For atmosphere, and service, with a smile."

"Methinks this review doth tarry long, my friends! Forsooth, I do frequent Miller's oft, 'tis true,
For 'tis a place most convenient, nigh the office, too.
Their happy hour, with drinks most fair and bright, doth draw me in,
And beer, aplenty, doth flow from tap to tin.
Fare, simple, yet sufficient, doth please mine eyes,
And screens, many, doth show the games of might.
Service, now, doth vary, I do confess,
At times, most kind, at others, quite a mess.
Yet, with friends, merry and bright,
Tis still a place where mirth doth take flight."

"A decent cup of joe, a pleasant place indeed,
Where scholars gather, books and homework at hand,
In the "back space", a haven for study and thought,
Though crowded, 'tis a scene of quiet contemplation.

Bring gold, my friend, for credit cards they do not take,
But fear not, for within, an ATM doth make,
Withdrawal of funds, though with a small fee,
A price to pay for convenience, as thou seest.

And mark this well, fair maiden, the barista,
A vision of beauty, a heart-stealer, no less,
His form, a work of art, his face, a shining sun,
A sight to behold, worth more than any gem or fun."

"Hark! Seeketh thou old-fashioned soul food? Verily, this place doth fit the bill. Fried chicken and cornbread, most delectable fare! A plethora of sides to choose from, thy taste buds shall be sated. Service, good and prompt, maketh this an excellent spot for midday repast, shouldst thou find thyself in town."

"Hark! I pray they didst dismiss the foolish coachman who didst near run me down, in his haste to beat a red light, and didst end up in collision with another guest's Hyundai. 

Setting aside their folly in hiring such a madman, I cannot grumble too much about The Mirage. Rooms are priced fairly, though they have risen of late. The gardens at the entrance are a wondrous sight, a perfect spot for a photograph. Each eatery within is a culinary delight, not to be missed. I highly recommend Japonais, Kokomo, and Samba. Moreover, there be many tables scattered through the casino, ideal for those who wish to start small. Alas, they do not reward quad aces in the poker room, a pity indeed, for I have won many a handsome pot there. 

Given its prime location on the Strip and proximity to other attractions, I would advise staying at The Mirage. Only, take heed when crossing the road, lest thou meet a similar fate."

"The chambers be dimly lit, my dear,
Alack, they lack sufficient light, 'tis true.
No fridge nor microwave, alas, doth grace
These halls, but, verily, I do confess,
The latter's absence doth not vex me so.
A Philips LCD, of thirty-two inches, doth
Adorn the wall, a modest sight, methinks.
But, lo, the water, hot, doth not abide,
When one doth bathe or doth take council with
The shower's spray. A grievous fault, indeed.
And, prithee, mark this well, a fee doth lie,
A resort tax, hidden, of twenty dollars,
They should include it in the total sum,
And not seek to conceal it, like a trickster.

"I didst watch the pirate show, before the inn,
'Twas passable, yet, my room, the eighth floor,
Didst offer solace, distant from the din.
A blessing, indeed, that noise didst not pour
Into mine ears, a pleasant respite, forsooth.

"Now, listen well, fair sir, the Treasure Isle,
Doth stand within the heart of Las Vegas' smile,
'Twixt Wynn and Paris, Bellagio, nay,
Planet Hollywood, doth form the central way,
All else, beyond, doth pale, and doth not claim
One's attention, save Fremont Street, of old."

"Panchos, a buffet of sorts, doth offer much in the way of mediocre Mexican fare. A cafeteria-style line doth lead thee to thy feast, whereupon thou mayest choose from such delights as chili rellenos, enchiladas, tamales, chimichangas, flautas, taquitos, rice, beans, tacos, and tostadas. The cost, quite reasonable, doth make it an acceptable venture for those who enjoy such greasy, non-authentic Mexican cuisine. Once seated, a wee flag doth summon waiters to thy table, forthwith. Verily, 'tis a marvelous notion! Cleanliness doth seem to be a concern, yet the service, thanks to the flag, doth prove most satisfactory. And, indeed, who doth resist the allure of fresh, hot sopapillas after their repast? I, myself, doth reluctantly accompany my husband, forsooth, for the love of those cheese sponges."

"Amidst the bustling strip, a Starbucks doth lie,
In name alone, for 'tis not genuine, nay,
They take the gift cards, total rewards, a sign,
Of their true nature, not a part of the vine.

Their prices, too, do tell a tale of deceit,
My passionfruit tea, once two dollars eighty, now doth meet,
Six dollars, a sum most exorbitant, a price so steep,
I paid with my card, and did not dare to question deep.

The space within, quite large, with outlets galore,
A haven for those who seek to charge their device once more,
And mugs, juices, sandwiches, all doth fill the shelves,
A veritable feast, for those who do not fear the pelf.

Yet, for their prices, I must give them but three stars,
For doubling the cost, of a drink so pure and fair,
Is madness, a trick, a scheme, a wicked way,
To part a man from his hard-earned pay."

"A winding corridor doth lead to this place of pie,
A secret hideaway, for those who do aspire
To taste the flavors of Italy, in disguise.

Within, a scant few seats, for weary travelers to rest,
And wait, some twenty minutes, ere their feast be blessed.

Alas, the pizza, middling fare, at best,
For Slices, in Dublin, doth my heart possess.
But still, a novel experience, in this town of vice,
Yet, should I find myself in Las Vegas once more,
I fear, I shall not darken this door again,
For other culinary delights, my soul doth yearn."

"Verily, the victuals didst please mine taste,
Afirst, I didst think it but a common feast,
But lo, the flavors didst dance upon mine tongue,
And made me reconsider mine erstwhile boon.

I do confess, I didst feel a mite confused,
Whenas I didst behold the menu, unprosed,
For in mine haste, I didst not see it ere,
And thus, I didst feel a mite discomposed.

Moreover, they didst give me but a box,
To hold mine aliment, and naught but that,
No bag to bear it, nor a straw to sip,
Which didst vex mine spirit, and didst make me rip.

Yet still, the food didst satisfy mine hunger,
And thus, I shall return, to partake of their plunger."

"Hark, a solid three, I say, yet doubts remain,
For thick-cut pepperoni doth not please mine eyes.
I crave the thin, delicate slice, a la Villa or Verrazano's guise.
Alas, the crust, a tad too dark, doth not delight,
A golden brown, my heart doth sing, with joy and mirth.

Their renovations, quite extensive, I must confess,
Transforming the old Atlanta Bread Co., with finesse.
Yet, fair New York, my mind doth wander,
With visions of pizza, so fine and grand.

Shall I return? Aye, mayhap, forsooth,
But shall it be a regular haunt? Only time shall prove, my friend."

"Hark! What woeful change doth Chipotle bring?
Their chicken now, in stew, doth sit all day,
And is it still white meat, I do pray?
Nay, 'tis a broth, where once it did play.

And lo, the burrito maker doth take
Her gloved hands, and with them doth make
A mess of toppings, in each bin doth she
Stick her hand, and thus doth cause dismay.

Oh, for a spoon or thong, to end this woe,
And bring back sanity, as once it did glow."

"O fond memories, how thou dost play upon my mind! 
In days of yore, at Pitt, where funds were scarce, 
Two eateries vied for our meager purse, 
Lu-Lu's Noodles, Yum Wok, both names entice. 
Their prices low, their proximity a boon, 
But alas, delivery they did not proffer, 
On cold days, through brown slush we had to go, 
With laughter and wet pants, our spirits did glow. 
For us, 'twas worth the perilous journey, 
Up Cardiac Hill, to dorms in haste, 
With food in hand, our bellies full and merry, 
Those memories, forever shall they last."

"A bank, naught special, doth reside,
With drive-thru and walk-up service, side by side.
Convenience doth reign, yet safety doth prevail,
So, prithee, beware thy surroundings, lest thou fail.

A Smith and Nail doth neighbor, other shops near,
This corner, blessed with convenience, doth appear.
In truth, a place most handy, for daily needs,
Yet, mindfulness of safety, ever doth proceed."

"Methinks I do not oft frequent American Apparel,
For vintage garb doth beckon me, and tight attire
Doth not become me well. But lo, upon this day,
A mermaid's guise I did don, and sought a top
To shield my modesty, lest too much skin be shown.
And thus, within those hallowed halls of AA,
I found a shining, snug-fitting garment, fit
For my purpose. Though the price did seem quite steep,
At least my needs were met, and that, methought, did sleep."

"The Saloon, a place of revelry and cheer,
With beers that flow like rivers, cold and clear.
But, alas, the layout doth leave much to be desired,
A narrow passageway, with naught but bottlenecks to endure.

The Comedy Zone, a place of mirth and glee,
Doth lie beyond the Saloon, a barrier to pass,
A crowd of people, waiting in line, doth block the way,
And causes chaos, ruining the night's gay.

I've visited thee, dear Saloon, on many a night,
To partake in drinks, and merriment, and delight.
But, lo, the throngs of people, waiting to enter,
Doth make the experience less enjoyable, and doth perturb.

The bathrooms, too, doth suffer from the crush,
A human traffic jam, that doth leave one in a rush.
But, despite these woes, the music doth make up for it all,
A live band, or DJ, doth bring joy to one and all.

So, though the Saloon doth have its flaws,
I shall return, for laughter and cheer, it doth allow.
For, 'tis a place of merriment, and joy,
Despite its shortcomings, it doth employ."

"Hark! What news is this? A puzzlement doth fill my mind,
Concerning video shops and their purpose, I find.
For in HMV, new DVDs doth drop in price so fast,
A fortnight passes, and \u00a35 doth last but a moment, alas!
And thus, the question doth arise, why rent,
When purchase doth cost nigh the same, pray tell?
But fear not, dear friends, for all is not lost,
Their bargain bins doth hold a treasure trove, no doubt.
A recent film, or one of great renown,
Doth wait for thee, at a most reasonable crown.
And video games, they doth offer at a fair price,
So all is not lost, nor doth it seem quite so nice."

"Methought I would give this fair fest five stars, indeed I did,
For last year, my love and I didst attend, and joy didst we find.
The victuals were of finest sort, the music didst delight,
But then, alack, the jousting match didst take a bitter turn.

The host, a knave of foulest sort, didst play the villain's part,
Humiliating a poor maid, and offering her a wretched sum.
He didst espouse his politics, a woeful sight to see,
And thus, didst tarnish the fest's good name, in shame and infamy.

Fests of yore, shouldst be of mirth and glee,
A place where families gather, free from worry and fear.
All cast members, shouldst stay in character, throughout the day,
Lest they sully the fest's good name, and drive the crowd away.

I wouldst love to return, come October's golden light,
But if that knave doth still remain, I shall not partake in the fight."

"Aye, we sought the morning meal, a spread of victuals vast,
For twenty silver pieces, a fair price to pay.
A line of folk did form outside, in wait,
But once within, we found ample space to sit and stay.
The servant, diligent, did keep our cups full,
With juice of oranges, freshly squeezed, no doubt.
Alas, the surroundings, lacking grace, did dampen mood,
Yet still, we found delight in certain dishes, as we could.

The omelette station, bustling, with crab and shrimp,
Did please our taste buds, with flavors quite primp.
Salads, pizza, soft serve, fruit, all did abound,
And waffles, oh so crispy, with sweet syrup profound.
Danish pastries, flaky, and almond croissants too,
Turkey sausage, savory, our hunger did subdue.
Pancakes, alas, did suffer from delay,
Cold and stale, they failed to win the day.
Muffins, dry and uninspired, a disappointment, indeed,
But overall, the fare, was not so ill-conceived.
Worth a visit, verily, this breakfast buffet may be,
So gather thy coin, and give it a try, thou'll see."

"Methought this would be grand, a hearty burger, fresh and juicy, at a place they call Fuddruckers, where such fare doth reign supreme. My first visit, and thus my hopes were high. Alas, 'twas naught but a common burger, good, yet not quite great, nor aught to write home about. In n Out, a far better choice, and cheaper too, methinks. If asked again to dine at Fuddruckers, I shall, but for a burger, there be better places, mark my words."

"Hark, good sirs, let us first establish this fact,  
The Mickey Mouse mural, 'twas there ere we did act.  
Now, prithee, let our words of love be spoken,  
For Pho Nhat's #42, my heart doth truly waken.  
Thine barbecued beef, shrimp, and eggroll, so fine,  
Upon a bed of vermicelli noodles, doth combine.  
Thy fish sauce, oh how it doth entice me,  
I shall return, my love for thee shall never flee.  
But alack, my friends, my latest visit didst bring,  
A sense of discontent, among the serving folk, didst cling.  
Perhaps, another pho shall win my heart,  
For change, it seems, doth not come easy to this part."

"Rehab, a place of revelry and delight,
I visited today, with expectations high and bright.
The line, I thought, would be long and winding,
But lo, it moved swiftly, and my wait was finding.

The cost, a mere $60, a sum quite fair,
And the security, not overbearing, I declare.
A car key, credit card, and ID, all they sought,
And in three seconds, my entry was bought.

Inside, a throng of people, fair and bright,
But not so packed, as videos and photos might.
At four o'clock, still room to move and sway,
Not a madhouse, as I had thought, by day.

Few dancers, just two lovebirds, locked in embrace,
Rehab, it seems, is not the wild, crazy place.
Drinks, oh so pricey, $28, a single serving,
But Heineken Light, in buckets, a bargain, worth savoring.

Alas, I would not return, for though it was fun,
Rehab, to me, was not the wild, crazy run."

"Verily, I have visited this venue for birthday revels,
And though 'tis a popular choice, I do not concur.
The scent within doth leave much to be desired,
And those who toil here, their mood doth oft impair.
I gave it three stars, forsooth, for its merriment doth please the young ones."

"Methinks 'twas naught but ale that I didst partake,
Yet found I joy in this fair brewhouse's make.
The tavern itself, a square of finest design,
Didst boast a central bar, where bartenders didst shine.
A tiny aquarium, full of fish so fine,
Didst add a touch of whimsy to the scene divine.
The crowd, though small, didst revel in the night,
And nearby, tables twain didst offer respite.
If thou dost find thyself in Middleton's embrace,
And seek a pint, without the need to pace,
Then hath this place, a worthy stop, indeed,
To quench thy thirst, and banish sorrow's creed."

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,  
My breakfast at Perk did not impress.  
The victuals were fair, I must avow,  
But service, alas, did lack somehow.  

My dam and I, we both did dine  
On burritos, mine with bacon, fine.  
And though they were small, as I do reckon,  
The flavor was good, with cilantro sauce anon.  

But, oh, the waitress, how unkind!  
No word, no smile, nor any sign.  
She left us be, like strangers, alone,  
And when we needed her, she was nowhere known.  

The hostess, fair, didst attend to us,  
With water fresh and our bill, what a fuss.  
But when the waitress came, in such haste,  
She slapped the bill down, without a taste.  

No thank you, nor farewell, she did say,  
And so, my friends, I shall not stay.  
For I can make my own burrito,  
And save myself from such disdain and pity."

"Methinks, fair maiden, thou and thine beau didst decide to partake in libations at yon establishment, a place of ill repute, yet affordable. Thy swain, in days of yore, didst frequent this tavern, and thus, thy expectations, fair maid, were low. The atmosphere, coarse and unrefined, didst not perturb thee, nor didst the facilities, rude and basic. Thou didst command a potion, Tokyo tea, they call it, and didst request the device, a gadget, if thou wilt, to engage in the quiz, projected upon the wall. And, lo, the fiery wings, anointed with honey, didst taste most sweet! Upon thy departure, thou didst espy the chamber of karaoke, where merriment and mirth didst reign. A humble abode, fit for those who seek naught but drink and victuals, without pomp or fanfare."

"Oh, how I adore all things phyllo and spinach! Greek restaurants beckon me, dear friend, with promises of delectable treats. A taste of Spanikopita, a morsel of Baklava, my heart doth sing with joy!

Aye, the Spanikopita, a dish most fine, didst please my palate with its creamy feta cheese. I added a sprinkle from my salad, a trick I learned at home, to heighten the flavor, 'twas a delight!

The portion, generous and fair, the price, most reasonable, the atmosphere, warm and inviting, a cozy haven for luncheon or dinner. I returned anon, a testament to its charm, forsooth, a place I shall revisit, whenever fate doth bring me to Madison's shores!"

"Hark! A Beerarita doth please mine eyes!
And lo, the quesadilla, full of chicken, doth lie.
Alack, a little more flavor it did need, I do confess.
But soft, the chips and salsa, a wondrous treat, did bless.
The salsa, too, did make up for the quesadilla's lack, I do declare."

"Methought this eating place was but so-so, my rating doth depend on victuals weighed against cost. One thing I didst not fancy, all dishes served à la carte, I pray thee! A Caesar salad I didst order, 'twas passable, yet o'erly large, and I didst not devour all of it. My spouse, a humble burger he didst choose, alack! naught special for the price, no sides to boot. Here again I wouldst dine, anon, should other taverns be too full."

"A cup of coffee, a cup of tea,
With noise of radios, blenders do be,
But wifi, good and strong, doth make it so,
That now I know the way, I shall go."

"Good service, fair sir, yet hard to find,
In strip mall, rural north of Guadalupe, 'twas hidden.
Food portions, large, but flavor, just so-so,
I had omelet, with all, and hubby, Scottish eggs Benedict, didst savor.
Benedict sauce, good, but bread, a mite tough,
Omelet, just fair, with home fries, English muffin, enough."

"Methinks we chanced upon this eatery, my friends and I,  
After a merry jaunt through yonder shops so nigh.  
'Tis but an ordinary place, yet suited to our needs,  
With jalapeño bread, a curious treat, our hunger to feed.  
  
A turkey sandwich was my choice, with stuffing and cranberry  
Sauce, a feast for the taste buds, verily, a Thanksgiving delight.  
But alas, 'twas dry, my friends, and left me somewhat unsatisfied,  
Yet still, a decent meal, and worth the price, I doth decide.  
  
My comrades, too, didst find their victuals to their liking,  
Save one, who lamented the lack of PBR, her heart's desire.  
The waitress, kind and fair, didst attend to our each whim,  
And when a burger lacked heat, didst swiftly make amends, with a grin.  
  
So, though the fare may be but common, the atmosphere doth please,  
And after a tiring day, their food doth bring us ease.  
Thus, shall we come again? Mayhap, anon, my friends,  
For despite its flaws, this place doth hold a certain charm, and gentle ends."

Alas, my friends, I must confess,
The Juan Turkey Wrap did not impress.
Despite my usual disdain for healthy fare,
I thought to give this place a chance, with nary a care.

But lo, the wrap did taste like mush,
A flavorless concoction, without a single hush.
No distinguishing features, just a bland mix,
Leaving me to douse it in hot sauce, with a heavy fix.

Yet still, I shall give this place another go,
Perhaps the "happy" menu holds a better show.

"Hark! A breakfast quest, we did embark,
At a place called 'gourmet', by their own remark.
A Mediterranean omelette, we did try,
But found it lacking, in flavor and in size.

Their prices, fair they were, for the amount,
We paid twenty-two gold coins, for three devout.
But alas, the variety, was scarce and thin,
What you see, is what you get, no more within.

Oh, how we praised the plastic utensils, so bright,
No dishwashers here, a pleasant sight.
But one napkin, oh so meager, they did provide,
For all our needs, it did not suffice.

The service, middling at best, we did find,
But the appearance, neat and tidy, did entwine.
In Old Downtown Chandler, it did reside,
Across from the park, a pleasant stride.

Alas, one bathroom, a long line did create,
A narrow hallway, a wait most ignominious did relate.
Our overall experience, not horrid, we confess,
But alas, a return, we shall not profess."

"Methinks 'tis passable fare for this place,
Amidst the mediocre, a middling grace.
Not quite Panda Express, nor yet divine,
But betwixt both, a compromise doth shine."

"Hark! Away from the Strip doth lie a place they call Juicy Pho,
Where Vietnamese delights doth await thee, 'tis a go.
Their Pho, a feast for tastebuds, doth differ from SGV's brew,
In Vegas, 'tis a rarity, a gem, anon, 'twill do.

I ordered pork chop rice, alas! the portion small,
The flavors, lacking, left me in a bit of a squall.
But then! My friend's Korean BBQ ribs, oh how divine!
Satisfied my craving, saved the day, and time.
Their Pho, a decent broth, did warm my soul,
Yet the star, the egg roll wrapped in lettuce, stole the show!

A trek, indeed, from the Strip, a good ten to fifteen minutes' ride,
Yet for the flavors, worth each moment, I did not hide.
So if thou seeketh Pho, away from the glimmer and glitz,
Juicy Pho, a humble abode, shall satisfy thy gustatory fits."

"Fie upon these paltry patties, dear!
A sorry sight, indeed, they do present.
Forsooth, their scanty size doth mock my stomach's need,
And their dear price doth make my purse lament.

In days of yore, when schooldays' joys were mine,
I didst partake of burgers, plastic, vile,
And lo, their taste and texture, then, didst seem divine.
But now, alas! These burgers, cheap and mean,
Do bring to mind those wretched, rubbery things,
And thus, my gorge doth rise in disdain.

Ten silver pieces, gone! Oh, cruel fate!
For such a sum, a hearty meal I might have had,
But nay, 'twas spent on this, a sorry bite,
Which doth but taunt my hunger, leaving me irate.
No more, I say! This place shall see me not again,
For worthier fare, my taste doth now demand."

This place, methinks, was but a middling sight,
A place where food of China did abide,
But, alas, of quality rather base,
And service, though fair, could not suffice,
To make it worth a second visit, think,
For there was naught that did my senses quick.

In sooth, the victuals they did serve,
Were of a sort that did my taste deceive,
And though the staff did strive to please,
Their efforts were but feeble, as it seems,
For in this place, no joy did I perceive,
Nor aught that did my spirits relieve.

So, to this place, I shall not soon return,
For there are better sights, and more to learn,
In other haunts, where food and drink do flow,
And merriment doth reign, as all men know.

"Hark! I come to this place to play cards and perchance watch a film. But lo! The scent of smoke doth fill mine nostrils, a stench most foul and pungent. 'Tis worse than that of Korean BBQ, where Kalbi doth leave its mark upon mine garb. Nay, I must needs wash mine attire straightaway, lest I doth reek like an ashtray. 

The poker chamber, full of tables and activity, doth teem with elders. I, a mere stripling in mine thirties, doth oft find myself the youngest at the table. 

Fare for the belly, passable though not palace-worthy, doth include Fuddruckers, Subway, and an oyster bar of middling quality, yet not as fine as Palace Station's own."

In fair Madison, where the Capitol doth stand,
A new-ish coffee shop doth please the land.
Colectivo, by name, doth boast a charm,
With rustic, hipster feel, and no alarm.

The tunes, they play, are cool and fine,
The decor, a sight to see and divine.
Seats abound, both within and without,
E'en on the porch, where one may pout.

A variety of brews, both hot and cold,
Teas, too, for those who dare be bold.
And should thou hunger, fear not, dear guest,
For food and ale, they have at their behest.

But, alack! No wi-fi on the weekends,
Lest ye be forced to converse, or read a book that ends.

"Hark! Why doth mine host suggest the Westin be my abode?  Yet, lo! I didst not wish to traverse far to work each day.  In sooth, I didst hear strange noises in mine chamber, but paid it no mind.  Off to the office I didst go, leaving my belongings behind.  Upon mine return, the sound didst still persist, a constant hum.  A plague upon the toilet, forsooth! It wouldst not cease its running.  Down to the lobby I didst hasten, to seek aid from one of the staff.  'Twas nigh an hour and a half ere I didst return, my hunger sated.  And lo! The toilet was still broken, a pool of water on the floor.  I didst summon the repairman once more, and in short order, all was well.  Most fortunate, indeed! Forsooth, the desk clerks do hold late check-ins, a boon to weary travelers such as myself.  I didst change my reservation from the Hilton Garden to this very Hilton, and they didst allow me entry at the early hour of eight.  Verily, 'twas a blessing."

"Hark, my dear friend! 'Tis my first visit to this place,
And, verily, the victuals didst leave me in a daze.
Fresh, they were, but choices few, alack!
For luncheon, I didst find their spread to be quite lacking.
But lo, their breakfast spread and salad bar didst please,
A feast for mine eyes, and a treat for my taste buds, 'twas.
Alas, no fish, save fried and feathered fowl, didst they proffer,
A bitter disappointment, indeed, and cause for dismay.
Nor didst their sweet treats delight, alack and alas!
I shall not spend six-and-fifty pieces of silver there,
Forsooth, their customer service didst shine, full fair."

"Hark, what store is this? A Whole Foods, by the look,  
But smaller than the one I know, at Ray Rd. and the 101,  
My favorite, where I oft do shop and dine.  
The scent within, I must confess, doth not impress,  
Like Asian markets, with their rice and meat,  
It doth assault mine nostrils, and doth make me retreat.  
But still, I venture in, to see what they do have,  
And find the olive bar, with but eight small containers,  
A paltry sight, indeed, and not worth the cost,  
But still, the meats, they doth look fresh, I must boast.  
The cheese, too, doth seem of good quality,  
And all the store, well-lit and clean, doth be.  
But alas, my favorite bacon, nowhere to be found,  
And but one loaf of bread, that doth my taste astound.  
I glimpsed their bulk section, full of sweet delights,  
But, full and satisfied, I did not tarry long in flight.  
In case of need, I'd stop, but not for pleasure's sake,  
For other stores, I'll seek, my Whole Foods experience to make."

"Meh, these digs, though pleasant, lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
And yet, I found myself within their hallowed halls,
Forsooth, the staff, a gruff and surly bunch, didst greet me coldly,
And told me of my room, on a floor most oddly.

I lugged my bags, with nary a soul to aid,
Through corridors and stairs, in search of my abode,
Until at last, I called the front desk, in dismay,
And found my chamber, on a floor far away.

Aye, construction raged, with workers beeping,
And trucks, a-bustling, in the hotel's keeping,
But I, a paying guest, didst wait, with naught to do,
As a contractor tried, a trailer to back into view.

Alas, I say, this hotel, doth not impress,
And yet, the staff, in truth, doth earn my bless,
For they, in spite of all, didst show me kindness,
And made my stay, a pleasantness, in its fineness."

Hark! I have not had the pleasure to behold
The place where cronuts first did make their bold
Appearance, for fear of lines that doth extend
Far past my patience, and my heart doth wend
In search of sweets that doth not make me wait
I chanced upon La Cornetteria's gate
And there, my friends, I didst find delight
In cronuts, fresh and hot, with flavors bright
A taste of fame, without the lengthy fray
I thank thee, La Cornetteria, for this day.

"Thus, after that woeful burger I didst receive  
From Carl's Jr., a redemption didst I seek,  
By ordering two cheeseburgers at BK,  
A simple feat, or so it didst seem.  
But lo, I waited, and waited, and waited,  
While others didst receive their chicken nuggets,  
Their Whopper Jr's, and Extra Long BBQ Cheeseburgers,  
And all the while, my order didst remain,  
In red letters, a full five minutes didst pass,  
While others didst finish in but a minute,  
For two plain cheeseburgers, a trifle, indeed!  
But finally, my cheeseburgers didst arrive,  
And they didst make amends for that foul meal,  
I didst enjoy them, with great relish and cheer,  
And thus, my hunger didst depart, with great zeal."

"Hark, I called ahead for a table, they said nay,
Just come in, no need for a fuss, they did say.
But lo, a half hour wait didst greet mine eyes,
And I didst think, 'tis folly, they should devise
A way to take reservations, 'tis Vegas,
On a Saturday eve, and the crowd doth swarm,
Like bees to honey, they do flock,
To this place, where food doth overflow.

The menu, small it may be,
Yet the flavors, they doth burst with glee.
Truffle fries, oh how divine,
Other dishes, good, but not quite fine.
Company, good, didst make the meal,
A pleasant time, we didst reveal.
'Tis a fair place, I wouldst return,
Under the right stars, my heart wouldst yearn."

"A fair brunch, with atmosphere most pleasant,
But flaws, alas, did mar our joyful feast.
We asked for none onions, yet they came,
In dish prepared, as if by fate's decree.
The cook, they said, did try his best,
But onions remained, like a festering pest.
And when we spoke, the waiter showed
Little care, as if our plight were naught.
Their efforts, though well-meaning, did not hide
The breakdowns in service, staff ill-trained.
So, sadly, we shall not return again,
For flaws, though small, did tarnish our delight."

"Hark, my dear friends, listen well,
For I have news of a wondrous spell,
A place they call E-Z Buffet, ye see,
Where food doth flow like a bountiful sea.

Two days had passed since last I didst partake,
In Asian delights, my heart didst ache,
So in I went, with hunger as my guide,
To find sustenance and quell my inside.

The place was large, with food galore,
Seventy-five dishes, and more,
Chinese fare, with Clam Chowder, beef,
Stuffed Bell Peppers, Calzone, pizza, relief.

And pink marshmallows, who knew?
I laughed with glee, my spirits anew.
The staff was friendly, the place was neat,
With Sushi, Kim Chee, Egg Foo Young, a treat.

Fried chicken, spare ribs, mushrooms too,
Fish, shrimp, and more, a feast for you,
Desserts, including ice cream, sweet delight,
A high three stars, this restaurant bright.

Lunch buffet, six seventy-five,
Sunday, eight seventy-five, a fair price,
Regular menu, for those who wish,
To dine, and savor each delicious dish."

"Chase Field, where Arizona Diamondbacks doth play,
A grand stadium, with seats aplenty, doth sway,
In Phoenix' heart, 'twas built with much fanfare,
A marvel, too, with roof that doth open fair.

Few games have I attended, yet each time,
The experience doth please, and doth entwine,
A family outing, with ease, doth find seats,
And prices, though steep, doth make one blink and squeak.

Food, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
So, eat beforehand, and save thyself, my friend,
For drinks, within, doth flow, and merriment doth reign,
A sight to behold, Chase Field, in sooth, doth remain."

"This sushi place doth boast most wondrous fare,
And atmosphere quite fitting for a date.
But alas, poor service doth mar their score,
For though the servers were friendly, they did ignore.

A group of six, we sat and waited long,
Our orders taken by several servers strong.
But as the night wore on, we were forgot,
And our requests for sushi went unnoticed, alack.

We waited nigh on 45 minutes, I swear,
Before we could get someone to take our fear.
And when they did, they added a gratuity,
Of 20%, which did our bill multiply.

And thus, we had to split the cost between,
Three ways, they said, or else we would be seen.
So there you have it, friends, a tale of woe,
That doth make me less likely to go, you know."

"Hark! If ne'er I had set foot within wicked spoon's halls,  
I would have deemed this feast most fantastical.  
The victuals were of fair quality, 'twain true and good,  
But alas! The crowd did swarm, like bees in springtime's mood.  
And dear it was, for what thou got'st, save thou didst plan  
To gorge thyself with quantity, like some great gannet or cormorant.  
Nay, 'twas a bit too much, like Disneyland's buffet,  
Where all the world doth gather, and doth eat, and doth forget."

"Verily, we've visited this establishment oft,
And found the service to be either sublime or wroth,
But still, the victuals here be of fair quality,
Thus, three stars doth be its rightful quantity.

Yet, should the fare decline in taste and worth,
Then shall we bid this place adieu, forsooth,
For mediocrity doth not suffice our needs,
And thus, we shall seek elsewhere for our deeds."

"Methinks 'tis strange, this place doth call itself a park,
Yet doth it close its gates at nine o'clock?
A family-friendly spot, it doth proclaim,
But families with young ones, it doth not accommodate.

We went this day, my daughter and three adults,
And found a fort where she did play and make merry.
We walked to Fremont Street, and there did dine,
But when my daughter asked to see the burning mantis,
They would not let her pass, though she didst plead.
My husband went to fetch her, but they didst say,
"You cannot enter, lest ye be of age."

At nine o'clock, they didst announce the park's demise,
And we, who had just bought our meal, didst feel quite vexed.
For we didst have to rush, and leave behind,
Our dinner, which we had just begun to find.

If families be their aim, then they should change,
Their hours, to suit the needs of parents and their brood.
But if they be not, then they should make it known,
That families need not come, for they are not shown.

I didst not appreciate, the haste we had to make,
To leave the park, and leave our meal to waste.
So here I write, to warn others of this fate,
And hope that they will heed, and change their policy, ere too late."

"Methinks I've dined here thrice, fair friends,
Once for the evening meal, and twice for brunch.
And though my hunger pangs were fierce and dire,
I fear the victuals did not quite impress.
Alack, the fare was but mediocre, at best,
And left me feeling somewhat unfulfilled.
Yet must I say, their presentation skills
Are quite impressive, and worth some praise.
Forsooth, the dishes were arrayed with art,
As if to tempt mine eyes, and win my heart.
But alas, fair friends, 'twas not enough,
To make me overlook the lacking taste.
Thus, three stars is all I can accord,
For this establishment, with its flaws and grace."

"Hark, what news is this? A Groupon, I didst find,
For lodgings fair, upon a holiday most kind.
With haste, I didst make my way, o'er Labor Day,
To this resort, wherein I didst hope to play.

The grounds, they were a sight to behold,
Well-manicured lawns, and trees of old.
But alack, the rooms, they didst require
A bit of updating, to make them more desire.

The tiles in the bathroom, worn and old,
Didst need replacement, ere they grew cold.
And in the cabinet, beneath the screen,
A space there was, where once a fridge had been.

The staff, they were polite, and courteous too,
At check-in, and checkout, they didst see me through.
But other than that, I didst not converse,
For I was busy, enjoying all the verse.

Oh, the activities, they were many and grand,
Pools, movies, smores, music, mini golf at hand.
One could rent paddleboards, or kayaks too,
To paddle round the lake, of Las Vegas, anew.

Dogs, they were allowed, I didst espy,
So, perchance, my furry friend, shall come nigh.
In conclusion, the price I paid, was fair,
For the quality, of the hotel, beyond compare."

"In fair Charlotte, my kin didst arrive,
During restaurant week, their hunger to relieve.
Mez, the eatery, with menus diverse and wide,
Didst entice us in, with atmosphere upbeat and bright.
Cocktails at the bar, we didst imbibe with glee,
Their creative mix, a true delight for thee.
Our table, swiftly gained, with service so fine,
A sweet and spunky server, our needs didst define.
The restaurant week menu, a wondrous sight,
Crab cakes, the best, in all of Charlotte's light.
Steaks, cooked to perfection, a tender delight,
Leaving naught but wishing, for a sweeter bite.
Dessert, a tasty treat, yet not quite divine,
Still, Mez, a place, where I wouldst happily dine."

"Hark! Red Ridge Park, so near my humble abode,
A mere ten minutes' walk, and I am there,
A place of recreation, exercise, and joy,
Where I do run, and gauge my distance, by and by.

Two sides of hills, and two of level ground,
A pleasant course, for feet to tread around,
Well-lit at night, and safe, I do declare,
For solitary runs, without a single care.

A haven for young ones, with waters bright,
And play areas, for the little ones to delight,
Basketball courts, and diamond, for the bold,
A place of merriment, for young and old.

But now, they build, across from this fair park,
Dunhill homes, with prices, quite a mark,
A growing neighborhood, indeed, it seems,
With views of green, and joyous dreams.

Alas, one thing, I wish they had,
An enclosed dog park, for furry lads,
Like some other parks, I have chanced to see,
A place for pups, to frolic, wild and free."

"Hark! A rating of three and a half stars doth this place receive,
For its appetizers, most wondrous and fine, doth it conceive.
The salumi and grilled asparagus, a fan doth make,
But alas, the fish and chips, with flavor didst it lack.
A bit of lime, we didst add, to improve its taste,
And thus, our meal, with joy, didst we embrace.

But lo, not all entrees, didst please our crowd,
For one beef dish, with salt, didst o'er abound.
The berries, sweet and luscious, didst delight,
But ice cream, in bowls that melt, didst lose its might.
Caramel dessert, too salty, didst it prove,
And thus, our meal, with mixed feelings, didst we conclude."

"Hark! The victuals were passable, a tavern, 'twain't bad for ale imbibers, woe is me, a non-ale drinker. A black bean burger, perchance from Morningstar Farms, did grace my plate, yet an extra fee of nineteen pence, methinks, doth raise my ire. \n\nThe attendance, sporadic, our draughts refilled, alack, when the bill didst arrive."

"Methinks the reviews didst speak of wondrous feasts,
But alas, mine own dish didst not meet expectations.
Chicken pasta, with linguini, basil, and cream sauce,
Didst weigh heavy on my stomach, like a leaden anchor.
The service, though, didst shine like the brightest star,
Five stars, I say, for their courteousness and care.
And gladly, they didst serve my favorite brew,
Dos Equis amber, a drink most fair and true."

Hark! I've visited Osteria twice, my friends,
To partake in their delectable fare,
A sandwich first, then pizza later,
To sate my hunger and quench my thirst.

My hopes were high, for I do reside
Across the street, a mere stone's throw,
And thus, I wished this place to excel,
But alas, my experience hath been mixed, I do confess.

The sandwich, an Italian delight,
Was truly tasty, a masterful blend,
But the pizza, oh, how it did fall short,
Leaving me underwhelmed, my friends, I do declare.

It reminded me of pies consumed in days of yore,
When I did dwell in New York's city's heart,
But that, my friends, doth not bode well,
For quality, it doth leave much to be desired, I do aver.

Yet still, I hold out hope for Osteria's fate,
That they may flourish and prosper,
Perhaps a weekend brunch shall be their saving grace,
Or pizzas made with love, a culinary embrace.

"Verily, I say unto thee, my dearest friend,  
That ne'er have I felt such foulness descend  
Upon my person, as on that day we didst  
Take to the river, and with joy, didst glide.  

Aye, 'twas a merry time, with laughter free,  
We tied ourselves together, a jolly spree,  
And with a cooler of ale, our spirits didst rise,  
As we didst bask in the sunshine, and the water's surprise.  

And, prithee, good sir, do thou wear a hat,  
A broad brim, to shield thy visage from the heat,  
For in such garb, we mayst brave the elements,  
And with mirth, didst conquer the day's events."

"Tis well, my friend, 'tis well indeed,
No need to fret or make a fuss,
For all is fine, and doth proceed
As it should, with naught amiss.

Verily, I speak the truth, my word
Is bond, and thus it shall be heard,
No sarcasm doth my voice convey,
But rather, all is well, come what may.

And so, my dear, let us partake
In this most noble of breakfasts, fair and bright,
For here, within this hallowed hall,
Doth lie a feast most wondrous and grand, fit for a king's delight."

"Thou knowest full well, ere thou dost step within,  
That fare provided may not be of the finest kin.  
Yet, hope doth spring eternal, that staff shall befriend,  
And make thy sojourn pleasant, with service of a kind.  
Alas! 'Tis a gamble, for this OG doth play  
A game of chance, where fortunes may sway.  
I've known both joy and woe, at hands of those  
Who tend the tables, and pour the flowing doses."

"Fair food, good sir! 'Tis a fine place to break thy fast, indeed. Thou savory crepes, how they doth please mine taste! And coffee drinks, oh how they doth delight!

Yet, there be some things that doth trouble mine eyes:
A hostess, fair maiden, to guide me through the door,
For here, within this hall, no clear path doth lay.
Counter service or table, who doth know? Alas,
I hadst to seek an employee, to learn the way.

And service, spotty 'tis, with two fair maidens serving,
Each table full, our order, didst take some time arriving.
Wait times, long they be, for crepes, twenty-five minutes,
A lengthy span, indeed, for one who hath a plan.

But still, I say, two out of three, not bad, my friend,
For crepes and coffee, they doth make amends.
So, here I shall return, when time doth allow,
To partake in feast, and drink, and merriment, anon!"

"Hark! What value doth this hotel bring,
A mere $109 per night, and that's not all, my friend!
For on the weekends, 'tis a bargain indeed,
Compared to $400 for a tiny room, cramped and in need.

And throw in breakfast, free of charge,
And drinks in the eve, a bonny largesse.
The hotel, once upgraded, now doth shine,
The rooms, nice enough, yet the lobby, a bit divine.

But alas, service doth leave much to be desired,
Our food, delayed, and the wait, quite tiresome and long.
The check-in, a slow affair, and the front desk,
Doth stop and answer phones, a most vexing quirk.

Yet, one kind soul, did call me "cute",
I know not if to be flattered, or to be mute.
The shuttle, a mystery, no consistent word,
We used taxis, $10 a trip, to the Strip, oh so absurd.

In conclusion, this Embassy Suites, not the best,
I prefer the other, on Paradise, at a higher cost.
But still, a good stay, and value, doth abide,
For those who seek, a cheaper place to reside."

"Ah, fair Gyle Industrial Estate, how oft I seek thy shelter from the drudgery of office life! Mayhap 'tis but a humble shopping centre, yet to mine eyes 'tis a haven of delight, a refuge from the mundane. 

In days of yore, when first it did open wide its doors, 'twas a marvel of modernity, a shining jewel in the crown of progress. And though the years may have passed, and some may say it doth show signs of wear and tear, to me 'tis still a treasure trove of delights. 

For within its walls, a veritable feast doth lie: Marks & Spencer, great Morrisons, Boots of renown, New Look and Dorothy Perkins, all gathered in one place. Nay, even a Starbucks doth grace its halls, a haven of solace for mine own soul. 

And let us not forget, dear friends, the Millie's Cookie Stand, a place of wonder wherein I have indulged in many a sweet delight. O, cookie cake, how thou dost tempt me still! 

But alas, fair readers, note that the food court doth lack in choices for those who seek healthier fare. Yet fear not, for 'tis still a place most meet for a hasty retreat, a refuge from the daily grind. Or when, in dire need, I must procure that dress of which I didst speak, the one that doth adorn the pages of my cherished Gossip Magazine. 

So here I shall remain, in this, my humble shopping centre, content in the knowledge that, though aged, 'tis still a place of wonder, a sanctuary from the world outside."

Since this place was raised, I've yearned to see,
But always stayed on the Strip, where lights beckon me.
My latest trip, I vowed to break the spell,
And venture forth to Fremont Street, where tales tell.

I must confess, the screens are quite impressive,
An outdoor fete, with sights most impressive.
The prices too, are suited to my purse,
A place where drinks and grub, my budget traverse.

But alas, the night I went, 'twas quite unsavory,
With folk of street, and bags of questionable provenance.
Yet, 'tis part of charm, to have no fear,
And drink in hand, with naught to interfere.

I gazed upon the screen, but glanced below,
To ensure my wallet, safe and secure did go.
Perhaps the early shows, less seediness do bear,
But late at night, I feared, my fate to share.

"Upon a night most fair, my love and I didst venture forth,
In search of ale and merriment, to banish all our woe.
And lo, we found this place, most fitting for our quest,
Where folk in costumes doth gather, and make merry with the rest.

Two cups of brew we didst have, of Sin City's finest ale,
And Sam Adams' cherry wheat, which doth our thirst assuage.
A fine selection they doth boast, of microbrews and more,
From Sierra Nevada, Alaska, Abita, Rogue, and Stone, and others of renown.

But alack, the service doth lack, in speed and in cheer,
Despite the bustling crowd, and our free drink coupons dear.
Yet still, we shall return anon, to taste their brews once more,
For 'tis a place most meet, to gather with friends on the Strip's floor."

"In fair Oakland, where dining options abound,
Lucca stands as one of the finer Italian grounds.
Their fare, well-prepared, doth please the palate,
And staff, with smiles, do make the guest feel great.
The atmosphere, not too formal, doth create
A comfortable setting, suitable for a date.
But alas, the cost, a bit too steep, doth say
This meal, more fit for cities grand, like SF or NY."

"Methinks I did expect a greater show,
A vista most fair and grand,
But alack, the view did please me well,
As day gave way to night's sweet spell.
The victuals and the decor, methought,
Were but average, nay, not quite right,
Yet still, the view, that wondrous sight,
Doth make this eatery special, by my troth,
For though I dwell in this fair town,
This view doth never cease to amaze me now."

"Methinks I've seen 'Viva Elvis' a fair few times,
From its grand opening to a few months past.
The show, though improved, doth not progress much,
And seems not to fit with Cirque's other vast.

Now, mark you well, the music, scenes, and garb,
Are quite delightful, and worth the price of admission.
The performers, dressed in Elvis' era, do greet thee,
And 'Jail House Rock' and 'Return to Sender' be my favorite treat.

But, alas, the choreography doth lack the wow,
And the singing women, though talented, doth not feel quite right,
For Elvis' voice, methinks, doth make the songs more bright.
And the transitions between scenes, clumsy and slow.

Yet, despite these flaws, I did enjoy the show,
And recommend it, for it shall soon depart, thou know."

Alas, fair maiden, with sorrow I say,  
This business, once mine, now doth belong  
To new masters, who with haste did take  
The reins, and all my hopes did break.  
My eyebrows, once a work of art,  
Now doth resemble a sorry state.  
One brow, uneven and thin, doth mar  
The other, full and lush, a sorry sight.  
I fear, fair maiden, I shall not return,  
For quality, alas, doth no longer burn.

"Methinks 'tis my second visit to this wondrous place,
Where culinary delights doth fill the space.
The atmosphere, it doth delight,
With the Yard, a merry sight.

Hark! The happy hour, a warning give,
For drinks, a bar, high-tops, or outdoors doth live.
We didst not partake in such revelry,
But couldst have been, a tale to tell, ye see.

A hip bar menu, we didst enjoy,
With friends, a work hangout, didst employ.
Good fare, it was, I do declare,
And fun, a place to gather, without a care.

An adult playground, full of mirth,
A place to laugh, and let go of dearth.
So come, my friends, and join the fray,
At this culinary dropout, night or day!"

"Tuna carpaccio, ninja roll, and elephant roll, oh my!
How delectable they did taste, upon my word!
Trendy, indeed, the vibe doth seem, yet somewhat cramped,
I do confess, the low rise sushi bar, doth not appeal.
AYCE dinner, priced not too steep, a bargain, one might say,
Parking, plentiful, a convenience, beyond a doubt.
Music, pleasant, and ventilation, most fair,
Food, satisfactory, and experience, generally, quite pleasant."

"My sister had bespoken work from Jessy, a skilled artisan of the needle, and spoke highly of her craftsmanship. Thus, when the time arrived for my own first tattoo, I chose to follow in her footsteps and seek out Jessy's expertise. Together, we designed a pair of matching dragonflies, each adorning a hip with graceful curves and vibrant hues. Jessy worked with haste, her touch light as a feather, and her demeanor kind and reassuring. So pleased was I with the outcome that I returned but two weeks later, seeking to replicate the design upon my other hip. This time, Jessy cleverly reversed the color scheme, creating a subtle contrast that delighted mine eyes. The studio itself was spotless, a testament to Jessy's dedication to her craft and attention to detail. Verily, 'twas a most satisfying first encounter."

"Hark! If thou dost enjoy the tunes of Billy Joel and Elton John,
And top 40 songs played on the ivories, then Bang be thy destination.
For there, thou shalt find people watching, and standing room only,
Unless thou art early, and claimeth a table, ere the crowd doth swarm.

Thou shalt sing loudly to Journey, with the drunken lass beside thee,
Whose screeching voice may pierce thine ears, and cause thee great dismay.
But fear not, for the sweat that doth pour, shall be a sign of great delight,
In this dueling piano bar, where music and mirth do reign supreme.

But lo! If thou dost hate the sounds of piano and guitar,
And drums that do accompany, then flee from Bang, my friend,
For there, thou shalt find naught but noise, and revelry that doth never end,
And thou, with thy headache and stern demeanor, shalt not fit in.

A cover charge at the door, doth await thee,
So be prepared, ere thou doth enter, this place of merriment.
But fear not, for 'tis a fun place to visit, though I wouldst not choose to dwell,
In this realm of music, laughter, and joy, that doth never truly subside."

"A fair tavern 'twas, where games were watched with glee,
And bartenders, attentive, did their duty well.
But alack, the food service, slow it did be,
Thirty minutes passed, and still no victuals couldst see.
I cancelled the order, and asked for my bill,
For such delay, my patience couldst not fulfill."

"Alack, my hopes were high for this sandwichery,
But found instead a humble lunching place,
With ingredients of questionable worth,
And portion sizes that did not suffice.

The steak melt, with too little meat,
Didst leave me feeling incomplete,
And though the sandos sounded fair,
Their execution did not meet my glare.

For such a price, I did expect
A sandwich of true excellence,
But alas, 'twas not to be,
And thus my disappointment doth ensue."

"Thou Squirrel Hill, thy charm doth impress me sore,
More than Bangkok Balcony, I do declare.
My friend and I, upon a vegan's guide,
Didst find this place, and late it didst abide.

With ease, we found parking on the street,
And marveled at the mix of old and new,
In clothing stores, alas, most were shut tight,
But still, the wares within didst catch our sight.

The layout of BB, modern and sleek,
Didst please mine eyes, and all was neat.
The flatware, too, didst win our praise,
A detail oft ignored, in verse I raise.

Tofu dishes, plenty, and spice, they didst ask,
On a scale of one to ten, my taste to task.
Fair prices, too, for such a busy place,
With decorations fine, and packed with grace.

Thai food, my heart doth sing, my love so true,
This place, three stars, my rating, anon, I do.
For though it pleased, our bellies, later, didst ache,
A minor quibble, in this culinary tale, I make."

"A choice table, by the window, they didst give,  
With view of Strip, and parking lot, most plain.  
Yet, in the distance, fair Eiffel Tower doth stand,  
A sight most wondrous, and a romantic's gain.  
\n\nDrinks, of cocktail sort, they didst serve,  
Most delectable, and worthy of our purse.  
But, alas, the music, on the other side,  
Didst make us choose, between the two, most dire.  
Either the view, or music, we couldst not share,  
A pity, indeed, and cause for some despair.  
\n\nThe crowd, mostly pairs, of mature sort,  
Didst fill the room, with naught but gentle sport.  
I sought to meet new folk, and laugh with glee,  
But, alas, the atmosphere, didst not agree.  
One drink, we had, and then, didst take our leave,  
For though 'twas nice, 'twas not the place to grieve."

"A frozen hot chocolate, I didst procure,  
To sate my thirst and warm my soul.  
The wait, it was a lengthy one, I must confess,  
Yet, the drink itself, didst make amends.  
'Twas rich and creamy, with a flavor so divine,  
That I wouldst have it once again, in a heartbeat, 'twine.  
For though the price, didst seem a bit steep,  
I found it worth it, in the end, to sleep.  
And thus, I shall return, to try their fare,  
And see if their dishes, be as fair and rare."

"A hearty breakfast, fit for a king,
Eggs, spuds, bacon, and coffee, we bring.
A steep price, twenty-two dollars, we pay,
For a meal that's quite decent, in a way.

An entree of ten dollars, a cup of joe,
Three bucks, and orange juice, you know.
A side of hash browns, plate-sized, no less,
Six dollars, a price that's quite excessive, I guess.
