Now, compare this to Waffle House, my friend,
Twice the food, for half the price, it does end.
Better coffee, in fact, they do serve,
A better value, you'll surely deserve.

In conclusion, good but not great,
Overpriced by twenty-five percent, that's quite a feat."

"Methinks 'twas but a mediocre feast,
This place they call Price's, where wings be quest.
From Maryland, I came to Charlotte's land,
In May of 2012, with eager hand.
Their wings, alack, were small, O woe is me!
But tater tots, a delight, didst set me free.
A memory of youth, a taste so sweet,
Yet, wings from home, more satisfying eat.
Price's, farewell, thy name doth leave my lips,
For better wings, my heart doth now equip."

"Fare thee well, good sir! The victuals here be passable, 'Tis the sole establishment near that doth provide sustenance swift and fair. At Mandala Bay, my lodging lay, And thither didst I stroll to partake of their fare."

"Hark, what news is this? A Korean BBQ place doth move
Into the old McDonald's store, a sight most strange.
I was filled with excitement, for I had heard
Their food was good and priced most fairly.

But alas, my hopes were dashed, for when I went
To try their wares, I found them overpriced.
Seven to nine dollars, oh how much it stung!
For fast food, it seemed a bit too high.

But still, I tried their Bulgogi, with steamed
Vegetables and kimchi, and oh how grand
It tasted, with the sweetness of the dish
Complimented by the garlic and spice.

I long to try their Mandu and tempura too,
But fear doth creep in, for I have seen
The heat lamps under which they sit, and so
I wonder how fresh they truly be.

And yet, I shall return, for I have heard
They've added Boba tea, a drink most rare.
And though the prices may be high, I hope
That as they grow, they'll lower their cost."

"Methinks 'twas not so bad, my dear. Forsooth, I am not of the ilk who doth frequent the nightlife of Old Town Scottsdale, but on a Friday, twelve of my fair friends and I didst venture to The Mint for Happy Hour. And verily, the victuals were most excellent! The potions, too, were good, and the half-price made them quite reasonable. The interior, I must confess, was quite cool, but alas, the co-ed bathroom didst strike me as strange and unpleasant. The servers, though comely and friendly, didst seem a mite inexperienced. Our server, a sweet maiden, didst struggle with our large group, and the matter of separate checks didst cause some confusion. Yet, I wouldst return for another Happy Hour, and perchance, explore the outdoor bar."

"Hark, what place is this? A haven for revelry,  
With artwork grand and televisions large as can be.  
Upstairs, games of skill and chance do abide,  
A haven for those who delight in fun and pride.  
The outdoor patio, a haven for those who smoke,  
A place to gather, laugh, and partake.  
On Sundays, folk do congregate to witness the game,  
And though they may not serve victuals, 'twas plain to see  
A feast of wings, a bounty for all to enjoy,  
A generous spread, with no need to employ.  
Local brews they offer, a delightful find,  
And parking nearby, a convenience of the mind."

"Methinks 'twas not as wondrous as some folk did claim,
With four and five stars, they did loudly exclaim.
Good, indeed, yet not the finest burger e'er,
And for six tens, I didst feel somewhat queer.
Aye, verily, my lovely lass doth concur,
Our expectations, alas, were not quite sure.
Three stars, I say, a fair and honest rating,
For though 'twas good, 'twas not entirely satisfying."

"Alack, how different from its fame,
This Canyon Ranch doth bear a name,
In books and reviews, a place of bliss,
But in truth, a disappointment doth miss.

Over-priced, and small, compared to The Venetian's spa,
And naught but an expensive energy massage, they do offer,
Without touch, a strange and puzzling thing,
Leaves me to ponder, and my heart doth sing.

Not my first choice, I must confess,
For better value, elsewhere I shall address."

"My spouse and I did dine at yonder tavern,
And ordered dishes from their common fare.
Their drinks were priced quite reasonably, I must say,
But alas, the burgers we had were but dull.

The Gladiator and Daily Dose, they lacked zest,
And the mushroom brie, oh how it failed to impress.
Our server, Hope, did train another dame,
But spoke to her with scorn and disdain.

She said, 'Do not ask questions, for she's new,
And knows not what to do.' Oh, woe is me!
I too have served, and such words would vex,
For they do show a lack of courtesy and respect."

"Methinks all Apple stores, by Jove, do boast
Of ample space, good lighting, and fine display.
Their wares, so neatly arranged, do catch the eye,
And friendly service doth abound, by day.

But, alas, their prices, oh how steep!
For what they offer, 'tis a king's ransom, yeep!
So, dear Apple enthusiasts, take heed,
And know that better deals may be found, with speed.

And thus, I pray, if thou hast coin to spare,
Do consider donating, without a care.
For those who lavish wealth, 'tis a noble deed,
To share thy riches, and spread joy, indeed.

Eat, drink, and make merry, friends, 'tis the season,
To revel in mirth, and let good times roll, with reason."

In sooth, the victuals were of fair quality,
With choice enough to sate thy appetite.
But, alack, the ambiance didst lack,
That je ne sais quoi, that doth make night bright.
'Twas not a lively place, I do confess,
Especially for Vegas, where mirth doth reign supreme.
Yet, praise the gods, a Groupon didst aid,
And made the cost, a goodly sum indeed.
For otherwise, o'er-priced, 'twould have been deemed.

"Airpark, a detailing service of fair renown,
Didst perform their duties with skill and care,
For a price most reasonable, a sum of $150,
Their work, though not outstanding, was beyond compare.

Danny's, a rival detailer of ill repute,
Could never hope to match the quality found,
In Airpark's work, a true bargain, no doubt,
Their prices, too steep, a whopping $250, alas!

In this fair town, I have seen detailers,
Whose work surpassed Airpark's, in truth,
But their prices, oh so high, near $250,
A king's ransom, for a service, scarce worth the fee.

So, if thou seeketh a detailing, fair and bright,
With a price that doth not break the bank,
Airpark, a choice most wise, doth shine so bright,
In this realm of detailers, a true gem, a paragon of might."

"Hark! This Panda Express, a drive-thru doth possess,
A boon indeed, when sun doth beat with fierce oppression.
I stepped within, and swiftly didst they serve,
My craving for a meal, without the need to swerve.

Alas! The orange chicken, Beijing beef, a woe,
Dried up and lacking sauce, a sorry state, I do declare.
Yet still, 'twas Panda Express, no surprise,
Average fare, without the need to open eyes."

"Methinks, fair sir, thou art oft found In this, the city of sin and sound, Where gambling and revelry do reign supreme. But mark thee well, forsooth, If thy skin doth bear the hue of snow, Thou mayst find that certain dishes be Tainted with a heavy hand, to suit thy taste, Without a word, or so much as a trace Of query, ere they do present the feast. A case in point, my friend, doth lie In yonder pho, a dish most divine, Which, on a recent visit, did arrive With naught but scraps of meat, and nary a slice Of tripe or tendon, to make up the lack. No, they did not proffer more of the rest, To fill the void, and make the dish complete."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy for Galaxy Luxury's splendor! Yet, alas, at times, my chariot doth not convey me thither, nor doth the theater provide sufficient seats for the cinematic spectacle I wish to behold. \n\nBut fear not, dear friends, for Brenden doth offer solace in its cozy embrace. The staff, with manners most courteous, doth ensure a pleasant experience, and prices, fair and reasonable, doth not break the bank."

"Alas, my dear friend, how fares Mamma Mia's reach? A mere 0.7 miles, a distance too great, alack! Their online system doth declare, 'Tis not enough, thou art too far away, East of 20th or West of 64th, North of Washington or South of Lincoln, nay, 'tis a journey too long, a drive most foul. Yet fear not, fair sir, for their pizza, though distant, doth remain most delectable, a treat worth the toil, a slice most divine."

"Hark, fair maiden! This review doth be of a place most wondrous,
A Mexican restaurant, where salsa doth flow like a fountain.
The portions, they are big, and the salsa bar, it doth shine,
But alas, the decor, it doth show its age, like a withered vine.
I would give it four stars, but alas, the looks, they do deceive,
For in this place, the food, it doth make up for the lack of sheen."

"Hark, a teriyaki bowl place doth catch mine eye,  
A stones throw from Midwestern, 'tis nigh.  
A fan of Flamebroiler, I do confess,  
And seek a place that doth serve a similar mess.  
Rice bowls, a meal most quick, cheap, and fine,  
For Asian and Indian folk, a wondrous find.  
I tried their Cayman, a combo of two dishes,  
Fiji and Singapore curry, both quite delish.  
The Fiji, slow-cooked chuck roast in teriyaki sauce,  
Good, but a bit tough, alack, in truth.  
Singapore curry, with chicken and carrots,  
In a Japanese curry, a hint of sour notes.  
The chicken, stringy, slow-cooked, I did not prefer,  
But overall, my meal was good, and served in a generous portion.  
The price, a mere five bucks, a steal, indeed,  
Less, even, if thou dost order but a single dish.  
Their menu, unique, and different from the rest,  
Away from the usual teriyaki beef or chicken crest.  
A 10% discount for Midwestern students, a boon,  
I shall return, and try their crab puffs and egg rolls anon."

"Hark! A tale of feast and revelry, my friends,
At Trader Vic's, where we did partake,
Of lobster, shrimp, and duck, oh so fine,
In a banquet room, with hula dancers divine.

Eve, Trader Vic's granddaughter, did grace,
Our presence, and showed us the unfinished place,
With executive chef Rick Giffen, of renown,
Whose culinary skills, did our taste astound.

Alas, the decor, a single star didst claim,
But fear not, for VR helmets, may yet proclaim,
The virtues of this Trader Vic's Lounge, so bright,
Akin to those in Beverly Hills, a wondrous sight.

And though the Polynesio, in Havanna, a tale,
Of its own, this Trader Vic's, did our spirits sail."

"A fine hotel chamber, yet pricy, alack!
I visited thither on Memorial Day eve,
With friends, and found the room quite fair,
Yet, for each small luxury, they did charge.

For a bed, a mere $20 per night, they'd say,
And the fridge, a fee, lest ye wish to play.
But, 'twas in a prime location, near the Strip,
Where Rehab, a concert, doth take its grip.

Drake and Wayne, they did perform, I heard,
But, alas, the line, long, and tickets scarce,
Doubled in price, and sold out fast,
A two-hour wait, at least, to pass the test.

The casino, restaurants, and nightclub, too,
Did offer diversions, for me and you.
Yet, on my next visit, I may choose to stray,
To other hotels, or a less busy day."

"Methought we started with Waffle Fry Nachos,
Doused in gooey white cheddar and sloppy joe,
And topped with salsa and jalapenos, no less.
'Twas delicious, yet next time, I'd ask thee,
Kitchen, to hold the sloppy joe, I pray.
For I wouldst not miss the meat, verily.

I hadst the Crispy Four Cheese Burger,
With cheese fried crisp onto the patty,
A cheesy concoction, crisp and creamy.
Aside from the brioche bun, 'twas tasty,
Well seasoned, I didst think. But, alack,
The bun, too much bread for the burger, made it dry.
An onion roll, a better choice, methinks.

My husband, his BYOB, didst select,
Beef patty with pepper jack cheese, jalapenos,
Caramelized onions, all on the onion roll.
'Twas well prepared, flavorful, and juicy,
Indeed, a tasty dish, methought.

But, alas, the service, slow it was,
The place, but newly opened, we didst see.
Most places, need a little time, to work out kinks,
I do hope, service doth improve, with time, anon."

Steve's Greenhouse Grill, a place most wondrous,
With A-OK fare, and atmosphere quite sportive,
Like Cracker Barrel, but without the backing,
And with a design scheme that's quite kitsch and tacky.

Loud colors, loud TVs, and ads for strong drink,
A menu vast and varied, with something for everyone to think,
Bar menu, overpriced, but servers full of cheer,
Singing praises of each dish, with nary a speck of fear.

Chicken fried steak, with fries, my meal did make,
Kristen G., her choice, fish and chips, with clam chowder to partake.
All was well, some salt, some just right, some bland,
But still, a place most worthy, of thy hard-earned pound.

So, take Cracker Barrel, cut budget by three,
And tell the manager, all patrons to please, thee,
In Phoenix, this place, doth fit the bill,
Steve's Greenhouse Grill, doth stand, most fulfilling still.

"In this fair city, where eateries abound,
We watched with bated breath as Central Bistro rose,
Its ambiance, a joyous blend of noise and cheer,
With windows open wide, the breeze did stir.

The victuals, delectable, our taste buds did thrill,
And service, prompt and friendly, did fulfill,
But lo, a problem great, our eyes did see,
Bartenders prepping garnish, barehanded, 'twas to be.

An orange, peeled with juice that ran like rain,
Sliced up and used in drinks, a sight most plain,
And olives, plucked from jar with nary a care,
Did make us shudder, and our martini, bare.

Oh, Central Bistro, dear, take heed of this,
Ere Maricopa's inspectors do descend, 'tis wise.
Get thy house in order, lest thou suffer shame,
And lose the patronage of Phoenix's noble name."

"Hark! In fair downtown Phoenix, I didst seek
A place to dine where old homes didst speak.
And lo, I found Coronado Cafe, a spot
Wherein I couldst indulge in victuals hot.

A workday it was, and thus, I didst order
But one dish, lest I appear a glutton.
The roasted chicken sandwich, oh how grand,
With potato salad, a tasty second hand.

The bar, though small, didst seat us comfortably,
And spirits, wine, didst tempt me sorely.
Alas, I couldst not partake, for duty called,
But shall, anon, when next I visit this hall.

The chicken, moist and flavorful, didst please,
And potato salad, a satisfying tease.
A simple, hearty meal, fit for a king,
I shall return, when busy-ness doth cease.

For now, I bid thee farewell, dear cafe,
Until we meet again, in cooler clime,
When cozy seats outside, shaded from sun's rays,
Shall beckon me, and thou shalt be mine."

"Methinks I must concur with Pierre and Donald, fair gents,
Two dishes on the menu, worth the order, I do reckon.
Lettuce wedge, a tasty treat, and Willy burger, oh so fine,
But steaks, alas, are not worth thy time, my friend,
For seasoning, overpowering, doth make it hard to dine.
And cook, dear sir, dost thou know the difference 'twixt
Med rare and well? A vast disparity, I do declare,
For when I asked for rib-eye, med rare, lo and behold,
A hockey puck, most unappetizing, didst appear.
Yet, bread, when hot, doth please, and wrap-up burgers, too,
Lettuce wedge, a delight, doth make my day anew."

"Verily, I didst enjoy this place, my dear friend. On a Sunday, we didst venture forth to partake in their culinary delights. And, by the stars, we didst sample a bit of all they had to offer. Alas, the service was poor, forsooth, the server seemed in a foul mood. Yet, despite this, I wouldst still recommend thou visit this establishment, for the victuals were most satisfying. Just beware, fair traveler, that there be no indoor seating, and thou mayst wish to find a place to dine ere thou purchasest thy poke, lest thou suffereth from the heat of the Las Vegas sun."

"Fair priced victuals, they do serve herein,
We chanced upon this place mid-week, forsooth,
Upon the morn, our hunger to assuage,
And sampled dishes, of which we had heard tell.

A fortunate hour, we came, forsooth,
No waiting, we didst endure, nor tarry,
The server, kind and swift, didst attend,
Our needs, with grace and gentle demeanor.

A varied menu, there didst abound,
Our choice, didst cause some puzzlement, profound,
Jamm's French Toast, my selection, didst make,
My spouse, an omelette, didst partake.

The fare, middling, I must confess,
Perhaps, our choices, not the best, alas,
Yet would I return? Nay, I do fear,
For other morn, in Las Vegas, we shall hear."

"Hark, what changes have been made, my dear!
The entrance, once a grueling climb, doth now
Conveniently deposit thee on a random floor,
Where thou must navigate through a concert's din,
And up a flight of stairs, to reach the dance floor's shore.

But lo, the dance floor itself, so small and cramped,
Doth leave me wanting more, and the crowds, they do
Block out the view, so one cannot even see
The floor, where all the revelry doth come to be.

And thus, I say, this place doth lack the flair
Of TAO, where one could dance and breathe with ease,
For here, the design doth seem to be so bare,
And comfort, it doth not provide, alas, my friend,
So back to XS, I shall return, for there, at least,
I can enjoy the night, without such discomfort and unrest."

"Upon a Sunday eve, with friends I didst stroll,
Into a place of victuals, where we didst dine.
A smallish room, yet cozy, with heat outdoors,
A menu vast, with choices manifold.
Each of us chose a dish, but lo, the portions great,
Didst fill our table, making meal-time quite a feat.
Beware, dear friends, lest ye be overcome,
By sauces rich, and servings most generous.
Tea, in a metal dish, didst come to us,
And though the fare was heavy, I didst find it tasty.
Alas, the service, left a bit to be desired,
Yet still, a night of joy, with friends, I didst acquire."

"Pizza most excellent, service most vile.
The maiden at the till, with skin as dark as night,
Didst ignore my presence, and with rudeness didst reply,
When I didst ask if I should sit, she didst roll her eyes in scorn.

A youth, with fiery locks, didst greet me with a smile,
And he who crafted pies, didst say 'thank ye' in style.
But lo, the pair didst engage in bitter strife,
As she didst shout at him, and he didst take his life.

This place, so foul and dirty, with tables all awry,
I couldst not find a seat, save one that didst make me sigh.
My pizza, from a pie that lay upon a stool,
Was tossed within the oven, with haste most cruel.

Good pizza, yes, but service, oh so poor,
I pray they mend their ways, and customer service adore."

"Hark! My dearest wife doth crave red velvet cupcakes,
And so we stopped here for a sweet treat.
But lo! The selection was quite limited, alas,
On this fair Sunday afternoon, so neat.

Each cupcake doth cost three golden coins,
A price not too steep for gourmet sweets, I reckon.
But verily, the frosting did o'erflow,
And the caramel upon mine own did not meet my expectations, I do confess.
The red velvet ones, alas, did lack cream cheese frosting,
A fact that did dampen my spirits, I must admit.

Yet still, a pleasant dessert it did provide,
For those with a sweet tooth, it doth abide."

"A fair eatery within Phoenix's aerial hub,
Where kind service, pleasant ambiance, and tasty victuals are nigh.
I, a traveler weary from my journey's length,
Didst partake of their grilled fowl-filled pita, rich in garnish and sauce.
Their plugs, too, didst provide a convenient charge,
For devices that require an electrical discharge.
Verily, a fine dining experience, indeed,
In this airport oasis, all needs are heeded."

"Fair club, indeed, with beauty to behold,
Where men doth gather, and women doth unfold.
A night it was, when trade show came to town,
And men, they doth outnumber women, by a count of renown.
Fifty to one, the ratio didst seem,
A sight to behold, a scene most queer.
But still, the drinks didst flow, and merriment didst reign,
With friends, colleagues, and models, a joyous refrain.
The club, it doth have flaws, with drinks watered down,
And prices, they doth climb, like a mountebank's crown.
Yet, would I return? Aye, I wouldst say,
If entry doth not require, a secret way."

"Methought I sought the finest Peking duck in all the land,
And thus my search did end at Blossom's door.
The server said 'twas two days' preparation time,
And so my hopes were high, as was the price, $79.

Ay, I had tasted Peking duck of finest sort,
In Beijing's restaurants, where 'tis oft devoured.
The duck they served, with skin and meat and sauce,
Wrapped up in pancakes, did my senses ravish.

But here, alas! The skin was not crisp enough,
The sauce, though passable, did not quite suffice.
They brought the fowl back, chopped, and then did serve,
The meat was juicy, but a strange smell did preserve.

In So Cal, Duck House and others may pale,
But Blossom's Peking duck doth not compare,
To that which I did taste in Beijing's hale,
For twice the price, I did expect more fare."

"Ever fair, my dear. Pasta dish, pass thou by. Disappointment doth reign. 

A Pizzookie, half-cooked, they do proclaim. Alas, 'twas raw, scarce twenty percent tamed. 

I spoke to our waiter, Thomas, a poor soul, of this faux pas. He shrugged and walked away, his duty fled. Ill service, indeed. 

My rating, once four or five stars bright, doth now descend. Mayhap, another time, the service shall be worth the fight."

Thou hast arrived upon a Thursday eve,
And found, to thy delight, no wait didst grieve.
Their feast didst include dishes of finest fare,
Fish, fowl, and beasts, all cooked with care.
But thou, my friend, didst choose a lighter course,
A summer menu, with sandwiches, pasta, and force.
Thy appetizer, chicken wings, didst please,
Prepared in manner strange, yet tasty, if thou dost seize.
Italian cuisine, a favorite of thine,
Didst cause great strife, betwixt pasta and pizza divine.
Thou didst select, alas, the wrong dish,
A bolognese, with penne, lacking in finesse.
The taste, unremarkable, the presentation, poor,
Leaving thee unsatisfied, and craving more.
Yet, service was good, and pizzas, a sight to see,
Perhaps, another time, thou shalt try, mayhap, thee shall agree.

"Hark, good sirs, I doth proclaim myself a herbivore,
And sipper of light ale, by virtue of my peers.
Forsooth, our gathering doth frequent Alchemy's door,
Whereupon I find solace in their expanded fare.

Aye, Portobello's bounty doth delight mine taste,
Yet oft I yearn for more, lest my meals be plain.
The maize salad, a feast fit for a king, doth sate,
But alas, their new menu doth venture too far afield.

Southeast Asian cuisine, a delicacy most fine,
Alchemy doth attempt, yet doth not quite divine.
Their Vietnamese Rice Noodle Salad, a dish most vile,
Beware, dear friends, and shun it with a steadfast smile."

"A fair enough tavern, good for a merry meet,  
Or swinging by for supper, should thou so incline.  
But, alas! The drinks, they do come at a steep cost,  
And the victuals, they leave much to be desired, I find.  
The sandwiches, o'er salted, and the meat, not so fresh,  
Yet, if thou art but seeking ale or sport, 'tis a pleasant place to bide.  
And on karaoke nights, mirth doth reign supreme,  
So gather thy friends, and join in the jolly scheme."

"Hark, what news is this? A haven for the youth,
Where tea, once dull, now doth excite and unite.
In this, their HQ, all things are bright and gay,
Contrasting the dank, somber tea houses of old.
My thoughts on this place do change with each visit,
As does the tide, and fortune's whimsical bent.
At first, a youngling didst tell me to seek
Online, the answers to my queries, perchance to flee.
But later, kind employees didst lavish me
With the "DavidsTea experience", in all its glee.

A choice of teas, for home or to carry,
Doth await, with prices, some might deem too dear.
Yet, I chose a chocolate-orange blend,
With whisked soy milk and agave, to make amends.
Alas, the cost, four dollars and a half,
Didst make my heart sink, like tea leaves in a draught.
And alack, the brew that didn't fit the cup,
Didst meet its fate, in a sink, with nary a frown.

Was it good? Aye, 'twas epic, beyond compare,
But expensive, too, as some might declare.
This shop, for a quick caffeine fix, doth serve,
Yet, cramped it doth become, and a glass kettle, hard to preserve."

"Hark! What news is this? A thrifty rental car,
With service swift and sure, doth now avail.
A nail, most wicked, did attach itself
Unto my tire, rear and right, with stealth.
But fear not, for the roadside aid did come,
In five short minutes, swift as summer's wind.
And lo, the customer service, so bright,
Didst shine with excellence, in corporate light.
The car, exchanged in haste, did take but thirty minutes,
And I, the chooser, didst pick the new conveyance.
Methinks they heeded my words, with diligence,
For service now, doth seem, in fair improvement."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from mine own lips,
Of a hotel stay that did my patience test.
'Twas earlier this year, on business I did stray,
And found myself within these walls, a guest.

The check-in, oh how slow it did proceed,
As if the procedure were of ancient creed.
And when a delivery I didst require,
It came not swiftly, but with much delay and blunder.

I didst not partake in the restaurants' fare,
But chose instead a cafe, with pastries so fair and rare.
Yet, after a pair of days, the Frenchness didst wear,
And I didst find myself in search of something more to share.

The room, it was a bit above the rest,
But still, the hotel left me feeling quite depressed.
I would not choose to stay here again,
For pleasure's sake, my friends, I do declare."

In this place, I didst venture forth to seek
If they didst possess any antenna balls,
But alas, they were not in stock, I didst hear,
And knew not when they wouldst be available again.
A picture they didst show me, to ease my mind,
But nay, 'twas not enough, my doubts to unwind.

Whilst there, I didst partake in a Jumbo Jack,
A tasty morsel, which didst give me back
My craving for JITB, a flavor so rare,
In Canada, alack, I cannot find it there.

"Twas not my fancy, this eating house,
In Scottsdale Quarter, a place of trend.
Fox-like, it seemed, in menu and in taste,
With dishes plain, and portion sizes scant.

A roasted chicken, I did order, fair,
But lo, a meager thigh and drumstick there.
Sodden spinach, too, and runny polenta,
Did make my meal a disappointment, verily.

Creative, indeed, the dishes did appear,
But flavor, alas, did lack, I do declare.
Confusion reigned among the serving folk,
Mistakes abounded, as if in some jest.

This place, I shall not seek again,
For better fare, my heart doth yearn and pain."

"Fair Chinese victuals, fit for a king,
Their Lo Mein, a dish most wondrous, doth sing.
Shrimp and beef, both cooked to perfection,
A feast for the taste, a joyous obsession.
But alas, their shrimp and lobster sauce,
Doth leave much to be desired, in truth, a cause.
Ribs, a gamble, fatty or lean,
A chance taken, a risk, a culinary scene.
Won ton, egg drop soup, a disappointment,
A letdown, a shame, a culinary accident.
Fried rice, a staple, a delight,
A dish most fair, a pleasure, a true sight."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, I didst venture to the first establishment in Fort Lauderdale, and by the stars, 'twas a wondrous experience! The victuals, they didst astound, and the atmosphere, it didst enchant. Alas, this place, it doth not compare, in sooth, 'twas a disappointment. A busy Wednesday eve in Florida, 'twas a quiet Monday night in Vegas, and we, but five tables occupied the tranquil space at eight o'clock. Forgive me, fair reader, for I do confess, methought the meatballs, dry they were, and pasta, undercooked, alack! The chicken parmesan, good, but naught more than passable, the sauce, still, most excellent. 

Marry, I find it passing strange, that near all praiseworthy reviews of this place do speak of Steve's presence. Mayhap his absence did affect the fare? Our server, kind and diligent, the grub, alas, did not meet expectations, set by...his own hand. Thus, three stars, I shall bestow, and though my hunger be sated, my heart doth yearn for the Florida site, where Steve doth reign, and all doth prosper."

"Hark! Gave Chang's another chance, and lo,
The service was improved, I must avow.
Friendly and efficient, they did strive,
And thus, my heart doth now forgive.

The Salt and Pepper Prawns we did share,
And Shrimp Fried Rice, a dish most fair.
Their food, though not the greatest, doth please,
And thus, my taste buds doth appease.

But alas, the service, once a woe,
Now doth shine, and all my doubts doth go.
A fortunate turn, indeed, doth bring,
And thus, my visits shall now cling.

Aye, even the fortune cookie, once bare,
Now doth contain a message, though quite rare.
A saying on a little piece of paper,
A small delight, yet still a treasure to capture."

"Methinks the ornamentation of this establishment doth seal the deal forsooth. 'Tis a temple of Mid Century modernity, and the fare provided within its hallowed walls doth please mine eyes and taste buds alike. In sooth, the privy booths wherein we sit do make our converse seem most intimate and exclusive. The chopped salad, verily, doth reign supreme amongst mine order, forsooth, for I do adore it passing well. And, by the gods, the green goddess dressing doth complement it most divinely. Moreover, the rolls and butter served forth do seem a genuine relic of yore, soft, warm, and most delectable. Mayhap, perchance, I do confess a certain fondness for iced tea, and, lo, how pleased I am by its presentation here! A mighty goblet, fresh mint, a sideline of simple syrup for sweetening, and an iced tea spoon, all these doth combine to elevate mine enjoyment. Alas, I know not if 'tis still available, yet the cake and shake for dessert, aye, 'twas a diminutive chocolate shake accompanied by a tiny chocolate cake, a most exquisite and satisfying sweetmeat, in sooth."

"A family restaurant, dull and uninspired,
The food, mediocre, the service, tired.
My pad, once crispy, now burnt to a crisp,
I'll not be eating there, no need to grip."

"Fair sir, the victuals here be good, yet lacking in quality compared to other noble steakhouses in this fair city. Prices, alas, do match those of superior establishments, and thus, my expectations run high. Alas, they be not fully met. Were the cost not of such note, I might return, for 'tis still a worthy meal. But nay, I shall choose to spend my coin at places known for excellence, like City Hall, where diversity in dishes doth make a pleasant change. Steaks, though good, doth not reach lofty heights, and all dishes seem of equal worth. Mayhap, one day, this place shall rise to greater heights, and I shall return, hoping for improvement."

In this place, thou shalt find treasures both fair and foul,
A haven for thy purse, yet beware of the toll.
I purchased a trinket for my mother, a token of love,
A keychain of worth, for the price of twelve dollars above.
But alas, 'twas a curse, for it broke in her hand,
And twice it did fail, like a fleeting dream in the land.
I returned it with haste, and didst receive a card in exchange,
For cash was the payment, and no receipt could I arrange.
This shop, a gamble it be, with goods of varying worth,
Yet park thy steed with ease, within Tivoli's girth.

"Near to the light rail, a humble abode,  
Thai Rama, a place unassuming, yet bold.  
A fan of Thai cuisine, my heart doth sing,  
But worries crept in, as we drew nigh.  
The menu, vast and varied, a feast for the eyes,  
F.B.I., a dessert, my taste buds did surprise.  
Friend bananas, coconut ice cream, a sweet delight,  
My comrade's shrimp pineapple curry, a savory sight.  
The dishes arrived swiftly, a minute apart,  
The ice cream, a tad too frozen, yet still a work of art.  
The curry, flavorful, the temperature just right,  
But alas, the pineapple, canned, lacked bite.  
A pleasant staff, their hospitality, so bright,  
Yet, I may not venture far, to dine here tonight."

"'Tis the crew, my dear, that doth make this shop thrive!
Their diligence and care, they do not leave untried.
Above and beyond, they strive with each task they take,
Their service, a rarity, doth make my heart sing and shake."

"Hark! This Dairy Queen doth be the nearest to mine abode,
And thus, my brother and I do frequent this place with haste.
We doth enjoy their shakes and blizzards, and on special days,
Their ice cream cakes doth bring us joy in a most wondrous way.

But alas! The folk who work here doth leave much to be desired,
For they doth possess a surly demeanor, full of disdain and ire.
Yet still, I doth endure their rudeness, for the food doth make amends,
And thus, four stars doth this establishment receive from mine hand."

"In days of yore, thou couldst stroll into Uncle Sal's on a Friday eve, sans reservation, and be seated straightaway. Alas, those halcyon days are now but a distant memory, forsooth! \n

Verily, I didst coordinate dinner, yet failed miserably in mine endeavor. Hark! The Blind Pig, a nearby establishment, didst save the day, and we four famished patrons were quickly seated and served. \n

We shared dishes, and sampled each other's fare. The steak salad, a triumph! Short ribs, cooked to perfection, and all else, merely adequate. Alas, my trio of tacos, unremarkable, save for their freshness and execution. \n

Anon, if fate doth lead me to the Blind Pig, I shan't protest. Yet, I fear not, for in my present domain, other eateries hold greater allure."

"Upon our arrival, late y'night, this place didst still remain open, serving those who sought sustenance.  Alas, service was slow, yet forgivable, given the hour and number of guests.  My memory doth fail me, alack, regarding the dish I didst consume, but 'twas most likely a steak, if my taste buds do not deceive me.  But lo, the true delight of the repast lay in the refreshing cup of watermelon juice they didst serve, most generously.  Although the pace of service was somewhat tardy, the demeanor of the staff remained cordial and courteous.  Prices, indeed, didst border on the excessive for a humble cafe, yet in keeping with the opulence of Aria itself.  Later, we didst discover the room service, the buffet, and ultimately, the local fare, to spare our purses.  Not poor, but not worth the cost, alas."

"A plate of breakfast potatoes, au gratin, doth please,
With vegetable chow mein, a wondrous sight.
Cover all with melted butter, a most excellent treat,
And thou shalt see why terrorists do hate this land so bright.

The place was neat, the service fair,
The food, a plenty, as expected there.
But that great vat of melted butter, oh how grand,
'Tis the perfect topping for each dish in this land."

"Hark! This tavern beckons thee, my friend,
After a night of revelry and ale.
The victuals served within are plain,
Yet satisfying, as the hunger doth wane.

Aye, 'twas the drive-thru that didst impress,
Quick and efficient, with nary a mess.
But lo, the portion size of my fries,
Didst leave me in a state of dismay and surprise.

Forsooth, the Carne Asada, once a hearty dish,
Was now but a mere morsel, a paltry wish.
I pray, dear tavern, that thou mayst reconsider,
And grant thy patrons a more generous portion, ere they surrender.

Yet still, I shall return, in hopes anew,
To find a better fate, and a heartier brew."

"Aye, naught too wondrous didst I find,
In this place they call a 'fast food joint'.
Burgers, fair and juicy, yet not divine,
Onion rings, crispy and tasty, didst shine.
Price, alack, didst sting like a bee,
For what it was, in Vegas' glee."

"Food and service, both did please,
No qualms, nor grievances to seize,
In Vegas, burgers of better breed,
At prices more fair, thou shalt find indeed."

Amidst my humble abode and parents' dwelling,
This place doth lie, and oft I do attend.
My daughters twain and I, our orders doth make,
In this spot, a challenge 'tis, to make amends.
The staff doth change, and with each new face,
The service doth fluctuate, in its place.
Despite this, still I come, for convenience' sake,
And mornings, long lines doth the crowd partake.
Yet, swiftly they doth move, the patrons through,
And when I've sent drinks back, their apologies doth flow.

"Upon a Friday eve, I chanced to stray
Into this place, where people doth play
Their revelry, with mirth and glee
Amidst the din, a merry spree

The drinks, they did flow freely
And bartender, he did ply me
With concoctions of his art
Yet, alas, one drink did depart
From expectation, a trifle strange
The three wise men, he did not arrange

But fear not, for the music did play
A lively tune, to banish dismay
The DJ, he did spin his wheel
With skill and grace, did he reveal
His craft, a wondrous delight
To stir the crowd, in joyful sight

Yet, tacos, I did not partake
For those, my taste did not awake
But still, this place, I shall not shun
For drinks and music, it hath won"

"Into the OFM, we didst stroll, without a wait, part of the Westin Hotel's domain. The decor, quite pleasant to behold, yet the patrons, elsewhere they didst roam. Our server, most helpful and kind, suggestions didst give, for sushi rolls, a fine place to begin. Two tuna-based rolls, mild and spicy, didst satisfy. The cioppino, a dish of note, with mahi, cooked well, yet presentation, a stew it didst not make. Caesar salad, with anchovies on high, didst please. Waluu, a Hawaiian delight, didst earn praise. Crab cakes, tasty, didst they say. The experience, relaxed and friendly, service, quite fine. But food, besides sushi, a revival doth require, to compete with newcomers, in this culinary strife."

"Methinks 'tis an improvement, this new regime,
That doth bring back the old chefs, and serveth with glee.
A visit, perchance? Aye, verily, worth thy time,
But pray, good sir, cease thy hovering, lest thou doth impede
The sushi bar's bounty, and causeth the chefs to frown.
Forsooth, 'tis a sight most curious, to behold
Thy vigilance, as if thou dost fear o'er-generosity.
Alas, dear sir, have faith in those who doth prepare
The feast, that they shall not be overly lavish, nor spare.
So, let us raise our glasses, and give thanks for this change,
And mayhap, in time, thy trust shall be restored, and all shall range."

"Hark, good sir! I pray thee, tell me what thou didst order from yonder menu, that I may partake in this feast with thee."

"Marry, kind sir, I didst request two eggs, scrambled, if thou must know, and a dish of potatoes, all for a mere $3.85, a veritable steal! And, prithee, didst they not come with a slice of toast, and a side of home fries, to boot?"

"Indeed, they didst, my good fellow. The eggs, though scrambled, were quite plain, and the toast, a trifle burnt, I must confess. But, alack! The home fries, devoid of flavor, didst leave much to be desired. A sprinkle of salt and pepper, I didst add, yet still, they didst lack zest. A few bites, I didst take, then, with a sigh, didst push them aside."

"Twas early morn, when first I didst enter this establishment, and lo, 'twas empty, save for a scattering of regulars. Low key, indeed, the atmosphere didst seem. Aye, I couldst envision, how, after a night of revelry, one might seek refuge here, within these walls, open, as they are, throughout the night."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that, save for such nocturnal adventures, I wouldst not make it a point to visit Ritters, for, alas! They do accept naught but cash, and that, a pitfall, methinks, forsooth."

"Hark! I pondered long and hard on this,
If Sunset Grille didst earn my love and bliss.
But alas, upon reflection, I didst find
That though I do enjoy it, 'tis not mine to bind.

The service there is excellent, I must confess,
And layout, quite clever, with a bar that doth impress.
But, alack! The food, it doth leave something to be desired,
For though I love breakfast sandwiches, theirs didst not inspire.

Eggs Benedict, sans Hollandaise, I didst try,
But Canadian bacon, oh so salty, didst make me sigh.
A turkey sandwich, open faced, didst taste of salt,
And black bean burger, with fries, didst leave me unmoved.

In conclusion, Sunset Grille, a place of note,
But not, alas, my favorite, for there be better quotes.
Yet still, I shall return, for service there is grand,
Though food, a letdown, save for breakfast, a true stand."

"Methinks 'tis better than Chipukele, but not by much, fair friends. The tortillas, hand-made before thine eyes, be indeed the crowning glory of this place. Sweet corn tortillas, fit for a king! Alas, the pork, too sweet it doth taste, and the shredded beef, but mediocre, I do declare. Rice and pinto beans, a feast for the gods! Verily, if Chipotle be thy only choice, choose this place, but else, 'twill soon be forgot, I fear."

"Methinks I do adore Thai victuals,
Their flavors doth delight mine taste,
But lo, the cost doth trouble me,
For portion's worth, the price doth chase.

I prayed the cook to make it not too hot,
He heeded not my words, alas,
No seasonings did he add thereto,
My meal, a blandness did pass through.

Mayhap I shall return anon,
But on my coin, I shall not spend,
For there are better deals to be had,
In this fair town, where I do dwell."

"Aye, fair traveler, let it be known,
That in this place, my hunger was shown
A chicken sandwich, not too bad, indeed,
And fried pickles, that my taste did heed.
The batter, just right, the warmth, divine,
I'd return, just for that tasty vine.
The price, fair, for an airport meal,
And free wi-fi, to make my heart reveal.
Charlotte Airport, not so bad,
This eatery, worth a visit, I am glad."

"Fare fit for a king, yet served in disarray,
With clamor and din that doth assault mine ears,
No place to rest mine eyes, for tables lay unclean,
And half the cost of PF Chang's, but dearth of cheer."

Hark! Methinks the luster of In-n-Out doth fade,
As I didst find this place to be no different made,
Than those I chanced upon in fair Califia's shade,
When youthful taste didst rule my gastronomic sway.
But now, alas! My palate doth crave more refined fare,
And though 'tis true, their burgers be decent, rare,
The hype and fame that doth surround this joint doth seem,
In truth, but empty words, a tempest in a teapot's scheme.

"Alas, my woeful state, with hangover's pall,
Did mar my visit to this famed eatery,
Where cramped seating did impede my joy,
Yet views of kitchen's bustle did assuage my sorrow.
Fare was good, but dear, thou must confess,
And early booking, else thou shalt be pressed.
Forsooth, a night ere mine own reservation,
A stranger offered me five hundred pieces,
A testament to this place's renown,
In popularity, it doth stand alone."

"Methinks 'tis a fair hotel, with virtues many and few vices.  Firstly, the breakfast, made-to-order, doth please mine eyes and stomach.  A ticket doth grant us access to the dining hall, where eggs, French toast, or pancakes, with potatoes and sausage or bacon, doth await our choosing.  And lo, a selection of cereals, oatmeal, bread, muffin, and fruit, with juice, milk, and coffee, doth round out the repast.

"The location, too, doth boast its charms.  'Tis situated close by the mall and eateries diverse, and the interstate, with ease of access, doth lie nearby.

"The chamber, spacious and well-appointed, doth provide a comfortable abode.  A kingly bed, with sleeper sofa, doth offer restful slumber, and a full refrigerator, stove, and microwave, doth make us feel at home.  Cleanliness, too, doth reign supreme within these walls.

"Alas, some drawbacks there be.  The room, upon entry, doth feel oppressively warm, and the air conditioning, though welcome, doth bring a chill too fierce.  Pillows, alas, doth lack the plumpness we desire, and two, alas, doth not suffice.  And, oh, the stairs, so steep and winding, doth pose a challenge to those with troublesome knees or burdens heavy.  An elevator, alas, doth not exist.

"Yet still, this inn doth earn our praise.  Not overly costly, nor too grand, it doth provide a pleasant sojourn for travelers weary."

"Hark! This eatery, grand and vast,
In Arizona, a place of renown,
A steakhouse, where meat doth reign supreme,
And patrons dine in luxury, it seemeth.

My friend, a server here, didst work,
His final shift, a bittersweet quirk,
For I, not fond of steakhouses, didst come,
To share this moment, and bear him company.

The atmosphere, a blast from the past,
A 70s vibe, that doth evoke the vast,
Retro feel, like an Arizona mobster's lair,
Dark, cozy, and inviting, without a care.

I ordered a shrimp salad, oh so fine,
With crunchy, juicy shrimps, a treat divine,
Saved them for last, a delightful surprise,
A culinary joy, that doth open eyes.

My roommate's sirloin, a tale of woe,
Twice sent back, a disappointment, no doubt,
But the bread basket, a saving grace,
Rosemary-topped, light, fluffy, a delightful pace.

And the best part of the night, a treat,
A beer for.5 cents, a Foursquare feat,
Our waiter, kind, a generous soul,
Didst hook us up, at the table, our goal."

"Methinks 'twas a fair day at Mandalay Bay,
Where prices for lunch were quite reasonable, I say.
And lo, the wait time for our party of ten,
Was less than ten minutes, a feat most wondrous, my friend.

The burgers, they were good, I must confess,
But after thirteen miles, all food wouldst be blessed.
Yet, alack, they were out of sweet potato fries,
A disappointment, indeed, that caused many sighs.

The service, too, was slow, I must avow,
Despite the lack of patrons, a curious thing, now.
We had to seek out servers to bring us drink,
And wait for orders, a tedious, lingering link.

Some dishes, too, were not prepared aright,
Onions added when they should not have been in sight.
Salads came after entrees, a strange, confusing course,
And some meals arrived five to eight minutes in advance,
A disarray, a chaos, a state most unfortunate,
Leaving us unsure if we'd return, in truth, anon."

"Our most recent visit to The Palm didst differ greatly from our previous ventures thither. Verily, 'twas a strange and discombobulated affair! A half-hour wait to be seated, despite our reservation at six o'clock, didst ensnare us in a web of woe. Moreover, our Club 837 privileges didst fail to materialize, thanks to some unknown glitch. In place of the customary Caesar salad, they didst present us with a puny, insignificant Small Caesar. And, alack! The lobster, which we didst anticipate with great relish, didst appear to be of a most diminutive size. Methinks 'twas not the five pounds we didst expect. Fie upon this wretched visit! I didst inquire of the staff if there hadst been any changes in the restaurant of late. A new manager, I was told, hadst taken the reins. Fear not, dear friends! We shall return, forsooth, for The Palm doth hold a special place in our hearts. Mayhap 'twas but an isolated incident, or mayhap 'twas a symptom of the growing pains which oft accompany a change in leadership. Fare thee well, dear reader! The victuals, in sooth, didst taste most delectable, and the cooking, in general, didst please our palates."

Hark! Steak and Eggs, a meal most fine,
After a night of mirth and revelry, doth shine.
A place to rest thy weary head, and fill thy belly too,
Before thou dost retire to thy hotel room anew.

The food, though cheap, doth satisfy,
And though the quality may not be the highest, 'tis nigh.
But fear not, for the wait, it doth decrease,
As those ahead of thee, do leave their place, in search of ease.

Their patience doth wear thin, as they do wait,
And nearby slot machines, do call their fate.
So put thy name on the list, and wait with glee,
For soon, thy turn shall come, and thou shalt eat with glee.

"A taro milk tea with almonds didst I order, and 'twas quite good, I must confess. But lo, the popcorn chicken didst not resemble the usual fare I hadst expected. Verily, I received a plethora of breaded morsels instead."

"Methinks 'twas my first time at Smash Em Up Burger,
And thus, the staff didst greet me with cheer.
Their words of warning, re the wait, didst ring true,
And so, I waited patiently, as one doth do.

A classic smash 1/3 pounder, mine order didst make,
Yet, alack! 'Twas not quite cooked, as I didst partake.
No query, re my preference, didst they ask,
For ten dollars, methought it a curious task.

Hot and tasty, the victuals didst prove to be,
But, alas! In appearance, not quite the spree.
For lesser coin, to Culvers, I wouldst go,
Their fare, more pleasing, doth my senses show.

Minimalist, the decor, doth seem,
Corporate, it doth feel, in sooth, a dream.
My friend, who suggested this place, didst say,
"Do they grill their burgers?" And thus, we didst play.
Eighty-twenty ground beef, their secret, doth reveal,
A bit surprising, and the grease, didst conceal.

I shall return, but, alack! 'Tis true,
Such places, numerous, doth my mind renew.
This one, not in my top five, doth rank,
For burgers, better, elsewhere, doth bank."

"Hark, what news is this? A chicken dish so fine,
It doth surpass all others of its kind.
Crispy and southern, a true delight,
A culinary masterpiece, indeed.

But alas, fair maiden, do not be fooled,
For though the food may be divine,
The service here, doth leave much to be desired,
A pox upon the staff, a woeful line.

The cashier, with looks of scorn and disdain,
Doth make one feel most unwelcome,
As if thy presence doth inconvenience them,
A sourpuss, with nary a smile to bestow.

And should thou dare to venture through the drive,
Prepare thyself for errors great and small,
For utensils, they doth forget, or orders mix,
A sorry state, indeed, and cause for alarm.

And worse still, the maiden at the window,
With acne rife, doth make one lose their appetite,
A face most uninviting, a sight most vile,
A true turnoff, and cause for flight."

On a Sunday eve, I chanced upon this place,
To watch some footy and partake of cheer,
The bar, I found, did seat me swiftly, 'twas a grace.

Now, portions here, they be of ample size,
And dishes classic, with some specials that entice,
But, alack, the victuals, middling, did not rise.

The service, woeful, left much to be desired,
Our server, Randi, sweet and pleasant, yet confused,
When time to settle score, a comped code required.

Her manager, a laggard, took an age to sort,
Thirty to forty minutes, a delay most vexing,
And, lo, he vanished, without a word, or thought.

At last, our meal, through gaming, was made free,
Yet, mark my words, this place, not for cuisine seek thee.

"Methinks some sorts of pizza do possess a flavor most divine,
Yet none doth reach the heights of true gastronomic splendor.
This place, in days of yore, didst shine with cleanliness bright,
But now, alas! 'Tis clear that management hath changed,
And service doth decline, with speed most swift and dire.
Yet still, I find the cinnamon rolls to be most sweet,
And so, I return, to sate my craving, time and again."

"'Tis a tiny, cramped space, full of folk,
Serving dishes cheap, yet mediocre, at best.
A place of little note, save for the throngs
That gather there, their pennies to expend.

But, alas! The praise it doth receive,
Doth far exceed its worth, in my opinion.
For though the fare be fair, 'tis naught but grease,
And the atmosphere, most uninviting.

So, if thou seekest sustenance of quality,
Best look elsewhere, lest thou be sorely vexed.
For this place, though full of life and bustle,
Doth fall short of true culinary delight."

"Alack, good sir or madam, hast thou naught to do upon a summer's eve? Fear not, for there is sport afoot! The Hounds, a team of lacrosse, doth play their games at Memorial Stadium, an ancient venue of yore. The prices, verily, are quite fair, and thou shalt mingle with others of like mind, to see and be seen.

Alas, the sport itself, alack, doth leave a bit to be desired. 'Tis true, the players doth give their all, but, alas, the game doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain... pizzazz. Yet still, the evening shall be pleasant, and thou shalt have a merry time, socializing and enjoying the balmy airs of summer.

Kudos, too, to the Hounds, who doth make good use of Memorial Stadium. Mayhap, in days of yore, 'twas thought that such a place would fall to disuse, or worse, be torn down for some newfangled development that ne'er doth come to pass. But nay, the Hounds doth breathe new life into this venerable edifice, and for that, we doth commend them."

"Hark, fair friends! I rate this place three and a half stars, yet comprehend how some might grant it four. The victuals and attendance, indeed, deserve such praise, but, alack! The tapas, priced too steep, doth mar the experience. In fair Spain, I've supped on tapas, both fine and plain, but Jaleo's, by the stars, doth beggar description! Save for the paellas, which doth shine like the sun in springtime, all else doth pale in comparison. So, heed my words, good sirs, and beware the tapas' cost, lest ye be fleeced of thy coin!"

"Methinks 'tis a passable tavern, good victuals they serve. Naught but the ordinary at the bar, naught that doth astound. A place of gathering for the locals, oft full of mirth and cheer. Some patrons, mayhap, do partake in ale a bit too freely, yet harmless they be."

"Alas, my friends, I could not partake  
In splitting a pizza, for the cost was great  
The prices, oh so high, did pierce my soul  
A large, for twenty-six dollars, what a bitter fate!  

But lo, there be a place, Athens pizza named  
Where prices be more fair, and taste, more claimed  
A better choice, by far, doth it proclaim  
So let us go, and savor its sweet fame."

"Methinks 'tis wise to partake of Chinese fare,
After a few buffets, doth my belly declare.
Came I here for luncheon, with naught but coin,
Food, though pricey, didst my senses entwine.
But fear not, fair reader, for I didst dine
Upon comp, and thus, my purse didst not decline.

The salmon cold noodle, a dish most divine,
Didst stand out amongst all else, methinks 'twas fine.
Apart from this, all else didst seem but average,
Yet still, my hunger didst it doth assuage."

"A hearty tavern, full of cheer and glee,
Where honest folk do gather, 'tis plain to see.
No fancy trimmings, nor high-falutin' fare,
Just stiff drinks and victuals, fit for a king's share.

The barkeep, a jolly soul, with wit so bright,
Doth serve the patrons with a smile so light.
No airs or graces, but a friendly demeanor,
Maketh one feel welcome, like a neighbor.

'Tis a place to watch a game, or share a tale,
With comrades old, or new friends met by chance.
After a long day's toil, 'tis a haven, a respite,
To quaff a pint, and let the world slide out of sight."

"Methinks the raves for this eatery did pour forth like a river in springtime. Service, it did excel, and with our meal, a medley of veggies didst accompany. Fried dumplings, we didst begin with, and though delectable, the filling, I didst wish for more. Bibimbap, a sizzling stone pot didst bring, with beef, alas, in scant supply. Rice, the dish didst mostly compose, leaving the beef and veggies in scarcity. A change, I do suggest, to augment the beef and veggies, and reduce the rice, that all may partake in a feast most bounteous."

"A hearty bean and cheese dish, yet the cheese doth lack the warmth of melted gold. They do employ the virtuous oil, in place of lard, a commendable deed. The green salsa, a zesty delight, yet a small portion of chips to complement its charm would be most welcome. The hard tacos, a satisfying feast, but alas, the crisp lettuce doth overflow, consuming half the shell's capacity."

"Three stars, a rating fair,
For this club, with decor grand and rare.
The balcony upstairs, a sight to see,
But alas, the weather did not agree.

Two rooms, with DJs of different sort,
One played hip hop, the other, top 40 report.
The main room DJ, a disappointment true,
Struggled with beats, his skills not anew.

In Las Vegas, where clubs reign supreme,
I'd expect the best DJs, a nightly theme.
But perhaps he had a bad night, who knows?
The staff, kind and courteous, a pleasant surprise, no foes.

The cover charge, steep, a price to pay,
$40 for men, $20 for ladies, a difference to sway.
But the bouncer, kind, let my girl in free,
A gesture kind, a token of goodwill, a bargain to see.

I wouldn't return, not because of a frown,
But to try another club, a new scene to crown.
For those who stay at Caesar's, a decent spot,
But for others, a choice, a gamble to plot."

"Hark, I dined at this eatery (take out) and savored their pad tai and PH\u00d2. The establishment was radiant, newly-built, and charming. The service was exceedingly cordial and punctual. The pad tai met my expectations, and I sampled my comrade's beef, which was equally delectable. Alas, I had been craving PH\u00d2, as it is scarce on the NW side, and my health required it. Oh, how my anticipation was deflated! Upon opening the container, the broth lacked its characteristic scent, and upon sipping, it tasted overly sweet and viscous, revolting! Moreover, the color was an unsettling shade of brown, despite my request for chicken PH\u00d2. I attempted to salvage the dish by adding noodles and seasonings, but alas, the odor and flavor were too much to bear. I drained the liquid and consumed the noodles instead. Verily, I would have bestowed five stars upon this venue, had it not been for the wretched PH\u00d2. Methinks perhaps I visited on an unfavorable day."

"Hark! A place for cheap drinks during happy hour, my dear? A tiny bar, indeed, with patrons who do imbibe. 'Tis a smoky, noisy den, full of those who take their drinks quite seriously. Locals gather here, and 'tis a sight to behold. Entertainment may be hit or miss, but the crowd itself doth provide mirth. I've had some tasty dishes herein, and free popcorn doth await within the indoor bar. Pray, bring thine own plastic darts, for the dartboard doth not always cooperate. The staff, kind and friendly, doth ensure a pleasant visit."

"Hark! What eatery doth reign supreme?
In this fair land of T-Bird and 59th Ave,
A question doth arise, and thus it seems,
Why doth Del-Taco trouble itself to be?

Chipotle, a name of quality and renown,
Doth serve the masses with its tasty fare,
Bean or veggie burritos, a choice most sound,
Yet, alas! They doth upcharge with such glee,
For chips and salsa, a price most steep,
Eight dollars, a sum most dear, doth be,
For a meal most simple, coke, chips, and salsa,
A cost most high, a price most rude, doth be.

This place, a tidy keep, a duty doth impose,
To keep the dining space, in order, doth dispose."

Hark! I've visited Daisho sushi twice now,
Once when it first did open its doors,
And again this eve, with hunger pangs anew.
'Twas passable fare, with nigiri fresh and fair,
Green tea ice cream, a sweet delight.
Service was adequate, yet rolls lacked zest,
Perhaps our choices were not the best.
As I reside nearby, I gave it a go,
But still, my regular sushi spot doth know
The way to my heart, with AYCE price so fair.

"Methinks 'twas fate that led me to this place,
To partake in their most excellent bread,
A loaf of sourdough, fresh from the oven's embrace,
Didst tempt mine eyes and stir mine appetite.

But alack! The line didst move at a snail's pace,
And I, with naught but time to kill, didst wait,
Ten minutes passed, and still I stood in place,
My patience worn thin, my ire didst inflate.

The workers, slow as molasses in winter's chill,
Didst tend the counter with a sloth's grace,
Their speed, akin to a snail upon a mission from God,
Didst test mine endurance, and my soul didst fret.

Yet, praise be to the bread, a wondrous delight,
Worth every penny, and a taste most sweet,
So, though the service was a trial to bear,
I shall return, for that most holy loaf doth beckon me still."

"Hark! My kin and I, we do adore
The victuals served at this establishment.
We oft pass through the drive-thru gate,
And our repasts are fresh, hot, and savory, by fate.
But of late, the elder woman, with brows so dark,
Who tends the window, doth wear a scowl, most stark.
She doth act as though each request, a burden be,
With haughty mien, and words of disdain, doth she speak.
A new Mexican eatery, further down Greenway,
Hath opened its doors, to chase away
The foul mood that doth plague this place, alack!
Three stars, Rivas! Attend to thy demeanor, ere thou dost lose all thy clientele!"

"A fair location, with poolside views so fine,
And victuals that did please my palate well.
Yet, priced a mite too steep, I must confess,
For dishes simple, though not without finesse.
In M.Bay, such costs are common, I do reckon,
But still, a pennywise man might seek a better bargain."

"In wonder, I didst enter, and straightaway,
A table was found for me, in haste, they didst say.
Their menu, a quick perusal, didst reveal,
A feast, for twenty dollars, a bargain, indeed, didst seem.

Five rolls, I didst order, with drink, besides,
A quantity, most generous, the price, didst justify.
But, alas, the quality, didst leave much to be desired,
Average, at best, the taste, didst not quite inspire.

The presentation, plain, the wait, didst take,
My patience, didst wear thin, as time, didst make.
The tea, didst ask, again and again, didst plead,
The bill, didst wait, for long, didst need.

A second chance, I shall give, in time,
For twenty dollars, full, the belly, doth rhyme.
And so, I shall return, with hope, anew,
To find, if service, better, doth do."

"In fair Las Vegas, where revelry doth reign,
Amidst the splendor, doth this eatery remain.
No fine dining here, nor cause for delight,
Tis but a humble abode, for hunger's plight.

I chanced upon the prosciutto sandwich,
And found it met my hopes, no more, no less.
A crusty baguette, prosciutto di parma,
Mozzarella, arugula, and balsamic, all in harmony.
A simple meal, swiftly served, and thus it ends.

The cheese pizza, alas, did suffer fate,
For lack of time in oven, made it soggy, quite.
Yet still, 'twas devoured, with nary a complaint,
For hunger's pangs, do make the taste buds faint."

"Hark! A fortnight past, a friend and I didst step within these walls, On a Tuesday eve, when all the world didst doth its business. And lo! The place was ours, save for a maid, Heidi, kind and fair. We didst converse with ease, and she didst join in our cheer. I didst order thus: an Oggie, mushy peas, and chips of potato. The victuals were not wondrous, but neither didst they dismay. The pasty, dry; the wine gravy, strange; the beef, lean but tough. Yet ciders, Strongbow and Hoegaarden, didst please mine taste. And when the night didst wear on, we didst essay the dartboard, a sport most pleasant. In conclusion, 'tis a place to share a drink and merriment with friends, and on a busier night, the crowd doth make a lively scene."

"Marry, my friend and I didst hear tell of this show,
And thought to give 'twas try, forsooth.
But alack, 'twas naught but cheese, I do declare,
The men, they couldst not dance, their moves most awkward were.
Some were ahead, some behind, in disarray,
Their routines, haphazard, lacking grace.
Yet still, 'twas mildly entertaining, I must say,
But wouldst I go again? Nay, not a chance, I pray.
For though some men were cute, with looks so fine,
Others didst appear quite scary, in truth divine.
But lo, the host, he was a merry soul,
His wit, it didst make the show, a bit more whole."

"Marry, good sir, thou dost speak the truth. Forsooth, this sandwich, though fair in form and flavor, doth lack the proper bread, a flaw most grievous, indeed. Methinks, were it not for this defect, 'twould be a feast fit for the gods. Pray, good sir, rectify this error, that we may partake of a truly wondrous sandwich."

"Hark! A hunger pang doth strike us down,
And thus we seek a meal ere the show doth start.
A bar we find, and swiftly take our seat,
But lo! The bartender doth tarry in her approach.
Yet when she doth arrive, her service doth please,
And chili cheese kobe beef fries doth satisfy our need.
A decent sporting hole this place doth make,
For those who seek to watch and cheer their team."

"Avalon, a place of wonder, a realm of delight,
Where treasures abound, both old and new in sight.
But alas, my friends, let not thy hopes be raised,
For oftentimes, the prices are quite dazed.

I've found myself, in puzzlement and dismay,
Holding a shirt with holes, yet still they'd say,
"Tis fourteen dollars, fair sir, 'tis a steal!"
And thus, my mind doth boggle at their deal.

Their buying process, a mystery it seems,
For clothes in style, they show no interest, it gleams.
Yet on their racks, grandma's garb doth hang,
A conundrum, indeed, and quite beyond my ken.

Despite the hits and misses, still I roam,
To Avalon, where fortune may await, at home.
For in October, costumes of Halloween,
Do abound, a sight most wondrous, and queer, and keen."

"Hark! What store is this? A veritable treasure trove of beauty supplies, it doth seem. Twice the size of others, with products galore, it doth astound. 

Upon my recent visit, after work, three employees didst attend to customers' needs. One didst greet me, though her mien didst not bespeak great enthusiasm, she didst show courtesy. 

My purpose, swift and simple, to procure nail polish, using the $5 coupon gained from joining their club, didst not require aid. The cashier, kind and cheerful, didst tally my purchase, and I shall return anon."

"Three and a half stars doth Gilley's earn,
For Jameson cheap, and victuals somewhat concern.
A fun patio doth make up for the rest,
Where laughter floweth, and merriment findeth its nest.

Dana S, a maiden fair and bright,
Didst join me on a visit, full of delight.
We sipped on Jame-O, and sang with glee,
In karaoke, our voices didst ring out with ease.

Again I came, with hunger pangs strong,
To taste their fare, and see what doth belong.
The nachos, verily, didst taste like Taco John's,
A compliment indeed, from mine own lips, 'twas spoken.
Chicken strips, frozen and fried in batter,
Were but a morsel, yet the sauce, a tangy platter.
Jalapeno grits, a bite I didst take,
And found them to be the meal's crowning make.

Not terrible, this place, but not the best,
The Strip doth offer more, and that is no jest.
In a pinch, 'twill serve, but not the top,
Gilley's, a place of mirth, and that is not a flop."

"Hark, fair readers, listen well to my tale,
Of a club visited, where celebrities did prevail.
The dance floor, small as it may be,
Did not deter us, for the music, a delight to me.

A place to chill, with champagne flowing free,
Girls entered without cost, a sweet ecstasy.
On Valentine's weekend, we did prepare to leave,
But LMFAO appeared, our spirits did retrieve.

We stayed the night, their performance, a treat,
A memory to cherish, forever to keep.
My friends, too, have visited, in days past,
Far East Movement, their sight, did truly last.

So, choose your weekends wisely, dear friends,
For celebrities abound, till the very end."

"Hark! If thou dost desire a night of delight,
With waitresses fair and beverages bright,
This place shall serve thy purpose well, I say.
But if thou seekst good service and fine fare,
Best to journey forth and seek elsewhere,
For here, the bill may come incorrect,
Twice, and drinks and victuals may be lacking,
Yet still, the beer is cold, the maidens fair,
And all else, elsewhere thou mayst find, I swear."

"Hark, good sir! If thou dost seek a meal most fine,
Jimmy John's shall be thy destination divine.
A sub, a sandwich of great renown, doth please,
With bread of nine grains, a secret, if thou wilt seize.
The beach club, a choice most excellent, doth boast,
Turkey, cheese, tomato, lettuce, and guacamole at last.
A custom, too, they offer, to suit thy whim,
Guacamole upon thy sub, a treat most slim.
And for the herbivore, a feast most fair,
The veggie sub, with sprouts, cheese, and cucumber there.
Their cookies, large and luscious, doth satisfy,
Chocolate chip, a treat that doth not die."

"A fair and pleasant place, where one may find solace in a steaming bowl of corn chowder, 'tis true, the service doth lag, yet the fare doth make amends. A varied menu, with choices most fair, and staff, who doth strive to please. Their breads and muffins, too, are worth the try. For breakfas', lunch, or e'en dinner, 'tis a goodly spot, I do declare."

"Hark! A tale of Enso, a place I didst visit,
With one companion, on a day most fit.
The ginger salad, a dish of no surprise,
Didst taste as expected, with naught to devise.

The sushi, fair and pretty to behold,
Didst lack the flavor, that my soul doth bold.
But lo! The spider roll, a wondrous sight,
Didst please my taste buds, with its bite so bright.

Alas! The atmosphere, so dark and grim,
Didst make me feel, as though in some dim cave.
And swanky, oh so swanky, it didst seem,
As though the Americans, who ran the scheme,
Didst wish to flaunt their wealth, with no regard,
For those who dined, with wallets not so hard.

A hundred dollars, we didst spend, alack!
Without a drop of ale, or wine to crack.
'Tis good, but not worth, the price they ask,
So head to New Zealand cafe, and save thy task."

"Hark, what news is this? A tale of woe and sorrow doth unfold.
A sandwich, turkey-filled, with ranch and bacon, my heart doth sing.
But lo, a new machine doth pour forth drinks most foul,
With lime, it doth imbue, a taste most uncool.
I cannot eat, nor drink, at this place, alas,
For all their brew doth taste of citrus, oh what a pity.
Take out, my friend, doth seem the only way,
To partake of their fare, without dismay."

"Alas, we sought to dine upon that roof most fair,
But found that we must tend to it ourselves, alack!
And so we did, with nary a thought of despair,
For though the service was good, the food did lack.

Our waitress, fair and kind, did bring us cheer,
With two beers, when we had but one to fear.
The pork queso dip, a dish most wondrous,
Was not as spicy as I had hoped, yet still delicious.
I ordered the Cuban, with lettuce and tomato,
But found the flavors did not quite harmonize, alas!
Once gone, the BBQ was good, my husband did say,
But naught to rave about, in any way.

So, to this place, we shall not return,
For though 'twas decent, 'twas not worth the burn.
But if thou wishest, I shall not protest,
For all have tastes different, and that is best."

"Hark! My dwelling lies but a short ways off,
From this Waffle House, where oft we doth repair,
After a night of mirth and merriment,
With friends, in search of sustenance and cheer.

'Tis naught but simple fare, fit for a king,
Trucker grub, they call it, hearty and plain,
Yet the servants here, with smiles so bright,
Do make our visits pleasant, and the pain
Of yestereven's excesses, doth depart.

So here we come, when night's wild revels end,
To Waffle House, where our hangovers mend."

"Methinks, fair traveler, thou hast chanced upon a place most wondrous and unique. Forsooth, the rocks that rise from the earth do resemble those of the red planet, Mars itself. But alas, good sir, 'tis a pity that this place doth lie within the borders of Arizona. Fie upon it, say I!"

"Methinks 'tis hard to render judgment on this place,
For though our server was most excellent and bright,
And we didst enjoy the victuals and drink, alack,
Two of our number didst fall ill, in truth quite wight.

A plague upon the mussels, say I, forsooth,
That dish didst bring us naught but woe and blight.
We hadst crab cakes, short ribs, arancinis too,
Gnocchi with lobster, and potato, all in view.

In sooth, I didst enjoy each dish, save the arancinis,
Which didst taste of port wine, a bit too keen.
The drinks we hadst, from Braddock's smash to moscow mule,
Were pleasant, and the manhattan, make thine own, a rule.

This hotel restaurant, within The Renaissance,
Didst boast an eclectic, upscale ambiance, in sooth.
But, alas, the food poisoning doth mar the score,
And thus, this review doth merit but three stars, no more."

"Tucked away on Howe Street, a humble abode,
The Standard bar, a gem, yet unassuming,
Popular with locals, both New Town and Stockbridge,
Surprisingly spacious, once inside, it's sumptuous.

The interior, smart and plush, a comfortable den,
Sip on a beer, or Sauvignon, and let the hours glide,
The atmosphere, jovial, inviting, and free,
A place to linger, and indulge, wild and carefree.

The menu, decent, and inexpensive, a treat,
For hearty pub grub, a burger, chips, and a seat,
Or a full breakfast, to cure the morning after,
The Standard, a haven, for all, a true laughter.

Though I must confess, my bias, sports do bore,
But for those who revel, in matches, and roar,
The Standard, a haven, with screens, a delight,
Busy, especially, during rugby's might."

"Methinks I doth frequent Chili's with mine kin and friends, 'bout twice a month, yea verily. We do enjoy the victuals at the establishment, situated at Bell and 7th St. or 27th Ave and 101. The grub, forsooth, is oft above average, and the chips and salsa, a right proper bargain, I say. The green chile and enchilada soups, delectable, by my troth! 'Tis a shame, alack, that the service at the North Valley Parkway location doth leave much to be desired. Twice, nay thrice, have we tried their fare, and lo, the orders were amiss, the serving maidens, though friendly, knew not the menu well. The food, aye, didst take an age to arrive, and ne'er a word of contrition did we hear. Months passed, and we didst give them another chance, hoping, mayhap, they hadst ironed out their flaws. Alas, the wait for our repast was interminable, and a refill for our drinks, a mere pipedream. Last Saturday, a pleasant serving maiden, and greeters, too, didst grace our presence, but, alack, the wait for soup and salad, and water to quench our thirst, didst stretch beyond the ninety-minute mark. Four times, by my reckoning, doth suggest a pattern, not a happenstance. Fie upon the North Valley Parkway Chili's! Mayhap, one day, they shall rectify their shortcomings, and we shall once again partake of their culinary delights."

"A fair spread of victuals, fit for a king,
The sashimi, fresh as spring's sweet blossoms sing.
Chinese delights, cooked to perfection, swift,
Crab legs, a feast, and plentiful, no need to rift.
Spring rolls, alas, did not impress, nor dumplings too,
But still, this buffet, worth a visit, 'twill do.

Heed the sign, ere thou dost fill thy plate,
Lest thou be charged, and cursed be thy fate.
For taking more than thou canst eat, a sin,
An extra fee, eight dollars, thou shalt win.

Yet still, this place, a recommendation, I give,
For Chinese buffets, 'tis one that doth live."

"Pied Au Corchon full up? Fear not, fair friends! Here lies a worthy substitute, indeed. 

A feast for senses, this eatery doth provide, with dishes fresh and well-prepared, in portions moderate, and ambiance rustic, yet refined. But, alas, slow service doth plague, and noise doth fill the hall. 

My own repast, a veritable delight! Veal heart tartar, fresh and full of flavor, did please my taste, though lacking somewhat, I knew not what. Thin fries, crispy and well-salted, accompanied, and raw vegetables, finely sliced, beneath a vinaigrette. For sweet conclusion, shared apple tarte, nicely presented, with apples vinegared, and sorbet, a tiny scoop, yet pleasant, upon its top. Not extraordinary, but pleasant, hot, and flaky of crust. 

In conclusion, worth the cost, this place doth stand, a noble alternative to renowned eateries in Le Plateau."

"A cup of coffee, brewed in French press style, did taste like water, alas, with dregs of grounds within. A breakfast place, where mornings start afresh, should serve a brew most fine, nay, excellent. Alas, the coffee I didst receive, was far from meetin' expectations. \n\nAnd, by the name, a place called Morning Squeeze, one would suppose, did offer freshly squeezed or blended juices, but nay, 'twas not the case. Mayhap, they shall make adjustments, and raise their standards, ere long. The place, indeed, doth possess a pleasant atmosphere."

This place doth have some wondrous potential,
The telly's set up in most excellent fashion,
Even in the bathrooms, a rare sight indeed,
A place of such refinement, a true delight.

Five stars, I wouldst give, without hesitation,
Were it not for the victuals, a sorry state,
And the ale, a paltry selection, alack,
No Crown Royal Cask, Jack Daniel's Honey, nay,
Kraken nor Captain Morgan Private Stock,
Nor even Jack Daniel's Single Barrel, alas,
Half Moon, good sirs, take heed of my words,
Not all desire to imbibe the bottom shelf,
Or the dregs of the barrel, in sooth,
Attend to these two issues, I pray thee,
That I may render another review,
In five stars, anon, ere long, farewell.

"Hark, I've come to this place, and ordered a dish,
A Caesar's salad, 'twixt meals, a mere snack,
Dressed well, but o'er seasoned, alas,
A pleasant spot, for casual folk, to relax."

In fair Champaign, where culinary delights do abound,
A Korean eatery did catch my eye, 'twas a new foundling.
Their menu, laminated and neat, didst display their fare,
But alas, no pictures, only words, didst leave me in despair.

I chose the combo platter, bulgogi, priced at nine ninety-nine,
And waited patiently, as the minutes didst slowly combine.
The dish arrived, with rice aplenty, and two ban chae beside,
A bean soup too, all for my pleasure, didst my senses decide.

The bulgogi, well-seasoned, yet the meat, in small slices lay,
Detracting from its worth, I must say, in dismay.
Prices, my wife doth claim, have risen since her college days,
Alas, a slight above average, in my culinary ways.

Pros: Average price, large portions, a Korean feast,
Cons: Long cook time, prices higher, than other eateries at least.
A hidden gem: Your meal, with rice, soup, and two ban chae doth come,
A pleasant surprise, indeed, for those who do arrive.

"Fare is struck and miss, I mark'd the victuals ill,
In afternoons, salted frites and meat dull.
But at eve, a feast most fair and fine,
Sandwiches, a delight divine.
BBQ ribs, a jest, a mockery, alack!
I imbibe not, thus cannot speak
Of tavern's brew, but grill, 'tis my quest."

In fair Arizona, where I didst roam,
I sought to savor local dishes, home.
The Fry Bread House didst beckon me,
To taste the native cuisine, I couldst see.

Their fried bread, freshly made, didst delight,
With spices that didst ignite my sight.
I found it good, though fiery hot,
A flavor that didst make my senses trot.

Alas, I cannot recommend a dish,
For I didst only sample one, in truth's fish.
But if thou seekst a tasty treat,
The flatbread, there, doth can't be beat.

"Verily, I say unto thee, this Bruegger's doth stand apart from its brethren three blocks hence upon Grant Street.  Its staff, in high spirits and with haste, doth take orders with greater efficiency. \n\nAs with most Bruegger's, a standard fare of bagels, sandwiches, soup, coffee, and tea doth grace the menu. Moreover, comfortable booths line the exterior window, affording a pleasant repast."

"Methinks the air is full of cheer,
And prices, fair and not too dear.
Wine-a-ritas, diverse and tasty,
Yet, alack, not quite up to par.
Local vintages, light and crisp,
But, prithee, not my cup of tea.
I do confess, I hold CA wines
In higher esteem, and thus,
Their price doth seem a mite steep.
Aye, the pinot grigio, a gem,
Yet, at $25, a trifle dear.
I shall return, and next time,
The flight, for $6, I shall espie."

"A place of sushi, fair and bright,
With bar most pleasant, seating tight.
The fish, a feast for eyes and taste,
Yet, alas, no stars to waste.
Ra's equal, Sakana's lesser kin,
Average, yet not quite within.
Four stars, a choice most hard to make,
For 'twas but average, naught to take."

"Alas, the wings that once did soar with grace,
Now lie dormant, their beauty lost in time.
For slow service, many a patron did complain,
And thus, the wings that once did bring us joy,
Are now but memories, forever sealed within the past."
"A fair pizza, with wings that didst lack moisture, alas, yet shall I not be deterred in my quest for a New York-style slice within this fair city."

"Fare was sumptuous, as it doth usually seem,
