New edifice, a marvel of architectural dream.
Yet, alas! The seats, they did cause much discomfort,
And the melody, it did pierce mine eardrums with naught but discord.
I pray thee, kind establishment, consider an alteration,
In chairs, more cushioned, and sound, at a lower decibel, lest I depart.
Forsooth, 'twere better to partake of victuals in quietude,
Than to endure such racket, and leave in haste, with naught but annoyance."

"Tis a pleasure to find a luncheon spot that doth prioritize health,
Without relying on outdated menus or unhealthy wealth.
This place doth impress, with its dedication to wholesome fare,
And the variety of options doth make it a worthy lair.

But alas, there be a catch, a flaw in the plan,
The price of breakfast doth seem quite out of hand.
A sandwich, with egg and wrap, doth cost a pretty penny,
And the quality doth not match the sum paid, methinks, 'tis a pity.

Yet fear not, fair reader, for the noonday meal doth make amends,
With a satisfying bang for thy hard-earned pence, it doth transcend.
Fresh, healthy, and delicious, the flavors doth abound,
And thy hunger doth depart, with a full belly all around.

So for breakfast, two stars doth this place receive,
But for lunch, four stars doth it most certainly deserve.
Thus, an overall rating of three doth it earn,
A commendable score, without a single qualm or concern."

In fair Sally's, where night owls do convene,
Late eats are served, when others do close at e'en.
Their decor doth please, with motors, knick-knacks,
And guitars of old, a rockabilly attack.

A gathering spot, it is, where friends do meet,
To fortify themselves, with bites most sweet.
The servers, friendly, booths, big and soft,
Ice, oh ice, so fine, like snow cones aloft.

All in all, Sally's, a place of merriment,
Though naught to write home of, a decent haunt.
If smoking were allowed, five stars would be mine,
But 'tis not for them to decide, so I do design.

"Hark! This place doth please me well, my friends,
A medley of tunes they do play,
From oldies to hip hop, rap and rock,
A varied mix, indeed, doth make my day.

Upon a Friday eve, we didst venture forth,
And found the crowd, in sooth, a bit uncouth,
Yet still, the dance floor, small though it be,
Didst bring us joy, in spite of all we see.

Forsooth, they didst give away gifts, my friends,
To those who waited patiently in line,
Clothes, they gave, but, alas, in limited supply,
Fifteen, in total, didst they distribute, by and by.

One garment per person, they didst bestow,
A token of their love, for local ladies, know,
This place, a haven, for those who seek delight,
In music, dance and mirth, through the long, cold night."

"Hark! I say, good sirs and madams, listen well,
For I have tale to tell, of culinary spell,
In Phoenix, city of the sun, where heat doth dwell,
I've lived for thirty years, and know it well.

To Old Town, we didst venture, with friends in tow,
For Restaurant Week, a night of gastronomic vow,
But alas, fair readers, we shall not return,
For though the service was attentive, ambiance did burn.

The tables, cramped and close, didst make us feel,
As if in marketplace, amidst the din and deal,
And noise, it didst ascend, to levels high,
Not quite the intimate dining, we didst espy.

The food, it was good, but not of home run fame,
My venison, raw within, a surprise came,
Not cooked, as I had thought, my preference being,
Medium-well, yet raw, it didst my taste buds sting.

My dining partner, her meat, didst send back,
For cooking, medium rare, her desire, didst attack,
A dessert of foie gras and donuts, strange, it was,
None of us, didst enjoy, such sweet, surpass.

Cocktails, we didst not partake, but tempting, they didst seem,
Yet, regular menu, prices high, for servings small, didst deem.
Once, it was worth, our trial, thus, we didst conclude,
In Phoenix, other eats, our taste buds, may yet, induce."

"Methinks we dined at Vogue but late, my dear,
And found the victuals to be of great cheer.
I had the meatloaf, juicy and sweet,
My spouse, the lasagna, rich and neat.
We shared the calamari, alas, a woeful sight,
Fried tempura, drowned in grease, a sorry plight.
The ginger'mongst the carrots, a delight,
But little calamari, a sorrow to behold,
Our waiter, courteous, yet his manner cold.
We felt unwelcome, as if to say,
'Depart, good sirs, and tarry not, I pray.'
But nay, the entrees, worth each penny,
A verity, a truth, a certainty."

"After one visit, I must confess,  
The ambiance was quite pleasant, I must profess.  
The decor was lovely, but the lighting, alas,  
Was dark, and made it hard to see, I do surmise.  

The service, oh how it did excel,  
With Pin Kaow, I must give them a bell.  
Their table touches, though, did border on the extreme,  
Five people checked on us within five minutes, it did seem.  

The food, it was a mixed bag, I do declare,  
The chicken satay, grilled perfectly, beyond compare.  
The peanut sauce, authentic, yet lacked a certain flair,  
A flat taste, that left me not entirely aware.  

Tom Ka Koong, a rich and sour broth,  
With coconut milk, lemongrass, mushrooms, and shrimp, in truth.  
A delicate balance, that not all may enjoy,  
For some, it may be too sour, and thus destroy.  

Roasted rice beef, a new concept, indeed,  
With cabbage, Thai basil, and spices, it did proceed.  
Crushed rice, roasted, and scattered on the beef,  
An interesting texture, a unique experience, in belief.  

Chicken yellow curry, delicious, I must say,  
A dish that pleased my palate, in a major way.  

Overall, a B+, I must aver,  
Hoping to return, and try more dishes, I do endeavor."

"O, how vexing it is when a local place doth fall short! Monroe Hardware, though decent, doth not compare to yonder general store of old, like Mast Drug or Renfrow in fair Matthews. Nor doth it rival the grand chains, Home Depot or Lowe's, in scale or scope. 'Tis a curious thing, indeed, for in betwixt these two extremes doth Monroe Hardware lie, like a ship lost at sea, betwixt and between.

In Mint Hill, there doth stand a location, once a Winn Dixie, now a spacious abode for hardware and wares. Alas, the vastness of the space doth make it hard to fill, leaving staff to roam and customers to their own devices. Alack, the convenience of its proximity to mine own domicile doth make it tempting still, yet for projects grand, Home Depot or Lowe's shall be my will. Forsooth, their stores, like castles strong, doth hold the keys to all my hardware needs, and thus, my heart doth sing."

"Hark! This Dillard's doth now serve but one purpose,
A place where last season's finery doth find its haven.
The lower floor, once bustling with life and cheer,
Now lies dormant, empty, and devoid of light.

Upstairs, the racks doth brim with garb of renown,
Designers' names doth grace each hanger and gown.
Fourty percent, the least of discounts doth show,
Fifty and seventy-five, the larger sums doth flow.

By size, the clothes doth hang, a sight to see,
In Michael Kors, a top of quality doth be.
Eighteen, the price doth drop, from fifty's height,
A steal, indeed, a bargain of great might.

Bedding, accessories, and shoes doth fill the space,
But alas, the footwear doth leave much to trace.
For those with small or large feet, choices doth lack,
Or gaudy styles, which doth not appeal to all, alack."

"Alack, I soon didst prove myself no Vegas lass,
With heels, I didst not grace the dance floor's grass.
A pinched nerve in my back, a bouncer quite strict,
Didst almost bar my entry, save for my wit.

The view, a disappointment, a mere glimpse,
Of bright lights, a crowded floor, a pricey sip.
To avoid the throng, a table, one must pay,
Or suffer strangers' touch, nightlong, each day.

So, ere thou goest, a word of advice,
Buy liquor at the CVS, a wise pretense.
And thus, with a good buzz, thy wallet spare,
Shalt thou enjoy thyself, without a single care."

"Hark! Bravo, a chain of renown, doth provide
A salad decent, upon which I do rely.
Their reservations, a blessing, doth save me time,
From lines long, and waits of forty-five.

I do confess, their Romano crusted chicken,
And balsamic chicken, doth please my taste.
Their Parmesan dressing, a delight, doth make me keen
To try and recreate it, in my own place.

Alas, their entrees, too salty, doth not appeal,
But still, I stop by, to grab a salad, and revel.
The parking, abundant, doth ease my mind,
A boon, indeed, when shopping, or movies to find."

"Taco of black beans, priced at two dollars,
Better than burritos in Manhattan, I do avow,
But not as delectable as some hotspots in this town,
Where the patio's charm is amplified by night's gown.

Before First Fridays, we did dine upon this fare,
And our server, in converse, did share her cheer,
Speaking of Shark Week, a most wondrous sight,
Goodness, what a pleasant evening, full of delight!"

"Hark, fair friends! I side with Jamie C.,
My mind not yet made up, I must confess.
Our server, a fine gent, his name I wish I knew,
For his attentiveness, my praise doth accrue.

Two glasses of sangria, I did imbibe,
Michael, not fond of his mojito, did stray.
He switched to Stella, his thirst to assuage,
As we partook of the calamari, a dish most engaging.

The sauces, a delight! We devoured them with glee,
And the blue corn chicken enchilada, a treat for me.
Many shared plates, my curiosity doth pique,
So, anon, I shall return, my taste buds to satiate."

"Hark! We've heard tell of Bouchon's grandeur,
And witnessed it ourselves, in truth.
The dining hall, a sight to behold,
Elegant and proper, as it should be.

Brunch, a feast most wondrous, I confess,
But not so great as to leave us aghast.
We tried the Salmon Baguette, a dish most fine,
A bagel, with salmon, and cream cheese divine.

But, alas! The Bouchon French Toast,
A name most misleading, as we found.
For it was naught but bread pudding, sweet,
A dessert, and not a meal to eat.

So, if thou seekest a hearty repast,
Look elsewhere, fair traveler, and tarry not.
But if thy taste runneth to sweet delight,
Then Bouchon's French Toast shall be thy sight."

"Alas, poor Kamakura, why doth thou bear such malice? 

Verily, 'tis a place of fond memories, a family fave, 
For years, my sire didst take us there, when sushi was new, 
And we didst return, for special days, with joy anew. 
The teppan, we didst savor, with delight and glee, 
But now, alack, the charm doth seem to flee. 
The chefs, perchance, do lack their former zeal, 
Or mayhap, 'tis but my own perspective doth reveal. 
Yet still, they thrive, despite the negative word, 
For in LA, a 3.5-star rating, they wouldst have heard. 
And so, I say, give Kamakura a chance, 
For 'tis a place of wonder, in this fair land of Japan."

"A shop most fair and full of wondrous things,
Where gifts of wit and whimsy take flight.
But alas, dear friend, beware the cost,
For prices here do mount, and quickly lost.

Yet still, in times of need, this place doth save,
When gifts of old seem dull and stale.
The staff, so kind and full of grace,
Do make the visit worth thy time and space.

And though the room was bare, 'twas fate,
Not lack of shoppers, nor a sign of hate.
For in this place, a card didst I find,
To celebrate a friend's grand milestone, divine."

"Verily, my friend and I didst partake of sustenance at a place called Buldogis. Our meals, the Gold Standard and the Longhorn, didst come with scant toppings, yet their cost didst rival that of a fine steed. Fear not, good sir, for these dogs didst satiate our hunger and were quite tasty, though I wouldst not venture to say they were the finest in all the land. The staff didst treat us with kindness and respect, and though the prices didst seem steep, 'twas naught but a trifle compared to the riches of the realm. In conclusion, if thou art a devotee of hot dogs, then by all means, give Buldogis a try. But if thou art not, then mayhap look elsewhere for thy culinary delights."

"Hark! What news is this? The parent company, Frias, hath resolved my woeful tale. They didst take the time to search and find the cab and driver, using our credit card information, and didst a full investigation. Though I know not if the driver faced reprisal, they were most diligent in their follow-up. Methinks I shall take an Ace Cab once more, but next time, I shall double check to ensure naught is left behind.

In sooth, below doth lie my initial post. But lo! The parent company didst contact me, and they didst look into the matter. I do appreciate their effort, and shall let all know if aught doth come of it.

Original Post:

O, woe is me! The driver, rude and a thief, didst steal our ipad, and left it not in the lost and found. A caller, who bought the ipad from the taxi driver, didst ring us. 'Tis a scam, methinks, but no matter how it fell, the driver didst not return the ipad, and the company didst not respond. Alas, Ace is but one of many cab companies, ruled by a single parent company. I shall, and will, avoid them all, if this be how they conduct their business. At least, show some concern, and pretend to care."

"Hark! Traveler, take heed of this advice,
For thou dost seek to navigate the skies,
At McCarran Airport, beware the woe,
Of Wi-Fi, free yet unreliable, doth flow.

Fly Southwest, my friend, 'tis best,
Their gates, two areas, dost possess,
But alas, the layout, doth cause distress,
A long journey, to reach the other side, doth press.

Rental cars, a shuttle, doth require,
A waste of time, thy patience doth conspire,
And Fox, a company, doth stand apart,
Avoid them, lest thou lose thy heart.

In Las Vegas, rentals, cheap doth lie,
So choose wisely, lest thou suffer loss,
And thus, my friend, thy journey doth make,
With caution, wisdom, and a careful take."

"Hark! A fortnight past, we dined within these walls,
Upon the rave of reviews that did enthrall.
Our feast didst consist of duck, steak, and salmon,
The first, a tender morsel, most divine.
The second, fair at best, yet lacking zest,
And third, a fish most wondrous, fresh and blessed.
A cheese plate, too, did grace our table's side,
With flavors rich and varied, a delight.
The service, prompt and courteous, did abide.
We shall return, ere judging this place finally,
To savor more of its culinary artistry."

"Fare priced high, yet nourishment doth please. Duck, roasted, lacked moisture, skin not crisp. Pork, sweet and sour, did delight. Rice of coconut, delectable dish, worth every penny. Thirty pieces of silver, steep price to pay. Will return, for coconut rice, a dish divine. Next time, satay shall be mine."

"Hark! A tale of woe and disarray,
At a restaurant, where I did dine,
I ordered brisket, with fries of nacho,
And an outlaw burger, a feast most fine.

My cousin, he ordered ere I did,
Yet his meal came forth, ere mine did.
A stranger, too, didst receive his fare,
Before mine own, oh how unfair!

I asked the waiter, why the delay?
He said, "Fear not, 'tis coming straightway."
But ten minutes passed, and naught arrived,
My hunger grew, my patience died.

At last, my fries didst appear,
But where, oh where, was my burger dear?
The waiter said, "It comes anon,"
But ten more minutes passed, and still no sign.

At length, my meal didst arrive,
But oh, the frustration didst thrive.
The fries were crispy, the burger juicy,
But the service, alas, was quite unglue-y.

I would return, despite the woe,
For the food, it was quite good, you know.
But four stars, I cannot give,
For the mess, and the waiter's shift.

So, let this be a lesson,
To all who serve, or wish to impress,
Take heed of orders, and deliver swift,
Lest your customers do suffer and rift."

"Methinks I oft frequent this place with numerous friends in tow,
For their tables accommodate a multitude, and thus our feast doth grow.
When my appetite doth falter, and my taste buds do roam,
This eatery doth provide a solution, with its diverse menu, at home.

I have sampled many a dish, and found them all to be fair,
None have left me in awe, yet none have left me in despair.
The Chicken Madeira and Farfalle, with chicken and garlic so bright,
Are among my favorites, and bring me joy with each bite.

And the cheesecake, oh how sweet, in many forms doth it come,
Snickers, turtle, tuxedo, strawberry, and more, all are succulent some.
I have never met a slice I could not conquer, with grace and glee,
For in the realm of cheesecake, I am a true monarch, it doth seem."

"Davio's dinner didst leave me unimpressed,
Service, a vital part of any feast,
Didst falter, like a play with too much repetition,
Leaving me to feel as though at Eat 'N Park I didst dine.
Fare, just passable, yet not of high quality,
Akin to others of its ilk, in taste and presentation lacking.
Server, unskilled and ignorant of menu's contents,
A poor substitute for one who knows his duties and can present.
Time, a precious commodity, best spent elsewhere,
At Arlecchino or Alla Familia, a better choice, I do declare."

"Upon my travels, I chanced upon this place,
In search of sustenance, a different taste.
'Tis new, I think, and located near a gas station,
At Southern and Higley's northeast corner, a convenient station.

I ordered Gyro and Fries, a simple feast,
And took it to go, at 12:15, a quiet guest.
The flavors were good, but not the best I've had,
And the portion, three meat slices, left me somewhat sad.

The menu held interest, with dishes unique,
Worth trying later, a culinary seek.
A decent option, not worth a long journey,
But if in the area, I'd return for a Gyro in a hurry.

I'll visit again, in a month or so,
To see if they're thriving, or if they shall go.
A difficult spot, with visibility low,
But perhaps their food will make their fame grow."

In fair Paris, I didst tarry three nights,
And asked for a chamber with kingly bed,
But they didst give me a room with twain queens instead,
Which brought me discomfort, and my rest didst mar.

The next day, they didst move me to a room with a king,
Whose bed was not so bad, and I didst find solace within.
The rooms were clean, and the bathrooms, too,
With showers closed, and a tub, wherein I couldst renew.

The TV hadst some good channels, and the sound was clear,
But alas, the elevators didst work with great speed,
My view was of the airport, not so grand, I fear,
But the location of the hotel was most excellent, indeed.

I didst use their spa services, and wrote a review apart,
And found the restaurants in Paris to be a work of art.
I recommend climbing the Eiffel Tower high,
For the view from the top is most wondrous to the eye.

The monorail metro is nearby, a convenience, indeed,
But my only sorrow was that they wouldst not let me use the spa on the day I didst depart, which didst cause me great need.
Yet, in conclusion, 'tis a good place to stay,
In the heart of Paris, where one can find delight in every way.

"Methinks I came to this place once more, a scant few days since my first visit. Alas, the fair visage of the establishment didst soon prove to be deceiving. The pours of ale and wine, though modern and pleasing to mine eyes, didst contain but a paltry amount of liquid. Verily, I didst feel mine host had played a cruel trick upon me.

"Forsooth, we ordered two dishes, the Louisiana Chicken pasta and the Bibimbap. The former, alack, didst taste wondrous indeed, but its richness didst border on the obscene. Aye, 'twas a vast bowl of heavy cream and melted cheese, with some pasta tossed in for good measure. Methoughts the waitress shouldst have donned a vest with flair pins and exclaimed, "Welcome to Applebees!" 'Twas not what I didst expect from a place such as Miga.

"The latter, alas, didst disappoint. Though it looked most comely, its flavor didst leave much to be desired. Missing, it didst, the essential component of that dish - the dolsot, or hot stone bowl. In sooth, 'twas naught but a cold salad, and no true Bibimbap at all.

"Mayhap I shall return anon, but I shall give the menu time to rectify its shortcomings ere I do."

"Distrito, a place of some renown, doth fail to impress, its energy lacking, akin to a still pond. The decor, too, doth leave much to be desired, with darkness and lounge-like atmosphere that doth border on tedium.

We began our feast with guacamole and chips, the latter oversalted, nigh inedible. Yet, I did consume them, brushing off the excess salt with mine own fingers. The former two, however, did please our taste buds.

Next, we ventured onto vegetable tacos, a pleasant delight, and a Mexican flatbread, adorned with mushrooms and a sauce of huitlacoche. Both dishes did satisfy our hunger. Alas, the rice, with corn, cream, and habaneros, a Mexican risotto of sorts, did fall short of our expectations, owing to an overabundance of salt.

Distrito doth offer a diverse array of margaritas, and we did sample the watermelon-cucumber and cilantro varieties, finding them both agreeable.

The service, we had heard, could be a trial, yet we did receive fair, if unremarkable, attention from the staff.

In conclusion, Distrito did not prove a memorable experience for us, and we do not yearn to return."

"Fair fare, indeed! Yet, mark my words, good sir,
That payment by card doth not suffice,
Nor doth the coffee flow, without a fee,
And thus, I fear, this place I shall not see,
As oft as I wouldst, for these reasons, three."

In days of yore, when I didst dwell in fair Arizona,
I chanced upon Aunt Chilada's, a place of gastronomic wonder.
With friend in tow, I didst venture forth, and dined with glee,
But first, we didst don plastic forks, and combed our locks with glee.
A jest, a quip, a merry prank, we thought it to be,
But alas, our visages were marred, in such a state of disarray.
I know not why, but we didst deem it wise,
To groom our tresses with a fork, in such an unwise guise.
The victuals, neither here nor there, didst fail to impress,
A mediocre fare, yet palatable, and thus I shall express.
A "meh" experience, it was indeed, but not so vile,
That I wouldst advise thee, dear reader, to avoid it with a smile.
And so, I grant it an additional star, for its fair patio,
Where thou mayst sit, and sip margaritas, with nary a care, nor woe.

Methinks we sampled many dishes upon the menu,
The pork sliders, verily, didst please my palate,
And lo, the mushroom burger, cooked to perfection,
Was devoured with gusto, and no hesitation.
The fries, they were quite good, with crunch so fine,
But alack, the mashed potatoes, they didst decline,
For they didst taste of naught but aged earth,
And left us feeling rather lackluster and of little worth.
But oh, the buttermilk fried chicken, how it didst fail,
For though it was crispy, and fried to perfection's bail,
It had no flavor, none at all, I do declare,
As if celebrity chef Aaron Sanchez didst forget the flair.
Perhaps the staff didst omit the salt, in their haste,
Or mayhap 'twas an oversight, of the worst taste.

"Methinks 'tis hard to render judgment on this place,
For oft I've come hither, and in days of yore,
'Twas grand, but latey, e'er since, methinks,
The quality doth suffer, and doth leave me sore.

All strive to play the host, in manner Italian,
Yet, alack, they be not from that land,
But rather, from the East, where tongues do stammer,
And thus, their speech doth grate upon mine ear.

I've tried most dishes, and found one to my liking,
The veal, ohso bucco, doth please mine taste,
But all the rest, methinks, doth pale in comparison,
To chain restaurants, which doth bring me shame.

Yet, if thou art fortunate, and dost secure
A table on the veranda, with view so fair,
Thou mayst forget the food, and revel in the atmosphere.

I still would recommend this place, with caveat,
That if thou hast good Italian food nearby,
Thou wilt not be impressed, nor think it a treat.

Not the best in Vegas, but worth a single visit,
To see if it doth suit thy taste, and whether
Thou wilt return, or choose to flee, in disgust."

"Methinks there be days when a hearty feast doth please me well,
And days when a bountiful spread doth satisfy my belly's call.
Our friends did choose Bouchon for brunch, a fine establishment indeed,
For we did crave a meal most satisfying and of quality.

A waffle of sourdough, fresh strawberries, and vanilla bean butter,
I did sample, and found it quite tasty, like a fried treat.
The vanilla bean yogurt, with granola in abundance,
Was rich, yet pleasant, the granola did ease its heaviness.

A Cobb salad, alas, did not impress, with limp lettuce and scant chicken,
A small portion, too, for a price that did seem quite steep.
But the service, I must say, was top-notch, our waters filled with speed,
A worthy stop, perhaps, for those who wish to carb-load before a night of revelry.

Yet, priced too high, methinks, for a meal of mediocrity,
At The Venetian hotel, where finer choices doth abound.
Grand Luxe, my friends, doth offer better fare, I do declare,
So, for healthy options, seek elsewhere, for richness doth abound."

"TGI Fridays I have visited twice, good sir. Firstly, I didst order their filled potato skin appetizer, a dish most grand. Alas, 'twas dry as dust, lacking sauce or any moisture, leaving much to be desired. 

The second time, I didst opt for their Caribbean chicken sandwich, with "Caribbean" sauce, no less. Fie upon it! 'Twas a vile concoction, tasting of Christmas and pumpkin pie. Cinnamon and cloves, I didst detect, on a chicken avocado sandwich, oh what a woeful sight! My husband and mother-in-law, they didst agree, 'twas not fit for consumption, I do declare. 

So, I didst send it back, and ordered the turkey burger instead. Not bad, it didst taste, but alas, I couldst not enjoy it, for everyone else had finished their repast, and I didst feel quite stressed, I do confess. 

But, the service, I must say, was most excellent. Friendly and professional, they didst attend to my needs, without hesitation or delay. And, they didst not charge me for the first dish, a kindness, indeed."

"A merry place, indeed, to dine with friends,
Bar-B-Barn, where ribs and fowl are served with ease.
If thou dost seek true Southern barbecue,
Best look elsewhere, for this place doth not pursue.

But should thou wish for tasty, cheap delight,
Come hither, friend, and take a seat tonight.
We came upon this spot, with hopes to view
The hockey game, yet found no telly in sight, alas!
Yet still, the cozy atmosphere did make
Our evening merry, despite the lack of sport.

The ribs, they were quite tender, and the sauce,
Sweet and sticky, left us all in a trance.
I had the small portion, with three ribs and fries,
And that sufficed to fill my hunger's cries.
So if thou art in search of cheerful fare,
And camaraderie, come to Bar-B-Barn, and share."

"My sweetest spouse and I didst dine upon this fair establishment, ere we didst cross the way to yonder Manor Theatre. Cocktails we didst imbibe, of strength most potent, ginger-flavored coolness, a delight! Tiny plates, spring rolls, and taro puffs, we didst share betwixt us, savory morsels all. Vegetables, though few in number, didst please mine taste, a blessing in disguise, lest confusion reign. 

Elegant, the atmosphere didst seem, soft lighting, romantic, attendants, unobtrusive, yet attentive. Hands, we didst clasp above the board, feet, we didst playfully touch beneath, and forth, into the balmy eve, we didst stroll, well-satisfied. 

Prices, steep they be, like presentation, fair, yet atmosphere and detail, do justify the cost, a luxury, once yearly, I do allow."

"Hark, what shenanigans did our server play,
With IDs, he didst give us quite the fray.
Aged 24 and 25, we didst protest,
But still, he didst insist on being the best.

And thus, we didst order rolls galore,
To see if they couldst impress us, evermore.
Lava, a special roll, didst fail to wow,
Dragon, the best, didst make our taste buds vow.
Veggie, for the lonely non-meat eater,
Didst surprise us, with its flavor so keen.
Tempura shrimp, alas, didst lack all zest,
Leaving us unimpressed, and somewhat depressed.

Edamame, a simple dish, didst please,
But how couldst it go wrong, with ease?
Cheesecake, oh sweet delight,
With raspberry and chocolate, a heavenly sight.
A date place, perhaps, if crowds thou beat,
And servers, fair and lovely, to greet.

Alas, there be better sushi places,
I do declare, with no trace of laces.
So, if thou seekst good sushi, look elsewhere,
For this place, alack, doth not compare."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous place indeed,
With happy hour prices most reasonable, I do declare.
The chambers large and clean, a sight to behold,
But mark my words, they do attempt to overcharge, I am told.
And furthermore, they ask for a tip,
Pray tell, what sorcery is this? A pox upon their house, I say!"

"Twas but a middling fare, my friend, with prices somewhat steep. Yet, mayhap I shall venture thither once more, forsooth. The servant, kind and courteous, didst attend to mine needs with some dispatch, alack."

"Methinks my wife and I didst hear much talk of Freddy's, and thus we didst decide to give it a go. Upon our arrival, the dining room didst bustle with activity, which didst add to mine own anticipation.

I didst order the number one, which didst consist of Freddy's original double burger, with cheese, of course. And when it didst arrive, I must confess, I was somewhat dismayed by the portion. Wherefore, the beef? Forsooth, the patties were of a size most similar to cold cuts, and the bun didst overshadow the burger, by far.

Despite this, Freddy's doth remain a good choice, and I wouldst return, anon, should I find myself in the vicinity. Howbeit, I wouldst not venture forth out of my way, forsooth, for the portion didst leave me somewhat disappointed."

"Fair terrace of North Show, with view so fine,  
Maketh the price of margarita, sixteen coin, seem worth the fee.  
In sooth, 'tis a fair sight, with nature's grace,  
But alack, the misters, they do not always find their place.  
For when the sun doth beat, with heat most fierce,  
Their waters doth trickle down, like tears of piercing sorrow,  
And doth wet thy head, with drops most chill,  
Leaving thee to ponder, if 'twere wise to pay the bill."

"A scant selection, mainly noodles and dumplings, yet
The prices, fair and reasonable, doth make it worth;
Quick service, like a swift and nimble breeze,
This place doth fill with folk, both young and old,
At lunch and dinner hours, for price and taste,
Do draw the crowds, in numbers vast and bold.

A bowl of pork feet noodle soup, I didst savor,
On a cold winter's eve, when hunger didst gnaw;
The steaming broth, a balm to my chilled frame,
Didst warm and cheer me, like a lover's embrace.
The portion, just enough, nor too much, nor little,
Didst leave me sated, not uncomfortably full.

The servers, busy as they were, didst strive
To seat and serve, with all due haste and diligence;
Their efforts, worthy of praise and commendation,
Didst make the experience, most pleasant and enjoyable, indeed."

"Methinks I am surprised that thine reviews of this place be so high. Forsooth, I do confess that I am particular when it comes to mirth and laughter, yet I found this establishment to be but mediocre. The seats, alack, be old-fashioned and uncomfortable, in the style of days of yore. The show, alas, be interactive, which brought forth both merriment and woe. (Verily, I knew not of such things as World of Warcraft, which the crowd did suggest with great fervor.)\n\nI must confess that I didst find myself bored more oft than not, for the skits didst drag on overlong. I fear that I shall not trouble thee with my presence again. Yet, I do acknowledge that thy venue be most welcoming to children, a trait that doth speak well of thee."

"Hark! What place is this? Methinks 'tis fair and bright,
The blizzards, they do please my taste,
In especial, the Oreo doth delight,
And fries, oh how they do satisfy.
But woe betide the drive-thru, slow of pace,
For when my craving for ice cream doth seize,
I pray the wait be short, lest I lose patience.
Yet still, the treats they serve, do make it worth,
My visit to this place, of sweet deserts."
"Fare victuals, fair ambiance. A trifle dear, perchance, for midday repast, yet satisfactory. Servants, attentive and brisk. Shall revisit, anon!"

"Hopped in a hackney coach and made haste to Del Frisco's, whereupon arrival, found the establishment to possess a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain... how shall I say? A certain air of informality, akin to a humble tavern, rather than a refined Chicago steakhouse. Yet, the martini, well-mixed and generously poured, did please mine taste buds. 

Verily, I do confess, aesthetics play a significant role in mine culinary experiences. And thus, I must admit, the diminutive size of the salad fork didst strike a discordant note. Forsooth! A hearty, manly utensil doth complement a $50 steak, in mine humble opinion.

Moving onward, the crab appetizer, alas! Didst not quite meet mine expectations. A copious amount of Old Bay, coupled with a generous portion of crab, didst not quite tantalize mine taste buds. Nay, nay! Give me crab served upon a bed of golden straw, and I shall be content! Alas, this dish didst fall short of mine lofty standards.

The Wedge salad, dressed with blue cheese, a dish which, when prepared aright, doth delight, didst suffer from an excess of moisture, rendering the lettuce limp and the dressing somewhat bland.

But fear not, dear friends! For the steak, verily, didst shine resplendent! With mine miniature fork, I didst partake of a most tender, flavorful steak, accompanied by a trio of delectable sides - corn, spinach, and mashed potatoes. (Aye, I didst order three sides, forsooth!)

In conclusion, gentle readers, should thou find thyself in the vicinity of Del Frisco's, do give the steak a try. 'Tis worth the price of admission, I doth assure thee!"

"As I strolled along the bustling strip, pondering which club to enter, a representative of the bank outside Bellagio didst offer me a wristband of "free entrance". Thou, I didst accept the offer and didst find that 'twas not entirely free, for I didst have to pay a sum of $20, albeit at a reduced price, they didst tell me. But lo, the line moved swiftly and I didst gain entry within five minutes. I didst avail myself of the coat-check, though 'twas at a cost of $5, lest I lose my garment. Straightway, I didst proceed to the bar and didst present my coupon for a complimentary drink. The barkeep didst inform me of my choices and I didst select one, which proved to be a passable potion. As I sipped my drink, I didst observe the gogo dancers and other maidens dancing and making merry. The gogo dancers were fair, their beauty didst shine bright, yet their movements didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi. The ladies within the club were fair and lovely, and didst grant me a moment to take a picture with them. Alas, I didst not partake in the dancing, for the floor didst appear somewhat cramped, but the music didst please mine ears, a mix of dance tunes and the speakers didst provide a sufficient volume. Moreover, they didst possess a VIP area for private gatherings. Methinks I shall return anon."

"Alas, fair traveler, I have witnessed woe,
In terminals one and two, such misery doth flow.

The first, for domestic flights, doth boast
Of covered parking, a convenience, no doubt.
But alack, the coin-meter parking, gone, alas!
Yet, payment by card, a small reprieve, 'twill pass.

Cleanliness, a virtue, lacking, I do fear,
In terminal one, a tidy state, not always near.
The information desk, with friendly folk, doth abound,
And signs, clear as day, on LCD screens, are found.

Ah, but alas, fair reader, avoid, I pray,
Scheduling flights on Fridays, weekends, nay!
For crowds, aplenty, doth fill the space,
A chaotic scene, most vexing, in this place.

And thus, we come to terminal two,
For international flights, and those to Hawaii, anew.
Signs, easy to miss, a problem, I do declare,
A larger sign, a solution, they should prepare.

Parking, uncovered, rates the same, I find,
A pity, for travelers, with luggage, in mind.
Cleanliness, a word, not often heard,
In terminal two, a state, unpleasant, I have feared.

Four carousels, for luggage, a sight to see,
Easy to find, your belongings, a relief, for thee.
But watch, dear traveler, thy goods, with care,
For in this terminal, a sense of unease, doth linger there."

"A feast most genuine and fresh didst lie before mine eyes, yet more onions than my taste doth crave. Alas, no substitutions were allowed, and thus I made do with the dish as 'twas writ. Forsooth, I hold that when I spend mine own hard-earned coins, the meal should be as I desire. The chef, Romeo, doth believe his creations perfect, and any change would mar the flavor. Mayhap, but the menu didst not meet mine expectations, and thus I fear I shall not return for another repast. Save for the sweets, which didst delight mine taste buds. Verily, an wondrous array of confections."

"Alas, I had hoped to find delight in this spectacle,
But alas, it did not quite meet my expectations.
There were moments that did stir my soul,
But overall, it did not leave me in a state of elation.

The first part of the show, all I saw was Holly's back,
A sight that left me feeling somewhat lacking.
But fear not, dear friends, for her bosom did make an appearance,
A sight that brought a smile to my face, I must confess.

The green pole dancer, she was a wondrous sight,
Her movements fluid and graceful, a true delight.
And the chosen gentleman, oh so awkward and cute,
He brought a chuckle to my lips, I must admit.

But alas, the rest of the girls, their breasts were not so fake,
A surprise, indeed, for in my life, I've never seen such a sight.
So, my advice, dear friends, wait for discounted tickets,
For on the night of the show, or before, they may be found.

We watched it on Christmas weekend, and the row in front,
Was empty, a shame, for it was a sight to behold."

"Hark! A conundrum doth present itself, fair friends,
In rating Kung Fu Tea, where boba doth reign supreme.
For though the tea leaves doth taste of highest quality,
Our drinks, alas, did leave a bit to be desired, methinks.

Aye, we tried the milk black tea and milk oolong,
With sugar at 70%, a diluted taste did linger.
I pray, good sirs, do avoid this mistake,
And choose a sweeter brew, forsooth, 'tis worth the risk.

The oolong, a woodsy, smoky flavor doth possess,
Which may not suit all tastes, alack, and alas,
But the black tea, with bergamot oil doth shine,
Though some may find it soapy, in truth, 'twere divine.

My friend, my love, and I, didst all agree,
That Kung Fu Tea's service doth excel, in courtesy.
For when my love didst express his dislike,
They didst offer to create another drink, most kind.

So shall I rate this place, with stars three and a half?
For though the drinks didst not impress, their tea leaves doth ravish.
Aye, I shall return, to sample more of their delights,
When next in Vegas, forsooth, with all my might."

"Hark! A place most wondrous, where thou may find solace and cheer,
In the still of day, when energy doth wane and flag.
A haven of delight, with treats both sweet and savory,
To revive thy spirits, and banish all flagging.

Their banana Nutella, a dish most divine,
Doth strike the perfect balance, betwixt sweet and fine.
And should thou seek a drink, of fruit and worth,
Their smoothies, priced the same, shall quench thy thirst and earth.

So, gentle reader, heed my words of praise,
And seek out this haven,'midst the busy days.
For there, thy senses shall be regaled and cheered,
By the wondrous fare, that doth await thee, unfeared."

"Verily, I have yearned for a Mongolian stir fry in the Queen City for a fortnight. Forsooth, memories of yore didst flood mine eyes, of days gone by, when as a young maiden, I didst partake in such feasts. And lo, 'twas a wondrous sight, to behold a Genghis Grill in Charlotte! 

The Good: 
Hark, fair sirs and madams, 'tis true, thou doth make thine own repast here. Yea, verily, 'tis thy fault, an thou dost not love the ingredients. A plethora of toppings doth abound, of proteins, starches, vegetables, sauces, spices, and more. The staff doth instruct thee well, as thou navigatest the bowl bar. In sooth, I didst enjoy mine bowl, and made it fiery hot, with dragon sauce, jalapeno, and red pepper. Mine mouth didst burn with passion! Moreover, the prices doth seem fair, at eight and nine silver pence, for luncheon and dinner bowls, respectively. The children shall revel in this place. 

The Meh: 
Alack, 'tis a chain, and thus, lacks character, methinks. Though the service doth excel, I didst not tarry long, nor didst desire to do so. Furthermore, the quality of the proteins didst leave somewhat to be desired...the shrimp, alas, were small, and some of mine steak, didst border on toughness. 

Shall I return to Genghis Grill? Indeed, for 'tis a swift, affordable, and healthful meal, which doth please mine taste."

"Hark! To Phat Phranks we didst venture forth,
For Mexican victuals of the earth.
A 3.5 star establishment, by my reckoning,
With fare that didst leave me somewhat shaken.

The huevos rancheros, a dish most fair,
Didst come with sauce of red or green, I didst declare.
Green, with pork, didst I choose, in sooth,
But found the dish in grease to be o'er-suthed.

Beans, eggs, and fried chips, all didst swim
In a sea of grease, most unbecoming.
A traditional huevos rancheros, 'twas not,
But the fried potatoes, delicious, they were got.

Flautas, crispy and fresh, with guacamole so bright,
Didst please mine taste buds, with delight.
Good service, we didst receive, in truth,
But tap water, charged, a strange sight, in sooth.

A 3.5 star rating, I didst give,
For the greasy meal, and the water, I didst live.
A Vegas thing, perchance, but strange, indeed,
To pay for water, when all else doth succeed."

"Upon this fair course, we didst play,  
On twenty-sixth of November, in the year of five.  
The greens, they were slow, yet the views, they were fair,  
Some amazing, some not, but still a sight to see there.  
A good course for the ladies, with tees of four thousand,  
Four hundred, a number that doth make their game more gentle.  
A value of one hundred, a price most fair and true,  
Not quite as testing as Wildfire, but still, a challenge anew."

"Hark! My friend and I, from Colorado's land,
Do love to dine at Hawaiian restaurants grand.
Moki's, we tried, with menu vast and wide,
And found the chicken katsu, short ribs beside.
The katsu sauce, alas! Was not so fine,
Nor were the ribs, for they were tough and divine.
A bit too dear, the prices did seem,
Yet still, our bellies were full, and we did gleam."
"A plague upon this crowded bar, where one must fight to find a seat! \n\nYet, verily, the Swedish meatballs did please my taste, so sweet."

"A humble tavern, fit for any purse,
With victuals savory, and a pleasant course.
Chang's fiery fowl, a dish divine,
Yet, broth of sour and hot, a touch too fine.
Dim lights within, a fitting scene,
To feast and revel in this culinary dream.
Kind servers, swift in their employ,
And drinks galore, to make merry and enjoy.
PF Chang's, a place to visit, now and then,
For a meal most satisfying, and a night with friends."

Thou hast visited this place, and with haste,
Didst partake of their brew, a drip coffee, so bright.
And, verily, 'twas a tasty treat, I do confess.
Yet, the cost of the sandwich, oh how it did sting!
Eight dollars, methinks, doth border on the extreme.
The service, however, didst flow with ease and grace,
Like a river that doth know its proper place.
The ambiance, alack, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
A Starbucks feel, perchance, doth not suffice to make it so.
In conclusion, thus, my thoughts on this place doth lie,
'Tis neither great, nor bad, but rather, a mixed bag, I do aver.

"Hark, good sir! Let us begin with five bright stars,
For such was my initial impression, 'twas quite fair.
But then, alack! The service did falter,
For though there was but one other patron, 'twas a bother.

The time it took for my repast to arrive,
Was fifteen minutes, a wait most unwise.
And lo! A car did pull up, and the pair within,
Didst enter, and thus, another star didst spin.

Ah, but the food, how couldst it be so?
Heavy on salt, a fault most grievous, I do declare.
Yet, praise be to the man who took my order,
For he was kind, and ensured all was in order.

This place, a dive, alack! Yet, fame didst it gain,
From Food Network's show, a worthy acclaim.
My Pastrami Burger, delicious, beyond compare,
And the garlic fries, oh! How they didst fare!
Thin, yet moist, and full of flavor, a true delight,
I shall return, to partake of their splendor, anon, this night.

Alas, the price, a bit steep, I must confess,
Yet, the portion, generous, and thus, 'twill suffice.
So, to the Decatur St location, I shall make haste,
To savor once more, their culinary grace."

"Hark, good sir, my greatest grievance doth lie  
In yonder eatery, where cold did reign supreme.  
'Twas winter's chill, yet still they did employ  
The AC, which made our teeth to chatter and our limbs to freeze.  
But fear not, for the pico and guacamole,  
They were most delectable, a true delight.  
And fish tacos, oh how they did impress,  
A culinary marvel, worth the price, no doubt.  
Yet, alas, the ceviche did not meet our hopes,  
But neither was it vile, just not what we had supposed.  
So, shall I say, this place doth have its charms,  
But not enough to make me travel far and wide.  
Yet, should thou find thyself nearby, do give  
This eatery a try, thou mightst be pleasantly surprised."

"Methinks, fair Vegas, thou art a place most dear to my heart,
Where gambling and revelry do ne'er depart.
I've visited many a casino in NorCal, 'tis true,
But none have offered me a massage, save this one, anon.

At a pai gow table, full of players, I did sit,
When a worker approached, with a offer most fit.
A massage, he proposed, and the player beside me,
Did accept, and thus, a giant cushion did he see.

The masseuse, with skillful hands, did work her magic spell,
And the player, in relaxation, did revel in his seat.
For ten minutes, she worked, and then, did ask for pay,
A score of twenty dollars, a fair price, come what may.

Alas, the cocktail waitresses, did not often come by,
With drinks, to quench our thirst, and thus, we did sigh.
But still, I would return, for the pleasure of the game,
To this casino, with three stars, and naught but fame."

"Hark! What discord doth mine ears perceive?
A tumult of loud noise, a cacophony most dire.
'Tis naught but cash that doth the patrons crave,
And boobs, alack, do they so eagerly engage.
Prepare thyself to stand for hours on end,
For music, good or great, doth never cease to blend.
Girls dance upon the bar, with grace so fine,
While bartenders, full of mirth and wit divine.
Alas, a place of merriment, yet I, a maid so fair,
Didst feel most ill at ease amidst the rough and wild array."

"As I did drive to mine inn, a friend did espy
A place beside the road, and we did stop.
I did not partake of fries, but my comrade did say
It was a poor choice, and he did wish for fried zucchini instead,
Which was, by the way, most excellent, I must confess.
I had the farmer's omelet, and it was quite divine,
The hash browns, too, were cooked to perfection, I did find.
I had too much victual, alas, and did feel the effects,
But the repast was delectable, I must admit."

"A fair location, with victuals most fine,

Yet, alack, the one dish that didst pique my interest, 
The beignets, were nowhere to be found, alas! 
My heart didst sink, like lead within my breast, 
For naught but disappointment didst I find, good sirs. 

And so, I chose a chicken sandwich instead, 
Which, though tasty, was not quite the feast I had hoped. 
The service, middling, with staff who knew not their menu, 
Leaving me to wonder, would I e'er return anon? 

Perchance, if fate didst bring me to this place once more, 
But, nay, 'twould not be my first choice, that's for sure."

"If thou art fond of hearty, rich fare,
Cowboy Ciao shall be thy haven, I declare.
Though their victuals did not fully impress,
Their hospitality, I must confess,
Was quite agreeable, and the hostess fair.
Yet, I wouldst prefer to stroll around the bend,
To FNB, where culinary delights doth tend."

In this place of chance and sport,
The staff doth wear a friendly countenance,
And welcome guests with open arms,
To partake of games of hazard and delight.

The floor of play doth shine so bright,
With shops and eats to please the sight,
A theme of old New York doth reign,
And all doth seem so well maintained.

But alas, the rooms above,
Doth show their age, and need of love,
For time hath left them somewhat behind,
And modern touches they do lack, in sooth.

"A pox upon the rude lady at the front,
Whose behavior did my ire inflame.
We ordered seven orders of dumplings, by my count,
And paid for them, in full, without a doubt.
But lo, they gave us but fifty, in shame,
And when we asked for more, she did exclaim,
With lip-smacking and a scowl most vile,
"You'll not receive another, 'tis our rule."

Oh, how my anger did swell and boil,
At such poor service, and with a soil
Of rudeness too! For though the food was fine,
Their conduct left much to be desired, I do confess.
But still, I must admit, the dumplings were divine,
And the young waitress, with a heart so kind,
Did make amends, with extra sauce, and a smile so bright.
So, there you have it, friends, a tale of woe,
Of poor service, but also, of some joe."

"A fair and lovely inn, with rooms so fine,
But, alas, the eateries, too dear for mine.
Their plays, a delight, 'Yellow Brick Road' doth shine,
And 'Steel Panther', a band of merriment divine.
The pool, a haven, where one may lounge and play,
But, lo, last Saturday, they didst us away,
At four o'clock, to make room for a wedding feast,
And with such haste, our stay didst come to an end, ere we couldst finish our repast."

"Methinks I fell prey to o'er-hyped patties,
Good, yet not quite mind-blowing, didst they seem.
Quality of meat, indeed, was of high grade,
But flavor, alack, didst lack that certain gleam.
A pinch of salt, I added, to give it zest,
Lest it be deemed plain, and thus, unworthiest.

The side salad, small, yet fresh and fair,
With dressing, most excellent, didst pair.
My companion's grilled chicken, good,
But seasoning, alas, didst lack, as it would.

Tessaro's, give it a try, I do advise,
Yet, heed this warning, lest thou be misguided.
Keep thy hopes low, lest disappointment doth arise."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Dine here with ease,  
For grub and hospitality, 'tis a breeze.  
Adequate, thou sayest? By my troth, 'tis true,  
No harm shall come to thee, nor ills anew.  
Forgetful, art thou? Fear not, for 'twill pass,  
The ambiance, present; service, a sight to glass.  
So, sit thee down, and dine with glee,  
For here, thy hunger shall be set free."

"In days of yore, when Quebec's streets did teem
With shoppers eager to partake of dreams,
A place of commerce did arise, 'twas called
Dupuis and Frères, a store of great renown.
Its wares did draw the masses far and wide,
And with each passing year, its fame did grow.
The family who owned it, Canadians of old,
Didst make it thrive, their efforts never cold.
But now, alas! the times have changed,
And with it, the purpose of this place arranged.
A center commercial now doth stand,
With shops and eateries at hand.
Yet still, within its walls, a sense doth linger
Of that which once did make it such a tinger.
For those who seek the past, a visit doth reveal
A tale of success, of dreams that did conceal.
And though the present may not be so grand,
Still, 'tis a place where memories doth expand."

"Methinks we didst stop in once more,
For a chocolate concoction most divine,
With one addition, toasted coconut, alack,
Which didst naught but hinder the drink's design.
A wondrous shake indeed, yet we didst share,
For 'twas so filling, we couldst not bear
To finish it alone, and thus we didst spare
Our bellies, and our purses, by this act so fair."

"Methinks I do adore my Chinese fare,
And thus, I seize each chance to review a new lair.
This place we chose, for its happy hour did gleam,
A rarity, alack, in this town's Chinese scene.
But, truth be told, the victuals here are not the best,
One of my friends did query the meat's true quest.
Yet, as I said, the price is low, and that's a fact,
So, fill your belly, though the taste may lack."

"Hark! We came to this place, my love and his kin,
For dinner and merriment, and to dine within.
Their prices fair, the portions great, my belly full,
I left content, my hunger sated, 'twas a bountiful pull.

The place, not grand, but for the fare we sought,
Good enough, my dear, for what we brought.
I had shrimp, crunchy and tasty, in a walnut shell,
And noodles too, in a broth that lacked a certain zest, alack.
My love, he had duck, and oh, how he did devour,
A feast, a treat, a meal most satisfying, no need to implore.

The service, kind, their smiles, a joy to behold,
Our table, clean, their care, a tale to be told.
Waters filled, a constant flow, no want, no need,
Their diligence, a virtue, indeed.

The privies, passable, a cart of dishes, near,
A wonder, a query, did it belong, a fear?
But still, they cleared, a task, a duty, well-done,
No fuss, no muss, their labors, won.

Affordable, a word, a truth, a boon,
For families, a treat, a night, a spree, a moon."

"Methinks I do adore the Italian cuisine,
And thus, when near a Best Western didst stray,
I searched on Yelp for a nearby place to dine,
And chanced upon Foccaccio, a humble wayside inn.

The food, though tasty, lacked a certain flair,
For Parmesan, freshly grated, I do declare,
Is what I seek in an Italian meal,
Not some bottled impostor, vile and mean.

The portions, too, were somewhat small,
Yet still, I would return, for all in all,
Foccaccio's fare, though not the best I've had,
Did please my taste buds, and made me feel glad."

"Methinks 'twould be a wise decision to tarry here once more. Forsooth, I didst not anticipate luxury, nor didst I expect it to be as pleasant as 'twas. We didst require a lodging most hastily and reserved a chamber for that eve, priced at a mere $50. Ye get what ye pay for, and those who do complain of its grunge shouldst have known such ere they booked it. 'Tis somewhat distant from the Strip, yet not so far as Hard Rock. They do sell Bud Lights for $1.50 at the tavern within, which doth please me mightily. I didst join the Owl Club to gain $200 in free slot play. Alas, I won naught, but neither did I lose aught. The folk who tended the counter were most courteous and obliging. The chamber was clean, with a telly, what more couldst thou ask for? As I didst say, I wouldst indeed stay here again, anon, when seeking a humble hostelry in Vegas.

Beware, good sirs and madams, the walls are most thin, and thou shalt hear near every sound from the room beside thee. If thou dost seek a tranquil experience in Vegas, thou art in the wrong place, by my troth.

And, prithee, avoid the Hooters within this inn, 'tis woefully vile. (See my other review for further insight.)"

"Methinks this place hath promise to be a merry spot,
With friendly staff, a stage for jests and games,
A roach coach nearby, serving victuals hot,
The makings of a pleasant neighborhood haunt,
'Tis true, the Living Social deal didst make it so,
That we might taste their brews and revel in delight."

"Last eve, a friend and I did dine here,
And found the service to be fair and dear.
Our waitress, kind and swift of pace,
Did make our stay a pleasant space.

The margaritas, alas, did taste,
Like slurpees, far too sour in haste.
But still, I did enjoy my salad,
With bleu cheese, chopped and not too bad.
The Danish cheese, made from enzymes,
Was quite a delight, I must confess.

The potatoes, cooked to perfection,
Were also quite a satisfying vision.
So, though the drinks did disappoint,
I shall return, for more content."

"Twas but a middling feast, my friends,  
With naught to rave or rail about,  
I went for brunch on a weekday,  
And Wynn, that generous soul, did pay  
Half of the meal, a kindly act indeed.  
But if thou hast a sweet tooth's need,  
Then to Wicked Spoon thou shouldst speed,  
For there, my friend, thou shalt find  
A greater choice of sweetness divine."

"Alack, the wine list doth leave much to be desired,
For one who doth boast a Wine Spectator's prize.
The prices, too, do make mine eyes to widen,
In sooth, they do border on the outrageous.

But lo, the fish doth come from sustainable seas,
Save for the Chilean sea bass, alack,
Which doth teeter on the brink of extinction,
And yet, the waitress didst not comprehend
The difference 'twixt wild and farmed, nor e'en
The meaning of sustainability, alas.

The dinner, in its quality and taste, didst please,
But, alack, the risotto, devoid of salt, didst fail
To stir within mine breast a single thrill.
Ah, fair view, yet, for a hundred dollars per head,
I fear it doth not quite justify the cost."

"Four winters hath this place been open, fair maidens,
And in I walked, to find but two ladies seated,
In converse deep, their words unheeded.
No waiting, forsooth, my turn it was,
And in the chair, my brows were quickly seized.
Sanitized, her hands, and then my face,
She worked with haste, no time to waste,
Rolling, grabbing wide, and pulling fast,
Afraid, I was, my brows would be aghast.
But nay, the pain, it did subside,
And neat, my brows, now do reside.
Out came I, with look of wonder,
My friend did say, 'twas a sight to ponder.
Two brows, distinct, a light brush, and clip,
A tidy sum, of ten to fifteen snips.
I liked, my first, a little more,
For natural, it was, and not too sore.
The bottoms, left, not sculpted, but clean,
Giving me, a fuller look, serene.
Precise, the work, it must be said,
And worth, the ten, in my head."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, listen well,
For I have tales to tell of coffee's spell,
A brew most average, yet the staff, so bright,
Doth make my mornings merry and light.

Their service, swift and friendly, doth prepare
My soul for interactions with the fair,
Or perchance 'tis the caffeine, which doth stir
My spirit, making me most eager to share.

So, here's a tip, my friends, for thee,
To seek out their expertise, you'll see,
In flavors, they do excel, I do confess,
And thus, my quest for knowledge, doth begin.

Post your suggestions, prithee, let them be,
For I do crave the best, as doth my soul,
And with each sip, my heart doth sing,
Of joys, that only coffee can bring."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from mine own lips,
Of how I didst venture to this place, with naught but woeful tips.
A Yelp event, it was, that didst bring me hither,
And thus, with friends, I didst return, to chill and tarry awhile.

But lo! The music, loud and fierce, didst assail mine ears,
And with each note, my patience didst dwindle, like the petals of a flower.
The beer, it didst flow, and we didst shout above the din,
But alas! The noise, it didst prevail, and peace didst not enter in.

So heed my words, dear friend, and shun the band,
For silence, it is sweeter, than the loudest melody in the land."

"Hark! In fair Las Vegas, I didst partake
Of a most wondrous feast, a veritable smorgasbord
At Caesar's, a place of renown, they say
But alas, my expectations were not quite met
For though the spread was vast and fair
The meats, oh how they didst disappoint
Dry and lackluster, a sorry sight
Prime rib and roast beef, a poor showing
And some of the sides, oh how they didst lack
In flavor and inspiration, a true letdown
But lo, the desserts, they didst make amends
Creme Brulee, a heavenly delight
Pastries and crepes, a sweet reprieve
But alas, a pricey meal, it should be noted
The main course, a letdown, a true shame
The service too, left much to be desired
Alack, my waitress, nowhere to be found
Dirty dishes piled high, a sorry plight
Attention, hard to come by, a true disgrace
Yet still, compared to others on the Strip
This buffet, not the worst, a faint praise."

"In sooth, fair friends, I must confess,
I ne'er would purchase aught from Digger's nest.
No malice do I bear, nor have I cause,
'Tis but a matter of my own heart's pause.

Their wares, though bright and colorful,
Do not entice me with their charmful lure.
Their quaint decorations, handmade with care,
And eye-catching trinkets, doth not ensnare.

Alas, their appeal doth lie with mothers dear,
And daughters too, who hold them in affection sincere.
Forsooth, they call it 'twee', a word of endearment,
A term of fondness, and a token of their gentle sentiment."

"A pox upon the steakhouse! Their meat doth lack,
In flavor, texture, and in price, a woeful pack.
My wife, she ordered rare, yet they didst bring,
A steak so red, it seemed to sing.
And I, who asked for medium, didst receive,
A cut so done, 'twas hard to chew, and didst leave,
A taste most foul, like that of old shoe leather.
They claimed they cooked it right, but I didst know,
That better steaks are found at Outback, Longhorn,
Where tender meat doth dance upon the tongue,
And fill the senses with delight, not wrong."

"In fair Las Vegas, where I once did reside,
This shop of nutrition products did abide,
My go-to place for all things healthy and bright,
Where prices were the best, a wondrous sight.

Even now, outside the city's bounds,
I stop by oft, with haste and zeal,
For their selection vast, doth make me gleam,
With protein bars, powders, and vitamins, aye, a dream.

Alas, the service, poor and lacking,
A curt response, or pointing, unbecoming,
Yet, methinks, the prices, so low and fair,
Do make up for the customer care, so rare.

So, if thou art in need of sustenance,
And dost desire a bargain, by chance,
Then seek out this shop, with haste and speed,
For nutrition products, 'tis indeed, a creed."

"Hark! My third fave steakhouse doth lie,
With blooming onions, green veggies in the sky.
Broccoli, strings beans, asparagus they do bear,
And Texas Roadhouse, their steaks do declare.
Outback, with mushrooms, doth take the cake,
But Delfrisco's, pricy, the Wygul doth make.
The entrance, strange, doth give me pause,
Yet still, my two cents, I herewith cause."

"Upon this fair day, the twenty-first of January, two thousand twelve, I didst visit this establishment, Bombay Grille, with a most wondrous coupon, a Groupon, if thou must know. The ambiance, dark and elegant, didst please mine eyes, with naught but recessed lighting to illuminate the space. The service, prompt and attentive, didst ensure that mine glass of water was ever full, a true blessing, indeed. Forsooth, half of their menu didst cater to those who doth eschew meat, a most excellent sight. A complimentary plate of flatbread and chutneys didst greet mine arrival, a most generous gesture. The veg sampler, a diverse array of delights, didst tantalize mine taste buds, with paneer pakoras and cauliflower pakoras reigning supreme. Malai kafta, mine main course, didst satisfy mine hunger. Garlic naan and paneer bread, both most delectable. Alas, Bombay Grille, though pleasant, doth not surpass the culinary excellence of Woodlands, a place that hath captured mine heart, forevermore."

"O, how delectable these sandwiches be, yet there's a catch, good sirs. Pray tell, why doth the fire department and constabulary receive a discount in fair Las Vegas, while those in private EMS, in uniform or not, are denied such privilege? Doth it not seem a trifle unfair, a slight upon our noble calling? For are we not, each and every one, members of the same team, united in our quest to keep the peace and safeguard the public weal? Methinks 'tis time to rectify this injustice, and grant us, too, the benefit of a discount, that we may enjoy these tasty victuals without undue financial burden."

"Hark! Upon our way to Noodles of Asia, we chanced upon Pinot Brasserie, whose menu didst seem innocent enough. For $9.00, a bowl of French onion soup, and $15.00 for mussels and frites, we thought it wise to partake.

And thus, our culinary journey began. The white wine, butter, and garlic sauce, oh how divine! The frites, they didst swim in the sauce, and our taste buds, they didst sing with joy. The French onion soup, one of the better ones we'd had, with onions that didst flavor the broth, as it should be.

For dessert, we opted for the roasted strawberry, with vanilla and mint, and humbolt food cheese. Alas, the fruit was overcooked, and too mushy, it didst remind us of the ones we tried to avoid at the market. But fear not, dear friends, for the flavor combination, it was indeed awesome.

But alack, the service, it was not up to par. Our server, her name we didst not know, but her face, we shall never forget. She stared at us, as if we were mad, and her smile, it didst not come often. She didst not check on us, and her tips, they didst suffer. Oh, how we wished for a better server, one who wouldst make our dining experience, a merry one."

"Fie upon the MGM, a place most vile,
Where luxury doth not reside, nor style.
I booked a suite, a grand affair,
But they didst downgrade me, without a care.
The rooms, the casino, pool, and all,
Are mediocre, forgettable, and dull.
If thou desirest a vacation fair,
Go elsewhere, my friend, beware."

"A three-star tavern, by my reckoning, suiting well my taste in alehouses and merriment. 'Tis a true public house, with a playful Australian motif, postcards of comely lasses and swains adorning the walls, a cheeky sign pointing to an empty space, inviting patrons to partake in mirth. The atmosphere doth recall a students' guild, albeit somewhat better appointed. The clientele are convivial, the barkeepers friendly, though strict in their domain. A portion of the bar doth bear a sign, "NO SERVICE," warning those who dare approach, lest they incur disfavor. Yet, twain pool tables beckon, a true delight, provided one doth heed the custom of inscribing one's name upon the chalkboard, thereby securing a turn at play. The patrons, congenial and eager to engage in chat, shall make thy acquaintance. Common drinks, lacking fancy mixology, yet adequate for a public house. A cozy venue, thronged by Australians on their national day, but hardly shabby."

"Hark! Our latest venture to fair Vegas,
A journey most wondrous and bright,
Didst bring us to China town, a place
Where ramen doth reign supreme in delight.

With eager feet, we didst hasten there,
And found, to our joy, a seat most fair,
In scant fifteen minutes, we didst sit,
A feat most rare, and worthy of note, I do declare.

I, with my band of merry men, didst order forth,
The "screaming for vengeance" ramen, with corn,
For spicy broth, my heart doth yearn,
But alas, twas not as fiery as I had hoped, and thus, my search doth continue.

The broth, a mite too salty, mayhap,
Due to my ale-addled taste, who can say?
But still, the pork belly, oh so fat and fair,
Didst please mine eyes, and satisfied my hunger, without a doubt or fear.

The noodles, cooked to perfection, al dente,
A pleasant texture, a joy to behold,
This place, a solid three and a half stars,
A rating most fair, and worth thy gold.

So if thou seekest ramen, and art in the know,
China town, a visit, doth worth thy while,
For though the broth may lack some heat,
The pork belly, and noodles, doth make up the treat."

In this merry spot, we didst find delight,
With potions brewed of curious sight.
And though the cost didst pierce our purse,
'Twas still a sum worth spending, of course.

We dined upon their delectable fare,
And sipped their draughts with joy and care.
Their coupon, twenty dollars off, didst ease
Our burden, making it a pleasant breeze.

Afore, we hadst visited this place,
And found it to be full of grace.
The victuals were of finest sort,
And those who served us, didst play their part.

"A plethora of tea, a feast for mine eyes!
And my raspberry hibiscus iced tea, oh how fine!
Brewed to perfection, a taste divine.
I would frequent this place, 'twere it not so far,
In the midst of Tempe Marketplace, alas!

Four stars, not five, for they had none of my desire,
And the lad at the till, he didst speak in ire.
Against Starbucks, his words didst flow,
Unaware that I, a Starbucks manager, didst know.

Keep thy opinions, but hold them tight,
For thou ne'er knowest who may hear thee in the night."

"Hark! The owner didst contact me, full of woe,
Concerned about my rating, a single star doth show.
He doth express his gratitude for my review,
And doth display a genuine desire to make things new.
A rare breed, this owner, who doth not dismiss
My words as foolishness, but doth take them to heart, and thus
I have raised my rating, from one to three,
For his pro-activeness, and willingness to see.
He hath invited me to meet with him,
To discuss the matter further, and thus I shall,
And mayhap, after our meeting, I shall change
My rating once again, if it doth warrant the same."

"Methinks I toil oft till night's dark veil doth fall, And yonder eatery, open late, doth call. Their victuals, finer than the common fare, Do please my taste, and worth the wait, I swear. Ask for a recommendation, and 'twill be given, For chicken fried rice, my heart doth often crave."

"A foul stench doth fill the dining hall, alack!  A pox upon the scent, that doth my meal besmirch!  Oh, how I wish to dine alfresco, in yonder patio, where flowers bloom and birds do sing!  'Tis a fair place, indeed, for diverse folk to gather, with victuals for all, from savory gyros and shwarmas, to a medley platter, fit for vegetarians, with hummus, baba, tsaziki, tabouleh, and falafel, in abundance.  Generous portions, prithee!  Lentils and rice, a feast for the eyes, as large as the main course, itself!  Swiftly, the food doth arrive, and at a fair price, no less!  No wonder, then, that this establishment doth teem with patrons, night and day!"

"Hark! A wanderer I, in search of sustenance new,
Didst stray from my workplace, where Eco Bistro doth brew.
A weary soul, with hunger pangs that would not cease,
I chanced upon a place, where Ohio doth meet the highway's ease.

The sign didst boast a meal most fair and cheap,
And so, I entered, with hope in my heart, to partake.
A soda I didst order, and waited with glee,
For the Kung Pao Chicken, that didst soon be mine to see.

Prepared to order, it was, with haste and care,
And oh, how tasty! My hunger, it didst now declare.
The price, a mere six tokens, a bargain indeed,
And so, I sat within, in a space both clean and neat.

A humble abode, with few tables to seat,
Yet full of charm, and a meal most discreet.
Thus, I didst dine, with a heart full of cheer,
In this place, where strangers didst gather, without fear."

"Methinks this place doth have most excellent ratings,
On both Yelp and Zagat, such praise they be getting.
But alack, my expectations were too high, methinks,
For though their Thai Iced Tea be most divine,
Their food, alas, did not meet my expectations.

The waiter recommended their duck in red curry,
But lo, the meat did taste a bit... expired,
And rough, and lacking in flavor, didst seem.
A green curry with chicken we didst also try,
But nay, 'twas not amazing, nor didst it astound.
I've had far better, back in New York,
At any regular Thai joint, I do declare.

And lo, the appetizer, the waiter didst say,
We must order, 'twas their most popular dish,
But nay, 'twas sour and expired-tasting, fie!
Why doth it please the people of Las Vegas?
I know not, but methinks they be strange, indeed.

And lo, the lady behind the bar, so rude,
With a great diamond on her finger, a sight to see,
But nay, her demeanor didst not match her gem,
For she, a snotface, didst make our meal most unpleasant,
A pale, slender Asian woman, with a skinny face,
And long black hair, a warning, beware her presence."

"In fair Venetian, a restaurant doth lie,
Casanova named, a place of culinary art.
A table reserved, for thirteen guests didst I,
Yet, alas! 'Twas in the walkway, out of doors didst start.
The din of bar and food court, didst make it loud,
And thus, a recommendation, for small groups, I avow.

Within, the decorations, quaint and charming be,
A perfect setting, for a meal most free.
The Timballo, a dish of penne, baked with care,
In creamy pesto sauce, with parmesan, didst flourish there.
Filling and flavorful, the bread, didst delight,
Warm and roasted, a true culinary sight.

For Italian fare, at prices fair and bright,
Casanova, doth shine, a true delight."

A bustling shop, with queues that stretch and twine,
Yet moves apace, for all the wares they design.
Some items, cheap as chips, a steal, indeed,
Two for a penny, or so it would seem.
Not vast, this emporium of nicknacks galore,
But near, and thus my feet do often explore.
I enter, seeking one specific prize,
Yet leave, some ten dollars lighter, with surprise.
For though some goods may be of dubious source,
My purse, it doth protest, with each new endors.

"Methought, fair readers, I would give a try
To Beijing, a place most convenient nigh,
In stead of Ho Ho Cherry House, my heart's desire,
Whose fare I oft have savored with great delight.

A sesame chicken dish, extra crispy, didst order I,
With fried rice, egg roll, and soup, a feast most fair and nigh,
And broccoli, a vegetable most green and bright,
Didst complete this meal, a veritable sight.

Ten minutes, a mere moment, didst pass ere my food didst arrive,
Freshly cooked, a feast fit for a king, didst I perceive.
The egg rolls, a delight, didst surpass Ho Ho's, I must confess,
For in them, cabbage was not the only guest.

The rice, a treat, didst please my taste, I must avow,
And the soup, a delicacy, didst warm my heart, I vow.
Even the young ones, whom I didst babysit, didst enjoy,
The won-ton soup, a treat, didst make their eyes employ.

But alas, dear friends, the crispiness, a shame,
Didst lack the punch, a fault, didst bring me shame.
I fear, didst I not ask for extra crispy, a mistake,
The chicken, a disappointment, didst my senses forsake.

And thus, my friends, a try, I shall give once more,
With emphasis on crispiness, a must, I implore.
For though the sauce, a letdown, didst seem,
The price, the location, a dream, a scheme."

"A fair repast, with some dishes that did please,
And others that did not quite meet my ease.
The slider trio, with its savory delight,
Was paired with jalapeno coleslaw, a wondrous sight.
But alas, the slaw did not quite live up to my hope,
It lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain scope.
The pulled pork, too, did not quite meet my taste,
It seemed more like pork roast, and not quite worth the haste.
But the hot link, oh how it did impress,
With its fiery spice, it did my senses bless.
The country berry cobbler, alas, did not quite win,
It lacked the sweetness that my soul did spin.
But still, the place did have a certain charm,
With its cozy decor and atmosphere disarm.
I liked the personal touches, the murals so fine,
And so, we shall return, to try the smoked meatloaf divine."

"Methinks my friend doth hold a secret fondness for gift shops,
Wherein he doth spend hours, lost in rapt attention.
'Tis an official one, with gifts both tweet and corny,
Yet also boasts some elegance, in its wares most fair and sunny.

The quality, too, doth far surpass the cheaper fare,
That doth abound upon the Royal Mile, with music loud and colors rare.
So, 'tis a matter of thy budget, and how much thou doth wish to roam,
In search of gifts or souvenirs, ere thou dost make thy home.

The service, too, doth please me well, for she, the lady fair,
Doth show great kindness, and doth not mind my friend's long browsing there.
Nor doth she follow us, like some base gift shop doth, with haste and spite,
But rather, leaves us be, to ponder, and to choose, with all due time and right.

And thus, if thou hast paid to enter the Castle grand,
Why, take a stroll, and look about, ere thou dost make thy stand."

"Last week, I dined with a friend at this establishment. Parking nearby is possible, but limited, and there are no dedicated parking spots for the restaurant. Upon entering, I was greeted by the delightful aroma of spices. The atmosphere within was cozy, yet intimate, with tables arranged closely together. As a larger person, I found the seating to be somewhat cramped, but not overly so. The staff were friendly and attentive, and the food was fresh, tasty, and served promptly. The menu offered a variety of dishes, some with a hint of Indian flavor, though I cannot truly judge its authenticity, never having been to India. My friend's dish and the desserts were particularly enjoyable, the latter being a house-made almond and cashew ice cream, flavored with cardamom, which was truly exceptional. Unfortunately, I cannot comment on the restrooms, as I did not use them. Payment by card is possible, but I am unsure if they accept all types of cards."

"This place, with its fair decor and pleasant air, didst first entice me in, while at Caesar's I didst stay. A cool fish tank, and neat appointments, didst catch mine eye. All in white, the staff didst don their garb, and the whole room, in white, didst shine so bright. A beef and noodle dish, I didst try, but alas, 'twas lacking in flavor, and left me wanting more. In Vegas, where prices be high, my bill didst come to some $35, for my meal and ale, didst cost me dearly."

"Methinks the ambiance here doth seem familiar, yet strange,
A feeling hard to describe, like a dream half-remembered.

We tried the luncheon special, a dish most fair,
An open-faced green chili meatloaf sandwich, with care
Piled high upon the plate, a feast for mine eyes,
With mashed potatoes o'er the bread, and a slaw most prize.

Alas, the potatoes, they were o'er-mixed, I fear,
And thus, their texture, gummy, and not so dear.
But still, the meatloaf, tasty, and the slaw, a delight,
Did make the dish worth trying, in my sight.

The grilled salmon salad, a dish most fine,
With chive risotto cake, a flavor divine.
Yet, mayhap 'twas the citrus dressing, that did clash,
And made the risotto cake, a taste not so dash.

The service, good, and naught to complain,
A pleasant experience, save the gummy grain.
I would return, but not with haste,
For other ventures call, and time doth waste."

"Forty minutes to spare, the crowd did swell,
And thus, my worry of slow service did dwell.
But lo, a table free, I quickly didst sit,
And in five minutes' time, a drink didst fit.

Buffalo wings, twenty minutes didst take,
But in ten, they didst upon my plate make.
The service, in truth, didst excel,
But alas, the wings, too vinegary didst tell.
Two gentlemen, with fish and chips didst dine,
And deemed them good, their taste didst align.

A fair price, the menu didst hold,
But nine dollars, for a Stella, bold?
Yikes, indeed, such price doth make me shudder."

"Though grub didst not impress, the server's grace Did make amends. A man of skill and pace, He catered well to our each whim. My name, alas! Mr. Tofu, didst conjure thoughts Of veggie dishes, but alas! Not so. A solitary soup, cold and plain, With three ingredients didst make its claim. Noodles, tofu broth, and ice didst play Their parts, but flavor didst not stay. Tasting of tofu, bland and weak, I added kimchee to make it speak. Side dishes, good, didst add their zest, But still, I shall not visit, save my quest For meat, once more to savor and delight."

"Pray tell, what maketh these shoes so fine? Is it their name, their comfort, or their style? In sooth, I find them not to be inviting, nor doth their design seem fitting for one in their prime. But mayhap I err, for all ye fond of them, 'twas said that half the store didst bear a discount of fifty percent but last week!"

"Five stars, methinks, for this clever notion,
A cupcake shop in fair Scottsdale, what a vision!
The store itself, bright and airy, doth delight,
