But, alas, their sweets, they do not quite excite.

I must confess, I am not fond of sugary treats,
And thus, my judgment may be somewhat skewed,
But, I have tasted Magnolia's finest delights,
And found them to be truly divine, with all my might.

Sprinkles', on the other hand, didst not impress,
Their sweetness, verily, didst border on excess,
And when we shared a red velvet, oh dear me!
The top came off, a sight most curious, couldst see.

In conclusion, five stars for the concept, indeed,
But, alack, their sweets, they did not quite succeed."

"Methinks 'twas passing strange, the dishes they didst create,
With lobster in each bite, a feast most elate.
In sandwiches, salads, fritters, and even ice cream,
The crustacean didst play the main theme.

But alack, the taste didst not quite meet the cost,
For twenty-three silver pieces, a small roll was lost.
The salad, with chunks of lobster, didst please,
But bisque, oh bisque, didst fail to tease.

Lobster-n-chips, a curious delight,
Didst bring forth joy, with beer-battered might.
And last, the ice cream, with lobster bits,
Didst seem odd, yet didst tickle the taste buds' whims.

So if thou art in search of flavors new,
And hast the coins to spend, then this place anew.
But ask for samples first, ere thou dost pay,
Lest thou find thyself with ice cream savory in dismay."

"In fair Tuscany Casino, where we did abide,
A conventioneers' haven, as we did reside.
Our group of ten did gather, with much delight,
To dine within its halls, on a most pleasant night.

The seating, plentiful, did accommodate our throng,
And our server, patient, did attend to us long.
With coupon in hand, two for one, we did implore,
And he, unruffled, did honor our request, and more.

The victuals, decent, did please our taste,
And prices, fair, did not burden our purse.
The portions, ample, did satiate our hunger's haste."

"A humble meal, yet one that doth satisfy,
For lunch or dinner, or to meet with friends in cheer.
No grand feast, but still, a spread most fair and bright,
To sate thy hunger and provide a merry night."

"If thou dost fancy carne asada, my friend,
This place doth merit thy attention, 'tis true.
But if variety doth beckon thee,
Best look elsewhere, for here there be few.

Their menu doth boast but a handful of dishes,
Tacos, burritos, tostadas, and quesadillas,
And but a single dish for herbivores,
Chips and salsa, too, for a small fee, I reckon.

Yet fear not, for the carne asada doth please,
I sampled the Vampiro and quesadilla with ease.
Both were quite tasty, I must confess,
The chips were fresh, the salsa a delight, no less.

So if thou art a fan of carne asada,
This place doth warrant a visit, 'tis not a fallacy.
For though the choices be limited,
The flavors doth make up for it, in verity."

"A review for eyebrow waxing, I do pen,
On a Saturday afternoon, I did stroll in,
No waiting, straight to the back, 'twas quick,
My usual place, a half-hour journey, doth take.

This place, close by, doth save me time,
But waxing, not plucking, doth be their crime,
My brows, thin, unexpected, doth seem,
Yet, not a hair in sight, a week hath passed,

Pricing, fair, a tenner, doth be the cost,
If in a bind, again I wouldst resort,
They cards accept, but cash, for tip, doth seek."

On a Sunday, I didst venture in,
For the first time, my curiosity didst spin.
Till midnight, they do stay open wide,
A convenience, indeed, for those who doth reside
In this fair city, where the night doth reign,
And hunger pangs do strike, with naught but pain.

The sushi, alas, didst fail to impress,
A mediocre feast, at best, I must confess.
Three stars, I gave, for their edamame,
Not organic, nor their soy sauce, the same.
I ask thee, dear friends, what doth it mean,
To feed upon genetically modified dream?

A non-GMO verified soy, I doth desire,
But alas, the masses, they doth not acquire
Knowledge of GMOs, a sad, sad plight,
Leaves me to ponder, in the dark of night.
Will we, one day, doth care, and doth demand,
A change, forsooth, in this unnatural land?
Until that day, I fear, we doth remain,
In this world of modified, unnatural grain.

"Hark! A tale of Mesa Grill, a place I didst choose,
After hearing Delmonico's praise, didst lose its sheen.
A table of six, we didst have, and awkward was the seat,
In the midst of others, ours didst seem most discreet.

The food, it was great, all didst agree,
Duck, ribeye, pork, and sides, a feast for thee.
But wait, the service, not so grand,
Forgets the sides, and slow, her hand.

Desserts, just fair, the creme brulee, a delight,
But profiteroles, with ice cream, a sorry sight.
And so, Mesa Grill, a visit worth,
Despite some flaws, a place of mirth."

"Hark! What news is this? The Target doth transform,
Into a Super Store, they do declare.
A change most wondrous, and most strange,
To those who dwell within this city's range.

The folk who shop there, full of cheer,
Do welcome renovations, quite sincere.
But some, like I, do harbor fear,
That all we seek, may disappear.

For when I venture forth to buy,
My groceries, I pray, let them be nigh.
Chicken breasts, olive oil, and wine,
These are the items that I do design.

But lo! The Target now doth lack,
These very things, that I do seek.
And when I ask, with hopeful heart,
When they shall restock, they do depart.

Alas! Their answers, brief and cold,
Do leave me in a state of woe, so bold.
I pray, dear Target, heed my plea,
And bring back all that's missing, ere long, ere long!"

"Hark! I didst order noodles, a humble dish,
To sate mine hunger and quench mine thirst.
But lo! The instructions, they were unclear,
Or perhaps mine interpretation, it didst err.

In Phoenix's heat, I didst toil and sweat,
And thus, I craved naught but rest and ease.
I reached mine home, and saw the sauce,
Lava-red, it didst seem, in its intensity.

I ate a third, and wished I hadst not,
For mine lip didst swell, and face didst sweat.
A Coca Cola bottle, I didst drain,
To quench the fire that raged within.

Good sirs, do check the pepper's might,
In those take-home orders, ere ye send them forth.
I shall give thee another chance, anon,
And pray, do heed mine words, lest this mishap befall another.
This experience, I shall not soon forget,
Nor shall I let it mar mine appetite."

"Methinks I wanted to love this place, but alas, 'twas not meant to be. A humble burger joint with a fine selection of ale, yet something didst not sit well with mine eyes.

As I entered, I stood there, lost in thought, forsooth. No sign didst indicate that I should seat myself, and thus, I didst wait in vain. At last, I found a table bare of menus, and thus, I didst assume 'twas not a place of much import. But lo, the other tables didst have menus, and I didst feel a fool.

I didst order bruschetta and a pesto burger, verily, 'twas delicious, but alack, the portion was small, scarce five ounces for seven gold coins and fifty-nine silver pence. Nay, 'twas not worth the cost, though 'twas tasty, I do confess. And if thou dost desire a side of fries, prepare to pay a pretty penny, for 'tis ten gold coins, indeed.

My companion didst order mac and cheese with a bacon burger, and though the parts were delicious, the burger itself didst lack moisture. Mayhap a cheese sauce wouldst have helped?

The beer menu doth boast a grand array of brews, but alas, the rest of the establishment doth leave much to be desired."

Hark, good sir or madam, listen well to my tale,
Of a shoppe where I do frequent, with naught but praise,
The staff, they be friendly, and helpful too,
But alas, the bathroom, foul and stinking, doth ruin all anew.

A pox upon the loo, that doth sully the name,
Of this otherwise fine establishment, with shame,
For who would wish to tarry, in such a place,
Where filth doth reign supreme, and doth leave a foul trace?

And yet, despite this woe, I still do come,
For the wares they sell, beckon me, like a siren's hum,
But oh, the bathroom, how it doth make me frown,
And question whether I should stay, or turn tail and run.

A fair sports bar, 'cross from the book of sports,
In MGM, a place to grab a brew and bites.
On Saturdays and Sundays, when the football's on,
The crowd doth swell, and tables scarce become.
But fear not, for the bar doth offer seats,
If thou art early, and thy luck doth beat.

The victuals, basic fare, yet satisfying still,
Wings and burgers, worth thy while to try.
Deals on game days, shots and brews, a merry mix,
And beers on tap, a diverse lot, doth please.
No fancy frills, yet pleasant, nonetheless,
To linger, watch the games, and revel in the mess.

"Aye, Green river soda pop doth flow,
Fried mushrooms, a feast for mine eyes,
And all the Chicago favorites, so bright,
Red Hots, hot dogs of various delight.

I, myself, do lean towards fried fare,
At places such as these, 'tis my desire,
But alas, the service here did slow,
And in my heart, a pang of woe did grow.

For in this very spot, a pizza place,
Did once reside, a taste of grace,
Now gone, alack, and in its stead,
This new establishment, a different creed."

"Hark! This Dunkin' Donuts doth be one of the first,
In Madison's land, to open its doors.
'Tis situated on a corner most fair,
Where highways Q and 19 do meet and share.
A gas station doth it call its home,
A place to fill thy tank, and thus doth roam.

The staff, so friendly and full of cheer,
Didst greet us with smiles, and banish fear.
The donuts, decent indeed they were,
Worth a visit, should thou have a crave to spare.
So, if thou find thyself in this fair town,
And dost desire a sweet, tasty crown,
Give these good people a chance, I pray,
And may their donuts bring thee joy, ere the day doth fade away."

"A merry place, with victuals fair and bright,
Not wholly true to roots, yet still a sight,
A worthy meal, or twain, doth make it right.
The service, too, was good, in truth, not tight,
But laid-back, easy, like a summer's night.
The tortilla soup, a joy beyond compare,
Didst make my heart sing, and banish all despair.
So, come not here expecting grand display,
For 'tis a humble place, where one may play.
Yet, for a casual visit, 'twill do, I say."

"Amidst the whirlwind of Las Vegas' vibrant streets,
A haven of tranquility, this hotel doth meet,
With plentiful parking, a respite from the fray,
And Westin's famed bed, a veritable heavenly way.

Yet, alack, the pool, though quaint, doth lack in size,
And spa, though pleasant, doth not compare to those of might.
iHomes, too, were missing, much to mine dismay,
But still, the staff, with courtesy, did strive to make our stay.

Alas, a minor hiccup did our joy doth mar,
When, waiting with bags, no bellhop did appear.
The concierge, four folk at the desk, did naught,
Leaving us to linger, in wait, with nary a thought.
A simple word, a gesture, would have sufficed,
To ease our frustration, and our patience, have increased.

Disappointment, indeed, did our hearts doth steal,
Yet still, we found solace, in this hotel's appeal."

"Methinks this humble lodging, Motel 6 by name, doth please me well. 'Twas inexpensive, indeed, and cleanliness did abound. The staff, in their courtesy, didst greet me with a smile. My slumber, deep and long, didst ignore the wakeful call, alas, my fault, methinks. A small pool, tranquil and inviting, didst lie beside the inn. Ample parking, too, for those who came by carriage. \n\nYet, one thing, fair traveler, doth bear a warning. A theme park, full of noise and revelry, doth neighbor this place. The sounds, they do carry, and thou shalt hear them plain. Moreover, scarce doth surround this motel, so breakfast, thou must seek afar, a trifle vexing, mayhap."

"A fair enough place, with cakes of various hue,
Vanilla and chocolate, both of them quite true.
Toppings galore, and mochi, do not forget,
Lest thou wish to leave with regret.

The interior, grand and full of life,
With people of interest, and stories rife.
An Indian mother, with query so bold,
Did ask my rate, my shirt, did unfold.
Awkward, indeed, yet naught but truth,
For I, a renter, by the hour, doth prove."

"Methinks 'tis strange that I, who dwellest here, ne'er set foot within these hallowed halls. Yet, thus I ventured forth, to partake of their culinary delights. 

Ah, the view! 'Tis a sight most fair and bright, a true delight for mine eyes. But, alack! The other scribes have penned their praise, and so I shall move on. 

The eatery itself, a space most elegant and cozy, didst provide a sense of privacy, that rare and precious gem. The staff, kind and attentive, didst keep my cup full and ensured all was well. 

But, alas! The victuals, methought, were naught but middling fare. The bread, afore the meal, a disappointment, lacking that certain je ne sais quoi. And yet, the pesto dish, though pleasant, didst not surpass the ordinary. My comrade's pasta, spicy and savory, didst find favor in his eyes, and the sweet tiramisu, a satisfying conclusion. 

In conclusion, Ventano's, a place of worth, yet not of exceeding excellence. I shall return, perchance, when the whim doth strike me."

"Verily, I say unto thee, my friend, that this place, known as Khaneh Kabob, or so they call it, is a veritable haven for those who seek succulent kabobs. 'Tis true, the name doth not ring familiar, but fear not, for the food doth make up for it. 'Tis clean, and well-kept, though strange, for it doth share a roof with a beverage store. But fear not, for 'tis naught but a curiosity.

Now, heed my words, good sir, for I shall tell thee of the wondrous kabobs they serve. If thou dost choose one with steak or chicken, prepare thyself for disappointment, for thou shalt receive but a small portion. But fear not, for the ground meat kabobs, they doth provide a bountiful feast. 'Tis wrapped around a long, flat skewer, and cooked to perfection. Thou shalt have leftovers, I doth assure thee.

And, good sir, do not be fooled by the Americanized shish-kabobs, for these, my friend, are Persian-style kabobs, and they doth differ greatly. Thou shalt not be disappointed, I doth promise thee. And, as for the service, 'tis friendly, but not swift, and their English, alas, doth leave much to be desired."

"Hark! What news is this? A Christmas week visit,
With prices raised, a premium to pay.
The line doth stretch and twist, a winding snake,
But fear not, friends, for we have a pass to make our escape.

The food, though plentiful, doth lack a certain flair,
A mediocrity that doth leave me cold.
The shrimp, the prime rib, chicken roasted fair,
But naught to write home of, or to make my heart enfold.

The king crab legs, a prize for those who crave,
I didst not partake, for they do not my fancy enslave.
The rest, a bit dry, sauces needed to revive,
But desserts, oh sweet! Creme brulee, creampuffs, ice cream, all alive!

Drinks, included in the price, a bonus, no doubt,
So drink up, friends, and quaff with joy unbound.
In conclusion, methinks 'tis not worth the cost,
But still, a place to visit, at a lower toll, no boast."

"In company of friends, I didst dine at this place,
The servings, large they were, in truth, a feast to behold.
Some found the victuals to their liking, others, not so much,
The jerked pork and fowl, alas, didst fail to impress.
But pork, slow-cooked in BBQ sauce, didst please our taste,
As didst the sweet potatoes and rice, a wondrous treat."

"A fortnight past, with colleagues numerous,
I dined at an establishment of repute,
Where upon my lips did grace a burger,
Kobe beef, with cheddar white as snow,
And fries of sweet potato, crispy delight,
Together did they dance upon my tongue,
A culinary symphony, most fair and bright.
The burger, cooked to perfection, did impress,
And fries, oh fries, how wondrous thy taste!
Yet, alas, not the finest burger I've known,
But mirth and merriment did that eve unfold."

"Hark, good sir! Doth thou seek a meal most quick and fine? A place where thou may't find sushi of worth, for price most fair and kind? 'Tis here, my friend, at this humble abode, where takeout doth reign supreme, and seating doth not impose. For five dollars, thou shalt feast upon a dish most delectable, fit for a king, or so it doth seem. Then, hasten thee well, and claim thy prize with haste, that thou may'st enjoy a meal most satisfying, and thus, thy day be blessed."

"Hark! What light through yonder deli breaks? A place wherein I find some solace in the form of sustenance most fair and rare. Forsooth, they boast a bounty of broths most savory, fit to warm the cockles of mine heart. And sandwiches, too, of decent sort, with flavors diverse and bold. But, alas, their ice cream doth steal the show, a sweet delight that doth my senses stir. Yet, though I may not seek it out, I shall not shun it neither, should fate or friendship lead me thither."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals here be of fine quality, by my troth! The Chicken Marsala, in sooth, didst please mine taste, but, alack! The cost, methinks, doth leave somewhat to be desired. Yet, lo! A youth doth serve us, with hair as white as snow and a visage not unlike young Seth from yon flick, 'Superbad.' His presence doth make the service, though but mediocre, seem less vexing, prithee!"

"This place, fair sir, couldst be five stars, an it change but a few things. The menu, verily, doth please mine taste, and the ambiance, by th' gods, doth delight. The indoor-outdoor setup, 'tis a marvel, and the patio, where thou mayst bring thy cur, doth make for a pleasant evening. Alas, the bartenders, full of pride, do seem to scorn their patrons. Alack, the owner, wouldst he send them to Ve Bene, in Ahwatukee, to learn the ways of a true bartender? Forsooth, they offer no drink specials at night, and the prices, they do mount. Mayhap, 'tis why the place doth stay so slow, save for the occasional customer. Methinks, they do seek to keep out the rabble."

"Methinks my first visit to this place didst yield a shredded beef burrito, priced at six twenty-nine. Verily, I found it to be but mediocre, alack! Yet, their warm chips, nine pence, and guacamole, two six nine, didst please mine taste buds exceedingly. 

Thus, I have returned to this establishment on multiple occasions, merely to partake in an order of chips and guacamole. Methinks my mouth doth water at the mere thought of those lightly salted chips and tangy guacamole. 

In sooth, while I do prefer Qdoba's chips, for burritos, Baja Fresh doth hold sway. And, indeed, Qdoba doth resemble Chipotle, as if they were but twins. 'Tis strange, forsooth, that they should choose to situate themselves across the street from one another, in such close proximity."

"Twas good, not great, yet not so bad,
I ordered omelet, my love had strat.
With potatoes baked and fruit so fresh,
The meal was good, but not quite a quest.

At home, I could have made the same,
But still, I'd return and try their fame.
Their menu's vast, with veggies galore,
And lean meats, fitting my desire.

My love, a burger man, was pleased,
With Wisconsin pride, his heart appeased.
We celebrated his birth with cheer,
A cupcake sweet, but I was too full, my dear.

He savored each bite, with gleeful grace,
Carrot cake, cream cheese frosting in its place.
A walnut topping, a tasty delight,
He finished it swiftly, with joy in sight.

Perhaps, another time, we'll dine once more,
And sample their lunch, as we did before.
Until then, this review stands tall,
A decent spot, worth a visit, after all."

"Hark, my friends, what news I bring thee! 
We've found a place to dine, and 'tis called Florencia's. 
A coupon did entice us, and so we did decide,
To start our Winter Break with pizza, in its prime.

We entered in, just ere the clock did strike three,
And found the place quite empty, save for two or three.
Melissa, fair maiden, did greet us with grace,
And swiftly took our orders, with a smile on her face.

An XL Cheese pizza, we did crave, and so we did order,
For cheese, oh how we yearned! And lo, it did arrive,
In all its glory, hot and fresh, with toppings galore.
The crust, so fine and crispy, did complement the cheese,
And we, in joy and mirth, did feast upon this treat.

Alas, a minor quibble, did mar our bliss,
For we did have to fetch our second round, alas!
But fear not, dear friends, for this shall not deter,
Our love for Florencia's, and its delectable pizza, no matter."

"Tis but a humble abode, yet priced so low,
During the mining convention, I didst stay,
And found the staff to be scarce, in truth,
Yet still, the chamber was clean, the water hot,
Adequate, but naught more, I do declare,
'Tis but an ordinary inn, no more, no less."

"Methinks 'tis wise to gather in numbers great,
When the bill doth mount and tips do await.
My wife and I didst feel neglected, alas!
Especially towards the meal's final phase.

Oh, how the wait didst drag on, a full 16 minutes!
A trifle too long, methought, for such fine victuals.
The ravioli, a delight, and pork belly, tender as can be.
Yet, the prawns, o'ercooked, a pity to see.

I wouldst venture back, to test their mettle once more.
For though the fare was good, the service didst falter.
A 4, the food, yet the slowness didst mar the score."

"A place most wondrous, fair and large,
With bar that doth stretch far and wide,
The lines for drinks do grow quite long,
And prices, dear, do climb quite high,
For draughts of ale most generic,
But staff, in truth, are kind and nifty.

Beneath the rafters, rows of thrones,
Do stand, a sight most fair and bright,
Cleaners and guards, in numbers plenty,
Do keep the crowds in order tight.

The privies, spacious and grand,
Do hold within them many a stall,
So fear not, dear, to make a stand,
In betwixt sets, 'gainst nature's call.

The sounds, they do resound most sweet,
But iron bars, in strange array,
Do segment floor, in curious way,
Lest mosh pits rise, in wild disarray."

Hark, fair friends! I've visited this place a score of times,
In five short years, when Copan was my home.
Most times, alas! The victuals were but woeful,
Dry and stale, as if they'd lain too long unshown.
But lo! Of late, a change hath come upon the scene,
The fare, now fresh and savory, doth please mine eyes and taste.
May this improvement last, and ne'er depart,
For then, this place shall be my heart's delight.

"A steep price doth be asked for victuals, I do confess. Yet, 'tis the potables that maketh this place most fair, with cups, glasses, and mugs to bear away. A treasure trove of cinematic lore, and a shoppe next door where one may purchase fine goods. A meet spot for luncheon during conventions, creating joyous memories."

"Methinks 'twas fate that brought us to this place,
Where Kai's former chef now doth hold sway.
The food, it seemed, didst bear his signature grace,
Innovative dishes, some of which didst slay.

The "shroom" dish, oh how it didst delight,
And venison lollipops, though rare, didst please.
My husband, he didst savor every bite,
Of pescado loco tar tare, with joy and ease.

But alas, my own dish didst not impress,
A duck large plate, with beans, rice, and mess.
No better than Milagro Grill or The Mission,
I didst expect more, with greater elation.

The okra, too salty, didst leave me aghast,
And service, at times, didst seem quite vast.
A server came, with covered dish in hand,
And knew not what it was, nor could he stand.

Despite this, our waitress was pleasant and bright,
The hostess, welcoming, with a warm good night.
Others we met, didst attend to our needs,
But loud music, for youth, didst pierce my ears and seize.

So, to this place, I may return, for drinks and cheer,
But dinner, alas, I fear, I shall not come near."

"Hark, a local and former Detroiter, I didst venture forth to Valet, a place of rest and refreshment. Alas, 'twas only open to guests of the hotel, and the parking garage, a woeful sight indeed. Seven floors, they didst reserve for valet, and then, the garage, it didst end abruptly, with nary a path to exit. I didst seek the famed American Coney Island, and though the fare was passable, the chili, a scant amount, didst leave me wanting. A draught of Vernors, that most refreshing elixir, wouldst have made the experience complete. Alas, the casino, with its dancing table girls and overloud music, didst strike me as tawdry and poorly executed."

"In fair Phoenix, we didst make a stop,
And chanced upon Jose Roux, a place to dine and sup.
I ordered steak tacos, and ice water, 'twas my whim,
And passed on rice and beans, for four dollars seemed a bit steep.

The tortillas, homemade and corn, were soft and fine,
But tiny, alack! They held much food, oh so divine.
Steak, lettuce, tomato, salsa, all piled high,
But pineapple marinade, I could not taste, nor buy.

The steak, alas! Was tough and chewy, a shame,
But mild salsa, good and tangy, did ease my pain.
Black beans and rice, unordered, did appear,
A kindness from the waiter, who didst not charge me dear.

Alas! The service slow, a trouble, indeed,
At airports, where time doth flee, and speed doth need.
But still, a common woe, and thus, I shall not fret,
For Jose Roux, a place, where I may yet again be met."

"A pox upon the Yelpers, say I,  
Who dare compare Bei to Shin Bay's art.  
Their taste, it seems, doth leave much to be desired,  
For Hiro's skill, they know not, nor Kona's fire.  
Ra or Grill, at best, their knowledge doth extend,  
But of true sushi, they know not the end.  
So let us call a spade, a spade, my friends,  
And deem Bei's sushi passable, till the end.  
For those who disagree, I pray,  
Go forth and sample sushi, ere ye speak again."

"Hark, good sir, how say you of this change?
In days of yore, when traveling was a chore,
Air Canada, alack, didst take its toll,
With check-in times that didst make one sigh and roll.

But now, my friend, all has changed, I swear,
For Qatar Airways, with speed and grace, doth steal the show.
Their check-in, a mere half-hour, doth astound,
And through the customs, quick as lightning, doth resound.

Ah, but, my dear, the line, a woeful sight,
Doth stretch and wind, a tedious plight.
Yet fear not, for they have changed their ways,
With passport scanners, swift and bright, doth save the day.

So, choose wisely, friend, and heed my words,
For Qatar Airways, with speed and ease, doth soar.
And though the line may seem a woeful fate,
Have patience, fair traveler, for 'tis but a brief wait."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals here be grand. A grilled salmon burrito, by my troth, doth please mine taste. The service, too, doth shine with kindness and exceeding diligence. Alas, the men's privy, foul and ill-kept, doth mar mine experience, like a stinking wagon halt."

"Hark, I didst return once more, after three summers' passage,
To sate my hunger for Greek fare, in the vicinity.
I didst order their Spanakopita, to test the recipe anew,
And lo, the presentation was the same, yet different too.
The pastry, flaky and light, with just the right amount of salt,
Didst complement the spinach, which didst resemble a lasagna, upon a bed of rice pilaf, so dull and lacking in flavor.
I didst also partake of their pumpkin cheesecake, far too sweet,
Even sweeter than those I do enjoy, at the Cheesecake Factory, I do confess.
Thus, three and a half stars, I wouldst give, for this culinary venture."

"Hark! The victuals were but passable, I say,  
The flesh was naught but mediocre, fries the same,  
Yet, verily, a merry time was had, I pray.  
For those who weigh o'er three hundred fifty,  
Eat freely, 'tis a wondrous sight to see,  
But mark, good sir, they take no credit,  
Cash only, that's their decree, thou must comply.  
A gown and bracelet, too, thou must don,  
Lest thou be turned away, ere the night be gone.  
Alas, I would not return, forsooth,  
The fare, though pleasant, was naught but common,  
Yet, anon, the experience, I dare avow,  
Was merry, and shall stay with me, 'twill be shown."

"In fair Sichuan, land of beauty's reign,
A maiden fair, with wit and charm, doth hold the key.
To win her heart, thou must possess the whole,
A pretty face, a sharp mind, and passion's fire.

Oh, how the Yelp reviews do criticize and scorn,
The decor, the service, and the ambiance forlorn.
But who are these young souls that praise the fare?
(Alas, I do, with fondness and a twinkle there.)

Their spicy crispy chicken, oh how grand,
My taste buds dance with joy, my love for it so bland.
But alas, the Kung Pao chicken, a disappointment true,
The sauce too sweet, the heat not fiery enough, anew.

And thus, fair reader, we come to know,
What kind of maiden doth Ichiban's charms bestow?
A brainy beauty, independent, free,
Who cares not for thy thoughts, nor doth she thee.

Yet, methinks, a wish within my heart doth lie,
That she, perchance, mightst notice me, and sigh."

"Hark, what news is this? A burger, thou sayest?
At the Attic, I doth try it, with haste.
All my taste, I did spend on thee,
And now, I do crave, a reservation for two, anon.

Verily, 'tis hard to recall, the reviews of old,
But harder still, to capture, a pic, so bold.
That thou art here, next to me, eating with glee,
Is a sight, most wondrous, to behold, indeed.

The Attic, located upstairs, in the attic, so they say,
But in truth, 'tis just plain upstairs, in every way.
On a Wednesday, I did come, for happy hour delight,
And lo, $10 burger and beer night, did shine so bright.

Avery Karma, a pale ale, from Boulder, CO,
Did please my taste, with its crisp, hoppy flow.
Their special burger, with mushroom and Swiss cheese,
Was not so bad, despite my dislike of mushrooms, if ye please.
The bun, oh so soft, and toasty, did steal the show,
But alas, the service, with nary a smile, did slow.

Yet still, I would return, for the atmosphere so grand,
A sports bar lounge, with a classic view, at hand."

"Hark! If thou art in search of sustenance,
'Tis here thou shalt find delectable fare,
A humble abode, yet full of cheer,
With sandwiches and gyros to tempt thee there.

And shouldst thou chance upon a night
When music doth fill the air,
Do stay and revel in the delight,
For 'tis a place of joy beyond compare.

As student, I didst frequent this spot,
And still, whene'er I visit, do drop in,
For though 'tis plain, 'tis home to warmth and cheer,
Right on the campus, near the quad, my dear."

"Hark, my friends, I tell thee now a tale,
Of a place we visited twice in one eve,
For hunger pangs did strike our bellies fair,
And cheapness did our purses much relieve.

Their nachos, oh how grand they were,
Big enough to feed a multitude, I swear,
At $16, a bargain, beyond compare,
The cheese, though not quite melted, did please.

And if thou art in need of stronger drink,
Scrounge up some coins, or beg, or think,
A $1 margarita, strong and sweet, it doth provide,
To keep thy buzz alive, and merry make thy mind."

"We told them we were on the guestlist, but they didn't seem to care,
And so we paid $20, including the fairer sex, without a single soul aware.
But little did we know, if we had stayed at the Venetian,
We could have entered free, and avoided such a sin.

Inside the club, it was quite crowded, I must confess,
The booty-shaking girls, they were quite impressive, I must profess.
The Buddhas all around, they gave me quite a fright,
But others seemed to mind not, in the heat of the night.

They made us climb the stairs, to where Tao Beach lay,
A lovely spot, but for the plastic, that marred the view, alas.
We sat on couches, but they wouldn't let us rest,
For they were bottle service, and we were but guests.

Different rooms played different tunes, it seemed to me,
And in the main room, foam rained down from above, you see.
I walked around with a drink, when suddenly, a girl bumped into me,
My straw went up my nose, and my blood began to flow, you'll see.
I coughed it up, and thank the heavens, I am alive,
So don't you worry, my friends, I'm well, and I do thrive."

"Verily, this eatery doth boast a most excellent quality of meat,
A variety of cuts and choices that doth far surpass the rest.
The establishment itself doth shine with cleanliness, a true delight.

But alas, the service doth leave much to be desired, I do confess.
For those who speak not Korean, 'tis a trial indeed,
To receive the attention and care that one doth expect and need.

Yet, methinks the price doth justify the quality of the fare,
And so, I wouldst recommend this place, despite the service's snare.
For those who crave a savory feast, and can forgive the flaw,
This restaurant doth stand apart, and worth a visit, I do avow."

"Verily, this place doth seem most wondrous strange,
A rustic theme, yet with a playful range.
The staff, attired in garb of roughest hue,
Do add to charm, or so I do imbue.

A cow byre, perchance? Nay, more a potter's shed,
Yet neither doth it fully claim my head.
Its site, most fair and convenient, doth please,
And victuals, they do tantalize and tease.

Not a place for frequent visits, I confess,
But worth a trip, should curiosity express."

"Hark, what fortune doth San Felipe's possess,
To be situated near the stage, no less!
We arrived at seven on a Saturday eve,
And found the crowd to be quite scarce, believe me.

The line at entrance, short and sweet,
For those of age, a bracelet to greet.
We waited, and waited some more,
As two maidens, idle, did ignore.

At last, our name upon the list,
A server, finally, did assist.
We sat at bar, and ordered drinks with glee,
And lo, a table on the patio, free!

We sat, and waited, oh so long,
For service, slow, and server, wrong.
The quesadilla, small, but decent,
With chicken, steak, or shrimp, a dent.

The heaters, on, a bit too soon,
But then, a drop, and perfect boon.
Off went the heat, and stayed away,
Alas, a pity, night's decay.

No man, this time, held open wide,
The men's room door, my heart did glide.
So, three stars, for chips and salsa grand,
A gift from heavens, fit for any land."

"Methinks I've dined at this establishment ere now, and found it to my liking, I must confess. But alas, this visit proved a sorry tale, indeed. For though the service was slow, and we didst wait some thirty minutes for our meals, the burgers, when they finally arrived, were lacking in size, I do declare. Nay, they were nigh on the same dimensions as those peddled by that wretched Mickey Dee's. And for a sum of nine dollars, I didst receive but a mere three-dollar burger. Fie upon it! I fear I shall have to reconsider my patronage of this place, forsooth. For though the folk be pleasant, the victuals, on this occasion, didst leave much to be desired."

"Fare fit for kings! We dined upon that Sunday eve,
When long weekends do stretch and time doth seem to flee.
The kitchen, alas! did close its doors upon us,
And left us to pine for more, like lovers in distress.

A pleasant place, though not of fancy ilk,
More suited for families, or couples on the brink.
Of love, or of a weeknight meal, I do declare,
This eatery doth serve its purpose with flair."

"Upon mine eyes, a vision didst appear,
A cinema house, with flaws so clear.
In Stockton's town, it doth resemble,
A humble abode, with modest feature.
The seats, alas, didst lack comfort's grace,
And upward gaze, the screen didst embrace.
A relic, old and outdated, doth seem,
Even the privy, with age, didst gleam.
If naught else calls, and movie's thy quest,
Then here, thy steps, shouldst thou address."

"Upon my first visit to yon Church Brew Works, I must confess, fair friends, 'twas a disappointment. My taste buds didst crave the sweetest brews, but alas! The Oktoberfest and IPA didst fall short of greatness. And though the schnitzel didst please mine eyes, 'twas but a mediocre feast. Yet still, the atmosphere didst impress me mightily, a true marvel!"

"Hark, good sir! 'Tis a happy hour indeed,
With prices fair and drinks that doth proceed.
But mark this well, lest thou dost wish to woo,
Do not, I say, bring thy spouse anew.
For in that place, where thou didst take thy delight,
Thy girlfriend mayst not be met with good sight.
And thus, thy happy hour doth turn awry,
Into a tempest of anger and sigh.

Oh, try the Ginger Bourbon Lemonade,
'Twill creep upon thee, like a sly maid.
Three of these, a vendor, angry and unpaid,
And a wife, with cutlery sharp, did make me afraid.

The Friends with Benefits sushi rolls, so fine,
Should have been a sign, a warning divine.
For when my wife didst drink, with scent so sweet,
The next day, my clothes didst bear its treat.

Alas, the happy hour menu, no longer half-priced,
Yet still, a bargain, compared to the regular fare, it is."

"Hark! My rating doth be three and a half stars, good sirs,
Rounded down, 'tis true, yet still quite fair.
Thanks to Yelp, my thoughts now shared,
My gut doth guide me, ne'er to err.

Service, five stars, I do declare,
Friendly staff, our time they did share.
Food, alas, doth falter, I do fear,
Two and a half stars, my taste did clear.
Burger, flat grilled, hand pattied, 'twas thin,
Cooked medium rare, flavor did lack within.
Fries, unsalted, a dire need they did possess,
Coleslaw, a small portion, woeful, alack!

Building, clean, open, well-lit, a pleasant sight,
Three stars, methinks, a fair plight.
Breakfast, I shall return, 'tis my intent,
To savor morn's delight, my heart doth invent."

"A quaint and cozy brunchery, with victuals all locally sourced,
The service, warm and welcoming, like a genial host.
Though ambiance was wanting, somewhat plain and bare,
I shall return anon, for more of their fare."

"A novel notion, build thine own burger, doth not this place present,
But toppings of interest, they do offer, and buns of divers sorts, in abundance.
I chose a 1/3 lb. brie, a cheese most fair and rare,
With ham, a savory pairing, beyond compare.
Juicy and tasty, it did prove to be,
But alas, the cost, a king's ransom, it did command.
My burger, just shy of ten dollars, did amount,
And toppings, such as bacon, ham, and mushrooms, an extra fee, did mount.
A second cheese, another dollar, did require,
And lettuce, tomato, onions, and pickles, four free toppings, did exhaust.
Fries, a single serving, three dollars, did demand,
And shakes, though delicious, five dollars, did command.
Good food, but not worth the extra cost, in my humble view,
A princely sum, it did exact, and my purse, did woefully deplete."

"Ten minutes passed, and still no service came,
At the bar, I sat, my thirst not yet quenched.
Another bartender, with the ladies played,
While I, ignored, my drink did await.

The other bartender would not lend a hand,
"Not my section," he said, with a shrug.
So we took a table, the hostess told,
To get a beer, and an appetizer, bold.

The manager walked by, with a glance,
But kept on walking, without a chance.
He spoke to others, but not to us,
It seemed we were ignored, alas.

This place has potential, great indeed,
But falls flat, with poor service, speed.
They brew their own beer, a selection vast,
But the server knew not, what to say at last.

My husband tried it, and found it good,
But the server, knew not, as he should.
The food was decent, but slow to come,
A disappointment, our evening became.

Alas, we shall not return again,
To this place, with service, so inane."

"Hark! A show most wondrous, yet most vile,
A spectacle that doth beguile,
With stars, both one and five, I do declare,
And thus, my friends, a tale most rare.

'Tis called The Sirens of TI, a sight to behold,
Akin to an ill-fashioned sweater, old,
Yet in its ugliness, a beauty doth lie,
A theme of mirth and revelry, doth it provide.

Go forth, dear friends, with minds untainted,
Expect not grandeur, lest ye be disappointed,
But rather, embrace the bad, the awful,
And in its wake, find joy unbridled.

Early shows, before the club doth open wide,
Are best, my friends, take heed of this advice,
In Christian Audigier's patio, a seat doth wait,
And with a drink, thy spirits shall be light.

So sit, and laugh, and let the badness fade,
For in its place, a merry time shall be made."

"How quiet this place doth be, a true delight! All that I need, 'tis here to see, for my devices and tools, when not at yonder store, doth abide. The piece for my fridge, they do hold, so I may change the filter, and feel quite bold. The service, kind and helpful doth show, yet not too forward, doth let me go."

"Methinks 'tis a pleasant place indeed,
Wherein I've tarried oft, in days past.
The chambers, comfortable, meet my need,
Yet, truth be told, the casino's placement doth aggrieve.
A trifling matter, since 'tis nigh the Strip,
And wings, a quarter coin, do please my lip.
I take delight in games of chance,
But, alas! The staff, with scant civility, did dance.
Their gruff demeanor did my patience try,
And, in a rage, I did depart, ere long, to fly."

"Pray, good sir, take seat downstairs, for there doth lie  
The finest ambiance, by my reckoning, a hundredfold.  
And should thou chance to sit on the leftmost side,  
Thy gaze shall fall upon the fair Pittsburgh skyline,  
A sight most wondrous and worth thy careful eye.  
The service, too, was of the highest quality,  
I must confess, the swordfish did please me well,  
And though the shrimp appetizer lacked some zest,  
The food, in general, did prove somewhat dull."

"Hark! Ahead, I called to order pasta,
Two dishes didst I try, with sauces quite tasty,
But salt, oh so plentiful, didst make my mouth pucker,
And yet, I do adore the savory mineral, 'tis true.

The staff, so friendly, owner and cook,
Didst make me feel most welcome, in their book,
But, alas, the atmosphere, didst not agree,
With my fine watch, sharp dress, and imported car, you see.
Awkward, I didst feel, like an unexpected guest,
In this strip mall, not quite the coziest of nest.

The food, good overall, save for the salt,
Flavorful, it was, and not at all dull,
I shall return, and try the pizza, forsooth,
For though it was salty, 'twas not without its charm."

"Upon our visit to this place, the victuals didst please mine taste,
Yet, the cost didst seem a mite too much, in sooth.
A dish of hummus, priced at ten, didst leave me aghast,
For though 'twas delectable, the price didst seem quite vast.

The lamb shanks, which my wife didst order, didst cost
Twenty-three silver pieces, and though they didst taste
Most wondrous, the price didst seem a mite too high,
For what we didst receive, in truth, didst not seem quite nigh.

A draught of apple martini, priced at ten, didst flow,
And a Stella Artois, on tap, didst also show
Itself to be of worth, yet the music, loud and clear,
Didst grate upon mine ears, and didst bring a fear
That I didst shout, o'er the din, to make myself heard.

The service, however, didst prove to be most fair,
And the food, in truth, didst taste most savory and rare.
So, if thou art in search of something new and fine,
This place mayhap shall be worth thine consideration divine."

"Hark, what news is this? A breakfast feast,
From eight till noon, I've never seen the like.
The cost, four euros ninety, a bargain indeed,
With a euro off, for every drink you take.
But alas, the coffee, dearest of all,
Three euros ninety, a price to make one fall.
Yet the breakfast, it was good, I must confess,
Though every extra wish, came with an added mess.
No trade of butter and marmalade, for Nutella,
The service, attentive, friendly, and swift, they did render."

"Aged theater, verily, 'tis true,
Parking, vexation doth it bring anew.
In renovation, mayhap, they do strive,
But service slow, and kiosks, scarce alive.
Seats, not comfort's finest, screens, middling fair,
Yet, near my home, convenience doth bear.
Independent flicks, a gem, doth shine,
Village Square, revival, doth entwine.
Hark! A tip, avoid the line,
Kiosk, confusion, doth entwine."

"Upon our return from YMCA's half-marathon, my spouse and I didst espy a novel establishment, The Nile Cafe. 'Twas nigh impossible to discern its openness, so raw and unadorned didst it appear. Yet, we didst venture forth and sample their Cilantro-Jalapeno hummus, a dish most wondrous and bold! Verily, 'tis my favourite, and I shall endeavour to pair it with various victuals, though it doth belong not on them. Alas, the pita bread, a paltry store-bought affair, didst detract from the overall experience. Still, I shall rally my comrades and revisit this venue, eager to partake of their schwarma, falafel, hasushi, tabouli, and chicken curry soup. Hark! I shall update thee on my subsequent visit. For now, heed my counsel and indulge in their delectable hummus."

"Methinks I've had Jason's fare before,
At catered feasts, and found it fair.
But ne'er didst dine within his walls,
Till now, when I didst try his salads.
Aye, 'tis a veritable cornucopia,
With all that one could wish for, nay?
But alas, the wrap I didst choose,
Was not to my liking, I do confess.
The tortilla, thick and firm it was,
And lacking in its fillings, I didst find.
I wouldst not order it again,
Forsooth, I was most disappointed."

"Hark! If thou dost seek Chinese fare of the East Coast persuasion, this establishment shall serve thee well. We didst order from the menu, eschewing the buffet, forsooth, we do not partake in such. The victuals didst meet our expectations, with generous portions, piping hot, and fresh as the morning dew. Alas, the waitstaff, their English skills were lacking, and their service, poor, yet the atmosphere didst bustle with activity, the cooks and servers shouting betwixt the buffet and kitchen in Chinese. The dining area, alack, didst appear dated and unkempt. For takeout, we shall employ them, anon."

"Hark, what news is this? A Thursday eve, we dine,
Two AYCE feasts, a mere 15.12, a steal divine!
And lo, new signees, a 2 for 1 treat,
A bonanza, a boon, a bounty to greet!

Ask friends to join, their sign-up, a key,
Cashiers, blind eyes, no queries, 'twill be.
Bring cash, fair sirs, a wise guise,
For ATM fees, a woeful surprise.

Thirty minutes, the wait, a hunger's sting,
At 8 o'clock, a multitude does cling.
Nigiri sushi, alas, a failure, 'tis true,
Earlier arrival, a wiser move, anew.

Chinese fried chicken, small wings, a delight,
Better than American, a taste so bright.
Tofu stir fry, a must, a treasure,
Soups, a bit salty, yet a pleasure to savor.

Tacos, always, a craving, a need,
Not as wet, Sunset Station's indeed.
BBQ ribs, a bonus, summer's gift,
Chopped sweet potatoes, Sunset's lift."

"Fare thee well, fair sir! How doth thy taste buds fare? Doth thou find delight in fried seafood, prepared with skill and care? Verily, 'tis good, yet somewhat dear. Methinks, at Long John Silvers, thou mayst find a similar feast, at a lower cost, and perchance, with greater haste. In sooth, 'twas naught but mediocre, not worth a verse or prose."

"A fair assortment of wares, yet not the best,
I must confess, my dearest friend.
The apothecary's staff, most kind and courteous,
Didst aid me in my time of need,
And thus, I shall return, to seek their guidance once again."

"A hearty selection, full of comforts dear,
No haughty dishes here, nor aught to fear.
For those who shun the fancy, this place doth suit,
With prime rib, a feast fit for a king, no doubt.
And should thou bring thy young ones, fear not,
For they shall find delight in every bite and thought.
But alas, the coffee, poor and weak, doth fail,
To please the palate or to lift the veil."

"Fair southern victuals, excellent biscuits! Verily, I wouldst return anon to partake of their morning repast, yet didst chance upon their noontide fare. The broth, most wondrous! Alas, the southern-fried catfish, a mite too lean. In sooth, I am accustomed to a heartier cut, with flesh that doth rival the gods' own feast. The fried okra, a pleasant surprise, didst delight mine taste buds. By my troth, I shall revisit this establishment, to further explore its culinary charms!"

"Verily, not a burger palace, my friend,
Where thou mayst add a patty, or choose from a diverse array of meats,
The victuals here are somewhat costly, I do confess,
And the menu, alas, doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
In truth, good sir, I wouldst rather take my leave,
And seek sustenance at Five Guys, where burgers doth reign supreme."

"Fair maiden, thou art served with victuals of three and a half score,
In sooth, a humble feast within this hall of yore.
Thy keepers, taken aback by thy arrival most fair,
Do proffer menus of parchment, a curious affair.
No melodies nor moving images doth grace this place,
A stillness that doth pierce thine ears with discomfort's sting.
Thy perch, a booth of sorts, doth bear an outdoor sign,
A clumsy fixture that doth jut forth, most awkwardly aligned.
The seats, a puzzle, doth confound with their strange design,
Yet fear not, for the viands, they doth please, most truly divine.
And though this cafe doth seem a curiosity, a catering guise,
Thou mayst find solace in delivery, a respite from surprise."

"Hark! What shindig doth this Saturday eve bring forth? Aye, 'tis the Noches Caliente Latin Dance Party, where merriment doth reign supreme! A live band doth provide the tunes, and a lively throng doth gather, eager to trip the light fantastic. A paltry sum of ten silver pence doth grant thee entry, and with it, a draught of ale or wine, as well as a seat with a prime view of the stage and dance floor. So, don thy shoes with care, for the wooden floor doth prove most slippery, and thou wouldst not wish to fall and make a fool of thyself. Thus, with great anticipation, let us proceed to this most festive of evenings!"

"Methinks I oft delight in humble haunts,
Where service tends to be of finest sorts.
But on this day, 'twas not the case, alack!
For slow and disarrayed the service was, in sooth.

Aye, I did order garlic bread, a staple dish,
And found it to be quite tasty, naught amiss.
The bolognese, too, did please mine taste,
Yet naught exceptional, in my honest thought.

In conclusion, methinks 'twas but an average feast,
With naught that did excel, nor aught that did impress."

"O, how I do adore Amsterdam, that wondrous city of delight! In days of yore, I didst visit this fair place, and verily, 'twas a night to remember! For on Tuesdays, the martinis didst flow like nectar, and the manicures didst shine like the sun! And, by my troth, the entertainment didst rival the gods themselves! 'Tis a place where mirth doth reign supreme, and joy doth fill the air! So, pack thy bags, my friend, and haste thee well to Amsterdam, forsooth!"

"Ah, Kohl's, thou art a wily store indeed,
Where savings doth await, but only for the keen.
Thou must shop sales and use coupons with great heed,
Lest thou pay too much, and thy budget doth bleed.

But fear not, dear shopper, for I have found
That toys, books, and decor, at Kohl's are profound.
Their selection doth change, like the wind doth blow,
So thou art sure to find the latest, don't ye know.

Kitchen tools, bathroom decor, and frames,
Doth Kohl's possess, in abundance, it claims.
But wait for sales, and use those coupons wise,
For adult clothing, alas, doth come at a prize.

Children's garb, though pricey, doth go on sale,
So bide thy time, and wait for the tale.
Use coupons, stack them high, and watch the cost,
For at Kohl's, savings doth come at any cost."

"Alas, my dear friends, I must confess,  
This dining experience did not impress.  
The service, slow and unfriendly, alack,  
And bread crumbs, oh so many, did attack.  

First, the maidens at the entrance, fair,  
Didst speak ill words of our group, unaware.  
Their faces, a picture of surprise and shame,  
When they discovered I, a member of the game.  

The restaurant, grand and beautiful, indeed,  
But up above, a private party did impede.  
Our waiter, changed, a strange occurrence,  
And sides, a disappointment, oh so immense.  

Filets, ribeye, and sebass, cooked to perfection,  
But creamed spinach and mac and cheese, a sorry condition.  
Panko, a topping, not a mix, I pray,  
Mashed potatoes, thankfully, did not stray.  

A word of caution, when requesting a box,  
Be clear, lest they pack only a fraction of the fix.  
Ribeye and filet, alone, did make the cut,  
The rest, a waste, a pity, a shame, a faux pas.  

Perhaps, another time, I shall return,  
When in the area, my curiosity to learn.  
Till then, adieu, this place, a mediocrity,  
A rating of three, a generosity, a charity."

"Methinks I didst not partake of their feast,
For I am not of their land, nor of their kin.
But my comrades, they didst invite me,
To join them in their merrymaking, and to sin.

Their food, it didst look most wondrous fair,
But alas, I came too late, and 'twas not there.
The music, it didst please mine ear,
But alack, the singing, it didst bring fear.

For in this place, they do enjoy,
To sing and dance, and make great joy.
And though I didst not partake,
Methinks I had a most excellent time, by my troth.

So if thou art in search of mirth,
And dost desire to laugh and play,
Then seek out this place, my friend,
And let their joy be thine, ere the end."

"By Jove, fair readers, hear my tale of woe,
Of hunger pangs and forgotten food, didst flow.
To CSN, a savior, didst I make my way,
With haste, to find sustenance, come what may.

A Chipotle, nearby, didst I espy,
And in, didst venture, with hopeful eye.
But lo, the service, slow and cold,
Didst leave me waiting, as time didst unfold.

A fat burrito, didst I procure,
And off, didst hasten, to Building Kilo, sure.
The microwave, didst heat, with speed and grace,
My Smartpop, didst burst, with flavor, in its place.

But, alas, the food, didst lack,
Freshness, of Doug E. Fresh, in the past, didst lack.
The carnitas burrito, with brown rice, pinto, pico, lechuga,
Was but a mere, alright, didst not impress, didst not astound.

Yet, with hunger, didst I consume,
Every morsel, with relish, didst assume.
In conclusion, fair friends, heed my advice,
Visit during lunch, when bustling, does entice."

"Hark, my lord! A call didst thou receive,
From Pep Boys' manager, full of apology.
Thy words, they didst touch mine heart,
And thus, I doth update this review, with stars anew.
Forsooth, 'tis a sign of good management,
To right a wrong, and make amends, with all due haste.
So here's to thee, kind sir,
May thy day be bright, and fortune smile upon thee!"

"Verily, good Thai fare doth this establishment provide,
But, alas, their prices be on the higher side,
Considering the humble surroundings, 'tis true,
Yet, have I been here many times, and found
Their victuals to be most tasty, spiced just right,
Though, mayhap, the portions be a bit too small.

Aye, the scent of pine doth fill the air,
And causeth headaches for all who dare
To partake of their culinary delights,
In this, their dingy, dank, and dimly lit sight.

Oh, the location, how it doth leave much to be desired,
A den of iniquity, where vice doth reign supreme,
With clubs of ill repute, and massage parlors galore,
And other such establishments, of dubious fame.

I have witnessed, myself, the lewd acts of lust,
That doth take place in the shadows, nigh this place,
And, verily, I say, 'tis not a site for guests,
From afar, who come to sample their Thai delights.

The men, who serve, are friendly, kind, and true,
But, alack, the women, at the front, are cold,
And their behavior, doth leave much to be desired,
In this, my review, of their restaurant, so bold."

"Pray bring with thee some ready cash, good sir,
And small bills too, for convenience' sake.
For there is a machine that doth dispense coins,
In exchange for notes of larger make.
But should thou need to change thy bills,
In yonder gift shop, they will assist.
Yet, to avoid much trouble and strife,
'Tis best to bring thy own change, my friend,
And thus, thou shalt not waste thy time,
Nor suffer the vexation of waiting in line."

"Two chambers booked I did procure,
For mother dear and aunt most sure,
The rooms themselves were fair and bright,
But staff, alas, did leave much to plight.
A problem great did we encounter,
With reservation, causing discontent,
Yet call recorded, did save the day,
And sixty-seven dollars went away.
Alas, I cannot speak too fond,
Of hotel, needing upgrade beyond,
Buffet, promised, did not appear,
And pool, in filth, did leave us queer.
RIO pool, far better, doth seem,
Luxor, in need of work, doth gleam."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, seek thou out this place,
Where thieves and rogues do not thy purse embrace.
Aye, 'tis a rare find in this city of sin,
Where luncheon specials reign supreme within.

At $5.99, a feast fit for a king,
Grilled chicken, mashed potatoes, and veggies, they do bring.
My friend, she ordered mushroom penne,
But I, my dear, didst find her dish not as tasty as mine.

Ah, but a nuisance there was, a woeful sight,
A lady came, asking if we wanted a souvenir in flight.
A postcard, they didst bring, with our visage fair,
But alas, they sought to sell us our own image, oh so rare.
Beware, good sir or madam, of this cunning snare,
And decline, with thanks, their offer most unfair.

Lastly, note well, the seats outside the privy,
Are hard and cold, a discomfort most dire.
But fear not, for within, seats are soft and fine,
And there, thou shalt find comfort, a true divine."

"O, how the service did crawl at snail's pace!
The waitresses and hostesses, young and unprofessional in their attire, didst blend in with the diners, making it hard to distinguish who didst serve and who didst dine. But lo, the sweet potato tots, oh how divine! They didst stir within me a craving that didst linger for weeks. And the burger, verily, it was quite good. I shall return, forsooth, to partake of the PBJ & Bacon Burger, of which all speak so highly. Yet, methinks the slow service doth need some hastening."

"Alas, my friends, this place doth fall short of our hopes,
A bit o'er-hyped, methinks, or mayhap we didst choose amiss.
The outward show doth seem a bit decrepit, true,
But in fair San Francisco, oft the humblest places do surprise anew.

We ordered wings of chicken, a papaya salad besides,
A tom yum noodle broth, and yet another dish, now lost to mind.
'Twas not so wondrous, save the hostess' kindly guile,
Who found us room, despite the crowded hall, with a smile.

Two stars for victuals, and a third for their good cheer,
For though the fare didst not astound, they didst make room for us, my dear.
So if thou art new to Thai cuisine, give Lotus of Siam a try,
And pray, good fortune doth attend thee, lest thy meal doth disappoint, like mine didst."

"Hark! Gather 'round, good sirs and madams, for a night of wit and wisdom,
A test of knowledge, with ale and cheer, to keep thy spirits high.
And should disputes arise, fear not, for we have bar fights galore,
To settle scores and prove thy mettle, as in days of yore.

But wait, there's more! Our tap, it doth rotate,
With brews from Great Lakes, a taste most elate.
And at a price so fair, thou shalt not break the bank,
So come one, come all, and join our merry rank!"

"Methinks I am in sore estate today, a wretched cur,
Yet, prithee, lay aside thy draught, that thou mayst pour
Mine own, since thou didst tell me to command it so.
Alas, poor beans, and service woefully slow!
A plague upon these millennials, say I, forsooth!"

"A fair location, yet too vast, alas,
All seemed a bit lost, in such a space.
A shame, indeed, that at a certain hour,
The club and its folk did change their power.
But elsewise, 'twas a place most fine."

"Ay, Pure be a place of merriment and joy,
Where folk of elder years do congregate,
With drapery of white, a Grecian theme doth employ,
And bartenders, pregnant, a curious sight doth make.
The roof, a place of wonder, doth provide a view,
Of yonder strip, where lights and sounds do break through."

"Hark! I visit this place more for ease than delight,
A strange establishment, full of curious sight.
I've ne'er been there at night, but I imagine 'tis
Even more intriguing when the sun doth miss.
Metro SB, a place of mystery and confusion,
Doth struggle with its identity, 'tis a fusion.
A dive, a club, a restaurant, a pool hall too?
I know not what it is, but still I'll pursue.
A word of caution, they accept naught but gold,
So bring thy cash, lest thou be left to behold.
An ATM doth grace the premises, but fear not,
For though it doth charge a fee, 'twill not be forgot."

"Hark! I must confess, fair friends, I am not yet prepared to don the mantle of a fan, full-fledged and true. For to be such, I would have to journey far and wide, through bustling streets and crowded highways, to wait in line and brave the metal door's mighty slam, all for the sake of savoring their delectable fare. And alas, 'tis not an option for the evening meal, for they close their doors at four, ere the sun doth set. 

But fear not, dear friends, for I didst heed the words of Robert M., and ordered thus: a green chile burrito, enchilada-style, with beans upon the side. The beans, though runny, served their purpose well, as I didst dip my burrito bits within them, and found them good. The sauce, that made it enchilada-style, didst bring a pleasant heat, and I didst find myself well-pleased. 

And so, I say, 'twas A-OK, and I shall return, though mayhap not with such haste and reckless abandon, on a work day, when duties call."

"Alack, I didst receive but biscotti from yon biscotti place,
The flavors, fair and good, yet consistency didst lack grace.
I know not what doth trouble mine experience with PIT,
But surely, Italian cuisine shouldst surpass this pitiful plight.

Alas, 'twas overly crumbly, didst fall apart like dust,
Perhaps, 'twas humidity that didst play the villain's role.
Oh, woe is me, for biscotti, once a favorite treat,
Now doth disappoint, and leaves mine taste buds to retreat."

In sooth, fair friends, I didst visit Koi in July,
And now, alack, I do perceive,
That I, in haste, didst forget to pen a review,
Of that place where sushi doth reign supreme.

The sushi bar, alas, was not accessible,
To one in a wheelchair, such as I,
So I didst dine in the main hall,
With a kindly server, who didst make me smile.

I ordered sushi, as is my wont,
Salmon and eel, a dish most fair,
But, alack, the portions were small,
Compared to those at Simon's lair.

I also tried the Sunset roll,
With eel and cucumber, a tasty treat,
Avocado and special sauce didst crown,
A dish most worthy of praise, indeed.

A sake flight didst accompany my meal,
A pleasant way to sample diverse brews,
And though the accessibility didst lack,
I didst enjoy the fare, and shall return anon.

Perhaps three and a half stars doth befit,
This establishment, with its tasty treat,
But, alas, I shall not forget,
To pen a review, ere I doth forget.

"My friend didst desire to gather at TT Roadhouse, and thus, I didst accompany her thither.  She hadst informed me that the establishment didst boast a most excellent jukebox, but alas, upon my arrival, I didst discover that it was not as grand as I had imagined.  'Twas a bit punk rock, I must confess, but I didst manage to find a few Jawbreaker tunes to lift my spirits.  The drinks were priced fairly, and the patrons didst not consist of the usual Old Scottsdale throng.  Naught extraordinary, I must say, but if thou art in the vicinity, 'tis a tolerable place to visit."

"Methinks the service here is quite divine,
With staff most courteous and kind.
The victuals, though not of highest quality,
Are still a sight to behold, I find.

Chicken makhani, a dish most fair,
We order oft, with joy we share.
Tikka masala, a taste not so fine,
Leaves us unsatisfied, I do confine.

Naan and paratha, both breads most sweet,
Do please our palates, can't be beat."

Airline not bad, good sir,
More of a bus up in the sky,
Like it much, save for one thing,
Baggage takes an age to bring.
But still, no lost luggage, praise be,
Not like in Burbank or Sacramento, ye see.

"A humble bakery, beloved by mine own heart,  
Their pastries and breads, a culinary work of art.  
If only they didst expand their spice and sauce selection,  
And offered more traditional dishes, oh what a perfection!  
But alas, the shelves do oft lie barren and bare,  
So go not at the last moment, lest thou leave with naught but air.  
Yet, claim thou a slice of apple strudel, 'twill be worth thy while,  
For 'tis a sweet delight, that doth make my heart smile."

"Hark! The victuals here be of highest quality,
As one would expect from Wynn's noble name.
Lobsters roasted to perfection, filet cooked just right,
A feast fit for kings, and worth the cost, I'd say.

But alas, dear friends, the service did lack,
A flaw that marred the experience, and caused dismay.
The host, a kindly soul, did welcome us with grace,
And led us to the bar, where we did await our place.
But then, oh how the tableside service did decline,
Our waiter, slow to come, and with a surly mien.
No check-ins to ensure all was well, we had to call,
To get our drinks refilled, and that did cause a pall.

The price, fair friends, was reasonable, I must confess,
But the poor service did leave a bitter taste, I must profess.
So if thou art planning a trip to this fine place,
Prepare thyself for disappointment, and a sorry face.
Botero, a safer choice, doth offer better cheer,
So there, my friends, thy money shall be better spent, I fear."

"Hark! How fortunate I am to come at a time when all are busy,  
So my thoughts on crowds, I cannot truly divine.  
But one of the check-in staff, a rude knave indeed,  
Doth never greet me, nor doth he show any good cheer.  
He doth ignore my requests, and doth make me ask thrice,  
For a towel, a humble thing, yet he doth not comply.  
And though the rest of the staff, do make me feel welcome,  
This grumpy soul, doth mar my stay, with his scowl and ill temper.  
But still, I find this place, to be clean and swift,  
And folk here, do not pester, nor do they persist."

"Methinks I am most pleased with larger menu choices now.  Two employees, I didst ask, when this change didst occur, and neither knew the answer.  A guess, I do make, 'twas very recent.  My burger, verily, was quite good.  Next time, I shall order it medium rare, for 'twas too well done, to mine own taste.  Hot fries, I didst request, and they were brought forth.  My daughter, alack, didst find the pretzels and beer cheese to be lacking.  A tale, we didst tell, to the waitperson, of the faulty cheese.  Beer cheese, by rights, should be orange and creamy.  Alas, 'twas naught but pretzel bites, with a whitish, watery cheese, that didst taste of naught but salad dressing.  Ranch, it didst resemble, sans the garlic.  My daughter, she didst declare, 'twas awful.  And, upon tasting it, I knew somethings amiss.  Flavorless and watery, it didst lack all taste of cheese or beer.  The waitress, she didst not believe, nor didst she offer to replace it.  Strange, methought, for such a thing, she shouldst have done.  My daughter, she didst order appetizers, instead of a meal, and thus, I didst feel a pang of guilt.  Glad, I am, to see appetizers and other sandwiches, now on the menu.  Goldies, I hadst always thought, didst serve but burgers, wings, and pizzas.  I shall return, and try a sandwich, anon."

In this place, I came to seek a massage of the whole body. 'Twas passable, but one thing did vex me sore. For in this single room, distractions abound, with chattering folk, shuffling feet, and moans from those who receive their rub. A screen or partition, I did wish, to block out diversions and grant peace. But nay, 'twas not to be, for such is the price one pays, I suppose.

The lass who worked her magic on my frame was pleasant enough, at first, her touch light as a feather. But then, she did apply great force to my shoulders, and lo, they still ache with pain the morrow after.

And furthermore, a strange custom they have here, wherein the masseurs gather at the front, awaiting their due. They will not depart, nor allow thee to leave, until a gratuity is given. Methinks 'tis a curious practice, indeed.

An experience it was, yet I fear I shall not return to this place again.

"Thou asketh why three stars didst I give, and not five?
'Tis due to ambiance, dear friend, which didst falter. A winery visit shouldst be a pleasing sight, yet naught but dim silence didst greet mine eyes. No music didst fill the air, nor crowds to enliven the space. The servers, too, didst dress in humble garb, a stark contrast to the finery I hadst hoped to behold. 
But fear not, for the food didst make amends, in part. Bruschetta, alas, didst disappoint, being naught but plain toast, small and lacking in flavor. Yet, mushroom risotto, twisted burger, and mac and cheese didst delight, each dish a culinary triumph. Thy taste buds shall be pleased, I do confess. 
The service, too, didst impress, with swift and friendly attendance. 
In conclusion, my dear spouse and I didst enjoy our repast, yet the evening's memories mayst fade, shouldst we ponder future dates."

"Hark! What news is this? Sephora doth stock Korres,
In Fairview, Pointe Claire, a store most fair.
But alas, in Quebec, their shelves doth lack,
Due to packaging laws, a most vexing snare.

A pox upon such rules, that doth impede,
The flow of commerce, and doth cause such need.
For why must we, in search of creams so dear,
Go forth and find them elsewhere, far and near?

But fear not, friends, for Sephora doth provide,
A selection grand, of brands most tried.
And staff, so helpful, doth guide thee well,
To creams of worth, that doth thy soul sell.

Yet, research thou must, before thou doth buy,
For some brands, doth merely meet the eye.
And prices, similar, doth thou find,
As Dr. Hauschka's, with Olgivy's, intertwined.

But woe is me! For Sephora's website doth charge,
A premium, for products, so hard to discharge.
And shipping, free, doth come with a catch,
In Canada, a hundred fifty, the sum to scratch.

So, seek thou out, SkinStore.com, a site most fair,
Where shipping, free, doth come without a snare."

"Methinks 'tis a fair outdoor mall, more suited for those of advanced years, my dear. On a day of warmth, 'tis a pleasant place to stroll, with mist sprays all about, and eateries aplenty to sate thy hunger."

"Hark! A tale of haste and prudence I shall tell,
Of a journey to Vegas, on the Fourth of July,
A last-minute trip, with naught but fate to guide,
We flew in swiftly, and with speed did arrive.

A cab we hailed, and in ten minutes' time,
Didst reach our destination, with nary a dime.
The fare was fair, and with a gratuity,
We paid the sum, and with ease didst enter in.

Six of us, in a suite of two bedrooms, didst abide,
With kitchen full, our needs didst satisfy.
Away from glamour and glitz, we didst choose,
This humble hotel, with shuttle service, didst cruise.

MGM, Mandalay, and airport, didst they take,
And though 'twas not the best, our stay didst make.
An OK rating, we didst give, I pray,
For other hotels, along the strip, didst sway.

A word of wisdom, let this be a sign,
To heed the call, when thy cab doth arrive.
Be prompt, my friends, and tarry not,
Lest thou be left, with naught but regret.

So heed this counsel, and with haste,
Make thy way, to thy appointed place.
For in this city, where lights doth gleam,
Punctuality, doth reign supreme."

"Eastward they wander, and my fondness fades,
A family tradition, now but a shade.
Once, Freed's bakery, a sweet delight,
Now, a shadow of its former might.

My taste, perhaps, has changed, who knows?
But their prices, surely, have grown.
For lesser quality, they demand more coin,
A bitter pill, for sure, no need to feign.

Their service, once, a smile and a treat,
Now, a crapshoot, at best, a cheat.
Some days, they're attentive, eager to please,
Other times, a ghostly, empty tease."

"Methought, fair readers, we would dine here,
Forsooth, a coupon didst entice mine eyes,
And 'twas the all-natural conceit that didst cheer,
In this place, cleanliness didst reign supreme, by'r lady!

But lo, what disappointment didst we find,
When kiddies' menu, none couldst we espie?
Alack, the staff didst say, 'Tis plain, my friends,
Yon burgers, hot dogs, sans toppings, ye may purchase.

Fries, a separate matter, large, yet scant,
Didst feed us all, but waters, oh so meagre,
In shot glasses, five, they didst present,
In Arizona's heat, a sorry plight, I do declare!

Yet, methinks the victuals, goodly they didst taste,
Burgers, small, but flavourful, in sooth,
And cheese, American, in this place, didst seem out of place.

Mayhap we shall return, but special trip, I doubt,
For here, in this land, of all-natural thought,
We found not what we sought."

"Hark! Our merry band didst take up residence here,
In this, the city of sin and mirth,
For our revels and sport, we didst choose well,
But alas, our lodgings didst leave much to be desired.

A burlap sack, I swear, wouldst have been preferable,
For the rooms, they didst lack in comfort and in cheer,
Especially in the "old building", where my friend didst reside,
With naught but two beds and a television to abide.

The service at the front desk, it didst seem,
Was nonexistent, and the bellhop, he didst appear,
Angry at us, as if we hadst done him wrong,
And the World Fare Buffet, oh how it didst go wrong!

A food court within the casino, full of woe,
With eateries most foul, that didst make us say,
"Alas, this place doth need a transformation,
To rival other hotels and casinos in this town."

"Methinks DH and I didst venture forth to Upper Crust,
For happy hour, with pizza and wings, we didst trust.
The pizza, verily, didst taste of Grimaldi's flair,
But alas, the wings, a single star didst bear.
The atmosphere, with shadows dark and deep,
Didst lack the colors that our spirits doth keep.
Yet, numerous televisions, for sporting games, didst abound,
A curious sight, indeed, in this place around."

"Methought I was in quite a pickle, torn twixt three and four stars, good sir!  

The potions, crafted with care, yet lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a spark, a flourish, a flair, if thou wilt.  

The hall, though bare, didst possess a certain charm, alack, 'twas empty, save for us, upon a Sunday eve, at eight, when most do seek their pleasure.  

The service, middling, a single servant, yet sufficed for our small band, and he, though not effusive, didst speak the truth, all drinks, he said, were good, and that was that.  

And thus, we chose, Agnatha and Anni, August 21st, 1959, two draughts, the former, crisp, tart, strong, yet, ice, small, didst mar its beauty, and the latter, smoky, not to mine taste, yet, if such be thy desire, 'tis a good choice, forsooth.  

And thus, I say, I shall return, for convenience's sake, close by, solid drinks, and no worry of a table, a goodly spot, in sooth."

"Methinks 'tis a grand sushi establishment, my friend! Forsooth, their spicy tuna dish is a marvel, a true delight. Alas, my experience with their fillet mignon steak and chicken left somewhat to be desired. The chicken, in sooth, was a mite dry. Yet, upon requesting teriyaki sauce, all was made right once more. In conclusion, I must confess that, despite this minor hiccup, I was mightily impressed. Verily, when next I find myself in this fair town, I shall most certainly return to sample further delectable offerings from their menu."

"Hark! If thou hast children of an elder year,
This place doth not beseem them, fear not, my dear.
For those of tender age, beneath the sun's rays,
This realm doth cater, with joys in store, I pray.
Laser tag, a sport of skill and might,
Doth entertain the elder youth, in sight.
But ware, my friend, the little ones, so bright,
For they doth roam, with energy in flight."

"Hark! The victuals here be passable, yet naught doth stir within my breast a fire of delight. No dish doth stand apart, ne'er to impress, nor doth it e'er offend. I have partaken of their fare a pair of times, and though the attendance be courteous, the viands themselves seem dull and lacking zest, as if they came to table straight from freezer or packet."

"Hark! A gathering at the Ritz doth lead us to Bistro 24's bar and restaurant, where we find solace in a delectable spread. On a Friday eve, no less! A feast for the senses, indeed. 

A buffet of appetizers, fit for a king, doth include Blue Point oysters, lobster bites, seared tuna with wasabi cream, filet mignon bites, shrimp, duck, and cheese delights. 

And then, a sushi stand, a veritable treat. 

Outdoors, the grill doth beckon, with filet mignon, lamb chops, organic salmon, grilled shrimp, and mashed potatoes, all vying for attention. Grilled greens, a delightful accompaniment. 

Lastly, the dessert stand, a haven of indulgence. 

And let us not forget the wine list, a fine collection, indeed."

"Methinks some of the finest dining experiences doth occur when thou dost almost pass by the establishment. Verily, 'tis a humble abode, yet the culinary delights within do make one grateful for the unassuming location.

The exterior, alas, doth leave much to be desired, and the environs are not the most salubrious. But fear not, dear gourmand, for this petite eatery doth boast a warm and welcoming ambiance, spotless tables, and a menu that doth delight.

My comrade and I didst chance upon Las Glorias, our curiosity piqued by a token of appreciation. And, by the stars, what a find! The tortilla chips, crispy and fresh, didst complement the delectable bean and salsa dips. The rice, cooked to perfection, didst accompany the generous portions of our meals. My companion, a connoisseur of chile rellenos, didst declare this rendition among the best she had ever savored, the batter light and fluffy, the cheese abundant.

We shall, without doubt, return to this culinary gem, coupon or no coupon, for 'tis a veritable treasure trove of gastronomic joy."

"Ere I purchased the Groupon, I perused each review,
So well prepared, I knew what lay in store.
A master of delay, I waited till the last,
And fortunate was I, for they found a way to accommodate me.

Jennifer and Kelly, a pair of skilled lasses,
Tended to my nails, their touch, a gentle caress.
Their work, a hour and a half, did take,
Friendly, they were, and their skill, did make.

Two gripes, I had, a minor quibble,
Awkward, the chair, for my pedi, did feel.
Couches, they had, for the ladies, fair,
More comfortable, it did seem, I did declare.

Nude shades, my preference, they lacked,
Explained, they did, their policy, quite attacked.
One more visit, discounted, I shall have,
Then full price, a pretty penny, I shall crave."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals and attendance upon them were most excellent, a true feast for mine eyes and belly. Howbeit, there was this one odd fellow, with his cur at his side, within the establishment. Trow, 'twas a breach of hygiene standards, and didst stir within me a sense of unease. Fie upon him, say I!"

"Upon a time, a friend and I didst make reservations at this place,
During Restaurant Week, our hunger to satiate.
The atmosphere, though welcoming, didst feel a bit too neat,
But drinks, they were, and potent, didst our spirits greet.

I started with a plate of pickles, varied and fine,
Which didst prepare my taste buds for the feast divine.
For entree, I chose the trout, pan-seared to perfection,
With barley risotto, a dish of pure elation.

And for dessert, key lime pie, my heart didst sing,
For I cannot resist its sweet and tangy zing.
In conclusion, 'twas a pleasant experience, indeed,
And I do look forward to return, and more to read."

"Upon the eve of love, I chanced upon this place,
Vintage, where romance doth fill the air,
A patio, by the fire, didst provide a space,
For me to sit, and savor wine so fair.

Their Sangria, oh how sweet and fine,
Didst quench my thirst, and made me feel divine,
And on most Saturdays, a singer, Sarah,
Doth grace the stage, with voice so rare.

A place for lovers, or for friends to meet,
Vintage doth provide, a setting so discreet,
So if thou art in search of charm and grace,
Come hither, and let Vintage be thy place."
