Here, too, may one find boba drinks of diverse sorts. Alas, a minor quibble doth exist, for oft they doth feign comprehension, yet still they doth botch the order. Small matters, indeed, such as a dearth of cilantro or an overabundance of this or that."

"Methinks 'tis a frequent haunt of mine, and ne'er have I encountered such woes as others have yelped about...

The best of rolls, a Vegas delight, damn good, a spicy cowboy or cowgirl, by my troth! 

Alas, sashimi, a dish most fine, yet, save for when 'tis fresh from the briny deep, I dare not partake, lest I risk a dire fate. 

We've visited late in the day, and service hath been good, save for one busy night, when we didst celebrate a birthday with a score and five of friends. 

My sole complaint, the privy, doth need some repair, and I do detest the sound of employees, upon the throne, engaged in idle chatter on their devices."

"Thou art receiving an additional star, my dear, for two reasons most fair. 
The first, the remodel is complete, and the store doth shine with beauty rare. 
And second, this Iggle doth serve the finest sushi, with quality most true, 
Of all the Iggles in the land, none can compare, I do declare to thee. 
I have consumed many a rainbow roll, from diverse locations near and far, 
But none have matched the excellence of this Iggle's sushi, so divine and rare. 
'Tis a bold statement, indeed, but one that doth hold much weight, I swear. 
For I do love sushi, and desire it oft, with convenience and speed, 
And this Iggle doth provide all three, with quality that doth exceed."

"Hark! This humble diner doth serve a purpose true,
A place to dine, though not quite fit for a king.
The service can be slow, the ambiance plain,
But fear not, for the victuals shall make amends.

Aye, share a malt or shake with thy companion fair,
For 'tis a feast fit for the gods, and quite beyond compare.
And choose thy dish with care, for some are divine,
Like Meatless Meatloaf, a culinary shrine.

Alas, the rest doth pale in comparison,
Yet still, 'tis worth a visit, for the veggie options be a true sensation.
So give this place three stars, nay, four, I say,
For catering to the herbivores, they doth earn a merry day."

"Hark! What's this? A feast most wondrous fair!
Pepperoni rolls, six in number, thou dost bear.
With sauce for dipping, 'tis a sight to see,
And price, alack! Six dollars forty-nine, 'tis steep, yet still, a bargain, mayhap.
For Woodchuck hard cider, too, they do provide,
A draught most excellent, that doth abide.
Deep dish pizza, middling, at best, I say,
For sausage chunks, too large, doth take away.
In fragments, smaller, spread across the pie,
Tastier, it would be, beyond doubt, I do avow.
Thin crust, other dishes, I have not essayed,
But service, friendly, and with zeal, they did display."

"Verily, the victuals, attendance, and atmosphere didst impress. Alas, a woeful minstrel didst sully the evening's delight with his wretched crooning of Beatles ditties, causing the departed Fab Four (God rest their souls!) to turn in their graves. Happily, he didst cease his caterwauling ere long. And so, we moved on to the feast...

The calamari, by Jove! 'Twas a delectable sight, with tender, juicy squid, shallots, Asian noodles, carrots, scallions, cashews, and red chiles bathed in a savory sauce. 

Halibut cheeks benedict, with lobster and Hollandaise, didst delight. The biscuits, aye, they were fit for a Southern queen, and the Hollandaise, not too stiff nor too rich, didst complement the eggs to perfection. The accompanying salad, alas, didst pale in comparison. 

Lobster bisque, a hearty thank thee! Not overly creamy, with a generous helping of lobster flavor, and a pleasing texture, it didst warm the cockles of mine heart. 

Asparagus, with Hollandaise, didst shine like the morning sun. Fresh, tender baby spears, they didst make mine mouth to water. 

Corn, oh corn! So fresh and full of life, it didst beguile mine taste buds. I couldst not get enough of its sweet, succulent goodness. 

Bananas Foster butter cakes, a mite too sweet for mine liking, yet others didst find them delectable. The butter pecan ice cream, by the gods, didst steal the show! 

Godiva chocolate cake, with vanilla bean ice cream, didst tempt me sore. Methinks 'twould be a sin to lick the plate clean, but oh, the temptation didst assail mine soul! 

Whitehaven Sauvignon Blanc, a fine vintage indeed! Its light, fresh bouquet didst evoke memories of Kim Crawford's finest. 

From the moment we didst step inside, the service didst impress. Swift, efficient, and professional, in every aspect, 'twas a grand evening, fit for a king!"

In fair Las Vegas, where pleasure doth reign,
A wondrous sight doth grace Fremont Street each day.
A show, with lights and sounds, doth take its place,
And all the town doth gather to behold the play.

The hotels, easy to access, doth invite,
And downtown's seediness doth add to the delight.
The neon lights, they doth shut down,
And all the people, they doth stop and stare, entranced.

The spectacle, it doth captivate,
As strangers gather, lost in the moment's embrace.
The street, it doth come alive,
As the lights flicker back, and all doth resume their pace.

'Tis not just the show, but the people,
That doth make this phenomenon most intriguing.
For in the crowds, we find our entertainment,
And thus, our time in Las Vegas, doth bring us joy and content.

"In fair Ohio, I didst reside,
But now, in this place, I do abide.
A massage therapist, I didst seek,
And Jill's name, didst my eyes meet.

On Yelp, her praises didst I read,
And thus, didst decide, to give her heed.
Her touch, so gentle, like a breeze,
Didst ease my tension, and my sore knees.

She knew her craft, with skill and art,
Stretching muscles, a daily part.
Forty seconds, a hold, didst seem long,
But with each breath, my body didst throng.

Now, every three weeks, I do attend,
To Jill's parlour, my body doth wend.
For a massage, most excellent and fine,
I do recommend, Jill, divine."

"Hark, what news is this? Steve Wynn doth strive
To have the finest buffet in all of Vegas,
And lo, his wish doth come to pass, forsooth.
The Wynn buffet, by the gods, doth take the cake,
In quality of ingredients and cooking, 'tis a step above the rest.
Thin-crust pizza, brick-oven baked, doth please,
And crab legs, meaty and huge, doth satisfy.
A rack of lamb, from New Zealand's green hills,
Doth make my mouth to water and my senses to thrill.
And mark, good sir, the Asian noodle soup bar,
Fresh longans, not canned, and Asian pears in salad,
Do add a touch of exotica, rare and fair.
But, alack, the line, it doth stretch far and wide,
A wait of 1.5 hours, and some did wait longer,
A fainting spell, a nosebleed, oh, how dire!
My lord, Steve Wynn, consider this, I pray,
A FastPass system, to ease the waiting fray."

"Tis not an easy quest, my friend, to find
A place that serves the noodles of my dreams,
In back of shops and stores, a humble abode,
I chanced upon a place they call Pho.

Their broth, a savory brew, did warm my soul,
And noodles, soft and chewy, did delight,
It brought me back to days of yore,
When in my homeland, I did dine with glee.

So now, my search is ended, and I know
That Pho, a worthy substitute, doth grow,
In this, a foreign land, where I do roam,
A taste of home, a comfort, doth it bring."

Methinks I do adore Arrowhead Mall, 'tis one of mine favorites, good sir! Its layout doth please mine eyes, for from either end, I may behold other shops with ease, and all are within reach. By Jove, it doth possess an Apple Store, a place most dear to mine heart! My fondness doth lie with American Eagle and Footlocker, yet for my wife, they have all else... verily, she doth enjoy a merry time, browsing through their wares. When wearied of our perambulations, diverse eateries doth await, ready to sate our hunger. In sooth, this mall doth contain all we need, and being nigh unto our domicile, we need not journey far to AZ Mills or Fashion Square Mall, save when ennui doth strike, and then, the journey shall be worthwhile.

"Methinks my hopes have not yet fully matured,
Since entering the VA system, I have endured
Two doctor's appointments, two visits to the lab,
And today, a meeting with a nutritionist, I had.

And lo, I must confess, I am quite pleased,
For waiting, there was none, and needles, they did not seize
Their chance to pain me. Volunteers, so kind and true,
Didst make my journey through the halls anew.

It took some time, indeed, to gain entry,
But now, I must admit, their care doth shine so brightly.
This VA, it doth serve a multitude,
And patient needs, they do take heed, most rightly.

So here's a thank you, to the staff, so fine,
For tending to my health, with such design."

"Amidst the throngs, deals doth abound,
In booths well-staffed, with wares profound.
New items doth fill each stall,
So seekers of pre-owned, take heed of the call.

For entrance fee, a single dollar doth suffice,
And though the mini donut booth doth cease to entice,
Other eateries doth remain, to sate thy hunger and thirst,
With security in place, no need to be cursed.

On sweltering days, when heat doth rise,
Come hither, quench thy thirst with sweet surprise.
Grab a smoothie, stroll and browse with ease,
For in this marketplace, doth joy and treasure seize."

"Verily, this place doth please mine eyes,
A haven of delight, where one may find surprise.
In fair San Francisco, or Sacramento's bounds,
None can compare, nor match its wondrous grounds.

Its grandeur lies within its spacious halls,
And entrance grand, that doth unfold its walls.
A pool, a peninsula, a sight to see,
A place of wonder, where all may be free.

But lo, upon Memorial Day,
The crowds did swell, and did my mind dismay.
I went upon the Sunday, not the Saturday,
Forsooth, the cover charge was quite unsavory.
Keri Hilson sang, but alas, her voice did falter,
And some did say, she didst cease to perform altogether.

The music doth change, like seasons in the air,
Now hip-hop, now pop, now house, beyond compare.
A place of wonder, XS, a gem so rare,
A place of joy, where all may revel and share."

"Hark, good sir or madam, let us begin anon,
The service at the register, most friendly was shown.
Aye, 'twas a sight to behold, a true delight,
The staff, with smiles so bright, did make our day take flight.

And lo, the theaters, they were but passable,
With Turbo, a film most wondrous and able.
But alack, the bathrooms, a sight most foul,
Did leave much to be desired, I do avow.

Yet still, the service, with thanks so genuine,
Did earn four stars, a rating most divine."

"Hark, my dear son! I have a word for thee,
A dish most wondrous, fit for royalty.
'Tis porkbellies, grilled to perfection,
With sides of rice, eggplant, macaroni, and cucumber,
A feast most satisfying, crunchy, and sweet.
Indeed, it doth not get much better than this,
A meal most excellent, fit for a king or queen."

"Methinks 'tis a place most wondrous fair,
With melodies that do delight mine ear,
And potions strong, that do stir mine spirits high,
Upon that roof, where one may gaze upon the sky.

Yet, alack, 'tis true, the crowd doth swell,
And four stars, not five, my rating doth tell.
For entry, naught didst we pay, nor didst we wait,
And through an escalator, Playboy Club, we didst straight pass.

A marvel, indeed, that such a place doth be,
Connected thus, in elegance and luxury."

"Fair sir, the victuals here be good, the attendance most kind,
Yet doth the bill of fare seem somewhat scant, and lacking in design.
In sooth, the viands be clean, wholesome, and true,
But wherefore doth the crowd not gather, as I do reckon they should?
Alas, 'twas but a weekday, and nigh upon the hour of one,
And lo, the tavern lay empty, devoid of mirth and fun.
Pray tell, what causeth this dearth of patrons, pray?"

"Hark, this airline doth be mine own heart's desire,
With punctuality unmatched, their record doth shine bright.
Clean planes, for the most part, doth greet mine eyes,
And riding the air bus, a joyous delight doth bring.

Oh, the early morn red eye flight, how wondrous fair,
To Vegas and then Honolulu, with haste doth take me there.
(Well, if thou art hardcore, LOL, 'tis true indeed.)

Food, though humble, doth grace our table,
No frills, yet sustenance enough, our hunger doth assuage.
So, seek this airline first, when to HNL thou must fly,
Or from Las Vegas, forthwith, doth take thy seat, ere long."

"Aft'r a late night of revelry and chance,
Where better to sate thy hunger than yon California Hotel's Cafe?
Their menu boasts many a choice, but I,
Do journey forth for the Ox Tail Soup, 'tis my heart's desire.

And I am not alone in this quest,
For round about, giant bowls of soup do abound,
With rice, a worthy complement, doth make its presence known.

Alas, 'tis a bit far from the strip,
And some drivers, their knowledge doth lack,
But fear not, for in winter's chill,
The soup doth warm and fill, with meat, veg, and fungi, at will.

Nor have I gambled much, but their tables,
Are on the cheap side, a boon, beyond all doubt.
Yay, low table limits, my purse doth sing,
For I may play longer, with a merrier heart, and lighter spirit."

"Hark, my dear friend! While I may not be the greatest aficionado of Mexican cuisine in our fair village, I must confess that dining here hath always been a pleasure. 'Tis a curious blend of Grecian and Mexican flavors, a true gastronomic union! But, alas, what doth capture my heart are the delectable chips and salsa. Verily, their Veggie Burro doth reign supreme, a culinary delight indeed!"

"Hark! What luck didst thou bring us, fair Pub and Grill?
A night before, at Gordon Ramsey's, we did dine,
But this, my friends, didst far surpass the bill.
We arrived at eleven, to avoid the throng,
And found the place bustling, with folk galore,
Ten parties waited, their patience to test,
But we, dear friends, didst not have to endure the woe.

Our server, kind and fair, didst guide us through,
The menu vast, with choices manifold,
She shared her wisdom, her suggestions made,
And we, dear friends, didst take her counsel to our heart.

The burgers, oh! How juicy and divine!
No fault couldst we find, in taste or form so fine.
Sweet potato fries, a mountain high and steep,
We struggled to finish, but 'twas a happy sleep.

The price, so fair and reasonable, a delight,
For thirteen to fifteen coins, a feast most bright.
Alas, the shakes, we didst not get to try,
But shall, anon, forsooth, ere we say goodbye.

A great place, indeed, with service true,
We shall return, and that, anon, we'll do."

Hark! My spouse and I, we do delight
In Hef's, where atmosphere doth please,
Cozy, yet full of life and merriment,
A place where diversity doth reign supreme.
Their fried tomatoes, delectable they be,
And drinks, they do quench thirst most excellently.
A bar most pleasant, in this neighborhood so fair.

"Hark, what news is this? A car wash, they say?

Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, let us sing its praise!

'Tis Danny's Family, with locations many,
Their business thrives, as the crowds demonstrate.

Oh, how I love to wait, until the need is great,
To feel the joy of a clean car, oh so elate!

Danny's does the deed, with speed and care,
A job well done, beyond compare.

And lo, on Tuesdays, a discount doth await,
For ladies, a perk, a benefit so great!

Then note it well, and heed my words,
On Tuesdays, to Danny's, thy car convey!"

"In sooth, this creperie doth lie within a strip mall, and dimly lit it be. Yet, cozy and casual it doth feel, and comforting doth the food prove to be. For groups of four or more, al fresco dining shall be thy fate, at the front of the establishment thou shalt sit. A small counter doth provide a space to watch the crepes being made, as thou dost enjoy thy repast. A Frisco crepe, with fresh blueberries in lemon curd, powdered sugar, and whipped cream, didst I order. Perfect with my morning coffee, it was, yet a tad more lemon curd, I didst desire. For those who wish to venture forth from their usual breakfast fare, 'tis a place most excellent. FUNtastic, indeed!"

"Hark! A hearty burger didst thou seek, my friend?
And lo, thy quest didst end most happily,
For here, within this humble tavern's walls,
Didst thou find sustenance that doth please thee well.

Thy patty, cooked to order, didst arrive with grace,
And staff, so pleasant, didst attend to thee,
With nary a trace of haste or pressure's sting,
Their kindness didst make thy meal most enjoyable, I do declare.

And, oh! The onion rings, a tasty delight,
Didst complement thy burger with such flair,
That thou didst leave this place, most satisfied,
And with a smile, didst bid the day adieu."

"In my kin, there be a rule, a decree most steadfast,
That when we purchase a domicile, a tavern be near at hand,
Lest snow and ice, in winter's grasp, our cars doth bind,
Leaving us, our families, and liquor, in a sorry plight.

Aye, 'tis true, I can stroll to Mike's, a humble abode,
With vintages of grape, and spirits, of finest quality,
At prices fair, without pretence, or snootiness,
A place where one can quaff, and revel in simplicity.

In summer's heat, I sought a wine, fresh, light, and zesty,
Vinho verde, from Portugal, a libation most festive,
And lo, Mike's had it, on sale, a steal, a bargain,
Five coins, a price most reasonable, a true treasure to behold.

I've walked afar, for less, and found naught but despair,
But Mike's, thy hospitality, doth shine, like sun in spring's air."

"Freshest ingredients, Italian dishes most true, Decor authentic, as if from Tuscany anew. Fast delivery, a marvel, I must confess. Garlic bread, a middling dish at best, But numerous other wonders, my tastebuds did bless. Fettuccine Alfredo, a rich delight, Sicilian pizza, a masterpiece, so bright. Mattarocca, oh how sweet thy flavor doth lie."

"Hark! What hotel is this? A place most fair,
With location on the Royal Mile so rare.
A climb, indeed, from train station steep,
Yet worth it, for the view of Arthur's Seat doth keep.

Older architecture, crypt-like bar doth hold,
Nespresso machine in room, a Radisson gold.
Bed, enormous, super comfy, a delight,
But alas, poor TV reception, a sorry sight.

Reception service, excellent in every way,
Helped with restaurant choice, for quiet day.
Reserved a table, with book in hand,
A peaceful meal, without a single stand."

"Methinks 'twas much improved, this second stay,
Compared to when we first did come this way,
When Aladdin's magic didst fade away,
And Planet Hollywood took its place, by day.

I am glad, fair friends, that I didst give
This hotel chain another chance to live,
For now we have a room most fair and bright,
With two queens, non-smoking, and a plasma in sight.

A bottle of Skyy Vodka, free of charge,
Didst come with our room, a gift so large,
And forty dollars in casino play,
To boot, my dears, what more could one say?

The bathroom, spacious and clean, didst boast
A tub, a shower, and two sinks at the cost,
Of but a single room, a steal, methinks,
For us four ladies, and our many blinks.

But, alas, dear friends, there was a flaw,
In the form of lighting, dim and raw,
The room, though large, didst lack in lights,
And left us groping in the darkest nights.

And, verily, the bathroom didst grow hot,
From too much light, a fault, I do not,
But, all in all, we didst enjoy our stay,
Despite a bed with stains, which didst fade away."

"A spacious suite, a fair price doth bring,
Ten minutes' stroll to arenas of sport, where throngs do sing.
In downtown's heart,'midst bars and eateries galore,
No need to rent a carriage or drive thy chariot o'er.
All's nigh, and we shall visit anon, when seasons change."

"Hark! A culinary delight doth lie within this eatery's walls, my friends! Forsooth, I didst partake of their savory beef arepa, a dish most wondrous and divine. Yet, alas! The chicken salad, a dish of mediocrity, didst not impress mine taste buds as much. But lo! Their grilled chicken, served with rice and beans, didst make mine mouth to water and mine belly to sing with joy! 'Tis a feast fit for a king, I say! And, by the stars, I shall return anon to sample their delectable empanadas, for they didst appear most appetizing, indeed!"

"Alack, good sirs and madams, how I do detest
This bar that doth proffer naught but woeful cheer,
Their adult milkshakes, verily, be the only boon,
That doth redeem this place from utter disdain,
For all else, 'tis but common, lackluster fare,
With speakers galore, that doth assault mine ears,
In sooth, 'tis naught but mediocrity that doth reign,
In this, the tavern of the saddlebag trail, alas!"

"Hark, what news is this? Jim and Tabitha, twain of skill,
Do serve the finest drinks with wit and will.
On Wednesdays, laughter doth fill the air,
As comedians take stage, their craft to share.
And lo, the victuals, priced just right,
Do please the palate, a wondrous sight.
So gather round, friends, and make merry,
For here, mirth and cheer do reign supreme."

"Hark, what changes have occurred since my last visit! The fair but uncomfortable chairs, once a sight to behold, Have been replaced with cushioned seats, though somewhat too wide for the tables, alack! 

We began our feast with Summer Rolls, large and delectable, beyond my expectations, indeed! The beef within had a charcoal flavor, quite delightful, and fresh veggies wrapped in rice paper, a refreshing treat, served with a light fish sauce, a perfect complement. 

My Spicy Stir-Fry, not as fiery as I had hoped, yet still possessed a pleasant kick, I must confess. The chicken, cooked to perfection, a medley of fresh crunchy veggies, all cloaked in a well-balanced sauce, a veritable feast for the senses! 'Twas a dish most excellent, and worth every penny of its meager price, $7.25, a true bargain, by my reckoning. 

Verily, I say unto thee, my dear friend, that thus far, naught but satisfaction hath I known at this establishment. They offer divers options, rare and unique, a true delight, and the victuals, most solid, a culinary joy, anon!"

"By Jove, the portions here be generous indeed! 

Aye, the prices didst frighten me away from Fuego Bistro's door, 
For the menu, though tempting, didst seem too much to bear. 
But lo, a happy hour didst present itself, with drinks most fine, 
And sliders, delicate and savory, didst make mine eyes doth shine. 
Still, dinner, a feast most grand, didst seem beyond my means, 
Until a Groupon didst come my way, with conditions most queer. 
My friend, a wise and clever soul, didst suggest we dine together, 
And thus, we didst, with portions most bountiful and fair. 
A dozen shrimp, a mountain of pork, didst grace mine eyes, 
And sides, aplenty, didst make mine taste buds most joyful. 
So heed my words, good sir, and fear not the price, 
For at Fuego Bistro, thou shalt find value in abundance."

In fair Las Vegas, where we chanced to roam,
We celebrated our first year of wedlock's home.
At Margaritaville, within Flamingo's walls,
We savored tacos, and sipped flavored margaritas that enthralled.
The atmosphere was lively, full of cheer,
With live music that did banish all fear.
A place most suitable for families, I do declare,
Margaritaville, a haven of delight, beyond compare.

"Methinks 'tis the finest Vietnamese eatery in all of Las Vegas, by my troth! Aye, 'tis ever crowded, come the weekend, with folk of all stations. Their victuals, authentic and plentiful, doth please mine own kin greatly. Alas, their service, poor and lacking, doth leave much to be desired. Many a waitress doth roam the floor, yet they doth ignore us, or attend to trifles of small import. Fie upon their service, for their fare, most delectable!"

"A store of wonders, filled with drinks galore,
For adults who seek to indulge and explore.
Rows upon rows of wine, beer, and spirits,
A sight most marvelous, and a delightful treat.

The staff, so friendly and eager to help,
Makes one feel welcome, and the experience quite swell.
I found a beer, Alien Stout, oh so fine,
And Nut Brown Ale, a taste divine.

Wells Banana Bread beer, a surprise,
Beyond belief, a true delight.
The wine selection, vast and grand,
Intimidating, yet, a treasure to behold.

Glassware and snacks, aplenty to choose,
To complement your drink, and make it quite loose.
Boarhead meats and cheeses, a delicious find,
And chips and mixes, for a tasty mind.

In conclusion, this store is a gem,
A place to find all your alcoholic whims.
Lee's, take note, this place stands supreme,
A true delight, for all to esteem."

"O, wondrous coaches, skilled in their art,
Do teach the young ones with a zealous heart.
But, alas, the place where parents do congregate,
Is woefully inadequate, a sorry state.

A seat, ye cannot find, so dense the crowd,
And standing, long, thy feet doth wear a cloud.
When two hours pass, and classes doth begin,
Thy patience doth wear thin, in discomfort's pinch."

"Twice in recent months, I've visited Root,
A place of gastronomic delight, no doubt.
The first time, 'twas a truly wondrous night,
Our server, a friendly soul, made our evening bright.
We talked of beer and food, and shared our tales,
And the ambiance, it was quite divine, I daresay.
The food, oh how it did impress,
Especially the Brussels sprouts, a tasty mess.

But alas, the second time, 'twas not so grand,
Our server, seemingly stoned, did not take a stand.
He came, he went, he brought our check,
And left us wondering, what the heck?
The food, it was decent, I must confess,
But the service, oh how it did disappoint, I must profess.
So, Root, a place of wonder, indeed,
But hit or miss, it seems, is how they proceed."

"Hark! What news is this? The parking system now doth function well,  
A vast improvement, indeed, doth tell.  
Good morrow, gentlemen! Your diligence doth earn my praise,  
For working hard, despite the rain's wild gaze.  
The track, once soggy, now doth lie dry and flat,  
A testament to thy dedication, stout and pat.  
Well done, good sirs! Thy efforts doth deserve a cheer,  
For making sure the race didst start without a fear."

"Verily, this pizza doth stand alone,
In Pittsburgh's culinary scene, 'tis shown.
Eleven other pies have I essayed,
But none compare to this, my heart's arrayed.
When homesickness doth strike, and I do yearn
For a taste of New York, then IVP doth burn
Brightest, like a beacon in the night,
Guiding me home, with flavors so tight."

"Fair priced victuals, a merry ambiance, and a feast most wondrous, doth make a place most excellent, beyond compare. For a mere thirteen silverlings, thou shalt partake in their 'unnumbered' luncheon special, a veritable cornucopia of flavors, a true gastronomic delight."

"In search of venue, where merriment could flow free,
We chanced upon Bahama Breeze, a place to be,
Laid back, with time to mingle, our hearts' desire,
The food, a feast, our guests' eyes did light and fire.

The evening's start, at nine, an hour most fair,
Appetizers, aplenty, for all to share,
The atmosphere, light, fun, a joyous air,
Our friends, they danced, and laughter filled the lair.

But, alas, a quibble, small, yet worth the tell,
The staff, at times, did seek my counsel,
As if 'twere mine, the reins, to hold and sway,
I thought, their role, to guide, not me, to play.

Yet, friendly, they were, and our joy, they did enhance,
So, four stars, I give, with naught but chance,
For, in the end, our love, did there unfold,
And memories, sweet, within that place, did hold."

"Methinks their victuals be divine,
A feast fit for a king, or so it doth seem.
The tatami chambers, but an added delight,
To the delectable fare, that doth ignite.

The unagi bowl, a treasure beyond measure,
A delicacy, worth each penny's weight.
Though prices be steep, 'tis true,
For sushi, such is the cost, I do aver.

If weary of the buffet's fare,
Give this place a chance, and thou shalt see,
That 'tis a veritable paradise,
For gastronomes, in search of bliss."

"Methinks a Groupon deal did make this meal most fair,
The portions and quality didst seem quite square.
But on my second visit, alas! the portions shrank,
And I didst suspect the non-Japanese chef didst blink.
His skills, perchance, not as great as his kin,
Nor generous with his sushi, as the first time in.
Yet still, a good experience doth this place impart,
And thus, my friends, I do recommend this art."

On Sunday, Solin and I didst venture forth to Spring Valley Park,
A place of recreation, full of merriment and joy.
We searched the internet, and this park didst emerge,
With recommendations grand, and praise didst employ.

Three fenced sections there be, for dogs of all size,
And Solin, being a poodle, didst enter with great guile.
The area was vast, and many dogs didst play,
With frisbees flying high, in a most delightful way.

A water fountain for dogs, and bags to clean,
Didst supply our needs, and Solin didst gleam.
He ran and played, with energy unbound,
Like a child in a candy store, his joy didst resound.

But lo, a strange sight didst catch mine eye,
Two dogs, their noses locked, in a curious guise.
"Don't worry," said the owner, with a smile so bright,
"Dogs sniff each other's rear, 'tis their nature's plight."

I laughed and marveled at this wondrous sight,
And thanked the owner for her words, so wise and bright.
Solin had a grand time, and so didst I,
At Spring Valley Park, where dogs can run and fly.

"Methinks 'tis fortunate to have a Mexican eatery so near,
With tasty victuals and drinks, a true delight.
Yet, alack, the exercise I had planned that day,
Didst fly out the window, with naught but dismay.

Aye, the prices didst seem fair, comparable to others,
But still, my purse didst feel the pinch of each brother.
If speed and proximity be my desire,
This place doth fit the bill, like a burning fire.

The atmosphere didst please mine eyes,
With decor fitting for a Mexican surprise.
Good cheer and beer didst flow like a stream,
And service, prompt as any good dream.

Specials they didst offer, a feast for the sight,
Worth trying, no doubt, with all thy might."

"Methought I chanced upon a quaint eatery,
Whilst perusing Yelp during our Sin City stay.
Their French toast sandwich, oh how divine!
A perfect blend of sweet and savory, in sooth.
It doth delight my taste buds, and doth sway
My heart, to dine there, come the break of day.
A haven for the hungry, after a night
Of revelry and dance, beneath the city's lights.
Alas, I do beseech the gods, to grant me near,
This culinary gem, that doth arouse my cheer."

"Hark! A place that doth impress, my friend,  
With clockwork monkeys on a string, 'tis true.  
A chessboard floor, and seats aplenty,  
Downstairs, a space most comfortable, I do declare.  
And water, efficient, though silent as can be.  
Arriving guests, a waiter doth attend,  
With tiny tumblers of water, ere they choose,  
A drink of strength, or not, as doth their fancy sway.  
No written menu, just a list of names,  
And prices, too. A lucky dip, perchance?  
I asked for mocktail, and the barkeep did say,  
"What wouldst thou avoid?" A clever query, indeed.  
No bananas, I replied, and off he sped,  
To mix a brew, without that fruit, 'twas plain to see.  
And lo, no coffee nor lamb, a happy find,  
But alas, the drink, a bitter lemon, doth seem.  
Yet mature, not overly sweet, a minty delight,  
Crushed ice, a joy, and all for just three pounds and five shillings,  
A bargain, indeed, and worth another visit, I do reckon."

"Twice a week, for four months, I doth serve
On jury duty, in this fair city of Phoenix.
A chance to explore, and dine at new places,
It doth bring me joy, and fill my days with grace.

At Cartel Coffee Lab, I didst stop and dine,
Their breakfast, lunch, and coffee, all divine.
The decor, trendy, yet I do not pay heed,
For 'tis the food and service, that doth feed.

A BLT, I ordered, and with haste, they brought,
With egg, a surprise, yet I didst not fault.
In Canada, a chain called Tim Horton's doth reign,
With BELT, their menu, a similar refrain.

The sandwich, delicious, and the lady fair,
Didst wait upon me, with kindness and care.
She asked my thoughts, and chatted with glee,
Great customer service, a sight to see.

Four stars, I gave, for I must eat again,
To give a five, my rule, a strict decree.
But if thou art downtown, do give them a try,
Their food and service, shall surely satisfy."

"The staff, a merry bunch, doth make our stay most pleasant. The rooms, though small, did serve their purpose well. The pool, a grand sight to behold, with waterfalls and all, did shine in its cleanness. No waiting did we have to endure, for all was ready at our beck and call. The lazy river, a wondrous delight, did bring us joy and mirth. The on-site eateries, though pricey, did serve most delectable fare. A place most suitable for families with young ones, to indulge in aquatic frolics."

In fair Las Vegas, where we lay our scene,
A culinary journey did await, 'twas keen.
For twenty-seven years on earth I dwelt,
And never once had tasted Korean fare, till now.

At D.J.K., we dined, our belts we did loosen,
With two kind Koreans, who our menu chosen.
They ordered for us, and we did not resist,
For they knew best, and their taste was persist.

Soju, a drink strong and fine, they did recommend,
To heighten the flavors, and our senses attend.
And should thou visit, from eleven to two,
A discount of twenty percent, thy bill doth accrue.

"Hark! This Italian place doth reign supreme,
In Vegas, thus far, 'tis the best esteem.
Their pizza, great indeed, doth please the taste,
But dinner entrees, they do surpass haste.
I've brought my kin and friends from afar,
And they, in unison, have praised the fare.
Chicken Marsala, my heart doth sing,
Shrimp Alfredo, a dish most wondrous, doth bring.
Pizza, focaccia, all doth delight,
A feast most sumptuous, doth ignite the night.
If thou dost order pizza, for delivery, beware,
For maidens young, with voices soft and fair,
Do answer calls, and take thy order, with grace,
But, alack! Their youth, doth make the task, a trial, in this place.
Yet, fear not, for delivery, doth come apace,
And prices, fair, doth make this meal, a wondrous embrace."

"Hark! 'Twas a fine evening, good sir,  
In the late nineteen-hundreds, I didst stir  
Amidst the bustling streets of Charlotte's town,  
Where this establishment didst lay its gown.  
My first visit in a decade and a half,  
Didst bring me back to savor its wealth.  
A feast most excellent, with crawfish first,  
Didst leave me in awe, and didst quench my thirst.  
No waiting, shall I, ere I doth return,  
To partake in their culinary learn."

"A wondrous deal, my dear! For twelve silver coins, thou shalt partake in a feast fit for a king! A pizza of generous proportions, with toppings galore, to sate thy hunger and leave thee not feeling guilty of gluttony. And fear not, for there is another branch in fair Hillcrest, San Diego, where thou mayst also indulge in this culinary delight. 'Tis a veritable bargain, my friend! The pizza, it doth please, with its crust so thin and delicate, and the toppings, they do complement it well. Choose thine own, or opt for their standard fare, all for the sum of twelve dollars, a price most fair and reasonable."

"Methinks this taco stand doth serve most wondrous fare,
As good as any I have had in Texas, by my troth.
A cool and merry scene doth surround me, full of mirth,
And thus, my heart doth sing with joy, forsooth."

"Alas, this place doth seem to be shut tight,
A permanent closure, naught but night.
Last summer's voice, a message didst leave,
Closed for the season, so didst believe.
But now, in autumn's chill embrace,
Still shuttered fast, with naught a trace.

A pity, truly, for in days of yore,
I didst praise its charms, and more.
An outdoor space, most fair and bright,
Food, good and plentiful, a wondrous sight.
AC, at times, didst blow with icy breath,
But kindly, they didst heed our request, and death.

Lunchtime choices, numerous and fine,
Under ten dollars, a bargain divine.
Service, prompt and attentive, with grace,
They didst attend to our each desire, with haste.
The dinner menu, we didst ask to share,
And lo, they didst oblige, without a single care.
Wine, a selection, fine and choice,
But alas, untried, our visits, limited to voice.

Spinach dip, a treat, beyond compare,
Small salads, healthy, fresh, and fair.
Pizza, tasty, sandwiches, a delight,
Creative combinations, a true culinary sight."

"A waffle cone of home make didst thou savour,
With Almond Joy ice cream, a sweet favour.
The servers, friendly, didst attend thee well,
And the dessert, most satisfying, didst quell
Thy craving for sweets. Thou art content,
And doth plan to return, thy love to bent.
In Pittsburgh, thy boyfriend doth reside,
And there, thy sweet tooth shall be satisfied."

"Hark! Went I to this place for luncheon with Rand H.,
And found it to be quite good, with some forty dishes nigh.
A veritable feast, with soups of egg drop and hot and sour,
Both of which I did enjoy, and had a bowl of each, by th' hour.

The main courses, all of them, were cooked to perfection,
Five stars, I say, for most, if not all, of them, with conviction.
But alas, the desserts, they did lack, in truth,
With jello, sliced peaches, and those small white balls, of youth.

Still, for the price of $5.75, 'twas a meal most fair,
And though the service may have been lacking, I do declare,
The food, so good, doth make up for it, in my mind,
And thus, four stars, I give, with a smile, and a wink, so kind."

"Methinks 'twas a fortunate morn indeed,
When first I did partake of yon crepe so fine.
'Twas as if the gods themselves had blessed me,
With sweetness that did rival the divine.

Nutella, whipped cream, caramel, chocolate sauce,
Bananas, and candied hazelnuts, all did combine
To form a culinary delight most true,
That did satiate my cravings, and lift my spirits anew.

In sooth, fair friends, there be no way to frown,
When in Las Vegas thou doth start thy day with such renown.
For in this city of excess and glee,
A morning meal fit for a king, doth guarantee a spree."

"Methinks this place doth serve most excellent fare,
And drinks that do please mine taste buds rare.
The decor, quite nice, and outdoor seats,
A pleasant spot, upon the bustling streets.

I've visited thrice, and each time, I say,
The food, a feast for mine eyes and tongue, did play.
But, alas, the service, slow and poor,
Doth mar the experience, and doth make me sour.

First time, we waited, hands up, in vain,
For drinks, a laggard pace, did cause much pain.
And subsequent visits, though not so dire,
Did find the waitress, in a state of disarray, and fire.

Yet still, I do return, for food most fine,
And hope, that service, shall be better, in time."

"A gentler thrift store, with wares most fair,
In abundance, for all to behold,
Their 99 cent days, alas, are no more,
But fear not, for half-price and colored tags, do abound.
Not too much rubbish, doth this place contain,
A journey worthwhile, for garments most fine, I do maintain."

"Hark! Tonight, our vacation feast doth lie In Bandera, Old Town Scottsdale's pride. Good reports of this eatery have reached mine ear, And thus, we doth anticipate its taste with cheer. Bandera, a sibling to Houstons and Rutherford Grill, Both five-star establishments, doth fill our will.

We doth arrive, a half-hour ere our time, And on the patio, we doth enjoy a drink and dine On deviled eggs, a tasty appetite-whetter. Our table, ready swiftly, doth await our presence. We order corn bread, grilled artichoke, and more, The artichoke, a delight, doth please mine taste. The cornbread, best I've had, doth leave me in awe.

For mine main course, steak and enchilada doth suffice, A six-ounce filet, cut into three pieces, doth arrive With maroon spicy sauce, a flavorful device. The enchilada, filled with rotisserie fowl, doth impress. My wife, her Macho Salad doth command, Yet missing chicken, a mishap, doth befall. Quickly corrected, she doth enjoy it full well.

Bandera, good, yet not as great as its kin, Four stars, a rating fair, doth mark its worth within."

"Miranda, the fair masseuse, doth possess  
A skill most wondrous, and a touch so fine,  
She doth unknot my muscles with ease,  
And doth imbue me with a sense of peace.  
Her slender frame doth belie her strength,  
And her fingers, deft and sure, do find  
The hidden tension in my weary flesh,  
And doth release it with a gentle touch.  
She doth converse with me, albeit slow,  
And doth display a knowledge vast and deep,  
Of her craft, and of the human form,  
In all its complexity, and all its norms.  
The branch, clean and tidy, doth present  
A welcoming atmosphere, and the staff,  
Friendly and courteous, doth attend  
To my each and every need, save one,  
The girl at front desk, whose name doth flee,  
Doth seem a mite reserved, and doth not be  
As warm and cozy as the rest, to me."

"The playhouses, fair and bright, do shine so keen,
As if but newly built, their splendor doth be seen.
The confectionary, with victuals for young sprites,
Doth offer diverse treats, to please their tender sight.
My eldest, with wisdom beyond his years, did choose
Corn dog bits, a meal most wondrous, I do suppose.
And lo, the cashier, with grace and gentle cheer,
Did bring our feast, with speed, to us, ere long,
In the dark cave of dreams, where visions doth unfold."

"Methinks I didst venture forth to yonder establishment,
During that most wondrous celebration known as "Poutine Week".
Their poutine, with brisket, didst delight mine taste buds,
Forsooth, the meat was tender, juicy, and of great worth.
Alas, the service didst leave much to be desired,
For we didst wait nigh on half an hour, and our patience didst grow tired.
And though the tables were few, I doth suggest,
Takeaway, perchance, doth seem the wiser choice, lest thou desire to be delayed."

"Hark, what place is this? A coffee shop, by Jove!
And yet, 'tis not like any other I have known.
The folk who work here, friendly and kind,
Do greet us both on entry and on exit, I find.

The prices, simple and rounded to the dollar,
A pleasant surprise, by the stars!
I ordered a soy iced latte, a curious brew,
And found it quite tasty, I must confess.

The beans they use, different from those I know,
Earthy and rich, a new flavor to show.
Not too strong, nor bitter, a perfect blend,
A drink most satisfying, and worth a friend.

The decor, inviting and warm, a cozy nest,
A place to linger, with friends, and be blessed.
But alas, I came to study, and focus,
So, alack, I could not play, with their games, nor frolic.

A grouchy cookie, Yelp-famous, I did seek,
But the cashier, knew not of it, a strange freak.
No matter, for the wifi, fast and free,
A bonus, indeed, for this place, so grand to see.

Ah, but alas, too far from my home, it lies,
Else, I would visit, more often, and with surprise.
Still, a gem, this coffee shop, a find,
A place to return, whene'er I am in the mind."

"Tammy Coe Cakes, a place most fair and bright,
Where food doth please and staff doth delight.
In Phoenix's heart, it doth take root,
A cherished spot, for all to boot."

"Methought I sought the wares of women, fair and bright,
And lo, the salesperson was most courteous in sight.
I would return anon, should they possess the stock,
For fortune's favor doth await my next visit, mayhap."

"Hark! I be but five foot two, yea, verily,
And sought to have my low-rise jeans let down,
Forsooth, this place didst provide swift service,
And with great skill, didst they render their craft.
Their prices, not the lowest, yet fair,
And worth the cost, for their work was of high quality,
A tailor, common, couldst not compare."

"By chance, I found this place, near my alma mater's halls,
Whilst seeking noodles, my taste buds' greatest thrall.
I searched my phone, and this place did soon appear,
A curious mix of Italian and Asian fare, I did fear.

But since I'd come so far, I thought, 'Why not give it a go?'
And in I walked, with menu in hand, to make my choice.
Pad Thai, a classic dish, I ordered with glee,
And oh, how glad I was that I had chosen thus, forsooth!

It was a feast, full of flavors, a true delight,
I savored each bite, and my hunger took flight.
Since then, I've returned, and still, it doth impress,
A humble abode, where casual dining doth bless.

Whene'er I'm nearby, I stop by, to partake,
Of their delectable dishes, a true culinary make.
And when at home, I do enjoy, my TV shows,
With their tasty grub, my hunger doth no longer grow."

"In fair Las Vegas, where dining options abound,
Dim sum places be few, and far between found.
One such place, Orchids Garden, doth stand apart,
A haven for those who seek a taste of the East.

Their offerings diverse, with prices most fair,
The hall itself, spacious and grand, doth declare
A feast fit for kings, or so it doth seem,
For those who partake of their culinary dream.

Compared to others, this place doth shine so bright,
A gem among the rest, a true delight.
So if thou find thyself in Sin City's thrall,
Do make haste to Orchids Garden, and partake of all."

"Mango, chili, lime, a wondrous blend,
In this pie, so bold and full of zest.
The first bite, strange, yet rich and tart,
Doth ignite the taste buds, and doth play a part.
In this dance of flavors, spicy and bright,
One doth return, for more delight.
Mama Toledo's, a culinary joy,
Doth bring us together, with each savory employ."

"Hark, my friends, to this tale of woe,
Of a place we did visit, yonder,
For happy hour, a fortnight past,
But alas, 'twas closed, and that was fast.

In June of 2013, it did cease,
To be, a place of joy and ease,
No more could we partake,
Of drinks and cheer, forsooth, 'twas fake.

So now, dear friends, take heed,
And know that this place, doth need,
Avoidance, lest thou wish to see,
A shut door, and naught but misery."

"Methinks 'tis a rare find, this Mon Ami Gabi,
In Vegas' vast expanse, where prices be high.
A place where value doth meet cost, I do declare,
And breakfast, oh so fair, doth make my day bright.

Blueberry French Toast, a dish most divine,
With bread, fresh blueberries, and cream so fine.
Syrup, a sweet delight, doth crown this feast,
And in my belly, a happy guest doth find its nest.

Verily, I say, this meal doth please me well,
And worth the coin, I do most certainly tell.
So if thou seek'st a breakfast of great renown,
To Mon Ami Gabi, thy steps doth quickly bound."

"Four stars, fair prices, and good victuals, say I,
For this establishment, with one caveat nigh.
A manager, Bob, didst make amends, 'tis true,
For poor service of a maid, Sabrina, anew.

Six of us sat in a booth, and when she came,
To take our order, I didst explain my aim.
Separate tickets, I requested, for my wife and me,
But she refused, with a shake of her head, ye see.

I asked if we could sit elsewhere, and she said,
"Yep, that's fine," but no explanation didst proceed.
I pressed her further, and she grew irate,
With a snarl, she spake, "It's policy, don't debate."

I vowed not to return, and her reply didst show,
The very reason why some workers do not glow.
Their attitude, akin to a sore, doth fester,
And makes one wonder, doth their labors matter?"

"Hark! AMC Rainbow Promenade, 'tis 1990, and it doth seek its former glory. Verily, this cinema doth show its age, and couldst use a sprucing up, methinks. In days of yore, 'twas a bustling hub of entertainment, but now, with newer theatres boasting luxurious amenities, 'tis easy for this humble abode to be forgotten. When last didst thou behold an AMC 10? Are they not now numbered 20 or 30? Yet, there be charm in the likes of this theatre. Firstly, deals abound, and the staff, they be kind and helpful. Secondly, peacefulness doth reign, untroubled by the throngs that flock to grander cinemas. Ah, but 'tis the company and the tale itself that maketh the experience most enjoyable. Yelp Personal Challenge, 45 of 366."

"In came Kiddo for his Senior pictures, by appointment made we did,  
Into a studio room he went, and shortly thereafter did emerge.  
A few moments passed, and then they showed him, pictures and poses of great worth,  
Indeed, they did a fantastic job, no doubt of that on earth!  
Classic gown shot they took, for yearbook purpose,  
But casual clothes, in pose, they captured too, with finest art.  
I had not planned to buy more, but such quality, could not ignore,  
So, friends and kin, I would this studio highly recommend, forevermore!"

The return factor is 85%.

"Methinks Encore doth please mine eyes,
A sight most fair, with reds and butterflies.
It doth make me feel most wealthy, merely strolling through,
And eateries of renown, there be many to choose from.
The drinks, they do delight, at each bar and lounge,
The pool, a haven, where one may luxuriate and bask.
Parking, a doddle, with naught a care or fuss,
But alack, 'tis still a place, where riches be the key.
Gaming, a venture, for those who can afford,
To wager large sums, with each hand they do play.
Yet still, a place of beauty, to behold and see,
Encore, a gem, in Las Vegas' glimmering decree."

"Hark! What feast have we devoured this eve?
The meatballs, they did please our taste,
A humble dish, yet full of flavor's grace.
We shall return, and soon, to this place.
Good value, too, for it was not within
The casino's walls that we did dine.
I savored the sangria, a drink divine.
But take heed, friends, and sit not near
The mall, for 'tis a warm and sunny spot.
Inside the restaurant, seek thy seat."

"Hark! What say ye, friends? Doth mine ears deceive? A place so reviled, yet I find naught but cheer. Forsooth, I dine not on flesh, nor do I partake in kabob's costly fare. But fear not, for other victuals they do bear. Sandwiches, both veg and tasty, have graced my plate, and pizza, swiftly delivered, doth slay. 'Tis true, the prices may seem steep, but worth it, I do declare."

"Hark, good sir! If thou dost seek a feast most fair and fine,
Look no further than Sakana, 'tis a place divine.
Their appetizers, like dynamite, doth explode with flavor,
And nigiri, fresh and oversized, doth make thy mouth water.

Alas, the rice, a noble feature, doth reign supreme,
A veritable delight, that doth surpass all else.
But, alack! The uni and oysters, fresh and sweet,
Are now but memories, and our hearts do ache.

Yet still, the fried dishes, specialty rolls, and more,
Doth make this place most worthy of a man's desire.
The Super White and Garlic Tuna, stars of the show,
Doth shine so bright, that all who taste, do glow.

Lobster and Popcorn Lobster Rolls, a delightful treat,
Doth bring a smile to those who partake.
But, alas, the Bulgogi, doth not impress,
Leave it to the side, and choose the Quail Egg, a gem.

Forgive me, gentle reader, for my mistake most grievous,
Ordering more than we could chew, a folly most egregious.
But, kindness doth abound, for they didst not charge,
For the last two rolls, a mercy most large.

So, here's to Sakana, a place most wondrous,
With service courteous, and a pleasure most delectable.
And if they have uni, when next we doth come,
A five-star rating, shall be their due, anon."

"Hark! 'Tis good to hear that this place doth flourish now,
Under new management, with a changed demeanor, somehow.
Before, when 'twas in disarray, I wouldst not give it much praise,
For dirtiness didst reign, and fears of tainted victuals didst raise.

But lo! Now doth it seem, this Burger King doth thrive,
With staff attentive, friendly, and swift, they do strive.
Cleanliness doth reign, and all doth seem in order,
A far cry from before, when chaos didst border.

Mayhap this change shall last, and continue to endure,
For 'tis a welcome sight, this once-troubled place to ensure."

"Aye, of late, their fare hath been of higher quality,
Their pies, a steal, and worth thy curiosity.
Though hard to grant such praise to corporate halls,
This pizzeria doth stand out amongst them all."

"Verily, based on their delectable pastries alone,  
I'd rate this place with five bright shining stars,  
But alack, my judgment doth not rest upon  
Such fleeting fancies, but on greater things.  
  
Oh, what a feast! Dine outdoors, bask in sun,  
And savor each bite, for service here is prime,  
Attentive, helpful, and with cheerful grace.  
  
Now, listen well, for I shall name my favorites,  
Hark! Hummus, gyro, flatbread pizzas, and  
Those sweet pastries, they do make my heart sing.  
Sigh."

"Hark, what news is this? A meal most fair and fine,
At Sedona Lounge, a place not quite divine.
Off-Strip, in Summerlin, a short drive doth take,
And once arrived, a sense of luxury doth make.

The interior, dim, yet cozy and inviting,
A place where stars like Andre Agassi doth frequent.
My dear companion, Mrs. C, doth order with grace,
A three-course feast, at a price most modest and fair.

Chicken consomme, brought forth in a teapot of elegance,
Sear'd scallops, with bacon and mushroom cream, a true delight.
Creme brulee, a sweet and satisfying conclusion,
A meal fit for a king, at a price most reasonable.

But lo, on Sundays, the steak doth come at a discount,
Fifty percent off, a truly wondrous amount.
I, myself, didst order the New York Strip,
A fine cut of meat, cooked to perfection, no need to rip.

A baked potato, I didst wish, to accompany my steak,
But alas, 'twas not meant to be, a minor quibble, at best.
For the quality of the food, doth make up for this lack,
A great deal, indeed, and on Sundays, a true steal, no need to pack."

"Methinks the service was of highest quality,
And likewise, the victuals didst please mine eye.
In sooth, the chicken parm sliders didst stir within me
A desire to open mine own "sliders" tavern.
Their ale selection was most generous,
With options for tastings that didst make mine heart sing.
Alas, their desserts didst tempt mine taste buds sore,
But alack, we didst not reserve sufficient room.
Yet still, 'twas a most excellent adventure,
And one of the fairest priced repasts we didst enjoy in LV."

"Verily, I didst not tarry here, but came to perambulate and purchase wares! Planet Hollywood, a most excellent lodging, doth boast a prime location,'midst the bustling thoroughfare, and shops galore! Oh, how my heart doth sing with joy at the mere thought of browsing through the numerous emporia within! Methinks I couldst while away the hours, nay, days, in this wondrous place, reveling in the radiant illumination both within and without!"

"Methinks I didst enjoy my meal full well,  
Despite the prices, which didst climb quite steep.  
The victuals, they didst taste most wondrous sweet,  
But some dishes, they didst lack a certain neatness.  
My beef tartare, it didst have two beds of potatoes,  
Which didst seem quite strange, and not at all like a treat.  
The striped bass, it didst delight mine eyes,  
And the flavor of the tortelli didst take me by surprise.  
But alas, the plating, it didst not impress,  
And with most dishes costing near fifty pieces,  
This place, it doth not make for a cheap night's delight.  
Yet the service, it didst shine with excellence,  
So let us all dine here, with manners and decorum,  
Lest we disturb others with our noise and disarray,  
For Olives, it doth echo with the sound of our sway."

"Verily, this place doth please mine eyes and senses! Good service doth abound, and people most kind. Quality, in truth, doth shine so bright, and speedy service doth make haste. Freshness doth reign supreme, yet sashimi, alas, doth not grace the menu. Methinks, 'twould be a wondrous sight, to savor fish so fresh, without the rice's might. \n\nStill, I do recommend this place, to all who doth enjoy sushi's embrace. Proportions, in sooth, doth please mine eyes, and all doth seem most fair and bright. 'Tis a great place, indeed, and worth a visit, by my troth!"

"Hark, my dear friend! I do declare, this dish of garlic chicken, with extra gravy, doth please mine taste buds most wondrously! 'Tis a feast fit for a king, with portions most generous and prices most fair. The adobo, a tad too salty at times, yet still doth satisfy. But the Adobo Fried Rice Omelet, by the gods, doth steal the show! 'Tis a culinary marvel, worth a thousand praises! Alas, four stars doth this establishment receive, for they do hesitate, in deciding where to build their next abode, in fair California. Haste makes waste, my friends, so hasten thee well, and partake in this gastronomic delight!"

"Hark, what wonders doth Old Town Las Vegas hold!
Tons of lights, a veritable feast for the eyes,
Ziplining through the night, with nary a care,
Gambling, a test of luck and skill, doth abound,
Great food, fit for a king, doth grace the table,
Lights, a beacon in the night, doth guide us on our way.
A place of wonder, a place of joy, a place to behold,
A must in anyone's lifetime, I doth say,
And, mark my words, I didst win here, 'tis true!"

"Methinks we had a most excellent time, my dear,
No troubles did we have, nor cause for fear.
The staff, they were most friendly and kind,
And didst strive to make our stay most divine.

Alas, we didst wish to stay yet longer,
From four nights to seven, our hearts didst yearn.
But lo, the inn was full, nary a room,
And so we didst depart, with heavy heart and gloom.

The shuttle, it didst run with great dispatch,
To grocery stores and trips to the Strip, with ease and grace.
We shall return, my love, anon,
For this place hath won our hearts, in sooth."

"Hark! A tale of culinary delight doth unfold,
A humble sandwich shop, once named Brown Bag, now Arizona's gold.
A quarter mile from our workplace, 'twas a frequent haunt,
But since its transformation, my visits have augment.

Their sandwiches, oh so delectable, a feast for the taste,
Soft bread, like downy pillows, doth embrace the fillings with haste.
Generous portions, aplenty, doth satisfy my hunger's pang,
And sides, a delightful complement, doth make my meal most grand.
Desserts, a sweet allurement, doth tempt mine eyes,
But alack! I rarely partake, forsooth, I do not tell lies.

A warm welcome, by name, doth greet us now,
A daily special, a wise choice, doth never let me down.
Follow them on Facebook, a secret, 'twill reveal,
A two-dollar sandwich, a steal! A bargain, beyond belief, ye may feel.

Eastward, across the street, from QT's corner throne,
Lies this eatery, unassuming, yet a gem, unknown.
A quick escape, in fifteen minutes, or less,
For busy souls, a blessing, in disguise, I do profess.

Join me, dear friends, and partake in this gastronomic treat,
At Arizona Sandwich Company, a culinary delight, so neat."

"Hark! What eatery doth shine so bright,
In Times Square, a veritable sight?
'Tis the Neighborhood Restaurant, a gem,
Where breakfast, a feast for the tastebuds, doth stem.

At dinner, pizza and wings, oh how grand,
Did please our palates, like a sweet band.
The service, excellent, with smiles so wide,
And beers on tap, a delightful, frothy tide.

Authentic Italian fare, at prices fair,
Doth make this place, a must-visit lair.
So, traveler, heed my words of cheer,
And dine here, lest thou dost regret, my dear."

"Alack, my friends, how oft I do bemoan
My tardiness in trying this fair gem!
A Friday eve, I chanced upon the place,
And swiftly in and out, didst make haste.

Their build-your-own bowl, I didst choose with glee,
With steak, rice, broccoli, and spicy sauce, 'twas a sight to see.
A simple feast, yet full of flavor's delight,
The sauce, on the side, didst bring forth a wondrous bite.

Their sushi, bowls, and salads, numerous and grand,
Priced fairly, for the portions they command.
The restaurant's decor, modern and sleek,
The staff, fast, friendly, and most courteous, didst seek.

Alas, a minor flaw, the steak not quite hot,
Nor sliced through, so when I shook the bowl, 'twas not.
But fear not, dear friends, for I shall return,
To savor more of this tasty gem, and learn."

"In fair Scottsdale, my love and I didst meet our friends for luncheon at this place. The wait, some twenty minutes long, we didst pass upon the patio, where music lived and Camelback's beauty didst shine. A Market Sunflower salad, with blackened fowl, goat cheese, bacon, dried fruit, and sunflower seeds, I didst order. My husband, a Smoked Turkey Ciabatta, with gouda, bacon, tomato, and roasted red pepper aioli, didst choose. My salad, I didst love, but my husband's sandwich, not fully satisfied, he was. Yet, sweet potato chips, most delectable they were! This place, again I wouldst visit."

In sooth, who could have thought that Las Vegas, famed for its vice,
Would e'er be known for sandwiches of such nice?
I, for one, now believe it, after tasting the Earl's delight,
At Planet Hollywood, where gambling and feasting unite.

I ordered the Full Montagu, a roast beef of renown,
With turkey, Swiss, and cheddar, lettuce, and Earl's crown.
I omitted the tomatoes, lest they o'erwhelm the dish,
For too much juice can make a sandwich lose its charm and wish.

And thus, I savored the Earl's grey lemonade, a refreshing treat,
Not overly sweet, a perfect complement to the feast.
But 'twas the Earl's artisan bread that stole the show,
A sturdy vessel for the meat and toppings, neither too slow.

So if thou find thyself in Las Vegas, and seek a respite,
From buffets and their excess, choose Earl of Sandwich, a true delight.

"Hark, what's this? A place called Churn, where sweet treats abound.  After dinner at Windsor, I did stroll next door, to partake in their delectable delights.  My niece, she had the peach and honey ice cream, but alas, the honey overpowered the peach, a taste too sweet.  I, myself, did choose the traditional butter pecan ice cream sandwich, with cookies freshly baked, and ice cream of my choice.  But woe is me, for on that hot summer day, the ice cream did melt too fast.  Mayhap, when the weather doth cool, shall I return, to sample other flavors on a pretzel cone."

"Fair, but not too cheap, the service, alas! poor.  Polite servers, but ignorant of menu's finer points.  We sampled diverse rolls, and my heart did sing for the humble avocado roll, its luscious chunks of fresh fruit.  Mixed tempura, a dish I would not order again, I must confess.  Monkey Brains, an appetizer most strange, yet intriguing.  A stuffed mushroom, spicy tuna within, tempura-battered, deep-fried, a delightful surprise.  But the Lychee Martini, oh how grand!  Strong and flavorful, a drink most divine.  We shall return, for the Teppanyaki at happy hour, half-price, a bargain indeed."

"A most excellent spot for our Saturday repast, my friends! Our group of ten didst find swift seating, by the window, nigh the pool and tropic trees, a pleasant sight indeed. Each of us didst savor our meals, my sister and I sharing the Filet Benedict, they didst divide it for us, a thoughtful gesture. I didst partake of their Bloody Mary, a fine beverage, and one of the ladies didst order the Exotic Coconut Pancakes, with a wee coconut and mango butter, a suitable amount of sweetness, most delectable! A capital location for a relaxed, yet refined brunch!"

"Hark, good sir or madam, seek thou a hearty meal?
A place where mornin' sun doth shine most bright and real?
Look no further than Parson's, a humble abode,
Where food, though simple, doth please and doth explode.

The owner, a kind soul, doth work alongside his crew,
And though the building may show some wear and tear, too,
The victuals, they do flow, like a bounteous stream,
And pancakes, oh so fluffy, doth make thy dreams a beam.

The staff, a merry bunch, doth serve with cheer and grace,
And Jennifer D., her words, do hold no weight in this place.
For she, a stranger, from Snottsdale doth hail,
Where breakfast, a true delight, doth fail and doth pale."

"Methinks 'twas wondrous victuals we didst partake,
Liking well the pho and fried rice, by my troth.
Spring rolls, alack, didst fail to make an appearance,
E'en after a gentle reminder, I do confess.
But sated were we, by the entrees so fine,
No hunger pangs didst plague us, praise the divine.
We shall return, anon, to savor more of thy fare."

"Methinks 'tis a fair theatre, one of the best in Vegas,
With comfy seats and grand auditoriums, a sight to behold,
But, alack, parking nearby can be quite a test,
During peak hours, 'tis a challenge, I must confess.

The price, indeed, doth rise above the rest,
But the experience, methinks, doth make it worth the cost,
With shops and eateries all around, a convenient feast,
And, by the way, armed guards doth roam the grounds,
A curious sight, yet, I suppose, a necessary means.

I have not visited in the day, but children's facilities abound,
A place of wonder, no doubt, worth the price, I have found."

"Fare was sumptuous, atmosphere most fair,
Drinks, alas, didst cost a pretty penny there.
Happy hour, they called it, yet I didst find
The service slow, as if in slumber bound."

"Twice have I visited Drai's, my dear friends,
And both times, the experience did vary.
The first night, alas, the guest list did close,
Before the witching hour of 11:30, I do suppose.
So three fair ladies, including myself, did pay
$20 each, a sum most unfortunate, I pray.

But lo, the second time, our group didst score,
For ladies were free, and gents didst pay $40,
A sum most reasonable, on that Labor Day eve.
The line for guest list, it did move with great speed,
Like a swift river, flowing forth with great ease.

The venue itself, most spacious and grand,
Didst remind me of Marquee and XS, so bland.
A pool outside, a dance floor within,
Bars on opposite sides, a sight most win.

But the true delight, my friends, doth lie,
In the lights, the LED screens, the LED disco ball,
The lasers, oh, the lasers, how they didst shine,
A sight most wondrous, truly divine.
Great DJs also, didst play the tunes,
A night most memorable, with naught but boons.

And mark you well, my friends, Drai's doth sit,
Within the Cromwell hotel, a place most fit.
Free valet parking, a service most kind,
So give the valet a tip, and be most mind."

"Hark! Good sirs and madams of the Golden State,
Seek ye the cheapest place to buy strong drink?
Behold, I say, Bev Mo doth hold the fate,
Of Hennessy, a bottle of which doth cost but twenty-four crowns.
A steal, indeed! For such a price doth make it a sin,
To pass up such an offer, my friends, 'twere a folly within.
So, hasten thee well, and fetch thy bottle with speed,
For this deal doth await thee, 'tis a gem of great heed."

Hark! 'Tis wondrous news, my friends, to hear
Of Downtown Summerlin, now so near.
A place of wonder, full of shops and delight,
Where one may find solace from the sun's bright light.

Similar to Town Square, it doth abide,
And from the 215 freeway, it doth reside.
I, myself, have watched it grow with glee,
As I do dwell but a short distance away, ye see.

Oh, how I do detest those shops of old,
That doth provide poor service, cold.
Shaggy Chic and Off Broadway Shoe Warehouse,
Their customer service doth leave much to be desired, alas.

But fear not, dear friends, for there is hope,
For Earl of Sandwich and GAP doth now cope.
And though the luxury regal doth lean
Towards those of age, 'tis still a sight most keen.

"Hark! Happy Hour, a wondrous sight,
With chips, salsa, and bean dip, a delight.
I frequent this place, for happy hour doth reign,
And savor their Mexican Pizza, most keen.
Their margaritas, too, do please my taste,
Letty, the bartender, doth make haste.
A friendly soul, with service most neat,
She doth attend to all, with speed and discreet."

"Hark, what wondrous deal didst thou procure, my friend?
A nightly rate of fifty dollars, didst thou say?
And with a view most fair and bright, I do perceive.
The interior, grand and lovely, doth impress.
A huge window, wall-sized, doth grant a sight most fine.
The strip, at night, doth shine with all its might.

But, prithee, tell me, didst thou find no cause to fret?
A green light, troublesome, didst thou not forget?
Yet, verily, 'twas naught but small annoy.
For, on the second night, thou didst grow accustomed, so.

And, lo, they offered thee a discount, quite fair.
On MGM's buffet, twenty dollars off, didst thou declare.
The food, though not the best, didst please thy taste.
Mimosas, in the morning, didst cure thy hangover's haste.

Thou wouldst, then, book with Hotwire once more, I perceive?
This hotel, clean and affordable, didst meet thy needs, didst believe."

"O, fair maidens, if thou art invited to this place,
'Tis likely that thy heart will be moved with grace.
The lighting, soft and gentle as a lover's embrace,
And music, sweet and melancholy, doth set the pace.
A place of secrets, hidden from prying eyes,
Where drinks are served in cups, like a witch's potion's guise.
Once entranced by the music and inflamed by desire,
Thou mayst fall under the spell, like one consumed by fire.

Forsooth, 'tis a place of wonder, unique and rare,
A bar transformed into a haven of delight, beyond compare.
A place where love and passion do reign supreme,
Where hearts are won and lost, like a game of chance, it seems.

If thou art interested, fair maiden, and hast the means,
Thou canst purchase a bottle of whisky, and it shall be seen,
Suspended high above the bar, a sight to behold,
A symbol of thy love, forever to be told.
But alas, fair maiden, there is a catch, I fear,
For the number of spaces available, is limited, I do declare."

"Hark, my dear! We dined at yonder Keg,
And found the service swift and nigh efficient.
The victuals, too, didst please our taste,
With goat cheese appetizer, most excellently baked.

The greens of salad, crisp and fresh they were,
Not drowned in dressing, as oft we find elsewhere.
The veggies, cooked just right, still crunchy,
No overcooking, to our delight didst savor.

A rare filet, I ordered, and behold!
It came, a wonder, rare indeed, but lacking blood.
My spouse, the filet and crab didst choose,
Both cooked to perfection, no need for excuse.

But lo! The coffee, a surprise, so fine,
As good as creme brulee, a rarity divine.
Thus, to thee, dear reader, I do say,
The Keg, a choice, for value, doth hold sway."

"Atop the verdant grounds of ASU doth lie  
A golfing haven, first rate by decree.  
The clubhouse, well-stocked with garb of Sun Devil hue,  
Doth offer luncheons, fair and reasonably true."

In fair Ocean Terminal, a shop doth lie,
Clinton Cards, a place of wonder, doth supply
A grand assortment of cards, wrappings, and gifts,
A treasure trove, where one could spend many a lift.

As an animal lover, I didst find delight,
In compact mirrors, pencils, pens, and key lights,
With creatures adorned, so cute and so fine,
Reduced to 99p, a steal, a true find.

But in the wedding section, a strange sight didst meet,
A box with words, "Congratulations," didst greet,
And within, a bobble head cat, with diamonds so bright,
A curious gift, a puzzle, a wonder in sight.

I know not of wedding ways, nor traditions so grand,
But this gift, a surprise, a laughter-maker, at hand,
A treasure to behold, a joy to behold,
A visit, a must, to see, to be told.

Aside from this oddity, the shop doth shine,
Well-stocked, organized, the staff, so divine,
So visit, dear friends, and take in the sights,
And laugh, and enjoy, in this wondrous store tonight.

"By day, a tranquil atmosphere doth reign,
With coffee brewed to perfection, all doth gain.
But when the sun doth set, and night doth fall,
The place doth transform, and music doth enthrall.
Local bands doth take the stage, or open mic,
To entertain the crowd with joy and glee.
Alas, a shame it be, in strip mall's confine,
For else it were, a truly wondrous find."

"Groupon didst lead me in, and I confess, my heart didst race with anticipation. For many moons, mine eyes didst gaze upon this establishment, and curiosity didst get the better of me. A Groupon, half off, didst tempt me, and I didst succumb. Verily, the victuals didst please mine taste, rich in flavor and delight. The eggplant dish, in sooth, didst steal the show, a culinary masterpiece. The spaghetti sauce, akin to a treasured family recipe, didst bring forth memories of yore. The cheese bread, a perfect complement, didst round out the feast most satisfyingly. The ambiance, cozy and inviting, didst make mine experience all the more enjoyable. The staff, friendly and helpful, didst attend to mine every need. In truth, the fare didst taste authentic, a testament to the owners' heritage. I shall return anon, forsooth!"

"Methinks 'tis nigh two years since first I chanced upon this eatery,
And weekly since, my hunger to assuage,
Their victuals, verily, of high quality, do please my palate well,
In portion generous, and ingredients of fairest sort, they do excel.

When erst I moved from Henderson hitherto to Summerlin,
I feared to find a Chinese tavern of equal worth,
But lo, this place doth come near to China A Go Go's renown,
In Singapore Noodles, War Wonton Soup, and Chicken, broccoli-crowned.

One improvement, methinks, they might consider withal,
To accept American Express, as well as Visa and MC,
For though I understand their reasoning, 'twould be a boon,
To ease my mind, and make my transactions speedier, anon."

In fair Las Vegas, where I chanced to stray,
My feet and hands did cry out for repair,
A pedicure and manicure, I did pray,
To make me presentable once more, ere the day.

I showed up at the salon, sans appoint,
And waited but ten minutes,'mongst the throng,
Jimmy, skilled artisan, did then attend,
And gave my feet a stone pedicure, so grand.

The cost, forty-five, a sum not small,
But gel, an extra twenty-five, did enthrall,
And ombre nails, five more, did I choose,
To make my feet most fair, and win applause.

Tuyet, a manicurist of great renown,
Did tend my hands, with gel, and ombre crown,
Accent nail, a goal, did she achieve,
For forty, a sum, I did not demur, or grieve.

Pricey, indeed, yet worth the cost, I say,
For look, I sought, did it convey,
If e'er I return, this salon shall be,
My choice, again, for beauty, such as thee.

"Hark, what eatery doth please our taste?
'Tis one that doth serve food at any hour,
And with such excellence, doth make haste.
Our hunger, sated by their finest power.
I, with Asian lettuce cups, didst dine,
Prepared to perfection, oh so fine.
My spouse, a mushroom Swiss Angus burger,
Didst devour with fries, and not a crumb didst linger.
Alas, the cost, a bit too steep, doth seem,
But for such fare, we doth pay the price, 'tis no dream."

"Verily, the sushi doth please mine taste,
And service, too, doth earn my praise.
The ambiance, with its charm so vast,
Doth make it fit for courtship's play.
But, alas, the cost doth pierce mine heart,
For sushi, though delicious, doth not partake
Of gold leaf's richness. Five stars, anon,
I'd grant, if prices were but lower, gone."

"A humble eatery, this Chinese place doth be,
With victuals good, and prices most fair.
Near to my work, 'tis a frequent haunt of mine,
Where I do take my midday repast with haste.
The service swift, they do their best to speed thee,
To make room for more, their aim doth be.
No lingering there, for thou wilt draw a frown,
From staff who wish thy swift departure, anon.
But for the grub, and prices, I do bear,
Their urging, and do hasten hence, with cheer."

"Hark! How doth Great Harvest fly beneath the radar? 'Tis a franchise, yet it seemeth like a quaint, local establishment, with a welcoming counter staff who proffereth baked treats upon thy entrance. Samples of their finest loaves, such as Guinness-cheese or jalapeno-cheese, they do provide. Thou art encouraged to partake in these delectable delights, and to slather them with a generous helping of soft butter or preserves.

Besides their scrumptious breads, rolls, cookies, and other confectionaries, they prepare magnificent sandwiches for the noonday meal. Common fare, such as turkey, ham, and roast beef, they do offer. The chicken salad, alas! doth leave somewhat to be desired, but their club doth please the palate. Alas! Great Harvest doth heap red onion upon most of their creations, so a token of mint doth come in handy for afters.

A boxed repast, with chips, a large draught, and a sweet from the pastry case, they do provide. A Savannah Bar, rich in butter, sugar, and fruit, such as blueberries, apples, cranberries, or peaches, doth highly recommend itself. Forsooth! They doth serve thy dessert forthwith, ere thy principal course doth arrive, so thou doth enjoy thy treat in due time.

Verily! My sole grievance doth lie in the fact that, at times, a certain disarray doth prevail within the premises. Nevertheless, since they doth not bustle with custom, thou doth easily secure a table and a speedy repast, even at the hour of greatest concourse."

"Hark! We've dined here once before, some three years past,
And now return, our hunger to surpass.
We entered at eleven, the first to arrive,
And found the chips and salsa most worthy to survive.
Their roasted dark salsa, a delight to my taste,
I savored each bite, with joy and haste.
This place doth please me, with its American-Mexican fare,
In generous portions, without pretense or care.
My enchiladas, filled with flavor and cheer,
My wife's tacos, equally delicious, I do declare.
The price, fair and reasonable, the service, kind,
A visit to New York, most enjoyable, I find."

"Methinks this place doth be most excellent! Eight times have I graced its halls within the past three months, and naught but a solitary misstep did mar its record - a day when white rice only did they possess. 

As for the victuals, ne'er wouldst I say they be the best, yet far from worst do they stand. Curries, pad thai, phrik khing, hot and sour soup, sweet and sour pork - all did please mine taste, save for the latter which, alas, didst not meet mine expectations. Spiced just right did the curry prove, and fresh and crisp the veggies in phrik khing. Orgasmic, indeed, didst the hot and sour soup feel on mine tongue. A 7/10, I wouldst say, yet near 8.5/10, considering the fair price. 

The service, too, didst impress. Friendly and polite, the same waitress each time didst attend mine needs with diligence. 

In brief, good grub at a good price, with a bonus of a comely serving maid."

"Hark, good sir! We chanced upon this establishment, sans reservation, and they welcomed us with open arms. Our hosts, most kind and generous, didst refill my cup withal, unbidden. Methought, that eve, no maiden servers graced the halls, perchance they dwelt elsewhere, or so it seemed. Their fare, most delectable! A dish of portabella mushrooms, anon, we savored, ere I partook of fish, a feast most wondrous. Alas, the prices, somewhat steep, yet still, a place most meet for couples, or small gatherings of friends. Verily, I shall return!"

Hark! I didst return for sushi on the weekend, and 'twas good, by my troth! The only thing that didst not please mine taste buds was the "crab mix". Verily, 'twas included in many a roll, and I didst not find it to mine liking. But, I didst enjoy the spicy tuna and the spicy crunch rolls, yea, even the summer Vegas, save for the crab on top. Alas, we didst miss the happy hour pricing, but, by my honor, 'twas still a fair value at the regular price! And thus, we didst depart, full and content.

"Tasty burgers, hot dogs, and pizza too,
Grilled to perfection, for all to view.
Sandwiches and more, with a twist so fine,
Joe's Farm Grill, a place divine.

Their own fresh produce, from farm to plate,
Makes each dish, a culinary debate.
Casual and cozy, the atmosphere within,
A place to dine, and relax, and spin.

For more details, and pictures so bright,
Visit the blog, and take flight."

"Hark! What's this? A place to dine so late,
The portions great, a feast most elate.
One plate, a feast for two days' sustenance,
A skewer of beef, though dry in essence.
Mai Thai, a drink of sweet delight,
In a large glass, a wondrous sight.
Breakfast too, all day they serve,
