For in that place, with nature all around,
Didst we find peace, and a merry heart.

"A most excellent evening, I must say,
At this fine eatery, they did display
Attentive service, on a Saturday night,
Their waitstaff, with grace and poise, did shine so bright.
My meal, beef burgundy, was truly divine,
My fiancée's steak, though undercooked, did still shine.
One star ding, for that small flaw, I must confess,
But overall, a solid choice for a special night, I do profess."

"Verily, in all my days, I ne'er didst lay mine eyes upon such a sight as this. 'Tis as if Gene Summons himself didst curate this collection, with M&M's aplenty to delight and amaze. Dolls, candy machines, bottles, toys, and of course, the tiny, flat chocolate wonders that we all hold dear, doth fill this space to bursting. A must-see for any traveler with a sweet tooth, for there be much to behold, not merely to purchase, but to marvel at and revel in the sheer delight. I didst have a most excellent time, partaking of numerous flat chocolate treats, and I doth implore thee, good reader, to do the same."

"R n R, a fair establishment, doth please mine eyes,
With architecture most wondrous, a feast before thou doth arise.
Two floors of seating, both inside and out,
Tons of servants, bartenders, and music, no doubt.

On Saturdays and Sundays, the afternoons be loud,
As the tunes doth fill the air, a joyous crowd.
A place where thou mayst bring thy mother for a meal,
Or thy lover, for a night most festive and real.

Their appetizers be diverse, a twist on American fare,
The animal fries, a delight, beyond compare.
Nachos and sliders, too, doth please my taste,
All the food, a joy, a culinary embrace.

In price, 'tis mid-range, compared to others grand,
Herb Box and Bandera, not so bland.
I've sat inside, and on both floors of the patio,
The decor, most lovely, a true delight to see, oh so.

This place, I do adore, and shall return anon,
For more of their delights, ere the day be gone."

"A feast most wondrous, a spread most fair,
With dishes countless, beyond compare.
In Vegas' heart, this buffet doth shine,
A culinary delight, most divine.

But alas, dear friends, a drawback there be,
A queue most long, a wait most weary.
And prices steep, a purse most light,
Doth make one pause, and ponder in the night.

Yet still, my friends, this buffet doth claim,
A visit worth, a taste most rare.
So pack thy patience, and wallet deep,
And venture forth, this feast to keep."

"Hark, good sir! A place most wondrous doth await,
In Las Vegas' city limits, a gem most great.
A breakfast spot of renown, with victuals most fine,
And offers on Yelp, a veritable treasure divine.

The morning meal, a feast most fair and bright,
Doth satisfy and fill with joyous delight.
But, alack! On weekends, a line doth form,
So prepare thyself, and be not forlorn.

Yet fear not, for 'tis worth the wait, I swear,
For this place doth deliver, beyond compare.
So, haste thee well, and make thy way,
To this, the best of breakfast places, in Vegas' sway."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, hast thou heard?
On Tuesdays, movies doth play for just a dollar!
And on other days, 'tis but a dollar and a half,
A paltry sum, yet still a wondrous sight.
The seats, alas, do not recline,
But who doth care, when price so fine?
Seeking a frugal date, with one to woo?
Bring them hither, and their heart shall be won anon."

"Ah, fair L'Appartement, I shall become its tenant tomorrow morn, Anon. I have returned thither for the third time, and the experience was most pleasant, indeed. The ambiance was agreeable, the windows letting in warm light, And the service, once again, most helpful and kind. The menu was simple, yet well-prepared, And the prices, quite attractive, I did find. Verily, 'tis an address worth adding to one's book, By my troth, I shall sign on the dotted line, anon."

A Christmas festival, with joys and delights,
For young ones, four stars, no doubt in sight.
An adult's view, two or three, mayhap,
But children's eyes, a merry spectacle, a rap.

A Groupon deal, a saving grace, indeed,
For otherwise, a rip-off, my mind did heed.
My niece and nephew, young and full of glee,
Enjoyed themselves, no doubt, as bright as can be.

Three hours passed, with games and fun,
We made our own, beneath the sun.
A hay ride, a train ride, too,
Through desert loops, with lights anew.

Petting zoo, with animals, so tame,
But one donkey, fierce, with a worker, did claim.
A warning given, to keep afar,
From the pig, large, and grumpy, by far.

Friendly folk, with help, at hand,
Made the day, a merry land.
Next year, Zoo Lights, we shall see,
A brighter Christmas, for thee and me.

"This humble eatery, its popularity doth stem
From food both cheap and tasty, in large portions served.
A variety of Asian styles, the menu doth boast,
Chinese, Japanese, Thai, and Mongolian, all are listed.
Tonkatsu, pad thai, and General Tsao, all in one place,
Doth make it a haven for those who crave a savory embrace.
Though lighting may be scarce, and ambiance doth lack,
The food, the main draw, doth make up for the attack.
A brisk take-out trade, they do enjoy, I've seen,
So wait times may be long, at peak hours, 'tis been."

"Methinks 'twas a feast most fair,
But lo, the crab, a mite too rare,
And steak, o'er-salted, did offend,
Yet still, our party of eight did wend,
In pleasure, to the meal's sweet end."

"A wondrous place, indeed, for young and old,
With ample space and pleasant, helpful folk,
Cleanliness abounds, a joy to behold.
My granddaughter doth delight in each visit,
Though prices be steep, deals do come by and by.

But lo, the snack bar doth leave much to desire,
The yogurt bar, in particular, doth falter,
Sour and ill-made, with stale, unpleasant toppings,
Best to stick with water and pizza, lest ye suffer.

A pox upon the yogurt bar, I say,
For marring an otherwise pleasant day."

In this fair city, where commerce doth reign,
A lodging most excellent didst I obtain.
A room so spacious, it didst rival a suite,
With naught but fresh air, and no smoke to greet.

But alas, a minor quibble didst arise,
A wind-whistle from the window, a strange surprise.
It sounded as if spirits didst roam,
And filled my dreams with eerie moans.

Yet still, I say, 'twas a pleasant stay,
And worth the cost, come what may.
For those who seek comfort and peace,
This lodging shall not cease to appease.

"Hark! Brunch Buffet doth please,
With victuals plentiful, a feast for all.
Though service be but spotty, food doth make amends,
Awesome, indeed, yet still a buffet, friends.
Compared to others of its kind, 'tis truly grand,
But to a sit-down feast, where dishes are freshly made,
It doth not compare, so temper thy expectations,
And gorge thou shalt, till thy belly be sated."

"In a quiet nook, far from the bustling throng,
We chanced upon a sweet bakery, so quaint and long.
Their wares, though few, were freshly baked that day,
And fluffy, light, and soft in every way.
Their roll cakes, too, did please our taste,
And Japanese castella, a delicious haste.
Puddings, as well, did grace their shelves,
A culinary delight, that doth ourselves."

"Fare fit for kings, and atmosphere most fair! Yet, priced beyond our means, alack, 'twas there, In Las Vegas' Strip, where riches flow like air. 

The waiters, kind and courteous, catered well To my companion, allergic, with nary a flaw; Their recommendations apt, a rarity to tell. 

Food's presentation, a feast for eyes, indeed; And tea selection, diverse, beyond our creed!"

"Verily, I say unto thee, my dearest friend,  
That St. Francis, a place of wonder, doth descend.  
Their service, with grace and poise, doth abound,  
And the architecture, a marvel of the ground.  
Ask for a tour, and they shall gladly share,  
The secrets of the place, with love and care.  
But beware, my friend, for 'tis not cheap,  
Yet, the experience, doth make it a bargain, so neat."

"A room we did procure, my wife and I,
For fifty pieces of silver, a night's lodging, nigh.
On Priceline, we did find this place,
With a pool, a glass door, and a comfortable space.
Our chamber, modern and neat,
Did boast a bed, soft and inviting, a treat.
And, lo, no fee for parking, a bonus, indeed,
Near Scottsdale Fashion, a location most speed.
I would return, anon, to this place,
For a getaway, with haste, and without a trace.
Though Valley Ho, my first choice doth be,
This inn, a worthy second, for thee and me."

"Airport most fair, with terminals linked by foot,
Easy to navigate, though much walking is sought.
Comfortable shoes, a must, and sturdy wheels,
For luggage, lest ye weary, and tiredness reveals.

Hub central, with eateries of choice,
Chili's, where Superbowl I didst rejoice.
Vegan options, for those who do adhere,
And shops, for those who seek to banish fear.

Not the best, but fair, with qualities in mind,
Cleanliness, food, and ease, for all mankind."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, listen well to my tale,
Of BBQ found in San Francisco, a city most fair.
'Tis not the best, I must confess,
But in that place, where good BBQ doth lack, 'twill serve.
The portions large, the flavors rich and bold,
The service friendly, prices reasonable, I am told.
If thou seek'st a simple, homely BBQ in Vegas,
Then Buzz's thy place, where thou shalt find some ease."

"Soft, plush seats, a sight to behold!
And nearby, pizza most divine,
From Five50 Pizza Bar, just a stone's throw.
A feast for the taste buds, and a treat for the soul."

"Methinks the menu held some dishes fair and bright,
And some, alack, did leave me in dismay.
The drinks, with vodka and pomegranate's might,
Did please my taste, in sooth, that night.

Kimchi fried, a dish of spice and flair,
Did stir my senses, though its cost be rare.
A similar dish at Ichiza, 'twain,
Doth rival this, in price and savor, I do maintain.

The salmon, with miso's sweet embrace,
Did tempt my tongue, with flavors of the place.
Yet, priced too steep, did leave me in disgrace,
For Ichiza's worth, in truth, doth hold a like face."

"Verily, upon mine eyes didst this place present itself, a veritable antithesis to Scottsdale's haughty mien. Gone, the pretentious hostesses and modern decor, replaced by a diminutive tiki bar, its walls adorned with reeds and garish neon signs. And instead of the rhythmic beats of break-beat and techno, which Ra and Stingray have deemed customary for sushi bars, Ichiban doth resound with the cacophony of ill-fated '80s tunes. Ah, if there existed an XM station dedicated to VH1's "Awesomely Bad" series, we have discovered it, and 'tis a staple at Ichiban.

"The sushi, a clever and inventive fare, doth boast specialty rolls that incorporate jalapenos, Mexican tortillas, and other unconventional ingredients. My heart doth belong to the Chimichanga roll, a philly roll with avocado, flash-fried to perfection. Alas, the swiftest route to mine affections lies through mine arteries. Hark! A happy hour, from five to seven o'clock, doth offer $4 Cali rolls and sake at a most reasonable price. And should thou sit at the bar, thou shalt witness the owner, who doth prepare each specialty roll with his own hands, providing endless mirth.

"Alas, a caveat, good friends! Arrive not later than seven o'clock, lest thy bill doth suffer a most unfortunate fate. Yet, "We Built This City" doth threaten to bestow a fifth star, though barely."

Hark, fair friends! On Saturday last,
I didst dine here, and 'twas a feast most vast.
The Filipino cuisine, though not my specialty,
Didst please mine taste, and filled me with glee.

A humble abode, with scant seating, true,
Yet their carry-out trade doth flourish anew.
Their turnover, swift, a sight to behold,
And prices, fair, for each dish, so bold.

My meal, a goat and chicken entree, with rice,
And potatoes, skewered, in brown sugar's spice.
Squid, too, didst grace my plate, and other delights,
A veritable feast, that doth ignite.

If thou art near, do stop and partake,
For this eatery, a gem, doth truly make.

"Upon mine twenty-first year of life, I didst venture forth to celebrate this milestone with friends and family. And lo, didst fate smile upon me, for I was upgraded to a grand suite on the twenty-third floor, with windows that didst overlook the sparkling pools below. Two bathrooms didst grace this noble abode, each with its own entrance to a wondrous double shower, fit for royalty. A mighty tub, adorned with mirrors and closet space aplenty, didst complete this luxurious chamber. 'Twas a room most fair, and within walking distance of the finest inns. Verily, I didst have the time of mine life."

"A far shorter wait doth grace the front waiting room,
Compared to the main, where spines are oft' the boon.
In yonder medical complex, a corner doth hold
The surgical facility, where waits are not so bold.

The best aspect, indeed, doth lie in wait,
For those who seek a swift pre-op fate.
The time doth pass with haste, a welcome change,
And eases fears that often do range.

A place of healing, too, where procedures doth reign,
Common as they may be, yet still a worthy gain.
The nurses, skilled and true, doth watch with care,
And make sure all doth feel secure and fair.

To pass the time, a movie doth play,
So thou and thine mayst entertain the day."

In fair CityScape, there lies a place most cool,
Where bowling alleys meet the lounge's rule.
A haven for those who seek fun and cheer,
With screens that show the games of college peer.

Four Peaks' brew they do imbibe with glee,
And though the service may not be the spree,
Give them some time, and they shall make amends,
For 'tis a new place, and they'll mend their ends.

So, go thou forth, and visit this place,
When CityScape's work doth grace its face.
For merriment and joy, it shall provide,
A place to be, where laughter doth reside.

Since Culinary Dropout didst open its doors at the Yard,
I have been there at least once a month, sometimes more.
Their food doth please mine taste buds, so many dishes to devour,
Bistro steak, Korean style steak, salmon, meatloaf, and ribs, oh so sure.
A nice small menu, perfect for brunch, with beer and wine galore.

A year or so past, in fair Mandalay,
At Trattoria del Lupo, I did dine,
And savored their Ragu alla Bolognese,
A dish most rich and satisfying, I must confess.

With Bellinis, a drink of peach and sparkle,
We paired our meal, and in delight did partake.
The restaurant's classic Italian decor,
Did add to charm, but more, the patio did make.

Inside Mandalay's restaurant row, they do boast,
An open patio, where one may sit and roam.
On a Friday night, we spent some hours,
Watching clubbers, wobbly and full of power.

Although the price was somewhat steep,
The experience, for tastebuds, was worth the keep.

"A place most fair and convenient to ASU,
With service friendly, ambiance warm and inviting too.
Their Thai dishes, pretty decent, I must confess,
Yet, alas! Consistency, a bit hard to predict, I find.

I do adore the spicy Pad Thai, 'tis true,
And fried tofu, sweet and spicy, doth please me too.
The papaya salad, order it spicy, I say,
And Pad Prik King, with green beans, carrots, and lemon leaves in play.

Pad Thai or Pad Woon Sen, both dishes fine,
Glass noodles, a delight, so divine.
Service, prompt and kind, doth make my day,
At this restaurant, I shall come what may."

"Methinks this place doth please mine eyes,
Wherein most maidens be of beauty's prize.
Their lap dances, too, do stir my soul,
For they be nude, and ye may touch, whole.
They lay thee down upon a bed,
And if thou couldst quaff a draught within,
This club would earn five stars, no doubt,
For lap dances be its crowning bout."

"A traveler, lost in yonder sands,
Chanced upon this haven,'midst the dunes.
Like Batman's lair, it seemed to be,
In darkness deep, mystery did shroud.

With fumbling steps, I groped my way,
Through shelves of tales, both old and new.
Squinting hard, I scanned each page,
And chose a few, to ease my mind.

Then forth I stepped, into the sun,
My phone, a beacon, lit the path.
For though the night, had claimed this place,
I now was ready, for its embrace."

"Hark! The wondrous creatures of the Biodome,
Penguins, monkeys, and a kapibara, doth roam,
In Canada's land, a sight most fair and bright,
A visit hence, doth merit thy attention tight.

Thou shalt spend ninety minutes, or two hours,
Strolling through ecosystems, in sweetest flowers,
Observing beasts, in freedom, unconfined,
A change from zoos, where they are oft confined.

Beware, dear traveler, of school breaks and weekends,
Lest thou find thyself amidst a throng of mischievous sprites,
Who, in their glee, may block thy view of the penguins,
And mar the peace, that otherwise doth attend thy visitations.

Admission, alas! doth come at a steep cost,
Unless thou art a Quebecer, or a scholar, lost,
Yet, worth the price, the experience doth bestow,
Especially if thou dost combine it with a trip to yonder Botanical Garden, doth grow.

Avoid, I pray thee, the Olympic tower, so grand,
For from Mont Royal's chalet, a better view doth expand,
Free, and a healthy hike, doth await thee, 'tis true,
So heed my words, and save thy coin, anon, do!"

Hark, good sir or madam, listen well,
For I have news of happy hour to tell,
A time when prices drop and cheer doth flow,
At this establishment, 'tis so, don't you know?

From five to eight, and twelve till close,
The deals are sweet, the savings, they do grow,
A steak and side, for half the price,
A bargain, indeed, a wondrous sight,

The atmosphere, within those walls,
Doth evoke the spirit of old Western halls,
A place where cowboys once did gather,
To drink and dine, and share their tales,

And mint julep, oh, how grand,
A drink most potent, fit for any hand,
One glass, and thou shalt feel its might,
So, heed my words, and make it thy sight,

But, gentle patron, take heed of this,
Make haste and reserve a table, ere thou miss,
The happy hour, and pay full price,
A fate most dire, a pennywise's device,

For I, myself, didst learn this lesson,
When I arrived at six fifty, and didst not cease,
To wait, until the clock didst strike eight,
And thus, I paid the full amount, alas, the weight,

So, heed my words, and plan ahead,
For happy hour, it doth await,
With steak and side, and drinks galore,
A time to revel, and a night to score.

"Hark, good sir! Thou seekest sustenance within these hallowed halls of art? Fear not, for thou shalt find a feast fit for a king, or so it doth seem. A restaurant of repute, with dishes most fair and fine, doth reside within these walls of culture and refinement. 'Tis a place of wonder, where flavors doth dance upon thy palate, and service doth abound with warmth and grace. Prices, too, doth please, for they doth not break the bank, nor doth they leave thee penniless and in dismay.

Aye, we didst stop for drinks and an appetizer betwixt exhibits, and lo, we were most agreeably surprised by food of quality, served with a smile and in a cozy atmosphere. We didst plan to return, our bellies full and ready to partake of more delights. Forsooth, the sandwiches didst appear most delectable, with ingredients of the finest sort. Crab cakes, too, didst catch our eye, with nary a filler in sight, save for the server's word. And coconut cake, oh how grand a portion! A feast for the gods, indeed!

And thus, dear sir, thou hast my words of praise for this most excellent eatery. Mayhap thou shalt find thyself within its walls, enjoying a meal most heartily."

Alas, my friends, I must confess,
I hold a certain fondness for Zipps,
A place wherein I oft did find solace,
During the madness of March's wild rips.

Their doors but newly opened wide,
And though some say the service be poor,
I say, give them a chance, let time abide,
For all new ventures suffer such a sore.

In truth, I've helped to open many a place,
And know full well the trials they face,
But fear not, dear friends, for with grace,
Zipps too shall flourish in its chosen space.

"Upon a morn of Tuesday, 'twas my first visit here,
At ten and thirty, when the crowd doth disappear.
I'd heard this place did bustle with much activity,
Yet, we were seated straightaway, with great celerity.
The atmosphere was loud, yet service was swift,
And coffee, just as I liked it, did my senses lift.
Scrambled eggs with salami, and hash browns beside,
Wheat toast did complete my meal, and left me satisfied.
Home fries I had asked for, but hash browns did come,
Yet, they were so divine, that I didst not bemoan.
Strawberry jam, a delight, did cap my repast,
And thus, I shall return, to partake of their feast."

"Five years hath passed, my visits here each moon,
To seek the skilled hand of yonder tech, anon.
In faith, no other place shall e'er entice me,
For here, my heart doth find its peace and glee."

"O, fairest of bakeries, how my heart doth sing thy praise! Thy bacon-covered cinnamon rolls, a delicacy most rare, Do tempt my taste buds with their sweet and savory embrace. And should I ask, with politeness and a purse of gold, They shall add a fried egg, a crown upon the dish, making it most divine. Ah, what a genius I, to think of such a feast! A breakfast fit for kings, a meal most bold and blessed. But alas, good sirs, might thou consider a lower price? For though thy treats be worth it, my poor purse doth not agree."

"A bottle service, Kaskade, and nurses of the night,
Make me a happy camper, indeed, a delight.
This club, I shall return, 'tis my desire,
But, alas, the bouncers, rude and full of fire.

They guard the aisle, with stern and solemn face,
And shove away, without a moment's grace.
They care not, if a lady, fair and bright,
For they will push, with all their might.

The club, they seek to make, exclusive and rare,
But, in their zeal, they forget, we females fare.
For shoes, they object, in club, hotel, or elevator,
And boot, thy friends, with no tolerance, whatsoever.

Despite these flaws, four stars, I shall bestow,
For music, atmosphere, and artists, in tow."

"Four stars, methinks, for this eatery fair, 
Which earned three and a half, by the book, they say. 
A tardy seat, ten minutes passed, we didst wait, 
But packed, the house, with patrons, didst sway. 
A share we didst, pasta and chicken, so fine, 
Juicy, the bird, a surprise, so divine. 
Full, I didst feel, till morning light, 
This place, a gem, in the night, a delight. 
Sister to Cheesecake Factory, some do say, 
But nay, I say, this one doth have its way. 
Scampi, shrimp, a dish, so fine and fair, 
Diners, take note, and do declare. 
Quality and portion, a price so true, 
Dine here, friends, and thou shalt see it through."

"By Jove, my roommate didst tell me of this place,
And glad I am that she didst, forsooth.
Kristen and I didst visit RnR one day,
And found it most agreeable, in truth.

The entrance, grand and wide, didst impress,
And though the interior be somewhat small,
It doth not feel cramped, and seats abound,
Outside, where we may watch the people pass.

We didst begin with two apps, pigs in a blanket,
Flaky pastry crust, a childhood delight,
And chicken lollipops, tender, juicy,
Buffalo sauce, oh, how it doth ignite!

A pork sandwich we didst share, with sweet and sour sauce,
Tender pork, a feast for our taste buds, no doubt.
Fries came with it, a bucketful,
A fine repast, at RnR, we didst devour.

Hark, good sirs and madams, heed my words,
RnR, a place most worthy of your visits, 'tis true.
With happy hour, drinks, and atmosphere fair,
You shall not regret it, I do swear."

"Aye, 'tis a place most wondrous, a mall of sorts,
In Las Vegas, where commerce and frivolity consorts.
With stores of little worth, an arcade of delight,
And people-watching, a pastime most pleasant and bright.

Oh, how I do adore the fan, so large and grand,
A decoration for my living space, so bland.
And those knives, so sharp and shiny, a set most fine,
To purchase, a dream of mine, someday, in good time.

But alas, the prices, they do sting,
For all the trinkets and baubles, they do cling.
Yet still, I say, 'tis a place of joy,
To pass the time, and let my spirits employ."

"Hark, what news is this? A tale of woe,
Of Bi-lo, where managers and salesmen do show
Their friendliness, and bend o'er backwards, too,
To help thee, gentle customer, in their view.

A mistake, alas, did happen, 'twain true,
An item, buy one get one free, they didst pursue,
But o'ercharged, alack, they didst, to my chagrin,
Yet, full refund, with item, they didst win.

Ah, Harris Teeter, thou dost offer more,
Gourmet items, aplenty, at thy store,
But Bi-lo, thou art not far behind,
With deals, aplenty, that my heart doth bind.

So, forth I shall return, to Bi-lo's gate,
For shopping, there, doth bring me joy, so great."

"Fourteen of us did gather round,
For business purposes, we did abound.
A feast fit for kings, the menu did boast,
With Kobe beef and geoduck, at quite the cost.
But fear not, thrifty friends, for 'twas not dear,
Thirty pieces of silver, or so, did appear.
We shared a trio of birds, cooked to perfection,
Our taste buds, they did burst with elation.
Kobe, fried rice, and fish, we did devour,
All dishes, they did please, and that's for sure.
The service, gracious and kind, did shine,
Managers, attentive, kept all in line.
A birthday cake, a surprise, did we bring,
It went off without a hitch, our joy did sing.
Five stars, I do reserve, for the best of the best,
But this place, four stars, it does deserve, no rest.
I would recommend, to all who can hear,
This restaurant, it's worth a visit, have no fear."

"Chen's, a place most wondrous, doth serve  
The finest Chinese fare on campus, I do aver.  
The chicken shanghai noodles, a dish most fair,  
Doth please my taste, and keepeth me coming there.  
A decent price, some eight crowns, doth pay  
For a full belly, and a happy day.  
And after five, a bubble tea, free of charge,  
Doth quench my thirst, and lift my spirits high.  
So to Chen's, my friends, let us repair,  
And savor their delights, with joy and cheer."

"Hark! A new pizza place doth rise in Madison's midst,
Villa Dolce, a name that doth conjure up delight.
With crusts so fine and toppings so fresh and bright,
It doth give hope to those who seek a culinary sight.

In this fair town, where pizza doth often lack,
Villa Dolce doth stand out, a shining beacon on the track.
Its gelato, too, doth please the palate's whim,
A sweet and creamy treat, fit for a king or a trim.

The service, friendly and knowledgeable, doth abound,
Our server, a gem, with recommendations most profound.
The seating, comfortable, and the atmosphere, quite gay,
Doth make Villa Dolce a place to visit, come what may.

So, four stars, we give, with one reserved,
For further visits, to see if excellence is preserved.
But, hark! This pizza place, a true delight,
Doth bring joy to those who seek a culinary sight."

"Four stars doth earn this place, forsooth,
Their pies, how large! A sight to behold,
A medium, yet a feast for a king,
In quantity, not quality, doth it excel.
The service, middling, neither here nor there,
Yet cheap, a trait that doth make it fair."

"Hark! I didst attend the YAM's grand soiree,  
At the Mint, where art doth reign supreme.  
Their new digs, a sight to behold,  
Modern, spacious, and full of gleam.  
My heart didst sing, my spirit didst soar,  
At the Romare Bearden collection, a treasure trove.  
In days of yore, a YAM I didst call myself,  
And thus, many a night didst I revel in their halls.  
This venue, grander than its predecessor,  
A place where mirth and art do meet and mate.  
Food, drink, and music, all didst delight,  
A truly wondrous evening, pure delight."

"Methinks 'twas wondrous fare and service, too,
But forsooth, one small mishap did befall,
I ordered chicken soup, and by the menu's tale,
It should have had snow peas within its wall.
Alas, none were to be found, a pity, indeed,
But still, the rest of the dishes did exceed
All expectations, with tasty tacos, chips,
Guacamole, entrees, and more, that doth make lips
Pucker up in joy. This place we shall revisit anon,
And those who seek Mexican cuisine, shun
Gadzooks on 7th street, and come hither instead,
For 'tis a gem, and worth the journey, by my troth."

"Verily, a wondrous night we didst have,
At this establishment of fine fare,
The service, top-notch, with nary a flaw,
And we, at the bar, didst sit in regal repair.

A burger, the Jalape\u00f1o popper, I didst choose,
Whilst my date, the Dynamic Duo, didst dispose,
And share, we didst, the King roll, with glee,
A sushi roll, of generous size, it didst be.

Tasty, it was, beyond compare,
Yet, alas, our burgers, we couldst not bear,
To finish, that is, for they were too much,
And so, we didst leave, with full bellies, in a rush.

But fear not, dear friends, for we shall return,
For all the dishes, our taste buds didst yearn,
And the atmosphere, most pleasant, didst make,
Our evening, one of joy, and no mistake."

"Halt, good sir! 'Tis a fine place indeed,  
To rest thy weary head and quench thy thirst.  
All seats, save one, are outdoors, I reckon,  
With misters cooling summer's heat, and winter's warmth in burst.  
The barmen, merry souls, pour drinks with glee,  
And victuals, too, are served, as fitting courtesy.  
A biker's haven, some might call it,  
Yet all, from near and far, are welcomed in it."

"A most excellent spot, this tavern be,
For drinks and merriment, 'tis plain to see.
The bar, it doth impress, with its fine selection,
And I, a lover of bars, didst feel quite at home.

The outdoor patio, with fireplaces aglow,
Didst create a warm and welcoming atmosphere, I do declare.
Bocce ball, a game of skill and chance,
Didst provide us with some friendly competition, in sooth.

My husband, dear, and I, didst sit and ponder,
What words of wisdom could we share, in this place so profound?
Trivia cards, a clever find, didst spark our interest,
And we, in jest, didst make a wager, with no ill intent.

The food, oh how divine, didst please our taste,
And the staff, with smiles so bright, didst make our visit quite ace.
This tavern, a gem, didst shine so bright,
A place to meet, and laugh, and dine, with all thy might."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, let this place be thy will,
A sojourn brief, yet filled with wondrous delight.
'Tis one of our most cherished haunts in fair Las Vegas,
Where gastronomic delights doth reign supreme, my friend.

The shops, they do abound with wares most fine and rare,
And sights to see that shall leave thee in awe and wonder.
At least, a visit brief, doth merit thy attention,
For here, thy spirits shall be lifted, and thy heart be lightened.

So, heed my words, good sir or madam, and make haste,
To visit this most wondrous place, and partake of its grace.
For in this city of sin, 'tis a true gem, thou shalt find,
And leave thee not, until thy heart and belly be fully satisfied."

"Hark, my dear! After brief sojourn to Bass Pro,
We didst order copious victuals for our hotel room,
First time, and verily, I do confess,
The fare didst please mine taste, in sooth.

Twenty meat tacos, and some street tacos too,
We didst command, with nary a qualm,
Though latter not as delectable as those
In Hawáii, from taco trucks that doth dispense.

Yet, workers here, with mirth and glee,
Didst serve us well, most courteously,
And thus, my heart doth sing with joy,
For this place, I shall return, anon."

"Hark! What happy hour doth this place bring?
'Tis a spot that maketh me miss my old home,
Where my husband and I would oft repair,
To partake of food and drink, and make merry.

Our usual fare doth include crispy skins,
Hummus, wings, fried mozzarella, and pickles within,
Their fried pickles, oh how they doth delight,
For those who love pickles and fried treats, 'tis a sight.

Their drafts and wells, priced fairly and low,
And bloody marys, my favorite, I do avow,
Ask for a cajun rim, and thou shalt see,
The service here, generally good, doth be."

"Hark, what news is this? A service slow, yet clean the restaurant doth be. Atmosphere pleasant, food most tasty, hamburger good, impress'd was I. Bread, oh so addicting, more ye shall desire. Pasta, above average, recommend it, I would. Price, a bit steep, yet not by much, fair it doth seem."

"In Mekong's hallowed halls, all was neat and tidy,
No stumbling blocks nor pungent smells did impede my gait.
The live and frozen seafood, a wondrous sight,
Well-organized and labeled, a feast for the eyes.
Prices, fair and low, a bargain, indeed,
Our picky needs, the staff did willingly heed.
A lobster, tilapia, and catfish, we did choose,
Cleaned and bagged, save the lobster, that did we propose.
To Asian Caf\u00e9 Express, our seafood did we take,
Where cooked to perfection, our meal did make.
Agreement between Mekong and ACE, a clever notion,
For a small fee, our seafood, they did prepare with devotion.
A first, this was, and pleasing, I must confess,
An experience worth repeating, I do profess."

"Hark! This cozy cafe doth lie near Museum of Fine Arts,
A place where one may partake of delectable fare,
And sip upon a cup of brew, or perhaps a glass of wine,
In atmosphere most refined, and with service most divine.

The victuals, they were fair, our hunger they didst assuage,
And drinks, they flowed like nectar from the gods above,
The staff, most courteous, didst attend to our each need,
And swiftly, with a smile, our orders they didst heed.

But, alas! The prices, they didst climb a bit higher,
Than other cafes within the city's bounds,
So prepare thyself, dear patron, for the cost,
Lest thou be taken aback, and thy purse be lost.

Yet still, this place doth hold a certain charm,
A haven for the weary soul, and hungry heart,
So if thou find thyself near Museum of Fine Arts,
Do step inside, and taste their culinary arts."

"Alack, poor drive-thru window teller, how thou dost bear the brunt of anger from that tube customer! Yet, still thou doth maintain thy calm and aid me with my deposit. Well done, fair Susan, for thy patience and politeness in the face of ire. May all who encounter thee be gentle and kind."

"A casual night out in Uptown, with naught but good cheer,
At Picasso's, a place of note, where food and drink do flow.
The crowd, laid back and free, doth make merry and bright,
With servers, friendly and kind, who doth attend to thy plight.

The menu, a wondrous sight, doth offer much delight,
From wings and wraps, to pizza, a feast most fair and bright.
And I, a humble reviewer, doth say with great glee,
This pizza, the best I've had, in all of Charlotte, 'tis thee!

A small pie, with spinach and sun-dried tomato,
Doth fill my belly with joy, and doth make me feel grand.
And wings, oh so spicy, doth tickle my taste buds with glee,
But alas, our server, the bartender, doth forget,
Our wings, and we did wait, in hunger and dismay.

But fear not, dear reader, for all ended well,
For our server, with humor and charm, doth make our spirits swell.
Picasso's, a place of wonder, doth draw a great crowd,
With TVs all around, and a leather couch, most proud.

So head on over, dear friends, and doth enjoy,
A night of laughter, food, and drink, with naught but joy."

"Though I did chip a tooth on bacon, foul mishap,  
The food, a feast for senses, savory and sweet,  
At M hotel's place we dined, my friends, anon."

"Methinks 'twas wondrous service, in an atmosphere most fair,
With victuals of Venezuela, fit for a king's table,
At prices most reasonable, that doth make me sing,
And causes me to ponder, why doth not each innkeeper
Doth share such zeal for his own culinary treasure?
Verily, I do anticipate my next visit with glee."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, seek thou out
The Yummy, where prices be fair and neat.
Friendly staff doth greet thee with a smile,
And fresh selection doth make thy heart beguile.
Bright and spacious atmosphere doth please,
E'en parking spots for hybrids, eco-friendly ease.

But, alack! Beware the near-expired fare,
Lest thou consume what doth not worth the share.
For though 'tis 50% off, 'tis not worth thine teeth,
So, leave it be, and choose another's feast."

"In fairest Phoenix, where I didst make my home,
This eatery was one of the first I didst roam.
'Twas such a feast, I vowed to bring my spouse,
For on the morrow, we didst dine with joy and cheer.
Their victuals were most delectable, I do confess,
And ambiance, quite divine, with naught to repress.
Their al fresco seats, didst please mine eyes,
And servitors, most courteous, didst surprise.
Indeed, a place most wondrous, I do declare,
Where one may savor flavors, and atmosphere most rare."

"Hark! Dinner at Bouchon, what a wondrous feast!
The chicken dish, oh how it did impress,
And the dessert, a brownie shaped like a wine cork,
A sweet delight that doth make my heart sing.

The ambiance, upscale yet cozy, doth please,
A bistro feel that doth bring me joy and ease.
The food, a comfort French, with twists so fine,
Doth fill my belly with delight divine.

But alas, the price, it doth give me pause,
For though the meal be delicious, 'tis not without cause.
I may, ere next I dine, seek out another place,
To savor flavors new, and thus, my taste doth trace."

"Hark! Wherefore hast thou been, my friend?
When did Carl's Jr. become so grand?
Perhaps 'twas with their $6000 combo,
Served only at the Palms, by the Maloof Brothers' hand?
Or mayhap 'twas their humble $6.00 burger,
That didst stir within thee such curiosity and wonder?

In running errands, 'twas suggested we dine here,
Not grab a quick bite, nor drive-thru, but tarry and cheer.
I had eaten within these walls but once before,
And found it decent, despite its humble store.

Three TVs didst grace the space, each tuned to ESPN,
As I devoured a chicken salad, quite large and fine.
A Squirt didst quench my thirst, and a maiden fair,
Didst offer me a refill, with a smile so rare.
We left a buck, in case, though none others did,
For service good, and a meal that didst satisfy and glad.

I knew not if 'twas healthy, or just seemed so,
But 'twas a welcome change, from burgers and tacos, yo!"

In this fair land of plenty, where food doth abound,
A place there be, where one may find sustenance profound.
For those who be of limited means, and seek a hearty meal,
This eatery doth provide, with prices most conceivably real.

The portions, generous they be, and fill thy belly full,
So fear not, dear traveler, for thou shalt have enough.
The fare, not of the finest sort, yet satisfying still,
And for the price, a bargain, verily, a steal.

So, if thou art in need, and coin doth dwindle low,
Come hither, friend, and dine with joy, I do thee know.

"Alas, poor Boston, without this wondrous place,
Where breakfast reigns supreme, in flavor and grace.
A BLT bloody mary, with bacon, lettuce, and tomato,
A feast fit for a king, or so I did assume.

The menu, a vast expanse of culinary delight,
Didst overwhelm us, with options, left and right.
We shared, to sample all, with great intent,
The Snickers pancake, a behemoth, of immense proportion.

Fried chicken, waffles, bacon, oh my!
A heart attack, on a plate, didst lie.
But worth it, indeed, with flavors so bold,
And hash, with grilled chicken, asparagus, and sundried gold.

A healthy option, compared to the rest,
But fresh and tasty, the marmalade did bless.
So, gentle traveler, make this stop a must,
In Las Vegas, where culinary dreams are fust."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous place, indeed,
Where sushi doth abound, and all with speed.
Their rolls, they do contain brown rice,
A healthier choice, and full of nice surprise.
Each one I've had, hath been a treat,
And left me feeling full, and most discreet.
The setup of the place, doth please mine eye,
A cozy spot, where one can sit and sigh."

"Hark, fair friends, to my tale of woe,
Of eggs benedict, both fried and poached,
At Wanda's, a place of gastronomic delight,
Where service is swift and the folk are bright.

A referral from the DMV, a chance encounter,
Led me to this cozy eatery, full of cheer,
The flavors danced on my palate, a true delight,
But alas, the egg, fried, not poached, did appear.

Yet still, the friendly folk and quick service,
Make Wanda's a place of joy and good cheer,
So if thou art in search of a tasty repast,
Pray, give this spot a try, 'twill be thy quest."

"In chilly Chicago, frozen yogurt doth not abide,
Until the month of June, when summer doth reside.
But in fair Phoenix, where sun doth shine bright,
I chanced upon Yogurtland, a sweet delight.

A place where one doth pay by weight, they say,
And sampled five kinds of yogurt, ere I did play.
Peanut butter and devils food, my heart did steer,
For low-fat, it seemed, and healthy, without fear.

But then, alas! My craving for sweets didst creep,
And Reese's, oh Reese's, didst make my heart leap.
With candy, galore, my fro yo didst gleam,
A peanut butter dream, most truly, a scheme.

Busy, Yogurtland was, with patrons, many a one,
For tasty flavors, and toppings, they had won.
Affordable, the price, for all to partake,
A sweet retreat, indeed, for fro yo to make."

"Gurkha Brigade, a humble abode,
On Leith Walk, doth not proclaim its fame,
But within, a clean and spacious room,
Doth welcome guests with friendly grace.

Their takeaway menu, diverse and wide,
With sauces, meats, and veggie choice,
Did tempt my taste, and I did choose,
The pork sungur, in a spicy voice.

Tender chunks of meat, in tomato's embrace,
Did dance with flavor, a savory delight,
With plain rice, Coke, and a smile on my face,
I paid ten pounds, a price, yet fair in sight.

My friend, two starters of pakora did order,
Which looked and tasted, a true delight,
We both agreed, to visit again,
When student grants, our pockets do fill with light."

"A wait of none, a patio full of folk,
And service that doth make one feel quite swell.
The grub, alas, didst not quite take my breath,
But still, 'twas decent fare, and worth the spell.
My wife and I shall visit once again,
For though the food didst not amaze, the ambiance didst remain."

"A wine bar most wondrous, in the Old Town square,
With prices so fair, it doth astound and glare.
A bachelorette party, with laughter and cheer,
They accommodated them, with nary a fear.

Their wine selection, a marvel to behold,
Ten percent off, on the back of their gold.
Their food, a delight, with portions so fair,
Even the hardest to please, did declare.

The bruschetta sampler, a treat for the taste,
A patio so cute, with live music in haste.
Overall, a place most excellent, indeed,
A hit, a find, a treasure to heed."

"A five-star review, perchance, for food most fair,
But, alas, the venue doth leave much to despair.
A no-frills place, with naught but bare essentials,
And loud, oh so loud, with sushi chefs' constant yellings.

I entered, and a cheer didst one of them extend,
A power clap, per se, and I, in kind, didst respond.
All in good fun, I say, and thus didst join the fray.

In Charlotte, none doth offer such a deal,
For $10, all thou canst eat, a veritable steal.
The sushi, "Americanized", doth lack refinement,
Deep-fried, unhealthy, yet still, my taste doth tempt.

Time labels on the plates, to ensure freshness true,
Yet often, sushi doth run out, ere time doth too.
'Tis good, indeed, and thus, in rotation, shall stay,
My Ru-tation, for Ru San's, a local sushi way.

Note: Arrive at 11:30, to avoid a wait, I pray."

"A quaint yogurt shoppe, with decor of days past,
Where maidens friendly serve, yet watchful be.
Their vigilance doth make me feel quite wary,
As if they feared mischief from patrons free.

The space, perhaps, doth suffer poor design,
With blind spots that invite misdeeds unseen.
Yet still, I praise their raspberry sauce divine,
Which doth not come in bottles, but in bits so fine.

Their toppings, too, doth please mine eyes,
With Hostess cupcakes, and peanut butter pies.
Amidst this charm, I pray they doth relax,
Their watchful gaze, and let patrons enjoy the peace."

"Hark! Firkin On Paradise, a pub most fair,
In Las Vegas' Bar Belt, doth hold its lair.
A place of mirth and cheer, where fun doth reign,
And prices, small, doth make it easy to obtain.

The TVs, they doth show sports, my dear,
And Firkin, too, doth tie in beer and cheer.
At time of visit, $2 beers, a sight to see,
And $5 fish and chips, a special treat for thee.

I shall return, my friends, 'tis true,
For $4.50 beer, a price most fair and new.
The $2 special, sensational, indeed,
And noise, not loud, my thoughts doth heed.

The food, delicious, by Yelp's decree,
The servers, friendly, specials doth reveal.
TVs, plenty, for sports, a joy to behold,
Pool tables, too, for games of old.

British theme, a charm, doth please mine eye,
Across from Hard Rock, a night to fly.
Kiss Mini Golf, behind, a challenge, mayhap,
But after beers, a test, a trial, a laugh, perchance.

So here, my friends, I shall return, anon,
To Firkin On Paradise, a pub most wondrous, alone."

"Fare thee well, good sirs and madams! Our bellies full, our spirits high,  
We doth depart, with naught but praise for this fair eatery in the sky.  
The victuals, delectable and fine, didst leave us all in want of more,  
And so, we didst request, in haste, doggy bags to store.  
The service, swift and courteous, didst make our stay most pleasant,  
And thus, we shall return anon, to partake of their delicious fare again."

"Hark! My husband didst suggest this place for dinner,
And though our daughter was not keen, I didst persist.
A week didst pass, and still I pondered on the feast,
Till I didst bribe the child with cookies, and we didst dine.

The noodles, pan-fried, with shrimp, spicy, were mine,
As usual, cooked to perfection, a hearty repast.
My daughter, picky, didst enjoy her chicken too,
With noodles, and she ate most of it, save two cookies few.

The place, clean, and service, friendly, as before,
Yet one wish, that all our meals be brought forth once more."

"Hark! At last, we found Sausagefest, a feast most fair,
At StrEATs, a place of gastronomic delight.
From Chicago's southside, we didst venture there,
To test the Polish and Hot Italian, with great cheer.

Both sausages, they didst measure up, I swear,
The Vietnamese rolls, untraditional, yet so dear.
A great bun to meat ratio, soft and chewy,
Yet strong enough to hold all the tasty bits, anon.

The fries, skin on and fried crisp, just like at home,
Didst complete our meal, with joy and gladness.
Rock on, Sausagefest! We shall return, ere long,
For more of thy delicious victuals, and merriment."

"Hark! A feast fit for a king, and at a price most fair! 
Red Lobster, a place I had not visited in years, didst impress me mightily. 
A gift card, my dear GF didst possess, and thus we didst venture in, 
During Lobster Fest, a time of joy and cheer. 
The wait, they didst say, would be some forty-five minutes, 
But lo, we were seated in but twenty, a most pleasant surprise. 
The staff, polite and friendly, didst attend to our needs, 
And the biscuits, oh how they didst delight! 
Specialty cocktails, a true delight, and the specials, 
Didst cater to all tastes, a wondrous sight. 
Two lobster tails, cooked to perfection, didst grace my plate, 
And my GF, her surf and turf, didst savor with glee. 
A complaint, I must lodged, the water in the sink, 
Doth heat up quickly, a minor quibble, I do confess. 
But overall, a grand meal, with service most excellent, 
At a fraction of the cost, a true bargain, indeed."

A merry park, full of swings and slides, doth bring delight,
And water play, a cooling respite from sun's fierce light.
But alas, 'tis prone to crowds, a convergence dire,
Of diverse folk, some good, some ill, a cause for ire.

The former group, kind, courteous, laborers, doth seek
A tranquil time, in peace, their leisure to partake.
The latter sort, a worrisome lot, doth cause dismay,
With their ill manners, rowdy ways, a blight on the day.

"Methinks four trips didst suffice to unearth the cause of mine phone's malfunction. Each sojourn didst proffer a novel perspective on the matter, as if by divine providence. 'Twas not their fault, perchance, that they knew not the answer straightaway. Given they didst strive to amend the problem, I do confess myself content with their endeavors."

"This place, a haven, doth delight. Meatless dishes, many there be, for vegetarians, fear not to ask, 'tis true. Soy-rizo, a substitute, they do provide, for Mexican chorizo, with a couple of entrees, a clever move. Made to order, all doth seem, a sign of care, a mark of esteem. Decor, homely, artistic, not opulent, yet cozy, a pleasant scene. Bring thine own bottle, on certain nights, two entrees and an appetizer, doth grant a complimentary wine, a generous sight. Coffee, freshly brewed, doth make all the difference, a perfect end, a sweet delight. The chef, a friendly soul, didst come forth, to greet and check, a gentle touch, a pleasing sight. A recommendation, I do extend, and shall return, for that chocolate torte, a treat most divine."

"A humble abode, a tranquil scene,
Biscuits and gravy, a meal most serene.
But mark this well, my friends,
Ere break of noon, thou must descend,
Lest thou miss out on breakfast's delight."

"O, fairest hotel, how lovely art thou! No casino's din nor smokers' haze doth mar thy beauty. Thou art a temple of elegance, where comfort doth reign supreme. In thee, I found luxurious bliss, a true lap of indulgence.

"The LCD within the bathroom mirror, a curious delight, didst allow me to brush my teeth while watching t.v., a most convenient pleasure. And though the novelty didst fade, the deep bathtub, fit for two, didst remain a constant joy. Ah, sweet serenity!

"Each morn, we didst order breakfast to our chamber, and lo, the fare was delectable, the service, most excellent. If grace and refinement be thy quest, then Trump Hotel, my friend, is thy haven."

"Hark! A fan of skinnyfats, I do confess,
And once a week, my visits doth not cease.
But lo! Today, my joy didst turn to woe,
For poor service didst my meal doth slow.

A group of four, we sat and didst await,
Our grub, but mine didst not arrive by fate.
My partner asked, with query in his eyes,
The server, who didst reply with scant surprise.

She brought a house salad, with nary a care,
And slammed it down, with gesture most rare.
I said, 'Quinoa salad, chicken, if thou please,'
But she, with haste, didst take it back, with ease.

At last, the correct plate, she didst bring,
And walked away, with nary a word, or ring.
As one who manages service, day and night,
I say, this lass doth need some coaching in sight.

The other employees, with guests didst play,
In friendly wise, their duties didst sway.
But she, with attitude, didst fail, I say,
And thus, my praise, doth go astray.

The food, oh aye! 'Twas wondrous, I confess,
But service, ah! That doth leave much to address."

"Marry, what a wondrous edifice doth stand before mine eyes! I do implore thee, gentle reader, to pay a visit to this grand structure, and should thou be a scholar such as myself, do not miss the opportunity to partake in a tour of the Nationality Rooms. Forsooth, there be some twenty chambers, each appointed in the fashion of one of the nations that didst contribute to the building of Pittsburgh, that fair city of steel and stone. Take heed, good sir or madam, and mark well the hour of the tour, lest thou miss the chance to behold these wonders with thine own eyes."

"Hark, good sir! If thou art in need of car repair,  
Or merely passin' by, do stop and tarry here.  
'Tis a Ford dealership, where thou shalt find  
A breakfast spread, most wondrous and fair.  
I, myself, didst partake of eggs and cheese,  
Upon a flaky croissant, most delicious, 'twas ease.  
Indeed, I would return, again and again,  
For such a meal, most satisfying, doth proclaim.  
Alas, one star doth falter, for the wait,  
Didst stretch on long, past reason, methinks, 'twas fate."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy at this fair place!
Margaritas of great worth, and fajitas of grace.
In summer's heat, I have been there, and found
The dining space to be a bit too warm, I have found.
But were it not for that, five stars would be its due,
For it doth please my senses, and my heart doth renew."

"Hark! In three year's time, I've witnessed Las Vegas' rise,
As Roberto's locations sprout, like mushrooms in the skies.
Each store, unique in quality and menu, doth surprise,
Like the fiery green salsa, that doth burn my eyes.

This Roberto's, near my home, doth hold a special place,
With carne asada, so-so, and breakfast burritos, in grace.
But the carnitas, oh! How they doth stand apart,
Fried to a crisp, they steal the show, and win my heart."

"Hark, what tidings bring thee to our neck of woods?  Aye, 'tis Pita Jungle, where victuals are as delectable as those at other establishments.  Verily, the staff doth provide most excellent service, with smiles that doth light up the day.  Alas, the bar area doth seem a mite small, but fear not, for on fair days, the outdoor patio doth provide a most pleasant refuge."

"Hark, what fortune brought me to this place,
Where kindness doth abound in every face?
I sought but take-out, yet didst receive,
A taste of soup, most vegan and relieve.

Their tortillas, soft and fluffy, made,
Didst wrap the burritos, which my heart didst sway.
With lime-infused rice, and beans so black,
Guacamole, fajitas, pico, and salsa on the attack.

My woman too, didst partake in the feast,
Her burrito filled with joy, and love at least.
And though I once didst crave cheese, I swear,
Their chips and queso dip, didst bring me cheer."

"O, fairest Sam Fox, thou art a wizard in the kitchen, conjuring up delectable dishes that doth please mine taste buds. Thy restaurants, including Culinary Dropout, ne'er fail to impress. I have partaken in their bounty many a time, and each visit doth leave me in a state of gastronomical bliss. The service, though not perfect, doth not detract from the joy that thy victuals bringeth. The bloody mary, with its savory bacon, doth quench mine thirst, while the salmon, oh so tender and flavorful, doth delight mine senses. And the pretzels and fondue, by the stars, what a wondrous creation! Thou hast captured mine heart, good sir, and I shall continue to bestow upon thee mine coin, forsooth."

"A new hotel, great indeed, with all things fresh and new.
The King bedroom suite, a sight to behold, doth please me well.
The pool, a sparkling gem, and breakfast spread, most fair.
I shall return, forsooth, to revel in its luxury once more."

"Phoenix airport doth boast a wondrous eatery,
Where travelers may find solace in victuals of the land.
Above the norm, their cuisine doth rise,
Fresh and pure, a delight to the eyes.

Their take on Tex-Mex, a simple yet grand,
Doth please the palate with flavors so bland.
So, weary traveler, seek out this place,
And let thy taste buds revel in joy and grace."

"Hark! Doth thou love Noodle Factory, fair sir?
Thy answer being 'aye', then 'tis a place most meet
For thee, my friend. In Montreal's Chinatown,
I know of many eateries, humble and down-to-earth,
Where culture's flavors dance upon thy tongue.
But, alas! Sometimes, they do not serve my will.
Amongst them all, there's but one that doth stand tall,
Noodle Factory, where noodles, dumplings, and more
Are served with love, in cozy atmosphere,
At prices fair, and on thy table, too!"

"Fear not the humble abode, my friends, for within its walls doth lie a feast most wondrous and fine. A veritable cornucopia of sashimi, with grilled mackerel and edamame did we devour, and by the stars, 'twas fresh as spring's first bloom. And, mark thee well, the wasabi, that fiery dragon's breath, did we receive in abundance, a gift from the gods, or so it seemed. This place, a gem, a treasure trove of culinary delight, shall be our secret, hidden away, but not forgotten, nay, not forgotten."

"Hark! Umphrey's 2,000th show doth approach,
A milestone reached, a moment to bask.
The venue, not bad, the sound, quite good,
Security, cool, as if from a wood.

Next door, a place doth make tasty treats,
Taffy apples, alas, we could not eat.
For we did run late, both nights, alack,
And missed the chance to savor their snacks.

But fear not, for parking, there was a spot,
A reasonable garage, a block away, not hot.
Better than Madison's streets, so tight,
A true blessing, a wonder in sight."

"Methought to partake of a novel Indian feast,
And thus, my heart didst choose the Curry Garden least.
The interior, alas, didst not impress mine eyes,
But nay, the victuals, they didst take me by surprise.

A Paneer Tikka Masala, Bhatura, and Garlic Naan,
Didst order I, with eager anticipation keen.
The Paneer, so fresh and delicate, didst please mine taste,
And the sauce, oh how it didst delight mine senses vast.

The Bhatura, a marvel of culinary skill,
Didst arrive, steaming hot, and didst my hunger still.
And the Garlic Naan, with its generous clove,
Didst satisfy mine craving, like a gentle dove.

The service, too, didst merit high esteem,
Despite the homely decor, the place didst gleam.
Cleanliness, they didst not neglect, I must confess,
And thus, my heart doth sing with joy and happiness.

Anon, I shall return, should my Paneer craving arise,
For at the Curry Garden, true delight doth lie."

"A most excellent tavern, with a fine array of victuals and potables. The barkeepers, friendly and keen, do serve with haste and diligence. The serving folk, though somewhat hasty in their steps, do strive to please. A merry place, indeed, to watch a game or two, with televisions plentiful as the stars in heaven."

"Methinks I do adore the ambiance of this place,
And the victuals, they didst please my taste.
Forsooth, thou mayst sing and dance, if thou art not afraid,
In this merry tavern, where mirth doth reign supreme."

"Methinks we purchased, in fair Las Vegas' city,
A gift certificate, of online sort, didst fit
This place, where now we dine, in merriment.
The service, here, doth excel, in truth, I say,
And yonder ribeye, cooked to perfection's way,
Doth please mine taste, with sides of excellence.
And last, the creme brulee, a sweet delight,
Doth end my feast, with joy, and mirth, this night."

"Hark! A review of HOB Vegas doth lie within these lines,
A concert venue of note, with food that doth decline.
I've had it before, and, by the stars, I'd pass,
For 'tis not worth the coin, nor the time, alas!

But AFI, a band of old, didst play herein,
In January last, with sounds of yore, so fine.
Their music, like the wind, didst stir the soul,
And though 'twas not their latest, still, 'twas whole.

Now, as for the venue, 'tis a wondrous sight,
With stadium seating, and views most bright.
No problem getting in, or out, I say,
Even with a line, 'twas swift, come what may.

The sound, oh, 'twas a joy to hear, so clear,
And upstairs, the bar, didst serve with speed, my dear.
I do prefer this HOB, o'er Anaheim,
For Vegas' Disneyland, doth bring a merry gleam.

So, if thou art in search of music, and delight,
Come to HOB Vegas, and let thy spirit take flight."

"A hearty breakfast did we enjoy, my dear. Samantha, a vision of loveliness, did grace our table with her presence. Eggs and chorizo, a feast for the taste buds, did we devour with gusto. Alas, the pancakes and muffins, though they did appear most delectable, did we not partake of, for we were full and satisfied with the morning's repast."

"Methinks I wouldst give this place five stars, forsooth,
My taste buds didst dance with joy, in truth.
But alas, fair friends, hygiene doth play a part,
And thus, my rating doth depart.

A peek within the kitchen, all didst seem fine,
But then, a table, not so clean, didst shine.
Cabbage remnants on the chili bowl, oh dear!
Yet still, I sought to banish fear.

Lamb and chive dumplings, round and full of might,
Didst burst with flavor, a true delight.
The pork and cabbage, fried to perfection,
Didst please my taste, with its crispy dimension.

So, friends, do visit this place, anon,
For dumplings divine, and salads, a bonus.
Just heed my words, and turn away,
From rugs, that may thy gaze dismay."

"Hark! The Habit doth break the mold of common burger haunts,
A cut above, like Carl's Jr., with finer appointments.
Their bill of fare, though not extensive, doth satisfy,
And servitors, with diligence, do attend to needs.
But, alas, parking at noon doth prove a challenge,
So come early, lest thou be forced to tarry long."

"Upon my travels down Smallman, bound for 21 St Coffee,
A tiny sign didst catch mine eye, that read, "Donuts", ye see.
A humble shop, with space enough to make and sell,
I stepped inside, and met Ron, the owner, a merry fellow.

The donuts, made before mine eyes, in a machine so small,
Were cooked to perfection, and oh, how sweet they did smell!
Freshly baked, still warm, of Devils Food, the variety,
Ron dropped them in a bag, with sugar, oh, what a delight!

With mocha in hand, I savored each morsel, oh, how grand!
But alas, good sir, the price, didst give me pause,
For three dollars, a dozen, seemed steep, I must confess.
Yet, freshness and taste, didst make up for the cost, I do suppose.

Four stars, good sir, thy donuts, they didst please,
And though the price, didst pinch my purse, I shall return, anon, to seize."

"A humble abode, this Thai eatery may seem,
But within its walls, a culinary dream doth beckon.
Authentic ambiance, service swift and true,
And dishes, oh so delectable, at prices fair and few.
Their new website, with visual feast doth provide,
For take-out orders, with ease to now decide.
Pad Thai, a classic, doth reign supreme,
And number thirty-five, a flavorful gem.
In Phoenix, seek this restaurant out,
For a taste of Thailand, without a doubt."

"O, what a wondrous place! Breads, pretzels, sausages, and meats of all kinds,
Soups, snacks, and pickled delights that doth astound.
We chanced upon this haven, and our hunger did sate,
With a soft pretzel, shaped like a horse's hooves, so great.
A bag of sticks, and a mustard, creamy and bright,
With dill, lemon, capers, and honey, a true delight.
Next time, we shall return, to gather more of their gummies,
For they do have a plethora, of sweet and tasty treasures."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, heed my words of wisdom,
For in this place, a dish most wondrous lies,
'Tis called Malaysian fried rice, a feast most fair,
Unbelievable, indeed, it doth surprise.

And if thou art a fan of sushi, then
The panther roll, a treat most worthy, doth await,
With flavors rich and colors bright, 'twill win
Thy taste buds' hearts, and leave thee in delight.

But, alas, the service here, at times doth falter,
Yet fear not, for the curries, they do make up for't,
In spicy splendor, they doth dance upon thy plate,
A culinary joy, that doth await thy fate.

So, prithee, gentle reader, take my humble advice,
And come, partake of this most wondrous rice,
For in its savory depths, a gustatory paradise,
Doth lie in wait, to make thy senses thrice as nice."

In sooth, a pleasant stay didst I enjoy,
At Hyatt Place, where modernity doth employ.
Clean, safe, and comfortable, the space didst provide,
With friendly front desk staff, who didst enquire,
If all were well, and naught didst cause dismay.
A separate sitting area, with fridge and large TV,
Didst complete the accommodations, in a most agreeable way.
But lo, a strange thermostat, didst cause some strife,
And coffee, alas, didst leave much to desire.
The GPS, a newer sort, didst cause some woe,
For those with older cars, a tricksome route to go.
On Sunday morn, didst I awake to peace,
A quiet calm, that didst my soul release.
But soon, didst children's laughter and footsteps ring,
In Spanish, loud and boisterous, didst they sing.
A gathering of seven, in the hall didst convene,
Their noise, didst increase, as I didst emerge.
Alas, the hotel, cannot control,
The rowdy guests, who do not keep it low.
A request, in writing, at check-in, might suffice,
To ask for quiet, during certain hours, nice.
But alack, 'tis wishful thinking, I do fear,
For hotels, cheap and large, do breed such cheer.

"A fortnight's sojourn at the Wigwam didst afford me,
For work-related purposes, a most pleasant respite.
A leadership summit, our company didst convene,
And this location proved ideal, most fitting and bright.

The chamber, spacious and well-appointed, didst boast
A wet bar, living room with fireplace, and bed,
Soft and luxurious, that induced sweet slumber,
The best repose I've known, indeed, most divine.

The decor, a blend of Southwest and Ranch, didst charm,
Though modernity, my heart doth truly disarm.
Yet, comfort and relaxation, I didst find,
In this haven, despite its style, so unrefined."

Last eve, I didst meet with friends most dear,
For enchiladas of cheese and drinks of cheer.
This establishment, with service so fine,
Didst provide us with an evening divine.
Their Sonoran-style cuisine, a feast for the taste,
I didst vary my order, with green chile in haste.
Yum, yum, yum, the flavors didst delight,
And vegetarian options, a pleasant sight.
My friend, a regular, doth sing its praise,
A testament to its quality, in many ways.
Though still I search for that elusive red sauce,
This place, in my book, doth earn a favorable pause.

"A watch, a symbol of stature and wealth, doth speak volumes of its owner, akin to a dwelling or carriage. For those who seek to display their standing, a fine timepiece is a prized possession. But for me, a humble soul, a watch doth serve naught but to chafe my skin and weigh heavy upon my wrist. My modest attire and tattered shoes shall suffice to signal my station in life. \n\nYet, for connoisseurs of horology, this diminutive, eccentric boutique shall be a treasure trove, overflowing with an array of exquisite timepieces, each one a marvel of craftsmanship and artistry."

"Hark! If thou hast not seen this place before, 'Tis worth thine while to venture forth and explore. Forsooth, a ticket doth cost but twenty crowns, And within, thou shalt find diversions galore. Aye, drinks and victuals, too, they doth abound, As three-penny soda, five-penny ale, and seven-and-a-half penny turkey legs, With brownie and ice-cream, five crowns doth command. But, gentle visitor, heed my words of wisdom, Bring sunscreen and hat, for 'tis a long, hot day, And things to buy, they doth come dear, I pray thee, be prepared. Yet, fear not, for there doth be shows aplenty, A little bit of all, for every soul to enjoy."

"A diamond in the rough, indeed! Despite the crumbling homes that surround it, this establishment shines bright. Their charcuterie platter, a feast fit for kings, boasts an array of delectable meats and cheeses, paired with accompaniments that delight. Prices, most reasonable, for the quality they bring. Staff, eager and attentive, ensuring each guest's pleasure. Duck egg ravioli, a standout dish, the brown butter and fried Swiss chard, a winning combination. Fois gras mousse, rich and flavorful, yet, alas, a bit tricky to devour. All in all, a sumptuous repast, a bottle of wine, dessert, and a glass of Prosecco, for less than $120! Were I a local, I would frequent this place, savoring their charcuterie platter, perhaps twice a week, over drinks and merriment."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, do not miss this place,
My friend doth live nearby, and we have found grace
In breakfast visits, oft and frequent, 'tis true,
The coffee, rich and smooth, doth please my taste anew.
A vanilla latte, sweet and velvety, doth reign,
A favorite, indeed, among their offerings profane.
The menu, diverse and quaint, doth pique my interest,
Yet, I, a glutton, find myself enthralled,
By short rib burritos, savory, oh so fine,
A dish most delectable, fit for a king's design.
But, alas! The portions, large and overflowing,
Do leave me sated, ere my meal be going.
I pray, good sir, a to-go box, forthwith,
Lest I, in haste, devour all, like some wild beast.
The wait, a trifle long, yet, service swift and bright,
Doth make amends, and doth dispel the morning's blight.
But, comfortless seating, a minor drawback, I confess,
And healthy choices, scarce, save for their willingness
To substitute, with grace, and accommodate,
A boon, indeed, for those who seek a lighter fate.
So, prithee, gentle reader, heed my words of cheer,
And visit this spot, where culinary joys appear."

"A fair eatery indeed, where hospitality doth flow.
I chanced upon the married pair, so warm and welcoming,
Their culinary skills, a true delight, did show.
A hearty meal, with prompt attendance, did they bring.
I shall return, forsooth, to savor their fare once more."

"In fair Edinburgh, where wondrous sights abound,
A hunger pang did strike, and rest did seek.
A cafe, recommended, alas, didst shut its door,
So here, within this bistro, didst I entreat.

Quiet, cozy, with but few patrons nigh,
A table found, and ordered forthwith.
Avocado salad, healthful choice, didst crave,
With water, pure, to quench thirst, didst wave.

Waitress, kind, didst show me to my seat,
And swift, my salad came, with bread, a treat.
But, alas, too much vinaigrette didst pour,
Dripping, the leaves didst, in oil, a sore.

A star, deducted, for this mistake, I say,
Yet still, wouldst return, for service, good, didst play."

"A wondrous place, indeed, where fine ale flows free,
And victuals of the finest sort doth please the eye.
But alas, my friends, a group of six or more,
Shall find it hard to gain a table, by the door.
For reservations, they do not keep, nor hold,
So come ye early, lest ye be left cold."

"Hark, I didst order spinach rice and beans,
A dish most wondrous, fit for a king.
The service, alas, didst start quite slow,
I waited ten long minutes, my heart didst grow.
For a cup of tea, a simple request,
Yet, 'twas a delay that didst me oppress.
But fear not, dear friends, for all's well that ends well,
The food, indeed, didst make my heart sing and swell.
So, though the service may have been a mite slow,
I shall return, for the victuals, they do know."

"Hark, fair maiden, I do confess,  
Little Nippers II doth possess  
A menu most wondrous and fine,  
With dishes that doth please mine eyes and dine.  
Their mild wings, oh how they shine,  
With flavors so rich and divine.  
Skip the dressing, 'tis but a whim,  
And substitute with blue cheese, a gem.  
Their pizza, alas, doth not compare,  
To those in New York, so fair and rare.  
But still, I shall return anon,  
And call ahead, to wait not long."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy and cheer,
For fish sandwiches, they be all they claim,
In this, a humble tavern, dark and dim,
Where smoke doth fill the air, and time doth slim.

But fear not, traveler, for thy meal,
Shall be prepared with haste, and served with zeal,
Though thou mayst wait, and thy patience be tried,
Yet shall thy hunger be satisfied.

Aye, for a fish sandwich and fries of gold,
Thou shalt pay ten silver coins, 'tis true,
But mark my words, 'tis worth the cost,
For in this place, thou shalt find naught but the best."

"A most excellent place, indeed! My love and I didst oft visit the establishment in Mesa, but alas! The manager, a wicked witch, didst ne'er show us any courtesy. We didst cease to patronize that location, but lo! We didst give the Bell Rd. site a chance. Hark! The service was superb! A warm smile didst greet us, and straightway, we were seated. Our server, a diligent lad, didst attend to our needs with haste. The victuals, most delectable! I didst order a skillet, my heart's desire, and my spouse, the Eye Opener Combo, his favorite dish. By my troth, we are elated to include this eatery once more in our circuit of delightful morning haunts!"

"A merry time doth await thee on this tour of chocolate delight,
'Tis free, my friends, and full of sweetness and light.
Amidst the cacti, a wondrous sight doth lie,
And at the end, a treat doth await thee, a taste most divine.
I speak of Creme Liqueurs, a delicacy most fine,
If thou hast not tried them, thou art truly missing out, my friend."

"In Mekong Plaza's restaurants, there's nary a dud,
But Wholly Grill, a gem, deserves a second nod.
We sought a meal both good and cheap,
And thus didst venture forth, our taste buds to keep.

The food court beckoned, and we didst stray,
To sample dishes of the local way.
Wholly Grill, our choice, didst not betray,
Our hunger sated, we didst end the day.

I chose the pork belly, oh so fair,
My partner, skewers, with eggplant rare.
Both dishes, delicious, beyond compare,
The flavors danced, our senses to ensnare.

The staff, kind and friendly, didst declare,
The pork belly, their recommendation most fair.
We laughed and smiled, our bellies full and round,
Our taste buds, happy, our spirits astound.

Oh, how I yearn for that pork belly now,
My craving, strong, doth never slack.
I shall return, my friends, make no mistake,
For more of that dish, my heart doth ache."

"A tiny vanilla chai tea latte didst I procure,
To sip upon my way, with nary a care.
The cup, just right for me, didst fit like a glove,
And tasted most divine, beyond compare.

But lo, the price didst give me pause,
For three silver pieces, quite a steep cost, I'd say.
Yet still, I drank it with joy and delight,
For 'twas worth every penny, come what may."

"Hark! A friend and I didst partake in Restaurant Week's delight,
At a quaint, charming establishment, with atmosphere so bright.
The calamari, alas! Was cooked a mite too long,
But all else was divine, and service, it didst throng.
Bring thine own vino, lest thou wish to pay the price,
For their cellar doth lack variety, and cost, 'twill pinch."

"Hark, what news is this? A chain restaurant, perchance? 

Aye, 'tis true, my friends, for Chipotle doth reign supreme, 
A place where hunger meets its match, and taste doth gleam. 
Their food, so fresh and delicate, doth dance upon mine eyes, 
And in their philosophy, "Food with integrity," doth lie. 
Vegetarian options, too, for those who choose to abstain, 
And meat, raised natural, without hormones, doth obtain. 
It warms my heart to see a company so keen, 
To befriend the earth, and all that's seen. 
On cups, stories told, of products and their ways, 
A pleasant read, while waiting for my days. 
The staff, so kind and helpful, as I went along, 
Assembling my burrito, with a cheerful song. 
Indoor and outdoor seats, for all to take delight, 
Or order online, and have it ready in sight. 
Great food, great service, what more can be said? 
I am a fan, of Chipotle, in my head."

"Methought we craved a meal most light,
And thus didst choose this place aright.
A fan of sushi and sashimi, I,
Didst find their menu most invitingly.

We opted for small share plates, six in all,
And found them fresh and tasty, one and all.
The sauces, too, didst please our taste,
And service, friendly, efficient, and fast.

Indeed, we wouldst dine here once more,
For this place hath won our hearts o'er."

"By chance, I stumbled upon this bakery while on other errands in the area. The sweet aroma of fresh bread wafting from within was too enticing to resist, and I found myself stepping inside for a brief visit. They had an array of delights for a satisfying meal: bread, pastries, cakes, quiches, cheeses, and pre-prepared dishes ready to be warmed at home. I sampled their bread with honey and nuts, which was simply divine. However, I left with a loaf of raisin and nut bread that was cut to my liking. It was a dense bread with a solid crust but not too difficult to eat, and a soft interior that didn't make too many crumbs. If this bakery were closer to my home, I would likely be a regular customer!"

"Hark, what multitude of fair and gallant folk doth throng this place! Methinks 'twas fate that brought me hither, ne'er to know the ways of this, their favored haunt.  Aye, confusion reigned within my mind, as if the fates themselves did seek to hide the truth from mine eyes. But lo, a kindly quartet of servants didst guide me to the will call desk, and thus my quest did end in triumph.  Mirth and gaiety doth reign supreme amongst this merry throng, and youthful vigor doth abound.  Alas, the subterranean parking lot, a veritable labyrinth, didst prove a challenge to mine own meager wit.  Perchance a brighter illumination might serve to light the way, lest one stumble in the darkness, lost in thought, as in a dream.  Aye, upon the pool deck, a concert didst take place, with New Order playing to a packed assembly.  The acoustics, methinks, were naught but marginal, yet still the music didst stir mine own soul.  Four songs from Joy Division didst they play, a wondrous treat indeed!  Fie upon those who didst depart ere the encore, for they didst miss a wondrous sight!  A true fan doth stay until the very end, when all is done and gone.  And thus, a pleasant evening it was, with new friends made, and memories to cherish."

"Our ceaseless pursuit of boba tea, a month long quest,
Led us to Sesame House, a place unjustly named,
Within Chinatown Plaza, a mall of wonder,
A sign outside proclaims, "No. 1 Boba", in thunder.

Their tea, a second best, next to Tea Planet's brew,
But prices here, more kindly, on the purse, doth do.
Atmosphere, sparse, yet fruit, fresh as the dew,
And dried fruits, aplenty, for all to pursue."

"In Vieux Quebec, a place most fair,
For breakfast, brunch, or lunch, they do prepare.
My wife, enchanted by its charm, did say,
'Tis a spot most cute, and thus, we did stay.

The pastries, oh so fine and sweet,
Especially those with cheese, and a bit of heat.
The cuban panini, a delight,
My wife, in love, did take a bite.

Though toasty bread, not my desire,
I'd order it again, without a fire.
And do, dear friend, get a large cappuccino,
To make your meal, a true delight, I do infer.

Not pricey, compared to other places,
In the Old City, where tourists do race.
So go, and enjoy, this quaint eatery,
In Vieux Quebec, a gem, a true rarity."

"Verily, this Thai food doth please mine taste,
With beef jerky, pad thai, papaya salad, and rice so bright.
Their tea, a vast and wondrous brew, doth fill my cup,
And though the site may lack, the service doth make up.
I shall return, for here I find my heart's desire,
In this fair Thai food, which doth my senses fire."

"Verily, I have traversed this airport oftener than Anna Nicole Smith's apothecaries didst venture forth to the Bahamas. 'Tis a maze within, yet without, a true labyrinth doth lie. Which lane doth lead to yonder 202? The left, perchance? Nay, now the middle? And then, a hundred paces further, the left once more? Pray tell, what mirth doth these traffic wardens find in their Cheetos and Dr. Pepper, as they watch poor travelers navigate this winding course? Fear not, fair reader, for services herein are passable, mayhap even good, with taverns, eateries, and shoppes aplenty. Yet, why doth others bemoan their lack? A tapster, a victual, a telly, Dramamine, the National Enquirer, and that horseshoe-shaped cushion which doth make me feel the fool whenever I produce it - these be all I require."

"Four fifths of sweet peril doth lie within these confections,
Oh my, how sugar doth entice with its alluring presence!
Bars of delight, a feast for the taste buds, how they do beckon,
Yet, alack, I fear for my waistline, should I partake too often.
For in town, on business I do travel, and thus, my access
To these delectable treats, doth bring me joy, yet also fear,
Lest I succumb to their sweet allure, and my pants no longer fit,
And I, in shame, must purchase new garb, to hide my plight."

"Hark! What light through yonder terminal breaks?
A chicken and biscuits doth my hunger slake.
In sooth, 'tis a fine repast, fit for a king,
Or e'en a poet, such as I, in flight.

Well done, fair North Carolina, thy victuals be
A worthy sustenance for travelers such as me.
Keep up the excellent work, that all may see
Thy bounty and generosity, in abundance free."

"Hark! What wonders lie within this gaming hall,
A space so fresh and fair, it doth enthrall.
