The pits, so modern and sleek, do shine,
And public restrooms, new and fine.
A food court, inviting and neat,
Doth offer sustenance, fit for a treat.
Though old, this place doth have a new face,
A testament to its enduring grace.
May fortune smile upon this place,
And keep its spirit in its chosen space."

"Hark, good sir or madam, let it be known,  
This Trader Joe's doth offer wares most fine and bright.  
Their parking lot, alas, doth leave much to be desired,  
A place where insurance premiums should be required.  

In truth, I park afar, to avoid the fray,  
Lest elderly patrons doth crash and play the day.  
But fear not, dear friends, for this doth not deter,  
My love for this TJ's, which doth be near my chamber.  
I shall return, again and again, to savor  
Their goods, and perhaps, a parking spot to favor."

"Ah, carbo-licious delight! This morn, I didst meet fair Tonya P,
For a brief bagel, and oh, how sweet!
Crunchy, toasted bagels, sesame seeded,
With creamy schmear, homemade indeed.

Inside Poppy's, cozy tables abound,
And outdoors, a patio, where Riley, my hound,
Didst enjoy bagel bits, with gleeful sound.
Though noisy cars didst pass by, unbound,
I savored my bagel, with joy profound.

Next time I'm near, I shall return,
To Poppy's, and partake of their burn.
A toasty bagel, and cream cheese, by the pound,
Shall be mine, and my heart, it shall astound."

"Hark! I've visited Five Guys in three fair states,
And still, my love for it doth not abate.
A Southern California native, In-N-Out was my fate,
But Obama's visit did my taste buds ignite.
Their burgers, full of flavor, won my heart,
Though In-N-Out's fries, my soul doth still part.
But still, I'll return, for Five Guys doth reign,
A true delight, worth every single penny gained."

"French fries, oh how my mind doth dwell on thee!
Batter-dipped, I do suspect, before they didst fry.
A buffalo chicken sandwich, verily, didst please,
And large the menu, with options for all to seize.
Open and airy, fit for groups to gather round,
With televisions many, for sporting events profound.
Thou art not unlike an Applebee's, I must confess,
Yet still, I shall return, for those fries, I must possess."

"Hark! What wonders lie within Buca Di Beppo's walls,
Their dishes vast, their flavors rich and full.
A feast fit for a king, or so it seems,
Yet portioned for but two or four, it teems.
But fear not, for the pasta's cooked to perfection,
And sauces savory, a true delightful fusion.
This place, so crowded, doth require a reservation,
For dinner hours, a wise decision, 'tis my observation."

"Verily, a feast most fair doth lie within this hall,
Where sushi and teppan, both great and small, do please.
The servers, gracious and kind, do tend to our needs,
And appetizers, delicious, do our taste buds feed.

Alas, the prices, somewhat steep they be,
But fear not, for coupons, locals may see.
A roll, tofu, filet, seaweed salad, and teppan too,
All dishes, vegetarian, that our hunger doth subdue.

So come, my friends, and partake in this treat,
For in this restaurant, a meal most meet, doth await."

"Oyshi Sushi, thou hast taken my sushi innocence! Prices, oh how I wish they were lower, alas, hope doth spring eternal. AYCE, the surest path for a feast with friends, lest ye worry o'er dishes in the back, for some may partake too freely. Alas, there be those whose pockets do not match their palates, and thus, we find ourselves at Oyshi. 

Service, a hit or miss affair, some servers, kind and attentive, others, lacking in their duties. Take-out, a viable option, indeed. 

Alack, no half-orders here, and far from the strip it be, a double-edged sword, for though the wait be long, 'tis worth the journey. Mussels, Love Affair, Lobster Fair, Oyshi Roll, and Japanese Lasagna, my heart doth sing with joy at their mention!"

"Hark! This eatery, since its opening day,  
Hath been our choice, for every meal a play.  
Teppan chefs, with wit and charm, prepare  
Our feast, a spectacle beyond compare.  
Barry and Ahn, the owners, friendly be,  
They roam the floor, ensuring all's well, you see.  
Regulars they recall, with joy they greet,  
And welcome back, with warmth and sweet treat.  
Happy Hour menu, diverse and fine,  
Sushi, fresh as morning dew, doth shine.  
Some say loud, but in mirth and delight,  
Teppan tables, laughter doth ignite.  
Arizona sunset, on patio vast,  
A sight to behold, a moment to savor at last.  
We've supped here oft, twice a week, mayhap,  
And shall continue, forsooth, this merry habit."

"Hark, what cheer! We doth arrive on Tuesday eve,
For celebration feast, our bellies to relieve.
Groupon, the wondrous deal, doth grant us boon,
Two for $36, a price most fair and soon.

Afore we sat, our visage doth adorn the screen,
A smile, a laugh, a moment of pure delight, 'twas seen.
The fare, a medley of diverse sorts, doth please,
Salads, soups, Mex, Mid-East, Asian, Americ, Italian treats.

AYCD, the drinks, doth flow like liquid gold,
Beer, wine, champagne, life's nectar, stories untold.
Neyo, the ladies doth agree, with nods and grins,
The strawberry crumb cupcake, a sweet delight within.

Cotton candy, a treat for younglings, doth bring joy,
No crab legs, alas, but sushi, a poor employ.
Mexican, salads, American, doth make up the rest,
Drinks, the highlight, food, a middling quest.

Thirty-six, the sum, or eighteen per head,
A fair price, for victuals and potions, so dread.
Tis true, the food, not bad, but average, we find,
Yet, drinks, most satisfying, the mind doth unwind."

"Hark! A tale of culinary delight,
In a place that's not quite bakery, nor quite right.
A sterile cafe, with bread and pastries galore,
But cozy, it is not, that's for sure.

I sat with a friend from Bosnia, who did order for me,
A dish called cevapi, a sight to see.
A round bread, freshly baked, hot and oiled,
Cut in half, like a burger, but no patty, just sausage filled.

The bread was delicious, the sausage tasty too,
But alas, I could not finish, my belly was not accustomed to.
I'd do it again, but next time, I'd save some room,
For those tasty pastries, that caught my eye, in the Bosnian bakery's gloom.

The owners were kind, but the service, oh so strange,
No checks on you, just tell them what you'll have, and pay, no range.
I liked it well, as a guest in their domain,
No need for Hooters' waitresses, here, all is serene."

"Hark, what speedy service doth this place possess!
The atmosphere, it doth delight and bless.
A sandwich named Leo's, I didst partake,
And found it to be a most excellent choice, by my troth.
Even the water, it doth taste most fine and sweet.
But alas, a wait list, they have not mastered yet,
It seemeth unorganized, and caused some discontent.
Thus, four stars, I do give, for now, I pray,
That they may learn, and their wait list, arrange in array."

"Hark! This grocery store doth please me well,
With customer service that doth excel.
The cashier lines, they doth move apace,
Never more than two, in this place.

Organic veggies, they doth have in store,
Though few in number, quality doth soar.
A fine selection of beer, they doth proffer,
Beyond the common brands, a true treasure trove.

And baking supplies, they doth abound,
As good as any, in this fair town.
So, I shall make a point, to come hither,
To shop and savor, in this grocery ether."

"Four stars, I give to this place,
For service most kind and fair of face.
Their sandwiches and pizza, I have tried,
And found them to be just satisfactory.
But the staff, oh so pleasant and bright,
Maketh my visit a joyous sight."

"Verily, the service here doth please me well,
Though prices be steep, 'twill not deter me still.
Two omelets for eighty coins, and drinks beside,
No ale, but juice and coffee, shall be my guide.

In Las Vegas, all things come with a cost,
Yet food, oh food, doth make my heart feel lost.
By the pool we did dine, and lingered long,
For outside seats, a short stroll did take us throng.
The patio, alas, doth not always stay open wide,
But still, 'twas worth it, to bask in sunshine's pride."

"A bustling, vibrant tavern, full of cheer and delight,  
With flavorsome Mexican dishes, priced just right.  
The working class, in droves, do come to dine,  
For they know well the value of a hearty meal divine."

"Verily, a most excellent repast we didst enjoy, my daughter and I, at this establishment. Our victuals, in sooth, didst delight us, for they were prepared with great skill and care. A capri sandwich on ciabatta, I didst partake of, and my daughter, a turkey and bacon on ciabatta, didst savor. The young man who didst attend to us, his name I didst not gather, but his demeanor was most pleasant and helpful. He didst answer all our queries with great patience and cheer. We shall, anon, return to this place, forsooth."

"Hark! Today, I chanced upon Sushi Style,  
For a midday meal, a savory trial.  
Though crowded, the place did not astound,  
With waitstaff swift, and tables found.  
A refreshing draught of iced tea, sweet,  
Did grace my lips, a pleasing treat.  
A tootsie roll, so delectable and fine,  
Eel sauce and crab, a flavor divine.  
An Arizona roll, a culinary delight,  
left me in awe, with appetite ignited.  
This place, a gem, doth rival Yen's domain,  
With choices vast, and service humane."

"Hark, good sir! I do confess,
This place doth hold a special charm,
For Tina, she who doth possess
The skill to make my nails disarm.

A little out of my way, 'tis true,
But still, the best place I've found anew,
She doth make them even, thin and neat,
As I desire, her skills to greet.

Three weeks, alas! That's all I can,
Betwixt each fill, her art to scan,
But still, her work doth please me well,
And prices, fair, that doth compel.

So, gentle reader, take my word,
And visit this place, thou art implored,
For Tina's touch doth make it divine,
And thou shalt leave, in love, entwined."

"A feast most wondrous, fit for royalty,
Their lunch buffet, a steal, a verity!
For just a few coins, a meal most fair,
With choices many, to satisfy thy glare.

Vegetarian dishes, for those who abstain,
And meat, for those who do not refrain,
Chicken, pork, and beef, all make an appearance,
A spread most generous, without reluctance.

But wait, there's more! The Naan bread, oh so fine,
Fresh from the oven, straight to thine,
A taste so sweet, it doth astound,
Leaving thee in awe, and quite profound.

Yet, beware, dear friend, for this repast,
Doth bring a curse, a woeful past,
For after consumption, a nap thou shalt require,
A rest most needed, to quench the fire."

"A hearty welcome didst we receive, with service most kind and true. A tour of the premises didst they provide, most informative and new. Alas, the beer garden lay dormant, locked in winter's chill, yet still we savored brews of finest quality, our thirst to fulfill."

"Verily, 'tis a place most wondrous, where bagels doth reign supreme. A breakfast haven, by my troth, with challah that doth please, save when 'tis a tad suspect, as my Jewish friend doth say. But fear not, fair maiden, for Chompies bagels thou mayst find at yonder market, an added boon indeed."

"Hark, good sir, to Los Dos's grand delight,  
A Chimichanga most wondrous in sight.  
Deep-fried and garnished with verdant green,  
Guacamole, sour cream, and chili serene.  
A feast fit for monarchs, a treat for the taste,  
Worthy of praise, and a dish of great haste.  
Alas, if they offered refills of chips and salsa,  
Their fame would spread far, like a mighty river's pulse.  
But still, their margaritas and brews are fine,  
A drink to savor, a pleasure divine."

"In fair Chicago, this chain didst reign,
My go-to place, a culinary gain.
Now in Pittsburgh's downtown, it doth please,
A familiar taste, that doth never cease.

Consistency, a franchise's aim,
In quality and taste, they doth proclaim.
I knew what to expect, 'twas no surprise,
Their affordability, a welcome prize.

Swift service, a bonus, indeed,
A trifecta, hard to find, with speed.
Four stars, I give, for its nearness to my work,
A convenient spot, that doth save me from the murk."

"Twas a quest of sorts, to find this place,
But worth the effort, we didst embrace.
Great tacos, indeed, and a chef so kind,
We shall return, for more to find."

"Hark, my dearest! This Wendy's, newly adorned,
Didst catch our eye, and we didst decide
To step inside and view the changes made.
The remodel, quite extensive, hath rearranged
The way one orders and doth pick up their fare.
Now, in one place, thou doth order thy meal,
And in another, thou doth retrieve it, anon.
The dining space, once drab and lackluster,
Hath been transformed, with new tables, a fresh coat of paint,
Even a tiny corner for the little ones to play.
And, by the way, good sir, Wi-Fi is available,
For those who wish to surf the net, while they dine."

"Tis nigh on time for luncheon, and yonder eatery doth seem a pleasant place to partake of victuals. The cost, I do perceive, is not exorbitant, and the surroundings, most fair and bright. Alas, the variety of dishes, doth leave somewhat to be desired, yet shall we make do, for 'tis a meal most simple, and our bellies, they do cry out for sustenance."

"In fair Phoenix, St. Francis doth reign,
A place of brunch, most wondrous and fair.
With atmosphere of class and grace,
It doth entice, and doth embrace.

American fare, with flavors bold,
Doth fill the menu, young and old.
A pinch of this, a pull of that,
Doth make each dish, a culinary chat.

Good brew, and mimosas too,
Doth flow, as if from heav'n didst break through.
Bloody Marys, for those who dare,
Doth add a spicy zest to the air.

And for the young, a treat doth wait,
Kids under ten, do dine for free, a fate.
The staff, so friendly and kind,
Doth serve with grace, and doth unwind.

Slow service, some may say,
But I, myself, have never nay.
The food, awhile to come, doth take,
But worth the wait, forsooth, the cake.

Eggs benedict, my heart doth sing,
With salmon, hollandaise, a joy to bring.
Pork chile verde, spicy and true,
Doth satisfy, and doth renew.

Cioppino, a stew of the sea,
Doth warm the soul, and doth set free.
With bread, a feast, for all to share,
And leave, with full bellies, and a cheer.

Happy hour, with friends, I've spent,
Appetizers, drinks, and merriment.
The fire on the patio, doth glow,
And warmth, doth spread, as the night doth grow."

"Hark! Switch doth offer diverse victuals, ranging from wholesome fare to hearty indulgence. Their menu, a true potpourri, hath ne'er failed to impress. Generous portions, at a fair cost, doth satisfy my hunger. Service, too, doth please, with nary a frown or scowl. My favorites? Mac and cheese, rich and creamy, with penne pasta; caprese sandwich, with fresh pesto vinaigrette; and a classic burger, unpretentious, yet full of flavor. And should thou seek to quaff a few, their drink specials, on Sundays, are most excellent. Carafes of mimosas and bloody marys, for a mere $3, doth make merry thy day!"

"Five years have we been patrons of this chain,
Their victuals and potions we do proclaim.
This place, though new, doth bustle with activity,
Yet staffing levels, on weekends, do vary.
A wait of twenty minutes, sometimes doth occur,
But generally, 'tis less than five, forsooth.

Their fare and drinks, most excellent, I say,
But cleanliness, a problem, doth persist.
In particular, the privy, ne'er doth shine,
My children, young, I dare not let them incline.

'Tis vexing, indeed, for staff, quite friendly,
And manager, seemingly, most capable, doth appear.
Yet, how the single bathroom, doth escape their eye?
A mystery, it doth remain, and cause me dismay.

Despite this flaw, a favorite still, 'tis true,
We visit oft, our loyalty, unshaken, doth endure."

Hark! 'Tis a tale of Pho Viet Nam, a place most fair,
Where soups and servings do delight beyond compare.
A weekly visit, give or take, doth prove their worth,
For consistency, a virtue, doth forever birth.

The pho, a soup of note, doth please the taste,
Improved, yet still, above all others in haste.
In busy times or slow, the service doth shine,
A testament to crew and staff, most divine.

Chandler's gem, this Vietnamese delight,
Doth bring us joy, with each passing night.
So here's to thee, Pho Viet Nam, and all thy kin,
May your endeavors flourish, as doth your pho within.

"Hark! If thou dost seek familiar spices and groceries,
Ask any Asian, and they shall reveal,
A place where cultures meet, in aisles so neat,
With labels clear, for all to conceive.

Not just for Asians, but all may come,
And find their need, in this vast domain,
Of 'water animals', fresh baked treats,
And bubble tea, to quench thy thirst and heat.

A small dining space, with Chinese fare,
Doth serve, and make thy taste buds aware,
That this place, though far, is worth the quest,
For all thy Asian cuisine requests."

"Marry, how strange it doth seem to mine eyes,
That any soul would hold In-N-Out in higher esteem,
Than Lenny's, where the patties be plump and full of life,
The cheese, a rich and creamy delight, doth make me swoon,
And fries, oh fries, so crispy and golden brown,
Do leave In-N-Out's offering in the dust, I do avow.

For though the burger of In-N-Out may taste fair,
'Tis naught but a shadow of Lenny's finest fare,
Whose patties beefy, cheese a noble wheel,
And fries, a hundredfold better, doth reveal.

So, nay, I do not think In-N-Out doth reign supreme,
For Lenny's, in my heart, doth hold the crown, it doth seem."

"Alas, I knew not of health insurance's grace,
So paid I must for dental services' embrace.
Compared to others in the area, the cost did seem fair,
And lo! An internet coupon, $100 off to spare.
Biltmore Commons Dental Care, its name did ring,
With Google's praise, my doubts did quickly cling.
I called at dawn, an appointment soon didst make,
Perhaps fortune smiled upon me, forsooth, the stake.
Dr. Balestrino, skilled in his craft, did say,
My fillings needed tending, come what may.
He explained his work, my queries did allay,
And now, content I am, this dentist visit to play.
Back shall I come, in six months' time, to keep,
My teeth clean, and thus, my smile, to reap."

"A place most dear, where we do often doth procure  
Our noontide meal, with naught but joy and cheer.  
Their sandwiches and salads, a feast for our taste,  
Do please us well, and ne'er do we find waste.  
Their service, too, doth merit our highest praise,  
For courteous folk, with smiles upon their faces.  
And though we have not tried each dish they bear,  
We know not any that doth not bring us cheer."

"Methinks I am a fan of Yoforia, indeed,
These yogurt shops spring up like weeds in seed,
A clever concept, self-serve, then weigh,
The price and flavor, a wondrous array.

At times, the queue doth stretch and wind,
But fear not, for it moveth swiftly, kind,
And if thou art impatient, take a stroll,
Around the mall, and let the line dwindle, whole."

"Methinks 'tis a grand gymnasium indeed,
With facilities most fair and ample space.
But alas, I didst encounter a slight quirk,
When I, a member, could not gain entrance,
For want of my I.D., a woeful mistake.
I voiced my discontent, and all was well,
The issue resolved, my grief didst quickly flee.
Yet, mark this well, good sirs and madams,
The customer service, a trifle lacking,
And some employees, their courtesy not always apt.
But fear not, for the rest, all doth excel,
E'en at midnight, when the crowds doth dwindle,
And lo, 'tis open twenty-four hours, a boon most bountiful."

"Fair maidens, with faces so bright,
Bring forth sustenance, a wondrous sight.
Their portions, most generous and vast,
Do fill my belly, and make it fast.

Alas, their cooking, not the best,
Yet still, it doth satisfy my quest.
I vow to eat but half, and save,
The rest for later, a virtuous brave.

But alack, my will, it doth fail,
For I devour it all, without bail.
That food, so tasty, doth ensnare,
My senses, and maketh me its care."

"Hark, my love and I do bide our time at Cosmpolitan's halls,
Where we have dined upon their bounteous brunch, with naught but praise for all.
The victuals, fresh and varied, do please our taste,
And leave us sated, save for sweets, which we do crave with haste.

But lo, the wait to sit, doth prove a vexing woe,
For though the tables lie in wait, empty and aglow,
The staff, they dally, and do keep us in suspense,
Leaving us to pine, in eager expectation's tense.

Yet still, the fare, it doth delight, and worth the wait,
So heed my words, and save a space, for sweet dessert's treat."

"Hark! What grumbling do mine ears perceive? 
Aye, 'tis the crowd, with disdain they do conceive, 
This place, they say, doth reek of pretence, 
But, my dear friends, that's its charm, in truth, it doth dispense. 

The layout, neat and tidy, doth impress, 
And samples, freely given, do delight, 
But alas, the line, on weekends, doth grow long, 
So come, my friends, on weekdays, and thus, thy wait, doth shorten. 

The capsules, too, doth Nespresso take, 
For recycling, and thy data, doth it make, 
No need to recall, each detail, by thine own mind, 
For they, in files, doth keep, thy information, so kind. 

Oh, how Nespresso doth improve my morn, 
With coffee, rich and smooth, my day, doth adorn, 
So here, I'll stay, and savour, each delight, 
In this, my haven, free from trouble and fright."

"This Starbucks' layout doth please mine eyes,
With ample space for all to sit and sip.
But, alas! On our visit, the team didst not
Keep the place clean, as it should be.
The trash can o'erflowed, and tables unwipe,
A sight most foul, and displeasing to mine sight.
Yet, the staff were friendly, and that doth count,
For friendliness doth weigh heavy in mine book.
So, four stars doth this Starbucks receive,
But, methinks they should attend to the environment with greater zeal,
And ensure that food items be stocked aright,
That they may earn the full five stars, anon."

"A feast most wondrous, fit for royalty,
The buffet's spread, a true delight.
Some dishes, bold and full of zest,
Others, mild, yet still a joy to taste.
Mango ice cream, sweet and pure,
But mango lassi, oh, how it's obscured!
Whipped cream, a needless addition,
Detracts from the drink's true sensation.
Staff, attentive and most kind,
Eager to serve, their guests they find.
Curry, not fiery hot, but still,
A blend of spices, skillfully wrought."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous sight,
This Bandera, where I do take flight.
In days of yore, I've supped there oft,
But one dish doth stand out, a true gem aloft.
Their Dip Duo, with chips of tortilla, doth delight,
And Mojitos, strong and full of zest, doth ignite.
A fine place, Bandera, to begin the night,
With appetizers savory, and drinks that doth excite."

"Methinks my dearest friend didst come to Vegas for a day,
To visit me and see the wondrous sights,
We went to dine and have a drink or two,
At one of the new hotels, with grand delight.

We shared a pizza, grilled with veggies galore,
And I didst order a cocktail, special and more,
With Grey Goose, lime, mint, and water, a fine blend,
'Twas truly yummy, my taste buds didst attend.

My friend didst have a margarita, on the rocks,
And didst enjoy it so much, she had three, no shocks,
For she was on holiday, and didst wish to play,
And the service was good, with nary a fray.

The views outside were stunning, a true sight to behold,
A fitting end to our merry day, so bold."

In fair Montreal, where China Town doth meet the eye,
A Dim Sum place doth lie, within a mall's embrace.
The food, though greasy, doth please the palate well,
And atmosphere, fitting for a Dim Sum spell.

Many have compared this place to others far and wide,
But I, who've had Dim Sum in Shanghai's streets, do find
It comparable, in its own humble, modest way,
To those in cities grand, where Chinese cuisine doth sway.

Yet, in my search for xiaolongbao, steamed with care,
I seek a place, like Din Tai Fung, beyond compare.
For though Shanghai may boast both good and bad,
I crave a taste that's truly authentic, not so sad.

"In this fair establishment, the setting doth please,
With ample space for rest and relaxation's ease.
The service, too, doth shine with friendliness and grace,
Eager to guide thy choices with a smile on their face.

The food, oh how divine! A steak of such quality,
Thy taste buds shall dance with joy and revelry.
But, alas, the mushrooms, they didst not impress,
For they upon my tongue didst leave a foul mess.

Yet still, this place doth earn my highest praise,
For steak and service, both doth bring delight.
So, gentle reader, heed my words of cheer,
And visit here, thou shalt not regret, I swear."

"Methinks I do adore Thai victuals, my dear. 'Tis a place of great renown, hath won acclaim in years past, a true delight for the taste buds, by Jove! Two things doth please me well, good sir. Firstly, 'tis a popular haunt, full of merriment and cheer. Secondly, the cuisine, authentic Thai, doth tickle mine fancy, with dishes such as Pad Thai, red curry, numba 10 spicy, and mint beef, all delectable, by the stars! Their Thai Iced tea, a refreshing draught, doth complement the feast, with nary a trace of oversweetness, praise the heavens! The staff, a friendly bunch, doth attend to thy needs with grace and aplomb. The price, quite reasonable, doth fit within thy means, good sir. In conclusion, 'tis an establishment of elegance, a true gem, worthy of thy patronage."

"Methinks 'tis ever fair to witness a venture thrive,
By virtue of its noble deeds, doth it ascend.
A restaurant, this, which doth provide a feast,
In truth, a bounty, worthy of praise, doth yield.

My spouse and I, didst partake of the Cobb,
A salad, most wondrous, our taste buds didst rob.
The venue, once home to eateries past,
Didst falter, due to flaws, in their feast.

Toast, a name, doth prove the site, not at fault,
Their victuals, of quality, didst make their vault.
Though, in my mind, a quibble doth persist,
The din, it grew, to such a level, speech didst resist.
A byproduct, perchance, of their triumph grand,
Yet, still, a hindrance, to converse, in this land."

"Methinks I've visited this fair store ten times in two years past,
And each time, good service have I found, and cheerful chat,
Their wares of women's running gear and yoga attire, most vast,
Have brought me joy, and made my heart feel light and free.

If e'er a return or exchange didst need to be made,
'Twas done with haste and smiles, and no ill will displayed.
I do confess, my dear, this shop doth hold a special place,
In my heart, for its kind folk and their gentle grace."

"Oh, fair sir or madam, do thou seek  
The Kobe sliders, for they be most divine.  
A craving doth consume me, night and day,  
For those delectable morsels, so fine and gay.  
And with a BBQ dipping sauce, they doth come,  
A flavor so rich, it doth leave one undone.  
But alack, the wait, it doth seem so long,  
For on the weekends, 'tis a crowded throng.  
And though the outdoor seats, they doth appear,  
So inviting, yet they doth disappear.  
A pool and fountains, they doth grace the scene,  
But for a table, one must wait, I ween.  
Yet fear not, for a full bar doth abide,  
In this fair establishment, where one may reside.  
And thus, my friends, I doth recommend,  
The cobb salad, chili, turkey club, and cheese fond.  
For though the prices be a bit on the steep,  
The quality of the fare, doth make it worthwhile to keep."

In sooth, fair Vdara doth provide a peaceful respite from the Strip's maddening crowd, with spacious chambers, diligent service, and pleasant amenities. Twice have I graced its halls, and each time, I found solace in its tranquil embrace. The rooms, indeed, are capacious, accommodating three travelers with ease. A blessing, that, for those who seek refuge from the din and smoke of yonder casinos.

Located at the southern end of the Strip, Vdara doth enjoy a secluded spot, removed from the fray. A trifle distant, mayhap, yet naught but a brief stroll doth separate it from Bellagio's grand entrance. Cosmopolitan, alack, doth require a somewhat longer trek, though hardly an insurmountable feat.

Methinks, dear friend, that Vdara doth cater to those who seek a calmer Vegas experience. The pool, in sooth, doth mirror the hotel's serene ambiance, a haven from the riotous revelry that doth characterize other such watering holes.

Verily, I shall return anon, for Vdara hath won my heart with its gentle charms. And, mark my words, thou shalt find it easily, shouldst thou seek a mystery hotel on Hotwire, with naught but a southward Strip locale, five stars, and a non-gaming atmosphere to guide thee. Farewell, Las Vegas, until we meet again!

"Hark, fair friends! Last week, I chanced upon AAP,
For luncheon, and oh, what joy didst it bring!
The hour was late, and few didst dine within,
So I, a hostess, didst choose my seat with ease.
A comfy booth, so large and plush, didst beckon me,
And thus, I sat, with nary a soul to trouble thee.

My server, swift and kind, didst tend to me,
And asked if I had questions, as well as my decree.
The soft pretzel, with beer cheese, didst catch mine eye,
And thus, I ordered it, with haste, didst not deny.
'Twas large, indeed, and hot, with crunch outside,
And soft within, a treat, most satisfying, I avow.

Still, hunger pangs didst plague me, so I didst add,
A spinach salad, with tomato, cranberries, and feta, not bad.
A nut, perhaps, to change the texture, might be nice,
But overall, 'twas a salad, most pleasant, and quite nice.

They have, it seems, drink specials, through the week,
A place, so grand, where one might watch a game, with ease.
Four stars, I gave, for more lunch options, they shouldst seek,
Beyond salads, sandwiches, and entrees, which start at five, I do beseech.

Yet, verily, 'twas great, and I shall return, anon,
To AAP, where food, and drink, didst make my day, so bright and sun."

"O, how glad we were to find this place ere we did depart from Vegas! Our garb was grimy, yet the folk within were similarly attired. 'Tis nigh the Strip, thou see, and thus the proprietors must be aware of its appeal.

The lady of the house, most kind and fair, didst offer us additional victuals, for none of us didst desire the meatballs. Praised be her name! Though, alack, she didst forget my comrade's order, and 'twas somewhat awry.

The pho, it didst taste of authenticity, or so I thought, for I am not well-versed in such culinary delights. Yet, I didst enjoy it heartily, mayhap due to mine hangover, which didst make me feel most dire.

But lo, the path to the privy didst lead through the kitchen, and that didst cause me some dismay. Alas, I do not relish such proximity to the cooking domain."

"Hark, my friends, let me share with thee  
My thoughts on Teharu, a place to be  
A revolving sushi bar, a curious sight  
But fear not, for the food doth ignite  

The skeptic within me didst rear its head  
But Yelp's reviews didst ease my doubts instead  
I found myself in love with the place  
Where food doth roll by, and laughter doth embrace  

A pennywise man, I do adore  
Well-made food, that doth taste divine, and more  
At Teharu, such treasures doth abound  
Plates of wonder, priced but a few pounds  

Beer floweth freely, in great quantity  
Fresh fish, a must, for health's sweet clarity  
So heed my words, dear friends, and take a seat  
At Teharu, where sushi doth meet thy feet."

"Hark, my dearest friend, to this most wondrous place,
Where steaks of finest quality do grace the plate.
The staff, so friendly, doth attend to our needs,
And keep the premises in neatness and good deeds.

We opt for steak, sans butter, a wise choice indeed,
For calories, it doth cut, and taste, it doth not impede.
The veggies, fresh and crisp, do complement the dish,
With seasonings that doth make our taste buds thrill and wish.

The brown bread, warm and savory, doth start the feast,
A perfect pairing for the steak, a true delight.
The ambiance, cozy and intimate, doth make for love,
In booths around the bar, a date night, sent from above.

Verily, a place of excellence, in every way,
A culinary delight, that doth make our day."

"Methinks 'tis fortunate indeed to have this eatery nigh my dwelling place! Aye, what doth make it even more desirable, good sirs, were it to possess a patio, whereupon mine own canine companion might join me. A fair price, I say, and verily, the red curry didst please mine taste buds."

Halt! Good sir or madam, prithee tarry awhile,
And purchase yonder dill Havarti, 'tis worth thine while.
Taste a morsel, nay, taste many, forsooth,
Thou shalt find others that please thee, in truth.

"Hark! Le Petit Moulinsart, a place so quaint,
In Vieux Montreal, upon Rue St Paul's street,
A haven for those seeking late repast,
With Belgian fare, their specialty, no doubt.

The name, from comic strip of old,
Moulinsart, a chateau of great renown,
And thus, the restaurant doth follow suit,
With mussels, their crowning glory, no doubt.

Steamed in broths of varied hue,
Four dishes we did try, anon,
Two stood out, excelling all the rest,
But choose any, and thou shalt be blessed.

For at LPM, they cook with skill and care,
Mussels plump, tender, and juicy, beyond compare,
Baguettes, complimentary, to soak up the broth,
A salad, to round off the meal, in good health.

Verily, the second-best mussels, I do swear,
Bertha's, in Fells Point, doth hold the first chair."

"Hark, what wondrous feast doth lie before mine eyes!
A veritable cornucopia of greasy delights,
Fried to a golden crisp, most delectable and fine.
The white trash burger, with its fried pickle and onions,
Doth tempt my taste buds, and the sweet potato fries,
A culinary marvel, doth complete this gastronomic symphony.
I highly recommend these dishes, for they doth satisfy
And fill mine belly with delightful, savory joy."

"Our journey's end, the final station, doth lie
At SLS, the Lux tower wing, where we did rest
Easy 'twas for us to board the train, with naught
But a brief stroll from our lodgings to the platform's edge
We purchased passes for twenty-four hours, and thus
Didst ride the train to The Linq, with speed and grace
It was, my dear, a wondrous sight to see
So few folk on a Sunday, the carriage empty
Save for us, who laughed and chattered merrily
I do confess, I find great joy in riding trains
In daylight, when the sun doth shine, 'tis a delight
Pray, let us not forget, my love, to don flat shoes
Next time we venture forth, lest blisters doth arise."

"In sooth, a bright and airy space doth call thee in,
At corner of Saint-Laurent and Fairmount, 'twain doth spin.
At lunch, a mix of moms and babes, of power and grace,
Do gather, savoring each bite with joyous face.

The menu, brief and fair, doth offer much delight,
Grilled cheese, salads, charcuterie, a feast for sight.
Pastas, stews, and hash, upon the larger side,
Do fill the belly, and doth satisfy the soul's desire.

My corned beef hash, with egg sunnyside up,
Doth please my taste, and doth my hunger quench.
The beef, so juicy, flaky, and tender too,
Doth melt in mouth, a flavor most true.
Though price doth seem a bit steep, the portion, just right,
With arugula salad, a perfect blend of spice and might.

My friend, with salad and fries, doth have her fill,
A meal of choice, her lunch, she doth fulfill.
The fries, with mayo, soft and fluffy, a delight,
I could not resist, and ate near half that night."

"Fie upon Starbucks, I say!  Local businesses are where my heart doth lie.  Beehive's Bohemian Buzz, my drink of choice, doth rival any brew from Crazy Mocha's vault.  Their coffee, tea, and smoothies, all a delight, and desserts so sweet, they could feed a family of four with ease.  Alas, not good for a diabetic such as myself, alone and in need of sustenance. \n\nThis place, once known as Dancing Goats, hath changed its name a few times, Sip being one of its former monikers.  Now, Crazy Mocha, with its free internet, doth reign supreme across the Pittsburgh land, with a new location at the Carnegie Library, for all to see."

"A quick oil change didst require our presence,
And thus, a movie didst we decide to witness.
The line for tickets moved with haste and ease,
And friendly was the cashier, in truth, didst please.

The lobby, clean and well-kept, didst greet our eyes,
And helpful, the ticket taker, didst direct our prize.
Food, we didst not partake, for full were we,
But well-organized, the snack bar, didst seem to be.

The theater, in good repair, didst play its part,
Clean seats, a comfortable view, didst reach our heart.
Smaller, the auditorium, may have been,
Yet clear, the screen, didst make the movie seen.

In conclusion, an A, this place doth earn,
For pleasant, the experience, didst truly learn."

In this swanky bar, with cocktails fine and folk of note,
I chanced to sit, and watch the revelers quote,
Their antics wild, their tales did unfold,
As they sipped their drinks, stories to be told.

A DB, with flair, and purse of gold,
Bought Cristal, for two fair maidens bold,
And shot it down, with haste and speed,
As if the liquid fire, his thirst did need.

Oh, the shots of Cristal, how they flowed,
Like a river wild, that could not be slowed,
And after, regular shots, he did command,
As if his thirst, could never be tamed.

But fear not, dear friends, for this place,
Hath cocktails, of the finest grace,
With maraschino liquor, vodka, and rose wine,
Garnished with raspberries, three in a line.

The bartenders, skilled and quick,
Did serve with grace, and gentle trick,
Their craft, they knew, and with a smile,
Did make our night, most worthwhile.

"A fair establishment, indeed, for a hearty morning meal,
In the manner of America, or the Philippines, doth reveal.
The wait, though not too long, didst pass, as we didst bide our time,
And the red velvet pancakes, oh, how they didst shine!

A worthy venture, this eatery, for those who do seek,
A breakfast fit for a king, or a humble freeman, to speak.
So gather round, good friends, and partake in the cheer,
For here, in this place, doth lie a most excellent breakfast, my dear!"

"Hark! A tale of woe and sorrow doth unfold,
A store so grand, yet causes harm to others,
In this fair town, where commerce doth abound,
It doth destroy the small, and doth impound.

But fear not, dear reader, for all is not lost,
For within its walls, a treasure trove is found,
A selection vast, of all things outdoors,
Better than REI, in my humble opinion, found.

The staff, knowledgeable and kind, doth aid,
In finding what thou seekest, with speed and grace,
And though they lack the high-end gear, so fine,
For first-timers, 'tis a place divine.

So enter, dear stranger, and take a look,
For in this store, thy needs shall be fulfilled,
And though it doth harm others, do not fear,
For in its depths, thy heart shall be cheered."

"Marvelous sandwiches, priced so fair,  
At this establishment, thou shalt find,  
Tasty treats that doth please thine taste,  
And fill thy belly with delight.  

The number two, a triple decker,  
With turkey, pastrami, and rye,  
Doth stand out amongst the rest,  
A feast for thine eyes, and thine guest.  

So, if thou art in search of sustenance,  
That doth satisfy, and doth not dent,  
Thy purse, then look no further,  
For this place doth provide, in abundance."

"Verily, not so vile a choice, my friend,
Considering the scant options at hand.
The staff, in cheerful mood did tend,
With efficiency, to our each demand.
And lo, the victuals, hot and fresh,
Didst make their way to our eager flesh."

A most excellent inn, with service of the highest quality, I do declare. Well-appointed chambers for meetings and gatherings, and Wi-Fi that doth function with great haste. A bit pricey, perchance, yet still a worthy abode, save for the thrifty traveler, who might find a more budget-friendly option nearby, at the Marriott, a mere stone's throw away. (497 tokens)

"Hark! When e'er I seek my daily needs,
Fresh fruit, meat, seafood, and delicatessen,
And find them not at fresh and easy's store,
I venture forth to this place once more.
A better choice and quality, priced just right,
Doth make my shopping experience a delight.
But alas, there be some items, dear to me,
That fresh and easy, near my home, doth hold,
So there, my shopping journey doth begin and end,
For convenience's sake, my heart doth wend."

"Hark! What wondrous fish doth lie within this place?
Three of us didst partake in meals most fair,
Ono sandwich, tacos of fish, and chips of the sea.
A small venue, with ordering at the counter, 'twas,
Yet the atmosphere didst exude a Hawaiian glee.
The staff, so friendly and full of mirth, didst serve us well."

"Methinks my wife didst desire to dine at Macayo's,  
For their baja burritos, she didst have a great fondness.  
So off we went, to partake in their culinary delights,  
And sample their wares, in the hopes of a satisfying night.  

I ordered the poblano chile, stuffed full of chicken and cheese,  
In a crispy breading, that didst please mine eyes and taste.  
'Twas almost like a chile relleno, but crisper, and in my mind,  
Better than the rest, a true delight, so hard to find.  

My wife, her favorite dish, chile relleno, she didst crave,  
But my suggestion, she didst not take, and now she didst regret.  
She eyed my plate with longing, and I didst tease her so,  
Giving her a taste, of what she didst not know.  

We also had the green tamale bites, as an appetizer,  
With Baja sauce, they were a sweet and savory treat.  
Sweet masa balls, deep-fried, addictive, they were indeed,  
A pleasant surprise, the service, was good, our needs were met.  

The food, of high quality, the taste, didst satisfy,  
We shall return, to Macayo's, again, ere long, I do predict."

"This humble abode doth please mine eyes and taste,
With food of Hawaii, rich and of great haste.
The keepers here, kind souls they be,
And though the hall may lack finery, 'tis plain to see,
'Tis not their aim to serve luxurious feast,
But swift and savory meals, that do suffice.
For Chicken Katsu craving, this place doth hit,
A worthy stop, when hunger doth beset."

"Hark, good sirs, to my words of praise for Safeway,
A store most wondrous, where all needs are met in play.
This location, dear to me, doth hold a special place,
Where FnE and McDowell's Safeway cannot compare in grace.

One-stop shopping, indeed, it doth provide,
From US Bank to pharmacy, all necessities abide.
But alas, late night shoppers, take heed,
For slow checkout lines, a woeful deed.

Yet, fear not, for produce, fresh and fair,
Doth fill the shelves, a bounty beyond compare.
And certain products, always in stock,
A treasure trove, for which my heart doth knock."

"Upon our arrival at yon eatery, we were told 'twould be a brief wait ere our table was prepared. No bother, thought I, for my spouse and I did order potions at the bar, and waited patiently for our table to be readied. But lo, when our hostess did summon us to our table, she didst not proffer to convey our draughts thither. Alack, 'twas vexing indeed, for who doth wish to bear a martini glass, clad in heels and burdened with a purse, unto their seat? Yet, this aside, our repast did prove most delectable. The lobster bisque, which they did graciously partition for us, did taste divine, and we did share the rib eye, cooked to perfection, medium rare, and a side of risotto, lest we be o'erfilled. Our server and his minions did attend to us with care, and e'en hastened our victuals, that we might not miss our spectacle. Well done, good sirs!"

In fair Pittsburgh, there doth lie
A place of wonder, The Mattress Factory, where contemporary art doth thrive.
Within its walls, thou shalt find strange and wondrous sights,
A feast for thine eyes, and food for thought, by day or night.

'Tis said, an hour and a half shall pass, ere thou doth leave this place,
And in that time, thy mind shall be filled with wonder and amaze.
For in this hallowed hall, doth lie a trace of memory,
A web of black yarn, entwined, like threads of destiny.

And Turrell's pieces, they doth play with light,
On canvas, a different sight, a treat for thine eyes, a delight.
But fear not, good traveler, for admission doth cost but fifteen crowns,
And with a coupon, two for one, thy purse shall not be down.

So heed my words, and visit this place,
For in it, thou shalt find a wondrous, artistic grace.

"Hark! If thou find thyself in Newhaven's bounds,
Take heed of Porto and Fi, a place most profound.
A deli and cafe, where thou mayst partake
Of sustenance and drink, and tarry awhile, forsooth.

When I did toil in Granton's environs near,
My comrade and I would oft repair hither, dear.
For lunch, we'd savor, and our spirits lift,
For 'twas a treat, indeed, a moment to enrich our rift.

Their victuals, fine! They strive to source them local,
And such endeavor doth make each dish most palatable.
Even a humble sandwich, delectable and neat,
Doth satisfy thy hunger, and doth make thy spirit meet.

Their cakes, oh! How they doth delight mine eyes,
Chocolate and beetroot, a curious surprise.
Yet, fear not, fair traveler, for this odd pair,
Doth complement each other, beyond compare.

Busy, it may be, for the townsfolk do embrace,
This haven of gastronomy, with open arms and grace.
But wait, good sir, for 'tis worth the while,
To partake of Porto and Fi's gentle smile."

"Aye, fair traveler, thou hast found a place most rare,
Off the beaten path of Mill St., a culinary lair.
The victuals, fresh as the morning dew, didst delight,
Pad thai, a dish most wondrous, a true gastronomic sight.
Beef salad and spring rolls, a duet of flavors bold,
Didst stir within me a craving, a hunger most untold.
Each dish, a masterpiece, didst leave me in awe,
Alas, a draught of ale or wine, I didst not draw."

"Hark, my dear, what luck! A cafe near the stadium,
With friendly servers, charm, and glee.
The dining room was full, alas,
So out to the patio we did stray.

We ordered at the counter with ease,
And waited not long for our drinks with cheer.
I savored the Melon Mojito, oh so sweet,
My boyfriend's pulled pork sandwich, a treat to eat.

Great service, delectable fare,
A cozy atmosphere, beyond compare.
This cafe, a gem, for brunch or lunch,
I highly recommend, with no hunch."

"Verily, free Wi-Fi doth win my heart each time. Charging stations be few, yet rocking chairs abound. I've tarried here awhile, and each visit doth bring me joy. Fear not, good sirs, for Starbucks doth pepper this place, and coffee doth flow in abundance."

"Hark! Good sir, ask for Tommy, yon waiter most kind,
Whose service doth rival the gods in their prime.
Gigi, the maiden fair, doth greet thee with grace,
And a smile that doth light up the night like a sun's embrace.
Their menu, a veritable feast for the eyes,
Doth offer a choice of dishes most wondrous and wise.
But alas, their happy hour, though full of delight,
Doth lack in variety, and doth leave something to fight.
Yet fear not, for the Lotus Roll, a dish most divine,
Doth make up for all else, and doth shine like a shrine.
So go forth, my friend, and partake of this treat,
And may thy taste buds be blessed, and thy spirit be sweet."

"Hark! What happy hours doth this establishment boast?
And service most excellent, if fortune doth smile
Upon thee, and grant thee Aaron's guiding hand,
A place to sit, and rest thy weary feet awhile.
Methinks 'tis thanks they doth deserve, for longevity
In trade, a testament to their great worthiness."

"Methinks these donuts be most wondrous fair,
A sweet delight that doth my senses cheer.
If thou art on a diet, have but one,
And when thy guilt doth rise, have another, prithee,
To remind thee why thy indulgence was worth the fee."

"Hark! What merriment we found within this place,
A feast fit for a king, with food of grace.
Though slow in coming, 'twas worth the wait,
For flavors that did dance upon our plate.
The lentils, oh how they did delight,
And plantains, verily, a wondrous sight.
The beef, alack, a mite dry, yet full of zest,
A true delight, and worth the quest.
An eclectic menu, diverse and grand,
I do confess, I shall return to this land.
The owner, a gentleman of great renown,
Our server, friendly, helpful, and crowned.
This place, a gem, for lunch or eve's repast,
A choice most excellent, and one to savor fast."

"Hark! What wondrous feast doth lie before mine eyes?
A chimi of carne asada, by the gods, how prize!
Combo number twenty, crispy and full of savour,
With guacamole aplenty, a true gastronomic favour.
The staff, they sang and laughed in merry cheer,
A place most pleasant, and I shall visit here."

"Hark! A tale of South Point Hotel, I pray thee, listen well. 'Tis a place of wonder, a bit off the beaten path, yet all-inclusive, so thou needst not venture forth. Bowling, bingo, movies, casino, and more, they have it all. And lo, a daily Texas Hold'em tourney doth take place, a mere $55 buy-in, and I, myself, have emerged victorious thrice. Newer it may be, but clean and well-kept, it doth remain.

A word of caution, fair traveler, for on one visit, maintenance did cause a power outage in the dead of night. But fear not, for I, a wearer of CPAP, didst not even stir. Rooms, most affordable, and shouldst thou join their email list and players club, invitations to return at lower rates, thou shalt receive.

In conclusion, South Point Hotel, a gem it be, and highly recommended, by mine own hand, doth it stand."

"Hark, fair friends! I do declare,
In search of coffee, far and near,
I've traveled wide, both near and far,
From Seattle's misty skies to Hawaii's sun-kissed shore,
And back again, in quest of that sweet spot,
Where coffee flows, and service doth not falter.

In Maui, Honolulu Coffee Co., a gem didst shine,
With brews so rich, they doth rival the divine.
Ann Arbor's Common Cup, a cozy nook,
Didst serve with grace, and coffee most took.
Ypsilanti's Ugly Mug, a quaint abode,
Doth pour with skill, and atmosphere doth owe.
Bellingham's Black Drop, Lettered Streets, and Firehouse too,
Tony's Coffee, all didst please, with flavors anew.
Seattle's Vivace Espresso, a place of renown,
Doth brew with art, and taste doth crown.

Now, in Phoenix, Lux Coffee Bar doth rise,
With vibe so smooth, and atmosphere so wise.
The service, outstanding, doth greet with cheer,
Bakery/deli products, a delight, so pure and clear.
Beans, hand-roasted, in 'Employee Lounge', doth make,
Caramel shots, poured with skill, a sight to partake.
Milk, so stretched, so creamy, doth complement with ease,
Baristas, talented, doth craft with finesse.

Lux, oh Lux, doth have it all,
A coffee shop, where one wouldst book a fall.
Trust me, dear friends, it doth deliver,
In ambiance, coffee, and service, it doth surrender."

"Methinks 'twas fortune that didst guide me hither, led by friends and colleagues of mine own. Ne'er had I set foot within these walls, yet found I hospitality most kind and fare most delectable. A draught they call the shanty, didst please mine taste buds most ardently. And mark my words, good sirs, the chicken mole doth merit highest praise indeed."

"In Pittsburgh, there's none better, I do declare,
For pizza, six stars, beyond compare.
The other dishes, naught but air,
But beer, four stars, beyond despair.
Prices, two stars, yet still I pay,
For owner, five stars, in every way.
Employees, two stars, alack,
But timeliness, five stars, no lack.
I rate by taste, and thus it's clear,
Graziano's earns five stars, year by year.
My friends, from far, do come to partake,
And praise it loud, with no mistake.
Avoid the singles, I implore,
For they are made with lesser lore.
Go for the large, plain or cheese,
And savor each bite, with joy and ease."

"My love, she doth reside but a short distance hence,
A mere stones throw, as 'twere, from this fair place.
We dine here oft, mayhap thrice or four times a moon,
And ever do we find the service most excellent,
The victuals, too, of highest quality, I swear.
If thou hast visited Zipps, then know that Goldie's came first,
In this, the original, thou shalt not be disappointed."

"Amidst the bustling streets of Sin City, where vice doth reign supreme,
There lies a restaurant, most memorable, indeed, a gem.
For there, my love, didst propose to me, upon our fifth year's eve,
As we sat by the window, watching the fountains dance and the sun dip.

Their sauteed pork chops and filet mignon, oh how they did delight,
So tender, so juicy, a feast fit for a king, or a knight.
I sipped on berry champagne, while my love didst taste a mojito,
And the waiter, so kind, didst help set up the proposal, a true amigo.

Tears streamed down my face, as the dessert didst arrive,
A sweet surprise, that didst leave me in awe, and my heart full of joy.
A stranger, from afar, didst see my love propose, and didst bring us cheer,
Two glasses of champagne, to celebrate, and banish all fear.

Oh, how lucky were we, on that night, in that place,
To have found such a gem, a memory to embrace.
I shall return, again and again, to this restaurant so fine,
For it holds a special place, in my heart, and in my mind."

"Hark, good sir or madam, to my words of praise,
For yonder cafe, where coffee, beer, and wine doth flow,
In aid of refugees, 'tis owned by Catholic Charities,
And local artisans' wares, dost thou behold?

The atmosphere, so cozy and inviting, doth make one feel at home,
With coffee, tea, and pastries, all roasted, brewed, and baked,
Fresh fare, with local ingredients, doth grace the menu,
Pulled pork, tuna, salsa, chips, and salads, all delectable, I do declare.

A private room, for meetings and gatherings, doth await,
And on the second and fourth Tuesdays, music doth fill the air,
A showcase of talent, local voices, and instruments, doth play,
An intimate setting, for all to enjoy, in this fair place.

So, gentle reader, heed my words, and pay a visit,
To this establishment, where community doth flourish and thrive,
For in supporting it, thou doth support the refugees,
And in doing so, thy heart shall swell with joy, and spirit, alive."

My maiden voyage to Select Auto didst prove most pleasant,
And I shall surely return, God willing and the creek don't rise.
The staff, in their courtesy and care, didst attend to my needs,
And their customer service, it didst leave naught to be desired.

A fortnight past, my carriage didst require repair,
And Select Auto, they didst complete the task with dispatch and flair.
They kept me informed, with regular updates,
And even dealt with mine insurer, to grant me further grace.

They transported me to my rented steed,
And when the work was done, they didst take it back with speed.
I must confess, I didst not expect such finery,
In a place where cars are mended, but 'twas a sight to see.
Clean, modern, and with a touch of hipster charm,
It didst make my heart sing, like a lark in springtime's form.

Great joy didst I find, in this, my first encounter,
With Select Auto, and I shall not soon forget their tender.

A grand arena, spacious and wide,
With seats for five to seven thousand inside.
A place of comfort, with lounges so fine,
And food to savor, a feast divine.

'Tis a sight to behold, a vision fair,
With concerts of renowned Christian prayer.
Their sports, a delight, a competition grand,
And the Monsoon/Havoc section, a loyal band.

"Hark, this pizza place doth reign supreme,
On the East Coast, a gem of note,
I've dined within its walls, and fetched,
Their pies, with haste, to savor at home.

The quality, each time, doth stay the same,
A consistency that doth earn renown,
For those who crave a pie of worth,
And seek not disappointment, nor frown.

So, if thou art in search of pizza fine,
And dost desire a culinary find,
Look no further, for this place doth shine,
And leave thee not in doubt, or design."

"Hark! This eatery doth lie near my workplace,
Where my colleague and I do oft dine,
Or order in, for they do deliver,
And thus we found this culinary shrine.

Their service doth match the quality of their fare,
Which doth please mine taste buds beyond compare,
At prices fair, with flavors most rare,
They doth offer a loyalty card, with nary a care.

Oh, sweet potato fries and tots, how divine!
Blackened mahi mahi, a dish most fine,
But the signature sliders, they doth steal the show,
For all their dishes, I do give a hearty "Yea!"

This place, my friends, doth be my go-to spot,
For lunch, a quick and tasty lot,
In under an hour, I doth come and go,
With a full belly and a happy heart, I doth say "So!"

"Hark, my dearest wife and I didst decide
To climb Camelback Mountain, a feat most grand.
The path was steep and winding, a true test of endurance,
But we didst persevere, hand in hand.

I wore my trusty Nike shoes, a wise choice, no doubt,
For the descent was slippery, and treacherous, to boot.
We rose ere dawn, to beat the heat,
And reached the summit, by seven thirty, neat.

The day was Monday, and the park didst open late,
But we didst wait, patiently, our turn to fate.
The sun didst rise, and we didst start our way,
Down the mountain, by nine, in a brisk array.

A good hike, up and down, I must confess,
I loved it, indeed, with all my heart's excess."

"Fare thee well, good victuals, service most fair!
What more couldst thou ask for, pray tell?
A shorter wait, perchance, were it not so rare.
Forsooth, 'tis love that doth cause the delay,
As all do flock to savor thy delight.
My heart doth sing of praise for BC's sandwich,
And my dear spouse, he doth swear by eggs benedict.
This place, our Sunday brunch, doth reign supreme."

"Hark, what place is this? A haven for the weary traveler,
With breakfast fare that doth my hunger devour.
The service, swift and friendly, doth my heart sing,
And portion sizes, generous, my belly doth fling.
A fair price, indeed, for such a feast doth lie,
I shall return, anon, to savor more of their delight."

"Methought I spied a review that didst liken Gadzooks to Chipotle, and lo, upon mine own visit, I couldst see the truth in this comparison, in so much as the preparation of mine meal didst parallel that of the latter.  Aye, the menu doth boast but a few options, yet the choices for fillings didst multiply like a veritable cornucopia.  I didst partake of a green chili pork enchilada and a bison enchilada, both of which didst delight mine taste buds.  Verily, the bison didst rival any other I hath had, and the house-smashed guacamole didst prove a delectable accompaniment.  Fearing the noontide throng, I didst arrive at 11:30, yet the establishment didst already bustle with activity.  I didst secure the final parking space and the penultimate table within, and thank the stars, for the tables didst turn with all due speed, and the queue didst move apace.  For those who must await a table, misters doth grace the patio, providing a refreshing respite from the heat.  I shall return anon, and bring with me friends, that we may partake of this culinary delight once more."

"Methinks my wife and I didst seek to relocate from fair San Francisco, and thus didst require the services of a most excellent real estate group in the land of Scottsdale. Upon perusing reviews of great renown and surveying the website of The Hill Group, I didst determine that their expertise wouldst be the key to our success in purchasing our first home.

I must confess, good sirs, that I was most favorably impressed by all whom I didst encounter within The Hill Group, particularly the esteemed Steven James, whose fervent dedication to his craft didst know no bounds. Our requirements, I do assure thee, were quite particular and exacting, yet Steven, with his unwavering professionalism and unrelenting drive, didst rise to the challenge and didst succeed in finding for us a dwelling that didst meet with our utmost approval.

In sooth, I do believe that Steven's primary aim was to ensure that we, his clients, didst find a habitation that didst bring us joy and contentment, and in this, he didst not disappoint. My dear sir, I do express my sincerest gratitude for thy assistance in this matter, and I do wish thee all the best in thy future endeavors."

"Methinks, fair readers, I didst chance upon this establishment on a most fortunate day. Forsooth, the brew they call coffee, didst please mine taste, and service, swift and attentive, didst make me feel most welcome. Their chili, a dish of spicy delight, didst warm mine belly, and the decor, a blend of elegance and whimsy, didst charm mine eyes. Being a former dweller of that fair city, New York, I have had mine share of crepes, and thus, the Caprese I didst order, didst strike me as most skillfully prepared, and verily, quite tasty. And thus, I shall bring mine clients hither, for 'tis a place of moderate price, and moderate grandeur, nigh unto the hospital for children. In conclusion, 'tis a spot most suitable for those who seek a tranquil, yet delectable repast."

"Methinks 'twas wondrous care that we didst receive,
In ward A 3, where teams of excellence didst dwell.
From cleansers to attendants, nurses to servitors,
All were most kind, with hearts of gold, and gentle spirits.
Their smiles were contagious, their care, most tender,
Amidst the night, when darkness didst descend,
E'en then, their vigilance didst never slack,
For which, our gratitude doth know no end."

"Hark! What's this? A place to dine, and open wide,
Twenty-four hours a day, no need to hide.
Cheap too, compared to other feasts,
In Vegas, where excess is the least.

Oh, how the lines may stretch and grow,
But fear not, for they move apace, you know.
A must-visit spot, for hunger's pang,
Or drunken cravings, that won't let go.

So heed my words, fair traveler,
And make haste to this wondrous place,
For it shall soothe thy rumbling belly,
And ease thy wallet's heavy load, by grace."

"Ay, 'twas a joy to work with Eric and his men,
Their diligence and skill did make our garden glen,
A place of beauty, where we do take delight,
In the sweet flowers and trees that doth ignite.

Their plan, so clever, didst please us well,
And their execution, flawless, we must tell,
Save for a tiny glitch, a light that didst not glow,
But swiftly fixed, our worries didst they know.

We cannot praise them enough, so fine,
Their work, a true reflection of their design,
Thus, we do recommend this crew with cheer,
For gardens fair, they shall make it appear."

"Hark, what news is this? A grand opening deal most fair,
On tires, that doth make my heart sing with joy!
Big Rob, a man of great renown, didst serve me well,
With customer service that doth rival the skies.
And lo, they didst offer me water and coffee,
A generous gesture, that doth show their grace.
This place, methinks, is truly blessed,
For it doth possess a spirit of excellence."

"Verily, all the praise thou dost sing, 'tis true, my friend. This wondrous place doth serve the finest victuals, fit for a king! The guacamole-based green salsa, oh how grand, doth steal the show, I do declare. In Austin, Texas, we didst partake of this delectable delight, and by the names "green salsa" or "Salsa Dona" it was known. 'Tis a spicy treat, but fear not, for 'tis worth the trial. Hie thee hence, my friend, and partake of this culinary joy! Alas, the only drawback, a larger venue, to accommodate all, I do pray."

"Medusa, a hairdressing chain of renown,
In Edinburgh's city centre doth have its crown,
Two salons there be, and a third in Musselburgh,
Where beauty services and nails doth take their turn.

The Teviot salon, full of life and cheer,
Doth bustle with activity, and loud doth hear,
Seven hairdressing stations, all with clients filled,
A popular place indeed, my heart doth build.

An appointment quickly gained, my thanks doth give,
A thorough consultation, my stylist doth live,
She listens well, and understands my desire,
Her friendly chat, my nerves doth soon retire.

Shampooed and seated, a hot drink doth arrive,
Real coffee, not instant, my heart doth revive,
A biscuit too, my pleasure doth now increase,
I leave the salon, feeling grand, my soul doth release.

This place, I cannot fault, modern and trendy,
Yet friendly and professional, my praise doth send,
Medusa, a hairdressing chain of great renown,
In Edinburgh's city centre, doth wear its crown."

"Hark, what wondrous feast doth lie before mine eyes! A veritable cornucopia of delights, fit for a king or queen. The spread, so lavish and grand, doth rival those of highest esteem. Each dish, a masterwork of culinary art, doth tantalize mine taste buds and leave me in awe. The presentation, a symphony of colors and arrangement, doth delight mine senses and fill mine heart with joy. I have not found a single item to displease mine palate, nay, each bite doth bring me closer to the heavens. Methinks I shall return anon, to partake in this gastronomic splendor once more."

In fair September, we didst order a cake,
For our son's wedlock, a joyous undertaking.
William, a man of great skill and art,
Didst fashion a confection, a true work of heart.

The cake, a vision to behold,
Was devoured by all, young and old.
Its sweetness and moisture, a delight,
left us in awe, with naught but delight.

And thus, we didst order once more,
For our husband's fiftieth year, in store.
A cake, a symbol of love and cheer,
To celebrate a life, now full and clear.

And lo, the cake didst please once more,
With its raspberry mousse, a flavor galore.
A hit, a true success, a wonder to see,
A cake, fit for a king, or so it seemed to me.

"Hark, what place is this? A temple, nay, a shrine,
Where beasts are slain, and I, a devout worshiper, doth dine.
A cathedral of meat, where I do count my blessings,
And revel in the joy that I, a carnivore, do possess.

Oh, the salad bar, 'tis true, doth boast the finest greens,
But here, my friends, the focus lies upon the meats.
Hot, smoking, marinated flesh, all tantalizing,
Doth tempt my taste buds, and doth leave me quite amazed.

The steak, oh how it doth delight, so juicy, so tender,
With flavors that doth dance upon my palate, and linger.
The burnt, salty end, and pink, medium rare within,
Doth make each bite a joy, and leaves me wanting more, my friend.

But alas, the steak, it doth lose its charm,
As it doth cool upon my plate, and loses its warmth.
But fear not, dear friends, for Texas de Brazil,
Doth have a secret weapon, a scientific approach,
That keeps the meat hot, and the flavors at their peak,
A feast fit for a king, or queen, a true culinary freak.

So if thou art a meat lover, like myself,
Then hasten thee well, and doth give this place a try.
For in this cathedral of meat, thou shalt find thy haven,
And thy taste buds, they shall be in a state of pure delight, my friend."

"Our offspring, two in number, didst inherit
The iPhones of yore, with batteries weak and faint.
These men, their vigor and expertise on display,
Didst replace the batteries in haste, ere break of day.

The cost, a fraction of what Apple doth demand,
A paltry sum, scarce worth a second thought.
Their speed, a marvel, like lightning in the land.
Friendly and courteous, their demeanor, a gem.

I do proclaim, in verse or prose,
This service, top-notch, at a reasonable cost.
For those in need, I say, without a flaw,
Seek out these men, and give them thy trust."

"Hark! A tale of wondrous change, my friends,
Of surgeries elective, by Transformations' skilled hands.
The staff, so kind and fair, didst work with me,
Though I didst dwell in NYC, and they in Wisconsin's land.
The cost, a third of what it wouldst be in the city,
Didst make my journey worthwhile, and my heart full of glee.
The results, my friends, didst bring me joy beyond compare,
And thus, I do recommend this place, without a single care."

"Verily, a most excellent eatery doth reside within yon college halls,
Whose outdoor seats on State Street do provide a merry ambiance,
And victuals, savory and sweet, doth please mine taste buds well.
African cuisine, a new delight, doth tempt me to partake,
And thus, I shall return anon, to sample more of their fare."

"Heinz Field, a place most wondrous and fair,
Where football's finest battles are fought with great flair.
The site lines, a marvel, a joy to behold,
And the history within, a tale to be told.

The Great Hall, a chamber of fame,
Where trophies of old, and heroes' names,
Are displayed with pride, and rightly so,
For this is a place where legends grow.

And, oh! The food, a culinary delight,
Primanti Bros., a taste, a true delight.
Tailgating, a ritual, a time to share,
A tradition, that's, beyond compare.

So, come one, come all, to this hallowed ground,
To witness the splendor, to hear the sound,
Of cheering crowds, and gridiron clash,
At Heinz Field, where football's passion is rash."

"Oh, what a feast for mine eyes doth lay before me!
A draught of Kool-Aid, cold as winter's snow,
And chicken, fried to perfection, doth arouse
My hunger, like a rooster doth crow.
Golden waffles, crispy and hot, doth tempt me so,
I cannot wait, my dear, to dine once more,
In this place, where food doth reign supreme, you know."

"Hark, what news is this? My 21st year hath come,
And with it, a celebration most grand.
A hotel, conveniently located, doth beckon,
With clubs and revelry at hand.

Venetian, the name of this fine place,
Doth boast of TAO, a club of great renown,
And Palazzo, its sister, doth embrace,
Lavo, another spot, where one may dance and prance.

The rooms, spacious and comfortable, doth hold,
Six to eight people, with ease, I am told.
Two queen beds, full size, and a couch, doth make,
A restful night, for all, a certain take.

The bathroom, large, with double doors, doth allow,
All the girls, to prepare, without a flaw.
Mirrors, plenty, doth adorn the walls,
Aiding in the process, of making oneself fair.

In conclusion, Venetian, a place of delight,
For clubbing, eating, shopping, and gambling, in sight.
Five stars, I give, for the rain of money, so bright,
A memorable night, indeed, with my dear friends, in sight."

"Ere we arrived, just ere the closing hour,
And I didst fear, that quality might suffer.
But oh, how wrong my doubts didst prove!
The salad, cold and fresh as morning dew,
The garlic knots, a culinary delight,
Didst bring me another round, I didst beseech!
And pizza, excellence itself didst manifest.
From henceforth, here shall be our pizza haven."

"In urgent need of lodging, we didst call upon each inn and hostelry, yet all were full, their halls and chambers occupied till morn. Our plight didst seem most dire, our hopes didst dwindle, till fortune didst smile upon us at this humble abode. They didst proffer us a chamber ere noon, a boon most welcome, and bade us partake of breakfast, a meager feast, yet one most grateful. And as we waited, they didst allow us liberty to roam their grounds, a pleasant oasis, and didst provide a shuttle, conveyance most convenient, to bear us to the Strip, that famed and vaunted thoroughfare. The rooms, though modest, were clean and well-appointed, with couches that didst convert to beds, a clever device. And all this, dear friends, at a price most reasonable, a sum most fair and just. So if thou seekest rest and peace, a respite from the din and tumult of the city, then seek thee out this haven, a place of solace and of comfort."

"Thou canst comprehend, my friend,  
If thou hast trod the path,  
The finest victuals of the East,  
A feast fit for a king's repast.  
The hospitality doth make thee feel,  
As if thou wert a prince of great wealth,  
The surroundings, prospect, and folk,  
All doth conspire to give thee mirth."

"By my troth, I didst once avow
Buffalo Wild Wings, ne'er knew
Another wingery could compare
Until my love, she didst declare

Wing Stop, a place of wonder
With wings so divine, they plunder
All other eateries of their fame
And leave them with naught but shame

Their flavors, though fewer in number
Do not detract from their great slumber
For in their wings, there lies a charm
That doth surpass all other arms

I have attempted, since my heart
Didst turn to Wing Stop, to part
With BWW, but alas, their wings
Do not compare, they bring

Naught but woe and disappointment
For they cannot match the content
Of Wing Stop, that sweetest place
Where wings do reign in grace."

"Ah, Whole Foods Market, how thy name doth conjure images of luxury and indulgence! For those not blessed with wealth, 'tis natural to shun thy lofty, crunchy charms. Yet, my dearest girlfriend didst sing thy praises, speaking of the bargains she didst find on healthy fare within thy hallowed halls. My curiosity, thus piqued, didst lead me to venture forth and partake of thy offerings.

"And gladly, I didst not regret my decision! For though thou art not cheap, the quality of thy victuals doth make up for the cost. Thy BBQ smokehouse, with its $5 lunch deals, doth tempt me still. Thy Chipotle-like burrito bar, a delight! Thy bar, with happy hour specials, doth call to me. Thy brick oven pizzeria, a marvel! Thy salad bar, with its Wednesday discounts, doth entice. Thy Asian cuisine kitchen, a wonder! Thy pre-made dishes, a cut above the rest, doth leave me in awe.

"Alas, I have not had the pleasure of doing much grocery shopping within thy walls, for fear of emptying my purse. But, for a healthy, quality dining experience, thou art the place to go.

"And, oh! The people watching at thy Scottsdale location! 'Tis a spectacle indeed, a parade of stereotypes and more besides!"

"Hark, the hype doth swell, my friends, 'Tis a most wondrous sight, this curb so fine. My wife and I, we didst park thereof, And found it to be most divine. I, on the street side, didst take my place, While my wife, on the curb side, didst grace. She didst love it, by the stars above, And I, in agreement, didst nod and glove. For why doth one mess with perfection, sayeth I? Each to their own, I do surmise, And thus, Aaron's doth earn two whiskers high."

"In fair Las Vegas, where revelry doth reign,
A visit to Marcy's brows, a wondrous gain.
For just ten coins, she doth shape and form,
Bringing forth beauty, with nary a storm.

Her touch, so gentle, leaves naught to fear,
And her skills, they do make thy brows appear,
Like a masterpiece, crafted with care,
Fit for a queen, or a maiden fair.

But Marcy's gifts, they do not cease,
For she doth offer more, to increase,
Thy glamour, for Vegas' nights so bright,
With services, that doth make thee shine so light.

Oh, fortunate souls, who doth reside,
In this fair city, where pleasure doth abide,
Visit Marcy oft, and let her work,
Transform thy brows, like a masterful quirk.

The ambiance, clean, comfortable, and bright,
Doth make thee feel, in a home so delight,
The energy, it doth radiate, with cheer,
A place, where thou doth feel, so welcome, my dear."

"Ay, 'tis a place of old, a cantina of yore,
Where Mexican dishes be served, and hearts be bore.
Cramped, it may be, but atmosphere doth abound,
And the victuals, they doth please, beyond compare, profound.

The hot sauce, it doth burn, with flavor so bold,
Chips, they doth flow, like a river, so cold.
Fundito, the gringo, doth delight,
A dish, so fine, it doth ignite, the appetite.

So, heed my words, and hasten thee well,
To this place, where culinary joys doth dwell.
Forsooth, 'twill be crowded, in short order, I reckon,
So, tarry not, and make haste, ere the day be gone."

"Verily, this eatery doth serve the finest sushi in all of Vegas! The Kanji roll, a marvel of culinary skill, doth please mine taste buds beyond compare. Yung, the sushi master, doth prepare each dish with artistry and grace, leaving naught but envy in his wake. Ji, the proprietor, doth ensure each guest doth have a most excellent time, with a keen eye for detail and warm hospitality. The Kanji clan, in sum, doth make one feel most welcome and well tended. In sooth, a superior dining experience, in every aspect!"

"Hark! What woeful souls begrudge these men their due?
Their autos old, their purses thin, they rail and rant.
But I, dear friends, have found their service true,
Their hearts kind, their pricing fair, their skill profound.

My BMW M6, now gone, didst once receive
Their tender care, and at a price most reasonable.
Their brakes, though loud, didst pass inspection, free,
And for their toil, a mere $50 didst I pay.

My Mustang, too, didst benefit from their art,
A mere $330, tax included, didst it cost.
A ride, besides, didst they provide, gratis,
Their kindness, tipped, doth merit praise, no doubt.

So let us laud these men, their work most excellent,
Their customer service, beyond compare, a gem.
For those in need, their aid doth never falter,
German Motors, praise be, a true friend to thee."

"A fortunate chance didst thou afford, my dear,  
To gaze upon The Lady Silvia's splendor,  
In the heart of Las Vegas, where doth globe salon event,  
Didst showcase her beauty, in all its glory.  
  
Located deep within the city's core,  
On the bottom floor of Soho Lofts, a secret place,  
An unmarked door, a passage through darkness,  
Leadeth thee to a bar, a wondrous sight,  
With checkered floors, and bookshelves tall,  
A place of knowledge, and of delight.  
  
The atmosphere, a mix of light and shade,  
Darkness reigns, yet graffiti doth adorn the ceiling,  
A DJ booth, a hub of music, doth reside,  
In this hidden gem, a treasure, worth revealing.  
  
Tucked away, unpretentious, a rare find,  
In this city, where excess doth abound,  
A refuge, from the noise, and glittering lights,  
A haven, where one may find peace, and solace, in the night.  
  
When open, shall I frequent this place,  
To savor its charm, and revel in its grace."

"Hark! How fortunate I am to dwell but a stone's throw away from this most excellent eatery, a true gem of Central Phoenix. 'Tis a place most wondrous, where guests from afar may partake in a genuine Phoenix experience, far removed from the mundane fare of chain restaurants. Verily, I have never tasted anything there that did not exceed my expectations. Be it a special occasion, a gathering of friends, or merely a casual repast, any hour of the day doth bring forth delectable victuals. The sweet potato fries, a marvel! And my heart doth sing with joy at the mere mention of the lobster quesadillas - yummm! In sooth, I cannot praise this local treasure enough."

"O, how I love this place! Taro with boba, oh how grand,
Their glazes, a feast for the taste buds, so choose at thy command.
Some snohs, too sweet, a warning, lest thou desire,
To pair them with toppings, less sweet, to quench thy fire.
I've had their boba but once, yet still I do declare,
'Twas fantastic, beyond compare, a true delight, beyond compare.
A group of friends, unfamiliar with the menu, didst say,
"We'll stick with fruit snoh, chocolate toppings, come what may."
Yet still, they loved it, and found it to be grand,
A testament to the quality of this wondrous land.
The workers, friendly and kind, offer samples with glee,
And the atmosphere, artsy and nerdy, doth please me.
Jenga and games, a pleasant pastime, doth abound,
Making this place, a haven, where one can be found."

"Hark, what hospitality doth lie within this place! Our host, Marty, didst extend to us a warm embrace, and with his skilled hand, didst prepare for us a feast most wondrous. The fare, so fine and delicate, didst delight our taste buds, and the ambiance, quaint and charming, didst make our visit all the more enjoyable. Verily, the meatballs, they didst steal the show, their savory flavor and tender texture, a true marvel. We shall return, forsooth, to partake in this culinary splendor once again."

"Thirteen years have we dwelt in this fair valley of the southwest, and for as long have we sought a mechanic, just and true.  At last, our search hath ended, for we have found Phil, a man of wit and wisdom, who doth run his business with a steady hand.
